column2: Notorious Nazi and former Hitler supporters are still being continued in key positions in the German economy, C. Monteith Gilpin, secretary of the Society for the Prevention of World War III, Inc., declared yesterday.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 26 (AP) -- Wilfred Crossley of Atlanta, Ga., the man with the automatic putter, today won the national public links championship by pouring on the heat to match the 97-degree temperature. He defeated Avery Beck of Raleigh, N.C., 6 and 5, over the Meadowbrook municipal course.

How does oil flow through sand and rocks in a field and how is it affected by underground water and gas? Oil men would like to know. If they did know they would be able to recover more oil from the ground. It looks as if Gulf Oil physicists will supply that knowledge.

WASHINGTON, Sunday, July 27 -- A last and unsuccessful Republican, challenge to the Democrats to permit a vote for an investigation of Attorney General Tom C. Clark thrust the Senate early today in the bitterest partisan fight in many years.

President Truman's nomination of James Forrestal as Secretary of Defense to head the new military establishment provided for in the unification bill which the Congress passed Friday and the President signed yesterday was not a surprise. It is none the less welcome.

City planning commissions and local authorities should be made to realize that industry no longer can be treated as a poor relation or a necessary evil when zoning regulations are drawn up, Ralph G. Schwebemeyer of Newark, N.J., president of the Society of Industrial Realtors of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, declared yesterday.

THIS book, the author's first, is an admiring son's biography of his highly individualistic father, a small-town Kansas lawyer of the period from 1890 to 1922. It is more than a monument to a man; it is a wistful tribute to the character and resourcefulness of the lawyer of "the old school."

LINDRITH, N.M. -- Discovery by teams of scientists from New York's American Museum of Natural History of dinosaur bones in the cliffs of the north-central section of New Mexico is arousing new tourist interest in this state.

VIENNA, July 26 -- Austrian and Allied sources seemed convinced today that, as a result of the new schedule of occupation payments, the Soviet Union was satisfied to keep its military garrison here at a low level. It was said that the period during which a country had a large number of soldiers in garrison seemed ended.

SINCE Florence Nightingale's day women have been nursing their men in war, but now, for the first time in history, a technically trained petticoat army is still marching along in peacetime civilian affairs.
ANYONE'S child is bound, at some time or other, to pick up words and phrases that horrify adults. The range of these words is broad enough to include the dirty, the blasphemous and the vulgar.

The American China Policy Association, Inc., made public yesterday a letter from its executive committee to Lieut. Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer, Ambassador to China, urging a "return to the traditional American policies supported by the United States in the Far East since 1899."

MADRID, July 26 -- With his referendum victory safely tucked away. Generalissimo Francisco Franco is preparing to leave for San Sebastian and after a few days there will spend a month of his vacation in his native Galicia. While he is away Government circles will sink into a trance until the hot weather ends.
WASHINGTON, July 26 -- Following are the full texts of ten documents selected by Library of Congress experts from the Abraham Lincoln papers of the Robert Todd Lincoln collection, made public today.

A new "National Military Establishment," with three" co-equal departments -- land, sea and air -- came into existence last week as Congress passed and the President signed the long and bitterly fought "unification" legislation. Former Secretary of the Navy Forrestal was immediately named the new "super" Secretary of Defense, and a new chapter in American defense history started.

IT has always been a part of the duties of the New York Police Department to hunt for persons who have been reported missing, but it was not until 1914 that a separate bureau was organized to take over that work. Capt. John G. Stein, now retired, was the third head of the Missing Persons Bureau, a position which he held for the nine years preceding his retirement.

NEWARK, N.J., July 26 (AP) -- Arthur T. Vanderbilt, Essex County Republican leader and dean of New York University Law School, said tonight he was opposed to the section of the proposed new state constitution dealing with the executive department.

Miss Nel Van Vliet and Mrs. Koster Van Feggelen, champion swimmers of the Netherlands, accompanied by Miss Gertrude Klapwijk, commissioner of the Royal Dutch Swimming Association, sailed for the United States yesterday from Rotterdam aboard the S.S. Westerdam.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- President Truman's legislative batting average in the first session of the Eightieth Congress cannot be set down with complete statistical accuracy, but Administration score-keepers counted today at least ten proposals on which he drew blanks.

SHANGHAI, July 26 (U.P.) -- Lieut. Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer said on his arrival here today that his fact-finding quest had produced results in the past four days and he believed he had convinced the Chinese of the sincerity of his mission.

THIS is probably the best general account of Texas which has been written. It is accurate, vigorous, comprehensive, well planned; it stands out particularly in contrast to the many dull or sentimental pieces that have been written about the state.
NEW ORLEANS, July 26 -- Towboat operators of the inland rivers have taken a lesson from the truckand-trailer fleets of the highways and have gone them one better.

CINCINNATI, July 26 (AP) -- Bucky Walters turned loose some of his pitching mastery today, holding the Phillies to two hits to lead Cincinnati to a 1-to-0 victory. The game was played in 1 hour, 28 minutes, the shortest of the major league season.

LIKE thousands of presentable and foresighted young gentlemen of the better sort, Mr. Connaroe pulled strings in the early months of the war to get a commission in the Navy. His idea, he says, was to avoid being drafted into that egalitarian chamber of horrors, the Army.

LOS ANGELES, July 26 -- Henry Wallace's western stalking horse, Robert W. Kenny, is quietly laying plans to extend the "spontaneous" California Wallace-forPresident movement to at least ten other western States.

PHIL BAKER will continue as master of ceremonies on "Take It or Leave It" for some six or eight weeks after the program switches from CBS to NBC at 10 P.M. on Sunday nights. The changeover is scheduled for next week.

The New York City Housing Authority and the State Division of Housing are conducting a $40,000 experiment in the hope of saving at least $140,000 on the cost of Lillian Wald Houses, it was learned yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, July 26 (AP) -- Beans Reardon, veteran National League umpire, denied today that he had told Outfielder Ron Northey of the Cardinals to "slow down" after Northey had smashed a long hit last Sunday in a game at Brooklyn.

ROME, July 26 -- The Vatican newspaper I'Osservatore Romano urged Western European statesmen today to pay due attention to Russia's fears that the Marshall Plan might represent a danger for the sovereignty of European nations.

When Donald L. Nelson, former head of the War Production Board, is discharged from the French Hospital, where he has been undergoing a physical check-up, he will visit Mexico to confer with President Miguel Aleman regarding the economic program of that country, it was learned yesterday.
THOSE who divided their gladiolus corms in several lots to be planted at two-week intervals last spring have started to cut the first spikes of bloom. This should continue for two months.
ATHENS, July 26 -- A guerrilla force of some 1,500 men that attacked Grevena yesterday had melted back into the Grammes and Smolika mountains today.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- Adjournment of Congress, as a collective body, brings no quitting time this year for an extraordinarily large number of individual members and committees. A heavy interim schedule has been laid out for the rest of the summer and the fall.

AND now it is Sunday, and upon a thousand beaches the fiddler crab submits to the curse of true artists and finds his audience increasingly difficult to hold. Back a bit from his stage, and set between two trees, is a hammock which could circle the globe, and in it, swaying gently, is an occupant who is growing restless.

AN Oxford philosopher who died during the war, Professor R.G. Collingwood shared with his older Italian colleague Benedetto Croce the distinction of being a historian who gained the recognition of his fellow historians. The wit of his learning and the many-sidedness of his gifts as a philosopher, scholar and artist are manifest in his latest and last volume -- a volume put together by Professor T.M. Knox out of Collingwood's papers and lectures.

TOKYO, July 26 -- Between Aug. 15 and Aug. 18 all objectionable Germans, all former German diplomats, and all non-objectionable Germans who would rather live in Germany than in Japan will be shipped from this country, the occupation announced today.

SUMMER art schools and workshops are fully functioning both locally and out of town. The New School for Social Research has four summer art workshops of ten sessions each, conducted by Camilo Egas, Mario Carreno and Hans Jelinek.

Modern thinking on the subject of taxation favors the policy of imposing high taxes to times of high prosperity. Accepting this policy as sound, one might conclude that President Truman's mid-year economic report to the Congress, which states that the national income is now running at a rate close to $200,000,000,000 a year, justifies his veto of the recently proposed tax reduction bills.

DUBLIN -- Though the Irish have a well-deserved reputation for doing things leisurely, the first thing that strikes you about O'Connell Street, one of the widest and finest thoroughfares in Europe, is that it is like a fast-moving East Fourteenth Street.

MISS GRINDROD'S concise presentation of the factual highlights of Italy's "transition from war to peace" is an example of that sound, careful research journalism in which the British, particularly those associated with Chatham House, excel.

Miss Margaret E. Osborne of San Francisco, the nation's top ranking woman player, heads a Wightman Cup squad of ten from which a team win be picked to defend the famous international trophy against the British team, it was announced yesterday by Julian S. Myrick, chairman of the United States Lawn Tennis Association's Wightman Cup Committee.

BOSTON, July 26 (AP) -- Tralle and McBride's War Raider, flying along the rail through the stretch, outfinished the two-to-one favorite, Brookmeade's Stable Musician, to take the $10,000 added Miles Standish Handicap today. He won by a neck, with Archer's Happy West two lengths farther back, before a crowd of 22,705 at Suffolk Downs.
EAST WILLISTON, L.I., July 26 -- The fifth annual Charles R. Casey Memorial Tournament narrowed down to eight teams today as the first round was completed.

LONDON, July 26 -- Appealing to Britain's miners to go "all-out" for increased coal production in the next two years, Foreign Secretary Bevin told the mine workers today that the "whole future we are trying to build up for all our people and all our children depends on you."
WASHINGTON, July 26--A breath of new life was infused into the Lincoln legend today as the nation formally took possession of documents which take up the career of Abraham Lincoln ...

THE life of Fred Colvin, expert on machine tools and all processes of shaping metal parts, recapitulates the growth of American industry from the post-Civil War era to the present day. Mr. Colvin was born eighty years ago into a Yankee family of proved mechanical bent, and at the age of 15 was apprenticed to a Philadelphia machinist.

The First Session of the Eightieth Congress comes to an end with a Democratic President and a Republican House and Senate deadlocked on important domestic issues, but with the bipartisan foreign policy established during war days still pretty much intact. To be sure, it had some rather narrow squeaks.

JOHN C. COOPER has produced a documented analysis of a third of a century's efforts to develop air power for the uses of peace. His views of those efforts as of today and of tomorrow are not cheerful. For Mr. Cooper grimly assures us that our attempts at extirpating ex-enemy air power since VE-Day lead straight to the recrudescence of another Luftwaffe and, of course, a far more horrible war in the air.
LONDON, July 26 -- The East, from Palestine to Japan, is feeling the effects of the British withdrawal from India.

WASHINGTON, Sunday, July 27 -- In a burst of session-end activity, Congress sent to the White House early this morning the last five of some $34,800,000,000 of appropriations bills that had posed the main obstacle to adjournment.

The big fight of the week in this city will take place at Ebbets Field in Brooklyn on Wednesday night. Gus Lesnevich, Cliffside Park (N.J.), battler who holds the light - heavyweight championship will tackle Tami Mauriello of the Bronx in a ten-round fray that is expected to attract a crowd of more than 25,000 and a gate in excess of $100,000.

With a grant from the National Mental Health Act, four competitive fellowships valued at $9,600 will be awarded for the first time by the New York School of Social Work, Columbia University, for post-graduate training in specialized psychiatric fields, it became known yesterday.

PATCHES in the lawn where grass has refused to grow, banks and terraces which cannot hold its roots and places where crabgrass crowds it out are good spots in which to try growing clover. Of the various kinds, wild white clover is recommended.

IN MANAGUA during the recent national elections, outgoing President -- but possibly not outgoing Dictator -- Anastasio Somoza in an amiable conversation referred to the Nicaraguans as, "these people." Not "our people" or "my people" but "these people."

ABOARD THE QUEEN MARY, SOUTHAMPTON, July 26 -- The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary successfully completed a two - day "shake - down" cruise along the coast today after having been refitted since her wartime service.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- It seems that lack of unification of the armed forces, of the kind made law today by President Truman's signature, caused friction between the Army and Navy during the Civil War too.

IF show business could be said to have its own aristocracy, one of the season's princeliest performers would be an amiable hobo in tatters. His coat-ofarms would be a disintegrating bicycle. The aristocrat, of course, is Joe Jackson Jr., and the bike that keeps falling apart is the one his father rode for half a century to an entertainer's immortality.

PARIS, July 26 -- The French won this week a diplomatic victory second only to that which they grained two years ago when they were admitted to the Foreign Ministers' Council of the great powers. It took the form of a short note from Secretary of State Marshall to French Foreign Minister Bidault promising that the United States and Britain would not raise the industrial level of Germany before they consulted the French.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 26 -- New York Guardsmen from Bayshore, Patcbogue and Freeport, members of the First Separate Battalion, scored the season's best shooting record here, the regimental records at Camp Smith indicated today.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 26 (AP) -- Favorites overtook the unknowns at the halfway mark in the $10,000 Columbus Open golf tournament today, but a couple of dark horses were still in there firing for the $2,000 top prize.

COLUMBUS, Ga., July 26 (AP) -- Mr. Bradley, who began life on an Alabama farm and amassed one of the South's greatest fortunes in cotton and coca cola, already had extensive textile and other interests when, in 1919, he and his lifelong friend and former schoolmate, the late Ernest Woodruff, became the principals in the syndicate which purchased the Coca Cola Company from Asa G. Candler for $25,000,000.

The last week of July in any year is a lush and lazy time, but this peculiar season's alternate rain and heat has produced a particular lushness over the countryside in this area. There is a kind of pause as summer passes its peak and prepares to coast down through August toward September, and that gives the illusion of laziness, which any countryman will insist is only an illusion.

ST. LOUIS, July 26 (AP) -- The Cardinals and the Braves clubbed away at each other's pitchers tonight with twenty-two hits -- nine for extra bases -- but the Redbirds pushed across enough runs to triumph, 9 to 5.

THE British are coming again to help celebrate Air Force Day next Friday. A squadron of four-engined Lincoln bombers, Britain's latest successor to the wartime Lancasters, is due in Washington tomorrow for a stay here and in Canada of several weeks.

Store-wide activity last week was fairly good, with sportswear and cotton dress clearances continuing to pull, and dress departments active, according to a survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.

As Congress Adjourns The first session of the Eightieth Congress drew to a close yesterday, and the nation took stock. First, it measured the job Congress accomplished against the job remaining to be done; second, it took a look at the state of the nation, as described in President Truman's Midyear Economic Report transmitted to Congress on Monday.

BATAVIA, Java, July 26 -- Netherlands communiques indicated tonight that Dutch troops advancing in eastern and western Java had caught the main body of the Indonesian Republican Army in a vise-like operation against the vast central section of the island.

THE professional "gadgeteer," who modifies photographic equipment in order to add improvements not included in the original product, is a new development of the post-war photographic era. A camera repair man has designed an open frame sports-type finder for the Rolleiflex; another added a center post to the Quick-Set and similar tripods to permit lowering and raising the camera without having to adjust the tripod legs.

IN midsummer it is hard to imagine a more refreshing spot in the garden than that beside a pool filled with waterlilies. The blooms are exquisitely fragrant and richly colored, and the sparkling water beneath is cool in appearance.

LONDON -- Whether American tourists are to have ice water with their meals in Britain became within the last few days a party issue of prime domestic interest. Water is one of the few things not rationed here, yet it is very difficult for Americans to have it served at the table as at home.

THIS volume of poems by the author of "Forever China" has many qualities of excellence. A score of poems, especially among the purely lyrical works, succeed by music, feeling and image in charming the reader. Nearly all the rest have at least a few lines indicative of the true poetic temper.

Continuing the trend started soon after the end of the war, colleges and universities throughout the United States are experiencing an all-time record summer session enrollment this year. In many instances the registration has doubled normal pre-war figures.

The Truman program for granting relief to Greece and Turkey will stimulate further an area that is already becoming the United States' fastest growing overseas market, according to a survey of Mediterranean trade made public yesterday by the American Merchant Marine Institute.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The recently publicized theft of secret documents relating to the atomic bomb has thrown official Washington into a dither over security and revived discussion of the need of some sort of official secrets law.

In a letter to Warren R. Austin, chief United States delegate to the United Nations, the National Conference of Christians and Jews yesterday called for support of a convention for the prevention and punishment of genocide.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, July 26 -- The fourth International Congress for Microbiology, in plenary session today, unanimously adopted a resolution "condemning in strongest possible terms all forms of bacteriological warfare."

ATLANTA, July 26 -- The singsong chant of the tobacco auctioneers ushered in the 1947 fluecured marketing season in the Georgia-Florida belt this week amid predictions that prices for the golden weed would reach new all-time highs.

CHICAGO, July 26 -- But Why Not, sleek 3-year-old daughter of Blue Larkspur, dazzled a sweltering crowd of 27,000 today by winning the $93,800 Arlington Classic and running the legs off the Calumet Farm's championship contender, Fervent, the four-to-five favorite.

Total distress conveyances of real estate in Manhattan for the first half of 1947 reached a lower level than for any comparable period in the history of authentic real estate statistics, the Real Estate Board of New York disclosed yesterday.

The two-week return visit of sixteen white children from Quincy, Mass., to as many Negro children who are members of the Grace Congregational Church, 308 West 139th Street, will end today. Church officials yesterday were summarizing the gains made by this program of racial betterment.

With land prices due to Increase and labor likely to hold its wage gains, there is no prospect of an appreciable drop in the costs of building, Henry J. Davenport, president of the Home Title Guaranty Company, declared yesterday in defense of the building industry against charges of excess profits and "skimping" on materials and workmanship.

BERLIN, July 26 -- Three of the seven alleged anti-Nazis held without hearing in Dachau for periods ranging up to twenty-six months have been released as a result of an investigation by Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor.
GRANDVIEW, Mo., July 26 -- Mrs. Martha E. Truman, the President's mother, died here at 11:09 A.M., Central standard time, today, as he was flying in his DC-4 transport plane to her bedside.

SIT down beside the table where one of the big-shot money bridge games is in progress, and you will see many items of bridge by-play that are totally foreign to the more relaxed atmosphere of the casual game. Unfortunately, unless you are a keen watcher you are likely to miss the items of chief interest.

THE Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, near Lee, Mass., will see another world premiere next week-end when Arthur Mahoney and Thalia Mara and their Ballet Repertory present Mr. Mahoney's ballet, "Parnassus." It is an original ballet in the style of the court ballets of Louis XIV, based on Mr. Mahoney's extensive research in the archives of the Paris Opera and the Louvre.

The New York Athletic Club dominated the annual men's Senior Metropolitan A.A.U. championship swimming meet yesterday at the Sunset Park Pool, Brooklyn, the Winged Footers snaring five of the eight titles at stake. The Flatbush Boys' Club was next with two first places.

THE encrusted belief in magic, embedded in all folkways, runs in unbroken sequence into our own day. Miss Hole brings the past into juxtaposition with the present, supplementing antique magic rites with instances drawn from recent headlines.

WASHINGTON, July 26--President Truman signed the bill today that permits war veterans who hold terminal leave bonds to cash them at any time after Sept 1. The Chief Executive advised them, however, not to do it.

Ladislav Hecht, former Czechoslovak Davis Cup star, captured the Eastern clay court tennis men's singles championship yesterday when he defeated Richard Savitt, Cornell sophomore from East Orange, N.J., in the final at the Jackson Heights club. The score was 6 -- 4, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 0, 7 -- 5.

THE Garden Club of America has announced the recipients of three medals decided at their thirty-fourth annual meeting held recently in Milwaukee, Minneapolis and St. Paul. The bronze achievement medal was awarded to Mrs. Beatrix Farrand, a member of the Garden Club of Mount Desert, Me., and of the Garden Club of America.

SPEAKING of that bane -- or boon -- of contemporary mankind and the United Nations, the corner file along with current intelligence indicates that nuclear fission is bound to smack Broadway sooner or later. Not since "Wings Over Europe" has the atom been as prominent in the local producing offices.

HERE in dozens and dozens of fine photos is the story of Great Man, Mr. Joe Louis. Addicts of the "fancy" will relish those subtle expressions of pain and bewilderment that briefly flashed over the faces of those unfortunates who found themselves in the squared circle with the taciturn champion.

BUCHAREST, July 26 -- The Soviet Union's Molotov plan is predicated on the knowledge that the war and the resultant destruction of Germany have shifted the European economic center of gravity eastward.

IF there were no historical settlement in Williamsburg, Va., it is likely that Paul Green's historical drama, "The Common Glory," would not be playing there. His poster design in early American history was first produced about ten days ago in a new outdoor theatre on the edge of Matoaka Lake, only a mile or two from the College of William and Mary and the end of the Duke of Gloucester Street.
OCEANPORT, N.J., July 26 -- Making a front-running race of it all the way, the San ford Stud Farm's Round View scored an upset victory in the 525,000 added Monmouth Handicap today.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., July 26 -- California Democrats, whose ties with the national party organization have been strained by the nonconformist leadership of their state chairman, James Roosevelt, today veered back toward the path of orthodoxy.

MINNESOTA -- Carnegie Grant As part of its enlarged program of study of the Scandinavian countries, the University of Minnesota is offering four $1,200 graduate fellowships and two $500 undergraduate scholarships in Scandinavian area study for the 1947-48 academic year.

MIAMI, Fla. -- Miami hotel operators plan to seek an early court ruling on the validity of the city's new 5 per cent tax on hotels, apartment and lodging house rentals, scheduled to go into effect Sept. 1.

REAL moonlight scenes may be successfully photographed by anyone with a camera permitting time exposures. The trick of photographing the sun as part of a scene, then printing the negative quite dark to simulate moonlight, is used frequently to give an impression of the real thing.

The strange sounds of war -- the whistle and crumpf of bombs, the stuttering of machine guns, the hoarse shouts of command -- came again last week to the Southwest Pacific. Suddenly, at midnight on Sunday, Dutch armed forces had opened a major offensive against the native Indonesian Republic in the Netherlands East Indies.

THE Hutchinson Family, originating in New Hampshire, sang their way around many of the states of this nation and around England during the Eighteen Forties, Fifties and Sixties, and some of them went on singing until the Eighties, and then the survivors sang at funerals and dedications.
Seven Protestant clergymen and a physician left La Guardia Airport yesterday morning for a visit of several weeks in Yugoslavia as guests of the Government of that country.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Reference is made to the editorial appearing in your paper of July 12, entitled, "Mr. Truman Backs the MVA."

IN ten States this summer Negro children are visiting white homes, and white children are visiting Negro homes. These visits, most of which are for two weeks, are all part of an important experiment in race relations known as the "Vermont Experiment."

Martha Ellen Truman was a personality in her own right. The vitality that kept her alive well into her tenth decade was partly a thing of the spirit. As a girl she lived through the Civil War in a turbulent section of Missouri where neighbor fought neighbor. This was enough to interest any girl in politics, and down to her dying day she kept this interest and formed and expressed her own decisive opinions.

Mrs. Natalie Wales Paine, chairman of Common Cause, Inc., 48 East Forty-eighth Street, said yesterday that the organization was not associated with the monthly magazine of the same name published by the Committee to Frame a World Constitution, headed by Dr. Robert M. Hutchins, president of the University of Chicago.

The 1947 campaign of the New York City Cancer Committee for $1,300,000 has reached its objective, Brigr. Gen. John Reed Kilpatrick, chairman of the drive, announced yesterday at a meeting of the campaign leaders in his office in Madison Square Garden, of which he is president.

Ruggiero Ricci, American violinist, appeared as the soloist at the Lewisohn Stadium for the first time last night. There was an audience of 11.250 and the New York Philharmonic-Symphony was led by Paul Lavalle, radio conductor, who made his stadium debut last summer.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I have just seen an article by Roy Chapman Andrews, writing on Exploration, Unlimited, in THE TIMES. He says, "In Australia the aborigines are probably the most primitive human beings in the world today."
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 26 -- The Bulgarian Government delegation led by Premier Georgi Dimitrov is due here tomorrow morning.

DURING summer, when annuals provide most of the garden color, only a few shrubs bloom. Those which flower, however, are reliable and well worth including in the border, although we may have to restrain ourselves from using too many of them.

MUSICALLY the twentieth century is apt to regard the nineteenth as a weak, neurotic child regards a tremendously gifted, successful and somewhat self-indulgent parent. The psychological family situation is complete even to the existence of a benevolent grandparent, the eighteenth century, whose simple friendliness, modesty and philosophical good senseshine down through the years offering a feeling of stability that contrasts pleasantly with the parent's excessive and highly emotional temperament.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, July 26 -- The dissolution of the National Peasant party, the largest in Rumania, was virtually decreed today.

Further declines this year in mill prices of lower grades of Northeastern white pine were ruled out yesterday by R.E. Broderick, executive secretary of the Northeastern Lumber Manufacturers Association. Standing timoer owners, aware of the continued strong demand for wooden crates for export purposes, are determined to maintain current high levels of stumpage, key to pricing of finished lumber, Mr. Broderick explained.

A thorough overhauling of service charges by banks in this state, with a consequent upward revision in rates, now seems likely as a result of the recommendations issued last week by the New York State Bankers Association. The recommendations, based on a detailed study by a special committee of the association, have been awaited eagerly by the banks, which long have recognized that the many service charge schedules now in effect are generally inequitable.

BOSTON, July 26--Bostonians are gazing upward these days to watch a strange shape close to fifty feet across that hovers in the air and then moves across the sky. They stare by the thousands, following its progress.

Bishop William Robert Moody of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Lexington, Ky., replying yesterday to the protest of Bishop William T. Manning over Bishop Moody's having permitted the marriage of a divorcee to an Episcopal clergyman, declared Dr. Manning had "spoken without adequate knowledge of the facts and with no effort to get them."

THE annals of the screen are studded with incidents calculated to prove that the movies are not satisfied with actuality. Gabriel Pascal, for instance, had a studio sphinx constructed for "Caesar and Cleopatra" on the grounds that the real thing was not sufficiently photogenic.
WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The President's mid-year economic report, which was released this week, calls attention to a matter that has been puzzling the public for some time.

A SPECIAL, localized, peculiarly American state of society is the real subject of Mr. Stegner's novel. Three human beings, ingeniously studied in turn, with about equal emphasis, seem to make up the matter of the narrative; but dominant in the lives of all these characters, over-riding them in real importance, is the formidable life of the community.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The notable career of James Forrestal began when, in the spring of 1915, Princeton graduates who had become established in business, finance and the professions made their customary visit to the campus as scouts for good material among the seniors.

LONDON (By Wireless). THE problem of Germany's future can be stated very simply thus: What will happen when the Allies withdraw and the Germans revive, when the mood of despair is over and the preoccupation with primitive needs is less intense? What forces will then move in to fill the vacuum?

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 26 -- A "strategy of silence" may be adopted next week by a group of representatives in the United Nations Security Council, it was learned today, to defeat what has been described as filibustering by the Slav Bloc against a United States proposal for a new Balkan Border Investigation Commission.

WASHINGTON, Sunday, July 27 -- President Truman signed in dramatic circumstances yesterday the history-making legislation unifying the nation's armed forces. Immediately afterward he nominated the Secretary of the Navy, James Forrestal of New York, to head the program as Secretary of Defense.

HOLLYWOOD. AFTER ninety days of bargaining the Screen Actors Guild and the motion picture producers have arrived at an agreement on the terms of a oneyear labor contract and ratification of the pact by the Guild membership following a mass meeting Aug. 7 is regarded as a foregone conclusion.

The old coastal liner Meteor, once the Chester W. Chapin of Long Island Sound routes, has entered a new chapter in a varied career. Once more for sale, the 2,868-ton vessel now lies at Shooters Island, S.I., and a foreign purchaser has bought an option and may complete the sale this week, according to her broker, Charles D. Hodges of 49 Wall Street.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 26 -- Long Island Sound may have had more fish of small fry or other variety swimming around it on occasion, but it never had more sailing craft in one school than it held today in the Larchmont Yacht Club's Race Week regatta.

AFTER seven centuries of patchquilt kingdoms warring with the Moors, the Spaniards were just on the point of completing their reconquest and establishing a unified state, when Columbus opened up to them a New World beyond the Ocean Sea.

Indications of a renewed interest in loss-leader legislation with accompanying controversial discussions for and against it appeared last week as trade leaders looked forward to a period of "keen competition" with markets again filled with merchandise.

DES MOINES, Iowa, July 26 -- Delegates to the International Sunday School Convention here, unanimously adopted a "supplementary" statement of objectives today, recording their opposition to "every ideology that draws men's loyalty away from God's universal will" as well as to "atheistic communism."

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., July 26 -- Harold Stassen, candidate for the 1948 Republican Presidential nomination, indicated today that he would refuse the Vice Presidential nomination if Governor Thomas E. Dewey of New York headed the ticket.

A WHOPPING musical season is obviously looming ahead. Because of the demand for dates, most of the bookings have already been made. An analysis of the figures shows that the smaller managers will be the ones who will handle most of the expanded business Relatively speaking, the larger groups will not present many more artists than in the past.

The master television antenna system, perfected by the IntraVideo Corporation of America and endorsed recently by the Television Broadcasters Association, was accepted last week by one of the largest real estate interests in the city as suitable for apartment house installations, Sol Sagall, Intra-Video president, disclosed in an interview.

Costs of building appear to be leveling off in southern New England, according to W.H. Nye, vice president of the Turner Construction Company in charge of the Boston office, who has just completed a survey of building conditions in that area.

MOSCOW. SOVIET films and film making are at an important moment of transition. For the film industry, always an important arm of the Soviet Government's agitation and propaganda forces, has, like all other arts, pledged itself to the slogan of rejecting the old and, to the Communists, "dated" idea of art for art's sake.

THIS record of thoughtful progress from scientific naturalism toward God, is worth reading. Mrs. Morgan is a person of keen intelligence who, desirous of tasting life to the full, has come to know that "delight is keener, suffering is richer, thought is more exciting, love and friendship are deeper, steadier in the long perspective of God."

TWENTY years ago this week in the Review: On the frontpage, three books recording the famed literary feud between H.G. Wells and Hillaire Belloc over the former's "Outline of History." Joining forces with Mr. Belloc and the anti-Darwinians, the reviewer challenged Mr. Wells' contention that man is a changing creature: "Since the dawn of history, there is no record that man has added a joint to his little finger. . . ."

SANTA MONICA, Calif., July 26 -- Julius F. Stone Sr., president of the Ohio State University Research Foundation and chairman of the board of the Seagrave Corporation, manufacturers of motordriven fire apparatus, died yesterday in his home here after a long illness. His age was 92.

PRAGUE, July 26 -- Economic negotiations of great importance to Czechoslovakia are taking place at the Foreign Ministry between Don Humphrey of the Economic Section of the United States Military Government in Berlin, Richard King of Britain and the Czechoslovak Government.

CHICAGO, July 26 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 500 head (estimated), total 2,500: compared with a week ago, batchers under 250 pounds around $1 higher, heavier weights $1 to $2 higher: sows $2 to $2.50 higher.
"WHAT is a liberal, anyway?" Judging from the wide variety of organizations and people who lay claim to the label, one might think it is the verbal "Anyface."

BOSTON, July 26 (AP) -- Ted Williams collected two homers and Jake Jones one, each with one on base, today as the Red Sox collected 16 hits to smother the Browns 12-1. Joe Dobson pitched his twelfth victory, walking none, fanning five and holding St. Louis to six hits.

CRESTWOOD, N.Y., July 26 -- In a brilliant exhibition of golf Mrs. Reinert M. Torgerson of Cherry Valley overwhelmed Miss Hilda Swanson of the Drumlin Country Club, Syracuse, 12 and 11 to retain her New York State title over the Leewood Golf Club course today.

"EVIL can seduce men, but it cannot become man," wrote Franz Kafka. In Nazi Germany, however, Evil did become man, as Monsieur Rousset had to learn during the sixteen months he spent in four different concentration camps, including Buchenwald.

A NOBLE experiment, and one most valuable to all lovers of Mozart, will be undertaken at the Berkshire Festival when the operatic contingent of the Berkshire Music Center gives the first American performances.

LONDON. THE long and intensive search for a Scottish girl to play Flora MacDonald opposite David Niven's Bonnie Prince Charlie has ended in the choice of an English girl -- 24-year-old Margaret Leighton, born and bred in Birmingham.

THE vacation vote was split three ways -- one wanted to visit the Adirondacks, one insisted on Cape Cod and the Maine Coast, and the children asked for historic New England points and visits to friends at summer camps.

IT is not overstating matters to say that here is a volume of short stories that would have had Scheherazade herself holding her tongue. In one or two cases she might have nodded a bit. But for the most part, the nodding would have taken its opposite and more flattering form, that of a vigorous gesture of approval.

A solemn Requiem Mass was sung in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church, Brooklyn, yesterday for Charles J. Dodd, New York State Supreme Court Justice from 1930 to 1942 and a former District Attorney of Kings County. Mr. Dodd died at his home in Brooklyn Thursday at the age of 74.

LONDON, July 26 -- The acute differences among the Big Four about the future of Germany take on an even more disturbing aspect in Germany. For while the Germans' capacity to make war is greatly reduced there is very little evidence that they feel much responsibility for World War II or any obligation to rebuild Germany so that they cannot be pushed into war again.

SOME miles outside almost any major American city, on a two-lane macadam road off the main highway, there is a group of large buildings, quite a few of them, probably of red brick. They sit on broad sweeps of beautiful greensward; a little network of small roads, all studded with signs that read "Speed Limit 15 M.P.H.," threads among them.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, July 26 (U.P.) -- President Teodoro Picado gave assurances today that his Government would guarantee free and honest Presidential elections in February and would deliver the power to whoever was chosen by the people.

THIS was the week in which General Eisenhower having been named president of Columbia University, the Columbia University Bookstore featured "My Three Years With Eisenhower" on its tables, surrounded on either side by "College Program in Action" and "Mind Your Own Business."

Ed Lopat, a little lefthander from the sidewalks of New York, horse-collared Joe DiMaggio aid stopped the Jolter's consecutivegame hitting streak at thirteen before 22,495 fans at the Stadium yesterday. Since it is more or less true that the Yankees go as DiMaggio goes, it should not come as too great a surprise that the White Sox beat the Yankees, 2 -- 1.
PARIS, July 26 -- Negotiations began today to prepare a questionnaire on the German problem for the European economic conference. They were expected to result in an accord early next week.
WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- The Senate authorized tonight an investigation of the State Department's foreign information programs, including the controversial "Voice of America" broadcasts.

THE French Line's steamer De Grasse is back in luxury passenger service. The 18,435-ton liner, which on Tuesday completed Her first post-war voyage to New York, will maintain a monthly schedule between New York, Le Havre and Southampton.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- Despite developments of recent weeks that would have cooled the purposefulness of people less ardent, the Progressive Citizens of America, wedded to the role of opposition to major party policy, apparently are undaunted in their determination to form a third party for 1948.

NANKING, July 26 -- There is growing Chinese apprehension over the prospect that Japan may again became a powerful economic and strategic factor in the Far East. It was reflected yesterday in a resolution against the resumption of trade relations with Japan adopted here by the Resident Committee of the Peoples Political Council.

Tuss McLaughry, head coach of the Eastern College All-Star squad which will oppose the New York Giants at the Polo Grounds in the ninth edition of the Tribune Fresh Air Fund football game, the night of Sept. 3, announced yesterday that he had added Paul McKee, Syracuse end, to the team's roster

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- Two recurrent bad dreams haunt the sleep these summer nights of those who are trying to formulate and execute Administration foreign policy. In one, groups of small figures march through their brains, chanting "no tax relief, no foreign relief."
WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The economic signposts are saying: "Millions at work; proceed cautiously."

Former Supreme Court Justice George Frankenthaler was named yesterday by Mayor O'Dwyer as impartial chairman of two arbitration panels that will attempt to settle the labor dispute between the management and employes of the Green Bus Lines, Inc., and the Triboro Coach Corporation, operators of bus lines serving nearly two-thirds of Queens.

THIS baroque eclogue is so baroque it will be read trembling by those who have noticed how contagious Mr. Auden'a innovations are, but it can well afford a suspicious air, since it is his most significant piece of work.

BERLIN, July 26 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor, urged today the speedy establishment of new industrial levels for Germany. He said that "every day's delay is just that much loss of motion in the revival of the German economy.

Better human relations through more adequate institutional advertising, house organs and other forms of labor-management communications was emphasized as industry's major problem at the Eighth International Management Congress held in Stockholm, Fred G. Rudge, president of Fred Rudge, Inc., consultants on labor-industrial relations, said last week on his return from Stockholm.

Most of the wholesale markets last week were comparatively quiet with considerably fewer buyers in town, according to the weekly market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buyers.

PALESTINE, which has been the scene of an occasional film such as the forthcoming Herbert Kline-Meyer Levin feature, "Survivors," may support a permanent movie industry, if the plans of Norman Lourie and Joseph Krumgold materialize.

The program of the world's business community for economic recovery and an expanding world economy was submitted to the State Department last week by Philip D. Reed, chairman of the General Electric Company, in his capacity as chairman of the United States Associates of the International Chamber of Commerce.

Retailers will be fully prepared to handle the additional consumer spending that will result from cash redemption of $1,800,000,000 worth of veterans' terminal leave bonds, it was pointed out last week, even though there is no particular desire on their part to be subject to inflationary stimulants under current economic conditions.

BAILEY ISLAND, Me., July 26 -- Good fishing weather and plenty of big tuna were the prospects facing the fifty-five entrants in the Maine tuna tournament as the motley fleet of fishing cruisers bearing the contestants fanned out across Casco Bay at 8 A.M. today.

THE American Humane Association announces its 1948 Motion Picture Contest for amateurs, in which prizes of $200, $75 and $25 will be awarded for films about pets, domestic animals, birds and wildlife that "create a friendly, kindly and constructive interest in animals."

LEEDS, England, July 26 (Reuters) -- South Africa, batting on a drying wicket, collapsed after the tea interval today, losing the last six wickets for 52 runs to go all out for 175 in the fourth cricket test match against England at Headingly.

RETAIL trade continued to give a good account of itself last week. Consumer demand was well maintained in comparison with the extremely high sales increases of a year ago. Confidence in fall prospects increased, if anything supporting the view that this year as a whole will hang up a new all-time record in dollar volume of retail trade, if not in units of merchandise.

PLANTING and transplanting, even in the heat of July, can be done successfully. Gardeners in recent years have strayed farther and farther from the old idea that there are only two planting seasons, spring and fall.
HOLLYWOOD. IT is a simple matter for Sigmund Romberg to select the music for his Tuesday night radio concerts. He plays the music he likes.

MADRID, July 26 -- The final official figures on the vote on the Franco Succession, Law were announced today. The percentage of yes votes was raised to 92.94 per cent of all the votes. Eighty-seven and four-tenths per cent of all registered voters cast ballot, the report said.

CHICAGO, July 26 -- If Clarence Iott, the left-handed refugee from the Browns, never accomplishes anything else he will always be able to lay claim to the distinction of having been one hurler who could come stalking into Wrigley Field and make the Cubs play dead with scarcely an effort.
THE food shortage brought about by the war prompted a great show of culinary ingenuity, but in all the substituting of this for that, no one devised any way of preparing jelly without sugar.

Brooklyn will get 24,000 new telephones in the next six weeks with the opening of four central offices, it was announced yesterday by A.G. Wright, vice president and general manager of the Long Island area of the New York Telephone Company.

JERUSALEM, July 26 (AP)--A clandestine discussion between the chairman of the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine and Menahem Beigin, commander of Irgun Zvai Leumi, will provide part of the background when the inquiry group writes its report in Geneva.

DALLAS, Tex., July 26 -- Conversion of cotton acreage in the Southwest to wheat and other grains in recent years has been replacing the traditional Texas farm scene of white dotted rows of blooming cotton with waving fields of grain.

FRANKFURT. IMMEDIATELY after the first World War there was an explosive outburst of expressionist literature in Germany. After this war there is comparative silence. Even the "bureau drawer literature," supposed by some optimists to have been written in secret during the Nazi regime, has scarcely materialized.

The first successful American helicopter dates only from 1940. But a recent report issued by the Helicopter Council of Aircraft Industries Association points out that this type of aircraft is already being used effectively on such diversified jobs as fighting forest fires, making geological surveys, patrolling pipelines, rounding up cattle and speeding the mails.

ONE of the most diverse and lively of the current summer group attractions has just opened at the Kraushaar Gallery, bringing together paintings by some thirty artists. Three of these are no longer with us -- Luks, Lawson and Glackens; the rest are contemporaries.
CHICAGO, July 26 -- The clock and calendar apparently have come around once again to that time of year known as the open season on master minds.

Governor Dewey has been following every development in the Queens police graft inquiry while he has been in the West and will take definite action upon his return to Albany on Aug. 2, it was learned yesterday.

BERLIN, July 26 -- The British decision to go to Washington after all and take part in the Ruhr Coal Conference is exceptionally significant for Germans. It reaffirms for them that the two countries are capable of speaking the same language intellectually as well as literally.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- The Senators scored their fifth straight victory by defeating the Indians, 8 -- 4, today and moved into fifth place. Cleveland, which at one time in today's game held a four-run lead over Washington fell back to sixth.

This morning, at the Bronx Veterans Administration Hospital, formal services will be held dedicating a beautiful new therapeutic swimming pool to the memory of the four chaplains of all faiths who gave up their own lifebelts to save others in the sinking of the transport Dorchester.

Widely circulated criticism of current price levels overlook the fact that American business has provided world leadership in showing how prices are most effectively reduced through applying scientific management methods, John Hancock, partner in Lehman Bothers, investment bankers, and chairman of the board of directors of the American Management Association, pointed out in an interview yesterday.

At Potsdam two years ago this week the Big Three heads of state agreed on the first step in peace-making. The Potsdam Declaration of Aug. 2, 1945, established a Big Five Foreign Ministers Council to draft European peace treaties. As Russia was not yet in the war with Japan the Declaration did not mention the Far East.

IT has been almost a year since 8 English Decca introduced its "Full Frequency Range Recording." During that time more than two dozen albums have been released, most of them of a distinctly superior quality, and at a price no higher than other imported records.

The continued momentum of market forces working for a shrinking of the spread between the short-term and the long-term interest rates has convinced market observers that the public money managers must soon institute new measures of control or re-establish old ones if the general investment pressure on intermediate and long-term Treasury bond yields is to be lightened.

PORT DALHOUSIE, Ont., July 26 -- The sixty-fifth Royal Canadian Henley Regatta concluded today with the Buffalo Westsides taking team honors, and John B. Kelly Jr. of Philadelphia retaining his championship singles.

TOM SCOTT, the Kentucky ballad singer, has here collected, in a book thin enough to sit well on the piano, thirty-five of our popular American folksongs. He has provided them with piano accompaniments of the proper simplicity, his wife has written some words which relate each song to the life from which it sprang, and Bernard Brussel-Smith has illustrated the songs with woodcuts.

From time to time learned men are dismayed as they rediscover that the poor have more children than the wellto-do. If they add to this fact the theory that the well-to-do are brighter than the poor, they may arrive at the sad conclusion, as Guy Irving Burch of the Population Reference Bureau did in a week-end statement, that the level of intelligence is declining.

THE increased use of hydraulic power in passenger cars is bringing new benefits to the motorist in automobile operation, comfort and safety. Automotive engineers emphasize the advantages gained in the operational ease and reliability of hydraulically powered equipment.
Hornbeam made it, but Risolater didn't. That was the story of the odds-on choices in the Saratogaat -Jamaica $10,000 twin features yesterday.

BASEBALL With Ed Lopat pitching a three-hit game and missing a shut-out only on Tommy Henrich's homer, the White Sox defeated the Yankees yesterday 2 -- 1. The Dodgers beat the Pirates, 6 4, with two runs in the ninth inning for their seventh straight victory, while the Giants downed the Cubs, 7 -- 3, with the aid of Johnny Mize's thirtieth homer.

THE best enemy of lawn weeds is good healthy turf. With weeds, as with many other things, prevention is much easier than eradication. However, many new chemical sprays are now on the market to make this problem a much easier one to handle.
WASHINGTON, July 26--The high cost of long work days and long work weeks in terms of productive efficiency, is shown by a Bureau of Labor Statistics study made public today.

DETROIT, July 26 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey was to arrive here tonight with his family on the final leg of a 6,200-mile vacation and sightseeing trip that brought him into contact with Republican leaders in thirteen states. He probably will talk with leaders of several others before returning to Albany at the end of this next week.

WASHINGTON, Sunday, July 27 -- The first session of the Eightieth Congress adjourned early today. When the final gavel fell in the Senate, at 3:50 A.M., there began what was expected to be a fivemonth suspension of national legislative action.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- Nearly 5,000,000 square miles of tropical jungle, the swampy forest of the Amazon basin, is to become a titanic laboratory where scientists of all countries will study the basic problems of human life in equatorial regions. This is the first major project of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural organization.

THE muddle of Occupied Germany, American Zone, must be tempting pickings for any writer looking for a timely setting in which to place a boy and a girl, a romance and a tragedy. And I.A.R. Wylie, who has proved often enough that timeliness is next to godliness, is not a one to shrink from temptation.

AS the first of several motion pictures projected by Hollywood on the subject of racial and religious prejudice right here in the United States, RKO's grim and grissly "Crossfire," which came to the Rivoli last week, warrants particular inspection and critical inquiry.

THE American elm tree is a 300-year-old heritage of the New England home and town. As a shade tree alone, it is worth more than $650,000,000 to the nation. Yet a deadly disease has spread across the country which threatens the very existence of this tree.

Confirming a condition that has harassed pessimists who have been predicting a business recession for many months, President Truman's report to Congress, showing the nation's economy enjoying "unprecedented prosperity," had a bolstering effect on sentiment in financial quarters last week.

SEOUL, Korea, July 26 -- Maj. Gen. Albert E. Brown, chief of the United States delegation on the joint United States-Soviet Commission, has accepted an invitation to attend tomorrow's rally of the Communist-dominated Democratic People's Front.

NOVELS that choose fallenand-risen France for their settings run the risk of becoming literary war victims. By focusing attention on an unusual Normandy family. Henry Blanchard has tried to save his story from slipping into the files of fictionized Resistance records.

Price rises announced at the end of last week by the Republic Steel Corporation, the National Steel Corporation, the American Rolling Mill Company and Jones Laughlin can be expected to set at pattern for the rest of the steel industry and certainly will lead to proportional price advances in other industries that build their products with steel, financial observers believe.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 26 -- The most controversial issue before delegates of the Constitutional Convention now in session at Rutgers University is that of taxes -- a question that directly affects the pocketbooks of most residents of the state.

UNDER the leadership of no less an all-around showman than Eddie Dowling, the first edition of "The Big Break" was run off last Sunday night at 10:30 on NBC's hookup. Representing radio's latest opportunity for unknown but talented performers to attain whichever of the theatrical spotlights they seek, the show is a refreshing refinement of the amateur program craze created on the kilocycles so many years ago.

First prize in the national advertising group of the annual Father's Day Advertising Contest has been won by Hickock Manufacturing Company, it was announced over the week-end by Alvin Austin, executive director of the Father's Day Council.

While retailers last week refused to be stampeded into a new buying spree, buyers who were visiting the wholesale markets, taking a realistic view of the situation, were placing larger orders and somewhat farther in advance than they had expected to, according to the reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

BAILEY ISLAND, Me., July 27 -- Although the wind that swept across Casco Bay was classed by the local boatmen as "moderate," and the swell that dipped and rolled the fishing boats was termed "mild" many of the contestants in the Maine Tuna Tournament were hanging over the stern by noon.

Those who looked for something sensational among the 18,350 Lincoln papers sealed by his son, Robert Todd Lincoln, twenty-eight years ago and now opened at last, seem doomed to disappointment. No rumored hints of treachery within the war Cabinet or other scandal has been found.

LONDON, July 27 (AP) -- Europe's fuel situation may be "not quite so critical" next winter as last, but emergency imports of American coal -- if there are dollars to pay for them -- probably will be needed until ]949, a European Coal Organization official said today.
MOSCOW, July 27 (AP) -- A. Russian critic of American literature accused "reactionary American publishers" today of deliberately suppressing certain "anti-imperialist" essays by Mark Twain.

NANKING, July 27 -- President Chiang Kai-shek today severely criticized "certain" United States writers and correspondents who, he charged, had written so much concerning corruption and inefficiency in the Chinese Government that they had endangered Chinese-American relations.

MAPLEWOOD, N.J., July 27 -- Fearing the home he built thirty years ago was being "endangered" by an adjacent 150-unit garden-type apartment house, Frederick F. Dieter, 76-year-old retired jeweler, attempted to wipe out his family in their sleep early today and to kill himself.

MEXICO CITY, July 27 -- The supreme importance of continuing financial aid from the United States for Mexico's efforts to eradicate the hoof-and-mouth disease from fifteen of her cattle-raising states, or more than a third of the country's total area, was reaffirmed by Norris E. Dodd Under-Secretary of Agriculture, just before he returned to Washington.

Bishop Cameron J. Davis of the Diocese of Western New York, chairman since 1940 of the commission on holy matrimony of the general convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church, declared last night that Bishop William T. Manning had no right to criticize the marriage of divorced women to two clergymen of the church without knowing all the facts in the cases.

PURCHASE, N.Y., July 27 -- Fred Annon of Innis Arden and Harry Bloomberg posted a best ball of 32, 31 -- 63 to head forty-four teams in a new annual full-handicap pro member event at the Old Oaks Country Club today.

City shipping interests are marshaling forces to combat a plan of the city to construct a large destruction-incinerator plant on the waterfront in the heart of the passenger liner district, it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The record of the first session of the Eightieth Congress, which convened Jan. 6 and adjourned this morning, pivoted around major legislation dealing with national defense, labor, taxation, international relations and appropriations.

TOKYO, July 27 -- Scandals centering upon the disposition of huge stockpiles accumulated throughout the war by the Japanese military forces have become Japan's foremost issue. The newspapers indicated today that the Katayama Cabinet's possible future was involved.

CHICAGO, July 27 -- Coming up with another one of their bruising attacks that overcame all obstacles, including the Cubs and their own spotty pitching, the Giants romped off with the series finale today, 12 to 6. It gave Mel Ott's merry Polo Grounders the set, two out of three.

ORANGETOWN, N.Y., July 27 -- This would be a most inopportune time for a fire to break out either in the police station hereabouts or in the home of Chief of Police Fred Kennedy. The firemen do not like him. For that matter the firemen are not fond of any policemen right now.

To THE EDITOR OP THE NEW YORK TIMES : It is a privilege for me to write this word of appreciation of THE NEW TORK TIMES. I am now spending the season at the Chautauqua Institution, which the late President Theodore Roosevelt characterized as "the most American thing in America."

CHICAGO, July 27 (AP) -- The West took its fifth straight triumph in the annual Negro All-Star baseball game, 5 -- 2, over the East, which garnered only three hits before 48,112 at Comiskey Park today.

SOFAR, Lebanon, July 27 -- During the next four years Saudi Arabia intends to spend $270,000,000 on internal projects, Fuad Bey Hamza, recently appointed Saudi Arabian Minister of Development, declared today.

CHICAGO, July 27 -- Grain markets turned downward late last week after an early bulge had carried all deliveries of oats and the deferred months of corn to new seasonal high prices. Hedging pressure developed in wheat later and there was heavy selling of corn as the result of a return to summer-like weather in the Midwest, which is expected to force the crop along toward maturity at a rapid rate.

Mankind is looking for individuals who by virtue of their unselfish simplicity and power of spiritual vision and leadership will point the way to a permanent peace and wise economic processes, the Right Rev. Austin Pardue, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Pittsburgh, said yesterday in his sermon on "The Cosmic Principle in Human Greatness," in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

VIENNA, July 27 -- The Austrian Socialist party warned workers today against Communist efforts to employ "Balkan methods" of infiltration and intimidation in the only elections that will take place in Austria this year.

A total of $1,131,445 was raised this year by the Greater New York Chapter of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, a sum 29.66 per cent less than the amount collected in 1946, William F. Snyder, chapter chairman, announced yesterday.

The prospects for a removal of the snags which threaten the Marshall Plan have grown brighter as a result of the action of the French National Assembly. It has voted an overwhelming endorsement of France's acceptance of that plan despite Russian rejection of it, and underlined that endorsement by paying homage to the United States for initiating a program of European recovery.

As scores of disabled veterans eagerly looked on, the new therapeutic swimming pool at the Bronx Veterans Hospital was dedicated yesterday with a message from President Truman. The message reminded the nation that it "must not forget" its war heroes.
BATAVIA, Java, July 27 (AP) -- A Netherlands Army communique:

Reporting on operations of General Mills, Inc., for the fiscal year ended with last May, James F. Bell, chairman, and Harry A. Bullis, president, informed shareholders in the nineteenth annual statement to be distributed today that while earnings reached a new high of $9,236,214, compared with $7,146,107 the year before, earnings per dollar of sales remained at 2 1/2 cents, approximately the same rate as the preceding year.

It would not be charitable to judge the sense of humor of the Russians by such a film as "Twins," which opened Saturday at the Stanley, so let's dismiss it as one of those unfortunate light comedies that any country can make. At least it doesn't tell about the war or propagandize the Soviet political system, so it may be classed as something of a novelty among the general run of Russian pictures shown here.

SEOUL, Korea, July 27 -- Maj. Gen. Albert E. Brown, chief of the United States delegation to the American-Soviet Commission for Korea, gave a stern warning today that the United States would not accept single-party provisional rule for this country.

The Best Laid Official agreement to close four East Side crosstown streets in the lower Thirties, so that the new medical center adjoining Bellevue Hospital may have elbow room, is a reminder of several things that have happened to our city since the gridiron plan for Manhattan Island was laid out in 1811 the year our City Hall was completed with its back to what was thought of as country.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : Perhaps I can answer the question put to you by William Adams Delano in his letter of July 22. He wanted to know how editorially you can seek "the preservation of the Sag Harbor Postoffice" and at the same time support "the Park Department plan to demolish Fort Clinton."

The United States should propose immediately through the United Nations an inventory of the security requirements of each nation in the world as a supplement to the Marshall Plan, Senator Brien McMahon said last night.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 27 (U.P.) -- An 81-year-old couple who drove here from Seattle, Wash., in a red-wheeled 1921 Model T. Ford were "remarried"' today at their 56th wedding anniversary party in Minnehaha Park.

United Medical Service, Inc., 370 Lexington Avenue, announced yesterday it has enrolled 201,944 persons during the first half of the year, compared with 113,733 during the like period in 1946, an increase of approximately 77 per cent.

Harold Krauss has been promoted from associate manager of candy, groceries and delicatessen of L. Bamberger Co., to manager of china and glassware. Frances Solomon has been advanced from assistant in glassware to manager of decorative gift accessories, replacing Jacob Ames, who has resigned.

Relaxation by the United States of the non-discrimination clause of the British loan agreement, which required Britain to accord American trade the same treatment as other areas, had a favorable effect on the market for sterling "forwards" last week.

LONDON, July 27 -- The Moscow radio asserted tonight that the reasons for the failure of the Anglo-Soviet trade negotiations were Britain's refusal to undertake the delivery of fixed quantities of industrial equipment for a definite promise of Russian food and timber and to agree to Soviet terms for repayment of a credit of u100,000,000 ($403,000,000).

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- President Truman on his return from the funeral of his mother will start the long grind of going through the heritage of bills left to him by the first session of the Eightieth Congress. There are about 250 of them, trivial and important, simple and complex, long and short.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., July 27 -- Three of today's four second-round matches in the fifth annual Charles R. Casey Memorial Tournament, a member-guest best-ball fixture, at the Wheatley Hills Golf Club went to extra holes.

Switzerland, which has maintained a policy of strict neutrality for over a century and a half, will observe its 656th year of demotratic freedom on Aug. 1. Once again traditional festivities, curtailed during the war when the nation was encircled by the Axis, will be held, similar to our July 4 celebrations.

The volunteer service for the blind operated by the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross, has a new program of sound recorded instruction, Mrs. E. Roland Harriman, chapter administrator of volunteer services, reported yesterday.

ELBERON, N.J., July 27 -- "The Church of the Presidents," more formally known as St. James Protestant Episcopal Chapel, overlooking the Atlantic Ocean here, may soon become a national shrine. Its vicar, the Rev. Christopher H. Snyder, who has seen his congregation dwindle with the years, has asked Representative James A. Auchincloss of Rumson, N.J., to interest Washington officials in taking the 68-year-old edifice over through a Federal appropriation.

Though attractiveness isn't usually one of the first things to look for in kitchen utensils, the burnished copper molds for shaping aspics, jellies and even cakes that now are being featured in stores here are as decorative as they are useful.

Mayor O'Dwyer in his year and a half in office has disposed of several major problems, and is moving in on others. It may be useful to take stock of some of the unfinished business that might, perhaps, be written off, at least in part, in the remainder of the year.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 27 -- Windblown sailing craft, again washing old records astern, were out today skimming and splashing around in the concluding regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club race week.

A radical change in the present method of financing the city's large-scale capital programs, involving huge bond issues outside the constitutional debt limit and the earmarking of special taxes to meet carrying charges on such securities, is before Mayor O'Dwyer for consideration, it was learned yesterday.

It would require six months and cost $500,000 to adapt the present subway and elevated line turnstiles to a 5-cent fare during rush hours and a 10-cent fare the rest of the time, it was reported yesterday.

Nearly three-quarters of the 105 American manufacturers surveyed by the National Industrial Conference Board on their organization for exporting now sell abroad primarily through their own foreign outlets, it was announced over the week-end.

DES MOINES, July 27 -- The convention of the International Sunday School Association came to a solemn and dramatic close tonight with a worship pageant in which nearly 1,000 choristers and players from Des Moines churches staged three Biblical scenes before 5,000 convention delegates and several thousand visitors.

BALTIMORE, July 27 (AP) -- Edmund W. Nash Sr., retired New York stockbroker and a brother of Ogden Nash, Baltimore poet, died here today in Union Memorial Hospital, where he had undergone an operation. He was 51 years old.
Babies, higher costs of living, insurance and homes of their own are among the things for which many war veterans will cash in their terminal leave pay bonds, it was indicated yesterday.

ATHENS, July 27 (U.P.) -- Government troops, aircraft and armed civilians killed, wounded or captured 100 guerrillas and beat off another attempt to seize Florina in a series of sharp clashes from the Yugoslav frontier to far southern Greece, newspaper dispatches reported today.

To THE EDITOR OP THE NEW YORK Times: The letter from "A Guamanian," published oh July 16, was primarily concerned with the applicability of democratic institutions to Guam -- a matter on which few people reasonably well acquainted with that island feel any uncertainty.

DETROIT, July 27 (U.P.) -- The General Motors Corporation will recall 115,000 production workers tomorrow after a week's layoff because of a critical steel shortage, but that was the only bright spot in the turbulent auto labor scene tonight.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 27 -- Henry Morgan, the radio comedian who makes fun of his sponsors, has signed a contract to make his screen debut in "So This Is New York," a picture to be based on Ring Lardner's novel, "The Big Town," which Stanley Kramer will produce for Screenplays, Inc.

Declaring that New York City's housing is a "mess," with 250,000 persons seeking living space that does not exist, Joseph Platzker, former Commissioner of Housing and Buildings, outlined a program yesterday to stimulate residential construction.

Demand for engineering work now exceeds the ability of many larger engineering firms to supply additional services because shortage of skilled engineers and technicians prevents expansion of their Staffs, leading firms revealed here over the week-end Many large projects are "going begging," they said, because the larger, engineering firms have reached a temporary ceiling in the amount of contract work they can accomplish with their present staffs.

GRANDVIEW, Mo., July 27 -- Friends and neighbors of Mrs. Martha Ellen Truman, the President's mother, paid their last respects to her here today. As they filed into her little cream-colored bungalow, they were greeted by President Truman, his daughter Margaret, his sister Mary Jane, and his brother Vivian.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The general index of basic commodity prices based on the August, 1939 level, rose from 304.7 on July 18, to 306.3 on July 25, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. The following lists daily index numbers and spot market prices:

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 27 -- Following is the provisional agenda of the second regular session of the United Nations General Assembly, which will convene Sept. 16 at flushing Meadow, Queens. Most of the data in brackets are taken from explanatory notes furnished by the United Nations Press Section.

More than $5,750,000 worth of machine tools from war surplus inventories are scheduled for new regional sales scheduled to open this week, Carl P. Malmstrom, regional director of the War Assets Administration, revealed in a statement over the week-end.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- Scholars avid for fresh Lincoln data found microfilm copies of the newly opened Robert Todd Lincoln documents available at the Library of Congress today, and spent long hours scanning them, although it was Sunday.

LOS ANGELES, July 27 -- The Democratic party in California has emphatically rejected the Henry Wallace-for-Preaident splinter movement within its ranka and reaffirmed its confidence in President Truman.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The International Association of Machinists, by a 3 to 2 referendum vote of the membership, has rejected reaffiliation with the American Federation of Labor until it gets what it calls a "fair" adjudication of its jurisdictional quarrels with certain other AFL unions.

The Long Island Rail Road has ordered five additional diesel-electric switching locomotives from the Baldwin Locomotive Works, it was announced yesterday by J.C. White, vice president. They will supplement eight diesel-electric locomotives already in yard service in Brooklyn and Queens.

BATAVIA, Java, July 27 -- The Netherlands Navy announced tonight that three newly captured ports in West and East Java would be opened to normal trade tomorrow and that blockade restrictions, in effect since last January, had been lifted.

PITTSBURGH, July 27 -- It is pleasantly monotonous to report that the Dodgers rapidly extended their winning streak to nine games today as they trounced the Pirates twice, 8 -- 4 and 11 -- 4, before the season's record overflow crowd of 42,716 at Forbes Field.

OWOSSO, Mich., July 27 -- Governor Thomas E. Dewey of New York may be the second choice of the Michigan delegation for the Republican Presidential nomination next year, John A. Wagner, GOP state chairman, said today. Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, will be first on the slate.
BOSTON, July 27 (AP) -- The Red Sox made it seven victories in a row today by winning both games of a double-header, 4-3 and 11-2, from the Browns before a paid attendance of 33,322.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., July 27 (AP) -- Ralph De Mott of Ridgefield scored a major upset today in the third round of the annual Eastern veterans singles championship, when he eliminated Henry Benisch of Forest Hills, N.Y., 6 -- 0, 6 -- 2, at the East Orange Tennis Club.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (U.P.) -- The CIO tonight joined the AFL in a united labor drive to force down prices by organizing consumer cooperative stores.
The general regulations adopted by the Temporary City Housing Kent Commission, which became effective today, follow:

The Rev. Dr. Harold T. Donaldson of Ward Memorial Chapel in Dundee, Scotland, delivered a sermon yesterday in Christ Church, Methodist, at 520 Park Avenue. He declared that "silent forces like retribution, sense of duty and love of home shape America's destiny, not wild voices that sound across the world."

One hundred and ten Venezuelan naval cadets and officers from the Venezuelan transport Capana, now in port for a courtesy visit, attended the 10 o'clock solemn high mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- Senator Homer Ferguson, Republican, of Michigan, delving into alleged wartime activities of Howard Hughes and Elliott Roosevelt, pictured the son or the late President as having power to "ram" a scout plane contract for Mr. Hughes "down somebody's throat," it was disclosed today.

Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., concluded negotiations over the week-end whereby the company acquired RKO Pathe News, one of the five major newsreel companies, it was jointly announced yesterday by Harry M. Warner, president of Warner Brothers, and Ned E. Depinet, vice chairman of the board of Radio Keith Orpheum.

"Top Secrets of the FBI" will be revealed when a new dramatic series bearing that title makes its debut over WOR-Mutual in September.
