The program, prepared with the official sanction of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, is scheduled to be a thirty-minute presentation on Sunday nights, but the time of broadcast and starting.

AS might be expected, when John Kieran of "Information Please" sets out to write a book about nature, he touches on much more than 'the animal, vegetable and mineral kingdoms. "Footnotes on Nature"* is an informal account of excursions afoot, and occasionally afloat, along the Hudson near this city, in Connecticut, western Massachusetts and Long Island.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The nation's lawmakers theoretically embarking on a five-month vacation after today's early-morning adjournment of Congress, actually will spend most of the time sizing up how their actions, heavily fraught with politics, were received by the public.

KATOWICE, Poland, July 27 (AP) -- Bob Fitch of Minneapolis today hurled, the discus 175 feet 10 5/32 inches, the second American in three days to better the recognized world record of 175 feet established by Adolfo Consolini of Italy in 1941.

Distribution of the consumer dollar for cotton textiles shows no appreciable change from 1939, even though there have been upheavals in the price and cost structure, according to a survey of The Cotton-Textile Institute, Inc., released over the week-end.

PARIS, July 27 -- Describing France's internal and international position as "extremely alarming," former President de Gaulle called on his former resistance followers today to rally to defend France against the activities of the Communist party from within and the peril of the Soviet Union from without.

SHANGHAI, July 27 (U.P.) -- Lieut. Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer worked his way through a schedule packed with appointments today and highlighted by conversations with Carson Chang, chairman of the Democratic Socialist party, and Li Huang-, leader of the Young China party -- the nation's foremost thirdparty representatives.

Protection against rent gouging is provided for hotel and apartment tenants in the General Regulations of the Temporary City Housing Rent Commission that will become effective today when filed with City Clerk Murray W. Stand, the Commission announced last night.

President Truman's Second Economic Report, made public last week, drew wide praise for the illuminating character and freshness of its statistical exhibits. Unlike the outdated appendices with which most of us have long been made familiar, these were as up-to-the-minute as the text itself, and the text brought the reader right through the second quarter of 1947.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 27 -- Yugoslavia has rejected a request of a United Nations Balkans subcommission to enter Yugoslavia to investigate alleged incidents on the border with Greece, the Government announced today. This is the second time permission has been refused.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Noel H. Symington of Market Harborough, England, in his letter to the editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, . asserted that America should not give financial aid to England because such contributions subsidized a "near-Communist regime, not a country."

LONDON, July 27 -- Gloomy conditions have returned to the stock markets here. The holiday quietude of business has given time for thought on the general economic outlook and for realization that we rapidly are approaching a dollar shortage crisis.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 27 (AP) -- Robert D'Arcy (Bobby) Locke of South Africa gave the American professionals another golf lesson today, winning the $10,000 Columbus open by five strokes and picking up a $2,000 check which made him the year's No. 1 money winner.

With Pan American Airways carrying its 100,000th passenger to Bermuda yesterday and Colonial Airlines announcing an application to fly there from Boston and Philadelphia (in addition to its New York and Washington services, which began Friday), a four-way race for the winter business to the ocean resort seems in prospect.

AMSTERDAM, July 27 -- The outbreak of hostilities in the Netherlands Indies had only short-lived influence on the stock exchange last week. After Monday's reaction of as much as 10 points, a marked recovery developed to far above the previous Friday's prices on expected early operations and the reports that relatively little damage had been done.
The 6,185-ton liner Acadia, long delayed in her return to peaceful pursuits after a varied war career, may once again serve on the Atlantic coastal routes for which she was built fifteen years ago.
Ship-to-shore radio telephone was added late yesterday afternoon to the instrumentalities of peace in labor relations.

The Coney Island Mardi Gras, colorful six-day celebration held for the last forty-five years after Labor Day week-ends, will be omitted this season because of "insurmountable obstacles" coupled with a general "erroneous" conception that the event marks the end of the resort's season, it was announced yesterday.

NORRIS, Tenn., July 27 -- This world-famous experiment in community planning under Government supervision is now adjusting itself for sale at a public auction that will introduce the democratic processes of local government.

The Rev. Dr. Ralph Walker, pastor of the First Baptist Church, Portland, Ore., preaching yesterday at the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue at Forty-eighth Street, declared that if the nations of the world were to escape the disaster and possible doom of the atomic bomb, mankind would need to develop a deeper sense of responsibility toward God, from which only flows a sense of understanding and responsibility toward each other.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- The eightieth Congress closed its first session early today in the heat of an angry Senate political battle over President Truman's nominations that left six of the major ones unconfirmed.
BATAVIA, Java, July 27 (AP) -- An ndonesian Republican Army Comnunique:
SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 27 -- Miss Dorothy Head of Alameda, Calif., gained her most notable victory on turf today to win the Seabright Bowl.

No longer in the realm of conjecture is the booking of "How I Wonder" at the Hudson, where Donald Ogden Stewart's comedy, starring Raymond Massey as a professor of astronomy, will supplant "State of the Union" on Oct8.

PITTSBURGH, July 27 -- The stiff advances in steel prices announced by several large steel companies last week will pose a problem for the United States Steel Corp., which so far has not raised its quotations, according to trade sources here.
JERUSALEM, July 27 -- A call for organized civil disobedience by the Jewish population of Palestine came from the underground today while sporadic attacks on British security forces continued.
CHICAGO, July 27 -- More than 50,000 persons gathered in Soldier Field today to observe the centennial of the Evangelical Lutheran Synod of Missouri, Ohio and other states.
An abnormal surplus of bulk-carrying steamships on the Atlantic Coast has driven the bottom out of the freight rate market between Atlantic ports and European terminals, it was learned yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 27 -- Strong support is developing for the election of Dr. Oswaldo Aranha of Brazil, who presided at the recent special session of the United Nations General Assembly as president of the regular session, which opens at Flushing Meadow, Queens, on Sept. 16.
The accent was on age yesterday at the Stadium as the Yankees split a twin bill with the White Sox before a gathering of 51,921 and had a game shaved off their league lead.

BAD SALZUFLEN, Germany, July 27 -- The cost of living has risen so high in the British zona that working-class households can meet only 57 per cent of their essential expenditures out of income, the Military Government reported today.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- An expected five months' vacation began for its members today as the first session of the first Republican-dominated Congress in sixteen years came to an end at 3:50 A.M.
Awards of twenty-nine fellowships to Latin Americans with stipends totaling $80,000 were announced yesterday by the John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $52,896,223,912. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

DULUTH, Minn., July 27 (AP) -- Charles Boswell, former University of Alabama football star, won the United States Blind Golfers' championship at Northland Country Club today by defeating Clint Russell, Duluth's defending champion, 2 and 1, in the 18-hole final.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- -- Cleveland clustered three of its five hits off Early Wynn in the sixth inning to score two runs and defeat Washington, 2 -- 1, today before a crowd of 19,046.

The $57,000,000 borrowed from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in 1940 to pay for construction of the Battery-Brooklyn Tunnel will fall at least $14,000,000 short of the amount needed and negotiations are in progress to increase the loan to $71,000,000.

Former Assemblyman John J. Lamula, candidate for Republican leader of the Second Manhattan Assembly District, East, said yesterday that high officials of the Police Department had assured him of adequate protection at the polls to tomorrow's primary election.

ST. LOUIS, July 27 (AP) -- The Braves defeated the Cardinals, 10 -- 3, today behind Johnny Sain's seven-hit hurling, hammering Harry Brecheen and four other Red Bird pitchers for 18 hits including seven doubles and Tommy Holmes' home run.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- President Truman was expected to sign the non-ferrous metals subsidy bill which Congress sent to him last night in a compromised form.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- A seated audience of some 500 persons and a standing crowd of perhaps 3,000 at four o'clock yesterday afternoon saw and heard the ceremonial exercises in the rotunda of the Library of Congress to which the general public was invited.

The undeclared war being waged by the Netherlands Indies Colonial Government on the Republic of Indonesia, whose de facto authority in Java, Sumatra and Madura it had recognized, is to be brought to the attention of the United Nations by India's Interim Government.

The number of people who daily stroll along Fifth Avenue at 135th Street, hopefully eying the new apartment buildings of Riverton, was reduced yesterday by ten families. These ten families were the first among 20,000 applicants to be admitted as tenants to the one building now completed.
Spring lines of woolen fabrics, to be opened in the next two weeks, will reflect the inflationary trend with price increases up to 10 per cent, according to a survey of the trade yesterday.

LONDON, July 28 -- Evidence in today's hearing of salvage claims against the owners of the freighter American Farmer, which was abandoned by her crew after a collision in the Atlantic last July, revealed the intense competition between crews of British and American vessels to gain possession of the ship.

NEW DELHI, India, July 28 -- India will formally refer the Indonesian situation to the United Nations tomorrow morning for action by the Security Council as a threat to world peace, Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, vice president in the Indian Interim Government, announced at a press conference today.

The list of committees of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York for the year 19471948, appointed by Harrison Tweed, president of the association, was made public yesterday as follows: STANDING COMMITTEES Administrative Law -- Robert M. Benjamin, chairman; Robert M. Bozeman, Herbert Brownell Jr., Stanley Buchsbaum.

BATAVIA, Tuesday, July 29 (U.P.) The United States in a note to the Indonesian Government shortly before the Dutch offensive began urged protection of the rich Americanowned oil fields in Sumatra, reliable sources said today.

LONDON, July 28 -- In a statement to the House of Commons today on the reasons for the failure of the Anglo-Soviet trade talks, Sir Stafford Cripps, President of the Board of Trade, carefully held the door wide open for the eventual resumption of negotiations.

Ground was broken yesterday for the new $900,000 parish school of the Church of St. Philip Neri. It is to be ready for occupancy by 1,000 children in September, 1948 at 3025 Grand Concourse, the Bronx.

MUNICH, Germany, July 28 -- The opening today of the trial of Sally Zeve, a Lithuanian displaced person accused of the misappropriation and resale of United States Army vehicles, has reawakened interest in the departure from Bavaria of a group of Americans prior to service on them of charges in the same case.

Argentine Government purchases of durable goods, machinery, tool, steel products and processing equipment will continue without cutbacks on the program outlined in the five-year plan which is now entering its second year, industrial equipment spokesmen here revealed yesterday.

OWOSSC, Mich., July 28 -- Taking a day off from the conferences with political leaders which have marked his Western "vacation, Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York devoted today to visits in this Michigan city of 20,000, where he was raised.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 28 -- Attorney General Walter D. Van Riper today warned delegates to the State Constitutional Convention here that adoption of a proposed amendment to legalize bingo and other "games of chance" would open the door to widespread gambling in New Jersey.

Citing the grave concern of American business over development of Manchuria, Arthur B. Foye, president of the Far EastAmerica Council of Commerce and Industry, has written to Secretary of State George C. Marshall expressing the hope that the Government will press for an "open-door policy" in the Port of Dairen and the rest of Manchuria.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 28 -- "Certain people" in China have deliberately provoked border incidents with Outer Mongolia to create international complications and "because they like what is going on in Greece," Alexei N. Krasilnikov of the Soviet Union told the Membership Committee of the United Nations Security Council today.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation in Washington made known yesterday that it objected strongly to use of the title, "Top Secrets of the FBI," for a proposed new program series on WOR. An official spokesman for the bureau emphasized the agency was not revealing its "top secrets," and that, contrary to the station's announcement over the week-end, it had not lent official sanction or approval to the series.

Supreme Court Justice Felix C. Benvenga denied yesterday a motion brought by three Negro war veterans to enjoin Stuyvesant Town from allegedly practicing racial discrimination in the selection of tenants.
SEOUL, Korea, July 28 -- Increasing numbers of clashes between Leftists and Rightists have been reported here in the last few days.
HAIFA, Palestine, July 28 -- Two more ships, carrying 1,174 Jewish unauthorized immigrants, were brought into Haifa today under naval escort.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., July 2 -- One year ago Gardnar Mulloy of Coral Gables, Fia., and William Talbert of New York played on of the great matches of the season in the final of the Southampton Invitation tennis tournament.

PHILADELPHIA, July 28 -- The Northern Natural Gas Company, Omaha, Neb., asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today for permission to increase its authorized common stock from 1,200,000 to 5,000,000 shares and reduce the par value of such shares from $20 to $10.

Secretary of State George C. Marshall has been elected an honorary member of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, it was announced yesterday. The award will be presented to General Marshall at the annual dinner of the society Dec. 3 in Atlantic City.

PARIS, July 28--Having gradually led up to an open attack on the French Communists and the Soviet Union in speeches in provincial cities, former President de Gaulle now intends to carry his campaign into the center of Paris, according to his followers.

Lewyt Corporation of Brooklyn has appropriated $1,000,000 for advertising of its new vacuum cleaner, utilizing all types of media, from Oct. 1 to Oct. 1, 1948, the organization's fiscal year. Insertions in daily and weekly newspapers in thirty-five marketing areas will be the keynote of the program, according to W.J. Daily, vacuum cleaner division manager.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The Government signed an $18,000,000 non-profit contract for 200-ton flying boats with Howard Hughes, airplane designer and film producer, and Henry J. Kaiser, the shipbuilder, against strong official engineering objections and maintained it after Jesse H. Jones had been directed to cancel it, a Senate war investigating subcommittee was told today.

BREST, France, July 28--Eight persons were killed and several hundred injured when a nitrate-laden Norwegian Liberty ship caught fire and exploded just outside Brest Harbor today, the French News Agency reported.

WASHINGTON, July 28. (AP) -- The Right Rev. Msgr. James H. Griffiths of New York said today that clergymen visiting in Europe were "reliably informed that more than 5,000 young boys have disappeared off the streets of Berlin in the Russian zone."

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Tuesday, July 29 -- A special meeting of stockholders of the Hudson Manhattan Railroad Company to elect new directors was thrown into turmoil early today in the First District Court of New Jersey here when a fist fight broke out between management and opposition supporters.

CHICAGO, July 28 (AP) -- Brolite Farm's With Pleasure smashed the six-furlong track mark today while scoring a half-length victory over Dixiana Stable's Spy Song in the $22,400 Quick Step Stakes at Washington Park. A crowd estimated at 19,000 saw the opening of the thirty-one-day meeting.

PANAMA, July 28 -- Ecuador's Minister of Economy, Leonardo Stagg, in a communication to the press today said that the preliminary report of the financial survey made by Dr. Robert Triffin was incomplete and mutilated. His communication corrects the article published in THE NEW YORK TIMES on July 16, which was based on the report published in the Telegrafo of Ecuador.

Under American inspiration and with American help, Saudi Arabia proposes to embark on a program of modernization and development which could spark the regeneration of the whole Middle East and create entirely different Power relations in that key region of the world.
SECURITY COUNCIL Completed consideration of United States resolution on Greek question. Meets today at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. (Open.)

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, July 28 -- Official circles today described rumors about the partition of Java and Sumatra into seven parts as "highly premature." According to an official Dutch spokesman the Dutch Government will not make plans until the police operations have come to an end and a survey of the situation is possible.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Two Federal agencies, under Senate pressure, are making an investigation of the disposal of $16,000,000,000 in surplus war plants and facilities.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 28 -- Officials of the Indian delegation here heard from New Delhi that the Indian Government intended to present the Indonesians' case to the United Nations. They are awaiting instructions here, which they believe may arrive by tomorrow.

KANSAS CITY, July 28 -- With her son, the President of the United States; at the graveside, Mrs. Martha Ellen Young Truman was buried in Forest Hill Cemetery here this afternoon. Her grave is next to that of her husband, John Anderson Truman, who died in 1914.

Store Sales Here Up 3% Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores increased 3 per cent last week over the comparable week a year ago, according to the "flash" report of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York yesterday. In the previous week a rise of 16 per cent was reported, while for the four weeks ended July 26 the gain was 11 per cent.
LONDON, July 28 -- The London autumn dress collections opened today with a sureness of design that is stimulating for the future of fashion.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your editorial "End of the British Raj" you say, "For the first time in twenty-two centuries the teeming millions of India can see the sun of freedom shining through." The masses of India had a very substantial amount of political freedom when the Guptas (fourth to middle of seventh century A.D.), the Palas, the Gurjaras and the Pallavas flourished in India, till the twelfth century A.D.
New York will be the focal point for the observance of the fortieth birthday of American military air power on Friday.
WARSAW, July 28 -- The Government has decided on a fundamental reform of the nation's educational system in order to bring higher schools into line with what is called "the new political reality."

Moderately-priced wood and upholstered furniture was welcomed back by Macy's yesterday at the opening of their midsummer show. New interchangeable sectional cabinets, luxurious-looking desks of finely ribbed wood Weldtex lacquered in decorator's colors, and sensible birch pieces with coordinated sofas took the limelight away from custom-made furniture for the first time in years.

June furniture cancellations approximated 19 per cent of new orders booked, compared with 25 per cent in the previous month, according to the monthly report issued yesterday by Seldman Seldman, accountants for many leading furniture manufactures.

The stock market was subjected yesterday to sharp realizing in the final hour that produced The widest retreat in prices since June 24 and Jeft the composite rate reduced by 1.34 points and wider inroads in some selected issues. The reversal came after moderate strength during the forenoon and brought out the heaviest and most intense pressure encountered in two weeks.

BOSTON, July 28 (AP) -- Sam Garfield's F.B. Eye closed fast through the stretch and caught A. Ryan's Ellen Mist a few yards from the wire today to win the feature by a neck at Suffolk Downs before 13,127 fans.

A year ago when it became obvious that existing facilities in this state were inadequate to meet the demands of veterans for higher education, the Legislature created the Associated Colleges of Upper New York. Now making plans for the opening of its second year, this college, a unique experiment in cooperative education, has proved to be sound and valuable.

Without referring directly to last year's election morning killing of Joseph Scottoriggio, Republican worker, Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallandern told 400 highranking officers of the Police Department yesterday that voters in the primary election today must be protected from their homes to the polling places.

A delegation of officers of the Greater New York Hospital Association visited City Hall yesterday to thank Mayor O'Dwyer and members of his administration for their "strong support" of the voluntary non-profit hospitals of the city.

Emile Marghab, president of Emile Marghab, Inc., manufacturers of fine linens, with offices at 1775 Broadway, died yesterday in the Doctors Hospital, Eightyseventh Street and East End Avenue, after an illness of several weeks. His New York residence was the Hotel Wellington, Seventh Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street.

TOKYO, July 28 -- Public sales of the shares of the giant holding companies and other firms that the occupation has ordered dissolved have now begun. Securities dealers have bought, for almost 6,000,000 yen, 115,000 shares in the closed institutions. These are being offered to the public this week.

TRENTON, N.J., July 28 -- State farm authorities said today that they had not received enough information to substantiate reports in central and southern New Jersey that farmers were plowing under large acreages of crops because low prices made marketing unprofitable.

LEEDS, July 28 (Reuters) -- Helped by a century by Len Hutton -- his first against South Africa -- and 75 by Cyril Washbrook, who between them scored 141 for the first wicket, England led by 142 runs on a first innings' 317, with three wickets still to fall at the end of the second day's play of the fourth test cricket match today.

The fire-damaged John Ericsson, formerly the luxury transatlantic liner Kungsholm, was repurchased from the Maritime Commission by the Swedish American Line for $800,000, it became known yesterday. The sale price was not announced when the transfer of the vessel was reported a week ago.
MUNICH, Germany, July 28 -- Dr. Phillip Auerbach, Bavarian Commissioner for Political Persecuted Persons, today received a protest against "Communist terrorism" by the group he represents.

Construction of the atomic pile and associated facilities for atomic research to be created at the Brookhaven National Laboratory on the 3,700-acre site that was formerly Camp Upton on Long Island will get under way next month, it was announced here yesterday by the United States Atomic Energy Commission.

VIENNA, July 28 -- United States Army suspicion that Russian geologists wished to hunt uranium ores in the American zone of Austria brought a Russian ultimatum in the matter of passes through the Russian zone last week. Accordingly the Russians now refuse to give any consideration to American applications for passes to go to or through the Soviet zone.
LONDON, July 28 -- Increasing nervousness among investors over the economic outlook was responsible for a wave of selling that hit the stock market here today.
CHICAGO, July 28 (U.P.) -- Sharp changes in temperatures hastened the death of Franklin D. Roosevelt, Dr. William F. Petersen said today.

CHICAGO, July 28 -- That Dodger winning streak was stretched to ten games today. It required a four-run explosion in the ninth inning, however, to give the Brooks a 4-0 triumph over the Cubs and send them on to St. Louis still holding their seven-game firstplace lead over the Cards.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- A new hospital map of the entire United States, showing where facilities now are and where they ought to be, is being assembled by the United States Public Health Service, as the Hospital Cohstruction Act of August, 1946 is now taking effect.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Gregg M. Sinclair, president of the University of Hawaii, in a letter to Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., of Massachusetts, replied to objections recently raised by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president emeritus of Columbia University against the admission of Hawaii to statehood.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 28 -- The United Nations' Security Council virtually completed preliminary action today on the agreed text of a resolution to establish a new frontier commission in the Balkans that would function for at least two years.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 28 -- "The Brain of Frankenstein," a comedy involving the entire horror roster of Universal-International, including Dracula, the Mummy and the Wolf Man, as well as Frankenstein's monster, has been scheduled as a vehicle for Bud Abbott and Lou Costello, the studio announced today.

Billy Rose is trying to purchase the Belasco Theatre. Reliable sources have it that the impresario made a big bid for the Fortyfourth Street playhouse late last week and that negotiations are still in progress. Asked to confirm the report yesterday, Mr. Rose begged off making any comment.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., July 28 -- Mrs. Donald O'Brien of Winged Foot held a one-stroke lead with a score of 42, 38 -- 80 as the first round of the Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association's threeday open championship was completed over the Quaker Ridge course today.

Ten thousand Staten Island commuters face a halt in their accustomed mode of transportation Monday as a result of a strike vote completed yesterday by 200 trainmen and conductors of the Staten Island Rapid Transit Railway.

Rising prices on fur skins can lead fur coat and trimming manufacturers into an era of speculation resulting in losses greater than those of last fall, Sol Rosenberg, president of the Association of Fur Coat Trimming Manufacturers, Inc., warned yesterday.
An agreement between the Todd Shipyards Corporation and employes that may lead to settlement of a nation-wide strike of shipbuilding workers was reached here yesterday.

PARIS, July 28 (UP) -- Flimsy wooden buildings along the Brest waterfront, built on the ruins of structures leveled by Allied bombs during the war, burst into flames from the blast and still were smoldering late tonight.

CINCINNATI, July 28 -- Johnny Vander Meer let the world know today that his distinguished colleague, Bucky Walters, wasn't the only one who could stage an eyefilling come-back. Vander Meer, at one time the mighty left bower of the Reds' pitching staff, decided that now was as good a time as any to stage a bit of a show himself.

With basketball, which drew 943,006, heading the list, a new alltime attendance record for Madison Square Garden was set for the fiscal year ending May 31, 1947, it was announced yesterday by John Reed Kilpatfick, president of the Garden.
JERUSALEM, Tuesday, July 29 -- Three condemned terrorists, for whom two British Army sergeants were being held as hostages by the underground, were hanged in the prison in Acre early today.

ALBANY, July 28 -- Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein ruled today that the state could not accept applications for soldiers' bonus payments before Jan. 1, should the $400,000,000 bonus be approved by the voters in November.

THOSE who have been following Marie Kimball's careful writings about our third President, the second volume of which, "Jefferson: War and Peace, 1776 to 1784,"* has now appeared, will be able to understand just how full and rewarding his life was, how brilliant his thought, how truly valuable his contribution to the American form of government.
Cotton futures were somewhat erratic yesterday with closing prices on the New York Cotton Exchange 12 to 31 points net lower.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Attorney General Tom C. Clark announced today that he has assigned two special assistants to work with the Kansas City Grand Jury investigating alleged irregularities in the 1946 primary election in the Fifth Missouri Congressional District.

ST. LOUIS, July 28 (AP) -- Two Cardinal catchers, Joe Garagiola and Del Rice, sparked St. Louis to an 8-7 triumph over the Braves today in a slugging, con test before 7,986 paying patrons. The victory enabled the second-place Redbirds to keep pace with the league-leading Dodgers.

I. James Brody, former Deputy Commissioner of Marine and Aviation, took the stand in General Sessions Court yesterday to deny point by point the testimony of Albert Gross, principal witness of the state, who has pleaded guilty to the same indictment under which Brody and James V. Auditore are being tried, charging conspiracy and accepting unlawful fees in the rental of city-owned piers.
If the children can't go to the zoo then maybe the zoo can come to the children.
BATAVIA, Java, July 28 (AP)-- The Netherlands Army said today that Dutch military columns, driving 100 miles in a week, had captured important coal and oil areas in southern Sumatra.

Another important step in the gradual decontrol of sugar from its wartime restrictions on prices and supplies was taken yesterday by the Department of Agriculture. Following by seven weeks its termination of rationing for householders and institutional consumers, the Department has now taken similar action with respect to industrial users.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: By a hasty retreat the leadership of the House of Representatives withdrew last week from its earlier announced decision to increase the 40-cent minimum wage in the Fair Labor Standards Act this summer.

ANDREWS FIELD, Md., July 28 -- Following a shaft of sunshine that broke through the pall of clouds just before their arrival, a flight of sixteen giant bombers of the Royal Air Force landed here today. The ships are on a goodwill and training mission.

WASHINGTON. July 28 -- Industrial sugar rationing ended at noon today, by order of the Department of Agriculture, due to the failure of Congress to appropriate funds to carry the program on through to the announced termination date of Oct. 31.
CHICAGO, July 28 (AP) -- The Washington Park Jockey Club announced today that it is attempting to match Assault and Armed in a $100,000 winner-take-all race at a mile and one-quarter.

The one-story business building at the southwest corner of Davis Court and Pierson Place, Long Island City, Queens, has been sold by Owens Illinois Distributors to Peel Richards, Ltd. The property occupies an irregular plot about 302 by 200 feet.

Formal approval of this country's participation in the 1948 Olympic Games was given yesterday by the United States Olympic Association at a meeting at the New York Athletic Club. No time was wasted by the Olympic Committee in setting in motion machinery in preparation for the VII Olympic Winter Games and the XIV Olympics in the summer.
OCEANPORT, N.J., July 28 (AP) -- Brookmeade Stable's Master Mind was the victor in today's sixfurlong Greek Syndicate purse $3,000 feature race at Monmouth Park.

CAUX, Switzerland, July 28 -- More than 1,000 persons are participating in the Moral Rearmament Conference, now at the height of its two and a half months' session in the organization's new Swiss home.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- Col. Charles Russell Broshous will succeed Col. Lawrence McC. (Biff) Jones as graduate manager of athletics at West Point next Spring, The Washington Post said tonight.

In a confusion of scattered books, prints, pottery and paintings an 1860 plaster bust of Abraham Lincoln, said to, be the first for which the future emancipator ever sat, went on display yesterday with other Lincolniana. in the Roberts Book Store, 384 Canal Street.

Less Dismal Science President Truman, pursuant to statute, gave us recently a most comprehensive account of the economic state of the nation at midyear. Just as there never was an economic man -- although economists have always talked as if there were -- so there never was an economic nation.

British experiments in refueling airliners in flight are in full swing, it was learned here yesterday. If successful in the future as they already have been, they will lead to non-stop flights between London and New York, with consequent saving of many hours' time at Shannon in Ireland and Gander, in Newfoundland.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- What new in politics is often termed the gravy train was known in Lincoln's time as the hog trough and the proper petitions and improper shennanigans, wheedling, groaning and griping of the runs through about half of the letters in the papers newly opened to the public in the Library of Congress.

Dominican Redemptions The announced redemption of outstanding United States dollar bonds of the Dominican Republic -- 5 1/2 s floated in 1922 and 1926 and not due until 1961 and 1969 -- will take place on Sept. 1 and on Oct. 1, 1947, respectively, it was announced yesterday.

A total of $86,050 was realized in two auction sales conducted Saturday by Joseph P. Day, Inc. One hundred and twenty-six seashore lots at Long Beach, L.I., were knocked down for $61,700, and four residences and thirtythree homesites were sold on the premises at Rivervale, adjoining Westwood, N.J., for $24,350.
JERUSALEM, July 28 -- In the Arab states bordering on Palestine there is considerable talk of an Arab uprising in the Holy Land some time between September and next summer.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, said today that unification of the armed forces was "the most decisive step taken since the foundation of the Republic," and viewed the task of making it work as a long and evolutionary process.

Initial units of the new vacuum cleaner now being produced on a contract basis by Lewyt Corporation, of Brooklyn, will be available in 15,000 appliance and department stores throughout the country by the middle of next month, Alex M. Lewyt, president, announced yesterday.

SHANGHAI, July 28 (AP) -- A jurisdictional riot between city and military police in a movie theatre took eight lives and wounded at least fifteen persons last midnight and led to this series of developments today: The city police went on strike, but most of them were talked out of it by the Mayor.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- Howard Hughes said today that Senator Owen Brewster, Republican, of Maine, had accepted his "hospitality" to the tune of $1,400 worth of free plane travel. Mr. Brewster replied that he did so only to accommodate Mr. Hughes with a conference.

Conn McCreary took a fall yesterday, and the rebound carried him into the stratosphere. The veteran jockey, thrown from the favored Jo Stafford in the second race on the program of the Saratogaat-Jamaica meeting, watched proceedings from the sideline in the third event, and then returned to the track to ride the winner in every one of the next four races.

Last night's Philharmonic-Symphony concert at Lewisohn Stadium introduced Bernard Herrmann, radio conductor, to a Stadium audience of 6,900, who heard William Kapell, young pianist, for the second time this year. The program consisted of Purcell's "Chaconne," "A London Symphony" by Ralph Vaughan Williams and Rachmaninoff's Second Piano Concerto.
The Roman Singers of Sacred Music, fifty-four men and boys from Vatican Chapel choirs, arrived in port yesterday aboard the liner Sobieski, but the ship is not expected to dock until 8 A.M. today.

PHILADELPHIA, July 28 (AP) -- Hank Majeski's sixth home run of the season, coming- in the ninth inning with Gene Handley on base and one out, gave the Athletics a 5-to-3 victory over the White Sox tonight before 7,336.

A dog that had been left alone in a store for a month was brought into Flatbush Court yesterday as evidence against its master, who was charged with cruelty to animals. After examining the thin animal and listening to the story of an agent of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, Magistrate Alex Pisciotta, gave the defendant until Thursday to pay a $25 fine or go to jail.

A Navy general court martial was told yesterday that Chief Signalman Harold E. Hirshberg admitted to a fellow prisoner of war in Japan that he had been responsible, for having another prisoner killed by the Japanese.

Outstanding players from the Negro National League will oppose the leading performers of the Negro American League in the annual All-Star baseball game tonight at the Polo Grounds. The encounter will get under way at 8:45 o'clock. In the event of rain, it will be staged tomorrow night.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- The new president of the American President Lines to succeed Henry F. Grady, who resigned to become Ambassador to India, probably will be named next month, official circles here indicated today.

CINCINNATI, July 28 -- A major league ball club, even though its personnel undergoes a constant turnover, usually follows a certain pattern which refuses to be altered by time, tide or the fluctuations of the daily standings.

The Manchester Holding Corporation, representing a New York syndicate, has purchased a vacant plot 96 by 100 feet on West Street, north of Palisade Avenue, between the Skouras Plaza Theatre and the Food Fair Market, Englewood, N.J., from the City of Englewood.
GENEVA, July 28 -- The complete texts of six of the eight chapters of the charter of the International Trade Organization have been agreed upon at the Geneva Trade Conference, it was learned today.

Arrest of an escaped convict early yesterday morning was credited in Felony Court to the quick action of a cab driver who, after being robbed of $14 by an armed passenger, swerved his car into the path of a police radio patrol car to get assistance.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 28 -- A three-sided contest for the $50,000 estate of Ira L. Hill, 72years old, New York society photographer fatally injured in an automobile accident last Nov. 25, brought a decision today. Westchester Surrogate Charles H. Griffiths rejected two earlier wills and admitted to probate a testament executed a month before the fatal mishap.

Gus Lesnevich, who is to meet Tami Mauriello in the feature tenround bout for the Damon Runyon Memorial Cancer Fund at Ebbets Field tomorrow night, completed his training- yesterday at Cliffside Park, N.J. After sparring three rounds, Lesnevich said he would scale under 180 pounds for the fight.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- National attention will be focused Thursday night on the speech Senator Robert A. Taft will make in Columbus, Ohio, at a dinner of Republican leaders. It is expected that the gathering will endorse him as its candidate for the Presidency.

DEAL, N.J., July 28 -- Mrs. Sophie Untermeyer of Hollywood, defending champion, today assuined a two-stroke lead over a field of sixty-three at the end of the first day's play in the annual Jersey 54-hole medal-play tournament.

PARIS, July 28 -- As the committees of the European conference studied European resources under the Marshall plan, it became known today that France would reap this year the smallest wheat crop since 1815.

PITTSBURGH, July 28 -- The seven-year-old United Clerical, Technical and Supervisory Employes of the Mining Industry, affiliated with District 50 of the United Mine Workers of America, will end its turbulent career Thursday.

County Judge Thomas Downs of Queens will charge the June Grand Jury, when it reconvenes in Jamaica today, on its rights and duties in its investigation into charges that policemen have been levying tribute on Queens bookmakers.

ROME, July 28 -- In a letter addressed to Charles Flory, president of the Semaines Sociales de France, Pope Pius called attention to the danger existing in many countries that the state may become dominated by organized labor.

DETROIT, July 28 (AP) -- The national Ford council of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, tonight recommended that the union's executive board grant strike authority in connection with the contract negotiations with the Ford Motor Company.

BERLIN, July 28 -- The French were reported today to have indicated that they were ready to accept an upwardly revised industrial level for Germany if some current laws prohibiting certain industries were strengthened.

Popular interest in today's primaries centers chiefly on Representative Marcantonio's effort to test the effectiveness of the new Wilson-Pakula Law to prevent the raiding of one party primary by members of another party. Ten Democratic and three Republican contests are at issue, but the hottest fights for leadership will be in those Assembly Districts tying wholly or partly in Mr. Marcantonio's Eighteenth Congressional District.

Surveys of opportunities for foreign factories in Western Europe, to be built by American capital, reveal that a number of important safeguards for business should be approved by European governments before a large-scale plant construction program can be started by American companies, industrial spokesmen revealed here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The State Department still expects conversations to begin here late this week between British and American experts on methods for increasing the Ruhr's coal production, it was said today.

The City Council will meet in special session today at noon to receive three bills to give greater protection to tenants, particularly against the threat of evictions. Announcement of the meeting was made yesterday by Joseph T. Sharkey, vice chairman and majority leader, who sponsored the recently enacted hotel rent control legislation.

SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain, July 28 -- A strong anti-American and anti-British movement has developed among the non-Communist Left in Spain as a result of recent events. They charged the AngloSaxon powers in particular and the United Nations in general with defrauding them by talking loudly against Generalissimo Francisco Franco's regime while quietly trading with him to the mutual profit of General Franco and the United Nations concerned.

BATAVIA, July 28 (AP) -- An Indonesian Republican Army communique : East Java: July 26 -- Singasari was recaptured. One Dutch company moved toward the Suchi area. Two sections moved toward Semampir, west of Surabaya.

The triple tie for first place in the European zonal chess championship preliminaries was broken in the eleventh round yesterday. Dr. Petar Trifunovic of Yugoslavia sustained his first defeat, according to a report from Hilversum in The Netherlands.

Bishop William T. Manning repeated yesterday his criticism of the Bishops of the Protestant Episcopal diocese of Lexington, Ky., and Michigan for approving the marriages of two clergymen to divorced women. He declared that a clergyman who was married to a divorced woman had ended his usefulness to the church.
Mayor O'Dwyer said he was still undecided yesterday about proposals to increase the transit fare as the Board of Estimate moved into its final week of discussion without a clear plan in mind.

ATHENS, July 28 (U.P.) -- The Greek Minister of Public Order. Gen. Napoleon Zervas, stormed from a Cabinet meeting tonight after pointed discussion of his right to criticize the manner in which Greek troops were fighting guerrillas.

BAILEY ISLAND. Me., July 28 -- The local weatherman proved just about as cooperative as the Casco Bay tuna this morning, for the strong south wind that swept across the bay sent the Coast Guard boat scurrying back to Mackerel Cove with a recommendation that the contest be canceled out for the day and be continued tomorrow.
The Bankers Securities Corporation for the first six months showed net assets of $49,758,695, compared with $49,500,465 on Dec. 31, last year.

Coming back from a shaky start, Vie Raschi did very well in his introduction to the Tigers last night at the stadium. The youth, only recently recalled from Portland to bolster a sagging pitching staff, thrilled 64,887 fans with a six-hit pitching exhibition which overwhelmed the Tigers, 5 to 1, and gave the Yanks another triumph, their fourth, over the redoubtable Hal Newhouser.

CHICAGO, July 28 -- Grain markets closed sharply lower on the Board of Trade today after fluctuating in a very nervous manner throughout the session. An early break was followed by a strong rally but the latter failed to put wheat and oats above the previous close, and late in the session a return of selling pressure sent prices to a new low for the day.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- An effort is being made by writers and others who were dipleased with the record of the Eightieth Congress to represent that body as having welcomed to Washington the largest and most active lobbies for special interests seen here in years and having been unduly responsive to these lobbies.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The Republican-controlled House of Representatives demanded tonight, through its majority leader, Charles A. Halleck, that it be recognized by the executive branch of the Government as "a full-fledged partner" in the conduct of foreign affairs from now on.

CHICAGO, July 28 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 8,000 head, total 10,000: fairly active: 50 to 75 cents higher on weights under 300 pounds: butchers over 300 pounds and sows uneven but generally 75 cents to $1 higher:

The need for a "Marshall-Plan" for the children of Europe was stressed yesterday in a cable received at the headquarters of the Foster Parents Plan for War Children, Inc., 55 West Forty-second Street, from Mrs. Edna Blue, international chairman of the organization.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 28 -- Millions of Europeans live in hunger and misery because their governments do not cooperate, Continentally, in economic reconstruction, Dr. Karl Gunnar Myrdal, executive secretary of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe, reported here today.

Two busloads of foreign delegates to the thirty-fifth anniversary Girl Scout international encampment started their two days of intensive sightseeing here yesterday by visiting the United Nations at Lake Success, L. I.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The World Bank is expected to grant its second loan within the next few weeks -- a credit of $150,000,000 to $200,000,000 for the Netherlands.

NEW DELHI, India, July 28 (Reuters) -- The executive of the Government of the Dominion of India will be selected on the "British model," India's Constituent Assembly decided today. This means that the President of the Dominion will appoint a Prime Minister who will be the leader of the majority party and, with the Prime Minister, will also name a Council of Ministers.

LOS ANGELES, July 28 -- Howard Hughes acknowledged today that he had, on behalf of his airplane company, entertained Army officers "to keep our competitive position," but he denied that this had been connected with the flying boat he had been building for the Government.

New issues of preferred stock and bonds of Public Service Company of Colorado and the Mississippi Power Company, having an aggregate principal value of $20,000,000, were awarded at competitive sale yesterday to a banking syndicate here Kentucky Utilities Company, meanwhile, announced that it has entered into negotiations with First Boston Corporation, Lehman Brothers and Lazard Freres Co., jointly, for the underwriting of $13,000,000 of preferred stock to be offered first to stockholders.

LONDON, July 28--A large part of the gold reserves of about $600,000,000 held by Britain will be used as a "stop-gap" source of funds to bridge the time between the expiration of Britain's present dollar loan and the operation of the Marshall plan, it was learned today.
PHILADELPHIA, July. 28 (AP) -- There's nothing new in the Williams' shift, Babe Ruth said today "They used it on me years ago."

When Congress put on its collective hat and went home Sunday morning it left on its legislative hook three important pieces of military business. When it reconvenes in January or sooner all three should be near the top of the list for quick Congressional action.

The S.K.F. Industries, Inc., announced yesterday a new national price policy, effective immediately, in which a ninety-day price protection clause against future increases was assured in sales for industrial applications. Other manufacturers indicated their endorsement of this policy both through statements to S.K.F. Industries, Inc., and through individual statements.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Gerald L.K. Smith announced today that the name of his America First party would be changed next week to Christian Nationalist party.

BOSTON, July 29 (AP) -- In his 107th jaunt to the starting gate, Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs' 6-year-old Stymie will be an odds-on-favorite to become the first $700,000 winner in turf history tomorrow in the $50,000 added Massachusetts Handicap at Suffolk Downs.

PHILADELPHIA, July 29 -- Revere Racing Association, Inc., of Boston, Mass., and General Portland Cement Company of Chicago filed registration statements today with, the Securities and Exchange Commission.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., July 29 -- Mrs. Edwin Longcope of Siwanoy took a one-stroke advantage today by adding an 83 to her first-round 81 for 164 in the Fairfield and Westchester Counties championship at the Quaker Ridge Golf Club.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The introduction in the closing days of Congress of a bill representing the views of the House Public Lands Committee on an organic act for Guam represents the high water-mark of American interest in the island over which the American flag has flown for the last fifty years.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Proposed increases in the statutory minimum wage would cause a considerable number of workers in the lower brackets to lose their jobs, a committee of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States concluded in a report today.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange turned reactionary yesterday and closed 62 to 67 points net lower than Monday's final levels.

BERLIN, July 29 -- The western powers have taken a strong stand in protest against the steady stream of abuse emanating from Germans in the Russian zone against the occupation policies of the western zones, It became known today.

Faced with vast needs for new building at a time when construction costs are not only high but often unpredictable, Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday that he was about to call together leaders of the construction industry to achieve stabilization of costs.

As the Board of Estimate devoted another executive session at Gracie Mansion to the higher fare proposal yesterday, the plan to charge 5 cents at rush hours and 10 cents at other times came under fire from the Citizens Budget Commission and Councilman Stanley M. Isaacs, Manhattan Republican.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 29 -- Three of Westchester County's principal banks, with capital funds of more than $7,750,000 and total resources in excess of $120,000,000, merged today as the County Trust Company, with eighteen offices in thirteen Westchester communities and principal offices at 169 Main Street, White Plains.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 29 -- With Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet delegate, abstainin in each case, following are the individual votes on eleven major parts of the United States resolution: Preamble, containing enacting clause and a finding that a dispute exists that is likely to endanger the maintenance of peace and security -- approved 10 to 0.

BOSTON, July 29 (AP) -- Defeated, 5 -- 1, by Bob Feller and the Indians, the Red Sox today dropped 10 1/2 games behind the American League's leading Yankees, who were idle. The result snapped a seven-game Boston winning streak.

Buyers' Arrivals Show Drop Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,091 compared with 1,190 last week and 963 in the corresponding week of 1946, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

MEXICO CITY, July 29 -- Mexico's reply to Argentina's recent note outlining a "doctrine of internal and external peace" was generally interpreted today as a polite rejection in favor of stronger support for United Nations and Pan American Union action.

TOKYO, July 29 -- Japan's new Supreme Court, which under the new Constitution will sit as the highest judicial authority of the country, is expected to be named early next month by the government of Premier Tetsu Katayama, it became known today.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Quickly following up their demand for "full-fledged partnership" in the conduct of foreign affairs, Republican leaders of the House of Representatives today selected the personnel of the nineteen-member group that will investigate conditions in Europe.
Staten Island commuters, threatened with a stoppage of rail transportation next Monday, received encouraging news from two directions yesterday.
Speedy police action led yesterday to the arrest of two Congress of Industrial Organizations seamen as suspects in a sneak assault on a non-striking teller employed by the Brooklyn Trust Company.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The Air Force will celebrate its fortieth anniversary as well as its new status as an independent military department on Friday with flying demonstrations in every part of the country and in Germany and Japan.

HARRISONBURG, Va., July 29 (AP) -- At least ten persons were killed today when an explosion demolished a beauty shop and blew away a portion of an adjoining jewelry store in the business section of this Shenandoah Valley town.

LONDON, July 29 (AP) -- Stockholders of the Oceanic Steam Navigation Realization Company voted today to sell 1,274,216 ordinary shares of Cunard White Star, Ltd., to the Cunard Steamship Company at L2 a share.

NASHUA, N.H., July 29 -- A new plan, calling for sharp curtailment of operations at Nashua Manufacturing Company with a consequent reduction in employment, was disclosed today to supervisory employes and a selected group of Nashua citizens by Royal Little, president.

LONDON, July 29 -- Evidence was completed today in the Admiralty Court salvage claims action against owners of the United States Lines cargo ship American Farmer, which was abandoned after a collision in the Atlantic last July.

Bonds Across the Sea The weakness in London's giltedge market has been communicated to the traffic in British investments carried on internationally with blocked sterling balances obtainable officially at heavy discounts from the official $4.03 rate of exchange.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., July 29 -- After one of the most turbulent stockholders' meetings in many years, the management group of the Hudson Manhattan Railroad Company today claimed an election victory after seveteen hours of bitter wrangling with the opposition. The new board went into office on 212,703 votes, as against 79,636 cast for the Carleton-ComptonDay group's ten unsuccessful candidates for directorships.

American vegetarians will be represented in the 1948 Presidential election by Dr. John Maxwell, a naturopathic doctor from Chicago, who was chosen as the Vegetarian party candidate for President at a meeting here last night.

RICHARD PHENIX started for home by driving rapidly in the opposite direction. He had just wound up five years in the Army, with service in Puerto Rico, England and France (mainly among the paragraph troopers), beginning as a buck private and ending with a captain's bars, and he wanted to see something of America and think over what he might do with the rest of his time on this planet.

The Joint Distribution Committee and the Union of Orthodox Rabbis of the United States and Canada jointly announced yesterday that an agreement had been reached to integrate their programs devoted to the rehabilitation and advancement of Orthodox Jewish life in Europe.

WARSAW, July 29 -- The welldisciplined and pre-censored Polish press is continuing to demonstrate its love for the Soviet Union by vilifying the United States. Its thesis is the familiar Moscow line that the Americans are the imperialists who are trying to dominate the Poles and that the Russians are their benevolent good neighbors.

OWOSSO, Mich., July 29 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York canvassed the political situation in Michigan, and the nation, at a three-hour closed conference with the state's Republican leaders here this afternoon. While Mr. Dewey's availability for the Presidential nomination was carefully avoided, it was agreed that the prospects are bright for a Republican victory next year.

Virtually all engineering and other problems have been solved in the development of Westinghouse Electric Corporation's first television set and initial units will be in dealers' stocks about Nov. 1, Edgar G. Hermann, home radio sales manager, disclosed yesterday.

It begins to look as though we might have to wait another eleven months -- until the end of the fiscal year 1947-48 -- before we can close the books on the controversy over the much-discussed Republican "economy program."
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- President Truman's Air Policy Commission of five members was formally organized today with its members uncertain as to their relation to a similar Congressional group.

The second annual "dream game" between the Negro National and American Leagues' all-stars attracted 38,402 fans to the Polo Grounds last night. The largest crowd ever to have witnessed a Negro contest in the East saw the American Leaguers score an 8-2 victory and even the series.

LONDON, July 29 -- The rejection of the Lords' amendments to the Government's transport nationalization bill by the House of Commons approximates singlechamber government in a veiled form, the Marquess of Salisbury said today.
LINCOLN, Neb., July 29 -- The Methodist Church opened today its First National Rural Life Conference in a continuing effort to raise the level of life in rural areas.

WASHINGTON, July 29--Henry J. Kaiser asserted today that "a very beautiful frame-up" blocked his wartime effort to build a vast fleet of 200-ton cargo-carrying planes with which to overcome the German submarine menace.

Two underwriting syndicates here shared the award yesterday of issues of $20,000,000 of bonds and debentures of the Florida Power and Light Company as two other syndicates prepared for public offering an aggregate of $12,280,000 of preferred stock and bonds of Public Service Company of Colorado and the Mississippi Power Company.

ALBANY, July 29 -- The adjutant general released the following orders today: NYNG Officers Assigned Lt. Col. H. O'Connor to 42d Qm. Co. to Hq. as Div. Qm. Maj. J.G. Firsching to 165th Inf. to Hq. 2d Bn. as Ex O. 1st Lt. R.A. Olden to 165th Inf. to Med. Det. as Med. Asst.

RUMSON, N.J., July 29 -- Mrs. Sophie Untermeyer of Hollywood boosted her lead to four strokes today in the second round of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's annual fifty-four-hole medal play shore tournament. She carded an 80 over the Rumson Country Club course for a two-day gross total of 155.
The opening of Floyd Bennett Field for commercial aviation, tentatively set for Friday, will be deferred at least two weeks, it was indicated yesterday.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 30 -- With most of the ballots tabulated, it appeared certain early today that City Judge Thomas N. Fasso had triumphed for a second time over the regular Republican organization here in winning renomination in one of the major contests in the Westchester County primary election held yesterday.

BERLIN, July 29 -- An unfortunate "lack of coordination" between the State Department in Washington and United States occupation authorities in Germany has pointed up a situation that may hasten the time when the State Department takes over the job here, it was indicated today.

Sales in the second half of this year will be higher than in the corresponding period of 1946, according to slightly more than 50 per cent of companies surveyed by the National Industrial Conference Board on the general outlook for business, the board announced yesterday.

A regional hospital plan in which the New York University College of Medicine will cooperate with at least six rural and suburban hospitals to aid young staff physicians in post-collegiate academic training was outlined yesterday by Dr. Clarence E. de la Chapelle, associate dean of the college and director of its post-graduate division.

Another wave of selling struck the stock market yesterday and, before some steadiness appeared near the close, prices were set back 1 to 4 points, with the average lowered 1.88 points. This second successive day of pressure returned the list to the lowest levels in about three weeks and produced the widest losses in two months.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 29 -- Six Catholic priests, found guilty of sabotaging a factory, were sentenced by a Zagreb court today. Two of them were sentenced to death; the others received long prison terms.

HONOLULU, July 29 -- In one of his rare statements on international affairs Gov. Earl Warren of California yesterday called for full preparedness by the United States against aggression as a way of giving maximum strength to the United Nations.

The largest group of vacationists to return to this country from Europe on a Swedish-American liner since before the war arrived yesterday on the Gripsholm. Of the ship's total list of 1,364 passengers, 1,021 had gone abroad as tourists or to visit relatives.

DETROIT, July 29 -- The United Automobile Workers, CIO, sent a call today to its twenty-two member executive board to meet here Saturday to pass on a request for sanction of a strike against the Ford Motor Company.
CINCINNATI, July 29 -- By way of demonstrating their versatility, the Giants scored two runs tonight, one on a circuit blow, the other on a squeeze bunt. The pair proved all Larry Jansen needed.

LONDON, July 29 -- Concentrating on day clothes suitable for lunch at smart restaurants or race meetings, the Digby Morton autumn collection, demonstrated today that interesting results could be obtained by mixing tweed fabric designs with a basic color theme.

Someone has finally come along with an idea to aid the long-suffering standees on the Long Island Rail Road's crowded commuter trains, an anonymous correspondent informed THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday, but whether the plan will work is still to be judged.

BAILEY ISLAND, Me., July 29 -- Late this afternoon Maurice Meyers of Brielle, N.J., fishing aboard his cruiser Poseidon, hooked a large tuna, and took the lead in the Maine Tuna Tournament. His fish scaled 724 pounds, seventy-one pounds heavier than the largest fish taken during the first two days.

Youngsters 4 and 5 years old at the James Playground of the Children's Aid Society, 154 Hester Street, beat adult New Yorkers to the polls yesterday. While grownups still were voting in the primaries, the citizens of "Tot's Town" completed the serious business of electing a mayor and a full staff of commissioners.

The motor vessel New York, an LST reconverted by the Sun Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company of Chester, Pa., and owned by Trailerships, Inc., arrived yesterday morning at Pier 80, North River, from Chester.

LENOX, Mass., July 29--The Boston Symphony Orchestra, with a generous assist from RCA-Victor, held an event this afternoon and evening at Tanglewood which was variously called a "Field Day," "Music for All," "New Horizons in Music" and "The March of Musical Fidelity."

Philippine sugar exports will be resumed before the end of the year and the islands plan to ship 250,000 tons in 1948, according to J. Bartlett Richards, United States Commercial Attache at Manila. Shipments up to now have not been possible owing to a yield of less than 100,000 tons, which hardly cover domestic requirements, he said.
A 50 per cent stock dividend was declared by the directors of Hajoca Corporation, industrial and marine supplies, at a meeting yesterday in Philadelphia, Pa. The dividend is payable on Dec. 1, 1947.

Employes now have five authentic sources of information on their rights and privileges under the Taft-Hartley Act, more than 700 industrial executives were told yesterday during initial sessions of a two-day seminar on industrial relations problems.

CHICAGO, July 29 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 9,000 head, total 12,500: market rather slow, generally 25 to 50 cents lower on all weights and sows; practical top, $28.50; around one load considered out of line.

Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora dismissed yesterday a $500,000 libel suit brought by Eugene Nelson Sanctuary, a retired Army colonel, against Mrs, Dorothy S. Thackrey, owner and publisher of The New York Post, and T.O. Thackrey, editor and general manager of the paper.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, July 29., (AP) -- Danish Premier Knud Kristensen, addressing the opening session of the seventh Congress of the Baptist World Alliance today, said the mutual confidence among nations necessary for world peace had not yet been established.

Chief Signalman Harold E. Hirshberg received a letter of recommendation from a Japanese prison camp commander in the Philippines, according to testimony yesterday before a Navy general court martial at the New York Naval Shipyard, Brooklyn.

Second in a series of TIMEStested recipe leaflets to be prepared by this department is "Twelve Quick Heat Dishes," It is designed in the same format as our first pamphlet "Twelve Frozen Desserts," issued the middle of this month.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 29 -- On a day crowded with interesting matches between the best young players of the nation, James Brink of Seattle and Richard (Pancho) Gonzales of Los Angeles went down in defeat at the Meadow Club today. Edward Moylan, Sidney Wood and Gardner Larned had narrow escapes.

Ludek Pachman of Czechoslovakia, by defeating Laszlo Szabo of Hungary in the twelfth and semi-final round, tied with Alberic O'Kelly de Galway of Belgium in the European zonal chess championship preliminaries yesterday, according to a report from Hilversum in the Netherlands.

The Queens County June Grand Jury went ahead with its investigation into alleged police protection of bookmakers yesterday after County Judge Thomas Downs had praised the prosecutor and charged the jury on its rights and duties.

Tomatoes costing New York housewives 19 and 20 cents a pound at retail yesterday were bringing some farmers in southern New Jersey 40 and 50 cents for an eighteenpound basket, or less than 3 cents a pound, a survey showed. On the Vineland tract in Atlantic County scores of farmers were reported to be plowing under acres of cucumbers, tomatoes, squash and carrots.

In what was believed to be the first such action under the TaftHartley labor law, a thirty-day strike notice was filed "under protest" yesterday by Local 66 of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, AFL.

A motorist's explanation that he was in severe pain and seeking medical aid when he drove his car through four red lights on July 19 was rejected by Magistrate Henri Schwob in Uptown Traffic Court yesterday. The court imposed a fine of $25 on Merwin Lasner, 40 years old, of 25 Central Park West, a knit goods manufacturer; suspended his driving license and referred the case to the State Motor Vehicle Bureau for investigation.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 29 -- A United States resolution for the establishment of a semi-permanent frontier commission in the Balkans was vetoed today by Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet representative in the United Nations Security Council.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- Manufacturers' deliveries to wholesalers and retailers declined slightly during May for the third successive month, the Commerce Department reported, today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 29 -- The United Nations, which already is weighed down with financial burdens, will have to take on a 25 to 50 per cent heavier load of expenses next year, Byron Price, Assistant Secretary General for Administrative and Budgetary Affairs, predicted today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In a recent issue of THE TIMES John J. Lamula, the legislative representative of the Joint Rent Action Committee, contended that the New York State rent control law would become effective upon the discontinuance of federal controls in New York, even though federal rent controls remained in force elsewhere in the United States.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- John J. McCloy, president of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, said today that the bank was considering a loan to the Netherlands "entirely on an economic basis," with the warfare between Dutch troops "and Indonesians likely to have no direct bearing on the decision.

The idea persists in Europe that the United States is being "forced" into adoption of the Marshall Plan by the sheer necessity of saving its own export trade. M. Pierre Cot expounded this theory to the French Assembly a day or two ago, and there has been enough similar comment elsewhere to suggest that this opinion, so convenient to its holders, is rather widely shared.

SECURITY COUNCIL Russia vetoed United States proposal for semi-permanent Balkan investigating commission. Committee on Admission of New Members -- Meets today at 10:30 A.M. (Open). Committee 2, Atomic Energy Commission -- Coordinating Group A-G held closed meeting in Empire State Building.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In "Topics of The Times" of July 9 you discuss a study on the extent of disability, prepared by the Research Council for Economic Security. You state that out of 300 million weeks lost each year through sickness or injury the nation's 28 million housewives lose 72 million weeks.

PARIS, July 29 -- The Government has informed Washington and London that it would be willing to consider a higher level for the German steel industry if the Allies agreed to its proposal for the international ownership and management of the Ruhr's coal mines and steel mills, it was learned today.

How Firm a Foundation Building in New York used to mean for the sidewalk superintendent great holes in the ground, uncovering hitherto unexplored depths of Manhattan's firm foundations-because the newer and taller the steel structure that was to stand in the hole the deeper it had to be planted.

The United States Steel Corporation realized a net profit of $29,336,868, equal to $2.65 a common share, in the quarter ended on June 30, Irving S. Olds, chairman, reported yesterday. The earnings compare with $39,234,511, or $3.78 a share, in the first quarter, and with $13,900,270, or 87 cents a share, in the second quarter of 1946.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., July 29 -- Mrs. Elizabeth Ingalls, 62-year-old wife of a Boston lawyer, who was convicted by a Federal jury of keeping a Negro maid in thirtyyear bondage, today received a suspended three-year prison sentence, but was ordered to pay the maid $6,000 damages.

Louis Schleifer, real estate operator, has purchased the New York Post Building at 75 West Street from Dorothy S. Thackrey, president and publisher of The New York Post, it was announced yesterday. The newspaper, which occupies the basement and first three floors of the sixteen-story and penthouse structure, leased back this space for twenty years, with a tea-year renewal option, at a rental of $120,000 a year.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 29 (AP) -- Rapid progress in the fight against cancer was predicted today by Dr. Cornelius P. Rhoads of New York City's Memorial Hospital.

Refinancing of the two six-story apartment buildings at 655 and 665 Burke Avenue, the Bronx, has been completed by the SonnenblickGoldman Company through the placing of two mortgage loans totaling $264,000. The brokers report that as a result of this financing the certificate holders will receive full dollar payment for their certificates.

The Algonquins had a name for the hemlock. They called it "Oh-neh-tah" -- Green-on-the-stick. The hemlock does not have the self-contained dignity of the white pine; it does not pretend to match the crisp, sturdy beauty of the resinous spruce. Nor does it offer the fragile loveliness of the wispy firs.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Republican politicians still, in Washington after the adjournment of Congress reveal no doubt that Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York will be among those members of their party who will follow the counsel of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio today that "before Congress meets again" Republican leaders should "freely discuss * * * the issues before the country, including the Marshall plan."

CHICAGO, July 29 (AP) -- Held to two singles for six innings, the Cubs broke loose with a five-run seventh today to overcome the Phillies, 5 to 4, and run their successes to 13 out of 14 against their Philadelphia "cousins."

GENEVA, July 29 -- In a secret session tomorrow the United Nations Special Commission on Palestine will hear a statement from a representative of the International Refugee Organization on the attitude of displaced persons toward Palestine.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 29 -- Manifestations of differences between Mary Pickford and Charles Chaplin over the management and possible reorganization of the United Artists Distributing Company, of which they are equal owners, appeared today in a deadlock over the services of Joseph M. Schenck as arbitrator and reorganizer.

Top-notch craftsmen in the musical field, Alan Jay Lerner and Kurt Weill are thinking of pooling their talents in the creation of a new song-and-dance show, it became known yesterday. Mr. Lerner did the book and lyrics of the successful "Brigadoon" for Cheryl Crawford, while Mr. Weill, composermember of the Playwrights Company, is remembered for his tunes in such musicals as "Knickerbocker Holiday," "Lady in the Dark" and "Street Scene."

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 29 -- Nothing is more important in "the crusade for a christian world" than increasing unity among christian churches, the Rev. Dr. Hampton Adams of St. Louis, president of the International Convention of the Disciples of Christ said here tonight.

Not so sweet, it seems, are the uses of publicity. As thus far revealed by the Senate committee investigating wartime government contract awards of $18,000,000 for airplane cargo carriers, these uses consist chiefly of butteringup public personages who might prove useful, smearing all drawn into the press agent's vortex, and loud proclamations of noble motives on and off the record.

WASHINGTON, July 29--President Truman returned to the White House today after an absence dating from last Saturday, when he flew to Grandview, Mo., in his futile effort to reach the bedside of his mother, Mrs. Martha E. Truman, before she died.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 29 -- Eight helium-filled balloons soared up from here today on a flight to extend man's knowledge of how cosmic rays may be expected to behave at various temperatures, and at altitudes up to 100,000 feet.

PORT DE BOUC, France, July 29 -- Jewish refugees turned back from Palestine and re-shipped to France refused to land today when the British vessels in which they were returned were brought to anchor under British military guard off this Mediterranean port.

LEEDS, England, July 29 (Reuters) -- England today won the first post-war test cricket series with South Africa by defeating the visitors by 10 wickets in the fourth game. England has won three games, against no defeat, the first match having been drawn. One match remains to be played.

Planning for a 4-year-old belle a room that would be equally appropriate ten years hence calls for ingenuity of the first order. One mother who was determined to achieve this feat took her cue from ceramic tile.

GENEVA, Switzerland, July 29 -- The amendment of the International Trade Charter to permit the establishment of preferential trade arrangements preliminary to the formation of customs unions has now been agreed on by all countries represented at the Geneva trade conference.
Three bills that would put apartments and other rented dwellings in this city under much stricter controls than those of the Federal rent law were introduced yesterday in the City Council.

The rate of hospitalization for veterans suffering from mental disorders is lower after World War II than after World War I, Dr. Nils B. Hersloff, chief of the neuropsychiatric division of Branch Office 2 of the Veterans Administration, declared yesterday.

The advertising budget of Garod Radio Corporation has been set tentatively at $500,000 for the current year, Joseeph G. DeVico, advertising manager, reported yesterday. Copy henceforth will feature increasingly the new television unit and radio models of the company and more insertions in national magazines will be made.
Trainer George C. Winfrey, who has been around the race tracks for many a long year, had a perfect afternoon yesterday at Jamaica. Both horses that he saddled made good in sprints.

NANKING, July 29 (AP) -- Representatives of the Democratic League told Lieut. Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer today that the Chinese people bitterly opposed any foreign assistance that would prolong the civil war "whether it comes from the United States or the Soviet."
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, July 29 -- Official sources revealed today that the Dutch Government now intended to ask the British Government to mediate in the Indonesian conflict.
SACRAMENTO, July 29 -- Gov. Earl Warren of California and former Gov. Harold Stassen of Minnesota talked things over here today.

PHILADELPHIA, July 29 (AP) -- The Athletics bunched five hits for five runs in the fourth inning tonight to defeat the White Sox, 5 -- 2, behind the five-hit pitching of Phil Marchildon who gained his twelfth victory of the season before 15,305 fans.
