Gus Lesnevich of Cliffside Park, N.J., world light-heavyweight champion, and Tami Mauriello, subject of one of Joe Louis' knockouts last year, meet in a ten-round bout for the Damon Runyon Memorial Cancer Fund tonight at Ebbets Field.

After a sudden appearance yesterday before the hold-over grand jury investigating the election day slaying of Joseph R. Scottoriggio, David T. Lehmann, 63-year-old father of Mrs. Doris Coppola, was held as a material witness in $15,000 bail by Judge John J. Sullivan of the Court of General Sessions.

JERUSALEM, July 29--All Palestine waited anxiously today for word of the fate of two British sergeants held as hostages for the three terrorists who had been hanged at dawn at the Acre prison and buried at Safad.

LONDON, July 29 -- Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery, Chief of the Imperial General Staff, has cut short his Far Eastern tour and is returning here immediately to discuss with the Government drastic cuts in Britain's armed forces to provide more skilled manpower for British factories, it was authoritatively learned today.

James V. Auditore, the one-time millionaire stevedore, gave Judge Jacob Gould Schurman Jr. and a jury in General Sessions yesterday an account of the shipping business as he learned it from his start as a youth so poor he wore canvas underwear.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Some weeks ago you published an Associated Press dispatch from Moscow reporting a statement made by the leading Russian magazine, "Bolshevik" to the effect that the United States was heading for a record-breaking depression.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- J. Monroe Johnson, Director of the Office of Defense Transportation; announced today that an agreement had been reached with the management of the Toledo, Peoria Western Railroad, a 239-mile conecting link in Illinois between eastern and western mainline railroads, involving a settlement for $6,252,865 for the period of wartime Government operation of the road.

Harper has scheduled for Oct. 29 publication "The Journals of Francis Parkman," edited by Mason Wade. The newly discovered papers present the material upon which his formal work was based, particularly his famous "The Oregon Trail."

Two candidates for Tammany Assembly district leaderships backed by Representative Vito Marcantonio, New York County chairman of the American Labor party, suffered defeat in yesterday's primary election, thereby lessening his chance of getting the Democratic nomination for re-election next year.

An employer's right to free speech in the expression of his views on pending labor union elections was restricted yesterday by the United States Circuit Court of Appeals when such expressions are "coercive."

Despite limitations on production imposed by continuing shortages of materials, principally steel, the General Motors Corporation showed marked improvement in sales and earnings during the second quarter of 1947, Alfred P. Sloan, Jr., chairman, and C.E. Wilson, president, reported yesterday to stockholders.

While no date for resumption of the Ryder Cup matches between teams of the United States and Great Britain has yet been been announced, the United States Professional Golfers Association yesterday released a point system by which players will be selected, The Associated Press announced.

ALBANY, July 29--Supreme Court Justice Isadore Bookstein today denied an application for an Injunction to prevent the state from allocating funds to a Jesuit college, thus virtually killing an attempt to challenge the constitutionality of state aid to sectarian institutions.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that the general level of prices received by farmers increased 2 per cent between midJune and mid-July. Prices for most farm products increased. Fruits and truck crops were exceptions.

PITTSBURGH, July 29 (AP) -- A four-run outburst in the third inning which chased Bill Voiselle from the mound helped the Pirates beat the Braves, 6 to 5, tonight. Pittsburgh's third-sacker, Frankie Gustine, collected four singles to run his consecutive hitting streak to twenty-one games.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Some of the students and manuscript hawks here agree that one certain paper, in the handwriting of Abraham Lincoln, stands higher than anything else recently unfolded.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- Admiral H. P. Blandy, the Navy's top expert on atomic bombs, sat in today at a secret Army and Navy conference, leading to unofficial speculation that he might direct some new A-bomb tests.
CHICAGO, July 29 -- General liquidation developed in the grain market on the Board of Trade today.

Price increases ranging between $5 and $10, a ton on principal steel products became general throughout the domestic steel industry yesterday as the United States Steel Corporation and the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's two largest producers, followed the pattern set last week by several smaller companies.
BATAVIA, Java, July 29 (AP) -- American-built Dutch fighter planes strafed Republican airfields on Java today, a Republican communique said.

BATAVIA, Java, July 29 (AP) -- The Indonesian Republican radio at Jogjakarta announced tonight that nine persons, including three British citizens, were killed when an Indian transport plane, bringing medical supplies to the Indonesians was shot down.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Yong Jeung Kim, president of the Korean Affairs Institute, which has headquarters here, warned today, on returning from six weeks in Korea, that "Communists will take the whole of Korea if the present state of incipient anarchy in South Korea is permitted to continue."

President Truman, who recently appointed a Civilian Air Policy Commission, now has on his desk a revamped version of the Brewster bin, which creates an Air Policy Board comprising five members of each House. The civilian commission is composed of men of excellent standing and may be expected to do an impartial, workmanlike job.

Representatives of local stations conferred yesterday with John F. Smithers, general manager of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, on the new state law relating to professional appearances on the air by children under 16.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- Sam Zoldak scored his third victory over Washington and his fourth of the season tonight as the Browns defeated the Senators, 8 to 2, before 21,252 fans.

The American passenger ship fleet is at its lowest point since the end of World War I and the Government has made no provision for revitalizing this important segment of the merchant marine, J. Lewis Luckenbach, president of the American Bureau of Shipping, declared yesterday.

GLASGOW, July 29 (AP) -- Robert B. Meyer of Locust Valley, N.Y., recaptured the Seawanhaka Cup for the United States today, when he piloted his six-meter yacht Djinn to a third-straight triumph over the British defender Johan.

ST. LOUIS, July 29 -- The Dodger winning streak was entrusted to handsome Harry Taylor, 28-year-old right-hander, in the opener with the Cardinals under the lights tonight and Manager Burt Shotton's trust wasn't misplaced.

IT'S been a long time since Southampton last had sight of John Kramer. Big Jake, the world's top amateur tennis player, is due to step out on the turf of the Meadow Club tomorrow, and even if it's only in doubles, his presence is a warranty that the biggest galleries they've known at the eastern end of Long Island since pre-war days will turn out.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, July 29--The Communist-dominated Government dissolved the Peasant party today on the ground that it had conspired with foreign imperialistic interests to...
LONDON, July 29 -- A fresh selling wave hit the stock markets here today despite the marking down of prices by dealers as a preventive measure in the early trading.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The State Department reduced its "Voice of America" foreign broadcast programs by 40 per cent today because of economies forced by Congress, but it added a halfhour program to the regular one of one hour to Russia.

CHICAGO, July 29 (AP) -- The Evangelical Lutheran Synod of Missouri, Ohio and other states renewed efforts today toward unity with the American Lutheran Church, then heard one of its minister educators assert that "the old Nazi idea is pretty well dead" in Germany.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 29 -- Georges Boris, French delegate to the United Nations Economic and Social Council, today appealed to the great powers to end their "distrust complex" and thus promote thorough European cooperation in the Marshall Plan.
RIO DE JANERIO, July 29 -- The Brazilian Congress will be called upon to pass on whether its Communist members should be deposed, now that the Communist party has been outlawed.

Fond farewells were said yesterday by foreign Girl Scout delegates who had been together since the thirty-fifth anniversary international encampment opened on June 29 at Camp Barree near Huntingdon, Pa. Today they call for their baggage and transportation home to their twenty-two respective countries at the organization's national headquarters at 155 East Forty-fourth Street.

KALAMAZOO, Mich., July 29 (AP) -- Top-seeded Herbert (Buddy Behrens of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., advanced to the fourth round of the national junior tennis championships today as unseeded players began cutting into the parade of favorites.

ROME, July 29 -- Speaking today in the Constituent Assembly on the ratification of the peace treaty, the Communist leader, Palmiro Togliatti, ascribed its harshness to Italy's "unilateral" foreign policy, which consistently supported the western democracies and showed indifference toward Russia.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- Maj. Gen. Butter B. Miltonberger, chief of the National Guard Bureau, said today that the National Guard ground forces air program was out of the planning stage and into actuality. Ground units of the National Guard soon will he receiving the first shipment of 780 light aircraft for use in artillery observation and liaison, he added.

Although there has been a rapid growth in the number of pension plans adopted for bank employes in the last five years, there is very little agreement among banks relative to the type of plan used for employe retirement, according to a study of such plans just completed by the Bankers Trust Company.

The United Seamen's Service, which has provided housing, food, recreation facilities, medical care and other assistance to American seamen since its creation in September, 1942, faces termination of its activities after Dec. 31 if direct financial support is not provided by the maritime industry, it was announced yesterday.

LEXINGTON, Ky., July 29 (AP) -- Spirited bidding for a pair of yearling colts offset to a degree today the slumping market as the usual "small" buyers found their chance to edge in on big spenders at the Keeneland Park auctions.
Residents of Waterbury, Conn., have "adopted" four towns in Europe, it was announced here yesterday by Aldro Jenks, head of that city's chapter of Common Cause, Inc.

NATHANYA, Palestine, July 30 -- For four hours this afternoon soldiers, police and newspaper men made a fruitless search in the Nathanya district for the two kidnapped British Army sergeants, whose deaths by hanging have been announced by the Irgun Zvai Leumi.
TREBNICA, Poland, July 30 -- The main road south from Posnan [Posen] to Wroclaw [Breslau] is straight and smooth and passes through a plain as level as the central stretches of Illinois.

CINCINNATI, July 30 -- Ewell Blackwell, baseball's standout pitcher of the year, had his spectacular winning streak snapped at sixteen games today, but the elongated right-hander of the Reds had at least one satisfaction to console him in his hour of defeat.
SECURITY COUNCIL Meets today at 3 P. M. to begin discussion on Indonesia at request of Australia and India and to resume consideration of the Balkan question. (Open).

HAVANA. July 30 -- Information from the Presidential Palace said today that the Cabinet had rejected a Communist petition to annul a Ministry of Labor ruling and give that party possession of the Labor Palace, from which it was evicted yesterday by the national police.

Freight rates in the country's big tramp shipping industry continued to slide down yesterday and more ships were reported idle in Atlantic ports as a result of lack of cargo or of rates below operating costs.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- Senator Brewster asserted in a broadcast tonight that "there is no truth in the suggestion" by Mr. Hughes. He added that the committee had replied to the statement by inviting Mr. Hughes to appear in person and make his charges under oath so "we can determine what this is all about."

JERUSALEM, July 30 -- Irgun Zvai Leumi announced today in a clandestine broadcast that it had executed two British Army sergeants, Marvyn Paice and Clifford Martin, held as hostages. It said they had been condemned to be hanged by a "field court" and that the sentence had been carried out.
All Air Force installations in the New York area, it was learned yesterday, will participate in the celebration of the Air Forces fortieth birthday tomorrow, its first as an independent military arm.

FLINT, Mich., July 30 -- Apparently satisfied that he is away out front in the race for the Republican Presidential nomination, Governor Thomas E. Dewey of New York ignored today a challenge from Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, regarded as his principal rival, to "speak out" on national issues.

Sister Elizabeth Kenny, widely known for her controversial system for treating poliomyelitis, declared on her arrival here yesterday aboard the Cunard White Star liner Queen Elizabeth that infantile paralysis research in Spain was far ahead of that in other countries including the United States.

BOSTON, July 30 (AP) -- Scoring six times in the opening inning and adding seven more runs in the sixth, the Indians tonight whipped the Red Sox, 13 -- 7. The defeat, second in two days administered by the Indians, dropped the secondplace Red Sox 11 1/2 games in back of the American League-leading Yankees, who beat the Tigers, 8 -- 5.
CAMDEN, N.J., July 30 (AP) -- Striking employes of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation today called off a planned mass picketing demonstration at the yard's main office building in Camden.

LONDON, July 30 (AP) -- Jackie Paterson of Glasgow, Scotland, was deprived of the world flyweight title he had held for four years today by concurrent action of the British Boxing Board of Control and the National Boxing Association of the United States.

In a move to cut down the accidents resulting from careless use of firearms brought back from abroad as souvenirs by returning service men, a group of Army, Navy and government officials met yesterday to form the New York State War Trophy Safety Committee.

Elmer Haslett, director of city airports, was found guilty yesterday of substantial misconduct in office and removed from his $8,350a-year job by Commissioner Frederick G. Reinicke of the Department of Marine and Aviation.

Patrolmen Joseph Gardner and James Slevin of the Seventy-first Precinct had just started out in their radio-car shortly after 6 A.M. yesterday whan an employe of the Sanitation Department hailed them at Fifth Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street.

VIENNA, July 30 -- Austria's Parliament took necessary legal measures today to complete the labor, peasant and commercial and industrial representatives' agreement, which will give the country a three-month "breathing spell."
Random notes: Both Martha's Vineyard and Cuttyhunk Island are now reported to be producing record catches of striped bass, both from boats and by surfcasting.

Edwin Franko Goldman devoted the first half of last night's Goldman Band Concert in Central Park to his organization's twenty-second annual memory contest. He played twenty anonymous excerpts, all from works the band has played this season.

One of our favorite bakeries Lichtman's, at 561 Amsterdam Avenue, at Eighty-seventh Street, is selling a new dessert called a peach parfait log that might cheer up any New Yorkers who must stay in this sweltering spot while their fortunate friends sniff a sea breeze.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Parts of the strategy by which Abraham Lincoln was nominated for President in 1860, and the wear and tear on the nerves of all concerned, is highlighted in a series of letters and telegrams now made known in a volume of the heritage gift of President Lincoln's son in the Library of Congress.

PHILADELPHIA, July 30 -- Stevedores began loading 1,000 tractors, purchased by the Argentine Government, aboard the Greek freighter Evros, here today. The cargo represents the largest single shipment of tractors ever to embark from an American port.

PITTSBURGH, July 30 (AP) -- Smashing out four home runs, the Braves bounced back to defeat the Pirates, 8 -- 5, in the second game of a twin bill today. The Pirates, aided by Billy Cox's eighth circuit clout of the season, took the opener, 5 -- 3.

An official War Department document and three supporting affidavits were barred yesterday from the record of the general court-martial of Chief Signalman Harold E.Hirshberg at the New York Naval Shipyard, Brooklyn.

WASINGTON, July 30 -- The United States has protested to the Soviet Government against removal by Russia of German and Italian assets in Hungary, Bulgaria and Rumania, the State Department announced today.

PARIS, July 30 -- A reduction of exchange controls to permit freer trade among European countries on a multilateral basis is regarded as the main, problem, along with that of production, facing the European economic conference. It is being discussed informally by experts of the principal countries, who expect to propose action against the monetary barriers to trade as part of the European program under the Marshall plan.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., July 30 -- Several members of the United Nations Security Council are considering a plan to strengthen the Balkan investigation commission's present subsidiary group with well-known delegates as a reply to the Soviet veto of a new commission, it was learned today.

Although Representative Vito Marcantonio, New York County Chairman of the American Labor party, suffered a defeat in Tuesday's primary election by the defeat of Marcantonio-backed candidates for Tammany district leaders and members of the Democratic County Committee in the Eighth and Tenth Assembly Districts; local politicians were reluctant yesterday to predict the defeat of Mr. Marcantonio for re-election next year.

Advertising as a part of the distribution process can help to develop markets for trade goods both in the United States and abroad, but advertising men face major problems in certain foreign countries, Sigurd S. Larson, president of Young Rubicam, warned yesterday on his return from Europe.

Approval of a "5 and 10 cent" fare on subway and elevated, lines by the Board of Estimate at a special meeting to be held today or tomorrow was forecast last night as its members left an executive meeting with Mayor O'Dwyer at Gracie Mansion. The nickel fare is slated for retention during rush hours, with the ten-cent fare in effect at all other times.

PHILADELPHIA, July 30 (AP) -- Frank Papish's four-hit pitching and Rudy York's eleventh home run of the season sparked the White Sox to a 3-2 victory over Jesse Flores and the Athletics tonight before 13,194 at Shibe Park.

LONDON, July 30 -- Charges he leveled at other members of the House of Commons boomeranged today against Garry Allighan, Labor Member from Gravesend, when he was found guilty by a House committee of "tipping" inside information in House proceedings to the press.
The United States Navy, faced with world-wide commitments and responsibilities, is all upset over the matter of a little green bowl.

From, time to time the suggestion is made that if federal tax reduction cannot be reconciled with a balanced budget, then the budget should be reconciled with tax reduction. In short, we are beginning to hear proposals again for setting up a "double budget." Under this plan operating expenditures of the Government would be listed in one budget; investment or non-recurring items, in another.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: We have read with interest in THE TIMES of July 27 the editorial "The Families of the Poor," which is about our recent population bulletin "Is American Intelligence Declining?" We are in agreement with practically everything you say in your editorial, but it seems there are a few points that should be clarified.

Leaders of building trades unions of the American Federation of Labor expressed yesterday full sympathy for Mayor O'Dwyer in his effort to stabilize construction costs in this city, but made it clear that they had no intention of abandoning demands for an increase of 10 per cent in building wages.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., July 30 -- Russia formally proposed today that the applications of Hungary, Italy, Rumania and Austria to join the United Nations be shelved until the peace treaties with those countries become operative.

LONDON, July 30--Prime Minister Atlee rallied the solid support of the Labor Members of Parliament today behind a new program of drastic cuts in dollar expenditures overseas and other stiff measures to meet the most urgent phase of Great Britain's economic crisis.

BATAVIA, Java, July 30 (AP)-A Netherland Army communique: West Java: A few attacks on Netherland posts were reported by armed Republican-groups or not easily definable gangs, among other places at Buitenzorg and Sumerang.

Prime Minister Mahmud Fahmy Nokrashy Pasha of Egypt, who is here to present his nation's case against Great Britain, said last night he was "completely confident" that the United Nations Security Council would direct the British to withdraw their troops from the Nile Valley.

CHICAGO, July 30 -- The first strike damage suit against a union brought in Federal District Court here under the Taft-Hartley LaborManagement Relations Act was filed today by the Globe Company against the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, and its local 3868.

LONDON, July 30 -- Although there was a fresh spasm of weakness at the opening of the stock markets here today -- sentiment being influenced by the overnight break on Wall Street and the prevailing political and economic uncertainty --jobbers reported a definite easing of selling pressure.

In the face of existing suspicions among nations, this country must demonstrate its will and ability to further collective security through an enlightened foreign policy, Gen. Joseph T. McNarney, United Nations Military Staff Committee member, declared yesterday.

MANILA, July 30 -- The Philippine Government is finding singularly small interest among the Filipinos in re-establishing trade with Japan under the plan worked out by Gen. Douglas MacArthur's headquarters in Tokyo. It is supposed to begin on Aug. 15.

Mrs. Lionel Stahl of 170 East Seventy-ninth Street and San Francisco has announced the engagement of her daughter, MarieLouise, to Dr. John Grantley Taylor, son of Dr. and Mrs. Grantley Taylor of Brookline, Mass.

The semi-annual statement of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced for publication today by Gwilym A. Price, president, disclosed a net income of $21,735,442 for the first half of this year after providing $14,761,419 for taxes and $5,500,000 to cover possible losses resulting from a drop in the value of manufacturing inventories now in plants.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- Attorney General Clark today announced filing of a civil action to require the United States Freight Company and Hickok Oil Corporation to divest themselves of all stock holdings in and control of Interstate Motor Freight System.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 30 -- New Jersey citizens were promised today an opportunity to vote on proposed liberalization of the gambling laws as the legislative committee of the State Constitutional Convention voted 7-3 to submit two alternative proposals to referendum.
BUFFALO, N.Y., July 30(AP) -- The 18-cent-a-quart price for home delivered milk which has been effective here since July will be increased to 19 cents Friday.

The American Repertory Theatre headed by Margaret Webster, Eva LeGallienne and Cheryl Crawford, apparently is more than casually interested in gaining a foothold in radio. On Tuesday evening in an NBC studio the group cut two audition records for eventual perusal by possible sponsors.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 30 -- Fourteen intellectual and professional leaders in Slovenia went on trial yesterday in Ljubljana for "anti-people's activities," it was announced today.

Jean Dalrymple, sponsor of the current revival, "Burlesque," has bought a new play by William McCleery and hopes to get it on the local boards by the first of the year. The script -- the author is at Peterborough, N,H., finishing it -- is entitled "A Play for Mary" and is about the effect Broadway success has on the mind and heart of a bright young actress.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 30 -- Allen Spencer, 7-year-old bay gelding by Spencer, driven by Milton Van Auken for Owner John Beck of East Aurora, N. Y., set a new world record for the mile-and-ahalf distance over a half-mile track tonight.

GENEVA, Switzerland, July 30 -- The United Nations Special Committee of Inquiry on Palestine decided by a small majority today to visit displaced persons camps in Germany and Austria. The vote was six to four, with one abstention.

The Taft-Hartley Act is likely to give impetus to organization of craft unions in factories and complicate collective bargaining in plants where industrial unions have been recognized, several speakers asserted yesterday during the second day of a seminar on industrial relations.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Puerto Ricans are coming to the mainland, chiefly New York, at a rate of well over 2,000 a month and perhaps as high as 3,000.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- St. Louis pushed over an unearned run in the eleventh inning tonight to defeat Washington, 2 to 1. The Browns produced the winning run when third baseman Eddie Yost fumbled Vernon Stephens' grounder, enabling Paul Lehner to score.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Consultations were held at the State Department today with Herschel V. Johnson, United States deputy delegate to the United Nations, in circumstances forecasting a prompt decision on the next step now that Russia has vetoed the United States proposal on the Balkans.
After fluctuating over a fairly wide range yesterday, prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 7 points lower to 6 points higher.

Promotion of a "pony meter" guaranteed to pick the winning horse at any track was the basis on which William. F. Wrieden was held in $2,500 bail yesterday by General Sessions Judge John J. Sullivan pending trial Tor grand larceny on eight counts.

The current heat wave forced the mercury up to 92 degrees -- the highest of the year -- at 3:40 P. M. yesterday. Little relief is expected today, for a top thermometer reading of near 90 is predicted.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, July 30 -- The Dutch Cabinet discussed the latest developments in Indonesia at a special meeting today. The meeting was held in the home of Dr. Jan Jonkman, Minister for Overseas Territories, who is ill at the moment and must remain in his bed.
"All aboard the retirement special" was the train call sounded yesterday by the New York Central System from its executive offices at 466 Lexington Avenue.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (U.P.) -- A House agriculture subcommittee predicted today that meat would be lower in price and more plentiful this fall "unless the policy of shipping large quantities abroad is continued."

NANKING, China, July 30 -- American reporting on China was defended today by the Shanghai Evening Post and Mercury, the only American-owned newspaper in China, in an editorial written in reply to Generalissimo Chiang Kaishek's criticism of American correspondents in this country on Sunday before a group of visiting editors and publishers from the United States.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 30 -- The Soviet-Yugoslav trade agreement is the fruit of negotiations conducted in Moscow in June of last year between Soviet Premier Stalin, Foreign Minister Molotov and Yugoslav Premier Marshall Tito according to the official version of the discussions published today.

AKRON, Ohio, July 30 -- Goodyear Aircraft Corporation reported today the receipt of the first approved type certificate to be granted by the Civil Aeronautics Administration for a swiveled landing gear. The device, which Goodyear was commissioned to develop a year ago, enables planes to land cross wind and is expected to eliminate in many cases the necessity for more than one runway to an airport.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 30 -- Two alleged violations of the constitutionally established American principle of separation of church and state, one in the field of diplomacy, the other in the field of education, were sternly assailed by the Rev. Dr. Charles Clayton Morrison of Chicago here tonight.
Chief Barker, the last one home in his two previous starts this season, had his running shoes on yesterday at Jamaica and won the Class C Only One Purse at better than 9 to 1.

A new color facsimile device in the operation of which any type of paper may be utilized and which may be attached to any FM radio receiver was introduced yesterday by Finch Telecommunications, Inc., at a press demonstration at its offices, 10 East Fortieth Street.

Hyman Pincus, former friend and associate of Irving Wexler, alias Waxey Gordon, prohibition era beer baron and racketeer, is wanted for questioning in connection with the fatal Election Day beating of Republican District Captain Joseph R. Scottoriggio, District Attorney Frank S. Hogan made known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- President Truman put appointments aside today and tackled again the avalanche of bills that were rushed through during the closing days of Congress. He signed fifty-seven and pocket-vetoed two.

Longshoremen yesterday walked off the S. S. Molda, Europe-bound freighter with 2,643 tons of hazardous ammonium nitrate in one of her holds, after their demand for "munitions" pay was refused. The 7,850-ton vessel was docked at Pier 34, Hamilton Avenue, Brooklyn, in the Erie Basin district.

LOS ANGELES, July 30 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Rams of the National Football League, well stocked with backfield material, today signed two linemen, formerly of Annapolis. They were Center John Martin, 235 pounds and a stand-out with the Navy in 1943, and Tackle Ben Chase, 6 feet 3 inches, 230 pounds, who captained the Annapolis team in 1944.

When it became evident in the spring that Larry (Yogi) Berra would stay with the Yankees -- if not as an outfielder, certainly as a catcher -- the little lad from St. Louis set for himself two goals. In his first full season in the majors, Yogi aimed to bat at least 300 and hit at least fifteen home runs.

The Bronx seems to be the place for animal stories and this one turned up yesterday before game time at the Yankee Stadium.The Detroit Tigers gathered in the visiting team's locker room and received a mascot-an 8-week-old Ocelot or American wildcat-from the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.
WESTBURY, L. I., July 30 -- The Ray M. Torgerson family is very much in the golf limelight these days.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., July 30 -- In a thrilling finish, Mrs. Donald O'Brien of Winged Foot became the new holder of the Elizabeth Wheeler trophy as the Fairfield and Westchester Counties open golf championship was completed over the Quaker Ridge course today.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 30--Senator John W. Bricker bowed out today in favor of Senator Robert A. Taft as Ohio's favorite son candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination.

Edward J. Marlow, in charge of men's furnishings at B. Altman Co. for the past twenty-four years, has resigned to direct sales in the men's division of Royal Robes, Inc., 16 East Thirty-fourth Street.

When the Security Council meets today to consider the consequences of the latest Russian veto, it will embark on the first stages of a debate which will ultimately determine whether the United Nations is capable of fulfilling the primary duty for which it was created, namely, to maintain international peace and security, or whether it is destined to go the way of the League of Nations.

While demand for American products continues unabated in some countries, there are a growing number of foreign markets in which selling is required, according to Robert Johnston, publisher of The American Exporter. The South African market for one, he said, is now among those in which business could not be done automatically.

Representative Carl Hinshaw of California will head the Congressional commission of five Senators and five Representatives to investigate and recommend an air policy at the next session, according to word received in aircraft industry circles here yesterday.
The Urge to Garden There is one thing all suburban householders, commuters and native residents alike have in common. That is pride in the plot of ground on which they live.

Underwriting syndicates will offer to investors today an aggregate of $26,800,000 of securities including $20,000,000 of bonds and debentures of Florida Power and Light Company, and 200,000 shares of estate-owned common stock of J.P. Stevens Co., Inc., textile manufacturer.
The name "California" is not the exclusive property of California business men, the United States Circuit Court of Appeals held yesterday in a two to one decision.

OCEANPORT, N.J., July 30 (AP) -- King Ranch's steadily improving Task beat ten 2-year-old rivals in the second running of the Sapling Stakes as the record-breaking thirty-six-day Monmouth Park race meeting concluded today.

Another of the major utility holding company systems, the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation, moved closer to compliance with the break-up provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act yesterday with the announcement that a new plan will be filed shortly with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 30 -- Following are the texts of the Indian and Australian letters to the Security Council, regarding the Indonesian situation, signed by Pandit Jahawarlal Nehru, Vice President in the Interim Government of India, and Col. W. R. Hodgson, Australian representative on the Security Council:

CHICAGO, July 30--The most that the jewelry industry can expect in the way of "relief" from the present 20 per cent Federal excise tax on jewelry is a reduction to the pre-war figure of 10 per cent, the National Association of Credit Jewelers was told today.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Dr. Eelco N. van Kleffens, the Netherlands Ambassador, said today that the United Nations Security Council lacked jurisdiction over the Indonesian question.

Fur Coat Linings Still Tight Sustained demand for rayon fabrics has kept the supply of fur coat linings from becoming ample, according to lining jobbers yesterday. The trade shows a preference for rayon linings, particularly for lower priced coats such as moutons and beaverettes, even though silk linings have increased and prices have come down.

An electronic instrument, the Theremin, gave a touch of novelty to the Philharmonic -- Symphony concert under Bernard Herrmann's directorship at Lewisohn Stadium last night. Clara Rockmore introduced the outdoor audience to Anis Fuleihan's Concerto for Orchestra, written especially for her.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (U.P.) -- The House Labor Committee will look into charges that the Philadelphia Newspaper Guild, CIO, has forbidden some of its members to resign, according to the committee chairman, Fred A. Hartley Jr., Republican, of New Jersey.

BOSTON, July 30 (U.P.) -- Fifteen lengths off the pace at one point, Stymie staged his typical stretch drive today to capture the thirteenth running of the $50,000 added Massachusetts Handicap at Suffolk Downs and become the first horse in turf history to earn more than $700,000.

TOKYO, July 30 -- Washington's stand on the Japanese peace treaty today received almost complete endorsement from Dr. Herbert V. Evatt, Australian Deputy Prime Minister, Attorney General and Minister of External Affairs.

Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, announced last night that a national registration campaign -- "the like of which has never been seen" -- has been started by the CIO.

WASHINGTON, July 30--No legislation for years has given to some critics a falser impression of its origins than the sugar imports quota bill, passed by the Senate in the last hours of the recent session of Congress after having been previously approved by the House.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended July 23, the Federal Reserve Board announced today:

PARIS, July 30 -- Following a discussion in the Cabinet today the French Government declined to use force to effect the landing in France of 4,500 Jewish immigrants brought back from Haifa aboard three British ships.

The Board of Estimate has informally approved as a "must" for the next two years, a capital program calling for expenditure of $135,686,700 for seventeen projects involving construction of new hospitals, replacement of old one and rehabilitation of existing facilities, Mayor O'Dwyer declared yesterday.

Headed by Mrs. Kay Stammers Menzies, five members of the British Wightman Cup tennis team arrived yesterday aboard the Cunard White Star liner Queen Elizabeth. A sixth member of the group, Mrs. Jean Bostock, is scheduled to reach here next week.
LONDON, July 30 -- Elegant clothes with gracious lines are, as always, the hallmark of Victor Stiebel's collections, to which the designer adds an artist's instinct for beautiful colors.

Six detectives will guard Benjamin Rockower, a 230-pound prisoner, when he leaves the Queens County Jail this morning to appear as a voluntary witness before the June Grand Jury. The jury is investigating charges, originally brought by Emetia Polizio, a local gambler, that Queens policemen have been charging bookmakers $1,300 to $3,000 a month for permission to operate.

James V. Auditore, on trial in General Sessions with I. James Brody, ousted Deputy Commissioner of Marine and Aviation, for conspiracy and accepting unlawful fees in the rental of city-owned piers, testified yesterday that in his mind all of his acts were proper and lawful.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- President Roosevelt stepped in to prevent cancellation of Howard Hughes' wartime contract to build the world's largest flying boat, a craft that still has not taken to the air, a Senate War Investigating subcommittee was told today.
CHICAGO, July 30 (AP) -- The Phillies defeated the Cubs, 9 -- 2, today, combing three Chicago pitchers for 11 hits and their second triumph in fifteen appearances against the Cubs.
GENEVA, July 30 -- A strong effort is being made by the United States, Britain and other Western countries to keep Czechoslovakia in the International Trade Organization.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., July 30 -- Australia asked the United Nations Security Council today to order the Netherlands Government and the Indonesian Republic "to cease hostilities forthwith" and begin arbitrating their differences without prejudice to the rights of either party.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 30 (AP) -- The effectiveness of "flu shots" on a wholesale scale was questioned today by Dr. Hollis S. Ingraham, Director of the Division of Communicable Diseases of the State Health Department, at the annual State Health Conference.

LONDON, July 30--The Burmese Government believes that the persons who assassinated U. Aung San and other political leaders in Rangoon are among those under arrest, Prime Minister Attlee announced to the House of Commons today.

CHICAGO, July 30 -- There was a lack of heavy commission house liquidation in the grain markets on the Board of Trade today, and general buying induced by reports that the Government had purchased large quantities of cash wheat overnight following an advance of 1/2 cent in the bid price and continued hot and dry weather over the main Corn Belt brought about sharply higher prices.
NEWARK, N.J., July 30 -- One block from Broad and Market, the center of Newark's business district, is a retail butcher shop that attracted almost 4,000 buyers today.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 30 -- Mrs. Virginia Kovacs of Oakland, Calif., the second-seeded American, defeated Miss Sylvia Knowles of Newport, R.I., today as play opened in the women's invitation tennis tournament at the Maidstone Club.

Tami Mauriello's bid for a come back among the heavyweights was crushed last night at Ebbets Field under the guns carried by a ring warrior almost twenty pounds lighter than the burly ItalianAmerican from Fordham.

Melodic voices filled the Council Chamber in City Hall yesterday at the noon hour as the fiftyfour members of the Roman Singers of Sacred Music, sang a brief chorus in Italian in appreciation of the welcome extended by Mayor O'Dwyer and other officials.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 30 -- Brig. Gen Julius Ochs Adler of New York reviewed the National Guard troops of the Seventy-first Infantry of New York and the 106th Infantry of Brooklyn tonight at Camp Smitn here.

The wartime crackdown on black marketeers will be duplicated in the Magistrates courts of this city with chiseling landlords the target, if the rent control bills now in the City Council become law, Joseph T. Sharkey, Vicechairman and Majority Leader of the Council, said last night.

Aimed at providing better coordinated medical facilities in Brooklyn, Beth Moses and Israel Zion Hospitals announced last night their merger into a single institution to be known as Maimonides Hospital.
MINEOLA, L.I., July 30 -- Hamilton Gaddis, assistant executive secretary to Governor Dewey, will be the Republican candidate for Town Clerk of Hempstead in November.

BERLIN, July 30 -- United States Secretary of War Kenneth C. Royall arrived here by plane early this evening to obtain, firsthand from Gen. Lucius D. Clay a. precise report on the occupation problems.
LONDON, July 30 -- The British Government has prohibited all supplies of war material to the Dutch for use in Indonesia, Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin told the House of Commons today.

CHICAGO, July 30 (AP) --Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 6,500 head, total 9,500: market slow, mostly steady, trade very uneven and some sales of heavy butchers and lightweight sows strong: market closing dull: top of

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 30 -- Miss Audrey Priest Hirst, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry P. Hirst of 25 East Eighty-third Street, New York, and Narragansett, R.I., was married here this afternoon to Herbert Rosenfield, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abner B. Rosenfield of this city, in the garden of Field Rose Knolls, home of the bridegroom's parents.
ST. LOUIS, July 30 -- The Dodgers did it the hard way tonight, staging a 10-inning, 3-hour 34minute struggle with the Cardinals before emerging on the important end of an 11-10 score.

LOS ANGELES, July 30 (AP) -- Howard Hughes issued a statement today demanding that Senator Owen Brewster of Maine, chairman of the Senate War Investigating Committee, "give the public the fact's concerning his abortive attempt to intimidate and coerce me by offering to call off this investigation of my airplane projects if I would agree to merge TWA (Trans World Airline) with Juan Trippe's Pan American Airways."

Within two months a five-man committee of experts will leave for Surinam, Dutch Guiana, to select a suitable area for colonization by 30,000 European Jews and to draft extensive economic, technical and financial plans, it was announced yesterday.

LONDON, July 30 -- Sir Gonne Pilcher, presiding judge, said in Admiralty Court today that the fund from which he could distribute salvage claims against the American Farmer was less than half the total values of the rescued ship and her cargo.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration today announced the suspension of shipments to both Communist and Government areas of North China "pending the negotiation by its China office of more satisfactory arrangement for distribution of a fair share of the UNRRA program to the Communist-controlled territories.

From time to time we still hear, from the dwindling company of fellowtravelers, that while communism is a bit different from our Western-style democracy, we would find that it is really a very democratic system if we would only take the trouble to understand it.
The Treasury served notice today that it intends to tighten up on licenses for export of gold in a move to prevent sales abroad at prices above the United States rate of $35 an ounce.

The New York City Housing Authority will receive bids on $22,244,000 of temporary loan notes on Aug. 7, Thomas F. Farrell, Authority chairman, announced yesterday. The notes will be dated Aug. 27, 1947, and will come due Feb. 27, 1948.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 30 -- Great Britain will propose to the United Nations Economic and Social Council that the 1948 international conference on freedom of information investigate any governmental restrictions against private citizens' owning or operating radio sets of their own selection, it was learned today.

A furtner drop of 1,333,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was shown last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Supplies at the end of the period amounted to 85,812,000 barrels, compared with 87,145,000 a week earlier and 88,959,000 on July 27, 1946.
LINCOLN, Neb., July 30 -- Delegates to the first National Methodist Rural Life Conference heard pleas today to save the soil and rebuild the productiveness of the country's farm land.

Motion picture advertising and publicity are due for a general whitewashing under a revised set of regulations unanimously adopted yesterday by the directors of the Motion Picture Producers Association.

The reaction on the Stock Market persisted yesterday although the list enjoyed short periods of recovery and pressure lightened. The liquidation still was sufficiently strong to produce the lowest price levels in almost four weeks, but fractional losses predominated, with the average down 0.53 point on the day.

Procedure whereby New York State veterans could build their own homes cooperatively with the help of the state bonus planned for next year was outlined yesterday by Herman T. Stichman, State Housing Commissioner. The bonuses will be paid if the voters approve such action next November.

CINCINNATI, July 30 -- There is a growing conviction out this way that, no matter what anyone may think about it, those unspeakable Bums from the East are really going to make it this time and bring the National League pennant to Brooklyn.

DEAL, N.J., July 30 -- Mrs. Sophie Untermeyer of the Hollywood Golf Club posted an 82 in the final round of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's 54-hole medal play Shore tournament today to carry off top honors with a total gross score of 237.

SINCLAIR LEWIS' "Kingsblood Royal" will have its dozens of readers for every reader that Worth Puttle Hedden's "The Other Room"* will have. And that's a pity in a way. For "The Other Room" has much the same theme as "Kingsblood Royal"--the intolerance of racial standards in this country--and it is much more subtly and convincingly written.

NEW DELHI, India, July 30 -- After a day's delay requested by Great Britain, the Government of India this afternoon instructed its permanent delegation in New York to place India's protest on the Indonesian situation before the chairman of the United Nations Security Council.
WELCH, W.Va., July 30 (AP) -- This coal town of 6,000-odd was at a loss today to explain exactly or find a remedy for a sub-surface slippage which has a large part of the downtown area sinking.

E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. and its wholly owned subsidiaries reported in a semi-annual statement, issued for publication today, net income for the six months ended on June 30 of $61,619,650, equal to $5.13 a share on the 11,121,927 shares of common stock outstanding.

Close Bidding Appraisal of railroad equipment trust credit continues to rank as something of an exact science compared with the catch-as-catchcan bidding that has been registered of late for issues of new public utility stocks and bonds.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- Federal tax collections in fiscal 1947, which ended June 30; fell $1,563,711,000 below the previous fiscal year because of heavy loss of revenue from the repealed excess profits tax, Treasury records showed today.

BATAVIA, Java, July 30 (AP) -- The Netherlands Army, referring to Indonesian charges that two Dutch fighters had shot down a mercy transport plane carrying medical supplies to the Republic, said today that the identity of the aircraft had not been clearly established.

MELBOURNE, Australia, July 30 -- Prime Minister Joseph B. Chifley, as acting Minister of External Affairs in Dr. Herbert V. Evatt's absence in Japan, announced today at Canberra that Australia's representative on the United Nations Security Council had been instructed to direct the Council's attention to the situation in Indonesia under Article 39 of the United Nations charter.

BOSTON, Mass., July 30--Douglas Chandler, convicted as a traitor, was sentenced today to life imprisonment and ordered to pay a fine of $10,000 for broadcasting Nazi propaganda from Berlin during the war. His lawyer asked immediately for a stay of sentence, preliminary to an appeal.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 30 -- Warner Brothers today announced the purchase of screen rights to Maxwell Anderson's 1939 play, "Key Largo," as an autumn vehicle for Humphrey Bogart and Lauren Bacall. The film version will be produced by Jerry Wald, according to the studio.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 30 -- Gardnar Mulloy of Coral Gables, Fla., went down in defeat at the Meadow Club today in one of the major reversals of the tennis season.
PARIS, Thursday, July 31 (AP) -- At least twenty-one persons, all of them believed to have been women inmates, died in a flash fire that swept through a section of a Paris prison last night.

PHILADELPHIA, July 30 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today the Potomac Electric Power Company's proposal to refinance its old preferred stock at a lower dividend rate and increase its authorized capital stock from $30,000,000 to $75,000,000, consisting of 400,000 shares of $50 par value preferred and 5,500,000 shares of $10 par value common.

BATAVIA, Java, Thursday, July 31 (AP) -- The Netherlands Government today set up as autonomous territories in the projected United States of Indonesia the major tin-producing islands of Bangka and Billiton and the strategic Rlouw Archipelago, Singapore's southern guardian and an important world source of bauxite.

BATAVIA, Java, July 30 -- Dutch troops bolstered by an amphibious operation lashed out from Sumatra's Medan area today, the Netherlands Army announced, and drove into the rich tobacco and rubber region of Sumatra, the big island northwest of Java.

Final steps in the reorganization program of the Indian Motocycle Company were approved yesterday at a special meeting of stockholders in Springfield, Mass., according to Ralph B. Rogers, president. Shareholders voted favorably upon a plan to merge the R. B. Rogers Companies, Inc., into Indian.
DETROIT, July 30 -- More than 59,000 Detroit automobile plant employes were idle or faced idleness today because of strikes or the heat.

LONDON, July 31 -- Special details from Scotland Yard guarded synagogues and Government buildings tonight as a precaution against violent acts in the wake of the hanging of two British Army sergeants by Palestine terrorists.

Both Alfred Toplitz, Tammany leader of the First Assembly District, North, and Gerard V. Murphy, his opponent, continued yesterday to claim victory in Tuesday's primary election, with supporters of Mr. Murphy more specific in their claim.
LONDON, July 31 -- Awards totaling u23,045 [$92,871] were made by Sir Gonne Pilcher, presiding judge in the American Farmer salvage action, which was concluded at the Admiralty Court today.

ATHENS, Tenn., July 31 -- One year ago tomorrow the tree-shaded streets of this sun-drenched East Tennessee town reverberated to the explosions of gun fire as a group of war veterans fought from rooftops and barricades to overthrow the local political machine.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady yesterday with gains of 21 to 37 points.

WASHINGOTN, July 31 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended July 26 totaled 919,928 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 194 cars, or .02 per cent more than for the preceding week; 9,415 cars, or 1 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year, and 33,498 cars, or 3.8 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

The proposed sale of the ParkMurray Building at 11 Park Place for $1,100,000 is being opposed by a group of stockholders. Letters sent out to other stockholders urge them to disapprove and oppose the proposed sale, which is to be submitted to them for approval at a meeting at 2 P.M. next Tuesday in the Commodore Hotel.

CHICAGO, July 31 (AP) -- Emil (Dutch) Leonard, the ex-American League knuckle ball pitcher, held the Cubs to five scattered hits today for the 3-0 victory that gave the Phillies their first series of the year over Chicago. It was Philadelphia's third victory in 16 meetings with the Cubs.

An anthology of true crime stories of the eighteenth century has been compiled by Lillian de la Torre, entitled "Villainy Detected." The book, which includes stories by Andrew Lang, Daniel DeFoe, Sir Walter Scott and Jonathan Swift, also contains a story by Miss de la Torre, called "The Disappearing Servant Wench," which has never been printed before.

A strong likelihood developed yesterday that the Federal Office of Rent Control would be unable to prosecute rent law violators in the Magistrates' Courts of New York, as contemplated in one of the bills now in the City Council.

CHICAGO, July 31 -- James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, agreed today to consider ending the AFM rule which forbids duplicating musical programs presented for standard band broadcasts, on frequency-modulation broadcasts, when the FM transmitters are operated jointly with standard band transmitters.

Reflecting the improved operating results for the first half of this year, directors of the Grumman Aircraft Engineering' Corporation declared yesterday a dividend of $1.50 a share on the common stock for payment Aug. 21.

Since a man s life is surely worth more than a ton of coal, safety regulations in coal mines ought not to be measured by what they cost. Nevertheless, it is encouraging to have the word of Capt. N.H. Collisson, Coal Mines Administrator during the period of federal control, that "increased safety and maximum production" can go together.

The United States Rubber Company, in its semi-annual report issued to shareholders yesterday by F.B. Davis Jr., chairman, and Herbert E. Smith, president, showed the net income for the first half of this year at $11,020,729 after all charges including $1,000,000 provision for adjustment of certain raw material inventories.

Bronx citizens may look down their noses at rodents but when it conies to Plagiodontia aedium they had better act respectful. At least that is the way Dr. Lee Crandall, general curator at the Bronx Zoo, would have them respond.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Philip Murray, President of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, accused the American Federation of Labor Executive Council today of trying to prevent a working unity between the rank and file of the two organizations to combat immediate economic and political problems.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I should like to comment on the ruing of Supreme Court Justice Benvega, relating to the suit brought by to three Negro war veterans to enjoy Stuyvesant Town from, the allege practice of discrimination in the seletion of tenants.

Keep your eyes open for the attack bombers that will lead an aerial review of all types of planes scheduled to fly over New York today at 10 A. M. Mitchel Field will celebrate the Air Force's fortieth birthday tomorrow with an air show starting at noon.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The Government's wartime efforts to control clothing and the "refractory" character of the clothing industry were both indicted in a review entitled "Wartime Apparel Price Control," issued today by the government Printing Office.
LONDON, July 31 -- Weakness in the stock markets here today was accentuated by the further heavy draft on the United States loan and by the plan for drastic cuts in imports.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., July 31 (AP) -- The New York State Department of the American Legion opened today its first full threeday convention since 1941 with all the pageantry characteristic of its pre-war meeting's.

COLUMBUS, July 31 (AP) -- The following is the text of the address of Senator Robert A. Taft at a Republican dinner here tonight: Fellow Republicans of Ohio: On Jan. 3, 1947, there met in Washington the first Republican Congress in 16 year.

PARIS, July 31 -- The steady decline in the quantity and quality of aid furnished to Jewish displaced persons in Germany, Austria and Italy threatens to undermine the health of these refugees, Dr. Joseph J. Schwartz, European Director of the American Joint Distribution Committee, warned today.
WASHINGTON, July 31 -- During the week ended July 30 member bank reserve balances Increased $110,000,000.

Low water and high temperatures seem to have driven most of the trout fishermen to salt water, but reports indicate that those who have been willing to fish during the early morning and late afternoon have been rewarded.

BERLIN, July 31 -- In anticipation of a three-power discussion on the level of western German industry. French experts are preparing a report that recommends a steel production capacity not much lower than that proposed by the United States and Britain, it was learned today.
Joe Louis will not defend his heavyweight championship of the world this year, but he will see action in a non-title bout at Madison Square Garden on Friday night, Nov. 14.

The stock market rebounded sharply yesterday, canceling out about one-third of the losses sustained during the three previous sessions. Prices rose 1 to 4 points on limited bidding and an absence of the pressure encountered earlier this week. Under the leadership of the steels, motors, chemicals and some selected issues the price average rallied 1.15 points on the day.
ROME, July 31 -- The Constituent Assembly ratified the Italian peace treaty tonight, 262 to 68. The majority was much larger than expected because eighty Deputies, mostly Communists, abstained.

BARNUM'S American Museum was advertising "marvelous living African mud-fish, brought here in dry, solid clay!!! -- and a million other curiosities." Water wheels were for sale. New York shops were close to ecstatic about the new "duplex elliptic steel-spring hoopskirt." A dentist, offering his services at 25 cents a yank, asserted that "nitrous oxide gas renders tooth drawing a pleasure instead of a pain.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, July 31 (AP) -- Eight B-29 Superfortresses striving for a new distance and speed record landed here today on a one-stop flight from Tokyo to Washington and seven left on the last leg of their trip after refueling.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 31 -- Freedom of the press is curtailed by the unequal distribution of the world's relatively scarce supply of newsprint, the United Nations Education, Scientific and Cultural Organization will report at a meeting of its commission of experts on Aug. 25 in Paris.
Pittsburgh Steel Company reported yesterday a net income of $1,170,415 for the quarter ended on June 30, contrasted with a net

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, July 31 -- As the strike against the Government continued today, the former Communist party, now the Vanguardia Popular, introduced a bill in Congress declaring a threemonth rent moratorium for both residential and commercial tenants.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 31 -- The International Convention of the Disciples of Christ has adopted a report of its commission on restudy setting forth in six points the basic tenets in which almost all members of the church believe. These are as follows:
HEKFORD, Germany. July 31 -- North Rhine Westphalia's highest governmental body entered today its protest against the dismantling of Ruhr plants.

The "pony" checks that Albert Gross said were drawn for cash payments to I. James Brody, former Deputy Commissioner of Marine and Aviation, were actually cash withdrawals of profits, James V. Auditore testified in General Sessions yesterday.

WASHINGTON. July 31 -- Department store sales in the week ended July 26 were 4 per cent above sales in the corresponding period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1946:

Public offerings of new securities here in July showed mixed trends, with bond flotations the smallest for any month since February and stocks the largest for any month so far this year. Fortyeight new issues of bonds totaling $341,463,000 were marketed, against fifty-one for $729,132,000 in the preceding month and thirtynine for $422,934,000 in the corresponding month of 1946.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- The War Assets Administration said today it may extend $122,255,000 in credits to seven foreign countries to buy surplus property in the United States.

After a perfect fifty-two-year record with the New York Central System dating back to Oct. 1, 1894, Edward J. Connors, 69 years old, retiring chief station master at Grand Central Terminal, flunked his last order yesterday at the railroad's send-off to him.

The Municipal Art Commission filed with the Board of Estimate yesterday a request that it reconsider its action of July 24, appropriating $54,000 to enable the Park Department to complete the demolition of the Aquarium in Battery Park.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The Air Force today is exploring warwidened frontiers of science, its main objectives being to surmount the speed-of-sound barrier and develop long-range, radio-controlled planes, plane-launched and guided rockets, and guided missiles of extreme range.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Culminating discussions begun last year, representatives of the frozen food industry meeting here this week have formed the National Frozen Food Council, Inc., to cultivate user acceptance of and preference for their products, it was announced today.

ST. PAUL, Minn., July 31 (AP) -- A 12-foot putt that dropped on the eighteenth hole for a birdie four swept Ed Furgol, Pontiac, Mich., professional, into a first-day lead in the St. Paul $10,000 open golf tournament today, with a 67.

HOLLYWOOD, July 31 (U.P.) -- Howard Hughes stated tonight that Senator Owen Brewster, Republican, of Maine, lied when he said a Trans-World Airline hostess "didn't dare" to be alone in an airplane with him.

Stabilization of labor costs in the construction industry was explored for two and a half hours yesterday at City Hall, in a closed conference called by Mayor O'Dwyer. The meeting was attended by members of his administration and fifty leaders in the construction field.
LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., July 31 -- The United States offered today to mediate in the undeclared war between the Netherlands and the Indonesian Republic.
WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The Federal Communications Commission has announced that a general increase in international cable and radio telegraph rates on press messages will go into effect on August 5.

Production of the Rototiller, a gas engine powered hand tractor, will be increased about 25 per cent when new plant facilities at York, Pa., go into operation in September, and a total sales volume of $20,000,000 for this machine is envisaged for next year, Joseph W. Frazer, chairman and president of Graham-Paige Motors Corporation, said in an interview here yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, July 31 (AP) -- The Sun Oil Company today announced price increases in several products and said the action was taken to "protect the fuel oil supply of its customers against the added competition of those who might be tempted to convert from coal to oil on the basis of sheer economics."

PITTSBURGH, July 31 -- The Joseph Home Company, Pittsburgh department store, will insert advertising in Sunday newspapers beginning next Sunday, breaking a tradition of ninetyeight years. The step was taken, in addition to the store's daily newspaper schedules, to gain the larger Sunday circulation in the expanding suburban Pittsburgh market, store officials said.

The organization of a Catholic Broadcasters Association to aid Catholic groups in the more effective use of radio will be launched at a conference to be held from Aug. 15 to 17 on the campus of Fordham University, it was announced yesterday.

STAMFORD, Conn., July 31 -- Ticket Collector Edward J. Downey of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad is not a sentimentalist. But it is safe to assume that he will never forget his tour of duty today on the New York-to-Stamford run.

The nation's present steel-making capacity is more than adequate for normal domestic and export requirements and should not be expanded to accommodate "current and temporary excess demands for our industries or for rebuilding Europe," E.G. Grace, chaiman of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, declared here yesterday.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The traveling public of the City of New York, which includes almost all of us, are living with a ball and chain around our legs, saddled with a debt of $1,100,000,000 in transit bonds.
The realization of an old, old dream -- a separate and independent air force-makes today, Air Force Day, the most significant celebraition of its kind in the history of United States air power.

The Wilderness Purse at Jamaica yesterday gave the customers plenty to buzz about. It resulted in a nose decision for the Brenda Hope Stable's Station over Mrs. Robert H. Heighe's Zax, but the "objection" sign flashed a couple of minutese later and it wasn't till the stewards had reviewed the movies that the result was confirmed.
ALBANY, July 31 (AP) -- Dr. Harvey M. Rice, a faculty member at Albany State Teachers College since 1943, was appointed president of Oswego State Teachers College today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., July 31 -- The possible use of individual or collective military action by member countries of the United Nations, under Article 51 of the Charter was foreshadowed today in a new Greek proposal placed before the Security Council.

LONDON, July 31 -- A radical slash in the current reduced living standard of the British people appeared a certainty tonight as the Government worked on a program to pull the nation through its economic crisis.

WASHINGTON, July 31--Air Force Day will be celebrated throughout the country tomorrow to mark the fortieth anniversary of military aviation in the United States. In the air and on the ground official and private efforts will be made to make the public aware of its renascent air power.

Negotiators for the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, CIO, in effect rejected an offer for a conditional 12 cents-an-hour increase in rate of pay offered yesterday by the Bethlehem Steel Company, operator of nine of the nineteen major shipyards on the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts, which have been on strike for thirty-six days.

TRENTON, N.J., July 31 -- A general survey of New Jersey crop conditions by state farm authorities indicated today that the farmers would have "a good year" despite adverse weather and poor prices for some produce.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 31 -- After today, Ray Torgerson, 36year-old stock broker who belongs to the Cherry Valley Club at Garden City, will be able to enter his own home without having to salute his wife.

Two young American musicians shared honors in their Lewisohn Stadium debuts before an audience of 9,000 last night. Richard Korn, former assistant conductor of the National Orchestral Association, led the Philharmonic-Symphony; Sidney Foster, winner of the first Leaventritt Prize in 1940, played the solo part in Tchaikovsky's B-flat minor Piano Concerto.

Mayor O'Dwyer and the Board of Estimate unexpectedly turned their backs yesterday on any test of a higher rapid transit fare at the Nov. 4 election. Instead, they announced their belief that the higher fare issue should be submitted to the people at a special election in which it would be the sole question before the voters.

A legal dispute over a 9-year-old girl, Filipina Mammano of Maolewood, N.J., caused considerable excitement on the American Export Line pier at West Fortyfourth Street yesterday as the Italian liner Saturnia was preparing to sail for Mediterranean ports with 1,552 passengers:

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- In the session of Congress just ended the Republican majority made a reduction in the cost of government. Whether it was almost $3 billions, as some figure it, or more or less is an argument that will continue, though there is no room for argument that the savings did not reach the $6 billions resolved on by the House leaders or the $4.5 billions pledged by those in the Senate.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 31 (AP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft will begin his speaking trip in California after a five-week vacation at the family retreat at Murray Bay, Canada.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Information which comes to a Federal conciliator in the course of his work is confidential and he should not be required to testify to it, the National Labor Relations Board ruled today.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- The volume of consumer credit continued its month-by-month recordbreaking climb through June, swinging up 2 per cent to another peak of $10,884,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported tonight.

A new collection of handprinted wallpapers that goes on exhibit today at Katzenbach Warren, 49 East Fifty-third Street, shows a new muted color range as well as a trend toward the small-scale repeats currently favored in decorative fabrics.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 31 -- The oldest inhabitants of this historic colony were trying to recollect tonight when there had been so much excitement in town as was provided at the Meadow Club today.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- A reorganization of the State Department's Office of International Information and Cultural Affairs to meet the reduced appropriation for the current fiscal year was announced today by William Benton, Assistant Secretary of State for Public Affairs.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- President Truman made recess appointees today of his three nominees to the expanded National Labor Relations Board. Action on their confirmation by the Senate was blocked during the adjournment rush early last Sunday morning.
BATAVIA, July 31 (AP) -- An Indonesian Army communique, as recorded hare from a Jogjakarta broadcast: East Java -- Our pressure on Lawang was intensified. West Java-On July 29 Tangerang.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 31 (AP) -- Dr. Leon Sternfeld, director of the State Health Department's Division of Medical Rehabilitation, declared today that chronic disabling diseases, especially heart ailments, are rising rapidly.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., July 31 -- The Central and South West Corporation received permission from the Securities and Exchange Commission today to sell $4,300,000 of unsecured serial notes to the First National Bank of Chicago and the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- The Government today sharply restricted the open season and bag limits on duck hunting, decreeing an average of thirty days shooting in the East and thirty-five in the Central and Western states. The curtailment reflects a marked decline in the waterfowl population and poor breeding conditions along the migratory routes.

CINCINNATI, July 31 -- The Giants' hitters, engaging the Reds in the series finale today, performed prodigious feats. Big Jawn Mize exploded a three-run homer, his thirty-first. Walker Cooper produced another three-run clout for his No. 24.

The alleged refusal of the Veterans Administration to advise a veteran upon his discharge from the Army that he was suffering: from tuberculosis resulted yesterday in the filing in Federal Court of a $200,000 damage suit against the Government.

ANKARA, Turkey, July 30 (Delayed) -- The lingering hopes of finding security through the United Nations have been shattered in Turkey and Greece by the Russian veto of the United States plan for a United Nations Balkan commission.
NEW DELHI, India, July 31 -- Hyderabad and Travancore, the two most powerful Princely States, will adhere to the Dominion of India, according to advices from those principalities today.

CHICAGO, July 31 -- The National Safety Council announced today that traffic accidents throughout the nation last month had taken 2,490 lives, or 5 per cent more than in June last year when 2,370 were killed. In the first half of 1947, however, fatalities due to automobile traffic totaled 14,480, still 9 per cent, below the 15,290 death figure in the same period a, year ago.

Though the height-of-the-season abundance of two summer favorites, peaches and corn, provides a pleasing highlight in this weekend's marketing, it is offset somewhat by an all too familiar story -- a general increase in the price of meats.
Housewives can expect no substantial reduction in processed food prices this year and probably not in 1948, Paul S. Willis, president of the Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., said yesterday.
Cotton textile activity has shown a marked decline in the last few days, it was learned yesterday, as the trade waits for the Aug. 8 crop report which will influence cotton staple prices.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The new United States Air Force dates the beginning of this country's air power to Civil War days. The Army of the Potomac used observation balloons to observe the movements of the Confederate Army.

DETROIT, Mich., July 31 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York brought his four-week combination political scouting and vacation trip through the West to a close tonight with a series of conferences with Republican leaders of Detroit and Wayne County.

The union recognition of the American Union of Telephone Workers, which switched from independent status to affiliation with the Congress of Industrial Organizations after the national phone strike last spring, has heen cancelled by the long-lines department of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Sava N. Kosanovitch, the Ambassador of Yugoslavia, held a press conference at the Embassy here today to present his just-published ninetyfive-page pamphlet entitled "The Case of Archbishop Stepinatz."

Young Negroes who have left Binghamton and Brooms County, N.Y., in search of jobs should return and fight for a place in community life at home, James Gitlitz, chairman of the Broome County Council declared yesterday. He participated in a panel discussion at the New School for Social Research sponsored by the State Commission Against Discrimination and the Summer WorKshop on Human Relations of New York University.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 31 -- Mrs. Edwin C. Longcope of Siwanoy, runner-up in the "open" championship of Fairfield and Westchester Counties which ended yesterday, returned to competition today. She played in the weekly oneday tournament staged by the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association at the Tamarack Country Club and won low gross honors by two sctrokes.
Substantially larger earnings over the corresponding period of last year were reported yesterday in the semi-annual statements of five large petroleum companies.

SECURITY COUNCIL United States offered to mediate in Indonesia at conclusion of indecisive debate on Australia's demand for cessation of hostilities and arbitration. Resumes discussion of Balkans at 11.30 A.M. and of Indonesia at 3 P.M. (Open).

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 31 -- With a sharp floor fight regarded inevitable over proposed changes in gambling laws, Governor Alfred E. Driscoll today called upon the State Constitutional Convention to sidetrack the problem for at least a year.

SEOUL, Korea, July 31 -- Abandonment of the United States position and acceptance of Soviet proposals regarding consultation with Korean political groups would "bring about a future Government of Korea predominantly of the People's Front," Maj. Gen. Albert E. Brown, chief of the United States delegation to the joint United States-Soviet commission, said today.

NATHANYA, Palestine, July 31 -- Incensed by the hanging by Jewish terrorists of two British army sergeants, whose bodies were found this morning, British military and police stormed into "off limits" Tel Aviv tonight and killed five Jews and wounded fifteen others.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 31 -- Presbyterian churches of California and Nevada were on record today as condemning action of California's "Little Dies Committee" -- a State legislative committee on un-American activities -- following their annual synod at San Jose.

DUBLIN, July 31 -- Premier Eamon de Valera stressed in an interview tonight that Ireland was lot disturbed at the prospect of being barred from the United Nations through the exercise of Russia's veto.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., July 31 -- The Oyster Bay Zoning Board of Appeals, of which E. Floyd Griffin is chairman, handed down today a decision approving a variance of zoning applied for by the Long Island University to enable the establishment of its college of arts and sciences at Hillwood, the estate of Mrs. Joseph E. Davies in Brookville.

A little late, but still as a relative Infant among military services, the United States Air Force celebrates its fortieth birthday today as an autonomous and equal member on the United States military team with the Army and the Navy. As it takes the air to celebrate its anniversary, the occasion merits a short look backward at air power's history and a long look forward to its future.

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Elizabeth will sail today for Southampton, England, from her West Fiftieth Street berth with 2,243 passengers, including representatives of the business and entertainment worlds.

From 10 A.M. today until late this afternoon, New York will be aware of the Air Force on its fortieth birthday. A succession of the latest planes, from fighters to giant cargo carriers, will fly in over the Battery and up over the center of the city as low as weather conditions will permit.

THIS morning's anthology -- "Travelers in Time," edited by Philip Van Doren Stern -- is an interesting collection of tales by various well-known writers about people who can foresee the future or review the past. People who play fast and loose with space and time. Fictions that truthfully assert that truth is stranger than fiction.

Industrial activity in Sweden is recovering well from the effects of the war, with some industries already ahead of pre-war volumes, Martin Edlund, president of Valskvarnskonernen, Uppsala, declared here in an interview yesterday.
Long Before Moses We have had a number of reminders lately of the variety of entertainment provided for the inhabitants of this town in our public parks maintained at the taxpayers' expense.
