Four subsidiaries of the United States Steel Corporation yesterday announced price increases ranging between $5 and $7.50 a ton on various steel products, according to The Associated Press.

VIENNA, July 31--The Yugoslav Government, through, its political representation here, charged the United States and Britain today with preparing armed intervention in Yugoslavia. It asserted that armed bands of terrorists were being trained by Americans and Britons in a displaced-persons' camp at Pongau, in the American zone, and the Strass, Wagna, Glasenbach and Leibnitz camps in the British zone.
Authorities of Nassau, in the Bahamas, are planning expansion of travel facilities operating from the American mainland, and are expecting a record tourist volume next season.

Many Brand Names Registered Manufacturers seeking to grain the benefits of the new trademark law are making application for registration of many thousands of brand names, New York attorneys said yesterday. Clarification of the right to obtain registration by one year's continuous use has been the biggest factor in the increased number of trademark applications, it was indicated.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Capt. N.H. Collisson said today that the record of government operation of the soft coal mines "refutes without question" any theory that maximum safety can only be accomplished at the expense of necessary production.

LONDON, July 31 -- At a Charles Creed fashion collection one expects to find a particularly dashing note of sophistication. Such a note is evident in his autumn collection of man-tailored velvets, grosgrain and brocade cocktail suits with dandy styled blouses in satin.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 31 -- Poland, which was cut off by the United States on July 23 from, receiving additional United States relief will suffer during the coming year from a "disastrously short crop of bread grains," the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization reported today.

Orders have been placed for more than $2,000,000 worth of new machinery In the $5,000,000 fiveyear expansion program of Russell, Burdsall Ward Bolt and Nut Company, Evans Ward, president, disclosed yesterday at the company's offices in Port Chester, N.Y. The company's steel consumption eventually will be increased about 20 per cent over present annual tonnage of 120,000.

ATLANTA, July 31 (AP) -- The Southeastern Conference's free and easy policy of granting football scholarships apparently was headed for the limbo today as Tulane announced it would abide by any code adopted at the next meeting of the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

PITTSBURG, July 31 -- Maj. Gen. William E. Kepner, commanding general of the technical division of Air Training Command at Scott Field, Ill., outlined here today four defenses against the atomic bomb. He addressed a luncheon meeting of the Aero Club of Pittsburgh and the Pittsburgh squadron of the Air Force Association.

Five persons were injured seriously yesterday morning when a fully loaded eight-ton coal truck caromed off a half-ton plumbing supply truck at 184th Street and Jerome Avenue, the Bronx, and rolled into an elevator pillar, pinning its driver behind the wheel.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange in July expanded to the largest total of the year despite the holidays: it also was the largest for a corresponding month since 1944. Sales crossed the million-share mark in every session but four.
A witness told a Navy general court-martial yesterday that the Japanese punished American prisoners of war in the Philippines for putting on a play.

The punishment of Douglas Chandler, convicted of treason in a federal court in Boston, will be life imprisonment, not death. This mitigation spoiled the dramatic effect of Chandler's speech to the court, in which he declared: "If I must die because I dared speak the truth, than let me die."

Undefeated and with a scow of 101/2--21/2, Alberic O'Kelly de Galway of Belgium finished first yesterday in the European zonal chess championship, according to a report from Hilversum, the Netherlands. The Belgian champion, whose steady play throughout kept him near the top of the standing, clinched his victory in the thirteenth and final round by winning from Charles Doerner of Luxembourg in a Caro-Kann defense lasting forty moves.

MUNICH, Germany, July 31 -- Counsel for Sally Zeve, displaced Lithuanian accused of misappropriating United States Army vehicles and illegally transferring them across the border, attempted today to establish that a precedent had been set for such transactions.
ALBANY, N. Y., July 31 (AP) -- Full assertion of "citizenship and leadership" by teachers was urged today by the executive director of the New York State Citizens Council.

ST. LOUIS, July 31 -- The Dodgers are becoming creatures of habit -- winning habits, that is. That seemingly unbreakable winning streak was extended to thirteen games today as they scored ninth-inning 2-1 triumph over the Cards before 21,873 cash client, largest week-day crowd of the season here.

The United States is replacing Europe as the medical center of the world, it was reported yesterday by Dr. Clarence E. de la Chapelle, associate dean of the New York University College of Medicine and director of its postgraduate division.
GENEVA, Switzerland, July 31 -- The United States has reached a tariff agreement with Norway, it was learned authoritatively today.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Price increases for bituminous coal and pig iron were chiefly responsible for an average rise of 0.2 per cent in primary market prices during the week ended July 26, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, United States Department of Labor.
LONDON, July 31--Princess Elizabeth and Lieut. Philip Mountbatten will be married Nov. 20 in Westminster Abbey, Buckingham Palace announced tonight.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- Mickey Haefner limited St. Louis to five hits as the Senators beat the Browns, 4 -- 1, tonight. It was Haefner's third straight victory and his sixth of the season.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 31 -- In a day of upsets, Mrs. Kay Stammers Menzies and Mrs. Betty Hilton of the English Wightman Cup team and Miss Dorothy Head of Alameda, Calif., were beaten today in the invitation tennis tournament at the Maidstone Club.

CHICAGO, July 31 -- G.R. Herberger, Minnesota department store executive, tomorrow will become president of Butler Brothers, $54,000,000 Chicago wholesale and store chain merchandising company. T.B. Freeman, who has been president since 1939, will become chairman of the board.

PORT-DE-BOUC, France, July 31 -- After another day of negotiations between French and British authorities, it was expected tonight that the French would try again to induce the 4,500 Jewish emigrants to land from the British ships remaining here.

BOSTON, July 31 (AP) -- Homers by Manager Lou Boudreau and Joe Gordon scored all Cleveland's runs today as the Indians swept a three-game stand by edging the Red Sox, 5 to 4, before a crowd of 5,879 at Fenway Park.

A revised contract agreement that calls for a 5 per cent wage increase and other benefits was signed yesterday by a negotiating committee for the Seafarers International Union, AFL, and the Atlantic and Gulf Coast Operators Association.

CHICAGO July 31 (AP)--Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follow. HOGS Salable hugs 6,000 head total 8,000: market slow: weights under 210 pounds opened steady to 25 cents lower general market on all butcher hogs around 23 cents lower: market...

Frederic Ullman Jr. has resigned, effective Aug. 9, as president of RKO Pathe, Inc., and will go to the West Coast as a producer of feature films for RKO, it was announced yesterday by Ned E. Depinet, vice chairman of the board of RKO.

Fire Commissioner Frank Quayle yesterday ordered two freighters carrying cargoes of ammonium nitrate to leave their Brooklyn piers without delay. He described their presence here as "a most serious fire and life hazard to the people of the City of New York."

The Baldwin Locomotive Works reported yesterday for the six months ended on June 30, a consolidated net income of $1,536,093 after charges and taxes, equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to 78 cents each on the 1,875,553 common shares outstand-

The battle for air freight begins in earnest today with the scheduled airlines cutting rates to an average of 20 cents a ton-mile, and Slick Airways, one of the largest independents, offering a wide classification of rates that average only 12 3/4 cents a tonmile.
Customs officials announced yesterday the arrest of a bonded truck driver in Brooklyn charged with pilfering public stores merchandise in the custody of the Customs Service.
PALO ALTO, Calif., July 31 (AP) -- A vaccine which makes cotton rats immune to infantile paralysis was announced today by a group of Stanford University medical and chemical researchers.
PHILADELPHIA, July 31 (AP) -- Stifling a last-inning spurt, the Athletics today beat the White Sox, 3 -- 2, on an eleven-hit attack led by Elmer Valo and Pete Suder with triples.

BATAVIA, Java, July 31 (AP) -- The scorched, dead city of Malang, seat of the Indonesian Republic's Parliament, fell to the Dutch today, the Netherlands Army announced, and other Dutch columns raced toward the blazing town of Chilachap, chief Republican port on the south Java coast.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 31 -- In a demonstration without parallel in state political history, the Ohio Republican organization brought together tonight 1,300 key members of the party ranging from precinct worker to Governor, to urge Senator Robert A. Taft to run for the Presidency.

The seasonal slump to commercial, industrial and agricultural loans of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System, which appeared to have been arrested last week, now seems to have been definitely halted, according to the latest figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain, July 31 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco arrived in San Sebastian tonight for a brief stay before going on to a vacation in his native Galicia.

LOS ANGELES, July 31 -- One of the current theatre's most-talkedof projects, Bertholt Brecht's "Galileo," a dramatic biography of the seventeenth-century scientist, had its premiere last night under the auspices of John Houseman's Pelican Productions, with Charles Laughton in the starring role.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 31 (AP) -- State Corporations Commissioner Edwin M. Daugherty announced today that the Tucker Corporation, which plans to make a new type of automobile, has been refused permission to sell stock in California.

Investment houses were pleased yesterday with the success registered by the Morgan StanleyHarriman, Ripley syndicate in widening the market for J.P. Stevens Co.'s stock to the extent of 200,000 shares. Although the total market supply of this stock is still only a small fraction of the textile manufacturer's capitalization -- mostly family-held -- it is estimated that yesterday's offering about doubled the pre-existent off-board supply, without affecting adversely the price level.

When George Abbott is drafted to stage a show other than his own, rest assured the assignment intrigues him -- not from a monetary standpoint, either. Otherwise, his services would not be available. Yesterday he confirmed a report that he agreed to handle the direction and make himself generally useful in behalf of "High Button Shoes," the musical in which Phil Silvers will appear for Monte Proser and Joseph Kipness.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The Air Force, which is now climbing out of the demobilization tailspin, is considerably short of its established minimum of men, aircraft and other essentials of a fighting air arm, but its leaders consider that what they do have is good and potentially strong.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 31 -- Samuel Goldwyn has acquired screen tights to "Secrets," an English play by Rudolph Besier and May Edgington first staged in 1922, and has engaged Borden Chase to prepare a new adaptation of the property as a vehicle for Teresa Wright and Dana Andrews, it was learned today.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture said tonight meat prices may come down in the fall and winter, but the amount will be governed largely by consumers themselves.

Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander and Investigation, Commissioner John M. Murtagh are to testify today before the Queens County Grand Jury inquiring into charges by Emetia Polizio, Astoria gambler, that Queens policemen of high and low rank have been extorting protection money from Queens bookmakers.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Sir John Boyd Orr, in his final annual report as Director General of the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, today made a strong appeal for a world food council and a world food program as about the last hope for one world.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The highest military authorities were thrown into "concern and apprehension" when civilian officials granted the Kaiser-Hughes experimental flying boat contract at the most critical period of the war, Robert A. Lovett, Under-Secretary of State, asserted yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 31 (AP) -- A shirt-sleeved crowd of 14,520 persons, using programs and folded newspapers to stir up local breezes in humid air, today greeted a return of racing to this resort's $4,000,000 horse stadium.

BOSTON, July 31 (AP) -- Weston Adams' Gay Moonbeam today ended the winning streak of H.R. Carr's Gray Star, defeating the gray filly by a length and a, quarter with Brown Hotel Stable's Buzzaround an equal distance farther back at Suffolk Downs.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, July 31 -- Governor Dewey's failure to appoint a co-ordinator of safety programs in the state, despite repeated urgings, was designated as hampering measures to curb accidents on the highways today at the opening of the twenty-fourth anniversary meeting of the New York State Automobile Dealers here.

CHICAGO, July 31 -- First reports of actual damage to the corn crop from hot and dry weather were received today from parts of South Dakota, Texas and Oklahoma. They started a buying movement that swept the new crop months up as much as 7 7/6 cents from yesterday's finish, or within 18 cent of the permissible limit for one day's upturn.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 1 -- Subject to certain conditions, the Securities and Exchange Commission today endorsed the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation's plan for complying with Section 11 (E) of the Holding Company Act as fair and necessary.

BOSTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Seven Hearts, Brown Hotel Stables classy campaigner, made his 1947 debut today and romped to an easy threelength victory over Oak Hill Stables' Bras Teddy in the feature race at Suffolk Downs.

ALBANY, Aug. 1 -- The State Controller's Office held today that New York and other cities, in preparing their 1948 budgets, may give effect therein to anticipated continuation next year of the $25,500,000 additional emergency state aid granted in 1947 to meet emergency teacher pay increases.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 1 -- Freedom of the press in the United States and Great Britain eixsts for only a few persons who possess the tens of millions of dollars essential to establish a large newspaper capable of survival, Alexander P. Morozov, Russian representative, told the Social Committee of the United Nations Economic and Social Council today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 1 -- The progress of democracy in Latin America is endangered by the kind of primitive economy that leaves two-thirds of the total population undernourished, Dr. Hernan Santa Cruz, Chilean delegate, today told the United Nations Economic and Social Council.

New York's inner harbor was clear of ammonium nitrate ships yesterday. One freighter sailed for European ports without picking up her general cargo and a second vessel remained anchored safely in Gravesend Bay after the Fire Department ordered her to leave a Brooklyn dock.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., Aug. 1 -- Little change was reflected in the level of business in the Pittsburgh district last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research of the University of Pittsburgh. There were small decreases in industrial production and originating shipments, but the declines were offset by a moderate gain in trade.

This is the season when the salt sticks in the salt-cellar, when the bread acquires a delicate green fuzz almost overnight, when the cookies turn limp and soft in the cooky tin. To revive an old phrase, the cause of this havoc in the kitchen is not the heat, but the humidity.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Howard Hughes said tonight that he would leave here Monday on a two-day flight to Washington, in time to appear before the Senate War Investigating Subcommittee Wednesday.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Aug. 1 -- Away on Its annual cruise, the fleet of the New York Yacht Club set sail from the breakwater here tonight. It was an augmented fleet, and some of the prizes in competition are more than one hundred years old. They are historical as well as coveted.

PARIS, Aug. 1 -- After two weeks of laborious negotiations, the French Confederation of Labor [CGT] today signed with the French Employers Association an accord for the revision of wages and prices. They said the agreement was aimed at putting an end to the steady succession of social conflicts that have been disrupting the French economy.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Soft coal production under the shortened work day of the new wage agreement has declined about 8 to 10 per cent, the National Coal Association estimated today on the basis of preliminary data. The association said, however, it was still too early to make an accurate comparison of output under the new and the old contracts.

Broadcast Music, Inc., has purchased all the capital stock of Associated Music Publishers, Inc., from the Associated-Muzak Corporation, it was announced yesterday in a joint statement by Carl Haverlin, president of BMI, and Harry Houghton, president of Associated-Muzak.

Puerto Ricans, seeking work, are arriving by plane and ship at the rate of more than 2,000 a month to augment the estimated 600,000 already here. The situation is causing the New York City authorities increasing concern because of the housing, health and other problems involved.

Supreme Court Justice Thomas A. Aurelio signed yesterday an order requiring Michael F. Sassi, Republican leader of the Second Assembly District, East, to show cause why there should not be a recount of the protested, blank and void primary election ballots in the Eleventh Election District of that Assembly District.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 1 -- Thirtythree more Jews were injured in Tel Aviv riots this afternoon during and after the funeral procession of the five who were killed yesterday in reprisal by incensed Britons for the hanging of two British sergeants.

DETROIT, Aug. 1 -- Fighting against time, negotiators for the United Automobile Workers and the Ford Motor Company agreed after a fruitless two-hour session today to meet again tomorrow morning, a few hours before the union is due to pass judgment on a national Ford strike scheduled to begin Tuesday.

TYLER, Tex., Aug. 1 (AP) -- The University of Michigan twice smashed the American record for the 300-meter medley relay tonight as three champions repeated in opening events of the national A. A.U. swimming and diving meet.

Three bricklayers, a father, his brother and his son, were killed yesterday afternoon when their scaffold broke atop a 170-foot chimney at North Hempstead Turnpike and 190th Street, Bayside, Queens, and they plunged to the bottom of the giant chimney.

Old Song Resung When this column, the other day, mentioned how some sardonic Guards of ficer on Lord Cornwallis' staff at Yorktown ordered the band to play a popular tune of the moment, "The World Turned Upside Down," for the surrender to the Continentals, it called to mind that respected London Street, the Old Kent Road, and a public house there.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Aug. 1 -- The United Nations Security Council, by an 8-to-0 vote, called on the Netherlands and the Indonesian Governments today to "cease hostilities forthwith" and to "settle their disputes by arbitration or by other peaceful means."

Young people of different races, colors and creeds, in an effort to unite the nation in the face of a world crisis, resolved yesterday at a session of the Encampment for Citizenship, at the Fieldston School, Riverdale, the Bronx, to carry back to their homes a program of national unity built on social justice.

A trend toward increased consumer preference for well-known whisky brands and a recession in demand for private brands as the Industry moves out of a period of post-war distribution uncertainty was noted in liquor circles yesterday.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug 1 (AP) -- High Trend, owned and trained by A. F. East, won the Sea Spray purse today at the Atlantic City track.

Ken R. DycK was appointed program head of the National Broadcasting Company yesterday in a move which is expected to result in greater emphasis on public-service programming by NBC and a review of the network's policies on censorship of programs.

LINCOLN, Neb., Aug. 1 -- The discovery in Nebraska of the fossilized bones of a marsupial sabertooth, a tiger-like animal, which lived in the Western Hemisphere about 1,000,000 years ago just before the Ice Age, was announced today by the University of Nebraska Museum.

Power to bring court actions against landlords allegedly violating the Federal rent law will not be given to the city's new Temporary Rent Control Commission, Joseph T.Sharkey, vice chairman and majority leader in the City Council, said yesterday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1 -- Corn prices continued on the upgrade on the Board of Trade today, all deliveries selling at a new seasonal high, with December and No. 2 white cash corn at a new record peak. Prof-taking developed in futures on the bulge and the market reacted late in the day.
D. L. Bogart, affiliated with American Airlines in various sales capacities for the past eight years, has been appointed cargo sales supervisor for the New York district.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Two new members and the general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board began functioning today with an exhortation to labor and management to recognize each others rights. They also urged the two parties in the industrial picture to be sensitive at all times to the needs and rights ou the public.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 1 -- Boris Morros and William Le Baron, United Artists producers, today announced the purchase of "The Woman of a Hundred Faces," a screen story by Thomas Mann, Louis Bromfield and Maximilian Ilyin, dealing with a European model who was painted by 100 different artists.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 1 -- Acting in accordance with authorizations received from the holders of 9,500 shares of preferred stock, a protective committee submitted to the Securities and Exchange Commission today a plan for "a prompt, orderly and economical satisfaction of the claims of the International Hydro-electric System's debenture-holders and preferred stockholders and the distribution to its class A stockholders of its remaining assets."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Studies of the recently opened collection of Lincoln papers showed today that a campaign to curry the favor of James Gordon Bennett, owner of the old New York Herald, was begun by the Civil War President's advisers in 1860.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Aug. 1 -- Duquesne Light Company of Pittsburgh filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering $75,000,000 of first mortgage bonds, series due on Aug. 1, 1977, which are to be offered for sale at competitive bidding.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Early Wynn limited the White Sox to seven hits in scoring his twelfth victory of the season, 8-1, for the Senators tonight. It marked Washington's first triumph over Chicago in seven games here this year. Washington blasted Joe Haynes for six runs in the first four innings and took an 8-0 lead with two more runs off Bob Gillespie.

The protested Dodger-Cardinal game of July 20 will be replayed at Ebbets Field on Monday night, Aug. 18, with the entire proceeds going to the Brooklyn War Memorial Fund, it was announced yesterday by Branch Rickey, president of the Brooklyn Baseball Club.

The gold and short-term dollar assets now available to foreign countries as a whole, excluding Russia, amount to some $18,000,000,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York points out in the current issue of its Monthly Review, issued today.

Federal Judge Vincent L. Leibell denied yesterday a motion by Randolph Phillips, a stockholder, for a preliminary injunction to restrain directors of the United Corporation from taking any steps to transform the utility holding company into an investment company in accordance with a resolution adopted by stockholders on April 30.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange turned easier yesterday and at the close were 28 to 46 points below Thursday's final level.

PARIS, Aug. 1 -- The committee for European economic cooperation, called into being by the Marshall plan, tackled today the basic and ticklish issue of European selfhelp through a reduction of barriers to the movement of goods and labor across frontiers.

A world food council and a world food program will be on the agenda of U. N.'s Food and Agriculture Organization at a fifty-nation meeting which will convene in Geneva three weeks from Monday. A newspaper reader might excusably be puzzled as to how FAO fits into the vast picture of the world's needs.
Another letter was sent out yesterday to stockholders of the Park-Murray Building at 11 Park Place concerning the proposed sale of the property for $1,100,000.

AFTER reading these two books I felt as If I had just spent a season in -- I was going to say Hell, but a stronger expression would be to say a season in a Nazi concentration camp. That is the subject of both books. One, David Rousset's "The Other Kingdom,"* is a personal testament and a kind of philosophical essay on the nature and consequences of Nazi sadism.

This country cannot provide the industries of the entire world with steel, Ernest T. Weir, chairman of the board of National Steel Corporation, declared in an interview prior to his sailing for Europe on the Queen Elizabeth yesterday. European steel output must be raised to meet the deficiencies now faced by export buyers, he emphasized.

BATAVIA, Java, Aug. 1 (AP) -- The Indonesian supreme command declared the Republican capital of Jogjakarta and surrounding districts a military area today and ordered it prepared for a last-ditch stand in the event of a Dutch attack, the Jogjakarta radio announced.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I note with real satisfaction your coverage of news items regarding mass X-ray programs. Many do not realize how important this examination is as a means of detection and therefore a valuable method for prevention of tuberculosis.

PITTSBURGH, Augr 1 -- Petermined to hold their position at the head of the pack that is frantically pursuing the Dodgers, the Giants tonight toppled the Pirates, 2 to 1, in the opener of a fivegame series that brought no enc of misery to a crowd of 28,885.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: If the city government and the real estate interests are willing to approach the problem of achieving self-sustaining transit facilities, the citizens of New York would undoubtedly be wiling to cooperate with a reasonable and honest proposal.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 1 -- The last member of the British Wigntman Cup team was eliminated from the women's invitation tennis tournament at the Maidstone Club today.

Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., Republican, from Massachusetts, sailed on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Elizabeth yesterday to investigate the workings of the State Department's information program in several European countries.

GENEVA, Aug. 1--The British Government has informed the United States that it cannot sign the multilateral tariff agreement, now nearing completion at the Geneva trade conference, without special exemption from the projected ban on discriminatory import controls.

GENEVA, Switzerland, Aug. 1 -- The subcommittee set up by the United Nations Special Committee 3f Inquiry on Palestine to investigate displaced persons camps laid out today a provisional itinerary of an eight-day flying visit to some of the largest camps in Germany and Austria.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1 -- Plans for marketing $105,000,000 in Chicago Transit Authority bonds were jolted today by the withdrawal from the underwriting syndicate of investment bankers who had been counted on to handle about $30,000,000 of the issue.

The string of successes the Yankees have fashioned against the Indians was snapped yesterday. Cleveland pushed across the decisive tally of a 4-3 game in the opening half of the ninth inning and then held firm against a determined counter-attack by the American League pace-setters.

A 25-year-old war veteran who had completed satisfactorily all but a few hours of a six-month probationary period as a city policeman has been dismissed from the department because of a tumor that may necessitate amputation of his left leg, it became known yesterday.

Mayor O'Dwyer warned yesterday that establishment of the United Nations world capital here may be endangered if bids for construction of the center -- estimated to cost $70,000,000 -- prove to be "unconscionably high."

NEWARK, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Les Mueller's pitching and batting were even too much for the Montreal "jinx" over Newark to withstand and the bespectacled righthander hurled the Bears to a 4-3 triumph tonight, their first in the last eleven meetings with the league leaders.
Two witnesses told a Navy general court martial yesterday that some of the acts of Chief Signalnan Harold E. Hirshberg aided the men in his section in Japanese prison camps in the Philippines.

Robert F. Wagner Jr., Cornmissioner of Housing and Buildings announced yesterday the dismissal of charges brought against Joseph F. Taggard, an assistant civil engineer in the department, after an investigation by Investigation Commissioner John M. Murtagh.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., Aug. 1 (AP) -- Hollywood Park will close a highly successful fifty-day meeting tomorrow with the $50,000 added Sunset Handicap, and the big question is whether Cover Up can travel a mile and five-eighths carrying 122 pounds and whip eight rivals.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The State Department said today that in offering its good offices to the Netherlands for a solution of the Indonesian conflict the United States was trying to make it possible for negotiations to be reopened between the Netherlands Government and the Republic of Indonesia.

DETROIT, Aug. 1--Price Increases of 2 to 6 per cent on Chevrolet, Pontiac, Oldsmobile, Buick and Cadillac passenger cars and Chevrolet trucks were announced "reluctantly" today by the General Motors Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The largest wheat acreage goal in recent years, 75,000,000 acres, was announced today for 1948 by the Department of Agriculture in a continued effort to cut down the world food shortage. If production follows the pattern of recent years, this goal may give the United States another record wheat crop.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 1 -- It has been many a year since form held up as well as it did today in the first and second rounds of the Metropolitan amateur golf championship at the Meadow Brook Club, scene of the first national Women's championship in 1895.

A handyman, his wife and their three small children, who had spent more than a week wandering about the city after their eviction from a cold-water flat, received aid yesterday after two radio patrolmen had found them in Prospect Park, Brooklyn.

John William Frick, 27 years old, of Redwood City, Calif., leaped to his death at 10:10 o'clock last night from a terrace outside the Starlight Roof Restaurant on the eighteenth floor of the WaldorfAstoria Hotel. His body landed on the east side of Park Avenue, about twenty-five feet north of Forty-ninth Street.

ROME, Aug. 1 -- Yesterday's ratification by the Constituent Assembly of the Italian peace treaty caused some extreme Rightist newspapers such as Ora d'Italia to appear today with heavy black borders around their front pages as a sign of mourning.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Elliott Roosevelt, as a colonel, caused a wartime photo-reconnaissane plane contract to be given to Howard Hughes over the combined objections of a major general in charge of such procurement and of the chief of air staff, the Senate War Investigating Subcommittee was told today.

The second volume of Robert Glass Cleland's history of California, entitled "California in Our Time, 1900-1940," will be published by Knopf Aug. 21. The book covers the spectacular growth of California in the present century, its politics, graft, reforms, the Los Angeles boom and many other topics.

Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday signed, after a brief public hearing in his office at City Hall, the local law requiring commercial garages and parking lots to operate under licenses and regulations of the Department of Licenses. Immediately afterward License Commissioner Benjamin Fielding announced that applications for licenses would te received beginning Sept. 1, with all garages and parking lots affected by the new law required to have licenses by Oct. 1.

The proposal for a Transit Authority to take over the municipal lines and operate them at a selfsustaining fare was renewed yesterday by Paul Windels, chairman of the Citizens Transit Commission. The proposal calls for earmarking all transit revenues in excess of debt service, operating and maintenance costs for new construction and rehabilitation of transit facilities.
CHICAGO, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Despite some uneasiness in pivotal industrial issues, the stock market advanced again yesterday. Only irregularly higher prices were recorded, however, to put the composite rate up 0.48 point. Business on the Stock Exchange slumped to the smallest in a month as transfers only reached 770,000 shares, compared with 840,000 shares on Thursday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- At the request of Senator Bushfield the Senate Small Business Committee has begun an inquiry into why the lard supply is reported to be 40,000,000 pounds more than normal.

The third and largest of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company's new apartment developments opened yesterday when two families moved into Stuyvesant Town. Among more than 110,000 applicants, these were the first chosen.

Further reductions in importers prices of hand-woven Oriental rugs, which have dropped approximately 25 per cent since the beginning of the year, were predicted yesterday by a buyer for one of the city's leading quality homefurnishings stores.

AT SEA IN TUAMOTU ARCHIPBLAGO, July 30 (By Wireless; delayed) -- At dawn today the Kon-Tiki raft expedition sighted land for the first time since we left Callao, Peru, three months and a day ago, to prove that a pre-Incan race of blond civilizers could have drifted on rafts from Peru to Polynesia some 1,500 years ago.
Just a breeze -- that's all the $4,000 Parade Girl purse was for E. P. Taylor's 2-year-old filly Spats at Jamaica yesterday.

ANKARA, Turkey, July 31 (Delayed) -- The Turkish Government is preparing to apply to the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development for a loan that may be as high as $400,000,000 for the development of her civilian economy, authoritative sources said here today.

ROME, Aug. 1 -- The Cabinet decided today to devalue the lira by 55 per cent, raising the official dollar exchange rate from 225 to 350. On the free [black] market, the dollar at present is quoted at about 640 lire. The exchange rate of other foreign currencies was increased accordingly.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 1 -- The policy deadlock between Mary Pickford and Charles Chaplin, coowners of the United Artists Distribution Corporation, was broken last night when the partners agreed on the election of Bradwell Sears as the new president of United Artists.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 1 Sam Match's hour of glory ended today in the semi-finals of the Southampton invitation tennis tournament at the Meadow Club.

John P. Redmond, president of the International Association of Firefighters, praised the morale of the members of the New York City Fire Department at the installation yesterday of officers of the Uniformed Firemen's Association in their headquarters at 63 Park Row.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- With retrenchment as the objective, the Veterans Administration announced today a restudy of plans for all except nine of the seventy hospitals in its $772,702,845 construction program.

BUDAPEST, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Paul Ruedemann, American director of the American-Hungarian Oil Company (MAORT), said today that the Hungarian Government had issued a decree reserving to itself almost complete control of the company.

Devotion to duty was more compelling than immediate possession of a $300 Contax camera to John Powers of 1604 Jesup Avenue, the Bronx. Mr. Powers was entitled yesterday to pick up at Police Headquarters the camera he had found on a bench in Riverside Park at 181st Street last March 15.

Frederick G. Reinicke, Commissioner of Marine and Aviation, as a closing witness yesterday in the trial of his former deputy, I. James Brody, and James V. Auditore for conspiracy and accepting unlawful fees in the rental of city piers, completely contradicted their previous testimony.

The "cost" of the economy practiced by Congress on the State Department's Information and Cultural Program has now been partially spelled out by Assistant Secretary William Benton. That part of the program dealing with Russia is to be continued -- the magazine "Amerika" and the broadcasts.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The Blind and the aged may soon look forward to some of the home-service benefits which New York alone, among the cities, provides for children under the Federal-state program of aid to dependent children.

LONDON, Aug. 1--In a lovely reconstructed Sheridan house that two years ago was a badly blitzed shell, Hardy Amies yesterday showed a beautiful and feminine collection of round-the-clock autumn clothes.

Mayor O'Dwyer received yesterday what was said to be the first World War II Victory Medal given in this area. It was presented to him by Leo Price, commander of the New York State Department of the Jewish War Veterans organization.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Fourteen of the nation's top flight 3year-old fillies were named today to go postward at Washington Park tomorrow in the $29,450 Artful Handicap, which promises to be a sensational seven-furlong race.

LONDON, Aug. 1 -- A general appeal to organized labor to work longer hours and thus help Great Britain out of her present economic crisis was made by the Socialist Government to trade union leaders here today. Herbert S. Morrison, Lord President of the Council, brought the heads of the nation's Trades Union Congress into consultation at the Ministry of Labor.
Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores in July showed an increase of 10 per cent over the same month a year ago, according to the monthly survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

BRESLAU, Poland, Aug. 1 -- Nothing out tof the ordinary happened in Breslau today, but what happens every day in this former German city is so extraordinary that it is always one of the best revival stories in Europe. Before the war this was the second city in Prussia, an important commercial and industrial center with a population of nearly 800,000.

Dr. Abba Hillel Silver, chairman of the American Zionist Emergency Council, parent body of all official Zionist groups in the United States, denounced yesterday the terrorist execution of two British sergeants, but at the same time attributed the crisis in Palestine to the provocative acts of the British Government.

Leading paint manufacturers are planning heavily increased news paper advertising schedules in the next twelve months to increase annual sales from a normal level of $750,000,000 to a 1948 level of $1,000,000,000, spokesmen disclosed here yesterday.

BOSTON, Aug 1 (AP) -- Freddie Hutchinson pitched and batted the Tigers to a 3-1 victory over the Red Sox tonight before a crowd of 32,286. The defeat left Boston twelve games in back of the leading Yankees and only a half game ahead of the third-place Tigers.

PARIS, Aug. 1 -- A marked forward thrust on the right side is an important new trend in winter hats. It is a definite reaction from hats of past seasons worn straight off the face. Although still uncovered, the brow is partly in shadow, shadow.

ATHENS, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Dwight Griswold, chairman of the United States aid mission to Greece, said today "we expect to be out of Greece within a year and we are not expecting to build American influence in Greece or obtain commercial interests here."

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, July 31 (Delayed) -- A tobacco tin planted in gale-packed snow and marked by a willow wand on the 20,270foot South Peak of Mount McKinley attests the climax of one of the most daring Alaskan mountain -climbing adventures in thirtyseven years.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 1 -- Vociferous endorsement of the Stratton bill to permit entrance into the United States for each of the next four years of 100,000 displaced persons was expressed by the International Convention of the Disciples of Christ today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- President Truman motored this afternoon to "Shangri-la," the Presidential retreat in the Catoctin Mountains, of Maryland, about sixty-five miles from here for what was described at the White House as "a week-end of loafing and resting."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Signaling systems and devices, of home and foreign design, were prominent among the 420 inventions on Which patents were issued this week by the United States Patent Office.

City College's student body baa been split into three factions and is prepared for a long struggle that may last until next summer. The split was precipitated yesterday at noon with the installation of a phonograph and loudspeaker in the college cafeteria, at 139th Street and Convent Avenue.

A total of 5,724 displaced persons in the American zone of Germany are students in schools conducted by the Organization for Rehabilitation Through Training, Mrs. Cylvia K. Margulies, director of the World ORT Union program in Austria, declared yesterday.

Trade Here Slowed Down Retail trade this week was a little soft as hot, humid weather slowed down business, resulting in but a slight increase. The grain for department stores was put at about 2 per cent over the like week of 1946.

SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain, Aug. 1 -- Spain raised the price of bread today because her chief supporter. Argentina, has raised the price of wheat. The official announcement said that the price rise was necessary because the countries supplying Spain had raised their prices.

No new developments were reported yesterday in the thirtyseven-day-old strike of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, CIO, against operators of nineteen major shipyards on the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEWYORK TIMES: The new directives given to General Clay in Germany can only be understood as the establishment of a priority to the revival of Germany's heavy Industry. Yet even the advantage of using the Reich's industrial potential for the reconstruction of western Europe makes this move surprising.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The Foreman's Association of America challenged the constitutionality of the Taft-Hartley Act in Federal Court today. It asserted that the National Labor Relations Board was illegally dismissing litigation brought by the association.

Not long ago there were long parallel lines of small, green spikes across the brown soil. Week by week the corn pushed higher and unfurled long pointed leaves. The staccato song of the tractor echoed from fields and patient horses pulling cultivators plodded back and forth stirring the mellow earth.

The case of Indonesia, brought before the Security Council by Australia and India, has resulted in the first cease-firing order that the United Nations has issued. The precedent thus established is by far more important than the American offer of mediation -- or as the State Department preferred to call it of "good offices."

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 1 -- A series of detailed proposals for international control of all phases of atomic production, starting when uranium and thorium ores are taken from the ground, were made public today by five working groups of the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission.

ST. PAUL. Minn., Aug. 1 (AP) -- An iron game that approached perfection rocketed Fred Haas Jr. of New Orleans, unattached professional, to a six-under-par 66 and a thirty-six-hole total of 135 in the St. Paul open golf tournament today.

Although they are in sympathy with the aims of the National Retail Dry Goods Association in achieving better standards for sizing of women's apparel, New York dress manufacturers expressed doubt yesterday that nondeviating specifications could be achieved either for sizes in competing price lines, or for the industry as a whole.

Joseph M. Proskauer, president of the American Jewish Committee, in a cable sent last night to the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine, now in Geneva, denounced the killing of the two British sergeants. "These acts of violence have their origin in the violation by Great Britain of the mandate by its issuance of the MacDonald White Paper," he added.

The future policy of the United States Air Force was discussed yesterday by Lieut. Gen. Hoyt S. Vandenberg, deputy commander of the Army Air Forces, at an Air Force fortieth birthday luncheon under the auspices of the Wings Club and other organizations at the Biltmore Hotel.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 1 (AP) -- It was all work and no play again today for Ike Williams and Bob Montgomery. The dual lightweight champions honed for their finest edge in Monday night's fight that will settle the long argument as to which is the rightful wearer of the crown.

Steel Earnings On the basis of reports to date from steel companies with 83 per cent of the industry's productive capacity, it is evident that earnings for the second quarter of 1947 will be approximately 24 per cent below those for the first quarter, according to a statistical study by Steel Magazine.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The First Amendment to the Constitution provides that "Congress shall make, no law respecting the establishment of religion or prohibiting the free exercise thereof."

JERUSALEM, Aug. 1 -- While the Holy Land once more is being made into an unholy battleground, Palestine's Zionist leadership steeled itself today to take one more step toward open warfare with the terrorist forces. The cessation of terrorism is an "inexorable national necessity," an assembly of community leaders declared.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Aug. 1 (AP)--Keeneland Park's yearling prices stood today as the third highest of all time with a $6,826 average and marked the thoroughbred breeding industry as profitable regardless of the 31 per cent drop from, last year's record average.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Aug. 1 -- Nearly a. hundred working newspapermen from eight states heard a plea tonight from Kent Cooper, executive director of the Associated Press, that they work toward preventing any Government control of the press in the United States.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Secretary of State Marshall will attend the Inter-American Conference at Rio de Janeiro on Aug. 15 for the negotiation of a hemisphere treaty of mutual defense, it was definitely announced today. Secretary Marshall will be chairman of the United States delegation.

A public service is being' performed by the Automobile Club of New York and Secretary Elliot of the Automobile Old Timers in calling attention to obscure traffic lights, bad sign posting and difficulties of parkway access in the city. Present conditions of congestion already impose a heavy strain on the New York driver.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 1 (AP) -- The Cardinals defeated the Phillies, 6-1, tonight. Murry Dickson helped to win his own grame by smashing out a fifth-inning single that sent home a run and put St. Louis in front. Whitey Kurowski clinched the victory over Schoolboy Rowe with two homers that accounted for four runs.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. T., Aug. 1 -- Legislation to "outlaw unscrupulous individuals and dealers now preying upon the public" by selling slightly used cars at exorbitant prices was urged today by the New York State Automobile Dealers here.

Bob Feller, Cleveland's ace right hander, leveled a blistering broadside yesterday at "several baseball big-wigs" whom he accused of dictating "how, when and where a professional ball player shall earn his money," The United Press reports. Without mentioning specific names, the Indian fire-baller vigorously rapped the knuckles of officials responsible for the currently -enforced post-season exhibition game rule restricting appearances of players after the regular season is ended.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Aug, 1 (AP) -- New York State's Legionnaires were told today that public apathy toward national preparedness might result in "the planned registration of every citizen of the United States."

The development of a post-waR program to expand Egypt's industrial facilities is taking shape rapidly, with American equipment and American technical experts cast in a key role, it was asserted yesterday by Mamdouh Bey Riaz, Egyptian Minister of Commerce and Industry, now in New York as a special delegate to the Security Council of the United Nations.

SPRING VALLEY, N.Y., Aug. 1 -- What commuters are calling the nation's first organized strike against a common carrier started today as residents of this area who work and study in New York resorted to car pools and rail transportation to avoid using two bus lines that have increased fares.

So far as the duck huntera are concerned, the blow has fallen, and the drastic cut in the bag limits and season lengths which have been threatened for several months no longer constitute a threat but a fact.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Edward Morris, weighing nine pounds and still less than twenty-four hours old at this writing, was the pride of the new Georgetown University Hospital today.

Declaring that the test of the United Nations will be its ability to prevent war, the Church Peace Union and the World Alliance for International Friendship through the Churches sent out a communication this week to church bodies throughout the country containing suggestions for the observance of United Nations Week, September 14 --20, by the churches and other religious organizations.

ALBANY, Aug. 1 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey returned to his desk today apparently well pleased with the results of his 7,000-mile vacation and political tour through the West, which apparently has increased his lead over rival aspirants for the Republican Presidential nomination.

The late Franklin D. Roosevelt, already personified on the screen, will be depicted on the stage in the fall in "The Bridge," an original play by Jack Preston. The producers of the venture, which is said to have movie money behind it, are Martin Mooney and Roger Rogers.

LONDON, Aug. 1 -- After further all-around declines at the opening the stock markets here today staged a rally in the late trading. In addition to bear covering -- the account ends on next Tuesday -- there was investment support at lower levels, particularly in the leaders of the shipping and chain stores groups.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Holders of certain secured claims against the New Haven Railroad will receive $8,511,731 in cash, to cover accrued but unpaid interest from July 1, 1943, to July 1, 1947, under a proposal filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission today by the railroad's reorganization committee.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- The Central Railroad of New Jersey, in bankruptcy, today notified the Interstate Commerce Commission it is willing to accept a reorganization plan submitted by three bondholder groups "as a starting point" for such reorganization.

One of the youngest generals in the Army, Maj. Gen. Robert T. Frederick, will take up his duties shortly as Army Ground Force Observer at the Air University at Maxwell Field, Ala. This institution is essentially a coordinating body for the education of the whole post-war air forces of the United States.

A FEW yards from the top of the High Street in Hardy's Dorchester (better known as Casterbridge) sits a statue of the town's great man, looking like a wizened version of Rodin's "The Thinker," erect in a rumpled sack suit, quietly attentive, pondering by the side of the road.
DETROIT, Aug. 2 -- Automobile circles wondered today whether a 2 to 6 per cent increase in car prices by the General Motors Corporation was the beginning of a new price spiral in the industry.

FEETNOTE -- The pedal extremes are in the city rather than the country. The Swedes, a statistically minded people, have just completed a foot survey in their country and come up with the observation that inhabitants of large cities have bigger feet than the rural population.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The Taft-Hartley act will not be fully operative until three weeks from now, but some of organized labor's defensive tactics already are clearly discernible.

ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 1 (Delayed) -- Nine Turkish newspaper men from Ankara, Istanbul and Smyrna will go on trial at Smyrna on Aug. 13 on the charge of having published statements that the elections to the National Assembly were fraudulent.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- One of its final steps before adjournment largely overlooked in the avalanche of last-minute legislation was the stamp of approval Congress placed upon the creation, for the first time in American history of an effective world-wide American intelligence service of its own.

A group of Italian artists has replied to a recent attack by the National Better Business Bureau, which asserted that Americans were being "stuck" with customs charges on unordered etchings sent from Genoa, it was learned yesterday.

Having been deprived of income tax reduction for 1947 through exercise of the President's veto power, we naturally conjecture as to the prospects for tax relief in 1948. In an election year we must expect politics to influence such legislation to an even greater extent than it did in the current year.

VACATIONS on credit, with twelve months to pay, are to be offered beginning Sept. 1 by all the Western railroads and most of the Eastern lines. The plan, a simplified version of the short-term personal loans available at commercial banks, permits the vacationist to borrow enough money to pay for clothes, holiday equipment, luggage, hotel accommodations and other ordinary expenses incidental to his trip, as well as for his rail transportation.

KARL ESKELUND, author of the lively, provocative "My Chinese Wife," introduces us this time to his father, Niels Eskelund -- a young dentist in Denmark after the first World War who, desperately bored with his routine life, leaves his country for the allure of distant Siam.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The Federal Works Agency reported the approval today of routes for a national system of interstate highways to be begun by states with Federal aid as part of a $3,000,000,000 post-war program.

THE documentary film is basically a method of shooting movies for the purpose of reporting a phase of human activity. The film may be simply a record, photographed objectively, or it may be a means of persuasion to a line of thought.

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 2 -- The State of Georgia's proposed purchase of Jekyl Island, the fabulous playground owned and used exclusively by Eastern millionaires since 1886, has raised a hot political issue and brought into the open once more the bitter rivalry between Gov. M.E. Thompson and Herman Talmadge.

GENEVA, Aug. 2 -- Leaders of the International Trade Conference here acknowledged today that the life of this greatest and possibly last endeavor to turn the world in the direction of freer trade hung by slender threads.

The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association has given over this month to activities for the family, except for Tuesdays and Wednesdays. On those days this week the association will hold its annual scotch foursome tournament over the Crestmont Golf Club course at West Orange, N.J.
MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., Aug. 2 -- This historic air base provided a thrilling finish to the Air Force's fortieth birthday celebration here today.

Lays Siege in Palestine As the first glow of dawn tinted the hills of Judea last Tuesday three Jewish terrorists were led one by one to the gallows at Acre Central Prison in northern Palestine. They were hanged by the British Government of Palestine for participation in a jail delivery at the same prison three months ago.

MOST reminiscing authors these days feel called upon to picture their family circles as aggregations of colorful neurotics, their home lives as resounding steadily with delicious domestic explosions. In contrast to such raucous nostalgia is the quiet gravity of Charles Angoff's backward glance at the important people of his youth.

FOR a long while I have wondered if Americans are sufficiently aware of the amount of work and on the whole, the good quality of the work that military government has done in Germany. The proper measure of achievement for a job like this is not whether things have gone well or badly, for many parts of the job may be impossible.

PRAGUE, Aug. 2 -- There is sincere and widespread apprehension among Germany's neighbors about the United States proposal to give the Germans more powers of control over the management and output of the Ruhr coal mines.

Sailing last night for Rio de Saneiro aboard the passengerfreighter Mormacsaga were Senator Tom Connally of Texas and Representative Sol Bloom of New York, two of the six United States delegates to the InterAmerican Conference for Maintenance of Continental Peace and Security starting Aug. 15 in the Brazilian city.

The area in East Harlem known as "Little Spain," housing the Puerto Rican population, has been marked in the last eighteen months by a sharp increase in crime, especially among the teen-age population.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The United Mine Workers Journal charged today that excessive fees were charged by undertakers for the burials of the victims of the Centralia, Ill., mine disaster of March 25 when 111 coal miners lost their lives.
The writer of the following letter is a member of the faculty of Northwestern University, Department of Psychology.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 300 head (estimated): total 3,300; compared with week ago all weights butchers and all sows approximately steady.

BUFFALO, Aug. 2 -- A petition to President Truman using him to call a conference of leading and representative men and women from the clergy, business, education and Government "to give serious consideration to the solution of the crisis which faces our nation and the world" was agreed upon tonight by the international convention of the Disciples of Christ.

NEW YORK CITY is now facing the most critical parking-space shortage in its history. As of Aug. 1 almost 950,000 motor vehicles were registered in the five boroughs, and the figure is rising steadily. Adequate measures have not been taken to meet the problem of parking thousands of these cars and public garage accommodations are far below pre-war levels.

Insurance companies which are using the so-called "Guertin legislation" to stimulate sales, were severely criticized last week by Holgar J. Johnson, president of the Institute of Life Insurance. The Guertin law permits companies to use a modern mortality table for calculating reserves and benefits of new life insurance policies.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The Legion of Merit was awarded today to key officers in the planning and execution of the Bikini atom, bomb tests in the spring of 1946.

HOLLYWOOD. THE difficulties of the United Artists Distributing Corporation, arising from a deadlock between Mary Pickford and Charles Chaplin, the two owners, have become more acute following what appeared at midweek to be an unsuccessful effort to enlist the services of Joseph M. Schenck as arbiter and reorganizer.
LONDON, Aug. 2 (U.P.) -- Dr. Louis J.M. Beel, Netherland Premier, said today that he expected an early settlement in the Indonesian war, with the help of the United States as mediator.

HOLLYWOOD. IT is always risky to make predictions concerning the modus operandi of a business as unpredictable as that of the motion picture industry, but there are indications that important changes are pending.
The writer of the following letter was director of information of the League to Enforce Peace. He is now chairman of the World Friendship School Committee for the United States.
"What makes the wildcat wild?" is a vintage question, but today the answer is twofold: guncranks and woodchucks.

DR. HEIMANN recalls the story of Hitler's rise to power in the early Thirties and the aid and comfort the Soviet Union gave to him in the first two years of World War II. He accuses the Soviet regime of appalling brutality, estimating it holds one of every twenty or thirty citizens behind barbed wire or in concentration camps.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 2 -- The Giants today gave another eyefilling demonstration of their vaunted power as they exploded five home runs to surpass their own all-time high of seventeen years' standing. Unfortunately, however, they could surpass the Pirates only once in two tries, to split an annoying double-header with Billy Herman's lowly Bucs.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 2 -- Miss Shirley Fry of Akron, Ohio, the defending cup holder, and Mrs. Helen Rihbany of Boston, reached the final round of the women's invitation tennis tournament today at the Maidstone Club.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 2 (U.P.) -- Regional committees of newsmen and printers today joined opposition Parliamentary Deputies in a fight against newsprint and other Restrictions threatening the freedom of the Argentine press.

TO THE EDITOR: Thank you for your courage in publishing Canon Bell's splendid article. The fact that such material can reach widespread circulation is encouraging -- our national ineptitude is at least recognized.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 2 (AP) -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey today recommended to the Federal Housing Expediter the names of seventy-six citizens for appointment to local advisory boards in fifteen of the twenty-three Federal rent-control areas in New York State.

THIRTY-FOUR years ago Dr. Brigham, Director of the American Antiquarian Society in Worcester, Mass., embarked on a project that (just now completed) is of primary and lasting importance to all concerned with the writing or study of early American history.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- A bold attempt by an unidentified numbers -racket player to tamper with the United States Treasury's daily balance figures came to light this week.

A SERIES of week-end canoe trips up the Hudson River is now offered New Yorkers who cannot get away for the somewhat standardized canoe trips on the distant lakes and rivers of Canada, Maine and the Adirondacks.

THE Irish can cook -- "Maura Laverty's Cookbook" proves it -- even if they still don't know how to bake a potato properly. The author does the remarkable, gives you some good reading along with a host of good cooking suggestions.

A SUPPLY of Robot cameras, the rapid-sequence miniature which had some vogue before the war, arrived recently from Germany. Burleigh Brooks, the importer, describes the new Robot as the improved Model No. 2, with Schneider Xenar f/2.8 lens instead of the Tessar f/2.8 lens used before the war.

BOSTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Ted William's twenty-fourth home run of the year, a two-run smash which he drove into the left-center-field screen in the first inning tonight enabled the Ked Sox to shade the Tigers, 2 -- 1, and snap a losing streak that had extended through four games.

PHILIP VAN DOREN STERN, collector of taste and originality, leads a frontal attack on Time. Introducing an anthology of literary time - experiments (with the aid and abetment of the Mad Hatter), he sums up against the tyranny of the benevolent -looking old gentleman with the white beard.

WEEDS that have to be pulled out of crevices in flagstone during summer raise the question what desirable plants will grow in such restricted spots. Suitable plants do not add up to a sizable list, but they are varied and require little care.

CARMEL, Calif. TWO performances of Johann Sebastian Bach's B minor Mass at Sunset School Auditorium last Sunday brought to a close the tenth annual Carmel Bach Festival and a week of music that has become, during those ten years, the most important music festival on the Pacific Coast.

Foreseeing the continuation of good business in the garment field at least through the early part of next year, coat and suit manufacturers last week began viewing fabrics for the spring season. This year will see an early overlapping of seasons, it was predicted, with spring buying beginning in October while there is a good bulk of fall goods yet to be shipped.
AMONG flower fanciers, August means gladiolus. Evidence of this is the innumerable gladiolus shows held this month all over the country and attended by thousands of enthusiasts.

LONDON. ONCE upon a time children were to be seen and not heard. Instinctively one falls back on the phraseology of the fairy-tale in referring to those quaint old days when the adult was the fine flower of civilization and the child was regarded as a regrettable necessity if not an active nuisance.

ROBERT W. HENDERSON is a man who deserves a high place in the official records, scrolls, halls of fame and semipantheons by which organized sport has begun to glorify itself in the last fifty years. For Mr. Henderson is by all odds the world's foremost student and soundest historian of the origin and growth of games that are played with a ball.

The search for the cause and cure of cancer will be aided by twenty-two grants totaling $133,382 to research centers and cancer specialists in ten states, the American Cancer Society announced yesterday.

BY this time of year many perennial borders are overgrown. Plants crowd together to such an extent that the beauty of the individuals is lost in a mass of interwoven leafage. The weight of rains then bends low both flowers and foliage.

HOT weather in major shopping areas of the country slowed retail trade last week. Nevertheless, early reports of consumer reaction to initial showings of the new fall styles were favorable. Promotions of furniture and other home wares likewise were said to have elicited good consumer response.

BETWEEN 1830 and 1920. about 122,000,000 copies of the McGuffey readers were sold. The number of persons who were "educated" by them is incalculable, and probably includes half or more of all nineteenth-century Americans.

BOSTON, Aug. 2 -- Dr. Karl T. Compton, president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and nine other voters have filed an initiative petition seeking adoption of "An Act to Allow Physicians to Provide Medical Contraceptive Care to Married Women for the Protection of Life or Health."
LONDON, Aug. 2 -- Britain's economy now faces the bleak prospect of a prolonged state of siege.

ABE BURROWS, a parlor comic of more than casual renown in cafe society circles, has decided to expose his whimsical wares to the millions in a new program which may be tuned in at 10:30 P.M. Saturdays over CBS.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 2 -- Frank Strafaci of Pomonok, the slightly-built 31-year-old defending champion, and John Smith, tall Winged Foot player, will meet tomorrow in the thirty-six-hole final of the metropolitan amateur golf championship at the Meadow Brook Club.

OXFORD, Me. -- Here in the heart of the camp country, more city children than ever before are basking in the sunshine of the biggest season in camping history. Old-established camps are Jammed to the bunk rafters, and many still have long waiting lists.

Some grounds for encouragement are found by the National Safety Council in the half-year figures for death due to traffic accidents. They reach 14,480 as compared with 15,290 in the same period in 1946. This is a drop of 9 per cent. It was made in the face of a road travel upswing of 11 per cent in the first five months of the year.

Influenced by the adverse economic and political situation of Great Britain, security and commodity markets met with a sharp reversal in price trends last week. Losses, however, were narrowed by a rally toward the end of the week, with about one-third of the earlier stock losses recovered and with commodities ending the week on an irregular note.

SUMMER exhibitions at the art colonies continue to flourish. The nineteenth annual exhibition of work by members of the Pemaquid Group has opened at the Art Center, New Harbor, Me., and will continue through Labor Day.

ALICIA MARKOVA and Anton Dolin and their company will provide the only dance events of the current Lewisohn Stadium season on Wednesday and Thursday evenings. In the company with them will be Bettina Rosay, Roszika Sabo, Albia Kavan, Carol Melson, Wallace Seibert, Rex Cooper, Royes Fernandez, David Tihmar and George Reich.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 2 -- Wyoming is planning a formal ceremony for the end of August to dedicate what Governor Lester C. Hunt describes as a wild life park "unlike anything else in the world."

HOLLYWOOD. HORSE actors, like human ones, have to take dramatic lessons to become stars in films. The tonier among Hollywood's equine set attend the Clarence (Fat) Jones Stable in North Hollywood which is, to horses, what the American Academy of Dramatic Arts is to humans, even if Fat Jones and his chief drama coach, Swede Lindell, do ignore the Stanislavsky Method.
GENEVA, Switzerland, Aug. 2 -- In the middle of its fourth month the Geneva trade conference this week still faced many obstacles.

BATAVIA, Java, Aug. 2 -- Indonesia will "cease fire" in accordance with the United Nations Security Council request provided the Dutch withdraw troops behind the original demarcation lines prior to the fighting and eventually get out of the entire archipelago, the Jogjakarta (Republican) radio broadcast today.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 2 -- The fastest tennis to come from the racquet of Francisco (Pancho) Segura carried the little player from Guayaquil, Ecuador, to victory over Victor Seixas of Philadelphia today in the semi-finals of the Southampton invitation tournament at the Meadow Club.

COUNTING fox-hole editions issued to men at war to stir their minds and stimulate discussion, "Plowman's Folly," published in 1943, has sold 340,000 copies. It is the fastest-selling book on technical agriculture in the history of American publishing.

FOR two years Eugene Weinstock, a Belgian of Hungarian -Jewish origin, was imprisoned in the Buchenwald horror camp, and in the present autobiographical chronicle he tells of it in detail. Unlike Ernst Wiechert, another ex-prisoner of Buchenwald, Mr. Weinstock, a cabinet-maker by trade, is not a professional writer, and "Beyond the Last Path" is far less philosophical than "Forest of the Dead."

New Perfections A CONSIDERATION of ancient Greek civilization illustrates the value of discordance. The race was awakened into progress by a great ideal of perfection. This ideal was an immense advance upon the ideals which the surrounding civilizations had produced.

Prime Minister Attlee, according to advices from London, is planning to present to Parliament this week a new government economic program designed to allay the crisis which threatens the British pound sterling. Precisely what form the program will take has not, of course, been officially revealed.

OFFICIALS of the Intercontinental Hotels Corporation and of the Latin-American interests, which are now cooperating in building eleven hotels in Central and South American cities, are already contemplating a similar chain of resort hotels.

WHILE August brings rewards to earlier labors in the vegetable garden, it allows no respite for those who aim at peak production through the entire season. Only by adhering to a maintenance program of cultivation, insect and disease control, adequate watering during dry spells and judicious succession sowing, can a plentiful variety of fresh vegetables until frost be realized.

Two cruises and week-end rendezvous are on the August calendar for the New York Athletic Club Yachting Department. Vice Commodore Jeremiah H. Valente is chairman of the committee that will pilot the club fleet this coming week-end to Mattituck, where the yachtsmen will tie up at a dock near the Red Mill.

GLASGOW, Scotland, Aug. 2 (AP)--Bill Vessie of Columbia University and Alan Naterson, 19-year-old Scottish Olympic hope, broke Britain's high-jump record by half an inch today when each cleared 6 feet 7 1/2 inches in an international track and field meet at Ibrox Park.

PARIS -- The steady arrival of American tourists has given Paris and other major points in France an aspect such as they have not been known to present since before the war. This travel will reach its climax in August and September when two large groups -- Boy Scouts and the American Legion -- will arrive for short stays.

From the remote resort of Sun Valley, Idaho, came the strangest football news yesterday since Ossie Solem briefly introduced a reversible center at Syracuse -- the Brooklyn Dodger linemen are going to play from an upright stance instead of a crouch this season.

THE perennial hibiscus or giant - flowering mallows seem to have disappeared from suburban gardens. Whether the generous space required by their shrub-like growth is responsible for this, or whether newer gardeners have not yet discovered these rosemallows and marshmallows, once so popular in gardens, is hard to say.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 2 -- Lew Worsham, Pittsburgh pro who holds the National open championship, carved out a 66, six strokes off par for the Keller golf course, to take the lead in the St. Paul open tournament today with a fifty-four-hole total of 202.

Indisputable support for the claims that the voters of the nation are tending away from municipal, or public ownership of power plants appears in a roundup of franchise election results held in thirty-four communities in thirteen states since Jan. 1, compiled by the Edison Electric Institute.

Arthur Whittemore and Jack Lowe, duo-pianists, were the guest artists with the New York Philharmonic -Symphony Orchestra last night at Lewisohn Stadium. Richard Korn conducted, and the event attracted an audience of 11,000.

MELODIES from overseas are the material for three of this week's releases. The most appealing of these is a pair of Vox albums, Palestine Dances and Songs and Jewish Holiday Dances and Songs, three ten-inch disks each.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 2 -- Fortified by what shapes up as the most formidable field in its history, the Eastern grass court tennis championship started at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club today. The opening session, however, provided little in the way of competition since many of the nation's topflight performers are still campaigning on Long Island.

ATHENS, Aug. 2 (AP) -- An authoritative source said tonight that Greece would propose a program involving nearly $2,500,000,000 for her share in the Marshall plan to cover a five-year reconstruction program and current needs from January, 1947, through June, 1948.

BERLIN, Aug. 2 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor, has received a "hands down" assurance that the recentlyordered delay in the publication of the level of industry plan for Germany in no way reflected on him or his command.

SMALL bulbs can be planted now and into October for bloom in the fall and early winter. These autumn flowers, among the quickest to grow, have a delightfully surprising quality. They repeat, near the close of the garden year, the sudden appearance and fragile charm of snowdrops, squills and crocus in spring.
LONDON (By Wireless). THIS land of ancient and traditional freedom has lately been asking the question: "Is freedom of the press menaced?"

REPRESENTATIVES of postal departments of a number of foreign Governments are currently making inquiries in New York regarding the feasibility of establishing philatelic bureaus here for the sale of unused stamps to collectors.

THIS novel of a farm in Provence and its youthful owner, the moody Pascal, will perhaps remind the reader of those naturalistic stories in the French tradition -- Flaubert's "A Simple Soul," and Maupassant's "Une Vie."

BUFFALO, Aug. 2 (AP) -- A flour shortage began to be felt throughout New England today as prospects grew dim for an early settlement of the twenty-day-old strike in this nation's largest milling center. Representatives of the five flour mills here that are shut and officials of the striking local, No. 21021 of the Flour Mill Workers, AFL, wound up deadlocked in a conference that reportedly was near bringing the strike to an end.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The first American babies born during the war will create a new school crisis this fall.

To the Drama Editor: As the president of a corporation organized to invest in the theatre on a long-term basis, I am puzzled at the beady-eyed reception accorded my recent proposal to make it financially possible for playwrights to write -- of all things -- plays.

One of the saddest of the world's problems is illustrated by the heavy Puerto Rican immigration into this city, as described in Albert J. Gordon's story published yesterday in this newspaper. The story is simply one of a population too great for the island's resources, yet unable to find adequate outlets elsewhere.
Anti-British slogans and crude swastikas were daubed Friday night on British consulates in New York and several other American cities, the police reported yesterday.

Indications of unabated steel production, at least for the balance of the year, and hints that the industry is not satisfied with the new price schedules it has just put into effect highlighted the second-quarter reports published last week by the leading steel companies.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation says that criminal activity in the United States reached a sixteen-year peak In 1946.

The following story of what is happening in the Antarctic was written by Alton L. Blakeslee, who accompanied the Byrd expedition to the south polar region last spring as correspondent for The Associated Press.

THIS month of August is rich in the wild flowers of meadow, swamp and roadside. The vacationist is fortunate in the varied species that offer themselves for identification and study, particularly in the Adirondacks, northern New England and Canada.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 2 -- A House labor subcommittee headed by Representative Hartley Jr., of New Jersey on Monday will open three weeks of hearings here on the ten-month American Federation of Labor jurisdictional strike in the movie studios and other Hollywood labor problems.
