TYLER, Tex., Aug. 2 (AP) -- Joe Verdeur of the Brighton Drake Swim Club, Atlantic City, splashed to a new national and American record and came within 1.2 seconds of the world record in the 200meter breast-stroke at the national A.A.U. swimming and diving championships tonight.
STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 2 -- State Tax Commissioner Walter Walsh denied here today that he intended to rely on "snoopers" to catch up with violators of the Connecticut use tax.

AMONG those of us who are fascinated by murder to a point just this side of committing it there are many who prefer their homicide factual rather than fictive. For these, Duell, Sloan Pearce, in recent years, has been presenting a series of real murder stories classified by cities.

PHOTOGRAPHS continue to glow after the lights go out in a new photographic process known as Milotone. Developed by Sam Milone, a research engineer of Jersey City, pictures made by this method provide their own illumination in a darkened room, remaining visible for an hour and a half.

ORDINARY objects assume a new appearance when photographed at close range with the aid of supplementary close-up lenses, a wide-angle lens and extreme extension of the camera bellows. To get a large image of a small detail of an object, the lens must be brought quite near the object.

NO book has ever told so much about civilian life in the North as "Arctic Village" by Robert Marshall. "Free Gold" is a book, quite different, not nearly so well written, but equally fascinating. It is a book that tells the truth -- and tells it simply and humbly.

IF an American visiting Paris before the first World War wanted to imbibe a good strong drink of logic, he visited 27 Rue de Fleurus and listened to Leo, and not Gertrude, Stein. For in those days, Leo Stein was looked upon as one of the great talkers of his generation.

Almost all branches and companies engaged in farm equipment manufacturing are expanding and modernizing their plants, Paul S. Williams, manager of industrial relations for Deere Co., Moline, Ill., revealed here yesterday, in disclosing that his company is now planning to double the 1948 farm tractor output of its latest new plant at Dubuque, Iowa.

"IS MORNING SURE?" gives ample evidence of Laura Benet's devoted reading of much English and American poetry. These unassuming poems express, in traditional numbers, her many and warm loyalties to men and women, and her responses to nature, love, death, old age, and other ageless themes of poetry.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, Aug. 2 -- The government of the Land [state] of North Rhine-Westphalia unanimously adopted a resolution today asking the British Government to "cancel confiscation of the Ruhr mines" and transfer control of Europe's most important coalfields to German trustees.
PARIS, Aug. 2 -- Former President Charles de Gaulle's attack this week on French Communists and on the Soviet Union, which, he says, is their master, was the climax of his current series of speeches.

THIS small book sets forth candidly the snares, pitfalls and dangers that await the too-enthusiastic, inexperienced city dweller who is making plans to wrest a living from the soil. In certain sections the book is almost brutal in emphasizing the dark side.

CROWN POINT, N.Y., Aug. 2 -- Mortimer L. Simpson of 948 East Twenty-eighth Street, Brooklyn, a retired New York City public school principal, died here yesterday in his summer home after a brief illness. His age was 56.

THE frantic early days of the war come vividly to mind as the Congressional inquiry into airplane contracts proceeds in Washington. President Roosevelt was demanding 50,000 planes a year from an industry that had not built that many in all its history since the Wright brothers flew at Kitty Hawk, N.C., in 1903.

AMERICAN food habits seem queer to our European cousins on several counts. We insist on ice in our drinking water, sweeten salad dressings on occasion, eat corn on the cob. In England, a Britisher once told us, it's the hogs and cattle that like the corn.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 2 -- Billy Luders in the International Surf, Arnold Monetti's Atlantic Hera, Bob McCullough's Herreshoff S. boat Felicity and Arthur Deacon's Star Armade were the "big boat" winners in the Y.R.A. championship regatta held by the Echo Bay Yacht Club today.

Benjamin Kaplan, 33 years old, was found slain early yesterday in the candy store he operated with his father at 1838 East Tremont Avenue, the Bronx. He had been shot twice. Two young women coming in to buy ice cream at 12:30 A.M. found him sprawled hear the opening between toe soda fountain and the candy counter.

To assure success of the Marshall Plan, Western European countries should keep all their steel plants, with the exception of the Hermann Goering Works, operating at capacity, Herman A. Brassert, president of H.A. Brassert Co., New York steel mill engineers and consultants, recommended yesterday in his first public statement since before the war.
VIENNA, Aug. 2 -- Of all the Danubian Governments today there is none outwardly more independent and inwardly more nervous than that of Austria.

A definitive series of pamphlets interpreting sound mental hygiene for parents is being prepared for the New York City Committee on Mental Hygiene of the State Charities Aid Association. Written by Nina Ridenour, Ph. D., with the assistance of Isabel Johnson, the first eight pamphlets will appear Sept 1.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 2 -- The Philippine Republic, as a country "specially affected" by the undeclared war between the Indonesians and the Dutch, proposed to the United Nations today that it help arbitrate the twelve-day dispute.

The largest daytime crowd of the season -- 62,537 paying spectators -- sat in on the longest game the Stadium has seen in many a moon yesterday and watched the league-leading Yankees end the five-game winning streak of the Indians by squeezing out a 3-2 victory in fourteen innings.

As a step in increasing uniformity in building code requirements, the American Standards Association has approved a standard covering light-weight floor construction. The action is the first ever made by the association on this type of construction and is intended for use by municipal and state building officials.

The Chicago Transit Authority's bond issue which is coming up for bidding on Tuesday is challenging the investment world in an unprecedented way. There is no gainsaying the promising blueprint worked out by the Illinois officials for setting up their metropolitan transit on a self-sustaining basis and for keeping the administration of the system insulated from the pressures and inhibitions of city politics.

HERBERT GRAF will stage the four music dramas of Wagner's "Ring of the Nibelungen," which will be restored to the Metropolitan Opera next season in re-studied, remounted productions. The cycle is planned for the first half of the season.

IN the thirty-five years covered by this chronicle, the growth of the Metropolitan Museum was astounding, even by present-day standards. Coming of age in 1905, after a comparatively precarious beginning, the next decades were to see it gain powerful friends who gave collections and money, built new wings and encouraged its varied activities.

Labor Member of Parliament I BELIEVE that the British press is the finest, freest and fairest in the world. Yet I successfully persuaded Parliament to set up a royal commission to Investigate it. Let me try to explain what seems to be a paradox here; in spite of the opening statement.
"A woeful hostess brooks not merry guests." -- Shakespeare.

ASPEN, Col. -- This well-known ski resort is now bidding for the summer trade. Its chair lift, reputedly the world's longest, is in operation as a sight-seeing lure and guides are ready to take vacationers on fishing expeditions, pack trips and trail parties.

MOUNT BEACON, N.Y. -- Fifty-nine miles out of New York City, overlooking the Hudson RiverDutchess County area, the world's steepest incline railway of its length is still carrying tourists and sightseers up and down the side of this 1,500-foot mountain, a task in which it has been engaged for almost half a century.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Chiefs of the Republican and Democratic National Committees assayed the record of the first session, Eightieth Congress, in prepared statements today and found no grounds for agreement.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 2 -- As matters now stand, and they do not appear to stand any too well for fourteen of the sixteen clubs that comprise major league baseball's set-up, the current campaign is almost of a certainty to produce a Yankee-Dodger world series come October.
Operators of first-class Atlantic liners now report that for the first time in months they are able to offer immediate eastbound space to travelers.

TWELVE years ago this week in this Review: A front-page review of a new novel by Willa Gather -- "Lucy Gayheart" -- holds that, while the book is "not an expansive reading of life," it adheres to Miss Gather's principle that "art should simplify."

At the suggestion of Dr. F. Zwioky, professor of astrophysics in the California Institute of Technology, the warhead of a V-2 rocket was loaded with slugs and exploded in the upper reaches of the atmosphere last Dec. 16. Theoretically slugs would be ejected with such speed that they would be heated to incandescence by friction with the atmosphere so that they would, become artificial meteors.

The Affiliated Young Democrats of New York City have adopted unanimously a resolution calling for repeal of the proportional representation method of electing members of the City Council, Harold R. Moskovit, state president, announced yesterday.

FEDERAL PROJECT -- The national mental health program, authorized by Congress in 1946 and implemented on July 8, 1947, by an appropriation of $7,500,000, was launched last week by Dr. Thomas Parran, Surgeon General of the United States Public Health Service.

American manufacturers an engineers will move into action promptly with money, men and machines to help work out practical details of the Marshall plan for western Europe, as it involve plant modernization and rehabilitation, spokesmen revealed here yesterday. But the major issues confronting designers of any successful scheme involve settlement of three basic questions which have not yet been decided, they said.
BRIDGE mathematicians know the odds and try to use them to advantage. There are also bridge swindlers, who try to circumvent mathematical disadvantages, and make advantageous positions doubly sure.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2 -- Yesterday's Dodger defeat here apparently was only the beginning of disaster. Before 34,108 prejudiced witnesses, today, the Cubs battered seven pitchers for seventeen hits and outscored the Brooks, 12 -- 7, further reducing their league lead.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Aug. 2 -- Rumania's Communist-dominated Government has made so much progress in the last week in smashing any semblance of organized opposition that it now feels it can safely ratify the peace treaty in mid-August, clearing the way for the withdrawal of Soviet troops, it was stated here today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 2 (U.P.) -- Bulgaria and Yugoslavia have reached a series of far-reaching agreements calling for a customs union, abolition of visas and coordination of foreign policy, the Yugoslav Government announced tonight.

Gerard V. Murphy, insurgen candidate for Tammany leader of the First Assembly District, North, appealed yesterday to Mayor O'Dwyer to use his influence to prevent the use of "chicanery" to defeat him for election as leader at a meeting of County Committee members Monday night.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Corn rolled ahead into new high territory again today on the Board of Trade, sustained by persistent commission house buying, which met a general scarcity of offerings. The yellow grain strength helped oats, but wheat lagged on hedge selling.

A middle-aged man and his 23year-old daughter who attempted to rescue him were burned to death early yesterday morning when a fire virtually destroyed a two-family frame house at 1129 Hegeman Avenue, Brooklyn.

THE Hollywood miracle men must believe in Santa Claus, or a reasonable facsimile, to bring this mock-serious Christmas story to the screen in summer. No doubt that excellent actor, Edmund Gwenn, playing the lead role of Kris Kringle, saved the day for the movie -- but lacking Mr. Gwenn, Valentine Davies' story will hardly create competition for Charles Dickens, come next Yuletide.

The writer of the following letter was formerly Special Assistant to the Attorney General of the United States in Admiralty and International Law matters. Until recently, he was for a number of years chairman of the Committee on International Law of the New York County Lawyers Association.

FISHERS ISLAND, N.Y., Aug. 2. -- Robert T. Moore's 12-meter sloop Nereus from Oyster Bay, L.I., today won the first run of the New York Yacht Club cruise, that of eighty miles through Long Island Sound from Glen Cove to here.

DETROIT, Aug. 2 -- The international executive board of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, gave unanimous sanction tonight to a nation-wide strike by 107,000 employes of the Ford Motor Company early next week.

VIENNA, Aug. 2 -- The Austrian Treaty Commission, according to responsible reports from all sides, has reached a complete dead end. The Soviet Union's representatives are said to have taken no part in the presentation and preparation of evidence except to have stated the Kremlin's views.

MUSIC, drama and fantasy will be the principal ingredients in the ABC-WJZ full - hour documentary show based on the Twentieth Century Fund's survey, "America's Needs and Resources," according to Robert Saudek, director of public affairs for ABC, who last week announced that the program has been entitled "1960?? -- Jiminy Cricket" and is scheduled for presentation on Monday, Sept. 8, beginning at 9 P.M.

THE pulse of the local art world continued to beat faintly last week, two group shows of sculpture and two one-man shows of paintings being on the calendar. The Clay Club's midsummer group show of diverse work by some of the younger artists reveals a wide variety of experimentation in several media and brings forward considerable maturing talent.

And Big Two Relations The United Nations is now eighteen months old. It has established most of the principal international agencies provided in the Charter. It has made a start toward dealing with some of the great political questions that confront the world.

Brewster's Inquiry Howard Hughes, 41, is a sportsmancapitalist, and one of Hollywood's most spectacular figures. A native of Texas, he inherited a $650,000 oil equipment business that has made him millions. As a young man he moved to the West Coast, began making motion pictures and designing airplanes.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 2 -- Three Mediterranean beaches, used by British troops and civilians for swimming, were closed today following reports that they had been mined by Jewish terrorists. British Army engineers went out with mine detectors to examine the beaches, which are at Bat Yam, Jaffa and Nathanya.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 2 -- Edward J. Nocton, magazine writer, former newspaper editor and retired advertising manager of the J.B. Van Sciver Company, furniture and carpet firm in Camden, N.J., died yesterday in his home here at the age of 79.

THE editor in charge of viewing -with-alarm notes is of the opinion that The London Times Literary Supplement is not kidding when it says, in a review of "Joy in the Morning." by P.G. Wodehouse: "Unfortunately, Mr. Wodehouse * * * has Jeeves tell a lie.

The Roman Singers of Sacred Music, under the Right Rev. Msgr. Licinio Refice, gave the opening concert of their tour of the United States and Canada last night at the Polo Grounds. Both the vocalism of the ensemble and the eclesiastical music they presented proved deeply impressive, arousing fervent enthusiasm from the large audience in attendance.
NIAGARA FALLS, Aug. 2 (AP) -- A plea for preparedness and internationalism was voiced today at the end of the 29th annual convention of the New York State department of the American Legion.

IT is a pleasure to read a first book of poetry and feel that the author has already developed a sound and flexible language of his own in which to present his work. In "A Private History" John Hay shows little evidence of the usual imprint of the masters who taught him his art.

Geneticists, as students of the mechanism of heredity are called, have been inbreeding and outbreeding mice for mary generations to discover the connection between cancer and heredity. In some pure strains or breeds of mice over 90 per cent of the females die of breast cancer; in other pure strains there may be no breast cancer, but lung tumors, leukemia, stomach cancer or some abnormal and peculiar growth.

Haakon VII, King of Norway, the only European king to be welcomed back by all his subjects after their liberation, celebrates today his seventyfifth birthday. Tall and lean and with the healthy complexion of a seafaring man, Haakon today is popular among his people.

A 28-year-old veteran, his wife and 19-month-old baby brought yesterday in Magistrates Court the first eviction case under the new city rent control law. Magistrate Charles E. Ramsgate adjourned the case until Aug. 18.

After nearly twelve years of misunderstandings and litigation, indications appeared last week that the next few months may see definite action to end the deadlock on interpretation of ambiguous parts of the Robinson-Patman act.

ALBANY, Aug. 2 -- "Firsts" that have made New York State famous will be displayed in the trailer exhibit of the New York Department of Commerce Division of State Publicity opening Monday at the St. Lawrence County fair at Gouverneur.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The determined Miss Kimo, who revels in muddy going, won the $28,250 Artful Handicap for 3-year-old fillies at Washington ParK today. She defeated the pace setting Ocean Brief by a length and a quarter.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 2 -- Charles Peck Sisson of this city, former Assistant Attorney General of the United States, who was comanager of Governor Dewey's campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination in 1940, died this afternoon at his summer home in Hopkinton, R.I., of a heart attack.

David Arnott, a veteran in the shipping industry who retired last week as vice president and chief surveyor of the American Bureau of Shipping, recommended that this country build new passenger liners for the transatlantic trade.

Concerned with the large number of teachers who are not qualified to be in the classroom, educational leaders have taken as their major project for the coming year the improvement of the nation's teaching profession.

ROCKPORT, Mass. SOME persons report high surtax incomes and wax fat from making others thin. They operate health courses, milk farms, diet emporia, sweat boxes and other slimming establishments. For the privilege of paving to be made thin, there are waiting lists as long as your arm, and sometimes the fees run as high as $14 to $18 a day.

BOSTON, Aug. 2 -- Textile workers' elation over a new wage pattern which was established early this week was later tempered by apprehension over the prospect of a mass migration of the industry to the South. This possibility was exemplified in the announcement of a "new Nashua plan" that will mean the loss of upwards of 1,600 jobs in that New Hampshire city.

THIS standard reference work presents annually a scholarly and objective record of trends and events in a wide range of fields: International relations, government, industry, finance, labor, art, literature, sports, science, drama, agriculture and many more.

A comprehensive formal personnel administration program stressing rapid exchange of organizational policies, ideas and information between management and employes, which has been in the process of development for more than four years, has just been completed by the National Broadcasting Company, Ernest De La Ossa, personnel director, disclosed in an interview last week.

TOMMY HANDLEY, Britain's top radio comedian, clings a little wistfully to a remark Bob Hope once made about Handley's ITMA (It's That Man Again) show on BBC. Hope said "I don't get it, it's too fast." During a brief stay in New York City last week -- incidentally, his first visit to the States -- Tommy tried to explain his stuff, which generally puzzles Americans.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The Reds took advantage of a lapse in Boston's defensive play in the eighth inning today to score seven quick runs, which gave them a 7-6 victory over the Braves before a crowd of 3,090.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The Interior Department yesterday opened the land along the Alaska Highway to settlement -- with reservations and a word of caution.

With many followers of the sport anticipating one of the most heated competitions in the history of the classic, the twenty-second trotting of the famous Hambletonian Stake will be held at Good Time Park in Goshen on Wednesday. Valued this year at $55,000, the race is expected to attract a record crowd of about 20,000.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Outfielder Ron Northey hit a long home run into the right-field pavilion that gave the Cardinals a last-minute 4-to-3 victory over the Phillies tonight. The Redbirds tied the game in the eighth inning after knocking Oscar Judd out of the box.

LEAVENWORTH, Kan., Aug. 2 (AP) -- William. K. Hale -- they called him "King of the Osages" twenty years ago at the time of his conviction in the murder of a wealthy Oklahoma Indian -- was a free man today.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 2 -- Talon, one of many capable importations from the Argentine, registered his first major triumph in the United States before the meeting's record crowd of 21,971 when he carried the banner of Richard Ryan to a nose triumph in the $25,000 added All American Handicap today.

BERLIN, Aug. 2 -- United States officials have incontrovertible evidence that the Soviet Union was the foreign power, thus far officially unnamed, that placed orders for armaments with two plants of the Askania Werke in the United States sector of Berlin, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The Senators came out on the short end of a 13-to-1 score today as the White Sox pounded 18 hits off three Washington pitchers. Rudy York and Cass Michaels both walloped home runs.

The recent merger of three Westchester County banks has revived comment among savings bankers regarding the so-called "discriminatory" legislative restrictions on the establishment of branch offices, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The Senate War Investigating Committee today placed in its records the following as an itemized expense account of Howard Hughes' publicity man, John Meyer. The account is headed "Col. Elliott Roosevelt."

A MIXTURE of the sentimental and cynical produces an engagingly fresh quality in "Stranger in Our Midst." Vince Bennett, back from wartime flying in the Pacific and fed up with the thrill of danger, resumes his career as a $60-a-week voice on a small station in Agua Blanca, Nev.

THE formal and testy objection which was raised the other day by the National Association of Women Lawyers to the portraiture of jurists on the screen is one which this back-bench observer will gladly lift his hand to sustain -- although we do wish the horrible examples picked by the Portias had been other than they were.

BERLIN, Aug. 2 -- Jack Bennett, financial adviser to Gen. Lucius D. Clay, foresaw today a possible direct clash between the system of trading envisaged by the so-called Molotov plan for Eastern Europe and the free trade practices that evidently are to be part of any program formulated under the Marshall Plan.

DURING his recent visit here J. Arthur Rank managed to snag a small galaxy of Hollywood stars for his English studios, including Bing Crosby, Claudette Colbert, Douglas Fairbanks Jr. and Joan Fontaine.

Great Britain faces an absolute dollar shortage and devaluation of the pound sterling may be necessary by the first of October, according to William R. Mathews, editor and publisher of The Arizona Daily Star, who has just returned from a three-month tour of Europe.
Prime Minister Attlee's decision last week to make further drastic cuts in British imports has made a profound impression upon responsible leaders of the American business community.
JERUSALEM, Aug. 2 -- This was a bad week in Palestine. The worst of it was that there seemed to be no end to the evil. It goes on and on; every week the weariness weighs more heavily.

The Bureau of the Census of the Department of Commerce has just reported that the percentage of American foreign shipments carried in American-flag vessels continued to decline in April. In that month this country's merchant marine carried 56 per cent of all merchandise exported and imported, a decline from 61 per cent in March and an average of 60 per cent for the calendar year 1946.

A check for $5,000 will go to the victor of Pete Bostwick's winnertake-all handicap polo tournament today at Bostwick Field, Old Westbury, L.I. The 22-goal California side will face the 16-goal Palo Duro quartet in the final-round match.

HARRY STACK SULLIVAN is one of the least widely known of great men. Within his own profession his name is legend. There Dr. Sullivan is recognized as the psychiatrist who removed schizophrenia from the class of necessarily incurable disorders.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- New interest was injected into the already exciting Republican presidential derby, scheduled for its twenty-fourth running next June 20 at Philadelphia, with the addition of a new entry, the seasoned campaigner -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio.

Detective Daniel B. Murphy was discharged yesterday from Roosevelt Hospital. He had been a patient there since July 7, when he was critically wounded in a pistol duel in a crowded Forty-second Street crosstown bus with an escaping jewel thief.

COLUMBIA ENGINEERING -- Rating A widely recognized but generally neglected aspect of engineering education -- the encouragement of the student in developing skillful personal relations -- will be scrutinized during the coming academic year in the Columbia University School of Engineering.

DETROIT, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The 1947 roster of the Detroit Lions of the National Football League was completed today with the announcement by Coach Gus Dorais of the signing of two ends who played last season in the All-American Conference.

Arnold, General of the Army, wartime Commanding General of the Army Air Force, in an article in The American Legion Magazine today that the AAF had been so crippled by post-war economies and neglect that it could offer but a "token resistance" to any lightning attack on this country.

Storewide activity last week was fairly good, with college shop openings winning excellent response, according to a survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Winter coats were gaining attention, while dress departments reported activity.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 2 -- More than 200 Puerto Rican migrants and tourists arrived or departed today on planes from the airport here. One hundred and seventeen passengers, including twelve children, arrived between 8 A.M. and 1 P.M. Planes scheduled to leave before midnight for Puerto Rico were booked for 101 passengers.

TOKYO, Aug. 2 -- Japan is being troubled by both floods and droughts. Torrential rains that lashed the southern island of Shikoku on July 13 caused damage estimated at 200,000,000 yen. NEW BRUNSWICK. N.J., Aug. 2 -- Apparently bowing to a demand by the state Congress of Industrial Organizations Council, which threatened to "oppose the entire document in November" unless its terms were granted, the constitutional convention set aside today its earlier timetable and announced that special hearings would be held Tuesday on its bill of rights and tax articles.

A picture postcard mailed anywhere in or around New York this week-end might read: "Having a wonderful time. Wish you were here. X marks my room. Sleeping under blankets." Yet, incredibly, this is the beginning of August, when the dog days of yore are supposed to be on summer's traces.

TWO correspondents of The Associated Press have here collaborated to produce a hasty and somewhat disparate survey of conditions in Yugoslavia, Albania, Rumania, Bulgaria, Greece and Turkey. The chapters on Turkey and Rumania -- which I assume were written by Frank O'Brien -- are full of illuminating bits of history.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., Aug. 2 (AP) -- The heavily backed Cover Up rolled through on schedule for his legion of new-found admirers today to win the $50,000 added Sunset Handicap as Hollywood Park ended its 1947 meeting before 45,876 fans.

THE backlog of transatlantic travel, eastbound, is shrinking. It is now possible to book passage for Europe, travel agents say, without the nervous tension experienced by anybody who tried to buy a steamship ticket in June or early July.
Changes in United States policy in some of the occupied areas -- and particularly major changes in the administration of those areas -- are forecast by recent events.

SCHOLARS so often take refuge in the jargon of their science that it is gratifying indeed to find one, an anthropologist, who has written an entirely readable book, richly documented, on the folk life of Brazil. "The City of Women" is a threedimensional study of human relations -- personal, religious, economicpolitical -- set well within the orbit of world affairs.

Dr. Robert H. Seashore of Northwestern University finds that children's knowledge and use of words is much greater than had previously been supposed. The average reader used in the classrooms of America's grade schools introduces only 500 new words a year, but the average child builds his vocabulary at the rate of approximately 5,000 new basic and derivative words annually.

THIS small volume represents a remarkable achievement in a number of directions and should serve a number of uses very well. The dangers attending sketches of this kind are notorious; the standards they must meet, very strict.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 2 -- The assumption that soft-coal production would decline approximately 16 per cent because of the reduction in the miners' working hours has not been borne out, according to tonnage figures reported since the diggers returned to work in the second week of July.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- One of the most significant conferences involving the future of Europe is to be undertaken here within two weeks when negotiations are begun with a British delegation on methods for increasing the coal production of the Ruhr.

The high spot in ready-to-wearmarket activity last week was the strong reorder trend in the coat and suit field, especially for furtrimmed box coats and satin and early fall crepe dresses, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

The nigh-goal polo competition at the Meadow Brook Club, Westbury, L.L., next month again will be spiced with an international flavor. Mexico, which last year bowed to the United States team in an international series on Long Island and then went on to win the Open title, has notified Meadow Brook's committee that it will defend the National Open championship in September.

TETERBORO, N.J., Aug. 3 -- George Levine, a 20-year-old Army veteran of 231 East Seventy-sixth Street, New York City, captured first prize this afternoon in the last event of the three-day International Air Classic for rubber-powered model aircraft held at the Bendix West Golf Course here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Elliott Roosevelt flew to Washington tonight, ready to take the stand tomorrow in a voluntary appearance before the Senate War Investigating subcommittee inquiring into the circumstances under which Howard Hughes obtained wartime plane contracts.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 3 -- Chester A. Smith, president of the Friendly Town Association, announced today that restoration work would begin here soon on the building in which Chauncey M. Depew studied law under William Nelson, friend of Abraham Lincoln.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 3 Universal-International has signed Edward G. Robinson to play Joe Keller, the warrtime manufacture of defective airplane engines, in the screen version of "All My Sons," to which the studio bough the rights last month for a reported $150,000.

The 65-year-old square-rigged ship Joseph Conrad, her tall spars bare of canvas, will pass through New York Harbor today bound in tow for Mystic, Conn., to end her notable career by becoming a museum relic.

New York unions have filed 613 strike notices with the State Mediation Board in the first five weeks of the Taft-Hartley labor law, Frederick H. Bullen, executive secretary of the board, reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The Federal Trade Commission issued two statements here tonight concerning products which have been marketed under exaggerated claims. In one, a Pelham, N.Y., corporation was served with a cease and desist order forbidding misleading claims for the effectiveness of an automobile gadget; in the other, a Los Angeles manufacturer and a Memphis, Tenn., distributor agreed to discontinue misleading claims about the effectiveness of an insect repellent.

HANOVER, Germany, Aug. 3 -- An attempt by the British Military Government to gauge how popular it is as occupying power has shown it is doing no better than any other occupying force in history. According to the results of a survey, made available today, 90 per cent of the people in the British zone consider that the British have lost considerable prestige since 1945.

BEDFORD VILLAGE, N.Y., Aug. 3 -- A double elopement staged by two teen-age Philadelphia couples in a stolen automobile ended here at dawn today with their arrest on charges of armed robbery after a wild chase over several miles of northern Westchester countryside.

An appeal to shun envy was made yesterdays by the Rev. Dr. Adam W. Burnet, pastor of St. Cuthbert's Parish Church, Edinburgh, Scotland, in a sermon at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 3 -- Before leaving Zagreb for further travels in Yugoslavia, seven American churchmen, here as guests of the Government to study religious conditions, said that freedom of worship existed here and that the imprisonment of Archbishop Aloysius Stepinatz of Zagreb appeared just, it was reported today.

PORT LEE, N.J., Aug. 3 -- Eleven members of the New York Chapter of the Committee for Racial Equality and Modern Trends were arrested here and in Cliff side Park charged with creating disturbances in Palisades Amusement Park.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 3 -- With price increases on a wide range of products placed in effect last week by steel firms, consumers were busy digesting what effect the boosts would have on their own finished products. According to authoritative sources, the additional cost to the initial steel consumers because of the steel price increase will run more than $350,000,000 a year.

The home, never a safe place statistically speaking, is growing even more dangerous, the Greater New York Safety Council reported yesterday. An analysis of figures on accidental deaths in the city in the first half of 1947, compared with the same period in 1946, shows an increase in fatal accidents in the home contrasted with a substantial decrease in all other kinds.

MUNICH, Germany, Aug. 3 -- A former Elite Guard lieutenant colonel, Otto Skorzeny, under arraignment in Dachau for war crimes, especially against war prisoners, gave yesterday, through the American prosecutor's office, a detailed account of his September, 1943, kidnapping of the late Benito Mussolini from his captors on Adolf Hitler's order.

Wage-rate increases in May averaged 1.7 per cent for all workers, according to the monthly survey of twenty-five industries reported over the week-end by the National Industrial Conference Board. Hourly and weekly earnings, real weekly earnings and payrolls were all higher than in the previous month, continuing the trend of the past fifteen months, while average hours, employment and total man hours were lower, according to the survey.
PARIS, Aug. 3 -- Eartabs and chiffon trimming are features of Maud Roser's collection. She adheres to the youthful small hat, pillboxes and bonnets.

BATAVIA, Java, Aug. 3 -- Both the Dutch and the Indonesian Republic announced tonight that they ivere willing to abide by the call if the United Nations Security Council for a cessation of hostilities in the East Indies.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.T., Aug. 3 -- The horses and the horse players will be In action again in this theatre of operations tomorrow, and tonight the race track folk were cutting up old touches along Broadway, peering at the past performances and wondering aloud whether the 1947 Saratoga meeting would be a financial as well as an artistic success.

Stabilization of the building industry in this city, which would hasten large-scale construction of housing and public works, is nearer realization, Edward C. Maguire, director of the city's division of labor relations, declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (U.P.) -- Americans for Democratic Action, an anti - Communist progressive group, began a nation-wide campaign today to protect tenants' rights under the new rent-control law.

BERLIN, Aug. 3 -- All German prisoners of war returning from the Soviet into the United States occupation zone of Germany are in such poor physical condition that they are unfit for work and many may never be able to work again, the United States Military Government said today.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Boston and Cincinnati split a doubleheader under a broiling sun here today, the Braves taking the opener, 4 -- 2, to snap Ewell Blackwell's string of consecutive complete games pitched at thirteen, while the Reds won the second game, 6 -- 1, before 26,184 sweltering fans.
Harvey Willard Burgher has been named personnel director for the Rexall Drug Company.

There is a world-wide tendency toward higher per capita incomes in those nations in which industrialization has made substantial progress. A comprehensive study made by the National Bureau of Economic Research shows that in the highly agricultural regions of southern United States, southeastern Europe, China, India, Africa and Latin America incomes are less by a major proportion than in the industrialized regions of western Europe and northeastern United States.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Aug. 3 -- The general strike, which has paralyzed business in Costa Rica for eleven days, ended this evening after day long negotiations between the opposing parties.

WASHINGTON, Augr. 2 (AP) -- Senator Reed of Kansas declared today he is "ready to impeach" the Interstate Commerce Commission if necessary for what he described as "legalized robbery" in some railroad reorganisation proceedings.

United States hostility toward the development of Socialist governments in Europe is driving many Europeans toward communism, Frank Rosenblum, vice president of the World Federation of Trade Unions and the Congress of Industrial Organizations, asserted yesterday.

Lou Boudreau made one miss-step yesterday at the Stadium and carried his Indians into the abyss of defeat. The usually flawless manager of the Tribe emulated Wrong-Way Corrigan on an easy tap by Pinch-Hitter Bobby Brown in the ninth inning when the Yankees and the Indians were deadlocked at 4-all.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 3 -- The brokerage business in this country, with 3,276 registrants having aggregate net capital of $923,886,714, was shown to be in good condition in a report made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The Democratic and Republican organizations in Brooklyn were understood yesterday to have agreed on a bi-partisan judicial slate for the November election for the three vacancies to occur on the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial district.

The Brooklyn Council for Social Planning calls attention to the inadequacy of Brooklyn's mental hygiene facilities. A survey just completed reports the existence in the borough of thirteen psychiatric clinics, as against twenty-six needed to meet ordinary mental health standards.

Milton Katims, young New York musician, who has been heard here as viola soloist, conductor, orchestral instrumentalist and chamber music performer, yesterday afternoon brought the conducting part of his career a good step forward when he led the National Broadcasting Company Symphony for the first time in one of its regular Sunday afternoon broadcasts.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The Browns overcame a three-run deficit in the late inning's today to win the second game of a double-header with the Athletics, 4 to 3, Philadelphia took the opener, 2 to 0, behind the shutout pitching of Phil Marchildon and the home run bat of Shortstop Eddie Joost before 19,094 fans.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Overlapping of taxation by the Federal Government and the states has developed to the degree that an over-Whelming preponderance of collections at both levels are being delived from the same tax categories, the Department of the Treasury brought out today in rnakrng public a staff of Federal-state tax relationships.
The simplest and perhaps the best known definition of science that we have is Herbert Spencer's. "Science," said Spencer, "is organized knowledge."

BOSTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Clubbing five Boston pitchers for sixteen hits the Tigers today trounced the Red Sox, 10 -- 3, before 24,565 fans, who made the total Fenway Park attendance for the year to date 1,004,807 at forty-nine games on forty-two dates.

BATAVIA, Java, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The text of the radio speech by Dr. Hubertus J. van Mook, Acting Governor General of the Netherlands East Indies, announcing the Dutch decision to cease fire in the Indonesian hostilities:

Although major materials of tire production are still under Government control, the rubber industry is the first major field in which manufacturers have defeated inflation trends and have reduced prices below pre-war retail levels on many popular sizes, industry spokesmen announced here over the week-end.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Bob Fitch, former University of Minnesota star from Sioux Falls, S.D., hurled the discus 178 feet 2 2/5 inches, in an international track and field meet here today, coming within two feet of his own unofficial world record with the third longest throw of his career.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : I came to the United States to represent Greece at the Fifth International Congress of Pediatricians, where I had ample opportunity to appreciate the progress accomplished in child care during the last decade.
To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : On Page 9 of THE TIMES on Monday, July 14, there appeared a brief special dispatch from Paris, dated July 13, the first paragraph of which read:

BATAVIA, Aug. 3 (Reuters) -- The Indonesian Republican Government is prepared to exert all its efforts to execute the United Nations Security Council's "ceasefire" order to end the fourteen-day old Indonesian war, an official statement broadcast from Jogjakarta said tonight.

Scarce industrial and construction equipment lines including farm machinery, mining machinery, structural bridge parts, incinerators and water purification equipment are among the new war surplus listings of the War Assets Administration scheduled for this week, Carl P. Malmstrom, regional director, announced over the weekend.

The private electric light and power companies of the United States have begun the greatest construction program in the sixtyfive-year history of the industry and will have spent $5,000,000,000, by 1952, Charles E. Oakes, president of the Edison Electric Institue, disclosed yesterday in that organization's statistical bulletin covering 1946 operations.
President Truman yesterday extended his greetings to the members of the Twenty-ninth National Recreation Congress who will meet at the Hotel New Yorker from Oct. 13 to 17.

COPENHAGEN, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The seventh congress of the World Baptist Alliance issued a manifesto on religious freedom tonight at the closing session and promised "active support of the United Nations."

MEDAN, Sumatra, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Dr. J.J. Vandervelde, Netherlands Commissioner for Northern Sumatra, said today that the Dutch engaged in the conflict with the Indonesian Republic because they "were going bankrupt" without access to the rich products of the Indies.

LONDON, Aug. 3 -- The stock markets last week experienced heir biggest skimp since 1940. Heavy selling of all securities caused the Financial Times' ordinary share index to fall eleven joints to 119, its lowest since October, 1946, and Government securities to 113, their lowest in two years.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: A proposal has been made to the Board of Estimate of New York City by Mr. Zeckendorf, president of Webb Knapp, the firm that acquired and sold to John D. Rockefeller the United Nations site in Turtle Bay.

A plea for the practice of kindness as an exercise in "practical Christianity" was "made yesterday in a sermon at thte Cathedral of St. John, the Divine by Bishop William R; Moody of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Lexington, Ky.

LONDON, Aug. 3 -- American film interests and the British Government are striving to work out a compromise plan that will help Britain in her present dollar crisis without penalizing American films, it was learned here today.
MOSCOW, Aug. 3 (U.P.) -- Russia's air force unveiled six new, ultramodern types of airplanes today, including jet-propelled models.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Secretary of War Kenneth C. Royall, asserting that long-range planning by the War Department could not be neglected "without serious, possibly fatal danger to the national security," revealed today plans for continued Government control over 131 war plants costing in excess of $3,500,000,000.

Dow Chemical Company, in its fiftieth annual report to stockholders for the fiscal year ended on May 31, showed a net income of $312,729,991, equal to $9.22 a share on the 1,248,706 shares of common stock, compared with $6,707,215, or $4.40 a share for the previous year.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- President Truman paid a surprise visit to a camp for crippled children today not far from the Maryland mountain camp, "Shangri-La," where he has been spending the week-end.
Special health, housing and relief problems have been created as a result of the unprecedented Puerto Rican immigration to this city.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- After three months' negotiations, a lendlease settlement with Russia is still at least several weeks off, it was learned today. However, State Department officials report that progress is being made.

Dr. Israel Weinstein, Health Commissioner, said yesterday that his department was prepared to "crack down" on 5,000 delicatessen stores in the city to enforce regulations covering refrigeration, exposure to dirt and dust, unclean handling of food and evidence of vermin.

One of the largest bedding manufacturers in the country may return to merchandise allocations because production has fallen below demand, Irving Baldinger, secretary of Eclipse Sleep Products, Inc., reported over the week-end. He attributed the distorted supply-demand picture to output lags resulting from plant-wide vacations at the beginning of the summer and large volume attained by retailers in bedding sales throughout the country.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug 3 -- College-trained women, who have married and had children consider themselves more useful to their families and communities than they would have been without their special training, according to a survey of the class of 22, first to be graduated from the New Jersey College for Women, Rutgers University.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 3 (U.P.) -- Ike Williams and Bob Montgomery, bitter rival claimants to the world lightweight championship, are scheduled to fight it out in Municipal Stadium tomorrow night for the undisputed right to the title.

There have been numerous complaints of retailers' enclosing letters or other written matter in small parcel post shipments or returns to manufacturers, M.J. Lovell, secretary-counsel of the National Association of Shirt and Pajama Manufacturers, declared over the week-end.

After a one-month test in Brooklyn, two police radio patrol cars with varied functions will get their acid test in Manhattan beginning at 8 A. M. today, it was announced yesterday at Police Headquarters.

Dress manufacturers themselves can reduce "piracy" of fashion de signs by "weeding out from their own number the concerns that employ no designers, Miss DeeDee Jarrette, president of the Guild of New York Dress Designers, declared yesterday at headquarters of the organization, 475 Fifth Avenue.
BABYLON, L I., Aug. 3-The set-to between Babylon and Washington over whether Sampawams should remain Sampawams or should be changed to something else still sizzles.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Ted Wilks checked a four-run uprising in the eighth, and Murry Dickson halted another threat in the ninth today and saved the game for Ken Burkhart in the Cardinals' 10-to-8 triumph over Fred Schmidt and the Phillies.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 -- His admiring home folks from Wausau, Wis. gave Johnny Schmitz a big Buick sedan before today's game, but the slim southpaw showed no such spirit of generosity toward the now decadent Dodgers.

The Office of Technical Services of the United States Department of Commerce, has allotted $47,000 for research on the possibility of establishing a year-round industry for processing the waste products of Alaska salmon canneries, John C. Green, OTS director, announced over the week-end.

GENEVA, Aug. 3 -- High French and British officials have been holding week-end meetings at Evian or the French shore of Lake Geneva to coordinate their countries' action in the economic conferences now going on in Paris and Geneva, it became known today.

The trials and tribulations of "Luna and Abner," those two leading citizens of Pine Ridge, will be broadcast at a new time and over a different network, beginning Sept. 29, when the program will be heard five times a week from 5:45 to 6 P.M. over CBS.
LONDON, Aug. 3 -- Anti-Jewish demonstrations broke out in Liverpool tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Frank Papish scattered seven hits to defeat Washington, 2 -- 1, today and gain his ninth triumph for the White Sox. It was Chicago's thirteenth victory in eighteen games with the Senators.

No Part of the Blueprint A predicament in which the Swiss find themselves as a result of Britain's austerity, enforced by a rigid rationing system, is just one of many evidences that you never can tell where the effect will be felt of measures taken in a supposed national interest.

From Belfast, Ireland, yesterday came 76-year-old Mrs. Jane Brown for her first visit to the United States. After alighting from a British Overseas Airways plane at La Guardia airport, she was rushed through customs in record time to be greeted by five children, one son-in-law, three daughters-in-law and eleven grandchildren.

TEMPLE, N.H., Aug. 3 (AP) -- Senator Charles W. Tobey, Republican, of New Hampshire, said tonight he had no knowledge that a report of an investigation of the relations between the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and the Baltimore Ohio Railroad was kept secret and proposed that it be made public "at once."

TYLER, Tex., Aug. 3 (AP) -- Joe Verdeur of the Brighton Drake Swim Club, Atlantic City, won the 300-meter individual medley -- final event on the program of the National A.A.U. swimming and diving championships tonight -- beating Jose Balmores of the Hawaii Swim Club by three lengths in 3:59.2.
DETROIT, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Negotiations are scheduled for resumption tomorrow in the two-week-old strike of 7,000 employes of the Murray Corporation of America.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Mrs. Sheila Summers of South Africa scored her second straight upset over an American foe by defeating Miss Doris Hart of Miami, Fla., 6 -- 3, 2 -- 6, 6 -- 2, today to win the women's title in the Swiss International tennis championships.

ONE gathers that John O'Hara does not think too highly of the human race -- or rather of that portion of it he puts into his stories. The portion might generally be-described as consisting of fairly well-to-do Americans, aimless, somewhat defeated, often devoid of morals and manners, and usually cynical about everyone's feelings, except their own.

Show business is threatened with a nation-wide strike of performers in the so-called legitimate branch of the amusement field, it became known yesterday. Last week Actors Equity and its sister union, Chorus Equity, an adjunct of "the former, filed a joint thirty-day strike notice against the League of New York Theatres, the employer group representing owners and operators of playhouses and theatrical producers.
LONDON, Aug. 3 -- Indonesian events will greatly influence Holland's economic and financial outlook.

To THE EDITOR OP THE NEW YORK TIMES: THE TIMES has done well to give space to reappraisal of the value of Proportional Representation as a means for choosing: members of the City Council. Professor Hermens' letter, dated July 21, ably pointed out the actual disproportion in representation that has been the result of this abortive attempt to assure representation of minority groups in New York's City Council.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 3 -- Eric Nordhoim of Washington D.C., made a successful invasior of Long Island Sound by winning the Long Island Bowl for Cornel Class craft today.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Aug. 3 (U.P.) -- Congress today decreed national mourning for President Tomas Berreta, who died here last night at Qie age of 71. A State funeral will be held tomorrow.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 3 -- Reports from Batavia, Java, that the Dutch and Indonesian armies would end their hostilities tomorrow, in response to the formal request made by the United Nations Security Council, were received here with qualified but immediate satisfaction.
A substantial increase in overtime cargo operations on ships in the Port of New York in the last year was reported here yesterday.

Mayor O'Dwyer now favors action by the Board of Estimate and the City Council to bring the question of a higher transit fare before the voters at a special election in January or February, while the 1948 Legislature is in session, it was learned last night.

Peacetime accidents can result in "scenes reminiscent of emergency transfusions on the field of battle," according to a survey on the use of whole blood and blood plasma in treating injured 'Civilians. The study, conducted by the Brooklyn Red chapter was made public yesterday by the Greater New York Red Cross Blood Donor Service.

PARIS, Aug. 3 -- The extreme urgency of measures to steady Europe through the coming winter, either through or ahead of the Marshal Plan, will be the dominant theme of a meeting here tomorrow of United States diplomats.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (A.P.) -- The House Merchant Marine Committee will consider this fall a plan, to charter ships to Germany and Japan for food transport, an idea first advanced by Herbert Hoover, Chairman Alvin P. Weichel of Ohio said today.
The Panama Pacific Line, a subsidiary of the United States Lines, will resume intercoastal freight service under private operation on Aug. 23, it was announced here yesterday.

DETROIT, Aug. 3 -- Tuesday at 1 P. M., Eastern Daylight Time, was set by the United Automobile Workers, CIO, tonight as the deadline for a nation-wide walkout of 107,000 employes of the Ford Motor Company after an eight-hour negotiating session failed to produce any area of close agreement on two fresh counter-proposals offered by the company.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 3 -- Dominating the play after a slow start, the Californiasis, led by George Oliver, defeated the Palo Duro team, 18 -- 1O, in the final of Pete Bostwick's $5,000 handicap polo tournament at Bostwick Field today.

A 4-year-old boy returning in a car with members of his family from a day at the beach was fatally wounded at 6:50 P. M. yesterday by one of six bullets fired by two policemen during a chase at a busy Bronx intersection.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 -- Wheat prices averaged lower and corn sharply higher on the Board of Trade last week, all deliveries of corn selling at a new seasonal high and December at $1.99 5/8 set a new record for that delivery. Cash corn was in broad demand and the white variety sold at $2.67 a bushel, or about 25 cents more than the previous high reached in August, 1917.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The names of the first group of American business men approved for entry into Japan were announced today by the Commerce Department. They will go into Japan between Aug. 15 and Aug. 29 on permits good for twenty-one days from the date of arrival.

ORADELL, N.J., Aug. 3 -- An extra-hole battle climaxed the 36-hole New Jersey State Scotch foursome championship today at the Hackensack Golf Club as Mike Cestone and Phil Damio of Crestmont tied with the Essex Fells team of Des Sullivan and George Ripley.

The Government's new edition of its fruit and vegetable canning booklet, reported here last week as being available from the Superintendent of Documents, Washington, for 5 cents in certified check or money order (not stamps), gives directions for the cold or raw pack method of preserving peaches and tomatoes in addition to those for the conventional hot pack.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 3 (AP) -- A pair of long putts that resulted in eagles 3's on the last hole of the Keller course threw Jim Ferrier of Chicago and Fred Haas Jr. of New Orleans into a tie with 272 totals at the end of the final round of play of the St. Paul open golf tournament today.
VIENNA, Aug. 3 -- Complete uncertainty was evident yesterday in Austria's chief bank, the Kreditanstalt, as to the fate of three important factories owned by the bank.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $52,897,866,912. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

The United Hospital Fund, as a result of a special study, announced yesterday that there had been a definite upward trend in the demand upon the city's voluntary hospitals. The fund aids in coordinating and expanding the services of eighty-nine voluntary hospitals and convalescent homes throughout Greater New York.

NANKING, Aug. 3 -- The Russians suddenly and mysteriously changed their maps showing the Outer Mongolia-Sinkiang border after 1940, according to Dr. Lo Chia-lun, Chinese Ambassador to India. The change was said to have come after Gen. Sheng Shihtsai, for many years the war lord dictator of Sinkiang, had shifted from a pro-Soviet policy to an anti-Soviet stand.

MOSCOW, Aug. 3 (U.P.) -- Boris Leontiev, Soviet political writer, reiterated today the Russian demands for full veto power in the writing of the Japanese peace treaty because the "entry of the U.S.S.R. into the war and the brilliant victories of the Soviet Army forced Japan to capitulate."

HAVERSTRAW, N.Y., Aug. 3 -- This sunny sabbath the residents of this village were in a reflective mood, contemplating how fame can slip away from a village as it can from a man; cogitating on the quirks of fate as applied to bricks.

Trade publications will be used by Royal Robes, Inc., to advertise the fact that its robes will be manufactured and merchandized in suit sizes instead of by "small," "medium" and "large" sizing which is the general rule in the robe industry, it was announced over the week-end.

This is no time to throw caution "to the winds, with the risk of inviting another inflationary spurt from which the reaction could be a good deal more serious," the National City Bank of New York declares in its August letter on general business conditions.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 -- Lard prices declined around 1 1/2 cents a pound last week as the result of commission-house liquidation due to a heavy make of that commodity, a rapid increase in stocks in cold storage and a lack of aggressive support.

PARIS, July 30 (By Airmail) -- Despite the cloak of secrecy surrounding the activities of the so-called "military committee for the renovation of Germany" in Russia -- successor to the former t Free German Committee -- details about the strange new German army now being trained in Russia are filtering through the iron curtain.

WESTBURY, L.I, Aug. 3 -- Diminutive Frankie Strafaci, 31-year-old Brooklyn insurance agent today became the second player in the forty-five-year history of the Metropolitan amateur championship to win the title for the fifth time.

TOKYO, Aug. 3 -- Although the Japanese press is filled with hopeful stories about the impending partial reopening of private foreign trade, which is scheduled for Aug. 15, the optimism is not shared generally by occupation officials.

For the first time in its history the Police Department this morning will mobilize its entire personnel of nearly 18,000 men to sweep from street, saloon, pool hall and other hangouts the horde of bookmakers, estimated to run into the thousands, that infests the city.

LONDON, Aug. 3 -- Sleeping measures that may change the whole course of Britain's economic history for years to come are under consideration as part of the Labor Government's drastic program to meet the mounting dollar crisis, it was learned today.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 3 -- Foud main Provinces -- two in India and two in Pakistan -- will be under British Governors after the transfer of power to Indian hands on Aug. 15, the Viceroy's office announced tonight.

An eleventh-hour settlement yesterday spared 25,000 Staten Island commuters a cessation of train service that had been set for 4 P. M. today by 200 trainmen and conductors of the Staten Island Rapid Transit Railway.

PORT DE BOUC, France, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Conditions aboard the Ocean Vigour, one of three British troopships that returned 4,500 would-be Jewish immigrants from Palestine to France last week, are unpleasant and uncomfortable but supportable.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (U.P.) -- Senator Chapman Revercomb, Republican, of West Virginia, said today that the Congressional investigation of prices and the high cost of living will turn the spotlight on "exorbitant" charges and will help in the drive to bring them down.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 3 (AP) -- This being a season of weird upsets on the grass courts circuit, the gallery at the Eastern grass court tennis championships remained until almost dark today while Phil Hanna, a radio singer from Jackson Heights, N.Y., battled Don McNeill of Orange.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 3 -- More than 7,000 Disciples of Christ from thirty-five countries gathered for both the international and work conventions of the brotherhood assembled for a communion service in Memorial Auditorium here this afternoon.

LAKE MOHAWK, N.J., Aug. 3 -- Best in show at the fourth annual dog show of the Lake Mohawk Kennel Club, held at the Lake Mohawk Golf Club today, was won by Mr. and Mrs. Phil Meldon's 2-year-old schnauzer, Dorem Display.

VIENNA, Aug. 3 -- Because Europe made the mistake of preferring to live high after World War I it lost World War II. Russia, which pursued a wiser policy, won that conflict and will win the next one, which is just as inevitable.

MUNICH, Germany, Aug. 3 -- One of the denazification tribunals in Munich soon will hear evidence against the Rev. Dr. Anton Scharnagl, who since August, 1943 had been the Auxiliary Bishop of the Munich archdiocese and one of the most prominent members of the Catholic clergy in Bavaria.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 3 -- The Governors Cup passed into the permanent keeping of Francisco (Pancho) Segura of Ecuador today when he won the Southampton invitation tennis tournament for the third time.

Despite man's great material'istic progress, the ancient problems of greed, pride and cruelty still level him and his machines to the dust, the Rev. Thomas F. Staher of the St. Patrick's Catheidral staff said at the solemn 10 o'clock mass there yesterday.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 3 -- At a press conference late last night aboard his special train returning to Sofia, Premier Georgi Dimitrov of Bulgaria termed "premature" references to a Balkan or Danubian federation as involved in the compacts h has just concluded with Premier Marshal Tito of Yugoslavia.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 3 (AP) -- A 3-week-old strike that all but paralyzed the largest flour milling center in the nation and threatened a shortage of flour in the northeastern states was ended today.

Two major offerings are scheduled for today, one consisting of $10,000,000 of 3 per cent sinking fund debentures, due on July 1, 1967 and priced at 100 per cent and accrued interest by the Lerner Stores Corporation, and 311,361 shares of the common stock of the New England Gas and Electric Association at $11.75 a share.

Random notes: The surfcasting reports on the fishing over the week-end were rather spotty, although Buzzards Bay and Martha's Vineyard seemed to produce good striped bass fishing. Long Island bass fishing was far from good, except at a few scattered points.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 4 -- Commodore De Coursey Fales' flagship, the schooner Nina, led the New York Yacht Club fleet tonight on its cruise run of thirty-six miles from Fishers Island here. Some had next to a noon-to-midnight sail.

Seeking to maintain a healthy installment credit control when th much-discussed Regulation W of the Federal Reserve Board goes out of existence on Nov. 1, the American Bankers Association disclosed yesterday that it will furnish all member banks with a schedule of down payments and maturities for different classes of installment loans.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 4 -- Ike Williams, 24-year-old Negro from Trenton, N.J., tonight became the first undisputed world lightweight champion since November, 1942, and proved himself a pretty good successor to a ring title rich in tradition.

Coinciding with the opening of an exhibition, "The Bird in Art and Fashion," at the Kennedy Galleries, 785 Fifth Avenue, the Onondaga Silk Company presented a showing yesterday at the Sherry-Netherland of fabrics dyed to the tones of birds' plumage and dramatized in costumes by nine designers.

Scrap Price Retreat? For the first time in two or three months, according to reports from Pittsburgh, there was talk yesterday among scrap dealers and brokers concerning a possible downturn in scrap metal prices. However, no softening has developed.

PARIS, Aug. 4 -- Tricornes, some dramatically large and Venetian, in feeling, are important in Albouy's collection. Some, large or small, have the three sides of the brim rolled. Others have flat triangular brims about an inch thick with velvet or jersey stretched on the underside but softly draped on the upper surface.

Sydenham Hospital, which nearly four years ago pioneered in the establishment of an inter-racial staff for an inter-racial clientele, announced yesterday another experiment designed to broaden the institution's community role in Harlem.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 4 -- Old Saratoga, where the horses have been running since 1864, had a triumphant opening of its at-home racing meeting today, with records falling on the track and in the box office and all hands having a most pleasant afternoon in the sunshine.

Real estate bonds made another slight gain in July, according to the average price index of Amott, Baker Co. July's advance of 1 per cent, following a gain of 1 1/2 per cent in June, lifted the average price to 3 per cent of their closing 1946 level.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 4 (AP) -- Mrs. B.C. Walsh's Forevermine, running the mile and a sixteenth in 1:46 1-5 to beat eight rivals of the $4,000 class, won the May's Landing Purse, feature of an all-claiming program, here today. A surprise winner, the 5-year-old son of Aethelstan II and Thine Alone paid $23.90, $12.50 and S6.50 across the board for a $2 ticket.

Prices of electrical appliances will remain at current levels for at least thirty days despite increased costs of steel, all elements of the trade agreed yesterday. Upward revisions, if any, by major producers are expected to be small. But distributors fear substantial increases by smaller operators forced to buy steel at "exorbitant" prices in the "gray market."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 4 -- David O. Selznick announced today that Alf Kjellin, Swedish stage and screen star, whom he has signed to a seven-year contract, will make his American film debut in "Tender Is the Night," with Jennifer Jones.

Permission for New York reporters to board the Russian liner Rossia was refused early yesterday off quarantine but a few hours later they were welcomed aboard the vessel at her Canal Street pier after her master described the earlier incident as a "misunderstanding."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- A New Yorker who complained he was maltreated by Louisiana mosquitoes and missed a plane connection because a Louisiana highway bridge remained open too long got some-action today from the War Department.

Thirty-five health inspectors checked sixty delicatessen stores yesterday in Helath Commissioner Israel Weinstein's drive to enforce the sanitary code. "Unsatisfactory conditions" were found in forty-eight of shops visited.

The question whether former Deputy Commissioner of Marine and Aviation I. James Brody and James V. Auditore were guilty of conspiracy and accepting unlawful fees for the rental of city-owned piers will rest with the jury today. The defense attorneys, Hyman Barshay for Brody, and Burton Turkus for Auditore, made their final pleas to the jury in General Sessions Court yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- No letup is in sight in the abnormal world demand for wheat, the Department of Agriculture said today in its report on the world wheat situation at the July 1 beginning of the new crop year.
OAK RIDGE, Tenn., Aug. 4 (AP) -- New aids for the attack on cancer have been developed through research with radioisotopes, a report of the Atomic Energy Commission revealed today.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 4 (AP)--The Commercial Credit Corporation announced today that when wartime installment buying regulations expire Nov. 1 it would "broaden its financing terms, but will make every effort to maintain such terms as will serve to protect the buyer against down payments and maturities which are uneconomic."

The stock market was unable yesterday to further the recovery of late last week and, although offerings proved light, the absence of support depressed prices from fractions to 2 points. The heaviness in the key industrials was transmitted quickly to other sections of the list and produced an inroad of 0.94 point in the composite rate.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 4--Pressing a move to obtain a more "equitable" distribution of state aid for education, State Senator Pliny W. Williamson of Scarsdale submitted to the County Board of Supervisors today figures showing Westchester receives a lower share per pupil than any other county in New York, $63.48.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 4 (AP) -- Jim Ferrier of Chicago shot a four-under-par 68 today to win the St. Paul open golf title and the $2,000 first money in a play-off with Fred Haas Jr. of New Orleans, who shot a 71.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Aug. 4 -- A selected group of eleven teachers of silversmithing and jewelry-making from universities, teachers' colleges and art schools of the nation gathered at the Rhode Island School of Design here today for the opening of a silversmiths workshop conference, the first of its kind in the United States, which will extend through Aug. 29.
This evening, at the moment of the second anniversary of the first atomic bombing, a large white cross will be raised in the Alamogordo Desert of New Mexico.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 4 -- Heavy firing began in the Eastern championship tournament today at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club. Frank Shields, Ted Schroeder, Gardnar Mulloy, William Talbert, Francisco Segura, Bob Falkenburg and many other American, British, South American and European notables entered the action.
With New York teams in first and second place, the first round of the World Master Mixed Team contract bridge championship was played yesterday afternoon at the Hotel St. George in Brooklyn.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 4--The duel of the year in American racing, Armed vs. Assault, seems likely to be staged some time this month at Washington Park, the track that's twenty miles or so from the heart of Chicago. The race, at a mile and a. quarter under scale weight of 126 pounds for a winner-take-all reward of $100,000.
Probationary firemen from the Fire College gave a noontime demonstration of skill and agility on eighty-five-foot extension ladders in City Hall Plaza yesterday before an audience of 2,500.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 -- More than 3,000 lines of consumer goods were displayed here today at the Merchandise Mart and the Palmer House and Stevens Hotel showrooms, as the forty-fifth semi-annual market opened, sponsored by the Commerce Association.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 4 -- Registration statements were filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Welsbach Corporation of Philadelphia and the Santa Maria Mines, Ltd., of Toronto, Canada, while two other companies withdrew registrations.

OGUNQUIT, Me., Aug. 4--Michael Myerberg's dramatization of Robinsons Jeffers' poem, "Dear Judas," was presented tonight before an attentive but not capacity audience at the Ogunquit Theatre, and those who suspected its religious propriety had their suspicions confirmed.

Zino Francescatti, French violinist, who was new to the Lewisohn Stadium, and Alexander Smallens, an old hand at directing the summer Philharmonic-Symphony, joined forces last night, in the last week of the series, to present an all-Beethoven program to an audience of 12,000.
Yesterday, for the third time in a week, 200 persons living on the westerly fringe of Idlewild Airport in Queens had a long hot walk. A bus line was stopped by a house in the road.

Longchamps restaurants has drawn up an advertising campaign, concentrated in newspapers, which calls for an increased budget in the next twelve months over recent similar periods. The nine principal New York daily papers will be used on schedules of two to seven times a week, to begin coincidentally with granting of new liquor licenses to the chain of cafes and bars.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 4 (AP) -- Supervision of the New Jersey Fish and Game Council's two coastal patrol vessels has been transferred from Fred C. Craig, Chief Game Warden, to the council's Boat Committee, it was disclosed today, but Arthur F. Foran, council chairman, said it was with Mr. Craig's approval.

The number of workers in the woolen and worsted industries during the first five months of this year was decreased by about 11,000, or 7 per cent of the number employed at the begining of the year, according to the National Association of Wool Manufacturers.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 -- Prospects for taking over of the surface and elevated lines by the Chicago Transit Authority, a public corporation, were lessened greatly today when a syndicate of 140 investment houses, formed to float a $105,000,000 bond issue for the authority, was dissolved.

Actors Equity Association yesterday turned down the League of New York Theatre's compromise proposal on the question of racial discrimination in the nation's capital. In a statement released by Paul Dullzell, executive secretary, Equity's council declared it was "shocked" to learn that a league negotiation committee should express opposition to the inclusion in the new contract of a clause directed at the existing ban on Negroes in the National Theatre, Washington, D.C.

EVANSTON, Ill., Aug. 4 (AP) -- The College All-Star football squad which meets the Chicago Bears, champions of the National League, in Soldier Field the night of Aug. 22, held its second practice session in the 100-degree heat of Dyche Stadium today.
Dress prices are following the pattern of increases shown in rayon goods, it was learned yesterday, and several manufacturers are raising prices on the average of $1 per garment on fall reorders.

The index is based on spot market prices. Most of the twenty-eight commodities are basic raw materials Store Sales Off 6% Here Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a decrease of 6 per cent last week over the comparable week a year ago, according to the "flash" report of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York yesterday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 (AP) -- The Cardinals made it four straight on their newest drive for a pennant recovery today by lambasting five Cub pitchers for seventeen hits and an 8-1 victory before a crowd of 20,215 sweltering in 97-degre temperature.

A survey of the comparative popularity of the frequency modulation stations in the metropolitan area has been made by Pulse, Inc., it became known yesterday. Findings of the survey indicate that approximately 3 per cent of the radio families in Greater New York had FM receivers, which would indicate that somewhere between 50,000 and 80,000 homes are equipped to receive the highfidelity form of radio transmission.
CHICAGO, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

A rent increase of 210 per cent -- from $25 to $77.50 for a "railroad" flat in an old law tenement -- was reported yesterday as a City Council committee prepared to call a public hearing on bills to give added protection to tenants.

TIMBER POINT, L.I., Aug. 4 -- A Star Class skipper, who came all the way from Chicago to see what South Shore sailing was like, gave a lesson to the local talent in the opening skirmishes of the thirtysecond annual Great South Bay Race Week today.
Associated Distributors, Inc., has moved Into larger quarters in the Pennsylvania Building, 225 West Thirty-fourth Street, it was announced by J. Harold Reuben, director.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 4 -- The House Subcommittee on Education and Labor which has been investigating activities of the American Federation of Musicians, AFL, resumed its inquiry today into alleged "featherbedding" and other labor practices in Hollywood.

HANK GREENBERG, resolutely driving himself along on aching legs, lashing at the ball and still hitting it for tremendous distances whenever he gets a fair share of his bat on it, seems very definitely to be playing his last season.

Influenced by a weak stock market and continued favorable weather in the South, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed 36 to 59 points lower than Friday's final prices.
Manager Bucky Harris probed hopefully in the darker recesses of his pitching cupboard last night. He found it quite bare of hurlers who had what it takes to stop the surprising Athletics.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- A Federal aid program for airports as revised and curtailed because of reduced appropriations by Congress was announced today by the Civil Aeronautics Administration.

Mayor O'Dwyer grave notice yesterday that in seeking to stablize labor costs in the construction industry, he was getting ready to deal with contractors who have been "padding" "their bids by as much as 50 per cent. Such bids, submitted on a "take it or leave it" basis, have prevented the city from going ahead with vitally needed construction, while contractors, equipment, money and mechanics are idle, the Mayor said.
