WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- The Export-Import Bank of Washington announced today the granting of $23,000,000 in loans to three large Italian industrial concerns, the credit to be guaranteed by the Italian Government.

Retail grocers yesterday started a two-way drive to improve service to the consumer by combating alleged uneconomic practices in wholesale distribution and considering merchandising improvements for stores. Both problems marked the annual convention of the New York State Food Merchants Association which opened at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

BOSTON, Aug. 4 -- The dental services of the Army and Navy were accused today of "discriminatory practices" and "gagging of officers" by Dr. Sterling V. Mead of Washington, in urging separation of the Dental Corps from the Medical Corps of both branches.
Trade with Japan of considerable volume is envisaged here by traders approved by the Department of Commerce for entry into Japan between Aug. 15 and 29, on permits good for twenty-one days.
LONDON, Aug. 4 (Reuters) -- Gloucestershire continued a strong bid for the English County cricket championship today by defeating Somerset by 316 runs, one of the easiest victories of the season.

There's no generalizing about American cooking. In a New York kitchenette, it's one thing; on a South Dakota farm, another: in a New Orleans household, still different. But in considering the various styles, one emerges that might be called simply "country."

Fireboats, blimps and airplanes are scheduled to participated New York Harbor's welcome to the refurbished Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary when she arrives here this morning from Southampton on her first post-war commercial crossing.

Passengers alighting from New York Central train Wolverine yesterday had much to discuss about the usually routine trip from Chicago. For it had been, the quick action of a dining car waiter that had saved them from a possibly disastrous accident and serious injury.

Textiles for the home have made a marked recovery since last spring as a result of sustained consumer buying, it developed yesterday at the semi-annual Domestics and Linen Show at the Hotel New Yorker.

The Third Coast Guard District, which is charged with the enforcement of safety regulations in the Port of New York and other ports from New Haven, Conn., to Edgemoor, Del., has issued an order raising the classification of all nitrate-bearing ships to the status of explosive carriers, it became known yesterday.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 5 -- Argentinos are definitely not tipping their hand regarding their attitude at the coming Rio conference.

The Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., in its semi-annual statement issued to stockholders yesterday by B. Brewster Jennings, president, reported consolidated net earnings estimated at $40,900,000 for the firs half of this year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Elliott Roosevelt denounced today suggestions that he had used "White House influence" to get a photoreconnaissance plane contract for Howard Hughes and shouted that the highest wartime command of the air forces had dismissed the accusation as "ridiculous."

Two years ago today a single bomb dropped from the skies brought death and destruction to the town of Hiroshima and signaled mankind's transition from an already grim iron age to an even grimmer atomic age. The bomb put a quick end to a slaughter which would have been much greater without it and thereby justified its use.

LYNDHURST, N.J., Aug. 5 -- A local character known as "The Indian," living up to his threat to kill anyone who attempted to evict him from his three-room shack, today killed a policeman and wounded another before he himself fell with three bullets in his body.

BERLIN, Aug. 5 -- The United States Military Government announced today that foreign students would be permitted to come to Germany and enroll at three universities in the American zone. This marks the first time that this type of international study has been permitted in the American zone since its suppression by the Nazis in 1933.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 5 -- A potentially important development in the Egyptian case before the United Nations occurred today when, according to reports from Khartoum, both Sudanese political blocs agreed on a joint request to the Security Council for the abolition of the Anglo-Egyptian condominium in the Sudan, establishment of a democratic government chosen by elections under United Nations control and the right of the future Sudanese government to decide the country's political future.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 5 -- Marshal Tito, it was learned tonight, told a group of American clergymen visiting Yugoslavia that "for the present" there were no signs of a break in relations between the Vatican and Belgrade "because we have patience."

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 5. -- Mayors of thirteen municipalities in northern New Jersey petitioned Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll today for State intervention in their fight to compel adequate train service at reasonable rates by the Central Railroad of New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Dave Ferriss limited Washington to five hits tonight, but his wildness cost the Red Sox a 3-1 defeat by the Senators. Ferriss walked seven and hit two batters in losing t Walter Masterson, who allowed seven blows in notching his ninth victory.

The war-time spree is over and a return to sound showmanship is imperative to maintain prosperity in the film industry, Jack L. Warner, vice president and executive producer of Warner Brothers Pictures, declared yesterday in announcing the studio's program for 1947-48 at the company's annual sales convention in Chicago.

SAG HARBOR, L.I., Aug. 5 -- The "crisis" facing the old Customs House here, which was to be razed to make way for a parochial school, has passed, it was announced today. Mrs. Nancy Boyd Willey, president of "The Old Sag-Harbour Committee," formed by local residents on July 14 to preserve the old landmark by raising $4,000, reported that public response has made it possible to save the building by moving it to another site.

TIMBER POINT, L.I., Aug. 5 -- Visitors' day in the Great South Bay race week competition today highlighted the first race for the Corry Trophy, a five-race series for Star Class yachts. Lads from outlying districts took three of the first four places in that event.
LONDON, Aug. 5 -- The stock market here had to contend with another bout of selling today when it opened after the August bank holiday.

Following strong protests against the action of certain apparel manufacturers in increasing prices of goods on previously confirmed orders, the Association of Buying Offices, representing stores all over the country, has called a meeting of ready-to-wear executives of the ABO and of National Retail Dry Goods Association members for 10:30 A.M. tomorrow.

President Holcombe Ward of the United States Lawn Tennis Association said yesterday that Gardnar Mulloy of Miami, Fla., Davis Cup player, had been ordered to appear before the amateur rule committee at the Harvard Club here tonight to answer "some questions about his expense accounts," The Associated Press reported.

PARIS, Aug. 5 -- French colonial difficulties took a new and dramatic turn today with an outbreak of violence accompanying a general strike in Tunisia and sharp disagreements in the Assembly Interior Commission over the statute of Algeria.

BERLIN, Aug. 5 -- Germans and many uniformed Allied personnel who had been alarmed by rumors that the western Allies were about to leave Berlin were officially reassured to the contrary tonight. They were told that the British would stay here as long as the others, including the Russians, and the point was made that this applied to the Americans and French as well.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5 -- Refusing to admit defeat, although no bids were received for its $105,000,000 bond issue, the Chicago Transit Board outlined today a new campaign to sell the bonds and make it possible to purchase and merge the surface and elevated lines for operation under public ownership.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Average earnings in manufacturing industries reached the record level of $48.91 per week and $1.22 per hour in June, the Bureau of Labor Statistics estimated today.

The report of the Food Machinery Corporation announced to shareholders yesterday showed record high customer billings of $25,087,219 for the second quarter of this year, representing an increase of $11,129,478 over the total for the similar three months of 1946.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- President Truman signed today a bill giving to Puerto Rico the right, for the first time since Ponce de Leon settled that island for the Spanish crown 439 years ago, to choose its chief executive by popular election.

Mayor O'Dwyer joined yesterday with Benjamin Fielding, his Commissioner of Licenses, in denouncing the action of the New York County Committee of the American Labor party which, on Monday night, voted Mr. Fielding down as a candidate for county vice chairman, ostensibly on the grounds that as a member of the Mayor's transit committee he had recommended a higher fare referendum.

The City of Minneapolis, Minn., awarded yesterday to a group headed by Phelps, Fenn Co., an issue of $1,300,000 of 1 1/4 per cent bonds at a price of 100.24 for $1,000,000 refunding bonds, and a price of 100.323 for $300,000 various purpose bonds, both plus accrued interest.

Negroes in the United States are still moving cityward in the same determined fashion they exhibited in 1910 when their migrations necessitated the organization of the National Urban League, the league's executive secretary, Lester B. Granger, announced yesterday.

Representing the 1,000,000 members of the largest patriotic group of women in the nation, 2,000 delegates will attend the twentyseventh annual national convention of the American Legion Auxiliary, which will meet here Aug. 28, 29, 30 and 31, it was announced yesterday.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 5 -- Miss Laddie Irwin of Glen Ridge, women's metropolitan champion, and Mrs. William Hockenjos of Crestmont, took a one stroke lead with 39, 40 -- 70 after eighteen holes had been completed today in the Women's Metropolitan scotch foursome two-day tournament over the Crestmont Golf Course.

Rail Merger The proposed consolidation of the St. Louis-San Francisco and the Gulf, Mobile Ohio railroads generally is considered a logical step. However, the belief is that it will require a long period for consummation.
Local 96, Financial Employes Guild, CIO, carried its three-weekold strike against the Brooklyn Trust Company into the heart of New York's financial district yesterday.

JACKSON, N.C., Aug. 5 -- Seven white men were freed today on charges of a lynching attempt upon a young Negro and soon afterward Gov. R. Gregg Cherry condemned failure of the Northampton County Grand Jury to indict them as "a miscarriage of justice."

With their celebrated home-run punch, the Giants charged to the support of Dave Koslo in his one moment of need last night and thus enabled their southpaw pitching ace to register his thirteenth triumph, 5 -- 2, over the Phillies at the Polo Grounds before a paying crowd of 27,233.

Nine more summonses were issued yesterday to delicatessen store owners in Health Commissioner Israel Weinstein's drive to enforce the city's sanitary code. Of the 130 establishments visited by thirty-five inspectors, conditions were found "satisfactory" in only twenty-seven, the department reported.

Buyers' Arrivals Increase Visiting buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,106, against 1,091 last week and 1,027 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Aug. 5 -- The Rumanian Parliament, dominated by Communists and fellow travelers, today voted unanimously to expel all thirty-two National Peasant party Deputies, including the twenty who had deserted their jailed leader, Dr. Juliu Maniu, and were willing to participate as "independents."

The International Ladies Garment Workers Union, AFL, will not follow the lead of other unions in boycotting the National Labor Relations Board or refusing to sign "no-strike" contracts under the Taft-Hartley Labor Law, David Dubinsky, the union's president, disclosed last night.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The first concrete steps in aid to Greece were disclosed by the State Department today in the announcement of contracts awarded to a total of $82,400,000 for the reconstruction and repair of Greek highways, railroads, bridges and ports. It was stressed that the restoration of communications was one of the most urgent tasks.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 5 -- The United Nations General Assembly will be asked to decide whether the principles of the Nuremberg War Crimes Tribunal should be codified to form a permanent part of international law.

Because one woman raised $1,000 in a month, youngsters at Camp Minisink, the New York City Mission Society's camp for Negro children near Port Jervis, N.Y., now have a much-needed road. When it is dedicated next Sunday, Mrs. Bertha J. Diggs, secretary of the New York State Department of Labor who raised the sum, will hand over the check.

BUFFALO, Aug. 5 -- Employment by the church of the group technique to salvage floundering marriages and combat the rising divorce rate was urged on the Third World Convention of Churches of Christ here this morning by Mrs. Clarence H. Hamilton, professor at Oberlin College, Oberlin, Ohio.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5 -- Buyer attendance and order volume at the Chicago fall market week improved today following a "spotty" opening, industry spokesmen reported here. The current heat wave, it was explained, kept buyers indoors on the first day as they sought to transact as much business as possible in one location.

The American Council for Judaism asked yesterday that the United Nations Committee of Inquiry on Palestine fully acquaint Jewish displaced persons in Europe of all relevant facts on Palestine and "Zionist propaganda" before polling them on their resettlement preferences.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The Department of Labor probably will keep secret the financial data required to be filed by unions before they may bring any action before the National Labor Relations Board.

Inventories of automatic electric washers are beginning to accumulate at retail, an executive of one of the nation's largest buying offices reported yesterday. He pointed out that this condition is a good indication that a full-scale buyers' market in these appliances is not too far off.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Aug. 5 (UP) -- Stephen Thuransky, naturalized American dramatically freed from Hungarian secret police, has been flown out of Hungary, an American Legation spokesman said today.

A public hearing will be held next Tuesday at City Hall on the three bills designed to give municipal authorities firm control over rents, evictions and the conversion of rented apartments into cooperatives.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The Library of Congress cited numerous appeals to President Abraham Lincoln for pardon or clemency in military and civil court cases as an "important clue" today to Robert Todd Lincoln's reasons for requiring his father's papers to be sealed for twenty-one years.

No plan for peace will be workable unless Russia and the United States participate in it, Dr. Theodor Rosebury, co-author of the Rosebury-Kabat report on biological warfare and bacteriologist at Columbia's College of Physicians and Surgeons, declared yesterday.

When summer draws on and the time of the Dog Star is fulfilled there is one consolation for the oppressive humidity that commonly settles on the countryside. When Sirius begins his reign the blue of the sky is reflected in the flowers that foretell the coming of a new season.

Longshoremen on the Atlantic Coast will press for a guaranteed eight-hour day when their union negotiators meet here tomorrow with employer representatives to discuss a new contract, it was learned last night.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 5 -- Victor Francen, who left Hollywood to return to France last year, has been engaged by Warners to appear in "To the Victor," which is now before the cameras in Paris. Francen will come to Hollywood when the company returns to the studio in September for final scenes of the film.

Negotiation of an agreement to stabilize construction labor costs went forward yesterday, but Mayor O'Dwyer reported that the desired objective seemed a long way from realization. The Mayor spoke optimistically of the strong inclination of both employers and union leaders to stabilize wages, but pointed out that many "details" would have to be worked out by the many unions involved.
The largest sales and earnings in its history were reported by the Procter Gamble Company for the fiscal year ended last June, according to the statement of Richard R. Deupree, president.
President Truman's program for aid to Greece received the official blessing yesterday of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

SECURITY COUNCIL Began consideration of AngloEgyptian dispute, hearing statements, by Prime Minister Nokrashy Pasha of Egypt and Sir Alexander Cadogan of Britain. Council meets today at 3 P.M. to continue discussion of Balkan problem.

I. James Brody, ousted Deputy Commissioner of Marine and Aviation, and James V. Auditore, onetime "millionaire boss stevedore," were convicted last night in General Sessions Court on all sixteen counts of an indictment charging conspiracy and taking unlawful fees in connection with the leasing of city piers.

DETROIT, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Pitching one-hit ball through six innings, Bob Lemon required some help in the ninth, but registered his second triumph since his promotion to a starting role as the Indians beat the Tigers, 8 to 4, today before a crowd of 25,626 in a twilight game.

A bright modern furniture department, brimming with practical suggestions for contemporary decorating schemes, was opened yesterday by Abraham Straus at a preview for designers and the press. The new section, called "Contemporama," is the first department in the store's new eightstory addition to be presented officially in its entirety.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As the time draws near when the resignation of Chairman Salmon o the City Planning Commission will take effect, the choice of his successor looms as one of the most important decisions that has yet confronted Mayor O'Dwyer.
DETROIT, Aug. 5 -- The Ford Motor Company avoided a strike of 107,000 workers today but at the same time announced a layoff of 51,000 starting within twenty-four hours.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 5 -- Declaring that "Egypt does not have to look far to find clouds gathering on the horizon," Mahmoud Fahmy Nokrashy Pasha, Egyptian Prime Minister, demanded today that the United Nations Security Council order the termination of British administration of the Sudan and the evacuation of British troops from Egypt and the Sudan.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 5 -- The Palestine Zionist leadership's ability to carry through its intended anti-terrorist campaign was put seriously in doubt by today's wholesale detentions of Revisionist and Right-Wing leaders.

STUTTGART, Germany, Aug. 5 -- The expediting of the complicated procedures currently hampering the export of German products was forecast today by Lawrence Wilkinson, director of the economics division of the Office of Military Government.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Howard Hughes took off for Washington at 2:32 P.M., Pacific standard time (6:52 Eastern daylight time), today to keep a date with the Senate War Investigating Committee, a spokesman announced.
BATAVIA, Aug. 5 (U.P.) -- The Dutch and Indonesian Governments clashed today on the question whether the United States or the United Nations should take the initiative to end their dispute.
SANTANDER, Spain, Aug. 5 -- Two American tourists have been wounded by bandits on the road near Santander and one is still in the hospital here, it was learned today.

Works of Nature Up in the Botanical Garden section of Bronx Park there are still about forty acres of the original forest that once covered the site of New York City. A notice posted by the park warning the public to be careful says that the forest has been called the city's "most precious natural possession."
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The Pirates jumped on four Cincinnati hurlers for eleven hits and ten bases on balls today to gain a 12-4 victory over the Reds.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 7,000, total 9,000; early market slow; later trade moderately active, uneven but generally steady to 25 cents lower on all weights and sows: liberal share of run sows;

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 5 -- Heartily devouring wind over the everlasting swells that wash the rocky coast here, the yawl Cotton Blossom, under charter to W. Mahlon Dickerson, today won the 1947 cup for sloops and yawls, put up by Vincent Astor.

Progress on New York's airports will be hindered little, if at all, by Congressional cuts in Federal airport funds, it was learned yesterday. The most urgent work in hand, at La Guardia Field, already is going forward with the Port of New York Authority making plans to fill in Bowery Bay, extend the east-west runway and repair the sinking east end of the field without undue interruption of traffic.

Reporting on operations of the Kendall Company and its subsidiaries for the twenty-four weeks ended on June 14, H.P. Kendall, president, informed stockholders yesterday that the net profit increased to $2,934,034 from $1,249,899 earned in the corresponding period of last year.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 5 -- Corruption in public life and the need of increasing industrial and agricultural production are cited by the Reserve Bank of India as the most serious economic problems confronting this country on the eve of its bifurcation and independence.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Ed Lopat handcuffed the Browns, 5 to 1, tonight, holding them to four hits and retiring seventeen batters in order as the White Sox scored their runs with eleven hits off Al Zoldak and Glen Moulder.

Louis Sherry now adds vacuumpacked coffee to its list of products that includes ice cream, candy and preserves. Beans from the area that embraces Antigua, Guatemala and southern Mexico go into the blend, trade-named Mayan. These have not been imported in any appreciable quantities here before, most of the supplies having gone to the Scandinavian countries.

Fred Waring and his orchestra, currently acting as the summer replacement for Fibber McGee and Molly, may be heard this autumn with their own permanent program on the evening schedule of NBC. Negotiations are being conducted for their appearance under the sponsorship of General Electric at 10:30 P.M. Mondays.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 5 -- Greentree Stable made it two in succession in the old race and Ted Atkinson made it three in a row for the afternoon when Star Bout took the seventy-third running of the $10,000 added Flash Stakes at Saratoga today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I believe that four years devoted to military service -- including nine months devoted to questioning Germans while tracing evidence of war crimes -- entitles my voice to a moment's hearing on the subject of increasing German industrial production.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved higher yesterday and closed with gains of 34 to 61 points.

Many orders for machine tools for Italian plants will be filled on short term delivery dates, after final agreements for Export-Import Bank Loans have been signed, industry spokesmen revealed here yesterday. Attractive delivery dates can be met by machine tool manufacturers, provided actual orders are placed before domestic orders increase this fall as a result of introduction of new models of tools, they said.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur in a special anniversary message to the people of atom-bombed Hiroshima observed today that the bombing gave warning that the destructiveness of war would progress until it could "exterminate the human race."

Advertising linage in New York newspapers during July totaled 8,844,560, a gain of 3.31 per cent over July, 1946, according to a compilation of Media Records figures. Losses were recorded, however, for financial, 29.92 per cent, and classified, 6.40 per cent.

Probably the basic cause of delinquency is that "kids have no money," Howard A. Lane, Professor of Education at New York University, Declared yesterday. Children who get into juvenile court usually are poor children and friendless children, he said.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 5 -- Thirtyfive leading Zionists were sent to the Latrun detention camp today 3 police and troops launched a wide round-up of suspected terrorist sympathizers. While the opertion was going on a bomb placed the Labor Department killed three British policemen.

GENEVA, Switzerland, Aug. 5 -- The decision of the United Nations Economic and Social Council to limit voting rights at the forthcoming trade conference to United Nations members has seriously impaired the prospects for a successful conference, Eric WyndhamWhite, secretary of the International Trade Organization preparatory commission, said today.
CHICAGO, Aug. 5 (AP) -- A home run by Del Rice with the bases loaded and another round-tripper by Whitey Kurowski escorted Harry Brecheen and the Cardinals to an 8-to-2 victory over the Cubs today.

Chief Signalman Harold E. Hirshberg told a Navy general court-martial yesterday that many of his fellow prisoners of war, including some who testified against him, had thanked him for his actions on their behalf during the period of imprisonment in the Philippines.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Representative Fred A. Hartley, Jr., the New Jersey Republican coauthor of the new labor act, who yesterday expressed the view that there may be an organized plot by the unions to evade its terms, today in Los Angeles excluded the Ford Company-UAW agreement from any category of planned evasion.

The Netherlands Government has agreed to lift all restrictions on the playing time of American films in that country, it was announced yesterday by Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Producers Association of America.

A position important to the city's physical development will become vacant when Edwin A. Salmon retires as chairman of the City Planning Commission. A letter printed elsewhere on this page today sets forth the high qualifications desirable in the successor to Mr. Salmon and presents the name of Ralph Walker, an architect long interested in city planning.

Directors of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway, at a meeting here yesterday, voted to distribute to the company's common stockholders as a dividend all the road's holdings of common stock in the New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 5 -- Standing pat on earlier recommendations, the Committee on Rights, Privileges and Amendments of the Constitutional Convention voted unanimously here today to reject appeals by the Congress of Industrial Organizations and the American Federation of Labor for stronger guarantees of collective bargaining and further simplification of the method of amending the charter.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 5 (U.P.) -- A special Federal grand jury Investigating allegations of widespread fraud in last summer's primary here, returned two more indictments naming six persons today.

TOKYO, Aug. 5 -- In the face of mounting opposition, the Government of Socialist Premier Tetsu Katayama has decided to push through the current session of the Diet the controversial bill for the nationalization of the Japanese coal mines.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- Tentative agreement was reached today to hold an industry-wide trade conference at New York City to frame regulations for the proper advertising and labeling of woolen garments treated for dimensional control.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 5 -- Coming up for their last licks, the Yankees needed one run to tie the Athletics tonight at Shibe Park, They got four. That ninth-inning outburst enabled the league-leaders to register an 8-5 victory over the Mackmen and a 14-length advantage over the Red Sox, representing their widest margin of the season.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 5 -- Public opinion and the Taft-Hartley Labor Law have forced the American Federation of Musicians (American Federation of Labor) in recent weeks to abandon a number of the stiff regulations that have given its president, James C. Petrillo, the reputation of a musical "czar," it was acknowledged today in testimony before the House Subcommittee on Labor and Education.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, Aug. 5 -- The transport shortage is helping industries in the Ruhr come back into fuller production than any other section of the AngloAmerican zones, Military Government officials disclosed today. The lack of railway rolling stock is becoming so acute that the coal stockpiles are growing in this area, even though production is hovering around 228,000 tons daily, half of the target figure.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 5 -- The Government tonight renewed its public attacks on The Associated Press. A communique issued by the Sub-secretariat of Information and carried on the radio denounced the agency as a distributor of stories regarded by Argentina as prejudicial to hemisphere harmony.

ATHENS, Aug. 5 -- The Greek Government, according to authoritative sources, is urging the United States to send a "symbolic force" of troops or fliers to back up an international body of frontier observers.
PARIS, Aug. 5 -- Elephant and squirrel grays, golden sand tones and black in taupe velours, velvet and suede are the colors of Legroux' collection, marked by quiet elegance.
MONTAUK POINT, L.I., Aug. 5 -- When you put out of this port after broadbill swordfish usually you can expect one of two things: a lot of exercise and excitement, or none at all.

Sara Jane Bray of Jackson Heights, Queens, a Pan American stewardess, told yesterday how she faced death in a blazing plane 18,000 feet over the Syrian desert on July 19. She was a witness before the inquiry of the Civil Aeronautics Board's safety division at the Hotel Lexington.

BOSTON, Aug. 5 -- With the timely help of a two-run, tie-breaking double by Hank Camelli off Hal Gregg in the sixth inning, Johnny Sain pitched the Braves to a 4-2 triumph over the Dodgers tonight before a crowd of 29,987 Hub fans.

DETROIT, Aug. 5 -- The temporary agreement as to financial liability under the new law, representing a contradiction of a stand taken last week by Henry Ford 2d, president of the company, was reached at 3 A.M., Eastern daylight time, and ratified ninety minutes later, after nearly eighteen consecutive hours of joint and private discussions.

CRESTWOOD, N.Y., Aug. 5 -- After two days of the Westchester competition in the fourteenth annual World-Telegram hole-in-one tournament at the Leewood Golf Club, the winner was produced today when John J. Whalen, 55-yearold chief engineer at the Hudson River State Hospital, in Poughkeepsie, struck a 9 1/2-inch shot that topped 322 players.

A million dollars for research into the cause and possible cure of infantile paralysis has been appropriated since the first of this year by the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, it was announced yesterday by Basil O'Connor, president of the foundation.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 5 -- Faris-el-Khouri of Syria, chairman of the United Nations Security Council, closed an inconclusive debate on the Balkan question today with the announcement that, although he was calling another session tomorrow, he had "not the slightest hope" for any solution.

The second session of the World Master Mixed Teams-of-Four championship was played yesterday at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn, with the New York combination of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis M. Jaeger, Harry Harkavy and Mrs. Gerre Strasser still in the lead.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Aug. 5 -- The eyes of every horse-lover who ever sat behind old dobbin will be focused on this town tomorrow when the Hambletonian Stake is trotted at Good Time Park, onemile kite-shaped track on which so much harness racing history has been written in the past two decades.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board has forbidden chartered airline flights between any points "with regularity or a reasonable degree of regularity" after Sept. 10.

ROME, Aug. 5 -- Russia will wage war as soon as she feels strong enough, an Italian Communist who said he had just returned after spending eight years in the Soviet Union wrote in the independent newspaper Tempo today.

BOSTON, Aug. 5 -- A bureaucratic plot by "feuding, conniving, scheming" agencies of the National Administration has sought to deceive Congress and change the American form of government, Speaker of the House Joseph W. Martin Jr. charged tonight.
A selective comeback was negotiated yesterday by the stock market, which repaired some of the damage to prices on Monday, although interest showed no appreciable enlargement.

LONDON, Aug. 5 -- Anti-Jewish violence continued today in many parts of Britain with new rock throwing assaults on Jewish property. Anti-Semitic slogans were chalked on walls and shops in Jewish residential districts.

JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 5 (AP) -- Most Negro voters went unchallenged today as Mississippi's new white primary law received its first test in a Democratic election for the nomination of a full slate of state and county officers.
SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 5 -- The large foreign contingent was all but wiped out in the men's singles in the Eastern grass court championships today at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Aug. 5 -- North American Light and Power Company asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today for permission to acquire 355,250 shares of the common stock of Northern Natural Gas Company, a subsidiary, if the latter splits its common stock two shares for one.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 5 -- Luis Carlos Prestes, Communist leader who has been missing since the Government outlawed the Communist party, appeared suddenly in the Senate and immediately asked to be heard.

The giant British liner Queen Mary, rebuilt after a notable war career in whch she safely carried 750,000 troops, chiefly Americans, returned to the familiar waters of New York Harbor yesterday as a luxury passenger liner.

Business men going to Japan this month will not make commitments for rayon textiles to be shipped to the United States, according to downtown importers yesterday. High duties applying to yard goods, they said, would make it impractical to import either gray goods or finished rayons.

Ranking police officials and the city's bookmakers were both in seclusion yesterday as investigations into gambling provoked more long conferences. Meanwhile, detectives and policemen on their beats visited countless street corners, cigar stores, newsstands, barber shops, bars and hallways.

ALBANY, Aug. 5 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, in his first public statement on labor since the enactment of the controversial Taft-Hartley Law, declared today that the principles of union organization and collective bargaining must be preserved.

THE patronizing attitude of some casual observers in blandly assuming that this country's sleek, well-fed athletes will have a competitive sinecure in the revival of the Olympic Games at London next year is appreciated no more at home than it is abroad.

LONDON, Aug. 5 -- Great Britain's Labor Government, in a surprise move, today introduced a bill to give it comprehensive powers over all industries and workers, to put teeth into its plans for overcoming the economic crisis.

STUTTGART, Germany, Aug. 5 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay today took occasion in his monthly address to the Council of States here to issue an emphatic rebuke to a "public official occupying a rather important position" who recently publicly charged displaced person with maintaining the black market.
Three Brooklyn youths decided to go swimming yesterday. For their pool they chose the East River and dived in off the Dupont Street pier in Brooklyn.

President Truman's plan to consolidate Federal housing activities is being put into immediate effect here, it was announced yesterday by Charles B. Lawrence Jr., director of the new regional organization of the Public Housing Administration. The effective date of the reorganization is Aug. 15, but the new set-up already has been planned.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 5 (U.P.) -- A counter-offensive by northern Paraguayan rebels today appeared to have forced the Government of President Higinio Morinigo to take desperate measures to defend his capital of Asuncion.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 5 -- Mozart's opera seria, "Idomeneo," in three acts and six scenes, received its American premiere last night in the Theatre Concert Hall at Tanglewood, where it was presented by the opera department of the Berkshire Music Center, under the direction of Boris Goldovsky.
BATAVIA, Java, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The Indonesian Army charged tonight that Dutch troops on two fronts had violated cease-fire orders in the East Indies.

SEELISBERG, Switzerland, Aug. 5 -- A radical revision in religious instruction and preaching by both Christians and Jews, including changes in the story of Christ's crucifixion, has been approved and will be proposed to the world's religious leaders by an interfaith conference of some sixty-five prominent educators, churchmen and laymen.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 5 -- Foreign Minister Raul Fernandas authorized me today to deny that Brazil was in any manner interested in the formation of a "Latin bloc" that is reported fathered by President Juan D. Peron of Argentina. Neither is he interested in the revival of the old bloc of Argentina, Brazil and Chile known as the "ABC bloc."

The United States and Soviet Russia are engaged in psychological warfare, and this country must maintain its military strength and alertness, Maj. Gen. William J. Donovan, lawyer and wartime leader of the Office of Strategic Services, declared yesterday.

Time, Inc., will not be able for "some time" to evict residential tenants of 270 Park Avenue to erect an office building there, Robert F. Wagner Jr. said yesterday. The Commissioner of Housing and Buildings gave his endorsement to a bill proposed by City Councilman Joseph T. Sharkey, which would prevent such evictions.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Unless the decision of Justice Benvenga published July 28 is reversed by a higher court, the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company and its subsidiary Stuyvesant Town Corporation, legally may continue to apply their policy of exclusion of Negroes from the Stuyvesant Town housing project.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- President Truman expressed confidence today that the world was headed for eventual peace with people living as "free individuals."

SCHENECTADY, Aug. 5 -- Contracts totaling about $35,000,000 for aircraft equipment for several new types of military and commercial airplanes have been awarded to the General Electric Company, it was announced here today.

Production of the Packard Motor Car Company in the second quarter of 1947 was 10 per cent higher than in the first quarter, but a net deficit of $724,461 resulted from operations in the three-month period ending on June 30 because planned schedules were not met, George T. Christopher, president and general manager, reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The Hungarian Government violated its armistice agreement with the United States in taking into custody and American citizen, known to Hungarian authorities to be such, the State Department charged today.

PARIS, Aug. 5 -- It is understood that Under-Secretary of State William L. Clayton and the three United States Ambassadors, whose conference here will end tomorrow, are agreed that the United States must act quickly to bridge the financially difficult interval between now and the coming into operation of the Marshall proposal for aid to Europe.

PARIS, Aug. 5 -- Returning to Paris from a Spanish Socialist party meeting in Toulouse, Indalecio Prieto, the party leader and a former Minister in numerous Spanish Republican Cabinets, said today that the Socialists would seek an accord with the Monarchist and Rightist parties for a coalition of all Republican groups of Spain.

Grocery distribution practices such as free deals, coupon offers, one-cent sales and premiums as presently conducted by grocery manufacturers are not "unfair and discriminatory" either to consumer or grocer, Paul S. Willis, president of the Grocery Manufacturers of America, stated yesterday answering charges made by retailers at the convention of the New York State Food Merchants Association.

Beaunit Mills Beaunit Mills, Inc., voted yesterday a quarterly dividend of 50 cents a share on the common stock for payment Sept. 2. Previously the company paid 35 cents quarterly with an extra of 50 cents distributed last December.

Carl G. Holmquist, an engineer in the firm of Sanderson Porter, who spent three weeks in Europe studying the physical and financial management of several harbors and inland ports, arrived at La Guardia Field yesterday aboard an American Overseas Airlines plane from London.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 5 -- The United Nations Economic and Social Council today appointed a committee of seven nations to report whether Chile's proposal for the creation of an economic commission for Latin America should be referred to the Inter-American Conference, wnich meets at Bogota, Colombia, next January.

American Gas and Electric American Gas and Electric Company directors declared yesterday the regular quarterly dividend of 25 cents in cash and 2/100ths of a share of Atlantic City Electric Company common on each share of common, both payable Sept. 15.

Aimed at "breaking the serious bottleneck in roller chain" a new production program for the product has been undertaken by Atlas Chain and Manufacturing Company, Philadelphia, Carl J. Meister, general sales manager, disclosed here yesterday.

ATHENS, Aug. 6 -- Premier Dimitrios Maximos called on Dwight Griswold, head of the American aid mission, today to discuss, according to informed Greek sources, economic questions. The Government's request for larger and more rapid arms deliveries to permit army expansion was also discussed.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- President Truman pocket-vetoed today the bill to set up a national science foundation, a project which he has sponsored repeatedly.
Brown was a predominant note in the dual show that Saks Fifth Avenue presented yesterday in the Penthouse Club, 30 West Fiftyninth Street. It was directed at the career girl and the collegienne.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Boston's Earl Johnson and Mickey Harris restricted Washington to a brace of infield hits tonight, but the Senators produced an unearned run in the first inning and Mickey Haefner made it good to beat the Red Sox, 1 -- 0.

If the Marshall Plan is to achieve its aim of increasing European industrial production, it will need the backing of American importers to place orders for consumer goods under more favorable tariff conditions, it was asserted yesterday by Samuel Shapiro, president of Smart Set Gloves.

Low-End Dresses Scarcer Dress manufacturers in many instances have withdrawn cheaper lines, according to trade sources yesterday. In one case, 70 per cent of dresses priced from $6.76 to $8.75 were discontinued. Dresses in the $4.75 range are limited, it was stated, and in cheaper ranges, values do not appear to be good enough for heavy commitments.

VIENNA, Aug. 6 -- Sir George Rendel, British chief delegate to the Austrian Treaty Commission sitting here, protested today against the Soviet seizure of the joint British and American oil refinery in Lobau opposite Vienna. He was supported by Joseph Dodge, head of the United States delegation.

The expected is happening in Indonesia. The Dutch accuse the Republicans of violations of the "cease fire" order that was issued on request of the United Nations Security Council. The Republicans, in turn, accuse the Dutch of violations, specifically of having pushed on to original objectives after the Sunday midnight deadline.

STOCKHOLM, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Nine American athletes gave Sweden's Olympic hopefuls some new marks to shoot for as a record crowd for a track and field meet turned out for the second program of the Stockholm games tonight.

The two major parties joined last night in amending their rules so as to have a castiron defense against infiltration by minor party groups, with particular reference to Vito Marcantonio and his New York County branch of the American Labor party.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Miss Maud Morlock, consultant of the Social Service Division of the Children's Bureau, protested today against the custom under which registration of births and deaths are financed by sales of these lists to commercial concerns, usually at a cent a name.

DETROIT, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Sweeping both ends of a doubleheader from the Cleveland Indians, 13 to 6 and 7 to 5, the Detroit Tigers vaulted over the Boston Red Sox into second place in the American League today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 6 -- The United Nations Security Council established a special seven-nation subcommittee today with instructions to determine by next Monday whether a single resolution could possibly be drafted to settle the Balkan question.

BOSTON, Aug. 6. -- The sponsor of Blue Cross Hospital insurance in Massachusetts filed today with the State Department of Insurance a petition to put a limit of $9 a day on the hospitalization costs it will pay.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- As Prime Minister Attlee was addressing the House of Commons in London today, two American Cabinet officers announced here the willingness of the United States to discuss with Great Britain liberalization of the $3,750,000,000 loan authorized by Congress.

BERLIN, Aug. 6 -- The United States plans to establish a termination date for the extradition of war criminals in the American zone wanted by other countries, it was learned today. This is a major part of the plan to complete the war-crimes program by the end of 1947.

Magistrate J. Roland Sala, who in April, 1946, gave a tonguelashing to a patrolman for tagging the jurist's illegally parked vehicle, was involved in another car incident yesterday. He blamed it on an "anti-union crackpot."

MAYS LANDING, N.J., Aug. 6 -- City Commissioner Albert N. Shahadi of Atlantic City, who also serves as the resort's Police Recorder, was indicted today by a hold-over January Atlantic County grand jury on three counts charging misconduct in his office as recorder.

The first break in more than three months in the soaring spiral of scrap metal prices was reported yesterday by one New York dealer, who reduced his quotations by $1 a ton for heavy-grade melting scrap at Pittsburgh. His new price is $44 a ton for the material.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 5.000, total 6,000; market fairly active and uneven, 25 to 75 cents higher; most advance on butchers weighing 250 to 300 pounds and on sows; top. $28.25; bulk good and choice

"Incomplete understanding" of the resolution on newspaper retail and general advertising rates adopted by the Newspaper Advertising Executives Association at their San Francisco conference was responsible for recent discussions between James W. Egan Jr., president of the association, and Lew Hahn, president of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, it was stated yesterday following a conference here between the two men.
Skippy, somebody's pet raccoon, is in the clink. But before he was caught at 9 A.M. yesterday the animal led children, parents and police of a Lower East Side neighborhood in a wild chase.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Two groups of Wisconsin Central Railway bondholders asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to re-examine a plan of reorganization for the road approved in June.

The nation's gasoline stocks declined last week only 167,000 barrels, the smallest weekly drop for several months, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the end of the period total supplies were 85,645,000 barrels, compared with 85,812,000 a week earlier and 87,217,000 on Aug. 3, 1946.

Bud Abbott and Lou Costello were signed formally yesterday to appear this fall on the ABC network (WJZ) with their comedy routine. The hour that they will be heard has not been decided but their series is scheduled to begin in mid-September.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES. The Art Commission of New York is entirely correct in asserting Jurisdiction over the question of the destruction of old Castle Clinton in Battery Park and its removal and the substitution for it of an open space in the park, as proposed by Park Commissioner Robert Moses.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 6 -- Charging that "unbridled and unconscionable profiteering" by American industry was leading the country toward a new depression, Jacob S. Potofsky, president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, Congress of Industrial Organizations, warned today that unions would have to seek further wage increases if prices continued to rise.

SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain, Aug. 6 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco took part here today aboard the Argentine cruiser La Argentina in a formal farewell ceremony concluding the visit of the ship to San Sebastian. The cruiser sailed at 1:20 P.M., for Lisbon, Portugal, to continue her 28,000-mile training cruise.

Free legal advice for New York tenants faced with rent increases, eviction threats or other problems under the Federal and city rent laws was assured yesterday at a meeting in City Hall of 200 members of the eleven local bar associations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Another regional warm-up for 1948, watched with keen interest here because it may provide a clue on where Ohio's twenty-five electoral votes will go in the Presidential campaign, will come Nov. 4 when Cleveland elects a mayor.

The first of two scheduled appearances by Alicia Markova and Anton Dolin and their little ballet company at the Lewisohn Stadium last night served to attract a capacity audience, with some wouldbe spectators turned away from the box-office.
In a surprise move late yesterday the National City Bank of New York announced that interest costs on various broker and dealer loans would be increased, effective next Monday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Howard Hughes swore today, and was strongly contradicted under a like oath, that Senator Owen Brewster had offered for a consideration to quash before it began the current Senatorial investigation of war contracts given to the Hughes interests.

VIENNA, Aug. 6 -- About $25,000,000 worth of foodstuffs have been shipped to Austria or contracted for under the United States relief plan for the months of July, August and September, according to responsible reports.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Aug. 6 -- Part of the bleachers collapsed at Good Time Park today and dumped 400 men and women, assembled for the Hambletonian trotting classic, into a shrieking, weeping tangle with broken timbers on the ground.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 6 -- E.P. Taylor's Spats shot out of the gate in today's thirtieth running of the Schuylerville Stakes, had a one-length lead in little more than a couple of jumps, and tow-roped the field for the rest of the way.

Dissenting members of the League of New York Theatres yesterday afternoon rallied to the support of Actors Equity in its campaign to have the League rescind the ban against the admission of Negroes at the National Theatre, Washington, D.C., by attending a closed protest meeting in the offices of the Playwrights Company, 630 Fifth Avenue.
By cocktail hour this afternoon, the nine Longchamps restaurants probably will be serving alcoholic beverages for the first time in more than five months.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- All unions will be able to get a hearing before the National Labor Relations Board under certain circumstances even if they refuse to file financial data and affidavits prerequisite to starting board action.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The White Sox bunched five hits in the second inning tonight off Bob Muncrief and scored as many runs in defeating the Browns, 7 to 3.
Twenty Boy Scouts from nineteen senior troops in Greater New York "camped out" yesterday in City Hall Park, pitching three tents, building a two-log fire, and cooking a barbecue, Western style.

SECURITY COUNCIL Established, a subcommittee of Australia, Colombia, France, Poland, United States, United Kingdom and Soviet Union to try to draft a new resolution on the Balkan problem. Subcommittee meets today at 10:30 A.M. (closed), and the full council at 3 P.M. (open).

TIMBER POINT, L.I., Aug 6 -- A brisk Southeaster that caused the small boats to be sent over a separate course in the interests of safety made no difference as far as the placings of the leaders in the Star Class series for the Corry Trophy were concerned today.

A foursome led by Harry J. Fishbein, of New York, three-time winner of the Vanderbilt Cup bridge tournament, won yesterday the World Master Mixed Team-ofFour championship of the American Contract Bridge League.

Foreshadowing rate increases by utilities in this and other states, because of higher operating costs, the Public Service Commission yesterday announced that it had granted a temporary increase in gas rates to the Kings County Lighting Company.

LONDON, Aug. 6 -- The whole question of how Great Britain's world position is to be adjusted to her present restricted economic situation is involved in projected Anglo-American discussions at a "high official level" that are exppected to begin in Washington next week.

Seen from miles, a spectacular fire in a storage warehouse on the lower East Side early this morning destroyed thousands of dollars worth of newsprint, including a supply consigned to THE NEW YORK TIMES as well as other metropolitan dailies, and routed 100 men, women and children from their homes in the Vladeck housing project and surrounding tenements.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 6 -- Spokesmen for the motion picture industry emphatically denied on the witness stand today suggestions by the House Subcommittee on Education and Labor that the industry had conspired with the American Federation of Musicians, (American Federation of Labor), to stymie the development of television.

Mid-summer dullness prevailed yesterday on the stock market and prices eased moderately with a reduction of 0.62 point in the composite rate. Both in volume and breath the session proved the dullest since late June with transfers on the Stock Exchange at 660,000 shares, compared with 750,000 shares on Tuesday.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 6 -- With one exception, Americans were in sole possession of the field in both the men's and women's singles at the end of play today in the Eastern grass court tennis championships.
PARIS, Aug. 6 -- Ho Chi Minh's government in Indo-China has given its concrete guarantees to facilitate the end of hostilities, according to Overseas Minister Marius Moutet.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 6 -- The team of Mrs. H.C. Ramsey of Baltusrol and Miss Maureen Orcutt of Ridgewood, Eastern champion, added a three-over par 78 today to its first-round 80 for 158 to win the women's metropolitan Scotch foursome tournament over the Crestmont Golf Club course.

ALAMOGORDO, N.M., Aug. 6 -- Atop one of the highest dunes of White Sands National Monument near here the divinities of Christianity, Judaism and Islam were invoked last evening to help mankind forestall an atomic war.

MATTAPOISETT, Mass., Aug. 6 -- The Alumni Association of the United States Navy challenge cups were up today on the squadron run of the New York Vacht Club from Newport to here. They were won by William T. Moore's 12-meter sloop, Nereus; Commodore DeCoursey Fales' schooner, Nina, and A. Howard Fuller's sloop, Gesture.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The Rumanian Government violated its peace treaty with the United States by its suppression of the National Peasant party and the arrest of Juliu Maniu, its leader, the State Department charged today. A further protest on the subject has been filed in Bucharest by Roy M. Melbourne, acting United States representative in Rumania.

After gaining an early lead, the Sanitation Department baseball team held off the Police Department nine in the closing stages to win, 4 -- 3, yesterday at the Yankee Stadium before 28,176 spectators. It marked the ninth consecutive victory for the Sanitation in the ten-year rivalry.

MARSEILLE, France, Aug. 6 (U.P.) -- Armed guards patrolled the docks hare today as the Runnymede Park, one of the three British transports which returned 4,000-odd Jewish immigrants from Palestine to French waters, was refueled preparatory to sailing with her sister ships to a secret destination.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Aug. 3 -- For forty years I have harbored an ambition to float in the ocean depths just as I have traveled the stratosphere in a balloon. But it was not until a few years before World War II that I saw a chance of carrying out my ideas, when the Belgian National Fund for Scientific Research supplied me with the necessary cash to begin experiments.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 6 -- La Nacion, one of the two leading oppositionist newspapers, has filed its answer to the Government's demand that it and La Prensa show cause why they should not be compelled to pay import duties on newsprint.

Scrap Shortage The steel industry continues to be plagued by a shortage of scrap metal, a vital ingredient of the steel-making process. Many companies had been pressing for Governmental haulage of battlefield scrap from foreign lands to the United States to alleviate the situation, but a recent report on the matter by the Navy Department probably will end that idea.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- President Truman accepted today President Eurico Gaspar Dutra's invitation to visit Brazil late this month or early in September. Dates and plans must still be worked out.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The Democratic high command is not only willing but even eager, it was learned today, to hold its 1948 national convention at San Francisco.

LONDON, Aug. 6 -- Powers akin to those invoked in the wartime emergency will be utilized by Great Britain in her fight for economic survival, Prime Minister Attlee told a crowded House of Commons today.

Thirty women and seven men, each carrying or escorting at least one small child, paraded outside the State Division of Housing at Broadway and Chambers Street, at noon yesterday. The demonstration was a protest arranged by the Manhattan Beach Veterans Tenants Association, against what was described as "the arbitrary, unexplained and unwarranted denial of two-room units to occupants of overcrowded one-room units."

LONDON, Aug. 6 -- With buyers coming into the stock market here today at the last moment before Prime Minister Clement Atlee's economic survey in the House of Commons, prices rallied in most sections.

BATAVIA, Java, Aug. 6 (AP) -- United States Consul General Walter A. Foote succeeded in broadcasting today a message to Indonesian headquarters in Jogjakarta an offer from Washington to mediate the conflict in the Netherlands Indies.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Allow me to congratulate you on your editorial of Aug. 3, entitled "The Tragedy of Puerto Rico."

Broadway managers, working out their plans for the fall season announced important casting news yesterday. The firm of Eddie Dowling and Louis J. Singer, which contemplates three projects this season, has engaged Julie Haydon to portray the schoolteacher in "Our Lan'," due at the Royale Theatre on Sept. 27.
CHICAGO, Aug. 6 -- Corn futures continued their sensational advance on the Board of Trade today, all deliveries selling at a new seasonal high, and September went to a new peak at $2.24 3/4.

WASHINGTON, Aug 6 -- Considerable embarrassment was in evidence at the State Department today over the way to treat French objections to the revival of German industrial production. The United States policy in the matter may have to be settled by President Truman, as two members of his Cabinet appear to be at odds.

An Army officer at two prisonerof-war camps in the Philippines testified yesterday that he gave Chief Signalman Harold E. Hirshberg and other non-commissioned officers orders never to hit Americans in the presence of the Japanese.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 6 -- Curtailment of the big power veto in United Nations Security Council decisions was recommended here tonight by John Foster Dulles, one of the five American delegates to the U.N. General Assembly convening at Flushing Meadow this fall.
SOFIA, Bulgaria, Aug. 6 (UP) -- Nikola Petkov, opposition political leader, pleaded not guilty to treason charges and implied that his prosecution by the Communist Government was a frame-up.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 6 -- Soviet proposals regarding the functions of the proposed international atomic control agency are "wholly inacceptable," Frederick H. Osborn, Deputy United States Representative on the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission, said today.

Prime Minister Attlee's statement to Parliament yesterday on the British "dollar crisis" followed closely in its general outlines the pattern forecast for it in advance news stories during the past few days. By and large the statement may be summed up by saying that it represented both a sober appraisal of Britain's exchange problem and an earnest of the Government's adherence to the spirit of the Marshall Plan, with its emphasis on self-reliance.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Army Chief of Staff, James V. Forrestal, who is to be the new Secretary of National Defense, and Kenneth C. Royall, Secretary of War, are among the speakers who will address the American Legion at its twenty-ninth annual convention here Aug. 28-31.
DETROIT, Aug. 6 -- The heat, shortages and strikes took a toll of more than 116,000 jobs in the automotive industry today, cutting sharply into already lagging production.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninetyfour leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended July 30, according to the Federal Reserve Board: An increase of $314,000,000 in loans and a decrease of $415,000,000 in holdings of United States Government obligations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- William A. Ayres, member of the Federal Trade Commission, said today he wanted an early clarification of the commission's position on cooperative procedures in achieving fair trade practices and would make some specific proposals of his own in seeking a solution of the policy conflict with Commissioner Lowell B. Mason.

With little in the way of positive effort, except by Larry Jansen, who went the distance impressively in registering his twelfth triumph of the season, the Giants took the Phillies into camp for the second successive time, 5 -- 2, before a crowd of 12,424 at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

With the signing by President Truman of the Butler-Crawford bill that amends the Organic Act governing Puerto Rico to allow the Puerto Ricans to elect their own Governor, our principal Caribbean possession has progressed farther along the road to the self-government that was promised in 1898 than any other off-shore territory of the United States, including Hawaii.

The author of this article is the leader of the Kon-Tiki expedition, a group of five Norweyian scientists and one Swedish scientist who are trying to prove, by duplicating the feat, that ancient preIncan Indians traveled from South America to the Polynesian islands on rafts carried by the Peruvian (Humboldt) current.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6 -- William R. Morgan, attorney representing a junior bondholders group of the Chicago surface lines, issued notice today that he would file tomorrow in Federal District Court a petition demanding the abandonment of the Chicago Transit Authority plan and the separate reorganization of the surface lines.

Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander declared yesterday at a press conference called in connection with the gambling investigation that he had no intention of demoting or pressing departmental charges against any of the twenty-two division commanders he transferred on Monday.
In addition to the tried and true favorites, plaids and corduroys, Franklin Simon had several new ideas in the fare presented yesterday in their College Shop.

PARIS, Aug. 6 -- The commander of the Soviet zone in Germany notified the economic conference of sixteen Western European nations today of his refusal to answer the questionnaire on Germany's requirements and capacity for selfhelp under the Marshall Plan.
PARIS, Aug. 6 -- The Communists withdrew from the Spanish government in exile today and precipitated the resignation of Dr. Rodolfo Llopis and his Cabinet.
After a lapse of six years, rowing in the Central Park Lake at 110th Street will be resumed tomorrow, the Department of Parks announced yesterday.

Gardnar Mulloy, fifth ranking amateur singles player in the country and a member of the Davis Cup team, appeared before the rules committee of the United States Lawn Tennis Association last night to answer "some questions about his expense accounts."

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 6 (AP) -- Challenging the constitutionality of the Taft-Hartley Labor Law, the Connecticut Federation of Labor and an AFL local union today, in paid newspaper advertisements, urged the political defeat of Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican, of Ohio, and Connecticut members of Congress who voted for the measure.

MANILA, Aug. 6 -- Philippine Government defense forces today mobilized 1,000 men around the United States naval base on Samar Island to prevent organized raiders from stealing $150,000,000 worth of American surplus property that Will shortly revert to the Republic under the Philippine Rehabilitation Act.

Predicting that Howard Hughes' arrival in Washington would mean "a little fun down there," and calling for an investigation of contract officers, military and naval, Elliott Roosevelt arrived at La Guardia Field by plane from the capital shortly after noon yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 6 -- The Third United States Circuit Court of Appeals refused today to order the Securities and Exchange Commission to discontinue its inquiry into the relationship between the Standard Gas and Electric Company, Chicago, and its subsidiary, the Market Street Railway Company, San Francisco.

PARIS, Aug. 6 -- At the meeting of William L. Clayton, Under-Secretary of State for Economic Affairs and the three principal United States Ambassadors in Europe, which ended here today, the prevailing view was understood to be that the best solution of the urgent European financial problems would be a special session of Congress this fall if it could be counted on to act quickly on emergency measures.

"PROTHALAMIUM," by Philip Toynbee, is by all odds the most unusual novel we've come across this year. It is the story of an afternoon gathering before a wedding in a modern England between the wars, but you have to work hard to find out what it's all about, and even then the intricate allegories that festoon it are apt to elude you.

Wide public relief will naturally be felt that the dispute between Ford management and labor did not result in the expected strike. A strike on such an important segment of the labor front might readily have proved a national disaster, especially if similarly inspired walk-outs had spread to other industrial fields.

Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday that he would ask the Board of Estimate at its scheduled regular meeting on Aug. 28 to reconsider its action of July 24 when it authorized the Park Department to complete the demolition of the old Aquarium in Battery Park and appropriated $54,000 for that purpose.
Moving above and below the previous closing levels, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday worked to final net gains of 5 to 16 points.

Sydenham Hospital, which four years ago appointed Negroes to its medical and nursing staff and included them among its trustees, announces the creation of an Institute of Community Relations. The hospital is to practice good corporeal medicine, the new institute a kind of social medicine.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 6 -- Sutan Sjahrir, former Premier of the Indonesian Republic, will leave Cairo tomorrow for the United States. He said today he would go to New York without any specific proposals for the Security Council.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6 -- A shortage of some lines of apparel during the fall and winter selling season is threatened because of curtailed buying early in the year, Wallace O. Oilman, general manager of the Merchandise Mart, warned today during the Chicago fall market week.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The Maritime Commission said today that it was reducing personnel in its field offices by about 60 per cent because of appropriation cuts.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 6 -- The detention yesterday by British authorities of thirty-nine Zionist leaders, including three Mayors, appears to have had a boomerang effect. The action has deeply incensed most Zionists in the country and may weaken the united front that was being prepared against terrorism.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 6 -- Yemen, whose application for membership in the United Nations was the tenth to be taken up in the Security Council's Committee on new members was endorsed today by the Soviet Union and France.

Looking for a Home Considering the national situation in regard to housing, the advertising of country homes, big and little, makes interesting reading. With people clamoring for any kind of protection from the weather, it was logical to assume that rural realtors would not bother with many adjectives.

SALZBURG, Austria, Thursday, Aug. 7. The Salzburg Festival reached its climax last night with the "world premiere of "Danton's Death," a violent, noisy and somehow extraordinarily effective opera by the young Austrian composer, Gotfried Von Einem.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Aug. 6 -- Mrs. Sylva Leichner, former New York State champion, and R. M. Torgerson, recent winner of the qualifying medal in the metropolitan amateur championship, formed the outstanding team of the biggest Long Island mixed foursomes championship today at the Piping Rock Club.

NANKING, Aug. 6 -- British officials in Hong Kong were charged with failing to cooperate with Chinese authorities in checking a stream of smuggling between Hong Kong and China by Dr. George Yeh, Foreign Office spokesman, at a press conference today.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Taca Airways, S.A., 8-year-old Panama-incorporated airline holding company, had a consolidated net loss of $7,920,406 in 1946, its annual report filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission showed today.

Benjamin J. Rabin, former chairman of the State Mortgage Commission and now a Representative in Congress from the Bronx, will be nominated tonight for the vacancy existing in the Supreme Court in the First Judicial District by the Democratic judicial district convention.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 6 -- Both the India and Pakistan Governments announced today special arrangements for the relief of refugees from riot areas, while in Bengal and Punjab Provinces the most stringent regulations have been introduced to curb growing communal disturbances.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The American Federation of Labor asserted today that "more than a million jobs will probably be lost" unless consumers could absorb an expected rise in production.

Americans, like rabbits, enjoy nibbling, while they are reading, chatting over drinks in a bar, listening to the radio, watching a ball game, sitting in a movie. They munch on popcorn, potato chips, peanuts, pretzels. Now a new finger food has been invented, the manufacturers of which call it "a chip off the old kernel."

Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Company, one of the nation's largest carpet producers, has expanded its product development, styling and design, market research and merchandise planning departments to meet keen competition, William N. Freyer, vice president, disclosed yesterday.

Although a record enrollment of 200,000 full-time students is expected in the colleges and universities of New York State this fall, there still exist 3,500 openings for freshmen in various institutions.

BOSTON, Aug. 6 -- Old Man Disaster, who, so far as Joe Hatten is concerned answers to the name of Bob Elliott, overtook the Dodgers under the lights tonight as the Braves beat them, 7 -- 3, and took a 2-to-1 edge in the current series thus far.

Customs-free zones for all international airports, like that at Shannon, Eire, were advocated yesterday before the Civil Aeronautics Board's safety division hearing at the Hotel Lexington by Gordon Cameron, in charge of line maintenance for Pan American Airways.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Aug. 6 -- Another Hambletonian Stake, harness racing's blue ribbon event for 3year-old trotters, is ready for the history books with Mrs. James B. Johnson Jr.'s Hoot Mon, trained and driven by the veteran Sep Palin of Indianapolis, winner of the famous 22-year-old classic.
YORK, Pa., Aug. 6 (AP) -- John W. Gibson, Assistant Secretary of Labor, said tonight, that the Labor Department was "apprehensive" over the Taft-Hartley Labor Act.

PARIS, Aug. 6 -- The sumptuous brocades, the velvety duvetyns and wool velours, the subtle colors of this season in the hands of Maggy Rouff, result in a luxury collection of great beauty. In a few words it is only possible to touch upon some of the highlights.

The extent of religious liberty in Russia, Spain and Italy is discussed in a world-wide survey to be published in book form today under the auspices of the American Committee of the World Council' of Churches. It bears the title "Christianity Today."

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 6 -- Long, long ago a baseball sage remarked: "You can't win 'em all." Old Bobo Newsom was able to second that motion today, as the Athletics handed him his first setback since he joined the Yankees. The score was 5 -- 3 in favor of Connie Mack's hustling lads, who wrapped this one up with a 4-run rally in the sixth inning.
Fire Commissioner Frank Quayle banned ammonium nitrate cargoes yesterday from all piers and storehouses within the city.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Aug. 6 -- Emery Thomas, professional at the Forest Hill Field Club, holed an ace, fifth in the tournament's history, in the New Jersey competition of the fourteenth World-Telegram hole-in-one tournament today. He achieved the feat on the special hole used for the tourney on his own course.
Unless conditions change rapidly for the worse, and with the recent fine weather this can happen, Martha's Vineyard should be the "hot spot" for surfcasters this Week-end.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- When Prime Minister Atlee in Commons today offered personal assurances that the forthcoming Anglo-American conferences to revise two clauses in the credit agreement between the two countries "would not cut across the Paris conference," he was repairing one of the strains that have arisen between Washington and London.

With the date of mandatory fair trade enforcement a little more than three weeks off, expectation was voiced in liquor trade circles yesterday that consumer buying, up to now running fairly level, may break into a last-minute rush to beat higher prices.
CHICAGO, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Roger Wolff, the knuckle-ball pitcher from the American League, today hurled the Pirates to victory over the Cubs, 7 -- 2, in the opening of a two-game series.

The Sinclair Oil Corporation and its subsidiaries had a consolidated net income of $20,476,207 for the first six months of this year; only $7,131,438 short of the $27,607,645 earned in the entire year of 1946, according to the semi-annual statement mailed to stockholders yesterday.

Declaring that effects of high taxes already are becoming apparent in retail operations, members of the New York State Food Merchants Association in convention yesterday adopted a resolution appealing for tax reductions at the earliest possible moment.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The Cardinals withstood a ninth-inning Cincinnati rally tonight to defeat the Reds, 6 -- 3, and extend their winning streak to six games. Stan Musial and Terry Moore connected for St. Louis home runs as three Redleg errors contributed to the Redbird scoring.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 6 -- "Daddies," a 1919 stage comedy by John L. Hobble, which Warner Brothers filmed in 1924, is to be remade by the company this season, it was announced today. The play, which deals with four bachelors, was staged by David Belasco in its original presentation. Warners has assigned Alex Gottleib to prepare the new screen version and produce it.
BUZZARDS BAY, Mass., Aug. 7 -- In a breeze that rose from twelve to sixteen knots and carried a tide wash with it the New York Yacht Club fleet regatta was held today out on Buzzard's Bay.

THE hucksters -- and their kind -- are still riding. Their gaudy station wagons, halftimbered like Elizabethan houses (what you might call the Stratford-upon-Detroit-River school of automobile design), continue to tool in, loaded with characters for new novels about the entertainment industry and allied arts. The people themselves don't look so new any more.

Firemen would rather fight a four-alarm blaze any day than Lake an examination. That was the consensus yesterday of 824 lieutenants of hook and ladder companies who had just taken the four-hour Municipal Civil Service Commission, examination for promotion to captain and held postmortems at Seward Park High School, 350 Grand Street.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Substantial price increases for steel products and some building materials were largely responsible for a rise of 0.5 per cent in average primary market prices during the week ended Aug. 2, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Department of Labor.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday, and closing prices were 50 to 76 points net higher.

ROCHESTER, Aug. 7 -- The General Executive Board of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers Congress of Industrial Organizations, called today on the union's 350,000 members to organize for the election to 1948 of a Congress pledged to repeal of the TaftHartley Labor Act.

GENEVA, Aug. 7 -- The persistent British refusal to bargain realistically on the reduction of Imperial preference tariffs is threatening to make a farce of the tariff bargaining part of the Geneva Trade Conference, highly placed observers say.

More than 15,000 spectators paid admissions yesterday and last night to see the new Tucker rearengine '48 car on public display for the first time in this city at the New York Museum of Science and Industry, 30 Rockefeller Plaza. About 40 per cent of the attendance were women, many of whom brought their children.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Aug. 2 were 921,591 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 1,663 cars, or 0.2 per cent more than for the preceding week, 23,200 cars, or 2.2 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year, and 57,681 cars, or 6.7 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

The Federal Trade Commission's newly established trade-mark division is of the opinion that no jurisdiction has been conferred upon the FTC over any brand names now registered under the Acts of 1881 and 1905, for which-the benefits of the new trade-mark law (Lanham Act of 1946) are not claimed, according to Walter J.
