Derenberg, trade-mark counsel of the Patent Office, in a statement to the United States Trade Mark Association released yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 7 (AP) -- Tony's Find, owned by Henry S. Horkeiner of Baltimore, beat six opponents in the three-quarter mile McKee City Purse today. Tony's Find gave Jockey Bobby Martin a double.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Aug. 7 -- South Africa's reaction to Prime Minister Attlee's plan for Britain's economic recovery, is a suggestion that exports continue from this country on a credit basis over a number of years. It is held here that such a scheme would not contravene the conditions of the American loan to Britain.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 7 -- Habib Bourguiba, exiled leader of the Tunisian Destour [constitution] party, said today that he had recently had quasi-official contact with a representative of the French Embassy who wished to know what solution he would accept for the differences between the nationalist movement and the French administration in Tunisia.

BAD SALZUFLEN, Germany, Aug. 7 -- The Allies' attempts to provide wider scope for women in German politics and industry have had little success, according to a British survey made public today. Approximately 60 per cent of the population of this zone would bar women from holding political office at the ministerial level.
Shortly after noon yesterday big red and white posters went into the windows of the nine Longchamps restaurants. "Bar Now Open," they said.

SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 7 -- The United States delegation in the joint United States-Soviet commissic today revealed that it had rejected a Soviet demand that representatives of fifteen South Korea Rightist political parties be summoned before the commission and questioned on an anti-trusteeship attitude.

BUFFALO, Aug. 7 -- A scathing denunciation of what he said was the moral poverty of United States foreign policy in recent years, particularly in the Far East, was made by Dr. Walter H. Judd, Republican member of Congress from Minnesota, before the final session of the third World Convention of Churches of Christ in Memorial Auditorium here tonight.

HEWLETT, L.I., Aug. 7 -- W. Russell Howe and John Humm Jr. of Rockville, the defending champions, turned in a 34, 33 -- 67 to lead the qualifiers during the first day of the Seawane Harbor Club's member-guest golf tournament today.
SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 7 -- An explosion of cannonball serves hit Donald McNeill today, and the defending titleholder was eliminated from the Eastern grass court tennis championship.

A plan to transfer to this country the entire student body and faculty of Baltic University, now in a displaced persons camp at Pinneburg, near Hamburg, Germany, appeared to be a step nearer realization yesterday.

BATAVIA, Java, Aug. 7 (UP) -- The text of today's Indonesian note to the United States follows: The Government and people of Indonesia heard with great gratitude and appreciation the broadcast offer on behalf of the United States to extend its good offices to the republic in any future negotiations in which the republic may be involved.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development granted to the Netherlands today a loan of $195,000,000, to be devoted "exclusively to the reconstruction of productive facilities" in the Dutch homeland.
SECURITY COUNCIL Received Indonesian Republic's announcement that it would submit to any Security Council decision in its dispute with the Netherlands.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 7 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer announced today that Greer Garson has signed a new seven-year exclusive contract with the studio and that her next picture, which starts in September, will be "Speak to Me of Love," with Walter Pidgeon.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 7 -- In what appeared to be a back-handed slap at the Revisionists, the Jewish Agency for Palestine, the Jewish National Council and representatives of national and local institutions adopted resolutions asking for the immediate release of the mayors seized on Tuesday in the general round-up.

Determination to resist contract violations of manufacturers, particularly dress producers, for raising prices on confirmed contracts, was expressed individually at a meeting of about fifty members of the Association of Buying Offices in the headquarters of the National Retail Dry Goods Association yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 7 -- The Indonesian Republic informed the United Nations today that it was "fully prepared" to submit to any decision the Security Council makes concerning the Dutch-Indonesian dispute.
VIENNA, Aug. 7 -- Lieut. Gen. Geoffrey Keyes protested today to Col. Gen. L.V. Kurasov, Soviet commander, against the Soviet seizure of the Lobau oil refinery near Vienna.

The scientists have themselves to thank for the President's regretful veto of the National Science Foundation bill. Years ago, when Senator Harley Kilgore began to introduce bills which authorized the Government to undertake and supervise research beyond the resources of private enterprise, the professors had insisted that a National Science Foundation must be under their control.
CHICAGO, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Kirby Higbe held the Cubs to seven scattered hits today to give the Pirates a 3-0 decision and a sweep of the two-game series at Chicago.

Four minutes after a 6:30 A.M. reveille yesterday, 500 soldiers quartered in a three-story concrete barracks on Governors Island were routed by a fire. The flames required the attention of all firefighting equipment on the base plus aid from the city Fire Department before they were brought under control two hours later.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Rear Admiral John E. Gingrich, USN, assistant chief of naval operations, has been appointed director of a newly established Division of Security and Intelligence, United States Atomic Energy Commission.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- The Department of Agriculture warned today that a possible decrease in foreign purchases due to lessened United States gifts and loans overseas might threaten domestic agricultural prices.
MOISSON, France, Aug. 7 (AP) -- The Boy Scouts have landed and the situation is out of everyone else's hands.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 7 -- Lewis Alien Weiss, chairman of the board of the Mutual Broadcasting System, told a House Labor subcommittee today that the American Federation of Musicians (AFL) was a "despotic" union which had engaged in a "racket" and, among other activities had effectively stymied the development of television and frequency-modulation broadcasting.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- President Truman declined today to contest Republican estimates of money savings at the recent session of Congress, but indicated that he would have a strong counter -blast in the near future. The tenor of his remarks at his news conference indicated that he set little store by the economy assertions put out by Congressional majority leaders.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- The ebb and flow of party positions across party lines is recorded throughout American history, and strikingly in the Democratic and Republican party platforms that have been adopted in the last thirty years. But, if the Democrats return to San Francisco in 1948, this flux will be especially evident when their platform committeemen examine the resolutions adopted in 1920, the first and last national convention held in that state.

On Tuesday night the Giants beat the Phillies, 5 -- 2. The next afternoon they did it again, 5 -- 2, so, just to be different yesterday at the Polo Grounds, Mel Ott's resurging athletes went out and walloped the Phillies, 5 -- 2. There may be some who will say the Giants are in a rut, but it's a happy one, indeed.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. Aug. 7 -- Tourist List and the apprentice rider. Franklin Hutcherson, combined their talents in the forty-fourth running of the $7,500 added Shillelah Steeplechase at Saratoga today to win at a shade under 12 to 1.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Competing on national networks, Carroll Reece, Chairman of the Republican National Committee, and Gael Sullivan, executive director of the Democratic National Committee, both sought to sell their party wares tonight on the record made by the Eightieth Congress.

In all their wartime pronouncements, beginning with the first United Nations declaration endorsing the Atlantic Charter, the victors of the Second World War proclaimed their principal war aims to be the destruction of the Nazi tyranny, the liberation of conquered nations, and the restoration of self-government based on a free choice of the people.

As the summer tournament of the American Contract Bridge League entered its sixth day at the St. George Hotel in Brooklyn yesterday, play started on the first of four sessions to determine the world's championship in Master Pairs.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- A tightening of controls over certain iron and steel exports, effective on Oct. 1, wa announced today by the Office of International Trade of the Department of Commerce.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 -- Light to soaking rains which, covered northeastern Illinois and northwestern Indiana early today, combined with lower temperatures in the main Corn Belt, led today to selling of futures at the opening on the Board of Trade, but the market rallied quickly and closing trades were 1/4 to 1 3/4 cents a bushel higher than yesterday.

Net earnings of the United States motion-picture industry will be sharply curtailed as a result of the 75 per cent tax imposed on imported films by the British Government, it was admitted in New York yesterday, since Britain is the largest foreign market for American movies.

On the eve of her departure for Britain aboard the Queen Mary, Lady Nancy Astor declared last night that the Moslem world was unwittingly being thrown into the Communist camp on the mistaken notion that Christians in the United States were deserting them to help the Jews.

A fine sense of color, a charming, well-bred sense of restraint and a fresh imaginative touch were in evidence at the first millinery showing by Brandt of Stein Blaine yesterday at the shop, 13 West Fifty-seventh Street.

LONDON, Aug. 7 (Reuters) -- Peter Smith, Essex player, established what is believed to be a record score in first-class cricket for a No. 11 batsman when he made 163 in a match between Essex and Derbyshire at Chesterfield today.
GENEVA, Aug. 7 -- United States proposals for concessions on the wool tariff were laid before the Australian delegation to the Geneva Trade Conference last night, it was learned today.
The fate of many families appeared yesterday to depend on whether city marshals would act quickly or slowly in carrying out evictions already ordered by Municipal Courts.

BOSTON, Aug. 7 -- Allowing only three singles, Charlie Barrett, the red-headed right-hander, today pitched the Braves to a 3-1 triumph over the Dodgers that gave the series to Billy Southworth's men, three games to one, and sent the Brooks home with the unenviable record of having won only one of their last seven games.
PARIS, Aug. 7 -- France wants discussions between "interested powers" on the level of industry in Western Germany, it was learned today officially.

Five hundred members of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, AFL, last night attended dedication ceremonies of the Roosevelt Auditorium in the building at 100 East Seventeenth Street where the headquarters of their Local 91 is located.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 7 -- Marshal Tito accused the United States today of trying to build "some hind of economic blockade" around Yugoslavia.

A net income of $3,261,008, equal to $1.83 a share on 1,781,350 shares of capital stock was reported yesterday for the six months ended with June by the South Penn Oil Company. The income includes $672,104 profit on the disposition of capital assets.

A contest to select young composer's from Argentina, Brazil and Uruguay for scholarships at the Berkshire Music Center next summer will be sponsored by the Empire Tractor Corporation of New York and Philadelphia, it was announced yesterday.

MONTREAL, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Australia made a sweep of the first day's singles matches in the North American zone Davis Cup tennis finals today. Dinny Pails won the opening match from Henri Rochon of Montreal 6 -- 1, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 1, and Geoff Brown had little more trouble in disposing of Brendan Macken of Montreal, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 1.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., Aug. 7 -- Better than seasonal gains in nearly all lines of economic activity last week boosted the index of business in the Pittsburgh district to the highest level since the end of January, according to the Bureau of Business Research of the University of Pittsburgh.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 5.000 head, total 6.000 Market fairly active: uneven: 25 to 75 cents higher: most advance on butcher hogs over 250 pounds and on all weights of sows; extreme sales $1

Testimony was completed yesterday at the Navy general courtmartial of Chief Signalman Harold E. Hirshberg, accused of maltreating fellow-Americans in Japanese prisoner-of-war camps in the Philippines.

An issue of $22,244,000 of temporary loan notes was sold yesterday by the New York City Housing Authority to a group of nine bidders. Proceeds of the issue, which will be dated Aug. 27 and will mature on Feb. 27, 1948, will be used to continue the temporary financing of two low-rent housing projects under construction.
C. W. Harrold has been elected vice president in charge of engineering and development for the Harris-Seybold Company, it was announced yesterday by A. Stull Harris, president.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- The labor committee of the National Planning Association said today there is evidence that a strong upturn in productivity is under way and called upon management to seek labor's participation in reinforcing the trend and upon labor to cooperate.

Paramount Pictures, Inc., in its statement covering the six months ended on July 5, last, yesterday estimated earnings after all charges including provision for taxes on income, at $17,407,000. This includes $3,189,000 representing Paramount's direct and indirect net interest as a stockholder in the combined undistributed earnings for the six months of partially owned non-consolidated subsidiaries.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Ralph Hodgin and Rudy York led the White Sox to an 8-4 triumph over the hapless Browns today for a clean sweep of a three-game series that drew a total of only 5,912 cash customers. Only 698 braved the 96-degree heat to witness today's contest.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (UP) -- Following are the major questions asked by Howard Hughes and the answers by Senator Owen Brewster, Republican, of Maine at today's session of the Senate war investigating subcommittee. The questions were read by Senator Homer Ferguson, Republican, of Michigan, chairman of the subcommittee.

A stronger market for reconditioned and used machine tools has developed here because the end of war surplus disposals is now in sight, machinery distributors revealed yesterday. Nevertheless, there is not enough room available in New York dealer warehouses to permit consideration of a new surplus consignment plan reported to be offered as a final step in the national War Assets Administration machine-tool marketing program, distributors declared.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- During the week ended Aug. 6 member bank reserve balances increased $55,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 7 -- San Francisco will make a definite bid for the 1948 Democratic national convention when information concerning the requirements is obtained from Postmaster General Robert E. Hannagan, chairman of the Democratic National Committee.
GOSHEN, N.Y., Aug. 7 (AP) -- Turning in the fastest mile of the year for trotting colts, a blistering 1:59 3-5, Victory Song captured the $5,050 trotting derby today in straight heats.
Longer skirts, circular flared skirts, tiny waistlines, rounded hips, natural-looking' shoulders and hoods galore were the trends in college clothes shown by Abraham Straus yesterday.

LONDON, Aug. 7 -- Indications that miners were ready to forego at least part of the five-day week in the economic crisis emerged tonight in a resolution adopted by their union's executive board. It announced it would recommend that miners work a minimum of two Saturdays each month beginning on the first Saturday in September.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- The Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations today issued a gravely worded report on the current world food situation as a basis for action at the coming FAO Council in Geneva, starting Aug. 25.

The statement to Parliament yesterday of Hugh Dalton, Chancellor of the British Exchequer, came as a decided anti-climax to Prime Minister Attlee's address of Wednesday. Where Mr. Attlee's words were those of a leader rallying his forces against threatened catastrophe, Mr. Dalton's were querulous and defensive.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 7 -- The much-debated agenda for the forthcoming conference on Freedom of Information and the Press was adopted today by the Social Committee of the United Nations Economic and Social Council by a 15-to-2 vote, Russia and White Russia voting in the minority and Czechoslovakia abstaining.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- The Justice Department has assigned two "observers" to the investigation for possible filing of perjury charges at the end of the hearing.

GENEVA, Switzerland, Aug. 7 -- At least four different plans for a Palestine solution were presented J today to the United Nations' Palestine committee during two highly secret informal meetings, it was learned tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Plans for a study of New York's Puerto Rican problem under auspices of Columbia University, with the aim of reaching an "intelligent solution," were announced today by Gov. Jesus T. Pinero of the island territory.

The share market on the Stock Exchange idled yesterday through another unproductive and inconclusive session with prices in an irregular drift to a mixed close. Weakness was again present in the films, while the textiles and petroleums strengthened.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Mayor William O'Dwyer of New York was understood today to have informed both President Truman and Gael Sullivan, executive director of the Democratic National Committee, that Democratic prospects for carrying New York State next year were growing brighter.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Ted Williams' twenty-fifth homer helped spark a 12-to-2 victory for the Red Box over the Senators today.

A new method of selecting men for plainclothes duty has been worked out by the Police Department as a result of its investigation into gambling, Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander announced yesterday at police headquarters. The new method is a drastic change from that used for many years.

TIMBER POINT, L.I., Aug. 7 -- It began to look today as though the Corry Trophy, the Star Class prize sailed for each year in connection with Great South Bay Race Week, would remain on Long Island Sound.

This is another article by Professor Piccard preliminary to his dive in an "underwater balloon" some 12,000 feet in the Gulf of Guinea, off West Africa. BRUSSELS, Belgium, Aug. 7 -- Many people have remarked, "It must take great courage to embark on such, a dangerous project."

A Democratic judicial convention for the Second Judicial District, meeting last night at Democratic Headquarters, 4-5 Court Square, Brooklyn, nominated a bipartisan ticket of two Democrats and one Republican for three vacancies on the Supreme Court bench.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- President Truman named Raymond M. Foley of Michigan today to head the Housing and Home Finance Agency, under which action in the Senate last month on a Presidential plan brought together all the main housing functions and agencies of the Federal Government.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 7 -- City Commissioner Albert N. Shahadi, who was indicted on four counts by the Atlantic County Grand Jury yesterday, said today that he would give up his job as Police Recorder "until I have been completely vindicated."

Random-notes. All signs and portents indicate that the United States team will once more take the famous Dewar Cup in the curtain-raiser at the Camp Perry matches tomorrow morning. Twenty American riflemen will compete with the top shooters of Great Britain, Canada, New Zealand and Australia for this coveted trophy.

THAT ominous rumbling you may hear of mornings and afternoons, be reassured, is no echo from atom bomb testing grounds. It's only the convulsions of the good earth as Steve Owen's New York Giants hit the dirt out in Superior, Wis.

More Loan Increases Following the lead of the National City Bank of New York, which announced on Wednesday that higher rates on its security loans would be made effective beginning on Monday, two other banks confirmed yesterday that they had taken similar action.

MUNICH, Germany, Aug. 7 -- William E. Griffith, chief of the Special Branch, as spokesman for the Office of Military Government in Bavaria, recommended tonight to the German public an acceleration of denazification proceedings. He urged completing of the program at the earliest possible moment.

LONDON, Aug. 7 -- United States motion picture interests awoke today to discover that a new tax depriving them of 75 per cent of their normal earnings in Great Britain had been imposed by the Labor Government under the spur of its economic crisis.

Long-awaited British exports of woolen goods, sweaters and tie fabrics will arrive in substantial quantities in the next four or five months, according to Ralph D. Schneider, president of Broadstreet's, Inc., clothiers and furnishers.

Contract discussions between representatives of the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, and employers, scheduled to begin here yesterday, were postponed because of a dispute over loading methods.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 7 -- A big United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration program has been halted as a result of the UNRRA's suspension of all supplies to China areas north of the Thirty-fourth Parallel. The UNRRA canceled all further shipments north of a line about a hundred miles south of the Yellow River recently after repeated attacks by Government air and ground forces on UNRRA cargoes destined for persons in Communist territories.

LONDON, Aug. 7 -- Food, raw materials and machinery for Britain's own use were the largest items purchased in the United States with proceeds from the United States loan, Hugh Dalton, Chancellor of the Exchequer, told the House of Commons today.
PARIS, Aug. 7 -- Christian Dior gives a bell silhouette to his corolla skirts; they spread like an open tulip.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- The Eightieth Congress sent to the White House thirty-three bills affecting war veterans, but all except half a dozen were of such limited interest that most newspapers ignored them.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 7 -- The proposal of the Arkansas Louisiana Gas Company, a subsidiary of the Arkansas Natural Gas Corporation, to borrow $14,000,000 to finance its construction program and the redemption of first mortgage bonds was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Department store sales in the week ended Aug. 2 were 1 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1946:

A systematic series of pilferings from parked trucks in the garment district, which police alleged had netted three youths and a purported receiver of stolen goods and textile materials valued at $10,000, was believed ended with the arraignment of the four men yesterday in Felony Court.

The Kimberly Construction Company, Ltd., of 50 West Seventyseventh Street, yesterday filed plans for a six-story apartment house for fifty-three families to be erected at 211 East Seventy-eighth Street. J.M. Berlinger, the architect, estimated the cost at $275,000.
The Army Port of Embarkation started yesterday the homeward voyage of three German prisoners of war, and disclosed that the twoyear program of repatriation had reached the bottom of the barrel.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 7, (AP) -- The second-place Cardinals unleashed a 16-hit attack today to down the Reds, 9 -- 2, and draw within four games of the faltering Dodgers. The victory was the surging Cards' seventh in a row and, although right-hander Jim Hearn shut out the Redlegs for eight innings, he weakened in the ninth and had to give way to Ted Wilks.
ALBANY. Aug. 7 -- The Adjutant General released the following orders today: N.Y.N.G. Officers Assigned. Col. A.N. Gormsen, to Hq. and Hq. Det., N.Y.N.G., as Engr O.

Greek exports to all countries for the year ending June 30, 1948, are estimated at $93,760,000, Joseph M. Besso, special envoy serving on an economic mission for the Greek Government revealed here yesterday in an interview at the Department of Commerce in the Empire State Building.

The threat of a Manhattan bus Strike was raised again yesterday by Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, in its effort to win compliance with its interpretation of a recent arbitration award covering pensions.

EVERETT, Mass., Aug. 7 -- Swooping out of a murky, earlymorning sky, a small, chartered Montreal-to-Boston plane plunged into the flaming chimney-mouth of a huge oil and gas furnace today, carrying the aircraft's four socially prominent riders to a fiery death.

Department and jewelry store buyers are exerting strong pressure on silverware manufacturers to curtail supplies of both plated and sterling flatware to canvassers, a spokesman for a leading producer reported yesterday. Retailers have come to realize that canvassers, who were regarded as something of a joke before the war, now represent a serious threat to store operations, he said.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- A resurgence in Europe of counterfeiting of American currency, coupled with increasing theft and forgery of Government paper, has pushed enforcement activities of the United States Secret Service toward pre-war proportions, the Treasury Department announced today.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 7 -- Within twenty-four hours the Argentine Foreign Office has announced the "adherence" of the Holy See and of the United States to the July 7 "peace plan" of Foreign Minister Juan A. Bramuglia, which was heard on the broadcast message of President Juan D. Peron the previous day.

In a new move to enforce adherence to the Sanitary Code in places serving foods and beverages throughout the city, Commissioner of Health Israel Weinstein said yesterday that in "a spot check" conducted in 250 bars and grills in Manhattan in the last two weeks, fifty-six summonses were issued for infractions regarding the washing and sterilization of glassware.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Elliott Roosevelt says his father, the late President Roosevelt, acted "in direct opposition" to the interests of photo reconnaissance in permitting the Hughes Aircraft Company to continue building a cargo plane during the war.

LONDON, Aug. 7 -- The Labor Government won a hard fought victory in the House of Commons tonight when its program of drastic emergency measures for meeting Britain's economic crisis was approved by 318 votes to 170.

Much of the news that merits frontpage position these days is depressing. We wish it were otherwise. Perhaps, as one reader suggested to a Cleveland editor recently, there should be a "bigger front page," which would permit a larger invasion of cheerfulness. One day this week, at any rate, Page 1 of this newspaper contained two unrelated stories that refreshed our confidence in human nature.

JACKSON, Tenn., Aug. 7 (U.P.) -- Casey Jones, the great engineer of song, received a clear track into the promised land of remembrance today when his admirers unveiled a monument on his unmarked grave.

LEONARDO, N.J., Aug. 7 -- Announcement by Capt. Andrew G. Shepard, commanding officer at the Earle Naval Ammunition Depot, that shipments of ammonium nitrates compound, an inflammable fertilizer blamed for the destructive blasts at Texas City, Tex., and Brest, France, would be shipped overseas from the depot's pier here, brought anxious inquiries from residents of the area today.

Roy Sherman of Philco International Corporation has been appointed manager of the radio division; Frederick Willard, manager of the refrigerator division; Henry Manson, manager of the appliance division; Frederick Grosse, manager of parts and accessory division, and John Noble, general traffic manager.

The strike of Atlantic and Gulf Coast shipyard workers entered its seventh week yesterday with no sign of a settlement between employers and the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, CIO.

One of our friends who is incurably sentimental about the Battery -- at once our city's front yard and birthplace -- has been deeply distressed by what the tunnel builders have done to the seaward tip of our island -- even though their occupation is assumed to be temporary.

BOSTON, Aug. 7 -- A report that children can be made 90 per cent immune to tooth decay by use of zinc chloride and potassium ferro cyanide, was made at the meeting of the American Dental Association today by Dr. Bernhard Gottlieb of Baylor University at Dallas, Tex.

DETROIT, Aug. 7 -- The development of a new type of tire for passenger automobiles, described as the most important step of its kind in more than twenty years, was announced tonight by the Goodyear Tire Rubber Company.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : THE TIMES recently published a report that the North Atlantic Traffic Conference of the International Air Transport Association had appointed a committee to discuss with the North Atlantic Shipping Conference interline ticketing and baggage arrangements which would facilitate sea-air travel.

Registering formal opposition to the stand taken by the League of New York Theatres in upholding the ban against Negroes at the National Theatre, Washington, thirty-seven producers, many of them leaders in their field, yesterday dispatched a joint telegram of protest to the League, which is at odds with Actors Equity on the issue.

BERLIN, Aug. 7 -- Countering a renewed Soviet request for additional reparations, the United States and Britain have sternly reminded the Russians of their pledge of German economic unity and added that they would oppose any further allocations until the Russians cooperated in this vital problem.

Reflecting substantially larger sales, the net profit of the American Viscose Corporation in the first six months of this year increased to $8,705,801 from $4,420,000 earned in the corresponding period of 1946, despite larger taxes and operating costs, its report said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- An associate of Howard Hughes swore today that an attorney for the Senate War Investigating Committee had declared baldly that Elliott Roosevelt was a special and central target in the inquiry into war contracts awarded to the Hughes interests.

Steel Makers Demand Scrap Industrial purchasing executives here revealed yesterday that their suppliers of steel are demanding that customers return steel scrap from metal-working production, as one of the terms of agreement on current deliveries.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As Arthur Krock in his article dated Aug. 4, 1947, "Organized Efforts to Bypass the Law" stated, the Ford U.A.W. dispute chiefly concerned the question whether management and labor might validly sign away rights as established by the recent Labor Management Relations Act, 1947.

SPOKANE, Wash., Aug. 7 (AP) -- Ben Hogan of Hershey, Pa., carding a five-under-par 65, tied with Herman Keiser of Akron, Ohio, today for the first-day lead in the $10,000 Esmeralda Open golf tournament.

Six hundred housewives who at tended a home-planning forum belt yesterday by Abraham Straus were advised to describe their living habits to an architect or decorator as they would tell symptoms to a doctor. As a result, their homes would be planned realistically, speakers declared.

News stories of the retirement of railroad men after a half century of faithful service seem to be nearly as commonplace as the refusal of a Russian diplomat to agree with someone. Yet the newspapers never fail to find some space to tell about each new case.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 7 -- To meet the demands of the atomic age, Yale University is to double the amount of science required of its undergraduate student body. Dr. William C. De Vane, director of the Division of Humanities and dean of Yala College, disclosed today.

Final plans for the proposed vehicular underpass connecting South Street and West Street must await action by the Board of Estimate on Mayor O'Dwyer's recommendation that a new lease of life be given the plan to save the shell of the old Aquarium in Battery Park and restore the structure as a Castle Clinton National Monument.

Mayor O'Dwyer and other city and state officials are about to put into effect two important plans for speeding the construction of lowrent public housing here, it was disclosed yesterday by Robert Moses, City Construction Coordinator.

AMSTERDAM, Aug. 7 (Aneta) -- Prices moved higher in extremely dull trading on the Stock Exchange. Although the uncertainty of the Indonesian situation kept most buyers out of the market, industrials and Indies plantations issues were strong with particular interest in shares of Malang Plantations following news that the company's estates in the Indies had been recovered intact along with considerable stocks of coffee and rubber.

Edward J. Heffron, a New York lawyer, identified himself yesterday as the "Mr. Heffron" who accompanied Howard Hughes to a private meeting with Senator Brewster last Februray, according to The United Press.

Mayor O'Dwyer and other city and state officials are about to put into effect two important plans for speeding the construction of lowrent public housing here, it was disclosed yesterday by Robert Moses, City Construction Coordinator.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- A message of praise for the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration from Pope Pius XII was today made public by UNRRA headquarters here.

"Symphony Five and a Half," the new composition by Don Gillis, will be introduced by Arturo Toscanini and the NBC Symphony at 5 P.M. Sunday, Aug. 31. The work carries the sub-title of "Symphony for Fun" and its four movements are identified as follows: (1) "Perpetual Emotion"; (2) "Spiritual -- ?"; (3) "Scherzophrenia" and (4) "Conclusion."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- President Truman approved today a bill, designed to provide the Army and Navy with the most competent officers, providing a program of promotion by merit to all ranks in the services.

ALBANY, Aug. 7 -- Development of a comprehensive state-wide program for adequate hospital facilities by the Joint Hospital Survey and Planning Commission will be undertaken soon, following appointment by Governor Dewey today of twenty-four members to the commission's State Advisory Council.

Plenty of "green money" will be required by consumers intent on purchasing steaks, pork products, Grade A eggs and butter this weekend. Discouraging news from the City Department of Markets indicates that advances in these commodities took place again for the second week in succession.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 (AP) -- William P. Odom radioed his Chicago base that he set down his converted A-26 bomber at Gander at 7:11 P.M. to complete the first leg of his attempt to halve Wiley Post's globe-circling solo record.

Moving higher for the third consecutive week, the volume of commercial, industrial and agricultural loans of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System confirmed the beginning's of a seasonal trend and advanced $41,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Aug. 7 -- An amazing gross best-ball round of 32, 31-63, nine below par, compounded by Robert Brownell's 67 and Ralph M. Bogart's 68, earned for that Washington pair from the Chevy Chase Club the qualifying medal by four strokes in the eleventh John G. Anderson Memorial Golf tournament at Winged Foot today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 7 -- The committee of the whole of the United Nations Economic and Social Council decided today to admit the National Association of Manufacturers to the list of consultative agencies of the Council. The Council still has to approve the decision.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 7 -- Overriding an earlier decision, 110 general chairmen of the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen instructed the union's President, A.F. Whitney, today to demand an increase in daily basic wage rates from the country's carriers.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 7 -- Lieut. Gen. Ira C. Eaker, deputy commander of the Air Forces, asserted today that 300,000 enemy paratroopers could "take" the United States, and added that he wished some of his military assignments had been as easy.
MIDDLETOWN, Ohio, Aug. 7 -- The Army Air Force signed today its first agreement with a manufacturer calling for a companysponsored military unit trained for instant action in case of war.

The semi-annual statement of the American Woolen Company and its subsidiary, the Pocono Company, issued yesterday to stockholders for the six months ended on June 30 disclosed a net income of $7,890,898 after all charges, including $5,450,000 provision for taxes and $1,000,000 for general contingencies.

Five hundred and fifty children in gaily colored costumes will stage a dance festival at Sheep Meadow, Sixty-seventh Street and West Drive in Central Park, tomorrow at 2 P.M. This program represents the work of children in Park Department playgrounds in Manhattan.
MIDDLETOWN, Ohio, Aug. 7 -- The Army Air Force signed today its first agreement with a manufacturer calling for a companysponsored military unit trained for instant action in case of war.

The semi-annual statement of the American Woolen Company and its subsidiary, the Pocono Company, issued yesterday to stockholders for the six months ended on June 30 disclosed a net income of $7,890,898 after all charges, including $5,450,000 provision for taxes and $1,000,000 for general contingencies.

Five hundred and fifty children in gaily colored costumes will stage a dance festival at Sheep Meadow, Sixty-seventh Street and West Drive in Central Park, tomorrow at 2 P.M. This program represents the work of children in Park Department playgrounds in Manhattan.

Record oil burner sales, in which 1947 orders up to August equal more than two and a half times previous annual sales, were disclosed here yesterday by Timken Silent Automatic oil burner officials. In addition, employment of personnel on installation crews is up over 300 per cent above prewar levels, they said, following a meeting with 150 dealer representatives in this area at the Park Central Hotel.

President Truman's projected visit to Brazil and to the Inter-American Conference on Hemisphere Security, which opens in Rio de Janeiro Aug. 15, will be the third visit of an American President to an Inter-American Conference in Latin America and the third visit too of an American President, or President-elect, to South America.

Determination of the cause of an accident to Pan American Airways Clipper Eclipse in the Syrian desert June 19 had not been reached when the Civil Aeronautics Board's safety division ended its hearing's yesterday afternoon at the Lexington Hotel.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 7 -- Mohammed Ali Jinnah, Governor General designate of Pakistan, left today to take up his duties as head of the new state in Karachi.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 8 -- What Great Britain's newly imposed 75 per cent tax on American motion picture revenue in the United Kingdom will do to Hollywood film production today caused a major alarm in the industry here. The reaction was epitomized by one leading independent producer, who said:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 8 -- "A Miracle Can Happen," a picture in four episodes, which Benedict Bogeaus has produced for United Artists, will be revised to eliminate an episode in which Charles Laughton appears in favor of a new sequence with Dorothy Lamour, it was learned today.

PARIS, Aug. 8 -- Premier Paul Ramadier, at a special Cabinet meeting late this evening, obtained authorization to place a question of confidence on the electoral law which is being passed by the Assembly to govern the municipal elections in October.

ORANIENBURG, Germany, Aug. 8 -- The Russians permitted a small group of Allied and German correspondents today to get a glimpse of anti-Nazi justice as carried out in their zone. At the same time they opened to outsiders for the first time since the Hitler regime the gates of the Sachsenhausen concentration camp.
Two veteran pilots are scheduled to take off this morning from Teterboro Airport in New Jersey in two 100-horsepower planes on a four-to-six-week 22,000-mile 'roundthe-world flight.

ROCHESTER, Aug. 8 -- The General Executive Board of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, CIO, charged today that the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, AFL, was carrying on an "unprincipled campaign with the object of raiding the Rochester clothing market."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Revised railroad fares for New York commuters proposed last month by Interstate Commerce Commission Examiner Burton Fuller were assailed as unfair today by six railroads serving the area.
GENEVA, Aug. 8 -- The International Trade Conference today took three steps forward and one step back.

A price-cutting war, reminiscent of pre-war days in the retail liquor industry, will be curbed in New York State on Sept. 1 when the State Liquor Authority's fair trades act becomes effective. Package stores that have been cutting prices on certain merchandise will have to raise quotations an estimated 15 to 35 per cent.

KEANSBURG, N.J., Aug. 8 -- Recorder Seymour Kleinberg of Raritan Township, today ruled that George R. Richardson of Pennington, N.J., was guilty of the charges made by Mrs. Laura Brownhurst of Eatontown, state agent of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, that raising a chicken in a bottle for advertising purposes caused the fowl to suffer torment and torture.

The City Housing Authority balked yesterday at the first step of a plan, outlined on Thursday by Robert Moses, for building subsidized public housing on two vacant sites in Brooklyn and Queens. The sites were not rejected, but the authority members decided to investigate them further and resume discussion at a special meeting on Monday or Tuesday.

BOSTON, Aug. 8 -- Members of the American Dental Association were told by one of their colleagues today that the profession was "devoting too much of its time to teaching and practicing better methods of extracting teeth and making artificial dentures and too little of its time teaching and practicing preventive measures."

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 8 -- A French compromise plan intended to solve the Balkan deadlock was rejected today by Andrei A. Gromyko, the Soviet representative, at an angry meeting of a special committee of the United Nations Security Council.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 8 -- The Soviet Union lost today its campaign to have the United Nations work with the World Federation of Trade Unions in promoting respect for trade union rights. After more than six hours of debate, the Economic and Social Council gave the task to the International Labor Organization.

Two women who were Presidential candidates in the last century are the subjects of fictionalized biographies. Thomas Nelson Sons has scheduled for Sept. 17 publication Laura Kerr's story of Belva Lockwood, who was nominated for President in 1884 by the Women's party in California, entitled "The Girl Who Ran for President."

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 -- Corn futures advanced 8 cents a bushel, the daily limit, at one time today on the Board of Trade, December leading, and all deliveries went to new seasonal tops, with the September contract at $2.31 3/8 at a new high record, and No. 1 yellow corn selling in the spot market at $2.42, also a new record.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial of July 24, "Wages and Prices," expressed the view that wage increases had aggravated inflation and would prevent price reductions on the ground that "high consumer incomes" make possible "the sale of goods and services at the higher prices required to cover higher costs."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Lingering shortages of toilet tissue and paper towels in some cities were attributed today to the diversion of paper mill machinery to other paper products. Facial tissues, now reported to be plentiful in drug stores after a scarcity in 1946, account for much of the toilet paper shortage.
JERUSALEM, Aug. 8 (AP) -- British authorities continued today the interrogation of approximately forty Jewish leaders arrested three days ago.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture forecast today that this year's cotton crop would be 11,844,000 bales, an increase of 3,204,000 bales, or 38 per cent, over last year's abnormally small crop. Production for the 1936-45 period averaged 12,390,000 bales.

PROVINCETOWN, Mass., Aug. 8 -- As Dr. Seth M. Milliken's large yawl Thistle and E.W. Clucas' yawl Manxman, both in the class one less in size than the America's Cup creations, were bailing along near the tip of Cape Cod this afternoon on the New York Yacht Club cruise, Capt. Sam Norton, master, went overboard from Manxman.

AMSTERDAM, Aug. 8 (Aneta) -- Prices were steady in extremely light trading on the Stock Exchange. Industrials were generally higher, while shipping stocks. Indies plantations issues, banking shares and state bonds showed only minor changes.
Five developments have spurred increased buying, for inventory purposes, by retail and wholesale distributors of metal products and durable goods, spokesmen revealed here yesterday.

ALBANY, Aug. 8 -- The State administration, confronted with a huge backlog of necessary and desirable highway construction projects, is making a study to determine how the State can finance a two-billion-dollar construction program during the next thirteen years.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Civilian employment mounted to a new all-time record of 60,079,000 in July, the Bureau of the Census reported today.

After a five-hour session behind closed doors yesterday the executive committee of the Richmond County Republican County Committee recommended to Governor Dewey, the appointment of State Senator Robert E. Johnson as District Attorney of Richmond County.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Opening of vast tracts of virgin timber in southeastern Alaska to the paper industry for the first time, promising easement of this country's paper shortage as soon as mills can be built and towns established, was announced today by the Department of Agriculture.

HONOLULU, Aug. 8 -- Maj. Gen. Samuel L. Howard, former commander of all marines in China, says that the United States must furnish arms and ammunition to the Nationalists if China is to be stabilized and all of the Far East saved from chaos.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 8 -- As freakish a set of figures as ever graced a mutuel board -- $52.50 straight, $95.10 place and $34.70 show -- flashed today when First Flight was up in the stretch in the twenty-third running of the Test Stakes and two "field" horses showed the way to the wire.

The Palestine question can be solved by "learning the true meaning of Christian ethics," John Stanley Grauel, former Methodist minister who was in the crew of the Exodus 1947 during her voyage to Palestine last month, said yesterday.

THE other day we were speaking of the cheerful American mania for books on the perils arid pleasantries of remodeling old houses in the country. There seemed to us at the time a certain dependable sameness about them; they generally stuck to remarkably familiar patterns. Well, here's an exception to that rule in Andrew Lytle's "A Name for Evil."*

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 8 -- Great Britain announced today that she planned to submit a questionnaire to the Soviet Government asking for further explanations on how the Russian proposal for international atomic control would actually work.

Friday's inspection tour of housing construction in New York, led by city officials in behalf of the Mayor, provided ample evidence that both public and private housing is moving forward in considerable volume. Mayor O'Dwyer's figures, reporting that more than 90,000 New Yorkers have moved into new homes since he took office on Jan. 1, 1946, bear this out, although half of the dwelling units completed are of a temporary, emergency nature.

The "big eight" of the American motion-picture industry rejected yesterday the British Government's new "confiscatory" tax on earnings of imported films by agreeing to cancel indefinitely further shipments of movies to Britain.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 8 -- A charge that there is a "concerted movement by the Communists to undermine confidence in Congress and to encourage disruptions in our national economy" was made here today by Senator William F. Knowland, Republican, of California.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., Aug. 8 -- Sidney S. McMath, Garland County's crusading young prosecutor who has been mentioned as a possible candidate for Governor next year, today named his wife, Anne, 26 years old, as the slayer of his father, Hal P. McMath, 56.

Although he is willing to admit that Yankee visitors will not need to sleep under two blankets, Bill Sharpe, the current historian of the Outer Banks along the North Carolina coast, insists that the fishing possibilities are unsurpassed.

The Giants consumed a tremendous amount of energy and no end of time trying to down Bill Southworth's Braves at the Polo Grounds last night while 30,610 perspiring onlookers put in nearly three hours of terrific torment.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department or Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 5,500 head, total, 7,500. Market moderately active and around 25 cents lower on weights trader 240 pounds: these scarce; heavier weight butchers hogs and

Plans to merge the two leading professional public relations groups into an organization that will be known as the Public Relations Society of America, with offices in New York and San Francisco, were disclosed yesterday following a four-day meeting in Chicago of representatives of both groups.
Kay Sullivan, formerly fashion editor of Town and Country magazine, has been appointed fashion counselor of Julius Garfinckel Co.

The Boy's First Bicycle It would be easy to confuse cause and effect in the case of the bicycle. When a boy first acquires one the break with home ties begins. Or, perhaps, a spirit of restlessness shows itself, and the bicycle is bought to relieve pressure deftly and persistently applied.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- President Truman left Washington today for a week-end of rest at the Presidential cottage near Thurmont, Md., after clearing his desk of the last of the 194 bills which Congress left to him on its adjournment. Of this lot, he approved 175 and permitted nineteen to die through the process known as "pocket veto."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Colonial Airlines, which operates between the United States and Canada, recently filed notice that it intended to permit passengers to carry their skis along without additional charge.

LONDON, Aug. 8 -- Despite the bitter Opposition attack led by Winston Churchill, who accused the Labor Government of seeking "a blank check for a totalitarian government," the House of Commons approved today in substance a bill giving the Cabinet sweeping emergency powers to deal by decree with Britain's economic crisis.

Two Canadian teams were ranked among the first five pairs at the close yesterday afternoon of the second of four sessions for the $5,000 Waldemar von Zedtwitz Gold Cup and the world championship in Masters Pairs being run by the American Contract Bridge League.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (U.P.) -- Secretary of War Kenneth C. Royall conferred today with seven prominent news executives who returned to the capital after a month-long tour of the Orient as guests of the War Department.

Consumer Credit The voluntary efforts to be undertaken by banks and other lending agencies to control consumer credit operations upon the expiration of Regulation W recall testimony given in June before the Banking and Currency Committees of the Senate and the House by Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, financial observers noted yesterday.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug 8 -- Miss Margaret Osborne of San Francisco, Wimbledon champion, and Miss Louise Brough of Beverly Hills, Calif., advanced to the final of the Eastern grass court tournament at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club today.

LONDON, Aug. 8 -- Reflecting the City's disappointment at lack of constructive proposals in the speech of the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Hugh Dalton, yesterday, the stock markets here today were subdued at the opening of business.

The reconverted Greek passenger liner Nea Hellas, on her first post-war voyage from the Mediterranean after a complete overhauling, arrived yesterday with 294 passengers, approximately one-fifth of her new capacity. She docked in Hoboken.

WOONSOCKET, R.I., Aug. 8 -- A plea for support of the Marshall Plan to rehabilitate the warstricken countries of Europe was made here today by Senator Alben W. Barkley of Kentucky, Senate Minority Leader.

The League of New York Theatres, faced with dissension in its ranks over the Washington racial controversy, will hold a general membership meeting at the Hotel Astor Thursday to thresh out the problem. The meeting has been scheduled at the request of thirtyseven producers, including many of Broadway's best known names, who recently questioned the League's contention that it was acting in behalf of "a majority of members."
Communist party leaders have postponed their national and state conventions from this summer to the summer of 1948, it was announced yesterday.

United States chemical exports are running four times higher than before the war, but European production is reviving and the world market may return to a competitive basis, the American Chemical Society reported yesterday.
CHICAGO, Aug. 8 (U.P.) -- The second heat wave in a week bore down on already parched Midwestern farmlands today, sending corn prices to new all-time highs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Secretary of State Marshall reminded the Argentine Government of President Juan D. Peron, in an exchange of notes made public today, of the scope of the effort the United States is making for the promotion of world peace.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 8 (AP) -- The Communist newspaper Borba asserted today that United States authorities were blackmailing with threats of loss of citizenship Americans of Yugoslav extraction who expressed sympathy for Yugoslavia or Marshal Tito.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 8 -- The Argentine delegation to the Rio de Janeiro hemispheric defense conference left this evening with a personal send-off by President Juan D. Peron and under a pledge to abide by the will of the majority in all decisions of the meeting.

A race-horse wire-room in a store at 227 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn -- less than 200 feet from Brooklyn Police Headquarters -- was raided yesterday afternoon by Inspector William O. Jones, who has been particularly active against bookmakers in the downtown area of that borough.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) -- The Justice Department today described as unfounded charges published by the Belgrade Communist newspaper Borba that blackmailing tactics have been employed in this country against persons of Yugoslav extraction who express sympathy for Yugoslavia or Marshal Tito.

PARIS, Aug. 8 -- Marcel Rochas' picturesque winter collection is based on lines reminiscent of the beginning of the century. He awakened Paris to the new silhouette he has launched by presenting a lovely young model garbed in his new grey satin brocade "guepiere," a waist corset, with brief tuile petticoat frill and brocade bra.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 8 (AP) -- William P. Odom, 22 hours 46 minutes out of Chicago and a third of the way around the world in his try for a new solo record, rode his Bombshell plane toward Karachi, India, on a tail wind tonight.
DETROIT, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Tying the score with a two-run rally after two were out in the ninth, the White Sox defeated the Tigers, 4 to 2, today on Rudy York's tworun homer in the tenth.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 8 -- The cost of running the United Nations next year will amount to about $39,400,000 and it will take at least another $3,000,000 to pay the organization's remaining bills for the rest of 1947, Secretary General Trygve Lie estimated today in his annual budget report.

Prices of unknown brands of safety razor blades have dropped from a wartime peak of about $24 per 1,000 to levels below pre-war prices in some lines, industry spokesmen revealed here yesterday. In addition, they said, while prices of standard advertised brand blades have remained steady, demand for these wellknown lines has increased and supplies are adequate to fill wholesale and retail pipelines.

ALBANY, Aug. 8 -- The State Banking Department approved today a certificate of reduction of capital stock of the United Industrial Bank, 217 South Fourth Street, Brooklyn, from $300,000, consisting of 3,000 shares at $100 par value each, to $200,000, consisting of 2,000 shares at $100 par value each.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 8 -- Striking back at United States opposition to Bulgaria's application for admission to the United Nations, a Soviet representative charged today the United States Government was violating human rights through the Taft-Hartley Labor Law, loyalty checks on Government employes, and other means.

BATAVIA, Java, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Fires were reported today by the Netherlands army on the Royal Dutch Shell Company's Chepu oilfields in east Java, as accusations of violations of the cease-fire order were renewed by both the Dutch and the Indonesians.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8--Howard Hughes laconically defied his Senatorial inquisitors today on the issues of his suddenly absent press agent, John W. Meyer, and pictured his own work as a war contractor as a task full of frustrations contrived by hostile influences in Washington.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 8 (AP) -- The International Truck Drivers, Chauffeurs and Helpers Union, AFL, Local 300, and three union officials were sued for $100,000 today on charges of violating the boycott section of the new Taft-Hartley labor law.

In a drastic shake-up Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander demoted yesterday four inspectors to the rank of captain. At the same time he transferred one deputy inspector, twelve captains and a lieutenant to other precincts.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Singles by Enos Slaughter and Terry Moore and a double by Pitcher George Munger gave the Cardinals their first two runs as they went on to a 6-0 victory over the Pirates tonight -- stretching their current series of triumphs to eight.

SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain, Aug. 8 -- The resignation of the Governmentin-Exile headed by Rodolfo Llopis was met here today with an indifference that shows vividly how the situation has changed within the last few months.

Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday that he had offered the $17,500 post of Corporation Counsel to John P. McGrath of Brooklyn, with appointment contingent upon the election of Charles E. Murphy, the incumbent, to the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial District on Nov. 4.

MOISSON, France, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Youth put the war behind it today as 265 Austrian Boy Scouts -- banned for years by Adolf Hitler -- marched in to take their places in the sixth International Boy Scout Jamboree and received the salutes of Scouts from Allied countries.

"Indiscreet" relaxation of installment terms by furniture stores when consumer credit controls are terminated on Nov. 1 will result in "ruinous situations" as far as cash reserves are concerned, an officer of a leading out-of-town furniture store warned yesterday.
The semi-annual statements issued yesterday by three large oil companies disclosed a substantial improvement in earnings over the corresponding six months of last year.

Directors of the Seiberling Rubber Company took no action yesterday on the common dividend due at this time. The company paid 25 cents on May 20. In 1946 three dividends of 25 cents each were declared, payable in April, October and the last on Jan. 1, this year.

United States Customs enforcement officers turned the department's narcotics search yesterday to the Maritime Commission transport-type liner Marine Carp and uncovered caches of opium and four small parcels of a type of oriental hashish.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Aug. 8 -- James A. Cullen was relieved as principal of A.B. Davis High School here and his status reverted to that of a teacher by unanimous vote of the Board of Education at a meeting that ended at 2 A.M. today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Senator Owen Brewster, Republican, of Maine, said today that he regretted making a press statement that an airline hostess was afraid to travel alone with Howard Hughes.

MUNICH, Germany, Aug. 8 -- The Bavarian Ministry of Food and Agriculture gave United States investigators today a list of vast amounts of food that had disappeared into the black market. The list was presented after seventyfive investigators had checked the books of wholesalers and retailers, as well as the Ministry's records.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Following are the texts of the notes on promotion of world peace, exchanged between Secretary of State Marshall and Foreign Minister Bramuglia of Argentina: The Argentine Note Buenos Aires, July 6, 1947.

Atlantic Coast dock workers of the International Longshoremen's Association presented demands to their employers here yesterday for a 25-cent-an-hour basic wage increase and other improved conditions.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange lost all their early gains yesterday and closed 89 to 99 points, or $4.45 to $4.95 a bale net lower.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Aug. 8 (AP) -- A get-away program that saw the unpredictable bay mare Ballad register a surprising victory in the featured 2:14 class trot concluded a banner Grand Circuit meeting at Good Time Park today.

The American Airlines' $130,000 radar-equipped experimental flagship Alpha, a twin-engined DC-3 craft, crashed in Flushing Bay last night six minutes after it had taken off from La Guardia Field on a routine flight to Buffalo.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Bill Nicholson's home run with one out in the eleventh inning and a triple play in the seventh gave the Chicago Cubs a 2-1 decision over Ewell Blackwell and the Cincinnati Reds today before a Ladies' Day crowd of 25,258.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: What would the founder of the Czechoslovak Republic, Thomas G. Masaryk, have done on his country's fateful day, July 10, last?

JERUSALEM, Aug. 8 -- The arrest of three Jewish mayors in the police round-up of persons allegedly sympathetic to the activity of the extremists on Tuesday has stirred up such a hornet's nest in Palestine that their release is expected shortly, according to informed sources.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Aug. 8 -- The Danish Government has prepared a detailed statement showing the contribution Denmark can make toward feeding Europe, and her requirements under the Marshall proposal for European economic rehabilitation.

Maintaining that evidence shows operating costs in materials and wages of the Brooklyn Borough Gas Company have increased, the Public Service Commission granted yesterday the utility a temporary increase in gas rates for a period to July 1, 1948 pending conclusion of the rate proceeding now in progress.

Retail Sales Decline Here Hot weather during the past week caused a slump in department stores sales here of 7 to 10 per cent, according to estimates yesterday. Chiefly affected were women's apparel, where business on radically changed styles remained relatively inactive in the early showings.

GENEVA, Switzerland, Aug. 8 -- The Jewish Agency for Palestine described the British memorandum to the United Nations Special Committee of Inquiry on Palestine last June as a scarcely veiled "admission of failure" in a formal reply handed to the members of the committee today.

The American Labor party in Brooklyn nominated its own slate of judicial candidates for three Supreme Court vacancies last night after Republicans and Democrats in the borough had joined in a bipartisan nomination of the three leading candidates.

"A Chinese farm? That's a new one on me." We weren't surprised at this answer from the gas-station attendant when we asked him yesterday to direct us to the Lichee Farm in Wantagh, L.I. With the land all around planted in corn and potatoes, the scene was strictly American, hardly the place to find Chinese coolies in straw hats and bare feet cultivating oriental vegetables.

OLD GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 8 -- The Army played the role of a modern St. Patrick here today. For nearly an hour, an officer and two enlisted men turned flame-throwers on an ivy-covered stone wall in an attempt to drive out a few snakes.

MONTREAL, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Australia moved into the Davis' Cup inter-zone final against Czechoslovakia today, with the winner to take on the United States for the trophy, as the doubles team from "Down Under" made up of Jack Bromwich and Colin Long swept to an easy victory over Canada.

SPARKILL, N.Y., Aug. 8 -- Miss Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches won her first one-day tournament of the season today, touring the hilly Rockland Country Club course in 38, 39 -- 77 for low gross honors in the Women's New Jersey Golf Association weekly event.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: While the nations rage furiously together, why should not qualified Americans and other free peoples begin the work of world modernization, commencing with those nations of Europe who wish to receive modernization aid?
BRISTOL, Conn., Aug. 8 (U.P.) -- Mrs. Helen R. Fournier, 45, was under the charge today of having embezzled $100,000 to $150,000 from the Bristol Bank and Trust Company of which she was chief teller.

Department and housewares stores, faced with plentiful supplies and increasing consumer resistance to both low-end cast aluminum and expensive club aluminum cookware, are centering their purchasing commitments on medium-priced, highly styled stamped aluminum items, buyers reported yesterday.

BUFFALO, Aug. 8 -- More than 1,000 Disciples of Christ, the remnants of a group of 10,000 who journeyed from all parts of the United States and the globe to attend the international and world conventions of their brotherhood here during the past ten days, today picnicked in a body at Niagara Falls.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- An improved system and apparatus for facsimile telegraphy and a new device for preventing the intelligible reception of fasimile signals by anyone except authorized persons were among the 333 inventions on which patents were issued this week by the United States Patent Office.
With the familiar sand of Ebbets Field again under their wheels, the Dodgers stopped skidding last night and defeated the Phillies, 5 to 0, before a welcome-home crowd of 32,170.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: On behalf of 375,000 hay fever sufferers in New York City, may this society call upon the public and on private property owners to cooperate with the Health and Sanitation Departments of the City of New York in the elimination of ragweed.

The first detailed listing of Japanesemade commodities available for export from Japan to foreign markets was announced last night by L.L. Horch, New York regional director of the Department of Commerce. The list includes 205 products, falling into 37 general categories.

DUBLIN, Aug. 8 -- For four days now Dublin has been in a carnival mood for the biggest and best horse show held here since 1937. Every hotel and guest house in the city is packed, as are all the hotels within thirty miles.

MUNICH, Germany, Aug. 8 -- Ten members of a subcommittee of the United Nations Committee on Palestine arrived here tonight by air from Geneva for an intensive tour of displaced persons camps that will take them also to Austria and Switzerland.

LONDON, Aug. 8 -- Demands for a further explanation from the Government for its decision to impose heavy taxes on American films are expected to be made in Parliament on Monday in view of the angry reaction of American film interests.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Aug. 8 (AP) -- Seven Army officers and a former enlisted man, former members of the 101st Airborne Division, were decorated by the Netherlands Government here today for their services during the Allied airborne invasion of the Netherlands in September, 1944.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 8 -- Defying a resolution of the United Nations General Assembly, the Union of South Africa announced today that it would not submit a trusteeship agreement for the territory of South-West Africa, which it has administered since 1920 under a League of Nations mandate.

The stock market was subjected yesterday to bursts of selling which reached a climax in the final hour and reduced the composite rate by 1.66 points. It was the sharpest reaction in more than a week and produced inroads in several issues with general weakness in the motion pictures and rails.

A three-year survey by the American Federation of Jews from Central Europe, sponsored by the American Jewish Committee and made public yesterday, shows that the Nazis destroyed Jewish communal property in Germany once valued at 236,700,000 Reichsmarks, corresponding roughly to $100,000,000 at the pre-war official exchange rate.
TOKYO, Aug. 8 -- The attempt of the Katayama Government to obtain speedy Diet approval of nationalization of coal mines apparently bogged down again today.

SPOKANE, Wash., Aug. 8 (AP) -- Marvin (Bud) Ward of Spokane posted a brilliant 65 in the second round of the $10,000 Esmeralda open golf tournament today but Herman Keiser of Akron, Ohio, maintained his lead by adding a 69 to his first-round 65 for a halfway total of 134.

A rush of reorders by mail and personal visits of buyers produced one of the busiest weeks of the fall season for New York manufacturers of coats and suits. Buying pressure has begun to approximate what was felt during the war, according to local manufacturers, who are beset with production problems and slow deliveries of woolens and linings for women's apparel.
The city's Department of Housing and Buildings has two new rubber stamps that may be deciding factors in forthcoming eviction proceedings, it was learned yesterday.

CALCUTTA, India, Aug. 8 -- The most brutal communal killing of the year here occurred this morning when a large mob of Hindus stopped a train at a suburban station, dragged out eleven Moslem passengers and put them to the knife.

Edward Leo Delaney, a grayhaired 61-year-old American citizen, who allegedly broadcast German propaganda before and during the war was arrested yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Investigation on a complaint charging treason.
Marked improvement in shipments of paper towels, following a period of critical scarcity, was reported here yesterday by the Brown Company, manufacturer of Nibroc Aqualized towels.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- President Truman, bowing to the express will of Congress, reluctantly signed today legislation terminating on Nov. 1 the remaining controls on consumer installment credit.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Aug. 8 -- The long-standing rivalry between Willie Turnesa of Knollwood, reigning British amateur champion, a former United States amateur king, and two-time winner of this John G. Anderson Memorial tournament, and Frank Strafaci of Pomonok, five-time Metropolitan titleholder, had a new climax at the Winged Foot Golf Club today.
BERLIN, Aug. 8 -- The United States Military Government revealed today a German falsification of crop returns that already had resulted in the jailing of one farmer and might lead to further action.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 8 -- The management of our national debt is just one of the war-born problems which young business school graduates of today must face, John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury said today at the 84th commencement exercises of Bryant College, after receiving an honorary degree of doctor of science in business administration.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- President Truman's appointment of David A. Morse as Under-Secretary of Labor was announced today by Secretary of Labor Lewis B. Schwellenbach.

TIMBER POINT, L.I., Aug. 8 -- Twin Star, sailed by Lockwood Pirie of Chicago, slipped around the course like an eel in grease to give the rest of the Star class yachts a spectacular beating in the fourth race of the Corry trophy series today.

A thousand delegates of the Third Order of St. Francis of Assisi in the United States and Canada will attend the sixth quinquennial congress of the order at the Hotel Netherland Plaza, Cincinnati, tomorrow through Tuesday.
PARIS, Aug. 8 -- France learned today with some consternation that the price of bread would be more than doubled beginning next Monday.

Mrs. Frances Farmer Wilder plans to resign as president of the Association of Women Broadcasters, to which she was only recently elected, as the result of her acceptance of a new post outside of the radio industry, it was disclosed yesterday.

The production in July of steel ingots and steel for casting amounted to 6,572,185 tons, a decline of 396,480 from the 6,968,665 produced in June, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The decline reflected the effects of the Fourth of July holiday and the idleness at coal mines early last month.

ROME, Aug. 8 -- A considerable step toward labor peace in Italy is believed to have been taken by an agreement signed late last night by the General Confederation of Industry and the General Confederation of Labor.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- The Veterans Administration, holder of many "biggest business" titles in its services to 18,000,000 veterans of World War II and 4,000,000 veterans of other wars, today outlined what a reduction of 10,000 in personnel would do to its services.

BOSTON, Aug. 8 -- Lefty Joe Page failed in a relief role tonight as the Red Sox pounded him for four runs in the eighth inning and downed the Yankees, 9 -- 6. Four hits, two of them homers by Jake Jones and Sam Mele, figured in Boston's closing rally, an uprising that moved the Bosox into second place, twelve-and-a-half lengths behind the New Yorkers.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Aug. 8 -- Pronouncements yesterday by Evzen Erban, Socialist Secretary General of the Revolutionary Trade Union Movement, and Antonin Zapotocky, Communist chairman of the Trade Union Congress, strengthened the belief that communizing is to be increased in Czechoslovakia as the inevitable consequence of the decision not to go to the Paris conference.

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary sailed on the return leg of her first post-war commercial voyage at 3 P.M. yesterday with 1,866 passengers, among them Viscountess Astor, American-born former member of the British Parliament and a group of United States delegates to the Farm and Agricultural conference in Geneva Aug. 25.

Billy Fox, Philadelphia Negro light-heavyweight, knocked out Georgie Kochan, transplanted Ohioan, last night in the fourth round of their scheduled ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden and strengthened his campaign for a return meeting with Gus Lesnevich, world's light-heavyweight champion.

SENATOR ROBERT A. TAFT and his younger brother, Charles P. Taft, are an intriguing study in contrasts. The former shares with Governor Bricker the devotion of all who yearn for the days before the New Deal. The latter, a prominent Cincinnati lawyer, civic leader and churchman, emerges, in this collection of speeches and magazine articles written from 1934 to 1946, as a few millimeters left of center.

ATHENS, Aug. 9 (U.P.) -- Press dispatches today reported guerrilla raids in the Epirus sector near the Albanian frontier. Greek military authorities said "large" units of Bulgarian troops were massed along the Greek border near the junctions with the Yugoslav frontier.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- The United States informed France today of its willingness to confer "without delay" in three-power meetings on the level of German industrial output.

SOMETIMES it seems there are more books about television than fresh developments in the art itself. Although this appearance isn't too close to fact, it rises from the concentration on sports and other non-creative events now taking over much of broadcast time.

MUNICH, Germany, Aug. 9 -- Dozens of displaced persons, selected at random from the population exclusively of the Jewish camp at Landsberg, gave personal testimony this afternoon before members of the United Nations Special Committee of Inquiry on Palestine who had flown from Geneva to survey the situation of such institutions in Germany, Austria and Italy.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 9 -- A record-breaking crowd of 24,541 saw Task, youthful stablemate of the powerful Assault, register his second straight New Jersey stake triumph in the sixfurlong King Neptune 2-year-old Special, headline attraction at the seashore race course today.

JUST where do women stand in this world of ours? Apparently they don't think they stand very well, for the "equal rights" crusade is taking on new pace and is widening out. The other day the National Association of Women Lawyers meeting in New York passed a resolution asking that women be appointed to policy-making posts in the United Nations.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Aug. 9 -- The State of Arizona is setting a neat, vest-pocket example for the country at large in the increasingly important field of international trade.
MOISSON, France, Aug. 9 (AP) -- The sixth world's Boy Scout Jamboree was opened officially tonight by Gen. Emile Lafonte on a flag-draped grandstand before 35,000 boys from twenty-four countries.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- The appointment of four key operating and administrative officials to work in important aspects of domestic atomic energy activity was announced today by the Atomic Energy Commission.

IT is about time, a correspondent advises, that reviews for this and other journals stopped throwing bean balls at the screen ("obviously terrible novel * * * clearly designed for the films") and credited the movie business with an assist.
LONDON, Aug. 9 -- "This is a battered old country!"

THE life of a doctor, whether he be the head of a great clinic or a small town physician, is fraught with drama. Drama not so much in the crises of the operating room as in the day to day contacts with people -- those little glimpses which are rarely revealed, except to the physician.

Colgate University will begin this fall a "core curriculum" course designed to help students understand and appreciate problems leading to conflict in the modern world and to relate these problems to the position of the United States. The program will further implement the university's "New Plan of Education" announced early in 1945 after more than two years of preparation by a seven-man faculty committee.

BOSTON, Aug. 9 -- Senator Owen Brewster, Republican, of Maine, said today that the Hughes investigation was merely "a curtain raiser" to a series of inquiries on war profiteering, involving highranking generals and large American industrial concerns.
