PEONIES, one of the handsomest and hardiest of perennial flowers, are one of the first things to be planted in September, so it is none too early to begin browsing through the catalogues and selecting varieties. This long-ranking favorite will be not only showy in flower in June but also decorative throughout the growing season; its handsome foliage is an asset from May to frost.

The City Club of New York asserted yesterday that one of the new bills introduced in the City Council by Joseph T. Sharkey, did not go far enough in protectting tenants from possible eviction by "unscrupulous landlords." In a letter to Mr. Sharkey, Bertram Boardman, chairman of the City Club's board of trustees, urged strengthening of at least one point in one bill.

A CHILD can't be "reasoned" out of his fear, yet grown-ups try it all the time. "There's nothing to be afraid of," we say briskly to the shrinking child; or "You're too big a girl for that"; or sadder still, "Only sissies are afraid."
CHICAGO, Aug. 9 -- No gains have been made in conquering the "most desperate" problem affecting inter-racial and inter-group relations in Chiago, that of housing, it was reported today.

TO regain his breath from the over stimulation of seeing a preview of "The Secret Life of Walter Mitty," your correspondent sought the cool quiet of a Fifty-second Street Mermaid Tavern and the soothing balm of a flagon of ale.

Retailers once again are girding to resist inflationary and unjustified price increases at wholesale levels and are shaping plans in the role of "purchasing agent for the consumer." This was brought out here last week at a meeting of buyers opposing automatic, unconfirmed price advances made by some women's garment manufacturers on contract purchases.

DANNY KAYE and the Warner Brothers were discussing an agreement which, at the moment of writing, (Wednesday) was said to be in its final stages. Queried in Hollywood, Kaye was unwilling to divulge details since the contracts had not been signed.

SPOKANE, Wash., Aug. 9 (AP) -- Herman Keiser of Akron, Ohio, fired a par 70 to cling by a single stroke to the lead in the third round of the $10,000 Esmeralda Open golf tournament at the Indian Canyon course.

Recent restrictions on importation of "luxuries" by Central and South American countries, except Cuba and Venezuela, constitute a serious threat to export volume of radio producers, Max Abrams, treasurer, Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation, said in an interview last week.

For more than a quarter of a century William Duncan Richardson had covered the sports beat for this newspaper before death claimed him Friday night, at the age of 62. Like the real newspaperman that he was, he finished his assignment before he went home to rest.

The Luna moths come beating their frail wings at the screens, these August evenings, and when one pauses there, entranced by the light inside, we can see the delicate beauty of its coloration. Pale green it is, a silky green unlike that of any leaf that grows, and each wing is marked by one small, dark "eye."

IMPELLED by an apparent zest for telling the story. Major James Ripley Jacobs has composed a readable account of how a "small, ill-paid, ill-clothed, illfed, and often ill-trained and illled" Army of the United States acquitted itself in its mission to thwart European aggression on all our borders and to guard and extend our western frontier.

HOWARD NEMEROV has attempted to read unity into his first book of poems by giving it the title "The Image and the Law," which, he says, "exposes the conflict and theme of the poems; the ever-present dispute between two ways of looking at the world, the way of the eye and that of the mind."

CHICAGO, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Corn set the pace today for a grain market which roared ahead into new high territory with turnover heavy on the Board of Trade. That grain soared as much as 8 cents a bushel, the limit permitted in a single session, and again marked up a new set of records.
ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 9 -- Appreciation of the Turkish armed forces for the interest shown by the United States was voiced today by Gen. Salih Omurtak, chief of the general staff.

SOMETIMES your palate is homesick for the simple foods of childhood -- a baked potato with a dollop of butter or home-made bread and a mug of milk. Other days the gastronomical mood changes, and you think with good appetite of the shrimps with lobster sauce that a Chinese restaurateur turns out.

As required by the General Assembly of the United Nations, Secretary General Lie today reports on plans developed for a permanent headquarters on the East River site. If they are carried out on the scale outlined in this preliminary draft the world organization will have a truly impressive workshop which will affect the whole character of that section of the city.
BERLIN, Aug. 9 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay disclosed today he had made his "one last effort" toward reaching an agreement with the Russians on the sorely-needed currency reform in Germany.

RED BARBER will conduct a special radio baseball clinic on ten of his regularly scheduled sports programs on CBS at 6:30 P.M. The special broadcasts will run from tomorrow's show through Friday, Aug. 22.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 9 -- The House Labor subcommittee investigating union practices in Hollywood today wound up a week of somewhat negative, although not unprofitable findings, with almost certain fireworks ahead.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 9 The United Nations contemplates constructing its own community settlement, including both living and recreational facilities, in Long Island City, Queens, directly opposite the East River site of the future world capital, it was disclosed today.

KINGSTON, Ont., Aug. 9 (CP) -- How the St. Lawrence steamship Rapids Prince was carried stern-first without rudder for six miles through dangerous rapids until she reached quiet waters near Morrisburg was told by Capt. P.J. Cherry of Kingston when the ship was put into drydock here last night.

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 9 -- The Ku Klux Klan is once again commanding attention in Georgia -- plastering its familiar stickers in various communities, burning fiery crosses and holding social functions in public spots.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Aug. 9 -- Dr. Jiliu Maniu, Peasant party leader, is ill today in his secret police cell and there are unofficial predictions that he may not survive until his trial on charges of having attempted to overthrow the current Communist-dominated Government.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Aug. 9 -- Perhaps because they realize that Czechoslovakia's decision not to attend the Paris conference does not represent the wishes of the Czechoslovak people, the Communists here are keeping up a fierce campaign against the Marshall plan.

FEW Westerners know Russia better than Bernard Pares. Mellow rather than dazzling, his books recall that lost Victorian ideal, the globe-trotting Grand Old Englishman. In Czarist times Pares was honorary usher at the first Duma; during World War I he covered the Russian front, earning his Medal of St. George; Communist Russia he has toured four times.

AUGUST is the month when there is danger of having too many flowers rather than too few. Unless restraint has been used in planning, planting and care, the garden may become overcrowded to the point of looking like a jungle.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs. 300 head (estimated), total, 2,300. Compared with week ago butchers' Hogs under 240 pounds around 25 cents higher; other weights of butchers' hogs steady; sows 25 to 50 cents lower.

There is today a nation-wide awakening of community conscience regarding responsibilities toward the disabled and the need for community rehabilitation centers. A splendid example of how these responsibilities can be met through cooperative community action has been demonstrated in Wilmington, Del.

TO THE EDITOR: Canon Bernard Iddings Bell in "We Are Indicted for Immaturity" draws blood with his harsh estimate of the American "common man" and his children, but his indictment is weakened by a toplofty attitude which no educator or cleric can afford.

The most encouraging sign for the future of wildlife in this country was the unprecedented public interest displayed by individuals and groups in the various legislative proposals affecting fish and game conservation during the session of Congress just closed.

Buyers of linens and domestics attending showings last week expressed satisfaction with lines displayed, and purchased heavily of better quality chenille spreads, according to the weekly market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Co., resident buyers.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Paraguayan Government supporters seeking refuge in Argentina reported today that rebel forces had defeated Government troops driving down on their rear from the north in an attempt to relieve a threat to Asuncion the capital.

THE three stories contained in this posthumous volume -- "Walterson," "Uncertain Molly Collicut," and "Rennie Peddigoe" -- were written for women's magazines. It is hardly necessary therefore to note that the main characters in the tales are females -- beautiful, bumbleheaded.

IF Oscar and Mary Handlin say what I think they do, a knowledge of their book should be required of all persons, either on the Right or on the Left, who generalize about American society. Disembarrassing themselves of a priori concepts, the authors immersed themselves in the social history of Massachusetts between the Revolution and the Civil War in order to find out what role the government actually played in the economy.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 9 -- Herbert Hoover, appraising the international situation on the eve of his seventy-third birthday, voiced the opinion that the outlook for "continued Western Civilization" seemed better than it did a year ago, despite Russia's "failure and unwillingness to cooperate in world restoration."

The biggest police shake-up in the memory of New Yorkers struck the city suddenly last week when Mayor William O'Dwyer ordered the transfers of twenty-two of the Police Department's twenty-three inspectors because they had failed to break up the alliance between police and bookmakers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- The ghost of Franklin D. Roosevelt, or at least the shadow, of that ghost, continues to stalk the political horizon. As the premonitory rumbles of the 1948 campaign gather volume and stridency it becomes increasingly apparent that the New Deal -- thinly disguised metaphor foe the name of the thirty-second President -- will be a major issue again, just as it has been in the last four Presidential elections.

THIS is a book that has been crying to be written -- a straightforward and scholarly history of the first quarter-century of mining in California. Although including two early songs for atmosphere, the book does not strive much for color or folklore, and it does not attempt to gain factitious unity by setting out to be the biography of a man or a river.

Europe's Ruhr In Washington's War Manpower Commission building this Tuesday there will begin discussions between American and British experts of a question that has a fundamental bearing on the outcome of the "Marshall Plan."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: With every turn on its axis the world is spinning madly toward self-destruction. Unless something is done to save it, it is only a question of whether it is five or fifty years before our civilization takes its place with the extinct dodo.

The Dodgers found to their sorrow yesterday that playing at home, and against the Phillies, affords no blanket guarantee of success at this critical juncture of the tightening National League pennant race.

After ten years' work on cancer Dr. H.S. Penn, Professor of Zoology at the University of California in Los Angeles, announced in 1942 that some chemical in human cancer fluoresces when exposed to ultraviolet radiation and that the spectrum of this fluorescence is strikingly like that of methylcholanthrene.

Consolidation of its operations at Nashua, N.H., will reduce Textron output of textiles for resale to other manufacturers approximately 15 per cent, it was learned from officials of the company last week. Loss of this yardage, however, will not raise much of a ripple in the industry, it was pointed out, and eventually the increased efficiency of its own operation will more than make up for the loss.

JEWISH Orthodox pilgrims have a habit of dropping small notes with requests into Abraham's Tomb at Hebron, Palestine, hoping that their wishes will be granted by the patriarch. Strangely, the ancient city's Arabs do not allow these Jews to penetrate deeper than the seventh step into the tomb, while not even a Moslem is permitted to enter the cave proper, lest the sleep of the saint and his family be disturbed.

IN its latest monthly survey and forecast, the American Express Company says that more people will travel to Europe by the close of 1947 than in any single year since 1930. A 1947 total of 295,000 individual crossings against a previous peak of 279,599 in 1931, is indicated in a special study.
TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 9 -- Proposals for admission of displaced persons to the United States at this time were flatly rejected today at the one-day convention of the New Jersey American Legion.

TOKYO (By Wireless). TWO years have passed since the dusty paratroopers of Maj. Gen. Joseph Swing's Eleventh Airborne Division landed at Atsugi Airport near Tokyo to begin the occupation of Japan. They have been fantastic years -- years of effort and of apathy, of sudden, sweeping changes and stubborn clinging to tradition as West and East met and attempted to hammer out of their contrasting ideas a new system for Japan.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- Record, recoveries from income tax investigations by Treasury and Internal Revenue agents during the 1947 fiscal year ending June 30 were reported today by the Treasury Department. Secretary John W. Snyder said that total additional assessments of taxes over and above original returns filed by taxpayers, plus penalties, were $1,938,183,000.

THE announcement from England of a "Company formed to create and to administer the Central Music Library for which the need has been felt for so many years in London" is of special interest to music lovers and scholars of this city.

ARTURO TOSCANINI is adding Ridgefield, Conn., to the places to be benefited by his conducting. He will lead a small orchestra of men from the NBC Symphony in the town's high school auditorium on Saturday night, Sept. 6. He is donating his services, and the event will benefit the Ridgefield Library and Historical Association.

519 Laws On last Friday President Truman signed four bills and sent them to the State Department to be enrolled among the statutes of the United States. The bills were the last of the measures sent to his desk by the first session of the Eightieth Congress.

THE gold in the hills around South Pass City was easy enough to come by, but the highwaymen who operated unmolested in the rough passes of the Wind River Range had forced the mine owners to store their bullion under military guard at the little frontier post of Fort Stambaugh.

OTTAWA, Aug. 9 -- The Canadian Cabinet will give careful consideration next week to the dollar position of this country following the decisions taken in London. It is unlikely, however, that any immediate announcement will be made or, indeed, that there will be any change in Canadian policy.

IN the introduction to this book the distinguished Nobel Prize winner, Harold C. Urey, writes that the only hopeful approach to the future is for us "to discipline ourselves in regard to the use of our powerful knowledge." The achievement of such an aim depends, in a democratic country such as ours, on a thorough comprehension of the problems involved.

FOR the seventh program in the week-end series by the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, near Lee, Mass., under the direction of Arthur Mahoney and Thalia Mara, Pearl Primus will be the guest-artist this week. She will present, among other things, three new dances.

Much food for thought, bearing on the future of American democracy and free enterprise and its survival in a topsy-turvy world, has presented itself to reflective American business leaders as a result of the British economic crisis that came to a head last week.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Aug. 9 -- Miss Nellie Van Vliet, 21-year-old Dutch swimmer who holds six world records for the breast stroke, lowered four American standards today while winning the special 220-yard breast stroke race as part of the program at the Hotel Lido.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Reference is made to the indictment of I.G. Farben officials, which was summarized in THE NEW YORK TIMES on May 4, 1947.

ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 9 -- A court of law in Smyrna acquitted today eight Turkish newspaper men under trial for having published a statement by an Opposition Deputy allegedly insulting the "moral personality of the National Assembly."

THE problem of explaining William Alien White is one that engaged Mr. White himself during his final years, when he was writing his autobiography. It has occupied six years of Walter Johnson's time, during which Mr. Johnson has produced an edition of the Emporia editor's letters and now this full-length biography.

MONTREAL, Aug. 9 (U.P.) -- The Australian Davis Cup tennis team completed a sweep of its matches with Canada today in the American Zone final as Geoffrey Brown and Danny Pails won their final singles matches to give the team a 5-to-0 margin.
THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Aug. 9 -- Dutch political circles generally feared today that many difficulties still stood in the way of a satisfactory settlement of the Indonesian dispute.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- The densely populated New YorkNortheastern New Jersey metropolitan area afforded employment in April to 5,582,000 persons -- 26 per cent more than the 4,447,000 reported in March, 1940, the Bureau of Census disclosed today.
LONDON, Aug. 9 -- Why does Britain stay in Palestine, subjecting a huge garrison of her own troops to continual guerrilla warfare from terrorist elements there?

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 9 -- Joseph Merrill's Feather, skippered by Bill Cox, gathered wind in her sails in the final stages, after trailing most of the way, to win in the international class today in the Yacht Racing Association regatta held by the Manhasse't Bay Yacht Club.

THERE is a tendency among those who have been in Germany for a month or a year to sit down and write a book or memoirs explaining the German problem. So we have books on Germany and the Germans, how they came to be that way; what's wrong with them; is there anything right with them; why they can't be changed.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 9 -- A statement from the Sudanese National Front said today that it had unanimously rejected proposals for agreement with the Sudanese Independence Front, a rival organization, and notified the United Nations Security Council of its entire support for the claims made by the Egyptian Premier, Mahmoud Fahm Nokrashy Pasha.

STRIPED bass and black bass may be first cousins, but the most successful anglers must adopt widely divergent methods to take these two game fish. A spectacular species haunting our coastal waters from Maine to Carolina, the "striper" delights in feeding in a boiling surf and can slash through heavy waves with the utmost ease.

QUITO, Ecuador -- Ecuador glad-hands motorists at Tulcan, a mile beyond the gorge marking its Colombian boundary. Passport punching and puzzlement over disposition of our strange gringo jeep consumed an hour.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Conditions exist in business which have a powerful influence hostile to the objectives that the President pleads for in his Midyear Economic Report. The writer is in full accord with the hearty and general approval the report has received.

THE small group of ship lovers who have had an opportunity recently to inspect the "new" Panama liner Ancon have come away with a sense of having viewed a brief but brilliant flash of the future. No ship that has emerged from reconversion yards, since the war released surviving vessels from their drab duties, can compare with the Ancon's offering in the field of interior decoration.

THE search for food which dominates the life of winter birds is also characteristic of the increased number of these friends in the summer. However, instead of one or a pair, whole families are looking for a feast.

BY tradition the middle of August is the time for lengthy polemics on the low state of broadcasting. The drab replacement programs which seem to go hand in hand with the warm weather are apt to wear down the professional auditor's resistance to the point where an anguished outburst against the ways of hucksterdom may come almost automatically.

VIENNA, Aug. 9 -- There seems to be a critical period in every series of discussions with the Russians when the other nations have to make a speculative appraisal of Soviet intentions and then act on that appraisal. The United States is now reaching the end of such a period in Austria.

The action of the United Nations Security Council in calling for the cessation of hostilities in Indonesia has given it the proportions of "a world question involving global peace," according to Sutan Sjahrir, former Premier of the Indonesian Republic, who arrived here by plane from Cairo, Egypt, Friday night.

RANGOON, Burma, Aug. 9 (AP) -- The Burmese Government said today that former Premier U Saw would be among those to be tried before a special tribunal within the next few days on charges of assassinating seven members of the Burma Executive Council and two attaches last July 19.

More than 25 per cent of the moisture that falls on the prairies of Canada and the northern United States is snow. About two thirds of this evaporates, and most of what remains runs off into furrows because the hard ground cannot obsorb it. In many parts of western Canada about 4.25 inches of water are thus lost.

THE 1947 convention of the Photographic Society of America will be held on Oct. 8-11 at Oklahoma City. Features of the annual meeting, held west of the Mississippi River for the first time in the society's history, include the annual exhibition, talks, clinics and demonstrations on varied phases of photography, a prize contest and the annual banquet, at which the society will announce the honor awards.
LONDON, Aug. 9 -- Organizations preaching "super-patriotism" of the sort familiar in the United States are abroad in Britain again.
To a considerable extent the training that students now receive in teachers colleges is inadequate and does not enable them to do a competent job when they become classroom teachers.

ROME, Aug. 9 -- Total benefits accruing to Italy from an agreement that the eonomic mission, headed by Ivan Matteo Lombardo, has negotiated with the United States Government amount to $1,000,000,000, according to an estimate made today by the financial newspaper Globo.

EVANSTON, Ill., Aug. 9 (AP) -- Bob Fenimore, former Oklahoma A. and M. halfback and one of the Chicago Bears' prize rookies, today suffered recurrence of an old knee injury as the College All-Stars hammered through a lengthy scrimmage, their first in preparation for the football game with the Bears at Soldier Field the night of Aug. 22.

The United States liner Washington, originally scheduled to come from the Newport News conversion yard in September as a single class ship, has been delayed and will not be ready for commissioning until the first of the year, it was reported here last week.

SKAGWAY, Alaska -- North of the fifty-fifth parallel you won't find streamliners, roomettes, elevated domes, maid service, coffee counters, cushioned lounges or any of the other features that are supposed to make modern train travel a constant delight Quite the contrary.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 9 -- Colors of the 165th Infantry, the old Sixty-ninth of New York, which followed the regiment through the Makin, Saipan and Okinawa campaigns and ended up in Tokyo, whence the 27th Division was transoprted by air, will be returned to the regiment at a review tomorrow evening at Camp Smith.

Allen Harvey of Louisville and Frank Weisbach of Cincinnati, the "hot shots of the Ohio Valley" climbed yesterday into first place in the world championship in Masters Pairs being run by the American Contract Bridge League at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn.

Wall Street is going collegiate. The Joint Committee on Education, of which Robert W. Fisher of Blyth Co. is chairman, has uncovered about 300 potential jobs for young men who are anxious to make their way in Wall Street.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- A detailed account in glowing terms of the accomplishments of the first session of the Eightieth Congress was issued today by Representative Charles A. Halleck of Indiana, Majority Leader of the House, as a sort of "campaign bible" for Republican office seekers and workers.

HEWLETT, L.I., Aug. 9 -- W. Russ Howe and John Humm of Rockville, the defending champions, led the way into the semifinal round of the thirteenth Arthur Man Memorial member-guest golf tournament with two matchplay victories today at the Seawane Harbor Club.

STYLES in furniture like styles in dress may appear at times to evolve in a purely capricious manner. But anyone who takes the trouble to look can usually discover a logical link between the development of a furniture type and the practical aspects of contemporary living.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 9 (U.P.) -- The terrorist attack on the Cairo-Haifa express coincided with another sudden series of arrests of Revisionist leaders by the police in Tel Aviv. At least three leaders, including the chief editor of the Revisionist daily Hamashkif, were detained.

THOUGH everyone remembers the fun Mr. Marquand had with the species in "Wickford Point," the author's agent has seldom appealed to novelists as a full-dress character capable of strictly human impulses and suffering (like normal members of the cast) from such ills as unrequited love and the conviction that life is without meaning, even at 10 per cent.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9 (AP) -- A stunned crowd of 31,000 saw the Chicago-owned With Pleasure defeat Armed, Calumet Farm handicap star, by two lengths in the $33,650 Sheridan Handicap at Washington Park today for his third triumph over the golden gelding this season.

THE volume by Mr. Lucas is a "must" in any bass fisherman's library. Angling Editor of Sports Afield, he dedicates his work "to those who are already sportsmen -- and also to the many fishermen who are good sports in their hearts but haven't yet learned how to apply sportsmanship to angling."

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 9 -- Apparently following the hint given by the Viceroy Viscount Mountbatten, the projected Government of the Dominion of India is reported to have initiated a "get tough" policy with those Princes who have not yet brought their States into the union with the Dominion of India.

Henry Morgenthau Jr., general chairman of the United Jewish Appeal campaign for $170,000,000, reported yesterday that a firsthand survey of conditions affecting the 1,400,000 Jewish survivors in Europe disclosed a dangerous lowering of living standards.

To the Drama Editor: MR. HOPKINS bases his argument on the premise that Actors' Equity, by acting against Negro exclusion in Washington, is hurting the theatre. I doubt this. Indeed, I prefer to believe that Equity is acting as the conscience of the theatre, demanding that each of us declare ourselves on this vital issue. * * *

BERLIN (By Wireless). FORTY-THREE years ago half a dozen industrial chemists seated themselves around a table in Ludwigsnafen in southwestern Germany and pledged themselves to an association. Out of that almost unnoticed meeting came an organization that was to be the backbone of the national war economy in two great world conflicts.

The further boost in wages and the expensive changes in working rules which the railroad labor unions now are seeking, if granted even partly, will mean that the railroads must obtain an increase in freight rates to absorb the additional cost of operation.
" 'Having wonderful time' means, 'See how much better off I am than you.' " -- Anon.

Insured mortgage operations handled by the New York district of the Federal Housing Administration for the first seven months of this year amounted to $124,697,360 for a total of 15,761 units, it was announced yesterday by Thomas G. Grace, State Director of the Federal Housing Administration.

LONDON -- Until recently one of the most popular skits in a local revue was a number in which the principals commented morosely on the absence of Eros, the winged god of love, from Piccadilly Circus, "the center of the center of the world."

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 9 -- The South American way was the winning way in the $25,000added Whitney Stakes before near-record throng of 24,432 somewhat startled spectators at Saratoga's horse park today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- The American, farmer appears to be heading into another "good luck" harvest with crops plentiful and prices high, according to voluminous data compiled at the Department of Agriculture.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 9 -- Dr. Charles P. Olivier, president of the American Meteor Society, appealed tonight to observers throughout the country to aid the society in compiling data on this year's spectacular display of Perseid meteors which will reach its height in the three-day period begining tomorrow night.

LONDON, Aug. 9 -- Final agreement in Geneva on a reduction of 25 per cent in the United States duty on raw wool was forecast in London today by quarters close to American and Australian delegates who are attending the International Trade Organization meeting there.

AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 9 -- A national strike against the B.F. Goodrich Company was ordered today by seven locals of the United Rubber Workers (CIO), to start as their contracts expire between Aug. 14 and 18 in enforcement of a demand for a company-wide contract.

SHREVEPORT, La., Aug. 9 -- A fight in the next session of Congress to prevent confirmation of President Truman's nomination of Robert N. Denham of Maryland to the new post of general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board was indicated by Senator Allen J. Ellender, Louisiana Democrat, tonight.

LONDON, Aug. 9 (Reuters) -- Describing the contrast between Delhi and Karachi, the respective capitals of the Dominion of India and Pakistan, the India correspondent of The London Sunday Times wrote in a dispatch from Karachi today that a cloud of frustration hung over Delhi.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Aug. 9 -- After a long struggle against a faint breath of breeze and a slow slide through fog and rain up the coast, the craft in the New York Yacht Club's last squadron run of its cruise straggled in here late this afternoon and tonight.

ACTORS hope one day to play Hamlet and, by a similar urge, authors yearn to write the life of Christ. To Father Ricciotti the idea came when he lay near death in a field hospital on the Alps, and in this ample volume with its many plans and pictures the idea is fulfilled.

A SERIES of stamps received from Salvador last week by the Tribune Stamp Company presents portraits of nine Salvadoreans who were identified with the development of the Central American republic in the nineteenth century.

A new treatment for the dread undulant (Malta) fever was explainedd recently to the Second International Congress for Microbiology in Copenhagen, Denmark, by its discoverer, Dr. I. Forest Huddleson, Michigan State College. The treatment involves a new application of the sulfa drugs which have hitherto been successful only if the patient could be treated in less than ten days after contracting the disease.

LONDON, Aug. 9 -- Promotion of film sales by United States film interests in Latin America and in the United States will be intensified to offset the loss of revenues from Great Britain, Cheever Cowdin, chairman of Universal Films, which has a contract to distribute British films in the United States, told a press conference here today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9 -- Chicago, northern Illinois and parts of Indiana, Ohio, Michigan and Wisconsin were shaken tonight by a slight earthquake which began at 9:57.22 P.M. and continued for three or four minutes. Newspaper switchboards were swamped by calls from Chicagoans who felt the quake.

FLOWER arrangements keyed to one's activities reflect the vacation spirit that prevails in most homes this month. Loose bouquets with many kinds of flowers suggest gardening days in August -- outdoor life and casual entertaining in country or town.

In adopting a major new policy of acting as the prime contractor for completely packaged power units in sizes of 500, 1,000 and 2,000 kilowatts, the Worthington Pump and Machinery Corporation has introduced a radically new marketing system for steam power equipment, officials revealed yesterday.

TIMBER POINT, L.I., Aug. 9 -- Hilary Smart of Noroton shook off the challenge of Lockwood Pirie from Chicago in today's race to return the Corry Trophy for Star Class yachts to Long Island Sound. It was the concluding brush in a five-race series that featured Great South Bay's annual race week.

ALL over the world medical men are searching for something which few even believed to exist before the war. They are looking for another penicillin, another streptomycin, another member of the family of antibiotics, of which, they are now sure, hundreds and maybe thousands are to be found.

TODAY, shotgun wingshooting has been taken from the game field to golf and country clubs and to thousands of independent skeet clubs scattered throughout the land. The popularity of the sport also can be attributed to the fact that skeet shooting was a salient part of the Army and Navy Air Corps gunnery program and thousands of new scatter-gun experts currently are on the loose.

LONDON, Aug. 9 (Reuters) -- In a day in which batsmen generally had the measure of the bowlers Peter Smith, Essex spin bowler who went to Australia last winter with England's team, today captured eight Leicestershire wickets for 98 runs for one of the best individual performances in county cricket games.

FOR THIS WEEK: Little chores that need to be done over and over again are typical of August. It will pay to keep shears, ties and a trash basket handy for any walk through the garden. Snip off dead flowers and seed pods in addition to cutting the fresh ones. . . . Stake the second bloom of delphinium and other tall flowering plants such as lilies.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 9 -- A CairoHaifa troop train was derailed by a pressure mine north of Lydda today, killing the engineer and causing minor injuries. After the blast military personnel and mounted Palestine police fought a gun battle with three fleeing men and captured two of them.

NELSON S. KNAGGS is a chemist who has been called out of his laboratory many times to study and search for waxes in some of the world's most remote places. Learning a vast dea about the subject, he has become enamored of waxes as some persons become enamored of guppies -- and his studies have led him to develop an affection for many things in marine, plant and animal life.

The Executive Branch of the American Government appeared this week-end to be headed toward some foreign policy decisions which may have a far-reaching bearing on the future of the so-called Marshall Plan, both at home and abroad.
Viscountess Astor denied yesterday a report quoting her to the effect that she did not care how many Jews were killed in Palestine.

IF the new season should produce an unusually slim crop of home-grown theatre offerings -- a prospect that was worrying the trade-paper seers last week -- compensation may be forthcoming in an unprecedented variety of plays and players from abroad.

THIS paper-bound volume, which records the difficult but miraculous transformation of a peace-loving democracy into the greatest arsenal the world has ever seen, will long be a textbook for all students of industrial mobilization and government administration.

The United Seamen's Service announced yesterday that it would open a center Sept. 1 in the port of Buenaventura, Colombia, to combat dangerous health hazards and other adverse conditions to which American seamen are exposed in the port.

JEWEL-COLORED flowers on plants at windows and on porches in small towns and country places during summer prove the enthusiasm for growing gloxinias. Although natives of tropical America, gloxinias are wonderful as house plants.

Force in Palestine From Geneva last Thursday the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine sent out a ten-man flying squad to investigate the situation of some 200,000 Jews in displaced persons' camps in Germany and Austria. Their itinerary includes Munich, Vienna, Berlin, Hanover and Hamburg and Bergen-Belsen.

NEW BRITAIN, Conn., Aug. 9 -- The final class in the annual fixture of the Farmington Valley Kennel Club, held today at Willow Brook Park, was judged by Mr. Helena H. Neal of New York, who selected the wire-haired foxterrier, Ch.R.B.N. of Fenbor as best-inshow.

HOLLYWOOD -- The tourist who banks on going from one motion picture studio to another, shaking hands and chatting with the stars, is doomed to disappointment. The iron-grilled gates which separate the studios from the outside world are closed firmly to all but a chosen few, and even a letter from your Congressman will not make any kind of impression on the blue-clad private police who stand guard at the portals to studioland.

LAST week proved quite typical of the summer season in town, unless one choose to decide that it was a shade livelier than usual for August. There were four scattered openings, which included group shows of painting and of sculpture, respectively; a one-man show, and "The Bird in Art and Fashion," with the Onondaga Silk Company collaborating.

The upward revision of interest rates on security loans, announced last week by three large metropolitan banks, is a reflection of the success of Government fiscal and banking authorities in restoring normal conditions in the shortterm money market, financial observers asserted yesterday.

FIGURES which became available during the past week indicate forcefully how the current aviation plant has outgrown, temporarily at least, the aviation market. There are bright spots, of course, such as the good transatlantic business and the fair business on the longer domestic runs.

A little more than half of the loans obtained by veterans from the Railroad Federal Savings Association under the GI Bill of Rights have been for homes costing $10,000 or less, George L. Bliss, president of the association, reported yesterday.
PARIS, Aug. 9 -- In the last stages of the parliamentary session the Ramadier Cabinet encountered today a double threat from the conflicts over electoral and overseas policies.

WITH the unveiling of the Lincoln papers in the Library of Congress has come the stimulating sense of a domain newly opened -- a public domain in which many a claim will be richly developed. It will take time to read, interpret and digest 194 volumes, containing more than 41,000 pages with millions of handwritten words; yet even a preliminary search has uncovered a wealth of genuine and meaningful material.

VIENNA, Aug. 9 -- Anxiety was expressed here today that Soviet political strategy might call for an effort to force inflation on Austria. In connection with the Soviet -sponsored resolution in the Allied Council Economic Directorate, stating that the Austrian Government bears the full responsibility for the results of the "breathing spell" program of sharply increased prices and wages, certain other facts come to light.
TO THE EDITOR: In Miami County, Ohio, a unique public mental-health program is under way. The full report of a survey of mental health needs here has been widely read. Unfortunately,

TETERBORO, N.J., Aug. 9 -- Two light single-engined planes of a type that usually ventures no farther than the next airport took off from the Air Terminal here this morning en route to Goose Bay, Labrador, on the first leg of a 'round-the-world flight.

Activity in all departments last week was good, with that in colege shops reporting excellent business -- furs doing well, winter coat business steady, sportswear clearances continuing to pull, girls' departments busy with back-toschool promotions and furniture business very good, according to a survey prepared especially for the NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both reports.

RETAIL trade increases over last year are now narrowing so far as dollar volume is concerned. Nation-wide department store sales for the latest reported period, the week ended Aug. 2, showed a rise of only 1 per cent over the like week of 1946, according to the Federal Reserve Board.

On the Home Front When on June 5 Secretary of State George C. Marshall enunciated the "Marshall Plan" it was hoped that a concrete program for Europe could be put into effect by this fall. Since then it has become clear that it will probably be 1948 before the American Congress makes the key decision -- how much the United States will contribute.

SALZBURG. THE twenty-fifth annual Salzburg musical festival has ended its first week with every indication of proving an artistic and financial success. It is an encouraging augury for the revival of Austria's tourist trade and that Austrian capacity to entertain which has been its mainspring.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 9 (AP) -- The Connecticut State Team No. 1 took the Caswell Trophy match, symbolic of the national team championship at the sixty-third national rifle matches today with a score of 2,388 of a possible 2,400.

American Airlines' "flying laboratory," the DC-3 Alpha that crashed in the water Friday night a few minutes after taking off from La Guardia Field, still rested on the bottom of Flushing Bay last night with the bodies of three crew members inside the cabin.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Aug. 9 -- William P. Odom, nearing the home-stretch in quest of an around-the-world flight record, notified Elmendorf Field here tonight that he expects to arrive on his hop from Tokyo at 9:15 P.M., local time (3:15 A.M., Sunday, Eastern daylight time).
The Giants went exactly nowhere yesterday. They did it virtually in record time as Billy Southworth's Braves flattened them for the second straight time in the current series at the Polo Grounds.

YANKTON -- Room for 100 Yankton (S.D.) College has room for 100 additional students for the coming academic year, according to an announcement there. The increase, it was said, can be made "without any wide departure from the small class and close working relationship between professor and student which has been a feature of the college from its earliest days."

PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 9 -- Once again boats which put to sea for salmon are returning to Grays Harbor and Columbia River ports heavily loaded with tuna. This fish, formerly thought indigenous only to the waters far off to the southward, will bring record rewards for the 1947 season to trollers berthed in the harbors of the North Pacific.

IF you just love parties, then you're surely just going to love "Primrose Path." Honey, the whole book is Just one long party. Six days, it lasts. It's all about this lady and her husband, who get transferred from Boston to this darlin' town in Virginia and move onto this darlin' street that's called Primrose Path -- only it's not anything like that one that Ginger Rogers went to ruin on in the movie.

"LEADING" lines do not lead nor do "distracting" areas divert the attention when viewing photographs, according to scientific investigations reported by Lloyd E. Varden, technical director of Pavelle Color, Inc. Evidence provided by a motionpicture "eye-camera," which records the movements of the human eye when examining a picture, shows that the usual rules of composition by which photographs are made and their value appraised have little basis in fact.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Phil Marchildon, brilliant Philadelphia right-hander, became the second pitcher in the American League to record as many as fourteen victories today as he pitched the Athletics to an 8-to-1 decision over the Senators before 8,042 at Shibe Park.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- The Democratic National Committee replied today to Representative Charles A. Halleck's appraisal of the Eightieth Congress record with a statement that the Republican Party had delivered -- to big business and lobbies, the statement said.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Cleveland's Indians twice downed the St. Louis Browns today, taking the first match, 5 to 2, on Bob Lemon's pitching and hitting, and winning the second, 5 to 4, when Manager Lou Boudreau drove in a run in the tenth with a double.
DALLAS, Tex. THEATRE '47 in Dallas, Tex., is concluding its first season tonight with, the final performance of Tennessee Williams' "Summer and Smoke."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- Organized labor's opposition to the Taft-Hartley Law appeared to be taking such different practical forms today that the new legal repressions may intensify the struggle between the two major union groups instead of driving them closer together, as many observers had prophesied.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9 -- Col. Robert R. McCormick, editor and publisher of the Chicago Tribune, and a vital factor in the Republican Party in the Central West, today squelched rumors that his proposed visit to Tokyo, probably next month, had any connection with the budding boom for General of the Army Douglas MacArthur as a candidate for President on the GOP ticket in 1948.

BOSTON, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Brookmeade Stable's Dart By, a Whirlaway colt, pulled away in the stretch to win the $25,000 added Mayflower Stakes today. He was a length and a quarter ahead of Irving Cushen's Andys Glory who had a similar margin on D.A. Rosenbaum's Reborn before a crowd of 24,328 at Suffolk Downs in the closing day of the summer meeting.

TAGGED VIRUS -- Dr. Raymond L. Libby and Caroline R. Madison of the American Cyanamid Company's research laboratories say that they have succeeded in "tagging" with a radioactive isotope the virus of the tobacco mosaic disease. The way is now open to tagging the viruses of such diseases as influenza, atypical pneumonia, the common cold, infantile paralysis and about twenty others.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 9 -- The Argentine Central Bank, which has struck several blows at inflation during the past few months, aimed another last nignt in a decree restricting credit on personal speculative ventures.

Financial markets drifted aimlessly last week in the dullest trading of the summer. Prices eased despite the settlement of the Ford labor troubles and Prime Minister Clement Attlee's proposed remedies for Britain's economic ills. The only market reaction to the British proposal was a weakening of the motion-picture stocks, due to the proposed tax on American films.

A dispute that had threatened to tie up the overseas flights of the American Overseas Airlines was settled yesterday morning after an all-night conference between officials of the company and the Flight. Communications Officers' Association, AFL.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Aug. 9 -- Bob Sweeny, former British amateur champion, and Chris Dunphy of Meadow Brook defeated Doug Ford, Westchester amateur champion, and Charlie De Lucca of Green Valley to gain the final of the John G. Anderson Memorial golf tournament at Winged Foot early this evening, 1 up.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 9 -- Using New York City as one of three "guinea pig" communities, Yale University traffic experts have developed a new method of studying the behavior of free-moving traffic, the Yale Bureau of Highway Traffic said today.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 9 -- For the first time in sixty years the South is developing sufficient apportunities to keep its young people at home, according to, Gordon R. Clapp, chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority.

SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain, Aug. 9 -- Enrique Cardinal Pra y Deniel, Primate of Spain, in a public statement today reaffirmed his full support of Generalissimo Francisco Franco and said: "Let nobody take it upon himself to regulate the destinies of Spain from outside."

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 9 (AP) -- Four amateur gunners continued to show perfect form today in the National-All-Bore Skeet Shoot, scoring 100 straight hits for the second successive day in the 250target event.

By the strikingly small majority of 251 to 148, with more than a third of the members of the House of Commons absent or not voting, the British Labor Government has surmounted its most serious political crisis to date. That is, it has passed the Supplies and Service bill, denounced by Mr. Churchill as "a negation of British freedom and the British way of living in time of peace."

HOLLYWOOD. THIS capital of the motionpicture world, where the rags to riches story long age became commonplace, has a new Cinderella in its midst. The town is showing unusual interest in the girl, a slim 19-year-old blonde, because her story outshines in implausibility the most fantastic tale ever concocted by a screen writer assigned to create a Hollywood success story.

WHAT people want to read about, and what they don't, is a question continually confronting both author and reader, not to mention publishers. Mr. Walker, deciding for himself, evidently believes that pleasant, pastoral ramblings and gently screwball characterizations fill the page and the bill to perfection -- at least this time of year.

THIS newest work by the son of the historian, Arnold Toynbee, is a venturesome and talented experiment in the novel form. It is successful more than half the way: On the credit side, it is brilliant; on the debit side, bewildering.

BOSTON, Aug. 9 -- All along Bucky Harris has insisted that the Red Box are too dangerous to be counted out of the pennant race. Even when the Yankees had a 14game lead, the New York pilot risked ridicule by refusing to concede that his team was "in."

Out of an original entry fleet of twenty-three super-powered speed boats, pampered, petted and finely tuned to do eighty, ninety, even better than 100 miles an hour on straightaways and nearly as fast on the hairpin turns, ten remained last night as the probable starters in today's fortieth running of the famous Gold Cup classic on Jamaica Bay, just inside Rockaway Inlet.

ATHENS, Aug. 9 -- A memorandum asking the United States to supply arms to provide for an increase in the size of the Greek Army was handed today to Amercan Ambassador Lincoln MacVeagh by premier Dimitrios Maximos. Mr. Maximos also gave copies to Dwight P. Griswold, chief of the United States mission to aid Greece, and Patrick Reilly, British Charge d'Affaires.

WARTIME advances in automotive engineering and design will be applied to civilian motor transportation in the 1948 Tucker car, which is now on display in New York as the first post-war rearengine American automobile, Preston Tucker, the manufacturer, reported recently.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 9 -- Helpless before the fury of Robert Falkenburg's cannonball service for two sets, Gardnar Mulloy of Coral Gables, Fla., waited out the storm today and then came on to win.
Docked About New York City's 163 municipally owned docks and piers there has swirled a scandal involving three men:

THREE large gladiolus shows are scheduled for this week and next. The International Gladiolus Show will be held at Kalurah Temple, Binghamton, N.Y., on Aug. 19 and 20. Over 25,000 blooms are scheduled to be shown by amateur and commercial growers from the United States, Canada and Holland.

In This House American tourists in London, after a visit to Samuel Johnson's house just off the Strand, and after a lunch at the Cheshire Cheese, will be going on to Craven Street, Strand, to see the house which was the home of Benjamin Franklin during the many years he lived in England.

PARIS, Aug. 9 -- Official United States opposition to the British plan to socialize the Ruhr industries, much discussed this week, is widely regarded in Europe as characteristic of American policy. Washington is believed to use its great influence not only against the extension of communism in Europe, as in the cases of Greece and Turkey, but also against the extension of socialism by nationalization of key industries in democratic western Europe.

ANYBODY who wishes to surprise his family and friends by getting a short story published In The New Yorker need follow only a few simple rules. The New Yorker short story is almost invariably a single-scene revelation of an emotional situation.

To the Drama Editor: ARTHUR HOPKINS is a man of taste and intelligence, and one of the most respected figures in the American theatre. It is, therefore, doubly disconcerting to see him appear as devil's advocate in the Washington exclusion controversy.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9 -- Attracting public interest in this part of Illinois is a lively battle being waged by an irate group of Du Page County residents against the Government's proposal to build in their territory new, permanent facilities of the Argonne National Laboratory to be used for research and development in the field of atomic energy.

ELIZABETH CARFRAE'S latest novel probably sets a new long-distance record for the obstacle race that true love regularly runs. It is a tough steeplechase that finally winds up at the church. Caroline Mason was the coachman's daughter at the Adamson manor, and when she was only a tot she was already in love with the handsome son of the house.

MANY books have been written about the lush, volcanic isles that Mark Twain once called the loveliest fleet anchored in any sea; but none, I believe, is more interesting or comprehensive than this new account by Blake Clark. As the title suggests, the volume is a plea for statehood for Hawaii.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- Congress received a 50-50 score on its observance of the La FolletteMonroney Legislative Reorganization Act today by the law's coauthor, Representative A.S. Mike Monroney, Democrat, of Oklahoma.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 9 -- Recent stormy sessions of the Security Council here, and particularly the latest Soviet veto, have raised the question whether the United Nations will survive the struggle between the United States and the Soviet Union.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 9 -- Sharp clashes on fundamental social and political issues appear inevitable Monday when floor debate opens on committee recommendations for revising this state's 103-year-old constitution.

ANNOUNCEMENT is made by the Allied Artists of America that its thirty-fourth annual exhibition of contemporary art will be held at the National Arts Club from Oct. 5 through Oct. 26. Receiving day for work by non-members is Sept. 22 and for members, Sept. 23.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Attorney General Tom C. Clark announced today that the Office of Alien Property had taken over the interest of Dutch and German owners in the North American Rayon Corporation and the American Bemberg Corporation, with plants in Elizabethton, Tenn., and executive offices in New York City.

As part of the Connecticut Emergency Housing Program, the City of New Britain has awarded a contract for 300 factory-fabricated homes to be rented to veterans. The contract was awarded jointly to Shelter Industries, Inc., and the Winner Manufacturing Company, who will erect, as well as manufacture the units, turning over to the city finished houses at a cost of $5,836 each.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- Howard Hughes declared today that he would exile himself from the United States if his 200-ton flying boat, now five years in the building on an $18,000,000 non-profit Government contract, turned out to be a total failure.

TWO years ago, at the age of 24, Robert Q. Lewis was airing a 15-minute sustainer over WNBC. One program he mischievously devoted to describing the channels one had to follow to reach the inner offices of radio vice presidents.

DETROIT, Aug. 9 (AP) -- The hitting of George Kell, third baseman, who got four hits in four times up, including a homer and two doubles, helped the Detroit Tigers whip the Chicago White Sox, 8 to 4, today to crack Pitcher Paul (Dizzy) Trout's five-game losing streak.

PARIS, Aug. 9 -- French officials were highly pleased by the Marshall note today. They were gratified that this time Secretary Marshall himself had published the note, whereas his earlier note on the same subject had been announced by the French and more or less contradicted afterward by United States Secretary of War Kenneth A. Royall.

Five-year-old Frances Holland wanted to be Alice in Wonderland in the worst way yesterday afternoon. She made her grandmother bring her all the way from her home at 1048 Fifty-seventh Street, Brooklyn, to Central Park, hoping she could join the rest of the girls in the annual dance festival sponsored by the Department of Parks playgrounds in Manhattan.

JUST eleven years ago this week in this Review: Machiavelli graced page one as the subject of a debunking biography (by E. Erskine Muir) which pictured him as "living the typical life of the responsible citizen and civil servant."

HOLLYWOOD. FATHER PAUL DONCOEUR, editor of the French Jesuit weekly Etude, who is regarded as the leading historical expert on Joan of Arc, has arrived in Hollywood to serve as consultant to Victor Fleming on the film biography of the Maid which Ingrid Bergman, Walter Wanger, Maxwell Anderson and Fleming are producing for MetroGoldwyn-Mayer release.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 9 -- Sharp clashes on fundamental social and political issues appear inevitable Monday when floor debate opens on committee recommendations for revising this state's 103-year-old constitution.

BUDD SCHULBERG'S new book is a hard-boiled successor to his first and tough little novel, "What Makes Sammy Run?" Just as full of heels and no-goods, and as fast, slangy and wisecracking, "The Harder They Fall" is in many ways a much better novel than "Sammy."

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 9 -- A number of Latin-American delegates to the United Nations expressed approval today of the decision by Secretary General Trygve Lie to fly to Rio de Janeiro Tuesday to attend the Pan American Conference, which opens there next Friday.

THIS is a fervent novel of patriotic and religious faith in America. Mrs. Runbeck gives voice to her own faith in America's vast potentialities through her story of the education and development of Amoret, the beautiful young bride of the heir to the Phelps fortune and hopes.

LONDON. WITH the event still approximately a year ahead, preparations for the fourteenth Olympic Games are already well under way here in a spacious tenroom office of the big Army and Navy Stores on Victoria Street not far from Parliament Square.

GENEVA, Aug. 9 -- The International Trade Organization conference has recessed for the weekend with charter discussions snagged on the issue of how far quantitative restrictions on imports may be applied by underdeveloped countries.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 9 -- The future world capital of the United Nations, as envisaged here today by Secretary General Trygve Lie in a formal headquarters report to the General Assembly, will constitute an imposing skyscraper monument to world peace.

DETROIT, Aug. 9 (AP) -- The hitting of George Kell, third baseman, who got four hits in four times up, including a homer and two doubles, helped the Detroit Tigers whip the Chicago White Sox, 8 to 4, today to crack Pitcher Paul (Dizzy) Trout's five-game losing streak.

Royall.

FATHER PAUL DONCOEUR, editor of the French Jesuit weekly Etude, who is regarded as the leading historical expert on Joan of Arc, has arrived in Hollywood to serve as consultant to Victor Fleming on the film biography of the Maid which Ingrid Bergman, Walter Wanger, Maxwell Anderson and Fleming are producing for MetroGoldwyn-Mayer release.

NATHANIEL BURT in his first book of poetry wears his Housman with a difference. His verse has the old-fashioned cachet of slight wistfulness and sometimes whimsy. This is not wholly a drawback, for Mr. Hurt's imagery is often trenchant and vivid, and where the golden A.E. fades at the end of most of his poems, this new poet, less nostalgic, writes with more youthful and active assertion.

ALL this week the most highly ranked contract bridge tournament of the year has been in progress in Brooklyn, and experts from many states and sections have been drawn together in competition. Comparison of their results permits examination of some of the pat descriptions which are ordinarily used to characterize the players from different sections.

BRUSSELS, Aug. 9 -- Although there's little enough space in our cabin, it will be crammed with instruments. Some will be for navigation, some to keep the occupants alive, and some, of course, for scientific observation.

BERLIN, Aug. 9 -- The vanishing jewels of German royalty lured investigators on a $2,000,000 treasure hunt tonight through a bizarre maze that already has involved a dozen nationalities in Berlin's underworld and promises to lead to an international incident.

BAD SALZUFLEN, Germany, Aug. 9 -- Ascribing a considerable part of the inflation in Belgium and the Netherlands to exceedingly high prices charged by the bizonal export office, liaison officers from those countries are pressing for a downward revision of the German prices, it was learned today.

A heavy thunderstorm struck the city soon after 7:30 o'clock last night, tying up theatre traffic in the midtown area, cutting off electric power in a 125-block area in the Fort Hamilton section of Brooklyn and flooding a mile-long section of the Belt Parkway.

Starts on new homes in the New York area during the first half of this year were off 36 per cent as compared with the corresponding period last year, according to figures released yesterday by the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the United States Department of Labor.
Columbia University has agreed to begin immediately a survey of the migration of Puerto Ricans to New York and the conditions under which they live after arriving here.

The Bronx is being completely overlooked in both, private and public housing plans, Bronx Borouogh President James J. Lyons declared yesterday in a letter to Mayor O'Dwyer. He added that "not a brick is being laid or a nail driven" in his borough.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9 (AP) -- The Cubs and the Reds split a twin bill today, the Cubs taking the first game, 8 to 1, and the Reds the second, 5 to 0, behind Rookie Everett Lively's eight-hit pitching. The Cincinnati victory ended a fivegame losing streak.

IN recent months the record companies have shown signs of emerging from the cautious wartime period when little that was new or different was chanced. The results of this changed policy will take some time to unfold, since it requires a good many months to translate the recording session into the disks for sale in your neighborhood shop.

Charging the nation was misled by the miscalculations of our steel needs by the large steel-producing companies, Henry J. Kaiser last night demanded Congress start "the greatest steel investigation that has ever been held in America."

They are the waves of the present, not the actual sea of our time; they are the crests whose cause is a stirring in the ocean depths and a storm in the upper air, a great whipping up of mankind by the winds of destiny.

Secretary Marshall's reply to Argentina's exhortation on the promotion of world peace highly, if somewhat dryly, approves the noble sentiments expressed by Senor Peron's government on the eve of the Rio Conference. By reference to our own course, however, we suggest some tangible contribution of noble deeds.

The domestic chemical industry, little more than seventy-five years old, is coming of age. Its production now is approximately four times its pre-war output, the industry is taking a prominent position alongside steel and coal as a basic occupation and is laying plans for expansion even more sensational than its tremendous growth of the last two years.

ATHENS, Aug. 9 (U.P.) -- Touring American track and field stars won seven of nine events against Greek athletes today in Olympic Stadium, and in so doing set four new stadium records.

THE Great Barrier Reef of Australia is a fabulous example of marine architecture. A maze of reefs, shoals and coral islands, it stretches for 1,250 miles and encloses an area of 80,000 square miles. Its builders were -- and are today, for the work goes on -- coral polyps, industrious little animals endowed with astonishing versatility.

PARIS, Aug. 9 -- Behind this week's events in Indonesia lies the basic economic situation, both in Holland and in the Netherlands Indies, which the Dutch have declared forced them to take "police action" to obtain a revival of Dutch-Indonesian trade.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- An area of agreement already defined augurs every chance of success for the fourth meeting of American Foreign Ministers, which will be called to order at Petropolis, in the mountains near Rio de Janeiro, Friday.

SAMUEL GOLDWYN, who, as everyone must know by now, is not afraid to speak his mind, or even put his head in the lion's mouth, recently shattered the calm of a Sunday morning in Hollywood with the declaration that there were not more than two dozen "fine" writers among the 2,000 authors now devoting most of their energies to the movies.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 9 -- When Egypt's Prime Minister, Mahmoud Fahmy el Nokrashy Pasha, stepped up this week before the United Nations Security Council to make formal protest both against Britain's troop dispositions in the Valley of the Nile and her administrative control over the Sudan, he raised a problem that reaches back through centuries of history.

Two years have passed since a geyser of iridescent vapor mushroomed 40,000 feet into the air over Hiroshima after the first atomic bomb ever launched in war exploded. This was the culmination of fifty years of research which began when Becquerel discovered the phenomenon of radioactivity in uranium and which led to a new conception of the atom and to the famous mass-energy equation of Einstein.

The United States will export a record volume of coal in August, according to Capt. Granville Conway, president of the Cosmopolitan Shipping Company and President Truman's coordinator for emergency export programs.

FOR several generations all of the Western world has been attempting more and more to guide the operation of the economy by public and private policies. Tariffs, exchange controls, social insurance schemes, subsidies of many sorts, credit controls, the encouragement of collective bargaining, regulation of railroad and public utility rates, deficit financing, progressive taxation are manifestations of this basic world-wide trend.

IF he is lucky enough to inspect the Jonathan Bourne Whaling Museum maintained by the Old Dartmouth Historical Society on the low brow of Johnnycake Hill in New Bedford, any admirer of Herman Melville's "Moby Dick" can find support for a theory about fiction.

Two radio car patrolmen, Mario Biaggi, who is first vice president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, and John Lenox, arrested two alleged automobile thieves and a burglary suspect within an hour early yesterday morning.

DETROIT, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Collecting fourteen hits including Rookie Dave Philley's three-run homer, the White Sox beat the Tigers, 10 to 2, today for their seventh victory in eight games. Ed Lopat, White Sox lefthander, won the seven-hit pitching and Freddie Hutchinson was the loser.

LONDON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- The text of Prime Minister Attlee's broadcast to the nation tonight: I have no easy words for you tonight, nor, as you may have seen in the press, must you expect high phrases or eloquence, but I want to hold your interest and stir your imagination, and this is best done by simple and straightforward words.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 10 -- Warren R. Austin, chief United States delegate to the United Nations, indicated tonight in a radio message that this Government supplied the maintenance of the veto privilege by the Big Five powers.

The increased pace of modern living and the steadily rising costs of nearly everything we need for bare existence are nowhere more clearly reflected than in the upward trend in the demands upon New York City's voluntary hospitals shown by the special study just completed by the United Hospital Fund.
CHICAGO, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Clyde McCullough's eighth-inning single with the bases loaded gave the Cubs a 4-to-3 decision over the Reds today and the series, three games to one.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 10 -- Warner Brothers has announced the signing of Danny Kaye to a contract under which the comedian will appear in five pictures for Warners during the next seven years on a profit-sharing basis. He will receive minimum guarantee for each picture against a percentage of the profits and he will have approval of directors and of basic stories for his vehicles.
SHANNON AIRPORT, Eire Aug. 10 (AP) -- Many times, in the thirty-two years since he had left Ireland, Felix Dolan dreamed of revisiting his native County Donegal. Today his dreams died with him.

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 10 -- Jack Webb of the Riverside Yacht Club sailed Rogue to victory over seventeen Lightning class rivals in the Stamford Yacht Club regatta today. Webb, a stand-out skipper during Larchmont Race Week, is considered one of the best Lightning sailors on the Sound.

Though rule 26 on mandatory fair trade, promulgated under New York State's Alcoholic Beverage Control Law, does not cover the selling price of private brands, comment in the trade over the week-end indicated that past experience of distillers will limit the development of new whisky brands.

Foundry backlogs suddenly disappeared in some plants between May, when heavy booking's existed nationally, and the end of June, C.E. Harrington, director of engineering service, Meehanite Metal Corporation, consultant to leading foundries, revealed in a summary of foundry operations for the first six months of this year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Howard Hughes, plane designer and movie producer, is scheduled to resume his testimony tomorrow to amplify charges that the personal animosity of Army officers barred him from obtaining contracts for aircraft speedier than those used by the armed services.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Settlement of newly opened land along the Alaska Highway within the territory may begin Oct. 2, the Land Bureau of the Department of the Interior said today. Secretary Krug last week approved an order removing military restrictions from 2,750,000 acres along the route.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 10 -- Ted Schroeder's candidacy for a singles berth on the Davis Cup team took a strong rise today as he won the Eastern grass court championship at the Orange Lawn Tennis club.

AMSTERDAM, Aug. 10 -- The granting last week of a loan of $195,000,000 to Holland by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development has been received favorably by the Netherlands press with the exception of the Communist newspaper, which denounced it as "dollar slavery."

LIGONE5R, Pa., Aug. 10Westbury of Long Island won the Rolling Rock Invitation Polo tourney today, defeating another Long Island team, Meadow Brook, 10-9, before a crowd of 8,500. Westbury had a threegoal handicap allowance for the final and was never headed as hard-riding Terence Preece notched six goals and Henry Lewis added a single score.

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 10 -- C. Howard Candler, son of the CocaCola founder, the late Asa G. Candler Sr., has made a gift of stock in Asa G. Candler, Inc., worth an estimated $5,000,000 to $7,000,000 to Emory University, Methodist - owned institution, it was announced today.

The Radio Manufacturers Association export committee will meet Aug. 19 in Chicago to launch plans for further promotion of the export trade and to discuss barriers raised by foreign nations against radio imports from this country, it was disclosed over the week-end.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Bob Feller limited the St. Louis Browns to five hits today to win his fifth shut-out and fourteenth victory of the year, 6 to 0, but the Browns came back in the nightcap to salvage their only victory of the five-game series, 4 to 2.

Indications that prices for new home construction will continue at the present high levels, or possibly may go higher, are revealed in a spot survey by the National Committee on Housing of leaders in the home building industry throughout the country.

LONDON, Aug. 10 -- Now that the big debate in Parliament on Britin's economic state is over, the first feeling is one of relief. The moderate rally in the markets, which had fallen before the debate, has expressed that relief, but it has expressed little more.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In previous letters of mine which you have published I pointed out that the problem of providing adequate care and medical treatment to the mentally ill in the state hospitals of New York is a legislative problem.

NANKING, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Government reports from Suchow field headquarters today said the Communist army of Gen. Liu Pocheng had escaped across the flooded Yellow River in western Shantung Province after suffering heavy casualties under Government attacks.

Future and Past A lengthy report to the United Nations from the architects charged with the plans for the international headquarters on our East River front has invited various interest as result of a meeting of minds and talents from both of the two worlds which the U.N. hopes to weld into one.

Two hundred Naval Reserve Training Corps midshipmen and officers from the U.S.S. Oregon City and the U.S.S. Albany, now in port after a two-month Caribbean training cruise, attended the 10 o'clock solemn high mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday morning.

VIENNA, Aug. 10 -- A report on Austria by the Preparatory Commission of the International Refugee Organization presented to members of the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine, who arrived here today, states that there are at present 34,500 Jewish displaced persons in the country.

The American Airlines radar experiment ship Alpha was brought ashore at 9:10 o'clock last night from Flushing Bay, into which it fell Friday night after overshooting La Guardia Field. Early yesterday morning Navy divers had extricated the bodies of Capt. Walter A. Davidson, First Officer W.R. Zundel and Howard Hickey, a mechanic.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10 -- William P. Odom zoomed his Reynolds Bombshell airplane over Douglas Airport's traffic control tower today at 1:58.40 P.M., Eastern standard time, to encircle the world over a 19,645-mile course in 73 hours, 5 minutes and 11 seconds.

The Giants were within an out of regaling a crowd of 39,886 at the Polo Grounds yesterday with a dazzling pair of victories over Billy Southworth's rampant Braves when something suddenly gave way that wrecked the whole show.

The Liberal party, right-wing off-shoot of the American Labor party, is maintaining its close ties with the Democratic party in this city, it was indicated yesterday when the party announced its nominees for the November election.

GENEVA, Aug. 10 -- With tomorrow afternoon set as the deadline for submission of memoranda by members of the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine on a possible political solution of the Palestine problem, two written propositions have already been circulated, one by the Yugoslav delegation and one by the Uruguayan delegation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The CIO today hurled new defiance at the Taft-Hartley Labor Law by putting in the hands of members a "1947 voting guide," listing the actions of Congress members, along with advice on how to defeat in 1948 those who "voted against the people."

The Division of Higher Education of the State Education Department has performed a distinct service to the would-be college students of New York and their families in making public the number of openings still remaining this fall in classes of many of the state's colleges and universities.

A dark horse entry from the Ohio Valley, Alien P. Harvey Jr. of Louisville and Frank Weisbach of Cincinnati, captured yesterday the year's most coveted bridge honor, the Masters Pairs world championship of the American Contract Bridge League.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Failure of the Congress to respond effectively as soon as it reconvenes in January to the President's refusal to approve the National Science Foundation Bill would be a calamity.

MOSCOW, Aug. 10 (Reuter) -- Charging a "brazen offense of Fascist hooligans" in Washington against the Soviet Embassy, Victoroy, foreign commentator writing in Pravda, official organ of the Communist party in Russia, lashed out today, at the United States House of Representatives' Committee on Un-American Activities as "failing" to take measures against Fascist organizations in the United States.

GENEVA, Aug. 10 -- The possibility of a new form of monetary entente in Europe has been considerably increased in recent days as a result of the deliberations of economic experts in Paris and Geneva. The new system, if organized, would be designed to establish a greater degree of convertibility among the "soft" currencies

John Green, national president of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, CIO, has requested the intervention of President Truman in the union's strike in Atlantic and Gulf shipyards, it was announced yesterday.

AMSTERDAM, Aug. 10 -- Cessation of fighting in Indonesia Mad no influence on the Amsterdam Stock Exchange, where Dutch Indies shares continued to move in a narrow range. This was due to uncertainty concerning damage to Dutch properties.

The plan for veterans to use their New York State bonus funds to help finance cooperative housing is being enlarged to include the use of their Federal terminal leave pay to increase the veteran's, ownership interest, Herman T. Stichman, State Housing Commissioner, announced yesterday.

VILLACH, Austria, Aug. 10 -- The road from Vienna to Trieste winds upward through, the Klagenfurt basin into, the valley of the Drava near the conjunction of the Austrian, Italian and Yugoslav frontiers.

BATAVIA, Java, Monday, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Walter A. Foote, 60-yearold United States Consul-General, took off today in a United States Navy Beechcraft plane on a mission to the Indonesian Republic's capital, Jogjakarta.

FORMOSA, Argentina, Aug. 10 (U.P.) -- A group of diplomats accredited to the Paraguayan Government of President Higinio Moringo arrived at this border town today after fleeing from Asuncion, the revolt-torn Paraguayan capital.

LONDON, Aug. 10 -- Prime Minister Attlee broadcast an appeal to the British people tonight for a united national effort comparable to that developed during the war to pull Britain through her present economic crisis.

MANSFIELD, Ohio, Aug. 10 -- Two refrigerators each minute will leave assembly lines from the new expanded electrical appliance producing plant of Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company here when capacity production is attained, J.H. Ashbaugh, vice president of the appliance division, said today.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 10 (AP) -- The Cardinals edged a half game closer to the league-leading Dodgers by outslugging the Pirates, 7 to 5, in the second game of a double-header today after Murry Dickson had held Pittsburgh to four hits for a 5-to-0 triumph in the opener.
