ATHENS, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Bob Fitch of Sioux Falls, S.D., hurled the discus 183 feet 8 inches -- by far the longest of his many recordbreaking heaves -- but his effort was nullified by a foot-fault tonight in an international track and field meet at Athens Stadium.

Although recognizing the fact that some suppliers have raised the price of materials to manufacturers, retailers last week were denying the request of a number of manufacturers for increased prices on merchandise on order but not yet shipped in the belief that these cost increases should be absorbed to keep prices from going higher, according to the reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

Price reductions averaging 20 per cent on aluminum building products -- including shingles, clapboard siding, and ceiling panels -- were announced here yesterday by R.S. Reynolds, president of the Reynolds Metals Company.

ZURICH, Aug. 10 -- Swiss official trade returns up to Aug. 1, soon will show exactly what Switzerland buys from and sells to each of the four occupied zones in Germany. This analysis has been deemed necessary, first because a rapid resumption of trade with Germany is expected from implementation of the Marshall plan and secondly because of divergent economic policies operating in the eastern and western zones of Germany.

Thirty-five hundred New Yorkers, from the Health Commissioner to the ubiquitous Anonymous Citizen, have written or wired to City Councilman Joseph T. Sharkey their comments on the three rent bills that are to be the subject of a public hearing at City Hall tomorrow.

More than 1.000 electric induction motors, priced at $6 each, are among the offerings of war surplus materials and equipment listed for future sale by the War Assets Administration, Carl P. Malmstrom, regional director, revealed in a statement over the week-end.

Those peaches on the backyard trees have a way of ripening all at once, then becoming overripe before you can preserve them. The same holds true, alas, of the tomatoes maturing on the vine. Yesterday they were green, today a deep crimson.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 10 -- A major worry among steel producers here last week was the unprecedented action of prices of scrap metal. So serious has the situation become that some said further sharp advances would demoralize the steel price situation and make stable costs impossible.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 10 -- With an attendance of 146,000 persons for all events, including chamber music concerts and rehearsals, an increase of 21,000 over last year, the tenth season of the Berkshire Music Festival came to a close this afternoon in a demonstration unsurpassed and seldom equalled at Tanglewood.

William A. Kane, 58-year-old patient at the Francis Schervier Hospital, a rest home, at 228th Street and Independence Avenue, the Bronx, was rescued by the crew of a police launch last night from a rocky bank of the Harlem River Ship Canal where he had been lying since Saturday morning.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The office of the general counsel of the American Federation of Labor defended today its advocacy of the exclusion of "no-strike" clauses from agreements and rejected contentions that this policy was an evasion of the Taft-Hartley Law.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 10 -- The Paraguayan Embassy here issued a special communique tonight, admitting that rebel army troops, seeking to overthrow President Higinio Morinigo, had virtually sealed off Asuncion," the capital, from the rest of Paraguay.

KARACHI, India, Aug. 10 (London Times Dispatch) -- The opening meeting of the Pakistan Constituent Assembly took place this morning in the Council Chamber of the Sind Provincial Legislative Assembly. The Assembly will write a Constitution for the new Moslem Dominion.

BERLIN, Aug. 10 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay reported today that the United States had released all German prisoners of war and had completed the destruction of top priority German military defense works in the United States zone.

California Joe Hatten's mastery over the Phils was given added emphasis yesterday at Ebbets Field when the slim southpaw shut them out with five hits, 2 -- 0, with the Dodgers scoring their second run in the eighth inning.

LONDON, Aug. 10 -- Britain's crisis and holiday season have brought new capital market activity to an abrupt halt, which, unless remarkable strides are made in economic recovery, seems likely to last for a considerable time. The output of new securities continued to expand rapidly right up to the moment of the impact of the crisis and during July new capital offerings totaled nearly u46,000,000.

Even in this enlightened day and age there are those reactionary folk who question the value of higher education for women. As if there were any real doubt about the matter, a survey just concluded by the New Jersey College for Women of Rutgers University finds a representative segment of its graduates believing that college experience benefits both family and community, indirectly but definitely.

BERLIN, Aug. 10 -- The United States Army announced tonight that it would ask the Russians tomorrow to investigate fully a report that the late Princess Hermine, widow of Kaiser Wilhelm II, might have been poisoned at a tea party by thieves who stole $2,000,000 worth of the German crown jewels.

"The spirit of heaviness, weighing down the world, will be lifted only when we find that life has meaning," Prof. Georgia Harkness of Garrett Biblical Institute, Evanston, Ill., told worshipers yesterday at the Broadway Tabernacle Congregational Church, Fifty-sixth Street and Broadway.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Aug. 10 -- A changed Josephine has returned here after an absence of ten years. When she made her first appearance for the campers at the Regional Museum, Twin Lakes, ten years ago, she fought her director.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Aug. 10 (AP) -- The 105-foot Gloucester fishing vessel Joffre caught fire sixteen miles at sea late last night and sank in mid-morning after her crew of ten escaped in two boats and came ashore safely.

PARIS, Aug. 10 -- Decisions vitally affecting the future economic structure of Europe will be taken within the next couple of weeks in the opinion of those in closest touch with the labors of the experts in the economic conference here on the Marshall plan.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 10 -- The United Nations Security Council, meeting tomorrow to take up Egypt's demand that Britain remove her troops from the Nile Valley and surrender control of the Sudan, is expected to ask both Governments to renew efforts to settle their dispute or submit it to the World Court, according to some observers here today.

While the committees of the Paris economic conference are working on a survey of Europe's needs and capacities for self-help, the decisive negotiations which will determine the scope and success of the Marshall Plan are about to begin in two other conferences dealing with the key problem of Germany.

With the appointment of S. Paul Johnston as executive officer, the President's Air Policy Board expects to complete its staff this week and plunge into the investigation of four phases of aviation, it was learned here last night.

Every record-breaking round-theglobe flight makes the world a little smaller -- and safer. Even an hour clipped from the previous record reduces the circumference of the earth by 300 miles or so of what the Relativitists call time-space. William Odom, 27 year old pilot, managed to accomplish much more than that all alone in his trusty Bombshell.

In a gruelling 90-mile race on Jamaica Bay waters so rough yesterday afternoon that drivers suffered torturesome punishment and boats and engines cracked, split and fell apart, a smiling, curlyhaired California bachelor and war hero, Danny Foster, became the 1947 winner of the fortieth Gold Cup classic in an amazing creaiton named Miss Peps V.

MAMARONECK, N.T., Aug. 10 -- Robert Sweeny, 1937 British amateur champion and a quarter finalist in last year's United States amateur championship and the vet eran Chris Dunphy, both of Meadow Brook, captured the 36 hole final of the John G. Anderson memorial golf tournament today with a 3 and 2 victory over Arthur F. Lynch and John J. Smith, of Winged Foot over the Winged Foot east course.

A full-rigged sailing ship, aboard which Adolf Hitler is reported to have held several strategy meetings with other Nazi chieftains, arrived here yesterday as a training craft of the United States Coast Guard.

George F. Mand, president of the Bronx Chamber of Commerce, has asked the Interstate Commerce Commission for a public hearing on the question of extending "free lighterage" limits to the Hunts Point section of the Bronx, it was announced yesterday.

On Dec. 17, 1945, a few days after the Anglo-American loan agreement had been signed, the late Lord Keynes took the floor in the House of Lords to discuss its terms, its background and its implications. Touching on the amount of the loan he said:

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 10 -- Industrial recovery in Europe has continued its upward trend in recent months, according to figures in the latest issue of the United Nations Statistical Bulletin, to be released tomorrow.

Support for Actors Equity in its intensified campaign to have Negroes admitted to the National Theatre, Washington, is gaining impetus, it was learned yesterday. Thirty-five cultural organizations in that city are to be merged into the Washington Arts Center Association, with the object of taking over Washington's old Belasco Theatre and operating it under an "open door" policy, according to David C. Adkins, spokesman of the over-all body, who described himself as a professional organizer.

SEMARANG, Java, Aug. 9 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- A spokesman for Java's 2,000,000 Chinese said today that feeling among his countrymen was so strong against the Indonesian Republicans that they might join the Dutch Army to protect themselves against massacre.

It is not generally realized to what an extent the automotive industry presses forward activities looking to greater safety on the roads and streets. It is animated, of course, both by enlightened self-interest and by humanitarian motives. Since 1935 automotive funds have helped to train more than 9,000 police officers, traffic engineers, school-safety "teachers, motor fleet supervisors, driver license examiners and other specialists in all states.
RAROIA REEF, Tuamotu Archipelago, Aug. 7 (Delayed) -- The Kon-Tiki Raft is on the reef here. The six of us who were its crew are safe and unhurt on an uninhabited island.

MANILA, Aug. 10 (AP) -- A small but influential group of Manila business men was embarked today on a movement to erect trade barriers to safeguard Philippines industry from what it calls "a colonial economy."

CHICAGO, Aug. 10 -- Vacuum cleaner and washer and ironer manufacturers today hailed President Truman's decision to end all credit controls on Nov. 1 as "an effective factor" in continuing record sales levels achieved by the two industries.

More police demotions were predicted yesterday as the department began the second week of its intensive anti-gambling drive. At the same time, it was learned that the second of four demoted inspectors had applied for retirement.

The series of outdoor concerts at the Lewisohn Stadium came to a fitting close last night. Despite the handicap of having been postponed from the night before, the final event attracted 9,600 and it was one of the finest concerts of the eight-week series.

PEIPING, Aug. 10 (U.P.) -- Dispatches from Mukden said today that Gen. Chen Cheng, Chief of Staff, was in charge of defense preparations for the expected sixth and mightiest Communist offensive in Manchuria this fall.

BERLIN, Aug. 10 -- Political observers here have noticed an increasingly lukewarm attitude of the German population in the Soviet zone toward the Russian nsored Socialist Unity party. The leaders of the party itself have noticed it also, and have set about trying to correct it with little apparent result.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 10 (AP) -- A Paraguayan Government communique from Asuncion said today that the attempt by rebel forces to infiltrate into the southern sector of the capital's defense lines had been defeated, with the capture

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The general index of basic commodity prices based on the average 1939 level rose from 305.6 on Aug. 1, to 308.4 on Aug. 8, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. The following lists daily index numbers and spot market prices:

PARIS, Aug. 10 -- Premier Paul Ramadier today averted a cabinet crisis by a, compromise that calls for a special session of Parliament to debate the new Statute for Algeria. This obstacle momentarily removed; he must obtain tomorrow a vote of confidence asked for in the election debate.

No limits should be placed on the power of God, the Rt. Rev. William R. Moody, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Lexington, Ky., declared yesterday in a sermon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.
Arrangements have been completed that will enable WNYC, the city station, to broadcast all the concerts of the Saratoga Spa Music Festival from the Spa Theatre, Saratoga Springs.

SPOKANE, Wash., Aug. 10 (AP) -- Herman Keiser of Akron, Ohio, dropped a three-foot putt on the seventeenth hole today to clinch first place in the $10,000 Esmeralda Open Golf Tournament with a sevenunder-par 273 after Ben Hogan and Ed Furgol had battled through a drama-packed afternoon In a futile effort to overtake him.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 10 (AP) Dr. R. F. Westermeier of Buffalo, won the all-bore championship of the ninth annual national skeet championships which ended today. He also teamed with Ed Lee of Norwich, N.Y., to win the doubles, and he paced the Buffalo Trap and Field Club to the five-man team title.

It you follow world events for a while from a tranquil beach on Cape Cod, the rushing current begins to look curiously spasmodic -- not swift at all but merely churning round in circles. The sands drift over the grass-tufted dunes, the tides lap gently on the scalloped shore, white clouds float slowly across the summer skies.

In his Midyear Economic Report, the President gave considerable emphasis to the importance of exports in the high level of economic activity attained in the first half of 1947. About threefourths of the increase in gross national product in this period was attributed to the expanding volume of exports.

PARIS, Aug. 10 -- There is a feeling for the monastical about the full, hooded cloaks and man ties of Madaine Gres' beautiful collection. They seem to call for the carved stone background of a medieval cloister.
SALZBURG, Austria, Aug. 10 -- Wilhelm Furtwaengler received a rousing welcome in his first postwar appearance in Austria today when he directed the Vienna Philharmonic in Festspielhaus.

May, a shiny black 7-year-old mare that for the greater part of her life pulled an old-style cab about Central Park, made her last trip yesterday. The end came mercifully and quickly for the animal when an agent from the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals shot her through the head.

Emil Rieve, general president of the Textile Workers Union of America, CIO, announced yesterday that the union was moving to obtain wage increases for its 125,000 members employed in Southern cotton and rayon mills. Recently 90,000 workers in New England, New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania mills received an increase of 5 cents an hour and other concessions.

SIX years ago a young writer stirred up quite a commotion with a vulgar, brutal, viciously sardonic novel about a vulgar, brutal, vicious man-on-the-make in the movie industry. "What Makes Sammy Run" by Budd Schulberg belonged to the brass-knuckle, foul-epithet school of realism and was about as pleasant to take as a dose of straight alcohol and paregoric mixed.

YONKERS, N.Y., Aug. 10 -- A vicious marsh hawk that for three days, together with its mate, had attacked women residents of the Home of the New York Guild for Jewish Blind at 75 Stratton Street, was killed by an air rifle shot yesterday afternoon.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 10 -- Members of an armed band wearing Arab dress opened an unprovoked attack tonight in a Jewish cafe on the bank of the Yarkon River at Tel Aviv, killing four Jews and wounding ten, seven of them seriously.

The National Council of Jewish Women, which last January discharged a woman employe on charges that she used her position to promote communism, has been ordered by James L. Fly, arbitrator in the dispute, to reinstate her.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 10 -- Best-in-show for the second day in a sow went to Robert B. Neff's wire foxterrier Ch. R. B. N. of Fenbor, who took the chief award in the annual all-breed fixture of the Rhode Island Kennel Club today. Handled by Phil Prentice the terrier won under the judging of Mrs. R. B. Choate of Danvers, Mass.

An unexpected forecast by the Government that this year's cotton crop would be larger than had been expected caused a sharp downward trend in prices in the market's final session on Friday. Prior to the announcement the market was strong, following a weakness in the early part of the five-day trading period.
Despite the panicky cries of women and the petitions being circulated in various parts of the country, New York designers are resolute on the subject of longer skirts.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Aug. 10 -- The King's Cup, foremost of all the prizes in American yachting, will be raced for tomorrow out in the ocean off here. A record entry of fourteen, eclipsing the thirteen that started in 1929, will compete.

DEXTER, Me., Aug. 10 (U.P.) -- High military and civilian procurement officers were allowed to win huge sums of money in "fixed" poker games during the war by contractors who wished to gain their favor, Senator Owen Brewster said today.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $51,665,929,912. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The United States Chamber of Commerce condemns the proposal to give to the United Nations authority for controlling world oil resources, Earl O. Shreve, president of the chamber, declared today.

A bonanza of animal fossils that ay throw considerable light on the origins of mammal life sixty million years ago has been exhumed in New Mexico by scientists from the American Museum of Natural History, the museum announced here yesterday.

Plans for intensifying the nation-wide drive of the American Heritage Foundation under the presidency of Thomas D'Arcy Brophy were announced yesterday by Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the board of the foundation.

Most American employers maintain adequate differentials between wage rates of workers in the ranks and their supervisors, a survey by the National Industrial Conference Board disclosed over the week-end. Of the firms surveyed, 16 per cent by specific design avoid granting a pay increase to one group just because another group gets one.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : In your issue of July 26 you published an editorial about the crime of genocide. There is no doubt that everyone concerned with the prevention of crimes similar to those committed by the Nazis must fervently wish that the United Nations will adopt this law.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10 -- A big bull market was on in corn last week, with record high prices established for the cash article and futures. All deliveries of that grain and oats sold at new seasonal high prices, and although there were hedging sales in wheat, the latter was carried upward by the strength in feed grains.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 10 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Athletics and the Washington Senators split a double -header before 19,496 fans today with Rookie Joe Coleman of the Mackmen limiting the Senators to four hits in winning the first game, 3 to 2, and Rae Scarborough scattering 12 Athletic blows -- all singles -- to capture the second game, 5 to 2.
CHICAGO, Aug. 10 -- The unofficial log of William P. Odom's flight is as follows, with all times Eastern Standard: Thursday, Aug. 7 12:53 P. M. -- Started from Chicago.

MALONE, N.Y., Aug. 10 (U.P.) -- Maj. Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, commandant of the United States military academy at West Point, warned today that the world was living in an era of suspended hostilities. Actual combat, he said, could be renewed at any time and urged this country not to become indifferent to men in the armed forces.

ANSONIA, Conn., Aug. 11 -- The home of the Paul sisters, who have lived there for seventeen years as recluses, was entered today by the police who found $7,236 in cash and $3,000 in negotiable checks scattered about the ten-room frame house.
Fare increases authorized on July 9 are "far from sufficient" to erase the Long Island Bail Road's deficit for the rest of this year, an attorney for the carrier testified yesterday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The cellar-dwelling Browns split a double-header with the White Sox today, losing the first game, 5 to 2, and winning the second, 8 to 4, behind Clif Fannin's six-hit pitching for his third victory over the White Sox and his fourth of the season.

The Chrysler Corporation and its wholly owned United States subsidiaries showed a net profit of $36,122,457 for the first half of this year after all deductions, including $23,500,000 provision for taxes, according to the report of K.T. Keller, president, to be mailed to stockholders today.

ALBANY, Aug. 11 -- Persons who go on a vacation, or who plan to do so, while collecting unemployment insurance will find the state stopping their checks, Joseph Crowe, head of the local information office of the State Labor Department's Placement and Unemployment Insurance Division, warned today.
Charley Sperber of the Sands Point Club took the lead among the Long Island competitors in The World-Telegram hole-in-one tournament at the Bayside links yesterday.

Brides almost always find it difficult to plan meals and to market, but now, with food prices high and meat costs in particular setting records, as they were last week in New York, they must deal with a situation that's hard even on experienced budgeters.

DETROIT, Aug. 11 -- The top leadership of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, was accused today by Clarence W. Avery, president of the strike-bound Murray Corporation of America, of fomenting chaos in the automotive industry by secretly wanting wild-cat strikes without accepting responsibility for them.

AUGUSTA, Me., Aug. 11 (AP) -- Senator Owen Brewster, Republican, of Maine, told fellow Republicans today that he came home from the Howard Hughes investigation "full of poisoned arrows that have been shot at me rather assiduously in recent weeks."

Genocide -- the word coined by the Polish scholar and Nuremberg trials adviser, Prof. Rafael Demkin, to identify the crime of annihilating national, racial or religious groups -- goes to the heart of the United Nations Charter. If the Charter, which reaffirms "faith in fundamental human rights, in the dignity and worth of the human person," means anything, it means that genocide, once and for all, must be recognized as an international crime.

A majority of the directors of the Italy America Society, Inc., an organization formed in 1918 to foster cultural relations between the United States and Italy, asked the Supreme Court yesterday to dissolve the society because it had been dormant since 1940 and could not now achieve its purpose.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 -- The number of manufacturers in the auto mobile accessories field has increased sharply since the end of the war, R.G. Ames, director of the Automobile Accessories Association, said today at the opening of a four-day exhibition sponsored by the association.

Celestina Lamour, 10 years old, of 40 Sunset Road, Newington, Conn., was injured critically at 5:50 P.M. yesterday when she was struck by a New York to New Jersey bus on West End Avenue near Ninety-third Street. She was taken to Knickerbocker Hospital, where the extent of her injuries was not determined immediately.
Officials of the Board of Education are studying a proposal to establish a residential school for New York public school pupils who are chronic truants, it became known yesterday.

WALWORTH, Wis., Aug. 11 -- Seventy-five young Catholic men and women from all over the country gathered at Camp Aurora here today for a week's study to try to work out a new pattern of recreation for Catholic rural parishes.

TORONTO, Ont., Aug. 11 -- Czechoslovakia, Austria and Greece were readmitted into the International Federation of University Women at the council meeting today which preceded the general meeting which opens tomorrow and continues until Saturday.

DETROIT, Aug. 11 -- City officials, acting to avert a complete shutdown of the most vital public services by Thursday because of a gasoline shortage, disclosed tonight that they were ready to order the confiscation of all stocks of the fuel "wherever we find it," even to the contents of tanks on private automobiles in the street.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange turned reactionary yesterday and closed 30 to 58 points net lower.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The Senatorial investigation into Howard Hughes' war contracts was suddenly suspended today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Gold refiners protested today against proposed Treasury controls intended to curb speculative foreign transactions in gold at premium prices.

BROOKHAVEN, L.I., Aug 11 -- Over the flat, sandy soil where American soldier recruits twice absorbed the cadence of war echoed today the forward march of science. With no khaki in sight as a reminder that these 6,000 acres once were Camp Upton, scientists in shirtsleeves dominated the scene.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The Far Eastern Commission has decided to permit the use of Japan's stock of gold and jewels to help finance the occupied country's peace economy.

LONDON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Winston Churchill demanded tonight that the House of Commons reject the Labor Government's "economic crisis" bill on the ground that it conferred virtual dictatorial powers on a Cabinet whose Prime Minister "might be discarded" at any moment.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- West-chester and Connecticut commuters assailed today what they called "serious flaws, omissions and injustices" in the new scale of rail-road commutation fares proposed for the New York area by Burton Fuller, Interstate Commerce Commission examiner.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 11 -- French North African and Indo-Chinese independence groups called today on Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, to ask the Security Council to investigate alleged terrorism and oppression by French authorities against the people of Morocco, Algeria and Tunisia.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Secretary of State Marshall gave youthful students of government from forty-one states today this two-step formula for becoming good judges of international events:

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 11 -- The rapid expansion of United Nations activities may compel the organization to operate a subsidiary, headquarters in the former League of Nations buildings in Geneva, Secretary General Trygve Lie indicated today in his annual report.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The second Congress of the International Association of Democratic Lawyers convened in Brussels, Belgium, on July 16, 1947. The idea for organizing this association of democratic lawyers was conceived during the Nuremberg trials.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Virgil Trucks limited the Cleveland Indians to nine hits tonight, and the Detroit Tigers, with only six safeties, won, 3 to 1.

Random notes. Plenty of bluefish ranging from two to four pounds are being taken by anglers fishing out of Long Beach Island on the New Jersey shore, and the surfcasters are bringing in quite a few stripers from the beach.

Emphasizing the part of early detection and complete hospital care in succesful treatment of tuberculosis, the Hospital Council of Greater New York recommended yesterday that facilities be made available in the city's general hospitals for some tuberculosis cases.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 11 -- Following is the text of the introduction to Secretary General Trygve Lie's report to the United Nations General Assembly:

Three Canadian youths, who were described by the police as responsible for a series of hold-ups of taxicab drivers and restaurants in the last week, were held in high bail on robbery charges yesterday by Magistrate Francis X. Giaccone in Felony Court.

A Navy general court-martial began yesterday to consider its verdict in the case of Chief Signalman Harold E. Hirshberg, accused of maltreating six fellow Americans in Japanese prisoner-of-war camps in the Philippines and informing the enemy of escape plans by three others.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 11 (AP) -- Frank Parker of Los Angeles, twice national singles champion, was eliminated today along with all but one of the seeded foreign players as the Newport Casino twenty-eighth annual invitation lawn tennis tournament started.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The Office of Defense Transportation ordered today an embargo on United States coal shipments into Canada by way of the Government-owned Canadian National Railways, to help relieve the continued railroad car shortage in this country.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 11 -- Registration statements covering an aggregate of 519,972 shares of common stock were filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by three companies.

R.H. Macy Co.'s second branch store in the city limits will open for business Sept. 2 in Jamaica Queens, on the south side of Eighty-ninth Avenue, from 164th to 165th Streets, it was announced yesterday.

Classic favorites of corduroys, plaids and gray flannels figured largely in the college fashions presented yesterday at Saks-Thirty-fourth. Among the corduroys was a light gray suit with a longer length, back-belted jacket, and skirt finished with a shaped contour belt.

Now that the bill creating the Air Policy Board, comprised of members of both Houses, has been signed by the President and that his own Air Policy Commission, comprised of civilians, is functioning, we may hope for a steady and searching examination of all the fundamentals necessary to a well-rounded program for our use of the air.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 -- Higher salaries and more professional security for teachers must be achieved at once if the United States is to win the present round of its never-ending fight against intolerance and anti-democratic ideas. Attorney General Tom C. Clark today told members of the Fraternal Order of Eagles, meeting in their annual convention, which will extend through Thursday.

Net income of the Western Union Telegraph Company for the six months ended on June 30 amounted to $6,258,355, equal to $5.09 each on 1,230,145 shares of Class A stock, Joseph L. Egan, president, reported yesterday in a letter to stockholders.

BATON ROUGE, La., Aug. 11 -- New sales, stimulants and improvements in selling methods are in prospect for the cotton-textile industry C.K. Everett merchandising director of the Cotton Textile Institute, told the Baton Rouge Managers Club here today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 11 -- Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, admitted somberly today that "the world political situation has not improved in the last year." He called on the fifty-five member nations to make "a more general effort to explore and resolve the fears and conflicting interests which are at the root of our difficulties."

MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 11 (AP) -- It was a day of overtime play and near upsets as the twentieth annual Essex County Club women's invitation tennis tournament moved through its first and second rounds today. Eight of the twenty-four matches played required three sets to decide with the tournament's top seeded player, Miss Dorothy Head of Alameda, Calif., involved in two of the overtimes.

Although the film division recorded a slight recovery yesterday, the main section of the stock market lost further ground in dealings on a level with last week. The sharp break of Friday apparently discouraged any bidding of note, with weakness in the industrials and the composite rate reduced by 0.93 point on the day.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 11 (AP) --The onrushing St. Louis Cardinals gained another half-game on the idle Brooklyn Dodgers tonight when they downed the hapless Chicago Cubs, 3 to 1, on the strength of Harry Brecheen's steady pitching.

PARIS, Aug. 11 -- Premier Paul Ramadier obtained a vote of confidence from the National Assembly today. The vote, 404 to 184, amounted to acceptance of the Premier's insistence on a return to consideration of the Government bill providing a new system of municipal elections.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: During my recent visit in Korea I interviewed thousands of people from all walks of life. I was shocked to learn, that South Korea was rapidly drifting toward anarchism and that North Korea has apparently become a police state under Russian dictate.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 -- Corn declined 8 cents a bushel, the daily, limit, at one time on the Board of Trade today, the first major set-back since July 29. During the intervening period prices had advanced 41 3/4 to 43 1/3 cents as the result of continued hot and dry weather.

The Senate subcommittee hearings on the case of Howard Hughes have come to at least a temporary conclusion. In Washington Mr. Hughes was described yesterday as "smiling broadly" as he issued a statement giving what he thought were the reasons for this unexpected chopping of the curtain.
NANKING, Aug. 11 -- The last month has seen some of the heaviest fighting of the civil war in Shantung, the main theatre of hostilities between Government and Communist forces in North China.

VIENNA, Aug. 11 -- Joseph M. Dodge, United States delegate to the four-power Austrian treaty commission, charged today that in the Lobau refinery case the Soviet Union had prejudged conclusions of the commission and the Council of Foreign Ministers.

Inspectors of the department of housing and buildings' hotel squad visited apartment hotels and studio apartment buildings in Manhattan yesterday in a drive ordered by Commissioner Robert F. Wagner Jr. to check compliance with safety standards provided in the new local laws and in state legislation.

LONDON, Aug. 11 (Reuters) -- Douglas Wright, bowler for Kent County and England took the last three Sussex wickets with successive balls as county cricket continued today. Other individual feats were the highest scores that C.S. Elliott and J.D. Eggars ever made.

The Citizens Budget Commission has just brought up to date its exhaustive digest of fiscal facts about the City of New York with the publication of a volume to stand beside that of 1940. The first volume covered twenty years, beginning with 1919. The new summary includes the fiscal years 1945-46 and gives some figures for an additional year.

The opening session of the metropolitan district's three-day junior Davis Cup play-offs was field at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills yesterday with Long Island defeating New Jersey and the combined Westchester-Connecticut team conquering Brooklyn.

CLINTON, Mich., Aug. 11 -- More than a score were injured today as a march by 125 employes as part of a back-to-work movement brought a clash with pickets at the Clinton Machine Company plant, closed for two weeks by a strike of the United Automobile Workers, CIO.

Store Sales Off 4% Here Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores declined 4 per cent last week against the comparable week a year ago, according to the "flash" report of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York yesterday.
CHICAGO, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 11 -- With the deadlock over international atomic control now becoming almost an accepted fact, Great Britain today submitted a series of questions intended to discover how the Soviet Union thinks the Soviet proposals would actually work.

SALEM, N.H., Aug. 11 (AP) -- An opening-day crowd of 11,321 saw Mike Salvia's 4-year-old Sunny move up fast on the inside today to win the Alton Allowance Purse of $3,500, featured race at the fifteenth annual summer opening at Rockingham Park.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Grady Hatton and Augie Galan each belted a homer to account for six Cincinnati runs as the Reds defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates, 8 -- 3, before 12,832 fans here tonight. Veteran Bucky Walters scattered eight hits for his sixth victory.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 11 -- The United Nations Economic and Social Council, by a vote of 13 to 0, with five abstentions, appointed a special committee today to study the creation of an economic commission for Latin America. Those abstaining were Russia, France, Canada, White Russia and India.

Ways and Means That time of year we now behold is much given over to moving about from place to place. We are annually admonished at this season on the desirability of vacations at home; from the Latin we learn that people change their skies but not their minds when they run about the earth; from the French of Mme. de Stael we have travel defined as the "saddest pleasure in the world."
BRUSSELS, Aug. 11 -- In the preceding articles, we have described the bathyscaphe at some length. But the craft is important only during the dive, only when we are at the place where we plan to dive.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- President Truman has made it plain to the new National Labor Relations Board that it is part of the executive branch of the Government. While he does not object to the board cooperating with the Joint Congressional Committee that is the "watch-dog" of the Taft-Hartley act, he feels that the board is responsible to him.

The Democratic National Committee is planning a major political broadcast within the next few weeks to challenge Republican claims on the record of accomplishment by Congress, it was reported yesterday.
CHICAGO, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Comparative hard time have hit the pari-mutuel horse race betting business.

BATAVIA, Java, Aug. 11 (U.P.) -- American Consul General Walter A. Foote conferred today with Indonesian President Saekarno and the Republican Cabinet at Jogjakarta on the United States tender of its good offices to end the Dutch-Indonesian dispute.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 11 -- The Republicans were challenged today by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, to nominate Senator Robert A. Taft for President in 1948.

Elm Court and Shorewood, the two waterfront estates of the late Edgar P. Luckenbach on Hempstead Harbor at Sands Point, L.I., have been purchased by Paul H. Gugger, president of the Plastico Corporation of Long Island City, and Irving Mariash, Manhattan attorney and a former lieutenant commander in the United States Navy. The purpose of the purchase was not divulged by the new owners.

DENNIS, Mass., Aug. 11 -- Faye Emerson, wife of Elliott Roosevelt, opened here tonight at the Cape Theatre in a new comedy, "Profile," which deals on a personal level with Russian-American relations. The play is intended eventually for Broadway.

Gregory's Dress Shop has leased a store in the two-story taxpayer which Sam Minskoff Sons, owners and builders, are erecting on the Thirty-seventh Avenue block-front between Seventy-sixth and Seventy-seventh Streets in Jackson Heights, Queens.

EVANSTON, Ill., Aug. 11 (AP) -- Two relatively new players in tournament golf and a veteran campaigner tied for medalist honors today with two-over-par 77's in the qualifying round of the forty-seventh annual Women's Western Amateur at the Evanston Golf Club.

BOISCHATEL, Que., Aug. 11 (Canadian Press) -- Gerry Kesselring of Kitchener, Ont., today successfully defended his Canadian amateur junior golf championship with a medal score of 149 for the thirty-six holes of play. One stroke behind came Bill Mawhinney of Vancouver.

Several hundred Brooklyn and Queens metalworking plants which make stampings, metal furniture, structural products, auto accessories and heating and ventilating equipment could increase their output by 50 per cent if larger supplies of sheet, strip and structural steel develop this fall, W.F. Koetzle, vice president of Kasper and Koetzle, Inc., Brooklyn hardware and steel merchants, revealed here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The State Department announced today the composition of the American delegation to the first "brasstacks" conference of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization.

ON the turf of the Mount Royal Tennis Club in Montreal the most important Davis Cup "tie" ever held in Canada will start on Thursday. The Dominion will be only an innocent bystander, serving as host for the contesting parties, who have come many thousands of miles from across the Atlantic and the Pacific.

Several amendments to the rent and eviction bills, on which a public hearing will be held today at City Hall, were made known last night by Joseph T. Sharkey, vice-chairman and Majority Leader of the City Council and sponsor for the municipal rent control measures.

Retail jewelers arriving at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday for the opening of the annual convention of the American National Retail Jewelers Association, which will run through Thursday, jumped at once into the job of placing orders. But an underlying, cautious approach to the problem of stocking up for fall and holiday business was reported by exhibitors.

The arrival of the Gdynia America liner Batory here today will be marked by a ceremony at which the vessel's physician, Dr. Wincenty Natkanski, will be honored for transferring to a freighter at sea and giving medical aid to an expectant mother seriously ill with pneumonia.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 11 -- The United Steelworkers of America, CIO, formally opened here today its part in the CIO Political Action Committee's campaign to elect, next year, to Congress the "friends of labor" who will try for repeal of the Taft-Hartley Act.
ATHENS, Aug. 11 -- Coffee, sugar and flour were difficult to find in Athens today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 11 -- Walt Disney is planning a feature-length film dealing with Alaska, his studio announced today after the producer's departure Saturday by private plane for Juneau. Disney will spend two weeks in Alaska getting impressions which will determine the format of the film and how much live action will be combined with animation and narration.

A slower pace of business than the season warrants, was evident in Worth Street yesterday, indlciting that buyers have begun,a waiting period to see the effect of lower staple costs on cotton textiles.

The assessed valuations of publicly-owned real estate in this city, which is tax exempt, have increased by 15.2 per cent, from $3,903,657,840 to $4,497,436,715, between the fiscal years 1939-40 and 1946-47, according to the second volume of "Fiscal Facts Concerning the City of New York," whose publication was announced yesterday by the Citizens Budget Commission, 51 East Forty-second Street.

A disabled veteran of both world wars, Paul J. Oliver, 50 years old, of 440 East 123d Street, told yesterday of his efforts to supplement a modest disability pension with a mobile shoe shine parlor. Mr. Oliver has lost his right eye, which he attributes to a gas attack while fighting in the Argonne Forest in World War I.

All machinery dealer contract with the War Assets Administrtion will be canceled as of Aug. 31, Robert L. Giebel, president of Giebel, Inc., and chairman of the surplus property committee of the American Machine Tool Distribtors Association, declared here yesterday.

Greatly heightened interest in understanding children's behavior Is evident among principals, teachers and school supervisors attending her summer course, Dr. Roma Cans, Professor of Education, Teachers College, Columbia University, reported yesterday.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 11 -- Last night's attack by an Arab band that killed five persons, four Jews and an Arab, in a cafe on the outskirts of Tel Aviv has brought Haganah, the Zionist underground militia, to its toes. The incident also seems to have laid a foundation for the strengthening of the Jewish community's defense forces.

BERLIN, Aug. 11 -- The United States Army's Criminal Investigation Division announced tonight that it was handing over the case of the stolen jewels of the late Princess Hermine to the German civilian police.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Dr. William Charles White, a pioneer in tuberculosis research, died today after an illness of several weeks. His age was 72.

The prospect that negotiations by representatives of the Bethlehem Steel Company, which operates nine of eighteen strike-bound shipyards on the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts, and the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, CIO, would be resumed this week after a twoweek stalemate appeared probable yesterday.

MOSCOW, Aug. 11 (AP) -- David Zaslavsky, in a Pravda article almost half a page long, delivered an attack on the United States press today, declaring that it was not an organ of opinion and conviction but a "commercial enterprise." Pravda is the official organ of the Communist party.

BOSTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Three singles, two of them scratchy affairs, kept Earl Johnson, southpaw, from a no-hitter tonight as he hurled the Red Sox to a 1-0 decision over the Senators, thanks to a third-inning home run by Sam Mele.

Canadian Pacific Dividend Some doubt was cast yesterday on a dividend payment this fall by the Canadian Pacific Railway on its ordinary stock. In recent years, it has been the practice of the company directors to meet in August with regard to a dividend payment on the ordinary stock.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- A total of 208,000 veterans and dependents of veterans of the Civil and Spanish-American Wars will receive a 20 per cent increase in their pensions beginning in September, the Veterans Administration announced today.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 11 -- A suggestion that perhaps there should be legislation to "clip the wings" of labor leaders beyond the extent of the Taft-Hartley Act, was voiced today as the House Labor subcommittee began its inquiry into the ten-month jurisdictional strike in Hollywood.
BERLIN, Aug. 11 -- The Russians refused again today to accept the United States proposal for printing new currency in Germany.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Greater demand by consumers plus higher price levels elevated last year the processing of salad dressings to a "hundred-miHion-dollar" industry, the Department of Commerce reported today.
CANBERRA, Australia, Aug. 11 (Reuters) -- Australia will accept the American offer of a 25 per cent reduction in the United States wool tariff, it was authoritatively learned here today.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 11 -- The Darby Dan Farms' Darby d'Amour made a runaway of the Class C Old Forge purse at Saratoga today, sprinting the six furlongs in 1:10 4/5 and winning by four lengths.

A dual price level in precision tools has developed in the New York area, industrial purchasing executives revealed here yesterday. Brown Sharpe lines have been advanced 10 per cent, varying by individual items, they said, but L. S. Starrett Company, Inc., a major competitive line, are still being sold at price levels announced last-May 27.

Representative Vito Marcantonio, speaking early this morning at the Kings County Convention of the American Labor party, called for a new national political party for the 1948 election. He predicted that it would become the majority party in the nation by 1952.

Despite the political deadlock between East and West and the new sense of crisis overhanging European economy, the peoples of the world are, nevertheless, accomplishing a great deal of constructive work and are demonstrating anew that vitality and will to live which have brought mankind through many another crisis, if at times only by the skin of its collective teeth.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Assertions that "the dignity and sacredness of marriage is disregarded and scorned" and that some fashions "leave little to the imagination" were made today at the sixth quinquennial, Franciscan Third Order Congress.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 11 -- Championing Egypt's demand that Britain withdraw her troops from the Nile Valley and give up control of the Sudan, Premier Mahmoud Fahmy Nokrashy Pasha, before the United Nations Security Council today vigorously criticized what he called "despotic" British rule.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 (AP) -- William Helis' fast-stepping 3-year-old filly Miss Kimo smashed Washington Park's seven-furlong track record today while speeding to a one-length victory in the $34,750 Misty Isle Stakes for fillies and mares.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Sales of chain stores and mail-order houses through the first half of this year continued at record levels, the Department of Commerce reported today.
A halt in public spending and tax relief are the first needs of

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 11 -- The President of Paraguay, Higinio Morinigo, and members of his Government were on the way this evening to Pilar, which is about 200 miles down the river from Asuncion, the capital, according to a Paraguyan diplomatic representative here.

A $10,000,000 bond issue for emergency housing will be offered for sale on Aug. 21 by the State of New Jersey. The bonds, dated July 1, 1947, due 1950 to 1957, will be awarded to the bidder submitting the lowest interest rate in a multiple of 1/3 or 1/20 of 1 per cent.

By virtue of victories In semifinal contests held last night, teams headed by Howard Schenken and Charles H. Goren will meet today in the finals of the world master teams-of-four championship at the summer bridge session sponsored by the American Contract Bridge League at the St., George Hotel in Brooklyn.

Jail sentences for small-fry bookmakers' runners and other boss gamblers' agents were asked yesterday by Kings County District Attorney Miles F. McDonald. He told Magistrate David P. McKean in Gamblers Court in Brooklyn that he knew of no quicker way to break up gambling.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Aug. 11 (AP) -- In the first such action since he became Professional Football Commissioner a year ago, Bert Bell today ordered the immediate suspension of Fred Vant Hull, veteran Green Bay Packer guard, for violation of the National League's "contract jumping" rule.

UNION BEACH, N.J., Aug. 11 -- Vladimar Juras, 42 years old, owner of a tavern on Route 36 here, was shot and killed at 8:45 A.M. today when he resisted a youth apparently bent on robbery. Aroused by the slaying, residents of this summer resort colony, six miles northeast of Red Bank, formed armed posses to help state troopers and local authorities hunt the killer.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Aug. 11 -- Twelve yachts, one less than the record number of 1929, went after the King's Cup off this port today and the winner was the 34-year-old schooner Pleione of the local Eastern Yacht Club.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The Department of Agriculture today forecast a corn crop of 2,659,949,000 bushels this year, a downward revision of its previous estimate of July 15. A record wheat crop of 1,427,747,000 bushel was predicted, however.

IN September, 1945, a British intelligence officer and former Oxford historian was assigned to the task of making as complete an investigation as possible of the last days and death of Adolf Hitler. Baseless rumors that Hitler still lived would be no help to the occupiers of Germany. So, H.R. Trevor-Roper went diligently to work.
The six young Scandinavian scientists in the crew of the Kon-Tiki raft expedition reported by radio yesterday that they were trying to salvage the remains of their forty-five-foot balsa-wood raft.

Responsibility for any airplane fatalities that may occur at La Guardia Field was placed squarely on the directors of the United Telephone Organizations by Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday after a City Hall conference failed to end a two-year dispute over laying telephone lines at Idlewild Airport in Queens.

MOSCOW, Aug. 11 (U.P.) -- Culture and Life, organ of the Communist party's propaganda committee, today accused the United States State Department's monthly Russian-language magazine, Amerika, of giving Russians a false and one-sided picture of life in the United States.

The American Company, formed last January by a group of top ranking actors, directors and stage technicians, is all set to swing into action. Two scripts have been acquired by the organization and plans are to start work on the first project -- Halsted Welles' "A Temporary Island" -- by early October.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The Office Employes International Union, American Federation of Labor, today became the first union to file its financial report and constitution with the Department of Labor under terms of the new Taft-Hartley Law.

ATLANTA, Aug. 11 -- Georgia abolished its highway convict camp system today in the aftermath of the bloody July 11th riot at the Glynn County camp which allegedly, developed when guards ordered Negro prisoners into a ditch occupied by poisonous snakes.

The long lines department of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company agreed yesterday to restore recognition rights to the American Union of Telephone Workers. CIO, pending submission by the union of new proof that it represents a majority of the company's 23,000 long-distance employes.

LONDON, Tuesday, Aug. 12 -- Britain's Labor Government won a crucial Parliamentary battle late last night when the House of Commons defeated, 278 to 136, an Opposition amendment moved by Winston Churchill to eliminate a vital clause of its emergency powers bill.

Carl Dolan. aeronautical technical staff assistant to the Senate Subcommittee on Aeronautics, yesterday inspected the wreckage of American airlines' flying "airlab," which crashed in Flushing Bay Friday night. The plane, a DC-3 transport alpha that had been used in testing electronic equipment, was stored in the airline's hangar 5 after it was removed from the water.

Buyers responded strongly yesterday to the exhibits of 175 manufacturers at the opening day of National Luggage and Leather Goods Show at the Hotel New Yorker. The show which is the first since 1941 will continue through Friday.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Refugees arriving in Argentina from across the Paraguay River said the military situation at Asun-

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Aug. 11 -- Rumania's Interior Ministry today asserted that rumors that Dr. Juliu Maniu, jailed head of the Peasant Party, was seriously ill had been "wholly invented," and reported that Dr. Maniu "enjoys perfect health."

LONDON, Aug. 11 -- With the Cabinet divided on the question of steel nationalization and reaction to Prime Minister Attlee's radio appeal last night, critical buyers found no incentive today to enter into stock markets here. Stock Exchange members, consequently, found little to occupy them.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., Aug. 11 -- John Humm and Joe Turnesa of the Rockville Club carded 35, 32 -- 67, five strokes under par, to win the annual amateur-pro championship of the Long Island Golf Association at the Wheatley Hills Golf Club today.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 11 -- Following is the text of a questionnaire submitted to the Soviet Union today by the British delegation to the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission:

Guy W. Vaughan, president of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation, reported yesterday a consolidated net loss of $241,837 for the company and its subsidiaries in the six months ended on June 30. The loss was after applying tax carryback credits of $5,000,000 and after transferring $665,511 from the reserve for post-war conversion.

A 4-year-old "gatecrasher" stole the show yesterday when the Police Athletic League took seventy-five West Side boys and one girl (who also crashed the party) on a fishing excursion in the waters of the Great South Bay off Fire Island.

VIENNA, Aug. 11 -- Lieut. Col. Henry G. McFeely, chief of the displaced persons department of the American Command for Austria told the subcommittee of the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine here today that in his opinion the best solution of the problem of the Jewish displaced persons was to send them to Palestine.
The Yankees didn't give Ole Bobo Newsom much help in celebrating the right-hander's thirty-eighth birthday last night.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Bob Feller announced tonight a post-season barnstorming tour of ten games in the United States, to be followed by a five-game pitching set in the Cuban League.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 11 -- Mayor Vincent J. Murphy, director of the Department of Revenue and Finance, today ordered the removal from the city's personal tax arrears list the name of William R. Cadmus after receiving from Miss Amy B. Cadmus of 38 Cypress Street the following letter:

A juvenile version of how the United Nations Special Committee of Inquiry might settle the Palestine question was given yesterday on the roof of the Educational Alliance, 197 East Broadway, with 500 youngsters participating.

Net profit of the Standard Oil Company of Indiana and its subsidiaries for the first six months of this year amounted to $40,936,430 after taxes and all charges, according to the semi-annual statement of operations issued to stockholders yesterday.
KARACHI, India, Aug. 11 -- Mohammed Ali Jinnah assumed the presidency of the Pakistan Constituent Assembly today after having been elected unopposed, as was expected.

Mayor O'Dwyer made public yesterday part of a report by Robert Moses. It listed the objectionable features of a proposal for public construction of apartments to be rented to families of moderate income, predicted that the housing shortage would stop increasing soon, and suggested five sites on which the city could build 4,600 apartments if it chose to put up "unsubsidized" housing.
KARACHI, India, Aug. 11 -- Mohammed Ali Jinnah assumed the presidency of the Pakistan Constituent Assembly today after having been elected unopposed, as was expected.

Mayor O'Dwyer made public yesterday part of a report by Robert Moses. It listed the objectionable features of a proposal for public construction of apartments to be rented to families of moderate income, predicted that the housing shortage would stop increasing soon, and suggested five sites on which the city could build 4,600 apartments if it chose to put up "unsubsidized" housing.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: There appeared under date of Aug. 4 a letter signed by Dorothy Thompson in which she voiced objections to Webb Knapp's plan for a monumental approach to United Nations headquarters, now under consideration toy the Board of Estimate.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 11-- Although Big Jawh Mize did not slam a homer, his big bat was largely responsible for a 3-0 victory for the Giants over the Phillies tonight at Shibe Park.
MONTREAL, Aug. 11 (Canadian Press) -- R.D. (Bob) Murray, a former Canadian Davis Cup player, will be official referee for the inter-zone cup final this week between Australia and Czechoslovakia.

New York savings banks are ready to invest $40,000,000 in five big new apartment projects as soon as building costs are stabilized, John D. Butt, executive vice president of the Seamen's Bank for Savings and president of Parkway Village, announced yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 12 -- A knuckleball does funny things. En route to the plate, it looks big and inviting, but suddenly something happens and the batter is fooled. When thrown by an expert like Emil (Dutch) Leonard, it is especially tantalizing.

Estimated net income of North American Aviation, Inc., for the nine months ended with June was $303,847 after including $4,260,500 carryback tax credits, according to preliminary figures announced yesterday. Sales and other income were $11,849,375, and cost of sales and other expenses amounted to $15,806,028, resulting in a loss of $3,956,653 before application of the carryback tax credit.

DETROIT, Aug. 12 -- Enough gasoline to avert a threatened paralysis of the police, fire, public works and transportation systems of the city was promised today when retail dealers, facing fourhour daily sales periods, brought pressure to bear on producers.

VIENNA, Aug. 12 -- The Soviet Union's definite decision to permit Austria to prepare for the creation of a civil aviation system was announced in the Executive Committee of the Allied Council today. It raised high hopes here and at the same time caused some curiosity as to possible secret developments in Soviet-Austrian relations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Two American airlines, Pan American World Airways and Northwest Airlines, have received temporary permits of indefinite duration to fly commercial passengers into Tokyo. State Department officials revealed that the permits were granted in an emergency effort to speed to Japan this week about 400 business men preparing to resume foreign trade with the former enemy country.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Aug. 12 -- Following is the text of a statement to the United Nations Security Council today by Herschel V. Johnson, deputy United States representative, together with the text of a new resolution he introduced: The Security Council has attempted for many months to find a solution to the Greek question by the processes ot pacific settlement.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 12 -- A showdown on the gambling issue, marked by the most spirited debate of the State Constitutional Convention to date, was postponed today until Thursday. The delegates found themselves unable to proceed without clarification of an opinion given yesterday by Attorney General Walter D. Van Riper in which he said that a new charter cannot be submitted to public referendum "in whole and in part."

Getting It Straight In our innocence we have always assumed that when people said they'd got it straight from the horse's mouth the notion that what came that way had to be true, derived from the practice of looking in the mouth any horse but a gift horse to find out the beast's age.

MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 12 (AP) -- A 27-year-old,Berkeley, Calif., mother, wife of an operatic tenor today provided a mild sensation in the round-of-sixteen singles' play at the Essex County Club women's tennis tournament. She is Mrs. Wilma Smith, unranked, unseeded and unheralded, who eliminated her doubles partner and the tourney's top-seeded star, Miss Dorothy Head of Alameda, Calif., 1-6, 6-4, 6-1.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 12 -- The trial of fifteen intellectuals and political figures in Slovenia ended today. Three of them were sentenced to death and the others received prison terms ranging from one to twenty years. Those sentenced to be shot included Professor Boris Furlan, known in the United States as a liberal during the war years.

The nine-story and penthouse building at 112-114 East Fortieth Street has been sold by Miss Polly Lux of Miami Beach, Fla., to a group of investors through A. Sheldon Jaffe, broker. Sale was for all cash above the existing first mortgage of $140,000.

The United States Treasury Department is especially interested in directing the attention of all banks to the new law under which the period of negotiability of certain Government checks is extended to ten years.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 12 -- A proposal that trucking interests and the International Brotherhood of Teamsters jointly set up a country-wide labor-management committee to "combat the lawyers' holiday which is seemingly just ahead of us" as a result of the Taft-Hartley law was laid before the Teamsters' convention today by Philip A. Smith of Chicago, president of the National Conference of Local Cartage Operators.

LONDON , Aug. 12 -- All parties in the House of Commons today deplored the execution of two British Army sergeants by Palestine terrorists and expressed the hope that the incident would not lead to a spread of anti-Semitic feeling in Great Britain.
SALEM, N.H., Aug. 12 (AP) -- Hitting the last turn in third position J.H. Hammond's favored Butler staged a stretch drive today to win Rockingham Park's featured Antrim allowance purse for $3,000.

Subscriptions for the 106th season of Philharmonic-Symphony concerts at Carnegie Hall, which begins Oct. 9, are selling faster than they have for almost fifteen years, it was announced yesterday. Sales, as of Aug. 1, show an overall jump of 6 per cent over last season and beat records back to 1933-34 when Arturo Toscanini and Bruno Walter were the conductors.

Despite a 2 per cent gain in revenues, net income of United Air Lines in the second quarter of 1947 was held to $250,471, equal to 8 cents a common share, compared with $1,353,601, or 71 cents a share in the same period last year, the company reported yesterday.

LONDON, Aug. 12 -- Further selling by investors was seen in the stock markets here today. Although the amount of stock on offer was not large, jobbers were reluctant to take it on their books, and as a result prices were marked down again sharply.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 12 -- William L. Hutcheson, president of the International Brotherhood of Carpenters, AFL, who has been represented at House Labor subcommittee hearings as the key man in the ten-month Hollywood jurisdictional strike, was depicted today as possessing a powerful hidden weapon against the motion picture industry.
GENEVA, Switzerland, Aug. 12 -- Four serious blows were levelled at the International Trade Organization charter and the draft of a multilateral tariff agreement today.
PARIS, Aug. 12 -- Sobriety and elegance mark Robert Piguet's collection, and yet it is definitely new.

TORONTO, Ont., Aug. 12 -- Winners of six fellowships were announced by the International Federation of University Women at the opening sessions of the World Conference here today, attended by 500 delegates from thirty nations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- A Capitol Hill caucus room, whose walls have echoed to many a stormy political gathering, was the scene of a junior feminine version of the operation of the United States Government today.

A $2.50 increase in monthly commutation rates within New York State was denied the Lehigh Valley and the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad yesterday at a hearing before the Public Service Commission, at 233 Broadway.

New warnings to municipalities that are deemed to have taken inadequate steps toward correcting the sources of pollution in New York Harbor and adjacent waters are being prepared by the Interstate Sanitation Commission.

CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., Aug. 12 -- Six New Yorkers won in the first round of the annual open championship of the United States Chess Federation today. They were Dr. Edward Lasker, Isaac I. Kashdan, Anthony E. Santasiere, George Kramer, Herbert Avram and Neil Bernstein.

The Radio Writers Guild announced yesterday that it planned to make a series of annual awards for the best programs in several classifications as well as afford recognition to actors, commentators, conductors, producers and sound-effects men.

Shipments of finsihed steel in the first six months of 1947 amounted to 31,172,157 net tons, the largest for any peacetime half-year period and almost equal to the total shipments in the entire year of 1939, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

For two years a jurisdictional dispute between unions has held up the installation of telephones for Idlewild Airport. On Monday Mayor O'Dwyer, high officials of the Port Authority and Edward Maguire, the Mayor's labor adviser, brought together the disputing unions at City Hall to make one more effort to get on with the work of laying a cable.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 12 -- George Killion, treasurer of the Democratic National Committee, was elected president of the American President Lines, Ltd., today, succeeding Dr. Henry F. Grady, who resigned in April to become Ambassador to India.

BOSTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Scoring twice in the ninth inning, the Red Sox today defeated the Senators, 2 -- 1, for their seventh straight triumph over Washington at Fenway Park. Mickey Harris, who pitched the ninth after Denny Galehouse was lifted for a pinch hitter in the eighth, was credited with the victory.
CHICAGO, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 4.500 head, total 6,500.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 12 -- A series of drastic moves, which as a last resort might culminate in the use of armed forces by the United States and other countries for the protection of Greece, was foreshadowed today by Herschel V. Johnson, the deputy United States representative in the United Nations Security Council.

Three youths and a 19-year-old girl were arraigned yesterday in Bronx Magistrates Court on a charge of selling and distributing marijuana cigarettes. Magistrate Joseph Levine held them in $500 bail each for a hearing on Friday. The defendants are Velora Flourney of 939 Longfellow Avenue; Paul Navarro, 16, of 756 Westchester Avenue; Jesse Cooper, 16, of 1517 Washington Avenue and Benjamin Rodriques, 17, of 582 Beck Street, all of the Bronx.

Far from, retarding momentous managerial decisions, yesterday's sticky weather accelerated them. Tour observer has been troubled this summer with an obsessior that humidity stimulates activity, especially in the theatre. Prompted by an understandable motive, Broadway denizens shook off their lethargy to forget the annoyances of a rising temperature.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 12 -- Despite Yugoslav insistence that Germany's industrial potential must not be built up, an AngloAmerican trade delegation from the western zones of Germany has concluded in record time a fouryear, $100,000,000 trade agreement with Yugoslavia.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Criminal prosecution of those who conspire to increase prices of food, clothing or housing is the objective of an investigation ordered today by Attorney General Tom C. Clark.

Gladioluses in greater numbers than ever before were seen in this city set a record yesterday when the annual show opened in the Einhorn Auditorium of the Lenox Hill Hospital, 131 East Seventysixth Street. The exhibit is sponsored by the Horticultural Society of New York and the Gladiolus Societies of Eastern New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
LONDON, Aug. 12 -- Talks between Britain, the United States and France on the level of German industry are expected to open in London next week, a Foreign Office spokesman said today.

Thirty thousand textile dyers and bleachers in New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania will receive a wage increase of 5 cents an hour under an agreement reached yesterday by representatives of 385 employers and the Federation of Dyers, Finishers, Printers and Bleachers, an affiliate of the Tetxile Workers Union, CIO.

SOFIA, BULGARIA, Aug. 12 (U.P.) -- The Bulgarian Government today demanded the death penalty for opposition leader Nikola Petkov on conspiracy charges, but recommended leniency for four codefendants who pleaded guilty and confessed implication in Mr. Petkov's alleged "plot" to seize the government.

The losses of Monday were canceled out yesterday by the stock market in a fairly well sustained rally which faltered only near the close of trading. Final prices showed recoveries of fractions to 2 points or more with a few pivotal industrial shares and some rails the widest gainers.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Al Gettel pitched a one-hit game tonight against the Tigers, the single safe blow being a double by Eddie Mayo that came in the first inning. The Indians won, 11 to 0, after taking the first game of a twi-night double-header 3 to 1.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- The Democrats opened running attacks today against the continuation into next year of the Senate War Investigating Committee, headed by Senator Owen Brewster, Republican, of Maine.

When J.C. Stefanatos spent hours at the Public Library studying the history of cakes, he found not only what he was seeking, a suitable name for his new pastry shop, but also inspiration for two of the specialties that he offers there.

Charles H. Goren of Philadelphia, world top-ranking contract bridge player, led his team last night to the World Master Teamsof-Four championship by the narrow margin of forty points in the final event of the twenty-first annual summer session of the American Contract Bridge League in the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn.

The one encouraging aspect of still recurrent outbreaks of race oppression in the deep South is that they are at last, in one way or another, producing a healthy reaction toward amelioration. In the past they were folded into a dark fog of bigotry as something nobody could or would be allowed to do anything about.

BERLIN, Aug. 12 -- The United Nations Palestine subcommittee arrived in Berlin today for a twoday investigation and spent the first afternoon in the drab and, depressing Dueppel center where dwell in enforced idleness 6,000 victims of Adolf Hitler's Reich.

EVANSTON, Ill., Aug. 12 (AP) -- A missed four-foot putt on the last green today ruined the chances of the young gallery favorite. Miss. Mary McMillin, to gain the second round of the women's Western golf tournament All other highly-regarded contestants moved ahead.

The roars of the 2,500 horsepower engines of the airplanes that fly the Atalntic out of La Guardia Field were almost drowned out yesterday afternoon by the skirling of bagpipes hailing the arrival of a "fiery cross" from Scotland.
After fluctuating over a fairly wide range, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed 22 points lower to 1 point higher than on Monday.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Bob Feller said today that he could not understand why his acceptance of an offer to make a five-game appearance in the Cuban League this fall had "created such a fuss."

Pearl L. Bergoff, who for thirtyfive years conducted one of the most extensive strike-breaking organizations in the country, died Monday night in St. Vincent's Hospital. Mr. Bergoff, who entered the hospital a week ago, gave his age as 62, but other sources indicated that he may have been 68.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The National Theatre, only legitimate playhouse in the Capital, announced, today that it will continue its ban on Negro patrons until discrimination is ended generally here.

The interior of the second-oldest church in Staten Island, the 99year-old St. Mary's Episcopal Church, was ruined yesterday by a three-alarm fire that brought eight fire companies from lower Manhattan to the scene.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 12 -- On the eve of the arrival of the first of the "big guns" of the United States delegation the Brazilian press notes that never before has the country been honored by such a large group of outstanding leaders.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The arrival of the Queen Mary yesterday brings to mind the vociferous welcome she received on her first entrance into our harbor, about eleven years ago. It recalls also an amusing experience of the welcoming committee then appointed by Mayor La Guardia.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 12 -- This city has become "the new port of hope" for great numbers of European refugees who spent the war years in Shanghai. Nearly 5,000 of them expected to pass through here this year for resettlement in other parts of the country, it was asserted today by Reuben B. Resnick, director of Community Relations of the United Service for New Americans.

ATHENS, Aug. 12 -- In a country rich in paradoxes not the least is that while Greece is clamoring for United States economic assistance 6,802 CARE packages, contributed by Americans and accumulated in Piraeus warehouses since last March, have not been distributed because the Greek Government has failed to ratify an agreement on the subject.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial entitled "Progress -- Not Enough," a news item further on relative to the "secret stamp" gratuitously used by the Building Department, and an item referring to total cessation of dwelling construction in the Bronx are all conducive to reflection.

Sustained buying interest marked the second day of the annual trade exposition of the American National Retail Jewelers Association in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday. It was estimated that more than 3,000 additional buyers viewed the showings of jewelry manufacturers, making a total of almost 9,000 registrations for the first two days.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 12 -- India attacked the Union of South Africa here today for refusing to place its South-West African mandate under the United Nations trusteeship system and condemned the action as a "slap against world public opinion."

In the United States, as earlier in Germany, social insurance has a tendency to expand beyond the scope originally planned for it, Dr. Walter Sulzbach declared yesterday in a study of "German Experience with Social Insurance" made for the National Industrial Conference Board.

RIO DF JANEIRO, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Talk of a "Marshall Plan" for Latin America bobbed up today as delegates to the Quitandinha interAmerican Conference on hemisphere defense continued to reach the Brazilian capital well ahead of the opening ceremonies on Friday.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 12 -- Four of the major colonial powers of the world lost a three-hour fight today to block seating of the Republic of Indonesia at the United Nations Security Council table.

Spokesmen for organized labor in the cleaning and dyeing industry urged State Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi at a public hearing in the State Labor Department's offices yesterday to approve a recommended increase of 21 1/2 cents an hour in the statutory minimum wage for 16,500 workers in the industry in New York State.

Buyers' Total Up in Week Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,370 compared with 1,106 last week and 1,355 in the corresponding week of 1946, according to lists published in the NEW YORK times.

Detectives, working on their own time, smashed yesterday the operations of a six-man auto gang accused of stealing ten cars in three states in the last five months and reselling them by altering registration certificates with a milk solution.
The first really big tuna taken by chumming at the Mud Hole was brought in by Thomas McCarthy of the Manasquan River Marlin and Tuna Club, and the fish tipped the club scales at 275 pounds.

These are the hot, mad days of August. Our own City Health Commissioner has just taken note of the season with a warning to avoid certain effervescent cold drinks, physical strain, overeating and depletion of salt in the body. Down in Washington, however, the dangers are even more fearsome.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 12 -- Charlie De Lucca of Green Valley, who reached the semi-finals of the Anderson Memorial tournament, scored 35, 35 for a par 70 at the Westchester Hills Club today to lead a field of 119 for low gross in the Metropolitan Golf Association's one-day handicap affair.

AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 12 -- A projected national strike against the B.F. Goodrich Company got its start today more than forty-eight hours ahead of schedule, when nearly 800 members of the United Rubber Workers, Congress of Industrial Organization, failed to report for work at the Tuscaloosa, Ala., plant.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Aug. 12 -- The Communist newspaper Romania Libera asserted today that National Peasant party leaders would be tried "as spies for a foreign power," for a series of crimes against "democratic" Rumania and for being anti-Soviet.
