ROME, Aug. 12 -- Some hope was held today that light might be shed on the circumstances attending the seizure and disposal of the so-called Mussolini treasure.

By a margin of 5,574 to 2,697, members of the Wholesale and Warehouse Workers Union, Local 65, CIO, have voted to tax themselves one week's pay to build a $500,000 strike relief fund against "the potentially destructive, effects" of the Taft-Hartley labor law, David Livingston, the union's organization director, announced yesterday.

LONDON, Aug. 12 -- Reports that the United States shortly will increase the price at which it buys gold from the present level of $35 an ounce to $50, persisted in British financial circles today despite the lack of any official confirmation.

Reluctance by clothing and apparel manufacturers to place orders for wool goods has disappeared, according to leading suppliers yesterday, and eagerness to buy marked the openings of spring lines for both men's and women's clothing.

The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, in the first six months this year, established a new peacetime rocord in sales with the total of $316,467,215 increasing over the previous peacetime high of $282. 736.171 a year ago P. W. Litchfield, board chairman, reported yesterday following- a directors' meeting.

After prolonged negotiations with the Reconstruction. Finance Corporation, the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority announced last night a comprehensive plan for refinancing the Queens Midtown and Brooklyn-Battery Tunnels.

In a purchase for investment, Arthur and Aaron Eckhouse have acquired the four-story building containing twenty apartments at 122 Sutter Avenue, near Barrett Street, Brooklyn, from the Milrac Realty Corporation. Title to the property, which occupies a plot 50 by 100 feet, was insured by the Home Title Guaranty Company.

SECURITY COUNCIL Heard Herschel V. Johnson, United States delegate, submit resolution in morning session calling on Greece's northern neighbors to halt assistance to Greek guerrillas. In afternoon voted to admit representative of Indonesian Republic to participate without vote la discussion of Far Eastern dispute.

Fifty ships, returned to the Maritime Commission from American and foreign operators, are to be sent into retirement this week, the commission announced yesterday as freight rate reductions in tramp shipping trades reduced American maritime operations.

The Twentieth Century Sporting Club yesterday completed arrangements for a ten-round welterweight battle between Tony Janiro, Youngstown. Ohio, battler, and Tony Pellone of New York. The clash is set for Friday night, Sept. 19, at Madison Square Garden.

An issue of $22,868,000 of Boston. Metropolitan District bonds was awarded yesterday to the First National Bank of New York and Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and associates on a bid of 100.82 for l 7/8s, and an interest cost of 1.83501.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Bert Bell, Commissioner of the National Football League, today proposed a three-point program aimed at "perfect harmony between colleges and pro football."

MOISSON, France, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Boy Scouts attending the World Scout Jamboree swapped addresses, songs and stories about their homelands tonight as EastWest antogonisms appeared to have dissolved completely among them.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The Pirates came up with a trio of singles in the twelfth inning today to score the marker that defeated the Reds, 3 -- 2, and gave Al Lyons his second victory of the season.

Reinforced-concrete construction is substantially cheaper than steel construction for the type of thrifty, modern fireproof building done by the New York City Housing Authority, it was indicated by bids submitted by contractors yesterday.

BERLIN, Aug. 12 -- German Communists let loose all the big guns of criticism at their command today against the United States' attitude toward the Ruhr. The attack was timed to coincide with the opening of the AngloAmerican talks in Washington on Ruhr coal production.

Firm prices have been discarded in several important lines of metal products, industry spokesmen disclosed here yesterday. In addition four important changes in price policies of metal products manufacturers also have developed.

PARIS, Aug. 12 -- The Communists started a filibuster in the National Assembly today in an endeavor to prevent passage, before the summer recess, of the municipal election law which Premier Paul Ramadier forced into consideration by a confidence vote taken yesterday.

IN Ulster lives a schoolteacher, Michael McLaverty by name, who writes excellent novels and short stories in his spare time. His three novels, "Lost Fields," "Call My Brother Back" and "In This Thy Day," have all been published in this country without arousing any perceptible interest in the general reading public.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Consideration of the broadest possible aspects of coal production in Germany's Ruhr Valley, whose output is vital to the whole European eponomy, will be permitted at the Anglo-American conference that got under way here today.

HANOVER, Germany, Aug. 12 -- The first joint export show to be held in the British-American zones is expected to attract 4,000 buyers from all over the world, military government officials said today.
Plans to tighten court procedure in bookmaking cases were drawn yesterday at a conference of law enforcement agencies called at City Hall by Mayor O'Dwyer.
A leader of the Polish Peasant party who arrived here yesterday denied that his country was Sovietdominated and called the withholding of a loan to Poland by the United States "unjustified."

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. Aug. 12 -- Maybe it was the bright sunshine. Possibly it was the charm of the surroundings. Whatever the reason, the Paragon Stable's 5-year-old Bob Mann, who hadn't visited a winner's circle in more than a year, felt like doing some running at Saratoga today.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Aug. 12 -- Dr. Herbert V. Evatt, Deputy Prime Minister, who returned from Japan today aboard the warship Hobart, said after landing at Brisbane that he had had full and frank discussions with General MacArthur, leading official representatives of the other occupation powers and with Japanese parliamentary and trade union leaders about problems that would confront the Allies in making the peace.

TOKYO, Aug. 12 -- Japan's political observers today are busily attempting to assess the effect of the Cabinet's action yesterday approving and ordering drafted as a bill for presentation to the Diet the plan finally approved by the three coalition parties for the control of the nation's coal mines.

A conference between Maritime Commission authorities and operators of ships in domestic trades will be held in Washington today when operators of the hard-pressed coastal and intercoastal lines appear before the Government agency to press for lower chartering rates.

GENEVA, Switzerland, Aug. 12 -- Zionist leaders are deliberately deluding the Jews and the rest of the world on the realities of the Palestine situation, the Arab Office in London charges in a new statement of the Arab position that became available to the NEW YORK TIMES.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 12 (AP) -- With the spectator still buzzing about former national champion Frankie Parker's crushing secondround setback, play in the Newport Casino Tennis tournament returned to normal today as well-seasoned American campaigners erased the last two of eight young foreigners sent here to gain experience.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 12 -- One Jew and one Arab were killed today in clashes, mostly near the Tel AvivJaffa border, in a renewal of an age-old-feud. These attacks are still isolated and not considered as being on an organized scale but they worry everyone here, especially those who remember the 1936-39 clashes that started with much less provocation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- As Attorney General Clark handed over the price investigation to the Justice Department's Anti-Trust Division today, Congressional subcommittees were set up to look into price increases in the East and Midwest.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12 -- Earl O. Shreve, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States warned today against basing a program of international reconstruction on charity. Speaking at a meeting of the National Institute of Commercial and Trade Organization Executives at Northwestern University, he also asserted the United States should regard Russia as in a self-imposed economic quarantine, and work to make that quarantine "total and effective."

SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 12 (U.P.) -- President Gabriel Gonzalez Videla today signed pa decree banning imports of seventy-nine non-essential articles, as a means of saving an additional $9,000,000 a year in foreign exchange.
DACHAU, Germany, Aug. 12 -- The thirty-one defendants in the Buchenwald concentration camp trial were found guilty today by a United States military tribunal.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 12 -- At a press conference this evening eight American clergymen, headed by Dr. Guy Emery Shipler, said: "In the light of what we have seen and the inquiries we have made, we wish to state without reservation of any kind that there is today in Yugoslavia complete freedom of worship and respect for religious beliefs and instituions."

LAKES SUCCESS, N. T., Aug. 12 -- Pakistan, which will be formally established on Friday, will be considered a new state by the United Nations and hence a nonmember of the organization, Dr. Ivan Kerno, Assistant Secretary General for Legal Affairs, ruled today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The country's total supply of twelve major canned fruits and vegetables in the 1947-48 season probably will run about 5 per cent less than a year ago, the Department of Commerce reported today. This included both the new pack and the carry-over from last year.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Aug. 12 -- The Dutch Government announced today that it intended to call shortly a round-table conference with representatives of all the Indonesian states and ethnic minorities in an endeavor to establish a United States of Indonesia.

Steffi Nussbaum, 11-year-old orphaned refugee, arrived here by train last night on the last lap of a journey that started in 1938 when she, her mother and grandparents escaped from Germany to Shanghai.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 12 -- Charles H. Sibley, 45 years old, of 153 West 133d Street, New York, was sentenced by Judge Archibald H. Tunick here today to serve three months in Fairfield County Jail at Bridgeport.

BATAVIA, Aug. 12 (AP) -- An Indonesian communique charged tonight that the Dutch were conducting a large-scale military campaign in western Java aimed at seizing control of important mountain passes and rich rubber and tea plantations.

A new juvenile firm, self-styled 'Baby Sitters, Inc.," composed of seven 12-year-old Greenwich Village boys, held its first professional meeting yesterday at the Children's Aid Society's Morosini Boys Club at 219 Sullivan Street. The members, who already consider themselves "veterans" at minding kid brothers, sisters and offspring of neighbors, came to get "pointers" from Mrs. Marion Foltete, nurse at the society's Lower West Side Center adjoining the club.

The Seafarers International Union, AFL, called a nation-wide strike at midnight last night against ships of the Isthmian Steamship Company, a wholly owned subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation.

The Westchester Connecticut squad registered its second straight victory in the metropolitan district's junior Davis Cup play-offs yesterday by blanking New Jersey, 9-0, at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills. In the other match, Brooklyn topped Long Island, 5-4.

There is one grim and tragic battle of the Second World War which has never ended -- the battle of the children. All through Europe and the Far East these least guilty of people, about whom there can be no controversial or political question, are critically in need of peace and humanitarian help.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 12 -- Plans for the future world capital -- which the United Nations made public last Saturday -- were hailed today by civic planning experts as promising a new inspiration for building in the metropolitan area.

MONTREAL, Aug. 12 -- The players who will represent Australia and Czechoslovakia in the interzone Davis Cup matches here were fairly definitely determined today. The series, to establish the nation which will challenge the United States for the cup at Forest Hills will start Thursday at the Mount Royal Tennis Club.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 12 -- After a warning by Finn Moe, Norwegian delegate, that the confidence of all peoples would be shaken in the United Nations if it failed even to "study" the rivalry of nations in the world oil market, the Economic and Social Council today rejected the proposal of the International Cooperative Alliance to make such a study, on the ground that it would be impractical and unrealistic.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 12 (AP) -- The scrap steel market which hit a new peak of $43 a ton here last week, showed weakness today with the large steel companies refusing to buy at the high price levels. Local dealers said there had been no actual sales but that the market was quoted at $40 to $41 a ton today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Increases in charges of the Railway Express Agency ranging from 0.52 to 53.51 per cent and calculated to yield an additional $61, 254,000 in annual revenues were proposed today by C. G. Jensen, director of the Interstate Commerce Commission's bureau of traffic.
Organized military training begins in the fourth grade in Soviet "Russia's school system, Dr. George S. Counts, Professor of Education at Columbia's Teachers College, declared yesterday.

KARACHI. India. Aug. 12 -- This city, which was familiar to thousands of GI's during the war as the principal airport of India, is undergoing a frantic building boom to accommodate the Pakistan Government, which takes over from Britain day after tomorrow.

PARIS, Aug. 12 -- William L. Clayton, Lewis W. Douglas and Jefferson Caffery, United States Ambassador to France, met here today to prepare for the expected talks on Germany's contribution to the reconstruction of Europe with the United States aid proposed by the Marshall plan.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Johnny Schmitz, Cubs southpaw, handed the Cardinals their second loss in their last thirteen starts today to put a soft brake on St. Louis' stretch drive in pursuit of the Dodgers. The score was 2 to 1.
GREENEVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 12 (AP) -- An estate unofficially valued at about $25,000 was left to Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt under terms of a will filed for probate in Circuit Court here today.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Aug. 12 -- A clear sky and scorching sun almost matched the warmth of the reception this city accorded 4,000 youngsters at the seventeenth annual orphan's day outing here this afternoon, representing thirty-three Protestant, Jewish and Catholic homes.
JERUSALEM, Aug. 12 (U.P.) -- Terrorists here opened heavy fire on police headquarters in the old Russian compound at dusk. Police and troops returned the fire.

A motion to release Michael (Trigger Mike) Coppola and Joey Rao as material witnesses in the Scottoriggio election day killing was submitted yesterday to General Sessions Judge James G. Wallace shortly before Coppola, his wife and his father-in-law appeared briefly at the District Attorney's office.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 12 -- Both rebel and government forces were claiming victory tonight in the battle for Asuncion and failure of the usual late afternoon communique to reach here has left the situation more confused than ever.
Three police vehicles, were involved in collisions in three boroughs -- Queens, the Bronx and Brooklyn -- last night and early today. No one was injured seriously in any of the accidents.

RAROIA REEF, Tuamotu Archipelago, Aug. 10 (Delayed) -- We have been out to examine the KonTiki raft, which is being driven closer to the beach each day, and we find that the main body is still in perfect condition. It should soon be beyond the reef and into the calm water of Raroia lagoon, as large waves are continually nudging it over the bottom.

Business spokesmen said yesterday that they welcomed a Federal investigation of prices if it were disinterested. Many, however, expressed the fear, aroused by Attorney General Tom C. Clark's statement, that business might be made the political scapegoat for price rises occasioned by spiraling labor costs, Government buying for foreign relief, and other factors.
BERLIN, Aug. 12 -- The United States Army found it difficult today to rid itself of the case of the stolen jewels of the late Princess Hermine, the second wife of Kaiser Wilhelm II.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 12 -- Criticism of the press in the United States, which has mounted in bitterness and scope during the last week, had for its target in one paper last night and two this morning THE NEW YORK TIMES.

LONDON, Aug. 12 (UP) -- The Ryder Cup professional golf matches, abandoned since 1937, will be resumed when Great Britain meets the United States on Nov. 1 and 2, the British Golfers Association announced today. The Americans, who hold the cup, had been scheduled to defend it in 1939, when the matches were postponed because Great Britain was at war.

National Distillers Products Corporation has begun an advertising campaign on its Mount Vernon brand whisky in the New York area and will extend it on a nation-wide basis as distribution permits. Handled through the Kudner Agency, Inc., 15,000 lines will be placed locally during the next thirteen weeks.

CALCUTTA, India, Aug. 12 -- Congress party newspapers this morning feature the story of yesterday's tour of Calcutta by Mohandas K. Gandhi and relate how both Hindus and Moslems greeted the "Apostle of Peace." In adjoining columns on the front page, they carry the story of yesterday's rioting.

One of the most controversial Government credit policies of recent years will go out of existence within a few weeks. This is the policy represented by "Regulation W" of the Federal Reserve Board, under which the latter has exercised control over the terms and volume of consumer credit.

LONDON, Aug. 12 -- The House of Lords passed the Labor Government's Emergency Powers Bill through its major stage today but only after deciding on the unique procedure of reassembling every three weeks or so during the parliamentary recess to keep a close watch on what use is being made of the dictatorial powers conferred by the bill.

Faced with an inviting opportunity to steal a march on their three stalking rivals in the exciting National League pennant chase, the Dodgers last night stumbled unsuspectingly into an ambush laid by the war-whooping Braves.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Aug. 12 -- Mrs. Frank Cassidy of Metuchen and her daughter, Mrs. Philip Cudone of The Knoll, won the mother and daughter golf championship over the Cedar Creek Club course today with a score of 40, 40-80.

YONKERS, N.Y., Aug. 12 -- With the time for filing petitions as a candidate for Common Council member in Yonkers having expired Monday night, James H. Sullivan, Westchester County Election Commissioner, announced today that there were twenty-one candidates.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 12 -- A step looking to amalgamation of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen with the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers, representing a combined membership of upward of 190,000 engine service men in this country and Canada, was taken today by the thirty-fifth convention of the Firemen and Enginemen.

Textile industry leaders will be invited to a three-cornered conference as soon as possible to consider spring delivery problems, it was announced yesterday. The announcement was made following a meeting of representatives of the vendor relations committee of the National Retail Dry Goods Association and the women's and children's apparel trade associations.
The New York City Housing Authority continued deadlocked yesterday over Robert Moses' proposal that it build a subsidized low-rent housing project in Jackson Heights, Queens.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12 -- Corn made a strong start and a tame finish on the Board of Trade today advancing around 5 cents a bushel early on buying induced by a bullish construction placed on a Department of Agriculture estimate on the crop made late yesterday showing a prospective yield of 627,000,000 bushels less than last year's record harvest.

Germany, Aug. 12 (AP)-Pvt. Frank M. Zelinski of Danielsville, Pa., was sentenced by a military court to life imprisonment for the murder on May 2 of a Polish Civilian guard. United States Army officials said tonight.

Some of August's hottest blasts in nearly a half century kept much of the Middle West gasping yesterday in torrid weather which forecasters said would linger several more days in many areas, the Associated Press reported.

ATHENS, Aug. 12 -- About 1,100 of the persons who were deported to Icaria, following the Government's allegation that a Communist revolutionary plot was imminent thirty-four days ago, have been released, leaving 8,900 on the island, it was reliably reported today. Nearly 800 have already landed at Piraeus.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 12 -- Bette Davis' program at Warner Brothers, following a year of absence from the sound stages, will include "Return of the Soldier" and "The Two-Worlds of Johnny Truro" as well as "Winter Meeting," it was learned today.

AMSTERDAM, Aug. 12 (ANETA) -- Trading on the Stock Exchange was quiet, distinguished only by the large losses sustained by Netherlands Ford and AKU. The decline in AKU was attributed to unfavorable interpretation by traders of the announcement concerning settlement of AKU's American interests.

PHILADELPHIA. Aug. 12 -- As the owner of 10,000 shares of common stock of the United Light and Railways Company, Harold L. Fierman of New York filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a plan calling for the merger of the American Light and Traction Company and the Continental Gas and Electric Corporation, subsidiaries of United Light and Railways, into the parent company.

TOKYO, Aug. 22 -- An Opposition candidate today won the first of a series of by-elections being held in five Japanese prefectures to fill six seats in Parliament's upper house vacated by the recent purge. While they cannot alter the coalition majority in the House of Councillors, the elections are being closely watched because they are the first public test of the popularity of Premier Tetsu Katayama's Socialist - dominated government, formed last May.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Glenn Moulder of the Browns, who previously won two games in twentyfour relief assignments, tonight won his first major league game as a starting pitcher. He defeated the White Sox, 5 to 3.

Declaring that "education in reverse" is taking place in Germany, Dr. John Slawson, executive vice president of the American Jewish Committee, who returned Sunday from Europe, said yesterday that American troops, instead of democratizing the Germans, were being infected with bigotry.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Aug. 12 (U.P.) -- Opposition Small Landholders party leaders charged today that more than 1,000,000 Hungarian voters had been struck from the ballot lists for the Aug. 31 election by electoral committees, many because they "belonged to the Opposition."

LONDON, Aug. 12 -- Owners of Britain's motion-picture houses urged the Government today to repeal its new "confiscatory" tax of 75 per cent upon the earnings of American and other foreign films. Retention of the impost in the face of Hollywood's determination to stop sending films to Britain would mean the closing of most of the motion-picture theatres in this country, according to the Cinematograph Exhibitors Association.

The nation's gasoline stocks last week decreased an additional 747,000 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the end of the week they amounted to 84,898,000 barrels, compared with 85,645,000 a week earlier and 87,186,000 on Aug. 10, 1946.

BERLIN, Aug. 13 (AP) -- The Neue Zeitung, official newspaper of the United States Military Government, said today that the entire Soviet leadership in Germany was undergoing a "thorough house-cleaning," the second shakeup since the occupation.
New York sweltered yesterday as high humidity and soaring temperatures, reaching 91 degrees, one degree below July 30's record for the year, made the day a hot, sticky one.

ROTTENBURG, Germany, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Increasing numbers of Germans reported "fleeing" the Russian zone to United States-occupied territory of Germany were said today to be carrying conscription orders to work in Saxony's Sovietoperated uranium mines.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Aug. 13 -- Field Marshal Jan Christiaan Smuts, 75-year-old Prime Minister of the Union of South Africa, said in an interview today that the veto would wreck the United Nations.

MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 13 (AP) -- Staggered quarter-finals and mid-90 temperatures slowed the pace of the twentieth annual women's tennis tournament at the Essex County Club today but Mrs. Virginia Wolfenden Kovacs of San Francisco and Miss Betty Rosenquest of South Orange, N.J., reached the semi-finals.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 13 -- Seven members of the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission's Committee on Controls -- a clear majority -- lined up today behind a new Canadian move to label the Soviet Union's atomic proposals "inadequate" as a basis for a world-wide control system.

LONDON, Aug. 13 -- A fresh wave of uncertainty over the economic and political situation hit the stock markets here today. Foreign and domestic selling was heavy in the gilt-edge and industrial sections, and brokers found it difficult to deal in even small lines of shares as jobbers were widening and marking down quotations in an effort to avoid taking any more stock on their books.

Boston has clamped down on "Dear Judas," the play with Bach music, a capella singers and dancing, in which the four principal characters are Judas, who is depicted in a more favorable light than in the New Testament; the carpenter (Christ), the mother (Virgin Mary) and Lazarus.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Aug. 13 -- According to usually well-informed sources here the Dutch authorities in Batavia, Java, exceeded their orders from the home Government in the recent fighting against the Indonesians.

Mass picketing was resumed for half an hour yesterday morning in front of the main office of the Brooklyn Trust Company at 177 Montague Street. Two hundred and fifty sympathizers and members of Local 96 of the Financial Employees Guild, CIO, paraded from 8:15 to 8:45 A.M.

Work has been started on forty one-family dwellings at Rowland Park in Blue Point, on the borderline of the Village of Patchogue, L.I., by Bering Homes, Inc., of which Max Novie is president. Phillip Freshman of Brooklyn is the architect.

At the present rate, the Health Department will achieve only 50 per cent success in its campaign to have 18,000 dogs on Staten Island vaccinated against rabies voluntarily by Oct. 1, it appeared yesterday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Rudy York's seventeenth home run of the season sparked a four-run rally in the seventh inning as the White Sox defeated the Indians and Bob Feller tonight, 8 to 7, before 37,103 persons.

The American Federation of Radio Artists will open its tenth annual convention today at the Hotel Astor. Delegates, expected to total nearly 250, will register from 2 to 5:30 P.M., with the first session scheduled to run from 8:30 to 11 P.M.

CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex. Aug, 13 -- After two rounds of the annual open championship of the United States Chess Federation at the White Plaza Hotel, three competitors from New York City are among the leaders with two victories.

There has just been made available to the public the accident investigation report of the Civil Aeronautics Board date July 23, 1947. This report covers the crash, on October 3, 1946, of a Europe-bound liner resulting in the deaths of thirty-one passengers and a crew of eight and the total destruction of the aircraft.
Two presentments were handed up to Judge Thomas Downs in Long Island City yesterday by the Queens County grand jury investigating charges that Queens policemen have been on bookmakers' payrolls.

VIENNA, Aug. 13 -- Terrorists nearly sent a British military train with 175 aboard rolling down a mountainside in the high Austrian Alps last night when they placed two bombs on the tracks over which the train was running.

Glass container manufacturers will begin today an advertising campaign in thirteen newspapers in six New England areas, principally Maine, Massachusetts and Rhode Island, to promote the oneway glass beer and ale container. The campaign will run through Dec. 15.

The National Legion of Decency yesterday placed the new British movie, "Black Narcissus," on its "condemned" list, on the ground that it is an "affront to religion and religious life." The J. Arthur Rank Organization, sponsor of the film, declared, however, that it was passed by the industry's Production Code authorities and would continue to be shown in its present form.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Blidborg Rothschild, Inc., of New York today bid in the 7,340-ton steamship City of Athens for $400,000 at a public auction ordered in Federal Court after creditors filed $1,052,000 worth of claims against owners of the liner.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- A special Senate subcommittee announced today that the second phase of its investigation into the supply and distribution of steel would be begun on Sept. 11.
TORONTO, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Members of the International Federation of University Women were warned today that it was time that women college graduates buckled down to work in a "world of reality."

Pairings in the women's lawn tennis team championship for the Wightman Cup between the United States and Great Britain were announced yesterday by the United States Lawn Tennis Association. Miss Margaret Osborne of San Francisco is slated to play in the opening singles match.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: There seems to be no doubt that the monetary crisis in Great Britain is loaded with explosive force of the most ominous kind. It is variously said that the remaining funds available in the $3.75 billion loan from the United States not already used or committed does not exceed $400 to $500 million.
Chorus of Nature Our visitor of a while ago who paraded distaste of for the suburbs and boasted attachment to the sidewalks, has, it seems taken time off to make an excursion into the deep country.

Substantial progress in its program, of painting subway stations and modernizing their sanitary facilities was reported yesterday by the Board of Transportation. The board announced that $258,400 would be spent by the end of the year on painting thirty-four stations and $3,700,000 in the next five years for painting 530 additional stations.

Harriet H. Higginson, general manager of the consumer custom products department of the Radio Corporation of America, Camden, N.J., has purchased the old Colonial home on Route 124 in Poundridge, N.Y., from the Westchester Skylands, Inc.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 13 -- Brookmeade Stable's Inseparable, the $32,000 beauty, again proved himself worth every penny of that 1946 Keeneland auction price tag when he won today's thirty-fifth running of the Sanford Stakes in perhaps the most exciting finish of the Saratoga meeting.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 13 (AP) -- Resuming its erratic course after a short return to normalcy, the Newport Casino tennis singles competition reached its quarter-final stage today while three more of its seeded stars were being snuffed out.

Further evidence that Manhattan's street-corner bookmakers and runners have gone on an enforced vacation appeared yesterday in Manhattan's Gamblers Court where, since the start of the current police drive, the number of bobkmaking cases has progressively diminished.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 13 -- Universal-International has purchased "Patent Applied For," a screen comedy by Herbert Clyde Lewis laid in Washington, D.C., and Virginia, and has named Robert Buckner to write the scenario and produce the film as his first assignment under his new contract at the studio.

GENEVA, Switzerland, Aug. 13 -- Substantial agreement on the terms of an international code to govern the treatment of foreign investment has been reached at the Geneva trade conference, it as disclosed today.

DETROIT, Aug. 13 -- A full-scale Congressional investigation of complaints of labor racketeering in the Detroit area will be started within a month, it was disclosed today by Representative Fred A. Hartley Jr, co-author of the TaftHartley Labor Act and chairman of the House Labor Committee.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Secretary of State Marshall, irked by the prolonged deadlock between the United States and the Soviet Union in Korean affairs, has proposed to Foreign Minister Molotov that the Joint Commission of the two governments report back by Aug. 21 on its progress toward forming a unified provisional government for Korea, it was announced today.
The official naming of a new variety of gladiolus was the climax yesterday of the two-day Gladiolus show, held in the Einhorn Auditorium of the Lenox Hill Hospital, 131 East Seventy-sixth Street.

The stock market was unable yesterday to show any appreciable change from the previous close as prices fluctuated irregularly and within narrow bounds throughout the day. Midsummer inertia gripped the share list and there was no alteration in volume on the Stock Exchange, the turnover being 690,000 shares, the same as on Tuesday.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 13 -- Cuba will definitely ask for a definition of aggression at the interAmerican defense conference, Dr. Guillermo Belt, Cuban Ambassador to the United States and head of the Cuban delegation here, said today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) -- A loan of perhaps $20,000,000 to finance Japanese purchases of American cotton, and thereby help re-establish a cotton industry in Japan, is under "general discussion" by financial officials here.

PORT ANGELES, Wash., Aug. 13 (AP) -- Rammed deep amidships by a heavy freighter in the fog after midnight, the motorship Diamond, Knot of the Alaska Steamship Company sank after daybreak near Crescent Bay, west of here, while in tow of two tugs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (U.P.) -- The Navy reported tonight that it has made progress in efforts to harness atomic energy. In a roundup of its accomplishments since V-J Day, 2 years ago tomorrow, the Navy said that much-needed basic research has been accomplished and much more was under way.

Harry J. Michalson has been elected a director and president of RKO-Pathe, Inc., it was announced yesterday by Ned E. Depinet, vice chairman of the board. William H. Clark was elected a director and vice president in charge of finance, and Jay Bonafield, vice president and general manager.

The Burlington Mills Corporation, in its report of operations issued yesterday for the nine months ended on June 28, shows consolidated net sales increased to $163,591,875 from $102,961,975 for the nine months ended on June 29, 1946.
The City Rent Commission obtained a summons yesterday against the first hotel operator to be named in a criminal complaint under the municipal rent control law.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Cosmic Bomb added another laurel to the William Helis stable's chain of victories this season with an upset triumph over the Calumet Farm's 3-to-5 favorite, Fervent, in the $27,850 Drexel Handicap for 3year-olds at Washington Park today.

Reports are arriving thick and fast on the big tuna that are now making a showing at the Mud Hole, the tuna grounds off Long Branch, N.J., with a lot of fish being hooked and lost and an occasional one brought in to the boat.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The long-sought and oft-mentioned discussions between United States and British officials will begin here next Monday in a joint effort to relax the terms of the British loan, John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, announced today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 13 -- The Soviet Union will vote against the proposed agenda for the 1948 World Conference on Freedom of Information because the program does not commit the press to a campaign against "fascism and warmongers," Alexander P. Morozov, Soviet delegate, told the United Nations Economic and Social Council today.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 13 (AP) -- Transair, ridden by Willie Balzaretti, captured his sixth winning purse in eleven starts today as he withstood the stretch charge of the favored High Trend to take the feature by half a length.

Hay fever sufferers in New York were dolorously reminded yesterday of a menace that needs no introduction -- namely, that their annual misery was about to begin. It was Health Commissioner Israel Weinstein who felt it his duty to announce the advent of the ragweed pollenization (or sneezing) season.

Industrial purchasing executives have stiffened their specifications on materials and supplies and in many plants have stopped providing waivers of quality specifications to suppliers, purchasing spokesmen said here yesterday.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Four home runs sparked the Pirates to a 10-2 victory over the Cubs today before a crowd of 5,111 fans.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 13 -- Arabs and Jews continued today to stab, stone and snipe at one another in the streets of Tel Aviv and adjacent Jaffa, causing three deaths and injuries to thirteen. Two Arabs and one Jew are on the death list.

The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation of Pittsburgh, second largest integrated producer of steel in that area and fourth in size in the United States, has opened negotiations with a large investment banking house here to arrange new financing to underwrite the construction of a huge strip steel plant in Cleveland, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (U.P.) -- The International Association of Machinists, the country's largest independent union, alleged tonight that the joint Congressional labor committee was "usurping the funtions of the National Labor Relations Board in a campaign to break up trade unions."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- United States corporations paid out $609,400,000 in publicly reported cash dividends in June, a rise of 18 per cent over the $517,300,000 distributed during the same month last year, the Department of Commerce announced today.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan announced yesterday that he would appear before Judge James G. Wallace this morning in General Sessions to ask for an additional extension of the November grand jury, which has been investigating the fatal election-day beating of Joseph R. Scottoriggio.

A strike that would impede movement of commuters and freight into this city has been set for Sept. 11 by 1,200 ferry and tugboat workers employed by six major railroads, it was announced yesterday by Francis M. McMahon, district director of the United Railroad Workers of America, CIO.

BERLIN, Aug. 13 -- A gang of four Germans has been arrested and jailed on charges of possessing war materials in contravention of the Allied Control Authority Law, it was disclosed today by Ray Ashworth, head of the public safety branch of the American Military Government for Berlin.

Art flourished Greenwich Villagestyle yesterday at the Educational Alliance, 197 East Broadway, as juvenile summer session arts and crafts pupils put on a sidewalk display of their creative work. Although juvenile painters worked assiduously at easels, disregarding "kibitzers" who glanced over their shoulders, and strongarmed teen-age metal workers set up an anvil chorus of hammering, it was not "art for art's sake."

Sales of leading mail order and chain companies increased 19.3 per cent in July over the same month last year, according to a compilation of forty-three companies made by THE NEW YORK TIMES. In June the increase over last year was 19.8 per cent.

AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 13 -- A National strike against the seven plants of the B.F. Goodrich Company by the United Rubber Workers, CIO, was averted today because of a last-minute agreement by the company to negotiate a company-wide contract with 21,000 members of the union.

The owner of a Brooklyn house, where rents of eight families were increased from $25 in June to $72.50 and $77.50 in July, after Federal decontrol of the building, offered yesterday her side of a case that has aroused considerable controversy.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 13 (AP) -- Victory Song, a 4-year-old, today set a new world record for a trotting stallion when he raced a mile in 1:57 3-5 in the second heat of the $2,775 Nancy Hanks Stake at the Grand Circuit program of the Illinois State Fair.

The Jewish Child Care Association of New York, now marking its 125th anniversary, has provided 900 college scholarships for young persons since the inception of its scholarship program in 1891, it was announced yesterday.

At 7:03 on the evening of Aug. 14, 1945, there flashed through the world the glad tidings that Japan had surrendered and that the greatest war in the history of mankind had at last come to an end. The final formalities were to consume another three weeks, and the final victory had been in the air since the surrender of Germany three months earlier.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Aug. 13 -- The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association mother and son, or father and daughter championship was won by the metropolitan champion Miss Laddie Irwin of Glen Ridge playing alternate shots with her father, Henry Irwin.

Roosevelt Hospital, which serves the busy midtown West Side area had a net loss of $105,921 in 1946, President Gayer G. Domimck said in the hospital's annual report yesterday. He also anticipated an operating loss of about $250,000 for this year.

So far as Parthenia Vickers knows, she is New York's only woman fire buff. Since childhood Miss Vickers has known no greater pleasure than watching firemen put out a blaze. Now she attends all of the city's biggest fires and many of its small ones, no matter what the hour of the night or the temperature.

When an alarm sounded at La Guardia Field yesterday, echoing across the airport from the International Terminal to the hangars of the domestic airlines, it was not because a plane was in distress. It was a call for "clothing accessories" badly needed by three babies who had arrived on an American Overseas Airlines plane from Copenhagen to be adopted by Americans.

BOSTON, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Romping to a five-run lead in the first inning, when they clouted three home runs, two of them on successive pitches, the Red Sox tonight took their eighth home victory in a row from the Senators, 10 -- 3, before a paid crowd of 34,451.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 13 -- The scheduled two-week vacation for the United Nations Security Council has been postponed because of the unprecedented accumulation of business, but its members now hope to get away the last week in August and the first week in September, it was disclosed today.

Doubtful of the city's ability to finance any extensive program for construction of municipal parking garages as a means of relieving traffic congestion, Mayor O'Dwyer is planning steps to encourage private capital to make large-scale investments in such enterprises.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Henry Thompson scored what proved to be the winning run on a passed ball in the last of the eighth after another Negro player, Willard Brown, tied the game with a home run, his first in the major leagues, to give the Browns a 6-to-5 victory in the second game of a twinight double-header after dropping the first contest to the Tigers, 7 to 1, tonight.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 13 -- The motion picture industry has aggravated its labor troubles by a policy of "appeasement" in the jurisdictional conflicts among its unions, a House labor subcommittee was told today by Y. Frank Freeman, vice president of Paramount Pictures and its Hollywood Chief.

PARIS, Aug. 13 -- Premier Paul Ramadier won a victory today when the National Assembly adopted in modified form the Government program for a system of voting in the October elections. The Assembly then adjourned for the mid-August holiday, after having agreed upon a special session Aug. 19 to Aug. 23 on the Statute of Algeria.

A freight wreck in which no one was injured completely blocked the main line of the Pennsylvania Railroad, one of the busiest stretches of track in the world, for more than thirteen hours yesterday. Many thousands of commuters and through travelers to and from the South and West were subjected to long delays.
Unless New Yorkers stock up their coal bins immediately they may find a shortage of anthracite during the winter, it was indicated here yesterday.

Members of the Seafarers International Union, AFL, who are on strike against the Isthmian Steamship Company approved yesterday a resolution calling for extension of the walkout to the entire shipping industry if provisions of the Taft-Hartley Act are applied in the dispute.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) -- The wife of a Congressman today advised teen-age girls of the American Legion School of Democracy to learn to say "no."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Secretary of the Treasury Snyder sought today to spike a persistent rumor in London's financial district that the United States planned to increase its gold purchase price from $35 to $50 an ounce.

Government taxing and fiscal policies are placing an undue strain upon the jewelry industry, John A. Danaher, former United States Senator from Connecticut asserted yesterday. In the fiscal year ended June 30, he said, jewelry customers were called upon to pay a retailers excise tax amounting to $236,615,429, approximately two and one half times the excise tax collected from furs and toilet preparations and three times the tax collected on luggage.
No housing structures can be demolished unless they are to be replaced with buildings for dwelling purposes, Municipal Court Justice James S. Watson ruled yesterday.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday 16 to 28 points higher, influenced by continued price-fixing against sales of cotton to Japan and Korea. Volume was rather limited.

People who live in apartments usually rely on a studio couch to provide additional seating space for guests by day and to serve as bed by night. But no matter how, neatly the cover may be devised to fit into a living room scheme, the width of the studio bed -- and the awkward sitting positions it invites -- give away the fact that the piece was designed primarily as a sleeping unit.

ALBANY, Aug. 13 (AP) -- State Senator Robert E. Johnson of Staten Island was appointed by Governor Dewey today as Richmond County District Attorney. He is the county's first Republican prosecutor in twenty years. Mr. Johnson, who is 37 years old, succeeds Farrell M. Kane, Stapleton Democrat who resigned to run for city court justice.

Drafts of the Port of New York Authority's lease that would bring Newark Airport into the authority's master plan for integrated development and operation of all major metropolitan airports were in the hands of Newark City commissioners yesterday.

MONTREAL, Aug. 13 -- The draw for the Davis Cup interzone match between Australia and Czechoslovakia will send John Bromwich against Vladimir Cernik in the opening contest. Dinny Pails will play Jaroslav Drobny in the second of the two singles on opening day tomorrow at the Mount Royal Tennis Club.

LONDON, Aug. 13 -- British film producers sought today an early meeting with their opposite numbers in the United States to find some means by which the British Government can cut the dollar drain for Hollywood movies without utilizing the present "confiscatory" tax of 75 per cent of their earnings here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The carriage of all first-class mail by air, where such carriage will be speedier than on the surface, will be urged upon the President's Air Policy Board from industry sources, it was learned here today.

TOKYO, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Testimony was introduced today before the international tribunal trying twenty-five Japanese wartime leaders that the Japanese had learned from the New York banking house of J.P. Morgan Co., Inc., of the contemplated freeze of Japanese assets almost a month before the freeze was ordered on July 25, 1941.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- With the confident promise of setting an example in good neighborliness for the United Nations, Secretary of State Marshall and his party of delegates to the inter-American defense conference took off in their special plane from National Airport this morning and headed for Rio de Janeiro.

BERLIN, Aug. 13 -- The United Nations Special Subcommittee of Inquiry on Palestine left Berlin today for Hamburg after hearing from Gen. Lycius D. Clay, United States Military Governor, that German economy probably could not absorb many displaced persons without causing an increase in anti-Semitism.

Foreign Gold The sending of foreign-mined gold ores here for refining and then selling the refined metal abroad at prices above the official quotation of $35 an ounce is expected to be stopped within thirty days.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 (AP -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 7,500 head, total 9,000. Market moderately active; uneven; 25 to 50 cents, mostly 25 cents, lower on butcher hogs, with sows averaging around 25 cents lower: practical

A part of the city's population of camp-age youngsters underwent a rapid turnover yesterday. During the morning 250 Girl Scouts left for four near-by camps and 248 boys set out from the Madison Square Boys Club, 301 East Twentyninth Street, for Clear Pool Camp in Carmel, N.Y. Starting at three o'clock the return contingents began arriving -- 400 Scouts and 350 Madison boys who had completed their vacations.

Melville Cooper has taken over the direction of "We Love A Lassie," the Broadway-bound attraction with the Scottish setting which the Messrs. Shubert are producing. Mr. Cooper, who ordinarily confines his activities in the theatre to acting, has had a high regard for the Marcel WallensteinMary Kathleen Kennedy script from the very first.
Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Company has named the following district managers: George H. Meyer, Houston; John W. Vann, Atlanta; and Patrick Moore, Dallas.

LONDON, Aug. 13 -- The British Parliament adjourned today with its summer holiday outlook heavily overshadowed by the grim prospect that the dollars of the United States loan will have run out before Oct. 20, the date set for the reassembling of the House of Commons.

KARACHI, India, Aug. 13 -- The social tradition of the Viceroyalty expired quietly tonight in the square-cut Government House of this far west India Provincial capital which tomorrow at midnight will become the capital of the world's newest nation.

Pearl Bergoff, self-styled "King of the Strike-Breakers," survived for many years the profession which made him. Today a professional strikebreaker would be hard put to it to make an honest or dishonest living. But the business brought Bergoff a fortune he once estimated at $10,000,000.

A FELLOW who returns from his vacation feels very much the same way Rip Van Winkle must have felt when he awakened from his slumber. The world has changed a mite in the interval. So this initial essay will, perforce, be an attempt to catch up with what's happened in the past few weeks, a bit of mental house cleaning as it were to sweep out the accumulated cobwebs.

A California used car dealer lost yesterday in the Eighth Avenue subway $11,800 in small bills that he had intended to use to buy automobiles, and then offered a reward of $3,000, more than one-quarter of his loss, for the return of the money.

The texts of the two presentments handed up yesterday by the Queens County grand jury to Judge Thomas Downs follow: We, the members of the June, 1947, Queens County Grand Jury now engaged in a "John Doe" investigation of alleged graft and corruption by police officers in protecting bookmakers, feel that an official presentment of our feelings on the general subject of bookmaking is in order, and for that purpose, make the following presentment.

BELLPORT, L.I., Aug. 13 -- Eddie Ketcham, with his craft Draco II of the Great South Bay fleet, secured a big jump this afternoon toward the Atlantic Coast Star Class championship by taking his second straight race in the series being held by the Bellport Yacht Club.
Three municipal bond issues, totaling $23,431,000, will be offered publicly today by investment bankers.

The Department of Agriculture's report on the condition of the nation's crops on Aug. 1 has just been made public, and it confirms earlier expectations that American wheat production for 1947 will set a new all-time high mark. The latest estimate places the yield at 1,427,747,000 bushels, a figure which exceeds even last year's record output by 270,000,000 bushels.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 13 -- Despite strong support, even from union adherents, a proposal to strike from the new charter all reference to collective bargaining and the rights of labor was defeated today by a vote of 54 to 18 in the state constitutional convention.
MANILA, Aug. 13 (AP) -- The Philippine sugar industry, which hopes to get back to pre-war status by 1950, is currently hamstrung by a dispute between planters and millers.

The frequency of disabling accidents in the building trades adds a "staggering" sum to already swollen construction costs, according to a report prepared by the New York State Workmen's Compensation Board and made public yesterday.
Mayor O'Dwyer reported yesterday that the city was about ready to build housing for families whose incomes exclude them alike from expensive new apartments and from subsidized low-rent housing.
NANKING, Aug. 13 -- A Government spokesman today announced far-reaching steps aimed at preventing Japan from recapturing the cotton textile markets of the Far East.

PARIS, Aug. 13 -- Pierre Balmain gives to a woman a new dignity by dressing her in the straight coat of the early Twenties banded in astrakhan, beaver or white wolf around a hemline about eleven inches from the floor.

ATHENS, Greece, Aug. 13 -- The firm statement before the Security Council by Herschel V. Johnson, United States deputy representative, was hailed almost universally in Athens today as an American, pledge to defend Greek integrity even to point of sending troops.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 13 -- Lefty Ken Heintzelman, a sorebacked southpaw who hadn't pitched in eighteen days, gave the Giants an all-over pain today at Shibe Park. The Phillies' well rested portsider, though relieved in the ninth, easily downed the Giants, 5 -- 2, before 3,891 fans.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninetyfour leading cities, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended Aug. 6:

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 13 -- A movement from the floor to raise the salary of Daniel J. Tobin, general president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, AFL, above its present $30,000 level was dropped by convention delegates today when Mr. Tobin, completing forty-one years as president, served notice that he would not seek reelection if his pay were increased.

BERLIN, Aug. 13 -- The trade agreement just concluded between Yugoslavia and the combined United States and British zones of Germany is taken by observers here to demonstrate clearly that the countries in the Eastern orbit are hardly relying upon the exclusive barter system envisaged by the so-called Molotov plan to satisfy their needs.

It is not often that an International conference meets with such possibilities of success as that of the Arnericas' Foreign Ministers, which convenes tomorrow in Brazil's resort city of Petropolis, near Rio de Janeiro. Its purpose is to draft a treaty for hemisphere defense.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: An argument frequently advanced against the United States putting itself in a state of military defense is that the country will be instantaneously overwhelmed by atomic onslaught; therefore defense will be impossible, and that in our ignorance of the character of future warfare we are not in position intelligently to make preparation against it.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The National Grange adopted today a distinctly cool attitude toward Attorney General Tom C. Clark's announcement of a plan for criminal prosecution of those who conspire to increase prices of food, clothing or housing.

Atlantic, Gulf and West Indies Steamship Lines and Subsidiaries -- Six months to June 30: Net profit $584,823 on operatingrevenue of $13,177,389, compared with net profit of $2,389,207 on operating revenues of $4,344,974 in 1946 period, when company had a profit of $1,791,740 from disposition of capital assets.

EVANSTON, Ill., Aug. 13 (AP) -- Miss Marilyn Smith, a Wichita, Kan., high school girl, who is making her debut in top-flight tournament competition, today emerged as the "surprise package" of the women's Western amateur golf championship.
Hope for prompt termination of the 2-year-old jurisdictional dispute that has prevented installation of vital communications' equipment at Idlewild Field was revived last night.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 -- Three Chicago hoodlums serving ten-year sentences for a $1,000,000 movie industry shake-down, were released on parole today from the Federal Penitentiary at Leavenworth, Kan., after serving only one-third of their terms.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I have read with great interest the letter of Arthur C. Holden, published in the times of Aug. 4.

LAHORE, Punjab, India, Aug. 13 -- With the partition of the Punjab into Indian and Pakistan zones only a little more than twenty-four hours away, this great northern province experienced tonight its bloodiest orgy of violence and fire in five months of communal rioting.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The State Department issued today a "point by point" denial of antiAmerican charges made by Marshall Tito to the official Yugoslav news agency on Aug. 7.

CALCUTTA, Aug. 13 (U.P.) -- Mohandas K. Gandhi gloomily surveyed the burned or deserted shacks around his new "peace mission" headquarters tonight and announced that he would have no Independence Day message tomorrow.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Aug. 13 -- Although sentiment at a public hearing last week favored permitting the Sister Elizabeth Kenny Foundation, Inc., to establish a hospital at the Frederic B. Pratt estate for the rehabilitation of poliomyelitis victims, the zoning board of appeals voted unanimously today to deny the foundation's appeal of its application, which was rejected by the city council three weeks ago.

THERE are parts of "Vespers in Vienna"* by Bruce Marshall -- the lay-sermon novelist who wrote "Father Malachy's Miracle" and "The World, the Flesh and Father Smith" -- that are far better than the whole. For when Mr. Marshall is lampooning the antics of his vulnerable fellow-men, he achieves an effective devastation.

See Rayon Rise for Spring Rayon piece goods prices for spring will show a rise of 15 per cent for spring merchandise, according to trade sources yesterday. This estimate was based on gray goods prices for fourth quarter delivery to converters upon which, it is expected, a reasonable mark-up will be added.
Durez Plastics Chemicals Durez Plastics Chemicals, Inc., voted yesterday a quarterly dividend of 20 cents a common share, payable Sept. 15. Previously 15 cents quarterly was distributed.

Combined net earnings of C.I. T. Financial Corporation for the Six months ended June 30 amounted to $3,134,834, equal to 88 cents a share, Arthur O. Dietz, president, reported to stockholders yesterday. Combined net earnings in the first half of last year were $2,453,771, or 69 cents a share.

Capt. William P. Odom, the former Army pilot who recently set a new record for a solo flight around the world, was received at City Hall yesterday by Mayor O'Dwyer with a minimum of fuss and ceremony. After a ten-minute private chat with the Mayor he left to keep other engagements.

The apartment house for thirtysix families at 684 Riverside Drive hag been sold to Jacob Goodman Co. to the 684 Riverside Drive, Inc., in a deal negotiated by Dennis Edwards, broker. It has a frontage of 100 feet on the Drive, at the southeast corner of 146th Street.

Following the lead of dress producers who raised prices on fall merchandise, coat and suit manufacturers are requesting increases on all garments in popular-price lines, it was learned yesterday. Increases throughout the market have also been noted in almost every line of sportswear, it was reported.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 13 -- Argentine Foreign Minister Juan Bramuglia declared today that he would propose that the interAmerican defense conference, which opens Friday, call a special economic meeting of all American nations.

PARIS, Aug. 13 -- The French have proposed to the British a discussion of a general European customs union as part of Europe's effort to recover economic health with United States aid under the Marshall plan, it was learned today.
A union of 121 engineers emloyed in New York milk pasteurizing plants threatened last night to call a strike that would cut off the city's entire milk supply.
TOKYO, Thursday, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Allied headquarters announced today trade procedures under which foreign businessmen will operate in Japan when limited trade is resumed tomorrow.

Declaring the task of obtaining tax relief too great for one organization to undertake, A. Mittenthal, director of the National Authority for Ladies Handbags, advised members of the National Luggage Dealers Association, in a handbag clinic yesterday, to seek action through local women's clubs.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 13 -- Dr. Juliusz Katz-Suchy, the deputy Polish representative, today endorsed the Egyptian demand that the United Nations Security Council order "the immediate, complete and unconditional withdrawal of British troops from Egypt and the Sudan."
The fourteenth annual World Telegram hole-in-one golf tournament ended yesterday at the Bayside Links with 1,061 performers having taken 5,305 shots over the various courses used.

The Yankees didn't have Joe DiMaggio and Tommy Henrich yesterday. Those slugging stars were nursing injuries, but even so it was an easy matter for the league leaders to make the Athletics swallow an 8-to-2 defeat.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 13 -- Lieut. Gen. Maurice Mathenet, military attache of the French Embassy in Washington, conferred the French Legion of Honor with rank of Commander on Maj. Gen. Cornelius W. Wickersham, commanding general of the FortySecond Division of the New York National Guard, at Camp Smith tonight.

Philip M. Reilly, 19 years old, an alleged deserter from the Marine Corps, pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal Court, Brooklyn, to wearing illegally the uniform of a first lieutenant in the Army Air Forces. Judge Harold M. Kennedy remanded him to the Federal House of Detention for sentencing next Wednesday.

KEARNY, N.J., Aug 13 (AP) -- Negotiations were broken off today between the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company and representatives of 3,800 union employes who have been on strike since July 1, a union spokesman said tonight.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 -- For the past eight months Dr. Robert J. Moon, nuclear physicist at the University of Chicago, disclosed today that he had been petitioning the Atomic Energy Commission and other Federal agencies in Washington for permission to take another job without fear of being imprisoned or facing a possible death sentence for unintended treason.

TRIESTE, Aug. 13 -- From the windswept porch of Gen. Bryant E. Moore's Eighty-eighth Division headquarters at the uppermost tip of the Adriatic the port of Trieste looks extremely active. The fishing fleet is busy, the promenade along the Miramare is active in the late afternoon and even the shipbuilding yards seem to have some work to do.

Nations Security Council would order Yugoslavia, Albania and Bulgaria to "cease and desist from rendering any further assistance or support in any form to the guerrillas fighting against the Greek Government."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Maj. Gen. Leslie Groves, America's atom chief until the Atomic Energy Commission was established, said today "a serious delay" in atomic development resulted from failure to set up domestic control soon after V-J Day.

EASTPORT, Me., Aug. 14 -- Senator Owen Brewster, with Presidential approval, it is said, is sponsoring the effort of Frank Cohen, New York and Philadelphia financier, to take over, without cost, this city's million-dollar "white elephant," Quoddy Village, it was learned today.

The Jewelry Industry Council is building up funds to go into advertising on a national scale and to promote fixed-event advertising through retailers' local copy. The council has a goal of $700,000 annually for space on St. Valentine's Day, Easter, Mother's Day, Father's Day, Thanksgiving and pre-Christmas as well as back-toschool promotion.

EVANSTON, Ill., Aug. 14 (AP) -- Three experienced hands in Western golf competition and a comparative novice, 21-year-old Miss Carol Diringer of Tiffin, Ohio, reached the semi-final round of the Women's Western Amateur tournament today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 7.000 head: total, 9,500. Market slow: 25 cents lower on butchers' hogs under 240 pounds, closing-very dull on these weights: heavier weights and sows fairly active

ROME, Aug. 14 -- Italian Foreign Minister Count Carlo Sforza, evidently disturbed by reports that the Paris conference is not going too well, today called on European nations to implement the Marshall proposals with a plan that is not only daring in appearance but also daring in substance.

For thousands of New York's children who are unable to go away in the summer to resorts, to camps, or even to near-by beaches, the Play Schools Association at 119 West Fifty-seventh Street, New York 19, offers programs that entertain, amuse and instruct them throughout July and August.

The autobiography of the late Lewis J. Valentine will be published by Dial Press on Sept. 22 under the title "Night Stick." It is his story of a half-century of fighting against gangland and political corruption.

Existing gambling laws, Mayor O'Dwyer said at City Hall yesterday, tend to breed corruption. He said he would, as long as his administration lasts, like to see a grand jury in each county in the city inquire into gambling and its attendant evils.

BOSTON, Aug. 14 -- Edmund M. Hanrahan, Securities and Exchange Commissioner, warned members of the National Securities Traders Association today to "play fair" with their customers or risk adoption of a market-disclosure rule.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- The United States today crossed off about $1,000,000,000 in debts owed by Italy and, in addition, liberalized its interpretation of the terms of the financial section of the Italian peace treaty to aid that country's frail economy.

Its spiritless pace was maintained yesterday by the stock market, and little hint was given is to the near-term trend of prices. The list showed moderate improvement in the late trading and fractional grains predominated at the close, with the composite rate raised 0.05 point on the day.

Commercial, industrial and agricultural loans of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System advanced substantially last week, rising $82,000,000 to a total of $4,309,000,000, it was disclosed yesterday.

BERLIN, Aug. 14 -- A Sharp denial of Russian charges that Britain was failing to meet her commitments on the destruction of war plants was made today by Lieut. Gen. Sir Brian Robertson, British deputy military governor. Sir Brian charged that a distorted version of a report of the four-power commission had been made public without approval of the Allied Control Council.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- The Republican majority in the Congressional session was indicted today by Senator Claude Pepper, Democrat, of Florida, for what we called its inactivity in combating the housing shortage.

The major recession in prices of scrap metal that had been anticipated in steel-making circles in recent weeks developed yesterday. Three important scrap-consuming centers reported declines ranging between $3 and $4.50 a ton.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 14 -- A move sponsored by Daniel J. Tobin, general president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Chauffeurs, Warehousemen and Helpers, AFL, to increase the per capita tax paid to the union's international treasury was dropped at the convention today because of a popular uprising of the membership.

The four-story eight-family apartment house at 152 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn, has been sold by Vincenzo Pipitone to Luigi Gallo. The building occupies a plot 26 by 97 feet at the northwest corner of Tenth Street.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- President Truman expressed approval today of Attorney General Tom C. Clark's investigation to determine who might be responsible for conspiring to increase prices of food, clothing and housing.

A strike that would have cut off the city's milk supply was averted last night when milk distributors more than doubled their best previous offer and gave 121 engineers a pay increase of $9.50 a week.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- The State Department has ousted twenty employes since July of last year for disloyalty, for the most part involving communism, it was brought out today.

CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., Aug. 14 -- After distinguishing himself in the second round by beating the Canadian champion, Larry Evans of New York lost in the third round of the United States open chess tourney today to Miguel Aleman of Havana, champion of the Cuban federation.

Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Didrikson Zaharias, the Texas tomboy, whose athletic feats have been amazing international sports circles for the last fifteen years, yesterday told newspaper men in an interview at the Hotel Chatham that she had forsaken the amateur ranks to accept a $300,000 motion-picture offer "which I could not very well reject."

President Truman's campaign to reduce prices by exhortation has been followed up this week with a threat by Attorney General Tom C. Clark to start criminal prosecutions against "conspiracies" to increase the prices of food, clothing and housing. Maximum fines and even jail sentences are in store, he says, for guilty parties.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Stubby Overmire blanked the Browns with four hits tonight, while the Tigers mixed timely hitting with Jack Kramer's wildness to take the rubber game of the three-game series, 7 to 0.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14 -- Corn closed today 5 1/4 to 6 1/4 cents a bushel higher than yesterday on the Board of Trade, finishing about the top. At no time was it below yesterday's last quotations. Inconsequential rains in the main corn belt, accompanied by reports of damage to late-planted corn in Nebraska and South Dakota since Aug. 1, and aggressive buying by commission houses were responsible for the upturn.

Reflecting substantially larger sales, the net income from operations of the Philco Corporation in the second quarter of this year increased to $1,626,974 from $14,787 earned in the similar three months of 1946, John Ballantyne, president, reported in the statement mailed yesterday to stockholders.

PARIS, Aug. 14 -- Funnel collars, the most spectacular yet devised, are a feature of Mad Carpenter's handsome collection. If pulled up to their full height instead of being worn softly crushed, they would reach to the eyebrows.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 14 (AP) -- In ninety-two words Baseball Commissioner A.B. Chandler today ended the plans of major leaguers to play in the Cuban Winter League during the thirty-day barnstorming period beginning Oct. 8.

KANSAS CITY, Aug. 14 (AP) -- The Oil Workers International Union, CIO, voted down today a proposal to require the election instead of appointment of district directors, but took no action on a proposal that the union join in with the policy of Philip Murray against the Taft-Hartley Law.

BELLPORT, L.I., Aug. 14 -- Great South Bay's sailing wonder, Eddie Ketcham of Bay Shore, today did not even give the other skippers of craft in the Atlantic Coast Star Class championship a chance to win. He took his third straight race.

Active resistance to excessive price increases is being shown by industrial equipment and supply distributors here, spokesmen revealed yesterday. They said that on price jumps as large as 30 per cent, recently introduced on a nationally known line of woodworking tools, dealers had canceled their backlog of orders rather than accept the increase.
Plans for a subsidized migration from Europe to fill the population vacuums of Australia were outlined yesterday by Arthur A. Calwell, Australian Minister of Information and Immigration.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- President Truman repeated today he could foresee nothing that would recessitate his calling a special session of Congress before the next regular session, in January.

CLINTON, Mich., Aug. 14 -- Settlement of the riotous strike against the Clinton Machine Company by the United Automobile Workers, Congress of Industrial Organizations, was reached tonight less than an hour after a regiment of the National Guard and the entire force of the Michigan State Police had been alerted for possible action.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady yesterday, 26 to 34 points net higher, but with only a moderate volume of activity.

Mayor O'Dwyer last night again demonstrated his sympathy with and friendship for the right-wing, state leadership of the American Labor party by speaking at the Bronx County committee meeting of the party and bringing with him to the meeting Benjamin Fielding, his ALP Commissioner of Licenses, who recently was snubbed by leftwing elements in the party.

After an ownership of less than a month, the five-story store, loft and office building at 98-100 Greenwich Street, near the Curb Exchange, was resold yesterday by Louis Schleifer, operator, to an investing client of A. Phillip Sweet, broker.

DACHAU, Germany, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Twenty-two Nazi officials of the Buchenwald concentration camp were sentenced to death by hanging by a United States war crimes court today, but Frau Use Koch, red-haired widow of a former commandant, who allegedly collected the tattooed skins of inmates for lampshades, was among those who received a life sentence.
Using late-model Constellations that have an increased range, Pan American Airways will start non-stop service between New York and London on Aug. 29, it was announced yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 14 -- The Giants ran the bases like elephants today at Shibe Park and lost to the Phillies, 6 -- 5. Unlike the pachyderms, who are supposed to rate high in the memory department, two New Yorkers forgot to slide and broke the backs of promising rallies as the Blue Jays made it three straight over the third-place Ottmen.

Anton Raadik, Estonian middle-weight who has been campaigning in Chicago since coming to this country fifteen months ago, will make his New York debut tonight when he tangles with Ernie Vigh of Newburgh, in the feature bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden.

Higher sanitary standards in the manufacture of ice cream may be established by the Association of Quality Ice Cream Manufacturers, which met here yesterday, according to Dr. John Barnhart, ex cutive secretary. Progress made, new policies and problems of manufacture were discussed.

Bank Management Aid Bankers will receive a batch of suggestions for streamlining their operating procedures in a booklet now being issued by the American Bankers Association. The booklet, "Aids and Suggestions for Improving Bank Operations," was prepared by the association's bank management commission.

In a historic event equal in importance to the most momentous happenings of our crowded days, the British flag is being hauled down today all over India, and two hundred years of British rule over that teeming subcontinent and its ancient civilization comes to and end in a manner far more noble than it began.
KARACHI, Aug. 14 -- Viscount Mountbatten of Burma, speaking for his King and for himself as Viceroy, said Britain's good-by and godspeed to Pakistan here this morning.

A group of admiring Brooklyn fans yesterday gave Carl Furillo a Buick convertible and the big center fielder gave the Dodgers a ball game with an eighth-inning single, a delightful juxtaposition of events that put a ladies day crowd to 25,923 into a new fervor of enthusiasm for Carl and his mates.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 14 -- There was one winner for the merchants and another for the citizens in the Merchants' and Citizens' Handicap at Old Saratoga today.

BATAVIA, Java, Aug. 14 (AP) -- The Netherlands Indies Petroleum Board's main dump at Port Tanjungpriok, Java, was swept by fire today, which, Dutch authorities said, "most probably" was the result of sabotage.

New York University's College of Medicine and the Goldwater Memorial Hospital, Welfare Island, will conduct in the fall a project in research of old-age diseases, it was announced yesterday by Dr. J. Murray Steele, associate professor at the College of Medicine and director of the university's Third Medical Division at Goldwater Memorial Hospital.
The New York City Housing Authority will offer on Aug. 22 an issue of $5,120,000 emergency housing notes, dated Aug. 29, 1947, and due on March 1, 1948.

Operations of the Colgate-Palmolive-Peet Company in the six months ended with June resulted in a net income of $9,783,002 after providing $4,659,033 for taxes and $2,400,000 for inventory price declines, E. H. Little, president, reported yesterday to stockholders.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- The famous dictum of Horace Greeley to "Go West, Young Man" has been adopted since 1940 by millions of persons of all ages, male and female, according to a report issued today by the Bureau of the Census.

The recent protest made to Kenneth C. Royall, Secretary of War, by Max H. Sorensen, national commander of the Catholic War Veterans, against the showing of "All My Sons" in the American occupation zones overseas has borne fruit. In his complaint Mr. Sorensen, who had not seen the play, alleged that this year's Critics Prize play, written by Arthur Miller and now running on Broadway, was "Communist propaganda" and "a party-line vehicle."

LONDON, Aug. 14 -- King George has made a present to Princess Elizabeth of Sunninghill Park, a twenty-five-room mansion near Ascot standing in 668 acres, it was announced today from Buckingham Palace.

PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 14 (AP) -- Slashing six strokes off par with a 66, Johnny Palmer of Badin, N.C., a former Army flier, led the field today in the first round of the 72-hole $10,000 Portland open golf tournament.
A perspiring, grinning young man affectionately tapped the back of Maj. Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, superintendent of the United States Military Academy at West Point.

NEW DELHI, Friday, Aug. 15 -- India achieved her long-sought independence today through the transfer of British power to the two dominions into which that land of 400,000,000 persons has been, divided, India and Pakistan.

The Board of Transportation will begin today the posting in conspicuous places in the stations of the city subway and elevated lines 3,500 large plastic maps covering the entire 250 miles of the unified rapid transit system.
