The maps, forty-one inches high, twenty-six inches wide and one-eighth of an inch thick, are made of tough plastic material.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 14 -- The last one home went to the top today as young Dick Mayer of Winged Foot, the New York State champion, turned in a sensational round of 37, 30 -- 67 to lead a small field in the Jess Sweetser Victory tournament over the Knollwood Country Club course.

Two groups of imported handblocked wallpapers, outstanding for their delicate colorings and quaint designs, have just arrived it local wallpaper firms. One collection from the Dutch firm of Rath Doodeheefver features dainty patterns in soft colors.

Emil Vilar, 49 years old, of 30 Hicks Street, Brooklyn, was cleared yesterday in Brooklyn Felony Court of a charge of burglary. He had made a vain effort to assume the blame for a theft committed by his 16-year-old son Walter.

Dillon, Read Co., Inc., which won an issue of 140,000 shares of $50 par value preferred stock of the Potomac Electric Power Company on Wednesday on a bid of $51.75 a share and a 3.60 per cent dividend, head an investment banking group which today will offer the shares in exchange for the 5 1/2 and 6 per cent preferred stocks of the company, outstanding in the amount of 70,000 shares.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The recent report in the times of the latest survey by the Interstate Sanitation Commission is, perhaps, an indication of good intentions, but how much does it really mean? Surely these officials do not need to be convinced now that pollution by sewage and industrial wastes exists.

BOSTON, Aug. 14 (U.P.) -- Meat prices soared to a new high level here today. Choice steaks sold in many retail stores at $1.50 to $1.75 a pound. Cube steak was $1 a pound. On the wholesale market, beef was sold at 52 cents a pound in Boston with the prices of pork, lamb and veal also high.

BAD SALZUFLEN, Germany, Aug. 14 -- Barter trading has made such inroads on the economy of the western zones of Germany that industrial planning "has become entirely ineffective," according to a report by the basic industries' division of the bipartite Economic Control Group.

Stainless steel powder base paint, using a spar varnish or lacquer vehicle, is now commercially available, John D. Dale, president of Charles Hardy, Inc., powder metallurgists revealed here yesterday in an interview. This is one of several major new products which have increased stainless steel powder sales more than 400 per cent over record production last year, he said.

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Nineteen nations have indicated that they will participate in the 1948 Winter Olympics here next Jan. 30 to Feb. 8, the Swiss Olympic Committee disclosed today in announcing the day-by-day schedule of the games.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: What is to be made of Britain course of conduct, especially in recent years, and poignantly at the moment toward the Jewish victims of indescrib able and unimaginable torture and an nihilation? What can any fair-minde person think of Britain's repudiation o solemn promises?

ESSEN, Germany, Aug. 14 -- The United States is prepared to rehabilitate the Ruhr coal mines with 600,000 tons of steel, it was learned today. The offer, which was made to the British Government by Maj. Gen. William H. Draper Jr., Gen. Lucius D. Clay's economic chief, assured deliveries of 100,000 tons a month.
LONDON, Aug. 14 -- Britain lost her Indian Empire tonight and welcomed the addition to the British Commonwealth of the two new dominions of India and Pakistan.

MONTREAL, Aug. 14 -- A new star of potentially the first magnitude made his bow upon the American continent today as Jaroslav Drobny defeated Dinny Pails, champion of Australia, to earn Czechoslovakia an even division the spoils in the opening day's play in the Davis Cup inter-zone match.

Health Commissioner Israel Weinstein warned representatives of 9,000 delicatessen owners yesterday that he would put out of business any dealer who flouted the city Sanitary Code as interpreted during the current clean-up drive.

A pick-up in employment in the garment trades has helped cut joblessness in this city 17 per cent in the last two months, it was disclosed in figures made public yesterday by Milton O. Loysen, director of the division of placement and unemployment insurance of the State Labor Department.

In Petropolis, near Rio de Janeiro, where the hemispheric diplomats are meeting, there is a heating problem. In short, it is too cold there in mid-August. At Werchojansk, Siberia, on Jan. 15, 1885, a temperature of 90.4 degrees below zero was recorded. A temperature of 63.1 below zero was observed at Poplar River, Montana, on Jan. 1, 1885.

A sharper upturn in refrigeration supply sales has occurred in the past three months because buyers stopped waiting for lower prices and started active buying, M. Seligman, president, Tenney Engineering Company, North Jersey refrigeration supply manufacturer, declared here yesterday.
A bad snarl in the administration of Federal rent controls in New York came to light yesterday, with the backlog of tenant complaints increasing in area rent offices.

Wages in six building trades went up about 10 per cent yesterday as employers and union leaders cleared away "inequities" preparatory to a three-year stabilization of wages in the construction industry.

DETROIT, Aug. 14 -- Negotiators between the Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers, Congress of Industrial Organizations, were reported tonight to have reached complete agreement on the terms to be included in a new contract which has been under discussion for more than four months.

An advance In the retail price of meat -- for the fourth consecutive week -- was reported yesterday, placing the cost of choice cuts at levels approaching or exceeding the record highs that followed price de-control in October, 1946.

The primary purpose for which the United Nations was created was to maintain international peace and security and to meet all threats to the peace, breaches of the peace and acts of aggression, if necessary by force. However successful it may be in subsidiary functions, it must stand or fall by its success in the cardinal task of keeping the peace.

PARIS, Aug. 14 -- French opposition to a rise in the level of Ruhr steel production has changed to the contention that there should be no unbalancing shift in the proportion between the German and other Western European producers, according to an official statement today.

LOS ANGELES, Aug 14 -- Representative Carroll Kearns, chairman of the House Labor subcommittee investigating the ten-month American Federation of Labor jurisdictional strike in Hollywood, asserted today that high-ranking AFL officials were trying to get out of testifying at hearings here, but that their efforts would prove futile.

Date and evening fashions for the college girl were a feature of the Martin's of Brooklyn college shop fashion show yesterday, but a well-chosen assortment of campus clothes, both the new and the classic, was included.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Department store sales in the week ended Aug. 9 were 3 per cent below those of the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1946:

Negotiators for the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, will submit modified demands for improved working conditions when they meet here today with employer representatives, it was announced last night.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 14 -- More than half of the rise in business in the Pittsburgh district recorded in the week ended Aug. 2 was canceled last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research of the University of Pittsburgh. Decreases were reported in nearly all major lines, some of the declines being counter to the seasonal trend.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- President Truman accused the Republican-controlled Eightieth Congress today of tearing down the Labor Department. He left the impression that the department, which has been deprived of many important functions in recent years, would be rebuilt.

If a kind woman had not given her shelter late last Tuesday night and a dime to call her parents the next day, there is no telling when Louise Joan Villa would have returned to her home at 472 Seventy-fourth Street, Brooklyn. Louise, who is 13 years old, caused her parents, the police and her neighbors considerable anxiety until she was found Wednesday night after a thirty-hour absence.

Failure of rayon textile converters to live up to their sales contracts in regard to price and delivery dates will not be condoned by the industry, according to the contract stabilization committee of The Textile Distributors Institute. Retailers as well as manufacturers are invited to submit any instances of violation of contracts, committee members said, with assurance that a full investigation will be made.

LONDON, Aug. 14 (Reuters) -- Eighteen wickets fell for 372 runs today in the cricket match between Gloucester and South Africa. At close of play, Gloucester, with 28 runs scored without loss in its second innings, required 261 for victory.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14 -- Record attendance and active buying was reported today at the conclusion of the four-day auto accessory exhibit sponsored by the Automobile Accessories Association. R.G. Ames, director of the association, stated that exhibitors were generally satisfied with the results of the market.

PARIS, Aug. 14 -- The first assault on Premier Paul Ramadier's moderate policies failed today when the Socialist party congress in Lyon approved by a vote of almost 3 to 1 the "moral report" on the conduct of the party during the year.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 14 (AP) -- While Alrick Man, non - playing captain of the 1947 U. S. Davis Cup forces, beamed his approval, Ted Schroeder of Glendale, Calif., who filled the No. 2 singles berth on last year's winning team, today gained the semi-final round of the Newport Casino tennis tourney with a 7-9, 6-3, 6-4, 6-4 triumph over Francisco (Pancho) Segura of Ecuador and Miami.

Resumption of negotiations today between striking shipyard workers and the Bethlehem Steel Company's shipbuilding division was announced yesterday after a session at the United States Conciliation Service's headquarters on Ninth Avenue.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 14 -- The United Nations plans to use the Nuremberg system of simultaneous interpretation at the coming session of the General Assembly, it was learned today. By this means it is hoped to prevent the session from dragging on for two or three months.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 14 -- The inter-American conference will open at Petropolis tomorrow with all the principal participants apparently sincere in their predictions of success in the solving of the basic issues of hemisphere defense.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Further price increases for dairy products and some steel products again were largely responsible for raising average primary market prices up 0.6 per cent during the week ended Aug. 9, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

LAKEWOOD, Me., Aug. 14 -- Here, in the Lakeside Summer Theatre, where, eight years ago tonight, the first tryout performance of "Life With Father," was staged, Warner Brothers presented this evening the world premiere of the film based upon that classic.
Polish-language newspapers published in this country have been exaggerating the Polish Government's "lack of sympathy" to the Catholic Church, Dr. John Frankowski declared here yesterday.

Mrs. George Scalzi, 33-year-old mother of seven children, agrees wholeheartedly with the sentiments expressed in the song, "Home Sweet Home." But she draws the line if she thinks the abode is too humble even, though recommended by the Department of Welfare.
PARIS, Aug. 14 -- France win face next month a financial crisis much like Britain's when the Government will be compelled to cut imports from the United States to a minimum for lack of dollars.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 14 -- Settlement of New Jersey's constitutional gambling issue was deferred until tomorrow when delegates to the charter convention voted today, 45 -- 31, to defeat an amendment by Amos F. Dixon of Sussex to eliminate all mention of gambling from the document.
JERUSALEM, Aug. 14 -- For the first time Jewish underground defense forces came today to the rescue of Jewish districts menaced by Arab mobs in the embattled borderland between Tel Aviv and Jaffa.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 14 -- The two-year-old Republic of Indonesia demanded today that the United Nations Security Council order the withdrawal of all Netherland troops from the East Indies islands of Java, Sumatra and Madura.

BATAVTA, Aug. 14 (U.P) -- The Indonesian Government, in a statement broadcast by radio from its capital at Jogjakarta, urged the United Nations Security Council to conduct a plebiscite on the future of the Netherlands Indies.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- President Truman said today that unification of the armed forces would be an accomplished fact in the near future and indicated that appointments to top positions in the Department of Defense would be ready for announcement at his press conference next week.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 14. (U.P.) -- Gen. Emilio Diaz de Vivar, Chief of Staff of the Paraguayan Army, and other officers were reported today to have been arrested for plotting to overthrow President Higinio Morinigo and put an end to the five-month old Paraguayan civil war.

Enactment of the Taft-Hartley law is going to force the nation's radio actors to "change their thinking" and engage in political activity to assure the measure's repeal, George Heller, national executive secretary of the American Federation of Radio Artists, asserted last night.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Yongjeung Kim, in his letter published in your columns on Aug. 12, has lone well to emphasize the instant need for reforms in our Korean policies.

LAHORE, India, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Fires swept through many sections of Lahore today, and bloody disorders spread into East and West Punjab on the eve of Indian independence which will result in the division of the province between the Hindu and Moslem dominions.

BERLIN, Aug. 14 -- Meetings of top economic officials of the United States, British and French Military Governments have been taking place during the week, it was learned today. The conclusions resulting from these deliberations are expected to have a profound effect on the three-power talks on German industry in London.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Loading's of revenue freight for the week ended on Aug. 9 were 905,244 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 16,347 cars or 1.8 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 6,158 cars or .07 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year, and 35,242 cars, or 4.1 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

Numerous ideas, stressing the new and unusual, were represented in the ready-to-wear collection of Harriette Harra seen yesterday at Stein Blaine. Miss Harra liked both the rounded hip, full-skirted silhouette and a slim wrapped one, developing both in several handsome fabrics, such as bagheera velvet, seen now for the first time since the war.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 14 -- Twentieth Century-Fox has acquired screen rights to "Belvedere," a new novel by Gwen Davenport, and has assigned the property to Sam Engel for production, it was learned today. Because of the shelving of ''On to Oregon," also an Engel project, F. Hugh Herbert, who was to have done final work on the script of that film and to have directed it, has been switched to "Belvedere."
Big tuna literally flowed into Brielle late Wednesday, including one scaling 658 pounds, which was reported to be the largest ever weighed in at this fishing port.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- During the week ended Aug. 13 member bank reserve balances increased $19,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

Christian Rath, 71 years old, who retired from the New York Police Department fifteen years ago, died yesterday in the Queens General Hospital after shooting himself in the abdomen and head, according to the police. Mr. Rath, who lived with his wife, Marie, at 82-86 Eighty-eighth Lane, Woodhaven, Queens, had been ill and had been discharged recently from the same hospital.
ALBANY, Aug. 14 (AP) -- The state's 1947 crops will fall short of last year's "unusually favorable" yields, the State Agriculture Department predicted today in a Federal-state report.

The League of New York Theatres, an organization of theatre owners, operators and producers, agreed yesterday to sign a new contract with Actors' Equity Association embodying a clause whereby actors shall not be required to play in Washington unless Negroes are admitted to the audiences.

THE question of off-track betting has come to the fore again with the recent recommendation of the Queens County Grand Jury that the state legalize this form of wagering. That's quite akin to prying the lid off the box of Pandora and the moralists already are mumbling in dismay. It is a ticklish and controversial subject with the disposition of it never able to satisfy everyone.

Jack Paar, who has been serving as the summer replacement for Jack Benny on NEC, has been signed for a regular comedy series of his own this fall. The young comedian will be heard at 9:30 P.M. Wednesdays over the ABC network (WJZ), beginning Oct. 1. His Sponsor will be the American Tobacco Company, which also presents Mr. Benny.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 14 (AP) -- J.C. O'Hara's War Dressing was a surprise winner of the fifth race today as the Man O'War gelding raced the six furlongs in 1:11 4/5 over a fast track to beat Count Did by a length and one-quarter.

VESTAL, N.Y., Aug. 14 (AP) -- The Board of Education has banned married pupils from Vestal Central High School but an attorney for the State Education Department said today he believed the move illegal.

Hope for a quick end of the three-day-old strike of the Seafarers International Union, AFL, against the Isthmian Steamship Company, a subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation, faded yesterday when negotiations were broken off after a meeting at the steamship company's offices, 71 Broadway.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Aug. 14 -- Twenty-one of the twenty-four former officials of the I.G. Farben chemical cartel entered pleas of not guilty as they were arraigned here this morning on charges of having conspired with the Hitler regime to wage an aggressive war.

As most everyone seems to be content with a simple diet like crackers and milk during this wilting weather, abundant supplies of vegetables, fish and Eastern-dressed broilers and fryers have been meeting with little demand in the last few days.
LONDON, Aug. 14 -- After opening with every appearance of having another weak session, the stock markets here today turned steadier as gilt-edge securities rallied to close with net gains.

The newly converted combination cargo-passenger ship Robin Gray, the third of a sister team rebuilt for the African service of the Robin Line, sailed from the company's Erie Basin pier yesterday with twelve passengers and a full cargo of 11,000 tons.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- The Taft-Hartley Act's ban against Government employes taking part in strikes does not extend to strikes against private employers, it was held today by Civil Service Commissioner Arthur S. Flemming.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- President Truman made it clear today that he would be far from displeased if Clinton P. Anderson, Secretary of Agriculture, were to succeed Postmaster General Robert E. Hannegan as Democratic National Chairman, but he said that it was a matter on which the national committee must decide.

A record high of $17,987,800 for research into the causes and possible cures of poliomyelitis and for the treatment of its victims was raised in the 1947 March of Dimes campaign, it was announced yesterday by Basil O'Connor, president of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis.

SPECIAL EVENT Lowering of old flag of India and raising of new Dominion flag at 12:20 P.M. today in front of Administration Building. SECURITY COUNCIL Heard Soviet Delegate attack United States and Australian resolutions on Balkan problem in morning session.

General Sessions Judge James G. Wallace refused yesterday to vacate an order holding Michael (Trigger Mike) Coppola and Joey Rao as material witnesses in $25,000 bail after Assistant District Attorney Jacob Grumet said the men "may be involved in this conspiracy to kill Joseph Scottoriggio and we are not going to give them immunity."

The Yankees continue to thrive in adversity. Although Joe DiMaggio and Tommy Henrich still were missing from the line-up, the Bombers mustered a ten-hit attack, good for seventeen total bases, to down the Athletics, 8 -- 5, before a sweltering crowd of 13,130 at the Stadium yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- President Truman went back in spirit today to the Japanese surrender two years ago and soberly conceded his disappointment that the peace he then believed would be securely won had yet to be attained.
A new attempt to settle the two-year-old jurisdictional dispute that has prevented installation of vital communications equipment at Idlewild Field broke up without visible results yesterday.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 14 (AP) -- When Miss Gladys L. Groves of London arrived in Louisville, she was midway in her own private "international friendship pilgrimage."

SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 14 -- Col. Gen. Terentyi F. Shtikov, chief of the Soviet delegation in the Joint United States - Soviet Commission, today declined an invitation from Maj. Gen. Albert E. Brown, American delegation head, to hold a meeting of the commission to discuss the formulation of a joint report to the governments of the United States and the Soviet Union on the deadlock in the commission.

Relief from the heat wave here was forecast for tomorrow by the Weather Bureau last night. The forecast followed a high temperature of 91.6 degrees at 4:15 P.M. yesterday, the second successive day when the mercury touched 91.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 14 (AP) -- When Miss Gladys L. Groves of London arrived in Louisville, she was midway in her own private "international friendship pilgrimage."

When 47-year-old Joe Vitale stepped into the surf yesterday at the Rockaways he figured the next time he touched land would be at Jones Beach, twenty miles away. He not only failed to reach Jones Beach, but wound up in a police station on a charge of disorderly conduct.

EVANSTON, Ill., Aug. 15 (AP) -- Miss Louise Suggs of Atlanta, the defending champion, and Miss Carol Diringer of Tiffin, Ohio, a co-medalist, will oppose each other for the first time in their golfing careers tomorrow in a thirty-sixhole test for the women's Western amateur championship.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The, United States has turned down flatly a proposal by the Soviet Union that the Japanese peace treaty be written by the Governments of the United States, the Sovet Union, Great Britain and China only.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : You recently carried an article by Dr. Howard A. Rusk under the heading "Treatment of Leprosy Seen Based on Biblical Prejudice," which was read by the patients of this hospital with great interest and praise.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The Chicago Cubs exploded for four runs on six hits in the eighth inning tonight to defeat the Cincinnati Reds, 6-5, before a crowd of 28,175.

PETROPOLIS, Brazil, Aug. 15 -- The projected revision, of the United States attitude on collective action failed to overshadow the insistent economic issue that dominated the first plenary session as the Inter - American Conference opened here today.

Savings Deposits Slip The "continuing" rise in the cost of living is very definitely affecting people's ability to save," Robert M. Catharine, president of the New York State Savings banks Association, stated yesterday in releasing figures of savings-bank deposits which showed a marked lag in the rate of gain in July.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The Office of Puerto Rico today made public Gov. Jesus T. Pinero's answer to charges that Columbia University's survey of living conditions of Puerto Ricans in New York would be "an unwarranted waste of Puerto Rican funds."

NEW DELHI, Aug. 15 -- Millions of Hindus and Moslems dropped their months-long fratricidal strife in the emotional upsurge of celebrating their first day of independence today as appeals for peace sped across the young Dominions of India and Pakistan, the world's second and fifth most populous states.

MONTREAL, Aug. 15-Australia defeated Czechoslovakia in the doubles match of the Davis Cup Interzone series at the Mount Royal Tennis Club today and virtually became assured of qualify ing to meet the United States it the challenge round at Forest Hills.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- President Truman asserted today that a "fully manned, equipped and trained" National Guard was essential to the security of the United States. In a proclamation fixing Sept. 16 as National Guard Day, Mr. Truman described the organization as "a bulwark of our military forces in struggles against foreign aggressors and the support of our people in times of domestic disaster."
A criminal charge was pressed by the City Rent Commission yesterday against a hotel owner for going to court and initiating a test case of the city rent control law.

Foreclosures of Manhattan real estate and surrenders to mortgagees in lieu of foreclosures increased in July over June and over July, 1946, but the total in both categories for the seven months this year remained below those for the corresponding periods of the past five years.

Rural regions need the most competent and best -- prepared teachers in America, Dr. Frank W. Cyr, Professor of Education at Columbia's Teachers College, decared in summarizing the recommendations of a three-week conference that ended yesterday at the college.

According to reports almost everything with a motor and a bottom, regardless of the bailing required, has been chartered for today and tomorrow by anglers who are anxious to get some of the big tuna from the Mud Hole off the New Jersey coast.

Military attacks in years to come will be spearheaded by the paratroopers, "the striking arm of tomorrow," Gen. Courtney H. Hodges, commanding general of the First Army, asserted last night at the second annual reunion dinner of the 101st Airborne Division in the Hotel New Yorker.

GENEVA, Aug. 15 -- The Geneva conference completed action today on the text of the controversial chapter of the International Trade Organization's charter dealing with measures a country may take to encourage economic development.

Perseverance and a talent for imitating drunkards paid off for three detectives of the safe and loft squad yesterday. They arrested a trio of safe burglaj suspects whom they had trailed ever since an alert woman jotted down an automobile license plate in the early morning' of July 19.

BATAVIA, Aug. 15 (U.P.) -- Premier Sjahriffoedin, in his appeal to Prime Minister Attlee, said: "I request you to consider whether the proposal that this dispute should be settled by international arbitration is not after all the most reasonable and likely to succeed," he said.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- The Soviet Union's plan for an international atomic, control system relying chiefly on inspection was put aside for the time being today by the Control Committee of the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission.

Ten nations have accepted the proposal to attend a Japanese Peace Treaty conference to be held "in the near future." These are, besides the United States, Britain, China, Australia, New Zealand, the Netherlands, France, the Philippines, India and China.

John McGiver's play, "All Gaul Is Divided," with which the Catholic University Theatre in Washington launched its season of new plays last June, is headed for a Broadway showing this year. A farce about American soldiers in the French Black Market, the work has been acquired by the newly formed Chicago producing firm of John F. Golden (no relation to New York's producer of the same name) and John Michael Lamdur.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 15 -At the end of a scorching day of 36 holes of golf, Ray Billows of the Dutchess County Club at Poughkeepsie, and Fred Fiore of the home club were deadlocked at 215 as the 54-hole Jess Sweetser victory championship came to a close over the Knollwood Country Club course here today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- President Truman today proclaimed Sunday, Oct. 5, the beginning of National Fire Prevention Week and called upon "every citizen" to maintain zealous vigilance against fires and their hazards for that week and throughout the year.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- A special committee of the United Nations Economic and Social Council agreed today to waive any right the United Nations may possess to make recommendations regarding specific loans by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development.
GARUT, Java, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The cease-fire order issued by the Dutch and Indonesians is a mockery here in the front lines.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- A proposed merger of the Sabine and Galveston customs districts in Texas was opposed today by officials of some Texas cities at a Treasury Department hearing opened by A.L.M. Wiggins, Under -Secretary.

The ocean is very restless. On peaceful days in heart of summer when the water's surface is placid and the tides flow calmly back and forth there are rocky places along the meeting line of land and sea where geysers of water spring into sunny air. The leaping surf puts on its most dramatic act in a great gale.

LONDON, Aug. 15 (Reuters) -- Kent today gained its expected victory over Middlesex, runner-up to Gloucestershire in the English county cricket championship series. "With Gloucestershire leading Middlesex by four points, the approaching match between the two top teams assumes major importance.

PARIS, Aug. 15 -- A proposal that steps be taken by the European economic conference to fit the German economy into the general plan for European reconstruction was made to the Cooperation Committee of the conference today by Ans Hirshfeld of the Netherlands.
The Creole Petroleum Corporation yesterday reported for the first half of this year a consolidated

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : Having been a reader of your paper for the last three decades, it occurred to me that it might be apropos to suggest another of your good editorials directed toward nationalism. I believe our people need some propaganda in that direction.

Retail sales of furniture and home furnishings for the second quarter of this year were 13.2 per cent higher than in the comparable period of last year, it was reported yesterday by Arthur Fertig Co., accountants. The first quarter increase was 12.41 per cent.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 15 -- Registration statements covering 3,217,259 shares of capital stock were filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by three companies, while a fourth -- the American Broadcasting" Company, Inc., New York -- withdrew a registration of common stock.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers pulled to within a game of the second-place Red Sox in the American League standings tonight by defeating the Chicago Wilite Sox, 9 to 2, before 36,086 fans.

Emetia Polizio, ex-convict and bookmaker, whose charges of police graft in bookmaking touched off the current investigation, eluded his police guard and disappeared yesterday from his tworoom apartment at 25-74 Thirtythird Street, Astoria, Queens.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 15 -- Joe Hatten still knows how to make the Phils lie down and play dead. Under the Shibe Park lights tonight the lanky southpaw hurled the Dodgers to an 8-1 triumph for his fifth success over the Blue Jays without a setback.

There's been some talk that the spread between the wholesale and retail prices of fresh produce is too great at present, that the wholesale tariff is low and the retail disproportionately high. Is this true?

Controller Lazarus Joseph recommended Yesterday that the city's capital outlay budget for 1948 be held to $180,000,000 earmarked for such vital projects as subway rehabilitation, housing and new schools, hospitals and health centers.

A volume of orders estimated at five to six times that of any previous exhibit of the Luggage Leather Goods Manufacturers of America, Inc., was attributed yesterday by association officials to low retail inventories, increased vacation travel and new styling of luggage lines.
CHICAGO, Aug. 15 -- The National Labor Relations Board has decided to delegate to the general counsel unqualified authority over the field personnel and will operate exclusively as a "labor court."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The National Coal Association reported today bituminous production for the week ended Aug. 9 totaled approximately 11,750,000 tons compared with 12,312,000 tons in the corresponding week last year.

BELLPORT, L.I., Aug. 15 -- Under a southwest breeze that rose from 17 to 20 miles an hour, the fourth race for the Atlantic Coast Star Class championship was sailed today and Eddie Ketcham in Draco II of the local Great South Bay fleet again was the winner.

Another good-will step in the field of sports between this country and Great Britain will be taken today and tomorrow as America's and Great Britain's foremost women tennis exponents renew their Wightman Cup series at the turf courts of the West Side Club, Forest Hills, being played here for the first time since 1939.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 15 -- Daniel J. Tobin, who is completing forty-one years as general president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Chauffeurs, Warehousemen and Helpers, accepted another five-year term today at the unanimous request of the union's convention.

Store Sales About the Same Department store sales in the city this week were affected by the heat which kept down shopping but they held fairly close to last week's results. Thus, it was estimated that volume ran about even to 4 per cent under a year ago.
SALEM, N.H., Aug. 15 (AP) -- Shaking off determined challenges in the stretch, Oak Hill Stable's Bras Teddy won the featured race at Rockingham Park today.
F. W. Kateley has been promoted to chief engineer and E.G. Mathauer to assistant chief engineer of the ACP-Brill Motors Company.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The State Department today denounced as having "absolutely no foundation in fact" reports Korea that Lieut. Gen. John R. Hodge, American commander, had been following a policy contrary to that laid down by the United States Government.

When President Wilson went before Congress on April 2, 1917, to ask for a declaration of war against Germany he sought to hearten the nation for its great ordeal by pointing to Russia, where a revolution had overthrown the Czarist regime on March 15.
The Maritime Commission issued notices yesterday to all private steamship companies operating Government-owned ships under charter that the charter agreements would be canceled on Sept. 1.

Protestant churches all over the United States that have been omitting "harvest festivals" in their parish programs have been urged to set aside periods late this summer and in the fall for such festivals.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- It is technically possible today to design a freight airplane of such low operating cost that it would revolutionize not only air transport and air mail, but also the business map of the United States and the world.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (Science Service) -- Deaths in the country's ninety-three largest cities jumped by almost 400 to a total of 8,877 during the week ending Aug. 9, reports to the United States Public Health Service here show. This is considerably above the three-year medium figure of 7,919.

Under a new policy of authorization of sales by independent construction equipment distributors throughout the country, a new mechanized brick-making machine which delivers from 3,000 to 6,000 bricks an hour per unit is being made available at early delivery dates, J.J. Mandryl, general sales manager of Brickmaster, Inc., 115 Broadway, revealed here yesterday.
BOSTON, Aug. 15 -- Walker Cooper performed some prodigious feats today in an heroic effort to stem the descent of the Giants. But it all went for naught.

The first "pilot" hospital to provide for world-wide cooperation in research on a cure for leprosy was planned yesterday afternoon at a meeting of leprologists of the medical advisory board of the Leonard Wood Memorial. The meeting was held at One Fifth Avenue.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 15 -- The Society of Independent Motion Picture Producers today protested to the Treasury Department and the State Department that the recent British 75 per cent import tax on motion pictures is a violation of Anglo-American Agreements and that enforcement of the tax "would leave the independent producers facing disaster."

The Yankees still have some business to attend to in the American League before they can think exclusively in World Series terms. However, they brought that happy state of affairs a good bit closer last night by a 10-6 triumph over the Red Sox that was more than a little discouraging to the 1946 champions of the junior circuit.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- The flag of a new, independent India was hoisted to the peak of a United Nations flagstaff at twenty minutes after noon today, taking its place among the banners of the fifty-four other member states.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Chief Petty Officer J.A. Young, 38, a crew member of the battleship Iowa and a native of Seattle, today became the first Navy winner of the War Department's national trophy individual pistol match in over forty years.

CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., Aug. 15 -- Fourth-round games in the annual tournament for the open championship of the United States Chess Federation brought victories today to George Kramer, 1945 New York State champion, and Herman Steiner of Los Angeles, open titleholder.

Although Dr. Juliu Maniu, head of the Rumanian Peasant party, was arrested several weeks ago, the people of Rumania heard about it for the first time the other day through the "Voice of America." This evidence of the effectiveness of the State Department broadcasts is contained in a recent dispatch from our correspondent in Bucharest, W.H. Lawrence.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The Argentine Olympic committee voted formally today to accept invitations to both the London games and the winter games at St. Moritz, Switzerland.

Officials of the new Government of India and leaders of that nation's industry and commerce here joined yesterday in ceremonies commemorating her independence as a dominion within the British Commonwealth.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 15 -- The dollar volume of 168 issues of securities effectively registered during the second quarter of 1947 aggregated $2,004,046,000, or almost double the amount in the preceding quarter, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today in its statistical bulletin for July.

TEL AVIV, Palestine, Aug. 15 -- An Arab woman, her husband, an adult son and four children were among eleven Arabs killed when a Haganah task force invaded an Arab orange grove near here early today. The Zionist secret militia also killed four men and then blew up the house.

The strongest rally of the month developed yesterday on the stock market, raising prices fractions to 2 points or more and producing an enlarged volume of trade. The sudden reversal of form from the spiritless dealings of the week was accompanied by no major news development and was credited in brokerage circles to some professional short covering and timid bidding which became effective because of a lack of offerings.

From a purely artistic standpoint the local ring debut of Anton Raadik last night in Madison Square Garden was accounted a success. The Estonian, who has been boxing in and around Chicago for the fifteen months he has been in this country, knocked out Ernie Vigh, Newburgh, N.Y., middleweight veteran, in the seventh round of what was to have been a ten-round battle.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Joe Coleman limited the Senators to four hits tonight as the Athletics captured a 3-0 victory before a crowd of 15,228.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Aug. 15 -- The Rumanian Government repudiated its currency today to speed up the sovietization of this country, which has lagged far behind the rest of eastern Europe in eliminating private enterprise.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 15 (AP) -- William Helis' End of Strife earned his second straight purse of the meeting today as the Peace Chance gelding skipped across the finish line four and a half lengths ahead of J.R. Steinman's Pompeian.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 15 -- A new record in the average value of Brazilian, exports was established during the first half of 1947, according to figures published here today by the Brazilian Statistics Service.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 15 -- The United Gas Corporation's proposal to issue and sell privately $116500,000 of first mortgage and collateral trust bonds, 2% per cent series, due in 1967, was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

With operating revenues rising 41 per cent while expenses were held virtually stable, American Airlines, Inc., realized a net profit of $786,343 in the second quarter of 1947, contrasted with a net loss of $3,073,636 in the first three months of the year, the company reported yesterday: Net profit in the second quarter of last year amounted to $325.901.

To the accompaniment of Scottish bag pipers, a whole clan of Scotch plaids will appear on the runway at Gimbels' college fashion show this morning at eleven o'clock. Plaid jackets, slacks, pedal pushers and skirts with flare, pleats or straight lines will be shown in matched sets or in contrast to solid color jerseys, sweaters and shirts.

VIENNA, Aug. 15 -- United States authorities believed tonight they had circumstantial evidence linking the bombing of a British military train high in the Austrian Alps Tuesday night to the Zionist terrorist organization Irgun Zvai Leumi, according to preliminary investigation reports from Bad Gastein.

LONDON, Aug. 15 -- With the Government giving official support to the gilt-edge market, the stock markets here today were able to make a much better finish to the week than seemed possible at one time. Investors followed the lead and British Government stocks wound up with all-around gains of up to 1 1/2 points.

Retail liquor sales in the metropolitan area appear to be running about even with a year ago, with a slight dip expected after Sept. 1 when observance of fair trade prices becomes mandatory, retailers stated yesterday in discounting reports of a threatened buyers strike.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 15 -- The Textile Workers Union, CIO, one of its local affiliates and two local union officers were made the target today of a $300,000 damage suit that was brought in Federal District Court by the United Piece Dye Works of Lodi.

At the end of a two-month survey of economic conditions in Europe, Lewis H. Brown, chairman of the board of the JohnsManville Corporation, singled out yesterday increased production of coal in England as the key to industrial recovery in Western Europe.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- assurances that the critical petroleum needs of the military force would be met were given today by representatives, of the oil industry, but the pledges were accompanied by warnings of an impact on civilian consumption in some areas through curtailed supplies of gasoline and household heating fuel.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Early prospects of profitable transatlantic operations by United States airlines without financial aid from the Government were seen today by James M. Landis, chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board.
PARIS, Aug. 15 -- Worth continues its tradition of fine clothes for women of great dignity, women in diplomatic circles who do not wish to be dressed like every other smart woman.

IVORYTON, Conn., Aug. 15 -- Paralysis of the piano industry was seen as a possibility tonight unless a strike at the Pratt, Read Company plant, which supplies the trade with 40 to 60 per cent of piano keys and actions, is settled quickly.
Following a day of light trading in cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, the market closed 6 points higher to 8 points lower than on Thursday.

LONDON, Aug. 15 -- A floodlit full-length portrait of Mohandas K. Gandhi dominated a colorful scene in the domed library of India House today at the ceremony of hoisting the flag of the new Dominion of India.

The New York City Housing Authority broke a wreck's deadlock yesterday to take three important steps. It approved use of a site in Jackson Heights, Queens, for a low-rent subsidized housing development, moved to acquire a similar site in the Bronx, and reaffirmed a long-standing policy against competing with private investors for property.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 -- Ralph T. Seward will become chairman of the United States Steel Corporation's board of conciliation and arbitration Oct. 1, succeeding Dr. Herbert Blumer of Chicago, who has resigned. The appointment was announced today by Philip Murray, president of the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, and John A. Stephens, vice president of United States Steel Corporation of Delaware.

Taking heed of what appears to be a lessening in demand, men's clothing manufacturers indicated yesterday that production next spring will show a drop of 20 to 25 per cent in unit volume. A rise in the cost of wool goods and rayon linings, will necessitate a price increase of $2.50 per garment, they said, and maintenance of the current rate of production under such conditions would prove too hazardous.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif, Aug. 15 -- "Sorrowful Jones," a story involving the character in Damon Runyon's "Little Miss Marker," has been scheduled by Paramount as a 1948 Bob Hope vehicle, it was learned today. "Little Miss Marker" was filmed by Paramount in 1934, with Shirley Temple and Adolphe Menjou.

Returning to this country for the first time since 1939, play in the Wightman Cup matches will get under way at the West Side Tennis Club's stadium in Forest Hills this afternoon. The competition, which brings together the top-flight women amateurs from Great Britain and the United States in team play, will be concluded tomorrow.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : The most faithful harbinger of the Autumntide is not the cumuli clouds riding five miles above the earth, and the stratum of wisps of half-dozen miles above them; nor the changed note of the tanager, the meadow lark and the starling, but the voice of the locust.

The first reaction of non-producing elements of the motion-picture industry to the 75 per cent tax imposed on film imports by the British was voiced yesterday by the Allied States Association of Motion Picture Exhibitors, a powerful group of independents, who objected to suggestions that production losses be made up by increased rentals in this country.

BATAVIA, Java, Aug. 15 (AP) -- An Indonesian communique, broadcast over the Jogjakarta radio, said today that the Dutch had dropped parachute troops south of Garut, in southwest Java, in violation of the cease-fire order.

MUNICH, Germany, Saturday, Aug. 16 -- Twelve key executives of the Krupp munitions works, headed by Alfried Krupp von Bohlen und Halbach as owner and directing head, were indicted today in Nuremberg. The date of their trials has not been set yet.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Bob Lemon and the Indians handed the weak-hitting Browns their second successive shut-out tonight, 2 to 0. Lemon stopped the Browns with three hits, while Ken Keltner drove in both Cleveland runs with a double and single.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Secretary of State Marshall believes that lack of food is slowing down world reconstruction and "strengthening the hands of those opposed to the democracy of free governments."

Thousands of jobs are open in Australia to American ex-service men and women, Arthur A. Caldwell, Australian Minister of Information and Immigration, declared yesterday, in an interview and at a luncheon in the Hotel Roosevelt tendered him by the Australian Society of New York, he described the industrial opportunities for American ex-GI's who decide to accept the Australian invitation for 1,000,000 of them to settle in Australia.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- President Truman dispatched Myron C. Taylor, his personal representative, to Rome today for discussions with Pope Pius XII on means of establishing peace "under a moral world order."
Gen. Omar N. Bradley, Veterans Administrator, sailed yesterday from Staten Island on an Army transport for a six-week "general inspection" tour of American troops in Germany, Austria and Italy.

Intense heat pushed the mercury up to 93.6 degrees at 4:05 P.M. yesterday to set a high-temperature record for the date and the year, As most New Yorkers sweltered for the third Successive day in temperatures above 90, the Weather Bureau confirmed earlier predictions of relief here from the heat wave by issuing a forecast for today of slightly cooler, less humid, with highest thermometer readings in the middle 80's.

PBTROPOLIS, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The text of Secretary of State Marshall's announcement on the new position of the United States regarding the hemispheric defense treaty today follows: In their replies to recent consultations concerning the treaty to be signed at Rio de Janeiro, a majority of the American Republics have expressed the opinion that decisions for collective measures should be obligatory on all parties to the treaty.

Four disputes affecting maritime workers continued to plague shipping and affiliated industries yesterday as negotiators reported no progress. Two strikes are in effect, another has been called for the middle of next month, and in the fourth dispute -- the dock workers' negotiations with employing stevedores -- the two groups recessed discussions.

Plans for an eighteen-story building costing" $11,000,000 in the Metropolitan Hospital replacement on the two blocks from Ninetyseventh to Ninety-ninth Streets, between First and Second Avenues, were filed yesterday by Charles B. Meyers, architect.

TAMPICO, Mexico, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Weather men late tonight warned that a hurricane, which swept onto the coast of Mexico early today to whip this oil center with 110-mile-an-hour winds, might build up and move on after apparently relaxing its intensity.

NEW DELHI, Aug. 15 -- Indians in New Delhi today celebrated the first day of their independence in such huge crowds that the pageantry scheduled for the event had to be called off because the surging mobs left no space.

LONDON, Aug. 15 -- One hundred and eleven coal miners were entombed today by an explosion in the under-sea workings of the William mine at Whitehaven, Cumberland. [The bodies of sixteen miners were located early Saturday, The United Press reported.]

ATHENS, Aug. 15 -- Archaeologists of the American School of Classical Studies at Athens finished today the twelfth season of excavations in the Agora, the main public square of ancient Athens and one of the oldest continuously inhabited places in the world.

PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 15 (AP) -- Firing another sub-par score. Johnny Palmer, Badin, N.C. postal a two-round total of 136 tt retain his lead today at the halfway point of the 72-hole $10,000 Portland open golf tournament.

MONTREAL, Aug. 15 -- The lack of American dollars may prevent the Czechoslovak Davis Cup players from competing' in the United States tennis championships at Boston and Forest Hills, Dr. Frantisek Bertl, non-playing captain of the Czech team revealed today.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The second-place St. Louis Cardinals kept in the thick of the National League pennant race tonight by powerhousing their way to a 7-4 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates before a crowd of 35,344.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 -- Continue dry weather in the Corn Belt, coupled with a five-day forecast by the Weather Bureau holding out little hope that the drought would be broken in that period, sent corn prices soaring again today on the Board of Trade.

THIS town temporarily became a more virtuous place when the law firm of Howe Hummel closed its doors soon after the turn of the century. And a duller one, too, of course. For those two unprincipled scoundrels had led the law an uncommonly merry dance through the roaring Seventies and Eighties, the more or less gay Nineties.

LAKE SUCCESS. N.Y., Aug. 15 -- United Nations offices in the Empire State Building and Rockefeller Center are to be moved into the New York City Housing Authority Building, on the permanent United Nations site in Manhattan early next month, it was announced today.
With hospital food bills said to be running about 33 per cent above those of the same period last year, plans are being made for exchanging hints on how to economize, it was reported yesterday.

Talks will begin in Washington on Monday between financial representatives of the British and American Governments to explore the possibilities for easing the British exchange crisis. Liberalization of the terms of the Anglo-American loan agreement is expected to provide the principal field of discussion.

SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 15 -- Col. Gen. Terentyi F. Shtikov, chief of the Soviet delegation on the Joint United States-Soviet Commission, was loudly booed by 65,000 Koreans during a Liberation Day address here today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Reports from United States officials in Rumania charge that the Soviet dominated Government there is using "third-degree methods" against Opposition leaders in an effort to force "confessions" from them, the State Department revealed today.

A front page editorial in The Brooklyn Eagle charged yesterday that a delegation from the Financial Employes Guild, Local 96, CIO, had attempted to dictate the paper's editorial policy on the thirty-day-old strike against the Brooklyn Trust Company.

The Fir Door Institute has inaugurated a full inspection system among its members on manufacture of pre-fit stock doors and is planning a promotion and advertising campaign on the advantages of the mass-produced Douglas fir doors.

POTSDAM, Germany, Aug. 15 -- Funeral rites of the Evangelical Church were held here today for Princess Hermine, widow of Germany's last Kaiser. With the permission of the Soviet military administration, the services were held in the historic Antique Temple of the Hohenzollerns on the grounds of the still-impressive Sans Souci Palace.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 15 (AP) --Ted Schroeder of Glendale, Calif., and William Talbert of Wilmington, Del., today appeared assured of reappointment to the U.S. Davis Cup tennis team by gaining the final round of the Newport Casino tourney in easy stride.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Employment in non-agricultural lines, estimated at 50,000,000, will probably remain the same for the rest of the year, but agriculture employment will probably fall off 2,000,000 to 3,000,000, Robert C. Goodwin, director of the United States Employment Service, said today.

Verdun J. Archimedes, 29-yearold former mess sergeant at the Fifth Army Headquarters in Italy who has an ambition to become a banker, was advised yesterday by Federal Judge Gaston Louis Porterie "to learn the rules of banking first."

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 15 -- Regular delivery of a New York newspaper in Los Angeles on the date of publication began for the first time today with the arrival of the first air-freight shipment of copies of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- The Kingdom of the Netherlands denied today the right of the United Nations Security Council to act in Indonesia and asked for an independent investigation of the warfare in the Netherlands Indies.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 15 -- By a vote of 66 to 12, the State Constitutional Convention settled today its most controversial issue to date by authorizing the Legislature to legalize bingo and other specific games of chance that may be approved by the people at public referendum.

VIENNA, Aug. 15 -- Officials of the economically merged United States and British zones in Germany raised today another hurdle for Austria to take in her efforts to make some sort of recovery. United States officials here were informed by the office of Military Government of the United States in Berlin that Austria may pay this year's coal bill immediately in full.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- Fulfilling the promise made in the shorter Schuylerville last week, when she was second after a powerful run through the stretch, Mrs. Laudy Lawrence's Bellesoeur won the fifty-sixth version of the Spinaway Stakes today by again turning on the power past the final poles.

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Stamp collectors throughout the world will help pay for the winter Olympics here next Jan. 30Feb. 8. Nineteen nations have indicated they will participate, the Swiss Olympic committee disclosed today in announcing arrangements for the events.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Gerhart Eisler, 52, a Communist already under sentence to serve a year for contempt of Congress, was convicted in Federal Court today on charges of passport fraud.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 -- In event of an atomic war, the qualities required for leadership both in combat and in the rear will be far greater than in the past, Maj. Gen. Leslie R. Groves, former director of the Army's atom-bomb project, asserted here yesterday.

PETROPOLIS, Brazil, Aug. 15 -- The United States delegation to the Inter-American Defense Conference modified tonight its position regarding collective hemispheric action to block or put down aggression against any American state.

Away back when motoring held a different kind of adventure from, today's high-speed perils quite a few hardy drivers made round-the-world trips behind the steering wheels of every make of car from a Cadillac to a Model A "flivver." Now we have aerial globe-circling tourists, William Odom, on the one hand, driving his swift converted bomber, and George Truman and Clifford Evans, on the other, piloting a pair of Piper Cubs.

DETROIT, Aug. 15 -- Disciplinary action by the Chrysler Corporation against eighteen veterans who left their jobs yesterday to celebrate V-J Day resulted today in a wildcat strike at the main Dodge assembly plant that made 8,500 idle.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- A composite cream, or ointment, which protects the skin against extremes of heat and cold, especially in industrial occupations, was one of 416 inventions on which patents were granted this week by the Inited States Patent Office, eightythree more than last week's total.

While warring Greek factions clash furiously in the turmoil of modern history, archaeologists of the American School for Classical Studies at Athens remain patiently at work unrolling the long, dim scroll of pre-history. Now, unearthing a royal Mycenaean tomb under the Agora, or public square of Pericles' Athens, they have carried the record back to 1,400 years before Christ.

BRUCE MARSHALL has changed his words but not the tune. Here are the world, the flesh and Father Smith all over again. In place of the author's Scotland the scene la now Vienna in the confused days of August, 1945.

THE chief reason for sowing countless packages of annual flower seeds every spring is certainly the constant bloom expected from them throughout the summer. Their blossoms turn the garden into a kaleidoscope, with colorful bits to be chosen and cut for different places indoors.

PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 16 -- The vast evergreen "rain forests" of the Olympic Peninsula, spread in a carpet of ridges and valleys between Puget Sound and the Pacific Ocean, have become the subject of a bitter political controversy involving many of the dominant economic groups in the Northwest.
NO one can tell how far a good deed will spread. Take, for instance, the one Homer Rodeheaver did in the 1920's.

THERE is a French saying that "les nations n'ont pas de cousins." The saying is true enough to be a warning against trying to make sentiment the basis of international cooperation. Sentimental friendships between great communities are likely to be of a watery kind and not proof against transformation into mass suspicion or even mass hatred.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Aug. 16 -- Mechanization has won out at the United States Military Academy.
TO fly around the world is becoming almost a commonplace. Only by adding something spectacular, like Bill Odom'a solo effort, do such flights now gain more than passing attention.

WINTER PARK, Fla., Aug. 16 -- Major Herman N. Archer, only man to wear Spanish-American War and Bataan campaign ribbons, who was the hero of Richard Harding Davis' book, "Captain Macklin," died at his home here this evening. His age was 68.

Northern Italy and not the Ruhr will be the first European industrial area to resume active industrial output in which new peaks of production above pre-war levels are envisaged, unofficial technical sources disclosed here yesterday. They said full details could not be furnished because of restrictions of State Dapartment policy.
PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 16 (AP) -- Johnny Palmer came marching home again today in one of the finest continuous golfing splurges in many a tournament to retain his lead in the $10,000 Portland open.

LONDON. THE summer doldrums of British radio have been enlivened by a sudden squall caused by a bullfighting broadcast. Edward Ward, formerly a BBC war reporter, went down the old Spanish trail at Easter, and, among the recordings which he made on old Spanish customs, was a bullfight commentary.

BERLIN, Aug. 16 -- The current discussions in Washington on the Ruhr coal production started because of complaints pressed chiefly by United States officials, but endorsed by other observers that the British were mismanaging the mines.

With the assistance of the Hebrew Sheltering and Immigrant Aid Society, 6,851 Jewish refugees and displaced persons emigrated from European nations other than Germany and Austria during the first four months of 1947, Samuel A. Telsey, president of the society, said yesterday in a semi-annual report.
IRIS is the poor man's orchid and the rich man's hobby. Probably there is no flower more generally loved than this one. It can be planted at any time from now until October for bloom next June.

With appropriate ceremonies, the Brookhaven National Laboratory began construction last week at Upton, N.Y., of the first peacetime chain-reaction atomic "pile," which is to cost $10,000,000. The laboratory is financed by the Atomic Energy Commission and operated by an association of universities which include Rochester, Cornell, Johns Hopkins, Pennsylvania, Princeton, Columbia, Yale, Harvard and Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

Privately-financed construction of new residential units in New York declined last month to its lowest level since December, 1945, with only 518 new permanent units started, compared to 618 in June and 1,950 in July, 1946, the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the United States Department of Labor announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Senator Claude Pepper denounced nearly the whole range of American foreign policy today, asserting that "insupportable conditions" were being attached to our offers of economic aid under the Marshall plan.
The study of American history was described yesterday as vital in the preparation of young persons as intelligent American citizens in an interdependent world.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- The United Mine Workers Journal said today that President Truman had "warned" the National Labor Relations Board that he would not reappoint members who permitted the Congressional Committee on Labor Relations to "interfere or dictate policy."

WHEN we say "that child needs discipline" we usually mean that he ought to "mind." We want him to do something, or to stop doing something -- upending ashtrays, yelling at bedtime, being rude to Grandma.

BOSTON, Aug. 16 -- The brakes, it seems, are still not holding our skidding Giants. They slipped a little further from the top and a trifle nearer the second division tonight as they went crashing down to a 4 to 1 defeat before Billy Southworth's Braves and a crowd of 25,949.

PARIS, Aug. 16 -- France's policy in Indo-China and the colonial issue generally reached a climax today in the Cabinet here and in the Socialist Party Congress in Lyon, endangering the Ramadier government.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- The President's Special Board of Inquiry on Air Safety recommended today a study to determine whether all passenger seats on commercial and military air transports should face the rear.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 16 -- Less than twenty-four hours after his re-election for another four-year term as president of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen, David B. Robertson today won emphatic approval by the brotherhood's convention of a detailed report on the Taft-Hartley Law in which he recommended a three-point course of action for the union.

INCREASED riding comfort and safety are the principal goals toward which, post-war research in automobile tires is being directed. Already several new types of tires have been produced and there are indications that more will follow before the first of the year.

THE symphonies that are with us late and soon on concert and radio programs have been recorded again and again, and the collector has a wide choice of interpreters. But the operas of the standard repertory have been less frequently recorded in full, because they are longer, require many more disks and sell at higher prices.
JERUSALEM, Aug. 16 -- Religious observance put a stop to Jewish-Arab rioting in Palestine today.

BATAVIA, Java, Aug. 16 (AP) -- A Dutch communique, which indicated that Republican activity had slackened, said today that twenty-nine Dutch had been killed, ninety-one wounded and one unaccounted for since the cease-fire order was issued Aug. 5.

Fifty-two railroads have agreed to share on a non-profit basis in the running of the Freedom Train, carrying more than 100 American historical documents, over a 33,162-mile, nation-wide, one-year tour, sponsored by the Department of Justice, Thomas D'A. Brophy, president of the American Heritage Foundation, announced yesterday.

SOME fifty years ago two philosopher-psychologists, William James and James Mark Baldwin, described the structure and development of the self or "ego." Their ideas made little impression on psychologists, who already were turning to objective and statistical research.

American industrialists must seize the opportunity provided by the International Labor Organization to exercise world leadership or risk the danger of Communist infiltration into world labor ranks, it was declared yesterday by James D. Zellerbach, American employer delegate to the recent ILO conference in Geneva.

THE amateur photographer who regularly uses one film, follows the exposure instructions packed with the roll, and always shoots pictures under the light conditions indicated to get average results, never has to think about "film speed."
CHICAGO, Aug. 16 -- Bewitch, Citation and Free America finished one-two-three to give the Calumet Farm a clean sweep in the $78,050 Washington Park Futurity today.

The beaches beckon these sultry mid-summer days. Within a fancy's flight of the steaming pavements of the town the forest streams run clear and cool. It is the time to water the parched imagination, which someone calls the courage of the mind, and let fresh winds from sea and forest blow away stale thoughts and arid controversies that make the international atmosphere as heavy as the weather.

VOCATIONAL ADOPTION, whose history is traced here, occupies a singular niche in welfare work. It concerns itself with those orphaned and unfortunate young people of all creeds and races who are too old for institutions and yet not old enough to have found their place in society.
QUONSET POINT, R.I., Aug. 16 -- New radar equipment designed to bring aircraft to a landing in thick weather is being tested at the naval air station here, pending official acceptance Sept. 1.

HOLLYWOOD. HOLLYWOOD'S major studios pay in excess of a million dollars a year for the use of those brief snatches of copyright music which are utilized in the background score of films to emphasize mood, atmosphere and description.

ASTEADY month-by-month improvement in the supply of flash lamps is reported by General Electric and Wabash, and both companies predict that their enlarged lamp-making facilities will reach full production capacity by the end of this year.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Aug. 16 -- Strained relations between Turkey and Communist-dominated countries have forced considerable decline in prosperous pre-war trade, official figures released by department of statistics reveal.

PERSISTENT rumors that "Information, Please" would become a MBS feature, to be offered to affiliated stations on a cooperative basis, were confirmed last week by Phillips Carlin, Mutual Broadcasting System vice president in charge of programs, and Dan Golenpaul, producer of the program.

The Decline in Keeping Scrapbooks No statistics are at hand for confirmation, but we have a strong feeling that the first half of this century, which has witnessed the extraordinary rise in popularity of the automobile, the radio and the airplane, has also witnessed the abrupt decline of the scrapbook.
LONDON, Aug. 16 -- A paradoxical fact about Anglo-American relations these days is that, although they have rarely Been better, British criticism of the United States has rarely been more outspoken.

WHITEHAVEN, England, Aug. 16 (Reuters) -- The story of the escape of the three miners who walked out of Whitehaven's death pit by a "back entrance" was told tonight by 46-year-old John Birkett, their leader.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- A note of contrast to the general trend of higher prices wag struck today by the Federal Power Commission in a report that the electricity bills of most residential and commercial customers continued downward in 1946.

THE Museum of Modern Art placed on view last week in one of the first-floor galleries four recent painting acquisitions. Most important of these is Roger de La Fresnaye's large 1913 "Conquest of the Air" (reproduced), acquired through the fund established some time ago by Mrs. Simon Guggenheim.

EVANSTON, Ill., Aug. 16 (AP) -- Completing the first double-slam in the half century history of the competition. Miss Louise Suggs of Atlanta, Ga., saved her best shots for the final round today to trounce Miss Carol Diringer of Tiffin, Ohio, 9 and 8, to win the women's Western amateur golf championship.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 16 -- Up-state troops who moved in Camp Smith Friday morning, replacing the 165th Infantry, the old Sixty-ninth of New York, now are settled in their training routine and will spend tomorrow on the target range.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- High Officers of the Army Air Forces, operational, engineering and administrative, are to meet here Tuesday to try to "cut its coat to fit its cloth." The decisions it makes, and it may take weeks to arrive at them, will have far reaching effect on the aircraft industry.
PLAINFIELD, N.J., Aug. 16 -- Robert Anderson Meeker of 527 Belvidere Avenue, dean of the State Highway Department, died last night in the Muhlenberg Hospital at the age of 93.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 16 -- Bobby Bragan came out of the bullpen shadows in the ninth inning today to win a ball game that the Dodgers, by errors and bad base-running, had tried hard to give to the Phils.

WOODSTOCK, Conn. NEXT Tuesday the President of a Florida college will celebrate his seventy-fifth birthday at his summer home in Connecticut. It was there that Dr. Hamilton Holt, surrounded by an aura of the past, posed for me the other day. His home, once the village inn of Woodstock and his great-grand-father's general store, has now the appearance of a museum.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 16 -- In two of the nation's largest regular religious assemblages, members of Jehovah's Witnesses and the Seventh Day Adventist Church, numbering nearly 45,000 persons, held simultaneous meetings here today.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 16 -- The United States today offered to join other major powers in relinquishing critically scarce short-wave broadcasting facilities to enable smaller nations to make themselves heard on the world's airwaves.

TRUMPET creeper is a vigorous perennial vine now covered with flowers. Attractive, clean leaves and big clusters of bright blossoms all summer make this plant worth its place where a climber is needed.
The American Federation of Radio Artists at its annual convention at the Hotel Astor discussed yesterday afternoon the problem of setting up more locals throughout the country.

CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., Aug. 16 -- A draw in the fifth round between Isaac I. Kashdan and George Kramer, both former New York State champions, caused a tie for first place between these two leaders in the annual tournament for the United States Chess Federation open championship at the White Plaza Hotel.

The population of the New York-Northeastern New Jersey Metropolitan District Has increased by nearly a million since 1940, according to a report made public yesterday by the Bureau of the Census. The population growth was from 11,691,000 to 12,684,000, or 9 per cent.

THE influence of Marxism, so strong in American intellectual life in the middle Thirties, declined in the later years of the decade and was largely obliterated by the Soviet-German pact of August, 1939. Five years later, when Paris was liberated, Americans began to hear about the Existentialists and the part they had played in the resistance movement.

ANN TODD, the British star who first brightened the American screen in "The Seventh Veil" and who will be making her Hollywood debut in David O. Selznick's "The Paradine Case," will not be returning to these shores soon, it became known last week.

SWEDEN -- Experiment A new educational system will be tried out this fall in a Swedish elementary school and, according to the Swedish News Agency here, if it proves successful it will be introduced generally. The reform includes less homework for the children and better contact between teachers and the homes.

State governments as a rule are not prone to issue publications that place their states in tat unfavorable light. A drastic exception to this rule, however, was a booklet published a year ago by the Mississippi State Board of Health in which it called Mississippi "The 48th State."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- A $1,125,000,000 program to provide hospitals and health facilities throughout the country according to community needs was one year old this week and ready to go into high gear.

VIENNA, Aug. 16 (AP) -- A crowd of 25,000 expecting a complete rout, salvaged solace today with three Austrian victories as a touring team of American Olympic hopefuls otherwise made it a one-two proposition in a three-nation track and field meet.

Orders were signed yesterday by Federal Referee Irwin Kurtz permitting Press Wireless, Inc., of 1475 Broadway, to continue in business and enjoining two creditors from proceeding with court actions in a reorganization proceeding under the National Bankruptcy Act filed in Federal Court last Friday.

A rather realistic example of the maxim, "the power to tax is the power to destroy," is presented in the case of the British tax recently levied upon the importation of American motion picture films. The tax takes the form of an ad valorem import duty, payable upon entry or declaration of films.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Aug. 16 -- A special conference of the Socialist party on the Indonesian problem, held in Amsterdam today, adopted a resolution regretting the opening of "police operations," but expressing satisfaction over the fact that the Dutch Government intended to carry out the principles of the Cheribon Agreement.

THE British are very much the subject of conversation in film circles at present. Aside from the tax situation, which is aggravating producers and run-of-the-job workers on both sides of the Atlantic, the British are currently and impressively represented along Broadway with three extraordinarily good films.

Flattering reports continue to drift in about Walsing Winning Trick, sturdy 11-month-old Scottish terrier, recently purchased in England by Mrs. John G. Winant, wife of the former United States Ambassador to the Court of St. James. Mrs. Winant plans to show the Scottie in this country at an early date.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 16 (AP) -- John Lyons, 23-year-old fuel-burner broker who captured the medal here yesterday with a one-over-par 73, continued his front-running ways today to enter the semi-finels of the twelfth annual Maidstone Bowl tournament over the Maidstone Club course.
