MANITOWOC, Wis., Aug. 16 -- Capt. Edward Carus, veteran Great Lakes skipper and long a source of nautical information, died today after a long illness. His age was 88.

Convicted yesterday, for the sixth time, of turning in a false fire alarm, Jean Kelly, 38 years old, of 1839 Third Avenue, was sentenced to a fine of $100 or thirty days in jail plus an outright jail term of thirty days. Without funds, she started to serve the sixty days in prison.

The railway operating brotherhoods, which a few months ago made demands for changes in working rules that would cost the carriers an estimated $1,000,000,000 annually, may withdraw these demands and instead ask for a rise in wages.

Arab vs. Jew Tel Aviv, lying on the Mediteranean Sea one-half of the way down Palestine's coast, is the largest all-Jewish city in the world. It is mainly a new city (its name means "Hill of Spring"), built since large-scale immigration of Jews into Palestine began in the early Twenties.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Enactment of a $6,000,000,000 personal income tax reduction bill next year, regardless of which political party gets the credit, wag urged today by Earl Bunting, president of the National Association of Manufacturers.
NEW DELHI, Aug. 16 (AP) -- The Joint Defense Council for the new Dominions of India and Pakistan decided today to strengthen the military forces in riot-torn Punjab Province.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (U.P.) -- The United States has poured out $2,000,000,000 to produce the atomic bomb but has failed to teach its youth "the art of democratic living," a group of educators asserted tonight.

EASTERN tourist cabins seem to be getting the play this summer that their western counterparts enjoyed in pre-war days and, for that matter, are still getting. Motorists and cabin-court operators in many Eastern districts report full occupancies -- the latter joyfully, the former with some dismay, especially when they have waited until late at night to start looking for a place to sleep.

IN search of some light summer reading we have turned the pages of John Erskine's recently published memoirs, "The Memory of Certain Persons" (J. Lippincott Company, Philadelphia and New York), and found therein a reference, treating rather curiously the facts involved, to ourselves.

SIX plays now appear primed to open next month -- the first stirrings of a season that showmen grimly view as tardy in birth and bedeviled in infancy by high costs, reluctant investors, a shortage of good scripts and an ugly thing called consumer resistance.

MISS DICKENS has taken such a family as you have already met in "You Can't Take It With You" and "The Constant Nymph" and given them an English accent, a mother from Philadelphia and an invalided, war-hero brother, and set them down in jovial confusion on an estate in Shropshire.

THIS is one of the most revealing inside stories to come out of Nazi Germany. The American public has not had access before to so many nauseating details about murderous Gestapo chiefs, conspiring Wehrmacht generals, terrorized Reich Ministers and the human freaks on top of the pyramid called the Third Reich, all told by a man who ten days before the outbreak of World War II planned to arrest Hitler.

Retail credit management stiffened this week in anticipation of sterner responsibilities to be shouldered this fall. In credit circles it was noted that collection percentages already have turned and competition indicates greater use of credit in creating sales volume.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Aug. 16 -- The nationalization of banking was decided upon by the Federal Cabinet today. In a statement Prime Minister Joseph B. Chifley announced that the Cabinet had authorized him and Attorney General Herbert V. Evatt to prepare legislation to be submitted to the Federal Parliament by the Labor party.

IT is always difficult to evaluate the work of a living artist, particularly if he is a close personal friend. In the present volume, however, Donald Bear, director of the Santa Barbara Museum, has accomplished his difficult task with distinction and with discrimination.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 16 -- Concordian, golden son of Sickle in the racing establishment of Barney Murphy, gave Philadelphia its second straight victory in the mile-and-a-quarter Olympic Handicap as he romped to an easy triumph in the $10,000 added feature at the seashore course today.

WHEN Ludwig Bemelmans was in Hollywood a season or two ago, he experienced one of those periods of paid unemployment which fall to the lot of almost every writer under contract to a major film studio. (They just forget you're around.) Some writers pass the days with gin rummy, some catch up with their reading and correspondence -- even to the point of composing four-page letters to old fraternity brothers; some go quietly mad.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16 -- About 1,000 policemen were assigned indefinitely today to keep order at the Fernwood Park Housing project on the South Side of Chicago, where demonstrations have been staged in protest against admission of eight Negro families as tenants.

Now that the Gold Cup for 1947 is history, the fraternity of the country's owners and drivers of the fastest speed boats afloat are planning their strategy and tactics for the remaining big league regattas. Two new events will beckon most of them, in addition to the traditional fixtures at Red Bank this week and the President's Cup on the Potomac next month.

WITH this book the publishers inaugurate their Great Writers of the World series. They could hardly have made a happier choice. In the first place, Horace himself was an inaugurator, and so powerful a one that few of the great writers of the world subsequent to his time have escaped some indebtedness, however slight, to him.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 16 -- As American Federation of Labor craft unions rounded out ten and one-half months of picketing Hollywood's major movie studios this week, a new element entered the situation.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 16 -- The New Rochelle Yacht Club was host to the twenty-seventh championship regatta of the Y.R. A. season today, starting the proceedings in a moderate easterly breeze which petered out when squalls and light rain interfered during the afternoon, then freshened to bring the boats home in ample time.

PETROPOLIS, Brazil, Aug. 16 -- As the Inter-American Defense Conference adjourned its formal sessions this afternoon until Monday, Mexico moved to defer the touchy economic questions to the Pan-American meeting at Bogota, Colombia, next January.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 16 (AP) -- The Reds bobbed up with two runs in the ninth inning today after two were out to shade the Cubs, 7 -- 6, and move back into fifth place in the National League.

THIS time of year is best for the country dinners which are a specialty of roadside restaurants in upstate and western New York, for now the harvest of fruit and vegetables is reaching its peak. Motorists who have once made the gourmet's junket of the upper part of the State have no need of road maps -- they route their trip by memory of the country dinners enjoyed before.

DAYTON, Ohio, Aug. 16 -- Headquarters of the Air Material Command at Wright Field, which does the Army Air Forces' research and buys its airplanes, is reported to be operating with one-fifth the money and one-third the persons it had on V-J Day.

THE jacket of Mr. Coniston's brief book points out quite correctly that words like "freedom," "democracy" and "independence" are difficult to use precisely under any circumstances but especially when bandied about in discussions of the Far Bast.

COLORING JEWELS -- A new X-ray tube which has a beryllium window to permit the passage of long wave-lengths can be used to change the color of gems. Under this process, it is possible to make the cheaper grades of yellowish diamonds look like stones that are much more valuable.

A LFRED HITCHCOCK (that virtuoso in terror) could work a special magic with either of these chillers -- though the present reviewer would hardly recommend them to his attention. Mr. Wykes' shocker has occasional sharpness of observation, patches of brilliance that lift it from the ruck: Mr. Lytle's is a pale carbon of the House-of-Usher pattern.

WEEHAWKEN, N.J., Aug. 16 -- Ten-year-old Lester Sweeney Jr., chronic runaway whose adventures have taken him as far as Pittsburgh, made seven separate bids for freedom within twenty-four hours before being plucked today from a ledge 150 feet up on the Palisades and returned to his home at 64 West 180th Street, New York.

NOT since 1943 has a round of the art colony shows been made previous to the round on which I have now embarked. The first chapter of the present excursion takes in summer shown current in Gloucester and Rockport on Cape Ann, and in Provincetown on Cape Cod.
WICHITA, Kan., Aug. 16 -- Riding high on the tide of the times, Kansas farmers are running the wheat business on their own terms these days.

SALEM, N.H., Aug. 16 (AP) -- Blazing over a sloppy six furlongs in the fast time of 1:11 2-5 under an impost of 113 pounds, G.R. Schneider's George Gains today won the $7,500 added Raceland Handicap before 17,167 at Rockingham Park.

DAVTD BOSWORTH and Penny Lorimer are an attractive pair who discover to their dismay how little the world really loves lovers and that love is a luxury that cannot be afforded by a young Oxford undergraduate with brilliant prospects but no income and an under-age art student with a highly correct Edinburgh family.
LONDON, Aug. 16 -- Britons are worrying about the film fare they will share in the months to come if American producers stick by their announced intention of cutting Britain off their export lists.
Two missing boys, for whom the police have searched extensively for two days, were found yesterday near a subway terminal in Coney Island.

A missing element in the periodic table has been explained in The Physical Review by two groups of scientists, including two University of California nuclear chemists. One of the investigations was headed by Prof. Glenn T. Seaborg, Professor of Chemistry at the University of California, when he was in charge of plutonium research at the Metallurgical Laboratory, University of Chicago.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 16 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians "fire ball king," Bob Feller, today hinged a donation of about $18,000 for the American League players' pension fund on Baseball Commissioner A. B. Chandler's permission for Feller to pitch in the Cuban Winter League this year.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Aug. 16 -- Senora Marta de Ubico, widow of deposed President Jorge Ubico of Guatemala, is preparing for a legal battle, to, recover property she claims has been confiscated illegally by the Guatemalan Government.

IN these days, when too many people are talking about the next war, there is a remarkable lack of interest in the last one. Book publishers have refused important manuscripts, born in the Hitler years and in World War II, on the grounds that "people aren't interested."

THE studious bridge player reads constantly of master plays and tricky leads and then never by any chance does he get an oportunity to make one of these plays. In fact, he eventually comes to wonder whether anyone is ever faced with such a chance in actual play.

NEW DELHI, Aug. 16 (Reuters) -- After a day of tumultuous rejoicing to celebrate their independence, the two new Dominions of India and Pakistan got down to serious things today, their first concern being defense.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Washington, these hot summer days, has the melancholy desuetude of Main Street on a Sunday afternoon.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, Aug. 16 -- The British delegation to the Washington Ruhr talks will seek United States agreement to proposals that would raise the prices of German domestic and export coal 50 per cent above the present levels, it was learned today.

"LEGALLY, as far as the United States is concerned, there are no refugees," the author, a Yale sociologist, asserts. The law of this country differentiates merely between "immigrants," admitted for permanent residence, and "visitors" who plan to stay here for a limited time only.

WASHINGTON. WHILE Secretary of State George C. Marshall is representing this country at the Inter-American Conference at Rio de Janeiro, the task of running the State Department rests upon the shoulders of Under-Secretary Robert Abercrombie Lovett.

LOS ANGELES. TO Hollywood residents, Howard Hughes' performance at the recent Washington sessions of the Senate War Investigating Committee seemed wholly in character. It was spectacular. It was combative. It obviously gave Mr. Hughes, despite tiresome and irritating moments, considerable pleasure.

BOSTON, Aug. 16 -- If Senator Owen Brewster of Maine has any political wounds as a result of the Howard Hughes investigation in Washington, they are not discernible to New Englanders, especially those in Maine, where he has returned for a vacation.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 16 -- Lightning injured eighteen workers and stunned dozens of others in a large tobacco barn in Hazardville, fifteen miles north of here, today. None of the victims was seriously hurt.

ALTHOUGH it undoubtedly is highly improper to engage in business while on vacation, there certainly must be a few exceptions to that rule. One would be when your business associates also happen to be firm friends and the business creeps into the social conversation merely because all the conversationalists love their business too much ever to forget it entirely.

The Law and Prices The Sherman Act of 1890 outlaws any "contract, combination * * * or conspiracy, in restraint of trade or commerce." The United States Supreme Court has defined a conspiracy as "a combination of two or more persons by concerted action to accomplish a criminal or unlawful purpose * * * ."

Joe DiMaggio and Tommy Henrich were back on the casualty list yesterday as the Yanks resumed hostilities with the Boston Red Sox before 34,675 at the Stadium, but 24-year-old Allie Clark, only recently up from Newark, took it upon himself to uphold the slugging power of the picket line to such good effect that the Bombers came through with a won-in-the-ninth victory, 1 to 0.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16 -- George A. Ranney, chairman of the board of the Peoples Gas, Light Coke Company, died in his sleep last night at the Homestead Hotel in Hot Springs, Va., according to word received here. His age was 73.

LONDON, Aug. 16 -- The underlying issue at stake in Britian today is whether the Labor Government is to go ahead with its own peculiar British brand of Socialist revolution or whether, under pressure of the economic crisis, there will now be a counter-revolution.
MONTREAL, Aug. 16 -- Australia again confronts the United States in the Davis Cup challenge round.

According to the mail received since the announcement was made of the 1947 waterfowl shooting regulations, there are almost as many opinions as there are individual shooters, and no one seems to be convinced that it was necessary to make such a severe cut in both season length and bag limit.

Karl Shapiro and Roy Fuller, who have written most movingly of the recent war were soldiers, but their styles had been fully developed in the comparative serenity of civilian life.

THE first of Vivian Locke Ellis' poems appeared at the turn of the century; several volumes of his verse were published about 1910. The present volume (and this we are told on the jacket) consists of work done over the past forty years.

Nehru and Jinnah Start At midnight last Thursday in India the Union Jack was hauled down. In New Delhi the saffron, white and green flag of the Union of India was hoisted; in Karachi -- 700 miles away -- the green, and white flag of Pakistan was unfurled.
The United States did the expected and swept the first three tests of the nineteenth women's international tennis matches for the Wightman Cup at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills yesterday.

GENEVA, Aug. 16 -- The prospects of completing a series of significant trade agreements at the Geneva conference are very gloomy, the latest roundup of the negotiations of the Preparatory Commission of the International Trade Organization indicates.

Almost a year after the break occurred Wall Street is mystified by the delay in the report of the investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission of the sharp decline in prices of stocks on the New York Stock Exchange on Sept. 3, 1946.
LINCOLN, Neb., Aug. 16 (AP) -- A statue of William Jennings Bryan, former Presidential candidate, dead twenty-two years, was the center of a controversy in Nebraska's capital this week.

DAYTON, Ohio, Aug. 16 (AP) -- The nation's scattergun stars were converging today on nearby Vandalia for Monday's opening of the week-long forty-eighth annual Grand American trapshoot.

The great migrations of the war years in the United States reflect to a considerable extent war causes, but other reasons must have played a substantial part also. Some extremely interesting figures emerge from a report on the period from April, 1940, to mid-1946 made by the Bureau of the Census.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

BERLIN, Aug. 16 -- The occupation policies of the French Government are hindering the economic rehabilitation of Europe, according to high United States Military Government authorities. These officials say the French complaints of the possible resurrection of the German war potential are inadmissable in view of the announced aims of the United States.
ROME, Aug. 18 -- When a United States official goes from Washington to Italy to investigate the needs and problems of this country he sees many strange and paradoxical things.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 16 -- An English translation of an address by Pope Pius XII to farmers, exhorting them to take steps to improve rural life, was published today by the National Catholic Rural Life Conference here.

JUST ten years ago this week in this Review: Publishers were generous even in midsummer. Jean Giono's pastoral epic. "The Song of the World," received a front-page review -- and not because it was "timely"; the French writer would, have it known "the present time disgusts me, even to describe."

OTTAWA, Aug. 16 -- Predictions that consumer prices in Canada would decline this fall are being proved unjustified and the tendency is the other way, according to the report of the Dominion Bureau of Statistics and in the experience of purchasers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- The Senators lost their fifth straight game today, bowing to the Athletics, 5 -- 2. Only 3,428 fans watched the contest, in which Bill McCahan captured his sixth game of the season. Ray Scarborough and Tom Ferrick were battered for twelve hits.

A photographer's routine question yesterday scored an unexpected scoop. It brought the news that Serge Koussevitzky, conductor of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, was married on Friday to Miss Olga Naumoff, his secretary for the past 18 years and niece of his late wife.

Aware of increasing criticism by apparel manufacturers and consumers, manufacturers of synthetic fibers pointed out last week that the lack of a competitive market was chiefly responsible for inferior goods.

THE WOODBINE (Iowa) TWINER recently reported that Mrs. Emma Ogden, 90, of What Cheer, Iowa, found a long-lost uncle, 103, by listening to the radio. The Unterrified Democrat of Linn, Mo., has been bemoaning the midsummer heat.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 16 -- There is a sharpening awareness today in the country's great farm belt of the immediate need for a long-range agricultural policy that will help promote a stable economy for the world, consumers and farmers alike.

ON a bright and blistering summer Sunday, the sidewalks (5,719 miles of them), streets, subways and office buildings of New York have a calm and empty look. Yet, according to the Police Department, the population remains pretty much the same, numerically.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- A building boom is causing many American cities to burst their seams and spread into suburban areas.

FAIRBANKS Alaska, Aug. 16 -- Alaskans are braced for the annual "Washington invasion." With the first wave already taken in stride, Fairbanks is preparing to welcome four more capital contingents in the next four weeks.

Storewide activity last week was good with college shop trade continuing excellent and coats and dresses in steady demand, according to a survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Activity on back-to-school children's items was good and furniture home departments busy, the survey stated.

FOUR Hundred years ago this year -- in September, probably -- a man was born, who, says Mr. Bell, was "one of the two great writers who more than any others have probed into the human soul and revealed the ways of man to man." William Shakespeare and Miguel de Cervantes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- There was plenty of heat generated this week over the stratospheric price level by Democrats and Republicans, business men and labor, all apparently undaunted by some of the hottest August weather in half a century.

THE first annual Photography in Science competition and salon is announced by the sponsors, the Smithsonian Institution's Division of Graphic Arts and The Scientific Monthly, journal of The American Association for the Advancement of Science.

ATHENS, Aug. 16 -- Gen. Markos Vafthiadis, Greek guerrilla leader, proclaimed in a broadcast the organization of a Military Government in "Free Greece." The Government seized published copies of the proclamation as soon as they appeared today.
The national office of the Seafarers International Union made it clear yesterday that the union did not plan to extend its strike against the Isthmian Steamship Company to other shipping lines.

Plans for the erection of a seven-story apartment building for 135 families on Pelham Road, in New Rochelle, N.Y., by the Golden Construction Company of Kew Gardens Hills, Queens, were announced yesterday by B.H. Whinston, architect.

LONDON, Aug. 16 (Reuters) -- A partnership of 98 runs in 100 minutes by Len Hutton and Denis Sompton, and another stand of 93 in 100 minutes by Norman Yardey and Kenneth Cranston, today helped England score 311 runs for he loss of six wickets in the first innings of the fifth and final cricket test match against South Africa.

Four months ago Thor Heyerdahl and five Scandinavian companions set out from Callao, Peru, on a forty-five-foot balsa raft with the bearded, pre-Columbian sun god of ancient Peru painted on its sail. The purpose was to drift and sail by way of the Humboldt Current to Polynesia.

STIR BOARDER -- Chicago police gave John Petahara, a transient, a free night's lodging only to have him complain next morning that his cell cot was uncomfortable and that the officers made too much noise during the night.
Red Bank's big moment comes next Saturday and Sunday. Down there on the North Shrewsbury they count time from the two-day excitement every August known as the National Sweepstakes Regatta.

STOYAN CHRISTOWE came to America from his native Macedonia when he was 17 years old. This is the story of how he became an American. A great many cliches have been woven around the ever-recurrent theme of Americanization, but this unsentimental, deeply felt and beautifully written book follows no derived pattern.

NEW YORKERS who have difficulty sleeping on hot summer nights and as a result spend as much time talking about it as doing it may find it useful to learn what experts know of sleep -- though unfortunately it isn't a great deal.

Can Russia implement the Molotov plan? Does she have the resources to dim the attraction of the Marshall plan for the Eastern European satellites by providing them with the machines, raw materials, food and technical assistance they need to rebuild their war-shattered economies?

With the general tendency of sales volume and prices to hold steady at a high level, the real estate market during July showed signs of reaching the stability which many brokers had predicted for late summer, the National Association of Real Estate Boards reported yesterday.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 16 -- Dr. Elliott Carr Cutler, pioneer in heart and thyroid surgery and a brigadier general with the Army Medical Corps in Europe during the recent World War, died today in his home. His age was 59.

Declaring that policies of the Democratic national administration had caused the people to lose faith in the integrity of their Government, Carroll Reece, Republican National Chairman, predicted yesterday that his party would be victorious in the 1948 Presidential campaign.

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 16 -- Emory University acquired this week a substantial part of the fortune based on the late Asa Griggs Candler's development of Coca-Cola. Mr. Candler's eldest son, Charles Howard Candler, president of Emory's board of trustees, gave Emory stock in the Asa G. Candler Corporation valued at from $5,000,000 to $7,000,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 16 -- To meet unprecedented demands for education, many Colleges, particularly those in the cities, face the problem of broadening the base of their financial support, Dr. Philip O. Badger, assistant to the chancellor at New York University, said here this week.

LONDON, Aug. 16 (Reuters) -- Close scores and large crowds featured Scottish League cup games today with pre-game favorites playing to form. Bright sunshine and soaring temperature brought fans out in full force and stadiums were sold out.

BERLIN, Aug. 16 -- The manufacturing industry in Saxony in the Soviet zone has hit the bottom with no immediate prospect of a revival, according to a foreign trader who has just returned from Dresden in search of goods to sell abroad.

FOR people who suffer wanderlust but do not have the money to indulge it, "The Enchanted Islands" brings hope. The Conways have written a guide for living in the Galapagos without money; and if enough rugged people read the book, those remote islands west of Ecuador are in for a boom.

THE International Gladiolus Show to be held at Kalurah Temple, Binghamton, N.Y., this Tuesday and Wednesday, promises to be the largest exhibit of a single flower ever held. Sponsored by the North American Gladiolus Council and the Canadian Gladiolus Society, the show classes are open to everyone.
CAMDEN, Me., Aug. 16 -- A lobster festival, said to be the first ever held in this country, attracted about 10,000 downeasters and vacationers to this Penobscot Bay community today.

NEARLY every newspaper man, at some time or other, swears he's going to quit the business and go into something a little more profitable. Usually it's just talk. But occasionally some actually do go through with it, even though they often profess a yearning to go back to it from time to time.

The 5-cent subway fare is still in politics, but with a difference. For years a purely local issue, its impact may be felt in the Presidential election in 1948, the Mayoralty contest in 1949 and the Gubernatorial race in 1950. It all depends on whether or not Mayor O'Dwyer goes through with his present plan to bring about a higher fare referendum at a special election to be held in January or February.

JEAN TENNYSON, who may be remembered as the star of the program generously entitled "Great Moments in Music," last week inaugurated a new weekly series of interview programs from her own studio in the Steinway Building on West Fifty-seventh Street.

An agreement covering 4,000 shipyard workers on strike in Baltimore since July 2 was reached late last night after a prolonged negotiating session here between officials of the Maryland Drydock Company and the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, CIO, a union spokesman said.

HOLLYWOOD. THE new British import tax of 75 per cent on earnings of motion pictures has given Hollywood an acute anxiety neurosis. With production costs at an all-time high, the loss of British revenue was enough to shock the solidest citizens.

PARIS, Aug. 16 -- Lewis Neikrug, director of overseas activities, of the Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society, said today he had been informed that the Australian Government had in the last few days asked organizations dealing with Jewish immigration not to send any Jews to Australia on ships flying American, British or Panamanian flags.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- The United States has made to the Indonesian leaders in Batavia its final offer to mediate the prolonged and bloody strife between Indonesia and the Netherlands, it was disclosed today.

STRAWBERRIES can be planted from the middle of August until the ground freezes. New varieties, with flavor and aroma never before equaled in the Northeastern States, make this crop an especially good one for home gardens.

THE Metropolitan Opera's two outstanding labor contracts -- those with the Musicians Union and the American Guild of Musical Artists -- are drawn up and ready for final ratification. The one with the orchestra requires merely the initialing of a correction already agreed upon.

ALEGAL proceeding without precedent in the annals of philately is described in the first issue of an Austrian stamp magazine, the Merkur-Kurier, received here last week from Innsbruck. The Vienna Court's decision in the case poses a unique problem for the publisher of the American Standard Postage Stamp Catalogue and will embarrass some stamp dealers.
NERINES, commonly known as Guernsey lilies, are choica house plants. They flower in late autumn and early winter owing to the fact that the bulbs are native to South Africa.

THE first interesting news of the coming ballet season stems from Ballet Theatre and is to the happy effect that the company will play a season of four weeks next spring at the Metropolitan Opera House once again.

WITH temperatures what they were last week in many sections of the country, business gauges dipped as the mercury soared. A few shoppers may have decided to visit air-conditioned stores instead of sweltering at home, but trade felt the effect of the heat.

ATHENS, Aug. 16 -- The impact on Greece of United States aid since Dwight P. Griswold, chief of mission, arrived a month ago has been mainly psychological. That is, non-Communist Greece felt reassured by a sprinkling of United States uniforms and automobiles bearing licenses marked AMAG on the streets of Athens and by the fact that Mr. Griswold was at last in their midst.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: To the many former servicemen who have been concerned with the need for revision of the Army and Navy courts-martial systems, a major item on the debit side of the record of the Eightieth Congress has been its actions with respect to correction of inequities in Army and naval justice.

AROUSING welcome for every visitor to New York City is the dream, of Royal Ryan, executive director of the New Tork Convention and Visitor's Bureau. To that end he has presented to the bureau's board of directors a two-year plan estimated to cost about $250,000, as a starter, which will help civilian visitors to New York feel as welcome as GI visitors were made to feel during the war years.
BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Aug. 16 -- Harold V. Ludlow, 47, president of the Binghamton Chamber of Commerce, and three other persons were killed this afternoon in a plane crash near Bath.

ASHRUB planting under large trees in front of a historic church in northern New Jersey is made particularly interesting by a ground cover of the familiar hen-and-chicks. A trial group started under our own heavy, nearly century-old maples is proving the adaptability and persistence of this Sempervivum.

ROSLYN HEIGHTS, N.Y. I WAS in comfortable mood when I picked up the Aug. 3 issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES Book Review. It was one of life's best moments: when, after a swim in the clean salt-solution of tang Island Sound (ocean water unvexed by surf), one sits on the veranda of a beachcombing cabin called Nostromo, wearing only shorts and a tingling skin.

Members of Congress, which limited Maritime Commission funds for building and improving passenger ships for the American merchant marine, are booking ocean passages for their authorized study missions abroad, but most of them are going on foreign ships.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 18 -- Eugene F. Burke, who began organizing maritime workers fortysix years ago and is hailed by his own union as "maritime labor's greatest leader," has resigned as secretary-treasurer of the National Union of Marine Cooks and Stewards, an affiliate of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

The Port of New York Authority's negotiations with the Navy by which the authority had expected to open Floyd Bennett Field to commercial air traffic have become seriously deadlocked, it was learned yesterday.

After almost two years of intensive effort to combat the extension of public power, the electric light and power industry returns from Washington with a record of defeat. An ironic commentary on its activities and the frequent appearances of utility men before various House and Senate committees considering Federal agency requests for power appropriations, the 1948 fiscal budget contains more projects than have been granted to these Government power agencies in many peacetime years.

Americans Meet At Quitandinha Hotel near Rio de Janeiro last Friday the Foreign Ministers of twenty American republics gathered for the "Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Continental Peace and Security." The twenty-first republic -- Nicaragua -- was not invited.
Australia's reservation against inviting Negroes in its current quest for immigrants has been protested by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, it was learned yesterday.
TRIESTE. "SLAV Reds Incite New Violence," scream the headlines of the Italian press. "Italian Neo-Fascists Determined to Wreck Independence," the Slovene banner head retorts.
CHICAGO, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Profit-taking appeared today in the corn pit on the Board of Trade and prices slumped following an early run-up. Oats followed corn, but wheat held relatively steady.

PARIS. THE theatre has always been internationally minded; it is now internationally organized. During the torrid last week of July in Paris, theatre experts from fifteen countries hammered out a draft constitution for an International Theatre Institute and laid the groundwork for its immediate and long-range functioning.

NEW DELHI, Aug. 16 -- Has peace come at last to India? This was the question on everyone's lips, and asked inferentially by Lord Mountbatten and the Indian leaders themselves in public addresses, as this immense subcontinent of four hundred million people became free of British rule on Friday.

LONDON, Aug. 16 (Reuters) -- Difficult conditions prevailed in Lombard Street throughout the greater part of this week, with some borrowers having to seek assistance from the official buyer on several occasions although conditions did turn easier after the heavy payments for Treasury deposit receipts had been completed.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 16 (AP) -- The Browns crashed the run column for the first time in three games tonight, but dropped an 8-to-2 decision to Don Black and the Indians. Black limited St. Louis to seven hits and had a shut-out until the ninth.

FOR THIS WEEK: Plant autumn crocus and sternbergia as soon as they arrive for bloom within six weeks. Sternbergia are placed four inches deep, the crocus a little less.... Even though they have started to flower, pull out or cut down stray ragweed. This means less pollen to cause hayfever this year and fewer weed seedlings in 1948....

THE illusion that our time's problems are somehow solved if we know the formulae of the grand strategy of world history is comforting, and sometimes innocent. It may, however, be dangerous if in diminishing our sense of urgency it withers our sense of moral responsibility.

Prices are rising but industrial buyers will not increase the size of their orders to speculate upon inventory appreciation, purchasing spokesmen revealed here yesterday. Representative companies have renewed firm policy statements on this point during the past week and purchasing heads have cautioned their staff members against "over-buying" beyond immediate production needs in lines on which prices recently have been increased.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 16 -- The pennant hopes of the St. Louis Cardinals got a setback today as the seventh-place Pittsburgh Pirates smashed out seven home runs to defeat last year's world champions, 12 to 7, in a game that saw the major league home run record tied at 10.

The Middle Atlantic Regional Council of the National Association of Housing Officials yesterday announced a tentative program for its 1947 regional conference to be held here at the Hotel New Yorker on Sept. 11 and 12.

THIS is the first monograph on the Confederate States Steamer Shenandoah, and might well have been the last, since the essential facts about her are not in dispute, and all that is needed is a careful sifting of detail. To replace the raider Alabama, Confederate agents in England purchased a merchant vessel and commissioned her off Madeira in October, 1864, James I. Waddell, Captain.

ACCORDING to the record, about one million new homes were started in this country last year. Since it is not too comfortable to sleep on the floor or eat from the window sill, these homes will need furniture, "a million of everything." In millions of other homes, wobbly tables and creaking beds are crying to be replaced by something new. A lot of furniture!

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Willard L. Thorp, Assistant Secretary of State, and Maj. Gen. William H. Draper Jr., economic adviser to the United States Commander in Chief in Europe, told a radio audience tonight that more coal could be produced in the industrial heart of Germany only by giving the German workers more food.

KARLSBAD, Czechoslovakia, Aug. 16 -- Unqualified condemnation of Irgun Zvai Leumi terrorist tactics in Palestine by nearly every principal speaker marked the four-day meeting of the Conference of European Zionists that closed last night.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your editorial comment on the new Lincoln papers you say: "Among the collection is Lincoln's heavy-hearted farewell to his old friends at Springfield. It is as touching as Washington's farewell to his officers after the Revolution."

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 16 -- It's the same old story. An odds-on favorite bit the dust in the first running of the Travers Stakes at Saratoga in 1864; an odds-on favorite failed to make it in the mud in the seventy-eighth edition of the nation's oldest stakes race today.

Pulls Great Powers The peace that came to the world just two years ago last Thursday, when Japan capitulated, is troubled and darkened by the contest of power between Russia and America. Between these two superstates there are clashes over many vital problems -- the atomic bomb, Germany, plans for Europe's recovery, the Balkans.

MUELHEIM (By Wireless). SPRAWLING along the banks of the Ruhr River, which gives its name to one of the most heavily industrialized regions of Europe, lies the city of Muelheim. Like so many other large cities in Germany, it was badly mauled during the war.

BELLPORT, L.I., Aug. 16 -- In another of Great South Bay's whistling breezes, this one from the southeast and blowing seventeen knots, the Atlantic Coast championship of the Star Class sloops was concluded today.

BELLPORT, L.I., Aug. 16 -- In another of Great South Bay's whistling breezes, this one from the southeast and blowing seventeen knots, the Atlantic Coast championship of the Star Class sloops was concluded today.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 16 (AP) -- Four nights of yearling auctions have put an end to pessimistic predictions that the Saratoga sales would follow the trend in other parts of the country and drop off drastically from the 1946 highs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Issuance by the Congress of Industrial Organizations of a "1947 Voting Guide" was assailed today by Carroll Reece, chairman of the Republican National Committee, as "a typical piece of impudence," but he made no reference to a possible violation of the Taft-Hartley Labor-Management Act.

NEW YORKERS who yearn for deep-sea fishing need go no farther than Battery Park or Sixty-ninth Street and the Hudson River to find fishing boats which will take them on a day's trip on the Atlantic Ocean.

Winners of the fourth annual Donaldson awards, given by The Billboard on the basis of balloting by almost 3,000 workers in the theatre, were announced yesterday. "Finian's Rainbow" piled up six of the prizes, including the one for "best musical" of the 1946-47 season, and "All My Sons" was rated the "best play."

By 1965 three billion dollars will be required annually to finance the nation's program of higher education, or more than three times the amount now being spent, Dr. Thad L. Hungate of Tchers College, Columbia University, predicts in his comprehensive study on "Financing the Future of Higher Education."

BOSTON -- Harvest time in New England is fair time, and already the first of the 259 fairs listed on this year's agricultural calendar have opened to throngs that come to admire bumper crops, well-fattened and well-groomed cattle, and fancy homemade jellies.

Emetia Polizio, the 47-year-old Queens bookmaker who touched off the current investigation into graft in gambling, was back in police protective custody yesterday after having eluded a twenty-four-hour detective guard "to get a week's vacation."
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 16 -- On the same day that it became an independent state, the Moslem nation of Pakistan applied yesterday for admission into the United Nations, it was announced today.

FOR the first time in this country, passengers on moving railroad trains can now make telephone calls to and receive calls from any telephone connected with the Bell, System as well as with telephones in many foreign countries.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 16 -- To enable California lawyers to keep abreast of developments in such rapidly changing fields as taxation, labor-management and administrative agencies, as well as major branches of the law itself, the state bar and the University of California announced arrangements yesterday for extension classes starting this fall.

If the Act of Parliament that set India's two new dominions free had been followed by general rioting in every province, from the Bay of Bengal to the Arabian Sea and from the Himalayan foothills to Cape Comorin, it would still have been justified. There was a long history of bloody turbulence under the British Raj.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 16 (AP) -- A day-long series of heavy showers today jammed up the windup of the Newport Casino tennis tournament and set up an overloaded program for tomorrow.

Tenant groups, fearful of a breakdown in the administration of rent control as a result of the 20 per cent reduction in staff planned for Sept. 15, mapped a program yesterday under which tenants could undertake their own enforcement of the law by invoking a rarely used section of the state penal code.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- A proposal to merge Ohio's extensive surveying and mapping activities is being studied by government experts as a potential model plan for the whole country.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Having spent the past fifteen months preparing the prosecution and indictment of I.G. Farben officials in Nuremberg, I should like to reply to Helmer R. Johnson's letter in THE TIMES of Aug. 10.

CLARY sage is one of the least known members of the salvia family. Called clear eye and see bright, this salvia sclarea is one of the more beautiful of its genus and is frequently planted in herb gardens because of its long association with medicine and perfumery.

A new program in advanced study of American history, designed to train outstanding college teachers in the values of liberty and democracy, will begin next month in the Graduate School of the University of Rochester. The program will lead to the degree of Doctor of Philosophy in American History.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 16 --Just how much of a test the Congress of Industrial Organizations plans on the political action phase of the Taft-Hartley Act appeared to be answered in Pittsburgh this week.

ON April 23, 1851, the brig Quail, out of Auckland, New Zealand, burned and foundered far south of the Pacific sailing lanes. Seven survivors came ashore on an uninhabited island which looked "like a huge dog asprawl on the water."

DETROIT, Aug. 16 (AP) -- There will be some new model automobiles around the start of 1948 but many will be delayed until well into the year; it may be mid-year before all manufacturers have their next models on display; it will be even later before the supply catches up with the demand.
Members of the Financial Employes Guild, Local 96, CIO voted yesterday to end their month-old strike against the Brooklyn Trust Company and report for work at 9 A.M. tomorrow.

EZRA STILES, the president of Yale, after having been entertained by Thomas Jefferson, then near 40, jotted down in his diary: "* * * a most ingenious naturalist and philosopher, a truly scientific and learned man, and every way excellent" -- a judgment still shared by Americans after more than a century and a half.

If the proposed merger of the General Machinery Corporation of Hamilton, Ohio, with Lima Locomotive Works, Inc., of Lima, Ohio, is approved by stockholders of the respective companies, an important new manufacturer will enter the diesel locomotive field, which has been rapidly expanding in recent years.

VIENNA, Aug. 16 -- Guests in the Hotel Sacher, the principal British military hotel in Vienna, were warned about 10:30 last night that in a few minutes the hotel would be blown up. Several left for a few minutes and Austrian police searched the building thoroughly.

Despite sluggish response to retailers' coat, suit and fur offerings, market conditions were such as to necessitate the making of additional commitments for later delivery as protection in anticipation of good seasonal business, according to the weekly market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buyers.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16 -- The University of Chicago has started a five-year program of research training and education in race relations under a $150,000 grant from the Carnegie Corporation and the Rockefeller Foundation, Chancellor Robert M. Hutchins announced today.

"GAY," is a fly-specked label in the critic's hope-chest: "breezy" is another tag that covers a multitude of sins. Yet both have a place in summing up this featherweight frolic. Mr. Axelrod has chosen the time-worn stencil of the young married couple that hires out to the Gold Coast as cook and chauffeur -- but even the most captious reader must admit that he has told it gaily.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- America is heading into a new electric light and power crisis.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 16 -- Fourteen nations, led by the United States, handed the Soviet Union a one-sided defeat today in its fight against accepting the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and the International Monetary Fund as specialized agencies of the United Nations.

WHITEHAVEN, England, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Rescue squads dug fifty-four bodies from the William coal mine today. They speeded the search for fifty other miners, spurred by the survival of three men trapped more than twenty-one hours in the undersea shaft.

Aluminum, occupying an almost unique position as a commodity in plentiful supply and priced substantially below pre-war levels, is usurping many former markets for iron and steel in this metal-starved era, but the industry feels that it must do considerable probing for new techniques and cost-saving processes before aluminum can present broad and serious competition with iron and steel.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Howard Hughes' sensational charge against Senator Owen Brewster, Republican, of Maine, has revived the long-pending controversy over the desirability of a "chosen instrument" to carry the United States flag in international air commerce.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16 -- The Central West, center of some of the bitterest attacks upon the Truman Administration's foreign and domestic policies, was the scene this week of a development of national political significance. Gov. Dwight H. Green, who, with Col. Robert R. McCormick, editor and publisher of The Chicago Tribune, and Senator C. Wayland Brooks, dominates the Republican party in Illinois, was projected into the 1948 Presidential picture.

PRIMITIVE man has his devils, the ancients had their oracles, and mediums of our day have their spirits. For thousands of years this belief in the supernatural has persisted. With the advance of science it has been subjected to systematic investigation, notably by societies for psychical research of which the oldest is the British.

RETAILERS report that the one home appliance in ready supply is the freezer. Deliveries on it are fairly prompt, while refrigerators, dishwashers and stoves are onorder items. In fact, merchandisers ruefully admit that where freezers are concerned, they have almost more than they can sell.

LONDON, Aug. 16 -- Winston Churchill, Britain's wartime Prime Minister, warned his countrymen tonight that a lower standard of living", hunger and the dispersal or death of a large part of Britain's population were in prospect if the Labor Government remained in power.

Atoms for Peace Beneath the squash courts of Chisago University's Stadium on Dec. 2, 1942, atomic scientists started a self-sustaining nuclear chain reaction in a graphite-uranium pile. For the first time in history men had shown that they could produce atomic power for peacetime technical purposes (if the energy is released slowly) or for a bomb (if the energy is released rapidly).

LONDON, Aug. 16 -- Winston Churchill, Britain's wartime Prime Minister, warned his countrymen tonight that a lower standard of living", hunger and the dispersal or death of a large part of Britain's population were in prospect if the Labor Government remained in power.

Atoms for Peace Beneath the squash courts of Chisago University's Stadium on Dec. 2, 1942, atomic scientists started a self-sustaining nuclear chain reaction in a graphite-uranium pile. For the first time in history men had shown that they could produce atomic power for peacetime technical purposes (if the energy is released slowly) or for a bomb (if the energy is released rapidly).
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Ambassador George Atcheson Jr., who is missing at sea west of Hawaii, was flying to Washington for conferences expected eventually to lead to a treaty of peace with Japan.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17 -- Pottery manufacturers concluded a twoweek showing of their wares here, reporting an "encouraging" buyer reaction for fall and holiday merchandise, but the outlook for the industry after the first of next year is uncertain, manufacturers and trade authorities said today.

A forty-eight-inch water main burst at 10:10 A.M. yesterday under the pavement at Eightyfifth Street near the corner of Central Park West and sent torrents of water cascading through four city blocks for more than two hours.
PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 17 (AP) -- Charles Congdon of Tacoma, Wash., won the $10,000 Portland Open golf tournament today with a 72-hole score of 270.

Nat Applebaum has been appointed assistant vice president of National Department Stores Management and Buying Corporation, in addition to his other duties. Burt Strouse has joined the company in charge of major appliances, traffic appliances, radios, phonographs and housewares.
LONDON, Aug. 17 -- A full-dress special meeting of Britain's Cabinet was held this evening. The purpose of the extraordinary session had the entire nation speculating.

SALONIKA, Greece, Aug. 17 -- The proclamation by the guerrilla chief, Markos Vafthiades, that his newly dubbed National Army was assuming governmental power in guerrilla territory was laughed off rather nervously today in official circles of this center of northern Greece.

A tenant who had quarreled for a long time with his renting agent was found dead by police yesterday afternoon in his apartment at 1754 Bathgate Avenue, Bronx, and last night the agent was booked on a charge of homicide. One of the causes of the quarrel was a difference of a dollar in the tenant's rent.

AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Kenny Holmboe, aged 15, of Charleston, W. Va., won the annual soap box derby before about 100,000 persons today, finishing a halflength in front of his nearest competitor, Eugene Miller, 14, of Akron.

HONOLULU, Aug. 17 (AP) -- A corporal and two privates first class stationed at a lonely radar station atop a western Oahu peak were highly praised by veteran pilots today for their skill in directing the vast, night-time aerial search for George Atcheson Jr. and others aboard the B-17 which crash-landed at sea to the west of this island.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 17 -- A sixth ship, the Navajo Victory, was tied up here yesterday in the thirty-seven-day-old strike of walking bosses against the Luckenbach Steamship Company.

BOSTON, Aug. 17 -- President Truman declared today that the United States had the greatest opportunity in its history to show that the practice of real democracy was the only practical method by which lasting world peace and prosperity might be secured and maintained.

Election of ten new members to the National Committee for Mental Hygiene was announced yesterday by Dr. George S. Stevenson, medical director, at national headquarters, 1790 Broadway. The three women and seven men elected have "given distinguished service in the field of mental health," the announcement declared.

The people of the world are sick of the "double-talk and weasel words" of politicians and want leaders who can see beyond the narrow horizon to a better world, the Right Rev. William. R. Moody, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Lexington, Ky., declared yesterday in a sermon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

One of the biggest gripes of Army and Navy enlisted men during and since the war was that there were two different standards of justice. There was one for the enlisted man. There was another for the officer. Two recent Navy courts-martial lend credence to that complaint.

One of the victims of the First World War was young Dr. H.G.J. Moseley, a Cambridge physicist who related the place-numbers of elements in the periodic table to the number of particles in their atomic structure. Had he not been killed at Gallipoli, at the age of twenty-eight, he would probably have won the Nobel Prize.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The United States has again expressed its strong disapproval of the policies of the Communist-dominated Government of Hungary. Today's action was in the form of a public statement by the Department accusing the Hungarian regime of attempting to fix the coming elections by disqualifying a million voters of the opposition.

MOSCOW, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The Soviet press and radio have been assailing for two days the current inter-American conference in Brazil as an attempt to impose the "military-political supremacy of the United States on the whole western hemisphere."

CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., Aug. 17 -- After six rounds of the tournament for the open championship of the United States Chess Federation at the White-Plaza Hotel, only five of the original eighty-six entries remain undefeated. Chief of these are Isaac I. Kashdan and George Kramer of New York tied for first place with totals of 5 1/2 -- 1/2.

SOUTHINGTON, Conn., Aug. 17 -- In 1902, when he was 7 years old, Ralph H. Powers jumped into a new Oldsmobile, grasped the steering tiller and bumped over several miles of the College Highway near this town.

Few persons will argue today, probably, that advertising has failed to make its case from the standpoint of economics. But that institution still has a number of social crimes and misdemeanors to answer for when it appears before the final bar of opinion which somewhere awaits it.

America's freedom and greatness have been formed on the "building stones" of a free Protestant Church the public school system and the American home, the Rev. Dr. Chester Sillars of the Christian Church in Danbury, Conn., declared yesterday at the morning service of the Park Avenue Christian Church, Park Avenue at Eighty-fifth-Street.

PEARL HARBOR, Aug. 17 (AP) -- George Atcheson Jr. sat quietly with a smile for his companions as their B-17 plunged into the sea last night west of Oahu, a survivor reported today in a radio interview from the rescue destroyer Rowan.

HONOLULU, Aug. 17 -- An Army B-17 plane bound from Tokyo to Washington made an emergency landing in rough seas west of Honolulu a little before nidnight last night and at least six of the thirteen aboard are dead. Three have been rescued.

A major new manufacturing industry for New York City is seen as a result of development of motor truck engine, now perfected after two years of intensive engineering and tests, Z. Arkus-Duntov, president of the Ardun Mechanical Corporation.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The Government will begin tomorrow its long-delayed investigation of the loyalty of more than 2,000,000 Federal employes.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The Cardinals gained ground in the hot National League pennant fight today as they beat the Pirates 6 to 5, in the first game of a doubleheader and then fought to a 0-0 tie in the nightcap that was called in the second half of the fifth because of wet grounds.

City Councilman Stanley M. Isaacs of Manhattan declared yesterday that the city's housing program had failed to make real progress "because some individuals in authority and of great influence, foremost among them Construction Coordinator Robert Moses, have never visualized the magnitude of the problem but have proposed limited programs when we are up against practically unlimited needs."

After Miss Doris Hart's threeset victory over Mrs. Betty Hilton in the first singles engagement had officially retained the Wightman Cup, the United States went on to sweep the last three matches and complete a 7-0 triumph over Great Britain's women's team at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (U.P.) -- Robert N. Denham, general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board, stated today that he had no choice but to refuse legal recognition to local unions if a single officer of their parent organization failed to sign an affidavit denying Communist ties.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Aug. 17 (AP) -- Tony Bettenhausen of Tinley Park, Ill., continued his mastery of the kite-shaped Goshen mile track today as he won the A.A.A. George Riobson Memorial 100-mile auto race for the second straight year before a crowd of approximately 16,500.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The White Sox and Tigers split a doubleheader today, Chicago winning the first game, 1 to 0, on Taft Wright's eighth-inning home run, and Detroit taking the nightcap, 4 to 3, by scoring all its runs in the fourth inning.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The subject of tax deductions based upon "entertainment expense" has received attention off and on for years. Without attempting to discuss all the aspects of the subject, I should like to make some observations on just one phase of it -- entertainment of Federal Government officials.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 17 -- Long Island Sound's surface today was no place for man or fish, yet 52 sailing craft competed in the regatta of the Huguenot Yacht Club, and of all things, two Snipes.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 17 (AP) -- A three-run uprising in the fifth inning by the Cleveland Indians gave them the margin needed to beat the St. Louis Browns, 4 to 3, in the second game of a double-header today after Paul Lehner pulled the first contest out of the fire for St. Louis, 7 to 6, with a three-run ninth-inning home run.

Joseph Philips, 32-year-old Bronx bookmaker, whose charges that the police demanded money for protection set off a grand jury investigation in that borough, was arrested yesterday as a material witness. The police charged that he attempted to leave the city to visit his wife and child, who are vacationing at Monticello, N.Y.

The bitter taste of defeat came yesterday to Vic Raschi for the first time since the Yankees called him back from Portland to help in the pennant drive. But there was no disgrace attached to the setback, after six uninterrupted triumphs, even though it delayed the mathematical clinching of the American League flag by Bucky Harris' troupe.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 17 -- Playing under leaden skies and on a heavy field, Alan Corey led his Long Island four to a 12-4 triumph over Pete Bostwick's Bostwick Field team, at Bostwick Field today. The threatening weather held the attendance down to 1,200 fans.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 17 -- In the early hours this morning, wearied United Nations delegates put the finishing touches on their work and wound up the fifth session of the Economic and Social Council.

LONDON, Aug. 17 -- Although bear covering toward the close of account gave the stock markets a steady appearance at the weekend, there were times in the last week when the markets were in an almost demoralized condition. This was particularly the case last Wednesday, when the break was the severest since the initial relapse caused by news of the British economic crisis little more than a fortnight ago.

The West Side Savings Bank sold the six-story apartment house on a lot 26 by 100 feet at 230 Clinton Street to the Stonemore Realty Corporation in a deal negotiated by Winston Schapiro, Inc., and the Harris Management Company.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The general index of basic commodity prices based on the August, 1939, level declined from 308 on Aug. 8 to 305.5 on Aug. 15, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. The following lists daily index numbers and spot market prices:

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 17 -- Pennsylvania's Sunday baseball curfew turned the second game of the Dodgers' double-header with the Phillies today into a travesty and the contest ended in a 4-4 tie. After the Brooks had notched their fifth run in the top of the seventh inning, the score reverted to the sixth.

WHEN Omar Khayyam more than 800 years ago wrote: "Myself when young did eagerly frequent Doctor and saint, and heard great argument About it and about: but evermore Came out by the same door where in I went" he was referring to religious and metaphysical speculation.

The continuing grocery store audit of the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association, is operating in seven cities, the Bureau disclosed over the week-end, and sixteen other cities are awaiting establishment of the audit system.

Green peppers being one of the many abundant fresh, vegetables at the moment, the following group of TIMES-tested recipes is offered. These should help in taking advantage of the current fine quality and reasonable cost. Suggestions for serving the food hot, cold and in the guise of homemade pickles are included.

Cargo-handling by overhead crane gear, while in many respects inferior to the more standard method of loading by boom gear, is reaching that stage of development where it can be called a success, according to a technical paper released yesterday by the Alumni Association of the United States Merchant Marine Cadet Corps.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 17 -- The Prime Ministers of India and Pakistan conferred today on joint steps to end the disturbances in the Punjab. At Lahore and the nearby Sikh holy city of Amritsar they are reported to have approached the great Calcutta riots of a year ago in seriousness.

NANKING, Aug. 17 (U.P.) -- Chinese Government troops under the personal orders of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek have launched a new three-pronged attack with air and armored support to clear Communist forces from the TsinanTsingtao area, a semi-official spokesman said today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17 -- The lard market was unsettled last week, the near-by deliveries acting heavy as the result of scattered liquidation and rapidly accumulating stocks, while the distant months were strong on prospects that a radical reduction of export allocations would be made by the Department of Agriculture.

PARIS, Aug. 17 -- Premier Paul Ramadier, Leon Blum and other moderates of the French Socialist party were placed in a minority when the party congress at Lyon today adopted a general policy report submitted by Guy Mollet, the party's general secretary and leader of the Left Wing.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 17 (AP) -- After winning the Newport Casino Singles tennis competition in brilliant fashion against Bill Talbert of Wilmington, Del., Ted Schroeder of Glendale, Calif., tired while teamed with Jack Kramer of Los Angeles and those Davis Cup stars surrendered their doubles honors to Gardnar Mulloy of Coral Gables, Fla., and Frank Parker of Los Angeles.
DALLAS, Tex., Aug. 17 (AP) -- Thirteen hundred members of the Little Below the Knee Club, an organized revolt against new long skirts, will hold that hem line in the Southwest this winter.

An estimated $110,000,000 worth of public and private monuments, more than ever before, are being built in America, according to Leonard H. Braun, Lansing, Mich., president of the Monument Builders of America. Mr. Braun will speak today at the forty-first annual convention of the monument industry, sponsored by the Monument Builders of America and the American Monument Association, which began yesterday at the Hotel New Yorker and will continue through Wednesday.

ZURICH, Aug. 17 -- "By the end of 1948 the railways of western Europe will be able to carry the same quantity of goods and the same number of passengers as were transported in 1938, provided the present obstacles are removed," was the conclusion reached last week by traffic experts from sixteen countries, assembled in Paris to compute what help Europe would need under the Marshall Plan.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 17 -- The unusual range of weather conditions in the great Midwestern Corn Belt has imparted a new importance today to the golden grain because it holds the key to food supplies for the next year.

Several weeks ago, with no little fanfare, Irene M. Selznick sent word from the Coast that she was "finally in a position to announce" the signing of John Garfield for the leading male role in Tennessee Williams' "A Streetcar Named Desire."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The Athletics took both ends of a double-header with the Senators today, thus sweeping a four-game series and extending the Senators' losing streak to seven.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 17 -- As the flames of rioting in Palestine were flickering out today, one more Arab was stabbed to death in Tel Aviv. A Jewish girl was slightly hurt when someone fired on a bus outside Tel Aviv.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 17 (AP) -- Staving off a late rally, 23-year-old Jack Lyons of Garden City captured the twelfth annual Maidstone Bowl invitation golf tournament today by defeating Fred Kammer of Detroit, 2 and 1, in the 18-hole final over the 6,402yard course at the Maidstone Club.

More than $2,000,000 in maritime fittings, kitchen and dining equipment are included in the $135,000,000 original cost listings of surplus items offered in more than 100 sales programs of the War Assets Administration, Carl P. Malmstrom, regional director, revealed over the week-end.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The Federal Trade Commission today charged the American steel industry with illegal price-fixing and restraint of competition.

Changing weather conditions in the Cotton Belt last week accounted for irregular price fluctuations in the local cotton futures market. At the end of trading or Friday active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were mixed, 15 points lower to 19 points higher than the week before.

IF Theodore Samuel Williams is at all gloomy, despondent or discouraged by his failure to send his current batting average up in the hitting stratosphere, he shows no signs of it. His disposition seems as cheerful as ever and he still laughs constantly, which is a rather surprising situation because Master Williams had been known to sulk in other years after only one hitless day.

Reorders on fur-trimmed and untrimmed coats highlighted a generally quiet week, in which a fair number of buyers visited the wholesale markets, according to the market reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices In the men's and boys' wear market purchasing was greater than during many of the past weeks.
BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 17 -- Men and women tennis players from a dozen nations will start out tomorrow in the national doubles championships at the Longwood Cricket Club.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- A House Subcommittee on Small Business will begin a country-wide investigation of consumer cooperatives here next Friday with a study of cooperative enterprises at nearby Greenbelt, Md., an early New Deal public housing project.
Port officials who clear steamship passengers entering New York from overseas will have their busiest day since before the war when 4,439 travelers reach here today on fourteen ships.

Patrolman Thomas J. Gargan of the Charles Street station, a holder of the Police Department Combat Medal, was shot fatally shortly after 10 o'clock last night by a burglar whom he surprised in a dark unoccupied attic studio apartment at 132 Bank Street, in Greenwich Village.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: This is in reference to your editorial of Aug. 8, entitled "The New Totalitarians," which seems to imply that the small nations of Eastern Europe have chosen their present oppressors and are responsible for conditions existing there.

Madison Square Garden, inside and out, was taken over yesterday by a segment of the New York Fire Department for the dress rehearsal of "The Midnight Alarm," the department show benefiting its welfare fund. Opening tonight, five performances will be given, with matinees as well as evening showings tomorrow and Wednesday.

ALBANY, Aug. 17 -- The State Department of Education announced today the winners of 827 university scholarships, valued at $1,157,800. The awards, which entitle each holder to $1,400 for tuition at any regents-approved college in the state, are granted in each county on the basis of the number of Assembly districts.
YONKERS, N.Y., Aug, 17 -- Suburbanites hereabouts will be surprised to learn of the infiltration of wildlife -- hawks, opossums, raccoons and foxes -- into their otherwise domesticated domain.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Aug. 17 -- Chanteyman, owned and skippered by Edward Raymond of the New York Yacht Club, today won the ninth annual race for the August Heckscher trophy, an overnight event for Class A cruising yachts, sponsored by the Huntington Yacht Club.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Aug. 17 (AP) -- A swelling stream of political refugees, pouring into Turkey by land, sea and air, were receiving increasing attention today.

Most of our post-war problems can be traced to "a woeful lack of neighborliness among the peoples of the world," the Rev. William T. Greene of the St. Patrick's Cathedral staff declared, yesterday in a sermon at the 10 o'clock mass.
In a pitched battle on a wet, sloping roof sixty feet above ground three detectives Captured two burglary suspects early yesterday.
BATAVIA, Java, Aug. 17 (U.P.) -- The Indonesian Republic today rejected for the second time the United States' offer to mediate in its war with the Dutch.

The airlines have deferred hope for the development of all-weather flying for another year. Frustrated by cuts in funds allowed by Congress for instrument-landing systems, ground control approach and high intensity lights in numbers sufficient to provide real service tests this winter, they are pinning their hopes on agreement by the members of the Air Coordinating Committee as a result of a series of studies and meetings that end in Washington this week.

BERLIN, Aug. 17 - Part of about $4,000,000 worth of Nazi loot, comprising precious stones, rugs, antiques and even the gold fillings taken from the teeth of concentration camp victims shortly will go on public sale in the United States, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- A penetrating and comprehensive analysis of Great Britain's economic crisis will get under way swiftly tomorrow. Then leading fiscal officials of that country and the United States will begin a joint study of ways to modify the terms of the loan to Britain.

A sharp decline in the quantity of meats, prepared and otherwise, brought in by immigrants and shipped from the Mediterranean area, was reported yesterday by the Bureau of Animal Industry, a division of the Department of Agriculture.

The American mission is just settled in Athens. The American representative in the Security Council has warned the members that the United States may have to act if the United Nations does not move to stop aggression against Greece. In London, Washington and Paris, committees are in session drawing up plans for the economic organization of Western Europe.

NEW DELHI, Aug. 17 (Reuters) -- Under the commission's award Lahore, fifth city of India with a population of 671,659, goes to Pakistan. Nanakana Sahib, holy shrine of the Sikhs in the Moslem majority Shekhupura district, to which the Sikhs nave been laying very strong claim, also will belong to Pakistan.

The planning committee of the Citizens Budget Commission announced yesterday that it had notified Mayor O'Dwyer in an interim report that its survey of five key city departments has progressed to the point where "it is already clear that significant recommendations for economy and efficiency will be made."

BERLIN, Aug. 17 -- The United States system of denazification was formally adopted by the Soviet Millitary Administration in an order published today. This decree granted complete amnesty to all but the biggest Nazis and abolished all Soviet occupation laws to the contrary.

GENEVA, Aug. 17 -- The United States has made it clear to the European countries interested in the Marshall proposal that a definite project for a customs union is one essential condition for further large-scale United States aid, according to unimpeachable sources of several nationalities in Geneva.
VIENNA, Aug. 17 -- The Soviet Union's official political voice in Austria, the Army newspaper Oesterreichische Zeitung, began to discuss the "economic division" of Austria today.

Murky skies, intermittent drizzle and low temperatures kept New Yorkers close to home yesterday. Beaches reported the smallest turnout of the summer season to date and concessionaires, estimating trade on the basis of Friday's record heat of 93.6 degrees, had almost full larders at nightfall.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17 -- Unfavorable weather conditions last spring and this summer have taken a heavy toll in the production of coarse grain in North America, according to estimates on the crops and the carryover from previous seasons issued by the Department of Agriculture and the Dominion Bureau of Statistics.
TOKYO, Monday, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Occupation headquarters announced today that there were five passengers and eight crew members on the Atcheson plane.

BOSTON, Aug. 17 -- With wind and tides still against them, Mel Ott's Giants drifted further into a sea of despondency today as the Braves made off with both ends of the afternoon's double-header to score a clean sweep of the fourgame series before 32,804 admiring onlookers.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Ted Smith of Buffalo, N.Y., 1945 national titleholder, won a 25-mile point race today to capture his second senior men's national amateur bicycle championship by one point.

A survey of leading advertising agencies preparing fall presentations of campaigns to their clients shows that manufacturers are cautious as to duration of the campaigns. Space purchases and contracts in many cases have been held to thirteen weeks, from previous longer periods.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- For the "lost" children of Europe, who seemingly have no future in official programs for displaced persons, plans for a "stateless children's sanctuary" on the Island of Nevis, in the British West Indies, and birthplace of Alexander Hamilton, have been developed here.

The harassed Giants are coming home tonight to strange pastures which will offer a respite from the thorny road they have been traveling in the National League pennant strife. Mel Ott will lead his Polo Grounders onto the field at the Stadium in the Bronx for the second skirmish against the Yankees in the intra-city series arranged in the interests of charity.

The United States and Great Britain cannot hope to accomplish anything definite by their joint protest to Hungary on its current purge of the national electoral lists to guarantee an airtight Communist dictatorship. Their appeal to Lajos Dinnyes, Communistsponsored Premier, to correct these abuses is like asking King Log to get up and walk.

Prices of pipe, valves and fittings have changed at such varying dates, and varied amounts, industrial purchasing executives revealed last week, that considerable confusion has existed in pricing of resale shipments by some whole sale distributors.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Measured in currently inflated dollars, the value of national production of goods and services reached a new peak during the second quarter, but in terms of physical volume the rate of production remained below wartime levels, the Department of Commerce reported tonight.

George Atcheson Jr. was a career diplomat with more than twenty years of experience in Far Eastern affairs. Born in Denver, Oct. 20, 1896, Mr. Atcheson attended the Fremont High School in Oakland, Calif., before entering the University of California at Berkeley.

Two Brooklyn residents, Raymond Biechele, 30 years old, and Miss Jean Graye, 20, spent eighteen hours tossing about the Atlantic Ocean in a sixteen-foot motor boat until they finally were picked up at 1 P.M. yesterday. They were rescued after their boat cracked up on a jetty, 200 yards north of the Monmouth Beach Lifeboat Station in New Jersey.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 17 -- Seymour Nebenzal and Charles R. Rogers have joined forces to produce three pictures in Technicolor, the first of which will be "Queen of Hearts," a projected vehicle for Maria Montez based on "Cousin From Warsaw," a French comedy by Louis Verneuil, first filmed in Paris in 1923.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Reds took a doubleheader from the Chicago Cubs before 22,310 fans here today, winning the first, 2 -- 0, as Grady Hatton's thirteenth homer with a team-mate on base gave Ewell Blackwell his nineteenth victory of the season, and the second, 11 -- 3, as the Reds smashed out nineteen hits.
ATHENS, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Greek Government informants asserted today, as fighting spread in the Albanian border area, that General Markos now had his guerrilla headquarters at Argyrokastron, Albania.

Our City's Own White House Our city White House, which became the Mayor's official residence in the reign of the Little Flower, sits, as we all know, in a park on Horn's Hook and commands a pleasing prospect of the East River and the turbulent currents of Hell Gate.

The widening space between "the perhaps unrealistic wants of teenagers and available job opportunities" has prompted formation of a special committee to study the employment problems of young people, Mrs. Beardsley Ruml, president of the Vocational Advisory Service, 95 Madison Avenue, announced yesterday.
