CLEVELAND, Aug. 17 -- N.R. Howard, president of the American Society of Newspaper Editors, told the convention of the International Typographical Union, AFL, today that expanded production would help, not hurt, the printing crafts.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 17 -- Ray Billows of Dutchess added a fifth victory in the Jess Sweetser Victory Cup tournament to his half-dozen Empire State titles and sundry other laurels today at the Knollwood Country Club. He defeated Fred Fiore of the home club by two strokes in the first playoff in the history of the 21-year-old event.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Secretary of the Treasury Snyder tonight announced plans for a refunding of $6,735,000,000 of the national debt, offering most of the new Government obligations at lower interest rates than those maturing.

The controversy between the Port Authority and the Navy that has kept commercial traffic out of Floyd Bennett Field in Brooklyn narrowed down yesterday to a $450,000 question of price. The Navy is asking $1,200,000 to transfer its facilities and the Port Authority is standing by its statement that it could not spend more than $750,000 for that purpose.

PETROPOLIS, Brazil, Aug. 17 -- The first of the completed drafts of the projected Treaty of Rio de Janeiro, that submitted by Bolivia, was made public today in the InterAmerican Defense Conference. The conference resumes its sittings tomorrow.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 17 (AP) -- A Soviet squeeze for Iranian oil appeared to be tightening today as the Iranian Parliament accelerated its organization, presumably for early consideration of the sixteen- month-old Soviet oil agreement. Some diplomats predicted "decisive government action, within the next forty-eight hours."

The appointment of Nevil Ford, vice president of the First Boston Corporation, as general chairman of the $15,575,000 campaign for the New York University-Bellevue Hospital Medical Center was announced yesterday by Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, Chancellor of New York University.

MARIENBAD, Czechoslovakia, Aug. 17 -- The first world conference of the Agudath Israel Youth decided here today to establish a central office in Europe to coordinate and strengthen the Jewish youth movement. Branch offices will be set up in several countries.

The appointment by Governor Dewey of the two additional members of the Board of Parole in the New York State Division of Parole, authorized by the recent act of the Legislature, is another step in the direction of a better understanding of the offender. Each member of the new five-man Board will be able to devote considerably more time to the study of individual cases than was possible with an overworked three-man Board.

Crime and mystery shows dominate the list of the most popular programs of the moment, according to the fortnightly Hooper audience survey, out today. The programs devoted in one form or another to the thrill and to the chill took seven of the first ten places, the only non-homicidal items being "Take It Or Leave It." Arthur Godfrey's "Talent Scouts" and "Your Hit Parade."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The British air transport and manufacturing industries are so handicapped in their development today that no effective challenge by that country to United States supremacy in international air transport is likely before 1952 at the earliest, according to Government sources here.
NANKING, Aug. 17 -- A new foreign exchange policy, announced here today, permits the purchase and sale of foreign exchange by importers and exporters at the open market rate.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $51,546,863,220. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 17 -- Prices of heavy melting scrap metal broke $3 here last week, dropping from the year's high mark of $43 a gross ton to a top delivered price of $40. This reversal of the rising trend in one of the industry's principal raw materials was the best news of the week to steel companies.

MANILA, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Public outcry against resuming trade with Japan had become so strong today that the Philippine Government feared it might be unable to market a quantity of cotton cloth recently bought from the late enemy, even though, textiles are badly needed in these islands.

The full name of the meeting of Latin-American countries at Petropolis, near Rio de Janeiro, is the InterAmerican Conference on the Maintenance of Peace and Security. That title could cover almost any subject of inter-American relations that any delegate wanted to bring up.
TOKYO, Aug. 17 (U.P.) -- W. MacMahon Ball, the-British Commonwealth representative on the Allied Control Council for Japan, announced his resignation today.

ROME, Aug. 17 -- The daily press has made a spectacular comeback in Europe but unfortunately what has come back is nothing new or hopeful but something astonishingly like the same old hodgepodge of squabbling political journals of opinion.

BERLIN, Aug. 18 -- A working alliance has been formed between the Niemoeller wing of the Evangelical Church and the leadership of the Social Democratic party for the dual purpose of reducing the influence of the Vatican in German politics and splitting the Christian Democratic Union, which includes both Catholics and Protestants.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is to be hoped that the embittered passions which swept Britain and the British community in Palestine recently in connection with the brutal revenge wreaked by the Irgun against the two British sergeants will not becloud the fate of the 4,500 hapless refugees on the Exodus 1947.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Aug. 18 (U.P.) -- A squad of touring American track and field athletes won all but three events of the fourteen held today in an international track meet at Brnos National Stadium before 10,000 spectators.
LONDON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Princess Elizabeth, cast by her country's troubles in the role of a "poor little rich girl," will lose the heart's desire of every bride-to-be -- a new trousseau.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Members of the Joint Congressional Committee, "watch-dog" of the Taft-Hartley Labor-Management Relations Act, differ with the interpretation of the anti-Communist section of the law as stated by Robert N. Denham, general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board.

PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 18 -- A dream of a home of his own where he could lead a useful life buoyed the hopes of Johnny Chiefa, Paterson war veteran, after physicians told him in 1945 that he would never walk again.

Firm prices and "fair to good" buying activity was reported yesterday at the National Toy Show being held at the New Yorker Hotel. The show, under the direction of Eugene A. Richardson Associates, had a registration of approximately 1,000 buyers through yesterday and Sunday when it opened. The event closes tomorrow night.

A new formula for settling the two-year-old jurisdictional dispute that has blocked installation of vital communications equipment at Idlewild Airport was put forward last night by the United Telephone Organizations.

MUNICH, Aug. 18 -- A challenge by the defense as to the impartiality of two members of the Dachau military tribunal to sit in judgment brought the trial of Otto Skorzeny and nine associates to a short halt this afternoon.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Aug. 18 (Reuters) -- Field Marshal Jan Christiaan Smuts, South African Premier, has rejected proposals made by Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, Prime Minister of the Dominion of Indian, for the resumption of relations between the two countries.

MADRID, Tuesday, Aug. 19 (Reuters) -- The roads leading from Cadiz were filled with people fleeing from the town early this morning. Many fires have broken out in the city and authorities have forbidden access to the city except to doctors, nurses and firefighters.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I should like to endorse Julius Lichtenfeld's refutation of Dr. Roger Lee's thesis that it is unwise, if not actually dangerous, for a person to retire on reaching the age of 60 or 65. I find, as does Dr. Lichtenfeld, that "I have less time since I retired than before" for doing things that keep me well and contented.

GLEN GARDNER, N.J., Aug. 18 -- The locomotive of an eas bound freight train of fifty-tv cars crashed into the rear of stalled freight train with 158 ca east of this station early this afternoon, tying up the two-track main line of the Central Railroad of New Jersey.

The election of Miss Sally Butler of Indianapolis as president of the International Federation of Business and Professional Women in Paris last month amounted to a ''draft," Miss Butler said yesterday. The executive committee felt that an American must have the post to keep the federation outside the turmoil of European politics, she revealed.

Scrap Down Again Prices of steel scrap in Pittsburgh declined an additional $2 a ton yesterday. This brings the quotation to $38 a ton, still deemed exorbitant by most of the major consumers, but $7 a ton below the record high level reached here less than two weeks ago.
The travesty on major league baseball that was perpetrated in Philadelphia in the second DodgersPhils game on Sunday afternoon has been erased by President Ford Frick of the National League.
LONDON, Aug. 18 -- South African gold shares were the feature of a more cheerful stock markets here today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- The United Nations Children's Emergency Fund will seek to collect $15,000,000 from the LatinAmerican members of the United Nations to help supply supplementary milk and food to undernourished children in Europe and Asia.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 18 -- A Canadian and an American company filed registration statements with the Securities and Exchange Commission today covering $40,000,000 of bonds, 100,000 shares of cumulative preferred stock and 700,000 of common stock.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18 -- Continued hot and dry weather over the Midwest and non-appearance of anticipated showers led to a rush of corn futures buying at the opening of trading today, with all deliveries except December soaring the 8-cent daily limit.

CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., Aug. 18 -- Defeating two of his most dangerous opponents, in the seventh and eighth rounds, respectively, Isaac I. Kashdan of New York today moved away from the field in the annual tournament for the open championship of the United States Chess Federation at the Hotel White Plaza.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 18 -- When the New York Yankees and the Buffalo Bills officially launch the 1947 campaign of the AllAmerica Football Conference at Buffalo on Aug. 31, both teams will know what to expect. They crossed paths on the gridiron at Ruppert Stadium tonight in an exhibition contest that resulted in a 29-7 victory for the Yankees, who last season won the Eastern division championship in the newly formed circuit.

PARIS, Aug. 18 -- The Jewish refugees aboard the ship Empire Rival, one of three British transports off Port-de-Bouc with about 4,500 visaless immigrants to Palestine who had been brought back after their ship, the Exodus 1947, had been intercepted by the British Navy, announced this morning that they were starting a hunger strike.
PETROPOLIS, Brazil, Aug. 18 -- Cuba this afternoon laid down her expected challenge to the United States on the issue of economic aggression.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 18 -- The American Federation of Labor was sharply criticized today by counsel for the House labor subcommittee that is investigating the Hollywood AFL jurisdictional strike. The AFL was described as "lacking either in moral fiber or in its constitutional by-laws."

The United States Treasury's decision to raise the interest rate for one-year money from 7/8 per cent to 1 per cent may tend to push upward the commercial bank rate on customers loans, financial observers asserted yesterday. Although disappointed over the "leanness" of the rate advance, objective observers conceded that the Treasury must necessarily move cautiously, and that the action is constructive, since it permits a "break-through" of the current 7/8% per cent rate.

The second annual exchange of teachers between the United States and Great Britain got under way yesterday afternoon as 125 American elementary and high school teachers sailed for England aboard the Marine Tiger.

A ten-ton trailer truck, its air brakes useless, went on a wild, three-block ride in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon, with resultant injuries to four persons and damage to two other trucks and two automobiles.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug 18 -- President Juan D. Peron will address the nation by radio four times this week, beginning Wednesday. The Subsecretariat of Information in an official notice today said that the series would deal with "the gradual destruction that is being carried on by those who are trying to change the order in our country."

Early pressure against the steel section developed into sympathetic action in other key divisions yesterday on the stock market. Declines in some important pivotal shares ranged to a point while the composite rate declined 0.31 points on the day.

PARIS, Aug. 18 -- Socialist party directives demanding revision of a Cabinet agreement will endanger Premier Paul Ramadier's Government in the debate on a statute for Algeria that begins tomorrow at a special session, of the National Assembly.

GENEVA, Aug. 18 -- William L. Clayton, United States UnderSecretary of State for Economic Affairs, will go to London tomorrow or Wednesday for what Geneva trade conference sources describe as showdown talks with the British on imperial preference tariffs.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock market here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 6,500 head, total 9,000: moderately active two-way market: butchers under 240 pounds 25 cents lower; heavier weights and sows generally 25 cents higher; some sales
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The editorial of THE NEW YORK TIMES entitled "Again Russian No" was timely.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- Westchester's long-anticipated and often-delayed toll collections on the Saw Mill River Parkway will begin at 11:59 P.M. on Aug, 27, county officials felt certain tonight. Fearing some last-minute delay, they announced the date merely as "during the week of Aug. 24," but confidential orders to employes fixed the specific date.

Celanese Corporation of America, for the first six months of this year, had a net income of $11,033,445, according to the report mailed yesterday to stockholders by Harold Blancke, president. This is equivalent to $1.72 a share on the common stock, after dividend requirements on the preferred stock, and compares with a net income of $7,444,403, or $1.07 a common share in the same period of 1946.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 18 (AP) -- Frank Boswell, state prison director, said today that fourteen convicts had been flogged at state penal institutions since Aug 1. Hereafter, he added, he would make a public report each month on the number whipped and the reasons.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Washington defeated the Phillies, 3 -- 0, today in an exhibition baseball game, with all proceeds from the crowd of 3,200 being donated to the Damon Runyon Memorial Cancer Fund.

Because steel fabricating plants here can successfully compete against such distant points as West Coast shops in the manufacture of steel tanks and large sizes of pipe, Crown Tank Corporation will build a new plant capable of expanding its production by $2,000,000, V.E. Irvine, president, disclosed here yesterday.
The Navy and the Port of New York Authority remained deadlocked yesterday over the expenses involved in preparing for the civil use of Floyd Bennett Field.

Three weeks and five days ago the Netherlands Indies Government broke off relations with the Republic of Indonesia over the form and extent of authority of the interim government that was to be set up pending the grant of full self-government to the Republic a year and a half hence.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Aug. 18 (U.P.) -- The Dominican Government asked today that an international commission investigate its charge that armed Communists plan to invade the republic from Cuba. It is assumed the request will be brought before the Inter-American Conference in Brazil.

THERE probably isn't a more overworked phrase in baseball than that of "crucial" (pronounced "crooshial") series. But the current one at Ebbets Field fills the description with pungent exactitude. The Dodgers and the Cards are playing for high stakes these days, the pennant itself -- along with that cut of the world series loot which makes victory all the more palatable.

Mrs. Wilbur P. Harris of Harrisburg, Pa., leaves today, her seventyfourth birthday, on a flight to Europe -- her birthday present to herself. She plans to see Scotland Yard (she is a stanch reader of detective fiction), have an audience with Pope Pius XII and visit Stresa on Lake Maggiore, Italy.

Lawyers who had volunteered to give free advice on rent laws took their stations yesterday in seventeen municipal courthouses. Tenants -- and landlords -- were quick to seek their counsel. The problems set forth in bewildering detail boiled down in almost every case to one of two questions: "Can they evict me?" Or: "Can I evict them?"

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Great Britain bared the severity of her economic plight to the United States today as British and United States officials opened a conference to review the terms of the AngloAmerican loan agreement.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The Iranian Parliament moved today toward early consideration of a sixteen-month-old oil agreement with Russia after electing Reza Hekmat, Government party candidate, as permanent President by a vote of 73 to 36.

TOKYO, Aug. 18 -- Informed Japanese opinion is still trying to appraise the effects of the loss of George Atcheson Jr. and the resignation from the Allied Control Council of W. MacMahon Ball, the British Commonwealth, member.

ALBANY, Aus. 18 -- The Adjutant General released the following orders today: N.Y.N.G. Officers Assigned 2d Lt. W.H. Davids, 226th F.A. Bn. to Battery B as R.C.N. officer. 2d Lt. D.L. Stearns. 174th Inf., to Company E as platoon commander. Chief warrant officer. A.P. Malanga, to 102d A.A.A. Brig. to Hq. Btry. as M.T.O.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 18 -- Commercial printers who employ members of the International Typographical Union, AFL, advised the union today that they had no desire to invoke the damage-suit provisions of the Taft-Hartley Act and proposed instead an arbitration plan to dispose of issues arising under contracts.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- The United Nations Security Council will resume debate tomorrow morning on the question of appointing a commission for the Indonesian dispute. The meeting was scheduled largely because of pressure from Andrei A. Gromyko, the Soviet representative, who asserted today that attempts were being made -- obviously referring to the United States -- to "compel" the Indonesian Republic to accept "arbitration" outside the Council.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Eight of thirty-six state champions broke 100 targets in a row at 16 yards today in the feature event of the forty-eighth Grand American trapshoot's opening day, requiring a shoot-off for the champion of champions title.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 18 (AP) -- Helen K. Haggerty's Rampart galloped home a winner of the Beauty Crown Purse today to qualify for the $15,000 added Miss America Handicap, closing-day feature Saturday. Rampart finished two and a half lengths in front of S. Buono's Galamilk, with Katherine O'Malley's Miss War taking the show, three and a half lengths farther back.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Following are the text of the chapter on military aviation and textual excerpts from the chapter on civil aviation in the report of President Truman's Air Coordinating Committee: Military Aviation The menace of mass-destructive weapons, whether atomic, biological or not yet imagined, together with long-range striking forces, presents a defense problem unique in this country's history and is intimately associated with the problems reviewed in this section.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 18 -- As the sixty-sixth tournament for the national doubles tennis championship started today at the Longwood Cricket Club the big interest centered in the two American teams that are neck and neck for the assignment of meeting the Australians in the Davis Cup challenge round at Forest Hills.

The appearance of Bedloes Island, site of the Statue of Liberty, may become worse before it improves, Charles S. Marshall, superintendent of the structure, warned yesterday, in an address before 400 monument builders attending the annual convention of the Monument Builders of America at the Hotel New Yorker.

PARIS, Aug. 18 -- After a second long discussion of the subject today it appeared likely that the European Economic Conference would name a committee to study a continental customs union or unions. It would report in a few months to the sixteen Governments involved.

Thirteen ships brought 4,987 passengers to the Port of New York from overseas yesterday and from early morning until late in the afternoon the arrivals moved ashore from piers on the Manhattan, Staten Island and Hoboken waterfronts.

A labor Agreement under which all disputes are to be resolved through arbitration and both sides renounce the right to seek damages through the courts was reached yesterday by officers of Local 62 of the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union, AFL, and four associations of negligee and lingerie manufacturers.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 18 -- Three more leaders of the right-wing Zionist Revisionist party were arrested by British troops in Jerusalem today in continuance of the round-up of suspected sympathizers of terrorist underground forces that began two weeks ago.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18 -- Resolutions condemning "mercy killings" and "multiplying divorces" were adopted today by the National Catholic Women's Union, which is holding a joint convention with the Catholic Central Verein.

Pennant fever ran high in Brooklyn last night and the temperatures of the 66,504 fans who saw the Dodgers crush the second place Cardinals twice, 7-5 in the afternoon and 12-3 under the lights, would have cracked any ordinary thermometer.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., Aug. 18 (AP) -- Dr. E.E. Elder of New York City, secretary of the Near-East Christian Council, said today that "if the United States admitted displaced persons in the same ratio to its population as Palestine is expected to, we would have to accept 20,000,000."

HONOLULU, Aug. 18 -- Little hope was held out today that any of the four missing passengers, including George Atcheson Jr., United States member of the Allied Control Commission for Japan, were still alive after their B-17 crashed into the sea off Oahu Saturday.

WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 18 (AP) -- Wilmington's Board of Park Commissioners today ordered all public and private swimming pools closed as eight new cases of poliomyelitis brought Deleware's total for the summer to thirty-seven.

HENRY SEIDEL CANBY, a scholar who has long played a major role in the bustle and excitement of the literary market place, is a mellow, tolerant and kindly man. In the sixty-ninth year of his age he is the author of a book. "American Memoir,"* which is personal without being autobiographical and serious without being solemn.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- President Truman called a strong National Guard essential to national security and expressed confidence today that the Guard's recruiting goal of 88,888 new men, or a man a minute during the Sept. 16 to Nov. 16 enrollment campaign, would be surpassed.

There was a time, and not too long ago, when Bowditch's Practical Navigator was both the Alpha and the Omega of most ship's libraries. Not the big trans-Atlantic liners, of course, but the smaller merchant ships that carry the world's commerce across the seven seas.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The United States today branded the death sentence imposed upon Nikola Petkov, leader of the Opposition Agrarian party in Bulgaria, an apparent "gross miscarriage of justice". It called upon the Soviet Union to instruct the Communist-dominated Bulgarian Government to suspend the sentence pending review of the case.
HONOLULU, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Fifteen planes and twelve ships crisscrossed the Pacific some sixty-five miles west of Pearl Harbor all day today in futile search for the men missing in the B-17 crash.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Eleven coastwise steamship lines told the Interstate Commerce Commission today that they not only wanted to increase their freight rates to match the 16 per cent rise recently asked by the railroads but that they also objected to the limitation of increases on certain commodities, as proposed by the railroads.

BERLIN, Aug. 18 -- Rumors of an impending financial reform in Germany -- not justified by the failure of the four occupying powers to reach agreement on this issue -- have intensified the critical shortage of coins and bills of small denomination.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 18 -- Dissatisfaction with yesterday's boundary awards grew in both Dominions as leaders of India and Pakistan, meeting in Lahore today, ordered the strictest measures to halt bloody rioting centered at Lahore (Pakistan) and the Sikh holy city of Amritsar (India) in the Punjab.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- The customers took a look at Ocean Brief's record -- four victories, a second and four third places in nine starts -- and bet Carr Hatch's filly down to 9 to 10 in the $4,500 Galatea Purse at Saratoga today.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 18 -- The local press, discussing "the necessity for continental economic equality," says Latin America is disillusiond by "the post-war New Deal" of the United States.

Not one witness of the thirty or more who have testified on alleged police graft before the Queens County grand jury in recent weeks has named a policeman who accepted protection money from bookmakers. Even Emetia (Joe Pledge) Polizio, Astoria gambler whose accusations touched off the inquiry, provided no names.

Random notes: The fifth annual Atlantic Coast Tuna Tournament will get under way this morning when the sixty boats carrying members of the eighteen competing teams push into the swell out of Shark River Inlet and point for the famous Mud Hole.
LONDON, Aug. 18 -- There is evidence today that British trade unionists are joining in the general clamor for the Government to announce a master plan to meet and defeat the economic crisis.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Aug. 18 -- Mrs. Homer Wilhelm and Joe Turnesa of the Rockville Club scored 76 -- 9 -- 69 to tie with Mrs. W. Horne and Willie Klein of Wheatley Hills, 81 -- 12 -- 69, for low net honors in the first womanpro, alternate-shot competition of the season, sponsored by the Long Island P.G.A. at the Cherry Vallay Club today.

Along the shoreline you will see them on gray, jagged cliffs that rebuff the onslaughts of persistent waves; on rocky peninsulas that push stiff arms into the ocean; on the crests of rolling dunes where beach grass spikes bend before the wind and write circular marks on the tan-gold sand.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- An examiner of the Civil Aeronautics Board said today a new direct air route between the Pacific Northwest and Hawaii should not be established.

LONDON, Aug. 12 -- With the opening at Oxford this week of its first training center for domestic workers, the Government sponsored National Institute of Houseworkers will begin to reap the fruits of two years intensive planning. By the fall, ten other centers will be opened throughout the United Kingdom.

The nation can appropriately join with President Truman in hoping that the theme of this year's convention of the American Federation of Teachers will be to some degree realized. This theme is "Strengthening Education for National and World Security." The President in his message to the convention, which opened in Boston yesterday, said:
CINCINNATI, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Suzanne Weller, 14 years old, of Pittsburgh, received today the 1947 Humane Act Award at the convention of the American Veterinary Medical Association here.

Better early than never is the philosophy of twelve women from Norway who arrived here yesterday to attend the first postwar convention of the International Council of Women, to be held in Philadelphia from Sept. 5 to 12.

Circling planes and ranging snips are still searching shark-infested Pacific waters for survivors of the Flying Fortress which crashed into the sea with Ambassador George Atcheson Jr. and three other members of General MacArthur's peacetime staff aboard. It is unlikely now that any more than the men already rescued will be found.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Attorney General Clark announced today that the Justice Department had filed a suit charging to Technicolor, Inc., and the Eastman Kodak Company a conspiracy to monopolize the production of color motion pictures.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Arthur C. Holden's letter in your issue of Aug. 6 points up the importance of giving serious consideration to a proper choice for Chairman of the City Planning Commission, when Edwin Salmon retires to join the staff of New York University.

Mayor O'Dwyer arrived a bit late at the Stadium last night and missed a great show by Bobby Thomson and Johnny Mize in the second game of the intra-city series for the Mayor's Cup and the benefit of the Greater New York Sandlot Baseball Federation and the Damon Runyon Memorial Cancer Fund.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 18 -- A coast-wise shipping tie-up following the effective date of the TaftHartley Act, next Saturday, was predicted late today by the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, an affiliate of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

A sharp improvement in supply of standard electric motors has occurred, coupled with price reductions of about 25 per cent during recent weeks, B. Javeline, secretary of Jay Hardware and Electric, Inc., 545 Eighth Avenue, declared here yesterday.

Fruit cobbler or, as New Englanders call it, deep dish pie is a dessert that has been favored by generations of Yankee and MidWestern housewives as one of the most delicious ways of presenting peaches, cherries or apples at the height of their season.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18 -- Lower backlogs of orders, faster deliveries and lengthening of buying policies were apparent in the economic picture outlined here today in a report of a business survey by the Purchasing Agents Association of Chicago.

The Federal Trade Commission has charged the American steel industry with "illegal price-fixing and restraint of competition." In a formal complaint against the American Iron and Steel Institute of New York and its members it states that there is a "conspiracy" in the industry to maintain identical price quotations on steel.

Having had difficulty Sunday in getting key city officials on the scene of the water main break at Eighty-fifth Street and Central Park West, Mayor O'Dwyer directed department heads yesterday to remain in touch with the police when they are out of town.

Retail Sales Drop 11% New York and Brooklyn department store sales last week decreased 11 per cent from the corresponding week a year ago, according to the "flash" report of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York yesterday.

The mention of Argyrokastron, in Albania, as the possible headquarters of the Greek guerrilla chief, Gen. Markos Vafthiades, may ring a bell for those whose memory goes back as far as seven years. This Albanian town was the symbol of a Greek victory in 1940, when the spirit and courage of the Greek mountaineers blocked the Italians' advance on Metsovo Pass, drove them back and exposed the weakness and inefficiency of Italian fascism.

BOSTON, Mass., Aug. 18 -- The public education system in the United States will be greatly weakened if public funds are used to subsidize sectarian schools, Drs. John L. Childs and George S. Counts of Teachers College, Columbia University, stressed in reports submitted today at the opening sessions of the convention of the American Federation of Teachers.
The lives of Emil Mueller and William Miller, residents of the Lower East Side, coincided in several ways.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- President Truman's Air Coordinating Committee declared today that the country's security demanded a long-range program of aircraft construction not subject to the vicissitudes of year-to-year budgeting.

New York University's Division of General Education will start this fall the "understanding of modern sciences" phase of its prolonged program designed to develop improved methods in adult education, it was announced yesterday by Ralph G. Ross, assistant Professor of Philosophy at N.Y.U.

An eleven-story apartment building at 39-53 West Fifty-eighth Street to accommodate forty-two families was among plans filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings. The cost is estimated at $425,000. Mayer Whittlesey of 31 Union Square West are the architects and the owner is listed as the 40 Central Park South, Inc., of 551 Fifth Avenue.
BERLIN, Aug. 18 -- Despite official denials, the Communist press in the Soviet zone persists in repeating the story that German youths are being recruited to fight against Greek guerrillas.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Aug. 18 -- Mere enlargement of the number of hospitals and beds for ailing war veterans is not the answer to the veterans' problem, Dr. Paul R. Hawley, medical director of the Veterans Administration, told the opening session of the National Convention of the Disabled American Veterans today.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 18 -- The State Constitutional Convention, by a vote of 63 to 15, to day defeated an amendment to its judicial article that would have required permanent assignment of judges to equity and law divisions of the court system.

The National Federation of Catholic College Students plans to weigh the "acceptability" of leading comedy programs, it was made known yesterday. It would be the first Catholic group to evaluate radio's fare in somewhat the same manner as the Legion of Decency judges films and plays.

Philip Evergood, artist, who owns the house at 132 Bank Street where a burglar shot and fatally wounded a patrolman on Sunday night, was arrested yesterday for a violation of the Sullivan Law. The police said he admitted owning the signal-flare pistol fired by the thug.

Several new provisions in the Sharkey rent bills, including one giving sweeping powers to the City Rent Commission to amend, rescind or enlarge the regulations with respect to evictions, were disclosed last night to have been written into the bills since last week's public hearing at City Hall.

"The Magic Touch," promised to local playgoers this month, will not be arriving at the International Theatre until Sept. 3, it was announced yesterday by the offices of the producer, John Morris Chanin. The Charles Raddock-Charles Sherman farce was to have opened Aug. 26 after a series of benefit performances, the first of which is to be given tonight.

The International Silk Guild, Inc., is preparing to resume its pre-war activities in promotion of silk products for the industry, and yesterday appointed Abbott Kimball Company, Inc., as the advertising agency. The guild was active from 1932 until 1941 in development of markets and products through coordination with manufacturers.

Roads to Destiny Quiet, back-country dirt roads are part of the nation's heritage. Long years ago men and women with dreams of new homes in their hearts left the security of towns along the seacoast and followed trails inland.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Aug. 18 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, disclosed in an interview today that his organization was planning a nation-wide work holiday for "all but essential industries" on election day in 1948.

Thirty-one ships have been tied up in the strike by the Seafarers International Union, AFL, against the Isthmian Steamship Company a union spokesman announced last night. Ten of the vessels are in the Port of New York, they said.

STONEVILLE, Miss., Aug. 18 -- Planters from all sections of the cotton belt watched under a broiling sun today as a mechanized flame-thrower went up and down rows of growing cotton at the Delta experiment station here and in a few hours did the work of twenty men with a hoe at a third of the cost.

The Federal Government filed a criminal complaint yesterday against eight leading rubber companies, ten company officials and the Rubber Manufacturers Association, Inc., a trade organization. The defendants were accused of having conspired since 1935 to fix the prices of automobile tires and tubes, and determine other trade practices on a uniform basis.
OMAHA, Neb., Aug. 18 -- A common comment heard throughout the country's corn and wheat belt today is "farmers are hip deep in folding: money."

Local 96, Financial Employes Guild, CIO, which on Saturday called off its month-old strike against the Brooklyn Trust Company, served notice yesterday that it might order a walkout at the Merchants Bank of New York next month.
Despite ominous reports from the Midwest of a spreading heat wave, New York should enjoy relatively comfortable weather today and tomorrow.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Victory claims in the battle for Asuncion were put forth by both sides today in the Paraguayan civil war.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The Maryland Drydock Company's 4,500 shipyard workers began voting today on a contract agreement that would end a strike that has tied up the yard since July 2.

MOISSON, France, Aug. 18 (U.P.) -- The Sixth World Boy Scout Jamboree was officially closed tonight as 30,000 boys, representing fortytwo nations, took part in a huge parade, which followed the lines of the "Carrick knot" emblem of the jamboree.

NEW DELHI, Aug. 18 (AP) -- A.C. Bhatia, Hindu assistant editor of The Lahore Tribune, one of the oldest English-language newspapers in India, said today that he was in Lahore and Amritsar last week when Boundary Force soldiers opened fire on each other with rapid-fire weapons to protect refugees of their respective religious communities who were being evacuated by train.

VIENNA, Aug. 18 -- The United States is preparing for a possible Austrian crisis this fall. Joseph Dodge, American delegate on the Austrian Treaty Commission, announced today that he had been requested to return to Washington for State Department consultations on future work of the commission.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- State Department officials indicated today that work on the drafting of a Japanese peace treaty could proceed without undue delay despite the growing certainty that George Atcheson Jr., chief American diplomatic figure in Japan, had met his death, in a plane crash in the Pacific.

In answer to a charge leveled by the Federal Trade Commission that the domestic steel industry has been guilty of a conspiracy to fix prices and to restrain competition, Irving S. Olds, chairman of the United States Steel Corportation, denied the accusation yesterday.

OTTAWA, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The drain on Canada's reserve of United States dollars was emphasized today with the release of statistics showing that the Dominion's adverse trade balance with her southern neighbor totaled $488,000,000 on June 30.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 18 -- Despite the recent rebellion of Irving Rapper, who had been assigned to direct the screen version of Moss Hart's "Christopher Blake," Warner Brothers announced today that the picture will go before the cameras about Sept. 1 with Alexis Smith in the leading feminine role and Peter Godfrey directing.

Frank Cohen, Industrialist and creator of the plan to use Quoddy Village, Me., as a training center where displaced persons from Europe would be prepared for settlement in South America, announced yesterday that only final word from the War Assets Administration prevented his project from getting under way.

Gen. Jonathan M. Wainwright completed yesterday one of the final assignments of his long Army career. The Corregidor leader, who will retire at the end of this month, finished sitting for his portrait in the Gramercy Park studio of Joseph Cummings Chase, famous portrait artist.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (U.P.) -- Soft coal operators said today that wildcat strikes had increased under the "able and willing to work" clause of their contract with the United Mine Workers.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- The United Nations Security Council voted unanimously today to admit the Arab kingdom of Yemen and the new Indian state of Pakistan to membership, but again rejected the application of Albania, Outer Mongolia, TransJordan, Ireland and Portugal.

New York joined actively yesterday in the Federal Government's campaign against price fixers in food, clothing and housing when Mayor O'Dwyer assigned John M. Murtagh, Investigation Commissioner, to 'work directly with the Federal officials.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: THE NEW YORK TIMES several days ago carried a dispatch from London describing a rumor, since denied, that the United States may raise its gold price to $50 an ounce.

Chief Signalman Harold E. Hirshberg's attorney went to the United States District Court in Brooklyn yesterday and challenged the jurisdiction of the Navy general courtmartial that convicted the former prisoner of war of striking fellow Americans while in the hands of the Japanese.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 18 -- A cooperative arrangement by which a traveler may use plane and ship facilities for a trip to many parts of the world, speeding his journey when ugency demands or slowing it when fancy dictates, was announced today by American President Lanes and Northwest Airlines.

TRIESTE, Aug. 18 (U.P.) -- Two British Army officers today pleaded guilty to charges of accepting bribes of between $30,000 and $45,000 while helping to administer the public works division of the American Military Government in Venezia Giulia.

Federal Judge Gaston Louis Porterie reserved decision yesterday on motions to quash subpoenas calling for production of the books and records of the Spruce Falls Power and Paper Company, a Canadian company, in connection with the Government's investigation of the newsprint industry.

PETROPOLIS, Brazil, Aug. 18 -- United States proposals for collective hemispheric assistance to any American nation attacked by an aggressor may undergo further modification. At least it was indicated authoritatively that this idea will be meticulously clarified to meet any issues newly arising.

Abatement of the noise of airplanes, responsible for growing complaints to La Guardia Field authorities by residents of Flushing and Jackson Heights, is already being attempted by the Civil Aeronautics Administration, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, AFL, will not boycott the National Labor Relations Board or the Taft-Hartley Act, it was announced today by its president, Daniel W. Tracy, at a special meeting here of 150 of its officers.

The rains predicted for the drought area in Texas on Monday failed to materialize, except for a few scattered thunder showers, and after early hesitation yesterday the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange developed renewed firmness and closed only slightly below the highs of the day with net gains of 38 to 42 points.

PARIS, Aug. 19 -- Thirty-one boy scouts from the Greater New York area paraded up the Champs Elysees and deposited a container of earth from the base of the Statue of Liberty at the tomb of the French unknown soldier today.

LONDON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- British Government sources said today that a boom in engineering industries, especially in heavy machinery, railroad cars and agricultural equipment, is "extremely likely" this fall as a result of this country's economic crisis production program.
In the children of 1947 mankind has the raw material to make one world, Dr. Agnes Snyder of the Cooperative School for Teachers and the Mills School, declared yesterday.
Negotiations to end the twoyear-old jurisdictional dispute that has prevented installation of vital communications equipment at the Idlewild Airport broke down yesterday.

SALEM, N.H, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Taking command at the eighth pole, Brown Hotel Stables' Buzzaround drove hard down the stretch today to win the featured Farmington Allowance Purse for $3,000 at Rockingham Park.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Aug. 19 -- Karl Brandt, who was Adolf Hitler's personal physician, and fourteen other medical and lay defendants were found guilty today by a United States tribunal on charges of participation in and responsibility for medical experiments on the inmates of concentration camps.

A new tank type vacuum cleaner the first of its kind to be made by the Hoover Company, will be introduced in New York stores next week, it was announced yesterday. The cylinder model is the latest addition to the regular line of up right cleaners that heretofore have been the specialty of this company.

Eliminate the task of scouring the pans in which food has been cooked and dishwashing ceases to be the tiresome chore that some housewives regard it. Two aluminum foil products that are now available in stores here are designed for just this purpose.

Depressing news continues to come from austerity-ridden England. The latest-that Princess Elizabeth must forego her trousseau -- will stir pity in the heart of every bride-to-be in America, who wouldn't dream of being led to the altar without all the new raiment she or her parents can buy.

The Betty Comden-Adolph Green musical revolving around the Alaskan gold rush of 1898, first on the agenda of Paul Feigay and Oliver Smith, is rapidly nearing completion. If present arrangements hold, the show should be on the local hoards by mid-December.

The emphasis that President Wilson placed on objectivity and a capacity for self-criticism, particularly about his own literary work, is illustrated in a letter he wrote in 1897, an excerpt from which was disclosed yesterday in the Woodrow Wilson Foundation's annual report.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- A group of incorporators today announced formation of the American Independent Oil Company, which they said was a $100,000,000 corporation created to engage in foreign petroleum operations, particularly in the Middle East.

Quick action by union leaders and employers in the construction industry promised yesterday to end a work stoppage which, though it involved no more than 250 men, threatened to halt construction throughout the city and disrupt efforts to stabilize wages in the industry.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES. Two recent court decisions make interesting parallel reading: the United States Supreme Court decision striking down discriminatory freight rates and the decision of Judge J. Waties Waring in United States District Court ruling out discrimination against Negroes in South Carolina Democratic primaries.

LONDON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Europe's heat wave -- in some regions the most intense in fifty years -- sent forest fires raging today through parts of Germany, melted snowcaps off some of the French Alps, and blighted crops in Britain and a number of Continental countries.

The Governor of French Oceania advised the Norwegian Embassy in Washington yesterday that he was sending a ship from Tahiti he the Society Islands to pick up the stranded crew of the-Norwegian Kon-Tiki Raft Expedition, from Raroia reef in the Tuarnotu Archipelago.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 19 -- Shots from a military vehicle were fired this afternoon at a Jewish-owned bus near Givat Brenner on the coastal plain, killing a Jewish boy who only recently came to Palestine from Europe.

VIENNA, Aug. 19 -- United States policymakers in Austria reached a definite decision to dodge a showdown with Soviet Russia on the issue of inspection of the distribution of relief shipments in the Russian zone of occupation.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The Phillies turned on the Cubs today and, behind the splendid hurling of Ken Heintzelman and Schoolboy Rowe, defeated them in both ends of a double-header, 8 -- 1 and 8 -- 2, before 6.239.
FLORINA, Greece, Aug. 19 -- This town in a remote corner of northern Greece between Yugoslavia and Albania is virtually besieged today.

Youthful styles adaptable to the wardrobes of college and career girls were seen yesterday at Saks34th in a showing that featured Minx Modes junior fashions. Selected for office or campus wear was a gray menswear wool with interesting button-trimmed tabs ornamenting the turtle-neck collar.

BELMAR, N.J., Aug. 19 -- The Atlantic City Tuna Club team took the lead on the first day of the fifth annual Atlantic Tuna Tournament, a three-day contest in which seventeen coastal fishing clubs are competing for the Governor's Plaque and the Hensler Challenge Trophy.

LONDON, Aug. 19 -- The final destination of 4,500 unauthorized Jewish immigrants quartered aboard three British ships off Port de Bouc, France, on July 29 has at last been decided, it was learned tonight. The decision, which is expected to be announced tomorrow, is reported to be to send the entire company to British-occupied territory in Germany.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The United States ended today its peacemaking efforts between the Netherlands and the Indonesian Republic.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19 -- Prospects that the main Corn Belt might experience relief from the hot and dry weather that is reported to have taken a heavy toll of grains led today to general commissionhouse and professional selling of corn futures in the early trading on the Board of Trade.

WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 19 (U.P.) -- Protesting the recent wave of Government anti-trust suits, Harry A. Bullis, president of General Mills, Inc., said today that prices "should be permitted to seek their proper relative levels."
Howard C. Adams and Ewing W. Reilley have been admitted as partners of McKinsey Co., management consultants. Both are war veterans who were connected with the Quartermaster General's department.

Heat and humidity closed in again on New York and the metropolitan area yesterday after a brief respite from the steamy weather of last week, and further collar-wilting conditions were forecast for today.

Winners of Charm Magazine's 1947 traveling fellowship awards, Betty Jane Crisp of Benton, Ill., a graduate of Washington University, St. Louis, Mo.; Rhoda Miller, Brooklyn, graduate of the Fashion Institute of Technology, and Mary Beth Stine, Henrietta, Texas, a Southern Methodist University graduate, were introduced yesterday to the New York fashion press at the New Weston Hotel.

CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., Aug. 19 -- Although he agreed to a draw with Anthony E. Santasiere, New York State champion, thereby dropping half a point, Isaac I. Kashdan of New York kept his hold on first place in the annual tournament for the open championship of the United States Chess Federation at the White Plaza Hotel today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Organization of a Congressional investigation of the housing situation brought a clash today between two Republican Senators. The chairmanship of the Senate-House investigating committee was the issue and the upshot was the surprise election as chairman of Representative Ralph A. Gamble, Republican, of New York, who had not sought the post.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 19 -- Robert J.H. (Bob) Kiphuth, head coach of the U.S. Olympic swimming team which will participate in the 1948 games in London, will leave tomorrow for Europe and a first-hand inspection of the foreign stars who will provide the opposition for the American team.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 19 -- Officers of the International Typographical Union, AFL, submitted to the convention today a proposed amendment to the union's general laws which would give extraordinary authority to the international president to veto contracts made by local unions.

Benelux, the customs union agreed upon by Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg, came quietly into being this month. It will not be fully operative until 1949, but already it causes the stagnant waters of the continent to stir. Benelux is a new economic unit, the first counter-move against Europe's fatal drift toward division and disintegration.

The international character of the Salvation Army has made it "one of the greatest forces for world peace," Commissioner Edgar Dibden, chancellor of the exchequer of the International Salvation Army, declared yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The Red Sox unlimbered their big bats, including a four-run circuit blow by Dom DiMaggio, to blast Brownie hurlers for eleven hits, nine walks and a 9-to-5 victory tonight before 3,300 fans.

BERLIN, Aug. 19 -- Military Government Officials disclosed today that for the first time since early March the bread ration was being met throughout the economically merged United States-British zones. Although the current drought is forbidding for the harvest of indigenous crops, official figures disclosed the most satisfactory condition in many months.

LINCOLN, Neb., Aug. 19 -- In the vast, prosperous American "bread basket," which natives believe to be the last stronghold of rugged individualism, discussions of any long-range agricultural policy invariably bring in what is declared to be the need for continuing Federal price supports.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The White Sox snapped a four-game winning streak for this Athletics by beating the Mackmen, 4-0, tonight before 16,139 fans. Joe Haynes held Philadelphia to nine hits for his eighth victory of the season.

The first day of conversations between British and American representatives on the British exchange problem was given over to a discussion of the symptoms and causes of that country's difficulties. This is, of course, a necessary preliminary to consideration of plans for relief.

Operating subsidiaries of the American. Telephone and Telegraph Company in twenty-one states have been granted rate increases amounting to $50,000,000 annually in the last four months, a spokesman for the parent company disclosed yesterday.

ALBANY, Aug. 19 -- New minimum wage orders affecting some 55,500 beauty service and laundry workers in the state were issued today by Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi. The orders are mandatory immediately, but to employers is granted a 60-day period to complete any business changes necessary to insure full compliance.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Aug. 19 -- Three persons already have been hilled and approximately 200 arrested as Communist-led mobs have taken into their own hands enforcement of Rumania's new monetary stabilization law.

DOWAGIAC, Mich., Aug. 19 -- With orders to break up union "goon squads," sixty officers of the Michigan state police were sent here today to the Heddon Bait Company plant after about 200 pickets in an automobile barricade ringed the struck factory.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 19 -- Sutan Sjahrir, the Indonesian representative, notified the United Nations Security Council today that his Government would not accept the good offices of the United States in settling its dispute with the Netherlands.

Our suddenly bereft Giants returned to the Polo Grounds last night to let the home folks see how they've been .doing it of late. While the exhibition scarcely pleased a sweltering audience of 23,224 it cannot be said Mel Ott's men held anything back.

The Philco Corporation has acquired the production facilities and all other assets of the Rex Manufacturing Company, Inc., of Connersville, Ind., for expansion of its refrigerator and freezer division, John Ballantyne, president of Philco, announced yesterday.

The Dodger pennant picture that the boys hung up so proudly for everyone to see Monday evening was turned face to the wall by the Cardinals at Ebbets Field yesterday -- but the Brooks hope it is only temporarily hidden.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 19 -- The Sudanese people may resort to forceful resistance and rioting and create "another Indonesia" in the Middle East unless British troops evacuate their country, Ismail el-Azhari, Sudanese leader, warned here today.

Two former Navy Landing Ships (Tank) continued last night to ply the Hudson River between New York and Albany without cargo, their debut as commercial carriers still delayed by a shoreside labor dispute.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Aug. 19 -- Dr. Harrison S. Martland, chief medical examiner of Essex County, reported today on the basis of an autopsy that the death yesterday of Miss Dorothy L. Burns of 15 Thomas Street here was due "to a new form of occupational disease connected with the fluorescent lamp industry."

Waxed Paper Supplies Ease Purchasing agents reported here yesterday that supplies of waxed paper, formerly almost impossible to obtain, have eased slightly. They said that on an order for 100,000 pounds, formerly almost impossible to place, not only had the contract been awarded after competitive bids, but the vendor wanted to deliver the complete stock within ninety days, whereas the buyer wanted deliveries made over the period of a full year.

Sales of the Eastman Kodak Company and its subsidiaries in the Western Hemisphere rose 29 per cent in the first half of 1947 and earnings increased commensurately as a result of the "substantial growth" of the company since the war, Perley S. Wilcox, chairman, and Thomas J. Hargrave, president reported yesterday in a statement to stockholders.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 19 -- Eagle-Lion will refilm extensive sequences from "Railroaded," a completed melodrama, to eliminate conflict in subject matter with Twentieth Century-Fox's projected picture, "Call Northside 777," it was learned today from EagleLion.
LONDON, Aug. 19 (Reuters) -- In the most exciting finish of the county cricket program today, Lancashire defeated Nottinghamshire by eighty-four runs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The Army Air Forces reassigned eighteen generals today in one of the largest mass shifts in recent years. The transfers are preliminary to setting up the United States Air Force separately under the new secretary of defense in the armed forces unification program.
TUSKEGEE, Ala., Aug. 19 (AP) -- All seeded players moved into the third round pf the men's singles of the thirtieth annual Negro national tennis championships today without a break in their ranks.
LONDON, Aug. 19 -- Gold shares again claimed principal attention in the stock markets here today. End-of-account profit-taking was absorbed easily and many issues recorded further gains on the day.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Paced by Ken Keltner's two home runs, the Indians walloped the Senators, 13-2 and 9-1, tonight in a twilight-night doubleheader.

DETROIT, Aug. 19 -- A twentyeight day "bottleneck" strike by 7,000 members of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, against the Murray Corporation of America was settled today on the basis of a straight wage increase of fifteen cents an hour and immunity for the union from certain provisions of the Taft-Hartley Labor Law.

The Holland-America liners Nieuw Amsterdam and Veendam have been scheduled to make one cruise each from New York to the West Indies and South America in December, it was announced here yesterday. It is expected that they will be the first major transatlantic liners to be diverted from their regular runs for cruise service since the war.

"Vox Pop," one of the first radio interview shows, is to be heard this autumn over the ABC network at 8:30 P.M. Wednesdays, beginning Sept. 1. The program, which features Parks Johnson and Warren Hull, is to be sponsored by the American Express Company.

MOORESVILLE, N.C., Aug. 19 -- The $2,000,000 expansion program to provide Mooresville Mills with "the largest and most modern rayon mill of its type in the United States" will be completed about Jan. 1, it was announced today by J.F. Matheson, president.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- An impenetrable curtain of secrecy dropped abruptly on the AngloAmerican loan revision talks today as experts from both the United States and British delegations dug into technical features of the $3,750,000,000 credit agreement.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIME: THE NEW YORK TIMES' joyful hand clapping at the prospect of the return of British dinnerware to America markets, as evidenced in the recent editorial entitled "Upturn in Britain confounds the native American potter industry, the 20,000 skilled workers employs directly, and the many thousands of others who gain indirectly.

City and Federal price-fixing investigations have switched anxiety about prices from purchasing departments to sales departments, purchasing agents disclosed here yesterday. Most worried about impending quiz programs, sales managers are concentrating their attention on trying to explain how identical bids occured in quotations on City, State and Federal purchasing invitations.

BOSTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Bob Elliott's seventeenth homer, with two on and two out in the ninth, gave the Braves a 7-5 victory over the Pirates tonight before a crowd of 23,192 fans. The Pirates forged ahead in their side of the last frame when Billy Cox sparked a two-run rally with a triple down the right-field foul line.

PRAGUE, Aug. 19 (AP) -- A minority group of eleven Americans attending the World Festival of Democratic Youth issued a statement today reporting that an American girl had been detained for two hours by an officer in a Czechoslovak uniform and a Communist member of the festival committee.

A general contract for the construction, of a 1,000-bed veterans hospital adjacent to the Fort Hamilton Reservation, Brooklyn, was awarded yesterday to the Cauldwell-Wingate Company, 101 Park Avenue, low bidder at $14,700,000. The award was announced by Col. William F. Heavey, district engineer, New York District, Corps of Engineers, 120 Wail Street.

BRUENN, Czechoslovakia, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Bob Fitch of Sioux Falls, S.D., and the University of Minnesota, who has toyed with the world discus record on almost every outing, won his pet event today with a toss of 179 feet 4 inches as a touring U.S. track team won eleven of fourteen events in a Czech-French-U.S. meet.

Supporters of the move to repeal Proportional Representation as the system under which members of the City Council are elected said yesterday that the move had accumulated 125,000 signatures on petitions asking for a repeal referendum at the general election in November.

BOSTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Lieut. Gov. Arthur W. Coolidge, addressing the business session of the Knights of Columbus convention, charged that "America is being drained of supplies which are being sent to Russia," adding that the "inflation which plagues this country, in a measure, is caused by draining this continent to bolster the Molotov plan.
LONDON, Aug. 19 -- The-British public's attention continued today to be centered on the progress of the dollar talks in Washington. All newspapers gave first position to accounts of the negotiations.

FORD FRICK'S indignant denunciation of Phillie stalling tactics against the Dodgers last Sunday and his order that the "tie" game be replayed from its point of interruption focused attention on one of the most irritating situations now confronting the sport. That is the Pennsylvania curfew law which sets 6:59 P. M. as the terminal point for Sunday play.
"Get 'em closer together!" photographers yelled, pointing to six bewildered little girls lined up, ready to push their doll carriages away from the starting line.

Consumer buying power on the Pacific Coast has remained practically at its war peak, and national advertisers are giving recognition to this factor in setting budgets and campaigns for the fall and winter, marketing men explained yesterday.

PARIS, Aug. 19 -- A three-power discussion of the German level of industry will begin in London on Friday. This was decided today at a conference between William L. Clayton, United States Undersecretary of State; Jefferson Caffery, United States Ambassador to France, and French Foreign Minister Georges Bidault.

DARIEN, Conn., Aug. 19 -- Daniel W. Ashley, publisher of The United States News and World Report of Washington, was killed by a bolt of lightning tonight during a severe electrical storm that extinguished temporarily most of the lights in Darien and crippled telephone service severely.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (U.P.) -- Railroad accidents are on the upswing again, largely because of higher speeds, it was disclosed today.

To offset the impression that New Tork's new mandatory fair trade pricing represents a grab by distillers, more price advertising by the major producers may appear in the state after Sept. 1, according to views expressed here yesterday.

MOSCOW. Aug. 19 (U.P.) -- The Russian public today heard the news it had been eagerly awaiting -- that the "tense struggle" for bread already was being won in the largest grain-producing areas of the Soviet Union.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 19 -- Joseph Padway, general counsel for the American Federation of Labor, was knocked down today by Irving McCann, counsel for the House Education and Labor subcommittee. The blow was struck during a Congressional hearing on the AFL jurisdictional strike in Hollywood film studios.

Jersey Railroads and Taxes The railroads operating in New Jersey are much concerned over the proposal under consideration by the Constitutional Convention of that State that second-class railroad property be taxed at the local rate.

Stephen Thuransky, the naturalized American citizen who escaped from the political police in his native Hungary on Aug. 3, two days after being arrested for alleged "anti-democratic utterances," arrived here yesterday.
A blanket wage increase of $4 a week was awarded to 3,500 employes of Bloomingdale's department store in an arbitration decision yesterday by Sidney A. Wolff. The pay rise is retroactive to March 1.
Official inquiry into alleged police protection of gamblers in New York City dropped to a summer low yesterday.

Concern over the inadequacy of the fire-fighting methods and equipment in many of the smaller communities of the country was expressed yesterday at the annual conference of the International Association of Fire Chiefs.

ORADELL, N.J., Aug. 19 -- The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association was host to sixty teams of husbands and wives who played alternate shots for the Jane Brooks Robbins Memorial Trophy over the Hackensack Golf Club course today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 19 -- Existence of an "implied contract" between the Waterfront Employers Association of the Pacific Coast and the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, Congress of Industrial Organizations, governing work on steam schooners was affirmed today by Clark Kerr, Longshore arbitrator.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 19 (Reuters) -- A firm statement that communal troubles would not be permitted in the new India Dominion was made tonight by Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, Prime Minister, in a broadcast on his two-day visit to the riot-swept Punjab.
A negotiating committee of the Atlantic Coast district of the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, last night accepted an offer of a 10-cent an hour wage increase from shipping companies.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Aug. 19 (U.P.) -- Charles W. Nash, one of the nation's pioneer auto makers, took a turn for the worse and was near death himself today after he was told that the wife he had married sixty-three years ago had died last night.

Meat prices have climbed so high in recent weeks that many restaurateurs are cutting all but one or two meat dishes from their menus, Paul Henkel, president of the Society of Restaurateurs, reported yesterday.

With one of the largest influxes of visitors in the city's history in prospect, officials of the American Legion expressed confidence yesterday that they would be able to house all who will attend the twentyninth annual national convention of the organization here next week.

BATAVIA, Java, Aug. 19 (U.P.) -- The Dutch and Indonesian Governments reported heavy righting tonight in central Java and the Republicans made a new appeal to the United Nations to take quick action to avoid an island-wide war.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Rain put a temporary halt to the forty-eighth Grand American Trapshoot today, but failed to cool the guns of 925 starters in the 200target sixteen-yard North American clay target championship.

BOSTON, Aug. 19 -- Archbishop Richard J. Cushing of Boston unleashed the bitterest public denunciation in his career tonight with statement that seven "handpicked" American Protestant clergymen had signed an "infamous and monstrous" document when they asserted that Roman Catholics and Archbishop Aloysius Stepmatz enjoyed freedom of worship in Yugoslavia.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 19 -- The United Nations Security Council reached complete and final deadlock on the Balkan controversy tonight when the Soviet Union cast two vetoes within thirty-eight minutes to block Australian and United States resolutions -- the last on the agenda.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 19 -- While the top American combinations were running into difficulties, Australia's two teams put on display that stamped them as dangerous contenders in the National doubles tennis championship at the Longwood Cricket Club today.
An 82-year-old woman was evicted yesterday from her tworoom apartment in an old brownstone building she formerly owned.
The State of Michigan will sell on Sept. 10 an issue of $30,000,000 of soldier bonus bonds maturing March 15, 1949-64. Earlier this year, the state sold $200,000,000 of bonus bonds.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The Office of Defense Transportation today lifted the embargo on coal shipments to Canada via the Canadian National Railways or destined to points on those lines, in effect since Aug. 14.

Though Congress went home, the problem of the "displaced persons" of Europe remained behind, more terrible than ever. The Stratton bill, which would permit 400,000 DP's to enter the United States over a four-year period, had been effectively pigeonholed by a House subcommittee; a Senate bill for similar legislation had not even reached committee stage.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- President Truman announced a threeway shift of high Federal personnel today to prepare the Government for the "critical problems" of displaced persons.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The announced denial by James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, of the request of the major networks that union musicians be allowed to play simultaneously for an AM and FM broadcasting will be taken up by the FM Association with the Department of Justice for an investigation and ruling.

GENEVA, Switzerland, Aug. 19 -- Except for a few organizational details and the question of the relations of the International Trade Organization to the World Court, the drafting of the new version of the International Trade Charter has been completed.

CADIZ, Spain, Wednesday, Aug. 20 -- A total of 134 bodies had been recovered early today from the wreckage left by the explosion of a naval torpedo and mine factory that shook this city of 80,000 Monday night.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Representative Forest A. Harness, Republican, of Indiana, today assured Secretary Marshall that the House sub-committee on propaganda, of which he is chairman, did not intend to interfere with the State Department's dissemination of "proper information" on the Marshall Plan for European reconstruction.

HAVANA, Aug. 19 -- The revolutionary expedition allegedly being prepared here to oust President Trujillo in the Dominican Republic has to all appearances retired behind a veil of secrecy. Cuban officials hotly deny Dominican charges that these revolutionists have been receiving aid from the Cuban Government.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Aug. 19 -- Delegates to the convention of the Disabled American Veterans applauded and cheered a speech today by Senator George Malone, Republican of Nevada, severely criticizing the foreign policy of the United States.

Real estate and property management interests are "putting heavy pressure" on members of the City Council to ease the controls proposed in the Sharkey rent bills, Joseph T. Sharkey, vice chairman and majority leader of the council, asserted yesterday.

BRIGHTON, England, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Eleven of fourteen professional golfers nominated for the British Ryder Cup team battled for money -- and tickets to Portland, Ore., to oppose the United States in November -- in the opening round of the London News Chronicle tournament today with Dai Rees strengthening his position as one of the "probables."

ATHENS, Aug. 19 (AP) -- A guerrilla force of 1,000 was beaten back to the slopes of Mount Vermion in Macedonia today after a fierce attack on the industrial town of Naoussa, fifty miles west of Salonika, Greek press dispatches said.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 19 -- The General Telephone Corporation of New York filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission today covering 200,000 shares of $50 par value cumulative convertible preferred stock.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Aug. 19 -- Gladiolus growers from thirtyfive states, Canada and Holland, gathered today for the opening of the International Gladiolus Show in Kalurah Temple. This is an outgrowth of the regional show held for three years and deserves its name in every respect.

Seventy-four of New York's ninety-six child care centers will continue to operate after Sept. 30 under a plan just approved by the New York State Youth Commission, Edward E. Rhatigan, Welfare Commissioner, announced yesterday.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 19 -- The State Constitutional Convention that has been in session here since June 12 gathered momentum today. With completion of the bitterly debated judicial article, reports were circulated that a compromise would be effected between Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll and Hudson County Democrats on the tax clause.
LONDON, Aug. 19 (Reuters) -- England finished in a strong position against South Africa today at the end of the third day's play in the fifth and last cricket test match of the series.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19 -- James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, refused today to lift his prohibition against the simultaneous broadcasting of music on AM (standard) and FM (frequency modulation) radio stations.

AMSTERDAM, Aug. 19 (ANETA) -- Prices on the Stock Exchange moved up briskly in light trading. Gains were most notable among Indies plantations issues, predicting an expected favorable development in the Indonesian situation. Industrials, oils and shipping shares also were strong, while banking stocks and State bonds were steady.

An important new line of wood finishing materials has been added to the plywood products nationally distributed through more than thirty branches by United States Plywood Corporation, and further additions will be made under future development of these products, A.R. DeVos, president, Breinig Bros., Inc., Hoboken, N.J., revealed here yesterday.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 19 -- Meyer C. Ellenstein, Commissioner of Public Works, today started his campaign against the leasing of Newark's airport and marine terminal to the Port of New York Authority with an attack on Mayor Vincent J. Murphy.

Parades on Wheels Parades are not what they used to be anywhere since clanking machines have taken over from prancing horses and motorized rolling stock has replaced in great part the tramp, tramp, tramp of the boys marching.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, repeated today his challenge to the Republican party to nominate Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio as its Presidential candidate in 1948, then called for Representative Fred A. Hartley Jr. of New Jersey to be his running mate so that labor, in defeating them could repudiate the labor bill which they sponsored.

DETROIT, Aug. 19 -- The Yankees gave their final swing through the West a negative inaugural today at Briggs Stadium. Shortly after 1 o'clock the league leaders got off the train which carried them, from New York, and two hours later they were in the process of dropping their scuffle with the Tigers, 2 to 1, before 19,984 fans.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 19 -- Saratoga's old horse park was a happy hunting ground for players of favorites today. Five of the people's choices did what their backers expected of them, the quintet being headed by the Darby Dan Farm's Darby d'Amour in the Class C Schenectady Handicap.

Although commercial bankers here have been considering prospects for resumption of business operations in Germany, the view prevails that only the most limited opportunities are available and that such considerations are generally premature.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Dr. Angel Morales, leader in exile of the opposition in the Dominican Republic, today described the charges of President Rafael L. Trujillo Molina that armed Communists planned to invade the Republic from Cuba, as a smoke screen to cloak the President's own campaign to intimidate opposition forces within the country.

Negotiations between the Port Authority and the Navy Department to permit partial use of Floyd Bennett Field for commercial aviation have completely broken down. The public welfare demands that they be reinstated and kept alive until a fair solution is found.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 19 (U.P.) -- A Paraguayan Foreign Ministry announcement said today that the five-and-a-half month old Paraguayan civil war virtually had ended with the surrender of revolutionary forces attacking the capital city of Asuncion.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The Postoffice Department said today it had alerted its inspectors to crack down on a new version of the old ."chain letter" craze -- baited with a $2,048 lure.

A series of questions regarding religious and political freedom in Yugoslavia was put to the Rev. William Howard Melish, assistant rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity, Brooklyn, in a telegram made public yesterday by the Rev. Edward Lodge Curran, president of the International Catholic Truth Society.

PARIS, Aug. 19 -- The most important single commitment that experts expect will be undertaken by the sixteen nations represented in the European economic conference under the Marshall Plan will be that to be proposed in the report of the currency committee, calling for Internal financial reforms.
CHICAGO, Aug. 19 -- Addiction to strong drink is now a predominating vice in the United States the National Catholic Women's Union said today.

BOSTON, Aug. 19 -- Channeled education in the Soviet Union is a threat to world peace, Dr. George S. Counts, Professor of Education at Teachers College, Columbia University, and authority on international relations, declared in an address here tonight.
The Eastern section of La Guardia Field no longer will be "an island floating on soup" if the engineering efforts started yesterday by the Port of New York Authority are successful.

Evidence that it is holding the price line and adhering to contract terms in the textile and garment field brought a flood of congratulations yesterday to Goldstein Levin, dress manufacturers here. The concern had expressed its views in an advertisement published yesterday.

Fractional losses again were sustained yesterday by the stock market in another dull session. Volume was the smallest since June 9, with turnover on the Stock Exchange at only 600,000 shares, against 710,000 on Monday. Final quotations were around the lows of the session and the composite rate showed a recession of 0.46 point.
