HAMDEN, Conn., Aug. 19 (AP) -- Three persons, father, mother and son, died here today in a terrific crash involving their automobile and a seventeen-ton trailer truck.

PETROPOLIS, Brazil, Aug. 19 -- The Inter-American Defense Conference through its key commission No. 2 grappled today with the question of what to do in cases of threats or acts of aggression against any American nation.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The Paraguayan Government declared today that the would-be rebel besiegers of Asuncion were on the run and announced that a fleet of rebel river craft had surrendered unconditionally.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your recent editorial, "Good, But Not Good Enough," dealing with the report of Housing Commissioner Moses, caused me to make further inquiries into the housing situation in New York City.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 7,000 head, total, 9,500, market active, 25 to 50 cents higher on all weights and sows, but market very uneven and some sales butchers over 270 pounds and

TOKYO, Aug. 19 -- Strategic releases of imported foodstuffs by the occupation have dealt a telling blow to the Japanese food black market. In the past month the extra-legal rice quotations in the largest cities have been halved. They remain high, but the first crop estimates, released today by the Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry, are strongly encouraging and support the Government hopes that gains against inflation can continue.

Patrick J. Shanley, one of the Shanley brothers, who operated the famous Shanley restaurants in Times Square, New York, until the prohibition era, died yesterday in his home, 33 Parkview Terrace, Huntington, L.I. His age was 78.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Robert N. Denham, general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board, made public today the nonCommunist affidavit forms required under the Taft-Hartley Act and reiterated that all officers of labor organizations must sign the forms before availing themselves of the board's services.

LEGHORN, Italy, Aug. 19 -- Lieut. Gen. John C. H. Lee, commanding general of United States troops in the Mediterranean theatre, deplored today the publication in the United States of articles that, he said, falsely charged him with personal misconduct and mismanagement of his troops.

PETROPOLIS, Brazil, Aug. 19 -- On the eve of his speech to the plenary session of the Inter-American Defense Conference tomorrow, United States Secretary of State Marshall appeared tonight to have brought Argentina, Chile and Mexico closer to Washington's point of view on keeping the projected Treaty of Rio de Janeiro clear of economics.

As many observers expected, strong discontent and bloodshed have emerged in the actual process of fixing the boundaries between the new Dominions of India and Pakistan. Abstract slogans of the past have now descended to hard measures -- the division of districts, and of families.

For the first time in several months, the nation's gasoline stocks last week recorded a gain, according to the weekly figures of the American Petroleum Institute. They increased 65,000 barrels to 84,963,000 at the week-end. A week earlier, stocks were 84,898,000 barrels, and on Aug. 17, 1946, they were 87,015,000.

An underwriting group headed by Sills, Minton Co, Inc., today will make a public offering of 102,000 shares of $1 par value common stock of the Jahn Ollier Engraving Company, Chicago, at $6 a share. It will be the first public offering of stock in the company's forty-five year history.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 20 (U.P.) -- Col. Rafael Franco, commander-inchief of Paraguayan revolutionary forces, arrived today in Corrientes, Argentina, and reported to Argentine military authorities, asking for asylum in this country.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- The Federal Trade Commission issued today a policy statement making it clear that any informal trade agreements it reaches with an industry, or individual member of an industry, would not preclude its taking regular action at a later time against willful violators.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Armed, the Calumet Farms golden gelding raced to a new track record in the $43,750 Whirlaway stakes at Washington Park today, in his final tune-up for the $100,000 winnertake-all match race with Assaut Aug. 30.
BERLIN, Aug. 20 -- An unprecedented number of high-ranking officials have left the United States Military Government within the last month or are known to be about to leave.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 20 -- The International Typographical Union, American Federation of Labor, took a strong stand today in favor of political action and labor unity. Primary inspiration came from the New York delegates.
The transfer of the regular membership of Herbert T. Tomlinson to William A.H. Leonard of Moore, Leonard Lynch was approved yesterday by the board of governors of the New York Curb Exchange.

GENEVA, Aug. 20 -- Meeting a "thrice-delayed deadline, the Geneva conference of the Preparatory Commission of the International Trade Organization finished its detailed work at an early hour this morning. A new draft of a charter for the International Trade Organization has been completed.

BATAVIA, Java, Aug. 20 (London Times Dispatch) -- An implied warning that the Dutch in Indonesia would renew their military operations unless the Republican Government revised its attitude and methods was voiced in a broadcast tonight by Dr. Hubertus J. van Mook, Acting Governor General of the Netherlands East Indies.

DON'T look now but that large and uncouth chap who was just leering over your shoulder was none other than King Football. His majesty's crown was tilted rakishly over one eyebrow, almost as though he were smugly aware of the fact that his arrival on the scene was both early and unseasonal. However, the big guy definitely is here -- or at least he will be here on the morrow.
FALL RIVER, Mass., Aug. 20 -- Citizens of Fall River, Democrats and Republicans alike, turned out today to observe Joe Martin Day honoring the Republican Speaker of the House of Representatives.

BOSTON, Aug. 20 -- Governor Thomas E. Dewey was accused today by Dr. Abraham Lefkowitz, principal of the Samuel J. Tilden High School, Brooklyn, of having acted against the best interest of the public when he signed the Feinberg salary law.

Ten years ago General Pershing and General Harbord, even then two aging men, stood together once more on the immortal field of Belleau Wood and Chateau-Thierry. They looked again across the slopes of the long, gravedotted valley where American valor had flung back Ludendorff's veterans from the very crest of victory.

AMSTERDAM, N.Y., Aug. 20 (AP) -- The Mohawk Carpet Mills of Amsterdam asserted today that the War Assets Administration apparently acted in a "highly arbitrary" manner in selling the New River (Va.) ordnance plant to the Burlington Mills of Greensboro, N.H.

EASTPORT, Me., Aug. 20 -- Displaced persons from the American zone in Germany would be brought here not only to learn trades but to work without cash payment and possibly for the profit of private Americans, producing tractors, shoes or other products for export to South America, under a plan agreed to by Eastport officials and Frank Cohen, New York financier, for the use of deserted Passamaquoddy village.

The National Broadcasting Company's local television station, WNBT, plans an unprecedented period of program, activity between tomorrow and Labor Day. In all, it expects to be on the air for more than seventy-seven hours during the eleven-day period, which would be a record for the video industry.

While the Soviet vetoes of the Australian and American resolutions calling on the Security Council for action in Greece were anticipated, the world is nevertheless shocked to see a great member Power deliberately block the operation of the peacemaking machinery on precisely the kind of issue the United Nations was instituted to deal with.

BOSTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- After hitting the million home attendance mark for the first time in history, the Braves celebrated that feat in disappointing fashion today by losing, 16 -- 10, to the Pirates.

The Greater New York Retail Furriers Association will launch an advertising campaign early next month in metropolitan newspapers to emphasize the new styling of fur garments. The copy will stress the association's message that women can be assured of correct styling in purchase of fur garments from members of the association.

Heads of the four national radio networks issued a joint statement last night declaring that the action of James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, in banning duplication of musical programs on both standard and frequency modulation stations was "clearly contrary to public interest."

Sterling Reaction The announcement that Britain would suspend free convertibility of sterling except in transactions with the United States produced a mixed reaction in financial circles yesterday. While any move to stretch Britain's dwindling supply of dollars is generally desirable, this latest action, it was held, might produce awkward repercussions.

GENEVA, Aug. 20 -- Following is a summary of the third or Geneva draft of a charter for the International Trade Organization as completed, subject to the final approval of the plenary meeting, by the second session of the Preparatory Commission of United Nations Conference on International Trade and Employment.

A research program covering textile supplies and delivery dates to assure a steady supply of women's and children's apparel was launched yesterday in the offices of the National Retail Dry Goods Association. The objective is coordination of the schedules of mills, cutters-up and retailers.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 20 -- Machine gun, Bren gun and small arms fire, along with rocketing flares, made Jerusalem look and sound like a battle area tonight after Jewish terrorists opened fire on guards in an unsuccessful attack on the Criminal Investigation Department building in the Russian compound.
CHICAGO, Aug. 20 (AP) -- The Athletics, held scoreless for seven inning's, came to life in the last three rounds to gain a 5-to-2 teninning decision over the White Sox before 3,806 fans today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 20 -- Alvin Mayer of Innis Arden teamed with his 23-year-old son Dick, New York State champion, to spreadeagle the field as they retained their Westchester County Golf Association father and son championship with one over par, 36, 35 -- 71, over the Westchester Hills course today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- A drastic policy of dismissing cases in which unions have failed to follow the Taft-Hartley law's registration requirements was announced today by Robert N. Denham, general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board.

A "no-strike, non-liability" clause that rules out recourse to the courts or to the new National Labor Relations Board by either side is included in a two-year agreement signed yesterday by the RCA Victor Division of the Radio Corporation of America and the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, CIO.

MUROC, Calif., Aug. 20 --The Navy sent the jet-propelled D-558 Douglas Skystreak, piloted by a veteran combat flier, roaring four times over a three-kilometer course at an average of 640.7 miles an hour today to set a new international air speed record.

PETROPOLIS, Brazil, Aug. 20 -- Senora Eva Peron, wife of Presiden Juan D. Peron of Argentina, made a dramatic entrance today into the Quitandinha conference hall just five minutes before United States Secretary of State Marshall was scheduled to speak.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The current controversy between Mr. Moses and the city administration over unsubsidized housing would be more in order under circumstances other than those confronting us today.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 20 -- One of Hollywood's oldest enigmas cropped up today to enhance the perplexity surrounding the House Labor Subcommitte's effort to untangle the jurisdictional strike of the American Federation of Labor in the movie studios.

FREEPORT, L.I., Aug. 20 -- The first hold-up on any of the Long Island State Park Commission's roadways, traveled by millions of motorists since they were started in 1929, occurred at 11 A.M. on Meadowbrook Causeway here today and netted $25,000 to the two perpetrators, who escaped.
ALBANY, Aug. 20 -- Railroads will be permitted to increase their class rates on intrastate freight shipments by 10 per cent, effective on Friday, the Public Service Commission announced today.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 20 -- Registration, statements covering 100,000 shares of convertible preferred and 113,678 shares of common stock were filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission today by two companies.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- The United States and Great Britain agreed today to come to the rescue of London's nearly exhausted dollar resources by temporarily ending free convertibility of sterling to dollars and suspending further withdrawals from the United States loan to Britain.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20 -- With no relief from the current hot and dry weather in the main Corn Belt in sight until the end of the week, if then, a general buying movement developed today in the corn market on the Board of Trade.

GREENVILLE, Miss., Aug. 20 -- Cotton planters, manufacturers and the Federal Government agreed yesterday to speed up mechanization of southern agriculture as the only hope of regaining lost foreign markets and competing with cheap synthetic and other fibers at home.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday until late in the afternoon when the volume of business increased. The weather was again the outstanding factor and when reports from Texas indicated that showers were becoming more general, prices gave way under selling pressure, the market closing barely steady and only slightly above the lowest marks of the day with net declines of 34 to 48 points.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 20 (AP) -- America's top-flight shotgun artists fired 154,500 rounds of 12gauge ammunition at the fortyeighth, Grand American trapshoot today and succeeded only in selecting a possible Class C champion as the largest entry lists in history snarled the program.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., Aug. 20 -- Mrs. Irving Kaufman of Sunningdale put together a 36 and 47 to take the medal with an 83 as sixteen players qualified for match play in the women's invitation tournament at the Briar Hills Golf Club today.

GUATEMALA, Aug. 20 -- The Inter-American Congress of Women, with delegations from the United States, Canada, South and Central America, opened here today. The Congress is sponsored by local Union of Democratic Women, recently formed by former members of the Guatemalan branch of the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Al Gettel's triple and a single by George Metkovich scored PinchRunner Eddie Bockman in the tenth inning of the nightcap of a twi-night double-header tonight to give the Indians a 7-6 triumph over the Senators.
Matched or harmonizing ensembles, skirt and shirtwaist combinations and ankle-length dancing dresses were featured in the college shop fashion show at Loeser's yesterday.

The Rev. Dr. Guy Emery Shipler, editor of The Churchman, issued a statement yesterday terming Archbishop Aloysius Stepinatz of Yugoslavia a "quisling collaborator with Hitler" and said the facts in his case "are the last things the Roman hierarchy wants reported in this country or elsewhere."

BOSTON, Aug. 20. -- Misuse of intoxicating liquor was denounced today by Archbishop Richard J. Cushing, of Boston, as the "root cause of much of the crime in the world today and among our own youths."

WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 20 (AP) -- The United States is fast overtaking the lead held by foreign nations in practical development of turbines and jet engines for aircraft power, Guy W. Vaughan, president of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation, said today at the annual stockholders meeting.

A special meeting of stockholders of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company has been called for Oct. 15 to authorize a new issue of convertible debentures that a would be offered stockholders in the ratio of $100 of debentures for each six shares of stock held.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 6,500 head; total, 8,000; market slow; uneven but generally steady on all weights and sows; top, $27.50: bulk of good and choice 180 to 260 pounds, $26.75-$27.25;

PETROPOLIS, Brazil, Aug. 20 -- Secretary of State Marshall's assurance that the United States had not lost sight of the economic problem of this hemisphere appeared to satisfy most LatinAmerican delegates today.

The Shortest entry in Ben C. Clough's enormous and rewarding collection of tall tales and folk tales -- "The American Imagination at Work"* -- is on the title page. It is a meaty bit of dialogue between a police court judge and a voluble drunk. The judge asks: "Is this true"? And the drunk answers: ''Well, judge, it's kinda true."
DETROIT, Aug. 20 -- The Yankees' farewell to Briggs Stadium for the 1947 campaign was one that long will be remembered by the 23,508 fans who viewed it.

City control of rents survived the first attack on its legality yesterday in an opinion by Municipal Court Justice Walter Adikes that the New York City hotel and rooming house law and regulations are valid under the State Constitution, the City Charter and the City Home Rule Law.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. Aug. 20 -- Following the script precisely, the King Ranch's But Why Not and the Circle M. Farm's Cosmic Missile made a two-filly fight of the Alabama Stakes through Saratoga's stretch today, with But Why Not managing to eke out a head decision at the end of the action-packed duel.
LEGHORN, Italy, Aug. 20 -- The United States Army's plans to evacuate Italy have been suspended indefinitely because of Russia's delay in ratifying the Italian peace treaty, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Edgar L. Warren, who will retire tomorrow as chief of the United States Conciliation Service, in his final report today declared that the transfer of the service out of the Department of Labor under the provisions of the Taft-Hartley Act on Friday "marks a major turning point in the administration of the labor relations policy."

Los Angeles, Calif., will offer $14,300,000 of new various purpose bonds on Sept. 16, at a rate not exceeding 4 1/2 per cent, it was announced yesterday. The bonds, dated Oct. 1, 1947, will become due Oct. 1, from 1948 to 1987. These obligations are a portion of the $53,663,344 bond authorization approved at a city election held May 27.

VIENNA, Aug. 20 -- Austria's Student Union, representing the student bodies of all the institutions of higher learning in Austria, announced today its withdrawal from the International Student Union in Prague, Czechoslovakia.

The owners of 100 hotels have indicated their intention to make alterations necessary for compliance with recent state and city safety laws, it was reported yesterday by Bernard J. Gillroy, deputy commissioner of the city Department of Housing and Buildings.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Much space has been devoted to the Indonesian situation without making this question much clearer to the reading public. The reason is that the reporting has been largely confined to Indonesian propaganda while important facts favorable to the Dutch were never printed.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Aug. 20 -- Max Charles Gaines, 56 years old, of 16 Colonial Road, White Plains, president of Educational Comics Publications, New York, and Samuel W. Irwin, 44, of 85 Parmelee Avenue, Hawthorne, N.J., an auditor for Armour Co., in Paterson, were killed today when their motorboat was struck by another craft.
A wildcat walkout of 4,000 longshoremen of the International Longshoremen's Association tied up the nation's largest liner and ten other ships yesterday.
SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 19 -- Army authorities here disclosed this morning that three United States soldiers had been arrested and detained by the Soviet Union on the border on Aug. 12.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- The State Department disclosed today that Joseph M. Dodge, American representative on the Austrian Treaty Commission, has been recalled for "consultation" based on his objections to the behavior of the Soviet Union representatives on the commission.

PETROPOLIS, Brazil, Aug. 20 -- Secretary of State Marshall told the inter-American peace conference today that economic assistance to Europe by the United States must receive priority over demands for a "Marshall plan" for Latin America.

BELMAR, N.J., Aug. 20 -- The members of the Brielle Marlin and Tuna Club ran up the top point score in the second day of the Atlantic Coast tuna tournament, but they are still 50 points behind the score run up by the Atlantic City Tuna Club on the first day.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- President Truman estimated today that the Government would end the 1948 fiscal year June 30 with a record surplus of $4,700,000,000, this without allowing for possible costs of the Marshall Plan.

BERLIN, Aug. 20 -- In a joint official statement, the United States and British Military Governments vigorously denied today "allegations that Allied authorities arbitrarily fix the value of the mark in relation to foreign currencies in each case as it suits them."

A proposal to raise the standards of teaching in the New York public school system through the increased use of modern instructional materials has been approved by the Board of Superintendents, it became known yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 20 -- The whole question of what disputes quarreling nations should bring before the Security Council arose today when the Brazilian member of the Council, Dr. Joao Carlos Muniz, proposed that Egypt and Great Britain again attempt to resolve their troubles by direct negotiations.

Attempts will be made to safeguard the future handling of ammonium nitrate, which is needed in large quantities as commercial fertilizer, it was announced yesterday at the annual conference of the International Association of Fire Chiefs in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Runway 13-31, which is 6,000 feet and the longest landing strip at La Guardia Field, where operations currently include more than 500 daily inbound and outbound flights, will not have to be closed this winter, J.C. Evans, chief engineer of the Port of New York Authority, said yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 20 -- A A public school here will be headed by a Negro for the first time in the city's history. The appointee is William L. Cobb, 37, educated at Texas College and the University of Southern California, who now is taking graduate work for a degree in education at the University of California.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 20 -- One weekly opposition newspaper was suppressed "for an indefinite period" and another was excoriated in a Government communique today.
ITHACA, N.Y., Aug. 20 -- Collective bargaining depends too much on "strong-arm stuff," Dr. Edwin G. Nourse, chairman of President Truman's Council of Economic Advisers, asserted here tonight.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20 -- A wage structure beyond the railroad industry's capacity to maintain would constitute a "serious disservice" to the carriers' employes, Gustav Metzman, president of the New York Central Railway Company, said today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Russia's foreign policy was described as intolerant, suspicious and distrustful tonight by Library of Congress experts, who warned that Soviet policy was keyed to a program of world revolution, possibly at the risk of World War III.

After observing "frightful" conditions in some of the buildings operated by the Department of Hospitals on Welfare Island, Mayor O'Dwyer said yesterday that the city could not carry out its much-needed hospital program unless capital and labor signed a three-year stabilization agreement so that construction costs would be lowered.
LONDON, Aug. 20 (Reuters) -- South Africa failed by only 28 runs to force a dramatic victory over England in the fifth and last cricket test, which ended in a draw today.

Chancellor Robert M. Hutchins of the University of Chicago outlined yesterday the details of a $12,000,000 nuclear research program started by his university to be devoted exclusively to the peacetime uses of atomic energy. The program is to be wholly independent from the Governmentsponsored program of the Atomic Energy Commission and is expected to be financed with funds from industry and private capital.

The increasing importance of women in life insurance was recognized yesterday by a major life insurance company, when George L. Harrison, president of New York Life Insurance Company, announced the election of Mrs. Douglas Horton, the former Mildred McAfee, president of Wellesley College, as a director.

MINDEN, Germany, Aug. 20 -- The executive committee on economics has asked newly formed Bi-zonal Economic Council to speed up its deliberations and action on the monetary reform plan for Germany, it was learned today. At the same time the committee presented to the council, a report on the problem by German "experts."

The behavior of Irving McCann as counsel for a House subcommittee in seizing the general counsel of the AFL by the throat and knocking him down, and later insulting a national vice president of the AFL with remarks in shockingly bad taste, is a disgrace which degrades still further the standing of Congressional hearings.
WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Aug. 20 (AP) -- A world-wide shortage of all fuels this winter because of unprecedented demand was predicted today by the Anthracite Institute.

Negotiations for the stabilization of labor costs in the construction industry were resumed yesterday when a small group of hoisting engineers and crane operators returned to work after a two days' absence. The engineers had remained away from their jobs because of the negotiators' failure to agree to their demands for a wage increase.

LONDON, Aug. 20 -- The expectation that the first experimental power plant running on atomic energy may be working in the United States within two years is expressed in a report by the scientific advisory committee of the British Trades Union Congress.

New charter provisions designed to stabilize the shipping market as well as stimulate coastwise and inter -coastal steamship operations were announced yesterday by the Maritime Commission at its local headquarters, 45 Broadway.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Aug. 20 -- Few if any flowers except gladiolus could have withstood Tuesday's heat and still have been worth seeing by the thousands who visited the International Gladiolus Show today. The twoday exhibition closed tonight.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Representatives of the National Collegiate Athletic Association this week will meet separately with Commissioners Bert Bell of the National Football League and Jonas Ingram of the All-America Conference to "clear the fog" on professional football's approach to collegiate players.

DETROIT, Aug. 20 -- The General Motors Corporation disclosed today that production at its huge Chevrolet and Pontiac divisions, accounting for virtually one-third of the national output of automobiles, would be halted for indeterminate periods between Aug. 23 and Sept. 7.

Fifty boys and their mothers appeared in Bronx Magistrates Court yesterday for the arraignment of Howard Farrington, who was identified by twenty of the youths as the man who had swindled them, of watches, bicycles and other property.

A new fifteen-cent airmail stamp whose design, according to Postmaster Albert Goldman, is "truly descriptive of New York," had its first-day sale yesterday after a ceremony in the lobby of the General Postoffice Building at Thirtysecond Street and Eighth Avenue.

Our Secretary of State delivered some hard facts in soft words yesterday in his first address to the InterAmerican Conference at Petropolis. First, he reminded the delegates that they had convened for the sole purpose of drafting a hemisphere defense treaty.

The American Guild of Musical Artists and the Metropolitan Opera Association have completed their annual negotiations and the contract between them is now signed, sealed and delivered. Both sides are pleased, for last year's dispute over the size of the chorus delayed the signing until midSeptember.

SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 20 -- Maj. Gen. Albert E. Brown, chief of the United States delegation on the joint commission, today announced that the American representatives on the joint United States-Soviet commission had submitted a report to Washington on the deadlock of the joint commission.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 20 -- -- Play in the National doubles championships was brought to a standstill by rain today at the Longwood Cricket Club after a round had been completed in the veteran's singles and two quarterfinals had been finished in the father-and-son doubles.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Relief supplies valued at $43,000,000 are scheduled for shipment by the United States to Austria during the period June through September, the State Department reported today.

Directors of most of the twentytwo child-care centers to be dropped from the city's program of day care under the terms of a new plan for delinquency prevention, announced by Welfare Commissioner Edward E. Rhatigan on Tuesday, were uncertain yesterday just how the change would affect their nurseries.
Consumers are beginning to increase their poultry orders as a result of the recent steady rise in beef and pork prices.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- The text of Secretary Marshall's address today before the InterAmerican Defense Conference at Quitandinha, Brazil, follows: I welcome this opportunity to participate with so many distinguished statesmen in the Inter-

The stock market labored yesterday through another dull and uninteresting five hours and emerged with another moderate setback, the third consecutive retreat of the week. Selling pressure was no worse than in the two previous sessions, but the lack of bidders allowed prices to sag gradually to the lows of the day at the close.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 20 -- The leaders of the Davis Cup teams of the United States and Australia today nominated four players each for the challenge round match to be held in the Forest Hills Stadium Aug. 30, 31 and Sept. 1.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 20 -- An anti-discrimination clause that would ban segregation in public schools and the militia was adopted today by the State Constitutional Convention. New Jersey thus promises to be one of the first states in the Union to have such a provision in its charter.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 20 (AP) -- The Cubs and Phillies played to a 1-to-1 tie today in a game halted by rain with, the Phils at bat in the seventh inning.

LAHORE, Pakistan, Aug. 20 (AP) Maj. Gen. T.W. Rees, commanding a joint military border force here, said today that he believed that underground leaders were waging a systematic program of extermination in riot-torn Punjab where the best compilations indicate that thousands of Indians have been killed since Aug 11.

The remaining members of the Hungarian soccer team representing the Ferencvarosi Torna Club of Budapest, arrived from Mexico at Newark Airport yesterday. The New York Hungarian Sport Club of the National Soccer League, which will meet the tourists tonight in their only New York appearance at Dexter Park, Woodhaven, Queens, entertained the visitors last night at dinner in the Hungarian Garden Restaurant on Second Avenue.

Emetia Polizio, known also as Joe Pledge, the Queens gambler whose accusations started the current inquiry into alleged police graft, lost yesterday his plea for removal of detectives assigned to guard him twenty-four hours a day.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20 -- The Catholic Central Verein of America ended its annual convention today with the adoption of a declaration of principles containing the statement that "it is an obvious fact that prejudice and hatred against the Catholic church still persists."

From the pages of Grimm's fairy tale, the Educational Products Company has borrowed the characters of Hansel, Gretel and the wicked witch and molded them into a set of plastic cooky cutters that will make that favorite bedtime story even more exciting for little boys and girls.

The plan to bring back Willie Howard in "Girl Crazy" -- the idea had its beginnings two years ago with Mr. Howard himself -- is in the making again. This time it is Theodore Adolphus who promises to undertake the venture and he says he has the necessary capital to follow through.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce reported tonight that manufacturers' sales in June totaled $13,600,000,000, continuing the "high level which has characterized the first half of 1947."

LONDON, Aug. 20 -- The United States delegation to the threepower conversations on the level of German industry, opening here Friday, will include Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor in Germany, and his political adviser, Ambassador Robert D. Murphy, it became known today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- The country's rail carriers laid before the Interstate Commerce Commission today their need for greater earnings to avoid financial jeopardy and to maintain necessary improvements to facilities and services to the public.

A charge that Bedloes Island, on which the Statue of Liberty stands, presents "many aspects of backyard unsightliness" was made yesterday by the Monument Builders of America and the American Monument Association at the final session of their convention at the Hotel New Yorker.

LINCOLN, Neb., Aug. 20 -- The American farmer today is not on a spending spree, although his pockets are lined with the highest cash income on record. The farmer is just as much concerned with the rising spiral of retail prices as his city cousin, but he may be putting more savings away as protection against the day when his record crops will not pull record prices.

With a reasonable facsimile of their old devastating power the Giants ended an eight-game losing streak by defeating the Reds, 10 -- 3, in the first game of a doubleheader at the Polo Grounds yesterday. Then, to the chagrin of 10,509 spectators, including Governor Thomas E. Dewey, they relapsed into offensive ineptitude in dropping the nightcap, 3 -- 2.

ANN ARBOR, Aug. 20 -- Only 65 per cent of American families were able to save any money during 1946, and another 27 per cent of them used up past savings or went into debt, a study made by the Survey Research Center of the University of Michigan reveals.
LONDON, Aug. 20 -- With buyers holding off pending the outcome of the Washington economic conference the new account in stock markets here today opened quietly.

When Mrs. Mildred MacColl and Abraham Chanrye were called before Magistrate Morris Rothenberg in Gamblers Court on bookmaking charges yesterday, the magistrate was a little startled to see two handsome blond women step up as the complainants.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 20 -- Warner Brothers announced today that Lew Ayres has been signed to play opposite Jane Wyman in the screen version of "Johnny Belinda" which will go before the cameras this month with Jean Negulesco directing.

NANKING, Aug. 20 -- The Chinese Government today erected a new legal barrier against the exclusive Russian occupation of the Chinese port of Dairen. The Executive Yuan order declared that the harbor was closed to foreign shipping.

A strike that would deprive 1,200,000 Manhattan bus riders of their customary - transportation will be recommended to employes of the New York City Omnibus Corporation at a mass meeting tonight, it was announced yesterday by Austin Hogan, president of Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union, CIO.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Aug. 20 -- Five German physicians and two laymen found guilty by a United States tribunal of war crimes, crimes against humanity and membership in the SS were sentenced today to death by hanging.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Aug. 20 -- Jimmy Cullen of the North Hills Club in Douglaston, paced a record field of 190 golfers with a gross score of 37, 37 -- 74, four strokes over par and a 74 -- 8, 66, in the one-day tournament of the Metropolitan Golf Association at the Fresh Meadow Golf Club today.

A white-collar job in the Police Department can be anything but dull. Take the record of Abraham Gralla, who announced yesterday at Police Headquarters his retirement, effective Sept. 1, after serving as a civilian clerk for the last thirty-four years.

PARIS, Aug. 20 -- Authoritative sources indicated today that in entering the three-power discussion in London Friday, the French Government did not expect to prevail over the decision by the United States and British commanders in Germany to increase the Ruhr steel production to 10,000,000 tons annually by the year 1951.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 20 -- The United States recommended today that the job of eliminating the four most destructive weapons known to man -- the atomic bomb, radioactive materials and deadly chemical and biological mixtures -- be handed over to the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninetyfour cities, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended Aug. 13: An increase of $146,000,000 in commercial, industrial and agricultural loans and a decrease of $235,000,000 in demand deposits adjusted.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Ewan Clague, director of the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the United States Department of Labor, declared today that there was no business recession on the horizon even if exports fell considerably.

Latin Collections Favorable Despite reports of dollar shortages, collections from Latin-American countries were said here yesterday to continue favorable. Priority lists, as in the case of Brazil, and actual limitations on imports, as in Mexico, however, may be expected from other countries if the exchange situation becomes more acute, it was reported.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I am a Socialist and a staunch supporter of the British Labor party. That in no way diminishes my great regard for the United States of America, where I lived for eighteen months during the early part of the recent war. It was a period when I could learn and appreciate the attitude of Americans to my own country, England.

A priest and a rabbi were among a group of survivors of Nazi concentration camps who arrived here yesterday from Bremerhaven on the transport Ernie Pyle. The ship, carrying 835 passengers, including 733 aliens, docked at Pier 90, North River, at 10:15 A.M.

One can only view with very serious concern the continuing rise in trafficaccidents in New York City. The Bureau of Safety of the Police Department for last week reported 501 accidents, against 393 a year ago. With the same number of fatalities for the week -- namely, seven -- it reported 671 injuries, as compared with 477 in the same period in 1946.

MADISON, N.J., Aug. 20 -- James M. Landis, chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, has urged George S. Burgess, a resident here, to accept the noise of airplanes, about which he complained vehemently last month, with patience, tolerance and a measure of resignation.

CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., Aug. 20 -- With an adjourned game from the tenth pound pending, Isaac I. Kashdah of New York continues to cling to the lead by the narrowest of margins today in the annual tournament for the open championship of the United States Chess Federation at the White Plaza Hotel.
New Yorkers were praised yesterday by a dozen British school teachers as "friendly," "helpful" and "very kind."

The City Planning Commission's proposal to amend the zoning regulations to give itself power to permit the location of large-scale parking garages and parking lots anywhere in the city was opposed yesterday by Robert Moses, City Construction Coordinator.

A new agreement has been signed between negotiators representing licensed personnel on thirty -five colliers running to ports between Norfolk, Va., and Portland, Me., and the operators of the vessels, it was announced here yesterday.

LONDON, Aug. 20 -- In announcing temporary suspension of the free convertibility of sterling into dollars for all nations outside the dollar area, Hugh Dalton, Chancellor of the Exchequer, told the British people tonight that the decision would mean reduced overseas purchases and cuts in the current food rations.

A national campaign advertising the precepts of the American Heritage Foundation, which aims to spur Americans to a fuller realization of the responsibilities and privileges of their citizenship, was announced yesterday by the Advertising Council.

Sales of industrial vacuum cleaners by the U.S. Hoffman Machinery Corporation are up more than 300 per cent above pre-war levels, L.B. Hardtla, vice president in charge of the air appliance division, revealed here yesterday.

NANKING, Aug. 19 -- Government officials concerned with financial matters are pleased wtih the initial business reaction to the operation, so far, of the new foreign exchange system. The general approval that has greeted the new measures has provided a good psychological situation for their enforcement and it is believed that a beneficial effect on the national economy will result.

With two out and the Dodgers leading the Cardinals by 2-1 in the ninth inning at Ebbets Field yesterday, Spider Jorgensen made what may become known as "the boot of the year," thereby permiting the tying run to score.

Calling All Critics An old-fashioned friena of ours has been reading a lot of book reviews of late. He finds some of them depressing. The reviewers seem tremendously interested in what he calls dissective processes and like to break butterflies on wheels.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The admirable editorial in your issue of Aug. 19 rings the true note in regard to the application of the Truman Doctrine in Greece. You rightly indicate that the Government allegedly set up in the mountains by Markos Vafthiades is neither free nor democratic.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 20 -- The fifty homes that fifty war veterans began building collectively here on one parcel of land on Palmer Avenue last Nov. 26 approached completion today virtually on schedule and with costs no more than 10 per cent higher than estimates.

The airlines, having passed through their post-war slump, are due for prosperity, Sigmund Janas, president of Colonial Airlines, told the New York Society of Security Analysts at a luncheon meeting yesterday. Asserting that losses on uneconomic equipment had now been written off, he decribed the financial position of the lines as suitable for long-term speculative investment.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's budget review today, complete except for its references to accompanying tables: Continuing the practice of former years, I submit at this time my annual midyear review of the budget.

Belgium's dollar position now is better than it was two years ago, and the country so far this year has exported more than $1,000,000,000 in goods and is importing only slightly less than this amount, Andre Closset, distributor for Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., in Belgium and Luxembourg, said in an interview here yesterday.

BUDAPEST, Aug. 20. (AP) -- A travel-weary United States track team won seven and tied for two firsts in a thirteen-event program today. The meet was started 30 minutes after the Americans, arrived following a six-hour bus ride, from Bratislava.
ALBANY, Aug. 20 -- Winners of 100 special state scholarships awarded to children of deceased of disabled New York State service men were announced today by the State Education Department.

Government by law is the best protection against the tyranny of totalitarianism and the abuses of government through the influences of pressure groups, Young B. Smith, dean of Columbia University's Law School, declared in his annual report to Dr. Frank D. Fackenthal, acting president of Columbia, made public yesterday.

The seven Scalzi children, whose parents took them to live in Franz Sigel Park in an open-air pavilion after refusing three dwellings offered to them by the Welfare Department, were deemed the victims of neglect after a hearing yesterday in Bronx Children's Court.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21 (U.P.) -- Bert Bell, commissioner of the National Football League, met with representatives of the NCAA today on the problems arising between professional and collegiate football, and both sides agreed that a "better understanding" resulted from their talks.

August drags out its days on sticky, muffled feet and the monotone symphony of insect wings is heard on the land. The sun reluctantly pulls itself above horizon's rim and starts its course across a washed-blue sky. Ragpuff mists blossom briefly on the lowlands. Twice in each cycle of months comes a period of quietness.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (UP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board issued tonight an emergency safety regulation requiring four-engined airliners to use longer runways or carry less weight in warm-weather take-offs.

The stock market managed yesterday to give some evidence of stiffening but price, changes proved too narrow and volume too light to show any conclusive results on the day. A minor selling flurry developed in the last few minutes of trading and a scattered few issues surrendered early gains but the list closed slightly higher on balance.

PARIS, Aug. 21 -- The treaty establishing a French protectorate over Morocco, where the United States has a special legal status, will probably be replaced by a new French-Moroccan agreement, it was officially acknowledged here today.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The Cardinals, routed by 9 -- 2 in the first game as their pitching and inner defense came apart, struck back at the Phillies with a long-range attack to take the nightcap, 13 to 3, and gain an even split in a double-header today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Department store sales in the week ended Aug. 16 were 6 per cent below sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from the like period of 1946.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21 -- Disputing the calendar and ignoring the thermometer, it's football time in the windless Windy City, where tomorrow night more than 103,000 gridiron fans will jam Soldier Field, grateful for the opportunity to watch the Chicago Bears tangle with the college All-Stars.

PARIS, Aug. 21 -- The French Government made a further retreat from its wage-stabilization policy today when it informed management and labor it would agree to an average increase of 11 per cent for wages as established in July, 1946.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- During the week ended Aug. 20, member bank reserve balances decreased $21,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 21 -- The tiny nitrate island of Nauru will be brought under the United Nations trusteeship council, it was announced here today by the Australian Government which now administers the territory.

BERLIN, Aug. 21 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States military governor, who with his political adviser, Ambassador Robert D. Murphy, will fly to London early tomorrow for the three-power conference on German heavy industry, said today he hoped the conference would not require more than three or four days.
SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 21 -- The American Command here has not received word of the fate of three United States soldiers abducted by Soviet troops in the border town of Yohyon on Aug. 12.

PETROPOLIS, Brazil, Aug. 21 -- The United States delegation at the Inter-American Defense Conference acted today to put collective hemispheric action agains aggression, short of actual armed attack, firmly under the oversight of the United Nations.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 21 (AP) -- A bill requested by President Gabriel Gonzalez Videla, authorizing the Government to suspend individual liberties and declare part or all of Chile in a state of siege for six months, was adopted by the Chamber of Deputies early today.

Health Commissioner Israel Weinstein congratulated a tavern keeper yesterday who caused the arrest of a bogus health inspector. The commissioner took the occasion to warn all proprietors of food establishments to demand an official Health Department identification card of all men representing themselves as inspectors.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 21 -- Final judgments in three injunctive actions instituted against brokerage concerns in October, 1945, by the Securities and Exchange Commission were entered on Tuesday by Federal Judge Robert N. Wilkin in Cleveland, the commission announced at its headquarters here today.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 21 -- Billy Johnson had himself a time at Municipal Stadium tonight as the Yankees crushed the Indians, 9 to 3, shattering a five-game winning streak by Lou Boudreau's Tribe, and lengthening the gap on the pursuit in the top-sided American League pennant race.
TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 21 -- New Jersey sold $10,000,000 of veterans' housing bonds today to a syndicate of fourteen banking houses for the lowest rate in its financial history.
NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 21 -- Senator-elect Theodore G. Bilbo, champion of white supremacy, died at 1:05 P.M. today. His age was 69.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Aug. 21 -- City Commissioner Michael Borelli, Director of Public Safety only since Tuesday, today assumed the duties of the Chief of Police, pending the appointment of a new Police Chief to succeed the retired chief, Edward McFeely.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Since the end of the war my country, China, seems to be one of the centers of international intrigue as well as a main topic of parlor conversation and newspaper articles.

Seasonal trade expansion as reflected in the commercial, industrial and agricultural lending activities of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System, slowed last week, such loans increasing only $11,000,000, to reach a total of 4,320,000,000.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Aug. 21 -- A three-man joint subcommittee of the Senate Committees on, War Surplus and National Defense opened hearings today regarding disposition of the Government's $140,000,000 wartime Basic Magnesium Project at Henderson, Nev.
Plans for a campaign to ask Mayor O'Dwyer for city support of child care centers were completed at a meeting held at Union Settlement, 237 East 104th Street, last night.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: England's serious economic situation and the apparent failure of Prime Minister Attlee to call attention to the root of the trouble deserves the serious concern of all of those who appreciate what it means to this country and the world to have Great Britain pull through and share with us the great task of really "making the world safe for democracy."

President Truman's review of the federal budget furnishes an excellent illustration of how much guesswork there is in estimating revenues. It also reveals a difference of opinion, which will puzzle the layman, as to how much was actually saved by the Republican-directed economy drive.
CHICAGO, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the united States Department of Agriculture follows:

The Navy, in its negotiations to lease Floyd Bennett Field to the Port of New York Authority, must "not dilute" the national defense funds given to it by Congress, Secretary of the Navy James Forrestal wrote in a letter to Representative Donald L. O'Toole, which the latter made public last night.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 21 -- Despite this week's announcement by Universal-International that its production program would not be curtailed as a result of the British tax problem. "Song of Norway," which was scheduled for the cameras next January, has been postponed indefinitely because of the British situation, it was learned today from S.P. Eagle, who was to have produced the film.

Plentiful supplies of fish, including porgies, shrimp and mackerel, offer an economical alternative this week-end to meat, which, despite lower wholesale prices, remains at the same high level it has held for the last two weeks in retail stores.

In response to charges leveled by Mrs. Natalie Wales Paine, the Rev. Dr. Guy Emery Shipler defended yesterday The Churchman, Protestant periodical, as a magazine that has opposed the political philosophy of the Vatican, rather than the Roman Catholic Church as a religious institution.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21 -- A group of Chicago oil dealers told a Senate subcommittee today that the alleged shortage of fuel oils was a trumped-up device of the major petroleum producers to drive independent distributors out of business.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 21 -- For the second successive night a furious fusillade of firing broke out in the central business section of Jerusalem after a phantom gunman reportedly fired on police headquarters and billets along the Princess Mary Avenue.

BOSTON, Aug. 21 -- Edwin H. Miner, Associate United States Commissioner of Education, told the convention of the American Federation of Teachers today that many of those who were ostensibly working for general Federal aid for schools were hindering its establishment by their insistence on special-advantage provisions.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 21 -- A considerable movement of population is taking place in the disturbed areas of both India and Pakistan, according to authoritative reports reaching New Delhi.

New cancellation privileges on orders for future delivery of industrial materials are being asked under revised purchasing policies revealed here yesterday by spokesmen for leading companies. When orders are placed with delivery dates beyond the normal sixty days limited on regular orders, they said, clauses are being inserted reserving the right of the buyer to cancel at any time up to thirty days in advance of shipment.

AMSTERDAM, Aug. 21 (Aneta) -- Continued sharp advances in Indies plantations issues, apparently in expectation of renewed Netherlands action in Indonesia, were the only notable features of a dull trading session on the Stock Exchange.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Swift completion of the current Anglo-American talks on relaxing the terms of the loan to Britain was indicated today as suggestions of hope and optimism intruded for the first time into a conference based on urgency and crisis.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is as I feared -- the new IND subway cars have the tiny boudoir fans instead of our old horizontal-bladed ones. Is it possible that, before subscribing to this futile system of "ventilation," no subway engineer or member of the Board of Transportation took the trouble to ride on a hot day on any of the BMT cars already so equipped?

Mobile fire-fighting units with equipment standardized on a nation-wide basis to insure adequate supply were recommended yesterday as the best means of defense against fires resulting from war by Col. Frank A. McNamee Jr., former director of the United States Strategic Bombing Survey.

Frank Cohen, financier and sponsor of a plan to bring displaced persons to Passamaquoddy, Maine, denied yesterday that the venture would produce any monetary profits. Mr. Cohen said his plan was intended to give the refugees training which would enable them to migrate to Argentina, Uruguay and Brazil, and to live there independently.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- A renewed protest by the United States to the Soviet Union over continued Soviet occupation of the Chinese port of Dairen was made public today by the State Department.
EASTPORT, Me., Aug. 21 -- This city of 3,400 persons is hoping to salvage something from the dream it once held and has explored every possibility to do so.

Park Tilford is planning a national advertising campaign this fall on wines and liquors which company executives call the most dramatic and extensive in the 107-year history of the company. The campaign will be predominantly in newspapers, and seventeen magazines will be used in full color, two color and black and white in full page, half page and one-eighth page.

DETROIT, Aug. 21 (AP) -- A double victory over the Detroit Tigers following a players vote of confidence in Manager Ossie Bluege restored peace to the Washington Senators today after reports of a rift between players and Bluege had capped an 11-game Senator losing streak.

Turner Blanchard, Inc., contracting stevedores, have purchased the three one-story industrial buildings at 19, 21 and 23 Fifth Street, Brooklyn, from Joseph Mauro. The property, near Smith Street, occupies a plot 66 by 100 feet.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- President Truman today named the Secretaries of the Army, Navy and Air who will direct the nation's military security under the Secretary of Defense appointee, James Forrestal.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 21 -- In making public a voluminous report based upon an eleven-month investigation and study of the stock market break of last Sept. 3, the Securities and Exchange Commission declared today that it found "no evidence that market prices depended at any moment on manipulative activities."

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 21 -- Efforts were launched today to reach a compromise formula for action by the United Nations Security Council on the Indonesian issue. If they are successful, a resolution will be introduced tomorrow, probably separating the two issues of Dutch-Indonesian compliance with a United Nations "cease fire" order and arbitrating the differences between the two countries.

A fighter who jumped into prominence on the strength of a single victory will appear in the feature bout at Madison Square Garden tonight. He is Joe Di Martino of Bridgeport, recent knockout conqueror of Marty Servo, former velterweight champion.

If there is one great fact to be learned from the eighty-first annual report of the Brooklyn Children's Aid Society, just published, it is that, in the words of Guy Du Val, president of the organization, "it costs much more to turn a child back from delinquency than it does to give him the care which keeps him from becoming a delinquent."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The Department of Justice was disclosed today to be engaged in a post-war revival of its long-range anti-trust program, with the recently announced drive against price conspiracies in food, clothing and housing as an added activity.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 21 -- Arnold Hanger's Argentine-bred Pujante, with Ruperto Donoso, the Chilean horse backer, urging him on in purest Castellano, made his record two for two over Saratoga's seven-furlong course today when he won the twenty-first running of the American Legion Handicap.

A prediction that the American Legion convention here next week would bring $10,000,000 worth of business to New York City was advanced yesterday by Hugo E. Rogers, Borough President of Manhattan. He expressed the belief that the convention, which opens Thursday and runs through Sunday, also would break all records for attendance.

BOSTON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Coming from behind with a five-run rally in the seventh inning of the second game, the Boston Braves defeated Chicago, 6 -- 4, after having thumped the Cubs, 8 -- 2, in the opener at Braves Field today to gain a full game on the second-place Cardinals and a half game on the leading Dodgers.

At a tumultuous mass meeting, nearly 1,000 members of Local 100, Transport Workers Union, CIO, voted overwhelmingly last night to strike "not later than 4 A.M., Monday, Sept. 8," against the New York City Omnibus Corporation if the bus drivers and maintenance workers do not receive a permanent pension plan, which they say was part of a recent arbitration award.

Alterations of business and residential buildings continue to lead the Manhattan projects as filed with the, Department of Housing and Buildings, while in the other boroughs new groups of small homes are being planned. One plan called for extensive interior changes in the Empire State Building.

Platinum Futures The Commodity Exchange, Inc., may add platinum to the list of metals in which it maintains futures trading. A member of the Exchange has brought up the matter of establishing a futures market in platinum and has sent a letter to the committee of the Exchange supervising the metal group.

Twenty manufacturers of replacement brake and clutch lining materials, who account for 96 per cent of the nation's production, were indicted yesterday by a Federal gand jury on charges of violating anti-trust laws. They were named in three indictments along with fifty-three individuals and the Brake Lining Manufacturers Association of 370 Lexington Avenue.

Mrs. Rose Fitzgerald, 38 years old, whose address since Aug. 7 has been 89-11 170th Street, Jamaica, will appear in Queens Municipal Court today to answer charges that she is a squatter on her own property. Counter to the trend, her tenant seeks to have her evicted.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The State Department took the view today that American forces would remain stationed in Italy until the Italian peace treaty had been ratified by the four major powers involved in the negotiations.

DETROIT, Friday, Aug. 22 -- After ten weeks of negotiations an agreement was reached early today on the new Ford Motor Company pension plan between Ford and the United Automobile Workers, CIO. Company officials said details would be announced later in the day.

A Chinese typewriter, the principle of which also can be used in typesetting, and which is expected to revolutionize Chinese office work and publishing, has been invented by Dr. Lin Yutang, Chinese philosopher and author.

Part, at least, of the confusion and controversy which have surrounded the National Labor Relations Act of 1947 since it was passed over the President's veto two months ago stems from the fact that this far-reaching piece of legislation has not until now been fully operative.

Production of most inorganic chemicals continues at a high level with the output of many above that of a year ago, L.L. Horch, New York regional director of the United States Department of Commerce, declared here yesterday on the basis of the August "Chemicals and Drugs Industry Report" of the Department.

GENEVA, Aug. 21 -- William L. Clayton, United States Under-Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, returned to Geneva today after talks in London with Sir Stafford Cripps, president of the Board of Trade, on outstanding tariff issues between the United States and Britain.
The eight-day strike of the Seafarers International Union, AFL, against the Isthmian Steamship Company ended last night in what union spokesmen called "a complete victory" for the men.

Negotiations between the Bethlehem Steel Company and the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, CIO, were resumed yesterday at a meeting in the company's offices at 25 Broadway. There was no comment from either disputant but another session was scheduled for this morning.

Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt and her son, Elliott; Mayor O'Dwyer and Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, headed a list of celebrities who attended the world premiere of the documentary film, "The Roosevelt Story," at the Globe Theatre last night.
Almost all classes of meat dropped in price this week at local wholesale markets, the United States Department of Agriculture office here reported yesterday.

On July 15, last, in fulfillment of the letter of the Anglo-American Loan Agreement, the British Government undertook to restore the pound sterling to full convertibility, except on capital transactions, into all currencies, including the dollar. This week, under an agreement reached here between representatives of the British and American Governments, that arrangement was suspended, except in the case of the United States or other countries included in the "United States account."
Clint Hartung, the Hondo Hot-shot, produced a heat wave of his own at the Polo Grounds last night, when he pitched himself a crackling two-hitter.

Jacques Fray, erstwhile member of the piano team of Fray and Braggiotti, is scheduled to become the first of the classical disk jockeys hereabouts. Beginning Oct. 4, it has been learned, he will be heard from 7:30 to 8 P.M. on Mondays and Wednesdays over WQXR.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The death of Theodore G. Bilbo posed problems today for Senate officials.
A new peak in residential property sales for Queens and Long Island was reported yesterday by Butterly Green, brokers, for the past four weeks, with 560 deals closed at prices aggregating $6,160,200.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The United States has received a protest from the Soviet Union against the impending conference of Great Britain, France and this country to raise the industrial level of the economically merged United States and British zones, the State Department disclosed today.

Early success in meeting Mayor O'Dwyer's demand for long-term stability of construction costs was forecast yesterday, when employers and union leaders endorsed "in principle" a three-year freeze of wages and other working conditions.

Pullman, Inc., railway car manufacturer, reported yesterday for the six months ended on June 30, a consolidated net income of $5,017,317 after charges and taxes, equal to $1.86 each on the 2,700,031 capital shares outstanding after the recent purchase of 529,866 shares.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 21 -- The Winged Foot Golf Club retained the John Hoffhine cup, symbolic of the strongest ten-man golf team in the metropolitan area, with an aggregate gross score of 770 for Westchester Country Club's championship west course today, continuing the monopoly it has held since the tournament's inception four years ago.

Justin R. Whiting, president of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation, announced yesterday the formation of the Southern Company, a new holding concern for five Southeastern electric utility operating companies that had been part of the Commonwealth and Southern system.

THE baseball fans have been honoring so many ball players with special days of late that what once was an unusual event has fallen into strictly a dime-a-dozen category. But there will be a totally different sort of "Day" at the Polo Grounds tomorrow. Hank Greenberg, a local boy who made good, will finally be paid tribute by his fellow-townsmen.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 21 -- The International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, an affiliate of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, announced late today that it had "alerted" all of its longshore locals on the West Coast "to make defense preparations for a lockout expected sometime after midnight tomorrow."

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The Athletics took over third place in the American League tonight, when they defeated the luckless Browns, 8 to 5. Jeff Heath's 22d and 23d home runs accounted for four of the Browns' runs off Rookie Bill McCahan.

Marking what Russian church observers here regard as "a highly significant" development in negotiations now going on for reconciliation of the Russian Orthodox Church in North America with the Moscow Patriarchate, Metropolitan Benjamin Fedchenkov, Patriarchal Exarch of the Aleutian Islands and North America, has been notified he must vacate the post he has held for fourteen years.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The refusal of James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, to permit the simultaneous duplication for FM (freguency, modulation) broadcasting of the musical programs of the networks and other AM (standard) stations with which FM stations are affiliated, was the subject of a forty-five-minute conference today between officials of the Department of Justice and of the FM Association.

The National Theatre Conference, a cooperative organization of directors of community and university theatres, is ready to launch its Tryout Studio in New York. The project involves the presentation of a select group of graduates from drama departments and civic theatres over the country in four or five plays selected to best show off the talents of aspiring performers.

When Ewell (Whitey) Blackwell took the mound for the Reds yesterday, not many in the crowd of 14,577 at Ebbets Field held out much hope for the Dodgers. The elongated Cincinnati ace was gunning for his twentieth victory and, in registering three decisions over Brooklyn, had allowed only a single run.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Six persons were hospitalized tonight for injuries received when lightning smashed a crowded Broad Street bridge across the Scioto River in downtwon Columbus.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox rapped Tex Hughson for three runs in the first inning for a 3-2 victory over the Boston Red Sox before 30,008 persons tonight. It was Chicago's third victory in sixteen games against the Red Sox this season.

OTTAWA, Aug. 21 -- Finance Minister Douglas Abbott issued today, what was intended to be a reassuring statement correcting the impression given in a press account of a statement by Sir Wilfrid Eady that Canada would be one of the principal sufferers of the decision to halt the convertibility of sterling into dollars.

ATHENS, Aug. 21 -- The Greek Government faces a frightening problem of what will become of refugees from the guerrilla warfare next winter. Peasant refugees number 250,000 throughout the country. About 190,000 are in Macedonia and Thrace.

AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, Aug. 21 -- The Netherlands, with the $195,000,000 loan from the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development will approximately bridge the gap in the country's balance of payments for 1947.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 21 -- The applications of Italy and Austria for membership in the United Nations were vetoed today by Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister. The two applications were strongly supported by the United States and Great Britain.

The Rockaway Beach, Queens, Lifeguard Team won the Park Department's annual lifeguard tournament yesterday, scoring firsts in seven of the nine events. The tournament was held on the oceanfront at Beach Ninety-sixth Street, Rockaway Beach, and was watched by 5,000 persons.

The reported decision of British authorities to send back the 4,400 Jewish refugees of the ship Exodus 1947 to Germany brought vigorous protests from American Jewish organizations here yesterday. Several groups asserted that the proposal to ship the refugees now in the French port of Port-de-Bouc to Hamburg inevitably would lead to retaliation and more bloodshed.

Commuting Life's Hardships We are pleased and even deeply moved to see the attention that our colleagues on The Sun are giving to the problems of the commuter. It has always seemed to us that these were inadequately dealt with.

CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., Aug. 21 -- Isaac I. Kashdan of New York gained the title of open champion of the United States Chess Federation and the first prize of $1,000 tonight, when he drew his game in the twelfth and semi-final round with Miguel Cuellar of Colombia in a Ruy Lopez after 36 moves.

Demand for legalized off-the-track race betting spread to Westehester County yesterday. The clamor was started last week by the Queens County grand jury investigating alleged police protection of bookmakers.

Suspension of free convertibility of sterling into dollars, as provided in the new agreement between Great Britain and the United States, is likely to intensify the decline in American exports which began in June. This was the immediate reaction in foreign trade circles here yesterday.

BELMAR, N.J., Aug. 21 -- A typical northeaster, bringing occasional squalls and a rough sea, made it impossible for the contestants in the Atlantic Coast Tuna Tournament to get off-shore this morning, and unless the weather abates by daybreak tomorrow the competition will be concluded.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended Aug. 16, 1947, totaled 906,305 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 1.061 cars, or 0.1 per cent, more than for the preceding week, 18,752 cars, or 2.1 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year, and 253,473 cars, or 38.8 per cent, more than during the corresponding week two years ago.
The American Federation of Musicians, headed by James C. Petrillo, is refusing to make instrumentalists available to new concerns anxious to enter the recording business, it was learned yesterday.

PARIS, Aug. 21 -- A significant victory was won by Premier Paul Ramadier for the Government's statute for Algeria tonight against an Assembly minority that included members of his own Socialist party.

LONDON, Aug. 21 -- An estimated 4,500 unauthorized Jewish immigrants quartered aboard three British ships off Port de Bouc, France, since July 29, have received an ultimatum to debark in France before 6 P.M. tomorrow [1 P.M. Eastern Daylight Time] or be taken to the British zone of Germany, the Foreign Office announced today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- A Republican reply, to President Truman's review of the Federal budget was issued today by Senator Styles Bridges of New Hampshire and Representative John Tabor of New York through the Republican National Committee.
The fifteen-story and pent-house apartment building at 65 East Ninety-sixth Street has been resold by Frederick Brown to a client of A. Robinson for investment.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Indications that talks to draft a peace treaty for Japan would be put off until late fall or early next year, were given today by the State Department.

It was a small and conservative collection of furs that the fashion press was invited to see at Jaeckel's yesterday morning. The coats followed certain well outlined trends. With the exception of one small evening jacket in ermine, all were collared.

Influenced by the fashions of older sisters, this fall's teen-ager fashions have a much more lady-like air and are given, new appeal and excitement via longer skirts and tiny waists as seen yesterday in a showing presented at Martin's of Brooklyn.

A hotel owner, who told the court he had brought eviction proceedings against a tenant merely to test the validity of the city's rent law, was found guilty yesterday in War Emergency Court, Manhattan, of having violated that law.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 21 -- Chinese wives and children of American war veterans are being held incommunicado by the Immigration Service here for months, the American Civil Liberties Union charged today.

LONDON, Aug. 21 -- A large section of the British press placed upon the United States today the onus of Britain's action in foregoing any further withdrawals from the dollar loan as part of the decision to suspend the free convertibility of sterling.

LONDON, Aug. 21 -- Reaction in the stock markets to the announcement by Chancellor of the Exchequer Hugh Dalton of the suspension of free convertibility of sterling into dollars was good today. Relief from an intolerable position was reflected in the brighter tone that ruled throughout.

ROME, Aug. 21 -- Italy has been hard hit by the British Government's decision to suspend the convertibility of sterling into dollars. Italy has a sizable sterling balance standing to her credit in London and it constantly increases because Britain absorbs about 50 per cent of the Italian exports and Italy sells considerably more in Britain than she buys there.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 21 -- A big calm settled upon the national doubles tennis championships at the Longwood Cricket Club today. Both of Australia's pairs ware eliminated in the quarter-final round, and the furore over their being grouped in the same half of the draw suddenly subsided.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 21 -- The Constitutional Convention affirmed today this state's parochial school bus act, which was upheld last February by the United States Supreme Court in a five-to-four decision, by defeating an amendment to wipe out a provision that public funds may be used for the transportation of children to all schools, public or private.

Walter J. Riley has been appointed divisional sales manager in charge of the technical sales division, Westvaco Chlorine Products Corporation, New York. He formerly was assistant to the technical director.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Aug. 21 -- With the domestic political situation still unsettled, public discontent is reported growing despite efforts by President I. Inonu and the moderate Republicans to end the crisis.

Civil engineering construction work for the week ended Aug. 21 amounted to $109,382,000, according to the national summary compiled by Engineering News-Record. The figure was 91 per cent above the previous week, 13 per cent ahead of the same week last year, and 9 per cent above the average for the past four weeks.

A letter informing him of a $20,000 bequest from the estate of his mother came too late, and Rubin Moreno, 19-year-old, sometime pugilist, yesterday found himself held in Felony Court on charges of assault and robbery.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- With increases for agricultural and nonagricultural commodities, primary market prices advanced 0.3 percent during the week ended on Aug. 16, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Department of Labor.

NANKING, Aug. 21 -- Lieut. Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer and members of his mission are going through the final stages of their survey of China. They will leave Nanking Sunday for Tokyo where they expect to spend a day or two before going to Korea for a two weeks' study of the situation there.

ROCKVILLE CENTER, L.I., Aug. 21 -- The twenty-fourth annual Long Island Golf Association father and son championship brought out the largest field in its history. Forty-eight teams teed up over the Rockville Country Club course today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that the nation's corn crop was indicated at 2,437,000,000 bushels as of Aug. 15. This estimate compares with 2,659,949,000 bushels forecast as of Aug. 1; last year's record crop of 3,287,927,000 bushels and the ten-year (1936-45) average of 2,639,102,000.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21 -- While railroad employes since 1929 have been getting a larger part of railroad revenues, investors have be getting less, Dr. J.H. Parmelee today told a Wage Arbitration Board. Dr. Parmelee is the railroad's statistical expert and a vice president of the Association of American Railroads.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is a fine thing for all of the nations of a hemisphere to join in a search for peace and international cooperation. It is, however, doubtful to many of us that peace or security can be obtained through the medium of treaties, instead of law enforced by an international body to which all nations subscribe, Treaties are adhered to just so long as expedient.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The Labor-Management Relations Act of 1947, passed by Congress on June 23, will become fully operative tomorrow.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 21 -- Seven Soviet vetoes in the last four days gave impetus today to a growing campaign to divert the United Nations emphasis from the eleven-member Security Council to the vetoless fifty-five nation General Assembly.

Export credit collections in Latin-American countries by the twelve New York City banks participating in the monthly survey conducted by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, were "somewhat slower" during July, the bank reported yesterday.
