WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Potential abundance of cotton, wool, silk, flax and rayon, once the war-time economic dislocations in the production of textile raw material were overcome, was foreseen in a world fiber survey published today by the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations.

PETROPOLIS, Brazil, Aug. 21 -- The economic issues involved in the Inter-American Defense Conference here will come before an urgent plenary session tomorrow in a new form. The development virtually guarantees that a hemispheric economic conference will be held in Buenos Aires between July 1 and Dec. 31, 1948.

The cotton market was in a waiting position yesterday and in absence of active hedge selling or trade buying prices in the futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange moved feverishly over a range of 17 to 40 points. At times there was a fairly active demand from commission house, local traders and New Orleans which sent values up 9 to 30 points but heavy profit-taking late in the session caused a quick reaction.

A contract embodying a new "share of production" pay plan was signed at a luncheon in the Waldorf-Astbria Hotel yesterday by a New Jersey paper manufacturer and a Congress of Industrial Organizations union.

ROME, Aug. 21 -- The Russian veto of Italy's admission to the United Nations exploded late this evening in Italian political circles with effects similar to those of a bomb. It is thought that it may cause the fall of Premier Alcide de Gasperi's Government when the Constituent Assembly meets again on Sept. 9.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 21 -- A declaration of policy to refrain from signing contracts in the United States went whooping through the convention of the International Typographical Union (AFL) today. Not a vote of opposition was cast.

ITHACA, N.Y., Aug. 21 -- Frank D. Newbury, director and former vice president of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, declared here today that without "ample profits" and increased production, there could not possibly be higher wages, lower costs and lower prices.

PARIS, Aug. 21 -- The formation of an inter-party group in the National Assembly pledged to policies favored by Charles de Gaulle drew sharp reactions today from the Communists and Popular Republicans, two of the largest parties in the Assembly.
The port's, two-day dock strike spread yesterday to seamen of the National Maritime Union, delaying the express liner America of the United States Lines for the second day.

BERLIN, Aug. 21 -- In the late winter of 1939 a large number of Jews and part Jews, many of whom already had served in concentration camps, left Berlin for Shanghai, having been told by the Nazi regime to "get out." Today 295 of them returned.

A former official of the International Refugee Organization, who returned yesterday from five months in Europe, expressed the belief that the problem of resettling displaced persons can be solved within two years.

LONDON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Financiers and Government leaders of countries inside and outside the British Empire tried today to calculate the "disturbance of trade" that Chancellor of the Exchequer Hugh Dalton forecast last night when he announced the end of convertibility.

ATHENS, Aug. 21 -- A request that more members be assigned to the delegations and to the secretariat in view of the rising volume of their work was cabled by the United Nations Balkan subcommission at Salonika to the main commission in New York yesterday.

The Government had a net return of $182,000,000 from its construction and operation of the Big and Little Big Inch pipelines, it was disclosed yesterday by John D. Goodloe, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. This compares with a capital investment of $145,000,000, which is substantially the amount received by the Government when it sold the lines recently to a private company.

BOLZANO, Italy, Aug. 21 -- In the capitals of Western Europe the statesmen are at least talking of broad-minded things: of regional cooperation, of customs unions and even somewhat timidly and unofficially of a federation. But up here along the disputed frontiers of the Alps the minds of men still dwell in the narrow prison of nationalism, regionalism and even sectionalism.

To THE EDITOR OP THE NEW YORK TIMES: The controversy concerning the Mediterranean command of Lieut. Gen. J.H. Lee emphasizes how difficult it is -- perhaps impossible -- for most civilians to realize that the character of any Army unit is largely determined by the character of its command staff officers.

TOKYO, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Seven Japanese defense witnesses at the International War Crimes trial testified today that no military installations or fortifications existed on Palau, Truk, Saipan, Tinian and other mandated islands prior to the outbreak of war Dec. 7, 1941.

BATAVTA, Java, Aug. 21 (Reuters) -- The Indonesian Republican Premier, Dr. Amir Sjahriffoedin, tonight urged the Indonesians to continue their struggle against the Dutch in a broadcast in which he said that the Indonesian Republic would not be "intimidated into surrender."

Mayor O'Dwyer is now holding in abeyance again the demolition of the remains of Fort Clinton at the Battery on assurances from the Department of Interior that it will make "suitable financial provisions" for its restoration as a national monument. This restoration would cost about $300,000.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21 -- Representative Fred A. Hartley Jr., Republican of New Jersey, co-author with Senator Robert A. Taft, Ohio Republican, of the Labor Management Act of 1947, today gave a warning that management will be called to Washington to explain why some labor contracts have granted unions immunity from certain sections of the act.

LONDON, Aug. 21 -- The most ambitious agricultural program ever undertaken by Britain was placed before the nation's farmers today as the Government intensified its fight for the country's economic survival.

Unless the practice indulged in by some garment manufacturers of raising prices on contracts with retailers is stopped it will gain momentum, cause losses and undermine the American way of doing business, Joseph Goldstein of Goldstein Levin, manufacturers of daytime frocks, said yesterday.

Nail Deliveries Improved Deliveries of nails have improved extensively, purchasing agents revealed here yesterday. While there are reports of large back-orders continuing at the mills, deliveries here have improved substantially, they said.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 21 -- Nothing will be done by the Jewish Agency for Palestine to persuade the refugees on three British transports at Port, de Bouc to debark in France, Mrs. Golda Meyerson, head of the Agency's political department informed the Palestine Government today.
To gain data that some day may make it possible to predict tidal waves and volcanic eruptions, the Navy is charting the Aleutian chain magnetically, it was announced yesterday.

METROPOLIS, Brazil, Aug. 22 -- Argentina's proposal that the Americas agree to act collectively to repel aggression only in the case of aggressors from outside the hemisphere threw a shock today into the Inter-American Defense Conference.

The slowest week experienced since May by the stock market was terminated yesterday with no change in the pattern. Prices managed to exhibit some firmness but eased off slightly from the day's peak rates to close mixed, although with a slight advantage toward the higher side.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 22 (AP) -- In a bitter duel from top of the stretch to the wire Henry S. Horkheimer's Tony's Find out-gamed W.S. Horne's Skylighter to annex the Sea Shell Purse today. Mrs. W.W. Vaughan's Lanlast was third, three lengths farther back in the field of nine sprinters.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 22 -- The Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen, one of the largest of the country's independent unions, will move to abandon its independence, now enjoyed for nearly seventy-five years, "if and when" the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations effect a merger, it was disclosed today.

Sales of power tools for home-workshops now include more than 50 per cent larger range of products than were stocked here before the war, Max Richter, owner of Richter Tool Company, 141 West Forty-first Street, declared here yesterday.

ATHENS, Aug. 22 -- The activities of the Port of Piraeus were halted for a moment this morning while Archbishop Damaskinos blessed a bargeful of flour, the first to be received under the United States relief program. He also blessed those who had sent it.

BALDWIN, L.I., Aug. 22 -- Mrs. Ruth Torgerson of the Cherry Valley Club shot a 77 to take the Gross prize during the one-day golf tournament at the Willow Brook Club today. Mrs. Barbara Kirkland, Piping Rock, was second with 80.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- Additional shipments totaling about $18,000,000 in "urgent military supplies" have been en route to Greece since the middle of this month in continuation of the United States aid program, the State Department announced today.

Self-Service Banking A self-service banking device, designed to accommodate customers who might be inconvenienced as a result of the five-day week now being generally observed by banks throughout the state, has been developed by a bank in Syracuse.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Aug. 22 -- Authoritative traffic organization heads have notified shippers here that the reduction in class freight rates made effective to the South today by the Interstate Commerce Commission means practically nothing in savings.
For Better or for Worse Hezekiah Cobb, confirmed countryman and unterrified foxhunter, was speaking:

A movement is being started for a round-the-world celebration this fall of the centennial of the hymn "Abide With Me: Fast Falls the Eventide." The aim is to link "all lovers of the hymn into an international family," according to a letter from the Rev. Dr. H.J. Garland of Millom, Cumberland, England, published in The Presbyterian, national periodical printed in Philadelphia.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Al Lakeman blasted a ninth inning home run tonight to give the Philadelphia Phillies and Dutch Leonard a 4-2 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals, knocking the Redbirds six full games behind the Brooklyn Dodgers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- The Special House Committee on Foreign Aid has been divided into five subcommittees preparatory to sailing next Wednesday for studies of European requirements under the Marshall plan.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug 22 -- The first round in the renewed fight to give the United Nations General Asembly a greater voice in the admission of new members will be fought out in the Security Council next week, it was learned today.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 22 (AP) -- William H. Miller, 18, and George R. Miller, 20, cousins, of Manchester, Md., still eluded the law today after Judge Michael J. Manley gave them a fifteen-minute headstart and said that he "didn't like it" when a swarm of policemen besieged the courthouse and tried to arrest the youths.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 22 -- Albert Sharpe, who played Finian on Broadway in "Finian's Rainbow," has been signed by RKO to a seven-year contract, the studio announced today. He will make his American screen debut in "The Boy With Green Hair," an experimental film, which Adrian Scott will produce.

Resistance of consumers to high prices and grower reluctance to accept lower prices is reducing the size of the 1947 pack of canned vegetables considerably, according to reports yesterday in the food trade, The Government figures last week of a 10 per cent reduction in the fruit and vegetable pack were called conservative.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Aug. 22 (U.P.) -- The Government today branded as an "unfounded generalization" the United States State Department's protest against Hungary's alleged disfranchisement of 1,000,000 non-Communist voters.

The almost incredibly complicated structure of railway freight rates was modified yesterday, following a Supreme Court decision of May 12, to place the South and the western portion of the Mississippi Valley at less disadvantage in comparison with the North and East.

CHICAGO, Aug. 22 -- The grain markets continued their sensational advance on the Board of Trade today. September corn and oats sold at new peak prices and cash corn and fancy malting barley also went to a new high record as results of buying induced by a bullish construction placed on the Department of Agriculture's crop estimate, issued late yesterday, indicating a yield of 2,437,000,000 bushels, or about 400,000,000 under the 1937-46 average.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Before the war, I visited several of the more famous Mediterranean archaeological sites with my father, who was an epigrapher and head of the Classics Department at Vassar College. I came to share with him a considerable appreciation of the art of early civilizations.
BOSTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- After appearing in thirty-seven games in relief roles for the Cubs, right-handed Emil Kush held the Braves to four hits for a 5-1 victory tonight before a crowd of 25,466.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 22 -- The International Typographical Union (AFL) adopted an anti-Communist resolution today without dissent after the convention's bitterest political furore.

The Office of Rent Control adopted several amendments yesterday in the rent regulations under the new Federal Rent Control Law to ease the plight of landlords whose rent schedules are so low as to cause them hardships.

Five classical and contemporary dramas of the British Broadcasting Corporation's "World Theatre" series, in which uncut versions of the plays were broadcast, are to be brought to local audiences through recordings by WNYC, Seymour N. Siegel, acting director of the municipal station, announced yesterday, after completion of arrangements with the BBC.

Retail August fur sale volume is running from 10 to 40 per cent below a year ago on a countrywide basis, reports here yesterday indicated. The showing, however, is not considered too unfavorable because the comparison is made with the extremely high sales totals of August, 1946, and also because retail prices at the start of the month averaged probably 25 per cent under those of last year.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In THE TIMES recently there appeared a dispatch by Tillman Durdin giving the views of Dr. Lo Chia-lun, Chinese Ambassador to India, on the question of the Mongolia-Sinkiang border. According to Dr. Lo, Soviet cartographic treatment of this boundary took a sudden turn after 1940 when the Soviets lost the confidence and friendship of the Governor of Sinkiang, Gen. Sheng Shih-tsai.

BERLIN, Aug. 22 -- The United States is expected to tell France at the London conference, which started today, that no change in the United States intention to reactivate the German industry was contemplated, nor would the United States consider any proposal for increased shipments of Ruhr coal to France unless a proper adjustment is made for the coal going direct to France from the Saar.

World-famous Rosenthal china from Germany has returned to this country after an absence of more than ten years. Traditional shapes and decorative patterns of the Bavarian chinaware have remained unchanged, but a new imprint -- "U.S. Zone" -- now appears on the back of each piece under the manufacturer's mark.

NANKING, Aug. 22 -- The Government's purge of troublemaking students hit the American-church-supported University of Nanking yesterday. The University received orders from the Ministry of Education to dismiss thirty-seven students.

The Secretaries of Army, Navy and Air chosen by President Truman confirm expectations. All are competent men, well seasoned in public service and with vigor that will stand them in good stead in the heavy tasks of reorganization ahead. They are already at work in their departments, an advantage as we move into the transition period under unification.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 22 (AP) -- Gordon Persons, chairman of the Alabama Public Service Commission, said today the "so-called" freight rate reductions which went into effect today in the South and parts of the West "will mean practically nothing" to this part of the country.

While longer range trade prospects in the Philippines are highly favorable; rehabilitation, particularly in Manila, is proceeding very slowly, Sidney Rothchild, vice president of the Excelsior Pearl Works, Inc., said in an interview here yesterday.
DETROIT, Aug. 22 (AP) -- The Tigers retaliated against the Senators today, paying back yesterday's double defeat from Washington by sweeping a twin bill, 7-6, 2-0.
CHICAGO, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

MARIENBAD. Czechoslovakia, Aug. 22 -- The World Federation of United Nations Associations ended a five-day assembly today. It rejected a move that it advocate summary abolition of the veto power in the Security Council and recommended measures on atomic and other disarmament similar to the American proposals rather than to the Russian ones.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 22 -- Largescale "anti-foreign" riots broke out throughout Cairo today. The police fired on mobs as they charged police ranks. At least ten persons were wounded, including the leader of the Moslem Brotherhood, which is alleged to have precipitated the rising.

The Supreme Court threw out yesterday a fourteen-year-old injunction forbidding a union of window cleaners to wage a secondary boycott, just as the Taft-Hartley Act, which bans secondary boycotts, went into effect.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 22 -- Adversity was a long time catching up with the Yankees here, but it came tonight and in a painful, double-dose.

LONDON, Aug. 22 -- The tripartite conference for the discussion of proposals to raise the level of industry in the economically merged United States and British zones in Germany opened in an atmosphere of optimism here today.

James Thurber and Elliott Nugent, who wrote "The Male Animal" seven year ago with advantageous results, are getting together again as a playwriting team During the last few months Mr. Nugent and The New Yorker kennel expert have been plotting out a comedy over the telephone and by letter.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Aug. 22 -- Billy Edwards, 16-year-old Hempstead High School senior, the defending titleholder who recently won the Metropolitan junior crown, found himself extended in the opening round of match play in the Long Island junior golf championship tourney today on Rockville Country Club course.

BATAVTA, Java, Aug. 22 (AP) -- The Dutch Army announced fourteen clashes with Indonesians at scattered points in Java and Sumatra today, including one "furious fire fight" in north Sumatra where 200 Indonesians were put to flight with many dead and wounded.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 22 (U.P.) -- An attempt to have the Prensa and the Nacion, Argentina's two large newspapers, pay customs duties on all the newsprint they have imported since 1939 was rejected by the Prensa today as without legal justification.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 22 (AP) -- A three-run double by Walt Judnich in the eighth inning enabled the Browns to come from behind tonight and take a 7-to-5 decision from the Athletics.

DENVER, Col., Aug. 22 -- The Department of Agriculture called attention yesterday to the tremendous amount of work to be done and the cooperation needed in soil and water conservation in the vast Missouri Basin to help protect the rich farm belt against floods and erosion.

ITHACA, N.Y., Aug. 22 -- Senator Irving M. Ives, who has been the object of criticism from labor because of his support of the Taft-Hartley Act, made an unscheduled last-minute appearance at a labormanagement conference here today, but went unrecognised by union and industry representatives alike.

The trial and convictions in Nuremberg of fifteen Germans for atrocities committed in concentration camps sharply focuses the question of genocide for the United Nations. That men could commit such crimes against humanity is unbelievable enough. That there is still no international machinery for dealing instantly with those crimes when they occur, now or in the future, is far more unbelievable.

BOSTON, Aug. 22 -- After a vigorous debate of more than four hours, the American Federation of Teachers, AFL in convention here adopted today the recommendations of its commission on educational reconstruction that Federal appropriations to aid education be limited to public schools.

PARIS, Aug. 22 -- As the conference of sixteen European nation enters the last stage of its labors to provide a foundation for the Marshall Plan its leaders are worried, it was learned today. They are said to be concerned lest the final list of European needs should loom too large in terms of dollars and lest the outline of what Europe can do for itself meanwhile should appear sketchy and provisional.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J. -- Aug. 22 -- With the State Constitutional Convention recess until Tuesday, because of inability of Republicans and Democrats to reach a compromise on the controversial tax issue, Mayor Frank H. Eggers of Jersey City declared today that "the greatest danger to a harmonious concluding to the convention lies in the intrusion of the railroad interests."

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 22 -- The ten-month Hollywood jurisdictional strike has resulted from an all-out "war" by the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes, AFL, supported by the majob movie producers, to destroy the conference of Studio Unions, AFL craftworkers' organization, the House Labor subcommittee was told today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- The domestic economy continued at a high level last month but it was marked by a slackening in industrial production in some fields and new price increases, the Commerce Department reported today.

The Department of Health's program to rid the city of the smoke nuisance will start after Labor Day, it was learned yesterday. To obtain compliance with Sanitary Code regulations regarding air pollution, Dr. Israel Weinstein, Health Commissioner, has established a smoke control unit in the department's Bureau of Sanitary Engineering.

CHICAGO, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Powerful-stroking Miss Ann Curtis of San Francisco established a new meet 100-meter free-style mark as two swimmers retained their titles and two new champions were crowned today in the opening session of the three-day National A.A.U. women's outdoor aquatic championships.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (Science Service) -- A new method for making rifle powder has won United States Patent 2,425,854 for Harvey B. Alexander of Kenvil, N.J. It produces a propellant in which violent explosives like TNT and PETN, formerly thought suitable only for bursting charges in projectiles, can safely be used for boosting bullet speeds to higher levels.

CHICAGO, Aug. 22 -- Senator Kenneth S. Wherry, Republican, of Nebraska, chairman of the Senate Committee on Small Business Problems, today recommended that the oil industry establish an advisory group composed of all segments of the industry to help work out problems effecting independent refiners and dealers.

Buick Motors division of General Motors Corporation will continue its supplementary budget on the advertising campaign featuring services rendered by Buick dealers, probably through the first quarter of next year, in eighty-seven newspapers in key cities.

The main issue at the Rio -- or Petropolis -- conference could not be put on the agenda. It was not whether the American nations could agree on a hemispheric defense plan. It was not whether the economic implications or consequences of such a plan should be discussed at this or at a later meeting.

DETROIT, Aug. 22 -- Agreement on a new contract between the Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers, CIO, which was reached just before midnight last night, leaves it up to the workers to decide whether they want a straight 15-cent hourly wage increase or an old age pension plan.

It's more or less out of fashion now -- except for a few discerning countrymen who know the inherent tangy goodness of it. In an era of food metamorphosis when edibles come frozen, dehydrated, concentrated and precooked, fried salt pork is likely to be dismissed without due consideration.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- Igor. Sikorsky, aero engineer, designer and producer, who developed, among other types of planes, the Sikorsky multimotored amphibian and the first successful helicopter produced in the Western Hemisphere, is represented in this week's United States Patent Office list of 448 inventions by an improvement in helicopter construction.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 22 -- Chestertown, 4-year-old bay colt by Voldmite Phoebe Hanover by Mr. McElwyn, driven by Sanders Russell for W.E. Smith of Los Angeles and R. Newman of New Orleans, established a world mark of 9:19.2/5 in winning the Roosevelt two-mile trot before a record crowd of 26,986 at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.
The United States liner America, premier express vessel of the American merchant fleet, was withdrawn from service at 3 P.M. yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 22 -- The United Nations Security Council was faced tonight with a complete breakdown in its efforts to bring about a settlement of the undeclared war between the Netherlands and the Indonesian Republic.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 22 -- Two Egyptian nationalists today grave the United Nations its first case of political disorder from the audience.

Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx renewed his demands for Bronx housing yesterday, with the announcement that three suitable sites are largely owned by the city. He also gave out the text of a letter he had sent on Thursday to Thomas F. Farrell, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- A House Small Business subcommittee opened a controversial investigation of the cooperative movement today by hearing charges and denials that the Federal Government was sponsoring a monopolistic cooperative at Greenbelt. Md.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- A desperate, dollar-short Great Britain left the loan talks here today with the knowledge that her grim domestic "austerity program" might become even more austere as a result of an agreement to import fewer goods from the United States.

PARIS, Aug. 22 -- Some 4,300 defiant Jewish refugees, whose attempt to reach Palestine aboard the Exodus 1947 was foiled by the British, were on their way to Hamburg, Germany, tonight after having rejected the British ultimatum to debark in France by 6 P.M.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Aug. 22 -- Fifty-three players started out today in the weekly one-day New Jersey Women's Golf Association tournament over the Montclair club course, but, hampered by sultry weather, many failed to turn in cards.

The bearded lady, the sword swallower, the thin man and the snake charmer in the side show were stared at, laughed at and poked at. The strong man's feats of "unequalled, stupendous" strength brought oh's' and yowls. The children edged back from the animal act and the trainer, who cracked his whip to keep his subjects in line.

A brief demonstration by a small number of pickets before the Bethlehem Steel Company's office at 25 Broadway introduced a new note yesterday into the negotiations between the company and the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, CIO.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 22 -- Only moderate immediate gains for shippers and manufacturers in this area were expected by traffic experts from the 10 per cent reduction in class freight rates that became effective today. The experts did not wholly concur with the idea that the new rates meant the beginning of a new industrial prosperity for the South.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- As the country's major labor law, the Taft-Hartley Act, became fully effective today, the new National Labor Relations Board announced rules and regulations for settling jurisdictional disputes between unions and processing other cases.
LONDON, Aug. 22 -- The British Government announced today a power conservation program designed to assure continued operation of her essential domestic and export industries next winter.

Vessel clearances during June dropped 10 per cent from the 1946-1947 peak of 9,646,000 net registered tons set in May, according to a report released yesterday by the Department of Commerce's Bureau of the Census. The June total was 8,725,000 net tons.

PORT HURON, Mich., Aug. 22 -- An open bid to the Congress of Industrial Organizations to take an active part in the 1948 campaign was made tonight by Gael Sullivan, executive director of the Democratic National Committee, at commencement exercises of the Franklin D. Roosevelt-CIO Labor Center Camp of the Michigan State CIO Council.

The National Industrial Conference Board announced yesterday that its weighted average of consumer prices in sixty-six cities had risen 15.9 per cent during the year ended in June. It added, however, that since March there has been a slight downward trend in nineteen cities, including New York.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- Representative Wright Patman, Democrat, of Texas, sponsor of a historical analysis of "Fascism in Action" issued today by the Library of Congress, stated in a foreword to the study that fascist manifestations were still "alarmingly" evident in our democratic society.

Even a New Yorker is apt to become hopelessly ensnarled in the tortuous twistings of the subway lines once he leaves the usually traveled route and strikes out for a distant part of the city. The Bronxite visiting a long-forgotten relative in Brooklyn is apt to find himself lost on an alien platform among roaring expresses and scurrying people, both curiously unconcerned with his bewildered presence.

EASTPORT, Me., Aug. 22 -- The buildings and plants of Passama-quoddy Village, the "dead" town upon which vast sums of federal money were spent in connection with an abandoned tidal power project, are in generally good condition. This tends to support the contention of officials and residents of tihs north Maine area that it would be a "crime" to raze the village and sell it for junk.

New homes in three boroughs, and alterations for various types of buildings in Manhattan were listed in the plans filed yesterday in the Department of Housing and Buildings. The projects included the following.

CHICAGO, Aug. 22 -- A record-breaking crowd of 105,840 shirt-sleeved football fans witnessed a tremendous upset tonight as the College All-Stars conquered the Chicago Bears, 16 -- 0. It was the first time the Bears ever had to finish second in the fourteen-year history of this Chicago Tribune pre-season classic.

JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 22 -- A political battle royal in which the number of probable contestants increased almost hourly was shaping up today around Mississippi's United States Senate seat left vacant by the death of Theodore G. Bilbo.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Cuyahoga County jurors have healthy appetites, State Examiner James E. Gallagher concluded today.

Reports of some good showers in West Texas and official prediction of more over the week-end depressed the cotton market yesterday and prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange, after showing fair firmness early, became reactionary in the afternoon.

The three-Power discussions taking place in London on raising the level of German industry are critical -- not as they affect the future of Germany but as they determine whether France, Britain and the United States can agree on a policy. This is the key to the future of Western Europe, and therefore to the future of the Continent as a whole.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Railroad freight rates on manufactured goods went up in the East and down in the South and parts of the West today, making this a red-letter day in the nation's transportation history. That upward and downward readjustment at one minute past midnight marked the actual start on the long projected national "freight rate equalization plan."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- The State Department today firmly denied for the second time assorted charges by Yugoslavia alleging discrimination against her by the United States.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 22 -- Vice Premier Edvard Kardelj, speaking in Ljubljana on Tuesday, told his constituency that the greater part of the Slovene clergy had been obstructing the advancement of the workers.

LONDON, Aug. 22 -- Although a little investment buying raised British Government stocks as, much as 1/4 point today, all-round brokers and jobbers found little business to keep them occupied in the stock markets.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: THE NEW YORK TIMES states that the eight American Protestant clergymen found "freedom of worship" in Yugoslavia. But did they find true religious liberty?
Dr. Benton Dales, former head of the neoprene latex laboratories of du Pont de Nemours, has been appointed director of a new laboratory established by Adhesive Products Corporation.

The Dodgers had to beat the Reds three times yesterday before they could make it stick. The end of a tense, three hour and forty-two minute struggle finally was reached in the twelfth inning, when Dixie Walker, co-hero with Hank Behrman of the marathon battle at Ebbets Field, crossed the plate to give the Brooks the decision by the score of 6 -- 5.

Lists of critical items remaining on purchasing lists have dropped to about five major classifications, industrial purchasing executives disclosed here yesterday. These are: pipe, some types of lumber, a few chemicals, many paper products and electrical supply items.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 22 -- Two calls were issued from this holy city today for all the World's Jews to join the Jewish community of Palestine on Monday in a day-long fast of mourning and protest against the British deportation of three shiploads of Jewish refugees from Port de Bouc, France, to Germany.
No fewer than 800 resolutions, including some on veterans' housing and immigration, will be considered by the American Legion when it opens its convention here Thursday, it was learned yesterday.

PETROPOLIS, Brazil, Aug. 22 -- An open debate in the Inter-American Defense Conference on the question of an anti-Communist pact, which had been informally discussed by many delegates, was averted today. The issue was potentially raised and was apparently, definitely buried in the conference's commission No. 2, on clauses covering aggression and threats to security.
AMSTERDAM, N.Y., Aug. 22 (AP) -- The Mohawk Carpet Mills, Inc., of Amsterdam, and the War Assets Administration continued today their duel over disposition of a surplus mill in Virginia.

PETROPOLIS, Aug. 22 (U.P.) -- In the view of the United States delegation tonight, acceptance of the Argentine proposal would be regarded throughout the world as setting up an American alliance against communism and specifically against Russia.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 22 -- Thomas T. Mott's Floating Isle, who has been piling up stakes placings but hadn't been able to win since May -- and that was his lone victory in two seasons -- was the big horse in the forty-eighth running of the Beverwyck Steeplechase Handicap at Saratoga today.

Net income of 402 companies having common stock listed on the New York Stock Exchange amounted to $1,681,920,000 for the first six months, according to the magazine Exchange, published by the Stock Exchange. This is an increase of 97.9 per cent over the like period last year.
Yesterday will long be remembered in the annals of New York's Bowery as the day when dreams came true.

FLINT, Mich., Aug. 22 (AP) -- Hard-punching Willie Pep, the curly-haired Hartford, Conn., fancy-dan, knocked out Jock Leslie of Flint in forty-five seconds of the twelfth round tonight to successfully defend his world featherweight championship before a crowd of 10,036 fans in Atwood Stadium.

TORONTO, Ont., Aug. 22 -- After a lapse of five years during which the grounds were converted to military uses, the Canadian National Exhibition, which boasts of being the world's largest annual exhibition, reopened here today for a two-week period.
PORT DE BOUC, France, Aug. 22 (AP) -- None of the Exodus 1947 refugees got off the ships today in response to the British Government's demand that they debark in France or be taken to Hamburg.
PARIS, Aug. 22 -- The Communist proposal to give Algeria the status of an associated territory within the French Union was defeated by a vote of 404 to 184 in the National Assembly today.

CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., Aug. 22 -- Isaac I. Kashdan of New York, who became the new open champion of the United States Chess Federation yesterday, finished his schedule today by defeating R.G. Wade, the New Zealand titleholder, in a Slav defense lasting thirty-four moves.

The first volume of "Memoirs of a Secret Agent of Free France," by Remy, has been scheduled for publication by Whittlesey House on Oct. 27. The volume, subtitled "The Silent Company," is the author's account of the relaying of information to England from occupied France.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug 22 -- Nineteen-year-old Bill Rickenbacker, son of the flying ace, soared into the Westchester junior golf title seat at the Westchester Hills golf club today, carding a two-under-par 68 to oust the defending champion in the semi-final, then conquering the tourney medalist.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- A twenty-five-year loan of $40,000,000 to speed the economic recovery of Denmark was announced today by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development.

Charley Fusari had no trouble with Joe Di Martino, upset conqueror of Marty Servo, at Madison Square Garden last night. Fusari, from Irvington, N.J., stopped his Bridgeport, Conn., opponent in 2:12 of the fourth round of a scheduled 10-round fray.

Secretary Forrestal is on unassailable ground when he says in a telegram to Representative O'Toole about use of Floyd Bennett Field that the Navy has a "responsibility not to dilute the funds given us by Congress for national defense." Nevertheless, it is logical to ask whether it is not essential for this very reason that the Navy reach an agreement with the Port Authority for partial use of Bennett Field by commercial airlines.

John F. Ryan, executive vice president of the Newspaper Guild of New York, CIO, announced yesterday that the guild's membership had voted to boycott the new National Labor Relations Board created under the Taft-Hartley Act.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Darkness dropped the curtain on the first act of trapshooting's greatest show today, with 805 of the huge cast of 1,830 due to fire tomorrow before the forty-eighth Grand American Handicap champion is named.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Aug. 22 (AP) -- The United States' demand that the Allied Control Commission for Bulgaria review the death sentence of Nikola Petkov, leader of the anti-Communist Agrarian party, was rejected today by Soviet Lieut. Gen. Alexander Cherepanov, acting deputy chairman of the commission.

CHICAGO, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Ted Williams pounded out five singles and a double and got two walks, one intentional, in nine times at bat as the Boston Red Sox split a double-header with the Chicago White Sox before 15,297 fans today.

LONDON, Aug. 22 -- A Foreign Office spokesman denied emphatically tonight that the Exodus 1947 refugees, en route to Germany from Port de Bouc, France, would be detained in Belsen after being debarked in Hamburg. He termed the report "mischievous, harmful and ill-timed propaganda."

ALBANY, Aug. 22 -- Supreme Court Justice William H. Murray reserved decision today in an Agriculture Department action to restrain two Long Island farmers from alleged violation of the golden nematode quarantine after defense counsel contended the state order interfered with his clients' constitutional rights.
DETROIT, Aug. 22 -- The United Auto Workers Garage Workers Local 415 today were restrained in a Circuit Court injunction from using squads to picket seventynine automobile dealer service stations.

Outdoor fireplaces, whether they're elaborate stone affairs in the back yard or an improvised grate dug into the sand at the beach, are an ideal setting for end-of-the-summer picnics. Meat makes the perfect fare, for from the lowly frankfurter to the choicest steak, it's at its most delicious when roasted to a rich brown over glowing embers.

CHICAGO, Aug. 22 -- Payroll and other costs are outdistancing gains in productivity on the country's railroad systems, Ralph Budd, president of the Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad Company, said today. He testified for the carriers before a wages arbitration board, which is hearing testimony on union demands for a pay increase of 20 cents an hour.

The Giants set a new all time seasonal attendance record at the Polo Grounds yesterday, and by way of commemorating the event engaged in an extraordinary contest with the Pirates. At times they appeared to be playing both sides of the board with rare diligence.
PETROPOLIS, Brazil, Aug. 22 -- The Inter-American Conference here formally and, it was hoped, finally rid itself of the economic issue in two meetings today.

GENEVA, Aug. 22 (Reuters) -- The three working parties of the United Nations Special Committee of Inquiry on Palestine, set up to study possible solutions of the Palestine problem have completed their task and will submit their findings to a plenary meeting of
Lieut. Dennis F. Casey of the Simpson Street police station completed his testimony yesterday before the Bronx County grand jury inquiring into alleged protection of gamblers by city policemen.

GENEVA, Switzerland, Aug. 22 -- The complete partition of Palestine has been provisionally rejected by a majority of the members of the United Nations Special Committee of Inquiry on Palestine, it was learned from a source close to the committee today.

The public utterances of the seven Protestant clergymen who recently visited Yugoslavia and declared that country now enjoys religious freedom were denounced yesterday by Bishop Iriney Georgevich, Serbian Orthodox Bishop of Dalmatia, Yugoslavia.

SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 22 -- Col. Gen. Terentyi F. Shtikov, chief of the Soviet delegation on the Joint Commission charged today that South Korea authorities, under American guidance were conducting a "pogrom" against leftists.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Aug. 22 -- The Wisconsin State Federation of Labor jumped into the political action arena with both feet here today. Without opposition, more than 500 delegates at the closing session of the federation's convention adopted resolutions outlining a political program, which includes the following activities:

Store Sales Break Even Department store sales in the metropolitan area this week were estimated yesterday to be about equal to those of the corresponding period a year ago. Business was reported off 10 per cent Monday, but improved rapidly during the week.

A ten-year-old agreement under which the National Labor Relations Board has ceded jurisdiction over cases involving several hundred thousand New York workers to the State Labor Relations Board may have to be thrown into the scrap heap under the Taft-Hartley Act.

Random notes. According to word just received from Rhode Island, the stripers are big as well as plentiful, both for the caster and troller. Jerry Sylvester, the Narragensett bait tycoon, who fishes the beach every evening, rain or shine, writes that the blue mullet plug is producing plenty of bass, but no really big ones.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 22 -- Frank Parker of Hollywood, Calif., and Gardnar Mulloy of Coral Gables, Fla., went the way of John Bromwich and Colin Long today in the national doubles tennis championship at the Longwood Cricket Club.

SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 22 -- Col. Gen. Terentyi F. Shtikov, chief of the Soviet delegation on the Joint Commission charged today that South Korea authorities, under American guidance were conducting a "pogrom" against leftists.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Aug. 22 -- The Wisconsin State Federation of Labor jumped into the political action arena with both feet here today. Without opposition, more than 500 delegates at the closing session of the federation's convention adopted resolutions outlining a political program, which includes the following activities:

TOKYO, Aug. 23 -- Pressure is being brought against the Government to speed plans for housing. Denichi Kaneiwa, an Independent, told the House of Councillors Tuesday that the country would need sixty years to overcome the housing shortage under present Government plans and newspapers have taken up the cry.

The first International Festival of Music and Drama to be held in Edinburgh, Scotland, will open there today. Latest word here reports that 75,000 tickets had been sold in advance and that a second festival would be held there next year.

THERE has long been a need for a study of the development of medical science and practice in relation to social and economic conditions in which medicine plays such an important part. Dr. Shryock's book goes a long way toward filling that need.

THE nice, comforting thought that regardless of what happened to Washington's National Theatre, the nation's capital would be entertaining legitimate productions at the Belasco, took on a forlorn aspect last week -- just about the time the League of New York Theatres and Actors Equity were formalizing their pact on the Negro exclusion issue.

Two plainclothesmen who went to the rescue of a man being beaten by four neighborhood toughs were set upon by a gang of fifteen hoodlums early yesterday morning at Columbus Avenue and 105th Street. In the ensuing battle one policeman emptied his revolver, wounding two of his assailants.

REDUCTION of carbon deposit, which impairs engine power, has been achieved through research conducted under the auspices of the Society of Automotive Engineers. A new type of rotating engine exhaust valve has been developed that is expected to save thousands of dollars in engine repairs while giving more mileage, according to the S.A.E. findings.

THERE are signs of increasing cooperation and interchange of ideas between the country's leading music schools. Last March the Juilliard School of Music played host to composition students from six other schools.

ONLY those who have taken on the task of trying to understand a nation other than their own will thoroughly appreciate the immense amount of work that has gone into Professor Brady's admirable comparative study of Canada, New Zealand, Australia and South Africa.

BOSTON, Aug. 23 -- A manifesto urging resistance to all forms of tyranny, and described as having been signed by 150 prominent persons, was released today on the twentieth anniversary of the execution of Nicola Sacco and Bartolomeo Vanzetti.

Rumania's ratification of the peace treaty yesterday makes a headline but does not change the fact that none of the European peace treaties can go into effect until Russia ratifies them. When our own Senate approved the Italian peace treaty last June it was argued that this action would end the state of war and military occupation and clear the way for the admission of Italy into the United Nations.

THIS collection of most of Winters' criticism (some Hound and Horn reviews, and the Poetry Magazine article on Tudor and Elizabethan poets are omissions one is sorry for) is a particularly good book to buy; one can put it between Empson's "Some Versions of Pastoral" and Eliot's "Selected Essays," and feel for them the mixture of awe, affection and disagreement that one always feels for a first-rate critical book.
Delegates and members of the American Legion Auxiliary are starting to arrive in the city today to attend the auxiliary's 27th annual convention to be held at the Commodore Hotel.

SOUTH SLOCAN, B.C., Aug. 23 (AP) -- Five men and a woman were under arrest today on charges connected with a reign of arson and terror in the Kootenay Valley which some officials attributed to a fanatical Doukhobor sect protesting the "coming of a third world war."

TUSKEGEE, Ala., Aug. 23 (AP) -- George Stewart, 24-year-old southpaw of the Republic of Panama, won the National Negro tennis championship today by trouncing top-seeded Lloyd Scott of Prairie View, Tex., 6-1, 6-2, 6-2. Stewart, ranked second, avenged a beating from the Texan in the 1946 semifinals by mixing a driving game with tricky drop shots.

PRAGUE, Aug. 23 -- Premier Klement Gottwald has promised the Slovak partisan fighters to support their demand for incorporation into the Czechoslovak Army. Thus he approved what is held to be the latest Communist attempt to use against the Democrats, majority party in Slovakia, the method employed successfully against the Hungarian Smallholders party.

BACK in the groove in every way after the war years, this annual gleaning of short fiction from the Post reminds the reader once again that the Post (within its limitations) is still a sensitive barometer of American taste -- and may still be relied on to provide its full measure of entertainment.

DETROIT, Aug. 23 (AP) -- The Tigers slipped back into a virtual tie for fourth place with the Athletics today as Marino Pieretti and Milo Candini pitched their way over five Washington errors to bring the Senators a 5-to-3 victory over the Tigers.
PARIS, Aug. 23 -- In the Washington, London and Paris press this week the future "coal and steel production in western Germany, which means the Ruhr, was extensively discussed.

ROME, Aug. 23 -- The Communist press attempted today to calm the anti-Soviet resentment of Italians who were angered by their country's exclusion from the United Nations by Russia's veto. Unita prints a box on its front page saying: "The policy of anti-Soviet hatred led Italy yesterday to defeat and catastrophe.

SEATTLE, Wash. -- Operation of, and public response to, the new Empire Builder, forty-five-hour streamlined between Chicago and Seattle, has been so successful in its first six months that an order has been placed with Pullman-Standard for five additional sleeping cars, according to F.J. Gavin, president of the Great Northern Railway.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Dick Fowler scattered four hits and an equal number of passes to help the Athletics gain a 7-to-0 triumph over the Browns -- four of the runs coming in the Athletics' sixthinning attack on Ellis Kinder.

BATAVIA, Java, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Dutch spokesmen declared today that the Indonesian cease-fire order was "a sham." A Dutch communique reported that Republican forces were active on almost every front in Java and Sumatra.

The high level of open-market sales activity in Manhattan real estate reached during the early months of this year is being maintained, with about the same number of sales in July as during the previous month, although the dollar volume of trading has declined.

THE Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo will have two new ballets in its repertory when it opens its season of two weeks at the City Center on Sept. 7. One of them is Ruthanna Boris' "Cirque de Deux," which had its premiere during the company's recent performances in the Hollywood Bowl.

PHOTOGRAPHY, the new quarterly, made its debut last week with, the fall 1947 issue, offering eighteen articles and departments, five reproductions in full color and many in black and white. But the promise of something really different in photographic periodicals, which advance publicity had indicated, remains unfulfilled.

DURING these hot days of late summer nothing could be more pleasing than a perennial flower so like an oversized snowflake that its very presence in the border seems to cool the surrounding atmosphere. Dianthus superbus White Lace has such a blossom and is all that its name implies.

IF you know an older boy who craves the excitement of pioneering, you will want to earmark a copy of this book for him. It is the story of Thorp Mason, who, captured and then released by Pawnees, stumbled onto the camp of Captain Bonneville and a hundred Mountain Men.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 23 -- Thomas Crosby Jr., Professor Emeritus of Brown University and dean of Rhode Island's amateur thespians, died here this morning in Jane Brown Hospital. He was 76 years old.

The night sound of the katydid has become, almost lonely by late August, no matter how many of these nocturnal cousins of the grasshopper may be making the darkness quiver. A few weeks ago it was an eager sound, with some of the ecstasy of courtship and youth.

SHERMAN'S nine-finger exercise in nostalgia (daybefore-yesterday brand) begins on the day of Franklin Delano Roosevelt's first inaugural -- when Mr. Sherman's standard young couple, after listening to the President's ringing proclamation of the New Deal on their Greenwich Village radio, decide to stop living in sin and get married.

WHEN New York gets set for a parade -- such as the American Legion parade along Fifth Avenue next Saturday -- the atmosphere at Police Headquarters resembles a briefing room before an air force mission Watches are synchronized.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE. L.I., Aug. 23 -- George Stuhr Jr. of Garden City, a member of Notre Dame's golf squad, became the second player in the twenty-six-year history of the event to triumph three times when he captured the Long Island junior championship today on the Rockville Country Club course.

ISLIP, L.I., Aug. 23 -- Speaking before 3,000 members of the Suffolk County Republican Club, Speaker Joseph W. Martin Jr., majority leader of the House, pledged the Republican Congress today to remove every Communist from the Federal payroll.

Ralph H. Kimball, vice president in charge of industrial relations and a director of the Western Union Telegraph Company, died yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital after an illness of several months. He was 61 years old.

Every friend of conservation in this country should rally to the protection of the great rain forest of the Olympic Peninsula in Washington as one of our very last remnants of a lavish nature which we decimated with so ruthless a hand until the establishment of the national park system.
LONDON (By Wireless). WHAT the world needs is not merely American dollars, food and machinery. We need an Amercan idea as well. Without that idea American loans will be dollars down the drain.

Both the Transport Workers Union, CIO, and the New York Omnibus Corporation accepted yesterday the city's intervention in the bus dispute that threatens to halt surface transportation in Manhattan on Sept. 8 and possibly slow down the subways.

LONDON. THE way the picture situation is at the moment, any notes on production plans from this side are bound to be a little sketchy. Few producers are willing to go out on a limb and announce a program, until they know what sort of market they are catering to, and how far they may have to increase their product, or cut down the time and costs of production.

BLOCK ISLAND, R.I. -- This little piece of land bounded by the Atlantic Ocean and Block Island Sound, shares with other islands a special qualification -- a seasonal time lag. The surrounding water masses are slow to change the temperature they have grown accustomed to over a period of months.

Seven important scientific and industrial developments observed in Austria convinced Dr. Henry H. Hausner, metallurgist of New York University, that although food and living conditions are bad in that country, progress is being made toward recovery in fields of science, industry and research, he revealed yesterday.

LONDON, Aug. 23 -- Roy A. Chadwick, one of Britain's foremost plane designers and creator of the Lancaster bomber, was killed today when the new luxury air liner, Tudor II, fell a few seconds after a take-off on a test flight.

PETROPOLIS, Brazil, Aug. 23 -- When United States Secretary of State Marshall strode to the rostrum to address the inter-American defense conference here Wednesday he received what was beyond doubt the longest and loudest applause of the meeting thus far.

The first important golf tournament of the early fall season will be the third annual North Jersey Country Club invitation championship which starts over the rolling hills of this New Jersey course on Tuesday and continues through Saturday.

MANY long faces are being bared in the movie industry on both sides of the Atlantic over the British film-tax situation. It was a revelation last week, therefore, when the cherubic Sydney Box, one of the big wheels of the British film industry, olew into town in the middle of the heat wave and did nothing but smile.

Mr. David Zaslavsky, The Pravda, Moscow. Dear Sir: On Aug. 3 this newspaper published under my signature an article pointing out the absurdity of the claim of Mr. Morozov of the Russian delegation to the United Nations that real freedom of the press existed in Russia, Under date of Aug. 11 in Pravda, on Page One, you did me the honor of replying to my article.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23 -- Fervent, leggy chestnut colt owned by Warren Wright's Calumet Farm, ran the fastest mile and a quarter ever run by a 3-year-old on an American track in winning the $93,250 American Derby at Washington Park today.

WHEN Mr. Warburg went to Germany last year to get a first-hand view of that country under occupation, he was, as the Army would say, exceptionally well-briefed. ATHENS, Aug. 23 (U.P.) -- Heavy guerrilla attacks continue, according to press reports, which said that 500 raiders from Bulgaria invaded the frontier villages of Neohorion and Dafnon, driving Government gendarmes out and setting fire to thirty houses as well as the Dafnon railway and police stations.

MANILA, Aug. 23 -- The Cabinet of President Manuel A. Roxas is now discussing the details of Manila's post-war rehabilitation. It has announced the projected construction, by the Philippine Government of a large international airport and several tamporary bridges across the Pasig River.

PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 23 -- Although sale of liquor by the glass has never been legalized in the Pacific Northwest since the repeal of prohibition, groups in both Oregon and Washington now are planning to make a major political issue of proposals to change the method of alcoholic control in the two States.
ANNFIELD PLAIN, England, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Nineteen Durham coal miners died today in Britain's second mine explosion in little more than a week.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- The National Park Service believes 26,000,000 persons may visit United States scenic and historic areas in the travel year ending Sept. 30 -- which would be an alltime record and one of the most tremendous travel increases in history.

JUST seventeen years ago this week in this Review: A front-page review of "Criminal Justice in America" by the dean of Harvard's Law School, Roscoe Pound -- a legalistic approach which could hardly serve as a reference work for the gangster era, but which nonetheless had some pertinent things to say about the origins of lawlessness in the United States.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 23 -- Elpis, queen of New Jersey's thoroughbred campaigners, further solidified her claim to the title when she galloped off with principal honors in today's renewal of the $15,000 added Miss America Handicap, mile-and-a-furlong filly and mare feature of the seashore meeting's final program.

The National Labor Relations Board occupies the ramshackle, eight-story former Rochambeau Apartment House on Washington's Connecticut Avenue. From this building over the past twelve years the three-member NLRB issued rulings and interpretations under the National Labor Relations (Wagner) Act -- which labor called its "Magma Carta."

NANKING, China, Sunday, Aug. 24 -- Lieut. Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer issued a vigorous, pointed statement stressing the need for "drastic, far reaching political and economic reforms" in the Government of China on the occasion of his departure from Nanking for Tokyo this morning.

A major expansion program in liquid gas equipment, opening distributor franchises in many territories of the United States, Canada and Mexico, was disclosed here yesterday by Harry W. Townsend, vice president of the Pacific Gas Corporation, Rockefeller Center.
The 1948 Congress will hear an aroused power and light industry demand that tax discrimination in favor of public power be eliminated or adjusted.

DALLAS, Tex., Aug. 23 (AP) -- With a band playing old-time songs and half its members dressed in grandmother's clothes, women of the Little Below the Knee Club stopped downtown traffic here today with a parade proclaiming long skirts old-fashioned and impractical.
BOSTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- As one clue after another peters out, New England authorities still continue their search for two coeds who vanished within six months of each other.

MONTAUK POINT, L.I., Aug. 23 -- A Coast Guard picket boat from the Ditch Plain Station near here recovered today the body or the Rev. John D. Bell, 52 years old, of Brooklyn, fifty feet off Cartwright Island, in Gardiners Bay.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 23 (AP) -- Arnold Guyot Dana, for thirtyfive years editor of the investment news department and managing editor of the railway and industrial section of The Commercial and Financial Chronicle, a New York weekly, died today in his home here.

LIVELY times are returning to New York's waterfront with old and new ships docking in -- the North River. Thirteen liners -- passenger and freighterpassenger -- brought close to 5,000 passengers into the Port of New York last Monday.

Lafe WEBSTER'S Collegiate Dictionary, which has a crew haircut, a class pipe, and a yellow oilskin slicker, describes a farm as "a piece of land leased for cultivation, hence any tract devoted to agricultural purposes."

MR. CORNELL has produced a brief, well-written criticism of the United Nations, as now operating, and makes a strong plea for a world government in its stead. CHICAGO, Aug. 23 (AP) -- A new buying movement got under way in corn shortly before the close of the market on the Board of Trade today and carried the September delivery to a new record peak. Trading was active on the advance, which was joined by oats.

A Toronto couple was arrested in a midtown hotel early yesterday on information supplied by Canadian authorities indicating they were involved in the $400,000 robbery of the Royal Bank of Canada at Toronto last Sunday.

The need for 22,000 new dwelling units for families in the upperincome brackets in Connecticut offers builders and investors an unusual opportunity, according to a report issued by the Connecticut State Housing Authority.

SALEM, N.H., Aug. 23 (AP) -- Mt. Desert Stable's Willing Spirit, a 13-1 shot came with a rush through the stretch in the fourteenth running of the $10,000 added Granite State Handicap, the oldest New England stake race, today to win by three-quarters of a length over a twelve-horse field at Rockingham Park.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 23 -- The Patriotic Order Sons of America, founded here on Dec. 10, 1847, Will open its six-day one hundredth anniversary convention tomorrow with re-dedication services at the POSA Building in historic near-by Valley Forge Park.

GENEVA, Switzerland, Aug. 23 -- The idea that the nations of Western Europe could solve some of their problems by forming a customs union, which is by no means a new idea, has achieved sudden popularity during the course of the discussions of the Marshall proposal.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 23 -- The West Coast's main population center is deliberately embarking on one of the greatest carrying-coalsto-Newcastle projects on record: That of luring more people to its already overcrowded purlieus.

ATLANTA, Aug. 23 -- Popular reaction against mob violence has been mounting heavily in the South in support of Gov. R. Gregg Cherry of North Carolina, who recently denounced a grand jury's refusal to indict, and moved vigorously to bring about the rearrest of seven white men in the attempted lynching of a 22-year-old Negro in Northampton County, N.C., May 24.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: When Sutan Sjahrir, in behalf of the Indonesian Government, notified the United Nations Security Council that his Government would not unconditionally accept the good offices of the United States in settling its dispute with the Netherlands, his action was logical and by no means implied either the intransigence or the anti-Americanism which many of our people may read into it.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 23 -- With a clatter of seventeen hits that ran the gamut from the bunt to the homer and a new season's high for an individual scoring inning, the Yankees said farewell to this city for the 1947 campaign today by smothering the Indians, 13 to 6, at Municipal Stadium before a gathering of 29,124.

President Truman's midyear review of the 1948 fiscal year budget of the Federal Government shows that the January estimate of receipts of $37,700,000,000 is increased to $41,700,000,000 and that the January estimate of expenditures is decreased by. $500,000,000 to $37,000,000,000.

LONDON, Aug. 23 (Reuters) -- More than a million persons swooped on stadiums throughout England today as the 1947-48 soccer season opened. They paid nearly u100,000 ($400,000) for the privilege and an additional 20,000,000 sent their pennies and shillings to pool firms.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- The United States went directly to Moscow today with an insistent protest against the Bulgarian Government's death sentence of Nikola Petkov, anti-Communist Opposition leader.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Labor has expressed its disapproval of a proposal to convert the ghost town of Passamaquoddy, Me., site of an abandoned vast tidal power project, into a temporary center where displaced persons would receive mechanical training and then be sent to South America, it was learned today.

Financial markets were extremely dull last week as activity in stocks contracted to the smallest total since early in May. While most of the business factors obviously are bullish, the market did not show strength compatible with such circumstances and prices gradually worked lower.

SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 23 -- Maj. Gen. Albert E. Brown, chief of the United States delegation to the joint United States-Soviet commission, revealed in a press announcement today that the American representatives during the last three weeks had made several new proposals to the Soviet delegation in an attempt to break the present deadlock.

LONDON, Aug. 23 -- Concessions by the United States and Britain to try to meet French fears of a reindustrialized Germany were discussed at today's session of the tripartite conference on raising the level of industry in the economically merged United States and British zones of Germany, it was learned authoritatively tonight.

RENO, Nev., Aug. 23 (AP) -- Ky Laffoon of St. Andrews, Ill., swept into the lead of the seventy-twohole $15,000 Reno Open golf tournament today with a three-round total of 204. He carded, a 34, 33 -- 67 to jump to the front of the field.

PARIS, Aug. 23 -- Barring the always, unpredictable and fortuitous upset, France's middle-ofthe-road Cabinet, under the moderate Socialist leadership of Paul Ramadier, seems destined to carry its endemic crisis through until the October elections or up to the point when a financial climax breaks.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 23 -- The attention of northern and central California is being drawn by Federal Reclamation Bureau officials to a 'critical" shortage of power. According to Richard L. BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 23 -- John Kramer and Ted Schroeder won the National Doubles Tennis championship today and their selection as the Davis Cup tandem virtually becomes inevitable.

Coleman Nevils, formerly president of the University of Scranion and formerly chancellor of Georgetown University, will become president of America Press and head of "America," internationally circulated Catholic publication in New York, it was announced today.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., Aug. 23 -- For another change from the almost monotonous whirl around buoys in western Long Island Sound, the season's championshipseeking sailors and their followers came east today for the regatta of the Riverside Yacht Club.

Repatriation of prisoners from the liquidated French penal colony of Devil's Island is almost half complete and may be finished by the end of the year, the Salvation Army announced here yesterday.
