For the fraternity of outboard and inboard speed-boat daredevils no week-end of the entire summer has been as busy as the one just ahead with its Labor Day holiday. Somehow or other, the A.P.B.A. schedule-makers assigned sanction dates to several localities, and the top-flight drivers are naturally wondering how they can be two places or even three places at once.

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 23 (AP) -- Gov. M. E. Thompson ordered state police today to investigate the alleged beating of a CIO union organizer and his wife at La Grange, Ga., and announced he would back authorities in swift prosecution of a reported political flogging at McRae, Ga.

The interesting articles from the pen of Prof. Auguste Piccard in THE NEW YORK TIMES have given us a good picture of the method by which he intends to explore the ocean at a depth not yet attained. From the account published by William Beebe of his descent off Bermuda to a mere threequarters of a mile we take it that not the least of Professor Piccard's problems will be presented by lighting.

Work is nearing completion on the new two-story and basement office and store building occupying a plot 100 by 115 feet at the northwest corner of Seventy-ninth Street and Thirty-seventh Avenue, in Jackson Heights, Queens, according to A.E. MacDougall, president of the Queensboro Corporation.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- A House small business subcommittee decided today that the operation of a cooperative store at the Greenbelt, Md., Government housing project was monopolistic.

THE owner of a small greenhouse who wants to pick those long-stemmed, largeflowered pansies, fragrant sweet peas, or even calendula, stock or marigolds in midwinter may miss these flowers because he neglected to plant the seeds at the right time.

IN this volume the ingenious authors have used the street map of this city and the road map of the adjacent country -- reaching up the Hudson and over into New Jersey and out on Long Island -- as a net to catch a prodigious variety of information, spiced with anecdote and gossip, about almost everybody that has been anybody at all in literature who ever lived or tarried in this vicinity.

THE recent announcement by the Ford Motor Company that it will sponsor a weekly one-hour drama series, beginning Oct. 5 on Sunday afternoons over NBC, has stirred up an unusual flurry of comment in the industry.
LONDON, Aug. 23, (U.P.) -- Great Britain tried again today to return 4,454 Jewish refugees to France by asking the French Government to receive them by train from the British zone of Germany.

One comment that can be made on the new era introduced by the TaftHartley Labor Relations Act is that it does not, as yet, appear to be an era of slavery. The longshoremen who struck against their own union leadership on Wednesday, and succeeded in tying up the liner America and paralyzing a large section of the port of New York, were not behaving like slaves.

NORTH HAMPTON, N.H., Aug. 23 -- John L. Sullivan, recently appointed Secretary of the Navy, does not expect any major changes in the new defense set-up of the country. He asserted today at his country home at Little Boars Head that the only immediate changes in policies would be in those that affect the courtmartial system.

The first volume of a new and strictly American translation of the Church Fathers is off the press. Its publication, first in a series of Seventy-two volumes comprising all the principal writings of Christian, origin from Apostolic times to the seventh century, was announced yesterday by Dr. Ludwig Schopp of 229 East Forty-ninth Street, editorial director and initiator of the project.

PARIS, Aug. 23 -- An estimated expenditure of $734,000,000 for imports in the next four years will be necessary to meet essential deficits in the railroad equipment of western Europe, a study of the report of the Inland Transport Committee of the European Economic Conference revealed today.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 23 -- Philip Caswell, past president and a charter member of the Newport Chamber of Commerce, Farm Bureau leader and a past commodore of the Newport Yacht Club, died in his home here today after a year's illness. His age was 68.

PETROPOLIS, Brazil, Aug. 23 -- Argentina conceded today the principal that there is no distinction to be made in aggression, as such, whether it originates with a power outside or within the Western Hemisphere.

ITALO SVEVO (1861 -- 1928) born Ettore Schmitz, had much in common with Franz Kafka, as a man if not as a writer. Both were of Jewish parentage, both were raised in non-German cities of the AustroHungarian Empire, Svevo in Trieste, Kafka in Prague.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The recent editorial, "Key to European Recovery," concludes that only by the revival of Ruhr industry can Europe recover from its present state and the United States be relieved of its heavy financial burdens in connection with the support of the occupation.

BOSTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- With a four-run first inning and a fiverun second, the Braves whaled out a 10-4 victory over the Cubs today. Boston collected fifteen hits for a total of twenty-three bases as Red Barrett chalked up his tenth triumph.

Dangers inherent in any new boom of office building construction, engendered primarily by the current high percentage of occupancy, are the cause of grave concern to conservative real estate leaders throughout the country, according to Lee Thompson Smith, president of the Lawyers Title Corporation of New York.

Documents tracing the history of the United States from the discovery of the American mainland by Christopher Columbus to the uniting of this country with others in the United Nations will be carried on the Freedom Train during its tour of more than 300 cities sponsored by the Department of Justice.
WASHINGTON -- Overshadowed by the fanfare attached to the Rio Conference on Inter-American Solidarity was another conference dedicated to the same objective that took place earlier this month.

POSSIBLY the greatest handicap under which America labored in the years from 1918 to 1941 was that of achieving a correct evaluation of Germany. We had then, as we have today, a wealth of theories to choose from.

NEW DELHI, Aug. 23 -- Though Indians are now masters of their own destiny, British influence will continue to be felt in governmental affairs at least until April 1, 1948. After that Britain will remain dominant in overseas commercial and cultural power in India unless there is an unforeseeable reversal of trend.

ALTHOUGH it may sound somewhat ridiculous to be mentioning football these sudoriferous days, the news is that Glenn Davis and Felix (Doc) Blanchard should be around again some time next month -- on the screen, that is Last week it was learned that Film Classics, which has been dealing in revivals has acquired "Spirit of West Point," in which the Army's backfield aces of the past three gridiron seasons make their screen debuts.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- The Taft-Hartley act, which went fully into effect yesterday, raises many questions for the trade union movement, and the answers may not be forthcoming until the law has been tested.

WHETHER one goes on a vacation or stays at home, this is the one month of the year when almost everybody relaxes. It is no time either to make or look at elaborate flower arrangements. Automatically, the eye is drawn to the coolness of green and white and to the tranquillity of horizontal lines.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- The United States today accused the Governments of Albania, Bulgaria and Yugoslavia of hostile and inflammatory actions against Greece and asserted that "international action" was the only way to restore peace in that region.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Aug. 23 -- Raynham Hall, probably the best known of pre-revolutionary homesteads left standing on the shore and original home of the famous Townsend family of Oyster Bay, has passed into the hands of the town board as a township charge and will be made a shrine of national history.

Current Federal attacks on industrial basing point price policies are merely the stepping-stone to future actions which will broaden through other industries, attorneys for leading corporations predicted here yesterday. Nevertheless, the Supreme Court may uphold basing point pricing systems in hearings next fall, they emphasized.

Dr. Frank E. Adair, a distinguished surgeon whose work in the field of cancer at Memorial Hospital, New York, is known throughout the world, has made a study of 5,000 cases of early breast cancer in women to determine the age at which tumors appeared and the effect of male hormone (testosterone propionate) in treating breast cancer.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- The United States appears hopeful that a good shake-up might strengthen the Government of Greece. Officials agreed that supplies would continue toward Athens and the program under Dwight Griswold, director of the American aid mission, would not be seriously retarded.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (U.P.) -- President Truman, still a polliwog, becomes a shellback next month, and Navy sources promised tonight that he will get the full treatment.

A warning that "the current real estate cycle has made such substantial progress in its upward movement that all forms of investments in this field bear increasing risks from here on out," is contained in a sixty-eight-page report issued by the International Statistical Bureau, Inc.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Aug. 23 -- Parliament unanimously ratified the peace treaty today, and the Government promptly made Premier Stalin an honorary citizen of Rumania. Acting on the third anniversary of King Michael's bold decision to imprison the Antonescu Government, to break with the Nazis and to fight on the side of the United Nations, the Communist-dominated Government sought in every way to minimize the King's role and to play up the Communists.
A complete survey of the needs of the American Merchant Marine is to be made by the American Legion when it gathers here this week in annual convention, it was announced yesterday.

The last frustrated passenger -- a tall girl in a green turban hat -- struggled down the pier of the strike-bound United States liner America at 3:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon, and the ship was officially ready for lay-up.

HOLLYWOOD. IN the absence of any concrete evidence pointing toward early modification of the 75 per cent tax imposed by England on earnings there of American movies, plans for tightening the economy of film company operations moved steadily forward last week and many workers suddenly discovered themselves out of jobs, or faced with the prospect of unemployment.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 23 -- Lessons learned in the Pacific are being utilized in the field training of National Guardsmen of the 105th Infantry from up-state and the 102nd Quartermaster Group of Brooklyn at Camp Smith, with veterans of combat action at Saipan heading both units.

GENEVA, Aug. 23 -- The Preparatory Committee of United Nations conference on international trade and employment closed its Geneva session today with a strong appeal to nations not to sacrifice the long-run objectives of international cooperation in the struggle to meet temporary problems.

WRIGHT FIELD, Ohio, Aug. 23 -- Nearly 100 German scientists, spurred on by the hope of an ultimate revenge on Russia, are working untiringly at Wright and Patterson army air fields to help the Army Air Forces plan its sky fleets of the future.

BASEBALL The Dodgers scored a costly 8-5 victory over the Reds yesterday, for both Peewee Reese and Eddie Stanky had to leave the field with spike injuries. Brooklyn retained its six-game National League lead over the Cardinals, who defeated the Phillies, 5 -- 3.

DOROTHY SPEARE has written the engrossing story of a Lost Lady -- a slick job and a far cry from Willa Cather. It is brightly done with all the modern embellishments: It has a title with the name of a New York numbered street.

An army of American Legionnaires will descend upon New York this week for a crowded program of fun and business. Although reluctant to forecast the size of the turnout, officials of the Legion are confident it will be tremendous. Some predict it will surpass the record set at the Legion's convention here ten years ago, which still stands as the organization's biggest gathering.

Henry Morgenthau Jr., general chairman of the United Jewish Appeal, announced yesterday that more than 6,000 Jewish communities in the nation would observe the High Holy Day period, Sept. 15 to 24, as the "Ten Days of Remembrance" in connection with a drive to reach the $170,000,000 goal of the appeal.

CALAIS, Me., Aug. 23 -- Beef costs 89 cents a pound retail today in this American town on the Canadian border. Across the St. Croix River in St. Stephens, New Brunswick, it costs only 35 cents. That about represents the difference between food prices in general on the two sides of the international boundary.

OTTAWA, Aug. 23 -- Out of the failure of the effort to make sterling convertible, there have risen many acute problems for Canada that have been officially minimized for a while but are now considered to loom menacingly over the near future.
This is the story of the Exodus 1947 and of her Jewish passengers.
TOKYO, Aug. 23 -- It is becoming evident that many Japanese export lines important in the past cannot be sold under present conditions.

MANY parents have been looking high and low for a school having space and staff enough for this year's big enrollments for kindergarten and first grade. Becky's father tells us: "She's awfully excited.

FRANCIS POULENC, in Paris, has occasioned a fine row -- something to which he never objected -- with his opera bouffe, "Les Mamelles de Tiresias." When this piece was produced at the Opera-Comique the "steady patrons" objected to a work which, in the estimate of the conservatives, was fit only for the burlesque stage -- if for that -- and not for this famous theatre.

Pointing out that a challenge of the constitutionality of local rent laws is expected to be started soon by some realty interests, John J. Lamula, legislative representative of the Joint Rent Action Committee, an organization of tenant groups, made public yesterday a determination from the Office of Housing Expediter in Washington disavowing conflict between Federal and local rent control.

TO THE EDITOR: You recently printed an article of mine ("Kind Words for the Soft-Shelled Clam") praising the soft-shelled clam and with a few curls of the lip for the culinary virtues of the hard-shelled clam or quahog.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 23 (AP) -- He insists he's a better trout fisherman than a trapshooter -- but 41-year-old Hugh Crossen, Gardiner, Mont., rancher, sporting goods dealer and tavern operator, today won the clay target sport's biggest prize, the forty-eighth Grand American Handicap.

TROY HILLS, N.J. -- "What you see with your own two eyes, your heart and soul must believe," bellowed the barker demonstrating a plastic vegetable juicer, as the tour of the Morris County Fair got under way last week.

Publications: Mount Zion; Ghastly Good Taste; Continual Dew; An Oxford University Chest; Shell Guides to Cornwall and Devon; Antiquarian Prejudice; Old Lights for New Chancels. LONDON, Aug. 23 -- Time, rather than dollars or food, is Britain's greatest lack in her struggle for economic survival, Herbert Morrison, Lord President of the Council, said tonight. He made this assertion in a radio appeal to Britons to speed output in all essential lines of production.

STUDENTS of the cinema will have an opportunity this fall and winter to see in historical perspective a program of films made in France, England, Sweden and Russia. The concluding section of "The History of the Motion Picture," which started last September at the Museum of Modern Art under auspices of the museum's film library, the program will include films dating from 1895 through 1946.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 23 -- Those never - say - die St. Louis Cardinals found a winning homer in venerable Joe Medwick's bat today and then extinguished a Philadelphia Phillies threat with an eighth-inning triple play for a 5-3 victory and an even split in their final four-game series here.
GENEVA, Switzerland, Aug. 23 -- Representatives of fifty nations have arrived in Geneva for the opening of the third annual meeting of the Food and Agriculture Organization.

RICHARD ROVERE, whose New Yorker article on the law firm of Howe Hummel expanded recently, as New Yorker articles will, into a full-length book (see page 12, this issue), side-slipped into that subject, almost by accident.

CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., Aug. 23 -- Herman Steiner of Los Angeles, who was succeeded as open champion of the United States Chess Federation by Isaac I. Kashdan of New York, undefeated victor with a score of 11 1/2-1 1/2, finally finished his schedule early today in the annual title tournament at the White Plaza Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Big business has been wondering lately whether it was in for another round of trust-busting in the Thurman Arnold tradition.

The crisis in the Greek Government apparently spring's from internal difficulties rather than external pressure, though the latter no doubt had its effect in bringing it to a head. Organized as a coalition of leading parties except the E.A.M. Leftists, it has failed to govern either wisely or well or to settle any major problems of the distracted nation.

A NEW type photoelectric exposure meter called the PR-1 will be introduced by General Electric Company tomorrow at the fifty-sixth annual convention of the Professional Photographers Association in Chicago.

YONKERS, N.Y., Aug. 23 -- George W. Kittredge, former chief engineer of the New York Central Railroad System for thirty-six years, died at his home, 592 North Broadway on Friday after a brief illness. His age was 90.
WHEN Abraham Lincoln was President, five of his predecessors in that high office were still living -- Martin Van Buren, John Tyler, Millard Fillmore, Franklin Pierce and James Buchanan.

IN the fruit garden, this might at first glance seem like the leisurely time when nothing needs to be done except to pick the delicious crop of apples, peaches, pears and berries now ripening. The gardener, however, who prides himself on his fruit patch, knows half a dozen or more small chores to make this season's harvest better and improve conditions for future years.

The Metropolitan qualifying round for the forty-seventh national amateur golf championship will be held on Tuesday on the Montclair (N.J.) Golf Club course with seventy-five of the area's foremost linksmen seeking the fifteen berths at stake.

BERLIN, Aug. 23 -- The French are willing to agree to collaboration with the United States and Britain in Germany if Ruhr coal is produced and allocated under international supervision. A further French stipulation is that allocation by countries be based on pre-war proportions, except in the case of Germany.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 23 -- Those happy, loyal crowds have converged on this city once again to see and enjoy the eighty-ninth Iowa State Fair, from yesterday through next Friday.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Aug. 23 -- Football and 90-degree temperature do not mix, but the New York Giants and the Green Bay Packers of the National Football League disregarded the weather to stage whale of a struggle before 15,000 persons tonight.

H.M. TOMLINSON uses the mood and beauty of the sea like a practiced hypnotist. While he works his magic on our sensibilities, his story is quietly gathering itself together. Presently we are carried off into an experience of other lives and other times without a backward thought for present-day reality.

FURNITURE, rugs, fabrics, wallpaper and the hundred and one little things that come under the heading of home furnishings are sold by so many different types of firms operating with different policies that it's no wonder homemakers are confused sometimes about where to start looking.

BOSTON, Aug. 23 -- Joseph F. Landis, of Cleveland, Ohio, president of the American Federation of Teachers, AFL, in an address today before the executive council of the organization, said that the school system in America was confronted with its greatest crisis.

The old conflict between employers who decry "impractical" college training and educators who fear overspecialization has been solved by City College's new Intensive Business Training Program. This is the opinion of Dr. Robert A. Love, director of the Evening and Extension Division of the College's School of Business, which operates the plan.

NANKING, Aug. 23 -- A plan for a temporary return to the "hard money" silver standard, which was abandoned by China in November, 1935, is being discussed in official circles here as a means of restoring faith in the Chinese dollar and tiding the Government over the severe financial crisis.
GULLIVER landing in the country of the Houyhnhnms could not have been more flabbergasted than a Berlin critic stranded in New York and thrown into the American theatre life of the Thirties.

PETROPOLIS, Brazil, Aug. 23 -- A 15-to-4 vote in Commission No. 3 of Inter-American Defense Conference virtually assured today a treaty provision that decisions on hemispheric collective action in case of aggression against an American nation shall be taken on the Foreign Minister level.

SCIENCE BOARD -- The Research and Development Board succeeds the Joint Research and Development Board and will promote research until a National Science Foundation ia created. The new board will allot research fields among the various armed services.

CONSTRUCTION of the Palisades Interstate Parkway, the forty-three-mile, fourlane highway from the George Washington Bridge up the west side of the Hudson River into Bear Mountain State Park, will begin this fall.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., Aug. 23 -- Thousands of Methodists took part today in an hour-long ceremony at the Ocean Grove Auditorium and then in a pilgrimage that ended at the site of a new Methodist Home for the Aged.
LONDON, Aug. 23 -- Economic events caught up with Britain in spectacular fashion this week and the Labor Government moved speedily to cope with the emergency.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23 -- Decisively defeated in their attempt to retail representation on the executive board, left-wing delegates at the CIO Illinois State Industrial Union Council convention today were warned by the newly elected council president, Joe Germano, that he would do everything he could to drive Communists out of the labor movement.

Surprised and angered at the Federal Trade Commission for the accusing finger pointed at the industry last week on the question of prices and competition, American steel companies have started preparation of briefs in defense of their fifty-year-old pricing system in an effort to settle this issue "once and forever."

THE great soul-struggle that racks New England -- the undying conflict between past and present -- is the theme of this fine novel, which traces the intellectual enmity between a father passionately in love with his heritage and a son who violently rejects it.

EASTERN MONTANA. THE chances are not high that one will be cast on a desert island, and I have always considered it a purely academic question as to what books one would take along to so improbable a destination.

PETROPOLIS, Brazil, Aug. 23 (U.P.) -- Dominican Government charges of financial and material aid to revolutionists plotting to overthrow President Trujillo were denied today by the Venezuelan Foreign Minister and Guatemalan Finance Minister.
WE conclude this week a glancing account of activities along the summer art colony trail. The installment that preceded took in Provincetown, Rockport and Gloucester, on the two Massachusetts capes.

Realtors now are facing the greatest opportunity in the history of their business. After years of suppressed production, the commodity that is their principal stock-in-trade -- home building -- can go ahead unhampered. This means more homes, more sales, more opportunity.

JUST a few days ago that suave conversationalist, Billy Evans, the reformed umpire and now general manager of the Detroit Tigers, bumped his head into the bottom of this column just as he was about to tell a story about Clarence (Pants) Rowland. The column ran out of space and Evans out of breath almost simultaneously. Now both have recovered sufficiently to bare all details.

Two of the most important unions on the East Coast waterfront are the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, headed by Joseph P. Ryan, 63, and the National Maritime Union, CIO, headed by Joseph Curran, 41. For ten years along New York's 250 miles of dockage the two unions have been bitter enemies. Last week both unions figured in a waterfront row which tied up part of New York's harbor.

The New York State Maritime Academy's training ship Empire State is due here Friday afternoon, completing a European cruise of three months. The ship, a modern World War II naval craft, left New York on June 1 with a complement of 350 cadet-midshipmen and a crew of forty officers and men.

IN a new documentary series entitled "The Third Horseman," presented at 9 P.M. Fridays, the National Broadcasting Company currently is exploring the most fundamental of all problems facing the distraught post-war world -- the food situation.

THE New York Botanical Garden has three courses starting next month. "Field Botany," with G.L. Wittrock as instructor, will be given on seven Saturdays at 1:30 P.M., starting Sept. 13. Mr. Wittrock will teach identification of trees, shrubs and autumn wild flowers in and near the Botanical Garden.

DR. EWING, the distinguished philosopher of the University of Cambridge, prefaces his essay on political philosophy with a statement that it is not intended as a general treatise on politics. It is concerned with three concrete political issues of our day: the question of the state and individual rights, the question of democracy and the question of the limitation of national sovereighty.

THIS new book of poems by Patrick Kavanagh -- a serious, loving evocation of rural Irish life, culminating in a long study of the old peasant. Patrick Maguire -- is so clearly above the general run of what passes for poetry among American publishers today that it seems ungenerous to record it as a disappointment.

Frozen foods, having passed through a period of distress during the past year, are slated for resumption of a sound expansion trend interrupted toy the war, industry spokesmen declared last week in viewing the current packing season which, except for certain non-seasonal items, is nearing its conclusion.

POPLARVILLE, Miss., Aug. 23 (AP) -- Amid peace and quiet which were in sharp contrast to the turbulence of his political career, Senator Theodore G. Bilho was buried today in the churchyard of the Juniper Grove Baptist Church.

AMERICANS have always been willing to pay for their scoundrels if they had humor, and Howe Hummel were certainly the funniest lawyers in the United States from 1869, when they went into partnership, until 1907 when the law finally caught up with the surviving partner, Abe Hummel, and put him in jail for subornation.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 23 -- The deadlock in the United Nations Security Council has been dramatized by a succession of Soviet vetoes, but it is realized here that these do not tell the full story of the Council's premature decline.

Plans for the agricultural and industrial development of Venezuela, to supplement and eventually replace imports which now are limited, are materializing, according to Finance Minister M.H. Perez-Guerrero, now in this country to confer with bankers.

Occupancy is scheduled for next month in the Thornley, fifteenstory residential building at 215 East Seventy-ninth Street, which is being completed for the Thornley Realty Corporation. The building will contain eighty-eight apartments of two to five and one-half rooms and four duplex penthouse units.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23 -- Railroad workers have more advantages than the employes in other industries, L.W. Horning, vice president of the New York Central Railroad Company, said today. He expressed this view while testifying before a wage arbitration board in opposition to demands by the non-operating unions for a pay increase of 20 cents an hour.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 23 -- The United States will urge the United Nations Security Council to act Monday to supervise the cease-fire order in the Netherlands Indies, it was reported today.

LONDON. OF the four most interesting openings in London during recent weeks two were home grown and two imported from the United States. It is difficult for a man like me who reads New York notices regularly to approach a new American play with a completely unbiased mind.

The curtain has been lifted a little higher on what we may look for in the speed of flight by the new record established by the Navy Douglas Skystreak which averaged 640.7 miles an hour over the Mojave Desert under the official observation of the National Aeronautics Association.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 23 -- As in the Whitney Stakes two weeks ago, it was Arnold Hanger's Rico Monte by a head over William L. Brann's Gallorette at the end of today's forty-fifth running of the $30,000 added Saratoga Handicap.

LONDON (By wireless). THE British Government's drastic act in setting up a heavy import tax on all foreign films, and Hollywood's vigorous counter move to stop exports of American films to Britain, produced a grave disturbance in the motion picture industry.

PARIS, Aug. 23 -- The final report of the European economic conference will show that Europe's need of outside supplies in the next four years will be so great that Western Europe can pay its way only if the "iron curtain" is removed or the economy of the Western world is reorganized.

Laurence M. Loeb, architect, has completed plans for the three-story cooperative garden apartment building to be erected by LanningHarris, builders, at Palmer and Brook Avenues, Yonkers, N.Y., according to the Cross Brown Company, agents.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Aug. 23 -- Governor Robert F. Bradford of Massachusetts reviewed a big float parade today which brought to a climax a four-day festival program in this historic New England seaport.

When the British withdrew from India on Aug. 15, leaving to the Indians the decision as to their future, they did more than grant freedom to one-fifth (370,000,000) of the world's peoples. PITTSBURGH, Aug. 23 -- The United Steelworkers of America, CIO, is now using its long-standing "no-strike" pledge as a bargaining point to win immunity from damage suits that might arise in wildcat work stoppages, it became known here this week.

A CARE for craftsmanship, intelligence and emotional control distinguish this English writer's first novel. BERLIN, Aug. 23 -- With three vital conferences concerning Germany going on at present, the United States Military Government is working under the tightest news curb imposed since the end of the war. Gen. Lucius D. Clay, who in some instances has ordered a thorough investigation of news "leaks," is especially concerned over the disclosures of classified information to newspaper men.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Mrs. Mary Arnold Prentiss of Los Angeles today regained two national public parks tennis championships she held nine years ago. Tomorrow Mrs. Prentiss will make a bid for another national title she had ten years ago.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- In a broad attack on this country's "costly and blundering foreign policy," Representative George H. Bender, Republican, of Ohio, called on President Truman today to reduce international and military expenditures.

A two-day meeting to consider the housing problems of America will be sponsored by the National Housing Committee of the American Legion, in connection with the twenty-ninth annual convention here, it was learned yesterday.

Suspension of sterling convertibility by Great Britain last week will have a world-wide impact varying by areas and producing important changes in both volume and direction of International trade, according to foreign traders here.

But Howe Products, Inc., of Chicago is the first company we know of to use candy as a medium for making a picture. And not elegant chocolates and bonbons either, but such homely confections as gum drops, jelly beans, licorice sticks and cinnamon drops.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 23 -- Directors of the Waterfront Employers Association of the Pacific Coast, augmented by a number of the association's members, continued today a series of meetings in an attempt to map their next steps in coping with the strike of longshore walking bosses in the ports of San Francisco and Los Angeles.

Want a job in Australia? St. Paul's Anglican Cathedral in Melbourne is looking for a new organist and is extending its search all the way to this country. Dr. Roscoe Wilson, acting dean of the cathedral, which is 10,541 miles the way the crow flies from New York.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Senate control will be a major contest in the 1948 election.
LAHORE, Pakistan, Aug. 24 (London Times Dispatch) -- India's Sikhs are on the warpath.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 24 -- Transplanted here in miniature this week acre the fears and conflicts of Slavic Europe, with leaders of the Polish National Alliance declaring that another devastating war is threatening.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Al Gettel's pitching and Joe Gordon's hitting combined to give the Cleveland Indians a 2-to-1 triumph over the Boston Red Sox in the second game of today's double-header after Boston had won the opener, 11 to 2, on Dave Ferris' five - hit hurling.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24 -- Prospects that the supply of lard early next year would be much smaller than anticipated recently, due to lighter feeding of hogs incident to a reduced corn crop, turned the lard market upward last week. Liberal short covering was evident, and there also was buying attributed to packers, although the domestic and export demand is said to be relatively slow.

Details of the second annual conference and products exhibit of the National Institute of Governmental Purchasing to be held at the Hotel Pennsylvania on Sept. 8, 9 and 10, which will be attended by more than 800 Federal, state and local government buyers, were announced over the week-end by President, Albert Pleydell, former Commissioner of Purchase of the City of New York.

On March 22, 1945, the late Leon Fraser, one-time head of the Bank for International Settlements, appeared before the House Banking and Currency Committee to testify on the then pending Bretton Woods legislation. On the question of currency problems he said:

An upswing in construction activity in metropolitan New York and Northern New Jersey was reported yesterday by the F.W. Dodge Corporation, which said that field reports of contracts awarded in July showed an increase of 9 per cent over June.

NEW DELHI, India. Aug. 24 -- Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, Prime Minister of the Dominion of India, paid a second visit to the disturbed areas in the Indian portion of Punjab Province today. Flying to Jullundur this morning, he planned to meet officials of the East Punjab Province and representatives of West Punjab in Pakistan.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: During two World Wars I have learned, in my work as chairman of the Central Relief Organization of Poland, to cherish the warm and disinterested friendship of the America people. Our organization was strivin to save millions from utter misery o extinction.

MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., Aug. 24 -- Major O.R. Allred of the Army Air Forces, described as a veteran combat and training pilot, and Corporal Ralph E. Poplett were listed here today as missing after a single-engine trainer plane from this field crashed into Long Island Sound shortly before midnight Saturday.
The long decks of the luxury liner America are still and empty, but some of her more fortunate passengers are well at sea today in the big British liner Mauretania.

Radical minority groups who demand "impossibly low rent ceilings and anti-discrimination clauses" as the price of limited tax exemption for housing projects are more concerned with creating political issues than with directing private capital into emergency housing, Robert Moses, City Construction Coordinator, charged yesterday.

DENVER, Colo., Aug. -- Eight Western states will undertake within the next three months a broad program to break what Governor Lee Knous of Colorado described as the Eastern monopoly on wool and textiles.

Events in the Far East seem rapidly shaping up to a clarification which has not been apparent in the past six months. They could at best be leading to some solution of the present distracted situation in China, Manchuria and Korea, or at least to a definite showdown of American and Russian policy in an area of trouble which threatens the peace of the whole world.

TEANECK, N.J., Aug. 24 -- The fastidious burglar who entered eight houses in Bergen County in the last two weeks and in each instance took a white shirt and a bath in addition to any cash and jewelry lying around, was in the hands of police today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The Department of Commerce reported today that per capita income for the country as a whole last year reached a new high of $1,200, more than double the $575 average for 1940 and nine per cent above the 1945 figure.

LIBERTY, N.Y., Aug. 24 -- An air show marked the dedication today of the 300-acre Grossinger Airport, with a 4,100-foot runway, said to be the largest of its kind in this part of the country. More than 5,000 spectators watched the exercises.

A picture in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine yesterday, depicting a group of black-gowned, black-hooded women waiting outside the parliament building in Athens for the casualty lists from the fighting in the northern mountains, is the appropriate Illustration for the story of the fall of the Maximos Government.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- Production of radio and television receivers decreased in July as a result of a seasonal decline plus many plant vacation shutdowns, the Radio Manufacturers Association announced today. July production of all types of radio receivers by RMA member-companies dropped to 1,155,456 against a total of 1,213,142 for the preceding month.

The "one world," for which all of us have longed and which science has now rendered imperative, fast is becoming a fading dream, the Rev. DuBois Le Fevre, of New Rochelle, N.Y., warned yesterday. the clergyman, formerly pastor of the First Unitarian Church in Youngstown, Ohio, preached at the All Souls Unitarian Church, Lexington Avenue and Eightieth Street.

Plans for an educational campaign to promote more informed buying and selling of plastic products and components have been completed by the plastics division of the American Cyanamid Company, it was announced over the week-end.
Exports from this country during the month of June dropped almost $200,000,00 from the May total of $1,421,800,000, according to a report from the Bureau of the Census of the Department of Commerce.

SEOUL, Korea, Monday, Aug. 25 -- Lieut. Gen. John R. Hodge, commanding United States forces in Korea, this morning categorically denied Soviet charges that conditions in South Korea "interfered with the work of the joint commission."

CHICAGO, Aug. 24 -- Grain markets continued last week their advance that got under way about a month ago. Prices of corn at the top showed an upturn of more than 50 cents a bushel in that period, with the cash article selling at $2.52, which was far above any previous domestic record, although official figures are available for 157 years.
JERUSALEM, Aug. 24 -- One wing of the Jewish underground in Palestine, the Stern group, is turning left, toward the Soviet bloc in international politics and toward socialism in internal affairs.

With the Cubs fittingly enough the victims, the Giants yesterday set a new National League seasonal home-run record as they shelled the ramparts of the Polo Grounds with five circuit blows in the course of a twin bill before a gathering of 26,715.
SAVANNAH, Ga., Aug. 24 (AP) -- A conflict over prices is raging in the great turpentine industry of the South, which supplies this vital commodity for much of the world.

Fire Chief Harold J. Burke, who was appointed reluctantly by Commissioner Prank J. Quayle on July 22, will appear with counsel before the pension board of the Fire Department today prepared to fight to retain his $11,500 post, it was learned last night.

Her next sailing date still indefinite, the strikebound United States liner America, with only a skeleton crew aboard, lay at her North River pier yesterday, three days after her scheduled departure for Europe had been postponed by a maritime work stoppage.
The Board of Transportation has asked the City Planning Commission for a 1948 capital budget allowance of $103,125,307, it was learned yesterday.

LONDON, Aug. 24 (U.P.) -- The Moscow radio said tonight that the United States and the Soviet Union had agreed that they must start afresh in attempts to set up an independent government in Korea. But Foreign Minister Molotov was quoted as having said that American "persecutions" in Korea must be stopped.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The nationally acclaimed $100,000 winner -take-all match race between Armed and Assault, scheduled for next Saturday at Washington Park, was called off today when Assault developed a soreness in his foot after an early morning workout.

PELHAM, N.Y. Aug. 24 -- Whispering around Long Island Sound in a faltering south-southwest air, 137 sailing craft took part today in the New York Athletic Club's annual regatta, one of the Yacht Racing Association series.

A comprehensive master plan involving the extensive redevelopment of property adjacent to the United Nations site in eastern midtown Manhattan will be presented Thursday before the Board of Estimate by the New York chapter of the American Institute of Architects.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 24 -- Cherry Valley captured the team championship of the Long Island Golf Association with a 306 total at the Hempstead club today. The victors were sparked by Ray Torgerson's one-under-par 72.

Senator Milton R. Young, Republican of North Dakota, and thirteen other Government officials and representatives of farm and consumer groups left La Guardia Field yesterday, to attend the opening today of the conference in Geneva of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization.

Russia is "playing a waiting game," Earl O. Shreve, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, said yesterday. "She is waiting for this country to crash financially and economically so she can pick up the pieces." Mr. Shreve spoke at the opening luncheon of the annual conference of the National Association of Junior Achievement Companies, at the Empire Hotel, Sixty-third Street and Broadway.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24 -- Women in the regular Army are expected to comprise 2 per cent of the strength of the Army itself, or about 20,000 enlisted women and 1,000 officers, Lieutenant Col. Mary L. Milligan, deputy director of the Wac, said today at the closing session of the Wac-Vets first national convention.

BOSTON, Aug. 24 -- The Socialist Party of Massachusetts took over observance of the twentieth anniversary of the execution of Nicola Sacco and Bartolomeo Vanzetti at a meeting on Boston Common today. It won approval of a resolution charging that the two "were murdered by the state because they fought for the freedom of workers."

JERUSALEM, Aug. 24 -- Al Wahda, newspaper of the Palestine Arab party, the party of the exiled Mufti of Jerusalem, Haj Amin el Husseini, proposed today the annexation of Palestine and TransJordan to Syria under certain conditions.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $51,544,423,220. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows: Aug. 28 -- Discount bills .......... $1,311,450,000

Having no defense against the atomic bomb, mankind's only chance of survival in an atomic world is final abolition of war through a world federation, Robert M. Hutchins, chancellor of the University of Chicago, declared yesterday.

Because of the acute international situation, Congress should be summoned into special session immediately to enact universal military training and other measures to strengthen the national defense, Paul H. Griffith, National Commander of the American Legion, said yesterday.

SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 24 -- Paced by the passing and running attack of Glenn Dobbs, former Tulsa University star, the Brooklyn Dodgers rallied last night from a 14-0 first-period deficit to overcome the Chicago Rockets in an All-America Football Conference exhibition game at the University of Utah Stadium.

SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 24 -- Soviet authorities in Korea released at 4 P.M. today three American soldiers whom they had held in custody since Aug. 12, it was announced tonight by headquarters of the Twenty-fourth Corps here.

To the editor op the new york times: Herbert Pell's case for PR, printed in the times of Aug. 14, sends us down a false trail. To quote him, his "crowning argument" is the fact that the old Board of Aldermen promoted voter apathy.

Customers' response to the cooler weather last week heartened retailers and resulted in a noticeable pick-up in retail volume, according to reports prepared especially for the NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

BOSTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- After getting off to a jittery start, the St. Louis Cardinals belted four Boston Braves pitchers for 15 hits, including Stan Musial's sixteenth homer, for a 9 -- 5 victory today before a sweltering 24,522 crowd. Pitcher Murry Dickson launched the Redbirds' attack by singling with the bases loaded in the fourth inning.

NANKING, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The text of Lieut Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer's statement on China: As promised in the initial press release, the inquiry into economic, political, military and social conditions has been undertaken without commitment or prejudgement.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24 (AP) -- San Francisco's Crystal Plunge, paced by Miss Ann Curtis triple, easily retained its team title, but a record -pulverizing Dutch girl, 21year-old Miss Nel van Vliet, stole the spotlight as the three-day women's National Amateur Athletic Union outdoor swimming championships ended today.

PETROPOLIS, Brazil, Aug. 24 -- A four-nation subcommittee of the Inter - American Defense Conference tackled here today the exacting job of composing a preamble to a hemispheric treaty that would suit all the twenty-one American republics.

ATLANTA, Aug. 24 -- Investigation of the bombing late last night of the home of C.E. Gregory, political reporter for the Atlanta Journal, turned today to a variety of possibilities. These are linked to crusades which he has led in recent years for his paper.

When religion is present in the home there is never any likelihood of a marriage resulting in separation or divorce, the Very Rev. Edward J. Bubb, dean of the Cathedral of St. John, Quincy, Ill., declared yesterday at the morning service of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Apostles, Ninth Avenue and Twenty-eighth Street.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24 -- A recommendation that reorganization of methods of treatment and administration in mental hospitals should precede extension of facilities for mental patients is contained in the full report of the Commission on Hospital Care released today in Washington and Chicago by George Bugbee, executive director of the American Hospital Association.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Senator Sheridan Downey, Democrat, of California, said today that "a migration of gamblers, racketeers and blackmailers" to California was providing a critical post-war problem for local and state officials.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 24 (AP) -- A three-run in-the-park homer by Jerry Priddy in the fourth inning started the Washington Senators off to a 7-to-4 victory in the second game of a double-header today after the St. Louis Browns had captured the first game, 7 1, behind the pitching and hitting of Cliff Fannin.

DENVER, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The Denver Post reported last night in a copyright article that huge caverns were being dug under Army and Navy supervision in a mountain range not far from Albuquerque, N.M., as "superdefenses against a possible World War III."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The nation's insured banks chalked up the highest earnings on record in 1946, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation reported today, but their "capital cushion has declined to an alarming extent."
ZURICH, Aug. 24 -- Switzerland will be affected only indirectly by suspension of the convertibility of sterling, all competent authorities here assert.

SPRING VALLEY, N.Y., Aug. 24 -- A twenty-eight-acre tract of marsh land long had been an eyesore and a breeding place for mosquitoes in the center of this village. Today all Spring Valley turned out for the laying of the cornerstone of Memorial Rotunda in picturesque Spring Valley Memorial Park, which was made to blossom on the former swamp.

ROOSEVELT FIELD, L.I., Aug. 24 -- George Bogardus, 32 years old, an aircraft mechanic of Troutdale, Ore., came to Roosevelt Field today and told of having made what local aviation authorities believe to have been the first transcontinental flight in a home-made airplane.

PARIS, Aug. 24 -- Cold blooded observers here, within and outside the European Economic Conference on the Marshall Plan, took the view today that if the conference were to come within even a measurable distance of fulfilling its gigantic task it must show far more positive results in the next two weeks than it has in the past.

No means of grace has been more effective than prayer, the Rev. Dr. Adam W. Burnet, minister of St. Cuthbert's Parish Church, Edinburgh, Scotland, asserted yesterday. He spoke at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street, where he has been preaching during August.

Every member of the City Council who was in town was besieged over the week-end by tenant and landlord groups and by individuals pleading for and against the Sharkey rent bills that are to come to a vote tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (U.P.) -- New mathematical laboratories in which giant "electronic brains" will find speedy answers to complex problems raised in atomic research and aviation have been established by the National Bureau of Standards, it was disclosed tonight.

A Few Brief Words on Vacations With vacations largely over for this year except for the sad, empty rites of wishing a churlish godspeed to those fortunate enough to have waited for September, it may be permissible to make some observations on this annual custom and sensible ways to celebrate it.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24 -- All deliveries of oats sold at new seasonal high prices last week on the Board of Trade, with September at a new peak for futures. The cash grain, however, failed to go as high as in 1919 when it reached

BATAVIA, Java, Aug. 24 (U.P.) -- The Indonesian Republic reported that virtually full-scale war was raging again in Java tonight. The strategic road town of Ampel was said to be under heavy attack by Dutch infantry and artillery.

SOFIA, Aug. 24 (U.P.) -- An attorney for Nikola Petkov, leader of the Agrarian party and former Cabinet Minister, who is under sentence of death, said he would file an appeal Monday. The attorney conferred with M. Petkov in Central Prison today.
Following is the text of Mayor O'Dwyer's proclamation of American Legion Week: To the people of the City of New York:

The regular winter shows start to return to the airwaves in appreciable numbers this week, the last of August traditionally marking the end of what is charitably called the "replacement season." In all, six premieres are listed for listeners from today through Saturday.

PANAMA, Aug. 24 -- The coup d'etat that ended the virtual dictatorship of President Jose Marie Velasco Ibarra in Ecuador had been planned by the army for a long time, according to information here. It appears that by clever, opportunistic tactics, Dr. Velasco Ibarra had been able to hold off the action.

Hardware and kitchen items, pneumatic and electric tools, construction materials, wire rope slings, marine specialties, pole line hardware and industrial equipment were among war surplus products listed in new sales offerings announced over the week-end by Regional Director Carl P. Malmstrom of the War Assets Administration.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The International Association of Machinists, with 13,028 grand and local officers, charged tonight that the new National Labor Relations Board was setting up impossible rules for filing the anti-Communist affidavits required by the Taft-Hartley law.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24 -- The action of corn dominated the wheat market last week on the Board of Trade, and all deliveries of the latter grain brought new season high prices. However, Government buying of cash wheat was also a factor, as sufficient grain was taken to prevent liberal hedging sales.
LONDON, Aug. 24 -- A triple move by Britain to prevent the execution of Nikola Petkov, leader of the Bulgarian Opposition, was announced by the Foreign Office tonight.

Cotton prices in the domestic market tended toward lower levels here last week. At the close on Friday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were flown 82 to 106 points from the close of the week previous. The largest net recession was in the spot month.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24 -- The chemists' laboratories still hold the key to the future of the "synthetic wonder cloths" which it was suggested might be stars of post-war production in the home furniture upholstery and women's garment fields, authorities in synthetic fabric trade circles said today.

CENTRALIA, Ill., Aug. 24 (AP) -- Miss Elizabeth Kenny, Australian nurse noted for her fight against infantile paralysis, today dedicated the first of what her supporters hoped would be a series of worldwide clinics to combat the disease.

The Roman Catholic religious devotional magazine, The Messenger of the Sacred Heart, official organ of the Apostleship of Prayer, has been banned in Yugoslavia, Albania, Austria, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland and Bohemia and Ruthenia in Czechoslovakia, it was announced yesterday.
E.T. Swan has been named domestic sales manager for the Kellogg Company of Battle Creek, Mich., retaining his other positions in the company. L.G. Buchanan has become sales supervisor.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- A new inquiry on wartime production, to investigate "fraud and overpayment" in war contracts, will be undertaken early next month by the House Committee on Expenditures in the Executive Departments.

Paul H. Griffith, National Commander of the American Legion, saw service in both world wars. In 1917, at the age of 20, he left school to enlist in the United States Army, and served overseas as a sergeant in the 110th Infantry Regiment, 28th Division, in the Aisne-Marne, Oise-Aisne, ChampagneMarne, and Meuse-Argonne offensive sectors.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Phillies and Cincinnati Reds divided a doubleheader here today, the Reds winning the first game, 12 to 3, on a tenth-inning nine-run rally, and the Phillies taking the seven-inning second game, 8 to 6, halted by the Pennsylvania Sunday curfew law.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 24 -- Hot weather and vacation schedules combined to force the steel industry's ingot operating rate off another half point last week to 93.5 per cent of rated capacity. In view of the excessive heat prevailing over most of the country, particularly in the Midwest, this rate is considered good in the industry.

RENO, Nev., Aug. 24 (AP) -- E.J. Dutch) Harrison of York, Pa., iring a smashing final round of 66, shattered par and the hopes of rivals today to win the $15,000 Reno open golf tournament with a 72-hole total of 272.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 24 -- The Indonesian Republic will call upon the United Nations Security Council tomorrow for "speedy, impartial and effective action" to settle its month-old dispute with the Netherlands Government, Sutan Sjahrir, Indonesian spokesman said today.

RED BANK, N.J., Aug. 24 -- Speedboating's two popular personalities. Danny (Red) Foster and Guy Lombardo, who for two days dominated the biggest Red Bank sweepstakes regatta in history, brought their performances to an amazing, even fantastic close, late this afternoon on the tranquil North Shrewsbury River.
LONDON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- A large part of Europe was in the throes of the worst drought in a decade today, bringing damage to crops similar to that which threatens in the United States corn belt.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24 -- Overcoming a cloudburst, an outfield that was dotted with miniature lakes after play had been interrupted for an hour, and the feeble pitching efforts of Charley (Red) Ruffing, the Yankees trooped off Comiskey Park this afternoon with a split in their double-header with the White Sox, convinced that Umpire Red Jones was the innocent, involuntary obstacle to a twin-edged triumph.
To the editor of the new york times: At the risk of seeming ungenerous, I should like to point out a few facts apropos of the food situation in Europe.
DETROIT, Aug. 24 -- Henry Ford 2d, president of the Ford Motor Company, announced tonight price increases for most passenger car models and all trucks in the Ford line, effective immediately.

PARIS, Aug. 24 By the end of this year French production will have approached close to the level of 9 , Premier Paul Ramadier said today in an address at Mende. He chided the French people for having so little confidence in themselves in the present difficulties.
OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 24 -- Breaking out with a nine-goal rush in the second half, Laddie Sanford's Hurricanes handed Bostwick Field a 12 to 4 setback at Bostwick Field today.

With the sanction of the State, War and Navy Departments, the first post-war exchange student from Germany will arrive in Septemper, Laurence Duggan, director of the Institute of International Education, announced yesterday.

GALVESTON, Test., Aug. 24 -- A savage tropical storm struck the Texas Gulf Coast late today to batter Galveston and explosiontorn Texas City with 68 to 70-mile winds. One man was killed and three were feared lost at sea.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Military gnd commercial airline officials tomorrow will witness preview demonstrations of a post-war sky truck, capable of carrying sixteen tons of freight at 300 miles an hour, at the Columbus plant of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation.

Playing without their star second - base combination, Peewee Reese and Eddie Stanky, both of whom are sidelined with injuries, the Dodgers continued their winning ways by outscoring the Pirates, 3-1, in the opener of a three-game series at Ebbets Field yesterday.

Bean sprouts grown in Brooklyn were one of the items that attracted our attention in a recent tour of the grocery department at Macy's. The tins in which the sprouts were packed bear the label of the Shing-Li Products company and the statement that the sprouts are grown by hydroponic farming.

Although not predicting any special heat wave, the Weather Bureau announced yesterday that the thermometer climbed to 91.8 degrees at 3:40 P.M., the highest temperature ever recorded for an Aug. 24 by the bureau.

As part of the contemplated system of interstate highways, and indeed as a major step in general post-war road construction, special attention should be given to bringing bridges up to date. A bridge built today is expected to serve for at least seventy-five years. Yet, many of our new bridges have not been built to support loads that can be carried safely by the pavement they link.

The Security Council of the United Nations has another opportunity today, when it reconvenes to resume consideration of the armed conflict between the Dutch and the Republic of Indonesia in Java and Sumatra, to show that it is capable of doing what the people of the world hoped it would be able to do when the United Nations Organization was set up over two years ago at San Francisco.

LONDON, Aug. 24 -- Britain's decision to suspend in most areas the convertibility of the pound sterling within a little more than five weeks after setting the currency free has neither shocked nor surprised the City. Those not acquainted with the psychology of stock markets have certainly been surprised that an event so serious as a default on dollars should have been followed immediately by a rise and not a collapse in the markets.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Aug. 24 (AP) -- Dan Bankhead, pitching star of the Negro American League, has been sold to the Brooklyn Dodgers of the National League for a price reported "over $10,000," it was learned today.
ATHENS, Aug. 24 -- Constantin Tsaldaris was fighting an uphill battle to form a government tonight.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 24 -- Universal-International and Artists Alliance, the Mary PickfordLester Cowan Producing Company, have closed a deal by which Artists Alliance will produce the screen version of "One Touch of Venus" on the U-I lot in January for U-I release.

DETROIT, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Pat Mullin's ninth-inning single with the bases loaded gave the Detroit Tigers a 5-to-4 victory 'over the Philadelphia Athletics today and a sweep of a double-header after Virgil Trucks had fanned nine men, pitching a seven-hit 6-to-2' victory in the opener.

GENEVA, Switzerland, Aug. 24 -- A "fair prospect" of Jewish acceptance of a partition of the Holy Land is seen by the Executive of the Jewish Agency for Palestine only if an Galilee, the northern Negev and the Jewish part of Jerusalem are included in the Jewish area, according to a letter addressed by the Agency to the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine today.

AMSTERDAM, Aug. 24 -- British financial economic developments are being followed here with keen interest because it is felt that in the British difficulties all western European post-war troubles are concentrated.

With the peak of this year's summer tourist season already passed, normal peacetime transatlantic travel conditions are apparent now for the first time since the pre-war days of 1939, according to John M. Diggs, general passenger traffic manager of the Cunard White Star Line.

QUITO, Ecuador, Aug. 24 -- Col. Carlos Mancheno, Minister of Defense, seized control of the Government last night from President Jose Maria Velasco Ibarra. Today Colonel Mancheno proclaimed himself President and Chief of Government.

Arthur Schwartz, who used to be quite active hereabout before he became enamoured with film doings, announced yesterday plans to enter the ranks of the Broadway producers this season with a new revue based on John Gunther's best-seller, "Inside U.S.A."

Determined to permit no further delay in installation of vital communications at Idlewild Airport, Mayor O'Dwyer is prepared to take direct action early this week if no settlement is reached in the twoyear-old jurisdictional dispute that has prevented laying of telephone cables at the new Queens field.

A union guarantee against strikes or stoppages until Feb. 1, 1949, is contained in new contracts signed by five of the city's largest department stores with locals of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, CIO, it was announced last night by Jules S. Freund, executive director of the Retail Labor Standards Association.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Taking a 5-to-0 lead in the first period and lengthening the advantage to 9 to 1 at half time, the hard-riding, superbly mounted Mexican polo team captured the first of a threegame series against a picked United States four, 13 -- 8, today at the Oak Brook Polo Club.

BAD SALZUFLEN, Germany, Aug. 24 -- The British Military Government has launched a campaign to allay fears of Germans that their forests are being completely stripped. A "background" policy letter, distributed to all regional Military Government chiefs am made available today, outlined the official British position on timber exports.

During the last two weeks the mast atop the Empire State Building has been struck by eight lightning bolts, each of which has been trapped and shunted through a battery of newly installed recording instruments.

Completion of a deal where by a group of tenants in the nine-story and penthouse apartment building at 112 East Seventy-fourth Street became owners of the property was announced yesterday by A.V. Amy Co., brokers.

NANKING, Aug. 24 -- Lieut.Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer's farewell statement, in which he declared pointedly that "promises will no longer suffice" to eliminate government corruption and inefficiency, was interpreted here today as a stern reminder to President Chiang Kai-shek that performance on long-promised political and economic reforms would be an important consideration in determining the American policy on China.

Sir Wilfrid Eady, head of the British financial mission and Second Secretary of the British Treasury, indicated satisfaction with the results of his loan talks in Washington before he took off for London from La Guardia Field yesterday.

To the sentimentalist the announcement that horses will soon disappear from West Point as relics of an outmoded form of warfare will mean simply the end of a picturesque feature of military training, the discontinuance of West Point's championship polo team and the disappearance of the academy's annual horse show.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Private fliers will have their own coast-to-coast highway -- a fortymile-wide strip which the Civil Aeronautics Administration today designated formally for marking as the nation's "Skyway No. 1."

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., Aug. 24 -- Four up at the turn, Ray Billows of Poughkeepsie defeated Tommy Strafaci of Plandome, L.I., in the final, to capture top honors in the annual invitation tournament of the Briar Hills Golf Club today.

Despite recent squabbling between Democratic party leaders and those of the American Labor Party, the outlook for a united front of the Democratic, American Labor and Liberal parties behind the Democratic presidential ticket in 1948 is regarded now as better than it was several months ago, it was indicated yesterday.

PETROPOLIS, Brazil, Aug. 24 -- The United States delegation to the inter-American conference met for three hours today under the chairmanship of Secretary of State Marshall, while the Argentines continued their efforts to line up other delegations behind the principle of a distinction between aggressors from within and without the hemisphere.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 24 -- In a communication to all members of the United Nations except Britain and the Arab states, the Executive of the Jewish Agency for Palestine implored them today to intervene against Britain's "illegal, inhuman and immoral" action in sending 4,400 Jewish refugees back to Germany in three vessels.

LONDON, Aug. 24 -- The Tripartite Conference on the level of German industry in the economically -merged United States and British zones completed today its general discussion of ways to meet French security fears and got down to the specific business of how the Ruhr mines are to be managed and controlled.

A tightening in the supply of Scotch whiskey because of its use as a leader in pre-fair trade selling during the last few weeks has caused some liquor retailers who ordinarily enjoy a good holiday trade on the item, to put the brakes on its further sale, according to reports yesterday.

By way of avenging their illustrious predecessors of the class of 1930, whose National League homer record had been wiped out the previous afternoon, the Cubs of current vintage did a deal of longrange clouting of their own at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

QUITO, Ecuador, Aug. 25 -- Col. Carlos Mancheno, as acting President after the forced resignation of Dr. Jose Marie Velasco Ibarra, announced today his appointment of a Cabinet of Liberals and Socialists. The new ministers took office at once.

Reflecting the current, gradual movement toward a somewhat higher level of short-term interest rates, three large commercial banks here yesterday announced increases in the rates on bankers acceptances of 1/16 to 1/4 of 1 per cent for short and long term bills.

The military uprising in Ecuador that unseated the elected President, Jose Maria Velasco Ibarra, was understandably upsetting to the representatives of the American countries meeting at Petropolis to frame a hemisphere defense treaty. The happenings at Quito are not germane to the conferences at Petropolis, however, except as they raised a question as to the credentials of the Ecuadorian delegation.

SPARTANBURG, S.C., Aug. 25 (AP) -- Aaron Kravitch, a Savannah, Ga., lawyer, told a three-judge Federal Court today that if South Carolina fishing laws are upheld in the courts Georgia and Florida could be expected to retaliate.

Growing evidences that newcrop cotton in the South is beginning to move in sufficient volume to satisfy the immediate demand superseded the weather news in the cotton market yesterday and prices for the near positions developed weakness under increased October liquidation.

BATAVIA, Java, Aug. 25 (UP) -- The Indonesian Republic said today that the Dutch had made an infantry, tank and mortar attack on Tengaren, a strategic town in the Salatiga sector, north of the Republican capital of Jogjakarta.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- The National Federation of Small Business, which has 85,000 members, sent congratulations to Attorney General Tom C. Clark today for his "forceful" anti-trust drive, but cautioned him against over-emphasizing "high prices."

City departments and agencies have requested a total of $2,532,500,487 for pending and new capital projects in the 1948 capital budget and the five-year capital program from 1949 to 1953 inclusive, according to figures made public yesterday by the City Planning Commission.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (U.P.) -- Complete data issued by the Bureau of Internal Revenue disclosed tonight that Federal revenues for the 1947 fiscal year that ended on June 30 totaled $39,108,385,742. This was a drop of $1,563,711,256 from the $40,672,096,998 in the previous twelve months.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25 -- The hardwood industry has almost completed the transition from a position of scarcity to a balanced market, an industry spokesman said here today. He described the market as "firm and steady," adding the prediction that it would remain in that position "well into 1948."

Our Common Lot President Truman's remark that all Americans are descended from, displaced persons is a statement of fact that nobody can deny. It applies even to those of us who are of American Indian descent.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 25 -- A large section of Palestine's Jewish community went without food today, in a traditional gesture of grief and distress, to protest the deportation of 4,400 refugees to Germany in British transports. The refugees had been turned away from Palestine.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Those of us who are interested in every phase of the complex problems facing the Puerto Rican Americans, both in their island home and in their adopted city, were most encouraged by the publication in THE NEW YORK TIMES of the study and the editorial comments on Aug. 3 and 4, and the letter and editorial of Aug. 7.

Prices of British woolens today are about 50 per cent above a year ago and "consequently are completely prohibitive," it was reported here yesterday by Jerome I. Udell, president of Max Udell Sons Co., Inc., men's clothing manufacturers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (U.P.) -- A Washington grand jury is investigating charges that the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey and Retail Gas Dealers, Inc., conspired illegally to fix gasoline prices, it was disclosed today.

Bronx County took another step into the Machine Age yesterday when Albert Goldman, New York Postmaster, helped local postoffice officials celebrate the installation of the first "Mailomat" in the borough. The main lobby of the Bronx Central Annex at 149th Street and the Grand Concourse, was where bustling officials lent excitement as Postmaster Goldman had a letter to President Truman snatched from his hands by the fast-thinking machine.

The New York City Fire Department's Pension Board retired Harold J. Burke yesterday as chief of the department. Mr. Burke had applied for retirement and later submitted a request for withdrawal of the retirement application.

FACTS are sometimes fearful things. They are particularly unpleasant at a time like this, when the entire world is surfeited with horror, with the misery and suffering and sacrifice of war, with the atrocities of the Nazis and with all the irreconcilable problems which still keep so many nations and peoples snarling at one another like suspicious dogs.

Mayor O'Dwyer and other city officials have gone to great pains to make the United Nations feel at home in New York City. They have cooperated in every way, including considerable expenditure of city funds, in the creation of the permanent headquarters for U.N. in east midtown Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, made public here today a list of individuals receiving from corporations compensation for personal services in excess of $75,000 for the calendar year 1945 and fiscal years ending in 1946.

At 2 P.M. yesterday the temperature in the city reached 92 degrees, coming within nine-tenths of a degree of the record for the date, set in 1893. However, there was a promise of some relief today in the form of scattered thunder showers, with temperatures confined to the middle 80s.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Aug. 25 -- The Rumanian Communist party is reported to be stepping up, in the expectation that Russia will ratify the peace treaty next month, its campaign to tighten its strangle-hold on this country and to continue it even after the Red Army leaves.

Domestic demand for printing presses and type-casting machines is ahead of a year ago and current deliveries are slower, it was learned yesterday. Leading makers of printing equipment reported their backlogs from two to four years behind, with shortages principally of steel, hampering production.

A world-wide promotional campaign on the use of wool will be prepared by the International Wool Secretariat through its chairman, Edgar H. Booth of Australia, Dr. F.J.C. Cronje, representative for South Africa, and R.G. Lund of New Zealand.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., Aug. 25 -- The Quantuck Yacht Club crew from out Southampton way took the lead for top honors in the national junior yachting championships in the Sound off the Cold Spring Harbor Beach Club today by finishing second in two races for 14 points.
NANKING, Aug. 25 -- The Central Government, which fixed its 1947 budget at nine trillion Chinese dollars, is now faced with the prospect that expenditures this year will be three times the estimate.

Second-day retailer purchases were spotty at the thirty-third semi-annual New York Gift Show in the New Yorker and Pennsylvania Hotels yesterday. To overpriced items buyer resistance was strong: and extreme caution was exercised in purchasing gadgettype merchandise.

For Viscount Jowitt, Lord Chancellor of Great Britain, yesterday's high temperatures in New York were not as trying as they might have been. He was not wearing the wig that is a traditional symbol of his high office.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (U.P.) -- Federal investigation of housing and real estate sales is under way n the District of Columbia and oon may be broadened into a nation -wide inquiry into the high cost of homes.

LONDON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Ten British golf professionals who have accounted for five of the twelve major tournaments this season and placed second or third in the others, head the list of candidates for Britain's Ryder Cup team which will meet the Americans at Portland, Ore., Nov. 1 and 2.

LONDON, Aug. 25 -- Substantial progress toward a "reasonably satisfactory" agreement on raising the level of industry in Germany was made when the United States, British and French heads of delegations to the tripartite conference here conferred for two hours today.

LEONARDO, N.J., Aug. 25 -- The loading of ammonium nitrate, a fertilizer that under certain conditions is highly explosive, will be discontinued at the Earle Naval Ammunition Depot here when a ship now taking on cargo sails from the base, probably before the end of this week, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- The Pullman Company, now owned by a group of fifty-seven railroads, today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to increase lower berth and other rates to meet increased costs. The increases range from 49 per cent where the lower berth rate is now $2.35 to 1 per cent where the rate is now $17.35.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 25 -- After a French veto on a proposal to appoint an eleven nation commission on Indonesia, the United Nations Security Council decided today to offer its "good offices" to the Netherlands and the Indonesian Republic rather than attempt to impose arbitration.

A two-and-one-half ton delivery truck parked in front of 110 East Forty-first Street rolled down the street at 3:40 P.M. yesterday and smashed into the window of a lunchroom at 121-25 East Fortyfirst Street, in the rear of the Chanin Building.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 25 -- The eleven-month "strike" of several thousand movie studio craft workers in an American Federation of Labor jurisdictional dispute is not a strike but a lockout, James Skelton, leader of the participating carpenter group, asserted to the House Labor subcommittee today.

An eighty-minute conference between officials of the United Telephone Organizations and the Port of New York Authority failed yesterday to end the two-year-old jurisdictional dispute that has prevented installation of telephone cable at the new Idlewild Airport.

A physical inventory of New Jersey farms, determining the condition of the land and the best possible uses to be made of it, is under way. The surveys, it is expected, will be important as forming the basis for erosion control plans for 2,000 farms.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Government will begin cashing terminal leave pay bonds one week from today.

MUNICH, Aug. 25 -- Gen. Josef Dietrich, commander of the Sixth Panzer Army and Col. Joachim Peiper made brief appearances today as witnesses at Dachau where Lieut. Col. Otto Skorzeny and nine German army and navy associates are on trial.
The Navy, at the request of the American Legion, has been busy making plans, including the dedication of a Legionnaire marching song, to put more zest into this year's convention proceedings.

ATLANTA, Aug. 25 -- Gov. M.E. Thompson expressed the belief today that persons responsible for the bombing on Saturday night of the home of C.E. Gregory, Atlanta Journal political writer, had been frightened away earlier from an attempt to bomb the Executive Mansion.

WINNIPEG, Man., Aug. 25 (AP) -- Canada's 1947 wheat crop appeared today to be somewhere between 340,000,000 and 360,000,000 bushels, with the actual figure uncertain until harvesting, now under way in many sections, is completed.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25 -- Rains in many parts of the Corn Belt accompanied by much lower temperatures, caused longs to begin liquidating their holdings of corn futures on the Board of Trade today. All deliveries closed sellers with a decline of 8 cents a bushel, the limit permitted for one day's trading.
