SOFIA, Bulgaria, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Bulgaria's peace treaty with the Allies, although termed "hard and unjust" by Government supporters and Opposition speakers, was approved unanimously by Parliament today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (U.P.) -- The Republican Open Forums announced tonight that it will begin nationwide discussions Sept. 1 on the subject of Communism and its threat to American democracy.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 25 -- It wasn't the race in the feature spot -- that one was nothing to write home about -- but the $4,000 Adirondack Purse, a sprint for 2-year-old fillies, that was the occasion of the best performance at sun-baked Saratoga today as the last week of the meeting began.
Most New York hotels housing Legionnaires started clearing their decks for action yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- Robert N. Denham, general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board, appealed to unions today not to by-pass the board by refusing to sign anti-Communist affidavits, declaring that the unions had much to gain by such filings.
The index is based on spot market prices. Most of the twenty-eight commodities are basic raw materials.

The possibility of a showdown between City Construction Coordinator Robert Moses and proponents of "monumental approach" plans for the United Nations site in eastern midtown Manhattan developed yesterday. Clarification of the issue was expected Thursday at a public hearing before the Board of Estimate.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- Walter S. Franklin, vice president in charge of traffic of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, will tell the Interstate Commerce Commission in hearings on the latest request of the railroads for freight rate increases averaging 17 per cent for the country as a whole, that Eastern railroads ought to have even greater increases than those asked for.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25 -- William T. Faricy, president of the Association of American Railroads, told a wage arbitration board today that railroad treasuries were in no shape to withstand the impact of another retroactive pay increase. He was the carriers' last witness at hearings on the demands of seventeen non-operating railroad unions for a 20-cent-an-hour wage rise.
SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 25 (U.P.) -- Three youthful American soldiers today blamed a $30 PX camera for their thirteen-day imprisonment by the Russians in the Soviet zone of North Korea.

The Veterans Administration has tightened its rules so that private hospital facilities for veterans will be authorized only in emergencies or when Government hospitals are filled, David P. Page, Deputy Veterans Administrator for New York State announced yesterday.

COLUMBIA, Mo., Aug. 25 -- F. V. Heinkel, president of the Missouri Farmers Association, tonight assailed the investigation of cooperatives by the House Small Business Committee as a "smear campaign against farmer cooperatives" and demanded to know if the "inquisition" had the blessing of national Republican leadership.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25 (AP) --Today's report of the livestock market here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 6,000 head, total 9,000; slow and very uneven but generally steady to 25 cents lower than Friday's average on all weights including sows: top $28.50 sparingly; bulk of

CHICAGO, Aug. 25 -- Supplies of cotton, woolen and rayon materials for sports apparel and work clothes, sold out for the remainder of the year, were exhibited here for spring lines by textile merchants and associated industries in cooperation with the Associated Garment Manufacturers.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Aug. 25 -- The Wisconsin Public Service Company asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today for permission to borrow $2,600,000 from several banks on Sept. 15, to be due on Dec. 1, 1947, pending completion of a permanent financing program.
LONDON, Aug. 25 -- The grimmest austerity measures yet evolved to combat Britain's economic crisis were decided upon by the Cabinet at a long meeting today.

PETROPOLIS, Brazil, Aug. 25 -- The Argentine proposal, under which a single nation could veto collective hemispheric action against an aggressor, was killed today by a 16-to-1 vote of the Inter-American Defense Conference's commission No. 3.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Aug. 25 (U.P.) -- Deszo Sulyok, leader of the dissolved Liberty party, has left the country, it was announced officially today. Reports indicated that he had been warned by the Communist party to get out before next Sunday's election if he valued his freedom.

DETROIT, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Collecting five runs for their first five hits and aided by two Tiger errors and seven passes by Freddie Hutchinson, the Philadelphia Athletics defeated the Detroit Tigers, 7 to 5, today in their final appearance of the season here.

PARIS, Aug. 25 -- Leaders of the European Economic Conference on the Marshall plan, whose calculations put the Western European economic deficit for the next four years at $29,200,000,000, will seek to reduce that sum to $15,000,000,000 or $20,000,000,000, it was understood today.

THE luncheon invitation was sent by the Man from County Mayo and he didn't shillyshally one bit in stating the purpose of it. He's much too direct and forthright a person for that. He frankly expressed his "extreme interest" in the All-Ireland football final to be held at the Polo Grounds on Sept. 14. Oh, yes. He was giving the luncheon at his house.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 25 -- Following is the text of a resolution on the Indonesian question adopted today by the United Nations Security Council: Whereas the Security Council on Aug. 1, 1947, called upon the Netherlands and the Republic of Indonesia to cease hostilities forthwith,

FORT COLLINS, Col., Aug. 25 -- The time has come for agriculture to put its house in order and remedy short-sighted courses in an effort to contribute to a stabilized economy for the future, Dr. E.G. Nourse, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, declared today.

Moving toward industrialization of Egypt, agreements have already been completed whereby five American companies will set up plants in that country and supply capital and technical "know-now' and control, it was reported yesterday by Mustafa Maher Bey, Director General of Industry in the Ministry of Commerce and Industry, of Egypt, at a press conference in the regional offices here of the Department of Commerce.

ALBANY, Aug. 25 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey today recommended to Federal Housing Expediter Frank R. Creedon the appointment of former New York City Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick as chairman of the Metropolitan New York Rent Control Advisory Board.

Despite difficulties encountered in Greece by the Cooperative for American Remittances to Europe, the Labor League for Human Rights will go ahead with its plans for shipment of 2,500 food packages to Greece for distribution on Labor Day, the league's New York offices said yesterday. The league is sponsored by the American Federation of Labor.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (UP) -- The NLRB decision in the case of eight employes of the Geraldine Novelty Company is enforceable in Federal Court. However, the NLRB has announced that it will review all existing orders in the light of the new law before seeking enforcement.
LONDON, Aug. 25 -- British Government stocks and Argentine rails provided the features in an otherwise neglected stock market here today.

PARIS, Aug. 25 -- There are two "Marshall conferences" going on in the world. One is being held here among the sixteen European nations. The other is going on under United States Secretary of Commerce W. Averell Harriman in Washington and New York.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Officials of the Public Housing Administration said today that negotiations were under way looking toward conveyance of Fort Niagara, N.Y., to the State of New York.
The National Football League last night declined a formal challenge by the All-America Conference to meet in a championship game with all the proceeds going either to the winner or to charity.
The six-day strike that held a dozen ships including the big liner America idle at their piers was declared ended last night after a secret vote was taken by insurgent longshoremen.

PETROPOLIS, Brazil, Aug. 25 -- After making a commission proposal this morning that was interpreted by many as a step toward compromising the United States position with that of Argentina on handling interior versus exterior aggression, Warren R. Austin, United States delegate, admitted tonight that he had spoken mistakenly and "off the subject."
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The discussion regarding our delegation's report on religious liberty in Yugoslavia is in danger of going far beyond the bounds of the subject studied.

LONDON, Aug. 25 -- "Tobacco Road," which since last Tuesday has been showing to members of a private theatre club here, was banned today from public showing by the Lord Chamberlain, the Earl of Clarendon.

ROCHESTER, Aug. 25 -- Nearly 400 police delegates from all parts of the state, representing more than 40,000 patrolmen, assembled here tonight for the annual conference of the New York State Police Benevolent Association.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 25 -- The prospect that Louis Calhern will play W.O. Gant, the father, in the screen version of "Look Homeward Angel," appeared today with the disclosure by Seymour Nebenzal, who will produce the film, that the actor has agreed to take the assignment when the picture is made next year.
CHICAGO, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Three small boys were found last night sitting in a pew in Holy Name Cathedral, with a suitcase and a plea for help beside them.
ALBANY, Aug. 25 -- Supreme Court Justice Isadore Bookstein today upheld the State Civil Service preference rights of disabled veterans with, "zero per cent" disability ratings.

SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 25 -- Maj. Gen. Albert E. Brown, chief of the American delegation to the Joint United States-Soviet Commission, today issued a blistering denunciation of the activties of the Soviet delegation and charged it with "attempting to usurp the functions of the joint commission."

Women's prisons throughout the world, child care programs in Sweden and health promotion work in South Africa were discussed in rapid order yesterday with three delegates to the coming triennial conference of the International Council of Women in an interview at 342 Madison Avenue. The conference will be held in Philadelphia, Sept. 5 to 12.

Two subsidiary airports became available for airline operation in the New York area yesterday when the Civil Aeronautics Administration took over operation of the tower at the Teterboro, N.J., air terminal and approved the instrument landing installation at Westchester County Airport, near Purchase, N.Y.

Cardinal Spellman announced yesterday that, in accordance with his recent promise to spend $25,000,000 on building in the New York Archdiocese, work would begin immediately on the Alfred E. Smith Memorial at St. Vincent's Hospital in West Eleventh Street.
MANILA, Aug. 25 -- A five-man military commission from the Philippine Army's legal department today began the trial of the Philippine Government's first war crimes case.

A 38-year-old woman was ordered evicted from her own house as a squatter yesterday in Queens Municipal Court. She was told to move from the cellar of her rented one-family house, where she has been living since Aug. 8 with her two small children.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- A group of top United States coal mine operators has been invited to sit down here with the British and American conferees on increasing the level of coal production in the Ruhr, it was disclosed today.

TOKYO, Aug. 25 -- Although the operation still depends upon availability of raw materials, occupation officials have authorized the Japanese to rebuild their wool industry to a point where it is capable of handling 665,000 bales annually. Orders issued last week permit 733,000 worsted spindles and 815 woolen cards.
A court contest for $5,000 found hidden in the lining of a fur coat in summer storage was disclosed yesterday with the filing of papers in Supreme Court.

General de Gaulle and His followers have finally taken the full plunge into French politics. The Rally of the French People, as their leader calls his organization, is offering a nation-wide list of candidates for the October municipal elections. The ballot box will determine whether or not the new movement is a force to be reckoned with.

HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 25 -- A series of violent detonations shook the suburbs of Helsinki last night. The ground trembled over an area of several hundred square miles, and inhabitants of cottages dotting the Helsinki archipelago were awakened.

Although a temperature of 91.8 degrees was recorded yesterday at La Guardia Field there were 6,300 New Yorkers nearby who thoroughly enjoyed themselves. They were the participants in Widows and Orphans Day who flocked to Flushing Meadow Park amphitheatre, the scene of the World's Fair Acquacade, as guests of the Honor Legion of the New York Police Department.

The United Nations must undertake immediate concrete action to solve the problem of 250,000 uprooted and homeless Jews in Europe, and the United States and other countries must, open their doors to displaced persons, David Rosenstein, chairman of the American delegation to the World ORT Union Conference in Paris, declared yesterday.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 25 -- The combinations of Pete Brown, Wheatley Hills, and AI Brosch, Cherry Valley, and Dan Casey Jr. of Hempstead, and Jack Sheridan of Brentwood, shot identical rounds of 34, 32 -- 66 to deadlock for top honors in the Metropolitan one-day amateur-pro tournament at the Hempstead Golf Club today.

Developments yesterday made it virtually certain that the American Legion would go on record officially at its convention starting here Thursday in support of the demand by its national commander, Paul H. Griffith, for a special session of Congress to enact universal military training and other national defense measures.

The stock market experienced yesterday another of its uneasy Monday sessions characteristic of recent weeks and, under pressure which reached its peak in the final hour, retreated from 1 to 2 points. Offerings were relatively light during the first four hours of business, but the expanded selling in the last period produced a decline of 1.16 points in the composite rate.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 25 -- Attempts to define what information individual countries should furnish to the United Nations on their non-atomic weapons remained sidetracked today, possibly for some time to come.

SALEM, N.H., Aug. 25 (AP) -- Sweeping over the six furlongs distance in a blistering 1:11, J.N. Thomas' One Up, heretofore regarded as a router, won going away from W.S. Jacobs' Ima Fastone in the London allowance purse before 9,633 today at Rockingham Park.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians battled from behind three times today and finally edged out the Boston Red Sox, 10 to 8, when two Sox hurlers lost control with the bases loaded in the eighth inning and walked three runners across the plate.

Among the many vegetables having their day now are snap beans and their more luxuriously priced cousin, limas. The snap variety particularly commends itself to consumers with budgetary burdens (and who hasn't them these days ?).

GENEVA, Aug. 25 -- Four of the major trading countries and a three-nation customs union now are prepared to sign a general agreement on tariffs making the substance of the International Trade Organization charter rules on commercial policy effective Jan. 1, 1948, it was learned today.

BOSTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Curveballing George (Red) Munger limited the Boston Braves to five hits while pitching the St. Louis Cardinals to a 5-2 victory tonight before 33,129 fans. Stan Musical's seventeenth homer with Erv Dusak aboard gave the Redbirds their first two tallies against Lefty Warren Spahn in the initial frame.

An amendment designed to aid veterans in the purchase of homes and another to permit landlords to remodel large apartments into smaller ones under certain conditions were added yesterday to the municipal rent control bills on which the City Council will vote today.
CHICAGO, Aug. 25 -- Trying to overcome the elements and the White Sox in one motion proved too much for the Yanks tonight in their farewell of the 1947 campaign to Chicago.
Hubert Glendon, head coach of Columbia's crews for fourteen years, has resigned his post, Ralph Furey, director of athletics, announced yesterday. No mention of a possible successor was made.

The women of the United States were called on yesterday to "henpeck" Congress into convening in special session immediately to enact universal, military training. The plea was made by Mrs. Norton H. Pearl, national president of the American Legion Auxiliary.

Dan Bankhead, 26-year-old Negro righthanded pitcher, officially became a Dodger yesterday when President Branch Rickey confirmed news of his purchase from the Memphis Red Sox signed him to a contract and announced that he would be in uniform at Ebbets Field today.

The immediate European political and economic outlook continues beclouded and unencouraging. When it became necessary for the United States last week to waive the convertibility provision of the British loan, that action represented a backward step in the contemplated post-war march toward a world system of maximized freedom of trade and exchange.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: One reader heartily thanks you for your piece in Topics of The Times, Aug. 9, under the heading "The Boy's First Bicycle," but I can see that you know only half the story.

Negotiations have been going on for a year and a half to settle out of court the State's and Federal Government's conflicting claims to eighty acres of land valued at $2,000,000 at Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn, State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein made known yesterday.

Random notes. The New Jersey Fish and Game Division will set a new record this year on pheasant liberation. A total of 58,000 pheasants will be released on open shooting lands throughout the various counties. Of the total, 8,000 birds were reared on State game farms, and 40,000 purchased from private commercial breeders.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Sam Zoldak shaded Rae Scarborough in a tight pitching duel tonight, 1 to 0, as the St. Louis Browns made it two out of three from the Washington Senators in the latter's final appearance of the season here.

SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain, Aug. 25 -- The Spanish press today published the full text of a bitter attack on the British Broadcasting Corporation, which was broadcast to the nation last night by the Spanish National Radio.

A record volume of foreign mail, both outgoing and incoming, swollen to a great extent by relief parcels, is flowing through the New York Post Office, the office of Postmaster Albert Goldman reported yesterday.

LONDON, Aug. 25 (Reuters) -- Middlesex, county cricket leader, was well on the road to victory against Surrey today while Gloucestershire, itts rival for the title, had the worst of the argument against Hampshire.

BERLIN, Aug. 25 -- Coal production in the Ruhr, at present of vital concern to conferences in Washington, London and Paris, has reached a new post-war, record, British authorities disclosed today. The British attributed the gains to the incentive program for the miners and the general improvement in the food situation.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 25 -- Communal disturbances broke out today in the old city of Delhi for the first time since late spring. An altercation outside a textile mill involving Hindus and Moslems resulted in the death of four persons and the wounding of seven, according to police reports.

A request by the Republican National Committee for equal time to counterbalance the forthcoming special program of the Democratic National Committee has been granted by the American Broadcasting Company, it was learned yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 25 -- Subjects of pre-war political-and religious persecution in Central and Eastern Europe, 257 refugees who spent the war years in Shanghai, arrived here today aboard the American transport General Meigs to seek a fresh start in the New World.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Aug. 25 -- Britain will unreservedly support Australia's insistence that no veto power shall operate in the Japanese peace conference expected to be held in Washington this year.

In a free slugging battle at Ebbets Field yesterday, the Dodgers had eleven runs as early as the sixth inning, but they were barely able to nose out the Pirates, 11 -- 10, and thus extend their winning streak to five games. A crowd of 20,166 enjoyed it all.

The countryman readily admits the intelligence quotient of the average hen tends toward the low side. Anyone who has tried to drive a hen in a straight line will corroborate that point of view. But there's something about a hen that gives her an affectionate place in a man's regard.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Norman W. Church's juvenile filly, Boswell Lady, defeated Calumet Farm's Free America, the 1-to-4 favorite, by two and a half lengths in the $28,150 Prairie State Stakes at Washington Park today.

Two women were killed and another woman and a man were injured yesterday in three accidents in the Bronx. Mrs. Edward McLaughlin, 32 years old, of 587 East 140th Street, the Bronx, was fatally injured when she was struck by a bus at 11:30 A.M.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Frank Heintzelman, chief of the Alaska Forest Service, said today the Federal Government will call for bids Oct. 1 on 8,000,000,000 board feet of pulp timber near Thomas Bay, Alaska.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- The War Assets Administration postponed today the deadline for bids on "Quoddy" Village, in Maine. The agency stated that it wanted further to consider the proposal that the village be taken over by the city of Eastport for a displaced persons training project.
ROME, Aug. 25 -- A parish priest in Yugoslav-occupied Istria was beheaded yesterday by a mob of Slovene Communists, the Vatican reported today. Another priest was severely beaten.
ATHENS, Aug. 25 -- Since there is no Greek Government to deal with, the work of the United States mission of aid to Greece lagged today while Greek party leaders jockeyed for office.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The recent Senatorial investigation of the Howard Hughes war contracts clearly demonstrates the dangers that exist when competitive bidding for public contracts is eliminated.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Reds socked Oscar Judd for six hits and five runs in the first two innings and went on to defeat the Philadelhpia Phillies, 5 to 3, in the final game of a series here tonight.
The index is based on spot market prices. Most of the twenty-eight commodities are basic raw materials.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (U.P.) -- The Commerce Department's lumber survey committee reported tonight that lumber production has increased, but it held out little hope for a substantial cut in prices.
LONDON, Aug. 26 -- Further sharp gains by British Government stocks and a brisk rally in South African gold mines shares put a brighter complexion on the stock markets here today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 26 -- Mrs. Reinert M. Torgerson, New York State women's champion from Cherry Valley, and Mrs. Sophie Untermeyer of Hollywood, deadlocked for top honors in the one-day tournament for Class A members of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association staged at Metropolis Country Club today.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Phil Marchildon, after pitching a perfect game for seven innings, doubled to score the winning run in the twelfth frame tonight as the Athletics defeated the Indians, 2 to 1.

While a substantial edge in the fight for the post of national commander of the American Legion was generally conceded to one candidate yesterday, the possibility of at least a three-way battle on the convention floor was seen.
According to eight women among those on strike yesterday against Hecht's Department Store, 53 West Fourteenth Street, it was too hot "even for picketing."

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 26 -- Strong bi-partisan support for New Jersey's proposed new charter was assured today when the constitutional convention adopted by a vote of 70 to 1 a compromise tax article under which Jersey City may regain lost railroad tax revenue and the Legislature retains its taxing powers.

The first contingent of 400 Legionnaires who will be housed at City College during the American Legion convention has arrived at the college's Army Hall, 138th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, bringing with them coconuts, live baby alligators and colorful Seminole Indian costumes.

FORT COLLINS, Col., Aug. 26 -- It is apparent that a long-range program for American agriculture to stabilize farm economy will include some price-support measure, Representative Clifford R. Hope, Republican, of Kansas, chairman of the House Agriculture Committee, said today.

GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, Aug. 26 -- Col. Carlos Mancheno, Minister of Defense and at present in charge of the Government after the coup d'etat that sent into exile President Jose Maria Velasco Ibarra, will not move into the Presidential Palace in Quito, he said today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Following are the texts of notes exchanged by the United States and Russia on the case of Nikola Petkov, Bulgarian Opposition leader, who has been sentenced to death. The United States note was delivered in Moscow by Ambassador W. Bedell Smith on Aug. 23.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 26 -- The United Nations Security Council -- which has been laboring under a heavy two-meeting-a-day schedule -- will wind up its work here on Thursday and take a tenday holiday before the General Assembly convenes at Flushing Meadow on Sept. 16.

ON BOARD THE RUNNYMEDE PARK, Gibraltar, Aug. 26 (Reuters) -- A double cordon of soldiers and police, machine gun posts and barbed wire entanglements sealed off the docks when the Exodus 1947 Refugee fleet tied up here today and immediately began coaling for the journey to Hamburg, Germany.

Parsnips Are Moot There are a considerable number of major matters about which people do not agree. Sometimes the divergences are comparatively mild and innocuous; in other instances the schisms are deep and fundamental.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Daily we read of millions, yes, billions, of American dollars being provided for reconstruction of war devastated areas abroad. With this worthy project, ever-generous Americans do not complain. Yet here at home so little progress has been made to relieve the distress that exists among our own people because of the lack of decent housing accommodations.

The American Legion will not hold the first session of its convention until tomorrow, but perhaps there are already enough Legionnaires in town to justify a welcoming word. When the Legion was here ten years ago it represented veterans of one world war. Now, in far larger numbers, it represents men who have experienced a second more dreadful and more ominous world war.

ROME, Aug. 26 -- Pope Pius XII this morning granted a private audience to Myron C. Taylor, President Truman's special envoy, with whom the Pontiff discussed what Vatican circles said were many problems affecting world peace. It was the longest audience in recent years granted by Pope Pius to a diplomatic representative.

CHICAGO, Aug. 26 -- Announcement of a new color film, which will be put on the market early next year, was one of the high lights yesterday of the opening of the annual convention of the Photographers' Association of America.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The Georgia, Florida Alabama Railroad Company filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission an amended plan of reorganization under which it would operate as an independent short-line railroad, apart from the Seaboard Air Line System.

The current drop in lightweight hide prices is being watched by the shoe and leather trades, but so far indications are that the decline merely discounts the increased slaughter and marketing of lighter-weight cattle at this time, according to authoritative quarters here.

James G. Petrillo, president of the American federation of Musicians, has accepted the proposal of the heads of the four networks for a further meeting on the problem of simultaneous duplication of network musical programs on both frequency modulation and standard stations.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 26 -- The United Nations Security Council made one more attempt today to stop the sporadic military clashes in Java by appealing to the Netherlands and the Republic of Indonesia to obey the cease-fire order issued almost four weeks ago.
More than 1,000 Americans, most of them former GI's married to Australian girls, have arranged for emigration to Australia, it was reported here yesterday.

Old-Fashioned Selling Job The effort of leading Chicago and New York investment houses to establish advance proof of a market for $105,000,000 of revenue-backed bonds of the new Chicago Transit Authority is taking on the aspects of melodrama, with novelty-proof bankers pinching them-selves to see if they are in the office or the movies.

An early decline of 9 to 15 points in the cotton futures market yesterday appeared to have reached a point where buyers were more inclined to replenish their lines and producers were less disposed to sell. The market then rallied sharply and closing quotations on the New York Cotton Exchange were 6 to 25 points net higher than on Monday.

Two suits listing 3,000 stevedores as plaintiffs were filed yesterday in Federal Court against sixty stevedoring companies, which under a ruling last June by the United States Circuit Court of Appeals are liable for millions of dollars in overtime compensation.

NANKING, Aug. 26 -- Foreign Minister Wang Shih-chieh, it is reported, told a closed session of the Executive Yuan today that the Government had sent a reply to the United States Embassy, taking exception to alleged "errors" in the farewell statement issued by Lieut. Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer on the completion of his fact-finding mission here.

The 950,000 members of the American Legion Auxiliary were called upon yesterday by Mrs. Lee Hutton, unopposed candidate for the presidency, to work to awaken all the women in the nation to the need for universal military training.

PEEPING, China, Wednesday, Aug. 27 (AP) -- The United States made strong representations in Nanking today after the former Nazi Gestapo chief in North China vanished and twelve other Germans were removed from repatriation lists.

CHICAGO, Aug. 26 -- The country's railroads are financially able to meet the pay increase of 20 cents an hour demanded by seventeen non-operating unions, according to labor economists. They made this assertion, today before the arbitration board that is hearing the case.
Princess Achraf Pahlevi, twin sister of Shah Mohamed Reza Pahlevi of Iran, arrived at La Guardia Field at 8:50 A.M. yesterday on an American Overseas Airlines plane from London.

Negotiations for a major installation of a National Guard air unit at Westchester County Airport will start today at Camp Smith, Peekskill, N.Y., it was learned last night. It also was learned that KLM, the Royal Dutch Airline now flying daily schedules between La Guardia Field and Amsterdam, is seeking a permanent terminal at Purchase to avoid the congestion at La Guardia Field.
Dr. W.L. Barrow has been appointed chief engineer of the Sperry Gyroscope Company. Inc., Great Neck, L.I. He joined the company in 1943 as director of armament engineering.

Mayor O'Dwyer was inducted yesterday as a member of the Forty and Eight, the American Legion's fun-making organization, but the veterans postponed his "wreck" -- the initiation ceremony through which every new member must go.

DETROIT, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Tex Hughson's strong right arm and the big bats of Ted Williams and Wally Moses kept the Red Sox hanging narrowly onto second place in the American League today after dividing a double bill with third-place Detroit.

THE title of James P. Warburg's book on the Germans and what has, what has not and what ought to be done about them, "Germany -- Bridge or Battleground,"* suggests a more realistic and hard-headed approach to the problem than most of his book turns out to be. A bridge between Eastern and Western civilizations, or a battleground between them, that is certainly the most important question about Germany.

The Ford Motor Company has announced over the past three days a series of price rises in all lines of its passenger cars and trucks -- Ford, Mercury, Lincoln and Ford "Luxury." The advances range from $20 to $229, depending upon the model and general price class.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., Aug. 26 -- Urging a "spokesman" for young children and parents in every state, Dr. James L. Hymes Jr., president of the National Association for Nursery Education, declared here today that many American children are being "cheated" in their early years.
CHESHIRE, Conn., Aug. 26 -- Despite the record heat which continued in New England, Coach Ray Flaherty sent his New York football Yankees through another scrimmage this morning.

ALBION, Mich., Aug. 26 -- The secretaries of evangelism of the Methodist Church opened their national annual conference today at Albion College, intent upon developing a program for recruiting hundreds of thousands of new members through both personal and public evangelism.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Saying that his staff of 600 employes had been "geared to a speedy and efficient administration of the Labor Management Relations Act," Robert N. Denham, general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board, made public today his organizational plan and announced new appointments.

CHICAGO, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: hogs Salable hoss. 8.500 head: total. 11.000: market slow; 50 to 75 cents lower on all weights and sows: bulk of good and choice 190 to 260 pounds. $26.75 to $27.50: top.

TORONTO, Aug. 26 (Canadian Press) -- Toronto Argonauts, who won their second straight dominion football championship last season with an all-Canadian lineup, tonight signed their first United States player "sight unseen" in Bates Ford, 185-pound Negro lineman from Alabama State University.
BOSTON, Aug. 26 -- Trawlers to the number of about 300 are being sought in the United States to be used in helping Germany to feed herself, it was reported in usually reliable circles today.

Mayor O'Dwyer promoted Theodore W. Kheel yesterday to succeed Edward C. Maguire as director of the city's Labor Relations Division, and swore in Joseph O'Grady, Brooklyn lawyer, as deputy director in Mr. Kheel's place.

A Brooklyn man, who had served as trustee in numerous bankruptcy proceedings while masquerading under his brother's name, was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury for gambling away the assets of a wine company.

Opening an appeal for greater Federal and public support for the country's merchant fleet, leaders of the maritime industry cautioned yesterday before the American Legion's Subcommittee on the Merchant Marine against repetition of post-World War I mistakes.

LONDON, Aug. 26 -- Britain stands ready to spend huge sums in modernization programs to increase the efficiency of the nationalized coal industry. Lord Hyndley, chairman of the National Coal Board, said today.

The Greek governmental crisis has now become threatening, both for us and Greece. For four days since the collapse of the Maximos Cabinet Constantin Tsaldaris, Royalist leader designated by King Paul, has been trying to form a new government. Now he has announced that he will form the government today of the Populist party on the ground that "the country can no longer remain without a responsible government."

ALBANY, Aug. 26 -- Governor Dewey in an obvious reference to the Russian regime in Poland, declared today the Polish homeland "is once again subjected to enslavement by a ruthless and a dictatorial power."

Dan Bankhead made his debut with the Dodgers yesterday. In his one time at bat, he hit a horn run with a man on base. His talents as a pitcher, and it was to bolster the shaky Brooklyn staff that Branch Rickey plucked him from the Negro American League, were not as evident.

GUATEMALA, Aug. 26 -- An article published in last night's local newspaper Nuestro Diario called the present Women's Congress, meeting here, Communist, hinting that delegates opposing universal disarmament in Saturday's assembly were not allowed freely to express their opinions and stating that the resolutions were approved without holding a debate.

The danger of a Transport Workers Union strike on the lines of the New York Omnibus Corporation appeared more likely yeserday after negotiations failed to produce a peaceful settlement during the day. The union has set Sept. 8 as the deadline for a strike vote.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 26 -- Foreign-inspired criticism of the United States in India was attacked by Dr. Henry F. Grady, American Ambassador to India, in his first major speech since taking the Ambassadorial post.

JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 26 (AP) -- Sam E. Lumpkin, top man in the first primary for the Democratic nomination for Lieutenant Governor, piled up a commanding lead today in a run-off against the Rev. Charles G. Hamilton, Episcopal minister, who ran fifth and last in the previous voting.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 26 -- Egypt remained relatively quiet today awaiting the United Nations decision but a strange, uncomfortable feeling permeated the country. Pressure from above in the form of appeals for peace and quiet until the decision is known appeared to be the only thing that kept the pressure from below from blowing the lid off the simmering kettle.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Aug. 26 (U.P.) -- Discovery of a new oil field near Oklahoma City which taps the fabulous Wilcox sand brought excited bidding for leases today.

SALEM, N.H., Aug. 26 (AP) -- With many of them facing bankruptcy, more than 300 owners of 930 thoroughbreds quarantined at Rockingham Park because of "swamp fever" tonight prepared to mark time for at least 30 days and probably until the first frost.

Big Jawn Mize put on a gorgeous one-man performance at the Polo Grounds yesterday as he virtually carried the Giants on his broad back to win the opener of what promised to be a very entertaining twin bill for a gathering of 14,187 onlookers.

COLUMBIA, Mo., Aug. 26 -- The 117,000-member Missouri Farmers Association, aroused by the House Small Business Committee investigation of cooperatives and Congressional curtailment of funds for the Farm Credit Administration and other farm agencies, declared open war today upon Congressional "enemies of the farmers."

The Greek Government has released 6,802 food packages consigned to the Cooperative for American Remittances to Europe that it had impounded, Paul Comly French, CARE executive director at New York announced yesterday. The release followed a CARE threat to discontinue further operations in Greece as of tomorrow.
PETROFOLIS, Brazil, Aug. 26 -- A burst of speed in the Inter-American Peace Conference has created a situation in which Brazil has one eye on hemispheric security and the other on Washington.

SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain, Aug. 26 -- The social insurance programs that are vaunted as one of the Franco regime's chief achievements are costing Spanish workers up to 25 per cent of their pay and as yet are returning little in Benefits, an Opposition worker's representative contended today.
The landlord of the thirty-six-story office building at 16 Court Street in downtown Brooklyn was reminded yesterday that many of his tenants are specialists in real estate law.
Before you finish reading this short paragraph two persons will have been injured accidentally somewhere in the United States. That is a condition that should startle all of us.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 26 -- E.P. Taylor's Sweet Pegotty, who was claimed for $12,000 in June from the champion claiming man, Hirsch Jacobs, and hasn't been out of the money in eight starts since that time, won the top event at cool and comfortable Saratoga today.

Sophisticated clothes for the college or career girl were offered in a young New Yorker fashion showing yesterday at Lord Taylor. For casual wear, corduroys in bright fall colors looked inviting in such combinations as a brandy tone jacket with gray pedal pushers or a brilliant yellow shirt worn out over trim gray slacks.

BALTIMORE, Aug 26 -- Automobile and other installment purchases could not possibly play any large part in producing inflation which might bring on a depression, according to A.E. Duncan, chairman of the board of the Commercial Credit Corporation.

The honeymoon appeared over yesterday as a bride and bridegroom of scarcely a month appeared in Felony Court and were held in $5,000 bail each by Magistrate Frederick L. Strong, charged with robbing several New York homes.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 26 -- Beset by a strike of walking bosses which began six and one-half weeks ago, the Luckenbach Steamship Company today made known it was "abandoning immediately and permanently" the stevedoring business it had conducted here for twenty-three years.
Mayor O'Dwyer demanded last night that the disputed telephone work at Idlewild Airport go forward even if it meant strikes by both of the unions involved.

Swift Co. introduced its strained meats for babies about a year ago, the first products of their kind to reach the market. Now, from the Department of Agriculture, comes a report of a study on the effect of such foods on infant health.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The Soviet Union has rejected as "interference" a proposal by the United States for Allied review of the death sentence imposed by a Bulgarian court on Nikola Petkov, anti-Communist Opposition leader, it was announced today.
His music teacher called him "Chopin" Blutman, but his neighbors thought his piano playing was just a public nuisance.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 26 -- "The Sainted Sisters," a property which has been inactive at Paramount since early this year, has been revived for production by Richard Maibaum in October with Betty Hutton playing the leading role, it was learned today.

CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 26 (AP) -- The Woodland Stable's Lighthouse, 3-year-old son of Knave High and Lady Bart, won the featured Tavistock Purse at Garden State Park today by two lengths over Cain Hoy Stable's Noble Creek.

Robert W. Brownell of the Manor Country Club at Norbeck, Md., was the early pace-setter last night as scores trickled in from thirty-two courses where more than 1,000 golfers fired their qualifying tests yesterday for the 1947 National Amateur championship.

PARIS, Aug. 26 -- In seeking to reduce the tentative figure for Western Europe's needs from abroad in the next four years, the Economic Conference meeting under the Marshall plan must ask the sixteen attending nations to scale down the standards of living they had set for themselves in those years, it was pointed out today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Armchair scrutiny of long-hidden mysteries of the ocean depths became a possibility today as the Navy announced that underwater television experiments had been successfully carried out.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The use by Federal and state governments of military-type trucks and other vehicles to provide this country with an up-to-date motor fleet ready for instant service in case of emergency was suggested today by a War Department official.

An early winter production of a new operetta dealing with Napoleon and his famous consort, Josephine, was announced yesterday by Seymour Zweibel, who will be making his managerial debut with the show. Heretofore, Mr. Zweibel's activities have been confined to the picture field.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., Aug. 26 -- The Niantic Bay Yacht Club crew won the second in an eight-race series for the national junior sailing championship in the annual cup series off the Cold Spring Harbor Beach Club today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Former high officials of the State Department have been summoned to explain how Hollywood musician Hans Eisler got papers to reside permanently in the United States, Representative J. Parnell Thomas, Republican, of New Jersey, chairman of the House Committee on Un-American Activities, announced today.

The stock market broke yesterday through the previous resistance line and sagged into the lowest area since June, but a later recovery reduced most of the losses. Tendencies were mixed at the finish in the major groups, and the number of issues to show declines only slightly exceeded those to record increases.

In addition to being flagrantly unfair, the latest proposal on firearms regulation now under consideration by the Committee on General Welfare of New York City will place a heavy financial burden and a maximum of red tape on every holder of a pistol or revolver license in the city.
GENEVA, Switzerland, Aug. 26 -- The United Nations Special Committee of Inquiry on Palestine has arrived at what looks like hopeless disagreement on a Holy Land solution, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Confidence in Britain's ability to pull out of her current economic troubles was expressed today by John J. McCloy. president of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development. At the same time fiscal experts let it be known that this Government had demanded more information before approving further relaxation of the conditions of the United States loan to Britain.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Aug. 26 -- Cincinnati city officials, judges and business men joined staff members of Xavier University's Institute on Family Life tonight in a radio discussion of practical methods to enable both urban and rural families in the Cincinnati area to strengthen family ties.

The other evening a group of people, mostly experts in foreign affairs, were discussing the darkening clouds on the world horizon and asking one another which was the most alarming. They mentioned Greece, China, Palestine, the renewed pressure on Iran, the British economic crisis, misgivings on the Marshall plan.

Many producers of appliances shortly will follow the lead of several leaders in the field who recently increased prices of such items as automatic toasters, waffle irons, electric mixers and roasters and mixers from 6 to 10 per cent, an executive of a large national appliance distributing organization stated yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 26 -- The Yankees marshaled enough strength against the last-place Browns tonight to demonstrate to 6,535 fans how they can come from behind in the ninth and tie the score. But, for a variety of reasons, their offensive bogged down then and the Browns lifted a page from the Yankee script and won the ball game, 4 to 3.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Aug. 26 -- An invitation to the United States to assume the initiative in the eventual negotiations on a Japanese peace settlement was extended today in the inaugural address of the British Commonwealth Conference on Japan, which got under way in Canberra.

ATHENS, Wednesday, Aug. 27 -- Premier - designate Constantin Tsaldar announced early this morning that he would form a Government today of the "Parliamentary majority," meaning his own Populist party, to end the Greek Cabinet crisis.

CHICAGO, Aug. 26 -- The cotton textile industry, now about to enter an era of more adequate supplies and of improved balance between buyer and seller, can look forward to several years of good business, Saul F. Dribben, president of the Cone Export and Commission Company, Inc., declared this evening in an address at a meeting of textile merchants and associated industries and the associated garment manufacturers.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 26 (AP) -- So many American veterans have applied for permission to settle in Australia that the Australian Consulate here is having trouble finding shipping space for them all.

The decennial silly season started here yesterday. Electric jump boxes, water pistols, ticklers and all the equipment used here by the Legionnaires in 1937 to work a fine raw edge on pedestrians' nerves were back in play, and pretty much in the same hands, now ten years older.
Gen. George C. Kenney, chief of the Strategic Air Command, advocated yesterday a constant long range air patrol to prevent a sneak attack upon the borders of the United States.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 26 -- A near side shot from 15 yards out less than two minutes before the finish by Johnny Clements enabled Westbury to tie Great Neck, 6 -- 6, on Whitney Field at the Meadow Brook Club today.

Emetia Polizio, the bookmaker whose charges of police protection inspired recent grand jury investigations and a Police Department shake-up, asked the Supreme Court yesterday to make Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander call off a constant guard over him.

East Baton Rouge Parish, La., announced yesterday that it would receive bids on Sept. 18 on $3,925,000 of sewerage district bonds dated Oct. 1, 1947, and due Oct. 1 from 1948 to 1877. Interest must not exceed 4 per cent.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 26 -- Dr. Albert W. Moore, chief pharmacist of the Englewood (N.J.) Hospital Association, today warned members of the American Society of Hospital Pharmacists, in convention here, not to handle any radio-active materials as a part of their work without first consulting a physicist who has had experience in that field.

BERLIN, Aug. 26 -- Gen. Omar N. Bradley, director of the Veterans Administration, arrived in Berlin today to start a six-week inspection tour of Army installations in Germany, Austria and Italy to "reorient" himself for a "new assignment."

TOKYO, Aug. 26 -- Evidence is beginning to appear that the authorities -- both Japanese and American -- are working toward price levels that will indicate a yen-dollar exchange rate between 200 and 250 yen to the dollar.

Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday that the Board of Estimate had set the stage for approval tomorrow of five sites to provide 4,600 units of unsubsidized housing within eighteen months at an estimated cost of $56,630,000.

CHICAGO, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Washington scored three runs in the first inning and another in the third to trim the White Sox, 4 -- 3, before 2,984 today. Walter Masterson yielded nine hits to gain his tenth victory.

Defeat of the Taft-Ellender-Wagner omnibus bill to stimulate private and public housing construction was predicted yesterday by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican, of Wisconsin. He told fifty housing experts, meeting with the national housing committee of the American Legion at the Princeton Club, that Senator Robert A. Taft had demonstrated that he was "not wedded to the T-E-W bill."

SALEM, N.H., Aug. 26 (AP) -- Mort Stuart's Halbarail, showing a liking for a sloppy track, took the Holderness Purse from D.F. Harrington's Pickpocket easily at Rockingham Park today before a crowd of 8,376.

TRIESTE, Aug. 26 (U.P.) -- Thirty-three persons have been arrested in connection with the murder of a Catholic priest and the beating of another during Sunday's attack on a Lanischie vicarage in Yugoslav-controlled Istria, Yugoslav press reports said today.

Standard Oil Company of New Jersey will begin next Tuesday a campaign in New Jersey daily and weekly newspapers describing its labor relations policies and record. A series of four 1,000-line advertisements will be run, and the campaign will be extended eventually to the seventeen other states in its marketing area.

The present stagnation, in the securities business should not be laid to the restrictions of the Securities Acts, even though there is room for much constructive revision of corporation disclosure and registration requirements, Francis Adams Truslow, president of the New York Curb Exchange, said yesterday at a meeting of the Junior Investment Bankers and Brokers Association.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 26 -- Faris el-Khouri, Syrian representative, told the United Nations Security Council today that an amicable settlement of Anglo-Egyptian treaties was essential because of the Palestine question.

Recent developments seem to have strengthened the prospect that this country "must eventually face the alternative of depending on foreign sources of supply or relying on higher-cost substitutes for natural petroleum," the Guaranty Trust Company of New York says in its monthly review of business and financial conditions, published today.

A thunderstorm that cascaded more than three inches of rain on parts of New York and its environs in two hours yesterday broke the back of the heat wave, but at the cost of flooded subways and snarled traffic.
BREMEN, Germany, Aug. 26 -- The Military Government for the Land [State] of Bremen announced today the suspension for one week of the Social Democratic party's publication privileges.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Arthur M. Hill of Charleston, W. Va., bus line executive, received the offer today of the post of chairman of the National Security Resources Board under the Unified Armed Forces. This became known a few hours after Secretary of the Navy Forrestal disclosed that Mr. Hill had been asked to take an important post within the new set-up which Mr. Forrestal will head as Secretary of Defense.

Republic Pictures will release forty-seven feature films, four serials, a novelty feature and four cartoon short subjects during the 1947-48 season, it was announced yesterday by Herbert J. Yates, president, and James R. Grainger, executive vice president in charge of sales and distribution.

The test of religious liberty in Yugoslavia is not the killing of a Catholic priest by a Yugoslav mob near Trieste but the way in which the Yugoslav Government deals with the perpetrators of the tragedy, the Rev. William Howard Melish, associate rector of the Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity, Clinton and Montague Streets, Brooklyn, said yesterday in a statement.

BOSTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Bill Voiselle prevented the Cardinals from gaining any ground on the Dodgers by turning in a three-hit pitching performance that gave the Braves a 5-1 victory tonight before a crowd of 24,168.

"Name" speakers with a message are preferred to inspirational or humorous talkers, according to the results thus far of a survey of members made for its luncheon program guidance by the Sales Executives Club, it was learned here yesterday.

OTTAWA, Aug. 26 -- The number of immigrants of different categories being admitted to Canada, following the recent easing or restrictions, is beginning to mount. They are being admitted to help Canada in supplying her own needs and to assist in the solution of the European displaced persons problem.

PETROPOLIS, Brazil, Aug. 26 -- Key provisions of the new Treaty of Rio de Janeiro took final form here today. They indicated Argentina's submission to a provision that collective machinery against an aggressor within the hemisphere would be set in motion on the same basis of immediacy as applied to an aggressor from outside the American hemisphere.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Aug. 26 -- John D. Lyons of Garden City Golf Club posted 70, 73 -- 143 on the Montclair golf course today to lead the metropolitan section for places in the United States Golf Association amateur championship. A field of 69 contestants battled intense heat also thunder and lightning in the all-day ordeal.

PURCHASE, N.Y., Aug. 26 -- The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association, continuing its procedure of splitting one-day tournaments into "A" and "B" divisions, staged the Class B event at the Old Oaks country club today, while the Class A field played at Metropolis.

This country's prospective contributions to European nations within the orbit of the Marshall Plan will be based in all likelihood on the recommendations to Congress by a nineteen-member special House Committee on Foreign Aid, its acting chairman asserted here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Postmaster General Robert E. Hannegan, back from a vacation in Hawaii, visited President Truman today but declined to tell reporters whether he would step down as Democratic National Chairman.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 --The shipping industry took exception today to seven specific points in the Congress of Industrial Organisations Maritime Committee's ''program for an adequate Merchant Marine," which was submitted July 25 to the President's Advisory Committee on the Merchant Marine.

The City Council adopted yesterday, 16 votes to 3, a series of three bills to establish municipal controls over rents and evictions and provide penalties up to ninety days in jail and $500 fines for violations.

GENEVA, Aug. 26 -- Warning that there was danger of a drift to a third world war unless something effective was done to relieve world distress, Sir John Boyd Orr, director general of the Food and Agriculture Organization, said at its conference today that the establishment of a World Food Council was the greatest task before the United Nations.
Fifteen hundred longshoremen, many of them still grumbling over the settlement of their wildcat waterfront walkout, returned to the piers yesterday to handle cargo and baggage.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 26 -- Four committees were appointed today at the second plenary session of the international high frequency broadcasting conference here to carry on the preliminary work that was initiated at the first plenary session on Aug. 16.

PETROPOLIS, Brazil, Aug. 26 -- The steering committee of the Inter - American Defense Conference decided late today upon a form of limited recognition of Ecuador's participation in the conference following the overturn of the Government at Quito.

In an open letter to Mayor O'Dwyer and members of the Board of Estimate, the Real Estate Board of New York served notice yesterday that It would oppose the City Planning Commission's $15,000,000 plan for an approach to the United Nations site.
SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 26 -- Lieut. Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer arrived here by plane today from Tokyo.
WILDWOOD, N.J., Aug. 26 (AP) -- Upsets featured the initial round of match play in the annual Philadelphia Professional Golfers Association tournament today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: A letter has just appeared in your column, titled "Future of Indonesia," by H. Rosse. We are quite astonished by certain facts which Mr. Rosse failed to elaborate further.
A new kind of bathroom almost devoid of conventional white tile and free standing fixtures has been installed on the fourth floor of Altman's, where it was opened for display yesterday morning.

STORRS, Conn., Aug. 26 (AP) -- Evidence indicating that molecules interact when separated, a revolutionary scientific concept of major importance in such fields as chemistry, biology and physics, Was reported here today by Dr. Alexandre Rothen, physical chemist at the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 26 -- The right for ail policemen in the state to retire after twenty-five years' service was set today as a major goal of the New York State Policemen's Benevolent Association by Harry G. Warren of Rochester, president of the group, meeting here in its twenty-third annual conference.

CHICAGO, Aug. 26 -- Corn lost its market leadership to wheat today on the Board of Trade. The latter grain showed a firm undertone from the start, and with broader outside business prices it moved up readily and closed at the top with gains of 2 to 4 1/4 cents a bushel, December equaling the seasonal high.

All along the sandy beaches from the Carolinas to the St. Lawrence you will find them. Their gentle, sad, soft whistles remind one of the plaintive poignancy of the wood pewee's call. Charadrius melodus, the piping plover, is one of the well-loved and familiar members of the wildlife family by the ocean.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 26 -- The United Nations plans to take over one of the idle Long Island estates near here and convert it into an international school for the children of its employes. Staff members will meet tomorrow in the Economic and Social Council chamber to discuss the school.

PARIS, Aug. 26 -- The economists and technicians at the European Economic Conference here have not finished their task, but they already have agreed on a fundamental fact. By applying the dispassionate method of collecting information they already have discovered what men seldom like to acknowledge:
BATAVIA, Java, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The Netherlands tooK another step today toward the formation of a projected United States of Indonesia by establishing the self-governing territory of East Borneo.

DUNDEE, Scotland, Aug. 26 -- The British Association for the Advancement of Science will convene here tomorrow in its first normal meeting since the war, with sessions continuing until next Wednesday.

Dan Ferris, secretary of the United States Amateur Athletic Union, denied charges that he had blocked the participation of American students in the current world university athletic games at Paris, The United Press reports.

PREAKNESS HILLS, N.J., Aug. 26 -- Mrs. Philip Cudone of The Knoll posted a 37, 38 -- 75 today to take medal honors In the annual North Jersey invitation tournament at the North Jersey Country Club. She led the field by one shot at the turn, then scored a 38 on the incoming nine to nose out Mrs. Janet Hemple of Saddle River by two strokes.

After almost a month of intermittent debate the United Nations Security Council has finally adopted proposals to end the fighting between the Dutch and the Indonesian Republicans in Java and Sumatra. In that the proposals adopted are positive steps they can be applauded.

BUDAPEST, Aug. 26 -- Zoltan Pfeiffer, leader of the Hungarian Independence party, lies in bed tonight at his home in Budapest suffering from concussion of the brain and other severe injuries sustained at the hands of Communists, who broke up a meeting that his party had planned to hold yesterday at Csongrad.

Robert Borella of 6515 Park Avenue, West New York, N.J., a former member of the Seventeenth Airborne Division who was seriously wounded by machine gun fire in a glider landing in Germany, has a temporary job with the Army Signal Corps in Astoria, Queens.
The Legion and New York There have, inevitably, been some changes made since the Legion was last here in convention ten years ago. New York is not the same, nor are the Legionnaires.

Newspaper advertising lineage in fifty-two cities during July totaled 145,262,633 lines, a gain of 10.7 per cent over the corresponding month in 1946, according to Media Records. All classifications showed gains for the month except financial, which dropped 11.1 per cent.

Plans for a "monumental" approach to the United Nations site, as proposed by the real estate firm of Webb Knapp and the New York City Chapter of the American Institute of Architecture, have found little favor with Mayor O'Dwyer and the Board of Estimate, it was indicated yesterday.

The Rev. Dr. Samuel G. Trexler, last of a group of seven Protestant ministers to return from their recent tour of Yugoslavia, said yesterday that he supported Dr. Guy Emery Shipler, spokesman for the seven, in the controversy that has arisen over the trip.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 26 -- A downward trend of shipping, with scarcely more than half as many vessels operating in and out of San Francisco Bay now as before the war, was shown today by surveys and Government figures.

Dan River Mills, Inc., has begun production of several cotton fabrics treated with a new and exclusive chemical process which the company claims renders them as wrinkle-resistant as woolens or worsteds, George S. Harris, president, announced yesterday.

Seniority and incentive pay clauses continued yesterday to be the stumbling block to an agreement between the Bethlehem Steel Company, which operates nine East Coast shipyards, and the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, CIO.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 27 -- Governor Alfred E. Driscoll saw today in the tax clause for the propose new constitution for New Jersey a way to end the long, political controversy over railroad taxation for the state and its municipalities. The new charter awaits voter approval in November.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 27 -- One person was killed and four others were slightly injured when a New York bound Long Island Rail Road train struck a 5 1/2 ton trailer truck at the Willis Avenue crossing at 11 A.M. here today.

The $105,000,000 Chicago Transit Authority revenue bond issue was oversubscribed yesterday, twenty-three days after the authority's scheduled competitive sale of the bonds was called off for lack of bids, and seventeen days before the Sept. 12 deadline set for selling 80 per cent of the issue as a requisite for establishing a firm underwriting commitment.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- President Truman will leave Sunday morning on a flight to Rio de Janeiro to address the closing session of the Inter-American Defense Conference on Tuesday. He will remain in the Brazilian capital to take part in the country's independence celebration on Sept. 7.

Fifty founders of the American Legion had their annual reunion last night at the New York Yacht Club, 37 West Forty-fourth Street. They swapped stories about their organization's first meetings held in Paris and in St. Louis in 1919.

Headboards and beds designed to fit into various room schemes. made in sizes to suit tall or short people, and engineered to simplify bedmaking were shown yesterday by M. Mittman Co., 316 East Fifty-third Street. Upholstered headboards that can be adapted in width, and used with a mattress and box spring custom-made in any length, were featured at a preview of the company's new showrooms.

PETROPOLIS, Brazil, Aug. 27 -- The United States proposal for throwing united hemispheric force, military and economic, against any aggressor against an American state was approved unanimously tonight by Commission No. 3 of the Inter-American Defense Conference.

Maria Teresa Escoda, 19 years old, and her brother, Antonio, 17, appealed yesterday at First Army Headquarters on Governors Island to receive the Medals of Freedom awarded posthumously to their parents, Mr. and Mrs. Antonio Escoda, citizens of the Philippines.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Following is the text of President Truman's statement on the first report from his Scientific Research Board: The chairman of the President's Scientific Research Board, whom directed last October to study the scientific research and development of this country, has made his first report to me.

FORT COLLINS, Col., Aug. 27 -- The five-man board of directors of the new International Cooperative Petroleum Association will meet in London on Sept. 25 and 26 to work out final details for moving into the world's oil trade now controlled by British and American private interests.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your issue of Aug. 22, Fessenden G. Blanchard gives specific instances, in textile weaving and coal mining, of Britain's lag in mechanization, resulting in outputs per worker far below those in America. It is that inability to produce exportable manufactures in adequate volume, at fair prices, which is at the root of Britain's present troubles.
LONDON, Aug. 27 -- A two-day postponement was granted to the Government today in the writ of habeas corpus application for six Jewish immigrants, Hamburgbound aboard the three British ships.

Theodore W. Kheel, director of the city's division of labor relations, announced yesterday that his joint conference with spokesmen for the New York City Omnibus Corporation and the Transport Workers Union, CIO, had been postponed until Tuesday.

Apparently responding to a denial by John J. McCloy, president of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, that the bank would make a new offering of its debentures this year, the market for its issues showed signs of firming yesterday, after recent weakness.

PARIS, France, Aug. 27 -- Heavy dependence on Western Germany, Poland and other eastern countries in the Soviet bloc to make up estimated coal deficits for the next four years by the sixteen nations attending the European economic conference is snown in the report of the technical committee on fuel and power.

Brooklyn's favorite formula for beating the Cubs, the principal ingredient of which is the nomination of Joe Hatten as starting pitcher, failed to function with its usual effect yesterday at Ebbets Field. Chicago jumped on the Dodger southpaw for three runs in the first inning, scored three more in the sixth and made these stand up for a 6-3 victory.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Aug. 27 The Hungarian Government charged today that a United States Legation spokesman's criticism of its refusal to ensure freedom of speech for Zoltan Pfeiffer's party in Csongrad was a "malicious generalization" and denied the charge flatly.

The Congressional Committee of Inquiry that set sail yesterday represents an effort by the House of Representatives to inform itself of the needs of Europe. The trip is not a junket, the chairman asserts. It was authorized by special resolution and is composed of members of both parties and of the most important committees in the House.

EASTPORT, Me., Aug. 27 (AP) -- Eastport's plan to convert "Quoddy" Village into a displaced persons' industrial training center tonight was ruled ineligible by the War Assets Administration for "public benefit allowances," a vital financial factor in the municipality's bid for the property.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 27 (AP) -- Howard Fox and Herman Wehmeier, Syracuse's ace right-handers, turned in a couple of strong performances here tonight to hurl the Chiefs to a double triumph over the Bears. Fox won the the opener on a three-hit effort, 7 --3, while Wehmeier duplicated in the nightcap with a three-hit triumph, 4 --1.

LAKE SUCCESS. N.Y., Aug. 27 -- Strong doubts that the United Nations had seen the last of the Indonesian quarrel persisted today, and involved the all-important question of how the American attitude finally would shape up.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 27 -- On a victory note the last Yankee invasion of the West came to an end at Sportsman's Park this afternoon, under almost incredible circumstances.

BOSTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -- While aggravating his recent right knee injury, Ewell (the Whip) Blackwell gained his twentieth victory for the Reds with a ten-inning 4-2 decision over the Braves tonight before a crowd of 20,374. The lanky righthander had to leave the game after his team-mates scored twice in their side of the tenth on two singles, a sacrifice and an error.

ATHENS, Thursday, Aug. 28 -- The Greek Governmental crisis ended shortly before last midnight when King Paul disclosed that Premier-designate Constantin Tsaldaris had agreed to enter a broad coalition Government under a neutral Prime Minister.

Benjamin Britten's opera, "Peter Grimes," has been acquired by the Metropolitan Opera for production next season, it was learned yesterday. The work, which was first presented two years ago in London, has already become one of the most famous operas of modern times.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Secretary of the Treasury Snyder, reporting on last week's British loan negotiations, stated emphatically today at a press conference that the Attlee Government had neither sought nor obtained any modification of the non-discrimination clause of the financial agreement.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 27 -- Miss Grillo, the Argentine oerby winner of 1945, whose first North American victory was scored in Saratoga's Diana Handicap last year, made her record two for two in that $10,000 added stake today.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Aug. 27 (AP) -- United States prosecutors said today that businessmen in the United States who had been exposed to the spy system would be brought here to testify against the directors. They listed as probable witnesses employes of the General Aniline and Film Corporation of New York and the subsidiary, Ansco film division, of Binghamton, N.Y.

LEGHORN, Italy, Aug. 27 -- Robert C. Ruark, Scripps-Howard columnist who accused Lieut. Gen. John C.H. Lee, commanding general of the United States forces in Italy, of having violated Army Regulations, had a two-and-onehalf-hour private conversation today with Maj. Gen. Ira T. Wyche, Inspector General of the United States Army.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27 -- John Foster Dulles, Republican adviser on foreign affairs, writing in the Sept. 3 issue of the Christian Century, calls for "a fact-finding body which is continuously in session" in the United Nations, to increase the organization's capacity in what he finds is its most effective role for world peace in the present circumstances, that of a forum for world opinion.

GUATEMALA, Aug. 27 -- The Costa Rican delegate, Ana Rosa Chacon, representative of the Women's Civic Group, today withdrew from the Inter-American Women's Congress, alleging that the Congress had Leftist tendencies.
ROME, Aug. 27 -- The Soviet Union intends to ratify the Italian peace treaty in the near future, according to information received by the Foreign Ministry today.

TOKYO, Aug. 27 -- Allied Headquarters tonight faces a minor re bellion as a result of its offensive against pets in hotels and apartments. Pets, it seems, must go -- with the exception of goldfish, which, according to a startling decision by the military mind, are "not pets, but decorative."

A middleweight match between Billy Arnold of Philadelphia and Laverne Roach of Plainview, Tex., has been closed for the opening show of the season at the St. Nicholas Arena on Friday, Sept. 26, the Twentieth Century Sporting Club announced yesterday.

Steel Activity With demand for virtually every steel product continuing unabated and with backlogs of orders in some instances even becoming greater because of inability to push steel production above 95 per cent of capacity in the last two months, the steel industry is continuing under heavy pressure for deliveries.

A five-year guarantee that New York motion picture makers will not be plagued by the jurisdictional strikes that have produced picket lines, broken heads and long production delays in Hollywood movie studios, was signed in Mayor O'Dwyer's presence yesterday by the heads of the thirteen principal film unions in this city.

PARIS, Aug. 27 (Reuters) -- The French Government replied favorably, with certain reservations, today to the British request of Aug. 23 that the 4,300 Jewish Exodus 1947 refugees, now on their way to Germany, be received back into France by train from the British zone, the French Foreign Office announced here tonight.

Sixty-three per cent of Europe is producing at the pre-war level or higher, but the dollar shortage is the basic paralyzing factor there, Louis Dolivet, international editor of the United Nations World, said yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Export Advertising Association at the Hotel Woodstock.

The Board of Estimate, meeting yesterday in executive session, agreed to postpone the demolition of the old Aquarium, or Castle Clinton, until the middle of next year. If by adjournment next year Congress has not appropriated the money for its restoration as a national memorial, the structure then will be demolished, it was decided.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 27 -- The United Nations Security Council is expected to clear its slate tomorrow and start a muchneeded ten-day vacation. Most of the members of the Council believe that it will accept a Brazilian resolution to refer the Egyptian appeal against Great Britain, the last item on its agenda, back to the two parties for direct negotiation.

SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 27 -- Lieut. Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer, here on a fact-finding mission for President Truman, today conferred with leading American military and civilian authorities on economic and political problems.

TORONTO, Aug. 27 (Canadian Press) -- With the Hamilton Tigers determined to introduce their exiled United States ace to Canadian football fans, hard-hitting Frankie Filchock tonight faced one of the toughest opposition line-ups of his career in his bid to play in Canada this season.

Fred F. Finklehoffe's production of "The Heiress," in which Wendy Hiller and Basil Rathbone are costarred and Patricia Collinge featured, has secured a Broadway berth and settled on the opening date. The play, by Ruth and Augustus Goetz, dealing with an attractive girl who falls in love with a fortune hunter, will be installed at the Biltmore Theatre on Monday evening, Sept. 29.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 27 -- The United States will be asked to pay $26,000,000 of the $65,000,000 needed to construct the future world capital of the United Nations, and insurance companies in this country will be approached for a loan of an additional $25,000,000, it was disclosed today.
Legionnaires with shopping lists tucked in their wallets made their appearance yesterday on flagdecked Fifth Avenue.

DUNDEE, Scotland, Aug. 27 -- Before a brilliant audience of the foremost scientists of Great Britain, a Nobel prize winner, Sir Henry Dale, formally opened the first post-war meeting of the British Association for the Advancement of Science.

Exports from the United States in some lines are now falling off rapidly, while volume in others is being well maintained, foreign traders here reported yesterday. They expressed little doubt, however, that when the total export figures for August and July are published by the Department of Commerce they will show a marked drop from the peak reached in May.
GENEVA, Aug. 27 -- The United States-French tariff negotiations, in a state of suspense for nearly six weeks, have been resumed, it was learned today.

The Australian Davis Cup players unfurled their new doubles combination of Jack Bromwich and Colin Long in a hard practice session at Forest Hills yesterday. The pair made a strong impression on several score American spectators who had not seen them in action before, The Associated Press reports.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Scoring single runs in the fourth and sixth innings after a four-run first, Washington won, 6 -- 5, from the White Sox before 4,431 today. Milo Candini emerged with his third triumph against as many losses. Candini turned in a six-and-a-third inning relief chore after wildness overtook the starter, Sid Hudson, in the third.

LONDON, Aug. 27 -- Orders putting Britain back on a wartime footing on food, motoring and foreign travel were issued by the Labor Government tonight. The socalled "siege economy" measures will go into effect between now and Oct. 1.
LONDON, Aug. 27 -- The tripartite conference on the level of German industry in the United States and British zones ended tonight without full agreement on the main point at issue.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- A program for bold and imaginative expansion of scientific research, entailing annual expenditures of at least 1 per cent of the national income by 1957, was proposed to President Truman today by his Scientific Research Board.

Two Federal missions whose studies abroad will strongly influence the position of the United States Government in dealing with foreign economic and refugee aid departed yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary.

The Pan American Petroleum Transport Company yesterday announced the election of Charles H. Wagner, president of the American Oil Company, a subsidiary, as a director to succeed the late E.G. McKeever. A.A. Corona was named vice president of Pan American, and J.A. Carroll Jr., vice president and treasurer, was elected a member of the executive committee.
