DETROIT, Aug 27 (AP) -- The Red Sox had a narrow squeeze today to retain their thin hold on second place by dividing their second straight double-header with the Tigers, bounding back again to take the nightcap, 5 to 4, after Detroit had won the opener, 7 to 2.
Despite recent reports of empty seats on passenger aircraft, American Airlines announced yesterday that according to its figures more persons are flying today than ever before.

Out of the over-all total of traffic accidents, of which we should all be ashamed, the proportion of crashes occurring at night remains inordinately high. Most motorists are all too familiar with the strain of driving against glare of oncoming headlights. While the courtesy of dimming lights or lowering beams, which should be universal, seems to be making some gains, the problem of glare by no means has been overcome.

With the smallest volume of business in three years, the stock market drifted yesterday within a restricted range and closed mixed with the composite rate advanced only 0.01 point. A few issues stiffened in the forenoon, but the lack of interest prevented any conclusive results.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 27 -- Accounts of union "dictatorship" in Hollywood and of hapless workers made jobless for nearly a year evoked threats of Congressional action today from the House Labor subcommittee investigating the American Federation of Labor jurisdictional strike in the movie studios.

One of the busiest sections in New York is the Times Square area, as everyone, including the out-of-towners, knows. And one of the busiest restaurants in the district is Dunhall's, 1440 Broadway near Forty-first Street, where about 2,000 people lunch daily between 11:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 27 -- Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, today announced seven new items of business had been added to the supplementary agenda of the General Assembly, to be convened here on Sept. 16.

PANAMA, Aug. 27 -- The United States Army is abandoning fourteen more sites in Panama, which were used during the war to defend the Panama Canal. This leaves only eighteen bases occupied outside of the Canal Zone.

Yesterday was "L Day." The Legion's aging Peter Pans established beach-heads at Manhattan's crossroads. Shock-troops (jumpbox operators) spearheaded the first wave, with water-pistol squads, tickler and cow-bell platoons in hilarous support.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27 -- Heavy buying of wheat futures attributed to professional traders and commission houses lifted prices today on the Board of Trade and they closed about the top, with net grains of 1 5/8 to 4 1/4 cents a bushel.
EASTVIEW, N.Y., Aug. 27 -- Two automobiles collided head-on this morning one mile south of here on the Saw Mill River Parkway, killing two persons and injuring three.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The Aug. 18 issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES reported plans for a "Stateless Children's Sanctuary" to be established on the island of Nevis in the British West Indies, where fifty children between the ages of 3 and 6 would be provided with "care, maintenance and education."

LAHORE, Pakistan, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Two United States State Department employes said today that a Sikh mob held up the train on which they were riding, killed fifteen Moslem passengers and twice attempted to force a way into the Americans' compartment.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Holland The commission, in Chicago to has begun construction of what will be one of the largest buildings in Europe, a special Dutch commission studying American construction and production methods, reported today.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 27 -- Immediate extension of medical care in the United States through insurance programs was urged before delegates to the American Pharmaceutical Association's opening session here by Dr. Howard A. Rusk of New York.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- A prediction that both the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations executive boards would sign affidavits disclaiming communism was made here today by a high labor authority who declined to permit the use of his name.

A report urging the American Legion to support the Marshall Plan as a means of building a bulwark in Western Europe against communism was made yesterday by the Legion's foreign relations committee. It was approved by the national executive committee for study and action at the Legion's twenty-ninth annual national convention, which opens today.
LONDON, Aug. 27 (Reuters) -- Results of soccer games played in Great Britain today: ENGLISH LEAGUE First Division Charlton 2. Arsenal 4. Chelsea 1. Blackburn 0. Everton 1. Manchester City 0.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 27 -- Repeal of the state anti-strike law and state financial aid to police departments were urged in resolutions today at the conference of New York State Benevolent Associations.

Flames arising from plundered villages lighten the dark skies over the Punjab, focal point of the Indian subcontinent's lingering religious strife. The exodus of Sikhs and Hindus from the Pakistan portion of the province is reciprocated by the flight of Moslems from the Eastern Punjab, which lies within the Indian Union.

New versions of the "Duette," a wool-filled bed cover that doubles as a comforter, were shown yesterday by Lord Taylor in spacesaving settings for one-room apartments. To create a trim effect by day, the covers are made in neat plaids as well as in wide stripes colored in subtle tones.

Three hundred tenants of East Side tenements scheduled for demolition on the site of the Alfred E. Smith housing project appeared in Supreme Court yesterday to protest what they feared was a suit by the city to evict them immediately. The city had served notice upon half the 1,321 families in the area that writs would be sought allowing the city to evict them if necessary.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27 -- Moving to beat the steel shortage, a group of twenty-five small and moderate size manufacturers has purchased for $4,000,000 a steel mill at Phoenixville, Pa., to round out its purchase last year of a sheet rolling mill at Apollo, Pa., Arnold H. Maremont, president, announced today.

SALEM, N.H., Aug. 27 (AP) -- The highest daily doable of the 1947 New England racing Reason was recorded at Rockingham Park today before 12,151 as two lightly regarded winners combined to pay off $1,086.40 on a $2 ticket.

Judge Louis Goldstein in Kings County Court denied yesterday the application of Miss Sally Haines, actress-friend of Julius Lobel, alias Jimmy Collins, for an order directing the Police Property Clerk to return $5,400. The money was removed by authorities from a safe deposit box during the investigation into the Mergenthaler Linotype Company swindle.

Both the surf and the off-shore waters are producing plenty of large stripers for the Martha's Vineyard anglers right now, and with decent weather over the week-end there is a good chance of record catches being made in this area.

CHEBOYGAN, Mich., Aug. 27 -- Charles E. Potter, 34-year-old legless war veteran and Republican winner by more than two to one in the special election for the House seat made vacant by the death of Fred A. Bradley, Republican, said today that he would go to Washington within a fortnight to prime himself for the January session.

THEY'LL be making the draw for the Davis Cup matches tomorrow and the experts seem pretty well agreed that, regardless of the way they juggle the pairings, the result won't be changed one iota. It still looks to be the United States in a breeze. The Americans swept all five engagements with the Australians in Melbourne late last December, losing only two sets in the entire operation.

Howard Lindsay, co-author and original star of "Life With Father," has accepted the assignment of master of ceremonies for "The Ford Theatre," which makes its debut on Oct. 5 over NBC, and will be heard every Sunday at 5 P.M. He will describe the settings of the dramas to be offered, introduce the players and provide such incidental narration as may be necessary.

Less than thirty hours before he stepped on the mound at the Polo Grounds last night, Ray Poat was a minor-league pitcher whose chief claim to fame centered about several chances he had flubbed with the Cleveland Indians. Called up from Baltimore of the International League, Poat was immediately pressed into service by Mel Ott and at once became the most talked-about Giant of the moment.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- The Government's war on rising living costs produced criminal charges today that the National Association of Real Estate Boards and the Washington Real Estate Board violated the anti-trust laws.

Applicants who passed a written Civil Service examination last March for jobs as City Housing Authority assistants, at an advertised base salary of $2,000, complained yesterday that the city was trying to trim them by $200.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- The heads of the states of East Indonesia and West Borneo protested to the United Nations today against "legal barriers" that prevented their being heard in the negotiations for peace between the Netherlands and the Indonesian Republic.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninetyfour cities, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended Aug. 20: Increases of $195,000,000 in loans and $206,000,000 in demand deposits adjusted, and a decrease of $180,000,000 in demand deposits credited to domestic banks.
CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 27 (AP) -- Mrs. E.H. Augustus' Blue Yonder came from last place in the fivehorse field to beat Shamrock Stable's Westminster by a half length today in the Kaighn purse.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that industrial production dropped during July for the fourth consecutive month. But it said the decline between June and July was due "in part to influences of a temporary nature," and that "scattered information now available indicates a somewhat higher level for August than July."

RHINEBECK, N.Y., Aug. 27 -- The American farmer holds the key to future world political developments and is the most important man in the world today, Gov. Thomas E. Dewey told an assemblage at the annual Governor's Day Ceremonies at the Dutchess County Fair here today.
PARIS, Aug. 27 -- A statute establishing a form of government of Algeria and designed to curb the growing Moslem discontent in North Africa was voted by the National Assembly tonight, 319 to 89.

NANKING, Aug. 27 -- A plan to enable the "Overseas Chinese" to participate in China's first national election, which is scheduled to take place this coming October, already has aroused resentment in Siam. A Central News Agency dispatch from Bangkok tonight said that Siam's Cabinet had decided to protest against any foreign vote-casting project there as a violation of national sovereignty.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 27 -- A float depicting Christmas morning in the home won for David and Andrew Huisman, 2 and 4 years old, of 293 Lincoln Avenue, Paterson, N.J., first prize in the golden jubilee edition of the Asbury Park baby parade here today.

While New Yorkers for the most part have known little about it, a small but energetic organization called Home Playyards, Inc., of 105 East Twentysecond Street, has been busily at work over a period of years providing children's play equipment for Home Playyard Centers in crowded city blocks where public playgrounds are not available.
An increase of half a cent a quart in the price of milk was announced yesterday by the Borden's Farm Products division of the Borden Company.
LONDON, Aug. 27 -- With buyers still inclined to await publication of the Government's austerity plans, the stock markets here today generally were quiet.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Aug. 27 -- Adrian is adamant about squared shoulders and slim hips. Trim slim and elegant as he sees the American woman is the dictum of his fall winter collection, presented in his Beverly Hills salon to a fashion alert audience.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Buddy Bomar of Chicago, who won $17,400 in bowling tournaments during the last year for an alltime record, today was selected as "bowler of the year" by the National Bowling Writers Association.

Irving Poretz, whom District Attorney Frank S. Hogan has called the brains behind the getrich-quick scheme by which he and William B. Benjamin, auto jack manufacturer, swindled banks and factoring concerns out of $650,000, pleaded guilty yesterday in General Sessions to one count of a fixty-six count indictment charging forgery, grand larceny, conspiracy and receiving stolen goods.

ADRIANOPLE, Turkey, Aug. 23 (Delayed) -- The constant threat of war has made Turkish Thrace -- a 1,312-square-mile area with great agricultural and industrial potentialities -- an almost desolated land virtually deserted by civilians.

GENEVA, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Some members of the majority in the Palestine committee were said to approve the boundaries proposed by the minority federalists, which would give the Jews roughly three main areas of the Holy Land. These are the eastern inland area of Galilee in the north, the coastal strip of central Palestine including Haifa and Tel Aviv, and the inland areas of the southern semi-desert of the Negev.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: This letter is intended to be in reply to THE TIMES editorial of July 13 and the letter of Leonard M. Wallstein which appeared in your columns on July 26, in so far as you favor the separation of command and judicial functions concerning military justice.

Several department delegations, notably California, had to "eat crow" on their estimates of attendance at the American Legion convention here and release rooms reserved for them on the eve of the opening of the gathering. They hoped, however, that late arrivals would still help to make the convention the biggest on record.

PETROPOLIS, Brazil, Aug. 27 -- The Treaty of Rio de Janeiro, putting the Act of Chapultepec in the form of a binding pact and symbolizing the determination of the Americas to defend themselves on an "all for one, one for all" basis, will be signed at the Brazilian Foreign Office in Rio de Janeiro on Tuesday.

New Yorkers enjoyed a comfortable day yesterday, with a high temperature of 73 degrees at 1:50 A.M., little more than a parting kick of the heat wave that was broken by Tuesday's storm. The low mark was 68 at 8:10 A.M.

PARIS, Aug. 27 -- In quest of maximum possible guidance from the United States in framing its final report on the Marshall plan, the Executive Committee of the European Economic Conference will meet with Mr. Clayton and Mr. Caffery tomorrow.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 27 -- A series of United States proposals for the limitation, or at least the definition, of the use of the veto brought an angry outburst today from Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet representative on the United Nations Security Council.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Today's report of tne livestock market here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 7,000 head total, 9,000. Market slow and very uneven but averaging around 25 cents lower on all weight and sows bulk of good and choice 190-260 pound

A decline last week of 1,048,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, total gasoline supplies were 83,915,000 barrels, compared with 84,963,000 a week earlier and 86,039,000 on Aug. 24, 1946.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- The National Federation of American Shipping presented figures today to show that foreign merchant fleets were expanding beyond earlier estimates primarily because of purchases of American warbuilt vessels and large construction programs.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Ken Keltner walloped his ninth homer of the season into the lower leftfield stands in the seventh inning tonight to give the Indians a 2-1 triumph over the Athletics.

The Cunard White Star liner Media, the first passenger ship to be built for the company since the war, received the acclaim of New York Harbor yesterday when she arrived from Liverpool on her maiden voyage.

ON BOARD THE RUNNYMEDE PARK, Gibraltar, Aug. 27 (Reuters) -- Anti-personnel depth charges were dropped at fifteenminute intervals throughout the night around the three ships, in which the visaless Jewish refugees are being taken to Hamburg, as a defense against attacks by "frogmen."

SALEM, N.H., Aug. 27 (AP) -- As the Rockingham Park management took drastic steps to check the "swamp fever" epidemic at its racing plant, veterinary experts and horsemen today feared that this equine infectious anemia may imperil much of the American turf world.

Members of La Societe des Quarante Hommes et Huit Chevaux -- better known as "The Forty and Eight" -- climbed off their "box cars," "locomotives" and other noisy vehicles long enough last night to open their national convention.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Emil (Dutch) Leonard held the Pirates to five hits tonight as the Phils scored a 4-to-3 triumph over Pittsburgh. It was Leonard's sixteenth victory against seven defeats. Mel Queen and Al Lyons allowed the Phils only four safeties but three of these were bunched for three runs in the first inning.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 27 (Reuters) -- The Constituent Assembly of the Dominion of India today rejected an amendment by Moslem representatives demanding separate electorates for Moslems in polling for all legislative bodies in the Dominion.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Aug. 27 -- An acute shortage of fine wools will face the world during the balance of this year and into 1948, F. Eugene Ackerman, executive director of the American Wool Conference, told a meeting of the council's executive committee here today.

Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, vice chairman of a Congressional committee investigating housing, joined the American Legion's housing committee yesterday on a tour of various developments here. While much that they saw impressed them, they found a notable exception in the 1,424-apartment Rego Park temporary emergency project on Horace Harding Boulevard, Queens.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 27 -- The International Longshoremen and Warehousemen's Union, a Congress of Industrial Organizations affiliate, asked CIO engineering officers and American Federation of Labor masters and mates today to leave seven Luckenbach Steamship Company vessels which are being picketed in this port by walking bosses belonging to the ILWU.

DETROIT, Aug. 27 -- The 65,000 members of Local 600 of the United Automobile Workers, Congress of Industrial Organizations, will take their choice of two contract proposals made by the Ford Motor Company at a mass meeting to be held on Sept. 14, it was stated today by Thomas Thompson, president of the local.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 27 -- Three quick, accurate bursts from a submachine gun fired by Police Lieut. Fred Small from atop a baggage truck in the Exchange Place terminal of the Pennsylvania railroad cut down three runaway steers today in view of a terror stricken crowd of 500 who thronged the station during the noon hour period.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 27 -- The age of six is too late to go into school from the small, close structure of the American family, Dr. Ruth Benedict, professor of Anthopology at Columbia University, said here today. The great role of the nursery school is to make a good transition from the family unit to the wider social pattern, she declared.

The New York Telephone Company withheld comment yesterday on Mayor O'Dwyer's demand that installation of telephone cable at Idlewild Airport be resumed with or without the cooperation of the two unions that have been quarreling for more than two years over which should do the work.
Union Free School District 27, Hempstead, L.I., sold yesterday an issue of $560,000 of bonds, due Sept. 1 from 1948 to 1977, to the Marine Trust Company and associates at a bid of 100.78 for 2s.

Announces New Pressure Cooker National Pressure Cooker Company shortly will introduce a new six-quart model in its line of Presto pressure cookers, Mark Van Buskirk, metropolitan area sales manager, announced yesterday. The item will retail for either $14.95 or $15.95, depending on area of distribution, and will be in dealers' stocks about Sept. 18.

PREAKNESS HILL, N.J., Aug. 27 -- Mrs. Philip Cudone of The Knoll scored a 6-and-5 victory over Mrs. Courtland Smith of Glen Ridge today in the first round of match play in the North Jersey women's invitation tournament at the North Jersey Country Club.

Commercial Solvents A dividend of 37 1/2 cents a common share was voted by the Commercial Solvents Corporation, payable on Sept. 30. The company announced plans to pay dividends quarterly instead of semi-annually. Previous payments were 50 cents each in June and December last.

Westinghouse Electric Corporation will impose any over-all increase in prices of electrical appliances and is exerting every effort to absorb recent increases in steel and other costs, J.H. Ashbaugh, vice president of the company's electrical appliance division, declared yesterday.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Aug. 27 -- George Nichols' famous international six-meter yacht Goose led in two trial races today to select a defender of the Scandinavian Gold Cup, which was brought to this country thirteen years ago and for which five nations will compete against the United States off here, starting on Sept 8.

American mothers and wives whose sons and husbands lie buried in Europe will get a first-hand description of the conditions of the graves and the battlefields on which the men fought during World War II.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The recent article by Edwin L. James, in reply to an allegation by David Zaslavsky, published in Pravda, that this country does not have freedom of the press, highlights the discussion between American and Russian journalists over the relative freedoms possessed and exercised by the press of their respective countries.

Retailing of alcoholic beverages in New York State will assume a new character on Labor Day when regulations providing for mandatory fair trade pricing take effect in New York State and powerful forces to police the industry swing into action, leaders in the business declared yesterday.

LONDON, Thursday, Aug. 28 -- Without contradicting Secretary Snyder's statements in Washington to the effect that Britain did not ask for any modification of the non-discrimination clause of the loan agreement, the prevailing view in London is that a satisfactory arrangement has been reached.

Paul H. Griffith, commander of the American Legion, who along with his aides and state officers of the Legion were guests of honor yesterday at a reception given by Mayor O'Dwyer and city officials, voiced an admonition to all attending the convention to be "ladies and gentlemen."

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 27 -- The United Nations fourteen month search for international atomic control moved into a new stage today as the United States, Britain, China and France gave their support to specific, detailed proposals for the actual operation of the long-debated global security agency.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Robert A. Lovett, Acting Secretary of State, in effect pledged the United States Government's support today to any European aid program under the Marshall Plan that could be described as "reasonable but realistic."

In the seven months between January and the end of July, the United Palestine Appeal spent $39,835,756 for the rehabilitation and resettlement of refugees and for the over-all development of Palestine, it was announced yesterday.

An invasion of the midtown shopping district by juvenile delinquents and hoodlums has brought cooperative action by the police and the West Thirty-fourth StreetMidtown Association, Inc., to clean up the situation, it was reported yesterday.

GENEVA, Switzerland, Aug. 27 -- The United Nations Special Committee of Inquiry on Palestine voted six to four today in favor of some kind of Palestine confederation, with a central economic administration to be imposed on the "states."

YONKERS, N.Y., Aug. 28 (Thursday) -- Col. John Stilwell, member of the Westchester County Parkway Commission and brother of Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell, was the first automobilist to pay the new 10-cent toll on the Saw Mill River Parkway at 12:01 A.M. today.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 27 -- Registration statements covering $1,750,000 of debentures and $7,000,000 of bonds were filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by two companies.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development announced today that Italy had applied for a loan of $250,000,000 for rebuilding.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 27 -- Audie Murphy, who has been described as the most decorated soldier of the war, will appear with Alan Ladd in Paramount's West Point film. "The-Long Gray Line," the studio announced today.

On Tuesday, September 3, 1946, the floor of the New York Stock Exchange was swept, metaphorically speaking, by three tidal waves of selling. Nearly 3,000,000 shares of stock changed hands during the five hours of business, and when the statistics had been compiled at the end of the day they revealed that the market break had been the most severe in fifteen years.

The Radio Communication Assemblers Union, Inc., an independent union representing workers in two New Jersey plants of the Radio Corporation of America, became yesterday the first union in this region to file the non-Communist affidavits required by the TaftHartley Act.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Aug. 27 -- The United States prosecution charged today that officials of the I.G. Farbenindustrie had duped industrialists in the United States into revealing trade secrets in return for "scraps of paper." This accusation was made as the war crimes trial against officials of Germany's greatest pre-war industrial combine was opened before a United States military tribunal here.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Once again the man to beat in the international Star Class yacht racing championship appears to be George T. Fleitz of Los Angeles, the defending world champion.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Aug. 23 were 900, 895 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 5,410 cars, or 0.6 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week; 15,940 cars, or 1.8 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year, and 47,469 cars, or 5.6 per cent, more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

Secretary of the Navy James Forrestal, recently designated to be Secretary of Defense under the Unification Act, told members of the American Legion, in convention at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon, that world peace and stability were the primary objectives of the United States international policy.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 28 -- More relief is on the way for sufferers of allergic ailments such as hay fever, asthma, certain types of eczemas and food allergies. Pharmaceutical scientists made this prediction this afternoon in a special symposium on anti-histamine drugs held before the scientific section of the American Pharmaceutical Association meeting here this week.

Now it is up to the courts to decide whether motorists will continue to pay tolls oil the Saw Mill River Parkway or ignore the line of shiny, new booths that bar free passage to traffic. The initial physical move in a battle to determine the legality of the fees was made, by the Automobile Club of New York yesterday.
CHICAGO, Aug. 28 -- Prices of wheat continued on the upgrade today on the Board of Trade. September sold at a record high for that delivery and other months went into new seasonal ground.

LAKE SUCCESS. N.Y., Aug. 28 -- Nassau County and local police were called out by the United Nations today to disperse its first fullscale political demonstrationcomplete with sixty EgyptianAmerican marchers, flags, banners, slogans, speeches and the National Maritime Union.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Urging the need for a modified wage set-up, the Social Action Department of the National Catholic Welfare Conference pleaded today for the establishment of a system of industry councils through which Labor and management, with the assistance of the Government, might jointly and democratically work out all of the major problems of economic life.

An estimated 2,500 visitors, mostly American legionnaires and their families, boarded the battleship New Jersey and six other warships in the North River yesterday as the Navy participated in the Legion Convention.

SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Dismissing an American proposal for a Korean plebiscite as "pure propaganda," the Russians today suggested the appointment of an all-Korean Peoples' Assembly as a way out of the present deadlock oveu arranging a unified government for this divided country.

Margaret Truman has applied for membership in the American Guild of Musical Artists (AGMA), it was learned yesterday. The application by the President's daughter was dated Aug. 19 and was sent from California, where she sang in concert at the Hollywood Bowl last Saturday night.

The playboys of the western world, the Legion wags, warmed up yesterday for what must inevitably go down in history as Manhattan's lost week-end. Their free show, pretty much the same as their 1937 production but slowed up some, had Broadway in the aisles yesterday -- only there were no aisles.
The off-shore swells of the past few days have been too much for most of the tuna fishermen, and the results have not been too good, but the weather is more hopeful for the week-end.

LONDON, Aug. 28 (AP) -- George Truman of Los Angeles and Cliff Evans of Washington, D.C., arrived here today on their leisurely round-the-world trip in two light planes, confessing they had acquired a healthy respect for the Atlantic Ocean.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Occasional news dispatches in THE TIMES indicate that the Commission on Palestine does not regard with favor the plan of partitioning the country, but inclines toward federation or confederation. It is not clear just how the Commission draws the distinction between federation and confederation.

PETROPOLIS, Brazil, Aug. 28 -- The technical committee of the Inter -American Defense Conference, working on the exact delineation of the new hemisphere security zone completed its task today. The final project will go before the full commission No. 2 at 10 A.M. tomorrow.

The last long holiday week-end of the season, with its promise .of fair weather, found the major railroads, airlines and bus transportation officials preparing yesterday for outgoing and incoming travel over the Labor Day period.

Maj. Gen. James M. Gavin, commander of the 82d Airborne Division, in the invasion of Europe, made a plea for the support of the current program for the development and maintenance of air power, in addressing' members of the Rotary Club yesterday in the Commodore Hotel.

What started as an eight-sided race for election to the highly prized post of national commander of the American Legion had narrowed yesterday to a field of not more than four candidates and James F. O'Neil of Manchester, N.H., stood far out in front.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Aug. 28 -- Goose, generally recognized as the most phenomenal six-meter yacht ever planked and canvased, today won her laurels to defend th Scandinavian Gold Cup on Sept. 8 against the best sailing creatior of five other nations.
LONDON, Aug. 28 -- The belief that the Government had temporized with a situation that called for more drastic action than the austerity program announced last night was widespread in Britain today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP)-- The National Association of Real Estate Boards today said real estate men of the nation "are outraged" at the anti-trust indictment returned by a Federal grand jury against the association and the Washington real estate board.

PARIS, Aug. 28 -- The French encouraged themselves today with the thought that the London Conference on Ruhr production had left them with at least an opportunity to continue their fight for a larger percentage of Ruhr coke and coal.

BOSTON, Aug. 28 (AP) -- The Braves today moved within one game of the second-place Cardinals by twice beating the Reds, taking: the opener, 8 -- 7, in 16 innings and winning the nightcap, called after five and a half frames because of darkness, 3 -- 2.

Households planning country or seashore picnics or backyard barbecues over the long week-end will find markets well stocked today with a variety of foods for cooking on the spot or preparing at home and carrying to the scene.

Joseph Philips, convicted bookmaker, who has been held as a material witness in a Bronx County grand jury investigation set off by his allegations of police graft, revealed yesterday in Bronx County Court that he had applied for a pistol permit for self-protection.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Aug. 28 -- The I.G. Farben trial abruptly recessed today until tomorrow after less than one hour of the afternoon session when a running fire of defense objections made it impossible to proceed. In declaring the recess Presiding Judge Curtis drover Shake, with some show of irritation, advised the defense it must be prepared to proceed tomorrow without further delay.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 28 -- Herbert K. Sorrell, leader of the Hollywood AFL craft union strike, charged before the House labor subcommittee today that the rival International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes, also AFL, was a, virtual company union created by the movie producers and was long engaged in a conspiracy with them to drive the craft unions out of the studios.

Modeled by members of the "pigtails fashion board" of Abraham Straus and their sisters and brothers from 3 to 14 years old, fashions for the kindergarten and grade school set were presented in a showing yesterday at the store.

When Larry Jansen struck out Pinch-Hitter Del Rice to end the ball game and seal a 6 -- 5 verdict for the Giants over the Cardinals yesterday at the Polo Grounds, the strains of the "Victory Song" were heard again. There's nothing unusual about that; because that robust tune always follows a triumph by the Giants.
Governor Dewey attacked as "balderdash" last night advocacy of universal military training as a substitute for high school or college or as a health-building measure.

On Aug. 6 Prime Minister Clement Attlee outlined to Parliament the Labor Government's general program for combating Britain's foreign exchange, or "dollar shortage," problem. In its broadest terms, that program aimed at a reduction in the demand for dollars, on the one hand, and, on the other, an increase in the supply.

SALEM, N.H., Aug. 28 (AP) -- Leading every step of the way, but winning by a scant nose at the wire, Mrs. Tom Haskos' sprinter Windmill won the Brookline Purse before 9,006 paid spectators at Rockingham Park today.

PARIS, Aug. 28 -- Experts on the press, radio and the films, meeting here this week under the auspices of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization to map a program for overcoming' war-produced technical deficiencies in the mass media fields, admitted today that they were meeting the same problem of scarcity in hard currencies that is plaguing the European Economic Conference.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) -- The United States will keep its biggest bombers shuttling between home bases and those in occupied Germany and Japan during the winter.

With a speed that must have been surprising even to themselves, delegations from nineteen American nations have virtually completed in two weeks at Petropolis, Brazil, the task of writing a treaty that provides for a greater degree of collective action against aggression than ever was agreed on by any similar group for any similar area.
SARATOGA SPRINGS. N.Y., Aug. 28 -- The lone filly in the lineup was the one who led 'em home in the forty-fifth running of the $7,500 added Albany Handicap at Saratoga today.

GENEVA, Aug. 28 -- In a gloomy review of the world food situation, Norris Dodd. United States Under-Secretary of Agriculture, warned the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization conference today that the United States could not be depended upon to meet the world's entire cereals deficit.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Aug. 28 -- As coach of the Eastern AllStar squad that defeated the Giants, 16 -- 7, in 1940 for the only victory the collegians have been able to score over the professionals in the Tribune Fresh-Air Fund benefit series, Tuss McLaughry is entitled to be hopeful of his current outfit's chances in the kickoff game of the New York football campaign at the Polo Grounds next Wednesday night.
The Board of Estimate unanmously adopted yesterday a reslution for which Mayor O'Dwye was sponsor, guaranteeing continued maintenance of the city's ninety-six child-care centers.

PETROPOLIS, Aug. 28 (AP) -- The Colombian delegation to the Inter-American Conference, still dissatisfied with certain features of the mutual defense treaty now virtually complete, prepared tonight to fight for revision, if necessary, at the final plenary sessions that begin tomorrow.

In the Porkkala Enclave Irritated by the security measures taken by the Soviets in the Porkkala enclave outside Helsinki, an excitable Finnish journalist exclaimed: "Are Finns to be treated as cattle?"

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 28 -- The Premier of Croatia announced tonight that Yugoslav authorities had arrested priests involved in a riot in Zone B, along with others who had participated in the disorders in Zone B last Sunday.

National Commander Paul H. Griffith of Pennsylvania rendered an account of his stewardship of the American Legion during the last year to the membership at the convention session at Madison Square Garden yesterday. Touching upon the many issues that have confronted the organization, he brought forth a salvo of cheers when the declared:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28-Increases for a few non-agricultural commodities caused an increase of 0.3 per cent in average primary market prices during the week ended on Aug. 23, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, United States Department of Labor.

Despite indifferent buying on the opening days, substantial orders were placed during the thirtythird annual summer New york Gift Show in the New Yorker and Pennsylvania Hotels, which ended yesterday. Exhibitors expressed satisfaction with results and stated that they hoped that the Boston Gift Show which opens next Monday will be as successful.

FORT COLLINS, Col., Aug. 28 -- There were strong indications today that unless Republican leaders took steps soon to curb the activities of some Congressional investigating committees the party would be faced with a rebellion of a sizable segment of the farm vote.

Edward Leo Delaney, 61 yearold American citizen, who was arrested on Aug. 8 by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation on a complaint charging that he had made treasonable broadcasts for the Nazi Government, was released yesterday.
To the blare of scores of military bands and the baton waving of pretty majorettes, 65,000 Legionnaires will begin their march up Fifth Avenue at 9:30 .A. M. tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- The State Department abruptly dispatched one of its highest-ranking officials to Greece today with orders to bring back a full report on "all aspects" of the unsettled conditions in that country.

PARIS, Aug. 28 -- Premier Paul Ramadier outlined today in grave terms before the press and the National Assembly France's disastrous wheat deficit, which led the Cabinet yesterday to reduce the bread ration to 200 grams a day.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 28 -- The structure of New Jersey's first major revision of its basic charter in 104 years was completed today when the Constitutional Convention, after sharp floor debate, adopted its compromise tax article on final reading.

The State of Pennsylvania plans to offer for sale an issue of $50,000,000 of institutional bonds at one time, according to advices received in municipal bond circles yesterday. Underwr.ting houses which had been expecting that the $50,000,000 borrowing would be marketed in installments are now reappraising the issue as a single offering. The financing will mark Pennsylvania's first issues of state | bonds since the soldiers' bonus issues of 1934.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., Aug. 28 -- The Buzzards from Wings Neck, Pocasset, Masa., were adjudged the winners of the twenty-third annual Sears Cup series for the national junior sailing championship at the conclusion of eight races today.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 28 -- The rapid spread of parent cooperative nursery groups throughout the country was reported today to the biennial conference of the National Association for Nursery Education.

HOLLYWOOD, Aug. 28 -- The consensus of authoritative persons here today was that the pact among motion picture industry unions in New York renouncing jurisdictional strikes for five years would have little effect on the situation here.

The American Legion will take over Madison Square Garden tonight. Members of the organization will be admitted free to the arena to watch the boxing program topped by a ten-round bout between Ray Robinson, holder of the welterweight championship of the world, and Flash Sebastian, Filipino battler who' is considered the best among the 147-pounders in the Orient.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 28 -- The Consolidated Electric and Gas Company applied today to the Securities and Exchange Commission for permission to retire $6,070,000 of 24 per cent bank loan notes on Sept. 30 with funds to be obtained through loans.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 28 -- Following is the text of a Brazilian resolution on the Egyptian question that failed by one vote of acceptance today by the United Nations Security Council: The Security Council, Having considered the dispute between the United Kingdom and Egypt, brought to its attention by the letter of the Prime Minister of Egypt dated 8 July, 1947.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L. I.. Aug. 28-Laurelton Hall, estate of the late Louis Comfort Tiffany, one of America's best known artists and co-founder with his father. Charles Lewis Tiffany, of the Tiffany Jewelry Co., has been contracted for sale to Mrs. Mary E. Smith for use as a 100-bed nursing home.

Last month a new husband and wife producing team, Kerry Stuart and John Wray, acquired "Exiles," the only play by the late James Joyce, for Broadway presentation in November. At the time, a spokesman for the couple asserted there would be no tampering with the original Joyce script.

DETROIT, Aug. 28 -- Although struggling unsuccessfully to keep abreast of a backlog of orders for more than 1,500,000 cars and trucks, the Chevrolet division of the General Motors Corporation disclosed plans today for a twomonth, multi-million dollar promotion campaign designed to bring the buyer back to authorized Chevrolet agencies for parts and repairs.
Four thousand boys and girls are now living in the children's village that is part of the British detention center on the island of Cyprus, 150 miles from Palestine.

CRESTVIEW, Fla., Aug. 28 (AP) -- Mrs. Margaret Irene Poland, British war bride, was freed today of charges in the fatal shooting of her American soldier husband. She planned court action to regain custody of their 16-month-old son.
T.E. White Jr. has been appointed national sales manager of Wilmington Hosiery Mills, Inc. Wilmington, Del. His headquarters will be in New York.

Gasper Carl, 9 years old, of 526 Third Avenue, who practiced at home on fried eggs and French toast, won the flapjack-flipping contest yesterday that marked the close of Roof Top Camp at Madison Square Boys Club, 301 East Twentyninth Street.

The Board of Estimate sent to its franchise bureau for study yesterday an application by the TriNboro Coach Corporation for permission to apply to the Public Service Commission for a higher fare on its lines in Queens.

HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 28 -- Rallying round the principle of freedom of the press guaranteed to the country by last year's Paris peace treaty draft, Finns of all political creeds except extreme Leftists are today rushing to the moral support of a small local publisher arrested last week for criticizing the Soviet Union.

LONDON, Aug. 28 (Reuters) -- Resolute hitting by Kent's middle batsmen saved the team from following on against South Africa today. When the last batsman was dismissed Kent was less than 100 short of South Africa'3 first innings total.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 5.000 head: total, 7.000 market active and generally 50 to 75 cents higher: top of $28 paid freely, bulk of good and choice 190 to 260 pounds.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Dr. Phillips Elliott of the First Presbyterian Church in Brooklyn, one of the seven Protestant clergymen who defended the Tito government's treatment of religion, makes two main points in his letter in the Aug. 26 NEW YORK TIMES.

Distribution of 1,200,000 new Manhattan telephone directories, each weighing four pounds, began yesterday. Paper shortage delayed the edition five months. Ordinarily new editions are published twice a year, in May and October.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 28 -- To give former holders of its common stock an opportunity to share in the company's large and unexpected profits, Callaway Mills of La Grange, Ga., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering' 123,306 shares of no par value common stock.

ROME, Aug. 28 -- President Truman and Pope Pius were believed in Vatican circles to have virtually pledged themselves to resist communism by all means at their command, in the letters they exchanged through Mr. Taylor.

BERLIN, Aug. 28 -- The United States and British Military Governments announced today an increase of nearly 50 per cent in the prices of export coal. The rises are designed to increase the income of the economically merged United States and British zones by about $4,500,000 a month.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 28 -- The question whether colonial powers should furnish information on "political progress" as well as social and economic data concerning their non-self-governing territories provoked a long argument in the United Nations today.

PARIS, Aug. 28 -- The European conference on the Marshall plan is expected to reach a crucial point Saturday when its Executive Committee will discuss its program with George F. Kennan, chief of the United States State Department's planning board, who arrived today.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 28 -- Contending that the Eightieth Congress "encouraged inflation" and that "there has been no sincere national effort to reduce prices," A.F. Whitney, national president of the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen, said here today that representatives of the five transportation brotherhoods would meet Sept. 8 in Cleveland "to draw up plans for wage increase demands."

CANBERRA, Australia, Aug. 28 (London Times dispatch) -- The permanent demilitarization and disarmament of Japan was urged at today's session of the British Commonwealth Conference here. The delegates also expressed the view that all armament manufacture, including the building of aircraft, warships and research into atomic energy, should be forbidden.

Dr. Vladimir Matchek, leader of Yugoslavia's Croatian Peasant party and former vice premier, denounced the regime of Marshal Tito yesterday as the "most communistic in the world after Russia." Interviewed at the Hotel Shelton the 68-year-old refugee who refused all overtures for collaboration with the Axis and now makes his home as an exile in Paris, made the following statements:

When the American Legion Convention Committee on Veterans' Housing meets in open session at 9:30 A. M. today in the Central High School of Needle Trades, 225 West Twenty-fourth Street, heated wrangling is expected to develop over the type of measures it will recommend to alleviate the housing shortage.

BUDAPEST, Aug. 28 -- It was admitted by a spokesman for the Hungarian Government today that some ten or twelve candidates for election on Sunday next had been disqualified by the device of dropping them from the voters' list without any right of appeal.

Following are the texts of the message from President Truman and of the addresses by Governor Dewey and Secretary James Forrestal at the "American Legion convention yesterday: President Truman Only the unremitting pressure of official duties prevents me from attending in person the twenty-ninth annual national convention of the American Legion.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 28 -- The 1,400 "non-operating" employes of the Union Railroad, a key unit in the operation of the country's largest basic steel producer, the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation, began a vote tonight to determine whether they will strike, if necessary, to obtain their contract demands.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 28 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie's estimated budget of $39,403,792 for the United Nations in 1948 should be cut by $4,108,098, the United Nations advisory committee on administrative and budgetary questions decided today.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Pitcher Joe Haynes of the White Sox won a twelve-inning victory over the Indians tonight, 4 -- 2, singling' home the run he needed for his tenth triumph of the season.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- The National Labor Relations Board will take affirmative action in virtually all important building and construction trade cases under the Taft-Hartley Act. It hopes, however, that the unions and their employers will evolve a voluntary plan to settle the vexing questions of jurisdictional disputes.

Utility Financing Possibility that the growing backlog of public-utility financing slated for after Labor Day might get off to a congested start by the marketing of big issues of the Detroit Edison Company and the Duquesne Light Company on the same day -- Sept.

The U.S.S. New Mexico, veteran of two world wars and the first United States battleship active in World War II to be broken up for scrap, is offered for sale to shipbreakers, it was announced yesterday. At present tied up at an Bast Boston, Mass., pier, the first flagship of the United States Pacific Fleet is being offered to the Junkman by the Navy Vessel Disposal Office, United States Naval Shipyard, Brooklyn.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Thirty-two youngsters swept through the first round of match play in the second national caddy golf championship today with only one upset recorded.

The cotton futures market was active and feverish on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday. After moving rapidly within a range of 25 to 32 points, it closed firm at about the best levels of the day, with net gains of 8 to 18 points.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 28 -- A member of the Chamber of Deputies, Jose Emilio Visca, has informed that body that he intends to introduce a bill that would call for strict censorship of the press.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- The new rules of the road in, the air, the new Part 60 of the Civil Air Regulations, will affect all flying when they become effective on Oct. 8, T.P. Wright, Administrator of Civil Aeronautics, said in a statement today.

Ending the bitterest debate in recent City Hall history, the Board of Estimate approved without dissent yesterday proposals of the City Planning Commission to improve the approaches to the United Nations site in midtown Manhattan at an estimated cost of $18,000,000.

OSLO, Norway, Aug. 28 -- Thirtyfive persons, including an unidentified American woman, were killed in a northern Norway air crash today when a Norwegian Flying Service hydroplane, flying to Oslo from Tromsoe, crashed against a mountainside near the Lofoten Islands.

LEGHORN, Italy, Aug. 28 -- United States soldiers here today said allegations of abuses of authority and mistreatment of soldiers recently published in the American press had caused a sudden improvement of conditions in some fields.

ANSONIA, Conn., Aug. 28 -- Mr. Bryant was born here on Jan. 8, 1873, the son of Edson Lewis Bryant and Mrs. Mary Elizabeth Clarke Bryant, being descended from early New England settlers. He practiced law in near-by Derby for many years.

SWA Persians Meet Strong Call Strong demand featured the auction yesterday of 110,294 SouthWest African Persian lambskins held by Eastwood Holt. There was 100 per cent sale, of the skins at an. approximate advance of 10 per cent over the levels of the firm's last auction in June.

SEOUL, Aug. 28 -- Continuing the wordy battle that has been raging between the United States and Soviet delegations to the joint commission, the chief Soviet representative, General Shtikov today issued a statement declaring that the Soviet delegation does not consider itself "guests" of either the American or Korean authorities of South Korea and implied that its members will continue to act and talk as they see fit.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- During the week ended Aug. 27, member bank reserve balances increased $86,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.
The Bronx Zoo and the Hebrew University, Palestine, have made a swap, it was learned yesterday. Nothing pretentious. Just an American alligator for three species of skinks.
ADRIANOPLE, Turkey, Aug. 24 (Delayed) -- From a wartime sanctuary for Jews and others fleeing German persecution, Turkish. Thrace has become today the refuge of those fearing Communist dictatorship.

The man of the hour in the United States' defense of the Davis Cup against Australia is John A. Kramer of Montebello, Calif. Yesterday Big John went out on the center court of ,the Forest Hills Stadium, scene of the international tennis action tomorrow, Sunday and Monday, and satisfied any doubts as to his readiness to fulfill the heavy role he la to play in the matches.

TOKYO, Aug. 28 -- Officials of Japan's Economic Stabilization Board today released their highly optimistic estimates for the nation's 1948 foreign trade. This forecast shows an adverse balance next year of only $28.000.00C against a 1947 deficit expected to approach $380,000,000.

GLOVERSVILLE, N.Y. Aug. 28 (AP) -- The Geraldine Novelty Company of Gloversville questioned today the standing of a Communistled union which won a National Labor Relations Board decision the day before the Taft-Hartley Law imposed conditions which the union has not met.
An extension of fifteen days was granted yesterday by the City Rent Commission for the filing of registrations by hotels and apartment hotels. The new deadline is Sept. 15.

The partly-demolished Aquarium building in Battery Park won a year's reprieve from total demolition yesterday when the Board of Estimate rescinded its action of July 24 appropriating $54,000 to enable the Park Department to tear down what is left of the old structure.

The rate of advance in the current seasonal upward movement of commercial, industrial and agricultural loans of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System was accelerated last week, the volume of such borrowings increasing 58,000,000 to a total of $4,378,000,000.

ATHENS, Friday, Aug. 29 -- In an effort to put back together almost the same Government that fell last Saturday, the leaders of seven political parties conferred in the Parliament building all day yesterday and half the night.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 28 -- Herman Barron of Fenway jumped into a two-stroke lead as the first round of the twenty-fifth annual 54-hole Westchester open championship was completed over the Gedney Golf Club course here today.

DETROIT, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Hal Newhouser, blond Detroit Tiger left-hander collared with an unimpressive record of thirteen victories and fifteen defeats this year after three straight "twenty-victory" seasons, drew a' $250 fine from Manager Steve O'Neill toda; for "indifference," and the stout pilot of the Tigers hinted there' be more like it if the Tigers "aren't in there hustling like they"should be."

CLEVELAND, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Fourteen planes flew qualifying runs for the National Air Races today, more than doubling the total of the first three days, as officials coupled demands for stepped-up activities with threats of disqualification.

It was many moons ago when the countryman first read Mr. Webster's ideas of a crab apple. The astute scholar who wrote a perennial bestseller by the efficacious expedient of placing words in alphabetical sequence gives two definitions: A small wild sour apple; an apple of a cultivated variety having small acid fruit.

Additional services for New York were announced by both domestic and foreign airlines yesterday, ranging from Pan American Airways' start today of its nonstop daily services to London to Capt. Eddie Rickenbacker's assertion that by raising its schedules from New York to Washington to thirty-two a day on Monday, the route becomes the busiest of any airline in the world.
LAHORE. India, Aug. 27 (Delayed) (London Times Dispatch) -- There are unmistakable signs that the plague of violence, whose victims are streaming east and west, is spreading in the Punjab.

LONDON, Aug. 28 -- The United States and Britain are to go ahead at once with their plan for raising the level of industry in their economically merged zones in Germany in spite of the failure of the tripartite conference here to remove French objections to the plan.

PETROPOLIS, Brazil, Aug. 28 -- Leading men of Brazil expressed great gratification today over the plans of President Truman to come to Brazil Monday and stay six days, at a time when he is carrying a heavy load on his shoulders in a world that refuses to settle down to peace and work.

The American Legion Distinguished Service Award, which in the last twenty-five years has been conferred upon only twenty-nine noted Americans, was presented yesterday afternoon at the Legion Convention in Madison Square Garden to Chief Justice Fred M. Vinson and Senator Edward Martin of Pennsylvania. It is an award for citizenship and for adherence to the ideals for which the Legion stands.

The Board of Education approved contracts yesterday totaling $5,500,771 for the construction of three more schools in its postwar building program at a meeting that marked the last official appearance of John E. Wade as Superintendent of Schools.

The Television Broadcasters Association sent a telegram yesterday to A.B. (Happy) Chandler, Commissioner of Baseball, urging that he authorize televising of the World Series in October. The TBA's action comes after reports of opposition by some owners of baseball clubs to the telecasts.

BERLIN, Aug. 28 -- The new level-of-industry plan for- the economically merged United States and British zones, which will be published tomorrow, will contain no important changes, despite the French protest, reports here tonight said.

Fewer than 10 per cent of the 1,454 Government-owned merchant vessels under charter to Americanflag steamship companies will be turned back to the Maritime Commission because of the adoption of a new system of bareboat chartering, it was declared yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 28 -- "Land of Promise," a 1914 play by W. Somerset Maugham, will be remade this fall by Paramount under the title "The Canadian" as one of eight films scheduled for production during the remaining months of 1947, the studio announced today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28 -- Representatives of the country's railroads and the seventeen non-operating unions concluded today before a six-man arbitration board their arguments for and against wage increases for toe approximately 1,000,000 non-operating employes.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug 28-No depression, not even a recession, is discernible on the business horizon, according: to Charles E. Wilson, president of the General Electric Company; who was here today en route to the plutonium, plant at Hanford, Wash., operated by his company under governmenet contract.

In the early days New York was the capital of the motion picture industry. Thomas A. Edison's work on the machines that helped make the movies possible was done in this vicinity. Most of the early "factories," as the studios were then called, were here. Now Mayor O'Dwyer is trying to woo some of the business away from Hollywood.

The United States liner America, carrying only about one-third of her passenger capacity, left Pier 61, North River, at 4 P. M. yesterday, eight days after her scheduled departure, which was delayed by a strike of longshoremen and seamen.

HISTORIANS of the future, looking backward with pity and shock upon the cruelty and violence,of the twentieth century, will not fail to note that the literature of our unhappy age kept pace with it. As. the speed and competition and insecurity of life increased and the variety of distractions and so-called amusements multiplied, books became more shrill and insistent.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., Aug. 28 -- Further industrial curtailment and a moderate drop in originating freight shipments explain the continued decline in business in the Pittsburgh district, last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research of the University of Pittsburgh.

BATAVTA, Java, Aug. 28 (UP) -- The Republican Government has decided to recall Foreign Minister Hadji Agus Salim from New York for a full report on United Nations Security Council action in the Indonesian dispute, the Jogjakarta radio reported today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Black market operations make it "difficult, if not impossible," for European nations to survey their food resources accurately, according to a confidential Agriculture Department report prepared for a Congressional investigating committee that sailed for Europe yesterday to make a first-hand study of foreign needs.

Improvement in luggage volume has continued since the trade show earlier this month, and the industry looks forward to Christmas sales that will exceed the volume of a year ago, spokesmen here said yesterday.

The United Aircraft Corporation announced yesterday the purchase for $20,000,000 of certain facilities financed for the corporation and three of its divisions during the war by the Government. The original value of the facilities was $56,000,000.

Bruno Walter, musical adviser of the New York PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra, will fly to London today on a ten-week concert tour of Europe. He will conduct the Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra at the Edinburgh Festival, concerts in Switzerland and Holland, and finally, the London Philharmonic Orchestra in England.

Locomotives shrieked, whales spouted and drum majors tossed their batons higher than the houses along Eighth Avenue last night as the American Legion's Forty and Eight paraded. Officials of the Legion's fun-making auxiliary set the marchers at more than 4,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 28 (AP) -- The Philadelphia. Phillies blanked the Pittsburgh Pirates, 7 to 0, tonight as Schoolboy Rowe pitched his thirteenth victory of the season against, nine defeats. The triumph advanced the Phils to within a few points or seventh place.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- President Truman and Pope Pius XII have pledged to each other to work together for lasting peace in the world.
LONDON. Aug. 28 -- An allround decline in prices of industrial shares was the reaction in the stock markets here today to the crisis cuts in motoring, food and travel.

Because veterans and their families constitute a majority, of the population of this nation today, a "staggering responsibility" rests upon the women of the American Legion Auxiliary Governor Dewey warned yesterday.

NANKING, China, Aug. 28 -- Thirty thousand Nationalist marines landed on Tuesday evening at the Communist-held port of Shihchiuso, sixty miles southwest of Tsingtao, in an amphibious operation preceded by an all-day naval bombardment of Communist defenses, the semi-official Central News Agency reported tonight.

The American Legion heard ardent appeals for universal military training yesterday from President Truman and the man frequently mentioned as his most probable rival for the Presidency in 1948, Governor Dewey.
SECURITY COUNCIL Rejected Brazilian resolution to refer Egyptian question to Britain and Egypt for direct negotiation. Council resumes discussion today at 3 P.M. (open).

Invoking provisions of the new Taft-Hartley Act, the Hanscom Baking Company has asked the National Labor Relations Board to hold three elections to determine whether its employes still want to be represented by the unions that called a strike against the company eleven weeks ago.

DUNDEE, Scotland, Aug. 28 -- Since the lifeblood of Great Britain is coal and since heat equivalent to 1,000 kilowatts can be obtained from a single gram of atomic "fuel," a large crowd gathered at today's session of the British Association for the Advancement of Science to hear Dr. J. D. Cockcroft, the first man ever to bombard atoms by artificial means. He discussed the possibilities of atomic power.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Two businessmen and a World War flier today announced organization of a "Draft Elsenhower for President League." They said they represented a group composed of Republicans and Democrats.

A. nation-wide organization of women sales specialists was started with the appointment of Patricia Playter and Ruth H. Levy as regional promotion managers, it was announced yesterday by Anthony B. Cassedy, director of appliance sales of the Yale and Towns Manufacturing Company.

The stock market plodded through another inconclusive session yesterday, with price changes narrow, final quotations mixed and a slight loss in the composite rate despite the fact that more issues ended higher than showed gains. Business rose slightly on the Stock Exchange to 580,000 shares, against Wednesday's volume of 480,000 shares, which was the dullest in three years.

Apprentice brick mason programs are under way in 329 communities, where nearly 8,200 veterans and other young men already have registered, Roy A. Shipley, president of the Structural Clay Products Institute, reported yesterday. The joint apprenticeship committees, composed of employers and local unions, have been formed in all but five of the states, Mr. Shipley said.

GUATEMALA, Aug. 28 -- The Inter-American Women's Congress must be considered a success because sincerity was its dominant note, the chairman, Miss Gumersinda Paez, said yesterday in a closing address.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The Attorney General's investigation of the high cost of living should be nrimarily concerned with prices of food, clothing and shelter. The ever-present grocery bill, the recurring rent bill, and the needed clothes, especially for growing children, consume the greater part of the worker's wages, and bring home to the housewife the crushing impact of soaring living costs.

Applicants for city housing jobs, who had been asked by the City Housing Authority whether they would accept appointment at a. salary $200 below the advertised annual figure, were informed yesterday that those who are appointed will get the full salary, $2,000 plus a $660 cost-of-living allowance.
CHICAGO, Aug. 28 (AP) -- At least half the persons who consult physicians have complaints which have an emotional rather than physical origin, Dr. Joseph. T. Wearn of Cleveland reported today.

The Board of Estimate authorized the New York City Housing Authority yesterday to build 5,768 apartments in the five boroughs, to rent at $12.50 a room a month to families for whom neither public nor private homes now are being built.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 28 -- The Resolutions Committee of the Polish National Alliance went into session behind closed doors today and delegates resumed deliberations over fiscal affairs of the fraternal insurance plan.

A warrant for the arrest of Samuel Fishkind, 28 years old, of 1225 Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn, was issued yesterday by Judge Louis Sobel in Kings County Court when he failed to appear in answer to an indictment charging him with sixteen, counts of grand larceny.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 29 -- The proposal of Dedham Water Company of Dedham, Mass., to sell $150,000 of first mortgage bonds and 3,830 shares of its $100 par value capital stock was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

PETROPOLIS, Brazil, Aug. 29 -- The Argentine delegation threw a hitch in the projected Treaty of Rio de Janeiro today with a restrictive amendment. But after the hottest debate of the Inter-American Defense Conference here, with the United States and Argentina squarely lined up against each other, a compromise was reached tonight.

Maybe it's the Flatbush air that causes the Giants to freeze when they cross the bridge for a visit to Ebbets Field. Whatever the reason, a familiar story emanated last night from Brooklyn, where the New Yorkers have won only one game this season.
The 10,000-mile three-month training cruise of the New York State Maritime Academy's training ship Empire State ended yesterday afternoon as the former Navy craft anchored off St. George, S.I.

Two armed men held up the South Brooklyn Savings and Loan Association office at 188-21 Linden Boulevard, St. Albans, Queens, at 1:30 P.M. yesterday and escaped with $9,800. Five hours earlier another hold-up pair took $5,125 from the operator of a check-cashing service on the Lower West Side and eluded a police radio car cordon.

In a long day overheated with many controversies the Board of Estimate received some more bad news on transit when another private bus company in Queens had the ill grace to report that it was losing thousands of dollars on the five-cent fare. Counsel for the Triboro Coach Corporation, which serves an area with a population of half a million persons, put its loss in the first five months of this year at $52,000.

Holiday Monday All financial and commodity exchanges in the United States and Canada will be closed on Monday in observance of Labor Day with the single exception of the Minneapolis Cash Grain market, which will operate for a few hours.

A small package wrapped in brown paper was delivered by express early yesterday afternoon to Herschel V. Johnson, deputy United States Representative on the United Nations Security Council, at his apartment at the Hotel Savoy-Plaza, Fifty-ninth Street and Fifth Avenue.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 29 -- Four steps to meet a national crisis in child care were outlined here today by the Planning Committee for Young Children in its report to the biennial conference of the National Association for Nursery Education.

GENEVA, Aug. 29 -- A considerable lightening of the atmosphere surrounding the Geneva tariff talks was noted in several key quarters today. The change is due to a number of concrete facts and some more important intangibles.
Following are the texts of the addresses by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Gen. Carl Spaatz and Admiral Chester W. Nimitz at the American Legion Convention yesterday:

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 29 -- Summonses and complaints were served here today on Westchester County officials in the suit brought by four New Jersey motorists, represented by counsel for the Automobile Club of New York, for an injunction against continuance of the Saw Mill River Parkway toll collections that were begun yesterday.
LAKE SUCCES N.Y., Aug. 29 -- The United Nations should coordinate the overlapping programs of its specialized agencies, Dr. George F. Davidson, Canadian representative, declared here today.

Many young people from institutions operated by the Jewish Child Care Association and others living in foster homes under its sponsorship have a real opportunity to acquire the finest educations obtainable through the association's provision of school and college scholarships.

Large contingents of the delegates to the American Legion convention have passed a quiet, pleasant two days and anticipate an equally quiet, pleasant week-end. With but a relatively few Legionnaires tormenting women and snarling traffic, many of the World War I and II veterans yesterday saw New York, frequented theatres and restaurants and visited cultural centers.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 29 -- Qualifying tests for the National Air Races, which begin here tomorrow and run through Labor Day, brought forth speeds today better than that which won the Thompson trophy race last year.

FORT COLLINS, Col., Aug. 29 -- The world food situation is so critical that Americans must decide whether to eat less at home to insure peace abroad, Stanley Andrews of the Agriculture Department asserted today.

Warning that the world has divided into two great camps of dictatorships and democracies, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower told the American Legion yesterday that the friends of freedom everywhere must stand staunchly in its support, or its foes would eliminate freedom from the earth.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Steelers of the National Football League turned in a surprising 24-17 victory over the Green Bay Packers tonight in a pre-season exhibition game which drew more than 31,000 fans. It was the first time the Steelers ever defeated their league rivals.

BOSTON, Aug. 29 -- The ancient Boston elevated railroad system, which carries about a million commuters daily, passed from private to public ownership today. The newly created Metropolitan Transit Authority paid $20,297,490 in cash to the directors of the Boston Elevated Railway Company for the system.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The Boston Braves moved to within a half-game of the second-place St. Louis Cardinals tonight as Bill Voiselle held the Phils to eight hits to hand up his fifth straight victory. His mates socked Ken Heintzelman, Charley Schanz and Fred Schmidt for seventeen safeties and an easy 9-2 triumph before 12,369.

Because of continued strong demand and critical scarcity of the merchandise, furniture retailers are accepting with little protest price increases of 10 to 15 per cent recently imposed by several solid mahogany bedroom and dining room producers, a case goods buyer for a leading department store disclosed yesterday.

Sidewalks of New York These dog days of late August have found many New Yorkers sitting on chairs on the sidewalks -- along Second Avenue, for example, where the street is lined with shops and tenements.

Creation of a Central Government Exchange Mart by the United States was suggested here yesterday by Fred J. Emmerich, vice president of Block International Corporation and vice chairman of the international trade section of the New York Board of Trade, as a step which may facilitate both export and import trade of this country and aid in straightening out the current foreign exchange confusion.
BERLIN, Aug. 29 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay. United States Military Governor, said tonight that the Ruhr coal discussions requested by France would begin here next week.

BERLIN, Aug 29 -- The United States and British Military Governments in Germany announced today their detailed plan to raise the industrial output of their economically merged zones to virtually the 1936 standard. In addition, the plan called for a IS per cent increase in exports from that area over the 1936 figure and an increase in the German standard of living to approximately 75 per cent of that prevailing in 1936.

Arrival of new crop turkeys is lagging far behind the amount usually received in Eastern markets at this season as Western growers, dissatisfied with current Eastern prices, are holding their stock for better prices later in the season, representatives of large turkey distributing companies here reported yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The burning question of Europe's displaced and homeless millions has not yet called forth in this country any far-sighted, boldly-conceived solution. Self-styled pro-American groups shudder at the mention of an expanded immigration quota.
Support for a powerful American merchant marine for both peacetime and emergency needs will be urged in resolutions completed yesterday by the American Legion sub-committee on the industry.
BERLIN, Aug. 29 -- The text of the Revised Plan for the Level of Industry in the United StatesUnited Kingdom Zones of Germany.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- President Truman plans to address a joint session of the Brazilian Legislature next Friday at 2 P. M. (E.S.T.), the White House announced today. He will address the Inter-American Defense Conference Tuesday.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 29 -- A recommendation that the Federal Government subsidize families to strengthen the bonds of home life was made today by the Rev. Edgar Schmiedeler of Washington, a member of the faculty of Xavier University's Family Life Conference.

When every penny counts, as it has to when food costs almost twice as much as it did in 1939, small economies may be made in purchasing groceries by keeping your eye on changing market supplies. Right now, for example, the pullet-size eggs are abundant, and will continue to be so through September.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 29 -- Registrations covering $40,000,000 of debentures, $4,500,000 of bonds, 175 shares of convertible stock and 273,500 shares of common stock were filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the three companies.

Vinton Freedley, who was a member of the New York group of theatre people witnessing the Dallas performance of Tennessee Williams' "Summer and Smoke," remains intensely interested in having something to do with its Northern production. Mr. Freedley, still without a commitment on the script, has suggested to Margo Jones, who first produced and directed it in Texas, that he would like to be associated with her in a Chicago presentation, Miss Jones to direct.

As workers inside the building kept on their jobs in an effort to complete them within the scheduled time, Borough President James A. Burke of Queens laid the cornerstone yesterday morning for the new branch store of Macy's New York at Eighty-ninth Avenue, between 164th and 165th Streets, in Jamaica.

The first instance in which a labor union invoked the Taft-Hartley Law to punish a sister union for unfair labor practices developed yesterday when the United Telephone Organizations opened a double-barrelled attack against Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, AFL.
ATHENS, Aug. 29 -- King Paul swore Constantin Tsaldaris into office tonight as Premier with a Cabinet of ten Populists, including himself as Foreign Minister, and one independent.

The latest report from Ducks Unlimited on the waterfowl situation in the Canadian breeding grounds is far from optimistic, but the over-all picture will not be clear until the survey of the northern areas, now under way, is completed.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Aug. 29 -- Gov. Earl Warren announced today that he would call a "general crime conference" with the Federal Bureau of Investigation participating, to discuss plans for dealing with a so-called invasion of California by Eastern racketeers and gangsters.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- Despite different views by some members of the National Labor Relations Board and the opposition of some union leaders, it was learned today that Robert N. Denham, general counsel of the NLRB, would not alter his ruling that officers of parent labor organizations must sign anti-Communist affidavits before any of their constituents or affiliates might have cases processed by the board.

LONDON, Aug. 29 -- Prospects of further severe cuts on national living and a budget in the fall kept business at a low ebb in the stock markets here today. There was not a great deal of selling, but wide price changes were quoted and it was difficult to deal in large amounts of stock.
