LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 29 -- A sixteen-man United Nations committee dealing with information from non-self-governing territories today adopted a Soviet proposal to include data on native participation in local government in reports concerning territorial health, labor, education and agriculture.

PARIS, Aug. 29 -- France will attempt to persuade the United States and Britain that the Ruh industry level plan fosters a dangerous war potential in machinetools. The French say this plan provides for a 224 per cent increase in aggregate machine tool production over the figure authorized in the Big Four agreement of March, 1946.
MADRID, Aug, 29 -- Manolete, greatest of all contemporary bull fighters, died early this morning of wounds inflicted by a bull yesterday in a fight in Linares, southern Spain.
The churches have arranged special services of welcome tomorrow for members of the American Legion, its auxiliary and relatives and friends of the Legionnaires who remain in town over the weekend.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 29 -- Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, turned down today a blueprint for the operation of an international atomic agency. He said it was based on principles that would give the United States a virtual monopoly in the atomic field.

The Brooklyn Citizen, a daily newspaper in Brooklyn since 1886, announced yesterday that it was ceasing publication. A front page statement, signed by David McLean, publisher, said the step had been forced by rising costs.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 29 -- In an effort to get its seven picketed ships unloaded without further delay, the Luckenbach Steamship Company today awarded to the Pacific Stevedoring and Ballasting Company a contract for handling all stevedoring work of the steamship line in the bay area.

New York State's equal pay law is making a material contribution to the industrial health of the state, it was reported yesterday by the State Department of Labor, following a "test area" survey. The law, which prohibits discrimination in wage rates for men and women doing the same work went into effect July 1, 1944.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- A special committee of Federal officials reported today that ammonium nitrate fertilizer, the explosion of which caused the Texas City (Tex.) diaaster last April 16, could be transported "with reasonable safety" aboard marine vessels.

Legion Cold-stream Cards, the water-pistoleers, performed in Times Square yesterday like naughty small-fry in the Saturday night tub. Singly and in nests, on fixed posts and in roving cabs, they laid down a water "barrage that kept the local populace under an all-day and all-night shower.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 29 -- Richard F. Walsh, president of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes, AFL, denied before the House Labor subcommittee today that his organization was a "company union" of the major movie producers or that jurisdictional encroachments by it had precipitated the present strike of APL craft-union members in the film studios.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Landing on Ellis Kinder for six hits and four runs in the sixth inning, the Detroit Tigers downed the St. Louis Browns tonight, 5 to 4.

As retiring head of the New York public schools, Superintendent John E. Wade has earned his rest from the labors of administering the world's largest municipal educational system. His last official meeting with the Board of Education on Thursday capped a notable career of nearly fifty years of service to the youth of this city.

GENEVA, Switzerland, Aug. 29 -Members of the United Nations Special Committee of Inquiry on Palestine said tonight that the committee's report to the United Nations General Assembly would Call for the termination of the British mandate in the Holy Land at the earliest possible moment.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 29 -- A $100,000 winner-takeall special race between the King Ranch's Assault and the Calumet Farm's Armed, under the same conditions as the meeting that was to have taken place at Washington Park tomorrow, has been proposed for Belmont Park on Saturday, Sept. 27.

BUDAPEST, Aug. 29 -- Disfranchisement of a number of voters unofficially estimated at more than 1,000,000 had become the chief and sorest issue in Hungary today. In fourteen Budapest flistricts with 645,873 voters, the Small Landholders party estimated 139,905 had been disfranchised and 113,444 had appealed but only 35,833 had been reinstated.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 20 (AP) -- A Bahamas skipper, Durward Knowles of Nassau, piloted his Gem II to an easy victory yesterday in the second of the five-race series for the international star class yacht racing championship.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange in August dropped to the smallest total of any month since April of 1944, it also was the dullest for a corresponding month in five years, or since 1942. Sales were below the million-share mark in every session with trading dropping to the smallest in three years for a full day's session on Aug. 28 on a turnover of 475,880 shares.

BATAVIA, Java, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The Netherlands Indies Government, listing for the first time the areas that it considers officially "occupied," by Dutch "police action" outlawed the authority of the Indonesian. Republic today in the most important economic districts of Java, Sumatra and Madura.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- Two aircraft landing systems were among the 422 inventions for which patents were issued this week by the United States Patent Office.

After the sightseers and visitors had followed the last celebrity out of the Seventy-first Regiment drill hall late yesterday afternoon the delegates to the American Legion Convention settled down to a discussion of business.

A move to get him to oppose Herman Talmadge in 1948 as candidate for Governor of Georgia was described in an interview yesterday at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn, by the Rev. Joseph A. Rabun, ousted pastor of the McRae Baptist Church, McRae, Ga.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- President Truman today directed Secretary of the Interior Krug to assist the United Nations Economic and Social Council to prepare for an international conference on the utilization and conservation of natural resources.
BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Aug. 29 (AP) -- A wild tale of five holdups and two kidnapping's within two days was unfolded today as two sailors and an ex-convict were jailed on charges of seconddegree assault.

"House Party," presently under cooperative sponsorship on the CBS hook-up, will return to General Electric's advertising budget exclusively Dec. 1 as something more than a $1,500,000 item, it became known yesterday. The program was introduced Jan. 15, 1945, under the product banner of the electric company, whose subsequent withdrawal left the show to the supporting revenue of cooperative sponsorship.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: If the world, under the leadership of the United States, is willing to make a major effort to readjust the European economy for the sake of world economy it cannot be concerned with the factors of production and distribution alone.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 29 -- "Call Northside 777," Twentieth Century-Fox's semi-documentary treatment of the Chicago Majczek affair, which was postponed last March because of scenario trouble, is now scheduled for the cameras in mid-September, with James Stewart, Richard Conte and Lee Cobb heading the cast.

Cardinal Spellman emphasized the importance of the spiritual aspects of the nursing profession, as exemplified by the sacrifice and devotion called for in practice, in addressing 167 graduates of St. Vincent's Hospital School of Nursing at commencement exercises yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

With grape production this year in the neighborhood of 3,000,000 tons and with carryover of both wines and raisins preventing diversion of much of the surplus through these channels, the fresh fruit industry in New York is preparing to move large quantities through trade channels here, the Fresh Fruit and Vegetable Council of New York announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission has before it requests from steel companies to make the Southern Pacific and the Santa Fe Railroads parties to the case involving reduced rates on steel of 48 and 54 cents a hundred pounds from Geneva, Utah, to Pacific Coast points.
GENEVA, Aug. 29 -- Discouraging reports of world food supplies for the coming winter continue to pour in.

Piet H. Hofstra, regional administrator of the Office of Rent Control, said yesterday that area rent directors and their staffs have been able, by "strenuous effort," to achieve a current status on tenant complaints and landlord petitions.
BROKEN BOW, Neb., Aug. 29 (AP) -- A Department of Agriculture economist forecast today that American consumers would get about 5 per cent less meat next year -- and perhaps pay higher prices for it.

VAN NUYS, Calif., Aug. 29 (AP) -- Twelve converted warplanes, tuned to the finest degree, were under lock and key at Metropolitan Airport tonight as their pilots awaited the take-off tomorrow morning in the $25,000 Bendix trophy race to Cleveland.

CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 29 (AP) -- Brookfield Farm's I Declare beat Going Airy by two lengths in the six-furlong Adolescent Handicap at Garden State Park today. Going Airy was a nose in front of Frantie's Bid, the one to receive the most support from the crowd of 17,039.

Ray Robinson, world welterweight champion, required only two punches to dispose of Plash Sebastian of Manila in the free boxing show for members of the American. Legion at Madison Square Garden last night.
Omens of a new spurt in meat prices next week were seen yesterday by students of the market's trends.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 29 -- The Polish National Alliance ended its quadrennial convention today after unanimously adopting a resolution urging immediate enactment of a law to permit entrance into the United States of 100,000 displaced persons.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 29 -- The last, longest and richest of the Spa's over-the-jumps stakes, the $10,000 added Saratoga Steeplechase Handicap, went today to Thomas T. Mott's Floating Isle. The Battleship gelding beat Miss Ella Widener's Iron Shot, winner of the race in 1942 and 1943, by about a length and a half.

CANBERRA, Australia, Aug. 29 -- An apparent agreement on an economic program in Japan that would achieve the Allied objectives and at the same time permit Japan to sustain herself was reached in the British Commonwealth Conference here today.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 29 -- Drs. Charles W. Bauer and William F. Martin of the Massachusetts College of Pharmacy at Boston, reported to the convention of the American Pharmaceutical Association that studies made by them show that some causes of skin eruption may be due to sluggish starch digestion.
The heaviest Labor Day traffic in peacetime years moved in and out of New York yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The State Department, out of patience with the breakdown of negotiations between the United States and the Soviet Union, today proposed a four-power conference for setting up a united independent Korea.
Details of bond financing proposals aggregating $108,600,000 were announced yesterday by Massachusetts, Pennsylvania and Connecticut.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Eight youngsters swept into the quarter-finals of the second national caddy golf championship today, with Bub Worsham of Washington, D.C., brother of National Open Champion Lew Worsham, assuming the role as No. 1 favorite.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Robert T. Oliver in his letter published in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Aug. 15 tried to discredit my report on Korea to THE TIMES by stating that I have had a "personal feud" with Dr. Syngman Rhee and Kim Koo for twenty-five years.

The stock market broke out of its narrow trading range yesterday, and without the benefit of any increase in volume prices advanced from fractions to as much as 2 points or more. The extreme gains generally took place in the thin-market and high-price issues, however, as the composite rate advanced only 0.92 point on the day.

Retail Sales Drop Off Metropolitan New York department store sales showed a decline this week of 1 per cent as compared with the corresponding week a year ago, according to trade estimates yesterday. This was attributed to the end of the vacation month and approaching Labor Day week-end and to low stocks.

PARIS, Aug. 29 -- Reflections of United States State Department officials on the work of the European conference on the Marshall Plan and those of United States emissaries who have been following it on the spot were compared today at a meeting in the United States Embassy here.

LA GRANGE, Ga., Aug. 29 -- Fifty-one patients who have survived malignancies for five to ten years -- living proof that cancer is not a hopeless disease -- got together here yesterday for what is believed to be the first cancer reunion ever held.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 29 -- The United Nations is planning to release ten typewritten pages of the recommendations of the Palestine inquiry committee for publication in Monday morning newspapers. It is planned also to release at that time twenty pages of the Council's plans for the future status of Palestine.

The research committee of the Broadcast Measurement Bureau has decided not to recommend to the bureau's board of directors acceptance of the offer by C.E. Hooper to associate the bureau with "The Listener Coverage Index," it was announced yesterday.

The music-makers of the American Legion shied away from the Times Square area yesterday and sweated it out in bright sunlight in competition for national championships in the Legion. Nearly every state in the union was represented by a band or drum and bugle corps in competitions that began at 8 in the morning and did not end until nearly midnight.

Following the pattern of recapitalization plans of other members of the industry, the Heyden Chemical Corporation of New York, one of the largest producers of penicillin and synthetic organic chemicals for industrial uses, informed stockholders yesterday of plans to raise between $6,000,000 and $10,000,000 through the sale of preferred stock and debentures.

LAHORE, Pakistan, Aug. 27 (Delayed) -- Passengers from New Delhi to Lahore on "The Frontier Mail" have had a front-line tour today of the religious war of Hindus, Moslems and Sikhs in the Punjab border territory of India and Pakistan.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The United States note to Russia, calling for a four-power conference, and the United States proposals on Korea follow: In your letter of Aug. 23, 1947, to Secretary Marshall the position of the Soviet delegation to the joint commission has been set forth in terms which corroborate a recent report received by this Government from the United States delegation to the joint commission.

A proposal to change the name of the Financial Advertisers Association to the Financial Public Relations Association will be acted soon at the group's thirty-second annual convention, Oct. 5 to 9, it was announced yesterday. Six hundred financial advertising and banking executives are expected to attend the sessions at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

LONDON, Aug. 29 -- Resisting the heaviest possible pressure from the State Department in Washington, the British Government so far has refused to alter its-decision to withdraw all its troops from Greece in the near future, it was learned authoritatively today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that farm parity prices hit a new peak in the month ended on Aug. 15.

PETROPOLIS, Brazil, Aug. 29 -- The Inter-American conference in its plenary session today declared unanimously that the hemispherc security, which it has now almost completed, shall not be used as excuse for an armaments race between the American states.

Owners of the Yorkville Casino, an East Side meeting hall, have taken legal steps to obtain title to about two square feet of land under the middle of their building that, apparently, they do not own, it was disclosed yesterday.

DETROIT, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Although Bandleader Guy Lombardo's Tempo VI has been withdrawn, there will be plenty of speed and competition in the Silver Cup speed boat regatta opening on the Detroit River tomorrow.

BOSTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Behind the three-hit pitching of Mickey Haarris, who turned in his first complete game of the season, the Boston Red Sox tonight celebrated 'Birdie Tebbetts Night" by defeating the Philadelphia Athletics, 2 -- 1, before 34,083 cash customers who swelled the total for fourteen night games at Fenway Park to 463,822.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- State taxes yielded $6,800,000,000 in the 1947 fiscal year, an increase of 12.5 per cent over the $6,000,000,000 collected in the previous year, the Census Bureau reported today.

DUNDEE, Scotland, Aug. 29 -- Developing the theme of its meeting, "Swords and Plowshares," the British Association for the Advancement of Science turned today to the possibilities of radio in meteorology and astronomy. The principal speaker was Sir Edward Appleton, the first to observe that radio waves were reflected by planes.
There cannot be another World War it Great Britain and the United States are determined not to have one and will plan accordingly, Sir Ian Fraser, commander of the British Legion, declared yesterday.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Aug. 29 -- Disturbed by the charge that they were impugning the United States Government, defense counsel in the I.G. Farbenindustrie trial this afternoon sought means of retiring as gracefully as possible from their original position that the defendants had signed affidavits under duress.

A blue-sky, white-cloud day of August is a good time to observe the bark patterns of trees. When high cumulus clouds roam like flocks of sheep between sun and earth the soft light emphasizes the intricate details of the bark and makes an etching of the main limbs and small twigs.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 29 -- The Patriotic Order Sons of America pledged itself today to crusade against "the red threat" in a resolution adopted at the closing session of its hundredth anniversary convention.

As the American Legion marches today in the great parade that is the convention climax we shall see some of the frivolities that, go with an uproarious good time give way to the orderliness of discipline, the somber warnings of convention speakers translated into the symbolic readiness of military formation, confusion yielding to the call of the marshal's command.

Bonds called before maturity for payment in August totaled $121,153,000, the smallest amount for any month since March, when $68,766,000 was retired, and the lowest figure for an August since 1943, when $63,233,000 was redeemed. The month's total compared with $420,286,000 in July last and with $447,901,000 in August, 1946.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs. 5.000 head, total, 7.000. Market very slow; 190 to 250 pound hogs steady to mostly 35 cents lower; heavier weights and sows uneven, 50 to 75 cents lower; top $28

LONDON, Aug. 29 (Reuters) -- Hampshire and Lancashire tied in their county cricket match at Bournemouth today. It was only the fourth tied match in the last twenty-one years of the county championship -- but the second this season.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The Supreme Court was asked today to rule that a public school board must pay for transportation of pupils to Catholic parochial schools.

A 30-year-old probationary patrolman still attending classes at the Police Academy emerged from a hiding place in a Broadway delicatessen store last night and shot and killed a hold-up man who, the police said, was attempting to rob the store for the second time.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 -- Preston T. Tucker, president of the Tucker Corporation, said tonight that the company's capital-raising campaign has been a success and "Chicago is now assured of its first fullfledged auto manufacturing company." He predicted the first cars to be sold to the public will be produced after the first of the year.

It's John Kramer against Dinny Pails and Ted Schroeder against John Bromwich in the opening two singles matches of the Davis Cup challenge round between the United States and Australia at Forest Hills today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- President Truman transmitted to Congress today a report of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration for the first quarter of 1947 showing that Poland had received the greatest amount of the UNRRA relief as of March 31.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 29 -- The United Nations Security Council plunged into a deadlock on the Egyptian question today after having rejected a Colombian resolution to return the dispute to the two parties for direct negotiation.

A determined effort to win the American Legion's support for the Taft-Ellender-Wagner housing bill will be made tomorrow on the national convention floor, Legion adherents of the bill declared yesterday. Equally determined opposition will be offered by its opponents, including members of the Legion's standing committee on housing.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 29 (U.P.) -- An American naval landing party fought with guerrillas when they went ashore in Chinese Communist territory yesterday to search for a missing naval fighter pilot, the United States Navy announced today.

Governor Dewey's advocacy of universal military training in his speech at the national convention of the American Legion on Thursday was said yesterday to indicate his intention of publicly expressing his opinion on controversial issues before next year's Republican National Convention, at which he will be a candidate for the nomination for President.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Aug. 29 -- The Netherlands Government announced today that it had accepted the offer of the Security Council of the United Nations to aid in ending Indonesian strife. The Government said it would grant to consuls of the United Nations powers in Batavia all facilities for carrying out their task.

Temporary banning of imports of raw furs by Great Britain, except through special license, will have long-range bearish aspects but little immediate direct effect on the trade here, according to views in the industry yesterday.
SALEM, N.H., Aug. 29 (AP) -- Rockingham Park was authorized today to run an "emergency" nineteen -day race meeting to accommodate horses quarantined by an epidemic of "swamp fever" at the track.

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 29 -- Off on the Stamford Yacht Club's Vineyard race, a fleet of sailing craft left from the breakwater here tonight. It is an annual event over the Labor-Day holiday that makes up one of the longest of the year's contests, instead of just an over-night whirlaround.

The voice of the American Legion -- its bells and whistles, bands and sirens, popguns and water pistols -- almost drowns out the din of the world crackling over the wires into Times Square. The shouting of the erstwhile captains of the AEF of 1917 overwhelms the faintly condescending wisecracks of the young GI's of yesterday.

LUEBECK, Germany, Aug. 29 -- The Military Government will level whatever legal charges can be developed against Haganah ringleaders among the 4,300 Jewish immigrants who attempted to enter Palestine on the Exodus 1947 and who are now being shipped to the British zone, Maj. Gen. W.H.A. Bishop, Deputy Chief of Staff on the Control Commission, said today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (U.P.) -- The Army is 80,000 men under strength and new enlistments are running 25 per cent short of the number required for bare replacement of dischargees, it was disclosed today.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 29 -- The twenty-fifth annual Westhester open championship ended in a tie at the Gedney Golf Clulb today.

PARIS, Aug. 29 -- The press, radio and film experts discussing the technical needs in mass media fields in Europe and Asia decided today to recommend to the next general conference of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization that a fund equivalent to $24,000,000 be raised to purchase newsprint for needy countries.
While their more fortunate comrades were parading the avenues and cavorting around this "seaport town," one group of nearly a thousand veterans of the A.E.F. had virtually no part in the celebration.

ROME, Aug. 29 -- The exchange of letters between Pope Pius XII and President Truman was expected today in circles conversant with Vatican aims and programs to give new impetus to the Catholic Church's relentless efforts to attain a post-war settlement based on Christian principles.

Campaigning for the highest prize in the American Legion, the post of national commander, reached its peak yesterday as other candidates still in the running fought to offset the formidable lead piled up by James F. O'Neil, Manchester, N.H., candidate.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 -- Grain markets on the Board of Trade continued to work higher today. Wheat closed slightly under the best prices but with net gains of 1 1/4 to 3 cents a bushel. September made a new high record for that delivery and the deferred months went to new seasonal tops.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The Department of the Interior disclosed today tentative plans to establish an all-weather seaport at Fire Island, near Anchorage, Alaska.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 29 -- Touro Synagogue here, which is the oldest building of its kind in this country, will be dedicated as a national historic site Sunday at 1 P.M., with Joseph W. Martin Jr., Speaker of the House, scheduled to deliver the principal address.

MANILA, Aug. 29 -- A master plan for changing the Philippines from an agricultural to an industrialized economy with an expenditure of 3,000,000,000 pesos over a period of fifteen years has just been made public.
Although the American Legion's fun-makers, the Forty and Eight, officially ended their convention yesterday, there was no sign that they were folding their tents.

MANILA, Aug. 29 -- A master plan for changing the Philippines from an agricultural to an industrialized economy with an expenditure of 3,000,000,000 pesos over a period of fifteen years has just been made public.
Although the American Legion's fun-makers, the Forty and Eight, officially ended their convention yesterday, there was no sign that they were folding their tents.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 29 -- Some $50,000 worth of diamonds were stolen from the Diamond Trust in Tel Aviv today in two closely coordinated hold-ups. One of the batches of gems had just been prepared for shipment to the United States.

SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Edward Furgol, a prominent campaigner out of Pontiac, Mich., and two young comers from the Southland shattered par by five strokes today to take a first-round lead in the $12,500 Western open golf tournament.

The futures markets for cotton closed last night until Tuesday morning. Trading operations on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday had a pre-holiday character and failed to show any definite trend. Prices fluctuated over a range of 20 to 25 points, but the market was influenced easily by small orders either way in the form of evening up contracts and there was little in the news to encourage any activity.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 29 -- Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg told the Brazilian Senate and House today that those who suspected ulterior motives in the writing of the Inter-American security treaty merely confessed to their own motives.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- President Truman virtually completed today the organization of the new national military establishment with the filling of six key posts in the unified defense system, including those involving the National Security Council, National Security Resources Board and the Munitions Board.

TRIESTE, Aug. 29 (AP) -- A spokesman for Bishop Antonio Santin of Trieste and Capodistria said today that the recent killings of two priests in Yugoslav-occupied Venezia Giulia and the grave injury to a Vatican prelate were part of a Slav campaign to "disintegrate the Catholic Church."

In a two-hour session yesterday the board of trustees of the Police Pension Fund retired 100 members of the department and increased the annual pension of former Second Deputy Police Commissioner Francis J. Kear by $2,000.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Baseball Commissioner A.B. Chandler today told Pacific Coast League directors and supporters of the circuit's plan to become a big league: "You haven't had major league baseball out here in over 40 years.

The Yankees, whose one aim these days is to wind up the American League pennant race in a hurry, last night advanced one step closer to the world series berth that is generally conceded to be their inevitable destination -- but had to work overtime to register this progress.

AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The champion Cleveland Browns picked up momentum in the second half to swamp the Baltimore Colts, 28 to 0, in an All-America Football Conference exhibition before 33,106 fans in the Rubber Bowl tonight.
MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 29 (AP) -- Four airmen and a fuel-less seaplane sizzled on blistering Caribbean islands today while the United States Coast Guard meditated up on the definition of "emergency."

OFFHAND you might think that what this want-haunted world needed least was another novel satirizing Hollywood. But, such is the waywardness of justice, that's precisely what it's been given. And a good one at that -- "Dirty Eddie,"* by Ludwig Bemelmans (the author with the chef's hat). Mr. B. is a tranquil satirist.

Placing his stamp of legality on the proceedings and giving approval to the findings of the courtmartial, Rear Admiral Monroe Kelly, Commandant of the Third Naval District, announced yesterday that Chief Signalman Harold E. Hirshberg had been sentenced to serve ten months in a Naval prison, after which time he is to be dishonorably discharged from the service.

Investment banking operations in August were at the slowest pace in a year and in marked contrast with the large volume of flotations in previous months of 1947. New bond financing was the smallest since September, 1946; stock offerings the least since June, 1945.

Successful operation of an atomic power plant of revolutionary design, using for the first time fast, instead of slow, neutrons for liberating nuclear energy from Plutonium at a controlled rate, was announced yesterday by Dr. Norris E. Bradbury, director of the Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory at Los Alamos, N.M., where the atomic bomb was developed.

SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 29 -- It was learned here today that the United States representatives would not reply to the most recent statement of Col. Gen. Terentyi F. Shtikov, head of the Soviet delegation, on the joint commission, in which he charged the Americans with complete responsibility for the deadlock of the commission's negotiations.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Dons outlasted the Chicago Rockets, 24 to 21, in a see-saw battle which opened the All-America Football Conference season before a paid crowd of 41,182 at Soldier Field tonight.

LONDON, Aug. 29 -- The Soviet Union has ratified the peace treaties with Italy, Hungary, Rumania, Bulgaria and Finland, the Moscow radio announced tonight. The Presidium of the Supreme Soviet has issued the ratifying decrees, according to the broadcast announcement.

Early reveille started thousands of Legionnaires out of profound slumber in Manhattan's hotels at 6 o'clock yesterday morning. They moved sleepily through a lowering dawn toward the parade take-off point on foot, in cabs, by subway and in buses.

Facing the Crisis The British crisis, however painful to the British, is furnishing a beautiful example of the working of free government. Everybody, including the rank outsider, is having or has had his say. Mr. Churchill blames the Labor Government, the Labor Government blames the weather, the editor of The Economist would spread the blame thin, over a whole generation.

LONDON (By Wireless). AFTER what has happened to them during the last two years, do the British people feel disappointed? The answer is that they do. But I hasten to add that other peoples feel disappointed too -- Americans, Russians and most Europeans. For example, the world is now full of frustrated young couples who passionately want houses of their own and cannot find them.

NOTRE DAME -- Science Laboratory A long-range scientific experiment was started last week at the University of Notre Dame when a selection of biological specimens was enclosed in the cornerstone of the new Laboratory for Germ-Free Life. According to an announcement there, the specimens will be observed and studied by scientists "when the building, which is expected to be utilized for more than 200 years, is razed."
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 30 -- A. Livingston Gump, art dealer, who was an authority on jade and Oriental art, died of a heart attack last night at his desk in his store here. He was 77 years old.

FORT COLLINS, Col., Aug. 30 -- While Government voices are appealing for a tightening of the American belt to send more food abroad, American farmers already are thinking of the possibility of tremendous surpluses which could threaten the agricultural economy.
SEVEN different languages were spoken by children in one schoolroom last year. Now their teacher wonders, "Why didn't I get their mothers to come and teach us a few words, or one of their songs?"

Willie Turnesa, holder of the British amateur championship and member of the United States Walker Cup team that successfully turned back Great Britain, remains the lowest handicapped player in the Metropolitan Golf Association. According to the revised listing for some 130 amateur clubs, released yesterday by the M.G.A., the Knollwood ace is still rated at plus-one, the only one to hold that honor.

EDDIE CANTOR, while in town last week on a visit, contended that if it is true that people stop listening to the radio in the summertime it is only because radio has stopped entertaining them. Broadcasting, in this respect, errs to its severe disadvantage, he said, pointing out that no showman would even remotely consider shuttering a successful Broadway production just because hot weather had set in.

HIGHMOUNT, N.Y., Aug. 30 -- President Truman in a message read today before the national convention of the Agudath Israel Council, praised the organization's activities "for inspiring American youth with high ideals and a keen sense of civic responsibility."

ROCKPORT, Mass. -- No one in this briny paradise seems to have thought of it, but a good advertisement for Rockport might be: "Cape Ann must be the loveliest spot on the New England coast -- even the glacier stopped here."
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Aug. 30 -- A colorful 45-year Army career will end here tomorrow for Gen. Jonathan Mayhew Wainwright, 64, hero of Bataan and Corregidor.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 30 -- The importance of coal in the manufacture of steel is pointed up once again by complaints from the steel industry of lowered production because of reduced coke shipments.

ONE of the summer's more interesting experiments comes to a highly successful close this week-end up at Green Mansions, a vacationists' camp near Warrensburg, N.Y. Here, for the first time, so far as available records show, a resort of this type has added to its entertainment schedule a concert dance company giving a weekly program of its own, along with the revues and variety shows which are more usual in recreational, centers.

New York City's Police Department, not overlooking the slightest detail in the American Legion parade to assure a minimum of casualties and traffic snarls, achieved those aims yesterday to the high praise of Mayor O'Dwyer and ranking Legion officials.

THERE are at least two fortunate aspects of the British film tax in so far as Hollywood is concerned. First, it comes at a time when the American industry is best able financially to absorb the potential loss in revenue, and, secondly, it may well force our studios into a sound dollar economy.

Generally when an affiliated group of corporations has elected to file consolidated income tax returns, the same form of return is required to be filed in subsequent years. One of the exceptions to this rule is where a new revenue act is enacted or where the law has been so amended as to reduce or eliminate the benefits from filing consolidated returns.

SEPTEMBER starts tomorrow and the New York music season opens on Friday. Each year, it seems, the first recital treads a little closer on the heels of Labor Day. Gone is the lull until October. And this season the first starters are not just stray, early birds.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Presidential politics showed up as an important aspect of Senator Robert A. Taft's forthcoming Western tour today in a schedule of the trip announced at his offices here.

Hotel men began to take stock last night, as the American Legion convention drew to a close, of the effect of the Legionnaires' merrymaking on their furniture and fixtures. The first reports from hotel circles about damage and loss were conflicting.

Illustrating the economic principle that to export it is also necessary to import, the import division of the Westinghouse Electric International Company has shown a steady gain in volume each month this year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- President Truman led off today's Labor Day statements by asserting that good labor relations "cannot be brought about by legislation." His statement was followed by that of Secretary Lewis B. Schwellenbach and others.

Advances in the prices of coal and steel have not set off a sharp spiral of general price inflation as many expected, the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents reported yesterday. The full impact on prices of advances in these commodities has not yet been felt, particularly in fabricated items, it was found.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The House Committee on UnAmerican Activities described the Civil-Rights Congress today as a Communist "front" organization engaged in "a campaign of vilification against the American Government."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The new directive of the United States Government on the Military Government of Germany of July 15, 1947, superseding JCS 1067/6 of April 26, 1945, has the purpose, among other things, of integrating our occupation policies in Germany into the framework of the Truman Doctrine and the Marshall Plan.

The current high costs of raw materials and labor will continue to be reflected in the prices of new homes and the shortages will continue to make it difficult to find a suitable house for several years to come, in the opinion of Charles F. Haring of the firm of Haring Grant, Inc., Westchester County builders.

MOSCOW, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Central Soviet press organs hailed today Soviet ratification of the peace treaties for Rumania, Hungary, Bulgaria, Finland and Italy as a major step in organizing peace, and made it clear Moscow considered three of the five ready to take their place in a new society that would little resemble pre-war times.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 30 -- On the tail of a storm which shattered the National Air Races program, and some of its planes on Cleveland's airport, Paul Mantz, last year's winner, dragged the field spectacularly just before 8 o'clock this afternoon to win again the Bendix Trophy Race.

The most interesting and perhaps the most important diplomatic development of the week was the ratification by Moscow of the peace treaties with Italy, Rumania, Bulgaria, Hungary and Finland. Russia was thus the last of the powers involved to approve the treaties; the action of Rumania and Hungary in accepting the pacts ten days ago was an indication that the Soviet approval was on the way.

IN the course of a recent tour of some seven major art colonies, concerning which comment has appeared in these columns on two successive Sundays, I was repeatedly struck with a brisk quickening in the department of promotion and sales.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Professional football, All-America Conference variety, officially opens its season here tomorrow in a game between the Brooklyn Dodgers and the San Francisco Forty-Niners.

ALTHOUGH Broadway is always within convenient earshot of the Wailing Wall, not all the dismal facts are imaginary. Never has a season opened against greater odds than the one that will officially start the new ledger on Sept. 3 with the premiere of "The Magic Touch."

WICHITA, Kan., Aug. 30 -- Kansas farms, once well over the brink of bankruptcy, have become debtless, solvent and an income tax collector's headache. In the Thirties their total cash income from crops and livestock hit a low of $179,000,000; this year it promises to exceed the billion-dollar mark for the first time.

CHICAGO -- A color negative material called Kodak Ektacolor Film, which eliminates two important steps in color print making, was introduced by the Eastman Kodak Company here last week at the fifty-sixth annual convention of the Photographers Association of America.

ATHENS, Aug. 30 -- Loy W. Henderson, chief of the State Department's Office of Near Eastern and African Affairs, arrived from Washington by plane this morning and devoted the day to conferences with Ambassador Lincoln MacVeagh and Dwight P. Griswold, director of United States aid.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30 -- The Institute of Design, founded here in 1937 with twenty-five students by the late Laszlo Moholy-Nagy as the New Bauhaus, has rounded out its first decade with an enrollment of 700, its own building and an impressive board of directors numbering many industrialists.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Spy Song unpredictable 4-year-old colt owned by Charles T. Fisher of Detroit, defeated his arch rival, William Helis' Rippey, in the $26,750 Chicago. Handicap before 28,000 spectators at Washington Park today, pulling down $17,750 for Dixiana.

A LARGE apparatus has gone into the making of the new recording of Rachmaninoff's choral symphony, The Bells (Disc, four twelve-inch records), and your judgment as to whether it was worth the effort will depend on how highly you value this work.

To say at the present time that American education is moving into a great period of development and regeneration necessitates a close look at trends as well as facts and figures. In general, the broad trends warrant optimism even though a few hard facts are proving stubborn.

PETROPOLIS, Brazil, Aug. 30 -- The Treaty of Rio de Janeiro for hemispheric security was formally and unanimously adopted by the delegations of the nineteen nations in the Inter-American Conference here a few minutes before 5 P.M. today.

After Labor Day, an influx of buyers is expected to check on slow deliveries of orders placed in June and to seek to replace such undelivered merchandise, according to the weekly market report prepared especially for The New York Times by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buyers.

PARIS, Aug. 30 -- With a grave economic crisis staring France in the face, it was announced today that Premier Paul Ramadier would appear before the National Assembly Monday to give a frank statement on the situation.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 30 -- Waterfront union chiefs conferred this afternoon with Charles de B. Haseltine, head of the Pacific Stevedoring and Ballasting Company, in another attempt to end the tie-up of seven cargo-laden ships here of the Luckenbach Steamship Company.

The grim specter of death has been cheated twice by Mrs Katherine Grimm O'Dell, 71 years old. She said yesterday that twice within four years she had fully believed the end was near, because of a chronic cardiac condition, but she had escaped by doing chores and now was too busy crocheting rugs "to die."

HOLLYWOOD. FRANK CAPRA'S current film project, "State of The Union," will reach the starting line at MetroGoldwyn-Mayer within two weeks with a budget of $2,600,000, according to the producer-director.

A new rent schedule for Brownsville Houses in Brooklyn, one of the city's thirteen low-rent public housing projects, was announced yesterday by Thomas F. Farrell, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority.

Potato flour for use in bread baking has taken a sharp upturn in demand, though the movement is independent of crop conditions affecting other flours, it was reported among leaders in the grocery trade here yesterday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates moved to within two games of sixth place today by humbling the Chicago Cubs, 8 to 5, and spoiling Chicago's celebration of Stan Hack Day. The victory gave Pittsburgh a 13-6 season's edge over the Cubs.

PARIS, AUG. 30 -- After what was described as "strong pressure" from United States officials, the Executive Committee of the European conference on the Marshall plan decided today to summon the technical committees of the conference Monday and to instruct them to cut drastically their estimates of Europe's needs for the next four years.

PARIS, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Doris Duke, the tobacco heiress, is planning to be married next week, the consulate of the Dominican Republic, said tonight. The bridegroom will be Porfirio Rubirosa, former son-in-law of President Rafael Trujillo of the Dominican Republic.

And U.S. Defense The American Legion is an organization of 3,325,000 veterans. About 1,025,000 of them served in World War I; their average age to 52. About 2,300,000 served in World War II; their average age is 29. Last week 42,000 registered Legionnaires and many others who didn't bother to register -- hit New York for the Legion's twenty-ninth annual convention.
History will repeat itself this week when veterans of World War II, like their brother veterans eleven years ago, will cash in service bonds paid to them by the Government.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 30 (U.P.) -- Ambushers, officially described as Arabs, wounded a senior British police officer and the British wife of a police sergeant today in an attack at Beit Dajan, near Lydda airport.

A study of Negro health conditions conducted by Dr. W. Montague Cobb, Professor of Anatomy, Howard University Medical School, for the national health committee of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, 20 West Forty-second Street, declared that the two existing Negro medical colleges are not meeting the community needs of the population.

THE family of Karl Wolfskehl had resided in the Rhineland since the days of Charlemagne. As a German poet and philologist, Wolfskehl has been deeply attached to German civilization, yet he has never failed to acknowledge his Hebraic heritage and his spiritual bonds with Zion.

A search for means to avoid recurrent business depressions through plans for action with "a background of Christian principle" is proposed in the annual Labor Sunday message of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America, to be read from Protestant pulpits today and next Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The Dostert translation system, initially used at the Nuremburg trials, will be employed for the first time in Washington at the International Statistical Conferences, which open next Saturday.
IT was reported recently in this column that the leading tournament bridge players in the East have taken to using the Blackwood convention, which for so many years they had disdained.

FANWOOD, N.J., Aug. 30 -- Mrs. Eva L. Van Hoesen of 145 North Avenue, an authority in the field of horticulture and a lecturer and writer on the subject, died today at Muhlenberg Hospital, Plainfield, N.J., after a long illness at the age of 71.

IF Ben C. Clough, the editor of this joyously muscular anthology of Americans real and not-so-real, had ever heard of Frank Jawbone, the Kippewa moose-killer, he would have given Frank a paragraph -- or, at least, a fat footnote, even though the man is Canadian. Every Saturday night Frank wore a solid gold medal five inches across that said: "Frank Jawbone" on one side, and: "World's Best Shot" on the other.

EGLIN FIELD, Fla. THE Florida chambers of commerce won't boast about this, but the truth must out -- a Florida skunk almost died recently in his native habitat when he was exposed overnight to a temperature of 70 degrees below zero.

THIS is a meditation on M. Jean-Paul Sartre's new novel, the translation of which was published here under the title "The Age of Reason" [reviewed July 13]. M. Sartre being himself a philosopher, I suppose he would wish me to meditate, to follow my thoughts through to the final conclusion, however dismaying.

THE New York Flute Club with 200 members has been in existence since 1920, when it was founded by the late Georges Barrere. Yet the public knows little about the group, for its activities have been kept on a club basis.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Vern Stephens singled to left, scoring Paul Lehner with the run that gave the Browns a 3-to-2 ten-inning victory over the Tigers tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The export trade of the United States is the principal economic peg on which the hope for European recovery hangs. At the moment, that trade is at the highest level in history and if sustained over a long enough period would provide Europe with the food, machinery and materials it needs to get its own productive capacity going.

THE story of frequency modulation broadcasting since the war has been one of disheartening delay and frustration. At every hand the greatest improvement in radio reception in years has been hampered and hamstrung by a succession of incidents in which the public interest has not been considered properly, if at all.

BUDAPEST, Aug. 30 -- The Hungarian Government said today that the entire public opinion of the country had received the news of the ratification of the Hungarian peace treaty with "extreme joy" and that "on the day before the elections Hungary has regained her sovereignty and independence."

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 30 -- A sudden possibility of a settlement of the eleven-month jurisdictional strike of affiliates of the American Federation of Labor in Hollywood film studios materialized late today, interrupting the Congressional inquiry into the strike.
CHICAGO, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The Big Nine next week launches preparation for the 1947 football championship race and one of its most active campaigns against intersectional foes in recent years.

Two new contracts, Involving more than $4,000,000 in ship reconversion and construction, have been awarded to the Ingalls Shipbuilding Corporation, of Birmingham, Ala., it was disclosed yesterday. One contract calls for reconversion work on four C-3 type cargo vessels, and the other for the construction of four motor vessels.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The General index of basic commodity prices based on the August, 1939, level rose from 305.6 on Aug. 25 to 306.1 on aug. 27, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. The following lists daily index numbers and spot market prices:

This last week rank and file Legionnaires with their uninhibited pranks and Legion leaders with their ominous warnings on national defense gave New York and the nation many things to laugh at and to ponder over. The activities of both groups were spectacular and received widespread attention.

The American Legion convention and the approaching Labor Day holiday were major influences affecting business trends here last week. Despite the Legion gathering, department store sales were estimated at slightly under the like week of 1946.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Aug. 30 -- With canvas bellowing in a breeze not nullified by city heat, the Long Island Sound sailing fleet had real going today in the seventy-ninth annual fall regatta of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club.

TO such unofficial titles as "greatest living photographer" or "master of the new photography." Edward Steichen recently added a new official title: Director of the Photographic Department of the Museum of Modern Art. As the new curator of the museum's collection of great ptotographs, Mr. Steichen was asked to select six of the great pictures from the collection.

Formation of national and international professional associations of workers in the field of public opinion research will be considered at the Second International Conferance on Public Opinion Research this week, Dr. Clyde W. Hart, chairman of the executive committee of the conference, said yesterday.

CAZENOVIA, N.Y., Aug. 30 -- Young adults of America and Britain expressed similar views on most points in a two-way radio broadcast discussion of "How Can We Build Faith in Democracy?" opening-day feature of the State Conference of New York State Young Adults sponsored by the State Department of Education and the New York State Community Service Council.

PARIS, Sunday, Aug. 31 -- More than fifty persons were believed to have been burned to death and approximately 200 injured when a motion picture theatre in the Paris suburb of Reuil was destroyed by fire last night.
With September only a day off, the time has arrived to check over your guns and hunting equipment and decide what last minute repairs and replacements are necessary before the season opens.

Secular as well as religious history is being recalled in the three-day celebration at Newport, R.I., of the designation of Touro Synagogue as a national historic site. For the early struggles of its congregation and the lives of its members were closely associated with the nation's own struggle for independence and growth.

Although the Giants got twice as many hits, the Dodgers outscored their interborough rivals, 3-1, yesterday at Ebbets Field and stayed on the course that evidently is leading toward Brooklyn's first pennant since 1941.

More than $1,000,000 worth of post-war radar equipment has been installed aboard eighty-one vessels since the first of the year, it was reported yesterday by George F. Shecklen, executive vice president of Radiomarine Corporation of America.

FALL, is the best time of the year in which to renovate an old lawn. It can be revived if at least 60 to 70 per cent of it is grass. However, an understanding of why renovation is necessary is essential if the job is to succeed.

AT first careless glance one might wonder why the author of "How to Cook a Wolf" and other books of culinary exoticism should try her hand at fiction. Strictly speaking. Mrs. Fisher has not produced a unified narrative.

ARTHUR MILLER'S recent eloquent plea for a subsidized theatre was a distinct relief. It found an echo in the hearts of many theatre people who have long shared that dream. It was particularly gratifying to those who have had a hand in previous efforts in that direction, to have the value of such an effort recognized by a playwright, and a newly successful one at that.

LABOR DAY no longer means the end of the vacation season. With more resorts remaining open through September and activities such as fairs and harvest home festivals scheduled by local communities, indications are that the fall will be a lively time for vacationists.

The Gdynia-America liner Sobieski arrived here yesterday with Joseph L'Heureaux, American consul general at Marseille, France, and one of the "founding fathers" of the American Legion, along with 754 other passengers, including his wife and their three children.

EDGEFIELD, S.C. PICKIN' time is, as it always has been, the cotton South's most festive season. It is a gala season even in years when the crop price is bad and cotton an impoverished king. This year, with the price of cotton high, pickin' time recaptures something of the legendary spirit of the Old South.

Arnold Frederick Kivi, accused of the theft of "highly confidential photographs" from the Los Alamos, N.M., atomic installations, consented yesterday to his removal to Santa Fe, N.M., to face the charges.

MURRAY, Utah, Aug. 30 -- America's traditional pastime of horseshoe pitching has gone modern at last. The National Horseshoe Pitching Tournament, to conclude here tomorrow, is being held in a trim, cement-surfaced arena illuminated by giant floodlights and surrounded by comfortable steel bleachers.

SALEM, N.H., Aug. 30 (AP) -- Breaking on top of the thirteenhorse field, J.L. McKnight's Agrarian -U held the lead all the way today in winning the $10,000 added Rockingham Park Handicap, feature of the closing day program of the summer meeting which was blighted by an epidemic of swamp fever among the thoroughbreds.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Wheat advanced today to new seasonal high marks on the Board of Trade, the September contract reaching $2.57 a bushel, but the best prices were reduced toward the close. Prices were reduced toward the close.

The two reconverted LSTs, owned by Trailerships, Inc., continue to ply between here and Albany "untainted" by cargo. They were designed to carry loaded trailers between the two ports, but union, difficulties have kept them cargoless.

A fight on the floor of the American Legion convention today over adoption of the Foreign Relations Committee report is forecast by the filing of a minority report by delegates from Midwest and Mountain states, traditionally inclined toward isolationism.

ROBERT FLAHERTY, the grand old man of the documentary movement, today finds himself in one of the roost fruitful creative periods of his highly productive career. He has just completed more than a year's work on "The Louisiana Story," a dramatic fantasy about a Cajun boy in the Bayou country, which he is now editing in New York for a late Fall release.

Crowded with championships for a variety of sizes, shapes and power of speed boats, the crescendo of mile-a-minute dare-deviltry that has been building up all summer will swing into a finale for most of the month of September, starting with an unusually heavy Labor Day week-end.

HERFORD, Germany, Aug. 30 -- Three Eastern European countries are recruiting in the western occupation zones of Germany former German air force pilots, it was learned today. Senior British Intelligence officers corroborated reports that the countries were the Soviet Union, Yugoslavia and Czechoslovakia.

MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 30 -- Dollar Volume of department store sales in Minneapolis, St. Paul and Duluth and Superior, Wis., sagged again in the final week of the August heat wave. For the four weeks ended Aug. 23, sales were 98 per cent of the figure for the same period in 1946.
ALL of the provisions of the TaftHartley Act are now in operation. The two months since its passage have been marked by a variety of reactions from labor and management alike.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30 -- Two Chicago newspapers, Col. Robert R. McCormick's morning Tribune and William Randolph Hearst's afternoon Herald-American, proved to their own exuberant satisfaction during the past ten days that they could make rain by sowing dry ice pellets in cumulus clouds from high-flying airplanes.

The latest news from the Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory seems to bring us nearer to the day when the force that devastated Hiroshima and Nagasaki can be domesticated for peaceful uses. Director Norris E. Bradbury and his associates have paradoxically succeeded in slowing down the emission of energy from fissionable material by using fast instead of slow neutrons.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Aug. 30 -- With a total of sixty-five players, including forty in the championship section and twenty-five in the three groups of the general tournament, the annual meeting of the New York State Chess Association gained an auspicious start in the large convention hall of the country club of the International Business Machines Corporation this afternoon.

GRASS is often taken for granted in the belief that it grows anywhere of its own accord and without any encouragement from gardeners. This may be true on deep rich soils of the prairie country but it is not so on the shallow, nutrient-poor and acid soils of the East.

OTTAWA, Aug. 30 -- If and when Canada is invited to adhere to the Rio de Janeiro pact pledging its signatories to united defence against aggression anywhere in the Western Hemisphere the business of drafting a reply will, it is admitted here, present the most difficult and harassing diplomatic problem this country has yet had to face since it assumed the direction of its own foreign relations.

BERLIN, Aug. 30 -- Maj. Gen. Alexander G. Kotikov, Soviet Commandant in Berlin, lashed out today at a press conference at what he called the "anti-democratic forces" in the four power Kommandatura. He asserted they "repressed the will" of those seeking the socialization" of the industries in the former German capital.

Lefty Joe Page, the peerless relief hurler of the Yankees, chalked up his third victory in as many games yesterday when Johnny Lindell cracked a single to left in the last half of the ninth Inning to score George Stirnweiss with the winning run in a 6-5 battle between the Bombers and the Senators at the stadium.

Construction of the first two of a group of six "Industry Engineered Homes" at the University of Illinois for the purpose of developing methods of reducing the cost of home building was reported by Tyler S. Rogers, president of the Producers Council.

RECENTLY the head of this house had occasion to reenter the library after an antic absence of a decade or two. There had been some changes, which for the most part were more picturesque than encouraging. A copy of Bartlett's "Familiar Quotations" had disappeared, for example -- and was found later, holding down a wayward corner of the kitchen linoleum.
With a handful of its pre-war stars and with one of its lightest schedules in years. Fordham's football squad will hold the opening drill of its fifty-sixth gridiron season Wednesday.

ATHENS, Ga., Aug. 30 (AP) -- Senator Walter F. George of Georgia declared today that Russian "obstruction" would continue to balk world cooperation, and recommended the early conclusion of separate peace in Europe and the Far East, regardless of Soviet views.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 30 -- Some recovery was registered in retail sales throughout the Twelfth District during the past week. Gains of from 1 to 15 per cent were reported by larger stores in every area with the exception of San Francisco which was down 1 per cent as compared with the same period a year ago.

HERE are essays on a variety of matters by an author to whom many on both sides of the Atlantic owe something for "The Concise Cambridge History of English Literature." His essays illustriously represent a department of letters in which American authorship is now giving a rather poor and niggardly account of itself.

ADULT-driver training is rapidly becoming one of the major factors in the nationwide efforts to reduce automobile accidents. Among the organizations engaged in campaigns to emphasize the responsibilities that rest with the man or woman behind the wheel are the Automobile Club of New York, the Greater New York Safety Council and the National Safety Council.

THERE are textbooks in American Government aplenty, but this is a book designed to give a simple account of the American Government for the average American citizen. It is written by a man immersed in American Government and politics, the son of Charles A. and Mary R. Beard.

Communism and Labor Headquarters of the National Labor Relations Board in Washington last week mailed out to unions throughout the country copies of the following form to be signed by union officials: The United States of America

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 30 (AP) -- The greatly strengthened Buffalo Bills open the 1947 All-America Football Conference season in the East tomorrow, facing last year's divisional champions, the New York Yankees.

THIS seventh edition of "Modern Chess Openings" succeeds the sixth pre-war edition edited by Reuben Fine. The new editor, Walter Korn, is known for articles of opening analysis in the British Chess Magazine, but his achievements as author and player are negligible compared to his predecessor's.

IT'S time, observed Tecumseh the other morning, that all this yammering about a slowstarting fall season on his favorite street was put to rest. It's just not so, he says. For instance, he points out, there have been laments in some quarters that this passing August failed to boast an opening and that's supposed to be an indication of things to come.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 30 (AP) -- A couple of youngsters 16-yearold George Allmon of Kansas City, and 17-year-old John Bernard of Columbus, Ohio, will battle it out over thirty-six holes tomorrow for the second national caddy golf championship.

TSINGTAO, China, Aug. 30 (AP) -- A new landing of Chinese Government forces on the Shantung coast was reported in pro-Government dispatches today as increasing land, sea and air activities pointed to a campaign designed to clear the important Shantung peninsula of Communists.

IRONICALLY, the names of the two most dreadful Nazi concentration camps, Buchenwald and Birkenau, remind you of beautiful trees, namely, of beeches and birches. The latter camp, officially termed Oswiecim II, actually was a death factory to which chiefly those unfortunates were sent who were not considered fit to produce weapons for the Wehrmacht at near-by Oswiecim I.

With this year's corn yield expected to be almost one billion bushels below the record crop of 1946, the export shipments of cereals over the next ten months must be maintained at a level which will not damage the nation's economy.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 30 -- A gloomy picture of the United Nations, its prestige and its outlook was drawn today by Faris el-Khouri of Syria. It came as a "farewell statement" after Mr. el-Khouri had served for a month as President of the Security Council during the unsolved Balkan, Egyptian and Indonesian cases.

PROBABLY no single group in America has taken more steady abuse, both real and literary, than the poor whites of the South. They have stood patiently under the literary microscope, all the way from the lewd chuckle of Erskine Caldwell's novels to the tender Christianity of James Agee's.

PEIPING, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Sighing with relief, the bedragrgled onetime ruthless chief of the Nazi Gestapo in North China and Mongolia was hauled from an earthen pit under an old Peiping house by Chinese police today in the climax of a two-year hunt.

CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 30 -- Picnic Lunch took the $10,000 added Rancocas Stakes at Garden State Park today. Treated to a splendid ride by Harrison Wilson the filly went off the turn the leader by a slight margin, and added to her margin as she sped to a four-length victory in the sixfurlong event before 33,592 spectators.

Eastern Canadian lumber mills and housing interests are sending trucks across the border to haul purchases of white pine in "substantial" quantity from American mills in Northeastern New York State, R.E. Broderick, executive secretary, Northeastern Lumber Manufacturers Association, revealed last week.

LONDON, Aug. 30 -- The Yorkshire coal miners strike potentially the most explosive factor in Britain's present economic crisis, seemed well or the way to settlement tonight as the Government and labor leaders prepared to invade the area and appeal to the workers to return to the pits.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The bench and bar throughout the world solved long ago the procedural problem of how to keep peace and maintain the status quo between parties who are threatening to reson to self-help or violence in support of alleged rights.

WE have profited by a peek at the page proofs of the fourth edition of Claire Reis' "Composers in America," which will issue from the presses of Macmillan in midSeptember. This edition presents, of course, many more names of composers, biographies, lists of works published, unpublished, recorded and publicly performed, than any of the preceding (the first of which made its appearance in 1930).

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The text of President Truman's Labor Day statement follows: Labor Day offers us a yearly opportunity to pay tribute to the contribution the free working men and women of the United States have made to their country's progress, prosperity and world leadership.
Election of James F. O'Neil of Manchester, N.H., is new national Commander of the American Legion appeared virtually assured last night.

In Crucial Phase In the Grand Palais in Paris last week the first detailed script for the Marshall Plan was being edited into final form. The authors, representing sixteen European nations and their 218,575,000 inhabitants, are delegates to the European Conference of Economic Cooperation.

LONDON. HAPPY is the man these days who has braved both the British clime and a gyrating economy and has still had the fortune to come out smiling. Such a one is Paramount producer Hal Wallis, who sailed for America Aug. 27 with his picture, "So Evil My Love," completed on schedule and within budget.

WHOEVER described General George S. Patton Jr.'s forthcoming, "War As I Knew It" (Houghton Mifflin) as a very personal story was apparently not -- as the late Ring Lardner used to say -- groping for words.

Stock prices coasted along last week in the dullest trading in some time. With the month of August ended, there was not a millionshare day in the period, and the transfer of 480,000 shares on Wednesday was the slowest for a full session in three years.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 30 -- Three students, two American and one British, arrived in Helsinki today after having been held in custody by the Russians for three weeks in the Porkkala enclave in Finland. Their yacht, the Seashark, had accidentally entered Porkkala waters, a Soviet prohibited area.

BERLIN, Aug. 30 -- Marshal Vassily D. Sokolovsky, Soviet Military Governor, bitterly attacked the United States and British Military Governments control council meeting today for having announced yesterday sharply revised levels of industrial production for the bizonal area, which he said violated the 1946 four-power agreement.
The scenery was different and the time was eight months later, but it was the same act as in Melbourne last December.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (U.P.) -- The National Council for Prevention of War accused the American Legion tonight of "trying to scare Congress into hasty action" on universal military training.
The heaviest week-end automobile travel in the history of the city was reported yesterday. Trains, airplanes and buses also carried an unusually large number of passengers to and from New York.

TO THE EDITOR: Thanks are due James F. Bender for his catalogue of female abilities in "Man's World or Woman's?" But they do not add up. We still end up in a man-made world. Any woman could tell you why in a free translation of I Corinthians, Chapter xiii:

Sea-Change REVOLT against conventional bonds and restraints is most noticeable, of course, on the lower levels of American speech; in the regions above there still linger some vestiges of Eighteenth Century tightness.

CONSCIENTIOUS gardeners have pretty well completed transplanting iris by midsummer, but it is easy to forget that oriental poppies are another perennial that demands attention. Since the plants disappear almost entirely after their splash of color in May and June, they are frequently neglected.

The interest of Furness, Withy Co. in Bermuda has not been diminished in the least by the recent disposal of some of the company's holdings in Bermuda hotels, according to Henry Smurthwaite, United States director of the company.

A coordinated social studies program combining geography, history and civics has been recommended for use in elementary schools by the Division of Elementary Education of the New York State Education Department.

September is a savory month, full of tang and color. Neither summer nor autumn, it partakes of them both. But particularly it has the sight, the sound, the smell and taste of ripeness and fulfillment. Apples redden, and grapes turn purple, and the earlier pears begin to color.

Editor New York Times Book Review: IN my short review of "The Balkans" I had no wish to cast aspersions on Mr. King's knowledge of that area per se. I merely intended to suggest that, since his first-hand knowledge dates from the end of the war, he has been predisposed by official distortions of the past to blame too much of the "distastefulness of Tito's communization" on the "ruthless official persecution" of Alexander's regime.

GENEVA, Switzerland, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Delegates to the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine said tonight that Paul Mohn, a Swedish alternate delegate, had proposed a compromise on boundaries for the proposed partitioning of Palestine between Arabs and Jews.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Aug. 30 -- The worried, anxious population of the Netherlands was told by Dr. van Mook, in a broadcast from Batavia today, not to expect much in the way of results from such devises as the "ceasefire" order and the "good offices" of foreign powers.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The Boston Braves, battling for second place in the National League, whipped the Philadelphia Phillies, 3 -- 2, today as Red Barrett hurled four-hit ball in a game cut to eight innings by rain.

FOR THIS WEEK: Dust lima beans and the second crop of bush beans with rotenone regularly against Mexican bean beetles. . . . Continue to spray roses every week against black spot. Fermate, bordeaux mixture or a threepurpose spray will help. . . . Because of hot weather leaves are falling early from many trees.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The House Small Business Committee, that only last year investigated cooperatives and gave them a clean bill of health, has set out, under its new management, to do the job all over again.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 30 -- Quality ruled in the first all-breed exhibition of the Lenox Kennel Club, held today on the grounds of Fox Hollow School, making up for the fact that the show ran under a 400 total.

LAHORE, Pakistan, Aug. 27 (Delayed) -- More than a million members of the famous bearded Sikh sect are holding grimly onto their homes and holy places in the Moslem Dominion of Pakistan in constant fear of raids by Moslems who have their Sikh villages surrounded.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- A new Congressional war investigating committee was introduced to the public this week as a possible permanent successor to the ill-fated Senate War Investigating Committee. One of its aims is to retrieve the cloak of respectability for such work.

AS Gene Fowler suggests in his foreword to Louis Sobol's "Some Days Were Happy," no one ever thinks of a Broadway columnist as once having been young. Omniscient and omnipresent, yes, but not young; born full-grown on a page with the theatrical ads, but with no time for childhood.

THE re-establishment of the private flyers' airway between Washington and Los Angeles might well be called the reconversion of Blanche Noyes. Appointed by the old Bureau of Air Commerce in 1936 to promote air marking, Mrs. Noyes flew several hundred thousand miles about the country in her own CAA plane, urging local trade and civic bodies to paint the names of their towns on barn and factory roofs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The National Park Service took a look at ballooning registration figures from its parks in the wide open spaces this week and concluded that the average tourist was heading West this year.

HAVING publicly professed that she would like nothing better than to make her next picture with William Wyler, whom she regards as "the best director in the business," Lillian Hellman is keeping the faith.

The battle to regain the title Mexico won last year begins today, when Stewart Iglehart lead's his 30-goal Old Westbury four against Laddie Sanford's Hurricanes in the inaugural match of the national open polo championship tournament on the International Field of the Meadow Brook Club, Westbury, L.I.

Frederick Hudson Ecker, chairman of the board of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, father of projects that house 100,000 apartment dwellers, was 80 years old yesterday. He has supervised the investment of more private capital than any man in history.

Columbia's 1947 football campaign, the Lions' eighteenth under Lou Little, will get under way Tuesday when fifty-seven players and an almost entirely new coaching staff report to Baker Field to start practice. The squad, which will practice twice daily in preparation for its opener with Rutgers on Sept. 27, includes nineteen lettermen from last year.
To the Screen Editor: IN his review on Aug. 22 of "The Roosevelt Story," T.M.P. offered a comment to which exception must be taken. At very least, a reply is demanded.

SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 30 -- Bob Hamilton of Evansville, Ind., and Ed (Porky) Oliver of Wilmington, Del., turned on the steam today to burst ahead of the field at the halfway mark in the $12,500 72-hole Western open golf tournament.
GENEVA, Switzerland, Aug. 30 -- Governmental plans to deal with the world cereal shortage are inadequate, D.A. FitzGerald, secretary of the International Emergency Food Council, said today.

WORD came from London last week that Stanley Gibbons, Ltd., publishers of the British standard postage stamp catalogue, had announced that it would not chronicle the recent postal paper which Hungary and San Marino issued in honor of Franklin D. Roosevelt, and that as dealers the firm would not handle the stamps.

AFTER this last holiday weekend, industry moves into fuller production minus the interruption of vacations, and trade girds itself for the test of fall merchandise values and styles. The August volume of industrial production will probably show a rise after declining for four months Retail trade for the month is likely to record a small decrease.

WHEN the illegal refugee ship Hannah Szenesch hove to off a deserted stretch of the Palestinian coast and made code contact with the landing party that was watching for her, soft voices called out of the darkness, "Shalom. Yehudim," and strong arms were raised to help the new arrivals into the waiting boats.

PARIS, Aug. 30 -- The French Government and press consider the bi-zonal level-of-industry plan a rebuff to France that will add to the embarrassment of French officials at a moment when they face desperate economic problems.
PARIS, Aug. 30 -- The conference of sixteen nations called to lay a European foundation for the Marshall Plan reached the final stage in its work this week.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 30 -- An inquiry into the extent and effect of labor union organization in the pharmaceutical field was voted by delegates at the closing session of the American Pharmaceutical Association's convention here today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30 -- Bedding Industry production is still substantially below capacity as a result of materials shortages and spotty labor conditions. Nevertheless, output has improved and the retail segment of the industry has launched an advertising campaign which has lifted newspaper lineage during the first half of 1947 to an all-time high mark, a spokesman for the National Association of Bedding Manufacturers revealed today.

NANKING, Aug. 30 -- The Chinese Foreign Office said tonight that China would reply to the State Department within "a few days" expressing her readiness to participate in the proposed fourpower Washington conference aimed at speeding up Korean independence.

AMERICA'S fondness for mechanization in any form has given her at least a century of still-life painters, many obscure, some of them famous. According to their talents and training they range from rank amateurs to first rank professionals.

ATHENS, Aug. 30 -- The end -- for the moment -- of the Greek Government crisis leaves Greece with a somewhat worse Government from the United States point of view than it had before and with rather uncertain prospects of improving it.
