THE dollar as a purchasing unit of stature is as historical as homemade bread. Nowadays a laborer has made a buck before he gets his overalls hitched; yet there was a time when the homely phrase "Another day, another dollar" meant precisely what it said.

ATLANTA, Aug. 30 -- Two recent floggings and a bombing, accompanying a wave of increased crime in Atlanta and Georgia, heightened public indignation this week and led state, county and city authorities into a vigorous clean-up campaign.

MOST culinary herbs have small, inconspicuous flowers, and this leads to a dilemma. A spot near the kitchen door is the logical place for herbs, since the cook is the one who will want them. Yet that location is the very one where a bright splash of color belongs.
CARDIFF, Wales, Aug. 30 -- Punch came out this week, as it has been doing for the last 106 years, and it carries one of those symbolic cartoons about the state of the nation in relation to the world.

Rulers of Greece In Greece the Populist party, supported by the monarchy and business interests, is the strongest political organization. In the 1946 elections, Populists won 160 of the 354 seats in the Greek legislative chamber -- more seats than any other single party.

THE Garden Club of New Jersey will hold an all-day conference for presidents of member clubs at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club, South Orange, on Wednesday. Mrs. Laurance N. Wilson, president, will act as hostess.

People around the age of 50 and all who are more or less herded together, in military or mining camps, old-age homes and similar institutions, ought to be immunized against pneumonia, in the opinion of Dr. Paul Kaufman of Goldwater Memorial Hospital, New York City, and his associates.
TROUBLES haunt the lawn. Any one of them, can ruin the smooth green expanse the gardener is proud of, so he watches closely for symptoms, even in late summer and fall.

VIRGINIA SORENSEN established herself as an accomplished story-teller with her first novel, "A Little Lower Than the Angels." This was an account of the Mormons of a hundred years ago, and she continued in a second book to bring their descendants down to the Nineteen Twenties.

To the editor: I shall comment on only one of Sumner H. Slichter's statements In "Eight Errors in Our Economic Thinking," as it is typical of all of the professional economists: "Spending needs to be encouraged in order to achieve full employment.
PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 30 -- With five days gone of their twelve-day training period, troops from the Buffalo and Syracuse area are planning to visit New York tomorrow, a holiday at Camp Smith.

Effects of the Kremlin's decision to ratify the peace treaties with Italy, Hungary, Rumania, Bulgaria and Finland by prompt registration of the formal documents will depend on how the settlements are carried out. On its face the Soviet decision seems to be a concession to world opinion.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- President Truman relaxed today and looked forward with pleased anticipation to his take-off tomorrow for a week's state visit to Brazil and a speech at the Inter-American Conference there.

TO THE EDITOR: Congratulations on the excellent poem "Dear Government" by Dick Graham. I clipped it out and sent it along to Washington with a letter of mine complaining of a claim which has been pending for a year.
Large-scale housing operations are overshadowing all other types of building work in New York as the fall season heralds the beginning of the third year of peace.

IN her preface to this volume of eight essays. Miss Helen Darbishere, who collaborated brilliantly with De Selincourt in Volume III of the Oxford Edition of Wordsworth's "Poetical Works." states: "I have assembled in this posthumous volume such of Ernest De Selincourt's essays and lectures as I have reason to think he would have approved for presentation.

THE HAGUE. A SHARP battle between "conservatives" and "progressives" is raging all over the Netherlands today, with plenty of atomic epithets exploding in air. Refreshingly, the issue has nothing to do with politics.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 30 -- Sales last week by department stores in this district were 3 per cent above a year ago. In the four weeks ended Aug. 23 they showed no change from the like period last year. Sales last week by central Philadelphia department stores were 1 per cent greater than a year ago but for the four-week period were off 2 per cent.

DETROIT, Aug. 30 -- Roaring over the Detroit River course at a speed at times exceeding 76 miles an hour, Danny Arena, in Herb Mendelson's Notre Dame, today won the first 45-mile heat of the Silver Cup Trophy race.

BATAVIA, Java, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Dr. Hubertus J. van Mook, Acting Governor General of the Netherlands Indies, advocated today that the Dutch "put an end to the authority" of the Indonesian Republican Government.
MUNICH, Germany, Aug. 30 -- Dr. Hans Ehard, Minister-President of Bavaria, said today that Germany must develop into a member of the world family of nations.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 30 -- The town of Hempstead's new ordinance requiring saddle horses to be "lit up" on night rides has stable owners and the horsey set alike scratching their heads. Nature has provided no place to put a headlight or a tail light on a horse.

The distinctive ensign of the United States Power Squadrons, with its vertical blue and white stripes and flown at the stern staff or starboard arm, has meant for more than a quarter of a century that that particular boat is skippered by a man who has spent many winter hours studying navigation.
Committeemen of the American Legion convention failed yesterday to make a clean-cut recommendation either for or against the TaftEllender-Wagner Housing Bill.
The uses and limitations of charts by investors is discussed in an article in the current Issue of The Exchange, the magazine of the New York Stock Exchange.

LONDON, Aug. 30 (Reuters) -- Arsenal jumped to the head of the first division in the English Football League today when it registered its third victory of the season, beating Sheffield United, 2 -- 1.
TO THE EDITOR: Re Richard L. Neuberger's "Etiquette of Bating -- West vs. East": Many a time have I waited for the gravy to be passed long after the meat was just a memory.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Stabling and racing privileges at three Maryland tracks were denied today to horses recently stabled or raced in Massachusetts, Rhode Island or New Hampshire.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- One of the Taft-Hartley Law's requirements for access by unions to the National Labor Relations Board -- the signing of an anti-Communist affidavit -- may bring an early test of the new statute.

OIL PUMP -- The symbols of the working oil field -- towering forests of derricks, with their nodding, horse-head pumps -- may soon go the way of the wood-burning locomotive, according to Business, Week. A new type of submerged oil pump, requiring no elaborate superstructure recently was set up in the Dominguez field of Los Angeles by Kobe, Inc., Huntington Park, Calif.

ROCKPORT, Mass. A BELIEF, widely held, is that New England is no more part of the United States than Texas. Many New Englanders and a goodly number of those who write about New England have been at no pains to correct this impression, because doing so might be counter to the best interests of all concerned.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Dr. Fine's recent article in THE TIMES on Dr. Hungate's report "Financing the Future of Higher Education" was concise and to the point. My difference of opinion is not with Dr. Fine but with Dr. Hungate.

A HALF dozen regular programs return to the air this week, Labor Day week-end marking the start of the formal winter season of listening. Here is the list: Today -- Ozzie Nelson and wife, Harriet Hilliard, resume "The Adventures of Ozzie and Harriet" at 6 P.M. via CBS.

ROME, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Spokesmen or a group of forty-four American Baptists touring Europe asserted today that the recent exchange of etters between President Truman and Pope Pius XII implied that the United States Government was "an lly of clerical totalitarianism."

THE infernal machine devised by Messrs. MacLeish and de San Marzano is a literate, informed, and very funny one. It is a pastiche of parodies, geared together with headlines, and lubricated, on occasion, by a light, thin oil of plot.

MARK VAN DOREN has always gone his own way as poet, and the reviewer is happily free from the necessity of placing him in this group or that. There is a spiritual grace, with more gravity than lightness, in his prevailing mood, a combination of major and minor tones such as the Elizabethans listened for.
HOLLYWOOD. THE cries of alarm which have echoed from the Pacific to the Thames since Great Britain imposed a 75 per cent tax on American film earnings have almost all missed the vital issue.

Despite the ravages of war, the famous hospitality of Norway remains undiminished. Hundreds of European children, mostly from 6 to 12 years of age, this summer are enjoying the serenity and beauty of the fjords, mountains and woods of the little demoocratic Scandinavian nation.

DUNDEE, Scotland, Aug. 30 -- With Nobel Laureate Sir Henry Dale presiding, the British Association for the Advancement of Science opened its first formal post-war meeting here last Wednesday. Unlike most similar meetings in the past this one has a theme, and the theme is "Swords into Plowshares."

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 30 -- A relaxation of rules governing immigrants through this port as the families of American service men was ordered this week. The change came after charges had been lodged by the American Civil Liberties Union that Chinese wives and children of service men were being held incommunicado for "months on end."

ALTHOUGH well known in Europe and South America, the Right Rev. Msgr. Licinio Refice is being introduced to concert goers in this country this summer and fall. As director of the Roman Singers of Sacred Music -- fifty-four men and boys chosen from the choir lofts of the four great Vatican chapels -- he is leading a total of ninety-nine concerts of religious music in large cities here.

Multi-colored money, proposed to Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder recently by Representative Edith Nourse Rogers of Massachusetts, aroused interest, some favorable, in financial circles last week. Under the proposal, which Mrs. Rogers has asserted she will introduce in the form of a bill when Congress reconvenes, each denomination of currency bills would be printed in a distinctive color, as is the practice with postage stamps.

BERLIN, Aug. 30 -- In quick reaction to the newly announced bizonal level-of-industry plan in Germany and in preparation for the coal talks starting Tuesday, the French Military Government called a press conference today at which a French spokesman said his Government did not object to the plan itself but felt that certain details were not realistic.

Sportswear departments last week stepped up activity, according to a survey prepared especially for The New York Times by Meyer Both Reports. Other trends reported were: dresses in demand, oats and suits steady, men's wear promotionally active, children's departments selling back-to-school wear strongly and home departments fairly good.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 30 -- The farther he went, the bettter he ran. That's the story of how the Circle M Farm's Relic, at more than 10 to 1, won the fortythird running of the $20,000 added Hopeful Stakes and added $48,200 to his earnings as Saratoga's race meeting ended today.

THE time to make new lawns is at hand. Experts agree that late August and early September is the best time for sowing grass seed, because the cool fall weeks to follow provide good growing weather for tender green blades.

COINCIDENT with bulb planting in early autumn, mice and even rats begin to look around for comfortable quarters in which to spend the winter. Since these rodents can do considerable damage to bulbs in either city or country gardens, it is most important to start preventive measures at the very beginning of the season.

With two major all-breed events on the schedule, the dog show scene moves to Westchester County next week-end. On Saturday, the Interstate Kennel Association will hold its fifth annual event on the grounds of the Briar Hills Golf Club in Briarcliff Manor and Sunday the Westchester Kennel Club will stage its fixture at the Westchester Country Club.
NANKING, Aug. 30 -- Since the first appearance of the American Military Mission in China (AMISCA) in late 1941 the Central Government has run up against four American generals, and vice versa.

WITHIN five years four notable exhibitions attesting to the perennial popularity of William Sidney Mount and his circle have been held in the New York region -- at the Brooklyn and Metropolitan Museums; at the Hecksher Museum in Huntington, and at the Suffolk Museum, Stony Brook.

With high-grade iron ores of the United States diminished to a point that indicates exhaustion within two decades, virtually every domestic ferrous metal mining company has started research for economic utilization of the nation's vast store of inferior ores.

PETROPOLIS, Brazil, Aug. 30 -- The United States delegation to the Inter-American Defense Conference was preparing tonight to report to its Government that a treaty had been written and approved here that satisfied every fundamental objective the delegation had set out to attain.

THE struggle of a man outside the pale to be accepted by the group is a familiar theme in fiction. Its appeal lies, probably, in the sense of superiority and security that always comes to the spectator. Much of Mr. Greenwood's success in this richly detailed little story depends upon that basic psychological response.

The new statement of policy by the Federal Trade Commission on fair trade practice conferences, taking a stronger stand on violations and ending the internal FTC dissension over Commissioner Lowell B. Mason's program, is now receiving increasing study in industrial and trade association circles.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- President Truman and other highly placed Democrats are in a stew at the moment, wondering just which way to turn for a new national chairman in the event Postmaster General Robert E. Hannegan resigns. In poor health for more than a year, Mr. Hannegan now is undergoing a series of examinations by his physician. He has indicated his future action will be dictated by the doctor's findings.

The total mortgage debt in the United States showed a rise of 13.4 per cent to $34,720,784,595 on Dec. 31, 1946, as compared with $30,417,975,387 on Dec. 31, 1945, according to a compilation made public yesterday by the Mortgage Bankers Association of America.

In the kick-off game of the New York football season, the Eastern College All-Stars, headed by Glenn Davis, Doc Blanchard, Arnold Tucker and five other members of Army's unbeaten, once-tied 1946 eleven, will oppose the New York Giants at the Polo Grounds Wednesday night.

Editor New York Times Book Review: WITHOUT disputing his right to disapprove our work I would like space to correct certain factual errors of Mr. Leigh White in his testy review of "The Balkans: Frontier of Two Worlds," which appeared in your edition of Aug. 3.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Aug. 29 (Delayed) -- In a long recital tonight before thousands assembled in the public stadium, Nuevo Circo, President Romulo Betancourt defended the acts of his administration and gave an accounting of the various departments of his Government.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Aug. 30 -- A total of 96 players, divided into three flights, started competition in the annual three-day memberguest handicap golf tournament at the Huntington Crescent Club today. The elimination of Arnold Brilhart of the local club, one of the 1946 winners, featured the opening skirmishes.

BY collating the known facts and many personal accounts of penal servitude in Soviet Russia, David J. Dallin and Boris I. Nicolaevsky have reconstructed a somber and ominous portrait of daily life inside a police state. The system they describe forms the angry cloud that hangs over the whole course of existence in Russia today.

THE 8mm movie camera is steadily growing in favor with the general public and will in time become the ypical amateur movie camera, according to Augustus Wolfman, editor of The National Photographic Dealer.

ALTHOUGH before the war many of New York City's tallest skyscrapers maintained observation roofs for sight-seers, today only three keep open roof -- the Empire State, the RCA Building and the Chanin Building.
PETROPOLIS, Brazil, Aug. 30 (UP) -- Following is the text of the Inter-American Treaty of Reciprocal Assistance, approved today by the nineteen American republics represented at the conference here:

At long last the women golfers at New Jersey have prevailed on the professionals through their president, Charley Gray of Upper Montclair, and their team captain, Dave O'Connell of Essex Fells, to grant them bisques rather than strokes in the triangular team matches for benefit of the New Jersey caddie fund to be played over the Maplewood (N.J.) Country Club course this afternoon, starting at 1 o'clock.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The cost-of-living index gave no relief to American consumers last month, as food prices in fifty-six cities edged up another 1.4 per cent between mid-June and midJuly, the Department of Labor announced today.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 30 (AP) -- When Paul Mantz ended his record-breaking hop from Los Angeles to Cleveland in today's Bendix trophy event, he yelled as he stepped from his plane: "Is that $10,000 I bet safe?" He was referring to the bet he made with Glenn H. McCarthy, Houston (Tex.) oil man and sportsman, who wagered that his P-38 Flying Shamrock would beat Mantz' red P-51 Mustang.

VERMONT has not yet quite equaled the State of Maine in exploiting its picturesque past -- but none of the summer people who throngred to country auctions this season could call Vermonters exactly slow to learn.

Boy Scouts from Alaska, the District of Columbia and every state in the Union -- a total of 1,089, including leaders -- returned here yesterday aboard the Army transport General Harry Taylor after participating in the ten-day World Scout Jamboree at Moisson, France, earlier this month.

Bargain prices for liquor in package stores will end legally at midnight tonight when New York State's new mandatory fair trades act goes into effect in a move to curb a threatened price war. Actually, they ended last night when the stores closed.

MUNICH, Aug. 30 -- Just north of the Starnberger See, which is a half-hour drive south of Munich, stands a spacious pink stucco mansion, once the property of a prominent Nazi. A few weeks ago it was taken over on an experimental basis by the United States Army Air Forces as a "Boys Town" with such excellent results that expansion has been ordered.

A stirring panorama of color and music thrilled 2,000,000 spectators yesterday as the American Legion, 52,000 strong, marched proudly north along Fifth Avenue in a mighty parade that lasted more than twelve hours.

Seeking a peaceful solution of its jurisdictional dispute with Local 3, International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, AFL, the United Telephone Organizations offered yesterday to drop its two punitive proceedings under the Taft-Hartley law if the issue could be settled.

A strong consumer demand for pre-packaged vegetables is hastening the development of facilities in the industry for handling produce in this manner, with chain store organizations spearheading the move on the retail front, sources in the fresh fruit and vegetable field declared yesterday.

Not even the dignity of the official reviewing stand kept its occupants immune yesterday from the spirit of the marching Legionnaires. Three-star generals and prospective Presidential candidates alike were caught up in the hilarity of the hour.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 30 -- Agreements have been signed in Paris between the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund and representatives of the governments of Poland, Finland, Greece, Bulgaria, Hungary and Rumania.

SUMMIT, N.J., Aug. 30 -- Jacob S. Wiley of 2 Hawthorne Place, a retired vice president of the New York Telephone Company, who long had been a leading member of this community, died here last night in the Overlook Hospital after an illness of several weeks.

JUST thirteen years ago this J week In this Review: THE TIMES' Mr. Kaempffert discusses a book, "Science for a New World," planned and arranged by Sir J. Arthur Thomson, which includes such famous scientists as Max Planck and Father d'Arcy.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 31 -- All Brazil seemed tonight to be preparing to welcome President Truman as warmly as this country welcomed his predecessor, Franklin D. Roosevelt, a decade ago.

The American Legion, after an acrimonious fight on the floor, refused yesterday to support the Taft - Ellender - Wagner Housing bill for veterans' housing, despite approval of twenty-two other measures affecting housing. The action was taken by a roll call vote at the twenty-ninth annual convention at the 71st Regiment Armory, Thirty-fourth Street and Park Avenue.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 31 -- A three-day program of exercises that was a source of interest to all Jews in America was brought to a close today with the dedication of the 184-year-old Touro Synagogue, the oldest synagogue building in the United States, as a national religious shrine, so designated by the National Park Service of the Department of the Interior.

LONDON, Aug. 31 -- The City's reaction to the second instalment of the Government's economic plan has been in marked contrast to its reaction to the first plan. When convertibility of the pound sterling was suspended, the markets here rose instead of collapsing.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Five singles, coming in quick succession with none away in the sixth inning, gave the Cubs a 6-3 decision over the Pirates here today before 22,925 fans and ended the series at one -- all.
By plane, train and bus the Legionnaires departed yesterday. Of the estimated 50,000 registered members and their families, the majority had left the city by early evening.

The American Legion was praised yesterday for its devotion to the United States Constitution by the Rev. Edward J. Bubb, dean of the cathedral of St. John in Quincy, Ill., and chaplain of the Seventy-first American Legion Post 487, New York.

PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, B.W.I, Aug. 31 -- President Truman, flying to Rio de Janeiro to attend the final session of the Inter-American Conference, landed here today with Mrs. Truman and their daughter, Margaret. A band played "The Missouri Waltz" as the President's plane, the Independence, taxied to a halt at the airport, where Mr. Truman was greeted by Sir John Shaw, Governor of this British West Indies colony.

It is sixty-five years ago this month since America's first Labor Day parade marched along the streets of New York City. As one looks back he may detect great changes in the character of the celebration. In 1882, for good or otherwise, there was probably more sentimentality about the abstraction called Labor than there is today.

BOSTON, Aug. 31 -- (AP) -- With Ted Williams hitting his twenty- seventh homer, a two run blast, the Boston Red Sox today defeated the Philadelphia Athletics, 5-1, for their fifth victory in succession, and their third over the Mackmen in as many days.
The price of a bottle of whisky was slated to rise sharply today in both New York and Illinois, where new retail Fair Trade price rules became effective at midnight last night.

James F. O'Neil, police chief of Manchester, N.H., was elected yesterday as the new National Commander of the American Legion. The vote was made unanimous after the three opposing candidates conceded their defeat before the first ballot was completed.
LINCOLN, Neb., Aug. 31 (AP) -- Gen. Jacob L. Devers, chief of Army ground forces, said today there were only two divisions and a regimental combat team of regular Army troops in the United States.

The American Legion voted unanimously yesterday to throw the weight of its 3,220,763 members behind the Marshall Plan after former Gov. Harold E. Stassen of Minnesota had solemnly warned that a program of American aid for European reconstruction was the only alternative to the spread of communism in Europe.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 31 -- Two days of the national air races, telescoped into one, thrilled almost 70,000 spectators here today. But while racing planes, all the way from the miniatures of the Goodyear Trophy to the sleek jets in the Allison contest from here to Indianapolis and back, kept technical and sporting interest high, the military demonstrations were the most thought-provoking.

Persons and personalities, as such, do not come within the normal province of this column. As a matter of practice, however, one can no more keep anthropomorphism completely out of the area of economic discussion than he can keep it out of mytholigy, religion, science, or auction bridge.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Monday, Sept. 1 -- As the polls closed at 8 o'clock last night, it was already certain that seldom, even in her current history, has Hungary known a more dishonest election than the one that took place yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Phillies and Boston Braves divided a doubleheader today before 31,510, the Braves winning the first behind the four-hit pitching of Johnny Sain 3 to 2, and the Phils taking the second by pounding their former team-mate, Si Johnson, for sixteen hits, 7 to 2.

Week Ended Aug. 29, 1947 A sudden and heavy demand for spot sterling falling in the closing days of last week, and which some had delayed acquiring in the hope of lower prices, turned to a rout of the procrastinators and quickly sparked a rise in that unit to $4.03 1/8 on Friday, highest since Jan. 15, last.
ATHENS, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The shaky Right-wing Government headed by Premier Constantin Tsaldaris was assured today of at least five days of life. The opening of Parliament was postponed until Thursday.

MADISON, Wis., Aug. 31 -- Students must beware of succumbing to propaganda in the conflict between ideas and ideals, and must pursue the Christian way, Bishop William P. O'Connor, of the Madison Diocese, told 250 Catholic delegates attending the constitutional convention of the National Student Association here today.

Americans were urged by the Right Rev. William R. Moody, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Lexington, Ky., yesterday to draw upon their faith and spiritual resources to overcome the dislocations of the war. His sermon was delivered in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 31 -- The joint United States-Mexican campaign to eradicate foot-and-mouth disease from Mexico may last one to five years, depending on the cooperation of the Mexican people. This was the opinion of officials of the two countries given to the press here this week-end.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers swept a doubleheader from the last-place St. Louis Browns today, 11 to 2 and 10 to 1, a big first inning in both games permitting Hal Newhouser and Stubby Overmire to coast to easy victories.

JACKSON, N.C., Aug. 31 (AP) -- A fifty-four-year-old anti-lynching law, enacted by a North Carolina legislature during an era marked by frequent mob action, will be called into play here Tuesday when charges against seven white men are aired at a special hearing.
Food retailers in certain sections of the metropolitan area are selling a substantial volume of canned goods for shipment abroad by parcel post, trade sources report.

NANKING, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Gen. Chen Cheng was en route by air today to Mukden to take over the Government command in Manchuria as the Kuomintang [Government party] executive committee urged "serious negotiations" with Russia to recover Manchuria for China.

Joe Angyal of the New York Athletic Club and the Old Dominion Boat Club of Alexandria, Virginia shared honors yesterday on the Harlem River in the 56th annual Middle States Regatta, sponsored by the New York Rowing Association. It marked the first time since 1920 that the regatta was held on the Harlem.

Twenty-five hundred American Legionnaires and their families were warned yesterday at a special mass in honor of the Legion at St. Patrick's Cathedral that it was not enough to condemn communism without offering a positive plan for national and international peace.

BERLIN, Aug. 31 -- A French mission has arrived in Germany to interview and select displaced persons for resettlement in France as coal miners, it became known today. The mission is acting on instructions laid out in an agreement between the French Government and the Preparatory Commission of International Refugee Organization.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: General Wedemeyer's statement to the press on the eve of his departure from China summed up the Chinese situation in simple terms and, in a perfectly noncommittal way, called upon the Chinese people themselves to solve their difficulties.

New York has extended an invitation to the American Legion to return here in 1949, Judge Vincent A. Carroll of Pennsylvania, chairman of the Legion's National Convention Bureau, told the closing session of the organization's twenty -ninth annual convention yesterday.

Between Aug. 17 and Aug. 26 this newspaper published sixteen comments on American policy from Soviet sources. Three were uttered by Mr. Gromyko at the Security Council, all variations of the charge that in-offering to mediate in the Netherlands-Indonesian dispute the United States was attempting to by-pass the United Nations and force the Indonesian Republic to accept arbitration.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 31 -- New negotiations to settle the elevenmonth craft union strike in the Hollywood movie studios encountered an obstacle tonight. That was a demand from the general president of one American Federation of Labor union that the general presidents of two other AFL unions participate.

Executive opinion holds that readjustment from inflation "might be painful but will probably be short," the American Management Association states in its annual report for the fiscal year 1946-47, released over the week-end. The report added that "near-term caution and long-term optimism seemed advisable."

PETROPOLIS, Brazil, Aug. 31 -- With the Inter-American Defense Conference here a memory save for a concluding session with President Truman's speech Tuesday, the way has heen cleared for the ninth International Conference of American States at Bogota, Colombia.
Sabbath calm took the city in mild embrace yesterday. The Legion returned Times Square to wandering Labor Day week-enders and to Father Duffy's pigeons, and there was peace in the land.

Home on the Range Our Mr. Atkinson told us yesterday that the theatre would be back on Broadway this week to begin a new season. New York's Rialto has hung around Times Square for so many years now that a lot of people cannot remember when it was anywhere else.

"Mr. District Attorney" continues to enjoy top place on the Hooper list of the most popular programs of the moment, the statistical tabulation out today being the last of the summer season. The next rating -- in two weeks -- is expected to reflect the return of the regular winter shows.

GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass., Aug. 31 -- The sleek black and tan Doberman pinscher, Ch. Alcor V. Millsdod, owned and shown by Mrs. A. Ernest Mills of Medford, Mass., was selected as best in the allbreed show of the Great Barrington Kennel Club today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Hinting at possible dissent within the Communist ranks, the Chinese Communist radio broadcast today a statement that the party had adopted a new program of redistributing land instead of merely reducing rents and interest.

"The loyalty probe now being made by the Federal Government is not a witch hunt, but a Judas Iscariot hunt," the Rev. Dr. Frederick Brown Harris, pastor of the historic Foundry Methodist Church in Washington, D.C., chaplain of the United States Senate during the war years, declared yesterday.

Following is a summary of the recommendations and conclusions of the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine, as authorised by the commission and made public last night at United Nations headquarters at Lake Success:

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Aug. 31 -- Vic Scott of Forest Hills, L.I., winner in May of the revived 130mile outboard marathon down the Hudson from Albany to Manhattan, continued to demonstrate this afternoon that he drives one of the hottest outboard hydroplane outfits on the regatta waterways.

LONDON, Aug. 31 -- Despite Britain's much publicized austerity, tourist trade for this season will run almost 25 per cent more than originally expected, according to estimates made by the British Travel Association.

The Giants drew abreast of the all-time major league seasonal home run record at Ebbets Field yesterday. But even this lofty achievement in no manner impeded the progress of the pennant bound Dodgers.

CHUN-CHAN YEH, a young Chinese who served as a major in the Chinese Army and also as a sort of cultural ambassador to the West (He translated many Chinese war stories into English for American and English publications), has never known even a comparatively short interval of peace and tranquillity in his native land.

EAST BROOKFIELD, Mass., Aug. 31 -- Employment gains by the Negro during war-time might be dissipated during the next five or ten years if Negroes, themselves, are not alert to improve their status with labor unions and the public, Lester B. Granger, executive secretary of the National Urban League for Social Work Among Negroes, said tonight.
William J. Brett has joined Fur Promotions, Inc., publishers, as president of the corporation.

BOSTON, Aug. 31 -- The Snetking, a derelict four-masted schooner, which has been a familiar sight in the harbor, was burned tonight. Police, firemen and waterfront officials alike were hopeful it would mean the end of the schooner, which has been a nuisance for the last decade or more.

MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., Aug. 31 -- Bearing the signatures of a number of national labor leaders of the United States and Canada, a manifesto calling for industry to join its working forces in a pattern of teamwork that would "sell" democracy to the world was presented today to the 700 delegates attending the North American Assembly for Moral Rearmament.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals ran roughshod over Cincinnati today to win, 15 -- 8, in a loosely-played game before a crowd of 15,997.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 31 -- Termination of the British mandate in Palestine and partition of the Holy Land into two independent states, one Arab and the other Jewish, were recommended tonight by a majority of the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine.

WARSAW, Aug. 31 -- United States Army orders assigning aerial photographers to the air attache's staff in Warsaw fell into the Polish Government's hands in June. This has resulted in the grounding of the military mission's plane on the Warsaw airfield.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- More than 9,000,000 veterans holding terminal leave bonds worth some $2,000,000,000 may begin cashing them Tuesday morning, but Senator Francis J. Myers, Pennsylvania Democrat, urged them tonight not to do so unless they "absolutely" were forced to raise cash.

The text of the report on Foreign Relations adopted by the American Legion at the closing session of its twenty-ninth annual national convention yesterday, and the text of a statement of the American Legion's policy on national defense, follow:

The knotty problem of casting the leading male role in Tennessee Williams' play, "A Streetcar Named Desire," may be resolved this week. According to reliable sources, a likely candidate is Marlon Brando, the young actor who first attracted notice in Maxwell Anderson's short-lived and controversial "Truckline Cafe."
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 31 -- The proposals of the majority of the United Nations committee were rejected immediately today by Arab groups and looked at with cautious favor by the Zionist.
Australia's hopes of winning back the Davis Cup were kept alive yesterday as the team from Down Under scored its first victory in eight challenge-round matches with the United States.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $51,534,652,220. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Aug. 31 -- A boys' game played by three young Bronx campers in the Palisades ended in tragedy in the early morning darkness here today when one of them fell on his hunting knife, severed his juglar vein and bled to death before medical aid could arrive.

A demand that Governor Dewey and the Republican-controlled Legislature call on Congress to repeal the Taft-Hartley Act will highlight the eighth annual convention of the State Congress of Industrial Organizations, opening in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., this Thursday.

When mariners put their ships on a southern course, out of the winds and storms of the northern latitudes, they do so with a sigh of relief. They know that between 40 degrees North Latitude and 40 South, the winds generally are predictable and benign and the seas smooth.

Poland has no intention of breaking contact with the West but fears that the Western powers may advance German reconstruction at the expense of devastated Allied countries, Jozef Winiewicz, Polish Ambassador to the United States, declared yesterday at La Guardia Field on his return from a three-week consultation in Warsaw.

ENDICOTT, N.Y., Aug. 31 -- Following up a fine victory over E.S. Jackson Jr., of Short Hills, N.J., in the first round, Jeremiah D. Donovan Jr., former Brooklyn College star, today defeated Julius Partos of Astoria in the second round of the annual tournament for the New York State Chess Association championship at the Country Club of the International Business Machines Corporation.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 31 (AP) -- San Francisco's 49ers, scoring in every period, opened their AllAmerica Conference football season today in impressive fashion by defeating the Brooklyn Dodgers, 23 to 7. A crowd of 31,874 witnessed the contest in sunny weather.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Aug. 31 -- Several wild animals that spent the summer in close contact with junior members of the human species decided today that the purpose of human civilization is to live without working. This philosophy, unwittingly nurtured by about 10,000 children who vacationed at the five camps in Palisades-Interstate Park here, has created a delicate problem of ethics.

CLEVELAN, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Behind effective hurling by Ed Lopat and Red Ruffing, the White Sox took a double header from the Indians today, winning the opener, 7 to 3, and taking the second, 3 to 1, to sweep their three-game series.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 31 -- The Congressional grant of $14,000,000 for cancer research will make possible a tremendous advance in clinical study, the training of specialists, experimental work, and the coordination of cancer research of an international scale, Dr. Leonard Scheele, director of the National Cancer Institute in Bethesda, Md., said today.

LONDON, Aug. 31 -- Announcing tonight that for the time being Britain had stopped all food purchases from the United States, John Strachey, Minister of Food, attributed the recent drastic British import cuts to the high tariff system in the United States.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Au. 31 -- More than a thousand youthful hikers who proved that intelligent self-supervision was feasible on hiking trails in this area were honored here tonight by the police of the Palisades-Interstate Park from whom they had learned this technique.
TOKYO, Aug. 31 -- Fifteen suspected Japanese war criminals were released yesterday from Sugamo prison by the American authorities. Eight more were freed from house arrest.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 -- Good rains fell over a considerable part of the main Corn Belt last week and were accompanied by lower temperatures, but there is considerable difference in opinion as to whether this change in conditions will add many bushels to the prospective corp.

The active United States merchant marine two years after the war is represented by nearly 25,000,000 tons of shipping, including dry cargo, passenger and tanker vessels, according to a recapitulation on various operating activities released by the Maritime Commission.

SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Johnny Palmer, 29-year-old Badin, N.C., professional who has been close to first-place money many times on the 1947 golf circuit, was on the verge of crashing the winners' circle today in the $12,500 and Western open tournament.

BATAVIA, Java, Aug. 31 (U.P.) -- The Indonesian Republic reported tonight that the Dutch were making a two-pronged attack on the town of Sukaraja, near the north coast of Central Java and that a fierce fight was in progress.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Aug. 31 (AP) -- Gen. Jonathan M. Wain wright, beloved hero of World War II, was retired from the Army to day in ceremonies at historic For Sam Houston.

VIENNA, Aug. 31 (U.P.) -- Foreign Minister Karl Gruber called on the Austrian people today to preserve the democratic constitution in the face of "blackmail threats against the Parliament and the Government."

A full-scale investigation into gang warfare among Bath Beach, Brooklyn, bookmakers was opened yesterday by the District Attorney's office of Kings County as the police arraigned two suspects in the sixth slaying in that sector in the last eight months.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: By your editorial "The Olympic Forests," in your issue of Aug. 24, you have led off in a fight for the interests of the people that I hope will inspire similar protests. Of course, we need lumber. We will always need lumber. We would need it even if every merchantable tree in the Olympic National Park should be sacrificed.

One of the city's youngest "veterans," in point of service in an appointive post, served his last day yesterday. Howard A. Shiebler, 47-year-old former newspaper man, returned to private enterprise after more than two decades in the service of the state and the city.

BUFFALO, Aug. 31 -- Perhaps the greatest "lift" that the powers- that-be in the All-America Football Conference could hope for was achieved today as the Buffalo Bills upset the New York Yankees, 28-24, in a thrill-packed inaugural before 32.385 fans at Civic Stadium.

Despite an estimated 25,000,000 automobiles on the roads and indications that as much as half of the nation was on the move in some sort of observance, the long Labor Day week-end -- favored by generally propitious weather -- still had a chance yesterday to become a safe and sane holiday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Top Congressional priority next year on legislation to admit 400,000 of Europe's homeless war refugees over a four-year period was urged today by the Citizens' Committee on Displaced Persons.

Sales of American war-built dry cargo ships to non-citizens and to representatives of countries that were enemies of the United States in World War II were opposed in a resolution adopted here yesterday by the American Legion.
BEDDAU, Wales, Aug. 31 -- One way to understand at least part of the British coal problem is to come down here in the Rhondda Valley and look at Mildred and Margaret.

With the four-week Saratoga session written into the records, horse racing returns to the metropolitan area today when the Queens County Jockey Club opens its eighteen-day autumn meeting at the Aqueduct course. This also marks the beginning of the last third of the New York turf campaign.

As the first of the new pack of canned salmon is beginning to arrive in stores here, the fishing season for the Chinook variety in the Columbia River and the Sockeye in Alaska is drawing to a close. Although this year's catches have ranged from good to fair, prospects are that supplies will not be much greater than they were in 1946, a record poor year, according to the National Canners Association.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Steve Beville of Hammond, Ind., and his "Galloping Ghost" today won the 105-mile Kendall Trophy race for P-51 Mustangs, a new event with $2,500 first prize money, at 384.6 miles an hour, bettering by eleven miles an hour the winning time in last year's Thompson Trophy event, the 300-mile closed-course speed classic of the National Air Races.

LONDON, Aug. 31 -- Responding to an appeal by Emanuel Shinwell, Minister of Fuel and Power, who told them that "the country is hanging on a thread," the majority of striking coal miners in Yorkshire decided today to return to work.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 31 -- As the first step toward compliance with an Interstate Sanitation Commission order to increase the city's sewage disposal facilities and end pollution of Staten Island Sound and Newark Bay, the Elizabeth City Council is scheduled to appropriate $10,000 at its meeting next Friday to engage a sanitary engineer.

BOSTON, Aug. 31 -- Five thousand electrical workers in the Greater Boston area have been asked to boycott the Labor Day rally of the Congress of Industrial Organizations on Boston Common tomorrow afternoon in protest against the appearance of Lieut. Gov. Arthur W. Collidge as a speaker.

HIGHMOUNT, N.Y., Aug. 31 -- The Agudath Israel Youth Council of America will send to President Truman a message scoring Congress for its "Inexcusable, indifferent attitude" on the Stratton Bill providing for the admission to this country of 400,000 displaced persons from Europe.

The Rev. Joseph Arthur Rabun, ousted pastor of the McRae Baptist Church, McRae, Ga., declared yesterday that, although he was being boomed for the nomination for Governor by a group of Georgia liberals, he would refuse it rather than split the liberal vote.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 31 -- "My Son Edward." an English play by Robert Morley and Noel Langford, in which Morley has been appearing for two years in London, has been acquired for the screen by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, the studio has announced.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The Army Air Forces has recruited more than 30,000 men in the last few months in an effort to regain its efficiency level.

The United Nations Committee on Palestine has produced a 7-to-4 report, made public yesterday in summary, which at least points a way toward a solution of the Holy Land's tragic and heart-breaking problems. The plan includes partition, with an economic union between the Arab and Jewish States: it would place Jerusalem under a United Nations trusteeship; it would admit 150,000 Jewish immigrants within the next two years; it would leave Britain.

Despite large wage increases, the average worker in this state is able to buy less with his weekly paycheck than he was at the end of the war, Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi reported in a Labor Day speech yesterday.

BALBOA, Canal Zone, Aug. 31 -- Three world records for light tackle were set in the second international sailfish and black marlin tournament which ended here at sunset last night after three days of fishing around the Pearl Islands in the Bay of Panama.

GENEVA, Switzerland, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Members of the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine signed their report to the United Nations Assembly in a closed meeting shortly before midnight tonight.

The airplane carrier Randolph, 27,000-ton veteran of the war in the Pacific, will steam out of Gravesend Bay at 6 o'clock this evening for Philadelphia, where she will join the Navy's "mothball fleet" of inactivated and decommissioned warships.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The letter published Aug. 10 of Raymond L. Wise entitled "Toward World Order," urging reconciliation of the differences between the "capitalisticdemocratic" and the "communistictotalitarian" sides, is an earnest plea for the abandonment of the use of force and the achievement of a world order.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The Atomic Energy Commission announced tonight that together with the National Research Council it was undertaking a long-range study of the survivors of the atombomb attacks on Hiroshima and Nagasaki.

Go to the hardwood ridges these late summer days and watch the sun's rays paint a picture of mullioned beauty on the three-branched ferns. Bracken is a sturdy, individualistic plant with tall coarse stems. In the mingled sunlight and shadow one can see a dozen shades of green blending together in an appealing picture.

AMSTERDAM, Aug. 31 -- Tjeerd Greidanus, a partner in the Amsterdam banking house of Pierson Co., warned yesterday of continued dangers of inflation resulting from the Government's unbalanced budget and cheap-money policy.
PALO ALTO, Calif., Aug. 31 -- Stanford University's first preschool program for children of exGI student families will open on Oct. 2, it was learned here today.

TOKYO, Aug. 31 -- Board of Trade regulations issued today gave the business world a clear idea what "limited private foreign trade" will be like with both the Japanese Government and the United States Army sitting in their laps.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 -- The supply and price of meat, dairy products, poultry and eggs for consumers between now and next summer will be determined largely by the amount of wheat the Government ships abroad, feed industry spokesmen said today.

PARIS, Aug. 31 -- The insistence by William L. Clayton, Under-Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, yesterday that European nations expecting aid under the Marshall plan should balance their budgets was anticipated by the committee of financial experts of the European conference, it was said here today.

ZURICH, Aug. 31 -- Last Thursday the National Bank of Switzerland suddenly suspended the unrestricted sale of gold coins. Selling will be resumed this week but the banks through which the public must buy will be put on very restricted quotas.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 31 -- With the Palestine and Egyptian cases pending before the United Nations, statesmen of Syria, Lebanon and Trans-Jordan have reacted swiftly and sharply against proposals by King Abdullah of Trans-Jordan to reopen discussion of his "Greater Syria" scheme.

QUITO, Ecuador, Aug. 31 -- An army counter-revolution against the new dictator-President, Col. Carlos Mancheno, spread to four key cities of Ecuador tonight. The Government imposed a nation-wide state of siege in an effort to curb it.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 31 -- Whether reconversion work is resumed on the Monterey and Mariposa, luxury liners owned by the Oceanic Steamship Company, a subsidiary of the Matson Navigation Company, will depend largely on a report expected shortly from George Sharp of New York, naval architect, a company spokesman disclosed today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 -- Wheat and oats for future delivery sold at new seasonal high prices on the Board of Trade last week. September wheat made a new high record for that delivery, and September oats sold at the highest price for any future in that grain.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Top leaders of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations, addressing independent messages to organized labor, struck a common note today in urging militant political action to force repeal of the Taft-Hartley labor act.

NANKING, Aug. 31 -- The shaping of the United States policy on China, it is felt here, will have to be considered in terms of three broad possibilities. There are elements of difficulty, uncertainty and risk in any of the following approaches:

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 31 -- During August demand for steel continued to outrun supply. Lack of scrap metal and pig iron plus hot weather put many steel companies further behind in their deliveries because the steel ingot rate failed to go above 93 or 94 per cent of capacity.
WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 31 -- A switch in its line-up paid off with a five-goal dividend to Stewart Iglehart's Old Weslbury team today.
Table lamps for modern interiors that offer new decorative designs for table tops are now appearing in New York stores. They are fashioned in simple shapes of clay, or are finished in wallpaper.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 31 -- "Parents are builders not merely of houses for the temporal well-being of their families; they are builders of homes, sanctuaries of spiritual training and fortresses against the enemies of spiritual life," Bishop William T. Mulloy of Covington, Ky., said last night at the closing session of Xavier University's first annual Family Life Conference.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 31 -- Thirty years have elapsed since the Balfour Declaration, which promised Jews a "national home" in Palestine. The United Nations committee that has just prepared its report on the Palestine situation is the sixth that has gone to that country armed with authority to make recommendations for its future.

The attack on the Civil Rights Congress as a Communist front organization, issued in Washington Saturday by the House Committee on Un-American Activities, brought a counter-attack from the Civil Rights Congress yesterday.

Another surplus landing craft, one type of war-born vessel that has found widespread utilization as a peaceful carrier, has been commissioned by the American Exporting and Importing Company for operation between Falmouth and Martha's Vineyard, Mass.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- President Truman, once more on a good-will mission out of the country, took off for Rio de Janeiro this morning aboard the new White House plane, Independence.

CAZENOVIA, N.Y., Aug. 31 -- Participation in national and international affairs is an obligation of young adults of America in building for future peace. This was one of the conclusions reached in discussions here today by the Sixth Annual Conference of Young Adults sponsored by the State Community Service Council.

Details of the colorful ceremonies that will attend the consecration of Bishop-elect Thomas J. McDonnell as titular Bishop of Sela in Egypt and Auxiliary Bishop of New York on Sept. 15 in St. Patrick's Cathedral were made public yesterday.

Without a dissenting voice the American Legion Auxiliary endorsed universal military training yesterday "as vital to a wellbalanced program of national defense" and asked that a special session of Congress be called to take immediate action.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 31 (AP) -- A private informant said today the Trails-Arabian Pipeline Company was "seriously considering" abanoning Lebanon as the Mediterranean terminus for its planned $150,000,000 pipeline from Arabia because of a delay in obtaining transit rights across neighboring Syria.
Because Washington throwing was of a negative character, the Yankees took both ends of a double-header from the Senators before a gathering of 44,541 at the Stadium yesterday.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Aug. 31 --"Capricorn Africa" as a factor in the economic recovery of Europe and as a democratic bastion against world-wide totalitarian aggression emerged from the realm of fantasy during the week-end.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 31 -- In a week-kneed northwest breeze that fell flat but gained its feet again, 138 craft competed today in the regatta of the Port Washington Yacht Club. A real nor'wester has been long overdue.

LAHORE, Pakistan, Aug. 31 -- Deep in Moslem Pakistan, mobs of Moslems halted a train, pulled thirteen Sikhs through the windows and clubbed them to death with hockey sticks, an American eyewitness, Richard Fischer of Moline, Ill., related here today.

The general trend of cotton prices in the domestic market last week appeared to be toward moderately lower levels. Active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange at the close of trading on Friday, were off 43 points to 30 points up on the week.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 31 -- The majority recommendations of the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine were received by Zionists tonight with pleasure and surprise, tempered with caution, and by Arabs with disapproval and disappointment.

PARIS, Aug. 31 -- Premier Paul Ramadier charged today that a wavering, spirit and cowardice charactrized the attitude of certain types of former President de Gaulle's followers and Communists in France's present difficulties.

MONTREAL, Aug. 31 -- One of the most thorough tests ever undertaken in the handling of fish has just been successfully completed with the shipment of 90,000 pounds of salmon and halibut a distance of 3,116 miles from Prince Rupert, B.C., to Montreal, it was jointly announced today by the Canadian Pacific and Canadian National Railways.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Armed galloped to an impressive three and one-quarter length victory in the $55,600 Washington Park Handicap today for second place in horse racing's list of all-time money winners.
PARIS, Sept. 1 -- Communists in the National Assembly launched today an unexpected attack on the Government's fiscal program, which Premier Paul Ramadier is scheduled to defend tomorrow.

SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Johnny Palmer, 29 - year - ok Badin, N.C., professional, won the Western Open golf championship today with a spectacular finish or the eighteenth hole that left an audience of 3,000 limp from excitement.

Music on the Marshes There is beauty and music on the spreading salt marshes these late summer days. On the upper reaches, where the tides cover the grasses only in the monthly climaxes, men are cutting the short, wiry hay and building conical stacks on the weathered staddles.
Twenty-two Iowa farmers arrived here yesterday on their way to Europe, where they will spend a month investigating the need for the Marshall Plan.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept 1 -- President Truman's wife and daughter, Margaret, shared a real Carioca welcome today. They reacted much as any American tourists would -- they were over-whelmed, grateful, excited and ultimately tired out.

More than $500,000 worth of electrical equipment is included in the list of items comprising the new offerings of Government surplus by the New York regional office of the War Assets Administration, it was announced yesterday by Carl P. Malmstrom, regional director.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Subjected to a 1-to-0 shut-out on the four-hit pitching of Bob Chipman in the opener, the Cincinnati Reds scored 10 runs in the first inning of the nightcap to gain a 13-to-2 decision and a split of their double-header with the Chicago Cubs today before 39,511 fans.

Two radio car patrolmen who found the door broken in at the Chase National Bank branch at Church and Worth Streets early yesterday thought they had run into a band of bank robbers and telephoned for aid. Police Emergency Squad 1 reserves from the Beach Street station and several other radio cars equipped with tommy guns rushed to the scene.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your recent editorial "The Cause of the Children" is very much to the point. However, we should like to correct a few statements which were made.

ORLANDO, Fla., Sept. 1 (AP) -- Senator Claude Pepper, Democrat, of Florida, in Labor Day speeches at Orlando, Wildwood and Daytona Beach, today called upon the nation to demand that the first act of the next session of Congress be the repeal of the Taft-Hartley Labor law.
MADRID, Sept. 1 -- Six former fighters in the French Maquis have been arrested by Spanish police in one of two recent important political raids, according to information received here today.

Charles E. Oakes, president of the Edison Electric Institute, reported yesterday that a new high record for new connections of electricity in the United States was established during the year to June 30, 1947.

DON'T ask how the conversation happened to follow along this particular channel. Those things can't always be explained. But all of a sudden Billy Southworth, a dreamy look in his eyes, was talking about Grover Cleveland Alexander and the dramatic entrance of Old Pete into the seventh and deciding game of the 1926 world series between the Cardinals and the Yankees.

BERLIN, Sept. 1 -- In the face of an expected critical food shortage the German Government of Wuerttemberg-Baden has underestimated its grain crop by 62 per cent, a Military Government check has revealed.
LONDON, Sept. 1 -- This was another black day for Britain's economy as 8,000 miners in the South Yorkshire pits stubbornly refused to return to work.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 1 -- Speaking at the opening session of the summer meeting of the Mathematical Association of America at Yale University today, Dr. Robert F. Bacher of the United States Atomic Energy Commission outlined what the United States was doing in atomic research.

FOURTEEN years ago a book was published in this country which, in spite of an excellent critical reception, never won the popular recognition it deserved. Times were not particularly propitious for subtle and scholarly works in 1933. Nevertheless, those who discovered "Peter Abelard,"* by Helon Waddell, did not forget it and did not let its memory die.

Maintenance of a permanent and stable high level of business activity in the states of New York and New Jersey depend largely on successfully coping with the problems of rising prices, declining construction and the growing gap between imports and exports, according to a quarterly survey of business and economic trends in the two states released yesterday by L.L. Horch, New York Regional Director of the U.S. Department of Commerce.
WASHINGTON, Sept 1 (AP) -- New construction work during August scored a more than seasonal gain over July, tha Commerce Department's construction division reported tonight.

New Jersey's extensive post-war road construction program has just moved forward one more step with the opening to traffic of the $3,600,000 three-mile improved link of U.S. Route No. 1 from Port Street, Newark, to North Avenue, Elizabeth. The stretch concerned is now widened to eight lanes and as such partly breaks a bad bottleneck on a heavily traveled artery.

RARITAN TOWNSHIP, N.J., Sept. 1 -- Amid the strains of bagpipes and the graceful steps of the Highland fling, clans from throughout the state of New Jersey renewed acquaintance today as they gathered in Linwood Grove for the twelfth annual meeting of the Scottish Games of New Jersey Association.
LAHORE, Pakistan, Sept. 1 -- Competent observers, both Moslem and non-Moslem, agree that a wholesale exchange of minority populations may be necessary before peace returns to India.
ATHENS, Sept. 1 -- Although Greece has a new Government, the governmental crisis is continuing just below the surface in constant negotiations and bargaining.

PARIS, Sept. 1 -- Leaders of the European conference on the Marshall Plan acted quickly today in response to the severe criticisms of their work that were made to them Saturday by Under-Secretary of State William L. Clayton on behalf of the State Department of the United States.

Civic leaders and municipal officials in several Nassau County communities advocate the purchase of land for parking by levying special assessments on property owners in business districts, according to a survey made by the Long Island Association and released yesterday.

The General Electric Company's switch to peacetime activity in marine propulsion includes the supplying of turbine-electric drive units for the newest of American-flag luxury liners and an important role in the reconversion of wartime cargo vessels, company officials said yesterday.

Real estate bonds reached a new high of $757 per $1,000 bond in August, according to Amott, Baker Co. The average price of a list of 200 issues advanced 0.6 per cent in August, marking the third consecutive month of increases. The previous high was $753 on June 30, 1946.

The petitions calling for a referendum in November on repeal of proportional representation as a method of electing City Council members will be filed with the City Clerk tomorrow at 1:15 P.M., it was announced yesterday.

A course in Personal Development for Executive Leadership," designed to demonstrate how young women may best capitalize on their "physical and psychological endowments," will be given this fall at the New York University School of Retailing, it was announced yesterday.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 1 -- Fully half this city of 2,000,000 plus a heavy drawing from, far and near areas of Brazil lined more than six miles of avenues and streets this afternoon and shouted a warm, friendly greeting to President Truman.

Good weather, Paris fashions, English customs searches and new automobiles were among the subjects discussed yesterday by passengers arriving here from Southampton on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Elizabeth. The ship docked at 7 A.M. at Pier 90, North River, with 2,258 passengers.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Combining 13 hits with eight walks for an 8-to-2 second-game triumph, the St. Louis Cardinals completed a twin killing of the Pittsburgh Pirates today. They pulled the first contest out of the fire on Del Wilber's tenth inning triple for a 6-5 victory.

MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 1 (AP) -- Alfred Waldron, a Fox Movietone News photographer who has had many thrilling experiences around the world, found himself the center of a grim drama today when his cabin cruiser exploded and took the life of his youngest son, Richard, 5 years old.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 1 -- The proposals of the United Nations special committee to partition Palestine have brought the Arabs to the boiling point. They more or less expected some form of geographical dismemberment, but when the United Nations group recommended a Jewish port at Jaffa, which the Arabs have claimed as their own for the last 1,300 years, they were in no mood to accept any part of the plan.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Sept. 1 -- Figures for the Hungarian election described as "final but incomplete" today showed the Communists in first place the dark-horse People's Democratic party, led by Istvan Barankovics, second, the Small Landholders third and the Socialists fourth.

Under 132 pounds, the heaviest burden he ever had carried in 109 trips to the post, Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs' rough, tough old Stymie won the $25,000 added Aqueduct Handicap yesterday as horse racing returned to the metropolitan area after a four-week absence.
The Dodgers just had to win their game yesterday morning. Cheering them to the point of hoarseness were 1,800 crippled children who took over three sections in the grandstand.

SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Application of the industry, sacrifice and diligence shown by the Utah pioneers would bring an era of unparalleled prosperity to the West and Southwest, Eugene W. O'Brien of Atlanta, Ga., president of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, said today in a keynote address opening the society's fall meeting.

EAST BROOKFIELD, Mass., Sept. 1 -- The National Urban League today turned its attention to job-getting and job-holding with emphasis on training and vocational guidance for Negro youth. Trade union officials and league executives also praised industry leaders for observing, in most instances, seniority rights in discharging unneeded workers.
BATAVIA, Java, Sept. 1 (U.P.) -- The Indonesian Republic said tonight that a Dutch drive against the Indonesian capital of Jogjakarta was under way.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1 -- Although some appliances remain in short supply, strong competition between the gas and electric industries for sales of major kitchen facilities will be renewed soon, industry spokesmen said today.

DETROIT, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers swept their second double-header in two days by lashing out twenty-four hits today to defeat the Chicago White Sox, 6 to 5 and 7 to 2, before 37,480 Briggs Stadium customers. Neither of the starting pitchers in either game went the route.
GENEVA. Sept. 1 -- Twenty-seven new tariff agreements have been reached and forty-two are almost certain to be finished by Sept. 10, it was learned from Geneva trade conference sources today.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 1 -- One of the most daring overtakes ever seen in an air race occurred in the Jet Division of the Thompson Trophy Race in which six Air Forces veterans flew Lockheed Shooting Stars. It cost Lieut. Col. Benjamin S. Preston of Washington, D. C., commanding officer of the 336th Fighter Group, the race, because he was forced to make an extra lap for cutting a pylon.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 1 -- Rioting swept 1,000 miles across India today from the partitioned province of the Punjab to India's other partitioned province, Bengal, where twenty-nine persons were killed and 292 injured in communal clashes in Calcutta.

RICHLAND, Wash., Sept. 1 (AP) -- Charles E. Wilson, president of the General Electric Company, urged an audience at the "Richland Day" celebration today to tell "the facts about life in the "United States" because "it is your insurance to keep your country strong."

Despite the oft-repeated assertion that "anything can happen in Brooklyn," the Brooklyn Baseball Club management was completely unprepared for the crowd of almost riot proportions -- and inclinations -- which stormed the unopened Ebbets Field gates early yesterday, bent upon seeing the morning game between the Phils and the Dodgers.

HICKSVILLE, L.I., Sept. 1 -- Twelve thousand persons attended here today the nineteenth Annual Firemen's Tournament for volunteers of Nassau and Suffolk Counties. The Hicksville Fire Department was sponsor of the event.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 1 -- American working men and women face no greater challenge and no greater opportunity on this Labor Day than the wise use of their full economic and political strength to promote their own welfare, Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, declared tonight.
SOUTHPORT, England, Sept. 1 -- Great Britain's labor movement today offered a free hand to the Government to direct workers to industries considered essential to the nation's economic recovery.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 1 -- A peace conference of warring American Federation of Labor factions arranged by Archbishop John J. Cantwell of the Catholic Church failed today to produce any basis for settlement of the eleven-month jurisdictional strike in the Hollywood film studios.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 1 -- 'The Great Man's Whiskers," a photo play by John Paxton based an a one-act play by Adrian Scott, which was presented here in July at the Actors' Lab Theatre, has been scheduled for October production at RKO, with Scott directing.

William Marcy Tweed in his palmiest days never pulled off an election like the one that has just taken place in Hungary. Repeaters operated under Mr. Tweed's benign regime, but they rarely or never voted ten, twenty, thirty or even forty times, as seems to have happened in Hungary.

Cooler weather stimulated business in the wholesale markets last week, according to the weekly market reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. Stores expected a large influx of buyers after Labor Day, the reports added.
Australia's six-month quest for the tennis trophy it lost to the United States last December ended in failure yesterday in one of the great matches of Davis Cup history.

Pessimism regarding the effects of Britain's recent suspension of convertibility upon the United States' domestic economy "may be overdone," and the conclusion that the development portends an "early and violent rather than gradual and moderate contraction of our exports would be premature," according to The National City Bank of New York.

A two-way rush of travelers, ending their long holiday week-end, tested the capacity of the city's transportation services yesterday as an uncounted horde of vacationists, week-enders and resort patrons turned homeward, apparently with reluctance and at the last moment.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Hilary Smart of Central Long Island Sound, N.Y., brought his sleek Hilarius home the winner yesterday in the fourth leg of the five-race series for the International Star Class yacht racing championship.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 1 (U.P.) -- President Truman, after a 5,000-mile flight from Washington, arrived in this Brazilian capital today on a state visit and received a welcome that Brazilians said was the greatest ever accorded a foreign visitor.

The Advertising Federation of America will release in October a new national campaign to promote better public understanding of advertising. All daily newspapers in America will be provided with mats, at the lowest possible price, through the 100 advertising clubs affiliated nationally with the Federation.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 1 -- Sport flying put on the roughest, toughest show in its history at the National Air Races today, with one pilot killed, four planes smashed and two records broken in the Thompson Trophy classic.

New York saw two spectacular parades of war veterans during the stay here of the American Legion. But the participants this morning are about to engage in a mass movement which will far eclipse numerically, even though not from the standpoint of drama, either of these demonstrations.

LONDON, Sept. 1 -- Present and prospective needs of Britain will be made a separate study of members of the special committee of the United States House of Representatives, which is due to arrive at Southampton early tomorrow on the Queen Mary.

HIGHMOUNT, N.Y., Sept. 1 -- The national convention of the Agudath Israel Youth Council of America closed a four-day session here today after calling on Jewish agencies in Europe to give a religious upbringing in accordance with "the dying wish of their martyred parents," to Jewish orphans in the displaced persons camps.

TOKYO, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The future occupation policy for Japan is expected here to be a major problem before the forthcoming peace conference and may provoke a sharp American - British difference of opinion.

CAZENOVIA, N.Y., Sept. 1 -- Resolutions favoring increased Federal aid for education, endorsing the Marshall Plan for rehabilitation in Europe and upholding the United Nations were adopted as the State Community Service Council closed its sixth annual conference this afternoon.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 1 (AP) -- Blanked for fifteen innings by Jake Wade and Hub Andrews, the Bears came up with three runs in the final inning but they served only to prevent a double-shut out as Jersey City took the holiday twin bill today 5 -- 0 and 6 -- 3 before 8,364 fans.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 1 -- Blown along by a sixteen-knot dry easterly, 156 craft were out today in the annual fall regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club, its last event of the season's championship series, and with that time-honored "Larchmont Luck," the breeze did not fail either in direction or strength.

SAN FRANCICO, Sept. 1 -- The bottleneck in emergency transpacific travel which produced a great backlog or applicants for passage to the Orient was described today as "definitely broken," but persons who expect surface transportation on a luxury basis face disappointment.

DETROIT, Sept. 1 -- Henry A. Wallace, urging immediate action to prepare farmers and organized labor for the 1948 campaign, told more than 10,000 workers gathered in a Labor Day rally in Cadillac Square today that "if we don't make the Democratic party into a party of peace and prosperity, we shall build a new party."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The recent article in the times regarding the excavations in Athens brings to my mind the memory of an old friend, who spent his life and fortune in an endeavor to bring to the Western World an appreciation of the art of ancient Greece.

LINCOLN, Neb., Sept. 1 -- An eight-foot bronze statue of William Jenningrs Bryan was unveiled today in front of Nebraska's Statehouse. More than 1,000 persons, including many friends of the Great Commoner, attended the ceremony, which took place sixty years after Mr. Bryan settled in Lincoln and twenty-two years after his death.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The Washington Senators dropped the Philadelphia Athletics out of the American League's first division today by sweeping the holiday double-header, 4 to 0 and 7 to 4, before a crowd of 28,565 and extending the Macks' losing streak to six straight.

The forthright positions taken by the American Legion and the Legion Auxiliary on the question of universal military training are two more straws in the wind of public opinion that, it is hoped the members of Congress will note carefully and act on when they return to Washington in January.

Spokesmen for the stevedoring industry here are apprehensive about their ability to continue in business unless a recent court ruling that would give longshoremen about $6,000,000 in overtime compensation is reversed.

GENEVA, Sept. 1 -- With the worst food crisis in recent times staring them in the face, delegates from fifty-three countries at the conference of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization find themselves without power to do anything effective about it.

With the Communists making temporary concessions to Christian views, it is on the right that American family life may face its "real present danger," the Rev. Thomas J. Darby declared yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral. He addressed 1,500 members of the Association of Catholic Trade Unionists at their fourth annual Labor Day Mass, which was celebrated by Coadjuter Archbishop J. Francis A. McIntyre.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (U.P.) -- The Green Bowl, Annapolis Naval Academy secret society allegedly devoted to helping members up the Navy's professional ladder, is headed for early extinction.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- The Federation of American Scientists observed the second anniversary of V-J Day with a statement today in which it was emphasized that world security, not a strong national science, provided the real key to national security.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 1 -- Labor was advised tonight by Senator Wayne Morse, Republican, of Oregon, that it could best strengthen its position with American public opinion by confining its program for a thorough overhauling of the Taft-Hartley Law to "the democratic procedures available to it through legal tests in the court rooms of America and political tests at the voting booths of America."
Registration for the fall semester at City College will begin today and 33,000 students, a record number, are expected to enroll before the first day of classes on Sept. 2.

CANBERRA, Australia, Sept. 1 (London Times Dispatch) -- Japanese self-government, subject to Allied Control Council inspection and supervision, was agreed upon in the final closed session today by the British Commonwealth conference on the Japanese peace treaty.
Beginning operations at 10 o'clock yesterday morning an completing them in the afternoon, the league-leading Dodgers broke even in two games with the Phils by identical scores of 5-0.

CALCUTTA, India, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Calcutta police used tear gas early today to break up a howling crowd of about 500 Hindus who besieged the Bellighatta compound where Mohandas K. Gandhi lives with the former Moslem Premier, H.S. Suhrawardym, as a practical demonstration of Hindu-Moslem amity.

Another one of those little gadgets that make one's kitchen career pleasanter goes on sale today at Macy's in the housewares department. It's a device of two small rubber cylinders that fits on to a faucet and that aerates all water passing through it.
NANKING, Sept. 1 -- Dr. Chen Li-fu, boss of the right-wing of the Kuomintang, dominant political party, condemned today China's "shameless tendency to rely upon others."
