TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The second anniversary of the proclamation of the Democratic Republic of Viet Nam on Sept. 2, 1S45, cannot be a time of rejoicing for the friends of freedom.
BOSTON, Sept. 1 -- The Yankees got quite a tossing around in their double-header with the Red Sox today before 35,294 fans, the largest crowd of the year, day or night, at Fenway Park.

NIANTIC, Conn., Sept. 1 -- This has been a perfect holiday week-end for anglers along the fringe of Long Island Sound, and from Niantic to Stamford there was a choice of striped bass, weakfish or snapper blues, with the latter predominating.

GENEVA, Switzerland, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The majority report of the United Nations committee will be accepted by the world Zionist movement as the basis for negotiation, a member of the General Zionist party said tonight.

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Three Army Reserve oficers, all Minnesotans, were killed today in a collision of two Army AT6 training planes as their flight of sixteen craft was returning to base after giving an aerial salute to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower at the Minnesota State Fair.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 1 -- After a year of delays, all political negotiations have been completed for the construction of the world's most capacious oil pipeline. It is to run from the American concession in Saudi Arabia to the Mediterranean coast in Lebanon.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 1 -- De Couraey Fales of the Narragansett Yacht Club sailed his 59-foot schooner Nina to victory today in the sixteenth annual running of the Vineyard Trophy race and gained his second leg on the cup by completing the 233 nautical-mile event in the corrected time of 39 hours 27 minutes 5 seconds.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 1 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower denied today any interest in becoming a candidate for President of the United States.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Sept. 1 -- New York and Westchestcr dice players, fearing detection in customary haunts, have been using isolated wooded glens of Saxon Woods Park here for high-stake games this summer, the County Parkway Police charged today.

Families planning to purchase ultra-modern homes or apartments need not fear that their antique furniture will have to be discarded. That is the message conveyed by the interiors designed by Macy's decorating department for a model duplex apartment in the new cooperative building erected by the City Investing Company at 15 East Ninety-first Street.

Acting to increase their dollar balances, foreign countries are continuing to liquidate their holdings of American long-term securities, while others are beginning to do so, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York states in its Monthly Review published today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The Treasury Department went outside the Government today to get three experts to help in preparing its tax program.

CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 1 -- The Taft-Hartley law was denounced today by officials of the American Federation of Labor at memorial services for Peter J. McGuire, founder of Labor Day, in suburban Pensauken township.

Instead of dominating the crowds on the streets, members of the American Legion were just stray tourists yesterday, lost among the Labor Day visitors. Most of the merrymakers who had turned the streets into a Mardi Gras during the twenty-ninth annual convention had returned to their home towns to resume the role of staid citizens.

The financing of "Strange Bedfellows," product of Colin Clements and his wife, Florence Ryerson, which has been on the verge of Broadway production for several years, has been completed. The work, budgeted at $70,000, is expected to, reach New York during the first week in November after two and a half weeks on the road.

Twenty families will begin moving today into the New York Life Insurance Company's housing development in Flushing, Queens, where two thirteen-story buildings have been completed. The other 600 apartments in these two buildings will be ready for occupancy during September and October, George L. Harrison, president of the company, announced yesterday.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 1 -- Zionism's only authorized spokesman now in the Holy Land, Mrs. Golda Meyerson, head of the Political Department of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, asked today that the United Nations General Assembly accept and "improve" its special committee's recommendations for Palestine and that the recommendations be implemented immediately.

DETROIT, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Guy Lombardo, driving as a guest pilot, sent Miss Great Lakes of Detroit over the Silver Cup speed-boat course on the Detroit River today at an average speed of 71.218 miles an hour to capture the second 45-mile heat of the race from Herb Mendelson's Notre Dame, another Detroit craft piloted by nanny Arena.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, sounded a call today to all working men and women and their friends to defeat in next year's elections Federal and State Legislators who have supported a "new wave of hostile, anti-labor legislation."

LONDON, Tuesday, Sept. 2 (U.P.) -- An official Soviet news agency charged today that United States military authorities in Southern Korea had refused to release a Russian major who crossed the border dividing the United States zone from the Soviet-held area.
Mayor O'Dwyer may be asked to appeal again to Federal authorities in behalf of the Port of New York's waning export-grain business, shipping interests reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- The by-election to choose a member of Congress in the Eighth Pennsylvania District a week from tomorrow has elements that justify the use of a cliche often employed in politics, but rarely apt. This is that the eyes of the nation will be on the voters in this district when they go to the polls.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 1 -- Emil Mayer, the Flushing Bay boat yard operator of College Point, L. I., was the only double winner this afternoon on the second and final day of the Eastern outboard hydroplane championships on the Connecticut River near here.

With licensing of the city's 10,000 parking lots and garages scheduled to become effective on Oct. 1, the Department of Licenses will start today distributing application forms, Benjamin Fielding, License Commissioner, announced yesterday.
MADRID, Sept. 1 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco left San Sebastian today for Vitoria, where he paused tonight to inaugurate the new health institute of the Province of Alava.

LONDON, Sept. 1 -- The British official and press reaction to the recommendations of the United Nations Committee on Palestine has been generally one of wariness as to what assistance could be expected in putting either plan into operation.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 1 (AP) -- R.C. Winmill's Frozen Custard, favorite of the 35,000 fans, streaked through on the rail to win the $10,000 added Pawtucket Handicap by three and a half lengths over R.A. Brown's Tennessee Kid as Narragansett opened its thirty-day fall meeting today.

DUNDEE, Scotland, Sept. 1 -- Since Britain's economic recovery depends largely on coal, it is to coal that sections of the British Association for the Advancement of Science are turning in the closing sessions of the organization's conference.

Miss Irene Harrigan, 31-year-old nurse at Sydenham Hospital, 565 Manhattan Avenue, was charged with felonious assault yesterday after, the police said, she had thrown the contents of a bottle of nitric acid at a woman seeking treatment for a head wound.

MADISON, WIS., Sept 1 -- The problem of educational opportunities for Negroes in the United States is crucial because in the present struggle for world leadership Americans are judged largely by peoples outside our national boundaries on the basis of the way in which Neggoes share in the fruits of American democracy, Dr. R.O. Johnson of the United States Office of Education, said today.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 1 -- Inflationary prices. Mexico's unfavorable trade balance and other post-war economic problems linked with the urgent need to develop natural resources and home industry were points stressed today by President Miguel Aleman in his first annual report to the Congress.

ENDICOTT, N.Y., Sept. 1 -- Frank Collins of Albany took the lead today in the annual tournament for the championship of the New York Chess Association when he defeated Phil Gold, president of the Brooklyn Chess Club in twelve moves in the third round at the country club of the International Business Machines Corporation.

BERLIN, Sept. 1 -- In a surprising switch in the usual line-up in such matters, the United States has joined the Soviet Union in a vigorous denunciation of British and French policy on reparations, it was learned today.

Mel Ott's mauling Giants soared to a new all-time high in home run clouting at the Polo Grounds yesterday and just to show such an accomplishment can also serve a practical purpose they regaled a holiday crowd of 43,106 with a pair of victories over Bill Southworth's Braves.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians regained fourth place today by sweeping a double-header from the St. Louis Browns. Bob Lemon allowed only six hits in taking the nightcap, 4 -- 2, after Bob Feller had hurled the Tribe to a 2-1 triumph in the opener.

"Town Meeting of the Air," which has been a regular Thursday evening feature over the ABC network (WJZ), changes tonight to its new Tuesday schedule. It will be heard from 8:30 to 9:30 o'clock. George V. Denny Jr., moderator of the "Town Meeting," finally has obtained a second speaker to take the affirmative side of tonight's topic, "Is There Really a Communist Threat in Hollywood?"

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- How the Federal Farm Mortgage Corporation fooled the experts by turning a profit of $105,000,000 on taking farmers out of debt only to promote a fight over disposition of the money is the story behind a tug o' war between Treasury and Farm Credit Administration officials for control of the funds.

SHANNON AIRPORT, Ireland, Sept. 1 (Reuters) -- The biggest transatlantic traffic jam in months was piling up today at Shannon Airport, aerial crossroads of western Europe, as the number of westbound passengers reached its peak for the year.

The inside story of how Franklin D. Roosevelt picked Harry S. Truman for the Vice Presidential nomination is told in the autobiography of Edward J. Flynn, Democratic National Committeeman from New York and close associate of the late President.

ROCKVTLLE CENTRE, L. I., Sept. 1 -- The Hempstead Golf Club won the third in a series of four Long Island quadrangular team matches to gain a two-point lead over Garden City at the Rockville Club today. Rockville is third and Cherry Valley last.

The Marshall Plan put a hard question to Europe, and the inventory being prepared by Europe in reply puts a hard question to the United States. On neither side, however, is the crux of the question the amount of money this country will be asked to contribute to a reconstruction program.

QUITO, Ecuador, Sept. 1 -- Army counter-revolutionists, claiming control of five key towns in Ecuador, tonight were reported marshaling planes, tanks and armored cars for an attempt to overthrow Col. Carlos Mancheno, the new dictator-President.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 1 -- Except in the Midwest Wheat Belt and in livestock areas, prices on farm real estate have halted their five-year upward advance, I.W. Duggan, governor of the Farm Credit Administration, reported today to directors of the twelve FCA districts.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Sept. 2 (U.P.) -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur today declared that Japanese economy had improved beyond danger of imminent collapse and called upon the Allied nations soon to write a peace treaty to "insure that this country has an opportunity to become self-sustaining rather than reduced to a condition of mendicancy."
Travel agencies in the United States are pressing for an increase in their commissions from steamship lines on passenger bookings, it was reported here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- How the Federal Farm Mortgage Corporation fooled the experts by turning a profit of $105,000,000 on taking farmers out of debt only to promote a fight over disposition of the money is the story behind a tug o' war between Treasury and Farm Credit Administration officials for control of the funds.
LIMA, Peru, Sept. 2 (U.P.) -- Constitutional guarantees were suspended today by President Jose Luis Bustamante Rivero because of a five-day-old general strike in Lima and its port of Callao.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 2 -- President Truman stood today on the quarterdeck of the battleship Missouri, on the spot where exactly two years ago the Japanese surrender ended World War II and told Latin America that the Western Hemisphere had demonstrated it knew how to make peace and keep it.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Three subsidiaries of the New England Electric System filed separate applications with the Securities and Exchange Commission today, asking authority to borrow $2,400,000 to finance construction programs.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- An aspect of the two reports to the United Nations by its Special Committee on Palestine that has impressed high officials here is that both the majority and the minority groups concede great merit to the case for a Jewish homeland.

Two important topics affecting provisions of the Taft-Hartley law were discussed at yesterday's meeting of the Actors Equity Council, the union's governing board. Both were tabled until next Tuesday's meeting, to give a more representative gathering of the council an opportunity to vote on them.

NANKING, Sept. 2 (U.P.) -- China will not alter either her domestic or foreign policy as a result of Lieut. Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer's mission, Premier Chang Chun said in an interview today. Premier Chang charged that the Presidential emissary was "lax" In his investigation in China.

SOUTHPORT, Lancashire, England, Sept. 2 -- Although many aspects of the Labor Government's handling of Britain's economic crisis were strongly criticized here today, delegates representing the rank and file of the country's organized labor voted overwhelmingly in favor of government control of labor at the second day of the annual Trades Union Congress.

SECURITY COUNCIL Atomic Energy Commission -- Committee 1 adopted unanimously drafts of proceedings of Commission for Jan. 1 to Sept. 1 and of report on consideration of proposals of Soviet Union. Committee 2 continued discussion of six working papers.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (UP) -- Text of Acting Secretary of State Robert A. Lovett's reply to a Russian note on the London conference on increasing the level of German industry:

CAMDEN, N.J., Sept 2 (AP) -- Four horses hit the wire as a team in the Westmont purse today at Garden State Park. After some deliberation the judges posted Mrs. W.W. Vaughan's Briar White the winner by a nose over Jaclyn Stable's Brown Moat.

With Jack Kramer of Los Angeles gunning for his second straight championship, seventeen countries will be represented in the national singles tournament starting Friday at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.

LONDON, Sept. 2 -- Millions of pounds were slashed from the market valuation of British industrial shares in stock markets today. After a fortnight of progressive declines, jobbers lowered bids as protection against the rush of investors trying to get out of their holdings.
Representatives of two maritime unions protested here yesterday against dismissals by ship operators of pursers and purser-pharmacist mates.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, vice chairman of the new Senate-House Special Housing Investigation Committee, today denounced what he described as "garbage-dump" veterans' housing and inaugurated an intensive campaign to "lick the housing problem."

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 2 (AP) -- M.J. Brady's Sole Parate, among the leaders from the start, saved ground along the rail and won the six-furlong Block Island purse for 4-year-olds and upward at Narragansett Park today. He finished a length and a half ahead of Mrs.
ALBANY, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Sharply increased enrollments, from kindergartens to colleges, were forecast today by the State Department of Education as the annual back-to-school movement began.
All kinds and cuts of meat went up 1 to 3 cents a pound at wholesale yesterday, and some retailers raised their prices by as much as 5 cents a pound over last Friday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- United States policy toward western Europe can no longer be safely based on the hope of Soviet co-operation in world peace and security, the National Planning Association's committee on international policy declared today in a public statement.

Two of the most pressing problems facing New York's public school system are the delays in new school construction and the revision of curricula to meet present-day needs, Dr. William. Jansen declared yesterday in his first statement as Superintendent of Schools.

LONDON, Sept. 2 -- The United States Congressional Committee on Foreign Aid, getting down to work on its first day in London, today heard the world shortage of dollars blamed for Britain's economic crisis.

CANBERRA, Australia, Sept. 2 -- A drastic reduction, of all Australian dollar imports except essential machinery and raw materials was announced tonight by Prime Minister Joseph B. Chifley following Cabinet discussions. The cuts will be effected immediately, he said, and all existing import licenses will be recalled and new licenses issued where approved.

Federal Judge John C. Knox directed from the bench yesterday, that toll collectors on the Saw Mill River Parkway issue receipts for the 10-cent tolls that have been exacted from motorists since 12:01 A.M. last Thursday.

Fall season buying in the New York garment markets showed signs of continuing strong despite some falling off of business at retail, a survey of the trade showed yesterday. Resident offices reported substantial reorders on coats, suits and dresses by mail after the Labor Day holiday, and the first influx of store buyers seeking to place their final orders for fall.

Many thousands of vacationists from the metropolitan area had the same idea about Labor Day travel and the result was that roads in many sections of New Jersey and Westchester were more crowded yesterday than they had been on Labor Day.

GUAM, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Nineteen Japanese today were convicted of torturing to death ten American prisoners of war in 1944 by the in-human experimental use of bacteria, dynamite, strangulation, bayonets and bamboo spears.

Two sessions of hard work under a hot sun marked Columbia's first football practice at Baker Field yesterday. Coach Lou Little, after watching his fifty-three candidates run, pass, block and tackle during the morning and afternoon, summed up his impressions by saying, "We'll have about the same team as last year."
CHICAGO, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

OTTAWA, Sept. 2 -- Unless Canada can get enough dollars from her exports to pay for her imports from the United States she will have to make radical and revolutionary changes in her entire economic structure, Finance Minister Douglas C. Abbott said today on the eve of his departure for London to attend the second annual meeting of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 2 -- The Soviet Union delegation in the United Nation Military Staff Committee, which refused last June to join the four other great powers in making any suggestion regarding the size of the proposed international police force, has now submitted a tentative estimate, it was learned today.

Further selective improvement was registered yesterday by the stock market which carried the composite rate ahead to the level of a week ago, but the force of trading remained tempered. Most of the key industrial issues reduced increases to fractions just before the close of trading, some of the high-price issues advanced more than a point and the combined averages showed a rise of 0.72 point on the day.
MADISON, Wis., Sept. 2 -- The National Student Association today voted 315 to 265 against permitting affiliation with other national student organizations.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The Waterman Steamship Company, of Mobile, Ala., charged the Martitime Commission with "evasion and circumvention" of Federal laws in chartering of government-owned ships, in a suit filed here today in the United States District Court.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Sept. 2 -- Lieut. Gen. V.P. Sviridov, Russian chairman of the Allied Control Commission for Hungary, summoned Socialist party leaders to confer with him today after he had heard that they had threatened to bolt the Communist-dominated coalition.

GENEVA, Switzerland, Sept. 2 -- The hotly debated issue of the permanent home of the United Nations Food and Agricultural Organization was decided in favor of the United States today by a vote of 22 to 20 in a conference plenary session.

A "Week" That Should Move Us All Of all the many days and weeks set aside by national or state edict none so well deserves the attention and support of the American people as that period just proclaimed by President Truman, the "National Employ the Physically Handicapped Week," set for Oct. 5-11.

Herbert Hoover believes it was unnecessary for the United States to enter World War II. He thinks we would never have been attacked by the Japanese "if we had not given them provocation." He also believes that no agreement with Generalissimo Stalin is "worth a damn."

Ted Atkinson, who earned more than $100,000 at his horsebacking trade last year, yesterday gave the 17,059 customers at Aqueduct another sampling of the riding skill which has made him an upper-bracket taxpayer.

Local officials of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, forecast last night that their members would strike against the New York City Omnibus Corporation by next Monday or earlier, in retaliation for legal moves by the company yesterday to enjoin a strike.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The House Small Business Committee reported today that a consumer cooperative at Greenbelt, Md., paid less than 30 per cent of the Federal taxes it would have paid as a private corporation.

PARIS, Wednesday, Sept. 3 -- Premier Paul Ramadier early today demanded a vote of confidence from the National Assembly on his entire economic and financial program. Since one day must elapse between the posing of the question of confidence and the actual vote, the Government's fate will not be decided until Friday morning.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Red Embree pitched the Indians to a 3-to-2 victory for his seventh triumph of the season tonight despite a ninth-inning rally in which the St. Louis Browns scored two runs and drove him from the box.
Veterans of World War II lined up at banks across the nation in moderate to heavy numbers yesterday to turn their terminal leave bonds into cash.

I REMEMBER distinctly the tumult and the shouting of Armistice Day, 1918, and the first woman I ever saw smoke a cigarette, and Rudolf Valentino's glossy hair, and the way Bobby Jones hit a golf ball, and the midget who sat on J.P. Morgan's knee and Fritz Kuhn imitating his master before the German-American Bund -- and so do a hundred million Americans.

BERLIN, Sept. 2 -- The new level-of-industry program for the economically merged United States and British zones has posed still another problem in the already difficult reparations situation, it was indicated today. This is the question whether the Russians will accept the lists of available plants to be offered to a four-power board for evaluation and allocation.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 2 -- Nineteen American republics signed today what will be called the Treaty of Rio de Janeiro, in the first formal implementation of Article 51 of the United Nations Charter, which sanctions the banding together of nations for individual or collective self-defense.

IT was during the Army-Columbia game at West Point last year that Stout Steve Owen delivered a most profound observation. The well-upholstered coach of the New York Football Giants had seen Doc Blanchard and Junior Davis in virtually every fray they'd played during their glorious years at the Academy and his admiration for them obviously was increasing week by week.

Adding to its holding at 471 Park Avenue, which it acquired about three years ago, the Aluminum Company of America has purchased the stock in the 110 East Fifty-eighth Street Corporation, thereby taking title to the four-story structure occupied by the Brummer Gallery at 110-114 East Fifty-eighth Street, and the two five-story apartment and store buildings at 115 and 117 East Fifty-seventh Street.

R. H. Macy Co.'s great expectations over the opening yesterday of its new store in Jamaica were more than exceeded. Between the time the store opened at 9:30 A.M. and the closing hour of 5:45 P.M., 70,000 persons passed through its doors, Richard Cukor, 36-year-old store manager, estimated.

LONDON, Sept. 2 -- The strike situation in the Yorkshire coal mines took an alarming turn for the worse today as stoppages spread to twenty-nine pits. Nearly 30,000 miners are now out on unofficial strikes and the loss to the country of this most precious of all commodities is estimated at 130,000 tons.

IOWA CITY, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The University of Iowa ripped the lid off the 1947 Big Nine football season today when fifty squad members of a slated fifty-four reported to Coach Eddie Anderson to start drills. The eight other Western Conference squads will report tomorrow.

Creosote-soaked railroad ties on a trestle of the Long Island Rail Road spanning Jamaica Bay between Howard and Rockaway Beaches burst into flames at 6:50 o'clock last night. The resulting two-alarm fire disrupted schedules and stranded thousands of persons at the Rockaways and delayed homebound workers in the communities of Raunt, Hamilton Beach, Howard Beach and Aqueduct.

Plans for the expansion and modification of the City College School of Technology, which provide for the erection of two small building's and redistribution of present facilities at a cost of $500,000, were announced yesterday by Dr. Harry N. Wright, president of the college.

We prophesy a busy fall for the Lichtman brothers if word about their new pastries gets around, as it's bound to. One would think that summer might have deadened the inspiration of these two men, for a bakery can get very hot, and theirs, at 561 Amsterdam Avenue, at Eighty-seventh Street, is no exception.
Acting District Attorney Edward F. Breslin of the Bronx said yesterday that he was looking into the policy racket in that borough to learn who the higher-ups might be.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 2 -- The office of the Nassau County Real Estate Bureau was reminiscent of the government land office of frontier days today as eager buyers of tax delinquent property jammed its quarters in the new courthouse here to "stake out claims."

In 1858 when R.H. Macy's was founded by a retired sea captain, who set up in business on Sixth Avenue near Fourteenth Street, the population of all New York City was only about a million souls. Queens was so small that no Manhattan merchant would have given it a second thought.
ROME, Sept. 2 -- Casale Monferrato, a city of about 30,000 inhabitants in the Province of Alessandria in northwestern Italy, has been occupied since yesterday morning by partisans.

SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 2 -- A new group of metals and ceramics soon will be available for atomic energy power plants and for new high-powered machines such as the turbo-jet and rocket, it was declared here tonight by Dr. Clyde E. Williams, director of Battelle Memorial Institute, Columbus, Ohio.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 2 -- Joseph Than and Anita Loos will produce their own screen story, "White Night," as an independent venture, probably for United Artists or RKO release, their attorney, Jacques Leslie, disclosed today. The story originally was scheduled for production by United States Pictures, with Joan Crawford as the star, but U.S. Pictures abandoned the project because Miss Crawford was not available.

Store Sales Here Drop 3% Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores last week were 3 per cent below the figure for the like period of last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

EAST BROOKFIELD, Mass., Sept. 2 -- Discussions of housing and residential segregation occupied the afternoon session of the thirty-seventh annual meeting of the National Urban League at Camp Atwater today. Speakers from Federal agencies, and the league attempted to arrive at the best steps to be taken in Negro communities for better housing.
NUREMBERG, Germany, Sept. 2 (AP) -- American prosecutors confronted I.G. Farben directors today with their own records showing that they had contributed $12,000,000 to the Nazis from 1933 to 1934.

Mayor O'Dwyer told 174 probationary patrolmen, who were graduated from the Police Academy, Recruit Training School, yesterday in the gymnasium of Manhattan Police Headquarters, that the morale of the Police Department was at its highest because of Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander.

A series of interviews and press tours to emphasize the need for continued care for the children of working mothers has been scheduled by the Child Care Center Parents Association, Mrs. Janet Karlson, acting president, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, sept. 2 -- James B. Carey, secretary-treasurer of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, declared today that he would recommend to the meeting of CIO vice presidents on Thursday that they refuse to sign the anti-Communist affidavit which is required before any affiliate may have access to the National Labor Relations Board.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Sept. 2 -- Fifty-five candidates for the City College football team, accompanied by six coaches headed by Dr. Harold J. Parker, arrived at their pre-season training camp today and immediatey staged a late-afternoon two-hour calisthenics drill.

Invocation of the Taft-Hartley Act to upset Mayor O'Dwyer's formula for settlement of the two-year-old jurisdictional dispute at Idlewild Airport presented several novel problems yesterday to the regional office of the National Labor Relations Board.

SAN FANCISCO, Sept. 2 -- The first group of American war veterans returning to Australia under that country's immigration program aimed at almost tripling the population in two and a half generations sailed late today aboard the Matson liner Marine Phoenix.

There is too much talk of war in the world and not enough talk of peace, James F. O'Neil, newly elected National Commander of the American Legion, said yesterday. The stocky police chief of Manchester, N.H., was outlining his policies upon assumption of his new office as head of the country's 3,220,763 Legionnaires in a final interview before leaving New York for the National offices at Indianapolis.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Sept. 2 -- In a day when world public opinion is a force which may determine global survival, the world public's information about international affairs is "woefully inadequate at best and dangerously distorted at worse," William Benton, Assistant Secretary of State, declared here tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Reports of widespread dissatisfaction with the actions of the Republican-controlled 80th Congress came in from all sections of the country tonight as the Democratic National Committee staged the first nationwide political meeting in radio history.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- A move by the Mexican Government to call back farm laborers illegally in this country was interpreted here today as fulfilling a United States-Mexican immigration agreement which would not in the long run hamper southern harvests.
The obligation of survivors of two world wars to work for world peace through the United Nations was stressed yesterday afternoon by John M. Murtagh, Commissioner of Investigation.
The State Liquor Authority received not a single complaint yesterday as package liquor store proprietors bowed to the state's fair trade price rules that became effective on Labor Day.

Twenty families, the vanguard of 10,000 home-seekers, who are expected to find apartments on the site before the end of next year, moved yesterday into the first available suites of the New York Life Insurance Company's Fresh Meadow housing project in Flushing, Queens.

The Farnsworth Television and Radio Corporation introduced yesterday its first post-war television receiver to the trade at the offices of its metropolitan area distributor, D.W. May Corporation, 250 Fulton Street. The set, now in the dealer sampling stage, is a table model with a ten-inch, direct view tube and will retail at $349.50.

During the early post-war months, before price controls were removed, many industries found themselves faced with a situation that was new in their experience. They found themselves confronted with the dilemma of trying to make a profit when their prices were ceilinged but costs were mounting steadily.

The representatives of one-third of our world, of one-third of the members of the United Nations, gathered around the council table in beautiful old Itamaraty Palace in Rio de Janeiro yesterday afternoon to put their signatures to a hemisphere defense treaty that had been negotiated amicably and speedily in a conference lasting less than three weeks.

Three hundred and fifty well-muscled applicants for strong-arm jobs in the Sanitation Department turned up in Van Cortlandt Park at 9 A.M. yesterday for physical examination, mostly weight-lifting. They left without flexing a fiber.

GENEVA, Sept. 2 -- Finances permitting, the preparatory commission of the International Refugee Organization in cooperation with various governments will resettle about 96,500 displaced persons during the next three months, William Hallam Tuck, new secretary general of the organization, said today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Senator William Langer, Republican, of North Dakota, said today he had subpoenaed Attorney General Tom Clark, J. Edgar Hoover, director the Federal Bureau of Investigation, and Preston Delano, Controller of the Currency, to testify at a public hearing here next Tuesday dealing with the First National Bank of Williston, N.D.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Miss Mommy owned by Mrs. Elmer E. Dale Shaffer, won the opening day's feature at Hawthorne race track today, the $24,600 Hawthorne Juvenile Handicap, before a crowd of 13,859.

Issues of common and preferred shares priced to yield $6,826,731, representing new-money financing for the Westvaco Chlorine Products Corporation and the Hooker Electrochemical Company, will be offered today to investors.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Housing Expediter Frank R. Creedon today exempted certain amusement and recreational facilities from regulations requiring Federal construction permits.

In a major move toward integration of facilities for the temporary care of neglected and dependent children, the Department of Welfare took over yesterday the operation of the Children's Center, 1 East 104th Street.

Trading in cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday was sluggish. Final prices were 20 to 27 points net lower than on Monday. Opening with declines of 9 to 17 points lower, the market eased under increased hedge selling, liquidation and gloomy reports about the export demand.
A traffic patrolman's horse started on a ramble around Coney Island last night, setting off a series of mishaps that sent a patrolman to Coney Island Hospital in serious condition.

Prices on rayon textiles for immediate delivery continued yesterday to soar with a sustained demand by apparel manufacturers for goods to meet fall commitmentts. Suppliers reported that activity in second-hand markets is equal to or better than in any period during the war with prices 50 to 100 per cent above those quoted by first-hand sellers.

Among the forty-four passengers arriving at La Guardia Field yesterday on a Pan American World Airways Clipper from London were an 8-year-old boy from County Leitrim, Ireland, who traveled here for an operation, and an 81-year-old Californian who was on the next-to-the-last leg of a 'round the world trip.

Industrial production in Sweden was described yesterday as 20 per cent above the pre-war level by Prof. Erik Lundberg, director of Sweden's Business Cycle Research Institute, who arrived with 1,376 other passengers on the Swedish American liner Gripsholm.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Armed, Calumet Farm golden gelding that boosted his earnings to $641,600 by winning the Washington Park Handicap, was prepared today for shipment to Garden State Park at Camden, N.J., for what appeared to be further competitive sharpening for a match race with Assault.

Private trading channels will be Used to the maximum by the Federal Government in the procurement of about $75,000,000 of incentive civilian goods under the Greek aid program, it was announced yesterday by L.L. Horch, New York regional director of the Department of Commerce.

The following is the text of President Truman's address yesterday to the closing session of the Inter-American Defense Conference at Petropolis, Brazil, as recorded and transcribed, by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

BOSTON, Sept. 2 -- Widely separated points in New England were struck today by small cyclones of the type more usual to the Western prairies and three persons were killed and extensive property damage done, which it was estimated might run into millions of dollars.
Jacksonville, Fla., announced yesterday that it would receive bids on Oct. 7 on an Issue of $15,000,000 electric revenue certificates.
LONDON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Lord Beaverbrook's Evening Standard which has been waging a fight against Great Britain playing host to the 1948 Olympic Games took another swing at the project today.

Liberal and minority forces were thrown on the defensive during the last year, both domestically and internationally, the American Civil Liberties Union declared in a pamphlet report, published yesterday, entitled "In Times of Challenge."

Railway Wage Award Railroad executives are of the opinion that the wage award, amounting to around $438,000,000 annually, which was granted yesterday the non-operating unions by the Arbitration Board in Chicago, cannot be absorbed by the carriers, and that an increase in rates will be necessary.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: According to THE TIMES, an issue was engaged on Aug. 28 between the city, as represented by the Board of Estimate and Mayor O'Dwyer, and those who want the United Nations buildings to be somewhat more than a group of dead-end office buildings.

Twenty-seven double-headers and two single-game shows are listed on Madison Square Garden's 1947-1948 program of intercollegiate basketball. The most ambitious schedule in fourteen years of court operation has been arranged by Ned Irish, with nine major 1947 conference champions included among the forty-eight visitors from out of town.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 2 -- Egypt plans to ask the United States to send a military mission to aid in modernizing the Egyptian Army and Air Force, it was learned today.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Sept. 2 -- With his skull crushed by a series of heavy blows, the body of Albert Silverman, 11 years old, was found at 10:30 o'clock tonight in the dining room of his home at 278 Claremont Avenue. Detectives discovered a machinist's hammer near the body.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Plans for a 1950 "Census of the Americas" were started here today by representatives of fifteen Western Hemisphere countries. The taking of this census is the first aim of a special committee of the International Statistical Institute.

The first of the New York couture showings, as represented by the custom-made collections of the up-town specialty houses, took place yesterday afternoon at Jay Thorpe's. In a conservative manner it told the story of some of the new fashion trends.
NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Disorders flared at new and distant points in the new Pakistan and Indian Dominions today.

DUNDEE, Scotland, Sept. 2 -- Creatures that were half men and half apes and that once roamed over South Africa were discussed today at a section meeting of the British Association for the Advancement of Science by Prof. W.E. Legros Clark, distinguished anthropologist.

Deservedly or undeservedly, the Labor-Management Relations Act of 1947 (Taft-Hartley Act) has become the subject of more intense feeling than almost any piece of domestic legislation in recent years. It is peculiarly unfortunate, therefore, that in putting the law into gear the first major test of its administration should turn on one of the weakest and most ambiguous clauses in the entire Act.

"A Cornish Childhood," by A.L. Rowse, English historian and author of "The English Spirit" and "West-Country Stories," will be published by Macmillan on Sept. 23. It is the story of his rise from the son of a china-clay worker who could barely read to a fellow of All Souls College, Oxford.

FOREST PARK, Pa., Sept. 2 -- Officers of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, AFL, will not sign the anti-Communist affidavits required under the Taft-Hartley labor law until all members of the Executive Council of the American Federation of Labor have signed.

"On Stage America," another program affording young talent an opportunity to be heard on the air, is announced for a premiere at 8 P.M., Monday, Sept. 29, over the ABC netwrok. Paul Whiteman will act as master of ceremonies. Performers desirous of being heard on the show will be auditioned first by means of recordings, with successful applicants being directed to their nearest ABC affiliate for a pick-up on the network.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The majority report of the United Nations Special Palestine Committee deserves the vigorous support of the United States at the forthcoming sessions of the Security Council and of the Assembly. Without such support there will be almost no chance that the proposed partition program can be improved and implemented.

With their fun restricted only by the fact that boating and related water sports were discouraged, 2,000 New York boys and girls spent a busy and happy afternoon yesterday at Bear Mountain as guests of the Police Athletic League.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Rollo, the Coldstream Stud's promising son of Volomite-Ruth M. Chenault, today won the $26,905 Horseman Stake for 2-year-old trotters at the Indiana State Fair Grand Circuit meet.

ENDICOTT, N.Y., Sept. 2 -- Held to a draw in the fourth round of the annual tournament for the championship of the New York State Chess Association, Frank Collins of Albany today was deadlocked for the lead by Albert S. Pinkus of Brooklyn at 3 1/2 -- 1/2.

Oakite to Use Newspapers Oakite Products, Inc., will use newspapers from coast to coast this fall, it was announced yesterday by Frank A. Connolly, merchandising manager, who lauded the effectiveness of newspaper advertising. In these highly competitive days, he commented, "the tremendous localized circulation that newspapers deliver for us, helps to not only protect our old markets but also to successfully develop the newer areas."

BERLIN, Sept. 2 -- There is a distinct possibility of France's finding a way of joining Great Britain and the United States in a three zone merger if she is able to obtain sufficient concessions at the coming Berlin conferences within the framework of the new level-of-industry plan.

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Richard K. Phelps, special assistant Attorney General, asserted today that "stiffs and ghosts were loaded into motor cars and carried from one precinct to another from central clearing stations," in the 1946 primary election in Kansas City.

Delivered from a platform exemplifying hemispheric solidarity, the President's definition of American policy at Petropolis had unusual force. The idea of Pan-America, united by formal treaty in a common defense system, makes an extraordinary impression on the rest of the world.

ATHENS, Sept. 2 -- Themistocles Sophoulis, 87-year-old leader of the Liberal party, declared in an interview today that he would never, under any circumstances, enter the Government of Premier Constantin Tsaldaris. Mr. Sophoulis said the Populist Government was "inadmissible" in the light of Greek political traditions and the national interest.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The Soviet Government in a note delivered to the American Embassy in Moscow and received at the State Department today refused to open Dairen, Manchuria, to international commerce as a free port or to be responsible for treatment of American interests there. A "substantial portion" of the note was made public by the department without comment.

In an effort to fit seasons and bag limits to wildlife conditions, New York will, for the first time, depart from a uniform open season on pheasants, with some areas receiving a 1 1/2-day season, others 5 1/2 days. All seasons will open on Oct. 20.

LONDON, Sept. 2 (Reuters) -- South Africa's cricket game against Sussex ended in a tie today after it had declared at its overnight score of 555 for six wickets. After the match the tourists left for Hastings, where they will start their final first-class match of the tour against a strong South of England side.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The United States has rejected flatly the Russian protest against the decision of the United States and Britain to raise the level of industry in their economically merged zones in Germany.

Mayor O'Dwyer, a member of the American Legion, said yesterday that in rejecting the Taft-Ellender-Wagner housing bill at its national convention, the Legion had exhibited "a deep, low sense of ingratitude" to the veteran.

PETROPOLIS, Brazil, Sept. 2 -- President Truman closed the Inter-American Defense Conference here today with a speech reducing the basic foreign policy of the United States to a desire for permanent peace, but emphasizing that to carry it out, the nation was determined to remain strong.

The Hilton Hotels Corporation established new highs in volume and earnings in the first half of this year, according to a letter to shareholders released for publication today by C.N. Hilton, president.

An optimistic view on rehabilitation progress in England and France was expressed here yesterday by Capt. Granville Conway, president of the Cosmopolitan Shipping Company, and President Truman's coordinator of emergency export programs.

LONDON, Sept. 2 -- Under pressure and promises from the United States State Department, the British Government showed signs today of relenting in its determination to withdraw all British troops from Greece by the end of this year.

Marking the largest monthly decrease this year, sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a decline of 9 per cent in August, compared with the same month of last year, according to the survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Football will make its local debut tonight when the Eastern College All-Stars, led by Army's incomparable Doc Blanchard and Glenn Davis, oppose the New York Giants of the National League before a capacity crowd of more than 52,000 at the Polo Grounds.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 2 -- With efforts of both a Congressional subcommittee and the Catholic Archdiocese to settle the American Federation of Labor jurisdictional strike in Hollywood unavailing, union officials hazarded tonight that the next major move might develop at the American Federation of Labor Convention in San Francisco next month.

Compulsory inspection of motor vehicles was emphasized as a ranking requirement for highway safety by the Special Joint legislative Committee on Motor Vehicle Problems in announcing yesterday the opening of a state-wide survey to improve road conditions.

DUGALD, Man., Sept. 2 (AP) -- The worst train wreck in western Canada's history killed at least twenty-seven persons and injured seriously fifteen others here late last night when a Canadian National Railways campers' special crashed head on into a stationary transcontinental passenger train at this flag station twenty miles east of Winnipeg.
The Atlas Plywood Corporation was able to expand its sales by 35 per cent in the fiscal year ended on June 30, it was announced yesterday.

MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., Sept. 2 -- "Democracy's key to winning over the twilight countries where the battle of ideologies is being fought" was being offered at the Moral Re-Armament conferences in session at Caux, Switzerland, and here, A.R.K. Mackenzie, member of the United Kingdom delegation to the United Nations, declared today.

JACKSON, N.C., Sept. 2 (AP) -- A superior court judge today dismissed charges against six of seven white men accused in the attempted lynching of a Negro but had the Northampton County jailer arrested and bound the seventh defendant over to a grand jury.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- President and Mrs. Truman will find their official residence looking much brighter when they get back from their Brazilian trip. Redecoration of much of the interior of the White House was completed today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: All over the United States, G.I. students have been making better scholarship records in the colleges than the other students. This has been generally accounted for by the consideration that they are more mature than the average students and more serious in purpose.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2 -- By a vote of four to two a six-man arbitration board today awarded a pay increase of 15 1/2 cents an hour to about 1,000,000 members of seventeen non-operating unions employed on the country's 130 Class One railroads.

New highlights of fashion such as the rounded shoulder, the tiny waist-and the longer skirt were featured in the collection presented by the Tailored Woman yesterday at the St. Regis Roof. Aimed at a middle course and never extreme, many versions of the new silhouettes were shown in a range of rich colors including red, green, brown, blue, the neutrals and black.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 2 (AP) -- A big sixth inning carried the Senators to their third straight victory and cost the Athletics their seventh consecutive defeat tonight, 7--4.

PARIS, Sept. 2 -- Sir Oliver Franks, chairman of the European conference on the Marshall Plan, said today that the "valuable advice" given by United States officials would receive "full consideration" in the framing of the conference's final report.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept.2 -- Prof. Dmitri M. Skobeltsyn, deputy Soviet representative on the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission, announced today that the Soviet Union would not submit amendments to the six working papers defining the functions of the proposed International Atomic Control Agency.

If the city's child-care centers become a part of the state's juvenile delinquency prevention campaign, "literally thousands of children would be removed from the program and in essence it would no longer be a program for working mothers," the Child Care Center Parents Association, 201 West Eighty-ninth Street, charged yesterday in a letter to Welfare Commissioner Edward E. Rhatigan.

Despite objections by some members of the city administration to the present form of the bills, indications last night were that the Board of Estimate would adopt today the three Sharkey bills to establish municipal controls over rents and evictions, with stiff penalties for violations.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- The United States has made a new move in an effort to save Nikola Petkov, leader of the Bulgarian Agrarian party, through a note delivered to the Soviet Foreign Ministry by Lieut. Gen. W. Bedell Smith, United States Ambassador in Moscow, the State Department announced today.

When the New York City Omnibus Corporation accepted arbitration of its dispute with the Transport Workers Union over new contract terms it bound itself to accept the arbitrator's findings. The arbitrator, David L. Cole, awarded a pension plan, but the company is balking, on the grounds that the decision was ambiguous.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Sept. 3 -- Princeton University is preparing a current master index of world public opinion that will be available soon for distribution to reference libraries.

Thirty-four men and four women athletes were named yesterday by the Amateur Athletic Union as the United States Eastern Seaboard squad that is to oppose an Eastern Canada team in a dual track and field meet at McGill University's Molson Stadium in Montreal on Saturday.

Important style changes in women's wear, set in motion in recent months, will flower by the spring of 1948 into "greater variety, subtlety of design and universal acceptance," according to the consensus yesterday at a preview showing of garments and accessories for next season held under the auspices of the National Shoe Retailers Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 3 -- Delegates to the Connecticut Federation of Labor's state convention approved today a resolution calling upon the New Britain Board of Education to bargain in good faith in negotiations with its teachers.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 3 -- Closing a month-long Congressional inquiry into the Hollywood film studio strike, Representative Carroll Kearns announced plans tonight for a new effort to settle the eleven-month jurisdictional controversy within the American Federation of Labor.

Petitions with 139,316 signatures calling for a referendum at the November election to repeal the proportional representation method of electing members of the City Council were filed yesterday with City Clerk Murray W. Stand in the Municipal Building.

ALBANY, Sept. 3 -- A right wing move to withhold official endorsement from the American Labor party was rejected by a margin of nearly four to one today by the executive board of the state Congress of Industrial Organizations.

A third volume in "The Founding of American Civilization," by Thomas Jefferson Wertenbaker, has been scheduled for publication on Monday by Scribner. "The Puritan Oligarchy" is a study of Massachusetts. The previous volumes were "The Middle Colonies" and "The Old South."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (U.P.) -- The text of the State Department note to the Soviet Union again protesting death sentence imposed on Nikola Petkov, leader of the Bulgarian anti-Communist party, follows: My Government has received your communication of Aug. 25 concerning the case of Nikola Petkov.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Sept. 3 -- The United States-Turkish agreement on aid to Turkey was ratified by the National Assembly yesterday.

MADISON, Wis., Sept. 3 -- Delegates to the constitutional convention of the National Student Association here today completed a major part of their work in drafting a constitution, with only the questions of racial discrimination and affiliation with the International Union of Students left to be resolved.

According to news dispatches from London yesterday, the strike in the Yorkshire coal mines which began on Aug. 11 has taken a turn for the worse. The stoppage, it appears, now involves one-fifth of that area's collieries; 50,000 miners are out, and the loss in production of this vital commodity has mounted to 200,000 tons.

In a refinancing of a group of buildings on the East Side, the Sonnenblick-Goldman Company, broker, obtained for the Lee-Bee Realty Company a first mortgage loan of $380,000 for ten years. The property was acquired by the present owner from the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company last year for $750,000, subject to a purchase money mortgage of $425,000 which is being paid off from the proceeds of the new mortgage.

An appropriation of $10,000,000 has been made by the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company to treble its present production of pliofilm and airfoam products, E.J. Thomas, president of the company, said in an interview here yesterday.

Ben Raimondi, a Brooklyn boy who made good in Indiana, was groomed yesterday by Coach Ray Flaherty for early duty in the New York Football Yankees' home opener against the Chicago Rockets at the Yankee Stadium tomorrow night.
Fordham's football reconversion entered its second phase yesterday is thirty-nine candidates for the squad embarked on a five-week training program at Rose Hill.

Four young men who seemed vaguely familiar brushed past Miss Ann Maglio, 28 years old, as she patted on her makeup on the ground floor of her home at 805 Barbey Street in Brooklyn's New Lots district at 8:20 A.M. yesterday.
White on Blue Pictures and descriptions of old New York make much of the white sails on the surrounding waters. White sails are not conspicuous in the spectacle presented by the harbor today.

At the annual meeting of stockholders of the United States Plywood Corporation yesterday, Lawrence Ottinger, president, said that net profit in the first quarter of its fiscal year on July 31 amounted to "nearly" $5 a common share, compared with 86 cents a share in the corresponding 1946 quarter.

PARIS, Sept. 3 -- Having almost despaired of United States action this year to relieve Europe's economic crisis, leaders of the European conference on the Marshall plan were delighted and encouraged tonight by the statement by Robert A. Lovett, United States Acting Secretary of State, declaring such action was necessary.

Richard Allen Knight, lawyer who was disbarred and sent to prison for circulating libelous letters about judges who had ruled against him in litigation over a $14,000,000 inheritance, was facing prosecution again yesterday for the same offense.

WARSAW, Sept. 3 -- The frightening specter of a revived aggressor Germany endangering both the country's security and the people's hopes for a better way of life is being drawn for the Polish nation as a result of the new AngloAmerican agreement on the level of German industry.

Six Eastern Orthodox churches were among twenty-three new affiliates added to the World Council of Churches in the last six months, Dr. Henry Smith Leiper, associate secretary, announced yesterday. There are now 116 affiliates in thirty-six countries.

Running an even race, in which he improved his position with stop-watch precision, the Clynmalyra Stud's 5-year-old Equanimous strode home to victory in the Tottenville, the mile-and-asixteenth event that featured the program at the Aqueduct race track yesterday.

Mayor O'Dwyer is scheduled to tack up the first safety poster at 3 P.M. today in a city-wide campaign warning motorists to protect children on the streets when they return to school next Monday. Ten thousand of these signs will urge drivers to "Take it Easy."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- British Foreign Secretary Bevin's proposal that the United States Government's gold at Fort Knox, Ky., be "redistributed" caught Washington officialdom completely by surprise. The reaction here was for the most part facetious, since officials could find no basis for the proposal in economics or common sense.

In the belief that establishment of a world federal government alone can assure the survival of man, World Federalist delegates from nineteen nations, meeting at Montreux, Switzerland, have urged transformation of the United Nations into a world federal government through increasing its authority and resources and amendment of its Charter.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: We wish to register a protest against two recent articles by Representative J. Parnell Thomas of New Jersey, chairman of the Congressional Committee on Un-American Activities. These are "Russia Grabs Our Inventions," American Magazine for June, and "Reds in Our Atom Plants," Liberty for June 21.

ALBANY, Sept. 3 -- Lieut. Gov. Joe R. Hanley, who returned to Albany last night from a two-week visit to the Middle West, said today that Governor Dewey' chances for the 1948 Republican Presidential nomination were increased by a belief in that section of the country that the election would not be too easy for the Republicans next year.

A police seaplane, three police launches, two Coast Guard cutters and a dozen uniformed policemen were dispatched to lower New York Bay late yesterday afterooon when word came from South Beach, a summer resort on the east shore of Staten Island, that a small boy was being carried out to sea on a red raft.

SELINSGROVE, Pa., Sept. 3 -- (AP) -- Amos Alonzo Stagg Sr., who has spent fifty-five of his eightyfive years as a football coach, today signed a new ten-year contract to work with his son in dealing up gridiron strategy at Susquehanna University.

"On behalf of the people of the United States," President Truman announced last night to the Fourth International Cancer Research Congress that progress in the production of radioisotopes by the United States Atomic Energy Commission now permits limited distribution to qualified research workers in other countries of radioisotopes, principally for medical and biological research.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 3 -- The United Nations Social Commission should attack the problem of the protection of family life, Georges Pernot, French delegate, declared in the sixth meeting of the commission here today. M. Pernot suggested that the commission's studies of this problem should include measures taken in various countries for the preparation of youth for marriage.

GENEVA, Switzerland, Sept. 3 -- Observers here who are familiar with the Palestine problem and the position of the Jewish Agency regard the just-issued statement of the Zionist General Council as a virtual endorsement of the report of the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine.

Some department stores that have not handled reconditioned refrigerators since before the war are seriously considering entrance into the field, retailers reported yesterday. Increased sales volume recently by appliance specialty stores and other retail outlets is said to be behind the move.

FOREST PARK, Pa., Sept. 3 -- The general executive board of the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union, AFL, began a fight today to have the Taft-Hartley labor law repealed by authorizing the establishment of a political department in the union and a $500,000 fund to supplement its activities.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 3 -- Lifting of the ban against the exportation of radioactive isotopes to scientists of foreign countries, making these enormously important research tools available at last for medical and biological investigations outside the United States, was announced tonight by President Truman.

The rise in Brooklyn of a new murder-for-hire gang rivaling the infamous "Murder, Inc.," was revealed yesterday in Kings County Court with the disclosure that there have been eight unsolved murders in that borough in the last year.

Mayor O'Dwyer declined yesterday because of "pressure of official business" an invitation to go to Moscow to take part in the three-day celebration of the 800th anniversary of the Russian capital, scheduled to start on Saturday.

PARIS, Sept. 3 -- Claude BouchinetSerreulle, secretary general of the European conference on the Marshall plan, suggested today that Western Europe might not need to import United States coal after 1951.

BOSTON, Sept. 3 -- The Yankee farewell to Fenway Park for 1947 was a cacophony of thirty-four hits that engulfed six pitchers, two of them on double-duty detail, and swamped the Red Sox in a doubleheader that attracted 32,723 paying spectators.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The question of the appropriateness of war memorials has been raised in a letter to THE TIMES. Its writer, noting the prevalent trend in the direction of living memorials, suggests that it might be well for sculptors to submit scale models of their work for countrywide exhibition and consideration.

Another project on the Broadway horizon is DeWitt Bodeen's new play, "Harvest of Years." Arthur J. Beckhard staged the work this summer at two Massachusetts theatres (Martha's Vineyard Playhouse and the Tanglewood Theatre, Falmouth) and was so pleased with the results that he has decided to go ahead with plans for a New York presentation in midOctober.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 --The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninetyfour cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Aug. 27, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

STONINGTON ISLAND, Marguerite Bay, Antarctic, Sept. 1 (Delayed) -- Our main southern trail party left this morning. Just after dawn they headed across the frozen waters of Marguerite Bay to start a 1,200-mile journey into unknown areas that will keep them on the trail for 100 days.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Sept. 3 -- Formally charged by the police with the hammer murder of her 11-year-old brother, Pearl Silverman, 18, of 278 Claremont Avenue, of this city, calmly re-enacted the slaying today in the presence of police officials and investigators of the Hudson County Prosecutor's office.

The forerunners of four British models of 1948 cars were presented at a preview yesterday by the Austin Motor Company, Ltd., at the American headquarters, 1920 Broadway. Two of the models displayed will sell for from $1,300 to $1,500, and the others from $3,500 to $4,000 delivered here.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 3 -- The Carolina Telephone and Telegraph Company, Tarboro, N.C., registered today with the Securities and Exchange Commission 21,250 shares of $100 par value common capital stock, which are to be offered at par to holders of its outstanding 53,124 shares of record on Oct 1.
QUITO, Ecuador, Sept. 3 (U.P) -- Two Provincial Governments were active in Ecuador tonight, a civilian one in Quito and a military one in Ambato.

The share market on the Stock Exchange was restricted again yesterday by a lack of trading interest and prices drifted narrowly and closed mixed. Except for the aircraft and a few gold mining issues, the industrial leaders received meager attention.

Setting the stage for further protests about the use of the "blind" draw, the United States Golf Association yesterday announced the pairings and starting times for the 210 players who will compete in the forty-seventh national amateur golf championship at the Pebble eBach course, Del Monte, Calif., next week.

CHICKENS never should be counted until they're hatched but there has been considerable talk of late, just as there was in 1941, about the advisability of shifting the Brooklyn end of the world series from tiny Ebbets Field to the capacious Yankee Stadium. The Sporting News, baseball's bible, even printed a recent "feeler" story in an effort to crystallize fan sentiment in that direction.
SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 3 -- The United States delegation to the Joint Commission has again rejected Soviet proposals to break the deadlock of the commission on Russian terms, it was announced today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3 -- Judge John P. Barnes of Federal District Court today directed United States Attorney Otto Kerner Jr. to draw up an order calling for a special Federal Grand Jury to convene Sept. 22 for hearing evidence on alleged price fixing by the food industry in Chicago.

ATHENS, Sept. 3 -- On the eve of the meeting of Parliament, before which Premier Constantin Tsaldaris still plans to present an all-Populist Cabinet for a vote of confidence, all Greek parties were agreed that the Cabinet was unsatisfactory but negotiations for its improvement were stalemated.

TROY, Sept. 3 -- Supreme Court Justice William H. Murray today upheld the quarantine order issued by the Commissioner of Agriculture in areas infected by the golden nematode, asserting that the law directing action to control the disease "is within the intent, spirit, scope and purpose of the Constitution."

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 3 -- Since the demise of the Office of Price Administration there has not only been irregular price-fixing on foods but also irregular scales practices such as short weights, John S. Burke, Jersey City, president of the New Jersey Weights land Measures Association, said today.

The sequel to the Hungarian elections supplies an answer to two of the most pertinent questions of our troubled time. Is It worth while for nations in Hungary's unhappy position to keep on fighting against overwhelming odds for political and civil liberties?

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Representative Clarence J. Brown of Ohio, chairman of the executive committee of the Republican National Committee, accused the Democratic high command today of attempting to "drag our foreign policy into the arena of partisan politics."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 --The American Federation of Labor's executive council may temporize next week on the ruling that the Federation's fifteen members must sign anti-Communist affidavits before the National Labor Relations Board will service any petitions or complaints by affiliates.
CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 3 (AP) -- Horses from Warren Wright's Calumet Farm, leading money-winning stable of the year, made their first 1947 appearance at Garden State today and were beaten in two races.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 3 -- At the end of his tour of the disturbed Punjab today, Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, Prime Minister of the Dominion of India, estimated that 2,000,000 persons might be displaced from their homes in the India and Pakistan Provinces of the Punjab as the result of the communal warfare since the middle of August.

WARSAW, Sept. 2 (Delayed) -- One of the most important trials in Poland's turbulent post-war history will end in Cracow this week with the prosecutor's summation against thirteen defendants. Among them are two leaders of the Opposition Peasant party [PSL] and Col. Franciszek Diepokojczycki, former commander of the underground organization WIN [Freedom and Independence] group.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 3 (AP) -- The Indians staged a two-run, ninthinning rally to win the second game of a twilight-night doubleheader from the White Sox tonight, 6 -- 5. Chicago took the opener, 8 -- 3.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 3 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today the institution of proceedings to determine whether a stop order should be issued against a registration filed on July 9 by Thomascolor, Inc., of Los Angeles.

Railway Earnings The increase of 15 1/2 cents an hour in wages granted to the nonoperating unions of the railroads, effective as of last Monday, is expected to result in many leading carriers reporting large net deficits after charges this month unless the Interstate Commerce Commission grants speedy relief in the way of increased rates.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 3 -- The printing of receipts for issuance to motorists paying the new 10-cent toll on the Saw Mill River Parkway in Yonkers was begun tonight. However, the county park commission deferred until tomorrow the placing of signs at the toll booths to inform motorists they could obtain receipts "on request."

Unless someone comes along with a 52-pound 1/2-ounce striped bass between now and the first of the year, and this is not an impossibility, George Ruppert is going to have to make a Solomon decision in making the award for this class in the annual contest, for two anglers now are tied with stripers scaling 52 pounds.

Paul H. Griffith, past national commander of the American Legion, sailed with 150 Legionnaires aboard the Cunard White Star liner Queen Elizabeth yesterday for a tour of European battlefields and to study the displaced persons problem and German reconstruction.

From now on, the Broadway season is going to improve. For "The Magic Touch," which turned on the lights at the International last evening, begins at the foot of the class. It says here in small type in the program that it is a comedy, and that Charles Raddock and Charles Sherman acknowledge having written it.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Right-hander Bill MeCahan, Athletics' rookie, today faced only twenty-eight men -- one more than absolutely necessary -- to hurl a 3-0 no-hit triumph over the Senators. It was the third no-hitter in the majors and the second in the American League this season -- and the 131st such hurling feat achieved since records first were compiled back in 1875.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 3 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today applications of the Southern Natural Gas Company and the Public Service Company of Oklahoma.

The city is again facing the necessity of finding shelter for destitute persons and those evicted or about to be evicted from their homes, Mayor O'Dwyer declared yesterday after a conference with Welfare Commissioner Edward E. Rhatigan and Philip J. Cruise, secretary of the New York City Housing Authority.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 3 -- The world-wide diplomatic trek to Flushing Meadow for the United Nations General Assembly has been completed smoothly and without last year's hectic last-minute arrangements by 150 delegates and advisers, it was learned today.

Fewer Buyers Register Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended on last Tuesday totaled 304, compared with 987 last week and 550 in the corresponding week of 1946, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

The national open polo championship tournament semi-final round match scheduled for Sunday between Mexico, defending titleholder, and Mike Phipps' Meadow Brook four on International Field of the Meadow Brook Club, Westbury, L.I., has been postponed until Sept. 14.

A new wrapper has been developed for butter, so successful that in markets where it has been used sales have held their level or even increased, and this at a time when prices were so high that the demand for butter in conventional packages has fallen off.

A Maritime Commission hearing on the proposed incorporation of freight charges on bills of lading opened yesterday morning, with the Port of New York Authority taking a firm stand in favor of such inclusion. The hearings are being held at the St. George Hotel, Brooklyn, before C.W. Robinson, commission examiner.

ALBANY, Sept. 3 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, in a proclamation designating Sept. 16 as National Guard Day, called upon individuals, communities, organizations and firms to give their whole-hearted support to the recruiting drive.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 3 (AP) -- A.C. Randolph's Good News made her first start at Narragansett Park a wining one today as she took the featued sixth race almost five lengths ahead of Mrs. Tilyou Christopher's Donna's Ace.

The police of the West Sixtyeighth Street station feel that they can relax now that they have chained "Lightning." "Lightning," so dubbed because of his speed of foot, is a tall, slender youth who for the last four months has been snatching poeketbooks from women in the vicinity of Central Park West tat the Sixties.

Despite the first day's rush for cash, on Tuesday, the majority of World War II veterans apparently have decided to hold their terminal leave bonds awhile longer, collecting interest of 2 1/2 per cent a year, a survey of representative banks throughout the city disclosed yesterday.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Sept. 3 (Canadian Press) -- A decisive battle over Olympic hockey between Avery Brundage, chairman of the United States Olympic Committee, and the International Ice Hockey Federation is expected to break out at the Federation's fiveday meeting beginning Friday.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Hans Fritzsche, former Nazi propagandist, testified in a United States war crimes court today that "awkward or incorrect" Allied propaganda had helped prevent the Germans from learning the truth about the Nazis during the war.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 3 -- President Truman, slipping away from Secret Service men this morning, climbed 1,000 feet up Mount Corcovada (The Hunchback) and came down an enthusiastic orchidologist.
Subway service on the Pelham Bay line of the IRT was disrupted yesterday morning for an hour in the rush period when an empty six-car train was derailed as it approached the Pelham Bay station.

SOUTHPORT, England, Sept. 3 -- British Foreign Secretary Bevin, speaking before the annual meeting of the Trades Union Congress, called on the United States today to redistribute its gold store at Fort Knox, Ky., to finance world recovery.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Acting Secretary of State Robert A. Lovett warned today that the progressively worsening economic plight of Great Britain and Western Europe could not wait for the Marshall plan of European recovery and that affirmative action by this Government would be required before the year's end.

CARDIFF, Wales, Sept. 3 -- A brief comparison of Britain's coal production with that of other countries illustrates that the present coal problem in this island is not so much a "crisis" as a chronic condition.

LONDON, Sept. 3 (Reuters) -- Results of soccer games played in Great Britain tonight: ENGLISH LEAGUE First Division. Arsenal 6, Charlton Athletic 0. Derby County 1, Burnley 1. Grimsby Town 0, Wolverhampton Wanderers

NEITHER those who blindly hated President Franklin D. Roosevelt nor those who blindly worshipped him are going to get full satisfaction for their oddly complementary emotional needs from "Reilly of the White House,"* an informal portrait of F.D.R. This breezy young Irishman was the President's Secret Service guard during the last ten years of his life.

CAIRO, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Hussein Abul Fath, editor in chief of the paper Al Misri, arrested with three other Egyptian newsmen yesterday in connection with a report published here regarding the United Nations hearing of Egypt's complaint against Britain, was released after questioning today and his brother, Ahmed, a member of his staff, was arrested instead.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Detailed rules were laid down today by the Far Eastern Commission in a policy decision for the elimination of Japan's industrial war potential through the destruction of plants or the designation of them for reparations.

Textile jobbers are engaged actively in a policy of cleaning house to reduce their inventories, it was earned yesterday, and they are proceeding cautiously in new purchasing to the point where it virtually has become hand-to-mouth.

ALBANY, Sept. 3 -- The State Department of Education, acting with the authority of the Board of Regents, announced today that high school diplomas might now be earned, without attending school, by veterans whose formal education was interrupted by war service, and by other adults who did not complete high school.

Dr. Leopold W.A. Brandenburg of 4260 Hudson Boulevard in Union City, N.J., and five other persons were taken into custody by a largre raiding party of detectives and men from the District Attorney's office yesterday in the rooms of an alleged abortion syndicate at 1328 Commonwealth Avenue, the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Secretary of State Marshall returned today from the Inter-American Defense Conference at Rio de Janeiro with a report of complete success in welding the Western Hemisphere into a strong union of nations devoted to peace and mutual aid.
GENEVA, Sept. 3 -- Forewarnings of trouble for the World Trade and Employment Conference to be held at Havana in November were sounded in the Food and Agriculture Organization here today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) -- An official of the Department of Commerce said today that the Government soon will scrap controls over the use of natural rubber in approximately 30,000 products but retain limitations on usage in tires and tubes.

It will be necessary for the city to defer $74,584,657 of capital projects in the 1947 capital budget, Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson reported yesterday to Mayor O'Dwyer. His report disclosed that $193,734,532 would be needed to proceed with 1947 projects now in varying stages of planning, but that only $119,149,875 was available to finance them.

The office of A.B.
