(Happy) Chandler, Commissioner of Baseball, is asking $100,000 for the rights to televise the World Series, a price which officials in the video industry promptly if informally labeled as "very high." Edgar Kobak, president of the Mutual Broadcasting System, said that, contrary to published reports, there had not yet been any bid by a sponsor at the $100,000 figure, though the matter still was under consideration.

British Foreign Secretary Bevin's arguments for distributing the gold stock of the United States offer a sharp contrast to earlier British statements, favoring paper currencies, Dr. Walter E. Spahr, Professor of Economics at New York University, said yesterday.
Two "career men" in the New York prosecutor's office who were selected by Thomas E. Dewey to be his assistants when he was District Attorney were promoted yesterday.

HOBOKEN, Sept. 3 -- Amendment of section 54F of the Internal Revenue Code so that educational institutions, engaged in business amounting to sums of more than $5,000, will be required to file Form 990 was urged here yesterday by the United States Testing Company, Inc.

Probationary Patrolman Thomas J. Lawrence Jr., a tall, curly-haired young man in whose family police work has been a traditional calling for many years, went on his first tour of duty last midnight in the same precinct in which his mother, Mrs. Hortense Thompson Lawrence, is on duty as a policewoman.

A "forgotten" group of "Gay Nineties" patrolmen and firemen, appointed before the turn of the century, voiced a determination yesterday to "parade our blind and crippled around City Hall" if a pension increase wa snot granted by the city.

As a closing observance of United Nations Week, which begins Sunday, Sept. 14, a solemn mass will be offered at 10 A.M. Sunday, Sept. 21, in St. Patrick's Cathedral. This was announced yesterday by Msgr. Joseph A. Flannelly, administrator of the cathedral, in a letter to his parishioners.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Ewell Blackwell gained his twentyfirst victory of the season as he pitched the Reds to a 13-6 victory over the Pirates tonight before an overflow crowd of 37,299. Ralph Kiner, Pittsburgh slugger, hit his forty-first home run of the season in the sixth inning with one on base.

Four buses chartered from the Children's Bus Service, Inc., pulled up yesterday at 2828 Broadway. "Are the children ready?" the bus driver asked. "Well, they're as excited as children," a volunteer from the New York Section of the National Council of Jewish Women replied.

The new system of bareboat chartering instituted by the Maritime Commission on all voyages of such tonnage after Sept. 1, is expected to save the Government an estimated $6,000,000 a month or $72,000,000 a year from ship charter operations, it was said yesterday.

ENDICOTT, N.Y., Sept. 3 -- Frank Collins of Albany today sustained his first defeat in the annual championship of the New York State Chess Association at the country club of the International Business Machine Corporation.

Dedicatory ceremonies were held at Tenth Street and Avenue D yesterday for Jacob Riis Houses, the last housing project the New York City Housing Authority can build with Federal aid, under existing legislation.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Sept. 3 -- The attempt made yesterday by Lieut. Gen. V.P. Sviridov, Russian chairman of the Allied Control Commission for Hungary, to induce the Socialist party to support the Communists and coalition bloc has so far not succeeded.

Rockland County commuters to Manhattan who use the buses of the Rockland Coaches, Inc., and the Spring Valley Motor Coach Company, drew out testimony from bus terminal managers yesterday that the commuters had only meager warning of an impending fare increase.

DONCASTER, England, Sept. 3 -- The south Yorkshire coal mining stoppages again increased today and the situation worsened in every respect. Already it is just about certain that Britain will have another coal crisis this winter.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 3 -- A report from New York that Premier Fahmy Nokrashy Pasha would ask the United States to send a military mission to Egypt to help modernize the army has been well received here, although there is no official comment.

The United States accumulation of the bulk of the world's monetary gold stocks startad in 1919, at the end of World War I. It appears to have been caused by the change from debtor to creditor nation that occurred during that war, by a subsequent excess of exports over imports and by a flight of capital from foreign currencies to United States dollars for safety.

The curtain rose on fashion's new drama at 5:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon when manikins began to move down the fourth floor at Bergdorf Goodman's, wearing that specialty store's offerings for the fall and winter season. The authors were Mark Mooring, Leslie Morris and Mary Gleason, the designers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- In preparing to approach Congress on the plan for economic assistance to Europe that is expected to grow out of the Marshall Proposal and the "balancesheet" being drawn up at Paris, administration officials have not forgotten certain essential details.

The National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, AFL, will seek a wage increase of $15 a month for ship captains when it begins negotiations for a new contract with operators here on Monday, it was reported yesterday. The agreement is to cover 6,000 members of the union on the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts.

CEDARHURST, L.I., Sept. 3 -- The United States tennis team won the annual match between the International Club of the United States and the International Visitors, 8 1/2 to 7 1/2, in the twenty-first staging of the affair at the Rockaway Hunt Club yesterday.

LONDON, Sept. 3 -- Extension of the coal strike was the signal for a continued decline in the stock markets today. More forced selling drove prices down substantially and dealers, again lowered prices as a precaution. The volume of liquidation, however, was smaller than in preceding days and toward the close there was some recovery from lowest levels.

TOKYO, Sept. 3 -- With the windup of the Canberra conference and the publication here of its communique, the Japanese public now has learned for the first time officially what kind of peace treaty the Allies are prepared to offer.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- A report on the condition of the Passamaquoddy power project in Maine, which has been proposed as a training center for displaced persons, is before Robert H. Littlejohn, War Assets Administrator. He will decide soon whether or not the abandoned village will be offered to bids as surplus property, it was learned today.
LONDON, Sept. 3 -- Britain's efforts to build up production both at home and in the British zone of Germany were put before a United State Congressional committee on foreign aid today.

The New York Yankees announced last night that the club would accept ticket applications for the 1947 World Series. Baseball officers, season box-holders and group-plan ticket-holders will have priority. Other orders postmarked after Sept. 3 will be filled in the order of receipt.

In a raggedly contested game, marred by the incessant hornhooting and whistle-blowing of five officials, the New York Football Giants crushed the Eastern College All-Stars, 21 -- 0, before 52,102 persons last night in the ninth Herald Tribune Fresh Air Fund classic at the Polo Grounds.
The big fashion whirl is on. Sally Milgrim put the stamp of her approval on the full-skirted styles yesterday morning when her collection was presented at her 6 West Fifty-seventh Street store.

BERLIN, Sept. 3 -- German newspapers and political parties in the western zones have protested against Gen. Lucius D. Clay's ruling that an increasing number of refugees from the Soviet zone be turned back. Whereas the Germans say these persons are political refugees, General Clay has chosen to describe them as persons seeking to avoid work, possibly forced labor.

YESTERDAY'S EVENTS Security Council Atomic Energy Commission, Committee 2 -- Canceled afternoon meeting. Economic and Social Council Social Commission -- Heard Lena Spiegel, representative of World Federation of Trade Unions, declare state should be responsible in giving economic and social assistance to children in collaboration with trade unions.

Despite the continued shortag of newsprint, national advertisers are investing in advertising United States daily newspapers a the rate of $350,000,000 a year, which is $80,000,000, or 29.6 per cent above the all-time high set last year, the Bureau of Advertising.

EAST BROOKFIELD, Mass., Sept 3 -- The National Urban League for social work among Negroes closed its annual conference at Camp Atwater today with the decision, by a narrow margin, condemn the Taft-Haftley law. Officials had advised a course of atching and waiting, and to study and evaluate the law, step by step.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3 (AP) -- The Cardinals launched a fifteen-hit attack, including a pinch homer by Ron Northey with the bases loaded, to subdue the Cubs, 11 to 1, today, cutting Brooklyn's National League lead to six games as the Dodgers remained idle.

NANKING, Sept. 3 -- Delegates of ten Far Eastern and South Pacific nations and colonies convened here today at the opening session of the United Nations Educational, Cultural and Social Organization's regional conference. Delegates are scheduled to discuss the problems of fundamental education for millions of illiterate Asiatics.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 3 -- Longshore walking bosses affiliated with the Congress of Industrial Organizations announced today that they would not bargain with any stevedoring company "unless selected representatives of the walking bosses are permitted to participate in the negotiations."
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 3 -- Another record was added to the many set this summer in the opening session today of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's fifteenth Race Week, when 260 craft competed.
Charles J. Bailey has been appointed New York regional sales manager of the Phosphor Bronze Smelting Company, Philadelphia. He formerly was assistant sales manager of the Bridgeport Brass Company.

Dairen is the great port of the Kwantung Peninsula, a city of a half million people, the principal gateway to one of the richest provinces of China. It is a Chinese city, but a Russian army sits in it, and the Russian Government in Moscow has just returned a flat and peremptory "No" to an American request that it be opened as a free port to international commerce.

New York City's bus controversy was broadened yesterday when officials of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, announced plans to place a pension demand before the Fifth Avenue Coach Company, where the union's contract expires on Sept. 30.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange turned irregular yesterday and closed 19 points lower to 32 points higher than on Tuesday. Near months were relatively easier than distant.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 8,500 head: total, 11,000. Market active: hogs under 250 pounds and light sows steady to 25 cents higher; heavier weights and sows above 350 pounds unevenly

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 3 -- Jose Ferrer, who was seen on Broadway last season in "Cyrano de Bergerac," has been signed to play Dauphin in "Joan of Lorraine," with Ingrid Bergman, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer announced today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 3 -- The Government of India today requested action by the United Nations against what it termed the Union of South Africa's refusal to comply with a General Assembly resolution of last December concerning treatment of Indian nationals.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange turned irregular yesterday and closed 19 points lower to 32 points higher than on Tuesday. Near months were relatively easier than distant.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 8,500 head: total, 11,000. Market active: hogs under 250 pounds and light sows steady to 25 cents higher; heavier weights and sows above 350 pounds unevenly

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The financial crisis in Britain has led to criticism of the loan agreement in certain sections of the British press, which is, I feel, unrepresentative of large sections of British opinion, as well as being unjust to the American Government.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4 -- John F. Krey, chairman of the American Meat Institute, asserted today that a "major catastrophe" is menacing this country and a hungry world because of the prospective drastic reduction in this year's production of corn.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 4 -- A drastic change in teaching mathematics, to make the study of statistics part of a liberal education in the nation's elementary schools and colleges, was urged today at the summer meeting of the American Mathematical Society at Yale University.

The second edition of the New York Football Yankees will be unveiled for local inspection at the Stadium tonight. Jimmy Crowley's offensively dynamic Chicago Rockets will provide the opposition for Ray Flaherty's 1946 Eastern Division champions of the All-America Conference.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Sept. 4 -- Under existing conditions, the food situation on the economically merged United States and British zones probably will reach a critical stage by next February, Dr. Hans Schlange- Schoeningen, director of food and agriculture in the bi-zonal administration, informed his associates on the Bi-Zonal Economic Council here today.

Because an old nemesis wielded his spell over the Giants last night before 49,886 fans at the Polo Grounds, the Dodgers increased their lead to six and one-half games over the inactive secondplace Cardinals in the race for the National League pennant.

PARIS, Sept. 4 -- Through their own production efforts and through purchases from overseas, the sixteen nations attending the European economic conference expect to possess by the end of 1951 a total merchant shipping greater than hi 1938.

The Special Joint Legislative Committee on Motor Vehicle Problems starts off on the right foot in urging compulsory motor vehicle inspection for this state. The experience in other states, notably our neighbor New Jersey, bears ample testimony to the wisdom of this requirement.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Sept. 4 (AP) -- "We will take the era of the last three years and wrap it up," said the football coach who found himself on the spot marked "X" today. "Practically everything is gone. We are starting out new."
The ten-cent glass of beer appeared on its way out yesterday, with reports that tavern and hotel keepers were considering raising the price to 15 cents.

A freakish thunder shower, marked by a heavy downpour of hailstones, swept late yesterday afternoon over the Rockaways, several towns in Nassau County, parts of Yonkers and the Bronx. The storm, lasting a little less than an hour, resulted in death to two persons, serious injuries to two others and widespread damage in Nassau County.

A severe shake-up among Brooklyn detective divisions, resulting in the transfer of forty-two detectives and the demotion of sever others, was ordered yesterday by Police Commissioner Arthur W.Wallander.

To the editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES: The management of the New York City Omnibus Corporation believes that your editorial titled "The Bus Men's Pensions" in the Sept. 4 issue of THE TIMES oversimplifies a very grave issue.

A feeling of fine restraint characterized the collection of Bendel Originals presented yesterday in a panorama of elegance in the custom order salon of Henri Bendel. Both daytime and evening fashions reflected this feeling, with never a tuck, a bit of padding overdone in their lines.

A fourth volume in a series by Van Wyck Brooks on the literary history of the United States has been scheduled for Oct. 31 publication by Dutton. Entitled "The Times of Melville and Whitman," the book covers the period from the middle 1800's to the 1890's, giving portraits of the writers, the places where they worked and vignettes of their times.

WASHINGTON, Sept 4 -- Under unification, it was learned today the Army and the Navy will implement by the end of this month a new joint procurement plan with the aim of achieving further economies, efficiency and simplicity.

BERLIN, Sept. 4 -- At least two countries whose governments did not send representatives to the Paris conference on the Marshall Plan -- Czechoslovakia and Poland -- will be visited by members of the Congressional committee investigating European conditions in reference to that plan.

LONDON, Sept. 4 -- British Foreign Secretary Bevin's proposal that the United States should redistribute the gold in Fort Knox is regarded in British Government quarters as "an idea well worth examining," authoritative sources said today.

The section of the Saw Mill River Parkway on which a 10-cent toll has been charged since Aug. 28 was not constructed with the aid of Federal funds, but was built entirely at the expense of Westchester County taxpayers, it was asserted in Federal Court yesterday.

We commend the State Department for the good conscience and loyalty to principle which persuade it to keep hammering away in an effort to get something done in the case of Nikola Petkov. A second stiff note has just been sent to Moscow in this matter.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Two Maritime Commission examiners recommended today that the commission award contracts to provide operating subsidies for: 1. The Black Diamond Steamship Corporation, to provide shipping service on Trade Route 8, between United States North Atlantic ports and Antwerp-Rotterdam.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- Higher prices for motor vehicles announced recently and for some farm products were chiefly responsible for a rise of 0.3 per cent in average primary market prices during the week ended last Saturday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Department of Commerce.

DENVER, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Herman Keiser, the Akron, Ohio, veterarn with the straight iron game, mastered the nerve-wracking Cherry Hills course today with a fiveunder-par 66 to take the firstround lead in the $15,000 Denver open golf tournament.

OTTAWA, Ont., Sept. 4 -- Canada has in operation an atomic energy pile with sufficient capacity to supply her present needs of isotopes for medical science, C.D. Howe, Reconstruction Minister, told a news conference today.

Return to a full pre-war schedule of eight days and revived European participation in the international military jumping contests will feature the second post-war staging of the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden.

When Congress adjourned in July it was with the hope but with no assurance that it would not convene again until January. Even the President's statement that he saw no reason for a special session unless the European situation deteriorated carried the implication that such a session might be necessary.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Sept. 4 -- The revolt of the Socialist party against Communist domination broadened today from the national leaders down to minor functionaries and reached the proportions of a movement that may require another Russian intervention to quell.

LONDON, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Great Britain is going ahead with her plans to stage the 1948 Olympics despite editorial criticism by Lord Beaverbrook's Evening Standard, and the offer by the Chicago Olympic Committee to take the games out of her hands, an official of the Organizing Committee said today.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Sept. 4 -- Emil Rieve, president of the Textile Workers Union and national vice president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, recommended today that organized labor concentrate its 1948 political efforts on the defeat of twelve incumbent Senators and 100 Representatives.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Sept. 4 -- The fundamental objectives of scouting, to build character and train for citizenship, should never be lost sight of, though much time and attention are given to the aspects of handicraft, camping and other activities which attract boys to scouting, the eighth national training conference of the Boy Scouts of America was told today.

BOSTON, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Spotting the Phillies five runs, the Boston Braves tonight scored two in each of three successive innings to beat the seventh-place Philadelphia club, 6 -- 5, before 16,125 fans.
In a fashion show presented at Martin's of Brooklyn last night clothes for the career girl to wear to work and after hours were shown.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 4 -- Assistant Professor Shuichi Kusaka, a member of Princeton University's Department of Physics and an internationally known theoretical physicist, was drowned at Beach Haven, N.J., last Sunday, it was learned here today.
An apartment house owner is not responsible if, unknown to him, his superintendent is exacting illegal bonuses for renting apartments, Magistrate Morris Ploscowe ruled yesterday.

At least half a dozen new shows are champing at the bit to pass in review here the week of Oct. 5. Whether all will arrive at their respective rendezvous and at the appointed time deponent knoweth not. At any rate, the following schedule is ample warning of what's in the offing:

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 4 -- The Connecticut Federation of Labor favors a broad program of concerted political action. However, the convention, in a four-day session here, has not reached a conclusion on whether the federation should abandon its policy of endorsing political candidates or scrap its nonpartisan political committee and use other means of defeating the "enemies of labor."

A Lady Takes the Floor We have had a visit from a lady -- a young blond lady and obviously a person of firm character. She says she does not share in the least the views of another recent visitor who talked about enjoying the freedom of the city and the long views of the country, and seemed to think that the principal virtue of both was the protection they gave against neighbors next door.

Industry figures for the first six months of 1947, plus individual figures for as late as Augnst, made available here yesterday, indicate that the major airlines have turned the profit corner for the year. Some of the smaller lines, however, still have much traffic to make up if they are to finish the year in the black.
A group of blind children from the New York Institute for the Education of the Blind, ranging in age from 7 to 10 years, will have a geography lesson today in unusual and realistic surroundings.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4 -- Evidence pointing to a belief that all stars may not have a common origin was outlined as a new theory at the seventy-seventh annual meeting of the American Astronomical Society today at Dearborn Observatory on the Evanston Campus of Northwestern University.

Mark Warnow and his orchestra have been engaged to offer a new musical program, at 9 P. M. Fridays over the CBS network, beginning Sept. 19. The program will be the replacement for "Arthur's Place," one of the casualties of the summer.

WASHINGTON. Sept. 4 (AP) -- Senator Albert W. Hawkes, Republican, of New Jersey, today endorsed Herbert Hoover's published opinion that the United States might have remained out of World War II, while Democratic members of Congress differed sharply with beliefs attributed to the former Republican President.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 4 -- Paulette Goddard and Macdonald Carey will play the leading roles in "Hazard" at Paramount when Miss Goddard returns to Hollywood from England late this month, the studio announced today.

GENEVA, Switzerland, Sept. 4 -- The trade agreement committee of the International Trade Organization conference is split almost evenly on whether the general agreement on tariffs should include substantive parts of the ITO charter.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today gave "special permission" to the Pullman Company to raise berth, room, tourist and special car rates, on 20 days' notice to the public, reserving to any one the right to ask that the increases be suspended and investigated.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 4 -- Cluett, Peabody Co., Inc., of Troy, N.Y., and the Derby Gas and Electric Corporation, whose principal office is in New York, filed registration statements today with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Commercial, industrial and agricultural loans of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose $44,000,000 to $4,422,000,000, during the week ended on Wednesday. According to the figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York the total is the highest since April 16, this year, and the latest advance represents a variety of borrowings with no particular industry outstanding in the volume.
ALBANY, Sept. 4 -- The State Board of Law Examiners announced today that 281 of 675 candidates for admission to the bar successfully passed the examinations held June 25 and 26.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin, who will spend the next five days in New York going deeper into the housing problem, today challenged the statement of Mayor O'Dwyer of New York that the American Legion's rejection of the Taft-Ellender-Wagner Bill showed "a deep sense of ingratitude" to veterans of World War II.
Flushing, who placed first in the fox trot and were a close second in the waltz and the rhumba. Mr.Stofka is a food store cashier. Mrs. Work's husband was in the audience.

ENDICOTT, N.Y., Sept. 4 -- When George Kramer of Queens met with a reverse today, Albert S. Pinkus of Brooklyn took sole possession of first place in the annual championship of the New York State Chess Association at the country club of the International Business Machines Corporation.
Unless adverse weather conditions develop today or tomorrow, this week-end should find everything right for the striper fishing at Cuttyhunk and Martha's Vineyard.

To the editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES: May I call your attention to a Hebrew book published here two years ago and called "Shylock"? It is by an author well known to Hebrew readers, Ibn Zahav, now on a visit to the United States. It has had a large sale in Palestine and is now in its second edition.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Sept. 4 -- A proposal that Congress use scientific polling techniques to find out what the people want and avoid wrong guesses was made tonight by a leading commercial public opinion analyst before the Second International Conference on Public Opinion Research at Williams College here.
DOVER, England, Friday, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Daniel Carpio, 35-year-old Peruvian distance swimmer, today whipped powerful three-knot tides to swim the English Channel after a 14-hour 46-minute effort.

A players' pension and savings plan, described by President Clarence Campbell as "exceptionally progressive," was approved yesterday by the National Hockey League's Board of Governors in the concluding session of a twoday meeting at the Hotel Commodore.

HAMBURG, Sept. 4 -- Charges that the British Military Government had issued an "ultimatum" to Jewish relief societies in the British zone, ordering them to aid the refugees arriving here this week-end or to leave the zone were made today fcy Joseph Rosensaft, president of the Central Jewish Committee of Liberated Jews.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 4 -- Charles Haseltine, owner and manager of the Pacific Stevedoring and Ballasting Company, today withdrew an offer of employment he had made to nine dock and ship foremen after they had been discharged by the Luckenbach Company, which was struck on July 11 by walking bosses in a collective bargaining dispute.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 4 -- President Truman's decision to release radioactive isotopes to other countries was heartily welcomed today by virtually all the members of the control committee of the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission except the Soviet Union.

In a move slated to expedite the disposition of the Government's accusation that he stole "highly confidential photographs" connected with the development of the atomic bomb, Arnold F. Kivi, 26 years old, consented yesterday in Federal Court, Brooklyn, to be charged with the offense in an information.

Strong prices, continued quotas on wanted leathers and a general demand for quality grades marked the opening yesterday of the American Leather Show at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel under the auspices of the Tanners Council of America.

Bulk cargo rates on chartered vessels operated by tramp steamship lines have started to climb from the low point reached last month, and tramp lines that had been all but pushed out of the charter market in the last two months are beginning to operate in the "black" again, it was reported yesterday.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 4 -- The annual institute of Trenton teachers and principals was urged today by Paul Loser, city Superintendent of Schools, to counteract the spread of communistic doctrines by intensifying their teaching of Americanism.
NANKING, Sept. 4 -- A major problem for the Nationalist military command is one-eyed Gen. Liu Po-cheng. Operating as a wrecker, raider and military "relief pitcher," he never seems to stand still.

Henry J. Tower has been appointed manager of the import department of the United States Foreign Corporation. He formerly was in charge of import activities at the Associated Merchandising Corporation.

BARCELONA, Spain, Sept. 4 -- Seventeen members of Spanish underground organizations are awaiting trial in prison here while the police hunt other members of their groups. The police have not made formal charges against them but it is reliably learned that they will be tried under the law imposing the death penalty for holdups or sabotage.

Two distinct waves of selling were encountered yesterday by the stock market, reducing prices 1 to 2 points and placing the list back at the June levels. With the combined averages lowered 1.40 points, net, on the day to produce the widest drop in a month, the market completed its unorthodox summer cycle.

New York University's Division of General Education has established for the fall semester a new Institute on Systems and Procedures, it was announced yesterday by Dean Paul A. McGhee. The institute, according to Dean McGhee, will offer three courses "designed to provide businessmen with practical on-the-job knowledge necessary for simplifying operational tasks."

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 4 -- The thirteenth annual Westchester County Flower and Harvest Show opened here this afternoon at the County Center, with exhibitors from all Westchester communities and from Putnam County, New York City, Connecticut and New Jersey participating in 350 contest classes.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- The status of union members against whom employers commit unfair labor practices today was under scrutiny by Robert N. Denham, general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board. His action follows an opinion by Representative Fred Hartley, Republican, of New Jersey, that unless union officers sign anti-Communist affidavits "employers will be free to commit unfair labor practices against members of non-complying unions with impunity."

LONDON, Sept. 4 -- The stock markets were more cheerful today mainly for technical reasons and prices In most sections recovered after the recent sharp declines. Although the increasing gravity of the coal strike caused prices to waver, many finished at the best levels of the day after fairly wide fluctuations.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 - Department store sales in the week ended Aug. 30 were 2 per cent less than sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1946:

An increase last week of 190,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. Total stocks were 84,105,000 barrels, compared with 83,915,000 a week earlier and 86,813,000 on Aug. 31, 1946.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- The Administration's dire reports of a swiftly deteriorating European crisis received scant support from the Opposition today.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 4 -- "The People's Charter," the United Nations' first motion picture production, is now available for showings in this country, it was announced here today.

Strong consumer resistance to check the steady upward surge of food prices was advocated yesterday by Markets Commissioner Eugene G. Schulz, while other authorities warned that higher prices were on their way.

Pete Mead of Grand Rapids, Mich., and Herbie Kronowitz, from, the Coney Island section of Brooklyn, will meet for the third time tonight at Madison Square Garden in a ten-round match that offers one or the other an opportunity to enter the high-earnings bracket of the middleweight division.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange turned firmer yesterday and closed 16 to 22 points higher than on Wednesday.

ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Turkey, which is receiving United States aid for security purposes, underwent a Governmental shakeup today that gave the Cabinet a more moderate complexion, a high source disclosed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- The Department of Justice today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to award reparations to the Federal Government estimated at from $30,000,000 to $40,000,000 on wartime rail shipments of ammunition and explosives.
CANBERRA, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Customs Minister Ben Courtice today announced thirty-two categories of goods the import of which has been banned in Australia as part of this Dominion's dollar saving drive.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP) -- New York, currently receiving $15,908,572 for construction of 208 miles of roads under the Federal aid highway program, has assurance of much greater assistance in the future.

Advertising in all New York newspapers during August totaled 9,743,310 lines, or 5.07 per cent more than in the corresponding month of last year, according to a compilation of Media Records figures. Financial and classified again showed losses, 32.79 and 3.72 per cent, respectively.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 4 -- Johnny Vasco of Sleepy Hollow, carding 36, 31 -- 67, three under par, on his own ball, won the day's individual honors and received best-ball help of five shots from Fred Ehrman of Century to annex the pro-amateur competition of the Westchester County Golf Association at the Knollwood C. C. today.

GRIMETHORPE, England, Sept. 4 -- With Yorkshire's unofficial coal strike threatening to approach the stature of a national calamity the Government and trade union leaders began an intensive drive today to get the miners back to work.
YESTERDAY'S EVENTS Security Council Atomic Energy Commission, Committee 2 -- Continued debate on six working papers and seventeen sets of amendments submitted by various delegations.

The Netherlands Government notified the United Nations yesterday that it is accepting the Security Council's plan to attempt a settlement of its armed dispute with the Republic of Indonesia. Its qualification that it still does not believe the Council competent to interfere was for the record and should not interfere with the operation of the plan.

Cooper-Bessemer A dividend of 25 cents a common share has been declared by the Cooper-Bessemer Corporation, payable on Sept. 26. This is the first payment on the common since December, 1945, when 25 cents was paid.

Justice Juvenal Marchisio, president of American Relief for Italy, took issue yesterday with the claim that distribution of its relief materials in Italy was designed to "strengthen the hand of the Vatican in Italian politics."

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 4 -- The United States White House was a Brazilian marble palace tonight. President Truman, his family and his entourage moved in a driving rain from the United States Embassy residence to the centuryold Laranjeiras Castle in the hills.
INLET, N.Y., Sept. 4 (AP) -- A bill to create a State Pollution Control Board of Health was approved today by a joint legislative subcommittee for submission to the 1948 New York Legislature.

Kilroy was very much there at the Children's Aid Society's Lower West Side Center playground yesterday at 209 Sullivan Street, where youngsters from live of its seven centers displayed their favorite pets. Kilroy, a five-monthold striped cat with yellow markings highlighted by a bright yellow bow tied round its neck by its mistress, 13-year-old Marie Perino, won the show's all-round championship honors among sixty-three entries.

DETROIT, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Jeff Heath's twenty-fifth homer of the season, a two-run smash into the upper right field stands after Johnny Beradino had walked in the first inning, was all young Fred Sanford of the St. Louis Browns needed today as he spaced five hits -- all singles-to beat the Detroit Tigers, 2 to 1.
NEW DELHI, Sept. 4 -- A oneday-and-night curfew was imposed on the old city of Delhi today after three persons had been killed and forty injured in communal clashes last night and this morning.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., Sept. 4 -- Owing mainly to a better-thanseasonal gain in retail sales, business in the Pittsburgh district reflected a moderate gain last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research of the University of Pittsburgh.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- During the week ended Sept. 3, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, member bank reserve balances increased $135,000,000.

Football traffic will be heavy at Ebbets Field this season. Starting with the Brooklyn Dodgers AllAmerica Conference home opener against the Cleveland Browns a week from tonight, twenty-nine games will be played in the Brooklyn ball park.

The Board of Estimate put off action yesterday until next Tuesday on the Sharkey rent and eviction bills after spokesmen for real estate owners and operators made a battering attack upon the measures at a hearing in City Hall.

To the editor of the new york times: The Anglo-Egyptian dispute, which is being considered by the Security Council, brought the Sudan question into the light and you may welcome few explanatory words.

Hosiery Price Schedule Revised The Mojud Hosiery Company, Inc., has repriced its 20-denier seamless stockings to permit a reduction at retail from $1.50 to $1.35 a pair, it was announced yesterday. At the same time it has increased the price of its 15-denier, 51-gauge line so that this style will retail for $2.25 instead of $1.95.

LODI, N.J., Sept. 4 (AP) -- A reputedly insulting remark to the wife of Jim White, New York football Giants' star tackle, set off a, general melee early today in front of a roadhouse here. It ended with a second Giant star out on the face and six other participants bruised and battered.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- Secretary of State Marshall hailed the ecent Inter-American Conference at Rio de Janeiro, in a radio report to the American people tonight, as one constructive international development in a world sadly in need of such encouragement."

After executing a credit arrangement with six banks, under which a maximum of $25,000,000 may be borrowed, the Twentieth CenturyFox Film Corporation filed a proxy statement yesterday to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Mass producers of garments in America cannot adhere to the radical Parisian styles shown for spring, but they will continue to follow the trend for fullness, sloping shoulder and padded hips, Simon Cohen, president of Simon Cohen Co., declared yesterday.

LONDON, Sept. 4 -- The British are not in a very good mood to face the impending economic crisis. There is an atmosphere of poised paralysis about the island, not dissimilar to the phony war attitude of late 1939 and early 1940.
An all-night vigil outside Brooklyn's Borough Hall and some assistance from American Labor party workers combined yesterday to produce a home for a 22-yearold Navy veteran and his wife and child.

Consumer installment credit registered the largest relative gain among the various types of loans of commercial banks and trust companies in New York State during the first half of 1947, according to the midyear statement issued yesterday toy Elliott V. Bell, Superintendent of Banks.
Twenty-three Sea Scouts from Manhattan, Brooklyn, the Bronx and Queens, returned yesterday from a seven-day training cruise along the Atlantic Coast on the big Coast Guard tugboat Tamaroa.
QUITO, Ecuador, Sept. 4 (U.P.) -- Acting President Mariano Suarez Veintimilla moved steadily today to consolidate his position as Ecuador's constitutional ruler.

Mystification The encores in economic doubletalk that came over the international systems of communication yesterday were evidently no more to the liking of the bond market than to that for listed stocks. Government bonds were sluggish, with most of the list showing sell-offs or mark-downs of 1/32 to 1/16 point.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept 4 -- An amendment to the proposed policy declaration of the International Council of Women will be suggested by the Netherlands delegation which feels that a strong protest should be made against totalitarianism, it was learned today.
Some hope that Manhattan may escape the bus strike threatened for Monday developed yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora.

ATHENS, Sept. 4 -- Constantin Tsaldaris agreed this afternoon, in a sensational reversal just before the meeting of Parliament, to hand over the Premiership to Themistocles Sophoulis and to serve under him as Deputy Premier.

EVERY once in a while there is an occasion which requires looking in two directions simultaneously. This was a comparatively easy operation for Janus, the Roman god, because he thoughtfully was equipped with two opposite faces. It was easy, too, for that remarkable character, Two-Top Bruskin, the two-headed pitcher, who could watch first and third bases at the same time.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 4 -- A new case of appalling butchery was reported today by a courier from a remote section of Pakistan Punjab. He said a small Hindu military force sent into Shakirgarh district, fifty-five miles southeast of Sialkot, to protect 120,000 Sikhs and Hindus had found only 1,500 known survivors and the roads, fields and villages littered with thousands of bodies of, victims.

SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 4 -- Large savings in sugar can be obtained by the storage of sugar beets at near-freezing temperatures while awaiting processing at mills, R.D. Barmington of the Colorado Agricultural Experiment Station at Fort Collins said here today.

FOREST PARK, Pa., Sept. 4 -- The International Ladies Garment Workers Union, AFL, said today that it would ask the American Federation of Labor to call a conference of the free trade organizations of the sixteen countries cooperating in the Marshall plan to insure an active role for labor in the economic reconstruction.

AMSTERDAM, Sept. 4 (Aneta) --Public interest on the Stock Exchange again was small and the market, on the whole, had a quiet appearance with dealings restricted. Shipping shares and banking stocks showed slight gains, while industrials were mixed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- Former Gov. Harold E. Stassen of Minnesota, out in full pursuit of the Republican Presidential nomination, will head for the West Coast next week for the second time within as many months. His trip will take him from Coast to Coast with appearances or speaking engagements in eight states.
ROME, Sept. 4 -- Less than a week before the Constituent Assembly is to resume its sittings after its summer recess, a series of agitations and strikes has broken out all over Italy.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- The Yankees, making a determined bid to snuff out the American League flag race as quickly as possible, tonight staged an electrifying four-run pull-up in the seventh inning of their battle with the Senators that Joe DiMaggio sparked with his eighteenth home run of the year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- Until or unless there is much more clarification of what the British Foreign Secretary meant yesterday when he told the Trades Union Congress that the United States should "redistribute" its gold stores, he invites the suspicion that he has been reading the works of "Coin" Harvey and the early fiscal philosophies of William Jennings Bryan.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- Secretary of State Marshall is expected by department associates to urge a special session of Congress for dealing with the European economic crisis when President Truman returns from his Caribbean cruise.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- Supporters of a plan to train European displaced persons at the abandoned Passamaquoddy power project in Maine were reported today to have agreed on unified presentation of their scheme to the Government.

PARIS, Sept. 4 -- In anticipation of the three-power talks in Berlin next week on German coke exports, French officials accused the United States Military Government today of seeking to turr Western Germany into a self-sufficing economic unit.

A warning that New York's public school teachers are dissatisfied with certain provisions of the Feinberg state education law and are preparing to wage a state-wide campaign for amendments will be given today by the Joint Committee of Teachers Organizations.

The political motivations of the revolution and counter-revolution in Ecuador are still obscure. The revolt of Colonel Mancheno against the government of President Velasco nine days ago was first described as a democratic revolt against a conservative, somewhat dictatorial regime.

LAHORE, Pakistan, Sept. 3 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Anti-American sentiment rose dangerously in this important city of Moslem India today, and United States business men started to evacuate their families in fear that the hatred vented on Sikhs and Hindus might be turned upon them.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4 -- The bull market in grain, now entering its sixth week, continued today on the Board of Trade. All deliveries of wheat, corn and oats sold at new seasonal high prices and record peaks for futures were reached by September corn and oats.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 4 -- Colonial administration by the western powers continued to undergo criticism from the Soviet Union and India today in the special United Nations committee that is considering the question of information concerning non-selfgoverning territories.

Housewives laying in supplies of perishable foods for the week-end will pay more today than they did last Friday for print butter, large and medium Grade A and B eggs, and all kinds of poultry except ducks.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 4 (AP) -- A pair of home runs by Shortstop Eddie Miller sparked Cincinnati's ten-hit attack today as the Reds defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates, 7-5.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4 -- There wasn't a tough bite in the 7,500 pounds of AA stripped tenderloin, termed "the tops in steaks," consumed tonight by General of the Army Dwight D. Elsenhower and 1,874 other guests at the annual banquet of the American Meat Institute in the grand ballroom of the Stevens Hotel.

On a sultry summer evening when day's humid air lingers over the countryside and the chimney swifts are twittering in their dark homes the tree toads begin their altoish chants. There are varying degrees of intensity in their cheerful trilling. If the night is seasonably cool and the weather cycle is just starting its regular round of cumulus, cirrus, stratus and nimbus cloud changes, Hyla versicolor blends his monotone theme into the night chorus.

Mayor O'Dwyer emphasized yesterday that "the lives of the children must be protected" as he put up the first poster in a city-wide street safety campaign. Ten thousand are to be distributed by the Automobile Club of New York before school opens next Monday.

LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., Sept. 4 -- A report on whether or not New York State needs a state university will be made to Gov. Thomas E. Dewey and the State Legislature, within a few weeks, it was disclosed today by Owen D. Young, chairman of the educational factfinding group known as Governor Dewey's Temporary Commission on Need for a State University.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 4 -- Plans to create a. world-wide organization to combat cancer and to coordinate cancer research in a manner calculated to concentrate all the world's best efforts against this major scourge on a global basis were outlined here today at the fourth International Cancer Research Congress.

Sophie of Saks Fifth Avenue has taken a strong and individual stand in the matter of fashion trends this season. In her collection, exhibited yesterday afternoon, she came out in favor of maintaining the skirt lengths she has been showing for several years, and the ones she thinks becoming to her customers.

LONDON, Sept. 4 (AP) -- The British Foreign Office said tonight that it had made a final, unsuccessful effort to debark 4,400 Jewish refugees from the Exodus 1947 in northern France and that the three transports carrying them were headed for Hamburg, Germany, as scheduled.

A joint underwriting account headed by John Nuveen Co. and the First of Michigan Corporation will offer today a new issue of $2,800,000 of 3 1/2 per cent water supply and sewage disposal system revenue bonds of the Landel Metropolitan District, Michigan.

TRIESTE, Sept. 4 (UP) -- Two United States Army officers and an enlisted man sent into the Yugoslav -occupied zone of Venezia Giulia to negotiate for the release of three other American soldiers, charged today they were "literally dragged" at gunpoint across the Morgan Line by Yugoslav soldiers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) -- The Association of American Railroads said today the Class I carriers had estimated net income, after interest and rentals, of $37,000,000 in July, compared with $32,700,000 in July, 1946.

The addresses on the InterAmerican Conference broadcast last night by Secretary of State Marshall and Senator Vandenberg, as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES, follow: By Secretary Marshall I returned yesterday from the Inter-American Conference at Rio de Janeiro.

TOKYO, Sept. 4 -- Tokyo's heavy drinkers, worshipers of the deity Jurojin, the god of longevity and one of the seven gods of good luck, have lost a battle to the seriousminded government of the Christian Socialist Premier, Tetsu Katayama.

Aladear had little trouble winning the Brocade Handicap, $5,000 added race that topped the bill at Aqueduct yesterday. With Conn McCreary in the saddle, the 4 year-old daughter of Questionnaire romped to a five-length victory over Joseph Dushock's Mahmoudess in the mile and a sixteenth event.

CHICAGO. Sept. 4 (AP) -- Today's report at the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows : HOGS Salable hogs, 8.500 bead; total, 13.500: market active: weights of 260 pounds down stead; to 25 cents higher: heavier weights, 25 to 75 cents higher; sows strong to 25 cents higher:

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 4 -- Top officials of the CIO meeting here today, in effect challenged the National Labor Relations Board to enforce its demand that affidavits certifying that all officers are not Communists be filed with the board by Sept. 25.

A collection of rare birds and mammals from Central America, some never before exhibited alive, will go on display at the Bronx Zoo tomorrow. The "star" of the collection is the female yapock, a rare water opossum. The bird rarities, may be seen in the Jewell Room.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 4 -- Arab nationalist organizations gave a hero's welcome today to seven veterans of the 1936-39 Arab uprising against Zionism whose life sentences in prison were remitted by the British administration.
Players from seventeen countries including almost every amateur of prominence, gather at Forest Hills today for the start of the men's and women's national championships at the West Side Tennis Club.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 4 -- No group was better able to provide vigorous and thoughtful leadership in achieving the country's national aims, President Truman said today in a message of greeting to the forty-eighth annual encampment of the Veterans of Foreign Wars.

GENEVA, Switzerland, Sept. 4 -- The inclusion in international commodity agreements of provisions for sales of surpluses to underdeveloped countries, at special prices, was suggested to the Food and Agriculture Organization conference today by Norris E. Dodd, United States Under-Secretary of Agriculture.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 4 -- Even a rip-snorting thunder squall did not stop the windjamming in the second day of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's race week.

SOUTHPORT, England, Sept. 4 -- British labor's powerful Trades Union Congress endorsed overwhelmingly today the foreign policy of Foreign Secretary Bevin and close ties between Britain and the United States.

GARY, Ind., Sept. 4 -- Charles D. Lutz, Superintendent of Gary Schools, today canceled all athletic events scheduled for Emerson High and Elementary School and expelled 600 high school pupils after about 1,300 of the school's 1,750 pupils refused to return to their classes.

Mayor O'Dwyer and the Board of Estimate gave a cool reception yesterday to a request by the Triboro Coach Corporation for permission to apply to the Public Service Commission for a higher fare on the company's thirteen lines in Queens.

President Tjokorde Gde Rake Soekawati of East Indonesia yesterday invited American business executives to take an active interest in commercial opportunities in East Indonesia. Addressing more than 150 members of the JavaTiffin Club at luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria, he said that steps will soon be taken to promote increased trade with the United States.

STOKE POGES, England, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Headed by Henry Cotton as team captain, three veterans of Britain's 1937 Ryder Cup defeat again will face the picked pro golfers of the United States when the international matches are resumed at Portland, Ore., in November.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 5 -- The Soviet Union proposed here today that the United Nations should send annual missions to investigate living conditions in the territorial possessions of the colonial powers.

Volume of bedroom furniture suite sales in small neighborhood furniture stores has increased so much in the last week that many factories have returned to quota selling to insure equitable distribution of production, manufacturers' representatives reported yesterday.

LONDON, Sept. 5 (U.P.) -- British Government-officials will hold separate conferences with American and British film producers within a month to discuss possible alternatives to the new 75 per cent tax on American motion-picture earnings, it was disclosed today.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 5 -- A plan calling for the exchange of all 802,553 shares of $10 par value common stock of the Atlanta Gas Light Company for the publicly held preferred stock of the Consolidated Electric and Gas Company, was sanctioned today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- Britain's economic plight is due directly to its coal miners and mine owners, who for thirty years have opposed mechanization until British mines have become "obsolete" in every economic sense.

TOKYO, Sept. 5 -- The Japanese Cabinet was warned today by Allied Headquarters that its authority was subordinate to that of the elected Diet. It was informed that it was not authorized by the new Constitution to legislate by administrative order.

Five ways the city might effect savings in the cost of public construction work were put forward yesterday by Max E. Greenberg, attorney. The proposals were explained in a letter sent to Mayor O'Dwyer on Thursday.

Stromberg-Carlson Company introduced yesterday its 1948 line of FM-AM radio receivers at the conclusion of a two-day Middle Atlantic and Eastern States regional distributors meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria. Feature of the presentation were the first two post-war television units produced by the company.

Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora reserved decision yesterday on a petition by Emetia Polizio of 74 Thirty-third Street, Astoria, Queens, to compel Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander to remove a twenty-four-hour police guard placed over him on July 23, after he made charges of a tie-up between the police and bookmakers.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your splendid editorial of Aug. 18, entitled "Understanding the Offender," correctly appraises the action of Governor Dewey in appointing two additional members to the Board of Parole of the New York State Division of Parole, as "another step in the direction of a better understanding of the offender."

Pete Mead, Grand Rapids middleweight, defeated Herbie Kronowitz of Coney Island in the feature bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night. The verdict, in favor of the Midwesterner, was a split decision.

STOKE POGES, England, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Australian Norman Von Nida and Britain's Dai Rees and Reggie Whitcombe tied for first prize in the u1,050 ($4,200) Penfold professional golf tournament today with aggregates of 270 -- the lowest scoring, in a British, golf tournament this season.

WARSAW, Sept. 5 -- The Polish military prosecutor in the Cracow espionage trial today demanded the death sentence for ten of the thirteen defendants. In a bitter summation, the prosecutor accused Arthur Bliss Lane, former United States Ambassador in Warsaw, with trying "to dirty the new Polish Peoples' republic."

CHICAGO, Sept. 5 -- The bull market in grains continued on the Board of Trade today after an early dip. All deliveries of wheat, corn and oats reached new seasonal high prices. Cash corn went to a new high record with the white variety selling in the spot market at $2.92 a bushel and the yellow at $2.57.

LONDON, Sept. 5 -- Great Britain has rejected the Soviet Government's protest against the recent three-power talks on raising the level of industry in the joint Anglo-American zone of Germany, the Foreign Office announced tonight.
After a twenty-four-hour delay caused by the rain, the men's and women's national championships will start today at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.

The National Federation of American Shipping is preparing for an exhaustive study of improved methods of cargo handling, it became known yesterday. A decision to undertake the survey was taken at a meeting of the organization's board of directors at India House, Hanover Square, on Thursday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- In one of the greatest peacetime programs of the kind ever attempted, the Navy Department's Office of Naval Research is cooperating with 100 leading American colleges and universities in the development of scientific projects and the training of graduate students in science, it was disclosed here today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- The Railway Express Agency has agreed to a wage increase of 15 1/2 cents an hour for 75,000 workers, representing 90 per cent of its employes, it was announced here today. An agreement was reached between George M. Harrison, president of the American Federation of Labor Brotherhood of Railway Clerks, and A.M. Hartung, vice president of the agency.

TONAWANDA, N.Y., Sept. 5 (AP) -- Remington Rand, Inc., announced today that all its employes affiliated with the Congress of Industrial Organizations in upstate New York would receive an additional 3 1/2-cent hourly pay increase Nov. 1.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 5 -- What may be the first effort by underground organizations to force Palestine's Jewish population into a campaign of civil disobedience against the British administration was reported by the Palestine police today.

John Day has scheduled for publication in October "I Want to Be Like Stalin," by B.P. Yesipov and N.K. Concharov, which has been translated by George S. Counts and Nucia P. Lodge. Published last year in Russia, with the approval of the Ministry of Education, it has been in general use for the training of school teachers.

The first studio outside of Hollywood to offer full-time professional training in motion picture work has been established at the New School for Social Research, it was announced yesterday by Erwin Piscator, director of the school's dramatic workshop.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 5 -- An appeal to the International Council of Women to call on the United Nations to "stop the terror regime" in the Baltic states was received today from the former presidenl of the Lithuanian Women's Council, now living in exile in Italy.

If all home games of the New York Yankees of the All-America Football Conference are as wide open and exciting as last night's Stadium opener in which the local eleven overwhelmed the Chicago Rockets, 48-26, the financial success of the second-year venture will be assured.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Sept. 5 -- A leader of the Banderov band, a Ukrainian named Burlak, has finally been captured by Czechoslovak reserve army officers and state police after a long hunt in the Fatra Mountains near the town of Urutky, Slovakia, it was learned today.
NANKING, Sept. 5 -- A countrywide "thrift and austerity" campaign was started today to conserve China's dwindling foreign exchange.
Justice Ferdinand Pecora won the agreement yesterday of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, to a postponement of its threatened strike against the New York Omnibus Corporation.

SOUTHPORT, England, Sept 5 -- Britain's labor unions agreed here today to forego the immediate nationalization of the iron and steel industry in deference to the Labor Government's contention that action now would disturb the national economy.

TOKYO, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Tulsidas Kilachand, chief of the Indian Trade Mission here, charged today that American "vested interests" seek to dominate the Japanese cotton market. The charge was promptly denied by Allied Headquarters.

AMSTERDAM, Sept. 5 (ANETA) -- Prices rose sharply on the Stock Exchange and more activity was noticeable. Shipping shares again were prominent which was attributed to reinvestments from the proceeds of Dutch-owned American shares, which have been sold.

"CARE, New York" is more than an address. It is a symbol of an old American concept of giving help to those less fortunate. To hungry Europeans, watching their famished and ragged children do with less and less each day, a CARE package with tangible, edible nourishment makes more sense than all the fine words of diplomacy.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Sept. 5 -- The state convention of the Congress of Industrial Organizations voted overwhelmingly today to continue its support for the American Labor Party, despite the warning of right-wing leaders that members of their unions were opposed to the ALP and would not vote for its candidates.

TRIESTE, Sept. 5 (U.P.) -- The United States Army today officially protested the "illegal arrest and detention" and "mistreatment" of two American officers and four enlisted men who were seized at gunpoint by Yugoslav soldiers last week on the Morgan Line and thrown into prison.

No sharp upswing in men's clothing sales here has followed the cashing by veterans of their terminal leave bonds, retailers and manufacturers agreed yesterday. In Boston, however, men's clothing sales forged ahead substantially, with the increase traced to spending by GIs.

With the dramatic show, the "Ford Theatre," planned for Oct. 5 at 5 P.M., the Ford Motor Company has indicated its desire to terminate the "Ford Showroom," with Meredith Willson's orchestra as the featured attraction.
NORTHFIELD, N.J., Sept. 5 (AP) -- Amateurs played conspicuous roles in shattering par today as the national pro-amateur golf championship moved into the quarter-finals.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: September 6, 1947, is the 290th anniversary of the birth of Lafayette. His place in American history was defined by Andrew Jackson, President of the United States, in a general order to the Army and Navy issued June 21, 1834, upon his learning of Lafayette's death. He said:

To Mr. Bender of Ohio, a Republican Congressman-at-Large, there is a very simple explanation of the present concern in Administration circles over the drift of events abroad. Mr. Bender, looking hard, "can see only one purpose to Mr. Truman's present course in foreign affairs."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- Cyrus S. Ching, former industrial relations director of the United States Rubber Company, took the oath of office as first director of the new Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service today. The $12,000a-year post was authorized under the Taft-Hartley Labor Relations Act of 1947.

FOREST PARK, Pa., Sept. 5 -- The 400,000 members of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, American Federation of Labor, will be taxed $1,800,000 during the next three years to provide a fund which would be used in part to meet any organizational emergencies under the Taft-Hartley Labor Law.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- Emergency controls over the use of natural rubber will be lifted from all but transportation items, such as tires and tubes, in the virtual elimination of the wartime rubber order next week, the Department of Commerce announced today.

Tribute to a Mayor and His City We suppose some of our readers may have rubbed their eyes in astonishment when they saw that a civic organization -- composed of hard-headed business men and taxpayers -- had proposed in one suburban community that its Mayor's salary be trebled.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 5 -- Moving strongly from fifth place on the outside during the final quarter-mile, April Star, R.L. Craig's 6-year-old chestnut gelding by Bert Abbe, won the $40,000 Nassau Pace by a length in 4:20 for the two miles over a good track before 17,304 at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- Responsibility for calling a special session of Congress to deal with the possibility of economic aid for Europe rests solely on President Truman, Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, Republican, of Michigan, said today. Mr. Vandenberg is chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee and President Pro Tempore of the Senate.

MADISON, Wis., Sept. 5 -- A satsfactory compromise on the controversial problem of racial discrimination in education was reached by 700 delegates from 350 colleges at the constitutional convention of the National Student Association here today.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Sept. 5 -- Mayor William O'Dwyer of New York City was assured tonight that he would have the support of all factions in the State Congress of Industrial Organizations if he sought election as Governor or United States Senator.
SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 5 -- The joint United States-Soviet Commission appeared today unable to agree on the joint report to Washington and Moscow on the deadlock in the commission's negotiations.

Use of a part of Floyd Bennett Field, Brooklyn, for commercial aviation seemed precluded last night after an order had been issued by the Chief of Naval Operations assigning facilities not needed at the airport for naval aviation to the Air National Guard of New York and the Army Air Reserve in the New York area.

PORT CHESTER, N,Y., Sept. 5 -- The white standard poodle Ch. Blakeen Osprey, the black miniature Ensarr Salute and the Welsh terrier Ch. Twin Ponds Carousel were the main winners today in specialty dog shows held on the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh J. Chisholm.

PARIS, Sept. 5 -- Food production in the sixteen countries participating in the European economic conference is expected to rise during the next four years to a level equal to or higher than the average production from 1934 to 1938, Timothy O'Connell of Ireland, president of the Technical Committee on Food and Agriculture, said today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 5 -- The Empire City Racing Association's home track in Yonkers is inadequate for horse racing under current conditions and to hold a meet there might result in "serious public disaster," Ashley Trimble Cole, chairman of the State Racing Commission, said in a letter today to Herbert C. Gerlach, County Executive of Westchester.

Juan Cardinal Gualberto Guevara, Archbishop of Lima, Peru, will attend the Eucharistic Congress to be held in Buffalo, N.Y., Sept. 22-25, in observance of the one-hundredth anniversary of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Buffalo. The invitation was sent by the Most Rev. John F. O'Hara, bishop of the diocese.

Directors of the Consolidated Vultee Aircraft Corporation and its largest stockholder, the Avco Manufacturing Corporation, have approved a plan calling for the organization of a new corporation consisting of the non-aviation properties of Consolidated Vultee, it was announced yesterday by Victor Emanuel, chairman of Avco.
ROME, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Four American Baptist clergyman were received by Pope Pius XII today and reported that they had upheld in the audience the policies of a fellow Baptist, President Truman.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- Substantial agreement on a coordinated program for stepping up the Ruhr coal production, including replacement of the North German Coal Control with an AngloAmerican management group, was reported today by representatives of the two Governments after a month of negotiations.

In these times of rapid change in the qualitative as well as the quantitative aspects of aviation, two recent shifts of personnel in the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics are reassuring. Dr. George W. Lewis gives up his post of Director of Aeronautical Research to become NACA's research consultant.

Passengers boarding the new Cunard White Star liner Media were warned yesterday that they would be permitted to take only u5 in Bank of England notes into Britain when the vessel docks at Liverpool on the return leg of her first transatlantic voyage.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) -- A Flordia delegation here seeking Government aid in combatting fish-killing "red tides" today pursued its efforts to obtain promises of help from the War Department if future emergencies developed.

National economic, financial and legislative problems affecting the operations of each country's securities markets will be explored at the first Hemispheric Stock Exchange Conference to be held here from Sept. 15 to 18.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- The first attempt to test legally the anti-Communist section of the Taft-Hartley Act is scheduled for argument in a Texas Federal District Court Monday afternoon.
The Metropolitan Delicatessen Dealers Association announced yesterday a one-cent retail price increase on bottles and cans of beer, effective next week.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 5 -- Dr. Rudolph W. Glaser; for the last twenty-seven years associated with the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research here and a leader in the research war against the Japanese beetle, was found dead yesterday in his automobile in the garage of his home on Prospect Avenue Extension.

ROME, Sept. 5 -- Italy needs $250,000,000 before Dec. 31 to finance essential purchases of food and fuel, official circles said today in commenting on the request for American assistance made by Ambassador Alberto Tarchiani to the State Department last week.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 5 -- A wildcat strike of some 1,800 engineers and firemen of the Union Railroad here paralyzed today the operations of four giant plants of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation, and national officers of the railroad brotherhoods moved to halt it.

DENVER, Sept. 5 (AP) -- A young Southern professional, Stewart (Skip) Alexander of Lexington, N.C., stroked his way into the lead in the $15,000 Denver open golf tournament today as favorites continued to fade on the difficult Cherry Hills course.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Sept. 5 -- A provisional international organization, the World Congress for Public Opinion Research, was set up today at the closing session of the Second International Conference for Public Opinion Research at Williams College here.

CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 5 (AP) -- Dion K. Kerr Jr.'s Flying Weather reeled off a speedy six furlongs in 1:10 3/5 over a fast-drying out track to win the Paulsboro Purse at Garden State Park today. The Happy Argo gelding beat Brookmeade Stable's Music by two lengths, with Robert L. Hall Jr.'s Tacaro Briar a length farther back in third place.

A female yapock, just arrived in this country from Costa Rica, where she was captured by a crew of natives under the direction of Collector Charles Cordier, will appear in public for the first time today in the small mammal house at the Bronx Zoo.

PARIS, Sept. 5 -- Leaders of the European conference on the Marshall plan are trying to cut their estimates of Europe's net commodity needs for the next four years from $29,200,000,000 to about $21,500,000,000, those in closest touch with the proceedings said tonight.

LEEDS, England, Sept. 5 -- The south Yorkshire coal strike continued today to work terrible havoc on Britain's weakened economy, but some faint hopes were aroused here by the Government's moves in London. There, Emanuel Shinwell, Minister of Fuel and Power, spent all day consulting the top men of the National Coal Board and the National Union of Mineworkers as well as the Yorkshire representatives of both organizations.

Commuters from Shanks Village, including several war veterans, protested yesterday against the recent increases of 25 to 30 per cent in fares and the purported failure of the Spring Valley Motor Coach Company and Rockland Coaches, Inc., to notify the public of these increases before they went into effect on April 25.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- The country's railroads asked today for an additional 10 per cent increase in freight rates, bringing to nearly 27 per cent the total rise they seek above their present charges.

ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Four Ministers moved into the Cabinet of Premier Recep Peker today in a shake-up of the Turkish Government after a stormy dispute in which Mr. Peker threatened to resign.

MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., Sept. 5 -- Soldiers came home to fight "to put democracy on the offensive in the war of ideas as she was in the war of arms," Major Robert Amen told a large group of American, Canadian and British veterans at the Moral Rearmament Assembly here today.
Heavy rains in the early morning and constant high humidity brought discomfort yesterday to the city's millions. Hay fever sufferers, however, found a measure of relief in the murky air.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- A prospecting system, with electromagnetic waves that the old-time prospector with burro and pick never heard of, is one of the 395 inventions for which patents were issued this week by the United States Patent Office.

Brooklyn's chief regret in this waning stage of the National League pennant race is that only four of its remaining twenty games are against the Giants The Dodgers trimmed their inter borough rivals for the second day in a row and the seventh straight time yesterday at the Polo Grounds, thus increasing their edge over the idle Cardinals to seven full games.

Arrangements have1 been made for the sale of a New York Curb Exchange membership at $13,000. This is a decrease of $1,500 from. | a sale on Aug. 18 and the lowest since August, 1945, when a membership was sold for $13,000. The current market is $12,500 bid and seats offered at $22,500.

ALTUS, Okla., Sept. 5 (AP) -- In the first year of operation of the W.C. Austin $12,000,000 irrigation project, farmers increased their average income to $130 an acre as compared with an average of $22 an acre from dry-farmed crops, Secretary of the Interior J.A. Krug said today at dedication ceremonies.

Setting a new high record for trade registrations, the leather show sponsored by the Tanners Council of America at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel closed yesterday. Shoe manufacturers, retailers and tanners from all sections of the country were in attendance, according to Irving R. Glass, executive vice president of the council, and he estimated the total for the two-day event at between 9,000 and 10,000.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Sept. 5 -- James L. Meehan of this city, who on Wednesday got $5 from a sympathetic New York City magistrate after he had posed as Richard (Rube) Marquard, famous old-time New York Giant pitcher, tried the same dodge today before Police Recorder Robert McAlevy Jr. here -- but it didn't work.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Irked by the "Rip Van Winkle" advertisements of Robert R. Young, the Office of Defense Transportation today made public data designed to show that Mr. Young's C. O. freight trains run slower than those of Western railroads he criticized.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 5 (AP) -- The power-packed and versatile Cleveland Browns opened defense of their All-America Football Conference championship tonight before 61,442 fans by defeating the Buffalo Bills, 30 to 14.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 5 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Athletics defeated the Boston Red Sox, 9 to 7 tonight in a wild game in which Ferris Fain, the Athletics' first baseman, was banished for a fight with Ed Pellagrini, and Boston's Manager Joe Cronin was ordered from the bench for yelling at the umpires.

CANBERRA, Australia, Sept. 5 (U.P.) -- Australia came to the rescue of desperately dollar-short Britain today with an immediate $5,250,000 in gold and a pledge of the entire Australian gold production, valued at $23,000,000 a year, as it is mined.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 5 -- Describing the Russians as "barbarians." Senator Styles Bridges, Republican, of New Hampshire, told the Veterans of Foreign Wars today that "unless some means is evolved to stop the Russian war machine all the sacrifices you and millions like you have made in the past two wars will have been in vain."

EVANSTON, III., Sept. 5 -- Latest advances in the mechanization of astronomical observations are by no means related only to increased size of telescopes. Instead, the tiny surfaces of lightsensitive photocells attached to telescopes of moderate size are serving for the first time actually to "count" the light from the stars and even to make measurements of their brightness possible in daylight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board has virtually completed the issuance of letters of registration, under rules promulgated earlier this year, to about 1,200 small air transport companies, which operate on a nonscheduled basis, it was learned today.

A total of $413,494,000 in civil engineering construction in the United States for the month of August was reported by Engineering News-Record. The average for each of the four weeks of the month was $103,374,000. This is 1 per cent below the average for July, and 5 per cent below the average for August, 1946.

TORONTO, Sept. 5 (Canadian Press) -- A United States fifteenman team today defeated Canada, 286 points to 19, for the international senior golf championship and the Duke of Devonshire Cup. The match was played under the Nassau system.

In an effort to obtain more authentic information on big game records, the Boone and Crocket Club is sponsoring a North American Big Game Competition, which will be closed to entries after Dec. 31 of this year.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 5 -- Following sensational reports of hitherto undisclosed massacres in the Punjab, Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, Prime Minister of the Dominion of India, conferred late tonight with Governor General Mountbatten.

HAMBURG, Germany, Sept. 5 -- British Military Government authorities declared today that utmost tact and patience would be employed in attempts to persuade the refugees to debark peacefully from the three British vessels when they arrive Sunday morning.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is hardly fair for you to imply that veterans cashing in their terminal leave bonds are either flighty or irresponsible, as you do in your editorial of Sept. 3. There is probably no other group of American citizens that is more hard-pressed with the problems of employment, housing and the soaring costs of living than the veterans of the Second World War.
