Treasury Bond Offer In Government bond circles here yesterday the late announcement of the terms of the new restricted 2 1/2 per cent Treasury bond issue brought no surprise. It was said, moreover, that the new issue would have negligible market effect, if any, and that the extent of restrictions reflected the intention of the Treasury that the new offering would not introduce any drastic new influence in the money market.

Retail Sales Again Decline Retail trade volume here slipped again this week, with estimates indicating a "slight decline" in department store volume as compared with a year ago. Weather conditions and the fact that sales in the comparative 1946 week were extremely high were cited as major factors in the decrease.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Sept. 5 -- Gen. V.P. Sviridov, Russian chairman of the Allied Control Commission for Hungary, has called in a leader of the Small Landholders party, in addition to the previously announced Socialist head, and has urged him to help keep the fourparty coalition bloc in being, it was learned today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Ken Keltner's three-run home run sparked Cleveland to a 61 victory over the Chicago White Sox before 24,247 fans tonight. Keltner connected for his tenth circuit blow of the season off Joe Haynes in the seventh inning to assure the fourth place Indians their second victory in the last eight games against Chicago.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) -- The Treasury announced today that it will start taking subscriptions from savings institutions on Sept. 29 for an issue of eighteenyear, non-marketable Treasury bonds bearing interest at the rate of 2 1/2 per cent.

Sharply criticizing police laxity that has permitted hoodlums to run wild in the Bath Beach, Brooklyn, area, where there have been eight unsolved slayings in recent months, Mayor O'Dwyer promised yesterday that the condition would be corrected speedily.
BERLIN, Sept. 5 -- Premier Rudolf Paul of Thuringia in the Soviet zone vanished Monday with his wife and four others. A country -wide search is being made for them.

The shorter the distance to market, the better the vegetable, and of no variety is this truer than of the tomato. It never tastes so fresh, so full of flavor as now, when it comes into town from gardens near by. The specimens shipped from the South and the West in the winter, delicious though they be, seem poor, indeed, compared to those from hereabouts that hit their peak in late summer.

LONDON, Sept. 5 -- Recovery of the stock markets continued today. In all sections there was a marked upswing, and by the time when the markets closed most industrial leaders had regained virtually all of the losses sustained earlier in the week.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 5 -- There was almost a drab blank in the sky and but a flicker of southerly air in which to start the third session of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's race week today. But it was started anyway, and wound up with 243 craft piling back into the bay in a freshening breeze.

LONDON, Sept. 5 -- The Foreign Office declared today that it had information indicating that 200 Jewish children might have been kidnapped from Hungary and that they might be aboard three British vessels carrying 4,300 Jewish refugees to Hamburg.

Crowding the vacation calendar the past few days, many thousands of boys and girls from New York City's "melting pot" have enjoyed one-day outings in the country at the Bear Mountain Interstate Park as guests of the Police Athletic League. After a sail up the Hudson River, these children, who know "no race, creed or color" lines, spent busy afternoons in the beauties of the woodlands and lakes, enjoying the many recreational facilities available.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Sept. 5 -- One of the world's most macabre treasure troves, approximately $1,000,000 in value, was formally turned over here today by Col. William G. Brey of San Francisco on behalf of the Military Government to the Preparatory Commission of the International Refugee Organization.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Sept. 5 -- The Netherlands has decided to take the United States into its confidence in the matter of Indonesia. She will plead for patience even if the Dutch resume military operations on Java.

The Swedish-American liner Gripsholm sailed from her West Fifty-seventh Street pier yesterday with 1,100 passengers, among them, thirty-two war veterans who will study economic and political science at the University of Stockholm, Sweden, under provisions of the GI Bill of Rights.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- The Yankees, flapping at the top of the American League like a huge flag that has snapped its lower halyard, ran into another embarrassing situation tonight as they dropped their second successive game to the seventh place Senators.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 5 (AP) -- Noncommittal as to whether he would support the proposed charter drawn at New Brunswick by the State Constitutional Convention, former Gov. Walter E. Edge today assailed its taxation article and the fiscal policies of Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll's administration.

PARIS, Sept. 5 -- The Ramadier Government obtained an unimpressive National Assembly confidence vote today and pledged sweeping reforms as a huge but orderly anti-Government demonstration, mostly Communist inspired, filled Paris streets.

Lamps guaranteed to shed 50 to 100 per cent more light than those now in general use will be introduced in New York stores on Monday. They include table and floor models. as well as boudoir and pin-to-the-wall lamps. They bear the tags of the Certified Lamp Makers, an organization of manufacturers.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 5 -- President Truman departed from his prepared address before a joint session of the Brazilian Congress this afternoon to give a strongly implied pledge of United States economic aid to Brazil.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Sept. 5 -- Representative James W. Wadsworth, Republican, called today for continued bi-partisan support of the foreign policy of President Truman and Secretary of State George C. Marshall.

GENEVA, Sept. 5 -- The United States delegation to the Havana world trade conference will consist of Representatives, Senators, business men and labor leaders as well as Government officials, it was learned today.

Resistance of the aircraft shares halted yesterday a further downward movement of prices on the Stock Exchange, although on balance the list was fairly heavily weighted on the lower side at the close.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Aug. 30 were 925,732 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 24,837 cars, or 2.8 per cent, more than for the preceding week, 17,292 cars, or 1.9 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year and 65,390 cars, or 7.6 per cent, more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Sept, 5 (U.P.) -- Clinton P. Anderson, Secretary of Agriculture, said tonight in a radio address that there is no longer any hope the United States will be able to export as much grain this year as last.

A new plan to enable persons in this country to purchase men's suits manufactured in Holland for delivery to relatives or friends in European countries was announced yesterday by L.F. Jansen of the Netherlands Exchange Control at 25 Broadway.

In the present international atmosphere the citizen-soldier must be prepared to meet an emergency without any delay, Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum, Commanding General of the New York National Guard, told a group of 250 Guard officers yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your correspondent Charles H. Taquey of Princeton wrote in commendation of European customs unions and suggested that the United States might take certain encouraging action.

BOSTON, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Lefty Warren Spahn tonight won his seventeenth game and his first of the season over Philadelphia as the Braves beat the Phillies, 2 -- 1, before 18,050 fans. The loss dropped the Quakers into a tie for the cellar with the Pittsburgh Pirates.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- Exports of American goods dropped in July for the second consecutive month, confirming authoritative forecasts that United States foreign trade may be headed for a decline after hitting a post-war peak in May.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Sept. 5 -- Four phases of scouting received attention in the report of the National Commission on use of program presented today before the Eighth National Training Conference of the Boy Scouts of America. These were outdoor and camping experience; planning and operation of program in the local unit; scout advancement, and bridging the gap between cubbing, scouting and senior scouting.

LONDON, Sept. 5 -- Cuts in capital expenditure are "under active examination" by the British Government, leading industrialists were told today at a meeting with Cabinet chiefs to discuss means of meeting the existing economic crisis.

GARY, Ind., Sept. 5 -- Only 250 students showed up for classes today at the Emerson High and elementary school here, with 1,500 pupils staying away to protest the rezoning ordinance which put thirty -five Negroes in their classes. The students referred to their absence as a "holiday."

It was a happy coincidence -- perhaps not entirely unplanned -- that made it possible for the President of the United States to be in Brazil both to participate in the most harmonious Inter-American Conference of recent years and to help South America's largest country celebrate the 125th anniversary of its declaration of independence from a European Power.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Sept. 4 (Delayed) -- The internal political life of Turkey entered a new phase today following the announcement of the Cabinet shake-up.

Thomas T. Motts 7-year-old Floating Isle won his third overthe-jumps stake in succession at Aqueduct yesterday when he charged up through the stretch to a two-length decision in the $10,000 added Harbor Hill Steeplechase.

CHICAGO. Sept. 5 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Deportment ot Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hozs. 5.OOO head: total. 8.000: market uneven; barrows and gilts opened fully 25 to 50 cents higher, closed with part of advance lost; sows unevenly steady to 50 cents higher; good

Butter went up another cent and a half to 2 cents a pound yesterday on the New York wholesale market, making the total increase for the week 3 1/2 cents and since July 1 12 cents. Some trade sources are contemplating the possibility of $1 a pound butter in retail stores by the end of the year.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 5 -- The International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes, AFL, Hollywood's principal labor union, charged today it had been deprived of a fair hearing in the monthlong Congressional inquiry, which ended this week.

ENDICOTT, N.Y., Sept. 5 -- Albert S. Pinkus of Brooklyn today added one and a half points to maintain the lead in the annual tournament of the New York State Chess Association at the country club of the International Business Machines Corporation.

The Federal Treasury and private shipping companies stand to lose thousands of dollars as a result of unfavorable circumstances affecting the return to Government hands of ships chartered to private operators, it was reported yesterday.

Steady increases in the number of eviction cases brought to the Municipal Court were cited yesterday as evidence that the city should extend to other tenants the protection already afforded fay local law to the residents of hotels and rooming houses.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 5 (AP) -- The text of President Truman's address to a joint session of the Brazilian Congress today follows: President Dutra, Mr. President of the Congress, Senators and Deputies: I am deeply grateful for the invitation to appear before the Congress of this great nation whose history is so entwined with that of the United States.

A national drive to lower costs of handling raw materials and finished products through scientific elimination of waste in the operation is being started by more than sixty manufacturers of materials handling equipment, Samuel W. Gibb, president of the Materials Handling Institute, Pittsburgh, an equipment trade association, revealed here yesterday.

Tightening of dollar exchange, particularly in the United Kingdom sphere of influence, has brought about a heavy decline in textile exports, it was learned yesterday. Rayon goods exports for the balance of the year will show a drop of approximately 50 per cent, it was indicated, and cotton goods shipments are expected to fall off by 20 per cent.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 5 -- Screen rights to "Burlesque," the 1928 play by Arthur Hopkins and George Manker Watters, have been purchased by Twentieth CenturyFox from Columbia and a new film version of the property will foe produced next year by George Jessel, Fox disclosed today.

The New York University College of Medicine has opened a special "pain" clinic to instruct medical specialists and educators throughout the United States in the nerve block technique of anesthetics, Dr. E.A. Rovenstine, chairman of the Department of Anesthesia at the college.

Turning down pleas for leniency by 100 sympathizers, General Sessions Judge Jacob Gould Schurman yesterday sentenced I. James Brody, ousted deputy commissioner of marine and aviation, and James V. Auditore, one-time "millionaire boss stevedore," to four and a half to ten years in prison for grafting in city pier leases.
East Rockaway, N.Y., announced yesterday that it would receive bids on Sept. 16 on an issue of $174,000 of general improvement bonds dated Sept. 1, 1947, and due on March 1 from 1949 to 1958.

SPRINGDALE, Conn., Sept. 5 -- L.J. Noah Jr. and Dr. W.E. Gallagher of Wee Burn won the medal in the qualifying round of the Woodway Country Club memberguest best-ball golf tournament by two strokes with a round of 31, 33 -- 64.
Mayor O'Dwyer answered Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin yesterday and invited the Senator to "chew on" the bitter words of a delegate to the American Legion convention.

LONDON, Sept. 5 (AP) -- The British Government's ban on pleasure travel outside the sterling area after Oct. 1, means that the holiday is over for millions of Britons who shun overcrowded vacation resorts at home to take their fun in the Swiss Alps, France, Italy and elsewhere on the Continent.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange turned stronger yesterday and closed 23 to 61 points higher. The far months showed relatively greater strength than the near months.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 5 -- Against the continued opposition of the Soviet delegate, the United States pressed today for adoption of a resolution whereby the United Nations Commission on Conventional Armaments would eliminate from its consideration not only atomic weapons but all weapons of mass destruction, equivalent in effect to famine or earthquake.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- The decision to distribute radioactive isotopes abroad, announced by President Truman on Wednesday and hailed as a boon to mankind, was not a unanimous action of the United States Atomic Energy Commission.

ATHENS, Sept. 5 -- Themistocles Sophoulis, leader of the Liberal party, announced tonight that "all difficulties have been overcome" and that if he received a mandate tomorrow from King Paul to form a Government, it could be sworn in Sunday or Monday.

Marking the first decrease this year, advertising expenditures during July were 7 per cent lower than the previous month but were 15 per cent more than the corresponding month of last year, according to the current issue of Printers' Ink. Expenditures for i national advertising in newspapers were 8 per cent less than in June but were 31 per cent higher than July, 1946.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 5 -- Synthesis of a recently discovered vitamin that has caused regressions of spontaneous breast cancers in 43 per cent of experimental animals injected with the substance was announced here today at the fourth International Cancer Research Congress.

"INFERNAL MACHINE," by A. Fleming macLiesh and Robert de San Marzano, is a slap-dash spoof on the wartime bureaucrats and other targets of opportunity. For the most part, it is chiefly Waugh-and-Potomacwater, but the cheerful irreverence with which Mr. MacLiesh and Mr. de San Marzano lampoon the riders on the Washington carousel produces a fair amount of nostalgic entertainment.

BERLIN, Sept. 5 -- Emil N. Carlebach, Communist ousted by the United States Military Government as editor of the Frankfurter Rundschau, will have a private audience with Gen. Lucius D. Clay, military governor, Monday in Frankfort on the Main.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Representative Harold Knutson, Republican, of Minnesota, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee announced today that the Republicans will renew their drive to cut taxes, as soon as Congress reconvenes.

A autumn visitor to New Hampshire last year, taken aback by the sheer beauty of the countryside, remarked to an innkeeper that he was certainly glad he had arrived at the peak of the season. "But you didn't," corrected the New Englander.

PARIS, Sept. 6 -- At a meeting Monday the Executive Committee of the European conference on the Marshall plan will debate the question to what extent it should modify the figures for Europe's needs to adapt them to the requirements of a critical United States Congress.

MONTREAL, Sept. 6 -- A handpicked track and field team from the Eastern Seaboard of the United States defeated an Eastern Canadian squad, 111 to 59, today in an international meet which saw four Canadian records broken -- three of them by athletes from south of the border.
WASHINGTON, Sept 6 (AP) -- Two groups, one named by the President and the other by Congress, will attempt to work out a national aviation policy this fall to insure American defense.
LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Russia declined today to waive the veto on any sanctions, even of a minor nature, against violators of a proposed pact outlawing atomic weapons.

THERE are 500 pictures in this book and 37,000 words of text; the words are light and neatly put together; it is a pleasure to read them. But in the end, if there isn't a picture, you feel that the subject has been omitted. For instance, Mae West.

The school bell will clang tomorrow for 1,100,000 New York children who will report to classes for the opening of the 1947-48 academic year. To the city's public schools will go 838,492 pupils, while 263,500 children will answer the roll call in Catholic parochial schools.

ENDICOTT, N.Y. Sept. 6 -- Entering the final round undefeated and with a score of 6-1, Albert S. Pinkus of Brooklyn drew today with Prof. Erich W. Marchand of Rochester in the championship tournament of the New York State Chess Association at the country club of the International Business Machines Corporation.

TO THE EDITOR: The kind of thinking expressed in the article, "Report From Rushville, Ind.," by Gilbert Bailey, and undoubtedly true of many areas of American life today, is not only pathetic but dangerous because it is not common sense and not practical.

The Other Side STRANGE it is that men should admit the validity of the arguments for free discussion, but object to their being "pushed to an extreme"; not seeing that unless the reasons are good for an extreme case, they are not good for any case.

WILLIAMS BAY, Wis., Sept. 6 -- Huge clouds of calcium gas, resembling the bright prominences on the sun and expanding outward at speeds of about 150 miles a second have been observed on the star Ux Monocerotis by Dr. Otto Struve, of the Yerkes Observatory here.

THE success story of the Lemonade Opera Company is one of the most cheerful in many seasons. It reflects credit on performers and audiences, and it suggests that there is room in our musical scheme of things for fresh and lively ideas.

LYNCHBURG, Va., Sept. 6 (AP) James A. Farley, former Postmaster General and former chairman of the National Democratic Committee, was quoted by The Lynchburg Advance as saying that he "will support the nomination of Harry S. Truman as Democratic candidate for President in 1948, and support it with pleasure."

THE gosh-all-hemlock style has all-but-vanished from our novel of the soil -- yet the memory lingers on. Cracker-barrel philosophers buy their Sunday best in K.C. now, and forget their philosophy for the radio, when they gather at Cow Corners on a winter's evening -- and yet, the over-all routine of their days, and their dramas, seems curiously the same.

LONDON, Sept. 6 -- The hopes of breaking south Yorkshire's disastrous unofficial coal strike rose today as the area council of all the mine union representatives backed the Government's call to the miners of Grimethorpe to return to work.

LONDON, Sept. 6 -- Britain's attitude toward the United Nations' proposals for Palestine is "This is where we came in." It is possible, but not yet certain, that the British Government's attitude toward the plan at the United Nations Assembly later this month will also be "This is where we get out."

NANKING, Sept. 6 -- Although China is still using her strategic raw materials to pay off some of her war loans from the United States and Russia, the production of tungsten and antimony is languishing because of the decreased dollar demand for these products.

DURING recent months Arthur Miller's "All My Sons" has been under fire as an insurgent or Communist play, as unrepresentative of American life and as "the most unfounded smear upon the American busines community which has been given currency in the theatre or in literature of our post-war days."

BROADWAY is the eighth wonder of the world, and the only one which is intangible. No longer is it just a street, or even a section of a street, but rather it has become the symbol for a state of mind. Like beauty, it is in the eye of the beholder, and, like both beauty and the lesser wonders of the world, it is the subject for endless quantities of literature.

OTTAWA, Sept. 6 -- Although the dollar situation and the action of the British Government ending the automatic convertibility of sterling have not yet greatly affected the life of the man in the street in Canada, there already are indications that their effects will not be long delayed.

ANIMALS -- all kinds of animals -- were Mr. Peck's weakness. The Pecks' city apartment overflowed with dogs, ringdoves, lovebirds, salamanders; their place in the country swarmed with bantams, guinea hens, raccoons, horses, geese.

Because of the short week few buyers were in the wholesale market last week, but mail orders were heavy, according to the weekly market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Co., resident buyers.

ONE of the prize-winning sculptors at the Village Art Center exhibition last year, Harold Tovish, has been appointed assistant professor of sculpture at New York State College of Ceramics, Alfred University, Alfred, N.Y. He was recently elected a member of the Sculptors Guild.
THE camera club season, resumes this week with enlarged memberships and busy programs reported for the opening meetings.

WOMEN'S modes, presumably since one morning when Helen of Troy adjusted her peplum to a new disposal about the hips, have always been subject to change and the changes have always aroused (at least temporarily) both feminine and masculine protest.
Post-war tax plans are still being formulated and new tax committees are being appointed to make recommendations for the improvement of the Federal tax laws.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Sept. 6 -- Addressing a Communist rally of 20,000 in Millenium Square today, Communist Leader Matyas Rakosi made his expected attack on Zoltan Pfeiffer's Independence party and his expected threat against "this association of Small Landholders malcontents, enemies of democracy and reactionaries."

A night of terror when he was lost in a Maine forest, where phantom creatures grew out of reaching pines and lichened rocks, has become a record in brilliant inks for the artist, Stanley Wilson. His experience forms a part of his first American show opening tomorrow at M. Knoedler Co., 14 East Fifty-seventh Street.

MORE than 300,000 residents of the United States live the year round in trailers, and most of them enjoy their nomadic and apparently carefree existence. A survey by the Trailer Coach Manufacturers Association reports that 73 per cent of the people who call a trailer home say they prefer their mobile quarters to a house.
GENEVA, Sept. 6 -- A revived effort to link eastern Europe with projects developed under the Marshall plan is forecast by the economic experts of several nations now in Geneva.

HERE in one volume are the seven novels of Thomas Love Peacock, "Nightmare Abbey" and "Crotchet Castle" complete, the others skillfully abridged with connecting narrative links. None will quarrel with Mr. Redman's choice of Peacock's two masterpieces, and the other novels suffer less than one would suppose from being presented in this fashion.

BOOKS about science for the general public assume a new significance today. Every American citizen of voting age can soon become, in a very real sense, a lay administrator of science -- now that our law-makers recognize the urgency of establishing, in some form, a National Science Foundation and expending, on a hitherto unprecedented scale, public funds for the support of scientific research.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 6 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Rams shaped up today as strong contenders for the National Football League championship and Los Angeles claimed a new Far Western crowd attendance for pro play as 80,889 turned out to see the Rams beat the Washington Redskins, 20 to 7, in an exhibition game for charity in Memorial Coliseum last night.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Sept. 6 -- As a result of a year's study of the relationships between the professional staff of the Boy Scouts of America and the community institutions which serve as parent organizations to Scout units all over the country, preparation of a statement of "the basic philosophy of institutional relationships" was recommended today.

MARTHA'S VINEYARD, Mass. NOW that this department's summer holiday has drawn to an end, it is time, I suppose, to turn to the contemplation of other things than the sparkling blue of Vineyard Sound, the multi -colored cliffs of Gay Head, or the gentle roll of the moorland that curves away beyond my cabin door.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Sept. 6 -- No one connected in any way with the Taft-Hartley Act or similar labor legislation can hope to be elected President of the United States in 1948, Louis Waldman, New York labor lawyer, predicted here today.
TARRYTOWN. THE Sleepy Hollow villages of Tarrytown and North Tarrytown in Westchester County along the Hudson will be the center of attention from coast to coast a week from today.
NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 6 (AP) -- The Sugar Bowl is sold out for its New Year's Day football game -- without selling a ticket.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 6 -- The Argentine delegation to this Inter-American Conference will be back in Buenos Aires next week, leaving behind Foreign Minister Juan A. Bramuglia's signature as sixteenth of the nineteen names on the new hemisphere defense treaty.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) -- America's unknown soldier of World War II will be brought home from overseas near the end of 1949 to lie in honor in Arlington National Cemetery, according to present plans of the War Department.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 6 -- The crew of the battleship Missouri has already amended the geography of the ship for the Commander in Chief, who will go aboard soon after noon tomorrow.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6 -- Failure of the Veterans Administration to provide a program for the rehabilitation of blinded former service men was assailed today at the annual business meeting of the Blinded Veterans Association.

LONDON, Sept. 6 -- With John W. Snyder, United States Secretary of the Treasury, due to arrive in London on Monday, British Government leaders were today busily emphasizing the international aspects of Britain's economic crisis.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 6 -- Kent Peterson walked Stan Musial with the bases loaded in the thirteenth inning tonight, forcing in the run that gave the Cardinals an exciting 4-to-3 victory over the Reds. The result cut the Dodgers' lead over St. Louis to six games.

Expressing a desire "to live a quiet life," Dr. Kurt von Schuschnigg, former Chancellor of Austria, arrived here yesterday aboard the Italian liner Saturnia. The vessel was three hours late in docking, because of engine trouble and fog.

ALTHOUGH steady increases of prices have had no adverse effect on the sales of automobiles as yet, according to country-wide surveys, many dealers are beginning to wonder what the eventual consequences will be.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Sept. 6 (AP) -- Amateur golf stars from every section of the country, survivors of nation-wide qualifying trials, today tested the rugged terrain and various pitfalls of the famed Pebble Beach course where the United States amateur championship will open on Monday.

The Long Island Association has issued a special service bulletin to allay unwarranted consumer fears caused by recent accounts of the quarantine placed on limited areas of potato fields in Nassau County because of the golden nematode.

THE pennant-bound Brooklyn Dodgers -- or are we being presumptuous? -- have often been described as a team without outstanding stars. It's hardly a fair description because there isn't one regular who doesn't scintillate to some degree. But the real, solid man on the ball club is the one-time runner-up for the marbleshooting championship of the State of Kentucky, Harold Henry Reese.

MARI SANDOZ, the author of the powerful folk story "Old Jules" and of the saga-like biography of "Crazy Horse," has written in "The Tom-Walker" a vigorous and thoughtful novel. As in "Slogum House" and "Capital City," her two earlier novels, the action is frequently violent, the dialogue uninhibited, and the principal persons are lacking in morals.

R.H. MARKHAM'S lively and authoritative report on the Yugoslavian tragedy makes especially timely reading in view of the recent left-wing Protestant declaration that "there is today in Yugoslavia complete freedom of worship and respect for religious beliefs and institutions."

THE confusion that exists about how the gold-plated statuette of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences came to be known as "Oscar" is cleared up in the 194748 edition of the Motion Picture Almanac, published last week.

THE Broadway bears came out on top last week. "The Magic Touch" opened and the critics, fresh from their rustic sojourns, wielded their typewriters like bolos; two of the month's hopefuls, "We Love a Lassie" and "The Stars Weep" were withdrawn after being unmercifully beaten on the road.

"SAYNDAY was coming along * * *" say the Kiowa Indians and thus begins, always in the winter, always at night and always with the same phrase, according to his own dictates, one of the stories which they love to tell of the man who got things started in the world.
For the first time the full amount of the Federal tax collected on the sale of sporting arms and ammunition will be released to the states for wildlife restoration and development during 1948.

A RESPECTABLE stand of grass beneath maple trees is not an impossibility. When the trees are valuable for beauty and shade, and are in prominent positions on the grounds, it is worth an effort to have an attractive lawn under them.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 6 (AP) -- Robert R. Young, railroad executive, today replied to a criticism by the Office of Defense Transportation of slow freight on his Chesapeake Ohio line by quoting what he said was a Congressional charge that the Interstate Commerce Commission was controlled by railroad interests of the South and West "to the injury of everyone."

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Sept. 6 -- Eddie Neu and Frank Ryan of Oceanside turned back Tim Holland and Joseph Brittain of Hempstead, 3 and 2, in the feature quarter-final match of the Rockville Club's member-guest golf tournament today.

"With the advent of new aircraft specifically designed as luxury passenger carriers, great progress will be made toward a truly comfortable and well equipped cabin," says John B. Schwab, accommodation engineer of Trans-Canada Airlines, Dorval, Quebec. The first big change will come with seats that face the rear of the plane.

ALTHOUGH most iris would be much better off if they had gone in the ground long ago, September is soon enough to plant Iris Kaempferi. Kaempferi is different from other iris in more ways than this. It blooms in July, when the main display is over; it has its own requirements, and the flowers are far and away the most spectacular in the whole rainbow clan.

In the cities and hamlets of Hungary last week, radio bulletins, newspaper headlines, town criers and posters tacked up on trees announced, A Kommunistak Gyoznek -- "Communists Win Victory." This was the result of last Sunday's national elections -- elections which American correspondents said had been rigged.

BOSTON, Sept. 6 -- A mysterious 84-year-old millionaire from the North End slums who once peddled penny fruit, today presented to the Boston Public Library more than $1,000,000 to start off a $3,000,000 trust fund.

The manifestations of an approaching new crisis in Western Europe are to be seen in that phenomenon of which the world has heard so much in recent months, a steady seepage of dollars. Italy, it is reported, will have exhausted its dollar exchange by the end of 1947.

MUCH has been said about the crisis in American education. Currently the newspapers, the radio, and the national magazines have taken the lead in informing the people of this country of the plight of our public schools.

HERE is a rueful novel that brushes an age-old problem with angry fingers -- and, like so many first novels that are both young and angry, does little more than state the basic antagonisms. Miss Crawford has chosen to retell the story of the Jewish boy who loves the Gentile girl in terms of minor tragedy.

FROM the little this vagrant reviewer heard about the movies while away on a month-long August vacation, there seemed little reason to return, other than to clean out the office and hit the boss for another job.

RELEASE of the Month Dep't.: From Storm Publishers: "Early in May a book columnist in one of the great metropolitan papers did us the honor of calling our innocent jacket copy for Fritz von Unruh's 'The End Is Not Yet,' the 'blurb of the month.' "

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 6 (AP) -- Jack Horne's Kandy Comfort, 9-to-10 favorite of the crowd of 22,000, proved a speedy winner of the $10,000 Consolation Purse, the six-furlong sprint feature for 2-year-olds at Narragansette Park today in place of the canceled Jeanne D'Arc stakes.

ITALY plans to issue soon three postage and three airmail stamps to mark the "6 centenario dalla nascita di S. Caterina, patrona d'ltalia" (sixth centenary of the birth of St. Catherine, patroness of Italy). Finbar Kenny of J. H. Stolow, New York, sends from Milan the designs of the postage items:
The projected New York University Law Center will occupy an entire block in Washington Square, but the exact location is being withheld for the present, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) -- New reports of the gravity of Europe's food and fuel situation were sounded here today.

TO many Americans, reading for pleasure is the original and unpardonable sin. They read for moral reform, for politics, for democracy, for religion; they read to get their lessons or to follow right reason or to combat those legions of that old deluder, Satan, the radio, the movies and the comic strips.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 6 -- Dr. John Herr Musser, specialist in internal medicine, president of the American College of Physicians in 1929-30, and vice president of the American Medical Association in 1933-34, died yesterday in New Orleans at the age of 64.
CHICAGO, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Grains moved lower today on the Board of Trade, but not until after several new high marks had been set early in the session.

EVERY schoolboy knows Patrick Henry the orator, the inciter of revolution. And even after generations of schoolboy declamations, after the words have become the cant of the very stage buffoon, Henry's gems, put back in their setting, still flash fire:

ALTHOUGH Julian Huxley's essay was written in connection with his work as executive secretary of the Preparatory Commission of UNESCO, apparently as a statement of his views on the function and scope of that organization, its importance transcends its purpose as an organizational document.

Leaders of the Liberal party have started an intensive campaign for repeal of the Taft-Hartley Labor Act and preparation for next year's national election. The party is expected to support President Truman, adjudged by its leaders to be virtually certain of nomination.

DESPITE all precautions, the National Air Races at Cleveland last week-end killed one pilot, seriously injured two others and left a score or more living on borrowed time. They are alive only because they were lucky.

Seventy leading building-code experts from all parts of the country are winding up several months of intensive work in order to have the basic code of the Building Officials Conference of America ready for study by all branches of the industry at the joint annual meeting of the Conference and the Building Officials Foundation at the Deshler-Wallick Hotel in Columbus, Ohio, Sept. 22 to 25.

To the Screen Editor: I READ with interest Mr. Pryor's remarks in THE TIMES of Aug. 31 on the current need for Hollywood to better its product now that it is faced with the loss of the British market.

MOBILE, Ala., Sept. 6 -- Reversing the national trend, imports through the port of Mobile customs district jumped $4,345,353 during the first six months of this year over the same period in 1946, it was reported here this week.

American business and local governments will begin this week to make heavy calls for new money on the capital market here, but investment bankers are by no means sure that the mechanisms of the distribution of securities, long geared to the scanty compensation spreads of the late cheap-money refunding era, will measure up readily to the task.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- The Yankees, who seem to have gone completely astray as they float aimlessly high above the field in the eerie American League flag race, dropped their third straight game to the Senators today, and while the situation can't be called alarming it certainly is becoming most embarrassing for Manager Bucky Harris.

WISCONSIN DELLS, Wis. -- For the best example of a civilized community living off nature, consider the people in and around this town named after the stone dells of the Wisconsin River. The town used to be simply Kilbourn until some alert business men took a good look at the dells -- those fantastically shaped, wind-carved sandstones along the local stretch of the Wisconsin.

OKLAHOMA -- New Accommodations Additional housing facilities recently completed make it possible to accommodate 100 more students at the Oklahoma College for Women for the new academic year, it has been announced. The institution, said to be one of only seven state-supported women's colleges in America, is situated at Chickasha, Okla.

FOR THIS WEEK: Finish dividing iris and set out peonies and oriental poppies as soon as possible. If necessary, daylilies also should be divided and transplanted this month. . . . Shade seedlings of biennials and perennials from strong sun, and water them daily. . . . Start taking up House plants preparatory to bringing them indoors.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 6 -- Those sailors who like a dry smoke, of the sea rather than the tobacco variety, enjoyed the racing in the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club regatta today.

SMILEY JOE, the bookie, is no longer a happy man. Plagued by the police in the current anti-gambling drive and convinced that the "heat" is going to stay on for a while, he is about to take to the tall timber, generally known as Miami, until he is able to resume operations in the old neighborhood.

Accused of forcing an innocent man, on threat of death, to allow himself to be arrested on a bookmaking charge, two ex-convicts were held in $10,000 bail each late yesterday afternoon by Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz on charges of coercion.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 6 -- Radioactive isotopes, man's greatest tools for probing into the mysteries of his universe, which provide him with the promise of transforming the world he lives in into a place fit for the realization of his age-old dreams of happiness and abundance, can be produced in quantities great enough to supply all the world's reasonable needs.

The increase of 15 1/2 cents an hour in wages granted last week by an arbitration board in Chicago to the 1,000,000 non-operating employes of the country's railroads will cost the companies an additional $438,000,000 annually.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 6 -- Argentina warned the Big Five today that blocking of an amendment to the Charter to abolish the power of veto could lead to dissolution of the United Nations.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Col. -- During the eleven weeks ended Sept. 1 the six attendants of the two Junior Chamber of Commerce information wagons -- surely six of the world's most patient men -- have had heartto-heart talks here with 154,000 automobile tourists from every state.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- From the time the Eightieth Congress in July adjourned its first regular session, its return this autumn in special assembly has seemed most probable to persons well-informed on conditions abroad and the Administration's foreign policy. This expectation has never been diminished by repeated statements up to now from those empowered to reconvene Congress -- the President and the Majority Leaders -- that no necessity for a special session is in sight.

ALLENTOWN, Pa. DOWN here in the Lehigh Valley they're getting ready for a special election which promises to be a preview of the 1948 elections -- same issues, same arguments and the same political forces lined up against one another. "Don't fool yourself," a local politician told me.
GENEVA, Sept. 6 -- Two years after the end of World War II about 2,000,000 men are still prisoners of war in the hands of the victorious powers.

FOR her latest recording stint, Carol Brice, gifted American contralto, has been assigned four Sacred Arias of Johann Sebastian Bach, and she has made the most of the opportunity. Her voice is big, smooth in texture and wide in range, and she uses it expressively.

THE author of this chronicle of famous storms and wrecks is a diver by profession. His lifetime of direct experience with maritime disaster adds weight and conviction to the remarkable fund of knowledge that he has drawn from the written record.

Although disclammg responsibility for the magnitude of the industry's exports, domestic steel companies patently are embarrassed by the fact that more than 10.5 per cent of finished steel output in the first six months of 1947 was sent abroad.

In one of the largest auctions of recent years, involving properties near the Times Square section, of Manhattan, Joseph P. Day, Inc., will offer the property at 305-325 West Forty-second Street, and extending through the block and including 308-22 West Forty-third Street.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Sept. 6 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Ross E. Rowell, USMC, retired, of Washington, D.C., originator of dive-bombing tactics, died early this morning in the naval hospital here. His age was 62.
Mayor O'Dwyer was urged yesterday by spokesmen for 115,000 tenants to expedite passage of the Sharkey rent-control bills, to halt the flood of eviction proceedings against apartment residents.

PARIS, Sept. 6 -- A four-man subcommittee of the House of Representatives Select Committee on Foreign Aid arrived in Paris today for a study of the French economic and political situation. They will report to Congress before the debate on American help for Europe under the Marshall Plan.

ROME, Sept. 6 -- The Italian mission of the Cooperative for American Remittances to Europe has brought suit against the Leftist afternoon paper Repubblica d'Italia for alleged libelous statements made in a series of three articles accusing its officials of enriching themselves by means of various illegal practices.

PEIPING, Sept. 6 (U.P.) -- Gen. Hsiung Shih-hui, who was relieved of his top Manchurian post recently, told a press conference today that the Nationalists had captured Russian arms from Korean units that had fought on the Chinese Communist side.
Several major cities are revising their building codes to help solve the housing shortage and facilitate modern construction methods, according to the Public Administration Clearing House.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6 -- Charles J. Whipple, president of the Board of Education, said today that the board this month probably would grant to Chicago teachers a $1,800,000 pay increase for the school year now starting. The money was appropriated by the Legislature and will be released Oct. 1 to the board for emergency use.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It seems to be very difficult to get the Congress to take an active interest in Universal Military Training. The activities of members of Congress at present show that most of them would really like to be re-elected next year. Sometimes one hears them criticized for thinking so much about the next election and trying so hard to be re-elected.

EVERY yard has a driveway which is going to remain conspicuous regardless of its length or location. This drive goes a long way in forming first impressions of visitors and passersby, either favorably or unfavorably. The favorable impression is easily accomplished through the medium of suitable and colorful border planting.

Harry L. Dimmick of 310 Elizabeth Avenue, Cranford, N.J., assistant vice president of the Union County Trust Company in charge of its Cranford branch until his retirement a year ago, died yesterday in Post-Graduate Hospital here.

HOLLYWOOD. THE state of the film industry continued to inspire gloom among observers last week as the determination of the British Government to limit dollar remittances remained unshaken and a new attempt to settle the year-old strike of the Conference of Studio Unions failed completely.

Without waiting for a ruling from Justice Ferdinand Pecora on a disputed pension arbitration award, the Transport Workers Union, CIO, announced yesterday a new strike deadline against the New York Omnibus Corporation.

It is perhaps characteristic of the American spirit that our awakened interest in India dwells on grievous events -- a year of rioting, culminating in the Punjab holocaust. Fresh accounts of mass murders, arson and homeless people continue to pour in from a countryside which hitherto has seen few foreign correspondents.

BATAVIA, Java. Sept. 6 (AP) -- The Indonesian Republic today designated Australia as its representative on the United Nationssponsored three-power commission to attempt reconciliation of the Dutch-Indonesian conflict.

LONDON, Sept. 6 (Reuters) -- Arsenal, the English Football League first division leader, handed Manchester United a 2-1 defeat today before 60,000 fans. This match was of top interest in a series of fixtures which attracted nearly a million spectators throughout the United Kingdom.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 6 -- Plans for two-hour stoppage of work by Jews in every country, including the United States, in protest against the deportation of the Exodus 1947 refugees to Germany were disclosed today by Isaac BenZvai, president of Palestine's Jewish National Council.

HISTORIANS in this country are a professional guild. By the curious regulations of the fellowship, while writers on Europe may range from the Renaissance to Hitler, or from France to Bulgaria, the Americanists are rigorously departmentalized into the national and colonial periods.
HAMBURG, Sept. 6 -- Upon orders of Commissioner Berry, correspondents will not be allowed within the area where the first of the three ships was to dock until two hours after she had been berthed.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- The recent wrangle over disposal of the ghost town of Passamaquoddy, Me., illustrates how infinite and unforeseeable are the tribulations of the War Assets Administration.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Sept. 6 -- The State Congress of Industrial Organizations recorded with cheers, whistles and applause today its hope that Mayor O'Dwyer of New York would run for Governor in 1950.

MANPOWER shortage is characteristic of the post-war era. Every field of endeavor seems to have suffered; some more than others. Education is probably the hardest hit. The lack of teachers is universally proclaimed and deplored. But the job of finding teachers is simple compared with that of finding college and university presidents.
LONDON, Sept. 6 (AP) -- United States industry has lost about $1,000,000,000 worth of business through the recent British, French and Australian decisions to cut imports, a survey showed today.

A substantial gift to help establish a department of visual aids for the promotion and distribution of religious films and slides has been presented to the World Council of Christian Education, 156 Fifth Avenue, by Mrs. Clifford S. Heinz of Pittsburgh, according to Dr. Forrest L. Knapp, general secretary.

DENVER, Sept. 6 -- Lew Worsham, seeking his first major tournament victory since he rose from obscurity last June to capture the national open golf championship, took the lead in the $15,000 Denver open today.
DETROIT, Sept. 6 -- The United Automobile Workers, CIO, went into the wholesale grocery business today and disposed of its initial $1,500 worth of stock in three hours.

THE New York City Opera Company, which has been giving opera at a $2 top every spring and autumn since 1944, is adding "The Barber of Seville" to its repertoire for its fall season, which opens Sept. 25 at the City Center.

BORN on a Michigan farm, of a remarkable mother and even more remarkable father, Bertha Van Hoosen eventually got to college and against the wishes of her parents commenced the study of medicine. She put herself through by earning her own way.

In the light of the world's present economic impasse, financial observers here were puzzled last week by the constantly reiterated assurances by American officials that the forthcoming meeting of the board of governors of the International Monetary Fund and the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development would be "purely routine."
TO THE EDITOR: When I first read the article, "Report From Rushville," I thought that your saying "the roots of isolationism can be traced" was the greatest understatement ever.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 6 -- Despite the complexity of the problems to be brought before it, competent authorities today expressed the hope that the United Nations General Assembly would find it possible to end its forthcoming session within eight weeks.

HAMBURG, Germany, Sept. 6 -- The 4,300 Jews of the refugee steamer Exodus 1947 returned to Germany aboard three deportation ships today. British officers were reported to have removed the refugees' leaders in preparation for the debarkation, set to begin at 5 A.M. tomorrow (midnight Saturday, Eastern standard time).

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., Sept. 6--The Afghan Ch. Ali Khyber from the kennel of Mrs. Leah McConaha of Great Neck, L.I., gained best-in-show today in the fifth and finest event of the Interstate Kennel Association. Night was drawing on fast on a fairway of the Briar Hills Golf Club when Mrs. W. French Githens made the selection in an excellent final field.

THE Interstate Commerce Commission last week granted the Pullman Company's application for higher sleeping -car charges, and when the company puts its new rates into effect, after twenty days' notice to the public, it will be the first move of the company's new owners to affect the traveling public.

Mrs. Dora Emerson Wheeler, widow of Dr. William Morton Wheeler, zoologist and one-time dean of the Bussey Institute for Research in Applied Biology, died on Friday, after a long illness, at her home in Colebrook, Conn. Her age was 77.

LONDON, Sunday, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Premier Stalin, in a message to the Soviet people on the 800th anniversary of the founding of Moscow, said today that Russia's capital represented the "liberation movement of toiling mankind from capitalist slavery."

Store-wide activity last week was good, according to a survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Activity in the various departments was described as follows: "Coat and suit departments selling, sportswear brisk, accessories in active demand, shoe departments peaking activity, backto-school promotions sparking sales, notions and school supplies excellent, yardage very active and upholstered furniture good."

A plea to Americans to aid Britain in her hour of economic need was issued yesterday by Mrs. Natalie Wales Paine, president of Common Cause, Inc., 48 East Forty -eighth Street, and founder of Bundles for Britain.

HIGH blood pressure, the late Dr. Logan Clendening rather wryly observed, "has taken its place like those other things of the spirit such as the weather, the income tax and the total depravity of grandchildren, as a staple topic of conversation."
UNESCO is a newly coined term designating the biggest name in the United Nations family -- the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

PARIS, Sept. 6 -- Premier Paul Ramadier and twenty other Socialist party deputies who have defied the mandate of the party as expressed in the recent party congress in Lyon must explain their recalitrance to another party congress, the Socialist party executive committee decided tonight.

Implying that the epidemic of gang slayings in Brooklyn in Bath Beach area was near solution, Deputy Chief Inspector William T. Whalen announced yesterday that "we are working on something that might split this thing wide open."

BERLIN, Sept. 6 (AP) -- A habeas corpus writ was denied today to six leading German officials of the Aakania works, accused of manufacturing war materials in Berlin for a foreign power -- reportedly Russia. A United States military court ordered them held without bail for triel within ten days.

The New York State Unemployment Insurance Fund has recovered its status as an enterprise with a billion dollars in back of it for the third time in the last three years, it was learned yesterday from an operations report of the Bureau of Research and Statistics of the State Labor Department's unemployment insurance division.

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 6 (AP) -- A jury in Federal District Court returned a verdict of guilty today in the trial of three men charged with conspiring to injure and oppress qualified voters in the 1946 Kansas City primary election.

MOST Greek tragedies are beautiful and memorable. Everyone knows the story of Oedipus and his fatal marriage; no one who has read "Agamemnon" ever forgets the shapes of blood -- more terrible than those of "Macbeth" -- which confront the doomed Cassandra, or the crimson carpet spread for the feet of the doomed Agamemnon.

The New York Telephone Company announced yesterday that three new central office installations, with facilities for 15,000 new subscribers, would be placed in service this week in a stepped-up construction program designed to provide the city with twenty-five new exchanges, at the rate of five a month.

Will U.S. Close It? Since the foundation of the Republic the foreign policy of the United States has never been formalized. There is no official document, bearing the Great Seal of the United States and locked in a Government safe, which has the title "American Foreign Policy: A Law."

Because of the pressure of other business affairs, William K. Anderson of Detroit, former chief commander of the United States Power Squadrons, has resigned his post as executive secretary of the American Power Boat Association.

A new weekly cruise service between New York and Havana, with calls at Nassau and Miami on both the outward and return voyages, was announced yesterday by Alton B. Sharp, president of the Eastern Steamship Lines. The cruises, which begin on Oct. 24, will be made throughout the winter by the liners Evangeline and Yarmouth.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- The reception that Senator Robert A. Taft receives on his trip through the Far West this month will reflect in large measure the way the public feels about Republican policy as translated into action in the first session of the Eightieth Congress.

LET the answer to the question, "Who can profitably read this book?" be an immediate check to those who are mentally pigeonholing "Unto the Least of These" as food for professionals in the social service field. It is the author's very theme that the natural rights of childhood insist that the answer to that question exclude no member of society.
JERUSALEM, Sept. 6 -- Broadly speaking, the Zionists have accepted the fundamentals of the United Nations Special Committee's recommendations for Palestine.

THERE could be no better examples of the variation in possible approaches to a subject than these two books. Mrs. Bradford has written a conversational thirty-one chapters on child training as viewed from a mother's on-the-aisle seat, while Professor Torgerson's book is a parcel of stern rebuke directed at the elementary school teacher.

Whither Now in Housing? It would be a curious instance of cart before horse if the almost insatiable demand of the American people for new automobiles should be satisfied before the American people was housed.

LADY PAMELA FOXE might, as plain Pam Fox, have found her way without noticeable comment into the women's magazines as a rather gaudy example of the revolt of a twentieth-century miss who dared all for what she conceived to be love.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. -- This winter resort city, fast growing on a year-round residential basis, is going through a building spurt approaching that of the Nineteen Twenties boom, but on a far different basis. The old boom was speculative.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- Senator Joseph H. Ball, Republican, of Minnesota, a leading exponent of labor law revision at the recent session of Congress, declared today that the Taft-Hartley Labor Relations Act was "so far working very well" and was being "quite generally observed."
TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 6 (AP) -- Herbert Kaufman, editor, author and poet, who in recent years had operated the Herbert Kaufman Newspaper Syndicate, died today at his home. His age waa 69.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 6 -- Thousands of additional layoffs in the steel industry seemed inevitable today in the "wildcat" strike of 1,800 inter-plant railroad workers here. Basic steel operations of Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation already are down, with more than 15,000 workers idle.

The Better Business Bureau of New York City, 280 Broadway, announced yesterday that reports reaching it indicated some Eastern European governments were imposing "unreasonable" duty charges on relief packages sent into those countries through private forwarding agencies operating for profit in this country.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Representative Adolph J. Sabath, Democrat, of Illinois, 81-year-old dean of the House, has been made an honorary citizen of his native village of Zabori in Czechoslovakia.
The New York Yankees announced yesterday that they will not accept any additional mail orders for world series tickets postmarked later than midnight last night.

Various aspects of the housing problem will be discussed at the fifty-fifth annual convention of the United States Savings and Loan League in San Francisco, Calif., Sept. 17-19. Topics will include planning and prices, credit for repair and improvement of existing houses, and the influence of home ownership.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- Research in the Radioactivity Section of the National Bureau of Standards has revealed that diamonds are sensitive to radioactivity and that single-crystal colorless diamonds can be used as counters of alpha, beta and gamma rays in exactly the same fashion as the Geiger-Muller Counter, it was announced today.

OMAHA, Neb., Sept. 6 -- Midwest Republicans may follow some political lessons of the Democratic "Solid South." Whether the effort is to be successful will be learned after the Republican chairmen of the nineteen states meet here Sept. 15 and 16.

HOLLYWOOD. UNACCUSTOMED as it is to forthright speaking, Hollywood is in a pleasant dilemma over a red-haired Englishwoman named Phyllis Calvert. This talented importation is a serious dramatic star, and experience has taught the town to expect a deal of the hauteur and temperament it tolerates (if not encourages) in Capital-A art.

Louis Wendel, former Chief Justice of the City Court, died yesterday afternoon of a heart attack at Pocono Pines, Pa., where he was on a vacation, according to word received here by relatives and friends. He was 75 years old.

TRANSPLANTED from the West little more than ten years ago, more than forty eastern dude ranches now invite the city dweller to enjoy the romance of the Old West in his own backyard in conjunction with golf, tennis, swimming, boating and badminton.

One thousand openings for veterans who are unable to gain immediate entrance to City College's day session are available for the fall semester in its "twilight" session, Dr. Walter A. Knittle, director of the evening session, announced yesterday.

A motorcade of ten automobiles, led by a horse and wagon, wound its way up Second Avenue yesterday morning as a demonstration for the continuance of the City's Child Care Center program for working mothers.

COPENHAGEN, Sept. 6 -- Nobody in Europe deplores the EastWest split more than the Scandinavians, who are in every respect caught in the middle. Just as the East-West conflict is the leading topic of political discussion the world over, so it is here also, with the added emphasis that Scandinavia fears that if war should come, this part of Europe would be the first no-man's land.

THE broadcasting picture is beginning to assume its familiar seasonal form, as more and more of radio's stellar stand-bys, returning from vacation, converge on the studios. Slated for openings this week are: Today -- "Juvenile Jury," the small-fry panel which offers counsel on the problems of other small fry, resumes on WOR-Mutual at 3:30 P.M.

DURING the two years since World War II ended, afterthoughts have mellowed somewhat. Nostalgia has permeated the less bitter memories, particularly those of the units the soldier belonged to in combat. Desirous of making permanent record of these wartime deeds and experiences, Army historical sections are obliging with an impressive number of division and regimental histories.

THE years 1918 to 1932 measured the full life span of Mike Brandon. "Killed in action?" You might call it that. You might also say he was the product of his time. Strong and sordid, Virgil Scott's tale is a brutal case history of a juvenile delinquent.
WITH the supply of flash lamps still low, amateurs would do well to consider the uses of flood-type lamps for subjects they might ordinarily shoot with flash.

THERE have been critics, especially in nineteenth century Germany, who regarded Shakespeare as above all a sage. There have also been critics who denied that Shakespeare had a mind at all. The latter have been increasingly common in twentieth century England and America.

In Washington last week the political strategists were hard at work. At headquarters of the Republican and Democratic national committees and of the AFL and CIO, staffs gathered statistics, mapped fund-raising drives, issued news releases, mailed out a constant flood of campaign literature.

Pessimism with regard to declining American exports is being overdone, as the volume of exports even at lower levels will remain far above pre-war totals for many months to come, Henri Stakgold, president of Block International Corporation and Corneliussen Stakgold, Inc., said in an interview here yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 6 (AP) -- The Red Sox defeated the Athletics, 4 to 3, today by coming from behind twice despite homers by Pete Suder and Sam Chapman of Philadelphia. Earl Johnson pitched his tenth victory and Dick Fowler sustained his tenth defeat.

IT seems to have become a popular diversion in recent months to ask, "Where are they now?" of all those post-war housing amenities we were promised in 1944. Certainly the most noticeable difference between houses dated 1940 and houses dated 1947 is the cost of building them.
LONDON, Sept. 6 (AP) -- A Tass report charged today that AngloAmerican military missions had promised help to an Albanian underground organization seeking to overthrow the Albanian Government.

BARCELONA, Spain, Sept. 6 -- Fugitive Nazis are still escaping into Spain more than two years after the end of the war and still find a friendly reception here. The Allied authorities have evidence of an organized underground that is running Germans across France to the more pleasant atmosphere here.

TODAY marks the opening of the 1947-48 season in radio, the beginning of another thirty-nine weeks of regular kilocycle fare. Promptly at 8 this evening the spry Charlie McCarthy will make his appearance, his indignant falsetto officially putting to rout the summer replacements.

ARTHUR MAHONEY and Thalia Mara, in their first (and incidentally, very successful) season as directors of the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival and school, near Lee, Mass., certainly did not elect to spare themselves.

AS THOUGH to make amends for a delayed entrance into the Civil War sweepstakes, Ben Ames Williams now gives us a 720,000-word jumbo that makes "Gone with the Wind" seem little more than a short story that got out of hand.

Clarification of the retail, function in the American economy and the role it plays in prices will be the objective of retailer presentations at the price investigation hearings to be held by subcommittees of the Joint Congressional Committee on the Economic Report, it was indicated here last week.

GENEVA. THE American public must make up its mind, individually and collectively, about the attitude it is going to take toward the foreign-trade policy of the United States. An American lead is essential if any program for economic reconstruction is to succeed.

ATHENS, Sept. 6 -- Themistokles Sophoulis, at the head of a Cabinet of ten Liberals and thirteen Populists, will be sworn into office by Archbishop Dimitrios Damaskinos in the presence of King Paul tomorrow afternoon or, at the latest, on Monday morning.

A MISPLACED card in a bridge player's hand often leads to a most unfortunate result. This circumstance had a happier ending in the deal reported today, however; and, in addition, provided an opportunity for a most unusual bit of bridge analysis.

Steel is being set on Park Avenue's first de luxe post-war rental apartment building -- a nineteenstory and penthouse structure on the former site of the George Blumenthal residence at the southwest corner of Seventieth Street.

Manufacturers and distributors of home appliances have all but abandoned the huge "pep meeting" method of imparting sales and product training to dealers and retail salesmen and are concentrating on small group and individual sessions free from "war and immediate post-war fol-de-rol," representatives of these segments of the trade reported last week.

THE trend to lower prices in sound projectors was indicated recently at a private demonstration at the Revere factory in Chicago, when it was announced that the 16mm. Revere Sound Projector, scheduled to sell for around $300, would be available toward the end of this year.
THE local art season set a record last year for number of shows and for volume of work shown. Losing no time, the galleries have swung into action again with ten exhibitions opening last Tuesday.

Gridirons throughout the nation are busy places these days. At little normal schools, junior colleges and great universities, footballs are flying as coaches prepare their charges for what is expected to be one of the sport's great seasons.

SALZBURG. THIS year's Salzburg Festival was not exactly a carbon copy of last year's, but the differences were superficial and the similarities significant. Neither the productions nor the audiences had the international character that made the Salzburg Festivals what they were before 1938.

Metal products manufacturers have cut back inventories to a maximum of thirty day production schedules in many plants, and are now depending upon their suppliers to notify them when present purchasing policies should be changed, spokesmen disclosed here yesterday.

Using money received from their terminal leave bonds, or taking advantage of the loan-guarantee plan under the GI Bill of Rights, groups of war veterans have launched the first of what promises to be a significant series of cooperative housing ventures in this area.

Resuming Saturday activity after a closure since May, trading in futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday was moderately active, and prices turned easier. The market closed 31 to 37 points net lower.

WHEN calves' liver costs as much as $1.25 a pound and even the humble chuck steak averages 59 cents, as both have in New York City recently, most women begin to think about finding substitutes that put less burden on the budget.

BERLIN, Sept. 6 -- The United States Military Government is under pressure from Washington authorities not to overemphasize the German bungling of the food and agriculture program, it was learned today. The purpose of this attitude is said to be the fear on the part of the United States and British Food Board in Washington that Congress will not authorize the requested appropriations for more German food imports, already reaching record highs.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 200 head; total, 2,200 (estimated), compared with week ago; hogs, 240 pounds down, $1 to $1.25 higher; heavier weights and saws, $1.50 to $2.25 higher.

NO people in the world, perhaps, are more sensitive to criticism than are the inhabitants of Brazil: yet Brazilians are forever engaged in criticizing themselves, at times in a manner that is salutary and constructive, at other times with an intensity that approaches the point of self-flagellation.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Sept. 6 -- The result of the Hungarian elections has put an unexpected question mark to the two and one-half year chronicle of steady Soviet absorption of southeast Europe.

FOREIGN rather than domestic developments moved into the business foreground last week. It became increasingly clear that the "dollar squeeze" was on in earnest. The Bevin proposal for redistribution of the Fort Knox gold pointed up the crisis which involves not only Britain but France and Italy as well.

LONDON, Sept. 6 -- In keeping with the bigger and better austerity program facing this country because of her economic difficulties, Britons will virtually become prisoners on their own shores as of Oct. 1. All but essential business travel outside the sterling area will be forbidden, and traveland-food hungry Britons, who since the end of the war have swarmed over the Continent in search of sunshine and steaks, will no longer do so.

With "Trade, Travel and Defense" as its keynote, the American Merchant Marine Conference will open here on Oct. 15, at a time that shipping men view as involving the greatest peacetime emergency in the history of the nation's merchant fleet.

ATLANTA, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Since 1932 business men and Southern newspaper publishers have turned an investment of $100,000 in research inot a multi-million-dollar industry presenting a competitive threat to the Canadian newsprint monopoly.

WHEN the century was young, "Broadway" was a glittering word. It connoted bright lights, gay nights, beautiful women and hardbitten men with hearts of gold. George Cohan gave his regards to it in a famous song.

RHYTHMIC, drowsy phrases are set to pictures that complement them perfectly in this new go-to-sleep book for very little children. Warm and bright in color, the illustrations show all the cozy, familiar details of a big cheerful nursery, with a bunny tucked Into bed ready for sleep.

MR. ROTHMAN'S first novel is a wicked little number that uses the instruments of serious writing to tell the contrived story of a pleasant young prostitute named Virgie. His point is that she's just like you and me.

A continued activity with improving conditions in the industrial real estate market is reported by the Society of Industrial Realtors, a division of the National Association of Real Estate Boards. One of the main factors for this activity, the report said, is the growing trend of industry to move from congested centers to smaller communities.

DETROIT, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Youthful Art Houtteman, the Detroit Tigers' 20-year-old righthander, hurled a masterful three-hit shutout, facing only 30 batsmen, to whip the St. Louis Browns today, 2 to 0, with the aid of catcher Bob Swift's first home run of the season.

DURING the next few weeks it is possible to see some of the loveliest blossoms of the year. Their beauty, however, is all too often marred by the slightly down-at-the-heels look of the garden. This may be due to lack of forethought last spring, to poor care during vacation days of July and August, or to planting too many perennials for other seasons at the expense of the fall garden.

Amid much somber news from Europe one item of good cheer is the action of the British Trade Union Congress in endorsing Mr. Bevin's policy of close cooperation with the United States. This supplements similar action taken recently at the annual Labor party conference.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 6 (AP) -- Owen P. Merrill, 38-year-old yacht designer from Riverton, N.J., took the lead in the tenth international Comet Class Racing Association regatta when he won the second race on Lake Cayuga late today.

William Talbert of New York, finalist in 1944 and 1945, failed to survive his opening match in the national amateur tennis championship yesterday as the tournament started at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.

SAN FRANCISCO. HAVE you been trying to find a good nursery school for a young child lately? Dr. James L. Hymes Jr. told us here the other day that he knows of a good one. It has a waiting list of 500 children.

Prices of securities continued their irregular pattern last week, reflecting a lack of public interest coupled with fears regarding European conditions and business generally. It was the third successive period of lower prices.
BERLIN, Sept. 6 -- On June 5, 1945, twenty-seven months ago, the following declaration was published by the Governments of the United Kingdom, the United States, the Soviet Union and France:

ALBANY, Sept. 6 -- New York State in 1947 has continued to enjoy the high-level prosperity which characterized the immediate postwar period, the State Department of Commerce said today in a survey of business conditions.

EARLIER in the summer I spent a couple of delightfully mad weeks in Havana, where, as might have been expected, I found a modern art movement of considerable range and robustness. The element of the expected was directly traceable to an exhibition of paintings by a group of Cuban artists held at our Museum of Modern Art in 1944.

NEW DELHI, Sept. 6 -- Burned and lacerated bodies in neat rows covered half the courtyard of the Delhi city morgue this afternoon. This was part of the toll of the past two days' communal rioting in this city and the surrounding villages.

THESE souvenirs of childhood recorded by Dr. Gulielma Alsop, for many years college physician at Barnard and sister of Mary O'Hara, who writes the "Flicka" stories, are surely among the most rapturous ever to find their way into print.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- Most Government economists have one thing in common these days. They are concerned about the high cost of living. But, as Mark Twain is supposed to have said about the weather, everybody's talking about it and nobody's doing anything about it.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Capital Airlines today joined United and American Airlines in asking Civil Aeronautics Board approval to reduce commodity freight rates up to 35 per cent from certain air freight-producing centers effective Oct. 5.

LONDON, Sept. 6 -- The use of atomic energy in industry has been an important topic of discussion at both the meeting of the British Association for the Advancement of Science, which ended last Tuesday at Dundee, Scotland, and at the World Power Conference, now being held at The Hague.

The accomplishment of Pan-American unity embodied in the Rio treaty is due to have a large effect in world deliberations. Coming at the time it does, and under international conditions as they exist today, its influence directly and indirectly is bound to be enormous.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 6 -- Argentina, although she went into the war late, is beginning to suffer the same dislocations of the postwar period that have been plaguing many other portions of the world far more deeply involved in the conflict.

LONDON, Sept. 6 -- About the liveliest meeting held at Dundee, Scotland, by any of the thirteen sections of the British Association for the Advancement of Science was the one in which Drs. J.D. Bernal, F.A.E. Crew, Louis Moss, O.H. Wansbrough-Jones, W.C. Wilson and S. Zuckerman discussed operational research and advocated its adoption in extricating Great Britain from its economic crisis.
PARIS, Sept. 6 -- The Marshall Plan--prematurely so called for three months --came near meriting its name this week.
"WE'LL open on Broadway, in the early fall!" What magic words for a producer to utter -- and what bewildering delight for a playwright to hear!

IS there danger of a shooting war between Russia and the United States? The sharp political, economic and ideological conflict between the two countries and the consequent division of the world into two worlds have aroused fears that the present "cold war" might become a "hot war."

Tucked away in the recesses of the big gray building that houses the Veterans Administration's Central Office in Washington is an exhibit that is helping the Veterans Administration meet its avowed policy of providing for disabled veterans the latest and most suitable types of prosthetic devices.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Finn Haakon Frolich, internationally known sculptor and art teacher, died yesterday at his home in Salinas, Calif., his daughter announced here. His age was 79.

MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., Sept. 6 -- Dr. Stoyan Gavrilovitch of New York, former Under-Secretary of Foreign Affairs of Yugoslavia and first chairman, of the United Nations Site Commission, told the Moral Rearmament Assembly here today why he had been so outspoken in urging that the United Nations headquarters be established in the United States.

DWARF evergreens have a great many forms and so they are suited to numerous locations. Some of them are better for low hedges than are taller plants that require severe shearing. Others cover banks and terraces, low walls and rock outcroppings.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat, of Virginia, who is proud of his reputation as a long-time advocate of economy, is shattering all governmental records each day now by operating a Federal agency which hasn't any funds.
