United Jewish Appeal agencies have spent more than $105,000,000 this year, Henry Morgenthau Jr., general chairman, reported last night at the opening of the organization's fall campaign for $170,000,000.
Evidence of increasing interest in teaching as a career is reported at Illinois State Normal University, where a record-breaking freshman class will report on Tuesday.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Sept. 6 -- The Bloomfield Lamp Division of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation issued today its first statement on safety precautions at the plant since the start last month of a state investigation of beryllium poisoning in which the plant figures.

Refinancing of the thirty-twostory Whitehall Building occupying the blockfront on Battery Place between Washington and West Streets in lower Manhattan was announced yesterday with the placing of a $3,700,000 mortgage loan on the property for the Sheraton Corporation of America.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 6 -- The Indian Harbor Yacht Club became the first winner of the Bermuda -Indian Harbor Trophy by garnering 96 points to the Bermuda Royal Yacht Club team's 48 in four races, three of which were sailed here today.

First impressions being lasting ones, it will be all right with the Dodgers if they don't see Ray Poat again for the remainder of the season. For yesterday at the Polo Grounds the pennant-bound Brooks got their first look at the 29-yearold right-hander and immediately nurtured a dislike that easily could develop into hatred.

Extensive hull repairs on the 20,183 -ton Moore-McCormack liner Uruguay were completed at the Todd Shipyards Corporation's Brooklyn division Friday and the vessel is now tied up at the "Long Dock'' in Section 20 of Erie Basin. Brooklyn, awaiting the end of the shipyard strike so that her reconversion can be completed.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 6 -- Robe F. Bingham, lawyer and a civil leader, died last night at the age of 56.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 6 -- Following is a supplementary list of items, made public today by United Nations headquarters, for the agenda, of the second regular session of the General Assembly, which opens Sept. 16: 1. Protection of the rights of the General Assembly in relation to the admission of new members: Item proposed by Australia.

The "Germany First" advocates in the United States have "finally succeeded in their plot to discredit and then junk the Potsdam decisions," C. Monteith Gilpin, secretary of the Society for Prevention of World War III, Inc., charged yesterday.

ASTEROIDS -- The University of Cincinnati Observatory will become the international clearing house and publishing center for data pertaining to asteroids -- the 1,200 little planets located between the orbits of Mars and Jupiter. Dr. Paul Herget, director of the observatory and Professor of Astronomy at the university, will be in charge of the work.

Two disappointments in the springtime scrimmaging among the 3-year-olds, William Helis' Cosmic Bomb and the Ridgewood Stable's Double Jay, were the big horses of the $25,000 added Discovery Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. They finished noses apart at the end of a mile-and-a-furlong run that had the crowd of 34,075 in a full-fledged dither.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: A peace treaty is an agreement entered into by belligerents to terminate a state of war. If the war ends with victory for one belligerent over the other, the treaty usually also contains the conditions of peace imposed by the victor upon the vanquished.

John Santo, one of the original organizers of the Transport Workers Union and now its director of organization, will be charged tomorrow by the Immigration Service of the Department of Justice with affiliation with an organization advocating the overthrow of the United States Government.

SHAKESPEARE'S characters do not often discuss ideas. They do not always even have ideas. But they are always involved in ideas. If they themselves are idealess the play, the total work, is not. If Shakespeare gives the impression of being without ideas, it is because he is a poet and works in images rather than concepts.

THE first fall festival of the Jackson and Perkins Nursery will be held at their rose garden in Newark, N.Y., this week. More than 22,000 rose plants are grown on the fifteenacre grounds that were opened last June.

With the National League clubs still occupied in training camps and exhibition contests, the AllAmerica Conference, whose race is under way, continues to dominate the professional football picture. By the end of this week all the Conference teams will have had their first taste of action.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- Initiation of an extensive program to survey all hazards resulting from atomic activity was announced today by the United States Atomic Energy Commission.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians defeated the Chicago White Sox, 6 to 4, today for Bob Feller's eighteenth victory, but the fast-ball star was withdrawn in the ninth after sporadic wildness.
Coach Lou Little believes Columbia will have a backfield definitely improved over the high-scoring unit of last year.

NO matter what action is taken by the United Nations on the Palestine report, its success or failure will depend on whether Arab and Jew can live together peaceably in the Holy Land, whether in separate states, or in a federated state. Meantime, recent outbreaks in Palestine and the prospect of new and even more sanguine conflict tend to make the outlook gloomy.

ALBANY, Sept. 6 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey announced today that New York's $600,000,000-a-year vacation business showed a substantial increase this year, with numerous additional visitors reported from other states and countries.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 6 -- President Truman was unharmed in a skidding of his automobile this morning on a wet-clay, corkscrew road while ascending Tijuca Mountain near here.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Mr. Bevin's proposal for redistribution of American gold involves a gift of some magnitude. Even so, the suggestion is impractical as long as there is a chance that the gold may come right back in payment for American goods going abroad.

SOUTHPORT, England, Sept. 6 -- Britain's Labor Government this week-end has an assurance that the labor unions will stand solidly behind it in the fight the nation faces for economic survival. The great Trades Union Congress in its annual gathering of delegates representative of 7,500,000 organized workers in Britain, has held a week's meeting here at Southport to take stock of the Labor Government's achievements.

SO that his readers may not be deceived, as they otherwise almost certainly would be, Mr. Stilwell expressly warns them that his book is a novel and not an autobiography. He is not the "I" of the story, he says, and the family whose violent fortunes he describes is not his family at all.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 6 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates used their most potent weapon, the home run, to come from behind today and beat the Chicago Cubs, 7 to 6, in ten innings.
GARY, Ind., Sept. 6 (AP) -- Indiana's new anti-hate law was invoked today as students of Emerson High School continued to defy official action permitting Negroes to attend the school.

HUCKLEBERRY HELL is the scene of a wonderful furor when the dog-catcher's wagon starts rolling -- without the dog catcher. You can see it all in Leonard Weisgard's vigorous sepia pictures, so full of action that they almost seem like movies.

WASHINGTON -- Americans are the greatest travelers in the world, both within our borders and abroad. This travel is an economic stimulant domestically and might be a boon to war-shattered foreign economies.

MONTREAL -- Seeing Canada from a train window is a tourist's delight, and a thrilling experience. The four-day run eastward from Vancouver affords an intimate and ever-changing view of the northern part of this continent, a mixture of rugged mountains, racing mountain streams and deep gorges, hours of crossing wide prairies and rich cattle country, fleeting glimpses of wild animals grazing even wilder terrain, and finally a ride through the Old-World civilization of eastern Canada.

THE first of fourteen new hotels being built in the Dominican Republic at a cost of $12,000,000 was recently opeped in San Cristobal, twenty miles by good motor road from Ciudad Trujillo, the capital city. Five more are scheduled for completion in 1948.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 6 -- Efforts at Communist penetration into women's groups in the British and American zones in Germany were described here today by a German educator.

MRS. DELIA CANER has reared four children of her own, has been a grandmother thirteen times, a great-grandmother twice and might be expected to be taking things easy. But recently Mrs. Caner, now in her sixty-eighth year, welcomed a 10-day-old foster child into her little home in Queens.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 6 -- Stirred by a militant speech by Representative James E. van Zandt, Republican, of Pennsylvania, delegates to the forty-eighth national encampment of the Veterans of Foreign Wars today voted unanimously to make pensions for World War I veterans their prime objective for the coming year.

IN this first novel about a certain aspect of Negro life today, I.S. Young has drawn an effective and disturbing picture. For "Jadie Greenway" is a Baedeker of the modes and customs of child delinquents living in the filth and moral stench of those overcrowded sections found in both Manhattan and Brooklyn.

MANILA, Sept. 6 -- The purchase and operation of a thirty-ton paper mill by the Philippine Government will be one of the first ventures in the industrialization program. This general plan is expected to give the Philippines its economic independence when United States money runs out and the Republic is really on its own financially around 1949 or 1950.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 6 -- Final awards were made today at the thirteenth annual Westchester County Flower and Harvest Show at the County Center here. The exhibition will continue through tomorrow from 10 A.M. to 11 P.M.

HOLLYWOOD. FRANCIS X. BUSHMAN, undisputed cinema swoon king of thirty years ago, who now, at 64, is a busy radio actor, asserts that broadcasting is the ideal easy work medium for the older actor who would like to retire yet is baffled by the problem of coping with complete leisure.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- Inquiries as to an individual's race and color were stricken from a proposed basic questionnaire to be used in a Western Hemisphere census in 1950 as a consequence of the sensitivity of many countries to such matters, it was disclosed today.

MANY a person who knew Cape Cod as it was twenty, thirty, fifty years ago has dreamed. I fancy, of writing a book about that fascinating community. But of those many, only a few have actually done it; and of those few, not many have done it well.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Sept. 6 -- The United States' oddest export is gurgling across the Arizona-Mexico boundary at the rate of around 250,000 gallons a day. It is plain water.

JUST fourteen years ago this week in this Review: "Germany Enters the Third Reich," a study by Calvin B. Hoover, crowded Gertrude Stein off the front page. Hitler, according to Professor Hoover, when he was outwitted by von Papen, "possessed the resources both of intelligence and self-confidence to find the way out of what then seemed to be hopeless cul-desac."

ALLENTOWN, Pa., Sept. 6 -- Organized labor, which has made the record of the Eighteenth Congress and the Taft-Hartley Labor Law in particular the issues of a special Congressional election to be held in the Eighth Pennsylvania District on Tuesday, began its final effort today to elect the Democratic nominee.

CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 6 -- In a field rendered slim by five scratches, the Pentagon Stable's The Doge won the $15,000 added Valley Forge Handicap at Garden State Park today. With only five others running against him, the 5-year-old son of Bull Dog made a fine stretch run to score by a length and a half over Mrs. E.H. Augustus' Blue Yonder, favorite in the mile fixture.

Last week's soaring food prices, comparable with the rocketing rises at the end of the Office of Price Administration, brought reports of housewives' resistance in New York and other cities of the country yesterday and demands from labor circles that price controls be restored.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations announced today that it would give local union groups, including wives of union members, any help they need in testifying on living costs before Congressional hearings on prices to be conducted soon in various parts of the country.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 7 -- The United Nations Security Council will make another attempt to break the deadlock on the British -Egyptian dispute when it reconvenes here after a ten-day holiday. The session will set the pace for an organization-wide drive this week to wind up all business in time for the opening of the General Assembly at Flushing Meadow, Queens, on Sept. 16.

ROME, Sept. 7 -- While one of the largest crowds that Rome has ever seen was cheering Pope Pius XII and his declaration of war against the forces that oppose the "spirtual revival of society," another large crowd in Modena was cheering Communist leader Palmiro Togliatti, who today declared war against Premier Alcide de Gasperi's Government.

RYE. N.Y., Sept 7 -- A Scottish terrier became best in show at one of the East's foremost dog competitions today. He was Champion Deephaven Warspite from the Marlu Farm Kennels of West Long Branch, N.J., and he topped a record entry of 1,612 in the thirtieth all-breed event of the West-chester Kennel Club at the Westchester Country Club.

ALBANY, Sept. 7 -- The State Education Department announced today the winners of state warservice scholarships, effective Sept. 1, as a result of competitive examination conducted Aug. 1. The fourth series of 1,200 such scholarships was established for veterans of both World Wars by the 1947 Legislature.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 7 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Reds pounced on Jim Hearn for three runs in the first, inning to start the way toward a 4-to-2 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals today after the Redbirds had trounced the Reds, 12-2, in the opener of a double-header.

The New York Omnibus Corporation will apply to Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora today to enjoin the Transport Workers Union, CIO, from carrying out its threat to strike against the corporation at 4 A.M. Friday, Edmund C. Collins, vice president, announced last night.
The thirty-third annual clinical congress of the American College of Surgeons will open this morning for a five-day meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Minding Our Manners A fellow traveler -- no allusion to the friends of Comrade Stalin -- he's just one of the millions who share with the rest of us the uses and abuses of our subways -- has turned up with a novel complaint.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7 -- A bull market has been on in grains for six weeks. All current deliveries of wheat, corn, barley and soy beans and the deferred deliveries of lard have sold at new seasonal high prices and September and cash corn and September oats have been traded in at the highest levels on record.

MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., Sept. 7 -- Political and racial rivalries that threaten the success of next week's Jamaica conference on the federation of the British West Indies are being solved through application of the spirit and program of moral rearmament, according to leaders from Jamaica and Barbadoes at the North American Assembly for Moral Rearmament.

In a reflective mood yesterday Lee Shubert cited reasons why his firm was showing unwonted producing activity this season in an effort to fill their houses here and on the road. A key man of long experience in the theatrical industry, he said he hadn't encountered such a state of affairs before.

PARIS, Sept. 7 (AP) -- The security police cracked down today on efforts by Stern Band sympathizers to wage a war of nerves on Britain from French soil, rounding up thirteen suspects in addition to a New York rabbi who was arrested, authorities said, as he prepared to fly to London with 10,000 leaflet "bombs."

CHICAGO, Sept. 7 -- Retail Hardware dealers are not having as easy a time selling their merchandise now as they had a month ago, William S. Ewert, executive secretary of the Illinois Retail Hardware Association, declared today. As a result of tightening consumer demands, the association has launched a series of sales clinics which, it is hoped, will reacquaint the hardware trade with competitive sales methods.

MOSCOW, Sept. 7 (Reuters) -- Vyacheslav M. Molotov, Soviet Foreign Minister, in a note to George C. Marshall, United States Secretary of State, published today, rejected United States proposals for Korea's independence put forward on Aug. 29 by Robert Lovett.

New York's four municipal colleges -- City, Hunter, Brooklyn and Queens -- will enroll a record total of 67,000 students in all sessions for the fall semester, the Board of Higher Education announced yesterday. This figure is 4,000 more than the previous high mark set last spring.

High inventories currently held by wholesalers have slowed their payments for goods and placed credit men on guard against possible default, it was learned over the week-end. Collection turnover has moved up from an average of thirty days to forty-five and in some cases sixty days, credit men said, and all indications point to an expansion of wholesale credit which closely follows the rapid rise in consumer credit recently experienced.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 7 -- President Truman tonight extended greetings on behalf of the United States to 1,000 delegates and observers representing twenty-five countries attending the opening session of the first post-war conference of the International Council of Women. The council has not met in nine years.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 7 -- Declaring that each week's delay could mean a year's extension of a war with Russia, Louis E. Starr, national Commander-in-chief of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, tonight urged President Truman to call a special session of Congress for the purpose of immediately considering and granting sufficient appropriations to rebuild our armed forces.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- A State Department spokesman tonight held it "highly unlikely" that a projected four-power conference on the political disposition of Korea would get under way here tomorrow as planned.

BATAVIA, Java, Sept. 7 (U.P) -- Australian and French representatives returned to Batavia today after a 500-mile tour of Republican territory, including the capital of Jogjakarta, and said they found everything "quiet and peaceful."

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Sept. 7 -- Juan Lame, president of the Boy Scouts Association of Mexico and of the Inter-American Scout Advisory Committee, decorated a United States and a Canadian leader tonight for distinguished service to the Boy Scout movement.

DETROIT, Sept. 7 -- The high strategy in a meticulously planned right-wing drive to capture overwhelming control of the largest union in the world will begin to evince itself tomorrow in Buffalo, when the International Executive Board of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, assembles for its last, and most important, regular meeting before the eleventh convention in Atlantic City in November.

Results on mail order promotions have shown marked improvement during the last two months compared to the lull experienced in the first six months of the year, according to Thomas McElroy, circulation promotion director of the American Home Magazine.

ON BOARD U.S.S. MISSOURI, Sept. 7 -- Amid the great pageantry of Brazil's celebration of her Independence Day. President Truman and his family sailed from Rio de Janeiro, homeward bound this afternoon on this battleship.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- The text of the draft treaty on international agreement on freedom of information follows: Individuals and peoples improve their understanding of each other through communication of facts and ideas.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 7 -- Electric tankers may help alleviate a power shortage in northern California if negotiations now under way between the Pacific Gas and Electric Company and the Maritime Commission are successful.

Inflationary price rises have virtually wiped out salary increases given to teachers early this year, Local 2 of the New York Teachers Guild declared yesterday in announcing that it would consider demands for new increases at an executive board meeting Wednesday night at 2 East Twenty-third Street.

PARIS, Sept. 7 -- The final estimate of the deficit in the sixteen western European nations participating in the conference on the Marshall Plan and western Germany, will be fixed at about $20,000,000,000, persons in a position to speak with authority predicted tonight.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 7 -- A secret broadcast by Irgun Zvai Leumi, terrorist organization, emphatically denied published reports, which it described as of British origin, that the organization had welcomed the proposal of the majority of the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine for partitions of the Holy Land.

American shipping companies are preparing to ask for further action if Colombia's discriminatory regulations are not removed. United States law provides for retaliatory penalties against any foreign merchant marine whose government countenances trade restraints or discrimination against United States vessels.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 7 -- "I'm only interested in one contract and that is the marriage contract." That was the answer that Barbara Jo Walker of Memphis, Miss America, 1947, gave today to a question as to whether she was interested in a stage, screen or radio career.

LONDON, Sept. 7 -- Grimethorpe miners turned down the Government's compromise suggestion this morning and voted to continue their unofficial coal strike. It is only too probable now that instead of being settled the Yorkshire strikes will spread, with consequences to the British economy that can be described only as disastrous.

Passage tomorrow of the Sharkey rent bills, in a form acceptable to Mayor O'Dwyer, was indicated last night by Paul L. Ross, chairman of the City Rent Commission, and Joseph T. Sharkey, vice chairman of the City Council.
More than half of the total tonnage of seagoing tankers now carries the American flag, according to a compilation released here yesterday by the American Merchant Marine Institute.
Edward O'Connor, 30 years old, a traveling salesman for the Grosset Dunlap Publishing Company, unwittingly balked a hold-up early yesterday at the cost of his life.

With. 1,100,000 public and parochial school children starting a new term this morning, Dr. William Jansen, newly appointed Superintendent of Schools, told a radio audience yesterday that going to school was one of the city's largest undertakings, exceeded only by home-making.

William Aubin, baritone, winner in last season's Talent Registry Contest of Margaret Walters Public Relations, Inc., gave his first New York recital late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. In a carefully devised and unhackneyed program, Mr. Aubin won instant favor by the intelligence of his artistry and his fully matured gifts as interpreter.

HAMBURG, Germany, Sept. 7 -- The British Military Government placed a special cordon of German police on the outskirts of the dock area today and alerted another 1,500 to deal with any action against Military Government buildings as the Ocean Vigour reached Pier 29.

ROME, Sept. 7 -- In a dramatic appeal to the Catholic world today Pope Pius XII urged all Catholics to rally with all their strength in the defence of Christian principles and to fight those forces that strike at the very foundation of Catholic life.

Though both the calendar and the thermometer testify that it is still summer, the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo opened its fall season last night at the City Center. This eagerness to get things under way resulted in a spirited performance by a young company that quite evidently gives everything it has on all occasions.

If the law of love dominated the world today, there would not be fear and frustration, the Rev. William E. Purcell, vicar of St. Peter's Church, Maidstone, Kent, England, declared yesterday in a sermon in the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity, 316 East Eighty-eighth Street.

One of the enduring idols of American tennis made his exit from, the national championship yesterday in a three-hour match that held a thrilled gallery in its seats until darkness settled on the Forest Hills Stadium.

In its inquiry to ferret out "crooked bondsmen, dishonest police and unscrupulous lawyers who have been conducting a racket in Brooklyn," the District Attorney's office there has questioned more than 2,000 persons in the last sixty days, it was announced yesterday.

BERLIN, Sept. 7 -- On the eve of the coal talks between representatives of the economically merged United States and British zones and France, there were indications today that the difficulties of meeting the French demands may be as great as, if not greater than those that were encountered in the French position on the level-of-industry plan.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Local boards in hundreds of communities are setting out to learn for themselves whether rent ceiling's affecting some 50,000,000 persons should be eliminated, raised, lowered or left alone.

ELMSFORD, N.Y., Sept. 7 -- Herman Barren, Fenway pro, an Milton Jentes and Ed Burke c Race Brook with Abe Shurr led field of ninety-nine teams compeling in the annual Elmwood Country Club pro-member tournament today.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 7 -- The United States Embassy has sent to the Colombian Foreign Office a prote by American steamship lines charging discrimination in favor of Colombian Government -owned ships in the transport of Colombian coffee.

Although it is the habit of the American mind to dismiss communism on the, ground of our "sheer and instinctive antagonism" to it, communism is a force to be dealt with on higher grounds than mere prejudice, the Rev. Dr. Albert J. McCartney, director of the Chicago Sunday Evening Club, declared yesterday in a sermon at Christ Church, Methodist, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

ATHENS, Sept. 7 -- Themistocles Sophoulis, 87-year-old Liberal party leader, was sworn into office as Premier of Greece with his coalition Liberal and Populist Cabinet this evening after Constantine Tsaldaris had returned his mandate to King Paul. The Government is composed of eleven Liberals and fourteen Populists, including one who is technically an independent.

Prices of cotton for future delivery in the domestic market failed last week to show any definite trend as the trade exhibited aution pending the Government's second forecast of the new domestic cotton crop, due today. At the close of the market on Saturday active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were mixed, 40 points lower to 58 points higher than a week before, with the distant positions showing the gains.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 7 --Efforts to raise the rate of production of steel ingots last week failed. The industry was barely able to operate at 92 1/2 per cent of capacity, or one point less than the week before. Lack of sufficient scrap and pig iron was the main factor in the production problem.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: On Aug. 28 you printed a letter from Bertram Schwartz deploring the proposed separation of command and judicial functions in the Army courtmartial system.

MADISON, Wis., Sept. 7 -- The National Student Association concluded its nine-day constitutional convention here today after approving affiliation with the International Union of Students on a provisional basis which would guarantee that American students would not be affected by any political action of that body.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 7 (AP) Owen P. Merrill of Riverton, N.J., 38-year-old boat designer, captured the tenth annual international Comet Class yacht racing association title on Cayuga Lake today when he placed second in the final race of a series of three.
Jerome Raynor has resigned his executive post with the tel St. George, Brooklyn, to take up his duties as president of Heymann Products Company of Canada, Ltd., import-export concern.

EDINBURGH, Sept. 7 -- Opera is represented at the Edinburgh Festival by Mozart's "Le Nozze de Figaro" (The Marriage of Figaro) and Verdi's "Macbeth," performed by the Glyndebourne Company which John Christie has reassembled after the break of the war years.

The responsibility for educating and training future leaders of the bar rests in the first instance with the great law schools of the country. New York has taken pride in the knowledge that one of the recognized leaders in this field of professional education is the School of Law of Columbia University.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- The general index of basic commodity prices based on the August, 1939, level, rose from 306.6 on Aug. 29 to 312.6 on Sept. 5, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. The following lists daily index numbers and actual spot market prices :

Governor Driscoll of New Jersey apparently has found in New York's methods of combating erosion some practical suggestions for beach protection in his own state. Recently the Governor spent a day in this area with Park Commissioner Robert Moses and some of his engineers.

PARIS, Sept. 7 -- France has only enough cereals for three or four months, Premier Paul Ramadier said today in an address at Condom, in the department of Gers. He added that it would be necessary to import cereals, but that these could be paid for because of the reserves of wealth in certain regions of France.

American prosperity is the result not alone of natural resources but of "the faithful, skillfull work of tens of millions of Americans in every industry, at every level from top-flight management to the least skilled worker," the Rev. Leland B. Henry, executive director of the Commission on Christian Social Relations of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, said yesterday.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 7 -- Communal murder spread today to New Delhi, the capital city of India, for the first time. [There have been many disturbances in adjacent Old Delhi, but the capital had hitherto been almost free from disturbance.]
DENVER, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Lew VVorsham, the former sailor from Washington, D.C., won the $15,000 Denver Open golf tournament today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- Following a careful reckoning by Skipper Bucky Harris, the Yankees got back on their course today and from now on, it seems reasonably certain, all should be rather smooth sailing.

Crown Prince Olaf and Crown Princess Martha of Norway arrived at La Guardia Field yesterday aboard a Scandinavian Airlines plane from Oslo on a trip undertaken so that the crown princess may undergo treatment for a spinal condition.

BALTIMORE. Sept. 7 -- Harry Buffington is 28 years old, a college graduate and a fellow who has been around football long enough to know better. But this rainy afternoon at Municipal Stadium, the 210-pound guard of the Brooklyn Dodgers went the wrong way on the very first play of the game between the Dodgers and Baltimore Colts and forthwith presented the opposition with a touchdown that led to a 16-7 victory for the Colts.

Everyday living can be made easier if we utilize "the gift of courage" given to us by God to fortify ourselves against temptations, the Rev. Charles J. McManus of the St. Patrick's Cathedral staff said there yesterday in his sermon at the 10 o'clock mass.

Some of us may remember camomile tea as grandmother's favorite nostrum for a variety of aches and pains, but others recall it as one of the pleasant herb beverages served after dinner at resort hotels along the Riviera. These herb teas are called tisanes by the French and come from the luxuriant flower gardens around Cannes.

The Right Rev. Charles K. Gilbert, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, and the Rev. Dr. Horace W. B. Donegan, suffragan-bishop-elect of the diocese, will arrive in this city today from their annual vacations.
CHICAGO, Sept. 7 -- Key union leaders in Hollywood's long jurisdictional conflict tried anew today to settle their differences but could agree only on another meeting in Los Angeles on Oct. 20.

LOS ALAMOS, N. M., Sept. 7 -- Five years ago the Atomic Energy Commission's center here reluctantly boasted of a one-room log cabin and of one-armed chairs in which the children sat to "learn the three R's." The picture has changed.

WARSAW, Sept. 7 -- The Polish Government has refused permission to Fred Lions of the United States State Department to enter Poland with the Congressional inquiry committee headed by Representative Christian Herter, Republican, of Massachusetts, it was learned today.

PARIS, Sept. 7 -- Attacking Washington's policy of raising the level of industry in the United States and British zones of Germany, former President de Gaulle, in a speech in Bayonne today, said the United States "seems to oppose the vital interest of France" and thus to run risk of "sacrificing something essential to momentary convenience."

ENDICOTT, N.Y., Sept. 7--In a close struggle among seven aspirants, George Kramer of Queens, 1945 titleholder, gained runner-up honors in the New York State Chess Association tournament today as adjourned games were played off in the eighth and final round.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 7 -- "Madams Bovary," Gustave Flaubert's first novel, published in 1857, will be filmed by MetroGoldwyn-Mayer early next year, probably with Lana Turner in the title role, the studio has announced. Pandro S. Berman will produce the picture and Robert Ardrey is writing the scenario.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- A proposed international treaty intended to "cover the earth with truth" by guaranteeing a free flow of information among nations and peoples was made public tonight by the State Department.

WINNIPEG, Sept. 7 -- (Canadian Press) -- Western Canada's 1947 wheat will be close to a new high in protein values, analysis of early samples by chemists of the Board of Grain Commissioners showed today.

LONDON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Following is the text, as broadcast by the Moscow radio, of a message from Premier Stalin to the Russian people on the 800th anniversary of the founding of Moscow: Greeting to Moscow, capital of our Motherland, on the occasion of its 800th anniversary.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature Within twelve months amount to $51,396,606,220. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

Formation of a state-wide Citizens Committee of One Thousand to advocate approval of three housing propositions to be voted on at the election on Nov. 4 was announced yesterday by State Housing Commissioner Herman T. Stichman.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Senator Milton R. Young, Republican, of North Dakota, declared today that he believed that Congress "after a battle" would approve some version of the Marshall plan to help put Europe back on its feet.

"Theory," said Karl Marx, becomes a physical force once it takes possession of the masses." Marx was referring, of course, to political theory, but he mignt well have been referring to stock market theory. And the Dow theory in particular.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: What, in my opinion, was a spectacular, impressive demonstration of democracy in action was enacted on Soldier Field, Chicago, when the AllStars defeated the Chicago Bears in a thrilling football contest by the score of 16 to 0.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Hank Edwards' twelfth home run of the season gave the Indians a 3-2 victory over the White Sox and Pitcher Red Ruffing before 9,751 fans today. Edwards broke a 2-2 deadlock with his drive into the right-field stands in the eighth inning to hand the 42-year-old Ruffing his fourth loss against three triumphs.

PITTSBURGH, Sept 7 (AP) -- Johnny Miller, making his second picthing start for Chicago, hit a home run with the bases filled on his initial time at bat today to account for all of the Cubs' runs as they edged the Pirates, 4 to 3. Miller's long wallop in the second inning was hit into "Greenberg Gardens" in left field.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, will be the keynote speaker tomorrow at the formal opening of the International Statistical Conference, whose 600 delegates include 325 from fiftyfive foreign countries.

New Yorkers who have been complaining bitterly about the humidity this summer were assured yesterday by Benjamin Parry, chief meteorologist of the city's weather bureau, that they have reason to be upset. He said that records compiled by the bureau over a seventy-two-year period showed that the humidity during the last three months had been above normal.

After a burst of overoptimism, the personal aircraft industry dropped into a good deal of a tail spin. Encouragement for it is to be found, however, in studies of airport use which have now been made public by the Air Transport Association. These show that for the first half of this year civilian private aircraft have an overwhelming majority over both airline transports and military aircraft in airport utilization.
TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Premier Ahmed Ghavam was charged in Parliament today with violating the 1944 oil law, which prohibits the discussion of oil concessions with foreigners.

W.E. Woodward, historian and biographer, author of "Tom Paine," "A New American History," and "The Way Our People Lived," has finished his autobiography and E.P. Dutton will publish, it on Oct, 20. "The Gift of Life" tells of his youth as the son of a South Carolina sharecropper and his rise to his present position in American letters.

LONDON, Sept. 7 -- Despite a touch of fantasy in the reported threat by sympathizers of the Stern Band, Palestine terrorist group, to bomb London, there is no tendency here to dismiss it lightly. London's air defenses have been at the ready since the threat was discovered in Paris.

George Bernard Shaw's traditional disdain for assuming extra chores in behalf of the theatre apparently also extends to radio. Miss Lilian Supove, director of special events for WNYC, returning by air from London yesterday, reported that she had asked Mr. Shaw to make a special recording by way of introducing the BBC's production of his play, "The Man of Destiny" to American audiences some weeks hence.
United States Senator Robert F. Wagner declared yesterday that, contrary to published reports, he had no intention of resigning the office that he has held since 1927.
AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Scoring in every period, the Chicago Bears gained a 37 to 20 victory over the Boston Yanks today in a National Football League exhibition game before 12,000 fans.

The board of directors of the National Association of Barbed Wire Clubs, composed of former prisoners of war, adopted a resolution yesterday appealing to the United Nations to call for the release of all former enemy prisoners of war being held in Great Britain, France and the Soviet Union.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 7 (AP) -- The Athletics swept a doubleheader from the Red Sox today, 7 -- 4 and 4 -- 3, with Eddie Joost's twelfth home run reciding the curfew game.

Activity in the wholesale markets, in so far as it concerned new purchases, was at a minimum last week, owing to the fact that early fall needs had been amply provided for and commitments had been placed well ahead, according to the weekly market reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 7 -- Mexico's poloists gave notice today that they will make a strong bid to retain the national open championship by halting Laddie Sanford's Hurricanes, 9 to 5, on International Field of the Meadow Brook Club.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 7 -- The momentum of inflation, which has been gathering speed here for two years, depends on how quickly imports can be resumed.

In an orgy of home-run hitting that thrilled an overflow crowd of 51,187 yesterday at the Polo Grounds, one majestic drive by Big Jawn Mize carried the authority and, as a consequence, the National League lead of the Dodgers took a clipping.
LONDON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Cries of "Heil Hitler" sounded in the streets of London's slum districts today while the British press swung into a campaign against the Fascist movement here.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Joe Vetrano's 12-yard field goal midway in the final quarter canceled the Los Angeles Dons' strong second-half comeback and gave the San Francisco 49ers a 17 to 14 victory in an All-America Football Conference game today before 31.298.

Metal-working plants are in the vanguard of industrial groups now weighing a broad variety of proposals for increasing sales of American equipment to foreign buyers, whose offers of orders now reach enormous proportions, spokesmen revealed here last week.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7 -- A broader demand for cash lard has developed recently and packers report they are now selling more than the current output. This is reflected in a reduction of 1,567,000 pounds in cold storage stocks during August, aggregate holdings at the close of business on Aug. 31 being 90,131,000 pounds.

BIG Jawn Mize lunged at a pitch, missed and practically fell flat on his face. Master Melvin Ott laughed heartily. Ordinarily Mel doesn't find humor in a Mize failure. But this was during batting practice before yesterday's game, when failure was unimportant since it didn't show in the averages.

The campaign for repeal of the proportional representation method of electing members of the City Council seems to be off to a poor start. The proponents of the repeal proposition, which is to be voted on at the Nov. 4 election have failed to get Mayor O'Dwyer to come out for it.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 7 -- Fires of the open hearth and blast furnaces of "Big Steel" in this area continued banked today as two conferences sought to settle the wildcat strike on the company's interplant railroad. The strike was in its third day.

CAUX, Switzerland, Sept. 7 -- New hope for the moral and spiritlal regeneration of the German people is held out to the world and to the Germans themselves by the Moral Rearmament Movement as result of its experience during its summer-long conference here at Caux.

Trucks, trailers and bodies, pumps, diesel, gasoline and electric generators, marine engines, tire casings and men's and women's apparel are among major lines of Government surplus offered in new September sales, Carl P. Malmstrom, War Assets Administration regional director, announced over the week-end.
TORONTO, Sept 7 (Canadia Press) -- A team of United State table tennis stars walked off with most of the open Canadian title at the Canadian national exhibition tournament which concluded last night.
DETROIT, Sept. 7 (AP) -- The Browns collected their hits in clusters to down an old nemesis, Hal Newhouser, and the Tigers, 3 to 0, today behind the four-hit hurling of big Jack Kramer.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Mr. Soekarno, the Indonesian President, must have been greatly dismayed to read in John R. Andu's letter concerning Indonesia that "such practical subjects as economics, technology and political science were conveniently left out of the curriculum" (of Dutch universities in the Indies).

NANKING, Sept. 7 -- The "Political Science Clique" representing more liberal elements in the Kuomintang - dominated Government have been embarrassed by the Wedemeyer mission to China. The rightist "C.C. Clique" appears to be maneuvering for an attack on Foreign Minister Wang Shihchieh's "subservient" foreign policy at the forthcoming Kuomintang congress.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- President Truman will make a nationwide radio address as part of a Democratic women's rally Oct. 8, the Democratic National Committee announced today.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Sept. 7 -- Although the Socialist party congress tomorrow could still balk Communist plans, prospects this week-end were said to be for a continuance of the coalition of the Communists, Socialists, Small Landholders and National Peasants and for a possible Opposition coalition of the Democratic People's and Independence parties.
DANVILLE, a., Sept. 7 (AP) -- The leisurely pace of recorded history finally has overtaken "The Wreck of the Old 97."

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 7 -- Those mathematical sailors. Arthur Knapp and Bill Cox; so-called because they have see-sawed in thousandths of percentage points for the summer championship in the International Class, went at it again today.

Machine tool builders expect that new orders will soon overtake and pass the volume of shipments, thereby again increasing the backlog of the industry, Tell Berna, general manager of the National Machine Tool Builders' Association disclosed in a statement over the week-end to THE NEW YORK TIMES.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7 -- Rain and lower temperatures prevailed last week in the Corn Belt. The change helped to check deterioration in the crop but experts agree that the principal effect will be to plump out the ears and that not many bushels will be added to the yield, as the rain came too late.

Herbert H. Lehman declared yesterday that the situation for Jews in southern and eastern Europe had deteriorated so much that in all Jewish communities there the people "are suffering the pangs of hopelessness and helplessness that defy description."

BOSTON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- With Blix Donnelly hurling a three-hitter, the Phils blanked the Braves, 2 -- 0, today as Howie (Stretch) Schultz provided the margin of victory with a two-run homer in the fourth frame. A crowd of 13,223 saw the Phils salvage the final game of the series in the fast time of one hour, twenty minutes -- speediest contest of the season in Boston.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Sept. 7 (Canadian Press) -- Canada apparently bowed out of the 1948 Olympic hockey picture tonight after refusing point-blank to accept amateur rules as laid down by the International Olympic Committee.

Some skepticism was expressed during the war as to whether the American soldier was fully aware of what was fundamentally at stake in the war he was helping win. The military services made a determined effort to tell him through service newspapers, radio networks in war theatres, some excellent documentary films, indoctrination classes and pamphlets.

While we strongly favor the calling of a special session of Congress to deal with the European situation, we agree with Senator Vandenberg that the initiative in this matter must come from the President rather than from the majority leaders of the Senate and the House, even though these leaders are empowered, under the new rules of Congress, to take such action if they choose to do so.

LONDON, Sept. 7 -- The stocK markets here continue to flounder in a sea of uncertainty and apprehension created by the Government's handling of the economic crisis. Fears are widespread that the present piecemeal policy of handling the situation will continue and will fail to match the seriousness of the situation.

Although no preventive or cure has yet been discovered for infantile paralysis there never has been such optimism in the research field as there is now, according to the annual report of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, made public yesterday.
BATAVIA, Sept. 7 (AP) -- The United Nations consular mission tonight received a written report of conditions inside the Indonesian Republic from the Australian and French consuls.

The establishment of a permanent planning board of engineers and other expert technicians within the Board of Transportation to modernize the municipal bus lines and make possible their efficient operation at the present nickel fare was recommended yesterday by Commissioner Sidney H. Bingham.

ZURICH, Sept. 7 -- Financial transfers between Argentina and Switzerland, suspended many months ago, were resumed on last Friday as a result of direct negotiations of prolonged duration between the Central Bank of the Argentine Republic and the National Bank of Switzerland.

GARY, Ind., Sept. 7 (U.P.) -- Catholic and Protestant clergymen appealed today to parents of striking students of Emerson School to send their children back to the classes they left because they did not want Negroes for classmates.

The two 23-knot passenger vessels being built in Scotland for the Victoria-Vancouver-Seattle "Triangle Run" are expected to be launched early next spring, according to George H. Baillie, vice president of the newly created Pacific region of the Canadian Pacific Railway.

The four International League participants in the play-offs for the Governor's Cup which get under way tonight will lead with their aces in an attempt to get that important opener on the right side of the ledger.

Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora, after conferring late yesterday with counsel for the Transport Workers Union and the New York City Omnibus Corporation, expressed his "hope and belief" that there would be no interruption of bus service by either side until "ultimate decision" had been made in the disputed arbitration pension award pending before him.

The Government's cotton crop estimate failed to stimulate sufficient buying in the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday and final prices were 5 to 39 points net lower than at the close on Saturday.
HAMBURG, Germany, Sept. 8 -- After a two-hour token struggle against British military police, 1,406 Jews turned back from Palestine debarked this morning on German soil.

Deputy Chief Inspector William T. Whalen, in charge of Brooklyn detectives, announced early this morning that an 18-year-old youth had confessed to the slaying on April 21 of Selma Graff, 15, in her home at 143 East Ninety-sixth Street, in the East Flatbush section of Brooklyn.

Louis V. Place Jr. of 2 East Sixty-seventh Street, executive vice president of the Manati Sugar Company at 106 Wall Street and for many years a prominent figure in the sugar industry, died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital after a brief illness. His age was 51.

ENDICOTT, N.Y., Sept. 8 -- Competition among eleven club teams, five on a side, for possession of the new Susquehanna Trophy, completed the annual meeting of the New York State Chess Association today. The Queens Chess Club of Woodside emerged victorious with a point score of 16 -- 4.

The Government made evident yesterday its determination to rid the United States labor movement of suspected alien Communist leadership when Department of Justice agents here arrested a second labor leader on a deportation warrant.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- A statement that more than 90 per cent of all accounts in corn futures on the Chicago Board of Trade as of June 30, 1947, were held by speculators was issued today by the Department of Agriculture.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 --The gigantic aircraft carrier Midway successfully fired a German V-2 rocket and then launched its planes in fighting array in a historic test in the Atlantic last Saturday, the Navy Department announced today.

The crowning touch to all the custom-made showings seen so far was Hattie Carnegie's collection shown yesterday at her salon at 42 East Forty-ninth Street, a collection so flawless it merited that seldom used word "perfect."

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Sept. 8 -- Goose, the old American six-meter yacht owned by George Niehols, showed her feathers today by winning the first race for the Scandinavian Gold Cup, leading her closest rival one second.

MONTREAL, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The National Boxing Association, opening its annual convention today, requested Governor Dewey to remove any statutory regulations that prevent New York State from affiliating with the NBA.

BATAVIA, Java, Sept. 8 (AP) -- United States Consul General Walter A. Foote, chairman of the United Nations Consular Mission, said today that the mission's military staff would begin arriving this week-end to supervise and report on enforcement of the United Nations cease-fire order in the Dutch-Indonesian conflict.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 8 -- While Jewish refugees from the illegal immigrant ship Exodus 1947 were being debarked today in Hamburg, the United States Consulate General confirmed that criminal charges against three United States members of the Exodus crew were being dropped by the Palestine Government.

BUFFALO, Sept. 8 -- The International Executive Board of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, decided today to reconsider its policy of by-passing the National Labor Relations Board under the Taft-Hartley labor law.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Free world interchange of economic statistical information was urged as necessary to future peace and progress at today's opening session of the International Statistical Conference by Secretary General Trygve Lie, for the United Nations, and by Secretary of Commerce Averell Harriman, for the United States.

PARIS, Sept. 8 (AP) -- A French court today issued holding orders for nine persons, including a United States rabbi, for further questioning in a security police investigation of an alleged plot to "bomb" London with 10,000 leaflets of the Stern Band, Palestine underground group.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As an American engineer whose main problem for twenty-seven years was that of helping to mechanize British coal mines, and as one who also supervised considerable prospect drilling of British coal fields, I am afraid James Reston's interesting article in the Sept. 4 TIMES may give some of your readers a few erroneous impressions.

Another chapter has been added to the bizarre career of "The Magic Touch." Although performances for last Sunday afternoon and evening and last Saturday's matinee were canceled because of a paucity of patrons, spokesmen for the producer, John Morris Chanin, said yesterday the engagement would be resumed this evening at the International Theatre.

Erdal Inonu, 21-year-old son of President Ismet Inonu of Turkey, was among the 1,160 passengers arriving here yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Mauretania. The ship docked at Pier 90, North River, at 1:45 P.M.

LONDON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Freddie Mills of Great Britain won the European light-heavyweight boxing title tonight by scoring a technical knockout over Pol Goffaux of Belgium in the fourth round of a scheduled fifteen-round title bout. Both fighters Weighed 172 1/4.

An 11-month-old girl, who insisted on crying despite the demand of two armed hold-up men for silence, succeeded yesterday in delaying a robbery in a fourteenth-floor apartment at 360 Central Park West, but failed to save money and jewelry belonging to her parents and her grandmother.

Fourteen Irish football players of the County Kerry and Cavan teams that will play in the All Ireland Gaelic football finals at the Polo Grounds on Sunday, arrived here yesterday from Cobh on the liner Mauretania.
Thirty dromedaries and twentyone antelope from Northeast Africa, destined for zoos throughout the country, arrived at Pier 1, Bush Terminal, Brooklyn, yesterday aboard the British freighter Trevider.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In spite of the excellent coverage THE TIMES is giving Germany, an important step toward the economic rehabilitation of that country has not been mentioned in your columns. I am referring to the commercial agreement recently concluded between Czechoslovakia and the American-British zones of occupation.

ROME, Sept. 8 -- Italy has pledged herself to restore her economy and to be fully self-supporting by 1952 if $2,500.000,000 is granted to her under the Marshall plan, circles close to the Government disclosed today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 6,500 head; total 8,500; market moderately active; 25 to mostly 50 cents higher compared with Friday's average; spots 75 cents higher on heavy butchers and sows;

PARIS, Sept. 8 -- The executive committee of the French Socialist party, which is the party of Premier Paul Ramadier and has the major responsibility for governing the country, made a strong attack on economic liberty tonight. The committee asserted that such liberty had caused "disorder and speculation, excessive sacrifices for the working classes and extravagance and waste by the wealthy.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 8 -- Almost $100 has been sent to the United Nations by well-wishers who want to help raise the $65,000,000 that will be required to build the future world capital in midtown Manhattan.

Charles P. Gross, chairman of the Board of Transportation, made public yesterday a detailed criticism of the plan of his subordinate, Transportation Commissioner S.H. Bingham, for city-wide bus service at a 5-cent fare and said Mr. Bingham's comments were "wholly political."
MONTE CARLO, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Russia has made a belated application to join the International Amateur Swimming Federation, it was learned tonight as the Federation Bureau met here.

Steel warehousemen here are expecting a cut of about 20 percent in their quotas of steel to be delivered from mills in the fourth quarter, spokesmen revealed yesterday. This expectation appears to be widespread among distributors, spokesmen disclosed, and with cut-backs in mill production ahead, due to relining furnaces, little prospect is held out for improved supply.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 8 -- With only one dissenting vote, the State Constitutional Convention adopted today the new basic charter it had been drafting since June 12. The final vote was 77 to 1, with two delegates absent.
Detective commanders left Police Headquarters yesterday after a conference with Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander with orders to bear down heavily on hoodlums.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 8 -- The Most Rev. Knut Ansgar Nelson, a Danish-born convert Benedictine monk from the Portsmouth, R.I., priory was consecrated as Titular Bishop of Birta and Coadjutor to the Vicar Apostolic of Sweden at solemn but rich and colorful ceremonies here this morning in the Cathedral of SS. Peter and Paul.

BERLIN, Sept. 8 -- Kurt Schumacher, chairman of the Social Democratic party, denied to the new york times today that he had reached a "working alliance" with the Niemoller faction of German Protestants, as stated in a dispatch from this bureau published on Aug. 19.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 8 -- The possibility of a third World War was raised today by the Palestine Arab Higher Committee in a bitter attack on both the majority and the minority reports of the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 8 -- Agreement on the international control of atomic energy might be "just the step required" to convert an "armed truce" into peace, President James B. Conant of Harvard University told members of the Commonwealth Club today.

Letters With Enclosures We have been receiving letters lately from presidents of big corporations and allied co-ordinating agencies. It is not an attention to which this modest corner is accustomed, and we are the more interested.

A drive to expose racketeers in materials and conspirators in pricefixing was urged by city officials of New York and Milwaukee during opening sessions of the National Institute of Governmental Purchasing at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 8 -- An appeal to the women of the world to come to the aid of Greece, "fighting against forces perhaps thirty times as strong as hers," was made today by Mrs. Sofia Anatoniades, president of the Greek National Council of Women.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 8 -- Delegates to the Veterans of Foreign Wars annual national encampment voted tonight to strengthen the Air Force, mobilize industry, set up a national science foundation and support a powerful National Guard and organized Reserve.

LONDON, Sept. 8 -- The importance Britain attaches to the visit here of John W. Snyder, United States Secretary of the Treasury, was indicated today when Hugh Dalton, Chancellor of the Exchequer, journeyed eighty miles by car to welcome Mr. and Mrs. Snyder at Southampton.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 8 (AP) -- The State Supreme Court in a 4-to-3 decision, held today that legislation to legalize betting on horse and dog racing in Alabama is unconstitutional.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture today estimated that this year's cotton crop, on the basis of Sept. 1 conditions, would be 11,849,000 bales, up 3,200,000 from last year's small yield.

The downward spiral in the stock market continued yesterday as increased liquidation depressed prices 1 to 2 points. The widest losses were sustained by several key industrial issues, with the composite rate dropping 1.43 points on the day.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 8 -- Registration statements converting 212,779 shares of cumulative preferred stock were filed with, the Securities and Exchange Commission today by two companies.

Incoming buyers of women's apparel are scouring the market for low-end and budget department dresses to offset consumer resistance to inflated prices that dominate a high percentage of fall lines, it was learned yesterday in a survey of the New York garment markets.

Until Mr. Gromyko made his written reply to the questions put to him by Sir Alexander Cadogan, it was possible to hope that on the great issue of control of atomic energy Russia might be moving gradually, if almost imperceptibly, in the direction of the position taken by the other major Powers.
Rippey ran according to expectations in the Bay Shore Handicap at the Aqueduct race track yesterday for a decisive victory in the $15,000 added seven-furlong test.

Two previously unpublished plays by Bernard Shaw and a new Shavian ending for Shakespeare's "Cymbeline" will be brought out in one volume by Dodd, Mead on Sept. 22. The first of the new plays is "Geneva," in which Mr. Shaw offers his version of the trial of the world's dictators.

Restoration of "absolute" free enterprise and the capitalistic system in Europe as it existed in the nineteenth century is no longer possible, Thomas Mann, 72-year-old author and Nobel Prize winner, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The case of the Netherlands Government in its dispute with the Indonesian Republic was presented for an hour and forty minutes today to Secretary of State Marshall and Under-Secretary of State Robert Lovett.

Eight persons were injured, three seriously, at 6:45 P.M. yesterday when an automobile, out of control plowed into four benches on which they were sitting in a twenty-foot-wide mall in the center of Broadway at Ninety-first Street.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 8 -- Moving on two fronts today to increase Westchester revenues, the county Board of Supervisors expanded a campaign for larger state aid for education and authorized retention of additional counsel in the parkway toll fight.

After putting his charges through their first contact drill of the season yesterday, Coach Ed Danowski declared that Fordham's football squad had progressed further than last year's group at a comparative stage of training.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Herbert Bayard Swope of New York, journalist and policy consultant, was rewarded with the Medal for Merit today for his wartime services to the nation.

ROME, Sept. 8 -- Approximately 1,000,000 agricultural workers in the Po Valley region went on strike this morning, endangering Italy's rice crop, which will be totally lost unless it is cut within the next few days. The strike will be extended to the Venetian provinces tomorrow.

Considerable resistance to advanced wholesale prices on beer took shape yesterday as tavern owners weighed the question of canceling their arrangements with local brewers who have announced increases.

BERLIN, Sept. 8 (AP) -- A German mine manager said today that small amounts of uranium were being produced in Soviet-controlled mines in the region of Marienberg, but that the veins were slight and that skilled engineers were lacking.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 8 -- Sharp differences over religious and educational contributions toward the relief of international tensions marked opening sessions here today of the eighth annual Conference on Science, Philosophy and Religion.

Glenn Dobbs, the Brooklyn Dodgers' outstanding halfback, was traded to the Los Angeles Dons of the All-America Conference in a surprise deal yesterday. Brooklyn received Angelo Bertelli, former Notre Dame ace, in return, and immediately passed him on to the Chicago Rockets for Robert (Hunchy) Hoernschemeyer.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Sept. 8 -- The Palestine Arab Higher Committee today directed its criticism mainly on two recommendations of the majority of the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine: Establishment of a Jewish state in the Holy Land and admission of 150,000 Jewish refugees in the next two years.

MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 8 (AP) -- A minor tropical storm which made an unexpected appearance in the Gulf of Mexico today became a meteorological "guinea pig" for history's first hurricane-busting experiment. But today's storm developed too close to the Florida west coast to be "seeded" with dry ice or other crystals by Army and Navy planes.

It is an exciting thing to get an education. When more than a million children and tens of thousands of teachers started the new school year in New York City yesterday we suppose a few of them at least looked at it otherwise. If these were some for whom it was merely a return to monotonous and trying routine, they have our deep sympathy.

Improvement in consumer demand for high grade shoes so far this month, coupled with low retail inventories, resulted in good buyer attendance and substantial orders yesterday at the advance spring showings of The Guild of Better Shoe Manufacturers at member companies' showrooms here.

GENEVA, Sept. 8 -- Suppression of the International Emergency Food Council and the transfer of its functions to the Food and Agriculture Organization not later than Dec. 31, were recommended today by the FAO committee in session here.

LONDON, Sept. 8 -- The Yorkshire unofficial coal strike entered its fifth week today with twentysix pits entirely idle, eighteen partly affected, 43,000 men out and more than 400,000 tons of coal lost.
CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 8 (AP) -- Danada Capt., a Chicago invader, won the Hop Creek Purse feature today by a nose to give Mrs. Ada L. Rice her first victory of the Garden State track meeting.

An additional five acres of parking space is to be opened soon at Jones Beach and another five-acre addition is being planned to make up for the loss of parking capacity resulting from the increased lengths of new cars, the Long Island State Park Commission announced yesterday.
John Dwight Sullivan, World War I pilot and New York attorney, was elected executive vice president of the National Air Council yesterday.

The fever of excitement that was stirred up at Sheepshead Bay by the 647-pound tuna brought in to the dock was mild in comparison to the pitch that was attained by the three anglers who alternated in fighting the fish. A blow-by-blow description of the battle reads somehing like the late Alexander Woollcott would have written in describing the second battle of the Marne.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Sept. 8 -- The majority report of the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine gave the following explanation today of the reasons why the port of Jaffa, with a population of 70,000, almost entirely Arab, had been included in the proposed Jewish state:

Favorable action was forecast at City Hall last night on clarifying amendments to the three Sharkey rent control bills, with the City Council scheduled to meet at 1:30 this afternoon and the Board of Estimate scheduled to act on the legislation at 3 o'clock.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The propriety of radio stations adopting an editorial policy and broadcasting editorial opinions will be considered at a hearing beginning Jan. 12, the Federal Communications Commission stated today.

SARANAC INN, N.Y., Sept. 8 (AP) -- Admiral Thomas C. Kincaid declared tonight that the United States, by insisting "upon stopping aggression," could "assure world peace and our own security for some time to come."

Immigrants and visitors from Greece and Italy are continuing to bring quantities of meat to this country from their hungry homelands. Government officials said yesterday. Under existing regulations the meat is seized and destroyed by Government agents, to prevent the introduction of rinderpest and foot and mouth disease into this country.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board today authorized helicopter passenger service for the first time. It approved experimental operation by the Yellow Cab Company of Cleveland, Inc., between the, city's municipal airport and downtown Cleveland and two suburbs, Shaker Heights and Euclid.
MUNICH, Sept. 8 -- A United States war-crimes tribunal at Dachau completed today the hearing of the case against Otto Skorzeny, former lieutenant colonel in the SS, and seven co-defendants.

Premier Stalin is not known to the Russian people primarily as a humorist, but his assertion that Moscow has "entirely eliminated" slums must have produced bitter smiles among the braver of the city's inhabitants. Millions of Muscovites live and will die in exactly the sort of slums that Mr. Stalin attributes to the rest of the world.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8 -- Grain markets were unsettled on the Board of Trade today, July being the only wheat delivery to work into new seasonal high ground. However, soy beans rose the 8-cent limit for the third straight day and went to a new high, as did yellow corn, the latter selling at a record peak of $2.57 3/4 a bushel.

For the first time in five years the New York State Employment Service will supply such specialized "luxury" household help as butlers, personal maids, companions, valets and housemen, it was announced yesterday. The new listings do not necessarily indicate any great increase in the supply of help, a spokesman said. It is a return to pre-war standards of serving- all employers and workers.

ON BOARD U.S.S. MISSOURI, Sept. 8 -- This 55,000-ton battleship, serving as the temporary White House as President Truman makes a leisurely trip home from Rio de Janeiro, rolled northward tonight some 520 miles out of the Brazilian capital and somewhere off Bahia, Brazil.

On the grandstand enclosure where Frank Shields furnished so many thrills on Sunday, Gardnar Mulloy of Coral Gables, Fla. and Robert Falkenburg of Hollywood, Calif., narrowly escaped disaster yesterday in the National Tennis Championships at Forest Hills.

A large group exhibition, sponsored by the Federation of Modern Painters and Sculptors, will open with a private view from 3 to 6 o'clock this afternoon at Wilden this afternoon at Wildenstein's, 19 East Sixty-fourth Street. The show will continue through Sept. 27.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Henry J. Kaiser, who was refused last month a request to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for an $85,000,000 cut in the debt on his Fontana, Calif., steel plant, submitted today a new proposal for a reduction in debt of $34,510,000.

Underwriting syndicates here will place on the market today new issues of public utility company preferred stock aggregating $20,000,000 in behalf of General Telephone Corporation, a New York holding company, and Florida Power Light Company.

TOKYO, Sept. 8 -- Japanese labor is being advised by allied authorities to revamp its trade union setup, placing greater emphasis on "democratic" locals and stripping power from the central organizations that are frequently used for political purposes opposing the occupation aims.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Philip B. Fleming, Federal Works Administrator, said today it was essential to safeguard ammonium nitrate cargoes but that controls must not hamper shipment of this fertilizer to needy countries.

GARY, Ind., Sept. 8 -- The United Steel Workers, Congress of Industrial Organizations, entered the student "holiday" dispute at Emerson School here today by threatening to suspend from the union any members whose children continued to stay away from classes.

Despite continuing critical shortages of steel and other materials, the average monthly production rate of electric ranges for the first six months of the year increased 70.18 per cent compared with the July 1, 1940-June 30, 1941, base period, according to statistics released yesterday by Carl M. Schaffer, assistant to the managing director, Institute of Cooking and Heating Appliances.

A marked rise in employment in the construction industry was reported yesterday by John J. Brennan, secretary of the Building and Construction Trades Council of New York. He attributed it directly uo the recent decision of Cardinal Spellman to proceed at once with the Roman Catholic Archdiocese's $25,000,000 building program.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Sept. 8 (UP) -- Participation by the United States and Canada in ice hockey in the 1948 Olympic games was a matter of conjecture today as a result of rulings at a two-day meeting of the International Ice Hockey Association.

IT'S odd how you react to those things. When the other fellow has a five-and-a-half-game lead, the margin seems insurmountable. When you have it, the doggone thing seems totally insecure. That's why the Flatbush Faithful are dazedly wandering around these days with their fingers crossed, hoping for the best. In fact the pennant race could very well be settled before this week is over.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Sept. 8 (AP) -- Following is the text of the official summary of the proposed new constitution adopted today by the New Jersey Constitutional Convention: OBJECTIVES OF THE PROPOSED NEW CONSTITUTION
Accounts J.M. Huber Corporation, to Fred Wittner Advertising, for advertising and public relations in its ink, carbon black, industrial products, clay, oil and gas divisions.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Sept. 8 -- The Hungarian Socialist party congress met today to decide whether to stay with the Communists in the four-party coalition or to break away, but at a late hour tonight had been unable to make up its mind.

A dispute within the National Maritime Union, CIO, over charges of discrimination against two of its New Orleans officials probably will be brought before the union's convention beginning here Sept. 22, it was reporoted yesterday.
SAVANNAH, Ga., Sept. 8 (AP) -- Turpentine, 61c; offerings and sales, 3 barrels: receipts 121 barrels; shipments 4 barrels; stocks 9,986 barrels.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 8 -- Held spellbound by the aging Frits Ostermueller through seven score less innings today, Giant bats surdenly came alive with a roar that echoed over Forbes Field, swept aside an eight-run deficit, hammered the Pirates into defeat, 10 to 8, and dropped Billy Herman's club into the National League cellar.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Robert N. Denham, general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board, and Lewis B. Sehwellenbach, Secretary of Labor, disagree on the former's ruling that top officers of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations must file with the Secretary of Labor financial data required under the TaftHartley Act.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Sept. 8 (AP) -- Top favorites for the most part breezed through first-round matches today of the 1947 United States amateur golf championship but rugged Pebble Beach nevertheless claimed some of the stars and big name players as its victims.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 8 (U.P.) -- Extremists ambushed and killed Yohanan Schwartzman, a member of the moderate Jewish underground organization Haganah, today as he stood guard near the British Army camp at Tel Litvinsky, southeast of Tel Aviv.

PARIS, Sept. 8 -- The sixteen nations in the European conference on the Marshall Plan were urged today to assume collective responsibility for increased production in Europe rather than wait for this responsibility to be "dictated" to them by the United States.
MOBILE, Ala., Sept. 8 (AP) -- Two freighters ran aground in Mobile Bay and a 43-foot cruiser with nine persons aboard was lost more than ten hours today as a tropical storm lashed at the Gulf Coast.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 8 -- Dennis O'Keefe has been engaged by Eagle-Lion to play the leading role in "Corkscrew Alley," the studio's melodrama, about a fugitive from a Southern chain gang, which Anthony Mann will direct starting early in October.

Gross revenues of the nation's electric light and power companies for the first half of 1947 rose $168,300,000, or 11 per cent, to $1,702,000,000, but sharp increases in fuel, wages and other charges, in the combined amount of $170,000,000, offset the gain, according to a report released by the Edison Electric Institute yesterday.

Ms early thirties, Jesse Goodwin, whose family has been in the wholesale fresh-water fish business for" three generations, that New York and its environs, with its large Jewish population, might be a likely market for ready-toserve gefullte fish, a favorite dish of Jews of many nationalities.

Great is a word that is kicked around haphazardly in sports. It is an adjective that often is without significance because of frequent usage. Yet it is the one word that best describes nearly everything that happened last night at the Stadium, where the Indians rallied to beat the Yankees, 4 -- 3.

LONDON, Sept. 8 -- The stock markets advanced appreciably today, continuing Friday's recovery. Disappointment over the week-end coal news caused a sluggish opening this morning, but industrial shares picked up rapidly and, while actual buying remained small, they finished with numerous net rises.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 8 (U.P.) -- With persons high in Methodism present, a funeral service for Bishop Ernest G. Richardson was held today at the Arch Street Methodist Church. Bishop Fred P. Corson of the Philadelphia area officiated. The Methodist bishop for Wisconsin died here Friday.

Money Market Money market conditions were somewhat easier yesterday with Federal funds quoted at 5/8 of 1 percent, compared with 7/8 on Friday. The thirty-seven New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System, which had excess reserves of $115,000,000 on Wednesday night, it was noted, had a deficiency of $84,000,000 on Thursday.

Reports on the efficiency of a high protein content in the body in improving the welfare of a paitient during and after a major surgical operation were given at the opening session of the twentysecond annual Congress of Anesthetists at the Hotel MCAlpin yesterday.

NANKING, Sept. 8 -- The Government announced today the organization of the Cabinet's Rehabilitation Affairs Commission to develop long-range projects that will be unfinished when the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration liquidates its affairs here by the end of this year.

Heavy increases in New York's public elementary and junior high school enrollments this fall win be offset somewhat by a decline in high school attendance, it was predicted yesterday at the Board of Education. An estimated 838,300 children reported to public school classes for the opening of the 194748 academic year yesterday morning.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Sept. 8 -- The pioneering work of the Boy Scouts of America in building an effective volunteer organization was hailed tonight by Dr. James E. West, the organization's first chief scout executive and now Chief Scout.

The work of many of the topflight designers of the country was assembled yesterday in a collection presented at the St. Regis Roof by Martha, Inc., of 501 Madison Avenue.
