Endorsing the new fashion notes of the season, important coats, suits and dresses illustrated how, in the wide variety of new styles, every woman will find a silhouette suited to both her taste and figure.

Six million pounds of food and clothing must be raised by the Supplies for Overseas Survivors (SOS) Collection of the Joint Distribution Committee from Sept. 25 to the end of the year, Edward M.M. Warburg, committee chairman, declared yesterday.

READING, Pa., Sept. 8 (AP) -- Jenko Hanover, bay son of Dean Hanover, flashed to a straight heat triumph in the Reading Fair Futurity for 2-year-olds, openingday feature of the Grand Circuit meeting here.

The Thirty-third Annual Clinical Congress of the American College of Surgeons, which opened yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria, was warned that much of the surgery in this country in the near future would be performed by inadequately trained practitioners who had been unable to obtain resident training in hospitals after their return from war service.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept 8 -- Two committees of the Atomic Energy Commission today adopted an amended draft of the commission's second report, which defines the functions of whatever atomic control agency the United Nations may set up.

Food prices went up again yesterday at both ends of the dinner menu. Soup meat, along with other parts of beef, hit new highs in New York's wholesale market, while two major grocery chains announced a two-cent hike in coffee prices.

SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 8 -- The United States-Soviet Joint Commission for the establishment of a Korean interim government has failed to agree to a joint report of its failure. The announcement was made today by Maj. Gen. Albert E. Brown, chief of the United States delegation.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8 -- Discrimination in favor of the Congress of Industrial Organizations in the matter of filing non-Communist affidavits with the National Labor Relations Board was charged by some officers of the American Federation of Labor today.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 8 (AP) -- A red-haired rookie and three southpaw aces were nominated today for starting mound chores as the American Association launches its twelfth annual play-offs tomorrow night at Kansas City and Louisville.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 8 -- Nineteen British women and six children were camping out tonight in no-man's land between Palestinian and Lebanese frontier posts north of Haifa waiting for reply to their appeal to British authorities of Palestine for permission to return to their homes.
FORT WORTH, Tex., Sept. 8 -- Federal Judge T. Whitfield Davidson today held the anti-Communist provisions of the Taft-Hartley Law legal, consistent and proper.

ATHENS, Sept. 8 -- Premier Themistocles Sophoulis, in a statement of policy before Parliament, announced today that the new coalition Government would invite "an international committee to supervise and guarantee" an unconditional amnesty for guerrillas who "lay down their arms as soon as possible and return to a peaceful life."

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 8 -- At least fifty Moslems were slain by Sikhs and Hindus today in the main New Delhi railway station before, a company of Ghurkas [volunteers from Nepal and not Indians], commanded by a British officer, took control of the situation.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 8 -- Maurice Walsh of Sunningdale and Al Rothenberg of Fenway posted a combined card of 35, 31 -- 66, four under par, to win by a stroke today in the final one-day tournament staged in Westchester this season by the Metropolitan division of the Professional Golfers Association.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 8 -- As Brotherhoods of Operating Railroad Workers began today mapping wage increase plans at Cleveland, a strike of 1,800 Union Railroad employes here went into its fourth day with company and union negotiators failing to break a deadlock in wage and grievance issues.

Our own country is so freely open without let or hindrance to the foreign correspondent that few Americans, except the professionals associated with the press, radio or the films, realize how much of the world is still under control of the censor's pencil two years after hostilities have ended.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Assets and deposits of national banks continued in the first half of this year the decline noted in the last half of 1946, according to a Treasury Department report issued here today and based on a "call" as of June 29.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: We read with great interest and unqualified approval your editorial "The Olympic Forests," which appeared in your paper on Aug. 24. We particularly applaud the fact that you take such a firm stand on the issue that our natural history resources belong to the people of the nation and not to the individuals of a particular locality.

Walter T. Raney, Washington's freshman coach, has been appointed head coach of crew at Columbia, Ralph Furey, Director of Athletics, announced yesterday. He succeeds Hubert Glendon, who resigned two weeks ago.

Toward the close of the last century George Ellery Hale, an imaginative, farseeing 24-year-old astronomer, overheard on the veranda of a hotel in Rochester, N.Y., that Mantois of Paris had a pair of forty-inch glass disks which he was willing to sell at cost. The biggest lens in the world was the thirty-six-incher of Lick.
YESTERDAY'S EVENTS Security Council Atomic Energy Commission -- Committees 1 and 2 adopted major sections of Commission's second report to Security Council.

BERLIN, Sept. 8 -- A conference to decide whether France will receive a larger share of Ruhr coal and coke opened today at British Military Government headquarters here. The conference was decided upon at the London meeting in which Britain and the United States refused, despite French objections, to delay promulgating higher production ceilings for German heavy industry.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 9 -- The absence as yet of any violent reaction by the Jewish underground to the return of the Exodus 1947 refugees to Germany has confounded the experts. A blow-up has been expected any night, and British security forces have been alerted for trouble.

The bakery used to be that small shop on the corner, where the proprietor "shoveled" the bread in and out of the oven, stopping every few minutes to rush to the front of his store, with a daub of flour on his nose, to wait on the neighborhood housewives.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 9 -- Strong new support for New Jersey's proposed new constitution appeared today when former Governor Walter E. Edge, who previously had been pointedly critical of several features of the document, announced that he would advocate public ratification at a referendum next November.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The population of the United States in April of this year was "about" 143,311,000, according to estimates released today by the Bureau of the Census.

GENEVA, Sept. 9 -- Constitutional changes necessary to establish a council of the Food and Agriculture Organization as a permanent intergovernmental body to further the objectives of the FAO were approved today by the administration committee of the Geneva conference of the FAO.

NEW DELHI, Sept. 9 -- Some 10,000 Moslems, driven from their homes, are encamped behind the walls of the Puranaqila Fort, built by the Mohammedan Mogliul Emperors who ruled India four hundred years ago. They have taken sanctuary here, as their forbears did, on the traditional site of the vanished city of Indraprastha.
Fordham University announced yesterday that it would start courses in journalism and book publishing beginning with the opening of the fall semester on Sept. 22.

HAMBURG, Germany, Sept. 9 -- Refusing to heed either the appeals or threats of British Military Government and Army officials, 1,485 Jewish refugees in the third and last contingent from the Exodus 1947 waged a fierce, bloody three-hour battle aboard the Runnymede Park today in protest against their debarkation in Germany.

Representative Fred A. Hartley Jr. of New Jersey expressed his hope last night that the country's employers would take advantage of "the restoration of their right of free speech" and let their employes know what is in the TaftHartley act.

Discovery that the stomach of patients with peptic ulcers contains about twice the normal amount of the enzyme lysozyme, a substance that dissolves certain types of non-pathogenic bacteria, was reported yesterday at the annual Clinical Congress of the American College of Surgeons at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., Wednesday, Sept. 10 -- The Republican party won a battle with organized labor last night when its candidate for Representative from the Eighth Pennsylvania District defeated the Democratic nominee, who was supported by labor and committed to repeal of the Taft-Hartley law.

A determined group of tenants slashed yesterday with their forthright landlord, but results were in conclusive. The tenants remained in their five apartments at 233 East Tenth Street, near First Avenue, but the landlord held to his plan to relocate them elsewhere in order to repair and remodel the five-story building.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9 -- Construction costs have about reached their peak and are likely to start down within a year, Roy Wenzlick, St. Louis economist, predicted today in an address before the National Contract Hardware Association's annual convention.

Volume of public relations advertising in all media may eventually equal or surpass $3,000,000,000, the amount now being spent annually on product advertising, Kalman B. Druck, research and development director, Carl Byoir Associates, predicted last night in an address before the Syracuse University Advertising and Publishing Club of New York.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 9 -- On the wings of a home run Jack Lohrke stroked with two gone in the ninth and Sid Gordon roosting on first, the Giants tonight swept to their second straight victory over the Pirates before 20,008 onlookers at Forbes Field.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Sept. 9 (AP) - A United States military court in Dachau today acquitted Otto Skorzeny, former lieutenant colonel in the SS, and seven aides on charges that they had violated the rules of war.
The Sharkey rent and eviction control bills were passed last night by the City Council and the Board Estimate in revised form.

Loudspeakers blared protests yesterday against closing by the state of many child care centers here on Sept. 30 and proposed changes in the city child care program, when 220 working mothers and thirty youngsters paraded in a Madison Square Park mass meeting.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The railroads today opened their case before the Interstate Commerce Commission, in which they are asking for freight rate increases intended to produce $1,800,000,000 a year in added revenue, by asking the ICC to grant before the end of the day an increase of 10 per cent in all freight rates to bridge the gap until the commission acts on the larger, long-range increase.

ALBANY, Sept. 9 -- Dr. frank L. Tolman, president of the Civil Service Employes Association, said today that postal authorities may be asked to investigate a post card campaign against the proposed constitutional amendments opening the way for higher salaries for members of the Legislature.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Sept. 9 -- With the slogan, "Open the Door for a Million More," a national commission of the Boy Scouts of America today proposed measures to overhaul the organization's fund-raising' practices.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The letter from H. Rosse appearing in THE TIMES for Aug. 21, extolling the contribution of the Dutch to the education of the Indonesians, reminds me of the one time when I had cause to toe proud of the public schools in Mississippi for Negroes.

Barber Asphalt A dividend of 50 cents a share was voted by the Barber Asphalt Corporation, payable on Oct. 1. The company paid 25 cents each in July and April. The board of directors, it is announced, intends that the 50 cent rate will become the regular quarterly rate.

A denial that there was any connection between the threatened bus strike and the revival of deportation proceeding's against John Santo, international organization director of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, was issued yesterday by John P. Boyd, executive assistant to Watson B. Miller, United States Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization.

YESTERDAY'S EVENTS Security Council Commission for Conventional Armaments -- Working Committee accepted United States proposal that Commission limit its work to weapons other than "mass destruction" and atomic.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept, 9 -- Mrs. J.B. Balding of the Cedar Creek Club carded 37, 38 -- 75 to gain a two-stroke lead in the thirteenth annual 54-hole medal play championship of the Women's LongIsland Golf Association at the Meadow Brook Club today.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Sept. 9 -- Premier Recep Peker unexpectedly handed in his resignation to President Ismet Inonu this afternoon, according to a communique released by the official Anatolian Agency, which stated his resignation was for reasons of health.

The World Series apparently is not going to be televised if present indications are a criterion. Despite some confident advertisements suggesting the purchase of new sets to see the games, sponsors continue to show a notable lack of interest in the $100,000 fee asked by the office of A. R. Chandler, commissioner of baseball.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 9 -- The United Nations General Assembly could save time by the elimination of the Greek question and the Franco Spain issue from its agenda, Alexei Krasilnikov, delegate of the Soviet Union, asserted today in the Assembly's fifteen-nation committee on procedures and organization.
Police Inspector William (Broadway) Jones, in charge of plainclothes men in Brooklyn West, played bookmaker in a music and phonograph record shop at 160 Fifth Avenue in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon.

LONDON, Sept. 9 -- The British Government, at a lengthy Cabinet meeting today, approved a plan submitted by Sir Stafford Cripps, President of the Board of Trade, for expanding Britain's exports by another 40 per cent.

The closing of "Sweethearts," starring Bobby Clark, has been moved up a couple of weeks to Sept. 27. Revived by Paula Stone and Michael Sloane, the Victor Herbert musical will have been performed 288 times when it departs from the Shubert.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9 -- The American Federation of Labor warned today that unless living costs were promptly reduced pressure for higher wages was certain to mount, but it rejected Government price controls as a solution of the problem.

An American Ryder Cup team listing only two hold-over members from the squad which met Britain's best professional golfers in 1937 was announced yesterday by Ed Dudley, P.G.A. president, for the post-war resumption of the matches at Portland, Ore., Nov. 1 and 2.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- A report of a 22 per cent decline in feed grains for livestock in the 1947-48 feeding season of world significance in terms of human consumption, was issued today by the Department of Agriculture. The estimate for all United States feed grains was 97,000,000 tons.
OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 9 No one has cooked our Goose yet.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: To anybody who has recently had experience in Soviet-dominated eastern Europe it can come as no surprise to ead the Warsaw dispatch, in. your issue of Sept. 6 to the effect that the Polish military prosecutor in the Cracow espionage trial has demanded the death sentence for ten of the thirteen defendants.

Commission Bates, Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, spent Monday in Philadelphia discussing the proposed increases in brokers commission rates with the Securities and Exchange Commission. He cited the increased costs of business and the decrease in volume of the daily shares traded as reasons for increases in commissions.

While Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora studied the pension dispute between the Transport Workers Union, CIO, and the New York City Omnibus Corporation, the union pressed forward yesterday with plans for a strike at 4 A. M. Friday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, who is on his way to the West Coast to determine whether there is grass roots support that would justify his seeking the Republican Presidential nomination, spent the hours between trains here today talking with political and business leaders of Illinois.

Voters seeking the abolition of proportional representation as a means of electing City Council members will vote "yes," and those seeking its retention will vote "no" in the coming referendum on the question, it was announced yesterday by City Clerk Murray W. Stand.

A. E. MacDougall, president of the Queensboro Corporation, yesterday challenged Herman T. Stichman's support of three public housing amendments that will come before the state's voters next November. The State Housing Commissioner responded to the challenge quickly, and reiterated his appeal in behalf of the amendments, which would increase state housing loan funds and raise subsidies to $13,000,000 annually from the present $9,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Lefty Ed Lopat limited Washington to seven hits tonight to register his fifteenth victory as the White Sox pounded three pitchers for twelve hits and a 6-1 triumph.

At the annual meeting of Pillsbury Mills held yesterday in Minneapolis, P. W. Pillsbury, president, expressed to stockholders the belief that despite the shortage of corn, this year's record wheat crop will help hold the family budget in line during the months ahead.

The first official visit of British naval vessels to New York since before World War II is scheduled to begin Tuesday with the arrival here of the 12,000-ton cruiser Sheffield and the 2,000-ton sloop Snipe.

BALBOA, C. Z., Sept. 9 -- The extent of the dislocation and readjustment in international trade through the Panama Canal by six years of war is indicated by a comparative study of the traffic for the fiscal years 1939 and 1947, for which statistics have been released here.

The use of a sympathetic nerve block to relieve the symptoms of a deforming paralysis known as the shoulder-hand syndrome was described yesterday by three New York doctors in the morning session of the Congress of Anesthetists, at the Hotel McAlpin this week for their twenty-second annual meeting.

TOKYO, Sept. 9 -- According to every indication, whether or not a peace treaty is signed, Japan will be compelled to seek from the United States next year food in quantities comparable to those imported during 1947. From Jan. 1 to Sept. 1 this year, this amount, according to official figures, was 1,400,000 metric tons.

Three detectives, two patrolmen and three high-ranking police officers won immediate reward yesterday for solving the Selma Graff murder case. The reward -- promotions, added pay, certificates of commendation -- was announced before Board of Estimate members by Mayor O'Dwyer and Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander.

In the last eight months 45,000 passengers have traveled between New York and Mediterranean ports on four ships handled by the American Export Lines, providing a total revenue of $9,000,000, it was announced here yesterday.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 9 -- The Veterans of Foreign Wars voted over-whelmingly today opposition to immigration of European displaced persons, endorsed universal military training and elected national officers at the final session of their national encampment.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- Harold E. Stassen, as yet the only avowed candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination in 1948, will enter the Wisconsin primaries April 6 as a first test of strength, he announced here today.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 9 -- The excursion steamer Island Queen was ripped apart at her downtown wharf at 1:15 this afternoon by two explosions and burned. An estimated twenty-one persons were killed and at least sixteen were injured.

ROME, Sept. 9 -- The first American wheat to reach Italy under the relief program that has followed the end of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration arrived in Naples today. The Italian rice crop was still in danger as a result of the agricultural laborers' strike in the greater part of the Po Valley region.

Large berets, snugly fitting toques, dramatically draped turbans and evening hats consisting of a tubular halo with sequined lace veiling or mantillas, characterized the first showing of millinery by Omie Monce, in her new salon that opened at 600 Madison Avenue yesterday.

LIVERPOOL, England, Sept. 9 -- The district of Edge Hill in the center of Liverpool is having a by-election on Thursday that is going to provide the first real test of the Labor party's toe-hold on the country. There have been thirty previous by-elections since labor took power more than two years ago and they have not yet lost a seat to the opposition.

Meeting this week in Chicago, the international executive board of the American Federation of Musicians, headed by James C. Petrillo, now has before it the latest appeal of the networks for permission to duplicate musical programs on both standard and frequency modulation radio stations.

Buyers' Total Soars Out-of-town buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday numbered 2,536, against 304 last week and 1,008 in the similar week a year ago, according to listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

PARIS, Sept. 9 -- A program of financial austerity was launched today by Premier Paul Ramadier, partly to show that France was willing to make genuine sacrifices to qualify for the desperately needed United States economic aid.

PARIS, Sept. 9 -- In an attempt to end the long drawn out VietNam conflict, France is prepared to grant VietNam autonomy and other advantages such as a customs union with the other Indo-Chinese countries, according to the terms of a broadcast scheduled to be made tomorrow at Hadong, Tongking, by Emilie Bollaert, French High Commissioner to Indo-China.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- Secretary of State Marshall will go to New York on Friday for the sessions of the General Assembly of the United Nations that open next week and remain there as chief United States representative for an indefinite period, the State Department announced today.

Delegates of the American Kennel Club, attending their quarterly meeting at the Hotel Commodore yesterday, transacted routine business and heard reports on how the sport involving purebred dogs was thriving.

The second island to the right as you leave the shore of Cape Cod has been remarkable in historic times for the intelligence, independence and stalwart character of its citizens. In former times these islanders pursued whales in the remotest seas. Now, still with a certain detachment, they wait for the whales to come to them.
An Arab League warning that the proposed partition of Palestine might lead to war was sounded yesterday by Emir Feisal al-Saud of Saudi Arabia.

The annual calamity which seems to strike the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo in the form of injury to one of its principal dancers struck last night, this time taking Leon Danielian temporarlly from the scene at the City Center.

TRENTON, N. J., Sept. 9 -- Senator H. Alexander Smith of New Jersey urged today that the 700,000 displaced persons in the American and British zones in Europe be "screened" to permit their emigration to the United States and other countries where they could be housed and employed.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 9 -- Although it is customary for heads of delegations to serve on the Political Committee of the United Nations General Assembly, it is understood that Secretary of State Marshall will share this responsibility with Warren R. Austin, permanent United States representative, and John Foster DuIIes, who also served on the American delegation to the Assembly last year.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J. -- After a summer stay in Florida, where she battled a serious illness, Mrs. Albert Becker of North Jersey Country Club, bested a field of seventytwo competitors in the women's New Jersey Golf Association match play championship today with a runaway 75 to pace sixteen qualifiers into the title flights.

NANKING, Sept. 9 -- Premier Chang Chun declared today that China was opposed to what he termed the American policy of "fostering Japanese strength." He indicated clearly that while China favored amicable relations with Japan she would insist in the drafting of a peace treaty on full reparations and on the steps regarded as necessary to prevent a "revival of the Japanese Empire."

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 9 -- Discussing world-wide problems of child welfare and health as essential to peace, delegates to the first post-war conference of the International Council of Women today adopted a resolution urging controlled hygienic production and distribution of milk from healthy animals.

It is the sacred duty of business and industry to assume an "increasing financial responsibility for the nation's medical schools" if the United States is to maintain its leadership in health control, Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase of New York University declared yesterday at the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway.

JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 9 -- The question of who will succeed the late Theodore G. Bilbo as United States Senator from this state has become so perplexing that, with less than sixty days to election day, an unprecedented cloak of silence has settled over this usual hotbed of political activity.

New Jersey's Constitutional Convention has completed, just within the three-month time limit, a business-like job of writing a new basic charter to replace a Constitution adopted in 1844. No one assumes that the result is perfection, but it is good enough that its ratification by voters of the State is taken for granted.

"The Passion Left Behind," a novel, by Lewis Crommelin Masefield, son of John Masefield, England's Poet Laureate, will be published by Macmillan on Sept. 30. Born in 1910, educated at Oxford, he had traveled extensively in Europe and made one trip to the United States. He was killed in action in 1942.

STUTTGART, Germany, Sept. 9 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay, the United States Military Governor, informed the Laenderrat [Council of States] here today that much had been said about the Military Government's opposition to the socialization of industry but that a considerable part of the discussion had been distorted and inaccurate.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The State and War Departments announced tonight that British-American discussions would be held here early next month on Britain's request to be relieved of her present share of the cost of the occupation of Germany.

Three robbers in a carefully planned hold-up got away with $50,000 in gold and platinum bars and $1,000 cash after beating Thomas J. Petrucci, a gold refiner, in his shop at 11 John Street yesterday morning. The police said that it was the largest theft in the jewelry district in the last fifteen years.

The energy expended by a tropical hurricane is enough to drive all the machinery in the world for three or four years. Yet the Army, the Navy and the General Electric Company are collaborating in a daring meteorological experiment which is to determine whether or not the colossal vortex that we call a hurricane can be broken by making it precipitate the thousands of tons of water that it contains.

In a move to give Health Commissioner Israel Weinstein a "big stick" in his campaign to clean up the food industry, the Board of Health decided yesterday to license 4,000 delicatessen shops, box-lunch packers and caterers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The Army's strength has fallen to approximately 965,000 men, or-about 105,000 fewer than the needed strength of 1,070,000, and the recruiting trend is downward, according to latest official figures obtained today.

BUFFALO, Sept 9 -- After five hours of vigorous debate in which factional lines had no apparent standing, members of the International Executive Board of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, rejected today a motion to reverse its basic policy of non-recognition of the National Labor Relations Board under the Taft-Hartley Labor Law.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- Dr. Hubertus J. van Mook, Acting Governor General of The Netherlands East Indies, declared at a news conference today that the Security Council of the United Nations was "useful and helpful" in the Indonesian situation.

The nation's first "sea-going" public high school -- a converted Liberty ship that carried troops and cargo during the war -- was opened yesterday for thirty New York boys who are studying for careers in the maritime trades.

Tom Brown is on the loose again. The tight-lipped San Francisco youth who came out of the Army to confound Frank Parker and Gardnar Mulloy in the championship with the fastest tennis of the 1946 season went on the rampage yesterday for the first time this season.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Sept. 9 (AP) -- The defending champion, several ex-champions and the favorite advanced through the second round of the United States amateur golf tournament today, virtually without mussing their hair.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 9 -- Dispatches from New York that the State Department had protested the alleged discrimination in favor of the Grand Colombian Merchant Marine in the shipment of Colombian coffee were printed under large headlines today in the newspapers Tiempo and the Liberal.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 9 -- In a last-minute switch a week before the start of the picture, the deal for M-G-M to distribute the Ingrid Bergman film "Joan of Lorraine" has been called off, and Sierra Pictures, the producing company, in which Miss Bergman is associated with Walter Wanger and Victor Fleming, has concluded arrangements for RKO to release the picture.

Urging an addition to the Marshall Plan under which foreign countries would tell the United States what they propose to return to us in goods and services in exchange for our aid, Mackenzie Stevens, manager of foreign distribution for the Reynolds Metals Company, asserted yesterday the so-called dollar shortage in foreign trade in reality represents production and monetary "mismanagement" in Europe and Asia.

EDINBURGH, Sept. 9 -- One of the most interesting orchestral events of the festival here is the visit of the Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra, which is playing three programs during this week under their old conductor, Bruno Walter, who last directed them in the days before Hitler marched into Austria.

A whopping big triple was Job Dean Jessop's contribution to yesterday's frolicking at the Aqueduct horse park. It included victory in the main event on Frank Frankel's Flashco, 9-to-1 fifth choice in a field of half a dozen 3-year-olds, and a triumph in a sprint for juveniles astride the outsider in a twelve-horse line-up.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) -- The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation today turned over to the Treasury checks totaling $146,1695,250.41., thereby repaying more than, half the money provided to it to start the program of insuring bank deposits in 1934. Officials said the money would help in paring down the $259,645,000,000 national debt.
READING, Pa., Sept. 9 (AP) -- Mr. Griff, well rated by veteran Paul Vineyard, today won all three heats in the 3-year-old pacing division of the Reading Fair Futurity.

Acting Detective Sergeant Henry (Harry) F. J. Butts, Police Department ballistics expert for many years, will become plain Mr. Butts on Sept. 15. The stocky be-spectacled police expert who read the markings on bullets as accurately as fingerprint experts read whorls and loops has put in his application for retirement, it was announced at Police Headquarters yesterday.

MOUNTAINSIDE, N. J., Sept. 9 -- Twin rivers of fire, with the flames shooting skyward 100 feet fed by 4,500 gallons of gasoline, flowed today for several hundred yards in the gutters of State Highway Route 29. They blocked traffic on the four-lane thoroughfare for nearly two hours.

Zionist leaders called on the United States yesterday to support the recommendation of the majority of the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine, for partition of the Holy Land. If Washington did not do so, it would bear the major responsibility for letting the world organization fold 'up in complete failure, Dr. Abba Hillel Silver declared.

Under new war surplus disposal policies opening larger quantities of supplies and equipment to lowcost procurement by city, county, state and Federal purchasing offices, large savings to taxpayers are possible, it was revealed yesterday by the War Assets Administration.

NEW DEHLI, Egypt, Sept. 9 -- (AP) -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru declared in a radio address tonight that the Government of the Dominion of India was confronted with a situation "analagous to war" and that it would meet the "serious crisis . . . on a war basis."

ALBANY, Sept. 9 (AP) -- A State Supreme Court justice has fixed what he termed "the most advantageous water levels" for Lake George and appointed the State Public Works Superintendent to supervise control of the longlitigated issue.

Fair trade prices of 7,334 drugs and toiletries have increased an average of only 1.39 per cent from June 1, 1939, to June 1, 1947, according to the results of a study reported yesterday by Fred J. Griffiths, secretary of the National Association of Chain Drug Stores.

GENEVA, Sept. 9 -- Seventy new tariff agreements will have been completed or very nearly completed by tomorrow, the original deadline for the end of the tariff negotiations here. This leaves thirtyeight to go, including most of the big ones.

BOSTON, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Aided by Jake Jones seventeenth homer, a three-run blast high into the leftfield screen, and by fireman Johnny Murphy, who doused a Detroit uprising in the ninth, Joe Dobson gained his sixteenth victory today as the Red Sox defeated the Tigers, 5 -- 3.

The customers of Harry Collins will find in his new collection, seen yesterday at 647 Fifth Avenue, the same lines to which they have become accustomed, plus the new fashion influences handled with moderation.

AMATEURS of Western Americana and students of photography should be equally interested in "Picture Maker of the Old West: William H. Jackson."* This large and handsome book is a collection of 393 photographs, sketches and water-color paintings selected by the artist's son, Clarence S. Jackson, and accompanied by an explanatory text.

Militant tavern owners adopted yesterday a resolution at a meeting of the State Restaurant Liquor Dealers Association in the Henry Hudson Hotel recommending investigation of the recent price increases of some brewers by the United States Attorney General.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: James G. McDonald's letter in THE TIMES of Sept. 3 must not go unchallenged, as the American public is entitled to know the full significance of its argument. What Mr. McDonald advocates is not only American support in the U. N. but also willingness to "share the responsibility."
NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 9 -- A gaily decorated midway with housewares as the main attraction and home economists as "barkers" will be opened tomorrow on Bamberger's seventh floor.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (U.P.) -- The only solution to the housing shortage is a large-scale program of Government aid to private builders, the CIO said today in its monthly economic outlook.

Continued full employment at higher wages with a vast consumer demand still unsatisfied indicates that retail sales volume will remain high for the remainder of this year and early next year, Roy Foulke, vice president, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., predicted last night at the Smaller Stores Clinic of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at Hotel Pennsylvania.

LAKE GEORGE, N. Y., Sept. 9 (AP) -- Charles D. Breitel, counsel to Governor Dewey, made it plain today the Dewey Administration intends to stand by the principles of the new permissive local tax program, despite current local resistance.

WHITE PLAINS N.Y., Sept. 9 -- With dealers receiving fewer new cars from the factories in the last thirty days than in a corresponding period of 1946, V. L. Murray, vice president of the Automobile Merchants Association of New estimated today that at le 000 units would be required the demand in the City.

AMSTERDAM, Sept. 9 (Aneta) -- Prices were irregular in limited trading on the Stock Exchange. Banking shares moved higher while industrials showed a mixed trend. Shipping stocks, Indies plantations issues and State bonds were steady.

Settlement of a twenty-year-old claim against British shipping interests in London last month brought a capital gain of $2,175,000 to the United States Lines, John M. Franklin, president, announced yesterday.

The state parks in Connecticut, from all reports, are running up a record attendance this summer. Total attendance in 1946, according to figures recently released, was 1,921,441, more than the state's population and 850,000 above the 1945 attendance. Each season the people of Connecticut are flocking in ever greater numbers to the salt and fresh water bathing beaches, picturesque hilltops, woodland glades, lakes and historic sites that make up the state park areas.

CHICAGO. Sept. 9 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs. 8.500 head: total. 10.500. Barrows and gilts 25 to 50 cents lower: mostly 25 cents lower, market closed moderately active at decline: sows steady to 50 cents lower;

GENEVA, Switzerland, Sept. 9 -- The expert committee of the World Health Organization's interim commission reported today that "it will be possible to bring tuberculosis under International control within a reasonable period of time."

Paul G. Hoffman, president of the Studebaker Corporation and chairman of the Committee for Economic Development, urged businessmen yesterday to join CED in combating the "dangerous" notion that a great depression in the early Fifties is unavoidable.

Banking syndicates headed respectively by the First National Bank of Chicago and the First National Bank of New York yesterday competed closely for .the $50,000,000 of veterans' benefit bonds offered by the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

Ground was broken yesterday afternoon for the Jordan L. Mott Junior High School (Public School 22) at College Avenue and 167th Street, the Bronx, at a ceremony attended by Deputy Mayor John J. Bennett Jr. and other public and educational officials.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., Sept. 9 -- Louis Nielson, 65-year-old veteran from the Piping Rock Club playing in the event for the first time, posted a 39, 38 -- 77 to win the nineteenth annual senior championship of the Long Island Golf Association at the Wheatley Hills Golf Club today.

The jurisdiction of the Federal court to determine the legality of the 10-cent toll being charged on the Saw Mill River Parkway was challenged yesterday by William P. Bleakley, former Westehester County executive.

Three plain weaves in handwoven carpeting without carved patterns are now available from the looms of V'Soske, Inc. They were shown for the first time yesterday at the opening of the concern's new showroom for decorators and their clients at 9 East Seventy-eighth Street.

Butter rose another cent a pound in retail stores here yesterday and trade circles forecast a two-cent rise today, bringing its average price to 90 cents a pound, as most food prices continued to move upward.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 9 (AP) -- The United States Circuit Court of Appeals, Eighth District, today ordered the Federal District Court in St. Louis to return the Missouri Pacific Railroad Company reorganization plan to the Interstate Commerce Commission for reexamination.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 9 -- After studying testimony, depositions and court records from several parts of the world, Surrogate Charles H. Griffiths ruled here today that Victor Brevort, New York and Miami sportsman, was drowned on Dec. 15, 1937, off the west coast of Spain.

It is certainly not surprising that Russian-American discussions of Korea have reached a new deadlock. One deadlock has followed another, in that unhappy little country, ever since the expulsion of the Japanese. Here, as elsewhere, in all cases where the fundamental question is the withdrawal of occupation troops, deadlock suits the Russian purpose admirably.

Senator Henry Cabot Lodge, Republican of Massachusetts, who returned here yesterday after a six-week tour of several European countries, described as "shocking the misrepresentations and untruths" being circulated in Europe about the United States.

BERLIN, Sept. 9 -- The Russians illustrated today more than they have ever in the past how they are capable of blocking the functioning of both the Allied Military Government and the German City Government in Berlin.

PARIS, Sept. 9 (U.P.) -- Rabbi Baruch Korff of New York, who was arrested in a purported Jewish Stern band plot to bomb London, said today that the former United States Army pilot who informed on him and his friends was a "British agent."

Two speeches delivered in Italy last Sunday, one by Pope Pius XII to an enormous rally in the square of St. Peter's in Rome, the other by Palmiro Togliatti, the Communist leader, in the Communist stronghold of Modena, in the Po Valley, deserve attention as alarm signals that the struggle that rends Italy is coming to a head.

ABOARD THE U.S.S. MISSOURI, at Sea, Sept. 9 -- The Presidential party aboard this floating temporary White House -- largely of landlubber personnel -- learned today that it would return to Washington introduced to the mysterious court of King Neptune and Davy Jones and be fully initiated into the "Royal Order of Shellbacks."

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 9 -- Henry H. Heimann, New York, executive manager of the National Association of Credit Men, predicted today a slight business recession within the next few years but said it would be welcomed because it will provide opportunity for reevaluation of our economic structure.

ATHENS, Sept. 9 -- The Cabinet today approved the amnesty law giving the guerrillas one month to turn in their arms. It also suspended all the death sentences passed by the military courts against guerrillas or their supporters.

Former Representative Hamilton Fish Jr., reappearing on the political scene as the new editor and publisher of Today's World magazine, yesterday attacked Governor Dewey's presidential aspirations on the ground that the latter failed to serve in the armed forces in World War II though of draft age.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 9 With the Soviet Union and Poland casting the expected "No" vote, the Working Committee of the United Nations' Commission on Conventional Armaments today accepted an American-Australian resolution excluding all "mass destruction" weapons as well as atomic weapons from the commission's jurisdiction.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Sept. 9 -- A Socialist party announcement revealed today that the Socialist revolt against Communist trickery in last week's elections and against the leadership of Deputy Premier Arpad Szakasits had collapsed.

David Y. Robinson, associated with the electric heating industry for fifteen years, who joined Yale Towne Manufacturing Company last February, has been named sales manager of the company's new general line of enclosed electric heating units.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 9 (AP) -- A triple by Al Zarilla and a fly by Jeff Heath in the fourth inning gave the Browns a 1-0 victory over the Athletics tonight.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 9 -- Lashing out against the "travesty and hypocrisy" of American policy in Greece, Dr. Harlow Snapley, director of the Harvard College Observatory, proposed tonight that the State Department be held accountable to the American people for its actions.

It was a spectacular showing of fall and winter fashions that Elizabeta Arden offered yesterday afternoon, in the fashion floor of her establishment at 681 Fifth Avenue. The designer was again Castillo. This is the fourth collection that he has made for Miss Arden since his arrival in this country.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9 -- Encroachment of football upon the baseball season received a new and painful twist at Wrigley Field when Cliff Aberson, a halfback for the Green Bay Packers last year, whacked a grand slam pinch homer for the Cubs today to beat the Dodgers, 4 -- 3.
Largely in sympathy with the strength in other commodities, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed 29 to 40 points net higher.

Niagara County has been added to the list of counties in New York that will be closed to pheasant hunting this fall, and, believe it or not, the county Federation of Sportsmen's Clubs requested that the season be closed. By their willingness to discipline themselves, the Niagara sportsmen deserve better shooting next year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- By econometrics management can definitely establish the level where the sales force gets lackadaisical, Charles Roos of the Econometric Institute, Inc., of New York told the International Statistical Conference today.

Price of Beer Report of another boost in the price of a glass of beer -- subsequently clouded with a shadow of doubt -- has stirred up in an old friend of ours fond memories of the days when, the nickel was the standard coin across the bars for that refreshment and gave unquestioned access to the free lunch counter as well.

After the second of the two tax reduction measures passed by the Eightieth Congress in its first session had been vetoed by President Truman, Representative Knutson of Minnesota, who had sponsored both bills in the House, expressed the opinion that no further legislation of the kind would be proposed "as long as Mr. Truman is in the White House."

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 8 (AP) -- A post-war rubber production plan for Brazil was launched today with the promise of Government subsidy when President Eurico Gaspar Dutra signed a law guaranteeing a minimum price of approximately 45 cents per pound until Dec. 31, 1950.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The statement today by Robert Garner, vice president of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (the World Bank), that this institution under its charter cannot supply stop-gap funds for primary relief to Europe before the maturity of the Marshall plan further reduces the prospect that anything short of a special session of Congress can make this provision.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Bucky Walters pitched a four-hit 2-0 victory for the Reds against the Boston Braves tonight as 24,351 fans gathered at Crosley Field for "Bucky Waiters Night." The victory was the 198th of the Cincinnati veteran's major league career.

The stock market labored yesterday through a session devoid of any hint as to its immediate course. Strength in railway and aircraft shares punctuated the trading at two separate intervals and, as a result, prices ended firmer, with the combined averages 0.25 point higher on the day.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 9 (AP) -- A tworun third inning, which included a double by rookie Vernal (Nippy) Jones, carried the Cardinals to a 2-to-0 victory over the Phillies tonight. As a result, the Redbirds cut to four and a half games the National League lead of the Dodgers.

Listed to open on the earliest date in the circuit's history, the National Hockey League will begin operations on Oct. 15 when the Chicago Black Hawks meet the Detroit Red Wings at Detroit, it was announced yesterday as the league's 1947-48 schedule was released.
LONDON, Sept. 10 (Reuters) -- Results of soccer games played in Great Britain today:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- The Treasury Department proposed today that separate Federal estate and gift taxes be replaced by a single transfer levy as a step toward eliminating certain "basic defects" in the present revenue law.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- The Justice Department charged three leading American glass producers today with "conspiracy to dominate and control" the fiber glass industry.

Opening of the nation's newest post-war department store, Foley's, Houston, Tex., on Oct. 20 was announced yesterday by Fred Lazarus, Jr., president of Federated Department Stores, at a special celebration at the St. Regis Hotel, followed by a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria for a delegation of some twenty prominent Texans and as many more New Yorkers.

ATHENS, Sept. 10 (U.P.) -- The Greek Parliament tonight gave the coalition Government of Liberal Premier Themistocles Sophoulis an almost unanimous vote of confidence, assuring the speedy adoption of his guerrilla amnesty bill. The vote was 279 to 2.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 10 -- Excessive nationalism was blamed today by scholars as the principal barrier to international accord. Dr. Christian Gauss, retired dean of Princeton University, called for a denationalization of education in the United States.

PARIS, Sept. 10 (AP) -- The French Government made "last appeal" today to Indo-China to accept independence within the French Union, with the provision that France retain control of the army and foreign policy.

"The American Past," a monumental work of 1,000 photographs and 125,000 words, by Roger Butterfield, is being prepared for publication Oct. 24 by Simon Schuster. The book, 9x12 inches, will have a section of twenty-one pages in color.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Secretary of State Marshall warned today that Europe must have United States assurance of emergency food and fuel by the end of the year to allay "intolerable hunger and cold" this winter and that Congress alone could authorize such action.

With 3,000 Manhattan and Queens bus employes set to strike at 4 A.M. tomorrow, hope for maintaining uninterrupted bus service hinged last night on a pension ruling to be made today by Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora.
SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, Sept. 11 -- Maj. Gen. Archer L. Lerch, Military Governor of Korea, died this morning in the Thirty-Fourth General Army Hospital. He was 53.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended Sept. 3: Increases of $112,000,000 in commercial, industrial, and agricultural loans and $241,000,000 in demand deposits credited to domestic banks, and a decrease of $151,000,000 in demand deposits adjusted.

A substance that neutralizes heparin, the liver-factor that prevents formation of life-endangering blood-clots, thus making its use much safer in heart disease and other ills, was described yesterday at the annual clinical congress of the American College of Surgeons in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The thousands of New York school children who are members of the Junior Red Cross are learning the "true essence of community service," according to the annual report of the central city committee, made public yesterday.

The Republican party has won a substantial victory in the special election for the Eighth Pennsylvania District. Its candidate, Franklin H. Lichtenwalter, received more than 61 per cent of the total vote, getting as expected overwhelming support in Bucks County, but carrying also Lehigh County, which was being watched as a testing ground.

Sales of leading mail order and chain companies increased 8.8 per cent in August over the same month last year, according to a compilation of forty-one companies made by THE NEW YORK TIMES. In July the increase over last year was 19.3 per cent.

Sixteen over-age American-flag passenger vessels are to be withdrawn from the Maritime Commission's Reserve Fleet and sold without restrictions, it was announced yesterday. They aggregate 140,000 gross tons.

H.J. Heinz Company will begin on Oct. 6 a promotional campaign for its soups which it describes as the biggest in its history. Backbone of the campaign will be a sampling program whereby purchase of three cans of its condensed tomato soup entitles the buyer to one can of another variety free.

A suit listing 174 longshoremen as plaintiffs was filed yesterday in Brooklyn Supreme Court against seventy - four stevedoring and steamship companies from which they seek to recover a total of $3,480,000 in overtime compensation.

After considerable discussion of the merits of post-graduate courses taken by teachers for advanced credit, the Board of Education by a vote of 4 to 1 yesterday revised its criteria under which New York public school teachers may qualify for a bonus payment of $200.

NANKING, Sept. 10 -- An agreement on the main principles that will govern the use of China's share of the $350,000,000 United States relief appropriation for needy foreign countries has been reached between American and Chinese officials here.

LONDON, Sept. 10 -- Official hopes of an early settlement of the strike involving 40,000 miners in the Yorkshire coal fields were high here tonight, following a report that the Grimethorpe mine workers would discuss a set of new proposals with their union leaders tomorrow.

Working in tones of brown and green, Arnold Constable illustrated in its showing yesterday at the Starlight Roof of the WaldorfAstoria Hotel the flexibility of the fall fashions in their variety of silhouettes.
BERLIN, Sept. 10 -- Taxpayers of the United States and Britain have paid $916,114,000 to feed the Germans in the United States and British zones since the end of the war in Europe.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Sept. 10 -- Giving no indication of faltering in her bid to retain the women's New Jersey Golf Association match play championship she won last year, Mrs. Albert Becker of the North Jersey Country Club defeated Mrs. Robert Pulleyn, Somerset Hills, 4 and 3, to pace the title field of sixteen into the second round.

The nation's gasoline stocks last week declined 769,000 barrels, according to the weekly figures of the American Petroleum Institute. At the close of the week they amounted to 83,336,000 barrels, compared with 84,105,000 a week earlier and 86,909,000 on Sept. 7, 1946.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 10 -- One of Russia's strongest and bitterest attacks on American atomic policy came today from Andrei A. Gromyko, who accused the United States of setting up a world-wide atomic trust, "bossing" other nations, grabbing economic privileges and trampling on the sovereignty of small states.

PARIS, Sept. 10 -- The need for the rapid transfer and training of workers across Europe's frontiers was emphasized today by Jacques Maillet, head of the Manpower Committee of the European economic conference in a summary of the committee's report.

Bill O'Dwyer, the County Mayo boy who made good in America's biggest city, was host yesterday to the sturdy lads of the Gaelic football teams from Kerry and Cavan who came all the way from Ireland to take part in the AllIreland final to be played at the Polo Grounds on Sunday.
LONDON, Sept. 10 -- The British Government has begun informal discussions with Dominion representatives on Empire aspects of the dollar crisis.
CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 10 (AP) -- Today was a sad afternoon for favorite players in the estimated crowd of 16,000 at Garden State Park as all lost.

LONDON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- A Foreign Office spokesman said today that the return of the Jews from the Exodus 1947 to Germany would in the British view, discourage the organization of "further odysseys" to Palestine.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower today disclaimed all association with a growing movement to form clubs backing him for the Presidency.

In his dressing room under the Stadium yesterday after the Yankees had beaten the Indians, 7 -- 4, and thus reduced their pennantclinching combination of victories and Red Sox defeats to a paltry six, Manager Bucky Harris lifted his glass in a simple but thoroughly sincere salute.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 10 -- A new charter for New Jersey -- the result of three months of effort -- was signed, sealed, and delivered to Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll today by seventy-nine of its eightyone authors in ceremonies at the state constitutional convention at Rutgers University gymnasium.

LONDON, Sept. 10 -- A peacetime United States program of lend-lease to aid Europe was suggested tonight by British Foreign Secretary Bevin in an address at a dinner attended by visiting American Legionnaires.

Surgery performed deep in the abdominal cavity with no discomfort to the patient because of the injection of nerve-blocking local anesthetics near the operation site was described before the Congress of Anesthetists at an afternoon session yesterday.

Solon E. Summerfield, founder and former head of the Gotham Gold Stripe Hosiery Company, who died in Santa Monica, Calif., on Sept. 2, bequeathed $2,500,000, less taxes, to his widow, Mrs. Vivien R. Summerfield of 737 Park Avenue.
Former Governor Herbert H. Lehman joined yesterday in the protests against the treatment accorded the passengers of the Exodus 1947 and their forcible return to Hamburg, Germany.
Food prices generally, which had been moving upward for days, surged to a new record high level yesterday, some items jumping up at the extraordinary rates of 10 to 36 per cent.

"Children's Theatre," a program drawing on record albums suitable for young listeners, will make its bow at 5 P.M. next Sunday over WNEW. The bill for the premiere performance will include "Tweedle Dum and Tweedle Dee," as recorded by Eddie Cantor; "Story of Celeste," made by Victor Jory, and "Aesop's Fables," featuring Barry Thompson.

For the second time in two days thieves yesterday ventured successfully "below the deadline" in New York's heavily patrolled financial district, broke into a radio, camera and jewelry concern's building, smashed open three safes and made off with loot valued tentatively at more than $60,000 .

Complaints being received by the Joint Legislative Committee on installment financing indicate that excessive charges are imposed on installment buyers by financing companies and dealers throughout New York, State Senator J. Raymond McGovern, chairman, declared here yesterday.

In the United States today purchasing power is being increased at a rate faster than production is rising, and when production in some cases is pressing against the limits of its capacity. This pressure on prices is being exerted chiefly in two areas of the economy.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission decided today it had no jurisdiction over the plan of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway Company to ride itself of control of the New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad by distributing its Nickel Plate holdings to C. O. stockholders as a dividend.

ST. L.OUIS, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Nicking Dutch Leonard for a run at a time, the Cardinals went on to a 4-to-1 victory over the Phillies behind the four-hit pitching of Al Brazle tonight. The Redbirds stayed four and a half games behind the league-leading Dodgers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Organized labor, principally the Congress of Industrial Organizations and the railway brotherhoods, with the Democratic National Committee once again following its lead, asked for the conclusions that will be widely drawn from the result of the by-election in the Eighth Pennsylvania Congressional District.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- The National Association of Railroads and Public Utilities Commissioners contended today that railroads seeking freight rates increases have underestimated revenues for 1947 by $622,000,000, based on past shipping trends.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 10 -- Emmet Lavery, playwright, and Martin Gosch, Broadway producer, filed two suits today in State Superior Court asking libel and slander damages totaling $2,000,000 from Mrs. Lela Rogers, mother of Ginger Rogers, movie actress.

Uniform purchasing laws in all state governmental buying agencies are the goal of purchasing officials now, Joseph H. Crowley chief counsel, law department City of Cleveland, disclosed yesterday. His declaration was made in summarizing panel discussions on a national survey of present confusing practices at closing sessions of the National Institute of Governmental Purchasing at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 10 -- "Beggars' Choice," a recently published first novel by George Axelrod, has been acquired for the screen by Eagle-Lion, and the story has been sent to Joel McCrea with an offer of the leading role in the film, the studio announced today.
The art of the nineteenth-century painter Gustave Dore and the Hotel Shelton's adding machines clashed in Mid-Manhattan Court yesterday.

ARCOLA, N.J., Sept. 10 -- The Arcola Country Club course continued to defy the best efforts of golfers to break par today. The result was that Gordon S. Park of Glen Ridge took the medal honors with a 1-over 72 in the twentyfourth annual Arcola invitation golf tournament.

The State of Michigan awarded yesterday an issue of $30,000,000 of veterans' bonds, due serially from 1949 to 1964, to a banking syndicate headed Jointly by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., the First National Bank of New York and the First National Bank of Chicago, at a net interest cost of 1.22 per cent.

A new theatrical syndicate, having fund of $300,000, has been organized to sponsor shows either on its own or in conjunction with other Broadway managers. William R. Katzell, co-producer with Lee Sabinson of the current musical hit, "Finian's Rainbow," is general manager and director of the new outfit called Theatre Associates, Inc.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 10 -- The Iranians have been stalling for some time to delay as long as possible consideration of the delicate question of Russian oil concessions but it looks now as if the subject is due for review.

A Communist memorandum asserting that "it will be necessary to expose the reactionary purposes of the Big Business sponsors of the Freedom Train" was acknowledged last night by the Communist party to be genuine, after parts of it had been printed in The New York World-Telegram yesterday.

While cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange lost yesterday part of the midafternoon gains, they closed 11 to 33 points higher than on Tuesday. Far months displayed greater strength than near months.

SANTA CRUZ, Calif., Sept. 10 -- Seven years of agitation, especially from lawyers in the "grass roots" areas of California, led today to the presentation before a convention of the state bar a plan of continuing education for attorneys. Sponsors believe the program may serve as a pattern nationally.

Production during the current year by Westinghouse Electric Corporation of major electric appliances, comprising refrigerators, ranges, water heaters and automatic washers, will exceed that of the pre-war peak year, 1941, by 10 per cent, J.H. Ashbaugh, vice president of the electric appliance division, predicted yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The group of ministers who recently spent two weeks in Yugoslavia, as the invited guests of Tito and his government, have made their report to the press. They are quoted as saying "there is today in Yugoslavia complete freedom of worship and respect for religious beliefs and institutions.
OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 10 -- The Scandinavian Gold Cup will remain in this country another year, making the fourteenth over which the Seawanhaka Yacht club will have had the pleasure of dusting it.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., Sept. 10 -- On the basis of unofficial complete returns in Pennsylvania's Eighth Congressional district voting yesterday, Franklin H. Lichtenwalter, 37-year-old Republican Speaker of the state's House of Representatives, was swept into the vacant seat by an overwhelming majority of 17,602 votes.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Under a recent date line, your paper published excerpts from a critical statement which I issued in Washington taking sharp exception to many aspects of our Government's foreign policy. I am writing this letter in order to clarify my personal viewpoint and to indicate what I believe to be a rising tide of important public sentiment in the Midwest.

ALBANY, Sept. 10 -- Commissioner of Education Francis T. Spaulding, chairman of the Advisory Committee on Teachers Salary Schedules, announced today that recommendations for regulations governing promotional increments under the 1947 Teachers Salary Law will be made about Sept. 22.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 10 -- The 105th Mineola Fair is breaking attendance records, with the attendance yesterday, the opening day, and today surpassing the first two days of last year's exposition by substantial margins. Tuesday's paid attendance was 13,162, more than 5,000 above the opening day last year.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 10 -- Australia and Belgium cast about today for a third nation to help them mediate the Dutch-Indonesian dispute as directed by the United Nations Security Council.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 10 -- An agreement has been signed here between the Yugoslav Government and British representatives which, it is hoped, will solve the repatriation problem of Yugoslav displaced persons. Details of the agreement, which was signed in Bled yesterday, were learned today.

From the Connecticut to the Delaware a tract where the whistle of the bobwhite once was a familiar sound, there is a silence that seems puzzling to hunters who move away from city streets only during the hunting season.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 10 -- New England's largest antiques show, New Haven's ninth annual, opened today for a run through Saturday in the Arena.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 10 -- The press and people are incensed over an alleged American complaint of discrimination by shippers and the suggestion of a possible violation of the commercial treaty between Colombia and the United States through favoritism on behalf of the Government's Grand Colombia Merchant Marine in the shipment of coffee.

The first act of the new Greek Cabinet was to give unanimous approval to the Amnesty Act, offered without condition to guerrilla fighters who turn in their arms within a month, and to suspend all death sentences passed by the military courts against the rebels and their supporters.

An underwriting syndicate headed by Coffin Burr, Inc., and Spencer Trask Co. will offer to investors today a new issue of $60,000,000 of thirty-five-year 2 3/4 per cent general and refunding mortgage bonds of the Detroit Edison Company at 101 1/8 to yield aboutj 2.70 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- A twelve-point program to raise the coal output in the German Ruhr to 300,000 tons a day by the end of this year and to place full responsibility for production in German hands under Anglo-American control was announced by the two Governments tonight.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Five runs in the seventh inning carried the Browns to an 8-2 victory over the Athletics in their final appearance of the season at Shibe Park, today. Walt Judnick and Jeff Heath each contributed two-run homers to the winning cause, while Sam Chapman slammed one for Philadelphia.

LAKES SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 10 -- The United Nations Security Council plunged into a new deadlock on the Egyptian question today after rejecting a third resolution to refer the dispute back to Great Britain and Egypt for direct negotiation.

ROME, Sept. 10 -- An editorial in I'Osservatore Romano today expressed gratification over what it said was Prime Minister Stalin's statement last Sunday that the Soviet Union was against all warmongers. It quoted Mr. Stalin as having said that "Moscow will unmask warmongers by gathering around the flag of peace all peaceloving nations" and stressed that this "would implicitly refute any accusation made by other nations that Russia is imperialist."
CANTON, N.Y., Sept. 10 (AP) -- A leader of the so-called "progressive" wing of the Universalist Church of America said today universalism was "a world fellowship, not a Christian sect."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- The Justice Department said today that it was investigating the prolonged detention of about 200 enemy aliens at Ellis Island with the possibility of "deporting, paroling or freeing" those not involved in court proceedings.
WARSAW, Poland, Sept. 10 (AP) -- A military court in Cracow sentenced nine men tonight to die and seven others to long imprisonment for espionage on behalf of foreign powers.

NANKING, Sept. 10 -- China's National Government has the means to fight the Communists for "another two years" even without foreign assistance, President Chiang Kai-shek declared in a "secret" pamphlet read here today before the Kuomintang party congress.

BUFFALO, Sept. 10 -- The United Automobile Workers, one of the most important standard-bearers of the Congress of Industrial Organizations in pressing post-war demands, is heading into a six-month period of relative stability on pay issues, it was learned tonight.

GENEVA, Sept. 10 -- Recommendations that governments continue their export controls and international allocation of commodities in short supply will be made by the Food and Agriculture Organization conference before it adjourns tomorrow.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Sept 10 (AP) -- Defending titleholder Ted Bishop of Dedham, Mass., and tournament favorite Frank Stranahan of Toledo, Ohio, were knocked out of the United States amateur golf championship today in smashing fourth round upsets.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 10 -- Ralph Kiner hit a couple of home runs as a sort of farewell to Larry Jansen and the Giants at Forbes Field today, but their influence on Pirate fortunes was strictly negative. The Giants overcame that slugging with some concentrated fire of their own at the expense of the ex-Yankee, Mel Queen, and defeated the Pirates, 3 to 2, for a sweep of the three-game series.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10 -- Hardware manufacturers were urged today to exert every effort to trim costs, for as a part of the building industry they were warned that "without earnest striving to reduce cost, by every factor in the building industry, there will be few buildings to design."
SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 10 -- The Soviet Union's refusal to participate in a four-power discussion of the Korean question has shocked moderate and liberal political circles here.
YESTERDAY'S EVENTS Security Council Reached new deadlock on Egyptian question after rejecting Chinese compromise resolution.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- A special Senate - House committee today assigned an investigator to delve into the high cost of building material and the profits of "middlemen" in a move to help solve the country's housing shortage.

Business, real estate and civic organizations joined yesterday in objecting to the City Planning Commission's pending proposal to amend the zoning regulations to give itself power to permit construction of parking garages and lots accommodating fifty or more automobiles anywhere in the city.

BOSTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Scattering eight hits and pitching his best in the tight spots, Freddie Hutchinson today hurled the Tigers to a 5-0 victory over the Red, Sox before 9,253 paying fans. The triumph moved Detroit within a half game of second-place Boston.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Charlie Trippi sped 71 and 65 yards the first two times he carried the ball in his Chicago debut tonight and the Chicago Cardinals crushed the New fork Giants, 52 to 21, in a National Football League exhibition game before a crowd of 39,850 in Comiskey Park.

Louis Shub, pianist from Baltimore, gave his first New York recital last night at Town Hall. There was vitality in his-playing, land he could command power as well as delicacy, with equal positiveness of effect. His tone never lost its mellowness and singing quality, even under stress, and he commanded a wide range of colors and tints which, combined with a fluent technique, lent his work at its best true allure.

A defense fund of $100,000 will be raised to fight the deportation proceedings against John Santo, Rumanian-born international organization director of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, it was announced last night by Michael J. Quill, chairman of the John Santo Defense Committee.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission authorized today increases in interstate commutation and multiple railroad fares to and from New York City, Chicago and other cities in the Eastern district, running from 15 to 25 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Officials of the Congress of Industrial Organizations today said that circumstances compelled them to await the lead of the American Federation of Labor on whether or not to have their top officers sign anti-Communist affidavits in order to qualify for having cases processed by the National Labor Relations Board.
Dallas, Tex. Dallas, Tex., announced yesterday that it would receive bids on Sept. 23 on bond issues totaling $4,340,000, dated Oct. 1, 1947, and due Oct. 1 from 1948 to 1967.

HAMBURG, Germany, Sept. 10 -- The pitched battle yesterday between 1,485 Jewish refugees and British troops and military police aboard the Runnymede Park was a mistake, Mordecai Rosman, leader of the passengers, said late tonight.
ABOARD U.S.S. MISSOURI, At Sea, Sept. 10 -- The carnival aboard this superdreadnought was halted suddenly today and the Missouri, serving as the floating White House, became an emergency mercy ship.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Government officials forecast still higher food prices today when the Agriculture Department scaled down its estimate of this year's corn crop to 2,403,913,000 bushels.
Joe H. Bagley has been named general sales manager of the Gerber Products Company.

Factory Supply Sales Rise Sales of industrial supplies and equipment have increased about 5 per cent since the beginning of this month, industrial distributors disclosed here yesterday. The increase appears to be well diversified covering lines ranging from hand tools to new light machine tools, materials, metals and industrial mechanical rubber goods, they said.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (U.P.) -- The Interstate Commerce Comission refused today to grant the national railroads an immediate increase in freight rates. The move was taken to permit shippers and other opponents of a rate rise to be heard.

MADISON, Wis., Sept. 10 -- Six hundred scientists from throughout the country assembled on the University of Wisconsin's campus today for a four-day discussion of radioactive isotopes, described as the most important medical research tool since the development of the microscope.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- The Antarctic oases discovered by a United States Navy expedition last winter off the Knox and Princess Ranghild coasts of that continent are salt-water creeks -- backwashes of the Antarctic Ocean.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 10 -- As part of a new policy declaration, the International Council of Women voiced a strong protest today against the lack of women members on the committees and commissions of the United Nations.

Jaroslav Drobny of Czechoslovakia and Robert Falkenburg of Hollywood, Calif., were the first two players to reach the quarterfinals of the men's national championship yesterday at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.

Forty-eight young demonstrators, including eight girls, invaded the supply office of the British Admiralty on the thirteenth floor of 43 Exchange Place at 4:45 o'clock yesterday afternoon and remained there until 7 O'clock, protesting the return to Germany of the passengers of the Exodus 1947.
ROME, Sept. 10 -- The farm laborers' strike, which has kept some 600,000 men in the Po Valley idle since Monday, was extended this morning to the Venetian provinces.

Fifty tenants living in Washington Square South between Macdougal and Sullivan Streets have formed a committee to oppose any attempt by New York University to build its proposed Law Center on the site of their homes, it was announced yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 10 -- Following are excerpts from the speech delivered by Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet representative, before the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission today: Those who bear responsibility for the preparation of the unacceptable recommendations and proposals contained in the first report, proceeded according to their past methods of work and succeeded to carry into their second report of the Atomic Commission all those provisions of the first report.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 10 -- The Mexican Government officially announced today the granting of the first contract to a foreign company to drill for oil in Mexico since the expropriation of foreign oil properties in March, 1938.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 10 -- Some eleventh-hour political byplay has resulted in the sudden switch of Senator Robert A. Taft's main scheduled appearance here Sept. 16 from the auspices of the Republican County Committee to those of a non-political organization.

Two new plans for the refinancing of the Equitable Office Building Corporation were submitted by Federal Judge John C. Knox yesterday to the Securities and Exchange Commission. Judge Knox said that if SEC approval is received by tomorrow he will rule then on whether one or both plans will be submitted to the stockholders for approval.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Uiuted States Department of Agriculture follows. HOGS Salable hogs. 7,000 head: total, 10,000: market active; all weights and sows 50 to 75 cents higher; good and choice 180 to 260 pounds, $29.00 to $29.60: top of $29.75 paid for one
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Personal income reached a record high in July, bringing the annual rate to $196,900,000,000, the Commerce Department stated today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Europe may accept a permanent flow of capital from the United States as normal rather than the cut in the standard of living which would restore trade equilibrium, Jan Tinbergen, director of the Central Planning Bureau of the Netherlands Government, today told the international statistical conferences.
On the eve of her seventieth birthday yesterday, Mme. Rosika Schwimmer, international pacifist of 1915 Henry Ford peaco ship fame, issued a plea for world peace.

Recent increases in wages and higher costs of materials and supplies have so reduced the operating margin of the nation's railroads that "disaster would speedily overtake them with any substantial drop-off in traffic," William T. Faricy, president of the Association of American Railroads, declared yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Traffic Club of New York in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- The State Department is at present studying both the Korean question and the problem of making peace with Japan, but until the considerations have proceeded further Secretary of State Marshall preferred to withhold comment today.

BOSTON, Sept. 10 -- A warning of "chaos and endless suffering" on a global scale if any government or group of governments decided not to persist in the attempt to reach agreement on major problems was voiced in a speech here today by Trygve Lie, general secretary of the United Nations.

PARIS, Sept. 10 -- French factories may have to close in two months if France does not obtain the $250,000,000 she is seeking from the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, it was said today in French official circles.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- The German V-2 rocket fired in a historic test from the aircraft carrier Midway last Saturday, it was disclosed today, might have streaked 200 miles and attained a seventy-five-mile altitude but for the malfunction of a gyro stabilizer.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Representative Robert F. Rich, Republican, of Pennsylvania, today suggested that Congress investigate what he termed its own "dumbness" in passing the 1944 War Contracts Settlement Act.
