In July the United States Army enlisted 2,907 fewer men than it had hoped for. In August the deficiency was 6,888. Yet those were comparatively good months. The total enlistment deficiency since Selective Service was abolished last January is 105,000 men.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Boston hit Ewell Blackwell and three succeeding Cincinnati pitchers for 15 hits, including two home runs, today to win the final game of the season between the clubs as the veteran Clyde Shoun held his old team mates to five hits in registering an 8-0 shutout.
All exports to Russia may be placed under specific export license in action now being considered at Washington, it was learned in foreign trade circles here yesterday.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 10 -- Praise of the increasing "interdependence" between business and the farm in the New Jersey State Fair was given in a proclamation by Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll marking the 202d anniversary of the annual event, which will open here Sept. 21 for a week-long stand.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 10 (AP) -- Larry MacPhail, president of the New York Yankees, said tonight that "anytime Chandler or anyone else labors under the impression I cannot express my opinions on baseball he is entirely wrong."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- The United States in vain urged the British Government at the time to reconsider its decision to send the 4,811 Jews from the Exodus 1947 back to Germany, Secretary of State Marshall announced today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Republican leaders here evinced more than average jubilation today over the special election yesterday in the Eighth Pennsylvania Congressional District, where Franklin H. Lichtenwalter won a distinct victory over Phil Storch, the Democratic candidate.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 10 -- Mohandas K. Gandhi, the master architect of an independent India, has been conferring with leaders of the Dominion Government since his arrival yesterday on measures to halt the religious strife in India's capital city.

Ruthanna Boris' career as a choreographer got off to a flying start last night at the City Center with the presentation by the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo of her first ballet, a completely fetching little piece called "Cirque de Deux." As its title suggests, it is a combination of the circus and the pas de deux.

BARCELONA, Spain, Sept. 10 -- Spanish industrialists are making a new bid for foreign loans under the guise of private credits since such credits have been refused to the government. The new plan is just getting under way here in Barcelona.

ROME, Sept. 10 -- The Soviet Union has made a stinging reply to the appeal for revision of the Italian peace treaty that the Constituent Assembly addressed to the legislatures of all countries concerned at the time Italy ratified the treaty.

The $7,500 added Bushwick Hurdle Handicap -- won by Bayard Sharp's Lieut. Well for the second successive year -- had top billing at Aqueduct yesterday, but the story of the day was the victory of Mrs. C. Oliver Iselin's 2-year-old filly Shimmer in the $4,000 purse run fourth.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Chief of Staff, expressed deep concern today over the falling strength of the Army and said that he would have to tell the facts to Congress in "bald terms" if personnel fell to a dangerously low level.

LONDON, Sept. 10 -- Great Britain is entitled to apply for a loan from the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development to help finance the modernization of her nationalized coal industry or for any general productive enterprise, John J. McCloy, president of the bank, said today.

Mother Earth Calling Holes in the ground, as this corner has more than once taken occasion to note, have always had an irresistible fascination for New Yorkers. They interrupt the headlong pace with which they are accustomed to pursue their routine of going places -- any place -- and stop to enjoy the spectacle presented by any excavation contrived by the building trades in the interest of what the realtors call "improvements."

CHICAGO, Sept. 10 -- The American Federation of Labor executive council said today that the United Nations "has proved itself almost impotent" and suggested a meeting of the Big Four chiefs of government for a frank, direct discussion of the problems of peace.

A spirited rise in the major commodities was mirrored yesterday in a late upturn on the stock market, where prices soared 1 to 4 points in late trading on restricted bidding. The rally in the key industrial issues generally ranged between 1 and 2 points, tout the average price only rose 0.33 on the day.

PARIS, Sept. 10 -- The emphatic dissatisfaction of the United States Government with the work of the European conference on the Marshall plan was frankly expressed today to the conference's Executive Committee at a twohour meting in the United States Embassy in Paris.

Bankers Commended Copies of Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder's commendation to bankers for their continuing assistance in reporting large and unusual currency transactions are being forwarded to all financial institutions in this district by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Because of the significant disparity between current amounts charged for depreciation and the cost of actual replacements, industrial depreciation policies are being subjected to increasing reviews, according to the National Industrial Conference Board's monthly survey of business practices.

The World Education Service Council, Inc., in affiliation with World Festivals for Friendship, has started a campaign for the 1947 "World Christmas and Chanukah Festivals," it was announced yesterday at a luncheon meeting in the New York "University Faculty Club, 22 Washington Square North.

LIVERPOOL, England, Sept. 10 -- Britain's most extensive political campaign since the general elections ends tomorrow when the citizens of the working class district of Edgehill, Liverpool, go to the polls. They are voting for a member of Parliament to replace a Labor MP, Dr. Richard Clitherow, who died.

Buying more from the United States than she sells in this country, Colombia, like many other countries in the Western Hemisphere, cannot continue in an adverse balance of trade without serious injury to her economy, it was pointed out yesterday by A. W. Buttenheim, president of the Colombian-American Chamber of Commerce.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 10 -- Mrs. J.B. Balding of the Cedar Creek Club added a 40, 41 -- 81 to her first-day score of 75 to lead with 156 at the end of two days in the women's Long Island Golf Association fifty-four-hole medal play championship at the Meadow Brook Club today.

It's not just a desirable economy today to stretch butter or to find suitable substitutes for this nowso-costly table fat. It is a downright necessity with many families. And with the prospect that prices may go even higher -- probably reaching $1 a pound in the next few weeks -- it is likely that more households will be considering how to derive the most from the food.

LONDON, Sept. 10 -- Continued absence of selling permitted prices of leading industrial shares to be marked up all around today on the stock market, although the improvement was not maintained fully at the close of the day.
The city's rent and eviction conrol bills were described yesterday by tenant groups as badly weakened by the revisions adopted by the Board of Estimate and the City Council on Tuesday night.

READING, Pa., Sept. 10 (AP) -- Inactive through much of the season, Fedor, bay son of Scotland, owned by S.A. Wathen, came forward to capture the $7,900 Reading Futurity for 3-year-old trotters today, vanquishing nine rivals in the feature event of the week's Grand Circuit meeting.

Food prices overrode consumer resistance yesterday, scoring new highs in pork and other meats, butter, eggs and other staples. Although the refusal of many housewives to pay the new high prices slowed the sale of some meat cuts in New York and several other cities, it was ineffective to break their price levels.

An old-fashioned corn roast was staged by the Police Athletic League yesterday as a harvest-day celebration for 120 Lower East Side juvenile farmers. Cold-water flat fire-escapes and modern Vladeck Housing project windows proved ringside seats for the festival.

The Radio Manufacturers Association Will petition Congress when, it convenes next January for prompt elimination of the 10 percent excise tax on radio receivers, Benjamin Abrams, president, Emerson Radio Phonograph Corp., disclosed yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 11 -- Some sweeping revisions in American educational concepts, including recognition that training for the professions is primarily a Federal concern, were urged today by Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard University.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The International Typographical Union, American Federation of Labor, announced today its acceptance of a proposal by the American Newspaper Publishers' Association for a conference "to resolve existing differences" between the ITU and the ANPA.

School Savings Film A novel promotional effort to expand its school savings department and to assist schools in teaching thrift and banking is being undertaken by the Dollar Savings Bank of the City of New York through preparation of a special film, "Save for a Goal."

The Board of Estimate is expected to take up next Thursday the problem of what it will cost to administer the rent and eviction controls over nearly 2,000,000 dwelling units that are to be given on Wednesday to the City Rent Commission.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 11 -- Three days before the Russian oil concessions were to be discussed in Parliament, Ambassador George V. Allen assured Iranians tonight that the United States was prepared to support their right to sovereignty if they had the courage to defend it by not submitting to threats or intimidation.

CANTON, N.Y., Sept. 11 (AP) -- A churchwomen's observer at the United Nations said tonight that she believed the United States was, as "insistent" as Russia to retain the veto power over the international organization's actions.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Sept. 11 -- The Prudential Insurance Company today submitted an application to construct here at a cost exceeding $4,000,000 a 653-unit garden-type apartment. The application was submitted at a special hearing of the City Commission in the office of Mayor Frank H. Eggers by Paul Bester, vice president of the insurance company.
The possibility of court action to remove the pending referendum on Proportional Representation from the November election ballot disappeared yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 11 (AP) Rudy York hit his twentieth home run of the year with two on base in the first inning to start the Chicago White Sox on a 7-to-3 triumph over the Philadelphia Athletics tonight before 7,445.

The second report of the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission will go to the Security Council with ten supporting votes. Poland did not vote when the question came up yesterday. Mr. Gromyko did not surprise anybody, after his remarks on Wednesday, by voting no.

The housewife who sets out to do her week-end marketing today with the idea that she will avoid the foods that have risen to almost prohibitive prices and select items that are more reasonable in cost is letting herself in for a herculean task.

LUEBECK, Germany, Sept. 11 (AP) -- In a secret interview inside a refugee camp heavily guarded by British soldiers, the reputed commander of the Exodus Jews today threatened violent action if Britain continued to refuse to let them enter Palestine.

After the strong males had finished battling the big tuna in the Soldier's Rip at Wedgeport, Nova Scotia, and the International Tuna Tournament was over, Mr. B.D. Crowninshield of Boston proceeded to haul in an 882-pounder that set two new records.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Americans must choose between voluntary meat rationing or legislative controls on the use of wheat in any plan of fighting hunger in Europe, Chester C. Davis, member of the President's Comimittee on Foreign Aid, said today.

Contrary to some predictions, women are holding on fairly well to the jobs they got during the war-time manpower shortage, State Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi reported yesterday. Employement of women in New York State, while slightly below the peak of 1944, was still higher than for any pre-war year.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 11 -- Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, said today that the secretariat would recommend to the opening of the General Assembly next week the creation of a committee to deal only with the Palestine report.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Walter S. Franklin, vice president in charge of traffic for the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, told the Interstate Commerce Commission today that unless it granted the increased freight rates that have been requested by the railroads, on which hearings are now being held, the Pennsylvania would have a net deficit of $95,000,000 in 1948.

A group of Boy Scouts, Girl Scouts and Camp Fire Girls will open ceremonies for United Nations Week at an open air program at Rockefeller Plaza Sunday from 2 to 4 P.M. Dancers in native costume will present a United Nations Folk Dance Festival on the lower plaza.
Although cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange lost part of the early gains yesterday, closing prices were steady, 13 to 30 points net higher.

John Kramer and Frank Farker each lost a set, Dinny Pails of the Australian Davis Cup team was eliminated by Francisco (Pancho) Segura of Ecuador, and Mrs. Nancy E. Wynne Bolton of Australia scored a crushing victory over Mrs. Patricia Todd of California, champion of France, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 1.

An anesthetic called procaine, injected into the human blood stream to relieve the symptoms of certain diseases such as arthritis, which can be reached only by venous routes was described yesterday at the final session of the Congress of Anesthetists in the Hotel McAlpin as a promising tool for medical use.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 11 -- Transfer of manufacture and sale of automotive specialty locks from the Stamford division to a new plant in the vicinity of Roanoke, Va., was announced today by President W. Gibson Carey of Yale Towne Manufacturing Company.

GENEVA, Sept. 11 -- In the final session of its third conference the Food and Agriculture Organization elected today eighteen nations as members of its new Intergovernmental Council and unanimously elected Viscount Bruce of Melbourne as independent chairman.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Department store sales in the week ended Sept. 6 were unchanged from the corresponding week a year ago, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following shows percentage changes from like periods of 1946:

Earle Raymond Gale, 36-year-old former soldier who allegedly cashed five checks in one day while wearing the garb of a priest, was indicted by a Federal grand jury yesterday for transporting the proceeds of the checks, $600, from Cleveland to New York.

The Department of Justice went to judges of the Circuit Court of Appeals yesterday in an effort to stop a proceeding initiated in the Federal District Court by the Aluminum Company of America, which seeks a final judgment declaring that it no longer possesses a monopoly of the aluminum ingot market.

READING, Pa., Sept. 11 (AP) -- Harry Goodheart, 62-year-old harness racing driver, was in Community General Hospital tonight, his condition described as fair after he had been tossed from a sulky during today's Grand Circuit races.

Brooklyn's Football Dodgers, who gave up their great Glenn Dobbs last Monday in a stunning deal defended as a step toward building a stronger over-all team, will make their 1947 debut at Ebbets Field tonight against the mighty Cleveland Browns, All-America Conference champions last year.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Ralph Kiner hit four home runs to tie Johnny Mize of the Giants for the National League leadership at 47-all and spark the Pirates to a double victory, 4 -- 3 and 10 -- 8, over the Braves before 7,010 spectators today at Forbes Field.

Widespread dissension among unlicensed seafarers of the United States liner America on the issue of Communist influence in their labor organization, the National Maritime Union, CIO, was reported here yesterday.

PAWLING, N.Y., Sept. 11 -- The Rev. Dr. Frederick Luther Gamage, founder and headmaster emeritus of the Pawling School here, now the Trinity-Pawling School, a well-known Protestant Episcopal boarding institution, for boys, died yesterday at his home on the campus after an illness of several months.

The teaching of surgery by television was officially endorsed yesterday by the American College of Surgeons, holding its thirty-third annual clinical congress. This action was taken after an experimental program in which seven major operations, performed on the tenth floor of the New York Hospital, were successfully projected on television screens on the fourth floor of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, where the congress is being held.
The banking troubles of John M. Holzworth, 59-year-old lawyer, explorer, writer, engineer and art buyer, bounced along yesterday in two cities.
Evidence to refute charges that the British press is under monoply control is presented by Viscount Camrose in a book, "British Newspapers and Their Controllers," published yesterday.

SANTA CRUZ, Calif., Sept. 11 -- Twenty-four hours before Senator Rooert A. Taft was to open his western speaking tour with two appearances at the California State Bar Convention, Gov. Earl Warren set a precedent for himself today by devoting a part of his address at the same convention to domestic and international affairs.

LIVERPOOL, England, Sept. 11 -- The Labor party candidate, Maj. A.J. Irvine, won the Edgehill division of Liverpool by-election today by a margin of nearly 2,000 votes over his Conservative opponent, J.R. Bevins.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The United Steelworkers of America, CIO, appealed today for an immediate expansion of the country's steel-producing capacity as a necessary preventive of depression and unemployment.

Spurred by the further integration of one of the largest producers of rayon goods, the Textile Distributors Institute will soon launch an advertising campaign in trade and consumer media, it was made known yesterday by Herman Chopak, president.

The stock market pursued yesterday a steady course with fractional changes predominant and major swings in only a few issues. Scattered attempts to further the advance of Wednesday were made at intervals, but they proved too feeble to register results.
BOSTON, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The second place Red Sox split a twinbill with the Indians today and thereby maintained a half-game edge over the Tigers.

Around the time "Anna Lucasta" was getting ready to close a highly prosperous stay of more than two years at the Mansfield last November, Producer Jack Wildberg kept insisting that he would bring back the all-Negro play because it hadn't exhausted its public.
Perhaps as a substitute for his recent plan to redistribute the United States gold reserves, Ernest Bevin has now suggested a revival of Lend-Lease.
ROME, Sept. 11 -- The farm laborers' strike in northern Italy completed its fourth day without any noticeable progress toward a settlement. Negotiations continue in Rome and Milan.

Charles D. Hubbard, at 70 years of age one of the last of the old school of pen-and-ink illustrators, has produced a completely handlettered and illustrated volume entitled "An Old English Village," which will be published Sept. 27 by the Falmouth Publishing House, Portland, Me.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 11 -- The Hudson Valley sister villages of Tarrytown and North Tarrytown were ready today to step into the national spotlight during United Nations Week to be hailed as a community typical of the best in America.

STONY BROOK, L.I., Sept. 11 -- Golden Hill, 8-year-old chestnut gelding owned by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Hale of Greenwich, Conn., retired the Henry H. Dickson Memorial Challenge Troohy presented by Arrigo Righi during the first day of the North Shore Horse Show at the Old Field Club today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In THE TIMES of Sept. 9, in the editorial entitled "A New School York Begins," you correctly and sympthetically allude to the fact that mounting cost of living has cause "rumblings of dissatisfaction amo teachers because their moderate sal gains have shrunk steadily."

For the past couple of weeks Bucky Harris has been reading and hearing about magic figures, involving mathematical combinations that would clinch the pennant for the Yankees. Perhaps the New York pilot was joshing, but he astounded a roomful of experts yesterday when, following his team's split of a twin-bill with the Tigers at the Stadium, he inquired the meaning of all the talk about numbers.

The 17,000-ton New Zealand liner Rangitiki, which was a convoy unit in the famous Atlantic battle in which the converted British merchant cruiser Jervis Bay fought to the death with a German raider to permit the escape of her convoy, arrived at Pier 54, North River, yesterday with 771 passengers.

Most of us who keep out of serious trouble with the law probably give little thought to our prisons and jails until a riot occurs or somebody breaks out. In this state the interest we all should have in penal and related matters of great Importance to society is represented by the Prison Association of New York.

The board of commissioners of the Port of New York Authority, at its first meeting since its summer recess, yesterday authorised steps for the completion of tne New York Airport at Idlewild, for the repair and improvement of La Guardia Airport and for new equipment for its tunnels and bridges.

ATHENS, Sept. 11 -- While Parliament was debating details of the amnesty law for guerrillas today, press comment showed that the amnesty, like the Liberal-Populist coalition itself, is rejected by both the extreme Left and the extreme Right.

A collection of woven or knitted wool fashions from Peck Peck, including a group of Paris imports, was presented at a luncheon fashion show given by the International Wool Secretariat at the Hotel Plaza yesterday. A quality of general wearability combined with modified changes in length and silhouette characterized the showing.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 11 -- Mrs. Ray M. Torgerson of the Cherry Valley club turned in a final round of 38, 39 -- 77 for a three-day score of 234 to win the annual 54-hole medal play championship of the Women's Long Island Golf Association at the Meadow Brook club today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11 -- Minimum initial margin requirements on speculative trades in grain futures were advanced 10 cents a bushel on wheat, corn and barley, 3 cents on oats and 25 cents on soy beans, effective on Saturday, by the directors of the Chicago Board of Trade today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: A baseball game will be played Friday night at the Polo Grounds between the "Broken Wings" (arm amputees) and the "Flat Tires" (leg amputees). It should be patronized liberally, for they are our war casualties.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 11 --The exceedingly low level of industrial production in Germany is retarding the recovery of Europe, Charles A. Saltzman, newly appointed Assistant Secretary of State for Occupied Areas, warned tonight.

Purchasers of burlap bags are showing their resistance to the high prices by short term orders for minimum requirements, it was learned yesterday in the trade. Current prices, it was pointed out, are at an all-time high, with little prospect of any substantial decline in the near future.

Twelve recommendations for the improvement of Franco-American trade relations are emphasized in the report entitled, "Franco-American Economic Relations," drawn up by the Committee for France of the National Foreign Trade Council, and made public by that organization yesterday.

MUNICH, Germany, Sept. 11 -- Military Government officials and German legislators of the Laenderrat (Council of States) will be asked to study a proposal to provide an indemnity for the victims of concentration camps at the rate of ten reichsmarks for each day each individual spent in confinement, according to Dr. Philip Auerbach, Bavarian Minister.

Small Percolator in Big Demand Most popular item sold in the Housewares Fair, which opened on Wednesday at L. Bamberger Co. in Newark, was a small percolator, of which 4,000 were sold in one day. Sales for the first day of the show totaled more than $130,000, according to John C. Williams, president, who said that more than 6,500 telephone orders were received.

MONS, Belgium, Sept. 11 -- Elizabeth Lazarus, 21-year-old French member of the underground Fighters for the Freedom of Israel (Stern group) was sentenced here today to one year's imprisonment for the possession of "letter bombs" of the type sent earlier this year to prominent Britons, including Cabinet Ministers.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Sept. 11 -- Mrs. Marge Becker, the defending champion now playing from the Knickerbocker Country Club, was beaten in the quarter-final round of the women's New Jersey Golf Association match play championship today by Mrs. Sophie Untermeyer of the Hollywood Club, at the twentieth hole at the Ridgewood Country Club.

Again attacking the bipartisan foreign policy of President Truman and "the war-with-Russia hysteria" as leading toward war, Henry A. Wallace declared last night that until he was proved wrong he would work with liberals within the Democratic party to prevent it from committing suicide.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 11 -- In protest against the recent 205 to 136 vote of the Screen Writers Guild in favor of collective royalties for screen writers, F. Hugh Herbert has resigned as secretary of the guild, it was announced today.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission, issued today a supplemental order approving the plan of the Interstate Power Company of Dubuque, Iowa, to issue and sell under competitive bidding new securities as a part of its reorganiztion plan.

LONDON, Sept. 11 -- Recent economic developments of the world have created a grave new cha lenge to the International Monetary Fund and International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, Hugh Dalton, Chancellor of the Exchequer and chairman of both international financial institutions, said here today.

Directors of Sharp Dohme, Inc., yesterday elected John S. Zinsser to be chairman of the board, William L. Dempsey to be president said Dr. William A. Feirer to be executive vice president. Dr. Feirer, formerly vice president in charge of medical research, also was elected a director of the company.

ALBANY, Sept. 11 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey called today for prompt approval of the majority report of the United Nations special committee recommending a partition of Palestine, declaring that it should be carried forward swiftly "to end the tragedy of homeless Jews being shipped against their will to a land of bitter memories."

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Kansas farmers agreed today that there had been no rush to market this year's record wheat crop despite the upward price spiral, but many of them differ on the reasons for holding back grain.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 11 -- Big Jawn Mize blasted his forty-seventh home run of the campaign out of Crosley Field today. Sid Gordon followed an inning later with an explosive burst atop the scoreboard in left center for his tenth round-tripper.

While an uneasy truce prevails in Indonesia awaiting the naming by Australia and Belgium of a third nation to complete the Security Council Commission that will attempt to work out a peaceful solution there, France makes what its High Commissioner in Indo-China describes as a "last offer" to the Viet Nam Republic.
YESTERDAY'S EVENTS Security Council Atomic Energy Commission -- Despite Russian opposition, approved outline of international atomic agency that would own all militarily dangerous ores and plants.

The "Fira Benenson look" emerged from the collection which that gifted and distinguished designer opened in her new salon de couture on the ninth floor of Bonwit Teller yesterday morning. In this day of feminine silhouettes in the couture, Mrs. Benenson has evolved the most feminine.

LONDON, Sept. 11 -- The Grimethorpe miners, key figures of the unofficial coal strike in Yorkshire's coal fields, voted today to end their defiance of the union and Government officials and return to work on Monday. They have been out since Aug. 11.
NEW DELHI, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The first outbreaks of long-feared epidemic disease were reported in the refugee camps of the Punjab today as rioting dwindled in Old Delhi and New Delhi.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Sept. 11 -- The Small Landholders, once the majority party in Hungary and since last week's elections the second strongest, today dropped from its political committee Premier Lajos Dinnyes, Foreign Minister Erno Mihalyfi, Minister of Education Julius Ortutay and Aladar Pomgracz, Under-Secretary to the Premier, as well as others who had appeased the Communists.

The work of fourteen prominent American artists, who for the last year have been engaged in translating varying aspects of Pennsylvania in terms of paint, was shown yesterday at a preview in the Associated American Artists Galleries, 711 Fifth Avenue.

GENEVA, Switzerland, Sept. 11 -- A summary of the International Trade Organization's draft charter, emphasizing changes made in response to United States criticisms of earlier drafts, has been prepared for circulation to interested United States organizations and individuals.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The United States Consulate was stoned without damage, a statue of Ferdinand de Lesseps, Suez Canal builder, pulled down and an attempt made to burn the British Consulate today by crowds of angry Port Said Egyptians protesting against the failure of the Security Council to oust British troops from the Nile Valley.
ROME, Sept. 11 -- Pope Pius urged today that Catholic women take an active part in politics.

To Miss Kimo, owned by William Helis, the man with the big cigar whose horses have been cleaning up in the feature spots at the meeting, went first money in the $7,500 added Fairy Chant Handicap before 18,729 at Aqueduct yesterday.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The 1947 World Series will begin in the Yankee Stadium in New York either Sept. 30 or Oct. 1, depending on the outcome of the close flag race in the National League.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 11 -- The outline of a powerful international atomic agency that would own all militarily dangerous ores and plants was approved today by the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission -- with the full blessing of the United States and the firm opposition of the Soviet Union.

PARIS, Sept. 11 -- The European conference on the Marshall Plan, which was scheduled to hold a final plenary session Monday, will continue for a week or more to rewrite large parts of its report in conformity with the demands laid down by the United States Government.

Thirty-five million persons used the facilities of the United Service Organizations up to Sept. 1, it was reported yesterday. The organization, which will end its activities this year, now has 229 units in the United States, half of them near permanent military and veterans hospitals, and a dozen clubs overseas.

ROME, Sept. 11 -- All Allied troops in Italy will have left the country by Dec. 14 following the coming into effect of the peace treaty on Monday, Lieut. Gen. John C.H. Lee, Allied commander in Italy, announced today. Thereafter 5,000 American and 5,000 British soldiers will garrison the Free Territory of Trieste along with 5,000 Yugoslav troops, in accordance with the treaty.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The Greek economic situation was described today as a continuing problem of too many people per arable acre by a Greek economist, Demetrious Calitsounakis, before the International Statistical Conference.
Nearly 500 members of the Frequency Modulation Association will meet at the Hotel Roosevelt today for their first annual convention. Registration will open at 10 A.M.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 11 -- Business in the Pittsburgh district held about unchanged last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh, Small increases in industrial production and1/2ui trade were offset by the drop in originating shipments.

LION FEUCHTWANGER, who has written such superior novels as "Power" and such inferior ones as "Simone," has never been a subtle or a polished writer. A distinguished German literary exile, he has brought to most of his works a heavy-handed, ponderous thoroughness which seems essentially Teutonic. Other writers produce longer historical novels than his, for bulk is the most popular attribute of such fiction today.
Under changing economic pressures, food prices now are seeking new and different levels, a comparison of the effects of three wars on United States food prices shows.

BERLIN, Sept. 11 -- Alexander Kabanov, head of the agriculture branch of the Soviet Military Administration, announced today the completion of land reform throughout the Soviet zone. At the same time he denounced the Western occupation powers for not having carried out similar measures.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- More than half of the establishments inspected under the Fair Labor Standards Act and the Public Contracts Act in the last year were found to have violated these laws William R. McComb, administrator of these two divisions of the Labor Department, said today.

General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower said yesterday that he would not "be a party to any draft" movement to nominate him for the Presidency. At the same time, however, he refrained from saying he would not accept a nomination if it came to him without any effort on his own part.

ALBANY, Sept. 11 -- Howard I. Russell, director of the American Public Welfare Association, declared today that increased federal assistance for public welfare programs served to stimulate rather than dry up state and local funds.
NANKING, Sept. 11 -- Reports of a new crisis in Sinkiang were discounted by Gen. Chang Chih-chung in a report to the central executive committee of the Kuomintang here this morning.

ARCOLA, N.J., Sept. 11 -- Defying tradition, Gordon S. Park of Glen Ridge, medalist in yesterday's qualifying round, survived the first two rounds of match play today in the twenty-fourth annual invitation golf tournament at the Arcola Country Club.

Eight printed Everglazed chintzes and five printed twills comprise the new series of "Everfast" decorator fabrics introduced yesterday at Altman's. Among both groups are some fresh designs for those who like the crispness of chintz but are tired of stereotyped patterns.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 11 -- A state-wide hunt for Eastern gangsters who are supposed to have "invaded" California today led straight into the very musty files of the New York Police Department -- or possibly the New-York Historical Society.

After twenty-two months of study by engineering and technical experts supplied by more than 100 companies and trade associations, the home-building industry has developed a basic, standardized dwelling design intended to reduce costs "substantially" for the average small-house builder and buyer.
SARANAC INN, N.Y., Sept. 11 (AP) -- Three state officials defended today the state's controversial special local tax law but admitted it needed adjustment.

JERUSALEM, Sept 11 -- Appearing hot and glum, two of the three Zionist mayors, held since Aug. 5 as suspected terrorist sympathizers, were whisked out of the British detention camp at Latrun this afternoon. They accepted their freedom grudgingly, protesting against the continued detention of the third mayor.

Continuation of Federal rent controls beyond their expiration date next February, and a strong Federal home building program, were advocated yesterday by Representative Benjamin J. Rabin, Democrat, of the Bronx.

BOSTON, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Increased railway passenger rates within Massachusetts were in prospect today although it appeared they would not become effective before petitions filed by the railroads were heard by the Public Utilities Commission next month.

The Bankers Trust Company has been appointed paying agent for principal and interest on $16,350,000 of Terminal Bonds, series M, 1% per cent, due serially on June 15, 1948-62, of the Port of New York Authority. The bank also has been appointed registrar for the common stock,- $10 par value, of the Potomac Electric Power Company.

BRANCH RICKEY always has held the theory that high-salaried players became too smug and too satisfied ever to remain good ball players. He has preferred the hungry kind, the hustling kids who are burning with ambition to make good. Of course the sharpshooters will be quick to say that the Mahatma is merely trying to save money.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 11 -- Dr. Veador Leonard, physician and research chemist, who discovered an important new antiseptic, died this morning at the Johns Hopkins Hospital, after an illness of three weeks, at the age of 59.

Reporting on operations for the six months ended on July 31, the National Department Stores Corporation, in its statement to be mailed today to stockholders, announced a net profit of $1,201,894 after Federal and state income taxes and all charges.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Sept. 11 (AP) -- One of the big favorites toppled with a crash today as the United States amateur golf championship field was reduced to four players for the 36-hole semi-final matches tomorrow.

DETROIT, Sept. 11 -- Three psychologists reported to the American Psychological Association today that youths of superior intelligence were better looking, taller and heavier than their less fortunate brothers.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Sept. 11 -- A new racket resulting from the shortage of new automobiles on the market was disclosed today, the Mamaroneck police said, with the arrest of Dominick De Angelis, 23 years old, who gave a Brooklyn address, on a grand larceny charge.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- A twelve-city investigation of high food and clothing costs to be made by a Congressional subcommittee may help efforts to check the soaring cost of living and bring it back to a reasonable level, members of the group said today.

MUNICH, Germany, Sept. 11 -- United States constabulary troops at Passau near the Czech border, reinforcing the German state police, at 3 o'clock this morning rounded up and arrested thirty-six members of a Ukrainian resistance group who had marched into Bavaria from their home territory.

The "biggest sucker set-up" in years was broken up yesterday when detectives raided a two-room suite in the Hotel Marguery, 270 Park Avenue. They seized "educated" dice, marked cards, transparent mirrors, an electric signaling device and a concealed coatsleeve card manipulator.
Omaha, Neb., announced yesterday it would take bids on Sept. 29 on bond issues aggregating $1,486,000, dated Nov. 1 and Dec. 1, 1947, and due Nov. 1 and Dec. 1. 1952.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11 -- The American Federation of Labor reaffirmed today its attitude on the question of unity with the Congress of Industrial Organizations, and William Green, AFL president, said he was frankly not optimistic about achieving amalgamation soon.

The threatened strike of 3,000 Manhattan and Queens bus workers was called off last night after Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora had ruled in favor of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, in its pension dispute with the New York City Omnibus Corporation.
CHICAGO, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:
ABOARD U.S.S. MISSOURI, at See, Sept. 11 -- The Truman family are "trusty shellbacks" after an Equator crossing session with Neptunus Rex, whose domain was invaded by this floating White House.

While the key to world trade and reconstruction lies in increased output, the people of the countries now seeking our aid do not yet realize that under-production is at the base of their difficulties, Wilbert Ward, vice president of the National City Bank, said yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I read with interest Nelson Ho's letter published in your issue of Sept. 1 regarding General Wedemeyer's statement on China. Mr. Ho suffers no inferiority complex in assuming to speak for four hundred and fifty million people.

Two special concerts for children under the age of 9 will be presented this season in Town Hall by the Young People's Concerts Commitee of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society, of which Mrs. Melvin E. Sawin is chairman, it was announced yesterday.
NANKING, Sept. 11 -- A reform platform designed to invigorate the Kuomintang, China's national party, was adopted here today by the Central Executive Committee.

Incident at Nikko Emperor Hirohito, who has been of late (no lese-majeste intended) the imperial guinea pig of experiments in post-war Japan which apparently have been rapidly democratizing him, suddenly reverted the other day to feudalism.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11 -- Wheat futures and the May and July deliveries of corn sold at new crop year high prices in the early trading on the Board of Trade today, but broke violently later on general selling induced by a suggestion by Senator Ralph E. Flanders, Republican, of Vermont that the exchanges should ask for margins of 100 per cent on speculative trades.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I read with interest Nelson Ho's letter published in your issue of Sept. 1 regarding General Wedemeyer's statement on China. Mr. Ho suffers no inferiority complex in assuming to speak for four hundred and fifty million people.

Two special concerts for children under the age of 9 will be presented this season in Town Hall by the Young People's Concerts Commitee of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society, of which Mrs. Melvin E. Sawin is chairman, it was announced yesterday.
NANKING, Sept. 11 -- A reform platform designed to invigorate the Kuomintang, China's national party, was adopted here today by the Central Executive Committee.

In a hearing room supercharged with tension, the Government formally lodged yesterday an amended deportation count against John Santo, international organization director of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, terming him a Communist and as such a subversive and undesirable alien.

Marshall Miles, manager of Joe Louis, signed yesterday for the heavyweight champion of the world to oppose Jersey Joe Walcott in a ten-round fight at Madison Square Garden on Nov. 14. The contract for the bout was entered into with the Twentieth Century Sporting Club.

Sidney A. Kirk, formerly sales manager of the Hotel New Yorker, has been appointed convention sales manager of the Kirkeby Hotels, effective Sept. 15, and will make his headquarters at the Hotel Ambassador in Atlantic City.

BUFFALO, Sept. 11 -- A wage strike by 2,400 carburetor workers in St. Louis will make about 350,000 idle in the automotive industry in "a matter of days," it was reported today at a meeting of the International Executive Board of the 'United Automobile Workers, Congress of Industrial Organizations.

Incident at Nikko Emperor Hirohito, who has been of late (no lese-majeste intended) the imperial guinea pig of experiments in post-war Japan which apparently have been rapidly democratizing him, suddenly reverted the other day to feudalism.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11 -- Wheat futures and the May and July deliveries of corn sold at new crop year high prices in the early trading on the Board of Trade today, but broke violently later on general selling induced by a suggestion by Senator Ralph E. Flanders, Republican, of Vermont that the exchanges should ask for margins of 100 per cent on speculative trades.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- For better ventilation at less cost for traffic tunnels, Ole Singstad of New York and Herbert G. Cruthers of Shokan, N.Y., have developed and patented (No. 2,327,075) an improved ventilating system and type of tunnel construction.

IN his mildly unexpected foreword to John Lardner's new book, "It Beats Working,"* Carl Van Doren says that he is himself no enthusiast for all sports, and neither, it soon becomes apparent, is Mr. Lardner. He masks his latent impulses to idolatry. He looks with a skeptical eye at people who take their exercise flagrantly in public. He marvels at the chicaneries that the public will stand.

ROME, Sept. 12 (UP) -- Diplomatic sources said today that General Lee might become President Truman's representative to the Vatican when he retires. Their comment followed a newspaper report that General Lee would become a religious worker.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 12 -- Pittsburgh's costly eight-day strike, of union railroad employes ended here shortly before midnight today when negotiators for the railroad and the two railroad unions involved reached an agreement which granted a wage increase of 15 cents an hour to the unions.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 12 -- "The Salem Frigate," a novel by John Jennings published in 1946, has been acquired for the screen by Universal-International in a package deal with Maxwell Shane, scenarist, who held screen rights to the property under an optional contract with the author, it was disclosed.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 11 -- The Duquesne Light Company, Pittsburgh, received permission from the Securities and Exchange Commission today to sell at competitive bidding $75,000,000 of thirty-year first mortgage bonds to pay off its 3 1/2 per cent first issue, due June 1, 1965.

STONY BROOK, L. L., Sept. 12 -- Russell Stewart's My Play Boy, aged bay gelding from Albany, gave the defending jumper champion, Sheik of Albrurae from Raymond Lutz' Albrurae Farms it Wilton, Conn., plenty of competition during the second day of the North Shore horse show at the Old Field Club today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Jack Kramer limited Washington to nine singles tonight as the Browns mauled three pitchers for fifteen hits to capture their fifth straight victory, 9 -- 3.

EDINBURGH, Sept. 12 -- The program of Bruno Walter's second concert with the Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra here today contained Schubert's "Unfinished" Symphony and Mahler's "Das Lied von der Erde." Here was the high noonday and the last sunset glow of Viennese romantic music before it sank into the dark night of nationalism.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (U.P.) -- Excerptg from Secretary Harriman's radio speech follow: Most of the food which we are sending abroad is being bought and paid for by our foreign customers, with their own money, or by loans.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 12 -- Dr. Alexander Alison Jr., pastor of the First Presbyterian Church here for thirty years, has disclosed to his congregation from the pulpit that he has an incurable illness but that he wishes to continue in his pastorate for "whatever days remain."

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 12 -- After taking the lead with a four-run rally in the ninth the Dodgers didn't have the stuff to hold it, even with big Ralph Branca becoming their fifth pitcher, and the Cardinals scored an 8-7 triumph under the lights tonight, again reducing Brooklyn's National League lead to four and a half games.
LONDON, Sept 12 -- A general decline was noted today in the stock markets here as a direct result of reports of a hitch in Paris in the plan for American aid.

BUFFALO, Sept. 12 -- Rank and file members of the United Automobile Workers of the Congress of Industrial Organizations are voting by a margin of more than eleven-to-one against a pension plan advocated by their own leaders as part of a new contract with the Ford Motor Company.

A referendum on the proposal to repeal proportional representation seemed assured last night as the deadline for challenging the validity of the referendum petition in the courts neared without any action from those favoring retention of the present system of electing City Councilman."

HOBOKEN, N.J., Sept. 12 -- A few hours after the Court of Errors and Appeals had ruled that he receive a new trial on charges of falsifying his own voting records, John R. Longo, foe for many years of former Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, was severely beaten as he stood on a street corner here this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission, listening to urgent railroad pleas for higher freight rates, was told today that at least one railway system will move soon for another increase in passenger fares.
The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday the suspension Of Charles D. Halsey, an allied member of the exchange and a general partner in the firm, of Laird, Bissel Meeds, for six months.

John Santo, Rumanian-born labor leader, was accused by a Government witness yesterday in deportation proceedings of having been not only an alien Communist but one working within the inner, secret circle of the party engaged in trade-union infiltration.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- A. D. K. Owen, United Nations SecretaryGeneral for Economic Affairs, today praised the work of a U. N. World Statistical Congress. The sessions just ending made advances toward a world statistical system, he said.

FAR HILLS, N. J., Sept. 12 -- Mrs. Edward P. Renner picked as best in show at the annual specialty exhibition of the Dalmatian Club of America today the Roadcoach Kennels' young bitch, Roadcoach Phaeton, nicely marked, a good mover and of pleasing personality.

Commuting rates on most railroads entering this city are going up because the companies have convinced the Interstate Commerce Commission that they\are entitled to more money. The commuter may feel better because of this official sanction, which is lacking in the case of food prices.
GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Sept. 12 -- Strong words on courtship and marriage were spoken here today at the opening sessions of the Catholic Tri-State Congress.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Secretary of Labor Lewis B. Schwellenbach today signed complaints charging that five plants of the Reynolds Metals Company violated the child-labor provisions of the public contracts law during the war years 1942-44.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 12 -- George Killion, president of American President Lines, acted today to provide expanding Pacific trade with a modern fleet of passenger and freight vessels.

ROME, Sept. 12 -- Negotiations in the farm laborers' strike in northern Italy were resumed today under Government auspices. The chances that they would lead to a satisfactory understanding were considered good.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Sept. 12 -- Two experienced tournament players, Mrs. Sophie Untermeyer of the Hollywood Golf Club and Miss Laddie Irwin of the Glen Ridge C.C., won their way into the final round of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association match play championships at the Ridgewood Country Club today.

Good news for steel-hungry Europe was contained in an announcement yesterday by the Maritime Commission that forty-one badly damaged vessels would be sold for scrapping purposes, either to United States citizens or foreign nationals.

A complaint by the American Jewish Congress that Columbia University's employment bureau was illegally requiring applicants to answer questions involving race, religion and nationality has been upheld by the New York State Commission Against Discrimination, the congress announced yesterday.

NANKING, Sept. 12 --Tighter party control over Kuomintang members participating in the Government was voted today by the party's central executive committee. The committee completed action on a platform designed to purge China's dominant political group of lukewarm and corrupt elements.

Further mechanization of freight handling at terminals, besides reducing idle time on turn-arounds and lowering costs per ton in handling, will help to ease present freight car shortages, Samuel M. Gibb, president of the Materials Handling Institute, revealed here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- An end to the steel shortage within two years was predicted, with conditions, by two industry leaders today in testimony before the Senate Small Business subcommittee on steel.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (U.P.) -- Crimes increased 20 per cent during the first six months of 1947 compared with the same period last year, J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, reported tonight.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12 -- Subpoenas for representatives of several meat packing companies to appear before a special grand jury called to investigate alleged price fixing in the food industry have been issued at the request of the Department of Justice, it was learned today.

We believe that New York City, the Port Authority, the flying public and the Navy Department can not conscientiously permit the question of Floyd Bennett Field to be closed short of a satisfactory solution. Civil aviation needs Bennett Field. La. Guardia Airport on each of two recent days of heavy traffic had about 660 plane movements, or double the proper capacity.

When the opening ceremonies of the United Nations General Assembly's second session get under way Tuesday morning, two batteries of television cameras will be trained on the scene. Secretary of State George C. Marshall will be one of the speakers.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12 -- The unique character of UNESCO among the various subsidiaries of the United Nations is strikingly brought out at the meeting of the National Commission being held here this week-end. Less than a year old, little publicized and meagerly financed, UNESCO excites more interest in this country in more unexpected places than any other specialized agency of the U. N.
TOKYO, Sept. 12 -- Japan's economic purge is now "for practical purposes complete." Maj. J. P. Napier of the Supreme Command announced today.

The sharp rise this week of food prices has prompted fresh discussion of a return to price control and a third round of wage increases. In seven days the sensitive food-price index of the Government's Bureau of Labor Statistics rose from 376.6 to 409.4, while the Dun Bradstreet food index advanced from $6.71 to $7.02 in the same period.

MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 12 (AP) -- A violent tropical hurricane with winds above 140 miles an hour near the center began to recurve toward the northwest late today. It took a course which the Weather Bureau said removed all danger to the islands of the Lesser Antilles and Puerto Rico.
GENEVA, Sept. 12 -- The United States and British Commonwealth tariff negotiations have received a new lease on life, authoritative sources said today.

LONG BEACH, Calif., Sept. 12 -- The United States present system of law enforcement is so weak that "legal punishment cannot be considered a major factor in the control of crime," Austin H. MacCormick, New York penologist, told the opening session of the American Prison Association's annual congress of correction today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The United States has demanded the "immediate release" by Yugoslavia of two United States and seven British soldiers seized by Yugoslav authorities in recent weeks in the vicinity of Trieste, the State Department announced today.

A major national shift in production, involving cut-backs , in cheaper metal products lines and an increase of quality grades of heavy metal goods lines, was revealed here yesterday by a group of large plant production executives.

Several cotton textile manufacturers have sold about 5,000,000 yards of print cloth for secondquarter 1948 delivery in the last few days, it was learned yesterday in Worth Street. These sales represent civilian business farther in advance than has ever been transacted in the market, according to trade observers.

A keen interest in things American characterized the approach of the hundred European teachers and Students who participated in the recent Salzburg Seminar in American Civilization, Dr. Margaret Mead, anthropologist and author, declared yesterday.

PARIS, Sept. 12 -- Twelve European nations and Iceland have decided to form a group to study the possibility of a customs union or customs unions, the Foreign Ministry disclosed today. The project has been under consideration at the Marshall Plan Conference for some time and previsions the establishment of a customs union under the projected International Trade Organization Charter.

DENVER, Sept. 11 (UP)-- Gov. Lee Knous told the Boston wool industry today that the West was "tired" of being an "economic vassal of the East" and said the West was ready to take over the industry from "sheep to sweater."
READING, Pa., Sept. 12 (AP) -- Two spills, marked closing of the Grand Circuit races at the Reading Fair today.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: A rather gleeful cartoon in a news-paper long unfriendly to Britain depicts her as washed up, done for, finished. In conversation one hears many references to her parlous state. Her Empire, we are told, is breaking up. Her exports are inadequate.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 12 -- Niles Trammell, president of the National Broadcasting Company, announced today that the NBC network favored immediate adoption of a new code of standards to curb excessive commercialism on the air and to improve programs.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Sept. 12 (AP) -- A pair of Californians Johnny Dawson of Hollywood and Skee Riegel of Monterey Park, today won their way to the final round of the 1947 United States amateur golf championship.

Metropolitan area motorists will welcome the news that Jones Beach parking space is being increased from the seventy-eight acres at which it stood at the opening of the 1947 season to eighty-eight acres. Five acres of this new space were added during the summer. Five more are to be opened soon.

The thirty-second semi-annual Outdoor Art Exhibit in Washington Square area opened yesterday, to continue through Oct. 5. It occupies the south side of the Square, Macdougal Street, and spills over into Thompson and Sullivan Streets.

BERLIN, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The Allied forces "Olympics," which will open tomorrow in the stadium that Hitler built in his heyday to impress his future enemies, promises to be a wide open contest which almost anyone can win.

ROME, Sept. 12 -- Tirana advice, said today that the trial of te Deputies and fourteen others fo an alleged plot to overthrow th Government of Enver Hoxha had threefold urpose. They said tha the aims were: (1) To eliminate the largest possible number of educated Albanians and persons hi genera, who had intellectual means t discredit the present Government.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 12 -- Sami Taha, Palestine's principal Arab labor leader, who was recently involved in an internal Arab political controvesy, was murdered on one of Haifa's main streets tonight. He was shot three times. [Press services described Mr. Taha as a political opponent of Haj Amin el Husseini, exiled Mufti of Jerusalem.]

Trainer Henry McDaniel, who had celebrated his eightieth birthday on Wednesday by saddling a winner that grave some longshot players good reason for dancing in the aisles, went to the rescue of favorite backers at Aqueduct yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Catcher Mike Guerra's wild throw hit Pinch Hitter Ralph Hodgin in the back tonight and allowed Luke Appling to score from third with a tenth-inning run that broke a 4-4 tie and gave the Chicago White Sox a 5-4 triumph over the Philadelphia Athletics before 11,612 fans.
LONDON, Sept. 12 -- The Soviet Union accused Iran of violating the Soviet-Iranian oil agreement, in a broadcast over the Moscow radio today.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES. About the middle of July there was a letter in THE TIMES asking "For a Propaganda, Truce" and quoting some wise, well-chosen words of Lewis W. Douglas. Apparently our more vocal leaders, both political and military, cannot see the wisdom in promoting confidence and allaying fear and hatred, as the papers have been reporting even more hints of United States armed action and "hit first" theories.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The Chicago Cubs slammed out seven extra base hits in sweeping a double-header from the Philadelphia Phillies today, winning the first, 4 to 3, and the second, in Which the Phils made five errors, 7 to 5.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Ralph Kiner, husky Pittsburgh Pirate outfielder, carried his team to a 4-3 victory over the Boston Braves tonight at Forbes Field by lashing out two home runs -- his forty-eighth and forty-ninth of the season.

A Federal loan fund for meritorious students wishing to embark upon a medical career was advocated last night at the colorful convocation ceremonies of the American College of Surgeons in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The proposal was made by Prof. Andrew C. Ivy, internationally known physiologist and vice president of the University of Illinois.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The relations between the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service and state authorities with respect to the adjustment of industrial disputes is one of the first of many problems on which Cyrus S. Ching newly named Government mediation director, has begun to work.

The annual fall convention of the New York Conference of the United Lutheran Synod of New York will open Wednesday at 10 A.M. and continue during the afternoon and evening at St. Peter's Lutheran Church, Lexington Avenue and Fifty-fourth Street.

PARIS, Sept. 12 -- A general offensive against French, foreign policy, and against the United States which was accused of seeking to force the French to open the Spanish frontier, was launched today by the Communists.
Harris County, Tex., announced yesterday that it would receive bids Sept. 23 on $5,250,000 of road and bridge bonds dated Oct. 15, 1947, due Oct. 15 from 1948 to 1977, and callable in ten years.

LONDON, Sept. I2 -- The announcement today that Britain has joined twelve other countries in forming a European customs union study group marks a definite modification of the British Government's attitude toward the matter of United States aid.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12 -- The American Federation of Musicians, American Federation of Labor, may prohibit its members from making new phonograph recordings after December as a result of the Taft-Hartley Law's restrictions on the use of royalties and welfare funds paid to unions.

ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., Sept. 12 (AP) -- A sizzling six-under-par 66 on the University of New Mexico golf course today by Jimmy Demaret of Oaji, Calif., was best in the first round of the $10,000 Albuquerque open.
After nearly a month of lonely operation, plying the waters of the Hudson between New York and Albany devoid of cargo, the little vessels of Trailerships, Inc., began to work yesterday.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Sept. 12 -- Mayor George A. Smock 2d and j three of his colleagues on the Asbury Park City Council -- Roland J. Hines, Joseph H. Ely and Thomas J. Smith -- were indicted today by the Monmouth County grand jury. They were charged with misconduct in office through letting beach-front concession leases without advertising and receiving bids.

VIENNA, Sept. 12 (Reuters) -- British and United States spokesmen declared today that the Soviet Union was trying to obtain a right to negotiate directly with the "weak Austrians" to retain freedom to take whatever they wished from Austria and obtain a perpetual guarantee against expropriation.

Strong upswing in demand for trade lines of paint, coupled with firming of prices and renewed shortages of white pigments and linseed oil supplies, has been noted this week in retail and wholesale trade levels, spokesmen reported here yesterday.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 12 -- The Tamarack Country Club turned its annual three-day memberguest tournament into a fiftyfour-hole medal play affair, which opened today. Both guests and their hosts appeared to welcome the change from the overworked best-ball handicap match play tourney of past years.

The World Trade Corporation is about to submit to the city a definite report and plan to implement its, $270,000,000 proposal of last spring to take over, rehabilitate and operate the city's waterfront facilities under a long-term lease program, Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The Federal Government will accept whatever the City of New York decides about the disposition of Castle Clinton, popularly known as the Aquarium, Julius A. Krug, Secretary of the Interior, has notified the New York City Parks Association.

PARIS, Sept. 12 -- What was described as a compromise between The United States and the European conference on the Marshall plan was practically achieved tonight after long exchanges today between the chief delegates here and their Governments.

The Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo, having hit the bull's eye with one of its season's premieres at the City Center and having come pretty close to doing so with another, offered the third one last night and managed to miss the target altogether.

Cotton futures turned slightly reactionary on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, closing 8 to 13 points net lower than on Thursday. The volume of business diminished from previous sessions and there appeared to be slightly more selling by the South as ginnings increased in the northern sections of the Cotton Belt.

WARSAW, Sept. 12 -- A group of American architects, town planners and housing officials finished a brief tour of Poland today and prepared to leave for home. According to Herman Field of New York, the experts were amazed at "the thoroughness and real brilliance of the Poles' physical planning."

Reports here yesterday indicated the Argentine Government has relaxed controls on the exportation of leather. The move was considered a possible forerunner of similar action on Argentine hides and skins which trade estimates have placed as high as 4,000,000.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 12 -- The Swedish Government is reconsidering its entire economic policy, because of rapidly dwindling gold and foreign exchange reserves, it was learned today. It was indicated that the Government may have to review the $250,000,000 commercial credit granted last year to the Soviet Union and also other credits extended abroad.

MADISON, Wis., Sept. 12 (AP) -- A small glass of orange juice containing radioactive iodine can cure poisonous or toxic goiter, Dr. Saul Hertz of the Harvard Medical School declared today. He addressed more than 500 scientists attending a symposium at the University of Wisconsin on the use of isotopes in biology and medicine.

Twelve men, arrested after detectives raided a "swindlers' paradise" in a suite in the Hotel Marguery, 270 Bark Avenue, on Thursday, were arraigned yesterday in Magistrate's Court on charges ranging from vagrancy to bribery.

ARCOLA, N. J., Sept. 12 -- Ray Torgerson of Cherry Valley, the 1946 winner, moved into the final of the twenty-fourth annual Arcola invitation golf tournament at the Arcola Country Club today when he defeated Joe McBride of the host club in a 21-hole match.

Random notes The Martha's Vineyard striped bass derby is due to get under way on Monday for a month's run, but if the bass are as plentiful there as they have been during the past few weeks no one needs the encouragement of a prize.

Federal Judge John C. Knox eliminated yesterday all but one plan for the recapitalization of the Equitable Office Building Corporation, which has been in reorganization since April 10, 1941. He directed that the remaining plan, a revision of one submitted by the Manufacturers Trust Company and Wertheim Co., be submited for the approval or rejection of stockholders.

With the deposit in Paris next Monday of the treaties with Italy, Hungary, Bulgaria and Rumania, the United States will take the first step toward liquidation of its occupation forces in former enemy countries in Europe. Since Italy was the only one of the four in which we maintained troops, the 15,000 American soldiers there are the only ones who are affected by the treaties.

Scoring almost at will on a devastating succession of groundeating plays, the dynamic Cleveland Browns rolled up eight touchdowns last night at Ebbets Field in routing the Brooklyn Dodgers, 55 to 7. It was a breeze all the way for the 1946 champions of the All-America Football Conference.

TOKYO, Sept. 12 -- Company decentralization will be accomplished by Diet action, the cabinet decided today. A bill, already prepared, will be presented to Parliament instead of being passed by Imperial ordinance.
Better ways of teaching, ways to include parents in school programs and ways to get citizen support for schools are subjects of wide general interest.

LONDON, Sept. 12 -- The importance of purely productive loans, from the standpoint of "healthy international relationships," was emphasized by John J. McCloy, president of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development in presenting the second annual report at a meeting today.

Retail Sales Advance 10% New York and Brooklyn department store sales advanced approximately 10 per cent this week over the corresponding week a year ago, according to estimates yesterday. However, the comparison was with a drop in volume a year ago caused by the beginning of the trucking strike.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 12 -- Britain called on all the United Nations today to turn in reports on their troop manpower as the first step in getting world-wide disarmament under way.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- With increases in most major commodity groups, average primary marked prices increased 0.6 per cent during the week ended last Saturday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, United States Department of Labor.

MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica, Sept. 12 -- Arthur Creech Jones, British Colonial Secretary, has been listening to some plain speaking from British Caribbean political leaders gathered here to formulate proposals for a closer union of these territories.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Nine borax companies were sued for $15,000,000 damages in Federal Court today as having conspired to fix prices, restrain trade and force competitors into bankruptcy.

VIENNA, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The United States, Britain and France lined up solidly today against Russia in the Allied commission on the Austrian peace treaty when the delegates began discussing the application of an Austrian law on German assets in Austria.
Secretary of State Marshall arrived here last night at Pennsylvania Station and went at once to his quarters in the Pennsylvania Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- Many countries in Europe must make basic financial reforms to assure their future welfare, regardless of how much this hurts, in the opinion of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, which today issued its annual report concurrently here and in London.
MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 12 (U.P.) -- Scientists of the University of Minnesota, using a "tame" atom smasher, began experiments today in an attempt to learn what holds matter together.

The public needs and should receive a better understanding of the contest that is going on between two small, well-informed groups over the future role of Government in housing, Dillon S. Myler, Commissioner of the Federal Public Housing Administration, declared yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 12 -- An appeal to countries with an excess of food to help feed the world "quickly and directly" was made today by Mrs. Jeanne Eder, newly elected president of the International Council of Women, as the council closed its first post-war conference.

NEW DELHI, Sept. 12 -- India's oody communal clashes, according to all reports, appear to have iated but cholera epidemics, spreading from the crowded, filthy refugee camps, threaten an additional tremendous loss of life in both India and Pakistan.

New Capital Market The aggregate of $250,000,000 of new securities -- corporate and municipal -- which came to market this week had in general a good reception. Of the $50,000,000 Massachusetts bond issue, all but $13,000,000 was placed by yesterday, and of the $30,000,000 Michigan issue, all but $12,500,000.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 James F.Byrnes, former Secreta of State, it was learned tonig has completed a three-day study the motion picture industry in Hollywood, Calif, primarily to defe the industry against charges th it has been infiltrated by Communists.

The stock market maintained yesterday its irregular course but with emphasis on the downside as the list lost the smattering of buoyancy enjoyed in previous sessions this week. It turned sluggish when the grains experienced heavy profit-taking, although the pace of trading in the commodities remained fast.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Sept. 12 -- Gaines Gwathmey and Mrs. G. R. McGrath of Piping -- Rock shot 41, 37-78 to tie with Mrs. Robert L. Clarkson and E. H. Driggs of Sleepy Hollow for the qualifying medals in the mixed foursomes member-guest tournament at the Piping Rock Club today.

LONDON, Sept. 12 -- Sir Stafford Cripps, President of the Board of Trade, warned today that the Government might start new industries if private manufacturers did not produce better and more export goods.

A proposal that frequency modulation broadcasters meet with James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, in an effort to bring about withdrawal of the union leader's ban on simultaneous duplication on FM of regular network musical programs, was made yesterday by Representative Carroll D. Kearns of Pennsylvania.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 12 -- Prof. S.D. Clark of the University of Toronto told the seventh annual meeting of the Economic History Association at Yale University today that the United States had surpassed Canada in economic growth largely because of the survival of a feudal class system in Canada based upon a close alliance between church and state.

Miss Mcma Paulee once worked for $12 a week in a Portland, Ore., bakery. Now, at 30 years of age, she is a member of the Metropolitan Opera Association, and also goes on concert tours with her accompanisthusband, Dean Holt, flying from city to city in the Holts' private plane.
ALBANY, Sept. 12 -- Delegates to the Northeastern Division meeting of the American Public Welfare Association were informed today that "public welfare is no longer only a depression business."

"The Magic Touch," the farce by Charles Raddock and Charles Sherman, will be withdrawn after tomorrow night's performance at the International Theatre, it was announced yesterday by the producer, John Morris Chanin. The show, which has had a checkered career since it opened on Sept. 3, will omit today's and tomorrow's matinees because of a sparsity of patrons.
BERLIN, Sept. 12 -- The novelist, Theodor Plivier, and Heinrich Mertens, the Mayor of Jena, have mysteriously disappeared from the Soviet occupation zone, it was confirmed today.
Dollar-wise purchasing by consumers held retail food prices steady yesterday after overnight increases, with no prospect of rises today, and caused some wholesale prices to weaken.

BOSTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians dumped the Boston Red Sox into third place by teeing off against Denny Galehouse and Tommy Fine for 17 hits and an 11-6 victory today before 4,855 fans. Babe Ruth was one of the spectators.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Helene Yuhas, formerely employe by the White House and later by the Soviet Embassy, said today that she has been asked to resign as secretary to William L. Clayton, undersecretary of state, because of "outside pressure" but has refused to do so.

Serge Koussevitzky, conductor of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, will direct the Juilliard Orchestra in a special concert on May 9 at Carnegie Hall, it was announced yesterday afternoon by William Schuman, president of the Juilliard School of Music, at the convocation exercises held in the Juilliard Concert Hall.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12 -- With John L. Lewis almost single-handedly resolving the issue, the American Federation of Labor embarked today in effect upon a boycott of the National Labor Relations Board as long as the ruling of its general counsel on non-Communist affidavits stands.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration in its final months in the Far East may be forced to admit that its "no political discrimination in distribution" policy is impossible to carry out in China.

Dr. Herbert V. Evatt, Australia's Minister for External Affairs, yesterday called on delegates to the United Nations General Assembly to cure the world organization's "temporary paralysis" and to establish a new starting point.

Blending their shots perfectly over the entire round, Jim Cullen of the home club and Dr. Sam Anziano of Wheatley Hills won medal honors with a best-ball of 67 in the sixth annual member-quest tourney at the North Hills Golf Club at Douglaston, Queens, yesterday.

Broadcast Measurement Bureau's financial statement for the thirty months from Jan. 1, 1945, to June 30 of the current year, issued yesterday, shows total receipts of $1,413,000, total expenditures of $1,335,000 and total assets of $100,000.

A suspect who had confessed burglary won acquittal in Felony Court yesterday by an indisputable alibi that he was in jail when the crime was committed. The defend ant, Jerry Randazzo, 24 years old, of 222 East Twenty-first Street, told Magistrate Vernon Riddick that the police had beaten him until he confessed.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12 -- The United States National Commission for the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization devoted today, the second day of its three-day meeting here, to study of the 1948 program proposed for adoption at the second UNESCO general conference at Mexico City in November.

PORTSMOUTH, N.H., Sept. 12 -- Declarations that operation of the Taft-Hartley labor law has been retarded by the failure of the National Labor Relations Board as the appropriate Federal agency either to discuss or interpret its provisions were made today by both management and labor at the convention of the New England Council here.
NEW DELHI, Sept. 12 (Reuters) -- Leave has been stopped for all ranks in the Indian Army, with immediate effect, armed forces headquarters announced tonight.

The distribution in Japan of 5,000,000 pounds at foodstuffs, valued at $1,512,000, by LARA (Licensed Agencies for Relief in Asia) has been accomplished without loss, Dr. G. Ernest Bott of Ottawa, first official of the organization to return after eighteen months of relief activities, said yesterday.

Rhea Jackson, soprano, was heard in her first New York recital last night at Town Hall. In a program containing German, French and Italian songs, and arias by Handel, Mozart and Charpentier, the youthful vocalist disclosed a light lyric voice of sweet quality, employed with charm, taste and refinement, but not, as yet, under secure control.

John Kramer stands face to face with the player to whom he last lost a match, Jaroslav Drobny of Czechoslovakia, and Frank Parker confronts John Bromwich for the first time since the ambidextrous Australian crushed him in the deciding match of the 1939 Davis Cup challenge round.

TRENTON, Sept. 12 -- John R. Longo won today a four-year fight for a new trial of charges that he falsified his own election records. The Court of Errors and Appeals voted unanimously to reverse a decision of the Supreme Court.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Sept 12 -- A United Nations General Assembly's special committee agreed today that the transmission of information by colonial powers on the development of self-governing institutions" in territories should be encouraged.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- nator McCarthy, Republican, of sconsin, said today the Congres nal investigation into the nation ie housing shortage already has closed that "more than 700,000 me buyers and builders are ced out of the market."
