As a disunited world struggled to solve post-war complexities, Jews here and abroad prepared to reawaken through faith the hope that their New Year, 5708, starting at sundown tomorrow would be host to a saner community of nations.

SANTA CRUZ, Calif., Sept. 12 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, bidding for support in the Far West for the Republican Presidential nomination, opened his campaign tonight with a speech vigorously upholding the Taft-Hartley Labor Act.
SEATTLE, Sept. 12 (AP) -- A new experimental jet-propelled bomber, the size of a B-29 Superfortress and with sharply sweptback wings and tail surfaces, will begin ground and taxiing tests soon.

ABOARD U.S.S. MISSOURI, At Sea, Sept. 12 -- President Truman, far out at sea on this floating White House but constantly in radio touch with Washington, remains unconvinced of the necessity or feasibility of recalling the Eightieth Congress into a special session to grapple with the problems of European recovery, it was understood authoritatively today.

For a noisy three-quarters of an hour this afternoon the stay-at-home New Yorkers, who are not at beaches or elsewhere, and some hundreds of thousands of dwellers in parts of Brooklyn, Queens, Bronx and over in Jersey can have a sports spectacle for free.
TO THE EDITOR Re R.H.S. Crossman's "TVA's for World Peace": * * * Why should Americans feel a TVA at the Jordan would be a worth-while project and one worthy of their dol-

A new venture in the fields of education and community relations will be started Oct. 1 with the opening of the Center for Human Relations, sponsored jointly at New York University by the School of Education and the Bureau for Intercultural Education.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- The State Department published tonight a White Paper dealing with the United Nations and the problem of Greece to underscore the importance the United States attaches to the Greek situation as it will develop before the United Nations General Assembly.
MINNESOTA and Iowa are our oat-producingest States, together accounting for almost a third of America's annual crop of this grain.
FIVE-YEAR-OLD LARRY and his mother are "playing" getting ready for a party.

ROME, Sept. 13 -- A two-day general strike of Italy's 800,000 steel workers was called today to take effect on Tuesday and Wednesday. The strike will paralyze Italy's heavy industry and automobile plants. Considerable political significance is attached to the strike because the steel workers are what the extreme left-wing parties call the "motorized divisions of the communist revolution."

The bulk of those genuinely "displaced" came to Germany in the summer of 1946, when about 100,000 entered the United States zone alone. There are now in the United States zone about 150,000 Jewish DP's, with another 15,000 in the British zone, including those debarked this week from the Exodus ships.

Stores reported good activity last week, according to a survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Back-to-school promotions peaked business, the report stated, while shoes, lingerie and coats and suit departments were in the lead.

The success or failure of any long-range effort to put Europe on her feet depends to a large extent on what use is made of the rich seams of coal in the Ruhr valley in the British zone of Germany. Before the war, coal dug out of the Ruhr's pits fired the furnaces of many of Europe's homes and factories -- and of Hitler's munitions plants.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13 (AP) -- The Cubs and Phillies ended their seasonal rivalry today, Chicago winning the first game of a doubleheader, 7 to 3, and Philadelphia the second, 3 to 1. In winning the series, 3 games to 1, the Cubs gained a 16-6 edge over the Blue Jays for the season's play.

POETS may scorn the idea that man can make a tree, but for forty years a small group of Government scientists has been working at that very thing. Although they're rightly cautious about predictions, they expect that the next few years will spell success.

Some well informed financial observers, previously strong supporters of the Bretton Woods projects, the Marshall Plan and other means for providing effective economic assistance to Europe, are begining to take a critical view of the current prospects of such methods, it was learned last week.

LOS ANGELES -- California's tourist business this summer showed some signs of contraction from the 1946 post-war splurge, but there was no evidence of any great decline. State boosters say the summer was definitely up to expectations.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 13 -- Stations affiliated with the National Broadcasting Company voted unanimously today to refuse to broadcast crime or mystery shows before 9:30 o'clock at night, New York time. The network's action was designed to minimize the likelihood of such programs being heard by children.

AN anthology falls afoul of a double standard: each piece which it contains ought to be judged in itself; but also, quite independently, the purpose and design of the whole mosaic should be considered. Why were these particular bits put together?

FOR over half a century in France literary war has been waged around the tall, gaunt figure of Andre Gide -- now 78 years old. His novels outraged critics; his criticism outraged novelists; and his ideas outraged both. Many of the younger French writers, though, followed him; many of the best writers of other countries were influenced by him; and the various and variously inspired literary movements claimed him.

Conceding twenty pounds to a topnotch mare proved too difficult a task for Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs' Stymie in the $25,000 added Edge-mere Handicap yesterday at Aqueduct, and at the end of the mile and a furlong the world money-winning champion was second to William Helis' Elpis.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 13 -- Lester B. Pearson, former Canadian Ambassador to Washington, will be elected chairman of the Special Committee on Palestine that is scheduled to be set up by the United Nations General Assembly, authoritative sources disclosed today.

One evening last week in a Midwestern city twenty Boy Scouts stood rigidly at attention. Upon hearing his name called, one of the boys stepped a pace forward, saluted and stood at attention as a bright bronze spread eagle on a fleur-de-lis, with the words "Be Prepared" beneath, was pinned over the left pocket of his khaki shirt.

FAR HILLS, N.J., Sept. 13 -- The Scottish terrier that gained best in show at the big Westchester Kennel Club event last Sunday made it two in a row and six in his career when he took the top award an the fourteenth competition of the Somerset Hills Kennel Club today.

BACK in the roaring Twenties and uncertain Thirties Kansas City was truly "Tom's town" meaning, of course, Thomas J. Pendergast. Big Tom took over the scepter some years earlier from his brother, Alderman Jim Pendergast, who started up the road to affluence and power back in 1881, after backing his judgment on a nag named Climax, which romped home ahead of the field at a fancy price.

LIVERPOOL, England, Sept. 13 -- Liverpool's famous Anglican Cathedral has almost recovered from its war damage. Another of the many stained-glass windows destroyed by bombing, the "Emerald" window in the presbytery behind the Bishop's throne has just been replaced.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 13 (AP) -- The president of the New York State Bar Association today urged the legal profession to adopt the principles of scientific research in order to provide "more efficient and inexpensive" legal service for the public.
SALONIKA, Greece, Sept. 13 -- The Bulgarian Government has informed the United Nations Balkan subcommission that it will not give the subcommission "any cooperation whatsoever."

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Sept. 13 -- Miss Laddie Irwin, always a courageous tournament competitor, returned from the national circuit in a blaze of brilliance today to defeat Mrs. Sophie Untermeyer of the Hollywood Golf Club, 1 up, in the thirty-six-hole final round of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association match-play championship at the Ridgewood club.

The extent to which women are continuing to hold jobs in industry and business, far beyond the number before the war, is told in the report for the "reconversion" year April, 1946, to April, 1947, by the State Industrial Commissioner. A survey by the Labor Department's Division of Women finds that 30.6 per cent of the female population over 14 years old was employed in New York State as of last April.

The tentative efforts that have been made in the United Nations toward reduction of world armaments may seem like putting the cart before the horse. There can be no real disarmament until there is a general feeling of security, which no one can say is present today.

Thoroughly concerned over the consistent decreases in business since early August, retailers last week gave special consideration to wholesale price trends and appeared determined to avoid placing commitments extending beyond few months.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Some day hundreds of thousands of homes may be mass-produced on the assembly line, like automobiles. But that day is not here yet.

TO dispute the oft-stated proposition that the business of the screen is to divert the thoughts and the feelings of people with the blandest theatrical make-believe, we would this time direct your attention to the Italian-made film, "Shoe Shine," which is one of the least "diverting" and yet one of the most engrossing films that we have seen.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 13 -- In this region which had a grandstand seat at the birth of the United Nations, no excitement is evident over the forthcoming General Assembly meeting. The session is attracting less interest than might be expected from an area that cradled the League's successor.

LAST Sunday we glanced at the modern art movement in Cuba, focussing our attention briefly upon a few progressive contemporary artists of Havana whose efforts have succeeded in forming the strong nucleus of a native Cuban school.

The turning point in industrial prices looms as bituminous coal producers and industrial consumers await the outcome of discussions now being held which envisage possible downward price adjustments, industrial spokesmen revealed here yesterday.

Section 9, paragraph (h) of the Taft-Hartley Act, as interpreted by the Labor Board's general counsel, Robert N. Denham, may not be the most preposterous bit of legislation ever enacted by Congress. However, as the proceedings of the AFL Council in Chicago yesterday indicated, it is in the running.

Through a thick fog last Sunday afternoon three ships steamed up the murky Elbe River to dock at Hamburg in the British zone of Germany. They were the Ocean Vigour, the Empire Rival and the Runnymede Park. They carried 4,311 European Jewish refugees.

Completing a full year of manufacturing without governmental restrictions on styles, New York garment manufacturers last week voiced their faith in the current trend which, they said, would be vindicated by large volume purchases at retail as the fall season gets into full swing.

"IF you're imaginative -- well, you seem somehow to be in touch with other worlds besides the one you happen to live in." Thus Owl, one of the characters in this strange fantasy, states the theme of this tale in which five children, spending the Christmas holidays in an old house in England, establish contact with the world of the supernatural, the "other side" of reality.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- The railroads completed before an Interstate Commerce Commission panel today their arguments for a stop-gap 10 per cent freight rate increase. They offered testimony that the need for additional relief became apparent even before they put into effect a 17.6 per cent increase in January.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 13 (AP) -- A strike which made more than 18,000 workers idle and cost enough steel production to build 64,000 automobiles ended today as inter-plant railroad workers in the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation district mills returned to work.

To the Radio Editor: AT the beginning of every radio season there is a "sad saga of sameness" in the radio columns of our newspapers. Every radio editor awakes as though from a sound sleep, and suddenly realizes that the programs for the coming season will be the same as they were last year.

GOOD gardens of the kind planned to be at their peak in one season of the year are hard to find. When such a planting is located on a very small property within the limits of Greater New York, it is doubly interesting.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 13 (AP) -- The New York State Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs today requested President Truman to call "at the earliest possible moment" a special session of Congress to provide temporary aid for Europe under the Marshall Plan.

A CERTAIN air of freshness pervades the large exhibition that became current last week at Wildenstein's -- and this despite the fact that little or nothing essentially new in direction or technical handling marks the canvases and sculptural work assembled by the Federation of Modern Painters and Sculptors.

Higher education in the South has steadily improved during the last half century, until today many Southern colleges and universities equal the best institutions of higher learning found anywhere in the nation. During recent years various conferences, workshops and symposiums have been held in the south to improve the educational systems in that region.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 13 -- Dr. Herbert Evatt, Australia's Minister for External Affairs, announced today that the third member of the special mediation, board to settle the Indonesian dispute would probably be named early next week.

THE helicopter bids fair to come of age this year. It has come far since 1939, when Igor Sikorsky, in the first practical American development of the powered rotary wing, used to scare the derby hats off his engineering associates by gaily lifting out of and dropping down into the parking lot next to his Bridgeport factory in a skeleton machine dangling leather belts and oddly placed propellers.
Most war-damaged port facilities in Europe have been restored to a point where capacity exceeds current shipping, Carl G. Holmquist, engineer, said here yesterday.

A WRITER'S minor works, like his poor ones, are of interest for what they can tell us of his major works, often of their strength, but quite as often of their weakness, of the reasons, that is to say, for which they are not really "major" after all.

THIS little novel introduces a new Canadian writer. It has in it just enough solid merit to make its ultimate failure a matter of regret. Mrs. Wilson's story deals with a young girl's infatuation for an older woman and her final rejection of this woman with the sure knowledge that "Good is as visible as green."

EDWARD J. FLYNN is college educated, a successful lawyer, an urbane gentleman who was an intimate friend, apart from being a political associate, of Franklin D. Roosevelt. He is also a political boss, one of the most successful of modern times.

SAN FRANSISCO SOMETHING new is happening in American life. American youth is apparently beginning to doubt whether this, after all, is the traditional land of opportunity. There may be others. At least, a group of American war veterans has set out for "a new land of opportunity."

ONE of the most brilliant pieces of literary criticism that I have seen in recent years is Charles J. Rolo's beautiful dissection -- and synthesis -- of Aldous Huxley, which appeared in The Atlantic for August. Mr. Rolo's essay is especially satisfying to this department because it seems to me to drive straight to the living core of Huxley's significance as a writer.

Potential building activity in Westchester County involving 1,800 to 2,000 new dwellings by the end of next spring and 2,000 apartment units within the next year is indicated in a survey just completed by the Westchester County Realty Board, Raymond D. Porter, president, announced yesterday.

DETAILED control of the results in color photography is exercised to an extent almost equal to the control possible with black-and-white in a method used by Benno Movin-Hermes of Stockholm, photographer to the royal family, whose exhibition of twenty-four color photographs will open Tuesday at the Architectural League, 115 East Fortieth Street.
ATLANTA, Sept. 13 -- People in this region appear to be growing increasingly pessimistic about the present status and the future of the United Nations.

In a partial concession to those who have been urging vast expansion of the nation's steel-making capacity since the end of the war, the steel industry last week announced the start of a program that will add 2,500,000 net tons to its present basic ingot capacity of 91,241,250 tons.

The FM Association will ask the Federal Communications Commission for a legislative hearing on a proposal to prohibit network agreements with radio stations that prevent the simultaneous broadcast of programs on both standard and frequency modulation outlets.

Food prices to consumers in New York and other cities held steady yesterday at levels rivaling or far exceeding those of the 1920 price inflation. Most retailers saw no hope of checking the upward trend this week unless buyer resistance gains greatly in strength.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 13 -- The newspaper Epoca renewed this evening attacks on THE NEW YORK TIMES that it began a few weeks ago, following a NEW YORK TIMES editorial on Argentina's role at the Inter-American Conference at Rio de Janeiro.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 13 -- The nation's birthplace began today, with a military parade and ceremonies at Independence Hall, a series of patriotic observances which will culminate next Wednesday with the arrival of the Freedom Train.

NO one, as Mr. Brock remarks in his foreword to this happy-go-lucky potpourri, knows just when the limerick was invented. Popularized by the artist Edward Lear, this five-line verse form has since become "one of the favorite playthings alike of metrical experts and unterrified amateurs" -- a whetstone, in short, "upon which scholars have sharpened the knives of their wit and made their learning accomplice before the fact."

Inventory adjustments now being made by New York industrial supply distributors reflect an advanced degree of cooperation between distributors and manufacturers, distributors revealed here yesterday. They said inventories are now in better balance in this distribution field than in others, because manufacturers of hack saws, pumps, precision equipment and machine tool accessories anticipated a large number of the problems and prepared policies to provide maximum cooperation with distributors.

To U.S. and U.N. For Secretary of State George Marshall the pressure of work last week was much like the wartime pressure that had been on Chief of Staff George Marshall when he prepared a major offensive. The Secretary, 66, said that there were not enough hours in the day to do all that had to be done.

THE Heiland Pressmaster is offered by Heiland Research Corporation, Denver 9. as a new type of flash synchronizer for all press-type cameras. It has manual fingertip release, permanent mounting, positive connector arm, Lumenar reflector, screw-lock battery case clamp.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Emphasizing the uncertainty of America's future foreign spending, Representative Robert L. Doughton, Democrat, of North Carolina, raised today a "go slow and be careful" sign ahead of Republican plans to start a new drive to slash individual income taxes by $4,000,000,000 or more.

The transplanted All-Ireland Gaelic football final will be staged at the Polo Grounds this afternoon with Kerry, defending titleholder and winner of sixteen All-Ireland championships, meeting the strong Cavan County team. Mayor William O'Dwyer is expected to throw in the first ball.

In spite of lagging retail volume last week, many buyers were in the New York wholesale market, according to the weekly market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buyers. The setback in retail sales, it was felt widely, was due to the extreme warm spell and the unwillingness of customers to buy other than immediate needs.
PARIS, Sept. 13 -- This week marked a notable, perhaps portentous, development in United States foreign policy.

HAMILTON, Bermuda -- The largest hotel deal in Bermuda's history, involving millions of dollars -- the parties refuse to disclose the actual amount -- has placed three of the country's six major hotel properties under the operational control of the Hilton Hotel Corporation of the United States, and given a decided psychological lift here at a time when a sharp recession of travel in the summer had begun to cause misgivings.

HENRY MORGAN, charter member of the sponsor-joshing cult in radio, has reversed himself and ruled that the public should see more of him. Accordingly, this heretic of radio, hitherto averse to live audiences, appeared this summer on the stage in "The Man Who Came to Dinner," and is going to Hollywood this month to make a movie.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Home runs accounted for every tally today as the Braves defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates, 8 -- 1, before a crowd of 16,396, including 5,675 children.
MOSCOW, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Pravda and other Russian newspapers displayed prominently today Tass News Agency dispatches from abroad commenting on food and living costs in the United States.

WHEN E.M. Forster characterized fantasy as fiction which costs something extra (because it is like a sideshow within a sideshow), he couldn't have had in mind the newest brand of fantasy -- which is more like a sideshow within a sideshow within a sideshow -- or, fiction carried to a third degree.

The 11,000 chemists and chemical engineers who will attend the 112th national meeting of the American Chemical Society, which opens tomorrow and will continue for a week, began to gather here yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD. THE current revival of New York City's perennial campaign to attract motion picture production to the Atlantic seaboard, though it is likely to make little difference in the Hollywood scene, has produced some response here.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 13 -- In a nerve-racking finish, during which Dodgers lost simple fly balls in the sun and Cardinal grounders took weird hops over infielders' heads, the Brooks finally nosed out the world champions, 8 -- 7, today. The end came when Dixie Walker took Erv Dusak's long fly near the right-field wall while two more Redbirds were flying around the bases.

The steady selling that has been going on this summer in the market for foreign dollar bonds had by last week piled up a mass of telltale evidence of how the investment world is reappraising the credit of nations caught in or exposed to the "dollar shortage" epidemic.

LONDON, Sept. 13 -- When the United Nations was established in San Francisco toward the close of the war its birth was greeted in Europe with the same high hopes as in the United States. It was regarded as a means of resolving international disputes amicably and it stood as a symbol of the recognition of the ideal of one world.

AS soon as September arrives gardeners start thinking of planting bulbs. Narcissus, tulips, madonna lilies and a dozen other Kinds are hopefully ordered -- after which confusion descends. Conflicting opinions about dates and depths of plantings cause unnecessary difficulties.

ALTHOUGH Michigan legends about the dashing and handsome Stevens Thomson Mason tend to obscure his real character, he was, in fact, an eminent as well as a romantic figure. He lived fast and dangerously, and made a real contribution to American history, even if he was not one of the foremost leaders of his period.

NOVELIZING the life of a gifted writer seems a curious act of supererogation or parasitism. What distinguishes a writer is his ability to express what he thinks, and observes and feels. How can a second writer, at a distance, do more with the materials of a man's life than the man himself did?

In 3,000 synagogues and temples in this country and in improvised places of worship throughout the world Jews will begin at sunset today observance of Rosh ha-Shanah, the beginning of their New Year, 5708.

Separate and apart from political considerations, income tax reduction is a real necessity. It is not to be expected that business can be long sustained without relief from the present burden of high war taxes. Nor should it be expected that the current price spiral can be wholly broken without tax reduction -- except by a business recession to which failure to reduce taxes will have substantially contributed.
TOKYO, Sept. 13 -- After months of comparative inactivity the Japanese Diet will be recalled into session on Monday to consider some of the most important legislation proposed since the surrender.

A two-story and basement branch store of Bloomingdale Brothers, Inc., will be started this fall in the housing development of the New York Life Insurance Company at Fresh Meadow, midway between Flushing and Jamaica, Queens, James S. Schoff, president of the department store, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Bids for a second block of Alaskan Timber totaling 1,500,000,000 cubic feet will be called for by the United States Forest Service in a few days. This is the second such bid requested recently. The Service says the timber offered in South-east Alaska is enough to operate $35,000,000 pulp mill for 50 years.

NANKING, Sept. 13 -- The Kuomintang movement to tap the assets of wealthy members for the cause of the party and the country bore fruit today. As the session of the Central Executive Committee closed it was announced that a group headed by Dr. T.V. Soong had begun raising a fund for families of Kuomintanng members who had died in fighting Japanese and Communiste.

SGT. ROY MARSHALL'S memory is partially blacked out. When he comes to himself, he is on a subway train. He does not remember getting on the train, nor does he know where he is going. At Columbus Circle he gets out without knowing why and goes into a bar.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 13 -- Dr. William Gillespie, Professor Emeritus of Mathematics at Princeton University since 1939 and member of the faculty for forty-two years before his retirement, died here today at his home, 28 Haslet Avenue, after a long illness.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 13 -- There is a widespread feeling here that the newly defined United States policy toward Iranian sovereignty may have sufficient force to deny oil concessions to the Soviet Union. The Majlis [Parliament] is expected to meet tomorrow to discuss a draft agreement for setting up a Soviet-Iranian oil company.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As the schools in Japan reopen this September, the Japanese boys and girls are resuming classes under acutely distressing but yet improved conditions. In contrast, the young people in the United States should count themselves among the favored few in a world of want and uncertainty.

SANTA CRUZ, Calif., Sept. 13 -- A 30 per cent higher productive effort by an already "tired and sick" British people, plus sale of exports, would enable them to "get what we want," the Lord Chancellor, William A. Jowitt, told members of the California State Bar at the closing session of its annual convention here today.
BERLIN, Sept. 13 -- The United States qualified thirteen men today for the finals tomorrow of

More than 100 foreign students here on the student exchange program were briefed yesterday at Town Hall on what they are to expect on the campuses where they are going this fall. They were urged to orient themselves, join college organizations to enlarge their friendships, and act as interpreters for their respective countries.

THIS fine novel of the American Revolution -- as seen from the Court of Versailles -- is an achievement of the first literary rank. It has intellectual substance, imagination, artistic stature: it makes history come alive.
ATHENS, Sept. 13 (Reuters) -- Deportation of thirty-four Greek officers, decided on before the formation of the new Greek Government, was suspended today by order of the Prime Minister.

With disputes between the great powers even more acute than they were a year ago, the United Nations General Assembly will convene at Flushing Meadow, Queens, on Tuesday amid cautious hopes that it will succeed in reviving confidence in the organization.

FOR the last 150 years the myth of Prussia has moved deeply many of the best German minds. This myth has found its central personality and inspiration in Frederick the Great. Without him there would have been no Prussian greatness; without him Bismarck would not have founded his empire in the Hall of Mirrors in Versailles in January, 1871, or Hitler his empire, sixty-two years later, in the garrison church of Potsdam.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Prices of grains staged a brisk recovery today on the Board of Trade, moving up several cents a bushel in a trade which expanded in volume late in the session. New buying appeared to have been attracted into the pits by the break of the last two sessions, which had carried quotations substantially under their seasonal high marks and dropped July wheat more than 20 cents.
Frank Parker again stands in the final round of the national tennis championship after such tumult and shouting as Forest Hills has not known in years.

ONE hundred and eighty American Youth Hostelers returned last week on the Marine Tiger from a two-month work-and-tour visit to Europe and immediately began planning a return trip next summer. The college students and recent graduates (the average age was 23) visited France, Switzerland, Belgium, Holland, Denmark and Norway.

A dozen more galleries reopened last week with shows of diverse interest. Curt Valentin, returning from Europe, has installed miscellaneous work by European and American artists at the Buchholz Gallery: some familiar, some not previously shown.

SURPLUS PROPERTY -- The Illinois village of Mansfield (population 700) hasn't had a night watchman for a quarter of a century; its jail hasn't seen a prisoner for fifteen years. So, recently the village board sold the jail at auction for $375.

THOUGH set in Florida in the Eighteen Thirties instead of Georgia in the Sixties, a story about a plantation belle who was a bit of a hussy is bound to call up memories. "Caline" (Carolina Nicholas Green) Cohran couldn't love the man she married and loved the man she couldn't marry.
"But pray, you that are a critic, is this play according to your dramatic rules, as you call them?" -- Sir Roger de Coverley.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13 -- Rehabilitation of educational facilities in war-devastated countries, fundamental education, the free flow of information across national boundaries and the reduction of tensions affecting international understanding, should receive top priority in the 1948 program of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, it was recommended today by the United States National Commission for UNESCO.

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Sept. 13 (AP) -- Jimmy Demaret scorched the University of New Mexico golf course with a seven-under-par 65 today to hang up a new competitive record for the second straight day and spread-eagle the field in the $10,000 Albuquerque open tournament.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Sept. 13 (AP) -- President Eduard Benes told the nation tonight that the world situation was "serious, really serious."

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Bespectacled Bill Dietrich, making his first start since July 31, limited his 1946 team-mates -- the Chicago White Sox -- to five hits at Shibe Park today, as 2,739 saw the Philadelphia Athletics keep alive their flickering hopes for a place in the first division by rolling to a 9-2 victory on a sixteen-hit assault against three Sox pitchers.

THE twenty-ninth edition of the O. Henry Awards deserves attention not only out of respect to longevity. It is one of the deplorably few annual collections of the short story -- a form of authorship in which America excels.

JUST a dozen years ago this week in this Review: Harry Elmer Barnes, with the collaboration of Henry David, had finished "The History of Western Civilization" (in two volumes, something over 2,000 pages and nearly a million words) and it represents, to the reviewer, "an impressive individual tour de force and an unusual range of scholarly cooperation."

A seminar for managing editors and news editors will open the second year of Columbia University's American Press Institute on Sept. 22. Twenty-seven newspaper men from nineteen states will attend the sessions.

ATHENS, Sept. 13 (UP) -- Dr. Oswald F. Hedley, director of the American Aid Mission's public health division, said today that a considerable amount of medical supplies in threes warehouses in and near Athens was deteriorating because of inadequate storage facilities and natural aging.

WHEN you consider that Heitor Villa-Lobos, Brazil's best known composer, has written something like a thousand works, give or take a few hundred either way, you wonder why he is not recorded more frequently.

The first "beef" shoot to be held in the Smokies since the war is now over, and by this time the black powder smoke has drifted off and many of the old muzzle-loaders are back on their pegs over the fireplaces of a hundred mountain cabins.

President Truman's Advisor Committee on the Merchant Machine is scheduled to hold a two-day "deliberative meeting" here the week. Indications are that the long-awaited report of the committee will be ready for the President before the end of this year, was learned yesterday.

WARSAW, Poland, Sept. 12 (Delayed) -- Poland's third annual Congress of the Recovered Territories ended today in Stettin. For three days 1,500 delegates representing 5,000,000 Poles who settled in these lands amputated from Germany have discussed the achievements of the last two years and have heard two major political speeches from government leaders.

An intensive drive to increase the number of Salvation Army Rural Service Units, of which 2,300 are operating, was announced yesterday by the national office of the Salvation Army at 120 West Fourteenth Street.

LONDON, Sept. 13 - Warning against the trend toward "totalitarianism" in the policies of Britain's Labor Government, the Liberal party put itself on record today as dissatisfied with the economic program announced by Sir Stafford Cripps.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 13 -- With streets and buildings bedecked with, flags and bunting, store fronts freshly painted, show windows with welcome signs and appropriate displays, Tarrytown and North Tarrytown were all set today for the opening tomorrow of their week-long observance of United Nations Week.

Many philosophers and other astute observers of trends in the civilized world have given warning more than once that man's pace is too fast, that the impulse to do represses the instinct to be, and as a consequence much of the serenity and beauty of life is not realized and bodily ills are increased.
The clinching of the 1947 American League pennant, it may now be authoritatively reported, has become a matter of only a few hours away. In fact, it could even happen before nightfall.
CHICAGO, Sept. 13 (AP) -- With eggs at the highest prices in a generation, the egg industry set out today to "do something" for Mrs. Consumer.

PARIS, Sept. 13 -- France and Italy agreed today to study the possibility of a customs union between the two countries. A declaration announcing the organization of a joint commission for such study was signed at the Quai Orsay today by French Foreign Minister Bidault and Pietro Camilli.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- The Supreme Court was asked by the Department of Justice today to rule that the Federal Government owns the oil-bearing lands off the coast of California. The request made by Attorney General Tom C. Clark would permit continued operation under leases already granted by the State of California.

BOSTON, Sept. 13 -- Mrs. Katharine Dos Passos, 51 years old, was killed and her husband, John Dos Passos, 51 years old, author and playwright, lost his right eye when their automobile crashed into the rear of a parked truck in Wareham, Mass., last night.

FRED F. FINKLEHOFFE, Broadway playwright - producer and, when the spirit moves him, Hollywood scenarist as well, has plans which go beyond the Sept. 29 opening at the Biltmore of Ruth and Augustus Goetz's play, "The Heiress," featuring Wendy Hiller, the British screen star, and Basil Rathbons.

"QUEST FOR SITA" is an adaptation by Maurice Collis of the Sanskrit epic concerning, with ramifications, the abduction of a beautiful woman by a dark angel, whose abode is, like that of the other immortals here considered, a reincarnate world of metamorphosed shapes.

Last week the fourth International Cancer Research Congress met at St. Louis. As in the past, the atmosphere was charged with optimism. But when the record is examined we find no more than the expected promising new approaches.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Members of the House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee, leaving tomorrow for Europe, plan to give "special study" to the problems of American flag line air carriers operating in European, Mediterranean and Near East waters, Representative Leonard W. Hall, Republican, of New York, said yesterday.

STEPHEN SPENDER, that most excellent poet and writer from Great Britain, has come over for his first look. He hasn't yet had much of a chance to do more than merely glance around; what instantly struck him, though, was that the skyscraper was not omnipresent (as he had somehow imagined) and that, rather, there was a wonderful combination of big and little, of old and new.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Sept. 13 (U.P.) -- Veteran weather observers said tonight that the hurricane was one of the worst ever recorded in this area. Ten Navy airmen, and this correspondent, who flew through the center of the storm, can describe it in one word, "terrifying."

To the Drama Editor: LEE STRASBERG'S "Answer to the Riddle of the Theatre" [which appeared on these pages Aug. 31] poses a whole new set of riddles. As a writer interested in the subsidy plan in a very practical way (it was my contract with Mr. Herd which was rejected by the Dramatists' Guild), I'd like to raise a few questions regarding Mr. Strasberg's arguments.

NO haphazard globe-trotter, Bailey Willis traveled through most of this country and much of the world before he went to Patagonia. As geologist and mining engineer he explored the Northwest in search of coal for the then unfinished Northern Pacific Railroad.

HOLLYWOOD. VERY quietly, and with no intention, apparently, of making a huzzah movie of it all, Columbia Studios and Producer John Haggott are putting Hollywood's first minority report for the poor Indian before the cameras.

CRESTWOOD, N.Y., Sept. 13 -- The two medalist teams who also figured in last year's final -- Al Curcinelli with Fred Pagano of Winged Foot, the defenders, and Pete Inglis with Willie Turnesa, British amateur champion, of Knollwood, 1946 runners-up, who tied in the qualifying round with best-balls of 66 -- reached the semifinals of Leewood Golf Club's annual member-guest tournament today.

TO THE EDITOR: BECAUSE, wnen I was a young, unknown writer, Mr. J.B. Priestley was one of my literary gods, and because, when I was no longer young and unknown, he continued to be one of my greatest delights, it hurts me considerably to say, in answer to his article, "A Briton's Faith in Britain's Future," "a sentimental lot of damned nonsense!"
THE Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo, with all its premieres out of the way, enters its second and last week at the City Center today.
Paul E. Fitzpatrick. chairman of the Democratic State Committee, charged last night that Governor Dewey and the Republican-controlled Eightieth Congress both had adopted a reactionary program.

STARS -- Do iron, calcium, nickel, zinc and other elements occur in exactly the same proportion on the earth and in the sun and other stars? Dr. Jesse L. Greenstein of the University of Chicago has obtained evidence that there are differences.

Harking back for more than a quarter of a century, the Bayside Yacht Club yesterday returned to the competition of the Yacht Racing Association of Liong Island Sound by holding a regatta that started the next to last week-end of the championship season.

LONG BEACH, Calif., Sept. 13 -- The ancient Anglo-Saxon tradition under which courts impose sentences on convicted criminals must be changed if modern advances in penology are to be realized, the annual Congress of Correction of the American Prison Association was told today.

ASTRONOMERS are able to rate stars by their brilliancy. But baseball fans cannot measure their stars by any set formula. There are much too many intangibles involved. Babe Ruth was a great star. He had color and he had performance.

After a rather poor start the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange recovered yesterday from the early low marks and closed 10 points higher to 4 points lower than on Friday. Strength was most pronounced in the near months.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 13 -- Sal Sava and Saul Lantzis of Fenway registered a best-ball 69 today to assume the lead after two rounds in the 54-hole medal play member-guest golf tournament at the Tamarack Country Club. Their performance gave the new leaders a 36-hole total of 140.

THERE is a certain, "queen play" that seems very difficult, when you see it in a published bridge hand and that looks as if it would rarely occur in play, making it hardly worth while learning. Yet an opportunity to make such a play comes up every few months, and somehow or other the players who have the opportunity seem to rise to the occasion quite often.

AFTER an elaborate piece of statistical detective work, the Bureau of War Records of the National Jewish Welfare Board has concluded that approximately 550,000 Jewish men and women served in the armed forces of the United States during World War II.

IOWA CITY, Iowa, Sept. 13 -- As the result of the attack made last May on a Jewish resident here, a former State University of Iowa student, who dropped out of school last August, has been barred from re-entering the university.

Since Vincent J. Schaefer, General Electric engineer, first produced snow artificially in November, 1946, similar experiments have been or are to be conducted in Chile, Mexico, Cuba, South Africa, Australia and Hawaii. In this country, tests will be made in Louisiana, Washington, Oregon, Arizona, California, Texas, Illinois, Oklahoma, New Mexico, Missouri, Iowa and Nebraska.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Sept. 13 Howard W. Maxwell, a former vice president of the Atlas Portland Cement Company and a vice president of the First National Bank of Glen Cove, died here today at Maxwellton, his home. He had suffered a heart attack this morning.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 13 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Rams scored two touchdowns in quick succession in the second period today and added another in the third to win a National Football League exhibition game from the Detroit Lions, 21 to 0.

Interest in security markets was subordinated last week to concern over higher prices for commodities. With short crops and an extraordinary foreign demand, the huge Government export of grains is blamed for the skyrocketing prices that are driving foodstuffs to new high levels.

THE question whether certain foreign governments' stamps honoring Franklin D. Roosevelt should receive recognition in future editions of Scott's American Postage Stamp Catalogue was decided last week by Gordon Harmer, president of Scott Publications, Inc., publishers of this "encyclopedia of philately."

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 13 -- The fight against the veto will start in the United Nations General Assembly with an outright challenge to the Security Council's power to reject applications for membership in the world organization, it was learned today.

OTTAWA, Sept. 13 -- Louis St. Laurent, Minister of External Affairs, who will lead the Canadian delegation at the United Nations General Assembly, has presented to his fellow countrymen what majority opinion in the press has considered a frank and fair picture of the progress, or lack of progress, that has been made to date in building a new world order.

CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 13 -- The Doge led them home in the Quaker City Handicap at Garden State Park today. The Pentagon Stable's 5-year-old, testing his speed against seven others, including the highly regarded Blue Yonder, scored decisively in the $15,000 added event, beating the lightly held Alexis by a length and a half.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 13 -- Frank Bates Fairbanks, president of the Horix Manufacturing Company, for the last ten years, died here this morning at his home. His age was 56.

ON BOARD U.S.S. MISSOURI, at Sea, Sept. 13 -- This temporary White House, now half way back to the United States from Rio de Janeiro, ploughed through choppy waters tonight. As closely as meteorlogical science can predict, this ship, with President Truman aboard, will cut through the wake of the current tropical hurricane within a day or two.

THIRTY years of the lyric poetry of Robert Hillyer, who won the Pulitzer Prize in 1934 for his "Collected Verse," have been brought together under a hope-giving title all too rare in this decade. The ear of the contemporary poet hears most readily a broken music, yet he acknowledges in his rough and nervous rhythms the perfection from which he likes to deviate.

ONE of the most amusing and light-hearted contributions to the expanding "Roosevelt story" to come off the presses to date is by the self-styled "Irish cop" who, as chief of the Secret Service White House detail, was the personal bodyguard of Franklin D. Roosevelt from the beginning of the war until his death at Warm Springs in April, 1945.

PARIS. The childish hat worn straight or on the back of the head dies with the frock of little-girl length. Intimately allied, as they should be, with the new grace and dignity of clothes, hats thrust forward to shadow the brow, though they may not lie upon it. Large, soft berets, tipped to one side, are frankly profile hats.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Sept. 13 -- The fog-bound Pebble Beach links heralded a new national amateur golf champion today when Robert (Skee) Riegel defeated a fellow-Californian, Johnny Dawson, by 2 and 1, in the thirty-six-hole final.

ABINGDON, Va. HAVING an empty opera house on its hands for a few moments, the Barter Theatre here reached into the hat and pulled out the Pulitzer Prize committee's favorite rabbit. Not only did it get "Harvey," but in a package deal it got "Harvey's" producer.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- John L. Lewis' stand against signing an affidavit stating that he is not a Communist may have important repercussions for the labor movement and for the carrying-out of the new Taft-Hartley Labor Relations Act of 1947.

MR. BRINIG'S entertaining new novel is another of his skillful arrangements of people, pulse and problems. Its portrait of the beautiful Helen Hemple Albertson, who almost too late discovers that a touch of grey matter is infinitely more to be concerned about than a touch of grey hair, should send a shock of recognition through the more sensitive representatives of middle-aged feminine vanity.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 13 -- Faith in the ability of this country to improve increasingly the standard of living for all its people was declared today to be essential for a sound national approach on the problems arising from the development of atomic power for industrial purposes.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial of Sept. 9 regarding Mr. Gromyko and the atom is discouraging indeed. But, as you say, Mr. Gromyko has at least cleared the air. He has made it perfectly clear that Russia's rulers do not want effective international control of atomic energy, and that no amount of patience, discussion or wheedling is going to make them change their minds in the foreseeable future.

DONCASTER, England, Sept. 13 -- Sayajirao, who cost the Gaekwar of Baroda a cool $117,600 as a yearling, paid back a fat installment on that investment today when he scored an impressive victory in the St. Leger Stakes, historic English classic for 3-year-olds.

FOR a few pages Mr. Stoll's novel promises romantic India with vivid patches of local color. But the story is mere ornamentation for a continuous tirade against his countrymen's nervous habit of imperialism. Mr. Stoll's indignation against British rule in India may be slightly out of step with today's news, but it has the intensity of an eternal flame.

ROME. A FEW days after my arrival in New York I had supper in a pizzeria at the corner of Second Avenue and Sixtieth Street, opposite the massive iron structure of the Queensboro Bridge and the smoky blue haze of the East River.

STONY BROOK, L.I., Sept. 13 -- Golden Hill, the 8-year-old chestnut gelding owned by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Hale of Greenwich, Conn., retained his conformation hunter championship with a total of 53 1/2 points in the North Shore horse show which ended at the Old field Club today.

HAMMONDSPORT. ON the hills above New York's Finger Lakes people are preparing for the festive time of year -- the gathering of the grapes. Above the waters of Canandaigua, Keuka, Cayuga, Seneca and Chautauqua, the shears of the pickers will be busy until the end of October, cutting the ripe clusters from the vines.

The New York Mercantile Exchange in downtown New York is the world's largest butter and egg market. In its two-story trading room dealers gather daily at 10:15 A.M. for the fifteen-minute "butter call" or sales period. Last week the 200 traders, who handle 4,000,000 tubs of butter a year, watched prices on the quotation blackboard mount rapidly to their highest level since the end of OPA.

The price of food is probably uppermost in American minds this week-end. Other prices, also, are too high by previously existing standards -- including other people's wages, salaries and profits. There are some real scarcities, notably and tragically in housing. This is the extent of the American economic problem.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The debarkation, with physical violence, of refugees, including women and children, by noted British regiments of the Eighth Air-Borne Division and the Sherwood Foresters is a tale which future generations of Britishers will regard with shame and which history will record as the symptom of the moral crisis of our era.

BUENOS AIRBS, Sept. 13 -- Brig. Gen. Juan Filomerio Velazco, strong-arm police chief who was ousted the day President Truman declared the United States-Argentine estrangement ended, returned to public office yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 13 -- Down 10 points at the half, the Chicago Bears stormed back after the rest period and conquered the Philadelphia Eagles, 13 -- 10, in an exhibition contest before 61,000 shirt-sleeved fans at Franklin Field today.

MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 13 -- A mighty tropical hurricane with winds exceeding 140 miles per hour pushed steadily through the South Atlantic on a course between west northwest and northwest tonight. It was centered about 800 miles east-southeast of Miami.

The surface complacency of the private electric light and power industry, in the face of sharp controversy with public power proponents since the early Thirties, is about to be replaced by a new attitude, which is best symbolized in the adage that the best defense is a strong offense.
The Columbia and Princeton football teams, who will not meet each other during the regular season, engaged in an informal scrimmage at Baker Field yesterday morning.

PUT out the four stars this morning for "1960? Jimmy Cricket!" With the American Broadcasting Company's musical documentary last Monday evening the woebegone kilocycles received a shot in the arm the like of which they have not known for many a day.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 - Food prices may go even higher, according to a survey prepared for the special Congressional investigation into living costs and issued today.

JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Dr. Hendrik Johannes van der Bijl, South Africa's foremost industrialist, believes that American ideas and products will play an ever greater part in the Union's economic development.
IT might be said with fair assurance now that "as food goes, so goes the business situation." Some observers might wish to amend this by substituting the phrase, "so goes the world."
ARCOLA, N.J., Sept. 13 -- The jinx that has laid so many golfing medalists low in match-play competition failed to operate against Gordon Park today.

BANANAS were extremely scarce during the war, usually unobtainable. Now they're back in pre-war quantities, but so greedy have we become for the soft, yellow tropical fruit that even current shipments are not enough to satisfy us. Bananas for top should be sliced only just before serving; otherwise they will darken upon exposure to air.)

TEHERAN, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Premier Ahmed Ghavam added to the confusion over the Soviet-Iranian oil situation tonight by being quoted as saying that he might submit an "unsigned" agreement with Russia for approval by Parliament.

At the University of Wisconsin a group of leaders in many scientific disciplines concluded a four day symposium yesterday on the use of radioactive isotopes in biology and medicine. Among the topics they discussed was the use of the radioisotopes in the study of plant metabolism and photosynthesis, application of tracer research in medicine, the use of radioisotopes in cancer, and many other subjects covering a vast range of investigations.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 13 -- An unexpected surge of communal passion arising from a feeling of insecurity when the country was quickly divided has forced India and Pakistan into an exchange of populations involving 4,000,000 or more persons "in a matter of weeks," Pandit Jawarharlal Nehru, Prime Minister of the Dominion of India, told a press conference tonight.

Two hundred Turkish merchant seamen will arrive here early this week aboard the Turkish liner Bakir to man the first four of ten merchant vessels recently purchased by their Government from the United States. The Bakir is due here on Tuesday, after calling at Baltimore, Md.

ADD to the groaning shelf of psycho-pathology Peter Packer's first novel, which seeks to delve into the gropings of an adolescent's febrile mind. The basic situation, that of a broken war marriage and the child of that union, a girl of 11 whose emotional make-up is seriously scarred by it, is eminently sound.

MANY years ago a Scottish medical man, Dr. Clouston, a mad-doctor as as they call him there, or what we should call an asylum physician (the most eminent one in Scotland) visited this country, and said something that has remained in my memory ever since.

PARIS, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Rabbi Baruch Korff of New York fasted today for the seventh day since he was arrested in an alleged plot to bombard London from the air with leaflets bearing a Stern Band promise of retaliation for British treatment of the Exodus 1947 Jews.

Rosa Sandra and Norman Atkins, winners of the audience vote in last spring's "Stairway to Stardom" contest, appeared late yesterday afternoon in the joint Town Hall recital which was their prize. Between those who came to hear the soprano and those who came for the baritone there was a fair-sized and enthusiastic audience in attendance.
ATLANTA, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Paul Porter, last Federal price-boss under OPA, locked gloomily today at America's economic future, and said the nation would be lucky if it escaped "bust."

Thomas Mann, the great German-born author who is now an American citizen, gave a shipboard interview last week after returning from a European trip. He said restoration of "absolute" free enterprise and the capitalistic system in Europe as it existed in the nineteenth century is no longer possible.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13 -- John L. Lewis, whose uncompromising stand is temporarily controlling the destinies of the American Federation of Labor under the Taft-Hartley law, has served notice on his colleagues that he intends to fight for his position.

PARIS, Sept. 13 -- A French proposal designed to meet United States objections to the program of the European conference on the Marshall plan was discussed tonight by the conference's Executive Committee.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Sept. 13 -- With two days of the Catholic Tri-State Congress past, 1,500 delegates today turned their attention toward the colorful pontifical high mass that will be celebrated Sunday morning by Edward Cardinal Mooney of Detroit, in the 5,500-seat auditorium at Grand Rapids.
CANTON, N.Y., Sept. 13 (AP) -- The General Assembly of the Universalist Church of America went on record today against compulsory military training, which was termed "a denial of individual rights."

JUST how serious is the danger of a substantial further rise in prices ? The economy of the United States is plainly operating at capacity and has been for the last twelve months. It can increase output only as plant is enlarged or improved, as methods of management improve, or as the efficiency of labor rises.

WHEN people say to an architect: "We don't want a modern house," chances are a hundred to one that they don't know what they're talking about. It was this conjecture that prompted the editors of Progressive Architecture to compile a volume, modestly titled "Homes," which will be published tomorrow.

There are, presumably, botanists who can identify all the asters and the goldenrods, and they should be having a field day now. There are about 250 species of asters, with many varieties in the different species, and there are at least 125 species of goldenrod, not to mention the varieties.
Department store sales by reserve districts, as reported by the Federal Reserve Board, are listed in the following table, which gives percentage comparisons with a year ago:
WITH the opening of the scholastic season last week, there came announcements from, three local institutions offering study courses on the motion picture medium, both functional and theoretical.

JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 13 -- Although campaign activity by candidates seeking the Senatorial seat of the late Theodore G. Bilbo is presently in the doldrums, there is a strong feeling here that Representative John E. Rankin will soon enliven the race along the traditional line of white supremacy.

FOR those who have not outgrown their love of fairy tales here is a behind-the-scenes report of Cinderella's ball. Teddy, who might be any small boy, arrives by one of those hocuspocuses of fantasy at the palace early in the afternoon, finding the royal household in the throes of last-minute preparations which strongly resemble those pre-party hours in any American family.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 13 -- The coming session of the United Nations General Assembly has stirred little excitement in this region. There has been almost no public comment about it. This does not mean, however, a general lack of interest in the U.N. itself.

THE National Council of State Garden Clubs will hold a policy-forming session at the Hotel Pennsylvania tomorrow. Plans will be made for the first meeting of American and Canadian garden clubs in Montreal on Oct. 15 and 16.

PORTSMOUTH, N.H., Sept. 13 -- A recession lasting some months will occur in 1948, with prices falling, the convention here of the New England Council was told today by Jacob Baker, former advisor to the Federal Government, and similar counsel now to private industries and to the Council.

LONDON, Sept. 13 -- A buying rush by British housewives to stock tip on textiles, homewares and other items before the Government plans to divert goods from the home to foreign markets was under way throughout Britain today.

EAST HADDAM, Conn. -- The magnificent, gadget-loaded estate which the late William Gillette, old-time Shakespearean actor and the theatre's outstanding Sherlock Holmes, established near here along the Connecticut River, has become since the end of the war one of the most entertaining objectives for New England-bound motorists following the Boston Post Road.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept 13 -- Detectives from Scotland Yard, secret police from Russia, members of the Saudi Arabian Royal Bodyguard and New York City patrolmen will help the United Nation's own security force to protect the General Assembly session, opening Tuesday at Flushing Meadow Park.

ROME, Sept. 13 -- When Communist leader Palmiro Togliatti, speaking in Modena last Sunday, threatened to use "30,000 wellarmed partisans" to overthrow the government of Premier Alcide de Gasperi, most Italians were alarmed but not particularly astonished.

THE rising number of highway accidents attributed to obscured vision and poor driver visibility is causing increasing concern among safety officials. An analysis offered by the National Safety Council emphasizes that one out of every five fatal mishaps is due to the inability of the driver to see the road -- and the dangers -- ahead.

BOSTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Dom DiMaggio's eighth-inning homer off relief pitcher Allen Gettel today gave the Red Sox a 3 -- 2 victory over the Indians as a 15,908 crowd paid tribute to war crippled Si Rosenthal, former Boston American League outfielder.

ROBERT SMITH waxes pretty rhapsodic in his "Baseball," which he further identifies as "A historical narrative of the game, the men who have played it, and its place in American life." A fan first and a historian next, Mr. Smith is a direct lineal descendant of the gentleman who said that Waterloo was won on the cricket fields of Eton.

Papers have been served on three high Netherlands officials in connection with a suit for $3,084,211 damages by the Isbrandtsen Company, Inc., steamship operators of 26 Broadway, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- The German High Command at one time contemplated a simultaneous invasion of Great Britain and the Soviet Union in its grand scheme for world mastery, according to captured documents published today by the Navy Department.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 13 -- Senator Ralph E. Flanders of Vermont proposed today that Great Britain be asked to supply the United States with iron ore from the newly discovered deposits on Labrador under "some form of reverse lendlease" in return for this country's financial aid to Britain.
BOSTON, Sept. 13 -- The general attitude of New England toward the United Nations can perhaps best be described as one of hope tinged with increasing pessimism.

The inflationary spiral has made another turn. Spurred by shortages of food and most manufactured goods, the present upward thrust is broader and more pronounced than the others in recent years. As usual, it has brought forth protests from consumers, and many are demanding that steps be taken by Government authorities to stop the upward price movement.

PARIS, Sept 13 -- The Communist party Central Committee called today for a popular front coalition of the left political groups to beat former President de Gaulle's French People's Rally in the local elections in October.

SAN FRANCISCO. SINCE 1851 this city has been lapping up its grand opera with as much relish as visiting gourmets devour crab and abalone at Fisherman's Wharf. Its own San Francisco Opera Association, founded in 1923 with Gaetano Merola as general director, opens its silver anniversary season next Tuesday with Mr. Merola still its guiding genius.

THE theme of this novel is, in Mr. Dogbolt's hands, classic; by a lesser writer it would be simply standard: the reluctant male pursued by a relentless matron. More specifically, a 4-F but attractive librarian with a social conscience finds himself the quarry of the young, impatient wife of his aged doctor.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- General of the Armies John J. Pershing observed his eighty-seventh birthday quietly today at the Army's Walter Reed General Hospital, where he has been living for several years.
OMAHA, Sept. 13 -- The United Nations is approaching the status of a negative quantity in the thinking of the Middle West.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13 (AP) -- A new synthetic plastic employed as an electric wire insulator in airplanes has been used successfully to replace normal membranes in brain surgery, three Boston neurosurgeons reported this week.

On the basis of company experience and current statistics of the United States Department of Commerce, C.G. Wigton, president of the Wigton-Abbott Corporation, nationally known building concern of Plainfield, N.J., finds costs of building leveling off, with little chance of an early decline.

For the first time since the end of the war civilian students will predominate in the freshman class of Columbia College, according to William A. Hance, assistant to Harry J. Carman, dean of the college.

KNOWING the well-established roving tendencies of Englishmen, one should not be surprised to find three such pioneers who covered the United States from south to north, hitting through the entire Texan area. The unique, dramatic feature of such a westward-ho pilgrimage is that the three sailors, Ingram, Browne, and Twide, made this journey in 1568.

THE New York City Symphony might well have folded its programs and passed away under the stress of added expenses, had it not been for a $10,000 gift from Local 802, American Federation of Musicians, AFL.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 13 -- In a Senate debate last night, Dr. Jorge Eliecer Gaitan, Liberal party leader, attacked the Government with the charge that quantities of arms, tear gas and bombs had been received secretly by the police force from the United States military attaehe in Bogota.
Tarrytown, in the well-known Slec Hollow section of Westchester County, is experiencing a revival of home - building activity which is attracting many new residents.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 13 -- W.G. Holloway Jr. and Mrs. V.D. Crisp of the Cedar Creek Club eliminated Mrs. Robert L. Clarkson and E.H. Driggs, Sleepy Hollow, tournament co - medalists, 1 up, today and advanced to the semi-finals of the Piping Rock mixed foursomes invitational golf tournament.

THIS novel opens shortly after the war, on an unnamed British dock where the merchant steamer Francis Hall is being readied to sail for Valparaiso. It is on the rain-drenched waterfront -- with its drabs, its thieves, its filthy pubs -- that two of the main characters, Stronach the Bosun and Mulligan, "rejected by land and sea alike," first appear.

LONDON. NORMALLY, there is no slack time in the London theatres to correspond with the New York summer season because, normally, we do not have the summer. This year, however, the hot weather went on and on and London reacted as New York reacts.

While the All-American Football Conference continues its championship competition with three games this week, the National League teams will play a final round of exhibition contests, topped by the meeting of the New York Giants and the Los Angeles Rams at the Polo Grounds Wednesday night for the benefit of the Hearst Disabled Veterans' Fund and three service charities.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 13 -- Partition of Palestine into independent Arab and Jewish states was urged today by eight American judges and lawyers as the best way to end the "festering" situation" in the Holy Land.

BUFFALO, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Auto Workers, Congress of Industrial Organizations, declared today that the automobile industry was "an equally guilty partner with the steel industry in a conspiracy of planned scarcity in America."

DENVER, Sept. 13 -- Although few Rocky Mountain residents can tell you precisely what Tuesday's U.N. General Assembly at Flushing Meadow is all about, it is incorrect to assume that the region has no interest in the United Nations.

Tighter control of American export licensing, both to buttress the Marshall plan and to eliminate illegal selling of individual export licenses, was foreshadowed by developments last week. The trend was also evident in the consideration being given by Washington to specific export licensing of shipments to Russia.
DALLAS, Sept. 13 -- What United Nations General Assembly?

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Orban (Spec) Sanders ran and passed the New York Yankees to four touchdowns and a 30-14 All-America Football Conference victory last night over the Los Angeles Dons before a record crowd of 82,675, a new high for a regular season professional game.

"HE was, surely, the most splendid and amazing boy who ever kindled youth in this land. He DID kindle youth; and who can wonder that the writer of such poems should carry the youth of his time to reform the art of his age?"

To the Screen Editor: In the Aug. 31 issue of THE TIMES there were two articles on the movies. One, in the magazine section, by Samuel Goldwyn, stated "we will welcome British films so that we may know the world as we want the world to know us."

THE General Assembly meets this week at Flushing Meadows in an atmosphere which is more and more plainly that of a crisis. The cause of the crisis which the U.N. faces is generally assumed to be the long and progressive deterioration in the relations of the United States and the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (U.P.) -- Vice Admiral W.W. Smith, chairman of the United States Maritime Commission, said tonight that the agency's authority to sell, operate and charter surplus cargo vessels will expire before the Marshall plan goes into effect unless Congress extends the present program.

TORONTO -- Canadians turn to their most lavish superlatives to describe the vacation and travel season of 1947's summer. From the Maritime Provinces to Vancouver, it was the biggest and the best season ever enjoyed, and the United States dollar exchange achieved thereby was welcome.

TOKYO, Sept. 13 -- Suehiro Nishio, chief secretary both of Japan's Cabinet and Japan's Socialist party, stole a press conference from his chief today with the assertion that Socialist Prime Minister Tetsu Katayama was the man best suited to head Japan's delegation to the peace conference.

LONDON. SIR LAURENCE OLIVIER'S production of "Hamlet" finally has been taken off the secrecy shelf, at least to the point that a limited number of newspaper observers were recently allowed on the lot to take a look around.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 13 -- Thousands of Arab workers formed a funeral procession in Haifa today for Sami Taha, 33-year-old labor leader, whose assassination last night has caused uneasiness in Arab political circles.
