Separation Center, sternly headed: "Subject: Indebtedness." With visions of a courtmartial and a stay at Leaven-worth, he read further, to wit:

BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 13 -- Widespread belief that the United States will soon lower the gold content of the dollar is the principal factor underlying the Swiss National Bank's decision this week to end gold sales, authoritative sources said today.

A FEW months ago I read "The Little Magazine," a pretty solemn historical work resulting from the collaboration of three scholars -- Frederick J. Hoffman, Charles Allen and Carolyn F. Ulrich -- on what had always been regarded as a frivolous subject.

LILIES-OF-THE-VALLEY blossom faithfully year after year on the gross neglect which is their lot in many gardens. We delight in them, when they are in bloom, but our attentions are usually confined to picking the dainty, sweet-scented bells in May and June so we may enjoy their beauty and fragrance at close range.

PAUL BROWN is very much like the Man Who Built a Better Mousetrap. He had such phenomenal success as football coach at Massillon High that Ohio State beckoned him. Then he had such phenomenal success with the Buckeyes that Arthur McBride, the owner of the Cleveland Browns, offered him the portfolio as the boss of his professional team in the All-America Conference.

Success of the plans being worked out in Washington for increasing the supply of Ruhr coal mines may have an interesting and not-unimportant effect on the problem of German occupation. For that outcome might bring the French occupation zone into cooperation with the American and British zones, which have been merged economically. Such a turn would increase the prospects for making Germany, outside of the Russian zone, a self-supporting economic entity.

Secretary of State Marshall conferred all day yesterday with sixty fellow delegates, alternates and advisers to set this country's course in the General Assembly of the United Nations, which opens Tuesday at Flushing Meadow, Queens.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- The specter of price control fluttered mustily over the nation's capital this week, stirred by the most alarming rise in the cost of living since the end of restrictions last fall.

ACCORDING to Russell Hill, our German policy, having been formulated when the Nazis were still capable of winning battles, was primarily designed "to make sure that Germany would never again be strong enough . . . to unleash a third world war."

Dr. James Conant's little book, "On Understanding Science," has made a profound impression on officials of colleges and universities. Harvard is to institute a course of popular lectures on science for liberal arts students -- lectures that Dr. Conant will deliver -- and Yale will do the same.
LONDON, Sept. 13 -- Grimethorpe Colliery where South Yorkshire miners started on Aug. 11 one of the most damaging strikes in Britain's history has become a symbol.

Operating deficits of the eighty-nine member voluntary hospitals of the United Hospital Fund totaled $4,500,000 in 1946, it was announced yesterday. Roy E. Larsen, president of the Fund, said this was two-and-a-half times the deficit for 1945.

Horticulturist, Arnold Arboretum ATINGE of red can be seen here and there among the branches of the trees and shrubs along the highways. Fall colors, the glory of the eastern part of North America and a few high-altitude areas in the west, will soon be here.

"LONELY CRUSADE" is a novel of fear, of the fear ever present in the mind of a Negro living in a white man's America. It is a fear that in the case of Lee Gordon, Mr. Himes' protagonist, so preys on his mind and emotions that his actions become unaccountable, even to himself.

KEARNEY, N.J., Sept. 13 -- An eight-state alarm was issued tonight by the police here for John Preston Jr., missing 11-year-old son of a local truck driver. The boy is believed to have been kidnapped yesterday while playing near his home.
PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 13 (AP) -- D.A. Rosenbaum's 2-year-old Reborn and 3-year-old Lady Phara captured $7,500 races today at Narragansett Park.
A nation-wide National Guard recruiting campaign will start on Tuesday, the anniversary of the induction of National Guard units into Federal service in 1940.

A BURGEONING enterprise on the American industrial scene -- one that was only a toddler a few years ago but today employs several thousand persons -- is microfilming. It has won its varsity letter in traditional business annals, even having its own little joke which goes approximately as follows: Question -- How does the future look for microfilming?

REPORTS from the field now underline what has been only suggested before -- that "Allegro," the new Richard Rodgers-Oscar Hammerstein 2d composition, is another departure from the conventional form of the musical comedy.

After a week of doggedly combing Brooklyn taverns, detectives located two youths yesterday and charged them with killing Edward O'Connor, a salesman for the Grosset Dunlop Publishing Company. Mr. O'Connor, 30 years old, was shot when he unwittingly balked a hold-up at Felzmann's Restaurant in South Brooklyn early last Sunday morning.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- While the Harriman committee to determine the economic capacity of the United States to aid in the reconstruction of Europe's economy awaits the completed draft of that Continent's requirements, other problems encountered in formulating a Marshall plan satisfactory to Congress are being studied elsewhere in the Government.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- The ghost of a third party has not quite been laid at Democratic National Headquarters here, but the more optimistic party workers believe that the threat has disappeared.

Autumn home buying on Long Island appears to have started early, according to brokers and builders in that area. With some projects reporting sales averaging one and two dwellings a day during August, the brokers noted an upward trend in purchases during the first two weeks of September.

A NEW system for firing flash lamps was announced last week at the season's first meeting of the New York section of the technical division of the Photographic Society of America. Known as the battery-capacitor source, the new photoflash power supply, as described by Paul A. Marsal and William H. Fritz of the National Carbon Company, uses a small battery to charge an electrolytic condenser, which then serves as a temporary reservoir of electrical energy.

LONDON, Sept. 13 -- Word was received here today of the death in Florence, Italy, on Thursday of Mrs. George Keppel, famous society figure during the reign of King Edward VII. She was the daughter of Admiral Sir William Edmonstone and a sister of Sir Archibald Edmonstone.

NEW DELHI, Sept. 13 -- In India today blood flows oftener than rain falls. No man, woman or child is safe to go where he pleases in this land where primeval savagery has been let loose by religious passion.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Sept. 13 -- With eight days of their twelve-day training period completed, troops from the metropolitan area now at Camp Smith prepared today to greet a large number of relatives and friends at camp tomorrow.

LONDON, Sept. 13 (Reuters) -- Arsenal retained the lead in the English Football League's first division today but lost its 100 per cent victory record when it was held to a 0-0 draw by Preston North End.

Flushing Meadow was almost ready last week for the delegates to the second regular session of the United Nations General Assembly this Tuesday. In the Assembly Hall two extra rows of delegates' seats have been added and 2,000 simultaneous interpretation sets of earphones have been installed.

Global starvation and want and domestic depression can be prevented by creating the atmosphere necessary for increased productivity, according to a survey released over the week-end by the American Management Association. Undertaken in preparation for AMA's national conference of several thousand industrial relations executives in New York Oct. 2 and 3, the survey showed most companies consider as essential to creating the desired atmosphere:

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 14 (AP) -- The battle for last place ended with Pittsburgh back in the National League cellar today as the Philadelphia Phils dumped the Pirates in both ends of a double-header, 7 to 3 and 9 to 7.

Both employers and unions in this state have been following a "go slow" policy in the first ten weeks under the Taft-Hartley Law, Arthur S. Meyer, chairman of the State Mediation Board, reported yesterday.

Confronted with an "invasion" of a horde of young hoodlums, the merchants of West Thirty-fourth Street have found it necessary to seek the cooperation of the police in solving a juvenile delinquency problem of their own. The boys causing the trouble are believed to be attracted to the area by its concentration of stores and by the thousands of people on the streets from whom they can beg, earn or steal money.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Who are the warmongers? Those who (as did I in my letter to THE TIMES of Sept. 3) urge American suppport of the majority report of the United Nations Special Committee of Palestine or those who (as did Khab Totah in his letter to THE TIMES of Sept. 10) threaten war if the Assembly of the United Nations dares to accept the partition, program of its committee?

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 14 -- On a cloud-etched day, with breeze and waters alive, eighty-five craft were under sail today in the regatta of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club, the last one to be held of the championship list this side of Larchmont.

Department store net profits in the first six months of the 1947 fiscal year, which began Jan. 31, dropped to 3.1 per cent of sales, less than half the figure attained during the first half of 1946, the Controllers' Congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Association reported over the week-end.

ROME, Sept. 14 -- Before 100,000 Communists who shouted "Death to Truman!" Italy's Russian-trained Communist boss, Palmiro Togliatti, denounced the United States today as a "world dictatorship," trying to "spread another war."

Following is the first of five articles by the United States' wartime Ambassador to London on his mission there. They are taken from his book "Letter From Grosvenor Square," which will be published soon by Houghton Mifflin Company.

Senator Robert F. Wagner issued yesterday a statement praising the majority report of the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine as "an equitable and practical solution of this tragic problem."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (U.P.) -- The Civil Aeronautics Administrator, T. P. Wright, forecast today greater regularity in airline schedules and increased safety in landings this winter through, use of instrument landing systems at a large number of airports.

To the Long Island Association we are indebted for the information that East Hampton, one of the island's most colorful historic villages, will reach the 300th anniversary of its founding next spring -- 1948 -- and will not have to wait until 1949 for that event, as many histories would indicate.

Week Ended Sept. 12, 1947 Those foreign exchanges which recently have been the center of interest by reason of their wide price swings -- the pound sterling, the Canadian free dollar and the Swiss free franc -- moved irregularly in last week's trading. There was no significance in this reversal except that the necessary adjustments imposed a drying up of buyers' interest and a narrowing of quotations.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 14 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey received an ovation from capacity crowds tonight at the first Eastern States Exposition since the war as he came to Massachusetts for the first time since the 1944 political campaign.

BOSTON, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Rain washed out the Boston Red Sox-Chicago White Sox double-header today while the teams were in a 1-to-1 tie after seven and a half innings of the opener. As a result, the two clubs will play twin bills tomorrow and Tuesday.

Increased consumer resistance and stronger demands for a return of Federal controls on food prices developed yesterday as city officials joined housewives and wage earners in the search for a solution to the problem of inflated living costs.

New York must not spend on capital projects in the calendar year 1948 more than $106,000,000 of new money chargeable against its constitutional debt limit, Mayor O'Dwyer declared yesterday in his annual message to the City Planning Commission.

NANKING, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Gen. Liu Po-cheng, Communist raider, his arms vastly replenished by conquest, is reported to be roaming the north bank of the Yangtze River about fifty miles from Nanking. The Government has imposed a curfew on Nanking suburbs and on river traffic.

The Police Department won an easy victory yesterday afternoon in the first annual track and field game for city employes at the Triborough Stadium on Randall's Island. Scoring 150 points, the police were trailed by the Fire Department with 50, the Board of Transportation with 11, the Magistrate's Courts, 10, and the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity with 9.

PASSAU, Germany, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Despite heavily reinforced patrols on both sides of the German-Austrian border, armed and uniformed men claiming to be Ukrainian fugitives from communism are continuing to slip into the American occupation zone of Germany, United States Army officials said today.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 14 -- Police and firemen put down a riot in the Fairfield County Jail here this afternoon after a two-hour battle with fourteen inmates who had barricaded themselves in a smoking room on the second floor of the west wing cell block.

None of the dialogue of "Life With Mother," the long-heralded equel to the famous "Life With father," has been written yet, but you have the assurance of the authors, Howard Lindsay and Russel Crouse, that it will be on paper pretty soon.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial favoring a special session cites the 120 days necessary to pass the British loan. Was not this delay helpful to impress the British with the acute need to put their house in order?

KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 14, (Reuters) -- Afridi tribesmen of the northwest frontier who threatened "revenge everywhere" for treatment of Moslems in East Punjab were today told by Mohammed Ali Jinnah, Governor General of Pakistan, to abandon any idea of retaliation.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14 -- A nationwide program to help relieve the shortage of nurses and to improve nursing care for the American people was voted today by the board of directors of the American Nurses Association, representing 153,000 registered nurses.

FOR fifty years Andre Gide has been one of the most admired and influential of French writers. The prolific author of fifty volumes of verse, drama, fiction, essays and literary criticism, he is a man whose subtle intellect, whose technical dexterity and whose bold defiance of conventional standards have made him the acknowledged dean of French letters.

WOODS HOLE, Mass., Sept. 14 -- The ketch Atlantis returned here last night after an eight-week exploration of the mid-Atlantic mountain ridge. Dr. W. Maurice Ewing of Columbia Unversity, who headed the scientific party, termed the expedition "highly successful."

BALTIMORE, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Trygve Lie, Secretary-General of the United Nations, said today that the failure to conclude peace treaties hampered the United Nations and delayed world economic recovery.

Facing new patterns of world trade in which Germany and Japan have all but disappeared from international commerce and Great Britain is fighting for survival, the United States will probably be a major seller of manufactured goods to the rest of the globe for many years to come.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Blanked 1 to 0 by Warren Spahn's nine-hit pitching in the opener, the Chicago Cubs came back to stop the Boston Braves, 6-1, and split a double-header before 35,022 fans today.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 14 -- Take it away Brooklyn! and when the penant is flying in Flatbush, don't forget the Giants were in there swinging for you all the time.

Cavan rallied to defeat Kerry, 17 -- 13, in the All-Ireland Gaelic football championship final at the Polo Grounds yesterday after sixty minutes of furious action, which might be termed legalized homcide. It was the first time in history that the title was decided on other than Irish soil and the crowd of 35,000 persons, including Mayor William O'Dwyer, an old Mayo man, seemed to enjoy the proceedings.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (U.P.) -- The Federal Trade Commission today notified the General Milk Company, Inc., New York, to dispose of its stock in foreign milk-manufacturing companies on penalty of losing its immunity from the Federal anti-trust laws.

MOBILE, Ala., Sept. 14 -- The first ship belonging to India to dock here since that country became an independent state arrived Friday with a mixed skirt-clad Hindu and Moslem crew and still flying the British flag.

Napoleon is quoted as having once said that "the happiest inspiration in battle often is a record of the past." In the present unhappy state of a world that appears so often to be guided by a counsel of despair, that might not be a bad dictum to follow. It is not necessary to go back very far.

BERLIN, Sept. 14 (AP) -- A well-balanced French team won the mythical championship of the Allied forces "Olympics" today with the United States second as track and field stars from the armed forces of eight nations bettered ten of last year's meet records.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The general index of basic commodity prices based on the August, 1939, level rose from 312.6 on Sept. 5 to 322.6 on Sept. 12, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. The following; lists daily index numbers and actual spot market prices:

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Sept. 14 (AP) -- Jimmy Demaret blew up after three record rounds and Lloyd Mangrum rolled home with a fourth sub-par card to capture $2,000 first money today in the Albuquerque Open golf tournament. Mangrum, Tarn O'Shanter pro from Chicago, finished with a 67, which with earlier cards of 69, 66 and 66 put him three blows to the good at 268.

When first frost has deepened the bloom on juniper berries and the last page of summer's book is slowly closing comes the time when the country man takes a day off and lines himself a bee tree. For the benefit of the uninitiated it should be explained that each year swarms of domesticated bees leave their hives behind barns and woodsheds and seek homes in trees in the woods.

The largest number of insertions in newspapers and nations magazines in its history have been scheduled from now until the end of the year by National Pressure Cooker Company, Eau Claire, Wis., it was announced over the week end.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14 -- The upward movement in the grain markets which had been under way for about six weeks came to an abrupt halt late last week as the result of heavy profit-taking sales. However, the downward movement did not get under way until after wheat had advanced 62% to 69% cents a bushel; corn 61% to 68 cents, and oats 32% to 38% cents from the low on July 29.

Beginning tomorrow, when the second regular session of the General Assembly of the United Nations opens at Flushing Meadow, New York will be the center of the great dispute on the fate of the world. In London in November the Foreign Ministers plan to resume the stalled negotiations for a European peace.

Peter Bourne, author of "Drums of Destiny," out today, is becoming one of the publishing world's mysteries. This is not a first novel by a young man, but rather a work that took ten years to produce while its author wrote prolifically in a vastly different field.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept 14 (AP) -- The Buffalo Bills scored their second All-America Conference victory in three starts today, downing the Chicago Rockets, 28 -- 20, before 33,648 spectators, a local pro football record turnout.

Fractional horsepower AC and DC electric motors were among the first items listed among new governmental surplus offerings in the New York area, Carl P. Malmstrom, regional director of the War Assets Administration, disclosed over the week-end.

NANKING, Sept. 14 -- The Chinese Foreign Ministry made public today the text of a statement handed to Lieut. Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer shortly after the President's investigator arrived in Nanking last month. The statement, which defended the Government's efforts to speed reconstruction amid internal strife and strained Sino-Soviet relations, was released to coincide with General Wedemeyer's scheduled return to Washington.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 14 -- Presenting his new Cabinet to the Majlis [Parliament], Premier Ahmad Ghavam declared today that while the Iranian Government wanted mutual friendly relations with all powers, it would not permit interference in the country's internal affairs.

Realizing that it takes more than a frame of pretty chintz to do justice to the picture window, the multiple window and the window wall, designers of drapery fabrics have been directing their efforts toward new weaves and new types of prints to perform an architectural rather than a merely decorative role.

LONDON, Sept. 14 -- Arthur Horner, Communist secretary of the National Union of Mineworkers, accused the British press today of "inciting" and "exaggerating" Britain's economic crisis. He also charged that "the national press" in Britain was "responsible for the loss of half a million tons of coal in south Yorkshire."

DETROIT, Sept. 14 -- With less than a tenth of the membership in attendance, the rank and file of Local 600 of the United Automobile Workers, Congress of Industrial Organizations, alternately booed and cheered today a proposal to include a jointly financed pension plan in a new agreement with the Ford Motor Company.
Selma M. Andrews has been named director of Hotpoint Institute, appliance research and test center and use-value training headquarters, for Hotpoint, Inc., a General Electric subsidiary.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: A North American Newspaper Alliance dispatch, appearing in a recent edition of THE TIMES, reports that 100 German scientists "who helped forge Adolph Hitler's war machine" are working for the Army Air Forces at Wright and Patterson airfields on supersonics, guided missile design and propulsion, nuclear physics, turbojets and high speed parachutes.

DARIEN, Conn., Sept. 14 -- Giralda's Zenia, a 4-year-old German shepherd from Mrs. M. Hartley Dodge's Giralda Farms of Madison, N.J., achieved her first big victory today when she took best-in-show at the twelfth Ox Ridge Kennel Club fixture at the Ox Ridge Hunt Club.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 14 -- The celebration of United Nations Week planned by Tarrytown and North Tarrytown, chosen as America's model community for the national observance, got under way today with special church services and an afternoon ceremony at the Washington Irving Stadium overlooking the Hudson River.

Eight out of ten American housekeepers serve pickles at least once weekly and two out of ten once daily, according to a survey just made by the Home Makers Guild of America, a consumer research organization. More than half the users, 54 per cent, put up some pickles at home, while the balance, 41 per cent, always purchase them.

NEWARK, N. J., Monday, Sept. 15 -- Fred Walter Smigelski, 14 years old, of 800 Thirteenth Avenue, this city, confessed late last night that he kidnapped and murdered John Preston Jr., 11, son of a Kearny truck driver, S. K. McKee, New Jersey Chief of the Federal Bureau of Investigatiori, announced here.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 14 -- Rabbi Morris S. Lazaron, in his Rosh ha-Shanah sermon tonight at the Madison Avenue Temple here, pleaded for a return to religion and for support of the Homeland rather than the Jewish State. In discussing the Palestine crisis, Rabbi Lazaron denounced "Zionist extremist hypocrisy, unscrupulous propaganda and exploitation of our brothers' misery."

JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 14 -- The possibility that many Mississippi voters will turn away from any candidate who bids for the Senatorial seat of the late Theodore G. Bilbo by emulating Mr. Bilbo's campaign billingsgate on the subject of "white supremacy" appears to be growing stronger daily.

Labor and its relation to the problems of the American shipping industry will be discussed at the twenty-first annual convention of the Propeller Club of the United States and the American Merchant Marine Conference, to be held jointly in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel on Oct. 15 to 17, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- Saying that expenditures of the Republican National Committee had exceeded income so that there was a deficit of $204,000 in its operations from January 1 to August 31, Carroll Reece, chairman of the committee, announced yesterday that Walter E. Hope, National Finance Chairman, had started a campaign to raise additional funds.

The Rev. Dr. Arthur Lee Kinsolving, rector of Trinity Church, Princeton, N.J., will become rector of St. James' Protestant Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue at Seventy-first Street, on Nov. 1. He succeeds the Rev. Dr. Horace W. B. Donegan, suffragen bishop-elect of the New York Protestant Episcopal diocese, who will be conconsecrated Oct. 28 in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Sept. 14 -- Responsibilities of Catholic laity regarding the dissemination of Catholic teachings and view-points provided the theme for the session today of the Catholic Tri-State Congress that will continue here through Wednesday.

MUNICH, Germany, Sept. 14 -- In an atmosphere taut with recognition of the possible consequences of their action, members of the state committee of the Social Democratic party of Bavaria this afternoon precipitated the long-predicted political crisis by voting to dissolve the coalition government in which they had participated with, the Christian Social Union since January of this year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- Five distinguished civilians from widely separated fields will begin tomorrow an inquiry designed to find the answer of security for the United States in an age of warfare based on atomic power and guided missiles carrying destruction almost beyond the imagination of the present day.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 14 -- "Born Yesterday," Garson Kanin's comedy, which has been playing on Broadway since February, 1946, has been purchased by Columbia, as a screen vehicle for Rita Hayworth, for $100,000 down and subsequent payments over a term of years.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 14 -- Putting on a splendid exhibition of team play, Mexico's poloists rode into the final round of the national open championship tournament today by halting Mike Phipps' Meadow Brook four, 8-5, on International Field of the Meadow Brook Club.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 14--The United States must tighten its belt buckle or reduce its grain exports which have caused soaring food prices because of Government purchasing methods that, in turn, encouraged market speculation, Chicago grain and feed-malt manufacturer declared here today.

ABIT of ould sod was transplanted from Dublin's Croke Park to New York's Polo Grounds yesterday as the All-Ireland final in Gaelic football was played before some 35,000 transplanted Hibernians. It was the finest outpouring of the sons of Erin since the last St. Patrick's Day parade.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 14 -- Financial and diplomatic circles in Switzerland believe that the United States, British and French Governments have virtually abandoned their objective of drying up the sources of Nazi financial power in Switzerland.

PARIS, Sept. 14 -- Italy, reduced in size and faced with a formidable reparations debt, will rejoin the family of nations tomorrow with formal deposit here of the ratifications of the peace treaty affecting her.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In his letter published Sept. 9, Martin Wolfson takes issue with the method of giving economics exams in high school. He contends that emphasis should be laid on contemporary controversial economic problems such as the Marshall Plan, the Taft-Hartley Labor Control Law, etc.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 14 -- Troops protecting the convoys of refugees now moving across India by the hundreds of thousands have had several brushes with armed mobs, according to military reports collated today in the Government House "War Room" here.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP) -- American colleges and universities move into the thick of the greatest enrollment crush in their history today, hopeful but by no means positive that their drastically expanded emergency facilities can handle the load.

Joe Van Blerek Jr. won the around-Manhattan Island motorboat race yesterday. He set a new record of just thirty-nine minutes. The Long Island manufacturer, 36 years old, won a $1,000 bond and the Harwood Bowl, boating's newest trophy.

Invitations are being sent out to all delegates to the forthcoming United Nations General Assembly meeting here to attend a special solemn high mass for the success of the meeting at St. Patrick's Cathedral next Sunday, it was announced yesterday at the cathedral.

West Indian Home Rule India breaks away from Britain, Indonesia tries to shake itself loose from Holland -- from all directions come reports of demands for independence, yearnings for autonomy, petitions for home rule in some form or other from territories subject in greater or lesser degree to authority exerted from points beyond their borders.

Forty French originals now at Henri Bendel feature such highlights as shoulders fashioned without padding, gracefully full skirts or slim versions with peg-like fullness at the hips. A new silhouette from Balenciaga sheathes the figure to below the hips and the flares out in a flounce.

EDINBURGH, Sept. 14 -- The Edinburgh Festival ended last night with the performance of "Le Nozze di Figaro" by the Glyndebourne Opera and a repeat of yesterday afternoon's concert of the Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra, under Bruno Walter.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 14 -- Heads of the three networks competing with the National Broadcasting Company took sharp reception today to NBC's new ban on the broadcast of crime and mystery shows before 9:30 o'clock at night, New York time.

HAVANA, Sept. 14 -- Additional equipment was reported today to have arrived here for groups said to be preparing a revolutionary expedition to Santa Domingo. There seems little doubt that planes purchased in the United States are being brought here as well as other material considered necessary for an invasion of the Dominican Republic.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 14 -- The board of directors of the Air Force Association approved tonight a resolution denouncing as "criminally negligent" the reductions in United States air power and air research imposed by Congressional appropriations.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Detroit pounded Washington's pitchers for thirty-one hits today sweeping a double-header, 16 -- 6 and 8 -- 4. The Tigers compiled twenty hits in the opener as Vic Wertz contributed a home run triple, double and single, scored five times and batted across four runs.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Sept. 14 -- The Merchant Marine Veterans Association of the United States went on record today at the closing session of its fifth annual convention in favor of making the Merchant Marine a part of the new national defense set-up with a status equal to that of the Army, Navy and Air Forces under an "Under-secretary of Merchant Marine."

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 14 (AP)--Scoring once through the air and once on the ground, the Green Bay Packers staved off a last quarter rally by the Boston Yanks to whip the easterners, 14--10, in an exhibition game between National Football League rivals at State Fair Park today before 17,895 fans.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 14 -- President Truman probably will be asked within a few days to recommend a United States loan to construct the $65,000,000 world capitol of the United Nations, it was learned today.

With buyers in the wholesale markets in greater numbers last week, business activity increased, although warm weather created a lull in retail trade, according to the reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 14 (AP) -- The Athletics battled the Indians to a 4-to-4 tie in the second game of a double-header halted at the end of nine innings by the Pennsylvania Sunday curfew law today after winning the first game, 11 to 9.

BRIELLE, N.J., Sept. 14 -- One man lost his life and fifteen other persons were injured, two seriously, in an explosion aboard the forty-nine-foot fishing boat Paramount III at her dock here early this morning. The blast rocked this town and was heard in many nearby communities.

Mike Gill, 36 years old, of 88-43 161st Street, Jamaica, Queens made the mistake, according to the police, of trying to hold up a detective last night and learned that this particular crime paid off only in a knock-down blow and prompt arrest.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- Henry J. Kaiser, the West Coast industrialist, urged the administration today to stimulate expanded steel production through tax concessions, declaring that an abundance of steel was a guarantee against depression.

MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 14 (AP) -- The intense Atlantic hurricane continued to move northwestward tonight and at 10:30 P.M., Eastern standard time, was about 35 miles east of Nassau, the Bahamas, the Weather Bureau reported.

ON BOARD U.S.S. MISSOURI, At Sea, Sept. 14 -- President Truman attended religious services with members of his family this morning on the open afterdeck of this battleship that is carrying him toward the United States.

BONNEVILLE SALT FLATS, Utah, Sept. 14 (AP) -- John Cobb of London roared through the measured mile at world record excelling speed today. But his car was damaged on the initial sprint and he was unable to make the return trip necessary to claim a new mark.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (U.P.) -- Hassan Ispahani, Ambassador-designate of the new nation of Pakistan, charged today that the warlike Sikhs of northern India, armed with surplus American war material, were "entirely and solely responsible" for touching off religious rioting in India, which has cost an estimated 200,000 lives in the past three weeks.

A new insulin compound that promises longer relief for many of the nation's 1,000,000 diabetics has been reported to the American Chemical Society, which will open its 112th national meeting here today.

SANTA CRUZ, Calif., Sept. 14 -- A flood of messages urging Senator Robert A. Taft to "hold the line" against relaxation of the closed-shop ban in the Taft-Hartley Act swept in on the Ohio Presidential aspirant tonight before he took a train for southern California.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 14 -- The steel rate for the country last week dropped off 9 points to 83.5 per cent of rated capacity. The decline was the result of steel plant shut-downs here caused by the outlaw railroad strike. While the latter was settled late in the week, it will be the middle of this week before all the open hearths that had been shut down arc again producing steel at a high level.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 14 -- Five states of the Missouri Valley region have suffered a total population loss of 400,000 in the last sixteen years largely because of land deterioration. A river control system similar to the Tennessee Valley Authority was today declared to be "desperately needed" in the area.

TRIESTE, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Disturbances, resulting in the death of an 11-year-old Italian girl and the wounding of a Slovene girl, continued throughout various sections of Venezia Giulia today as the hour approached for the withdrawal of British and American troops from the Morgan Line.

Following is the text of the address by George G. Marshall, Secretary of State, before the American Association for the United Nations and cooperating groups at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday, as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

Searching for slim clues to help solve "The Case of the Missing Thigh Bone," a mystery more than 1,000,000 years old, scientists of the University of California are now in South Africa preparing to start excavations in the limestone caves of Stirkfontaine, about 50 miles from Johannesburg.

NYACK, N.Y., Sept. 14 -- Artists and artisans, writers, radio and theatre folk and other professionals numbering in all 1,000 came today to view their own and their neighbors' works at a preview or the second annual "open show" of the Rockland Foundation, inc.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14 -- Deliveries of goods to the majority of buyers have improved as a result of slightly higher employment and production, P.C. Patch, business survey chairman of the Purchasing Agents Association of Chicago, said today. The survey, made at the end of August among members of the group, also revealed larger stocks of finished goods in the hands of manufacturers.
The number of private airplanes in the metropolitan area has almost doubled in the last year, according to an announcement yesterday by the Regional Plan Association.

AMSTERDAM, Sept. 14 -- The tendency of the Amsterdam Stock Exchange, in contrast to the markets in New York and London, generally has been toward a strong undertone. This is attributed partly to slight inflationary influences based on an increase in the circulation of currency and also to generally favorable business reports, both economic and financial.
JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 14 (AP) -- The State Council of Machinists today asked the aid of all organized labor in a campaign seeking repeal of the Taft-Hartley Labor Law.

City Councilman Eugene P. Connolly, secretary of the New YorK County Committee of the American Labor party, made public yesterday a complaint in affidavit form asking the District Attorneys of New York, Bronx, King's and Queens Counties to start investigations leading to Grand Jury action on alleged forgeries, perjuries and other violations of the election and penal laws in the petitions for repeal of the proportional representation method of electing members of the City Council.

Concerned over the possible impact of the upward spiral of food prices upon the city's expense budget for 1948-49, Mayor O'Dwyer and his fiscal advisers are about to speed up work on their program for more extensive state aid and the relaxing of constitutional restrictions upon the city's power to tax real estate and borrow for capital improvements.

Declaring that certain national and state real estate interests planned a fight to defeat New York State's housing program this fall, Herman T. Stichman, State Housing Commissioner, said yesterday that private builders had failed to provide sufficient housing for veterans.

Confirmation from the Weather Bureau that the humidity has been above normal this summer may offer some assurance to housewives that they are not imagining musty odors or seeing mildew spots without just cause.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Scoring touchdowns in the first and third periods, the San Francisco Forty-niners defeated the Baltimore Colts, 14 -- 7, today and maintained a perfect record in the All-America Conference Professional Football League.

NANKING, Sept. 14 -- The fight against mass illiteracy in the Far East, where internal strife has added to the burdens of wartime dislocation, appears to hinge primarily on the development of Asia's economic resources and a consequent improvement in living standards.

The casual attitude of the average churchgoer was rebuked yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Peter Marshall, pastor of the New York Avenue Presbyterian Church, Washington, and chaplain of the United States Senate, in a sermon at the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.
So far as the Yankees were able to press their case, they could well have clinched the American League pennant yesterday and done it with a grand flourish.

PARIS, Sept. 14 -- With the control of France's upper legislative house at stake, the Popular Republican National Committee called today for a conservative front to beat the Communist People's Leftist group in the October local elections.

Henry Bishop, 6 years old, of 20 West 134th Street, slipped down a chimney of an adjoining house sometime Saturday evening and was not found until yesterday noon. He was rescued by a Police Emergency Squad, hungry, dirty, proud of the attention his exploit was receiving, and with only a few bruises to mark his experience.

Secretary of State George C. Marshall said yesterday that the territorial integrity and political independence of Greece were threatened by the aid being furnished to guerrillas by Yugoslavia, Bulgaria and Albania. He called upon the United Nations General Assembly to devise means of protecting the Greek people.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 14 -- The City Council here will receive on Oct. 5 a long-range plan to set up sewage disposal facilities that is expected to be approved by the Interstate Sanitation Commission, which has ordered Elizabeth to cease pollution of the Arthur Kill and Newark Bay, Walter H. Cole, president of the Board of Works, announced today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14 -- Although there is a sizable surplus of lard in the United States, consumers face the possibility of a shortage by next spring, meat packing interests said today. With lard stocks in cold storage close to the largest in three years, a prospective shortage, in the next six months at first would seem unlikely.

ROME, Sept. 14 -- This week promises to be a crucial one on the Italian labor front. More than 1,000,000 workers are on strike and the number will be swelled to about 2,000,000 on Tuesday when 800,000 steel workers will quit for two days.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 14 -- That nice blue and white Brooklyn pennant which has been fluttering in the first place spot daily from the pole atop the Ebbets Field stands since July 6 almost certainly will be there at the season's end.

Philanthropy has discovered that available funds cannot be used to fullest advantage for lack of trained investigators. Accordingly the John and Mary R. Markle Foundation has embarked upon a new program to relieve the teacher shortage in medical schools and to provide more trained investigators for medical research.

John A. Kramer stands as the undisputed king of the realm of amateur tennis, but the crown of this Alexander of the courts was shaky on his head as the climax came to his season of world conquest, undoubtedly his last as a simon pure.
Observance of Rosh ha-Shanah, marking the start of the Jewish New Year, 5708, began at sunset yesterday.

BERLIN, Sept. 14 (AP) -- The Neue Zeitung, official German newspaper of the American Military Government, reported today that the Russians had shipped out of Germany to the Soviet Union in the last fortnight 222 carloads of grain and fourteen carloads of livestock.
The local art season really swings into its stride this week with four museums and many galleries opening exhibitions.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 14 (U.P.) -- The Egyptian Cabinet was summoned into an extraordinary urgent session tonight to consider the situation in the Sudan, where Britain has announced she intends to go ahead with an economic development program without waiting for a decision of the United Nations Security Council on Egypt.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The world will produce somewhat more breadgrains in 1947 than it did last year, but the difference Will be more than offset by the increased requirements of certain "deficit" areas, notably Europe, the Department of Agriculture said today.

Commenting recently on the critical shortage of nurses which is now jeopardizing full medical care in many of our hospitals, we suggested that one of the methods of meeting this problem was the increased use of practical nurses in the various tasks which do not require the technical skills of the professional registered nurse.

LONG BEACH, Calif., Sept. 15 -- A widespread tendency to discount the importance of education in correctional institutions was deplored today by penologists speaking before the annual Congress of Correction of the American Prison Association.

It would be difficult to conceive of a program which typified more perfectly the purely political approach to an economic problem than that which has been put forward by Representative Adolph J. Sabath of Illinois as a formula for combating the present trend toward higher living costs.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15 -- Metal-working plants are now getting into real mass production, according to reports from members in all districts, Howard Goodman, president, National Metal Trades Association and vice president of Goodman Manufacturing Company, revealed here in forecasting record national output for the industry in 1948.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 15 -- Virtually blasting their way around ten miles of Long Island Sound, the sailors of the international class on Long Island Sound and the Royal Bermuda Yacht Club engaged today in a renewal of their team racing after a lapse of eleven years.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned strong yesterday and closed 59 to 87 points net higher on the day.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Sept. 15 -- Coach Steve Owen put his New York Football Giants through a three-hour workout this morning in preparation for the exhibition benefit clash with their National League rivals, the Los Angeles Rams, at the Polo Grounds tomorrow night.
Reflecting a move to readjust bulk product sales to prevailing commodity price levels, producers of corn syrup and starches have advanced their prices, it was learned yesterday.
To understand the collection that Adrian exhibited yesterday afternoon in the Maisonette of the St. Regis, one must know what he personally thinks of fashion this season.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 15 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, backing Secretary of State George C. Marshall's stand against foreign meddling in Greece, declared today that he favored elimination of the veto in the United Nations Security Council if a satisfactory definition of aggression could be written into the charter of the world organization.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 15 -- Better teeth for American children, with decay reduced between 40 and 50 per cent, was envisioned today at the opening session of the fiftieth annual convention of the Southern California State Dental Association.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 15 -- A showdown in the United Nations General Assembly, between the United States and the Soviet Union, with Secretary of State Marshall in personal command of a drive to persuade or compel the Russians to stop their obstructionist tactics, was forecast tonight on the eve of the Assembly's opening session.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Sept. 15 -- Top-flight medical leaders presented a unified front today to cope with the diagnosis and treatment of poliomyelitis. With several parts of the nation again confronted with the disease in epidemic proportions, experts in the various specialties involved opened a three-day discussion at the Georgia Warm Springs Foundation.

Discarding original plans for a ten-round non-title bout on Nov. 14, the Twentieth Century Sporting Club announced yesterday that Heavyweight Champion Joe Louis would make the twenty-fourth defense of his crown against Jersey Joe Walcott on Dec. 5 at Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- The growing wave of strikes in Italy is handicapping American efforts to extend economic aid to that country, it was said at the State Department today. The strikes were described as serving only political ends.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- The dilemma that confronts the administration as it seeks to create a Marshall Plan for Europe has the usual two horns. One is the problem of convincing Congress that the proposed recovery program for the Continent will get that cooperation from its beneficiaries which is essential to achieve the objective.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:

CHICAGO, Sept. 15--Will C. Grant, president of Grant Advertising, Inc., returned today from a four-day conference in Havana with twenty-four executives from his seventeen offices in nine countries. Highlight of the conference was the announcement that Grant had acquired the General Advertising Agency in Calcutta and absorbed the Raisbeck Agency in Hollywood, Calif.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 15 -- The Indian Army today began using tanks to escort long columns of Moslem evacuees moving toward Pakistan through the Hindu and Sikh country of East Punjab, a military spokesman said tonight. At the same time the Indian Government, under an agreement with Pakistan, sent its own troops across the Pakistan border to protect caravans of Hindus and Sikhs leaving the West Punjab.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 15--A close race for the Presidency of the United Nations General Assembly developed tonight between Dr. Oswaldo Aranha, former Foreign Minister of Brazil, and Dr. Herbert V. Evatt Australian Minister of External Affairs, as a result of the last-minute decision of the United States to support Dr. Evatt.

PARIS, Sept. 15 -- Delegates to the Marshall plan conference virtually agreed tonight on new sections of their report designed to meet five of the six criticisms made Wednesday by the United States State Department through William L. Clayton, Under-Secretary of State for Economic Affairs.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- The Commodity Exchange Authority, warning of a "boom-and-bust" danger in grain prices, asked the nation's big grain exchanges tonight to double their margin or down - payment requirements in grain futures transactions.

ZURICH, Sept. 15 -- Last Thursday almost every leading newspaper in Switzerland carried half-page announcements headed: "CHAD-Statement to Shareholders," signed, SOFINA (Societe Financiere de Transports et d'Entreprises Industrielles of Brussels) and Credit Suisse of Zurich, the oldest and largest commercial bank in Switzerland.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., Sept. 15 -- The record of the country's newspapers for "having met their responsibilities fully and made perhaps the greatest single contribution to the winning of the war" should challenge them to greater efforts in peacetime for constructive leadership, E.B. Stahlman Jr., president of the Southern Newspaper Publishers Association, declared today.

Murray Hill Merchant All spring and summer in Murray Hill he came every day -- pretty regularly, too, considering the vagrant nature of his pleasant trade. His cry "Flowers" was known through every open window in the neighborhood.

DOJRAN, Greece (On the Yugoslav Border), Sept. 14 -- (Delayed) -- Villagers along the Greek-Yugoslav frontier, who have borne the brunt of guerrilla fighting during and since the war, were prayerfully hopeful today for the success of the amnesty project begun by Premier Themistocles Sophoulis' new Government in Athens.

ABERDEEN, Md., Sept. 15 (AP) -- Capt. Charles W. Warmack, 25 years old, of Paris, Tenn., parachuted to safety today to become the only survivor of ten men on board a B-17 bomber which exploded and sank in Bush River.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 15 (AP) -- The American people must decide whether they will eat less meat so wheat can be shipped to hungry people in Europe to prevent "anarchy and chaos" or whether that wheat is to be consumed by animals and poultry in this country, Secretary of Commerce W. Averell Harriman said today.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 15 -- The New England Public Service Company's alternative plan for the retirement of its 178,747 shares of prior lien preferred stock was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
BOSTON, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Thanks to the Chicago White Sox, and especially to Don Kolloway and Righthander Orval Grove, the New York Yankees have their fifteenth American League pennant clinched.
Random Notes:

NANKING, Sept. 15 -- The fast-moving Communist guerrilla units that recently swept down from western Shantung into central China are combing through an extensive area of Anhwei Province, threatening villages within sixty miles of Nanking.

Two men employed by the United States Department of Interior suffered burns and were forced to leap overboard shortly before 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon when the Government motor launch In which they were riding in the East River was set afire by an unexplained explosion, off Ninetieth Street, police of the harbor precinct reported.

The nation's savings banks, in cashing terminal leave bonds, have had no unusual difficulties, although the identification process has been a widespread problem, according to a survey just completed by the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Britain's sale of $80,000,000 in gold in this country today was regarded by Treasury officials as a routine transaction indicative of nothing more than that country's continuing dollar shortage. This Government's only part in the transaction was to make good its standing offer to buy any gold presented at $35 an ounce.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Sept. 15 (AP) -- The head of Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation today described as "baseless" a civil anti-trust suit filed here by the Justice Department last week, charging "conspiracy to monopolize" the production of glass fibers in the United States.

The consecration of the Most Rev. Thomas J. McDonnell, national director of the Society for the Propagation of the Faith, as titular Bishop of Sela, in the Nile Delta, and Auxiliary Bishop of New York took place yesterday morning in St. Patrick's Cathedral in an ancient ceremony vibrant with ecclesiastical colors and symbolic action.

Consolidated net income of the Warren Petroleum Corporation and its subsidiaries for the fiscal year ended with last June amounted to $4,926,388, equal to $8.21 a share on 600,000 common shares outstanding, it was reported yesterday. For the previous fiscal year the corporation showed a net of $1,115,041 or $1.86 a share.

DETROIT, Sept. 15 -- Representatives of automobile plants denied today that the strike by 2,400 carburetor orkers in St. Louis would seriously hamper production by about 90 per cent of the industry outside the Ford Motor Company in "a matter of days."

The seven-story loft building at 697-701 Greenwich Street has been purchased by the West Shore Twine and Paper Supply Corporation from the Boxwood Realty Company. The property has an assessed valuation of $105,000. J. P. McGif and Walter C. Korn were the brokers and the attorneys were Jacob Linett for the buyer and Bandler, Brady Haas for the seller.
CHICAGO, Sept. 15 -- The Stewart - Warner Corporation introduced today eight new models of radios and radio-phonograph combinations at a regional conference for distributors here.
GENEVA, Sept. 15 -- A stiffening United States position in tariff negotiations with Britain was reflected in today's meeting of the United States and British Commonwealth negotiators.

Money Market Firmer Money market conditions were somewhat firmer yesterday with Federal funds quoted at 1/2 to 5/8 per cent. The New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System, which on Thursday night had a deficiency in reserves of $100,000,000, after completing their adjustments on Friday, reduced the figure by only $40,000,000 so that they began yesterday with a deficiency of $60,000,000.

NORFOLK, Va., Sept. 15 (AP) -- Four hundred and fifty Navy aircraft were sent from the Norfolk area today bound for three places in New York State -- Buffalo, Syracuse and Rome -- as a precautionary treasure based on reports of the Atlantic hurricane.

ON BOARD U.S.S. MISSOURI at Sea, Sept. 15 -- Three of the nine sixteen-inch guns of the "Mighty Mo" hurled 2,700-pound projectiles into assigned targets seven and a half miles away in a spectacular thundering practice today with President Truman as a much satisfied Commander-in-Chief.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 15--On the eve of the meeting of the United Nations General Assembly, the Soviet Union invoked the double veto in the Security Council here tonight. By so doing, it blocked the plan of the United States to permit the Assembly to make recommendations on the Greek question and at the same time to keep the question on the Council agenda.

The United Nations General Assembly, opening its fourth meeting today at Flushing Meadow, is not powerful by the customary realistic standards nor democratic by idealistic standards. It cannot order any nation to do anything. It cannot even recommend action in any matter pending before the Security Council.

Three thousand employes in five plants of the Lever Brothers Company will receive pay rises averaging 12 1/2 cents an hour, their third general increase in eighteen months, it was announced yesterday by Charles Luckman, president of the company, and the heads of three unions involved.

BATAVIA, Java, Sept. 15 (AP) -- "Satisfactory progress" in supervising and reporting on the United Nations Security Council's ceasefire orders in the Dutch-Indonesian conflict was announced tonight by the United Nations consular mission.

A rush-hour tieup of all BMT transit facilities in Brooklyn inconvenienced thousands of subway, elevated and surface car passengers from 5:40 to 6:27 o'clock last evening, and in some cases resulted in hysteria among the stalled travelers.
A return to wartime meatless days in New York's public eating places was urged by Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday as one of several stopgaps against advancing food prices.

Sharp increases in exports from the Union of South Africa to the United States are likely this year with an average gain of 25 per cent or more probable for non-gold products, which will range to above 100 per cent in the case of fruits, Richard Kulze, general counsel of the international trade section of the New York Board of Trade, said in an interview yesterday.

The Shuberts have added another musical to their ever increasng list, which already includes atleast six. The latest is "Silent Serenade" and its action is said to take place in Italy during the middle of the nineteenth century. The authors involved are Victor Clement (he contributed the book), Denes Agay (composer of the music) and the team of Fred Jay and rving Rifkin (responsible for the lyrics).

The Whitney Museum, 10 West Eighth Street, reopens to the public today with a show that includes selected material -- oils, water-colors and sculpture -- from the permanent collection. This work is to remain on view through Oct. 12, shortly after which the museum will bring forward its centennary exhibition of paintings by Ryder.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Detroit blasted Mickey Haefner and Tom Ferriek for thirteen hits tonight to defeat Washington, 7 to 2, and move a full game ahead of the third-place Red Sox. It was the sixth straight loss for the Senators.

YESTERDAY'S EVENTS Security Council Meeting at Lake Success, adopted United States resolution dropping Greek question from agenda, permitting General Assembly to take up dispute. Double Russian veto blocked earlier resolution, resulting in termination of United Nations subcommission watching Greek borders.

The $17,000,000 program of water-front improvement offered to Hoboken by the Port Authority, after a requested survey of the obsolescent facilities there, is of greatest interest to that city, but the entire port of New York will be watching the aftermath of events. The piers involved were taken over in 1918 by the Government in confiscation proceedings at a cost of $7,146,583 and are now operated by the Maritime Commission.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Two bids for the Government-owned glass furnaces and byproduct coke oven plant at Granite City, Ill., were rejected by the War Assets Administration today as "inadequate."

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 15 -- The Federal Government was accused by New England merchants today of contributing to the high cost of living by purchasing commodities for foreign relief at prices above the going rates.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 15 (AP) -- The Pirate batsmen enjoyed a hitting spree today in taking a 12-to-2 victory over the Phillies as Pittsburgh climed out of the National League cellar.

The increase in the prices of material is leading that of labor in the building industry, according to a nation-wide survey by the Dow Service. The present survey, the first conducted by the concern since 1941, spotlights the changes in building cost levels in 150 of the nation's leading metropolitan areas.

The New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad announced yesterday that increased interstate monthly commutation fares authorized by the Interstate Commerce Commission would become effective at 12:01 A.M., Eastern Standard Time, Thursday.

Emil Sandstroem, chairman of the United Nations Committee on Palestine, declared flatly here yesterday on his return from the special ten-week tour of inquiry that partition was the only solution for the Holy Land problem.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Attorney General Tom C. Clark told a national conference of Federal attorneys today to push campaigns in their areas against illegal price-fixing which increases the costs of food, clothing and housing.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 15 -- The question here now is whether the Cardinals can finish second. The 5,914 cash customers at Sportsman's Park this afternoon debated whether Mel Ott's robust clubbers could climb into the runner-up position, after seeing the Giants batter the Cards into a 10-to-5 defeat, the third in a row for the club which, a few days ago, was challenging for the National League flag.

HAVANA, Sept. 15 -- There was a gun battle this afternoon between two factions of the National Police and the Army was forced to intervene in the town of Marianao, just across the Almendares River from Havana. Five or six persons were killed and ten were wounded.

Amid an extraordinary setting, which saw the newly crowned champions doing nothing more inspiring than sitting in their sumptuous Stadium dressing room, the New York Yankees yesterday clinched the 1947 American League pennant.

A game of "follow the leader" played in earnest by an airliner and a small private plane at 2,000 feet over New York and New Jersey yesterday brought the private ship safely into La Guardia Field. The "leader" was an Eastern Air Lines plane that was "holding" over Newark Airport during the morning, preparatory to making its one scheduled stop between St. Louis and Boston.
MONTE CARLO, Sept. 15 (AP) -- The Congress of European Swimming Leagues tonight officially confirmed the mark of Alex Jany of France in winning the 400 meters in 4:35.2 as the new European record.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, in its report submitted yesterday to the Federal Communications Commission, showed a net income of $80,482,753 for the first seven months of this year, compared with $92,912,322 for the corresponding period a year ago.
CHICAGO, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Bob Chipman stopped Johnny Sain short of his twentieth victory of the season here today with nine-hit pitching to give the Chicago Cubs a 3-2 victory over the Boston Braves.

Police Captain Nicholas P. Gaffney, and two sergeants and six patrolmen who were on his staff when he commanded the West Fifty-fourth Street precinct, Manhattan, were served yesterday with departmental charges as a result of an investigation into bookmaking.

Following is the second of five articles by the United States' war-time Ambassador to London on his mission there. They are taken from his book "Letter From Grosvenor Square," which will be published by Houghton Mifflin Company.

TRIESTE, Tuesday, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Yugoslav troops made their first contact with the American-British forces on the new provisional Italian-Yugoslav frontier at 2 A.M. today, [8 P.M., Monday, Eastern daylight time], the moment at which the Italian peace treaty became effective.

Discovery of a new clue to the secret of longevity was reported yesterday at the meeting of the American Chemical Society at the Hotel Pennsylvania by Dr. Thomas S. Gardner of the scientific department of Hoffman-La Roche, Nutley, N.J.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Sept. 15 (AP) -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, proposed here tonight a second national labor-management conference to stave off inflation which he said threatened to become "the worst in the history of the country."
HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 15 -- Robert Brewer Newell, president of the Hartford National Bank and Trust Company, died in his home here this morning at the age of 68.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 15 -- The fall home furnishing exhibit that opened yesterday at Kresge-New-ark features dual purpose rooms for varied types of suburban homes with emphasis on attractive informality and individuality.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 15 -- A resolution to retain "legal talent," and if necessary, to file an injunction suit to prevent Negro children from attending Catholic white schools was adopted last night at a meeting of more than 700 persons in the Electrical Workers' Hall.
LONDON, Sept. 15 -- There was a lot of talk in the stock markets here today about the new export plan but very little business was done and price changes of importance were few.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 15 -- The Philadelphia Company, Pittsburgh, today filed an amendment to its voluntary plan of corporate simplification providing for the reorganization of its gas properties in the State of Pennsylvania.
Securities Exchange leaders from the United States, Canada and nine Latin-American countries met yesterday in the first hemispheric stock exchange conference in the Plaza Hotel.
MUNICH, Germany, Sept. 15 -- Minister President Hans Ehard today accepted the resignations submitted by the four Social Democratic Ministers in his Cabinet.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 15 -- Edward Small has concluded a deal with Colombia for distribution of his independent production, "The Fuller Brush Man," with Red Skelton, Columbia announced today. Skclton and S. Sylvan Simon, who will direct the film, have been borrowed by Small from Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, to which company they are under contract.
CHICAGO, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department at Agriculture follows.

Ten Army transports are being overhauled in East Coast shipyards in a project costing $34,859,400 that will provide greater passenger comfort complete fireproofing and extra cargo-handling gear, it was announced yesterday.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 15 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York declared today at the Eastern States Exposition here that increased United States agricultural production was essential to meet critical needs in Europe, as well as the United States, and laid stress on the importance of improving agricultural techniques in order "to increase production."

An exhibit demonstrating how men and women all over the world, though centuries and thousands of miles apart, have had the same ideas in interpreting fashion is presented under the title "Clothing One World, An Anatomy of Fashion," which is opening today at the Brooklyn Museum.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Sept 15 -- Governments should not be criticized for taking international action outside the United Nations if a deadlock prevents that organization from functioning swiftly as a unit, Ambassador Humphrey Hume Wrong of Canada declared here tonight.

OMAHA, Sept. 15 -- The Republican chairman and vice chairman of eighteen Midwestern and Rocky Mountain States demanded today that President Truman take the people into his confidence. They urged that he give out the full facts of the world situation.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Sept. 15 -- Eighty persons suspected of plotting to overthrow the National Government have been arrested in Slovakia, the Ministry of the Interior of that state announced today.

HARRISON, N.J., Sept. 15 -- Fred Walter Smigelski, 14-year-old Newark boy, today re-enacted in detail for Hudson County Prosecutor's officers and local police the kidnap slaying of John (Jackie) Preston Jr. of Kearny, in the old Purdy Steel Company plant, now used as a warehouse by the Worthington Pump Company.
Homer Replogle, national accounts manager of American Home Foods, Inc., has been named general sales manager of the company.

Quarantaine found the sloppy going at Aqueduct yesterday exactly to her liking. The 3-year-old daughter of Isolator ran through the mire in front to take the winner's share of the Swinging Purse, the seven-furlong burst for fillies and mares that occupied the top spot on the day's racing program.

The stock market returned yesterday to the lowest levels since June, continuing the record of declines which have characterized each Monday session for the last two months. A few issues managed to creep ahead during the morning but most major gains evaporated under moderate pressure in the late trading.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 15 -- Officials of city maintained institutions announced today that they would ask the City Council for about $400,000 in emergency funds to meet the rising cost of foods.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:

FOR every historical novel which is discussed in this space there are probably at least thirty or forty which are not noticed. Mass production has produced too standardized a product for criticism to be worth the time or effort. One doesn't criticize one toothbrush and compare it with a rival make. They are different in detail, but identical in purpose and over-all design.

ROME, Sept. 15 -- The territorial clauses of the Italian peace treaty began to be put into effect at 6 P.M. when twenty French gendarmes marched into San Dalmazzo di Tenda, the principal inhabited center in the territory that Italy ceded to France, and took possession of the customs offices there.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations will bring a test case of the Taft-Hartley Act on appeal from a ruling by the general counsel of the NLRB, Robert N. Denham, in a few days, according to a statement today by Lee Pressman, the CIO's general counsel.

MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 15 -- A long stretch of the East Coast from Florida to North Carolina was officially alerted and warned tonight to expect high tides and heavy seas with increasing winds offshore as a great hurricane approached.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- In New York, the delegates to the United Nations General Assembly may be deploring the Soviet Union's "abuse of the veto power," but down here in Washington even the "veto problem" has its optimistic aspects.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Secretary of Commerce W. Averell Harriman chided British Foreign Secretary Bevin today for having suggested recently that the United States "redistribute" its Fort Knox gold or reinstate the lend-lease aid system.

Joan Davis, comedienne, is the latest recruit to join the growing ranks of "cooperative" programs offered by the networks to their affiliates for local sponsorship. Miss Davis, heard last season on Monday night, is scheduled to return to the Columbia Broadcasting System network on Saturday, Oct. 11, in the 9 to 9:30 P.M. spot.

The splitting for the first time of atoms of lead, bismuth, thallium, platinum and tantalum, thus opening up a new phase in man's mastery of the atom, was announced last night before the annual meeting of the American Chemical Society.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 15 -- The text of the proposed new code of standards of practice for the radio industry, as made public here today by the National Association of Broadcasters, follows:

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 15 -- The National Association of Broadcasters, embracing the four networks and most of the country's independent radio stations, announced today a proposed code of standards under which advertising on the air would be reduced from 3 to 20 per cent.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 15 -- War in the Middle East, "probably sooner than later," will ensue if the United Nations attempts to carry out the recommendations of its Special Committee on Palestine, the Arab Office, representing the seven Arab League states, warned today.

TRIESTE, Sept. 15 -- United States and British troops began moving back at 10 o'clock tonight from the Morgan Line in Venezia Giulia toward the French Line that marks the new Italo-Yugoslav boundary. The evacuation began even before the scheduled time as the peace treaty with Italy went into effect.

LONDON, Sept. 15 -- John W. Snyder, United States Secretary of the Treasury, said today at a press conference that the "flexibility" of the crucial questions of non-discrimination and convertibility gave Britain plenty of room to act within the framework of the Anglo-American loan agreement.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 15 -- A Six-week strike of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's union, Congress of Industrial Organizations, which had tied up the Alaskan ports of Ketchikan, Juneau and Seward, ended at 8 A.M., today with the return to work of the longshoremen, according to word received here by union headquarters and by the Waterfront Employers Association of the Pacific Coast.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Sept. 15 -- An offer to lease Hoboken's federally owned piers and to operate them on a profit-sharing basis for fifty years after carrying out a $17,000,000 improvement program was made today to the City Commission by the Port of New York Authority through Howard S. Cullman, its chairman.

Even if debate should wax warm when the General Assembly meets today in Flushing Meadow, delegates should manage to keep fairly cool. Maintenance crews started driving accumulated summer heat out of the chamber walls last Friday.

WITH the Yankees clinching their pennant yesterday and the Dodgers merely waiting for the referee to count ten over the prostrate Cardinals, there no longer is any doubt as to the identity of the World Series contenders. Of course, the Yanks have been "in" for so long that no one even has bothered to pay too much attention to the American League standings.

While dollar shortages are reflected in a drop in radio exports from the peaks of recent months, no precipitous slump in such shipments is anticipated, it was reported yesterday following a meeting of export managers of the Radio Manufacturers Association at the Hotel Roosevelt.
ALBANY, Sept. 15 -- The two-month National Guard drive in this state will seek 8,100 recruits.

Stores Sales Down 3% New York department store sales declined 3 per cent during the week ended Sept. 13 compared with the corresponding period a year ago, according to the "flash" report of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York yesterday.

RALEIGH, N.C., Sept. 15 (AP) -- A fourteen-day quarantine of the North Carolina State College football team was imposed today after doctors had reported that me member of the squad was suffering from an acute case of infantile paralysis.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP). -- The National Federation of American Shipping estimated today that net dollar payments to United States ship operators accounted for only 2.6 per cent of British expenditures in this country in the year ended June 30.

LONDON, Sept. 15 -- Another warning of the gravity of Britain's dollar crisis was sounded today when the Treasury announced that the Bank of England had sold gold valued at u20,000,000 (more than $80,000,000) to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Restaurant patronage has increased at least 10 to 15 per cent in the past two weeks because housewives are boycotting retail butchers as a protest against rising meat prices, Paul H. Henkel, president of the Society of Restaurateurs, declared yesterday.
JERUSALEM, Sept. 15 -- Arab brigands killed a British Army officer in Palestine this afternoon. There were four bombings tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- A fleet of 5,000 civilian transport planes as a necessary reserve for military emergencies was suggested today by Admiral Emory S. Land, retired, former chairman of the Maritime Commission.

Seeking jobs for the city's 3,100 unemployed disabled veterans, Mayor O'Dwyer called upon all employers in the city yesterday to support the campaign for job-training to bring the veterans back into productive employment.

As a condition of American assistance under the Marshall Plan, the spokesmen of our State Department now attending the Paris conferences are said to be insisting on specific guarantees from the participating European nations in such matters as increased production, currency stabilization and the lowering of trade barriers.

The Park Department's own report on the public's use of its recreational facilities this summer shows that when New Yorkers play, swim and rest they do not do it by half measures. The department's census-takers tell us that 99,312,000 visits were made to all of its recreational opportunities, indicating that city dwellers have learned to take full advantage of the playgrounds, swimming pools and other play spots open to them.

Of seven hat silhouettes offered, Mary Goodfellow's preference seemed to lean toward the beret in her collection shown yesterday at the St. Regis Roof. She developed it in dressy and tailored types, and in such fabrics as a black watch plaid with a red velvet cocarde trim and a handsome gray peau d' ange in a Parge bloused version with a flashing jeweled trim.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Eleven Army athletes, chosen after a canvass of overseas and domestic units, are now training at West Point for the United States tryouts for the modern pentathlon event in the 1948 Olympics, the War Department said today.
Hundreds of thousands of Jew in New York attended temples and synagogues yesterday at Rosh haShanah services that marked the first day of the Jewish New Year 5708.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- National Guard Day, set aside by proclamation of the President, will be observed throughout the nation tomorrow with parades, celebrations and open house in armories.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:

Russia never ceases her pressure on what she regards as an unstable front. Toward the south she finds three such fronts: Iran in the Near East. Greece and now Italy in the west. In Iran new pressure is apparently to be employed. A year and a half ago Soviet occupation forces held the entire northern province of Azerbaijan.

For the second time since 400 workers at the Continental Paper Company, Ridgefield, N.J., entered into a "share-of-production-pay plan" with their employer last month, they will carry home extra pay in their envelopes today.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 15 -- An air force to compel peace in the world was demanded at the opening here today of the first convention of the Air Force Association.

Rare objects of art, dating from 3,000 B.C. to the fifteenth century and valued at $1,000,000, have been purchased recently by the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The announcement of the purchase which contains the major part of the private collection of the late Joseph Brummer, came yesterday from the Metropolitan's president, Roland L. Redmond, at the first autumn meeting of the museum's trustees.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 15. -- Army lost Blanchard and Davis, but it won't get any sympathy in New Haven. Yale has enough grief of its own. Barzilauskas and Schuler have checked out and they were the best pair of inside and outside linemen to wear the Blue in a half dozen college generations.

Something has to be done to encourage investors to build more housing and the most effective step the city and state can take is to grant tax exemption on new houses, Joseph T. Sharkey, vice chairman of the City Council, declared yesterday.

The nation's gas-utility companies reported yesterday, through the American Gas Association, that rever es for the twelve months to June 30 amounted to $1,313,800,000, a gain of 13.4 per cent over the preceding twelve months when sales resulted in revenues of $1,158,600,000.
