PITTSBURGH, Sept. 15 -- Police acted here today to quell an incipient riot between Communist and anti-Communist factions of the Croatian Fraternal Union which broke out over the seating as a delegate of a New York attorney recently convicted of contempt of Congress.
CHICAGO, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Record crowds will see football on a grandiose scale in the Western Conference this season, which will be climaxed by the champion appearing in the Rose Bowl.

DETROIT, Sept. 15 -- The Ford Motor Company is expected to close a leasing arrangement with the Navy Department tomorrow morning providing for acquisition by the company of the $30,000,000 arsenal at suburban Center Line.

SALEM, N.H., Sept. 15 (AP) -- Leading all the way and opening up three lengths in the stretch, Mort Stuart's Halbarail ran like the 3-5 favorite he was on the board today to win the $3,000 Atbleboro allowance purse at Rockingham Park.

An executive of a large national distributor reported yesterday that two important appliance producers have committed themselves in writing to hold prices at current levels. Both, he said, explained that they are confident that this can be done despite increased production costs.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 15 (AP) -- George Metkovich's triple off the right-field wall and Lou Boudreau's single gave the Indians an eleven-inning 2-to-1 victory over the Athletics tonight before a crowd of 11,514 for a Philadelphia season attendance record of 869,760.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Unless this country institutes voluntary food controls to help meet the new world crisis, western European Governments may be expected to fall, Norris E. Dodd, Acting Secretary of Agriculture, warned today at a press conference.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Early Wynn snapped Washington's six-game losing streak with a fourhit pitching job against the Tigers tonight as the Senators dealt Hal Newhouser his seventeenth defeat, 4 to 1. It was Wynn's sixteenth victory.

Let any physicist speak of fission, a term used in biology for many a decade without raising any fear, and the newspaper reader thinks of chain-reactions, the release of atomic energy, coalless power plants and bombs. So it was when Dr. Glenn T. Seaborg in his address before the American Chemical Society paid a tribute to his University of California colleagues who had split bismuth, lead, thallium, platinum, tantalum and arsenic.

The rock-ribbed defense of the New York Giants, found wanting against the Chicago Cardinals last week, will be put to another test tonight when the offensively potent Los Angeles Rams invade the Polo Grounds for a charity exhibition contest.

BOSTON, Sept. 16 -- Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, was among the securities executives of North and South America who participated today in opening a new radio service from Boston by which closing prices on the New York Stock and Curb Exchanges and other major world markets will be carried by short wave to Latin America.

British naval experts are keeping pace with world research on new weapons and carriers but to date no new type of warship has resulted for use by the Royal Navy, Vice Admiral Sir William Tennant, commander-in-chief of Great Britain's American and West Indies station, asserted yesterday.

NANKING, Sept. 16 (U.P) -- Vice President Dr. Sun Fo indicated today that China would align herself with Russia unless the United States soon came to her rescue in the current economic and political crisis.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 16 -- The public utilities divisio of the Securities and Exchange Cominission recommended today that the $370,000,000 Philadelphia Company of Pittsburgh be dissolved as an unnecessary and costly corporate complexity whose continued existence is "detrimental to security holders and consumers."

Emphasis was placed on the glamorous and picturesque in a collection of custom evening and cocktail fashions presented yesterday by Oleg Cassini at his new salon, 16 East Fifty-fifth Street. This designer, who recently returned from Hollywood, used heavy satins in combinations of rich colors.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 16 -- The New Jersey Supreme Court held valid today indictments charging Edward J. McFeely, former Hoboken police chief, and the late Bernard J. McFeely, former police inspector, with wilfully neglecting to enforce horse race gambling laws.

OMAHA, Neb., Sept. 16 -- A political situation is being whipped up in Iowa. It will come to a head on Oct. 8 at Des Moines when Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio and Harold E. Stassen, former Governor of Minnesota, will appear together at a meeting arranged by a group of leading Iowa Republicans.

LONDON, Sept. 16 -- Announcement of the u20,000,000 gold withdrawal from Britain's last resources was the signal for increased selling of gilt-edge stocks in the stock markets here today. Old Consols fell 1 5/8. Other losses ranged from 5/8 to 1 1/2 points.
ROME, Sept. 16 -- The steel workers went out on a nation-wide forty -eight-hour strike this morning as part of an alleged Communist plan to overthrow the Government of Premier Alcide de Gasperi.

The couriers of the post office often have proved their ability to get the mails through rain, hail, fog, sleet and snow. To the list of obstacles that fail to stay the delivery of mail was added yesterday another category -- storm sewers. This was accomplished swiftly despite the fact that one of the couriers failed in the completion of his appointed rounds.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 16 (AP) -- A seven-run rally in the seventh inning of the nightcap gave the Athletics a 7-3 victory over the Indians today and a split in the double-header, to Keep alive flickering hopes of a first-division berth.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Mandamus proceedings were threatened today by the American Federation of Labor against the National Labor Relations Board and its general counsel, Robert N. Denham, unless national unions are permitted access to the board's machinery despite the Denham ruling that all top AFL officers must sign anti-Communist affidavits.

NANKING, Sept. 16 -- The Chinese Government, which has manifested a fear of Japanese economic resurgence under the American occupation policy, is planning to "renegotiate" with Gen. Douglas Mac-Arthur and the Far Eastern Commission the placing of Japanese cotton spindles on the preferential list that is excluded from reparations payments.

The complete program for the twelfth season of the New Friends of Music, which will be devoted to music by Beethoven, Bach, Mendelssohn and Hindemith, was announced yesterday by Ira A. Hirschmann, president and founder of the organization.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- An Administration accounting for "nearly $20,000,000,000" spent for foreign aid since the end of World War II, together with a bill of particulars on what it proposed to accomplish with additional funds to be requested of Congress, was demanded today by Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat, of Virginia, chairman of the Congressional Economy Committee.

In the crowded General Assembly Hall at Flushing Meadows yesterday the interest of delegates, guests and visitors was focused on two top-ranking women diplomats -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and Mrs. Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit, head of the delegation of India.

High food costs are having a serious effect on diets of expectant mothers and of children, Health Commissioner Israel Weinstein declared yesterday at the New York City Department of Health, 125 Worth Street.

All prices of fresh meat, fish, poultry and eggs quoted in today's column are derived from the City Department of Markets. Though prices are changing from day to day, the amount of waste mentioned in the various foods discussed here does not.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Sept. 16 (AP) -- Eight harness racing drivers today were fined a total of $1,650 and one of them was suspended for the rest of the year for failure to compete in the feature event at the Saratoga track last Friday night.

Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky was described is a "nice old man" by crewmen of the Cunard White Star liner Queen Elizabeth, who said they were overwhelmed by the reception accorded the Soviet and other United Nations officials on their arrival here yesterday.

Just to let the world know that but for climatic interference on Monday they could just as well have clinched the American League pennant on their own power, the Yankees stepped out on the green of the Stadium yesterday, before a surprisingly large crowd of 18,926 and forthwith stepped all over the Browns to win the opener of the afternoon's twin bill, 8 to 3.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Sept. 16 -- The family farm is the "cornerstone of our national strength" and "one of the most effective bulwarks any nation can have against communism," Charles F. Brannan, Assistant Secretary of Agriculture, declared at the Catholic Tri-State Congress here today.

Under the provisions of the amended Federal rent law a landlord is authorized to cause an eviction "to seek dwelling space for other members of his family," the Appellate Term of the Brooklyn Supreme Court ruled yesterday.

SOME day an American novelist is going to write a book steeped in the lore of a particular American occupation, say wholesale groceries, in which the hero will be an honest man, a good citizen, a loyal husband and an understanding father. When he does, perhaps the novelty of his theme will win his book critical plaudits and financial rewards.

Former Secretary of War Robert P. Patterson accepted yesterday the national chairmanship for Brotherhood Week, sponsored by the National Conference of Christians and Jews, at an informal ceremony in the Bankers Club of America, 120 Broadway.

NANKING, Sept. 16 -- A movement of Communist troops across the Yellow River into central China was hailed today in a Communist broadcast from North Shensi as a "great counter-offensive," raising the curtain on "the battle for the liberation of the provinces north of the Yangtze."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Robert Moses, New York City's Construction Coordinator, called the Administration of the Ruhr coal mines in Germany a "mess" in a report released today by the War Department and he recommended control of that area by "a single board for policy and a single individual for execution."

MANILA, Sept. 16 -- Warning that the pre-war monopolistic Philippine hemp industry was slipping into trouble, President Manuel A. Roxas delved personally today into the perplexing land ownership problem in Davao Province on Mindanao Island.

BUENOS AIRBS, Sept. 16 -- The war between the Government and opposition papers entered a new and possibly historic phase today when an underground edition of the Socialist La Vanguardia was put on sale for one peso -- 25 cents.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- The election of Dr. Oswaldo Aranha of Brazil as President of the General Assembly of the United Nations at Lake Success today was very popular with the Government of the United States, whose delegate was among those that supported his chief competitor, Dr. Herbert V. Evatt of Australia.

RONNE EXPEDITION BASE, Stonington Island, Margutrite Bay, Sept. 13 (Delayed) -- Our first trail party, which left thirteen days ago on the start of a projected 1,200mile trip into the interior, has been ordered to return to this base.

As a result of overcrowded class rooms, inadequately equipped laboratories and overtaxed facilities, American colleges will face their greatest challenge in the 1947-48 academic year, Charles M. Edwards, dean of the New York University School of Retailing, declared yesterday in his annual report to Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase.

PARIS, Sept. 16 -- Under-Secretary of State William L. Clayton today told the chief delegates of the sixteen nations forming the European Economic Conference on the Marshall plan that their latest revised draft report would meet the wishes of the American State Department and would make a favorable impression in the United States.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., Sept. 16 -- Lisle Baker Jr., vice president and treasurer of The Louisville Courier Journal, was elected president of the Southern Newspaper Publishers Association at its convention today. Mr. Baker had served as a director at large.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Sept. 16 -- Four defense lawyers pleaded today before Bulgaria's Supreme Court of Appeals for the life and liberty of Nikola Petkov, Agrarian leader who had been sentenced to hang for attempting to overthrow the Fatherland Front Government of the Communist Premier, Georgi Dimitrov.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 16 -- The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association staged another split tournament in Westchester today, with Class A players participating here at the Knollwood Country Club and those in Class B at Fairview, in near-by Elmsford.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16 -- Bookings of orders for new machine tools were active at the preview of the machine tool show in the former Dodge-Chicago plant here today. More than 500 leading New York and New England industrial and financial executives were among an estimated 5,000 visitors in this twelve-acre exposition aimed at reducing production costs.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 16 (AP) -- The Phils bounced out of the League cellar into seventh place today as Blix Donnelly scattered nine Pittsburgh hits to beat the Pirates, 2 -- 1.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 16 -- Faced with a last chance to do something for their Flatbush neighbors, the Giants today hammered the Cardinals into defeat, 7 to 2, for a clean sweep of the farewell series between the two clubs. The setback sent Eddie Dyer's thoroughly demoralized troupe into its longest losing streak this year at Sportsman's Park -- four in a row.

ON BOARD THE U.S.S. MISSOURI, AT SEA, Sept. 16 -- President Truman saw in action today the 40-millimeter anti-aircraft which saved this superdreadnaught from the explosive dives by Japanese kamikaze (suicide) planes off Tokyo in 1944.

Meaningful Bids Competition for issues of public utility securities yesterday was suggestive of more than one straw in the wind. The indicated liberal spread on the Monongahela Power preferred and the San Diego Gas and Electric common shares, occasioned from one syndicate man the meaningful comment, "realistic."

CHICAGO, Sept. 16 -- A recommendation of the Commodity Exchange Authority to leading grain exchanges that margin requirements on speculative operations in grain be increased to one-third of the actual price of the grain started today a general selling movement on the Board of Trade.

A shift in the emphasis of hospital care from acute illnesses to degenerative and long-term ailments is noted in the August issue of The Bulletin of the Hospital Council of Greater New York, to be issued today.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 16 -- Two important seizures of explosives from the Arabs were reported by the Palestine Government today. The seizures were made yesterday in the south, where explosives are perhaps being smuggled into the country from Egypt.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Rear Admiral Thomas L. Sprague, Chief of the Bureau of Naval Personnel, raised the possibility today of reducing ship's complements or even of laying up ships if recruiting fails to meet the monthly goal of 15,000 men.

Free enterprise offers the greatest hope of attaining lasting peace and ever-rising living standards, Jerome M. Ney, chairman of the board of the American Retail Federation, said in an address yesterday before the Swedish Retail Federation at Stockholm, the text of which was released here.

With cotton yarns no in a relatively free position, there has been a marked increase in competition for business, it was learned yesterday in Worth Street. Contrary to conditions in other segments of the textile industry, there is considerable undercutting of prices on certain types of yarn, and prices generally are equal to or below the last ceiling prices under Office of Price Administration control.
Operation of a new ticket and reservation control system devised to give air travelers spot confirmation of their seat requests was demonstrated yesterday by National Airlines.

BOSTON, Sept. 16 (AP) -- The White Sox, who had not won a game in Boston until yesterday when they knocked the Red Sox out of the American League flag chase, won their second today when they halted the Red Sox, 8 -- 3, in the closing game of a double-header.

TRIESTE, Sept. 16 -- Yugoslav troops attempted today to force their way into the Free Territory of Trieste by intimidation, but were stopped on the demarcation line by the firm stand of twelve American soldiers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (U.P.) -- The Red Cross today alerted its seventy-eight disaster experts from Maine to Florida to prepare "for any eventuality" if the hurricane roaring over the Bahamas should hit the United States mainland.

The Dominion of Pakistan will hale India before the United Nations General Assembly "if the slaughter of Moslems is not stopped in India," Sir Zafrullah Khan, head of the Pakistan delegation to the United Nations, declared yesterday on his arrival at La Guardia Airport from London.

Halcyon Air, unable to win in eight previous starts this season, had the benefit of the Atkinson treatment in the Class C Kilarney purse at Aqueduct yesterday. The treatment consisted of a hustling ride by Master Ted; it resulted in victory for Albert F. Wall's colt at better than 14 to 1.

Increased commutation fares approved recently by the Interstate Commerce Commission were announced yesterday by the West Shore Railroad, a division of the New York Central System, and the Pennsylvania Railroad for stops between New York and North Jersey coast stations on trains operating via the New York Long Branch Railroad.

BOSTON, Sept. 16 -- The United Rubber Workers of the Congress of Industrial Organizations today cracked down on the union leadership in their national convention here by refusing its international headquarters additional funds "to fight the Taft-Hartley Law" and denying increased wages for international leaders of the union and authorization for a union second vice president to handle administrative details.

There was a professional atmosphere about the New York recital debut of Eunice Podis, pianist, at Town Hall last night. The young pupil of Artur Rubinstein has performed throughout the country, and her reputation must have preceded her, to judge by the size of the audience.

With a surplus for discretionary spending, or saving, of $89,000,000,000, the nation's ability to continue use of a plant capable of twice the pre-war volume of production depends on economy in distribution, Don Francisco, vice president, J. Walter Thompson Company, stated yesterday in an address before the Purchasing Agents' Association of New York.

The governing body of Actors Equity Association, AFL, ratified yesterday a resolution requiring all council members, officers or representatives to sign oaths that they are neither Communists nor Fascists. The resolution, which was adopted by the actors' organization last week against strong opposition, will be put into effect "as quickly as possible," according to Clarence Derwent, president.
LONDON, Sept. 16 -- The International Monetary Fund has agreed to provide Britain with $60,000,000 in exchange for sterling within the next few days, the British Treasury announced tonight.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 16 -- A prediction that the United States will adopt a national long-range policy of abundance of production for agriculture, instead of the economy of scarcity that was followed during the New Deal, was made here today by Representative Charles B. Hoeven, Republican, of Iowa, a member of the House Agriculture Committee.

Underwriting syndicates competed here yesterday in four public utility financing transactions involving more than $18,000,000 in new issues of bonds, preferred and common stock. A negotiated transaction -- public offering of 343,106 shares of Atlantic City Electric Company common stock by a Union Securities Corporation syndicate at $20.075 a share -- was announced for today.

The plain choice between a success that would solidify the peace and a failure that would mean another war was presented to the United Nations General Assembly yesterday by Dr. Oswaldo Aranha of Brazil, its new president.

Dr. Oswaldo Aranha, who preided with great success over the special session of the United Naions General Assembly on Palestine last spring, was elected president of the second regular session at its opening meeting at Flushing Meadow yesterday.

Few can be under the illusion that the filing of five formal treaties automatically brings the dawn of peace to any part of Europe. Bulgaria, Rumania and Hungary are either absorbed or being absorbed into the Russian night. Finland waits in a doubtful Arctic twilight.

The second General Assembly session opened in a calm sylvan setting. Delegates and visitors walked toward the great meeting hall through acres of meadow sweet with the scent of freshly cut greensward. Official limousines glittered in bright September sun.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- A vice president of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway Company argued here today before the Interstate Commerce Commission that association of his railroad and the New York Central System would increase the latter's earnings and benefit railroad investments generally.
The United States and British delegations to the United Nations General Assembly lined up openly yesterday behind the campaign to moderate the veto power in the Security Council.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 16 -- Justice Robert H. Jackson of the Supreme Court, drawing on his experiences with the Russians at the Nuremberg trials and elsewhere, declared tonight that it was his reasoned belief that Russia did not now want war.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 16 -- Plans have been completed to merge Slick Airways and California Eastern Airways, two of the largest independent air freight carriers in the country, pending a two-thirds vote by the stockholders of both companies and the approval of the Civil Aeronautics Board, it was learned at Newark Airport today.

An aggregate of $30,895,000 of major new municipal bond issues was placed on the market yesterday following competitive sale, the total including obligations of Los Angeles, Calif.; Cuyahoga County, Ohio, and the State of Connecticut.

Beginning Sept. 28, a newspaper and radio campaign described as the "biggest introductory drive in the history of Sterling Drug, Inc.," will launch Lyons tooth paste into the $86,000,000 annual dentrifice market as a new product of the company's R.L. Watkins Company division.
BONNEVILLE SALT FLATS, Utah, Sept. 16 (AP) -- John Cobb of London today raised the world land speed record to 394.196 miles per hour.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your issue of Sept. 5 you published a letter from Siddig Abdel Railman El-Mahdi. As the eldest son of later Khalif Abdullah El-Taishi, I should be grateful if you would kindly allow me to comment on that letter.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 16 -- After starting out with two first places today in the second teammatch between the top-ranking Long Island Sound skippers and those of the Royal Bermuda Yacht Club in their sister sloops of the International Class, a kite-flying situation developed and the Bermudaians did not fly theirs high enough.

Reporting demands for more and more export control to assure that goods financed with United States dollars shall make a significant contribution to relief and reconstruction abroad, Francis McIntyre, director of the Export Supply Branch of the Office of International Trade, yesterday indicated that foreign dollar balances granted by this country might be withdrawable only through requests naming specific materials.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- A program to insure priority for veterans of World War II in the disposal of permanent war housing was announced today by the Housing and Home Finance Agency. The following order of preferment was set up for the purchase of such Federally owned housing:

The stock market broke out from its state of indecision and confusion yesterday to register the best recovery so far this month. Bolstered by increased interest, the list negotiated a slow but steady advance which reached its peak in the final hour and left values fractions to 2 points higher.

Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander was described yesterday by Mayor O'Dwyer as "the greatest Police Commissioner this city ever had." The Mayor spoke at a ceremony in the residence of the Swedish Consul General, 600 Park Avenue, at which the commissioner received the Swedish Royal Decoration, Order of Vasa, with rank of Commander.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 16 -- John Shepard 3d of Boston, chairman of the Yankee Network in New England, acknowledged today that he was "not paying attention" to the ban of James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, on the duplication of network musical programs over both standard and frequency modulation stations.

The higher top-price limit of $100 for articles in the useful objects exhibit that opens at the Museum of Modern Art today is to be attributed neither to the higher cost of living nor to any loss of interest in good design at low prices.

Buyers' Total Lower for Week Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,221, compared with 2,536 last week. No buyers were reported in the corresponding week of 1946, due to the truck strike at that time.
President Truman is expected to take part in the ceremones formally opening Idlewild Airport in July, Howard S. Cullman, chairman of the Port of New York Authority, announced yesterday.
The United Nations General Assembly moved ahead yesterday at double the pace of its sessions last year, thanks to 1,800 tiny radios hanging around the necks of delegates and visitors.

The future world capital of the United Nations will be a city made largely of glass, with even the forty-story secretariat skyscraper standing like a solid glass block against the skyline, it was disclosed yesterday in a preview attended by wide-eyed General Assembly delegates at the Flushing Meadow hall.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 16 -- Pandit Jawarharlal Nehru, Prime Minister of the Dominion of India, in a statement tonight took sharp exception to criticisms of the Indian Government attributed to Nawabzada Liaqat Ali Khan, Prime Minister of Pakistan, before the West Punjab Moslem League Council in Lahore on Saturday.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Sept. 17 (AP) -- The number of known deaths from typhoon-born floods increased slowly today, with 2,384 Japanese dead or missing, and there was an unconfirmed report that two United States soldiers had been drowned.
National Guard Day was observed throughout the nation yesterday, marking the beginning of an intensive recruiting drive.

LONDON, Sept. 16 -- The board of governors of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development today approved a form of agreement between the bank and the United Nations, one article of which, in effect, set forth that the United Nations should refrain from making recommendations respecting certain loans or conditions of financing.

John D.L. Hood, Australian member of the United Nations special committee of inquiry on Palestine, refused to support either the majority or the minority recommendation of the committee because he felt that the committee's report should present both plans without recommending either.
An important old holding of the Lewisohn interests in Washington Heights was reported yesterday to have passed into new hands in its first change of ownership in forty-four years.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 16 (AP) -- A corporation "is run for the benefit of its stockholders and not for that of its managers," the Third United States Circuit Court of Appeals ruled today. The decision, written by Judge John Biggs Jr., ordered the Transamerica Corporation to submit to stockholders for determination three proposals which the management rejected.

Late Again, Hitler! Captured documents of the German High Command, just made public by the United States Navy Department, disclose that Adolf Hitler, in 1940, swollen with the false confidence engendered by deceiving victories, decided to hurl forty of his divisions into an invasion of Britain, but was deterred by "the indisputable fact that the British people have up to now shown extraordinary morale and most remarkable stamina."

Uppermost in this writer's mind as she sat watching the parade of new styles that took place yesterday morning in Bloomingdale's Green Room Specialty Shop was the thought that as long as New York manufacturers are interpreting the mode for her, the American woman need have no fears.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 16 -- Only five days ago the National League penant race was a blazing bonfire. Today it has become only a dying ember.
CHICAGO, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows.

DETROIT, Sept. 16 -- More than 300 striking garage mechanics returned to their jobs today in what appeared to be a back-breaking assault against a wage walkout which began oh Aug. 19 against seventy-seven automobile dealers in the Detroit area.

The surf caster is coming into his own. Whereas the trout fisherman is reputed to be delayed until the leaf of the willow attains the size of a mouse's ear, the surfcaster begins to find excitement after the leaves have turned and are falling.

SALONIKA, Greece, Sept. 16 -- As a result of the action of Greek Army planes in scattering amnesty leaflets over the mountain areas inviting the guerrillas to give up, Third Army Corps headquarters here reported twenty-five surrenders in Thrace and Macedonia up to late this evening.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Dr. Sutan Sjahrir, "Ambassador at Large" of the Indonesian Republic and its recent spokesman before the United Nations Security Council, declared today that the Indonesian problem "cannot be settled peacefully unless outside parties, as in this present instance the United Nations, take a hand in working out a solution."

Senator Elmer Thomas of Oklahoma, back from Europe a few days ago, declared that "professional belly-achers" in the United States should be "sentenced to thirty days in any part of Europe." Having served their time, he continued severely, they would be very glad indeed to return to the country about which they had been "belly-aching."
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 16 -- The Freedom Train, a shining red, white and blue symbol of democracy, arrived here today, the first stop on its 33,000-mile trans-continental tour.
Hope that the United Nations will succeed in maintaining world peace was expressed yesterday in sermons delivered on the second day of the Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish New Year.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 16 -- The Screen Writers Guild schism of last week over the question of collective royalties for scenarists, which resulted in the resignation of F. Hugh Herbert as secretary, has been healed by a decision of the board of directors to submit the controversial question to the entire guild membership in a mail referendum.

THERE will be a benefit football game at the Polo Grounds tonight with the Hearst disabled veterans fund and other service charities profiting thereby. The contestants in this exhibition fray are the New York Giants and the Los Angeles Rams, a pairing which certainly means that Stout Steve Owen's heroes are in for a mighty rugged evening.

The involved case of art by Gustave Dore and checks by John M. Holzworth came up again yesterday when the Manhattan Storage and Warehouse Company announced Oct. 28 as the date of a new auction for the disposal of the nineteenth-century collection of paintings and etchings.
DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Gene Abbe defeated a select field in the American Legion twenty class pace stake of the Grand Circuit harness racing card at the Delaware County fair today.

The dramatized presentations of reportorial accomplishments known as "The Big Story," broadcast Wednesday nights at 10 o'clock on NBC's network, were renewed for thirteen weeks yesterday by the Pall Mall division of the American Tobacco Company.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 16 -- A strong voice for labor in work of the United Nations was demanded today by R.J. Thomas, vice president of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, in two speeches at the observance of United Nations Week in the Tarrytowns.

BOSTON, Sept. 16 -- Charges that speculative hoarding by distributors had caused increases in food prices in this area were made today to a Congressional sub-committee investigating the causes and possible remedies of the high cost-of-living.

An extensive "gray market" in certain major appliances, particularly refrigerators and electric ranges, is in full swing in several Southern cities and some evidence of it found in New York City, an executive of a nation-wide retail organization disclosed yesterday.

Paul V. McNutt, who recently resigned as the first United States Ambassador to the Philippines, has been engaged to represent the major American motion-picture companies at the forthcoming hearings of the House Committee on Un-American Activities, investigating alleged "Communist influences" in Hollywood films.
GLASGOW, Scotland, Sept. 16 -- Three ships were launched from Scottish shipyards today -- two right here on the Clyde River and one at Dundee.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Immediate blocking of permits to expand American air services both in the United States and abroad was urged today by two leading spokesmen for the American air lines, in testimony before the President's Air Policy Commission.

It is eminently fitting that the Red Cross idea, embracing as it does the ideals of selfless and unselfish service to the wounded, the homeless, the needy and victims of disaster of all kinds, should be instilled in our children during their formative years while learning is their chief occupation.
WARSAW, Sept. 16 -- Efforts to bring nearly 100,000 Westphalians of Polish descent back to work in the Polish mines and factories have provoked a minor crisis in Anglo-Polish relations.

MIAMI, Fla., Wednesday, Sept. 17 -- A severe hurricane menacing life and property on the rich and populous Florida east coast playground area moved slowly early today toward the mainland between West Palm Beach and Miami.

After pleading guilty to a disorderly conduct charge specifying that she smashed a show window, showcases, and a neon sign in a meat and grocery store at 1798 Third Avenue because the proprietor withheld $111 from her $140 relief check to pay her account, Mrs. Fela Cruz, 37 years old, of 201 East 102d Street, was held in Mid-Manhattan Court yesterday for sentence tomorrow.

HARRISON, N.J., Sept. 16 -- Defense coun sel for 14-year-old Fred Walter Smigelski indicated today he would challenge the right to try the youth on a murder charge in the Hudson County Court of Oyer and Terminer.

MT. HOPE, N.Y., Sept. 16 -- Mrs. Edwin C. Longcope of Siwanoy, the new ladies' champion at her home club, won gross honors by a stroke in the weekly oneday tournament staged by the Women's Westchester-and-Fairfield Counties Golf Association today at St. Andrews by carding 43, 40 -- 83.
Cotton futures continued to climb yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange, closing 37 to 53 points net higher them the day before.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Sept. 17 has become known throughout the country as Constitution Day. It was on that day, in 1787, that the Federal Constitutional Convention, sitting in Philadelphia, adopted the Constitution and voted its submission by the Congress to the thirteen states for ratification.

Hobbled by an old injury to his left knee, Frank Sinkwich has asked the New York football Yankees to place him on the voluntary retired list for the remainder of this season. This request by the former All-America halfback from the University of Georgia was revealed last night by Dan Topping, president of the All-America Conference team.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 16 -- It's going to be more fun playing football and teaching it at Brown this year. The trouble is, as Rip Engle sees it, that there are going to be more laughs all around for coaches and players generally in 1947.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) -- The Bethlehem Steel Company reported today it has rejected a Congress of Industrial Organizations' union offer to arbitrate disputed contract issues involved in a twelve-week-old strike against nine Bethlehem shipbuilding plants on the East Coast.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Reports that President Truman's Cabinet Committee on Food would consider at its meeting Monday either a plan for a special session of Congress or one for reimposed controls, voluntary or otherwise, were discounted today at the Department of Agriculture.

Element 96, or curium, the last and heaviest of the four man-made elements, has been isolated for the first time in pure form in sufficient quantity to be visible to the naked eye, it was announced yesterday at the semi-annual meeting of the American Chemical Society in the Hotel New Yorker.
WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Sept. 16 -- Medical scientists attending the sessions of the Georgia Warm Springs Foundation applauded today advances in the treatment of poliomyelitis.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) -- R.V. Gilbert, former research director for the Office of Price Administration, testified today before the Interstate Commerce Commission that he believed that J.H. Parmelee, statistical expert for the Association of American Railroads, had overestimated the carriers' expenses and underestimated their revenue for the last half of this year when he was a witness before the ICC last week.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 16 -- Dr. Wingate M. Johnson, chief of the diagnostic clinic at Wake Forrest College, declared today that the need was for more family physicians and fewer specialists. He spoke at the ninety-seventh convention of the Pennsylvania Medical Society.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., Sept. 16 -- Senator Robert A. Taft, a leader of the Republican majority in the Eightieth Congress, said in practically so many rds today that the party would not go along with the enactment of any program of social legislation until 1949 at the earliest -- in other words, until after the election of 1948.
Observance of meatless days, as in wartime, spread yesterday to Philadelphia, Washington and Chicago as food prices held at the high levels established last week or moved higher.

James S. Lowry has been appointed vice president in charge of sales of Vanity Fair Mills, Inc. He will continue to supervise the Extacee sales division. Calvin Neff will continue to direct the Vanity Fair sales division.

As a result of a disagreement with Preston Tucker, president of the Tucker Corporation, the Chicago automobile manufacturing concern, over the expenditure of funds raised through public financing, Col. Harry A. Toulmin Jr. resigned yesterday as chairman of the board of the corporation.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- A hemispheric labor organization, projected for years by anti-Communist trade unionists, will be realized next January in Lima, Peru, according to plans now in preparation.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 16 -- Local independent radio stations objected strongly today to the proposed new code of standards for the radio industry, asserting primarily that it would put them at a competitive disadvantage with the affiliates of the networks.

Wide approval of Secretary of State Marshall's proposal for limitation of the use of the veto and his suggestion for the creation of a standing "Little Assembly" was indicated yesterday, although several nations, notably Great Britain and France, withheld any disclosure of their attitude.

A BOOK in praise of the pleasures of living within gunshot of the clanking Third Avenue "El" rarely comes our way. We go months at a time without seeing a volume telling how two imaginative people transformed a modern city house designed by Lescaze into a log cabin lit by kerosene lamps and swarming with authentic imported mosquitos.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Sept. 17 -- Midway in a thousand-mile air inspection of the great reclamation projects of the Southwest, Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio asserted today that his party has "always favored development of all feasible projects."

About 4.3 per cent of the steel bought by domestic consumers in the last six months was obtained in the gray market, The Iron Age, national metalworking publication, reported yesterday on the basis of a survey of 1,500 steel consuming companies.

The Italian-flag liner Vulcania, well known to Atlantic travelers a decade ago for her luxurious accommodations, is scheduled to arrive here Monday with 1,400 passengers on her first voyage after reconditioning at a Genoa shipyard.

The text of the address made yesterday by Secretary of State Marshall to the United Nations General Assembly, as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES, follows: Mr. President-Fellow Delegates: I have been asked by the President of the United States to extend to you the cordial greetings of the Government and people of the United States, as well as his own warm personal welcome.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17 -- More than 10,000 factory managers, master mechanics, works managers and production superintendents from leading plants throughout the country started pressing for early deliveries from machine-tool builders exhibiting at the Dodge-Chicago plant national tool exposition here today.

An immediate stockpiling of relief packages for Europe to meet the needs of approaching winter was urged on the Cooperative for American Remittances to Europe, a non-profit organization, by Gen. Lucius Clay, commandant of the American Zone of Germany, in a cable message yesterday to CARE headquarters in New York.

DETROIT, Sept. 17 (AP) -- KaiserFrazer Corporation, which has produced slightly more than 84,000 automobiles so far this year, is aiming at an output of 1,500 vehicles a day by early next spring, according to Edgar F. Kaiser, vice president and general manager.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 17 -- Construction costs of the first phase of a proposed pipeline to be operated by the Michigan-Wisconsin Pipe Line Company will approximate $72,500,000 after allowing $700,000 for working capital, the Securities and Exchange Commission was told today.

DETROIT, Sept. 17 -- Civil war between the left and right flanks of the United Automobile Workers of the Congress of Industrial Organizations broke out today when Walter P. Reuther, anti-Communist president of the union of 900,000 members, issued a blunt appeal for the ousting of his topranking adversaries.

TRIESTE, Sept. 17 -- Tension between Anglo-American and Yugoslav military forces, which has been keeping Allied troops in a state of permanent alert, continued today. Yugoslavs claimed seven of the sixteen Allied-manned outposts along the border between the Free Territory of Trieste and Yugoslavia.

The police guard of six detectives that had been watching twenty-four hours a day over Emetia Polizio, Queens bookmaker, since July 23, was ordered removed yesterday by Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander. Polizio gave a "general release" to the city, foregoing any claim for damages for the curtailment of his liberty.

Consumer resistance to high food prices lowered wholesale meat prices a little yesterday and forced breaks of 1 1/2 to 2 1/2 cents in all wholesale butter prices as a national committee of businessmen was organized to seek to cope with the situation.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17 -- Bill Nicholson drove his twenty-third homer of the campaign into the rightfield bleachers at Wrigley Field today and halted the Giants within a stride of a five-game winning streak.

Sentiment seems to be developing in the City Council to look into the question whether tax exemption in some degree might be a substantial encouragement to housing construction. It will not be easy, probably, to determine in advance how much effect such a measure would have.

PARIS, Sept. 17 -- A warning that United States aid to Europe in the coming winter will be vital to the success of the Marshall plan will be given in the final chapter of the report that the European Economic Conference on that plan is expected to adopt Saturday.
TOKYO, Sept. 17 -- The United States and the Soviet Union clashed again at today's meeting of the Allied Council for Japan.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows. HOGS Salable hogs 7.500 head, total 10,500; weights under 260 pounds 25 to 50 cents lower; closed very dull and 50 to 75 cents lower on weights under 210 pounds, weights 260 pounds and over
LONDON, Sept. 17 -- "Jane's Fighting Ships 1946-47," published today, predicts that the main armament of battleships will be guided missiles as a counter to atomic bombs.

The condition of former Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia became increasingly grave last night after a day in which expressions of concern emanated from all parts of the city. Dr. George Baehr, his personal physician for many years, said in a bulletin at 10:30 P.M. that the former Mayor was not expected to regain full consciousness.

BOSTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Only a broken bat single, looped into right field by Wally Judnich in the seventh inning, kept Red Sox pitcher Joe Dobson from hurling a no-hitter today as he blanked the Browns, 4 -- 0, in the second game of a double-header before 7,064 fans. The cellar dwelling St. Louis club won the opener 9 -- 4.

MIAMI, Thursday, Sept. 18 -- A wide belt of southern Florida was left badly buffeted and shaken today by a vicious week-old hurricane which lashed 150 miles across the peninsula and into the Gulf of Mexico.

Secretary of State Marshall addressed the parliament of the world yesterday in terms that left no doubt that the United States has seized the diplomatic offensive and means to force a showdown on an issue no less crucial than the existence of the United Nations and the whole dream and plan of international cooperation of which it is the symbol and the instrument.

FORT PIERCE, Fla., Sept. 17 (AP) -- Passengers aboard trains in lower Florida got an air-conditioned view of the hurricane today. It lashed the peninsula mainly from West Palm Beach to Miami, but this area felt the winds, too. Two trains from Miami cleared through here this afternoon for the north, but five passenger and four freight trains bound for the South were held up until tracks are cleared of fallen trees and other debris.

The Canadian Government has never liked the veto provision of the United Nations Charter "and would now support any practicable improvement," Humphrey Hume Wrong, Canadian Ambassador to the United States, declared yesterday.

LONDON, Sept. 17 -- The Vienna State Opera opened its London season of three weeks at the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden, last night with "Don Giovanni," which of all operas is best calculated to test the company's capacity. Its performances will include Mozart's three Italian comedies (sung, of course, in German), "Fidelio" and "Salome."

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 17 -- "Free For All," heralded as a comedy satire on communism, in which Brock Pemberton, Broadway producer, had at least a prospective interest, opened at the Belasco last night. It would appear to offer less grounds for concern to Mr. Stalin than to Mr. Pemberton.

The only full-dress trans-Atlantic liner in the United States merchant marine, the America, which was held here for eight days after her last listed departure on Aug. 20 because of a waterfront strike, departed on schedule yesterday. She had 880 passengers bound for Cobh, Cherbourg and Southampton. The ship, operated by the United States Lines, left Pier 61, North River, at 4:12 P.M.

BOSTON, Sept. 17 -- When a Lowell speaks to a Cabot these days, you don't have to eavesdrop to know what it's about, and it's no surprise if the Cabot, without apology to the Deity, speaks to the Lowell. The whole town's talking about the Boston College line.

Secretary of State Marshall's speech before the United Nations General Assembly yesterday served notice or a change in United States veto policy, a change that for the first time threw United States support to the countries that have pressed for abolition of the veto in the peaceful settlement of disputes.

BOSTON, Sept. 17 -- Growing agition by labor and consumer groups for a special session of congress to take action on the rising cost of living prompted assurances today by Senator Raymond Baldwin, Republican, of Conecticut, that the Congressional committee investigating prices ould keep an "open mind" on the subject.

Although it will carry no weight during the forthcoming National Football League campaign, a tremendous upset was recorded last night at the Polo Grounds, where the New York Giants toppled the Los Angeles Rams, 30 -- 3, in an exhibition contest before 28,834 spectators.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- The first case testing the ruling or anti-Communist affidavits by Robert N. Denham, general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board, was filed with the board today by the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, American Federation of Labor.

Taking vigorous exception to intimations that he was "gunning for or out to get" Baseball Commissioner A.B. (Happy) Chandl, Larry MacPhail, president of the Yankees, yesterday put it on the record that he had the highest respect for the office of the Commissioner and enjoyed cordial relations with its present occupant.

Appointment of a "czar" to settle labor disputes in the social welfare field and creation of a permanent arbitration panel were suggested yesterday by Frederick I. Daniels, executive director, of the Brooklyn Bureau of Social Service.

NANKING, Sept. 17 (U.P.) -- Chinese Communist raiders were reported attacking south of the Yangtze River today. The semiofficial Central News Agency said Communist troops had penetrated Chenghsien and Nanling respectively forty-five and thirty miles southwest of Wuhu.

That there is no arbitrary silhouette for the fall season was the theme of a fashion show at Milgrim yesterday. The showing opened with a sequence of new styles, each one in a completely different silhouette.
Mayor O'Dwyer publicly laid down the rule yesterday that there can be only one boss of the Police Department, Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander, and that "when it comes to operations I don't butt in."

LONDON, Sept. 17 -- A tentative plan through which Great Britain and the United States could be relieved of some of the economic burden of the industrial rehabilitation of the Ruhr through an international loan was divulged today by John J. McCloy, president of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- A November grain export allocation of 788,800 long tons, or 29,514,000 bushels, was announced today by the Department of Agriculture, a sharp cut from the October export quota of 1,213,400 long tons, or 45,685,000 bushels.

Col. Wassily de Basil, manager of the original Ballet Russe, was directed yesterday by Federal Judge John Bright to pay $52,250 plus costs to Universal Art, Inc., for "deliberate" breach of a contract entered into on April 15, 1938, to merge the two ballet organizations.

Behind the seven-hit pitching of Allie Reynolds, the Yankees made a start toward altering the one unsatisfactory entry in their ledger as 1947. American League champions by defeating the White Sox, 5-0, at the Stadium yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities show the following principal changes for the week ended Sept. 10, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

Synthesis of element 61 and its preparation for the first time in pure form, thus filling in the last gap in the Periodic Table of Elements, was announced yesterday at the semi-annual meeting of the American Chemical Society at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (NANA) -- A change in the course of the Florida hurricane has prevented an experimental "seeding" of the storm's clouds with dry ice dropped from Army planes. The attempt was to have been made in an effort to dissipate the storm's strength by artificially inducing heavy rainfall.

YESTERDAY'S EVENTS General Assembly Met at 11:23 A.M. and received Secretary General's report on matters before Security Council and its decision to refer Greek question to Assembly for recommendations.

The city of Baltimore, Md., announced yesterday that it would receive bids on Oct. 1 on bond issues aggregating $21,200,000 to finance various sewerage, school building and equipment, airport, stadium and recreational improvements. The bonds will come due from 1953 to 1957.

PURCHASE, N.Y., Sept. 17 -- Air commuting service between the Westchester County Airport here and an amphibian plane base on the East River at Wall Street in New York will begin next Wednesday, Air Commuting, Inc., announced today at a demonstration of its new twin-motored Grumman Mallards and other facilities.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Negotiations to end the strike of the 30,000 Bethlehem Shipbuilding Company workers collapsed today. The strike began June 25. Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, asserted that the company, "in callous disregard of the welfare of its employes and the public, has rejected a union offer to arbitrate the differences which forced 30,000 workers to strike."

The stories from Glasgow by Herbert Matthews detailing the remarkable peacetime record of British shipbuilding yards are pleasant reading by themselves. They are a comparatively bright spot in a generally gloomy picture of British economy. No one will want to deny the British that bit of cheer.

Ministers and lay delegates to the annual fall convention of the New York Conference of the United Lutheran Synod of New York at St. Peter's Lutheran Church, Lexington Avenue and Fifty-fourth Street, were urged yesterday morning by the synod's president, the Rev. Dr. Frederick R. Knubel, to oppose gambling games as means of raising money for church support.

DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Forbes Chief, brown colt from the Newport Stock Farm of South Plainfield, N.J., won the second $38,200 "Little Brown Jug" for 3year-old pacers in straight heats today, each in 2:05 to take down a purse of $19,100.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Sept. 17 -- Frank B. Moore, Controller of New York State, recommended here tonight that county governments undertake the task of providing better library service.
New York became yesterday the nation's first city to establish local controls over apartment rents and evictions.

The great, whirling wind has struck Florida and is pounding away on a 200mile front. Miami, however, has opened up hope by reporting escape from major, damage or loss of life. It is described as the worst storm to lash Florida since the hurricane of 1928, which cost 2,500 lives and did $75,000,000 damage.

Harold E. Stassen, former Governor of Minnesota and avowed candidate for the Republican nomination for President, yesterday called upon President Truman to call a special session of Congress to give immediate aid to Europe to prevent starvation there this winter and to begin the implementation of the Marshall plan for the economic reconstruction of those nations willing to accept it.

Returning to Ohio Field on the University Heights campus yesterday after a three-week practice session at the Lake Sebago camp, New York University's football squad still faces many more hours of drill before its opening game with Temple University in Philadelphia, Sept. 26.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange turned easier yesterday and closed 53 to 67 points net lower than Tuesday's final levels.

Columbia re-established pre-war eligibility standards for its varsity teams yesterday, and consequently lost two members of the football squad just ten days before its opening game of the season with Rutgers.

A plea for further aid to the war's survivors overseas "even at the cost of a reduction in the general standard of living" here was made yesterday by the executive committee of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- even Senators set out today to nd a "long range farm program" at will "get crops on consumers' bles without having price increases of 300 or 400 per cent."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Maj. Gen. Edmond H. Leavey, chief of transportation in the War Department, asked today for a closer working relationship with the transportation industry. He spoke at a meeting of the transportation corps advisory committee and the board of directors of the Army Transportation Association.

Following is the fourth of five articles by the United States' war time Ambassador to London on his mission there. They are taken from his book "Letter From Grosvenor Square," which will be published soon by Houghton Mifflin Company.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Unable to count definitely on a special session of Congress to provide emergency relief for Europe, the State Department has speeded up the adjudication of foreign government claims against this country to prevent any interruption of food and fuel shipments to the neediest continental nations.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 17 -- Solution of the Palestine question at Lake Success might strengthen world confidence in the United Nations, Dr. Victor Hoo, Assistant Secretary General of the organization, declared here tonight at a United Nations week celebration in the stadium of Washington Irving High School.

NANKING, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Government forces, trying to pin down Gen. Liu Po-cheng, were reported today to have stormed into Shucheng, 120 miles southwest of Nanking, forcing the Communists to flee westward.

Canadian Currency Recent rumors that Canada was considering devaluing the Canadian dollar -- a step that would undo the 1946 upward revaluation of the Dominion currency-were revived yesterday in financial circles along with the ballooning of another possibility:

The Texas Company mailed last night to its stockholders warrants giving them the right to subscribe to one additional share at $45 for each five shares held. The warrants will expire on Oct. 8. They were sent to holders of record at the close of business yesterday.

Rounded shoulders, only lightly padded, and all manner of high flaring or wide shawl collars that could be wrapped close to the throat were features of the custom -made furs shown by Gunther yesterday at the Hotel Pierre. Most of them were designed by Alice Orovan.

The Union of South Africa submitted to the United Nations yesterday a detailed memorandum denying year-old charges that it had discriminated against Indian nationals living within its domain and in turn blaming the Indian Government for the existence of strained relations between the two nations.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- The clamor for renewal of domestic price and allocation controls of foodstuffs, in which some leaders of both wings of organized labor have taken the lead, is making many politicians in the two major parties more shy than ever of an extra session of Congress.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The most voluble complaints about the "high cost of living" come from organized labor, through the mouths of union leaders. The cry goes on -- wages must be increased because of the "high cost of living." Even one of our leading publications has fallen into the error of saying that "labor rates have grown because the cost of living has risen."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Mrs. Elmira Bears Wickenden, executive secretary of the National Nursing Council for War Service, received today the Medal of Merit for her work in recruiting the nurse-supply of World War II.

LONDON, Sept. 17 -- Eamon de Valera, Prime Minister of Ireland, will come to London Friday to discuss with Prime Minister Attlee plans for closer cooperation in meeting Europe's economic crisis, and particularly the dollar shortage, it was announced today.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Sept. 17 -- Authoritative sources reported tonight that the Bulgarian Supreme Court of Appeal had rejected the appeal of Nikola Petkov, Agrarian Opposition leader, who has been sentenced to hang for allegedly attempting to overthrow Premier Georgi Dimitrov's Fatherland Front Government.

We have had two reminders this week that Britain has by no means exhausted all available sources of "stopgap" funds, pending the establishment of a long-term self-aid plan. On Monday she turned over $80,000,000 of her gold holdings for American dollars and followed this action on Tuesday by obtaining another $60,000,000 from the Monetary Fund in exchange for sterling.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17 -- Grain markets were weak early today on a continuation of general liquidation created by uncertainty as to what action directors of the Board of Trade would take regarding increasing margin requirements on grain trading at their meeting tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- James Forrestal took the oath of office today as the nation's first Secretary of Defense in a ceremony...
SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 17 -- The Joint United States-Soviet Commission held its sixtieth meeting here this afternoon.

Stocks put on a bullish display yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange and, accompanied by the first million-share session and the widest gains in two months, prices climbed 1 to 3 points. The sharp run-up, which canceled out the losses of the last two weeks, encompassed practically every key section of the list and left only 118 out of the 1,034 issues traded on the lower side at the close.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Robert A. Lovett, Acting Secretary of State, today notified Vyacheslav M. Molotov, Soviet Foreign Minister, that the United States would refer the Korean problem to the General Assembly of the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Robert R. Young confidently promised today a "revolutionary" improvement in the service, equipment and financial position of the New York Central if the Interstate Commerce Commission permitted him to accept a directorship of that railroad.

Despite the marked success which Father's Day has achieved within the last ten years, "the surface has barely been scratched," Clare E. Nelson, general sales manager of the Manhattan Shirt Company, said yesterday at a luncheon meeting held by the Father's Day Council of its industry cochairmen at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17 -- A dispute behind the scenes between Preston Tucker, president of the Tucker Corporation, and Col. H.A. Toulmin Jr., who resigned yesterday as chairman of the board of the company, broke out today into a public verbal battle which included critical comments by Mr. Toulmin in the morning and a rebuttal session conducted by Mr. Tucker in the afternoon.

The need for Americans to rededicate themselves to the principles of democracy underlying the United States Constitution and through doing this to set an example for the rest of the world was emphasized yesterday by speakers at ceremonies throughout the city marking the 160th anniversary of the signing of the Constitution.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Locked controls probably caused the crash of the United Air liner when forty-three persons were killed at La Guardia Field May 29, the Civil Aeronautics Board said today.

With the International Tuna Matches over, the tuna that hover around in the Wedgeport (Nova Scotia) rip gave up their partial fast and began grabbing at every herring in sight, including several with hooks attached.

A librarian who did more than lend books, a museum director who did more than collect and display objects of beauty -- such was the late Beatrice Winser of Newark. Miss Winser, whose career of fifty-eight years' service at the Newark Public Library and the Newark Museum ended in recent retirement, had the perspective of a true citizen.

Kent Miller's Elkridge, who keeps rolling along season after season, hit another medium-sized jackpot at Aqueduct yesterday when he took the first award of $7,850 hi the twenty-ninth Glendale Steeplechase Handicap. Hitting jackpots is an old story to Elkridge; the 9-year-old gelding was the nation's No. 1 moneywinning steeplechaser as far back as 1942.
Southern Florida was under a virtual communications blackout yesterday, blocking the efforts of New York residents to make contact with friends and relatives in the stricken hurricane area.

Renovations and improvements at Carnegie Hall, from the concert stage to the top balcony and including, for the first time in the auditorium's fifty-six-year history, the addition of a bar, are planned for the opening of the fall concert season.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Nathan D. Golden, motion picture consultant for the Department of Commerce, testified today that the average motion picture operator would "have no difficulty whatsoever" learning to operate the Thomascolor projector.

Following our column a week ago today on substitutes for butter in bread spreads and general cookery, several inquiries have been received asking such questions as these: May salad oil pinch hit for butter in cakes?

Scout, the springer spaniel K-9 war veteran that last spring gained nation-wide attention and even an appeal to President Truman, when he was saved from the gas chamber, is in the Bronx animal shelter again -- this time probably doomed to death, for biting a fourth person.

WARRENTON, N.C., Sept. 17 (AP) -- The Warren County grand jury today freed two white men of conspiracy charges growing out of the unsuccessful attempt of a masked mob to lynch a 22-year-old Negro in adjoining Northampton County last May.

Despite a good supply of Broadway showcases, one of those booking entanglements loomed yesterday. Benefiting considerably from an upturn in business which became noticeable last week, "Call Me Mister" now will be transferred from the Majestic to the Plymouth Theatre on Monday evening, Oct. 6.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Testimony by leaders of the air transport industry today before the President's Air Policy Commission brought virtually unanimous opinion that the Government should spend more money on this transportation arm, and spend it faster.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 17 -- Another incident occurred today in the hidden but grim struggle between the rival organizations of the Zionist underground for control of the situation in Palestine during the United Nations deliberations on the country's future.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 17 -- The Dodgers moved another step nearer the world series gravy train tonight when they beat the cellardwelling Pirates, 4 -- 2, before 33,916 fans, who crowded into Forbes Field for the festival.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 17 -- A charge that the home-building industry was being subjected to a continuing "political attack" because of the housing shortage, despite a "tripling of production" in a two-year period, was made today by Walter W. McAllister, president of the United States Savings and Loan League.

PRAGUE, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Slovak Ministry of Interior officials conferred in Bratislava tonight but declined to confirm reports that arrests had exceeded 600 in what they said was a plot aimed at the overthrow of the Czech Government and the assassination of President Eduard Benes.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (U.P.) -- The New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today for permission to raise its passenger coach fares by 15 per cent.

Although there has been an increase in the number of American buyers visiting Great Britain to purchase woolens, they are showing greater discrimination in their selections, according to W. Thow Munro, chairman of a delegation of British weaving and knitting manufacturers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Limited to one hit by Ray Scarborough in the first five innings, Cleveland blasted him for five runs in the sixth and added two more runs off Milo Candini in the seventh to defeat the Senators, 7 to 0, tonight behind the six-hit pitching of Al Gettel.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17 -- Excessively high margin requirements on grain will upset trading and will provide no cure for the high price situation, J.O. McClintock, president of the Chicago Board of Trade, said today at a press conference in the office of the board.
LONDON, Sept. 17 -- With increased prospects of a Government budget in the coming fall, the stock markets here today started the new account on a cautious note.

ON BOARD THE U.S.S. MISSOURI, at Sea, Sept. 17 -- President Truman invoked tonight a recently enacted law to make surplus war property available to victims of the Florida hurricane. In response to an inquiry by J.W. Follin, acting administrator of the Public Works Agency, the President sent the following radio message:

PARIS, Sept. 17 -- A mutiny in a prison camp housing Vichy regime collaborationists near Toulouse last Sunday threatens to become a political issue in the October local elections, informed political opinion believed today.

BERLIN, Sept. 17 -- Denazification will be virtually eliminated in the United States zone for all but the "hard core" of fanatical Nazis by a law that will be proposed to the German Ministers Friday by Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 17 -- Senator Edward Martin, Republican, of Pennsylvania, denounced communism and its sympathizers in America today at the christening of the Freedom Train. The spirit of the rolling shrine, he said, was this country's best weapon against the doctrine.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 17 (AP) -- For the second successive time in five days, Lefty Johnny Vander Meer flashed his old pitching form today, shutting out the Phillies with four hits and leading Cincinnati to a 12-to-0 victory.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 17 -- Paced by Stephen (Laddie) Sanford's three goals in the first two chulckers the Hurricanes turned back the Freebooters, 5 -- 3, in the opening round of the Autumn Plates 12-goal tournament on Cochrane Field at the Meadow Brook Club today.

ALBANY, Sept. 17 -- Governor Dewey is expected to deliver a major speech on national and international food problems Oct. 10 at Ithaca, where he will help dedicate Savage Hall, a new building housing the School of Nutrition of Cornell University.

"Every type of artist and designer whose work contributes to making a home is represented in an exhibit, "The Modern House Comes o Life," that will open today at the Bertha Schaefer Gallery, 32 East Fifty-seventh Street.

Requests for an increase of $600 a year in the pay of the city's 30,000 policemen and firemen and the 97,000 employes of other city departments, excluding the Board of Transportation, Board of Education and Board of Higher Education, were made yesterday by three organizations of city employes.

THEY'VE been saying for the longest while that Madison Square Garden has been having minor league fights at major league prices. But the major leaguers will return tomorrow night when Tony Pellone and Tony Janiro, the first and second ranking welterweights behind Ray Robinson by last week's N.B.A. ratings, will square off in what promises to be a bristling battle.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept 17 -- The Dominion of India Government today for the first time included in an official Information Ministry announcement reports that Pakistan troops were operating against non-Moslem Indians in West Punjab.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 17 -- Sailing skippers who moor them selves and their craft between Stamford, Conn., and this yachting center scored this morning another victory in their international class match with the Royal Yacht Club of Bermuda.

It is notable that in the list of entries just released by the United States Golf Association for the forty-seventh women's national amateur golf championship, which starts at the Franklin Hills Country Club, Franklin, Mich., on Monday, that this, their greatest event, will be without benefit of Mrs. Babe Didrikson Zaharias, the 1946 winner.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 17 (AP) -- It may be different when the play begins, but insofar as Baseball Commissioner A.B. Chandler is concerned the numberical strength of the Dodgers and the Yankees in the coming world series will be the same, with twenty-seven athletes on each club.

An advertising and merchandising portfolio titled "Plus Profit Power" has been distributed to 2,000 department and retail specialty stores throughout the United States by the Brand Names Foundation, it was announced yesterday. Showing examples of brand name promotion and advertising campaigns by retail stores in all sections of the county the portfolio explains how retailers can meet the increased demand for branded products.

Fantasy for children, as concocted for "Land of the Lost," will be extended on the WJZ-ABC chain when the program returns to the kilocycles as a Saturday morning feature Oct. 11 at 11:30. Red Lantern, Kid Squid and J. Edgar Bullfish will reappear among the undersea characters in the half-hour show, which was conceived and is written by Isabel Manning Hewson.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Sept. 17 -- Immediate psychological treatment of poliomyelitis victims was recommended here today as the key to their return to a satisfying life. Insecurity, feare and uncertainties can be eradicated by giving patients an understanding of their actual and potential physical and mental assets, Dr. Morton A. Seidenfeld, director of psychological services of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, asserted.

The Hattie Carnegie Jeune Fille Salon, 31 East Forty-eighth Street, has broadened its horizon. It has done it not only stylewise but also on a financial basis, for this branch of Hattie Carnegie's, which is run by Josephine Hughes and has hitherto shown fashions for the budget-minded, has increased prices on part of its fashions.
ON BOARD U.S.S. MISSOURI, at Sea, Sept. 16 -- This 55,000-ton battleship, taking President Truman home from Brazil, steamed along tonight after another day of warlike operations.

See Shortage of Wool Underwear A shortage in heavyweight wool knit underwear will be felt this winter, according to trade sources yesterday, Output in units; it was reported, will be close to that of a year ago, but demand has been stepped up by continued employment in the heavy industries and fewer work stoppages.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 17 (AP) -- The Athletics knocked Detroit out of second place into third and moved within stepping distance of the first division as they beat the Tigers in both ends of a twin bill today.

Although Fordham outscored City College three touchdowns to two in an informal football scrimmage at the Rams' field yesterday, both Coach Ed Danowski of the Maroon and Dr. Harold J. Parker, the Beaver mentor, declared that they were satisfied with the results of the ninety-minute workout.
Wrecking crews yesterday started tearing down the sturdy brick walls of the old Vanderbilt mansion at the northwest corner of Fifty-first Street and Fifth Avenue.

TOKYO, Thursday, Sept. 18 (AP) -- The United States Army reported today that flood waters were pouring into five northern and eastern districts of Tokyo, while fresh reports from the typhoon disaster pushed the unofficial casualty toll to 3,370.

To make use of every foot of space in a new steel house 23 by 39 1/2 feet, unit furniture that can be adapted to small areas was selected by Gimbels decorators in charge of the interior. The house, now on display in Wilton. Conn., costs $9,809 plus $4,000 for the furnishings.

Because of ineffective training methods and emphasis on comparatively short periods of study, only a fraction of the 1,200,000 teachers at work in schools in the United States have had adequate preparation for a career in education, Dean Ernest O. Melby of the New York University School of Education declared yesterday in his annual report to Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 17 (AP) -- The Braves and Cardinals each pounded the ball for fifteen hits tonight but the Boston club staved off a lastminute rally to down the Red Birds, 10 to 8 -- the fifth straight Cardinal defeat.

As the site for a large commercial building to be erected by the new owner for his occupancy, a plot 12 by 108 feet at 95 to 103 Worth Street has been sold by Henry Goelet, operator, to a client of Braislin, Porter Baldwin, Inc. It runs through the block to Catherine Lane, just east of Broadway, and at present is used as a parking lot.

MANHASSET, L.I., Sept. 17 -- Ten thousand persons thronged today through the wide entrances of the new Long Island store of B. Altman Co., its third suburban branch. The store opened this morning on Northern Boulevard at the Gate here.
OTTAWA, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Canada's adverse trade balance with the United States rose $84,900,000 in July to reach the record high of $572,800,000 for the first seven months of the year.

GENEVA, Sept. 17 -- Representatives James G. Fulton of Pennsylvania and Jacob K. Jalvits of New York, Republicans, of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, said today they were impressed with the work being done at the Geneva Trade Conference.
Slowed by age but resplendent in coats of lacquer and enamel and shining nickel, brass and copper, ancient automobiles rumbled away from the Hotel Plaza yesterday morning for Hartford, Conn.

A former Communist, once high in the councils of the party, set forth yesterday at the John Santo deportation hearing the Communist formula for a successful revolution by force and violence in this country.
Really liking children and thinking that they are important and interesting is basic to successful work with boys and girls, Jennie N. Haxton, author and educator, declared yesterday.

GENEVA, Sept. 17 -- A spokesman for the Swiss Government denied today that the Swiss were responsible for the lag in carrying out the agreement with the Western Allies on the liquidation of German assets in Switzerland.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 17 -- The American Federation of Musicians, of which James C. Petrillo is president, imposed today a new ban on the appearance of "live" musicians over a network of frequency modulation radio stations.

Crude oil production in the United States last week reached a new peak, with output averaging 5,217,300 barrels daily, an increase of 44,250 over the previous week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Crude oil runs to refineries also established a record weekly average of 5,318,000 barrels daily, or 72,000 higher than the 5,246,000 in the preceding week.

Dclaring that "safe roadway, safe equipment and safe thinking and methods" had brought railroad travel to a high level of safety, William T. Faricy, president of the Association of American Railroads, said last night that the 1946 passenger fatality rate was one for every 629,000,000 miles traveled, and the injury rate was one for every 14,000,000 miles traveled.

Because of high food prices, "many families are now 'eating thier clothing,' " Miss Laura M. Piedalue, home economist at Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York, declared yesterday at its headquarters, 477 Madison Avenue.

GLASGOW, Scotland, Sept. 17 -- British shipbuilders, despite the fact that they are producing more ships than the rest of the world put together, are harrassed, unhappy and disappointed men these days. While Americans look on in wonder and admiration at the great new transatlantic liners coming along, the men who build them are disgruntled.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., Sept. 17 -- The Southern Newspaper Publishers Association served notice in a statement of policy today that its members would accept "no demands in violation of the provisions of the labor-management relations act."
