POLA, Yugoslavia, Sept. 16 (Delayed) -- Yugoslav administrators told a crowd of about 5,000 today that Allied troops had acted worse than Germans during their stay in Pola. They were charged with "fleeing from the city in a cowardly fashion."

MOSCOW, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Mosow's newspapers published a Tass lispatch from New York today asserting that United States policy in the United Nations sought to subject the world peace organization to the White House, or failing that, to wreck the United Nations.
Secretary of State Marshall proposed yesterday that the United Nations General Assembly establish a standing committee that would "consider situations and disputes impairing friendly relations."

Fifteen hundred persons in Manhattan Center last night cheered attacks on the Government's deportation proceeding against John Santo, international organizer of the Transport Workers Union, and approved a drive to raise $100,000 to carry the case to the United States Supreme Court.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission reviewed today tobacco purchases by P. Lorillard Company, Inc., in an inquiry into company claims as to the use of "price crops" in Old Gold cigarettes.

Offerings of new public utility securities aggregating more than $16,000,000 will be made to investors by underwriting managers here today as follows: Monongahela Power Company -- $7,000,000 of first mortgage 3 per cent thirty-year bonds at 102 to yield 2.90 per cent, by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Penner Beane; Hallgarten Co.; Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis, and Francis I. du Pont Co.

A medical report that the pilot and two crew members had been drinking before the wreck of the American Airlines experimental plane Alpha at La Guardia Field last Aug. 8 caused the Queen's District Attorney's office yesterday to begin an inquiry into the crash, in which the three men were killed.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Sept. 17 -- The eleventh annual Antique Sale and Exhibition opened this morning at the Y.M.C.A., with sixty dealers -- mostly from New Jersey and near-by points in New York -- showing their wares on three floors of the building.

The Providence Worcester Railroad Company, a leased line of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad Company, awarded yesterday at competitive sale an issue of $1,500,000 of twenty-year bonds to Adams Peck and H. Hentz Co.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 17 -- Romney Brent, who was on Broadway last season as the Dauphin in "Joan of Lorraine," with Ingrid Bergman, has been signed by Warner Brothers to play Philip III of Spain in "The Adventures of Don Juan," an Errol Flynn film, the studio announced today.

ROME, Sept. 17 -- The Italian labor situation took a turn for the better tonight. It was announced that the 900,000 steel workers who struck yesterday morning would return to work tomorrow after their forty-eight-hour walkout. Direct negotiations were resumed for settlement of the farm laborers' strike in the Po Valley which has been in progress since Monday of last week.

A Soviet motion to delete the Greek question from the agenda of the United Nations General Assembly was defeated yesterday, by a vote of 12 to 2, at a meeting of the Assembly's General Committee at Flushing Meadow. The debate was brief but sharp, forecasting the clash that lies ahead.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 17 -- Finishing his round with an eagle two, Robinson Murray of the home club posted a 76 today to pace the field in the thirteenth annual championship tournament of the Westchester Seniors Golf Association at the Westchester Hills Golf Club.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 17 -- Charles R. Denny Jr., chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, told the nation's broadcasters today that radio was still "too commercial" and urged them to act on a new code of standards.
ALBANY, Sept. 17 (AP) -- A State Education Department official said today soaring food prices have forced increases in school lunch prices.

Oligarchy in the Wilderness Oligarchy is a form of government far removed from the liberal and democratic American tradition. The Greeks, of course, knew all about it. When the rich, who were always few, got control of a city state and proceeded to oppress the poor, who were always many, that was an oligarchy as Aristotle understood it.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It seems to me that the veto abolitionists underestimate their task.
Harold E. Stassen, former Governor of Minnesota, talked to political reporters yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel and discussed frankly his candidacy for the Republican nomination for President.

Commitments by a "well-known American financial group" have assured establishment of Egypt's first steel plant. It will be erected in Assuan Province, in the southern portion of the country, within eighteen months, Leon Setton, Cairo industrialist and a leading member of an Egyptian financial syndicate interested in the project, disclosed yesterday.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 18 -- Around the Rio de Janeiro waterfront comments were heard today: "Those North Americanos are really unique."

GENEVA, Sept. 18 -- The immediate calling of a United Nations conference to lay down plans for the liquidation of the displaced persons problem within three years was recommended today by the House Foreign Affairs Subcommittee that has been studying the problem in Europe.

PATERSON, N.J., Sept. 18 -- With impressive ceremony, the Most Rev. Thomas Aloysius Boland was installed this morning as the second Bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Paterson. He becomes the spiritual leader of 135,000 North Jersey Catholics in Passaic, Morris and Sussex Counties.

BOSTON, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Trailing by six runs after the first three innings, the Boston Red Sox rallied today, poling fourteen of their sixteen hits in the next three innings for all their runs in a 10-6 victory over the St. Louis Browns. The smallest crowd of the season, 3,592, was in the stands.

BOSTON, Sept. 18 -- Denials that meat, butter and eggs had been hoarded to promote shortages and thus raise prices were made by distributors today to a Congressional subcommittee investigating the high cost of living as it ended hearings here.

MINDEN, Germany, Sept. 18 -- United States and British officials have launched a thorough investigation of the German steel industries to determine whether imports of steel products from the United States are necessary to rehabilitate the economy of the Ruhr, it was learned today.

Turkey, the Philippine Islands and Japan -- and of course the United States -- are bright spots in a world otherwise depressing because of misery, poverty and the spread of communism, Frank E. Gannett reported yesterday. The publisher of the Gannett Newspapers spoke at a luncheon of the National Association of Public Relations Counsel, at the Hotel Lexington.

The semi-annual report of the Home Insurance Company of New York issued to stockholders yesterday shows that total admitted assets on June 30, last, were $184,818,098, compared with $177,414,558 at the end of 1946.

ROME, Sept. 18 -- Negotiations between represenatatives of landowners and farm laborers, which had lasted almost uninterruptedly since 5 P.M. yesterday, were approaching a conclusion here tonight. The exact moment when the strike of the 1,000,000 farm laborers in the north is officially called off is considered of little importance since the majority of the men returned to work this morning on their own initiative.

DETROIT, Sept. 18 (AP) -- The Probate Court in near-by Macomb County today authorized Mrs. Eleanor Clay Ford to distribute, as administratrix, $131,548,434.08 of the estate of her husband, the late Edsel B. Ford.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Foreign investors have disposed of more than $1,000,000,000 of assets in this country during 1947 and the liquidating process still is going on because of the continued demand for foreign exchange.

WASHINGTON, Sept 18 (AP) -- The supply of teachers for public schools will be ''slightly better" this year than last, the National Education Association, said today, "but there is little reason for rejoicing."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The top ranks in the new national military establishment were filled today when oaths were taken by John L. Sullivan as Secretary of the Navy and by W. Stuart Symington as the Secretary of the now independent Air Force.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 18 -- David Horowitz, head of the economic department of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, said today that a Jewish state, as proposed by a majority of the United Nations Special Committee of Inquiry on Palestine, could absorb 1,000,000 additional immigrants within seven to ten years.
Eugene Dennis, general secretary of the Communist party, addressing 13,000 persons in Madison Square Garden last night, pledged Communist support to a third party movement in the 1948 elections.

NANKING, China, Sept. 18 (U.P.) -- All except three of Nanking's gates were ordered closed tonight and cities along a 450-mile front south of the Yangtze River were alerted for raids as Gen. Liu Pocheng's Communist troops reportedly gained control of the Yangtze's north banks.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 18 -- There will be no pennant party aboard the Dodgers' homebound train tonight. Wally Westlake took care of that little matter in the ninth inning today when he whacked Clyde King's first pitch into "Kiner's Korner" to give the Pirates an 8-7 triumph over the Brooks.

The traveling show of contemporary British art has reached the Metropolitan Museum, the last stop in its transcontinental tour. Installed in the balcony galleries there, it opens to the public today and will remain through October.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Two officials of the New York Central Railroad appeared as unexpected witnesses under subpoena by the Virginian Railway in a hearing today before a member of the staff of the Interstate Commerce Commission on the request of Robert R. Young, chairman of the board, and Robert J. Bowman, president of the Chesapeake Ohio, that they be allowed to sit on the board of the New York Central.

Almost 100,000 Federal income tax refund checks, some of them running into four figures, are unclaimed at the Brooklyn and lower Manhattan district offices of the Bureau of Internal Revenue, it was disclosed yesterday. A substantial additional number are awaiting claimants at the mid-Manhattan district that covers most of Manhattan and all of the Bronx.

ON BOARD U.S.S. MISSOURI, at Sea, Sept. 18 -- President Truman neared the end of his 5,858-mile sea journey from Rio de Janeiro tonight as this floating, temporary White House pushed on for Norfolk, where it will dock at midday tomorrow.

While "the need for United States investment abroad is greater than ever and the opportunities are many," Willard L. Thorp, Assistant Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, urged last night that "every endeavor should be made to employ such capital at home where the need is urgent."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (U.P.) -- Warning that "a showdown with Russia is inevitable," Charles A. Eaton, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, tonight urged Americans to make it "absolutely clear" that they are determined to defend their liberties and to "assist to the limit all other peoples" in maintaining their freedoms.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed unchanged to 37 points net lower yesterday, with the near months relatively easier than the distant options.
Gerhard Eisler was pictured yesterday at the John Santo deportation hearing as the Communist who spurred the party's drive that resulted in the organization of the Transport Workers Union in 1934.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The first referendum for the union shop under the Taft-Hartley LaborManagement Relations Act of 1947 will be held on Monday, it was announced today by Robert N. Denham, general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Sharp increases in farm products and foods were mainly responsible for a rise of 1.6 per cent in average primary market prices during the week ended Sept. 13, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Department of Commerce.

DARWIN, Australia, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Brilliant star shells fired in the air from a British submarine terrorized rebellious Solomon Islanders and helped to nip a revolt planned to engulf the entire island group, British naval officers said today.

The play-by-play accounts and color descriptions of baseball's world series have been assigned to Walter Lanier (Red) Barber and Mel Allen. Mr. Barber is covering the regular season games of the Brooklyn Dodgers on WHN and Mr. Allen those of the New York Yankees on WINS.

With a brilliant four-hit effort that quelled the White Sox, 3 -- 1, at the Stadium yesterday, Frank (Spec) Shea emphatically cast his hat into the ring for the open job to start the world series for the Yankees.

SAMPSON, N.Y., Sept. 18 -- To meet, the needs of students who may find other colleges overcrowded, Sampson College is now expanding its facilities to provide room for an additional 1,000 to 1,500 students.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 18 (AP) -- The fading St. Louis Redbirds suffered their sixth straight defeat tonight, falling before the crafty southpawing of Warren Spahn of the Boston Braves, 6 to 2.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 18 -- The United Nations week celebration struck a new note tonight when the world peace organization was criticized severely by Eelco van Kleffens, Netherlands Ambassador to the United States.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 5,000 head, total 7,500; slow; market steady to 25 cents higher on butchers over 220 pounds: lighter weights steady to 25 cents lower: some bias off more on light

LONDON, Sept. 18 -- Although business was not very large a more cheerful tone marked the trading in stock markets here today. Persistent inquiries from the Provinces caused dealers to mark up industrial share prices sharply as they were caught short of stock.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 18 -- Three men allegedly involved in the theft of $20,000 in merchandise from Pennsylvania Railroad freight cars were under arrest today, it was announced by Samuel K. McKee, New Jersey chief of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

Jewelers now feel that more money must be spent on promotion, putting the figure at between 5 and 6 per cent of sales against 4 per cent last year, according to the report on a annual nation-wide survey issued yesterday by Arnstein Brothers Co., diamond cutters and importers, 608 Fifth Avenue.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Sept. 18 -- Incomplete estimates of the damage to the German harvest caused by the drought indicate that some regions will suffer a 30 to 35 per cent loss, Gen. Lucius D. Clay said today at a press conference here.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (U.P.) -- War Assets Administrator Robert M. Littlejohn today ordered his salesmen to get out and ring doorbells if necessary to sell the Government's remaining surplus real property by midsummer, 1948.

YESTERDAY'S EVENTS General Assembly Met at 11:10 A.M. and heard Senator Jose Maza of Chile, Dr. Herbert V. Evatt of Australia, Dr. Wang Shih-chieh of China, Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo of the Philippines and Louis St. Laurent of Canada.

Handprinted wallpapers showing refreshing design subjects as well as pleasant variations on popular types of motifs were presented yesterday by Wall Trends, Inc., 509 Madison Avenue. Small, widely spaced motifs or simulated textured effects of woven materials predominate in browns, deep blues and grays as well as polished white and black grounds.
In order to encourage sales on a firm basis and avoid disputes, the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers has recommended adoption of uniform conditions of sale, it was announced yesterday.

Washington, Sept. 18 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended Sept. 13, totaled 922,360 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 113,310 cars, or 14.0 per cent more than for the preceding week, 15,191 cars, or 1.7 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year, and 66,259 cars, or 7.7 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

The convention of the National Association of Broadcasters, just concluded in Atlantic City, undoubtedly represents a turning point in the brief but spectacular history of the broadcasting art. For the first time since the criticism of excessive commercialism on the airwaves reached appreciable proportions, the individuals responsible for what we hear on the radio have come to grips with specific proposals for the elevation of standards for their industry.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18 -- Larry Jansen stumbled badly in his bid for No. 20 today against the Cubs before a gathering of 5,944 at Wrigley Field. But his failure didn't affect the fortunes of the Giants for Buddy Kerr and Bobby Thomson went to town with their war clubs, Sheldon Jones came up with a fancy four-hit pitching piece through six and two-thirds innings, and the Ottmen scampered off with the decision, 9 to 5.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 18 -- Sun Beau, 51-year-old chestnut gelding owned by Sterling Smith of Ravenna, Ohio, and ridden by George Braun, won the first division of the $500 W.S. Blitz Gold Cup competition, a feature of the first day's program in the forty-second annual Piping Rock horse show at the Piping Rock Club today.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 18 -- The wage committee of the five operating railroad brotherhoods, representing 350,000 employes of the country's railroads, agreed unanimously late today to demand a 30 per cent wage increase, with a minimum money increase of $3 per day, effective Nov. 1.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Sept. 18 -- A $7,000,000 plan for development and improvement of New York State's public libraries, drawn up by the State Department of Education, was outlined for the first time here today at the annual conference of the New York Library Association.
A pre-fabricated Crawford hut of the type used extensively in military training camps during the war yesterday assumed a new peace-time role on the shore of Gravesend Bay in Bath Beach, Brooklyn.

I NEVER fully appreciated what a sheltered life a newspaper critic leads until I read about the reporters, copy editors, rewrite men and city editors whom Robert J. Casey has glorified in "More Interesting People." The reporters and copy readers and so forth whom I have met in the flesh have all been singularly sober, upright and law-abiding citizens.

SARANAC INN, N.Y., Sept. 18 -- Elimination of spiraling garage and parking lot fees throughout the state by drastic legal curb was demanded in a resolution passed today at the annual convention of the New York State Automobile Association here.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Nine men who flew on Tuesday farther into a hurricane than men have ever been before came out with information which the Weather Bureau hopes may make possible forecasting of the paths of these great storms by as much as twentyfour to forty-eight hours.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 18 -- Defeated in a play-off for the crown in 1946, Robinson Murray, 56-year-old export advertising man, of the home club, was more successful in a similar situation today and captured the championship of the Westchester Seniors' Golf Association of the Westchester Hills Club.

The embattled housewife won a small victory yesterday against rising food prices. Butter sold for 2 cents less in retail stores in New York and other cities, with a few reporting declines up to 4 cents, reflecting previous declines on the wholesale market.

One-half of the low income family's budget today goes for food, Miss Cornelia Dunphy, chairman of the New York Budget Council and home economist consultant for family service of the Community Service Society, declared yesterday.

Stewart Warner Corporation will not raise prices on its television and radio sets during the next sixty days, Samuel Insull Jr., radio division manager, stated during an eastern regional distributors meeting yesterday in the Ambassador Hotel, called to introduce new models.

Vigorous denial that the late Capt. William A. Davidson could have had anything alcoholic to drink before crashing the American Airlines experimental plane Alpha in Bowery Bay on Aug. 8 came yesterday from the airline and from the attorney for Captain Davidson's estate.

Mahmoud Fahmy Nokrashy Pasha, Prime Minister of Egypt, who spent more than two months in the United States pleading his country's case in the British-Egyptian dispute before the United Nations Security Council, declared yesterday that he would have faith in the United Nations when British troops leave Egypt.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Sept. 18 -- Bulgaria's Supreme Court of Appeal announced formally today that it had confirmed the conviction of Nikola Petkov, Agrarian Opposition leader, who has been sentenced to hang for allegedly plotting the overthrow of Premier Georgi Dimitrov's Fatherland Front Government.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 18 -- Universal-International today announced the acquisition of two story properties, "Beauty and the Beast" and "Velvet Fleece." The former, a 1946 magazine story by Fay Kanin and Elick Moll, about a girl who inherits a wrestler, was purchased for production by Michael Kanin, husband of the coauthor of the yarn.

ATHENS, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Generals Kalabalikas and Tzamakos, who are former commanders of divisions of the Elas, military arm of the EAM, have placed themselves at the disposal of the Greek Government to fight guerrillas, it was disclosed today.

Artificial crystals, the Bell Telephone Laboratories announced yesterday, may soon be produced in quantities almost large enough to supplant most natural quartz, a product hitherto indispensable in long-distance telephone and radio work.
New Britain, Conn., awarded yesterday issues of bonds aggregating $890,000 and maturing from 1949 to 1967 to Coffin Burr and associates at a bid of 100.40 for 1.20s.

PARIS, Sept. 18 -- The probable effect of the Marshall plan for the United Nation, as outlined in the Secretary of State's speech in New York yesterday, was contemplated with some anxiety by those who spent today virtually finishing the report that the European conference is to make to Secretary Marshall Monday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Russia will not have the industrial capacity to fight the United States for at least twenty-five years, Ernest G. Ropes, chief of the Commerce Department's Russian section, said today.

Now I want to speak about t making of modern war and look at the relative position of Great Britain to Germany and Italy in manpower, armaments, food, trade and foreign purchasing power at the outbreak of the war.
CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 15 (AP) -- C.L. Dupuy's Appleknocker, third to The Doge and Blue Yonder in the Valley Forge Handicap at Garden State Park, drove to a head victory in the Cinnaminson Purse today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18 -- Directors of the Chicago Board of Trade took no action at their meeting today on the recommendation of the Commodity Exchange Authority that margin requirements on transactions in grain futures be raised to 33 1/3 per cent of the price of the grain.
Good taste and wearability marked the work of two designers, John Dean and Bernard Newman, seen yesterday in a collection of ready-to-wear originals at Bergdorf Goodman.

ATLANTA, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Lew Worsham, the United States open champion, lived up to his favorite's role by shooting a 3-under-par 68 today for a two-stroke lead in the opening round of the $10,000 North Fulton open golf tournament.

The screen tastes of approximately 15,000,000 children between the ages of 6 and 12 will be served by the American film industry, it was announced yesterday by Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association of America. After a year's experiment in showing films for children, 2,500 theatres throughout the country will be utilized for screening specially selected films each Saturday.

Discovery of a new vital food factor in milk, leafy foods, pork and beef muscle and in liver extracts found to be essential in animals for the proper assimilation of proteins and for growth, was announced yesterday at the semiannual meeting of the American Chemical Society in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Former Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia lay dying yesterday in his Riverdale home at 5020 Goodridge Avenue. The 64-year-old "Little Flower" had been almost continuously in a coma since Tuesday evening and no hope was held out for his recovery.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 18 -- The American Light and Traction Company amended its reorganization plan today and notified the Securities and Exchange Commission that it was prepared to pay $33 a share, plus unpaid dividends, for all of its outstanding preferred stock, instead of the originally proposed $25 a share.

Five members of the House Foreign Affairs Committee were among the 2,080 passengers who left here yesterday for Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Elizabeth. The ship sailed at 1:25 P.M. from Pier 90, North River.

LONDON, Sept. 18 (AP) -- A dispatch by Tass, Soviet news agency, broadcast by the Moscow radio tonight, said that United States Secretary of State Marshall had failed to present "any convincing proof" for his picture of the situation in Greece in his address to the United Nations General Assembly Wednesday.

LONDON, Sept. 18 -- Aroused citizens of Hackney Borough held a mass meeting in their Town Hall tonight, demanding that the Government ban the Fascist, antiSemitic meetings that are being held each Sunday in Dalston, the biggest district of the East End borough.

Although prices of meat remain at high levels with many cuts, especially of pork, from 2 to 6 cents more than they were last Friday, the great variety and abundance of fish now in the stores offers a thrifty substitute for more costly protein foods.

Although feelings were somewhat ruffled, things seem to have subsided over that tempest in a teapot caused the other day by the unexpected switch on Oct. 6 of "Call Me Mister" from the Majestic to the Plymouth, which has rarely housed a musical the size of "Mister."

Lilly Dache gave a complete top-to-toe picture of the new silhouette at her millinery showing yesterday in her penthouse salon, at 78 East Fifty-sixth Street. Today hat and costume must go togrether. The outlines of one must compliment the other.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Sept. 18 (AP) -- Boarded and empty, the stately homes of this winter social capital still stand intact but pavements are littered with the remains of famous trees.

Delegates to the United Nations General Assembly session at Flushing Meadow yesterday expressed shock and dismay at the fury of the attack that Russia's Deputy Foreign Minister, Andrei Y. Vishinsky, made against the United States.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In an editorial in THE TIMES on Sept. 14 you defend John L. Lewis for exercising his right to decline to comply with that provision of the TaftHartley Law which requires officers of labor unions to swear that they are not Communists, otherwise their unions will not receive recognition before the Labor Relations Board.

MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 18 (U.P.) -- Here is the hurricane's itemized expense account for its one-day passage across the South Florida gold coast: Miami -- Damage estimated by police at $4,000,000. Plate glass windows smashed.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Lieut. Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer returned today from his investigation of conditions in China and Korea and conferred with Robert A. Lovett, acting Secretary of State.

DETROIT, Sept. 18 -- The Hudson Motor Car Company said tonight that it would halt its final assembly lines tomorrow to allow for conversion to the manufacture of an "entirely different" automobile with the center of gravity so low as to permit the driver and passengers to step down to enter from the curb.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 18 (AP) -- The Government of India and the Acting High Commissioner for Pakistan in New Delhi joined today in efforts to halt the flow of Moslem's from India's capital into refugee camps to await evacuation to Pakistan.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 18 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Reds today finally caught up with Emil (Dutch) Leonard, Philadelphia pitcher who had beaten them three times previously this season, knocked him from the box in the sixth inning and went on to win, 9 to 4.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- During the week ended Sept. 17, according to the Federal Reserve Board, member bank reserve balances increased $196,000,000.

We Impatient Americans Secretary of State Marshall remarked recently: "Americans are an impatient people." This corner, after careful thought, after weighing impartially the available facts, is inclined to believe that Mr. Marshall has something there.

Current indications are that when spring lines of men's clothing are opened about the middle of next month, prices on regular weight worsted suits will show an advance of 5 per cent over fall levels, it was reported in trade quarters here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) -- The Civil Service Commission took drastic steps today to remove temporary wartime employes from Federal agencies in order to reinstate 1,000 career workers who lost their jobs in the post-war reduction of Government payrolls.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 18 -- Nightly, since he came to Harvard, Richard Cresson Harlow has added the postscript to his prayers, "and please send me a good passer."
WARSAW, Poland, Sept. 18 -- Polish officials maintain that unless this country receives aid to re-equip her coal mines soon the Marshall plan to aid Europe will be ineffective.

ALBANY, Sept. 18 -- Governor Dewey told a group of up-state newspaper editors at a conference in the executive mansion today that he hoped the people would approve in November the six proposed amendments to the state constitution, including the $400,000,000 soldier's bonus, and the three propositions relating to lowcost housing.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan joined the fight for rent control yesterday with his first prosecution of a rent collector accused of extorting a bonus from a prospective tenant. Up to now such cases have been handled by the Federal Office of Rent Control in this city, although since 1946 Section 965 of the Penal Law has made it unlawful for anyone to accept money in excess of the stipulated rental.
ANTWERP, Belgium, Sept. 18 (Aneta) -- The United States took the lead in tonnage entering the port of Antwerp during August, with a total of 538,612 tons, carried in ninety-five vessels.

Dr. Herbert V. Evatt, outspoken Australian Minister of External Affairs, put to the United Nations General Assembly yesterday what was considered a fundamental question of the peace organization -- "Is the Economic and Social Council to be all harness and no horse?"

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Sept. 18 -- While consumers in New York are paying 6 1/3 cents a pound for U.S. No. 1 potatoes, the Government, to support the price, is buying them up here at the rate of 100 carloads a day for 2 1/10 cents a pound and shipping them to alcohol plants.
The master of the refugee ship Exodus 1947 and three members of his crew arrived yesterday morning at La Guardia Field aboard a Trans World Airline plane from Palestine.

Representative countries from almost every part of the world formed a swiftly growing line-up yesterday behind United States foreign policy, as voiced by Secretary of State Marshall Wednesday, in the United Nations General Assembly.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 18 -- The Cherry Valley pair of Al Brosch and Ray Torgerson put together 66 and 68 for 134 to finish twelve strokes under par while winning the seventh Metropolitan Golf Association pro-amateur tourney at the Hempstead Golf Club today.

ROSLYN, L.I., Sept. 18 -- Mr. and Mrs. Otto Steih Jr. never figured that some day a raccoon might come between them. Tonight, however, in the little house at 90 Parkside Drive, dinner was a little tense, and the raccoon grinned.

VIENNA, Sept. 17 -- The summerlong Soviet obstruction of the drafting of a new Austrian peace treaty was vigorously denounced today by David Ginsburg. United States representative on the Vienna Treaty Commission.
Replies were obtained last night by telephone from several of the nine United States business and political leaders denounced as "war-mongers" by Mr. Vishinsky. Others could not be reached.

The radio division of StewartWarner Corporation, together with ninety-seven distributors throughout the country, will begin a fall newspaper campaign on behalf of its television and radio receivers in virtually all major markets, Kenneth W. Sickinger, advertising manager, disclosed yesterday.

The 1948 session of the New York Legislature will face a crescendo of demands for increased aid to localities. But we doubt that any of these will be able to make a better case than our public libraries. The New York Library Association, which has been meeting at West Point, has brought out some of the facts in this inequitable situation.

NEW ORLEANS, Friday, Sept. 19 -- Storm winds of seventy-five miles an hour or more threatened this city early today as a vicious, unpredictable hurricane swept toward Louisiana from the Gulf of Mexico with widespread distress and multimillion dollar damage in its wake.

Perhaps the most significant and encouraging development in the food and relief situation during the past few days has been the declining emphasis on finding a scapegoat and the emergence of a new sense of hard-headed realism in the search for a satisfactory answer to the problem.
LONDON, Sept. 18 -- The British Government announced today the details of an emergency order instituting the "limited direction" of labor in an effort to increase production in essential industries.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Sept. 18 -- A verdict granting reinstatement with full back pay and all other rights to two Hoboken policemen ousted from their jobs by the McFeely regime last year was handed down by Judge August Ziegener in Hudson County Special Sessions Court here today.

The plight of the English churches is now sufficiently grave to warrant a drive for sheer survival, Ernest D. Jeffs of the Congregational Union of England and Wales, told American churchmen yesterday at a luncheon in his honor at the Parkside Hotel, 18 Gramercy Park, South.
A wide selection of costumes in all the important silhouettes was presented yesterday at Macy's. Enhancing the models, which were from the Little Shop, were accessories that added flair and color.

ALBANY, Sept. 18 -- The New York State Teachers Association urged today an immediate further increase of $103,000,000 in state aid for education, as Governor Dewey declared that the $50,000,000 increase in such annual aid since 1943 had been "a record of continued generous support to our schools through most difficult times."

The annual report of the American Ship Building Company and its subsidiaries, issued to shareholders yesterday for the fiscal year ending last June, shows a net income of $329,103 after deducting $71,771 loss on sale of assets, but after giving effect to a tax credit of $225,000.

More than 4,000 vehicular employes of the Railway Express Agency, members of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, AFL, went on strike in the metropolitan area at 12:01 o'clock this morning, a spokesman for the union announced.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The most moving and oftenest cited of Secretary Marshall's April 28 comments on the futile Moscow Conference reads: "The patient is sinking while the doctors deliberate. So I believe that action cannot await compromise through exhaustion."

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Sept. 18 (AP) -- A United States Army report said today the Ukrainian resistance army fighting for Ukrainian independence was so large that units estimated to number between 15,000 and 20,000 men had engaged Polish and Soviet troops in pitched battles.

SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 18 -- In a long statement to the press today, Col. Gen. T.F. Shtikov, chief of the Soviet delegation on the joint United States-Soviet Commission, charged the United States representatives with resorting "to artificial complication and prolonging of the Joint Commission's work, the emphasizing and sharpening of dissensions between the delegations with the purpose of proving the impossibility of resolving the questions confronting the commission."

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 18 (U.P.) -- With a million-dollar "hot potato" on its hands, the State of Virginia today tried to decide what to do with the jewel and art treasure of Czar Nicholas II of Russia.

DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Grand Parade, fast-stepping bay colt from the Baker Acres Stable of St. Charles, Ill., was a surprise victor today in the featured $6,250 "Old Oaken Bucket" 3-year-old trot at the Delaware Grand Circuit meeting.
Plans for new low-cost housing projects were shuffled yesterday by the Board of Estimate, with the East Bronx getting the stateaided project originally intended for a site in Jackson Heights, Queens.

TRIESTE, Sept. 18 -- British General Terence S. Airey, supreme commander of the United States and British forces in the Free Territory of Trieste authorized today a statement saying that "British and United States troops and the Allied Military Government are prepared quickly to meet any eventualities."

JERUSALEM, Sept. 18 -- Exerting steady pressure on the dissident forces of the Zionist underground, the British Army and the Palestine police arrested nineteen persons in Jerusalem today on suspicion of having connection with terrorist activities.

The stock market returned to an irregular course yesterday as demand slackened after Wednesday's sharp rally. The forenoon saw extension of the recovery but selling in the afternoon left the list irregularly lower on the day. Even the liquors were unable to maintain early increases although activity continued heavy in this division.

Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Deputy Foreign Minister of the Soviet Union, excoriated every phase of United States foreign policy in an amazing address that occupied an hour and thirty-two minutes before the United Nations General Assembly in Flushing Meadow yesterday.

Bank Statement Methods The poll of banks regarding their methods of preparing and presenting monthly statements, recently undertaken by the New York State Bankers Association, discloses some novel procedures, according to early reports received from up-state banks.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18 (AP) -- The nation's machine tool industry is either in a boom or on the verge of a boom, exhibitors at the National Machine Tool Show said today -- and backed up their contentions with a survey of 643 companies showing they intend to purchase 8,669 tools this year.

OUR beautiful, wonderful, incredible Bums return home to Flatbush today and will strut proudly into Ebbets Field tomorrow, their pennant quest virtually at an end. It's still rather hard to believe, particularly for a fellow who watched the Dodgers in Havana and the Cardinals in St. Petersburg. The Brooks were so uncertain in so many positions, the Cards a ready-made ball club with the confident air of champions.

Acceptance by the United States of nomination as the third member of a Security Council Committee of Good Offices to attempt a peaceful resolution of the armed dispute in Indonesia completes the machinery suggested by the Council in its resolution of Aug. 25 and which had been accepted by the Netherlands Government and by the Republic of Indonesia.

A year-old dispute between Local 111, United Public Workers, CIO, and William C. Davis, director of City College's Army Hall, over the dismissal of two Negro workers for alleged inefficiency, will be reviewed today by an impartial committee set up by the college.

Fourteen years ago, at the age of 8, Ruth Slenczynski, made her debut as a pianist in New York, and her remarkable talent persuaded even the most skeptical listeners that she was the real thing as a wonder child. Last night Ruth Slenczynski, now an attractive young woman, played at Town Hall again after an absence of about seven years, and the sad news this morning is that she is a prodigy no longer.

United States acceptance of the role at third member of a "committee of good offices" to deal with the dispute between the Netherlands and the Indonesian Republic was announced yesterday at United Nations headquarters at Flushing Meadow.

PARIS, Sept. 18 -- The chances of an early end of the Viet Nam conflict seemed remote today as a Viet Nam Republic spokesman said that his Government would reject the mediation offer of Annam's former emperor, Bao Dai.

TOKYO, Sept. 18 -- The establishment of a number of mixed civilian and military commissions to try the remaining Japanese "Class A" war criminals -- men accused of playing a major part in the instigation and conduct of the war -- is being considered by the Allied authorities here, it was learned today.

Arthur Nash, attorney for the Brooklyn Children's Aid Society, and Mrs. Bess Kuttner, a supervisor for the organization, had an uncomfortable few minutes yesterday afternoon outside Brooklyn Supreme Court as they left the building with 11-year-old Barbara Ann Smith, subject of a court controversy in which her mother is seeking to regain her custody.

Those who have been itching to get in a bear or deer hunt, but are restrained by the financial outlay required for such trips, will have an opportunity to enjoy this experience by participating in one of the non-profit wilderness hunts conducted by the North Carolina Wildlife Resources Commission.

LONDON, Sept. 18 -- William L. Clayton, United States Undersecretary of State for Economic Affairs, will discuss the problems of Empire preference and United states tariffs with Sir Stafford Cripps, President of the Board of Trade, tomorrow, an official announcement said today.

LONDON, Sept. 18 -- William L. Clayton, United States Undersecretary of State for Economic Affairs, will discuss the problems of Empire preference and United states tariffs with Sir Stafford Cripps, President of the Board of Trade, tomorrow, an official announcement said today.
Mrs. Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit, chief Indian delegate to the United Nations, yesterday asked for "objectivity" in considering the "fratricidal strife" that has been sweeping her country.

The index is based on spot market prices. Most of the twenty-eight commodities are basic raw materials. Shoe Sales Below Output Estimates in the shoe and leather trade indicate shoe output for the first nine months of this year is at the annual rate of 450,000,000 pairs.
The City Rent Commission granted a respite yesterday, to tenants in all eviction cases pending in the Municipal Courts except those brought for non-payment of legal rent.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Apprehension about the state of the country's economy and its prospects if present tendencies are not arrested was the dominant note before the Economic Institute of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States today.

Visit Little Italy this week-end and see one of New York's oldest Italian settlements celebrate a gay and colorful festival. Flags, festoons and arches decorate Mulberry Street from Bayard Street north to Houston Street, with multi-colored lights blazing after sundown.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The atmosphere of the theatre with which important oath-takings in Washington are now firmly invested gave way very quickly to one of grim earnest as the heads of the newly integrated defense establishment of the United States qualified themselves for office.

A warning that the United States "can slip backward with alarming speed" unless the present crisis in education is checked was given yesterday by President Truman in a letter read to 250 industrial, business and advertising executives.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) -- A representative of shippers told members of the Interstate Commerce Commission today that they are in danger of being used as a wage-rise rubber stamp. He was A.G.T. Moore, traffic manager of the Southern Pine Association, New Orleans.
Pipette, in her third race of the season, was back in her 1946 form yesterday at Aqueduct and accounted for a handsome victory in the $5,000 Philander purse, a sixfurlong affair for 3-year-olds.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) -- The farmer who raises beef cattle is getting about 70 cents of every dollar the consumer spends now for meat, compared with 51 cents in 1939, figures at the Department of Agriculture showed today.

Tony Janiro, Youngstown, Ohio, welterweight, will face Tony Pellone of Greenwich Village in the feature bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight. The fight marks the return of "big time" boxing to the Garden and the promoters are confident that it will attract a crowd of 15,000 fans and a gate of $55,000.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 18 -- Accumulating another top-heavy score this afternoon in the fourth race of their team match in International Class sloops, the Long Island Sound skippers made it a clean sweep over those from Bermuda.

DETROIT, Sept. 18 -- Abstaining from any reference to the wideopen fight which flared yesterday within the United Automobile Workers, Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, presented tonight to Walter P. Reuther, UAW leader, the annual award of the National CIO Committee to abolish discrimination.
TOKYO, Friday, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The unofficial casualty toll in Japan's typhoon disaster reached 5,015 today, and fresh reports from north of Tokyo said 500,000 Japanese were marooned there.

TEHERAN, Sept. 18 (Reuters) -- A second Soviet note demanding a share in Iran's oil and urging swift action without "delaying tactics" was delivered to the Iranian Government by the Soviet Ambassador, Ivan Sadchikov, on Sept. 15, it was reliably learned here tonight.
The Department of Markets' daily moderate-cost menus for a family of five follow. The cost of the dinner is $2.46. eRcipe for the wheat germ fish fry, the main dinner dish, is appended to the menus.

HONOLULU, Sept. 18 -- An agreement for consolidation to be submitted to stockholders was being prepared here today which would merge two of Hawaii's largest sugar plantations, the Hawiian Commercial and Sugar Company, Ltd., and the Maui Agricultural Company, Ltd., into the largest single cane sugar producing unit in the United States or its territories.

Atlantic City, N.J., Sept. 18 -- Affirmative action on the proposed code of standards for the radio industry is expected to be taken here tomorrow morning by the board of directors of the National Association of Broadcasters. The form or scope of the contemplated action, however, could not be ascertained.

LONDON, Sept. 19 -- Fears were expressed before the opening of the stock markets here today that the outburst of Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Deputy Foreign Minister of the Soviet Union, against Great Britain and the United States last night before the United Nations General Assembly in New York would affect sentiment in the markets here.

ROME, Sept. 19 -- While the farm laborers' strike in the Po Valley was officially settled today, fean were again expressed that the Communists and Left-Wing Socialists might use the "hunger march" demonstrations they are leadering tomorrow, to attempt some sort of revolutionary coup.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Up to 92,000 surplus machine tools will be tagged for stockpile starting Oct. 1 as a "reserve against a national emergency," the War Assets Administration announced to day.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 19 -- With the cost of living shaping up as the big issue for the 1948 campaign, Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican Presidential aspirant, accused the Truman...

Fiorello H. La Guardia was nearing death early today in his home at 5020 Goodridge Avenue in Riverdale. Dr. George Baehr, his personal physician, announced at 8:10 P.M. yesterday that New York's former Mayor was "sinking rapidly" and might live only a brief time longer.

Several thousand fans, some ,of whom waited nearly three hours, greeted the Dodgers yesterday morning when the Brooks arrived at Pennsylvania Station from Pittsburgh, last stop on their last tour of the hinterlands. The Brooklyn Symphony Band was on hand to serenade its favorite Bum and a number of placards were prominent.

When the Giants' train rolled into Grand Central Terminal yesterday at the end of the club's final-Western trip, it brought also the end of a competitive era for the squad. Mel Ott, the popular manager who has guided the club since just before Pearl-Harbor, snapped the last competitive link with the era of the late John J. McGraw when he announced his retirement as an active player.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- A strong drive will be made at the United Nations Assembly to get al nations to contribute to the International Children's Emergency Fund, Maurice Pate, executive director, told a press conference on his return from Europe today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 (AP) --Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable bogs. 4.000 head; total, 6,500; market very slow; generally 50 cents lower on all weights of barrows and gilts; few lots early steady; sows steady to 25 cents lower;

The United States and Great Britain and, incidentally, Greece and Turkey appeared the main objects of Andre Vishinsky's wrath at Flushing Meadov on Thursday afternoon. But Mr. Vishinsky's arguments, brought over with the rest of his baggage from Moscow and apparently augmented from sources in the neighborhood of Union Square, were not really directed at the countries mentioned.

'MY FATHER'S HOUSE,"* by Meyer Levin, is a deeply moving story of a boy's search for his family, for certainty, for hope. The search takes place in Palestine, where the boy, David, who has miraculously escaped the gas chambers of Nazi Germany; believes in spite of all the desperately disheartening evidence to the contrary that he will find again his father and his mother and his brother and his sisters.

September Rail Earnings Indications are that a large number of railroads will report net losses for September. R.E. Woodruff, president of the Erie Railroad, stated yesterday that although carloadings this month will be at a high record for any peacetime period and 4 1/2 percent higher than in September, last year, his road will report a net loss for the month.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 19 -- The Professional Horsemen's Association challenge trophy for open jumpers was won by My Play Boy, aged bay gelding owned by Russell Stewart of Albany, N.Y., and ridden by Miss Ann Morningstar of Greenwich, Conn., at the forty-second annual Piping Rock horse show today.

CHICAGO. Sept. 19 (NANA) -- Construction of a laboratory to produce the nation's supply of B. C. G., the vaccine that some specialists say may virtually eliminate tuberculosis in twenty to forty years, will begin here immediately at the University of Illinois medical center.

VIENNA, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Harold Trowb, head of the American Joint Distribution Committee in Vienna, charged tonight that "horrible and shocking" experiments had been made on Jewish children in a Vienna hospital, but the hospital's chief surgeon, Dr. Joseph Zikowski, said the experiments had been "perfectly legal."

DECATUR, Ill., Sept. 19 -- Liberal credits and outright gifts to foreign countries by the United States are one of the chief causes for the inflation of farm prices, a Conference of 300 industry and agriculture leaders was told here today.

Charles P. Gross, chairman of the Board of Transportation since Dec. 1, 1945, submitted his resignation, effective Oct. 18, to Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday. The resignation, in the form of an application for retirement on the date named, was accepted.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 19 -- British troops and police, who have lately been having notable success in turning up terrorist weapons in Jerusalem, found three more arms caches in early morning searches today. The efficiency of the troops has increased with experience and the frequency with which they pinpoint arms stores suggests that they are receiving some information from the Jewish community.

Rice picking started in Louisiana and Texas in August, in Arkansas and California this month; the middle of November will see it finished in all four states. To those who regard it, as we do, as among the most versatile of foods, it's good news that this year's crop is expected to be large, and that the quality is unusually fine.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Sept. 19 (AP) -- A committee of the New York State Magistrates' Association urged today that the Federal Government set up facilities to handle alcoholics. Another committee recommended that the State of New York establish a special institution for the treatment of sex offenders.

Mayor O'Dwyer appealed yesterday to householders and apartment house operators to purchase as soon as possible their supplies of coal and fuel oil for the coming fall and winter so that dealers whose bins and tanks are now full will be able to get in new supplies well in advance of the first cold weather.

Three thousand Jewish displaced persons in Austria and Germany have learned new skills and occupations this year through courses provided by ORT, the Organization for Rehabilitation Through Training, and by the end of 1947 18,000 will have completed courses or will be in training.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., disclosed yesterday that it has filed with the Public Service Commission an application for permission to issue one of the largest blocks of preferred stock in the history of the utility industry.

Fall will be a little "late" this year. The Naval Observatory in Washington, official body entrusted with such matters, reported yesterday that autumn would begin next Tuesday, Sept. 23, at 5:29 P. M., Eastern Daylight Time, when the sun arrives over the earth's equator on some remote spot in the Pacific Ocean.

HAMPTON BEACH, N.H., Sept. 19 -- Harold E. Stassen, as Presidential candidate, tonight flatly denied Vishinsky's statement before the United Nations Assembly that the United States is preparing for war with the Soviet Union.

ON BOARD U.S.S. DYESS With President Truman in Chesapeake Bay, Sept. 19 -- President Truman stepped back on United States soil today after a twentyday, 10,000-mile air-sea journey in the interests of peace and solidarity among the Americas, a trip on which, incidentally, he obtained a much-needed rest.

MOSCOW, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Deputy Foreign Minister Andrei Vishinsky's speech to the United Nations Assembly-probably the strongest words ever used by a Russian diplomat against the present policy of the United States -- was presented to the Soviet public today in full -- page spreads in all the principal newspapers.

First activity in private brand whisky retailing under New York's mandatory fair trade regulation occurred with the launching of a bonded Bourbon and a blended rye by Hearn's Department Store, setting the stage, it was observed in the trade yesterday, for private brand competition among the "volume" liquor stores.

WARSAW, Sept. 19 -- The Polish Government announced today the signing of a treaty with the Soviet Union whereby Poland takes over complete control of the Baltic port of Stettin. The Russians have maintained large facilities there, although the city itself has been under Polish administration.

American Airlines continued yesterday to gather additional evidence to refute charges that Capt. William A. Davidson had been drinking before the crash of the experimental plane Alpha in Bowery Bay Aug. 8. Captain Davidson, pilot of the plane, and two crew men were killed in a crash landing when an engine failed soon after take-off.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 19 -- Ox DaGrosa' was one of those who sounded the cry a few years back to give the game of football back to the boys. There is no one coaching who has more enthusiasm for his calling or caters more to his men, even if he can be as hard and as much of a taskmaster as the next fellow.

TRENTON, Sept. 19 -- As a member of a special committee of the Governors Conference, Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll will go to Chicago next week to discuss possible changes in present Federal and state tax laws with sub-committees of the House Ways and Means Committee and Senate Finance Committees.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Sept 19 -- The board of directors of the National Association of Broadcasters today voted approval of a new code of standards for the radio industry, effective Feb. 1.

The more than $100,000,000 in pay rise demands already deposited with the city or immediately in prospect from New York City employes make it clear that Mayor O'Dwyer faces, in the next few months, as difficult a task of budget management as the City Hall ever struggled with.
LONDON, Sept. 19 -- The Cabinet will meet tomorrow morning to decide the British Government's policy toward the report of the United Nations Special Committee of Inquiry on Palestine.
Dress manufacturers are from three to four weeks behind on deliveries of fall dresses to retail stores as a result of delayed shipments of piece goods, it was learned yesterday.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Sept. 19 -- A Bulgarian governmental newspaper conceded for the first time today that clemency for Nikola Petkov, Agrarian Opposition leader whose death sentence was confirmed yesterday, might be "in accordance with the public interest."

Newsweek, the weekly magazine, issued yesterday a correction about "some misquotations and a serious misrepresentation" in the remarks Thursday of Deputy Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky of the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- President Truman, steaming slowly up the Potomac River on the yacht Williamsburg tonight, will begin hard work tomorrow after the rest he has had aboard the...

Classics in adventure literature, as selected for the CBS dramatic series, "Escape," will be resumed on the network Oct. 1 at the new time of 10:30 to 11 P.M., Wednesdays, after a brief absence. The series, which was introduced July 7, was suspended temporarily, pending assignment of a new air time, after the Aug. 18 broadcast.

BOSTON, Sept. 19 -- Prof. rt J. Bok, associate director of the Harvard University Observatory and noted scientist, asserted tonight that he and Dr. Leo Szillard University of Chicago atom scientist, were denied passports to attend an International Science Conference in England recently by State Department delaying tactics.

The arraignment of two men in Felony Court on extortion indictments yesterday ended the manipulations of what State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein described as a ring that had swindled victims of $80,000 in the last two years by posing as law officers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Northern and Eastern states are doing a bigger share of the nation's post-war department store business than they did before the war, the Commerce Department reported today.
After two weeks of discussion a new procedural code, designed to speed up work of the United Nations General Assembly, was completed yesterday.

Greedy practices by some maritime business interests in this port are causing serious concern among mid-western shippers and may result in serious loss of revenue to the harbor, it was asserted yesterday by George Weiss, manager of the Chicago office of the Port of New York Authority.

City officials and administrative heads of the New York public school system participated yesterday in ground-breaking ceremonies for two elementary school buildings in Queens. The event was the first "double-header" of its kind in that borough in recent years land brought to five the number of new school units now under construction there.

Here on a ten-day visit, Margo Jones, managing director of the enterprising Dallas Theacre '47, has signed contracts whereby she will produce and direct Tennessee Williams' new play, "Summer and Smoke." The play is scheduled for a New York presentation either next spring or early in the fall.

A Plain Blunt Word An ironmonger deals in iron -- the Anglo-Saxon word back of it, the dictionary tells us, is mangere. A wordmonger deals in words. And in this corner we are professionally engaged in that employment.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- As a preliminary to the coming intensive investigation of the operations of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, Lewis M. Stevens of Philadelphia was appointed today as chief counsel and executive director of the staff of the Senate Banking and Currency subcommittee.

George Herrick, gambler, and six other men seized by the police on Sept. 11 in the Hotel Marguery at 270 Park Avenue after a raid on a crooked gambling suite there were cleared yesterday in Lower Manhattan Court.

LOS ANGELES, Sept 19 -- Celebration of the discovery of gold in California in 1848, to be marked next year, is being reflected already in fashion collections. Fichus, long-sleeved tight bodices, whalebone hoops at skirt bottoms, dust ruffles, and tucked and frilled Berthas escape being quaint and lend themselves admirably, to changing shoulder lines and skirt lengths.
Reports from almost every State emphasize two things: the all-out effort to provide more fish and game for the angler and hunter, and an unprecedented number of fish and game law violations.

The development of television, particularly if color telecasts can be perfected, can be of invaluable use for instruction in the field of surgery, Dr. John H. Mulholland, chairman of the Department of Surgery at the New York University Medical College, declared yesterday at the New Weston Hotel.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 19 -- The world-famous Swedish explorer, Dr. Sven Hedin, has sold his outstanding maps, photographs and sketches of central Asia to the United States Department of the Army, it was learned here tonight. Dr. Hedin's maps cover Asiatic districts from the Yellow Sea in the East to the Russian Turkistan in the West, and from Hungary in the north to Himalaya in the south.

A survey made in many of the communities in which branch stores are located has led to the conclusion that one of the most fertile fields for millinery sales lies among women who attend church, it was pointed out yesterday by Joseph Monaghan, millinery merchandise manager of Interstate Department Stores.

The stock market maintained its "resting" attitude yesterday after the strong upswing of Wednesday, but emphasis still remained on the lower side, with irregular price changes at the close. A few sections, notably the films, managed to break out on the higher side, but most key groups drifted within a narrow range, hampered by further mild profit-taking.

ATLANTIC BEACH, L. I., Sept. 19 -- The pilot of a Navy Hellcat fighter plane that crashed into the ocean today a half mile offshore here was rescued by a lifeguard and a civilian. A Coast Guard rescue ship searched in vain for the plane.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, Sept. 19 -- Strikes and demonstrations on a scale far larger than the hunger protests last spring" are expected to break out in the Ruhr next week when a public announcement is made of the complete list of plants to be dismantled, reliable sources said today.
YESTERDAY'S EVENTS General Assembly Met at 11:12 A.M. and heard Dr. Jose Arce of Argentina, Kuzma V. Kisselev of White Russia and Mrs. Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit of India.

ALBANY, Sept. 19 -- Declaring that jobs are "going begging," Gov. Thomas E. Dewey called upon employers today to cooperate to the utmost in finding employment for the physically handicapped who, he said, did an outstanding job in industry during the war.
By a 9-to-2 vote the Soviet Union last night lost a fight against allowing the United Naions General Assembly to debate the calling of a world conference to amend the power of the Big Five.

LONDON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Arthur Lees, 1939 Irish open champion, and Eric Green, a young professional who has been nibbling at the fringe of success all year, were named today to the British Ryder Cup golf team that plays America in Portland, Ore., Nov. 1 and 2.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- United States coal production, according to the Bureau of Mines, has decreased in average weekly output by 959,000 tons since last June when mining hours were reduced under the new United Mine Workers' contract

To the editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES: When an educator like Dr. George D. Stoddard, president of the University of Illinois (THE NEW YORK TIMES, Sept 7), in an otherwise excellent article uses an admittedly incorrect term, "Russia," four times in succession, readers have right to inquire about the reasons which may motivate such phraseology.

MANCHESTER, N. H., Sept 19 -- The common practice of throwing away surplus milk during flush producing periods in this dairy farming area was brought to the attention of a Congressional price investigating subcommittee today, eliciting expressions of disgust by members.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Sept. 19 -- Dr. Francis T. Spaulding, Commissioner of the New York State Education Department, disclosed here tonight that the Board of Regents had definitely shut the door to state aid to libraries for the coming year.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 19 -- Michael Curtiz Productions has sent the script of "The 49ers" to James Stewart as the first step in negotiating for his services as the star of the film, it was learned today. The picture will be made early next year by Curtiz and George Amy, his producing colleague, at Warner Brothers, with Doris Day and James Mitchell in supporting roles.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Sept 19 (AP) -- The former chief of the German Army's ordnance staff testified today that Germany Would have been powerless to rearm or to attack another country without the I. G. Farbenlndustrie combine.

ATHENS, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The guerrilla radio broadcast today a defiant response to the week-old amnesty offer of Premier Thremistocles Sophoulis. Informed sources here said early indications augured against any great success in inducing Greece's warring Leftists to turn in their arms.
PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 19 -- The indirect effect of the United Nations on South African policies was seen by many observers in three events here today.

To the editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES: Mr. Bevin has indicated that America has not done, enough for Britain; it 'should do much more because of the dollar crisis. The facts clearly show that Britain is suffering from, a pound sterling crisis.

Despite back-to-work instructions sent out by Daniel J. Tobin, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, AFL, a drivers' strike continued in effect yesterday against the New York branch of the Railway Express Agency.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 -- Secretary of Agriculture Clinton P. Anderson discounted today the need of a special session of Congress to combat rising food prices. The Cabinet officer visited Chicago briefly on his way to Washington from his home in Albuquerque, N. M.

BUKITTINGGI, Sumatra, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Republican Vice President Mohammed Hatta challenged the Netherlands today to agree to an internationally supervised referendum so that Sumatra's 9,000,000 inhabitants could choose freely between the present republic and "small Dutch-controlled puppet states."

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 19 -- Condemning what he called, war and anti-communism hysteria in America, Henry A. Wallace, former vice president, said tonight that he was shocked by President Truman's recent "instructions from the Battleship Missouri that James Forrestal be sworn In immediately as Defense Secretary because of an 'international emergency.'"

DETROIT, Sept, 19 -- Gov. Kim Sigler today made a flying trip to Detroit to make a personal investigation of a strike by about 600 garage mechanics affiliated with the United Automobile Workers of the Congress Of Industrial Organizations.

GORIZIA, Italy, Sept. 19 -- Italian military commanders here charged today that for the last four days Yugoslav forces had been conducting a "war of nerves" that had kept Italian border patrols in a state of suspense. There are twenty-eight Italo-Yugoslav border posts in the Gorizia area, and at every point local Yugoslav commanders of posts have challenged the Allies' interpretation of the French line, the Italians said.

LONDON, Sept. 19 -- The sale of British gold and the purchase of dollars from the International Monetray Fund are "danger signals" for the entire British Commonwealth, Hugh Dalton, Chancellor of the Exchequer, said today as he asserted that more such sales and purchases would be necessary.

Professor Selig Hecht of Columbia, who died the other day at the early age of fifty-five, was a rare combination of research scientist and teacher. Physiologists and physicists long ago recognized the importance of the fine studies that he made of acuity of vision, visual purple, dark adaptation and related subjects -- studies which began with an investigation of the effect of light on the lowly clam.

Manufacturers' deals featuring a combination offer with an extra package of the product thrown in for 1 cent are slated for discussion among food merchants in the next few months, according to comment in the retail trade yesterday.

The Greek Government bluntly warned all member countries attending the General Assembly session at Flushing Meadow yesterday that if they did not support Athens against continued armed attacks from Albania, Bulgaria and Yugoslavia they must share guilt for letting Greece succumb to "Communist dictatorship."

CRESTWOOD, N. Y., Sept. 19 -- Mr. and Mrs. Donald O'Brien of Winged Foot established a monopoly on the Theodore G. Law Trophy today by winning the WestChester County Golf Association's husband and wife championship for the third straight year at the Leewood Club.

In a stormy three-hour session yesterday at City College a special faculty arbitration board heard Jack Bigel, New York district president of the United Public Workers, CIO, accuse William C. Davis, director of the colleeg's Army Hall, of "anti-labor bias and discrimination against Negro workers."
A possibility that the Dominion of India and South Africa might settle their British "family dispute" outside the United Nations developed last night.
NEW DELHI, Sept. 19 -- Communal disturbances have spread eastward from Delhi to the United Province coincident with the arrival of refugees, an Indian Government military spokesman revealed today.

PARIS, Sept. 19 -- With the exception of the Communist press, most Paris newspaper comment today was hostile to Mr. VishiNsky's attacks on'the United States. However, there was a strong note of regret that both sides found it necessary to create a world situation in which France faced being caught between two great opposing forces.

Tony Janiro of Youngstown Ohio, defeated Tony Pellone of Greenwich Village in a furious tussle at Madison Square Qarden last night. The rival battlers went through the entire ten rounds of the feature event at top speed, and the action proved a delight to the crowd of 13,094 fans on hand.

Radio and appliance manufacturers may raise prices if the Interstate Commerce Commision grants railroad petitions for an immediate 10 percent increase, an appliance and radio buyer for a large homefurnishings chain said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The Motion Picture Owners Association and the American Theatres' Association merged at a joint convention here today, to form the Theatre Owners of America.
ATHENS, Sept. 19 (Reuters) -- King Paul left Corinth today on board the destroyer Seranda to inspect garrisons and fighting troops of the Greek Army in Epirus, Macedonia and Thrace.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 19 -- The Nuremberg trials were summed up by Federal Judge Florence E. Alien as a "mighty advance on what seemed the almost insurmountable path of substituting law for war," in a speech before the forty-eighth annual convention of the National Association of Women Lawyers tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The United States, today has less than one-third of its pre-war passenger -carrying maritime tonnage and construction and operation of additional tonnage is one of the pressing problems facing the Maritime Commission.

PARIS, Sept. 19 -- The European conference on the Marshall plan finished its work today by the adoption of an amended report that estimated the aggregate deficit in the balance of trade between Western Europe and the American Continents during the next four years would be $19,310,000,000.

BERLIN, Sept. 19 -- The first definite "trust-busting" achieve ment of the United States and British Military Governmenta' decartelization branch will be and nounced in a few days. This announcement will be made seven months after the passage of the decartelization law.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative, high-grade state, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers.

Meat prices to the consumer will fee shaded 1 or 2 cents a pound next week, with a few low-grade types cut as much as 4 cents, dealer reported yesterday as a second business week closed with food prices at peak levels.

Press comment on the address of Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Deputy Foreign Minister of the Soviet Union, before the United Nations Assembly, as gathered by the NEW york times: New York 'Mere Nihilism' Is Seen New York Herald Tribune Secretary Marshall, it seems to this newspaper, has tried to say something.

MARATHON, Fla., Sept. 19 (AP) -- Hurricanes or no hurricanes, a feverish building boom is under way along the chain of islands forming the Florida Keys where one of the most vicious tropical storms on record spread death and destruction a dozen years ago.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 -- Any significant increase in production must come from increased use of better and more efficient machine tools rather than higher productivity of the individual worker, Myron S Curtis, assistant director of engineering for Warner Swasey Co.. said today.

On Aug. 6 Prime Minister Clement Attlee presented in general terms to the British Parliament the Government's program for meeting the foreign exchange ("dollar shortage") problem. Broadly speaking, it called for a curtailment of the demand for dollars, on the one hand, and an increase in the supply, on the other.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Two official's of the New York Central Railroad, who yesterday were subpoenaed by the Virginian Railway to testify in a proceeding before a member of the staff of the Interstate Commerce Commission on intermediate steps looking to ultimate unification of the New York Central with the Chesapeake Ohio, were questioned today on their position that such a plan would not improve the standing of the New York Central.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Sept. 19 -- The Venezuelan Government said today it hoped to double this country's population within ten years under the new immigration policy. The present population is approximately 4,000,000.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals kept their flickering pennant hopes alive tonight and ended a six-game losing streak by turning back the Chicago Cubs, 5 to 2, behind Al Brazle's tight pitching.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Two weeks of hearings on the railroads' request for an immediate 10 percent boost in freight rates ended today with counsel for the carriers and shippers still in disagreement over whether a railroad emergency exists.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Sept. 19 -- Hundreds of residences and a number of industrial plants in this city and a section of near by Hillside were affected by an interruption of gas service today. Residents in some neighborhoods were forced to flee gas-flooded homes.
Chase M. Longueil has been appointed Eastern division sales manager for Kitchen Art Foods, Inc. Mr. Longueil formerly served in a similar capacity for Thomas J. Lipton Company.

Many of the 479 passengers who sailed for Sweden on the Swedish American liner Drottningholm yesterday were forced to leave trunks and other heavy baggage behind as a result of the Railway Express Agency strike.

What will be the effect on the United Nations of the verbal battle between Mr. Marshall and Mr. Vishinsky? From this thunderous start, can the Assembly settle down to its important business? Is there any chance now of a rational consideration, of the American or other proposals to make the machinery work?

ALBANY, Sept. 19 -- An Administration spokesman indicated today that Governor Dewey was willing to accept amendments to the 1947 permissive local tax law which would strengthen the statute and make it more workable.

ALBANY, Sept. 19 -- The Board of Regents adopted a resolution today directing the Commissioner of Education to proceed with plans looking toward the establishment of a new type of school administrative unit known as the intermediate district.

A powerful new method for separating natural substances in pure form, expected to find wide application in the production of ultrapure chemicals, was described yesterday at the semi-annual meeting of the American Chemical Society at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

NANKING, Sept. 19 -- Increasing signs' of Communist preparations for their sixth offensive against the narrow Nationalist salient in Manchuria were reported today. Neutral military sources said 25,000 Red troops were marching south along the Manchuria Jehol border in an apparent attempt to cut the Peiping-Mukden Railway supply line.

The playing heard from Clifford Herzer, pianist, at his recital last night in Town Hall displayed marked improvement in his work since his previous appearance in the same auditorium a year ago. His performances had gained decidedly in vitality in the interim.

SARANAC INN, N. Y., Sept. 19 -- Superior adaptability of girls, when compared with boys, to automobile driver-training instruction in schools and the increased deadly perils of winter motoring were emphasized today at the closing session of the annual convention of the New York State Automobile Association.

A big increase in business nearly swamped the Temporary City Housing: Rent Commission yesterday until the agency obtained volunteer workers from the staffs of neighboring offices in the building at 500 Park Avenue.

GENEVA, Sept. 19 (U.P.) -- The Soviet Union has formally refused to attend the forthcoming world trade conference in Havana and has notified all United Nations members of the refusal, official sources of the International Trade Organization said here today.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 19 (Reuters). Prince Mozaffar Firouz was dismissed from his post as Iranian Ambassador in Moscow last month and has "vanished," police officials here stated today. The latest reports of his whereabouts was a Moscow statement that he had left for Teheran by air Sunday.

Store Sales Gain 20% Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores this week were estimated yesterday to be 20 per cent above those of the corresponding week in 1946. Warm weather, it was noted, continued to be a retarding influence.

NEW DELHI, Sept 19 (Reuters) -- Viscount Mountbatten, Governor General of the Dominion of India, today issued an ordinance empowering commissioned officers, warrant officers and noncommissioned officers of the Indian Army and air force to "fire upon or otherwise, use force, even to causing death, against any person who is acting in contravention of any law or order."

MOSCOW, Sept. 19 (Reuters) -- Glaring headlines in today's Soviet press, such as "Russia stands for peace and friendship against war kindlers" and "Truman-Marshall plans irreconcilable with U.N.," told the story of official Soviet reaction to Soviet delegate Vishinsky's speech to the United Nations Assembly yesterday.
