Eight years ago, William K.H. Wenzel, then 10 years old, went to Denmark from Rochester, N.Y. with his father, James, a salesman for the Eastman Kodak Company. He returned yesterday to the the United States as a stowaway with a story of time spent in a German concentration camp, employment with various United States Army units and assignment to a displaced persons camp.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 19 -- America's law schools must train this country's future "international negotiators" in preparation for the give and take of world politics, Dr. John W. Taylor, president of the University of Louisville, declared here tonight.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed. 11 points lower to 5 points higher yesterday.

DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The world record for trotting mares on a half-mile track fell by the wayside today on the getaway program of the Delaware grand circuit harness racing card. Onolee Hanover was brought from behind Algiers to win the second heat of the Dr. Spencer free-for-all trot in 2:013-5. The old record was set in 1943 by Mary M. and tied in 1945 by Kaola.

TOKYO, Sept. 19 -- Occupation efforts to force the Japanese Government to pass the economic decentralization bill will reach a climax next week." They focus attention on fundamental MacArthur policies vis-a-vis business, which to some appear far more progressive than anything the United States was asked to consider under the New Deal.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 (AP) -- George Ratterman, Buffalo quarterback, tossed four touchdown passes as the Bills defeated the Chicago Rockets, 31 to 14, tonight in an all-America football conference game in Soldier Field before 22,685 fans.
ATLANTIC, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Jimmy Demaret of Ojai, Calif., fired a two-under-par 69 to take the lead in the $10,000 North Fulton open golf tournament today.

The motion-picture industry will act as an entity, for the first time in many years, to combat a state censorship authority by instituting court action against the censor board in Memphis, Tenn., which has banned the film "Curley" on racial grounds.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 -- The hardwood industry was warned today that it can hold its own against competitive lines only through production, orderly distribution and supplying the kind of lumber best suited to its customers. The warning was issued by J. Jackson Kidd Jr., Baltimore, Md., president of the National Wholesale Lumber Distributing Yard Association.

TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Sept. 19 -- Prospects off eftective action by the United Nations are not, as dismal as they might seem, Dr. V. K. Wellington Koo, Chinese Ambasador to the United States, told an audience of 8,000 here tonight at a United Nations week celebration in the Washington Irving High School stadium.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 -- Chicago won new ward lines today after years of stalling. The final chapter of the fight was written with unexpected speed. In less than 30 minutes the City Council approved the remapping by a vote of 45 to 1.

For the second year in succession the running, of the Beldame Handicap will cost the Queens County Jockey Club an extra $50,000. Today's renewal' of fillyand-mare stake has drawn twentyone entries, too many for the Aqueduct track to accommodate at one time, so again there'll be two races, each for $50,000 in added money.

Manufacturers of many lines sold to business buyers are studying the eighteen-point new promotional campaign put forward by manufacturers of materials-han dling equipment, it was revealed here yesterday in a statement by R. Kennedy Hanson, secretary manager of the Materials Handling Institute, Inc., Pittsburgh.

The French Line is planning to build two de luxe passenger liners of 45,000 to 50,000 gross tons each for the North Atlantic trade by 1950, Guy de Berc, general representative of the line in the United States and Canada, announced yesterday.

The first world assembly of Methodists in sixteen years will be convened at 3 P. M. Wednesday and continue for nine days, ending in a session starting at 11 A. M. Thursday, Oct. 2, in Springfield, Mass. The sessions will be held at Trinity Methodist-Church and in the Municipal Auditorium.

Joseph Zack Kornfeder, former Communist leader, told at the Santo deportation hearing yesterday how he and five other American Communists were trained at the Lenin School in Moscow by uniformed Red Army officers, specialists in civil warfare techniques, to carry out armed insurrection in capitalistic countries.

NEW ORLEANS, Saturday, Sept. 20 -- A devastating hurricane was centered in mid-Louisiana early today moving in a northwesterly direction toward Arkansas. Six persons were reported dead along the Gulf Coast and some 400 injured in its wake.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Animproved resuscitating apparatus designed to eliminate risk in the operation of machines for producing artificial respiration, or assisting in the natural but labored respiration of persons suffering from asphyxiation, drowning, or the like, has been patented (No. 2-427,219) by Chester C. Rausch of Newtonville, Mass., and assigned to Mechanical Resuscitator, Inc., of New York.

Kuzma V. Kisselev of White Russia revived the demand before the United Nations General Assembly yesterday that all member nations break off diplomatic and economic relations, including rail, sea, air, coastal, telegraph and radio communications with Spain.

TOKYO. Saturday, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Fresh, floods spread across fifteen square miles of northeastern Tokyo today, adding eight more bodies to an estimated toll of 2,000 Japanese dead in the five-day-old typhoon-borne disaster.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 18 (Delayed) -- Thousands of used army vehicles of the United States, Britain and Canada, as well as large numbers of new American-made tractors, steamrollers and stump pullers have transformed much o the already overcrowded Buenos Aires waterfront into one vast ordnance dump.

Off the west coast of Africa near the equator is a region called the doldrums, a region where there may be a dead calm for days. Warm air rises from the water, and cold air rushes in to take its place. The rotation of the earth gives the updraft of moist, warm air a spin, and so a hurricane is born.

OTTAWA, Sept. 19 -- The possibility that Canada may be able to improve her dollar position and get rid of surplus foodstuffs by freer export to United States was suggested by James A. Gardiner, Agricultural Minister, on his return here today from attending the food conference in Geneva, Switzerland, and after discussing future food contracts in London.

Reliable sources reported last night that the executive of the British Labor party in London had voted to support the majority report of the United Nations Special Committee of Inquiry on Palestine, including its recommendation for partition of the Holy Land.

Because of today's domestic and international crises, the role of the legislative branch of government "hangs more critically in the balance" than the executive and judicial branches, it was declared last night by Dr. George B. Galloway, staff director of the Joint Committee on the Organization of Congress.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 -- General liquidation was on in the grain markets on the Board of Trade today, wheat breaking 10 cents a bushel; corn and soy beans, 8 cents, and oats, 6 cents, the daily limits, and the close was at the bottom. It was the second consecutive day of a limit decline in corn.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company, San Francisco, registered today with the Securities and Exchange Commission $100,000,000 of its forty-year debentures, due Oct. 1, 1987, for sale at competitive bidding.

Boleslaw Jan Czedekowski, Polish artist, presented last night to the Kosciuszko Foundation House, 15 East Sixty-fifth Street, a portrait of Gen. Tadeusz Kosciuszko, Polish soldier-engineer, who helped in the American Colonies' fight for freedom.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Union leaders received additional time today to file non-Communist affidavits with the National Labor Delations Board if they want their pending cases processed.

Although Kuzma Kisselev, Foreign Minister of White Russia, yesterday Continued the Soviet attack against the "reactionary groups that are pushing "the reactionary policy of the United States," the third day of the opening debate of the United Nations General Assembly brought a definite lowering of political temperature.

LONDON, Saturday, Sept, 20 -- Representative British press reaction to Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky's speech before the United Nations General Assembly on Thursday, as published more fully today, ranges from outright denunciation to sarcastic indifference.

An agreement continuing in effect for five more years a halfcentury-old arbitration agreement was announced here yesterday by the American Newspaper Publishers Association and the International Pressmen's Union, AFL.

A new model kitchen set in a pleasant background where a housewife may relax while waiting for the pot to boil will go on exhibit Monday at Abraham Straus, Called the "Garden Kitchen," the setting- combines work units and a convenient butler's pantry with a sitting room and built-in garden.
CHICAGO, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The St. Louis Browns scored five runs on eight hits during the first five innings and coasted to a 5 to 3 victory over the Chicago White Sox today.

OXFORD, Miss., Sept. 20 (AP) -- The good right arm of Charley Conerly and the big, grasping hands of Barney Poole accounted for a Southeastern Conference football victory for the University of Mississippi over Kentucky's Wildcats today, 14 -- 7.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Sharp declines extending to the limits of 10 cents a bushel in wheat, 8 cents in corn and 6 cents in oats were recorded during the first few minutes of trading today in the Chicago Board of Trade. For corn it was the third consecutive day of a limit decline.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The patent advisory panel of the Atomic Energy Commission pointed today to a loophole that "enlarges" opportunity for outsiders to uncover United States atomic secrets. Secrets might be revealed through application for patents on the method American scientists used on how to make the bomb, the panel reported.

HANOVER, N.H., Sept. 20 -- The youth movement paid off for the Brooklyn Baseball Dodgers. Dartmouth is working on a similar long-range program, hopeful that 1948 will find it restored to the high position it held before the war as one of the football powers of the East.

In a study recently published by the Twentieth Century Fund under the title "America's Needs and Resources," Dr. J. Frederic Dewhurst and his associate economists confined themselves closely to basic factual data in measuring the growth of the American economy and estimating its productive capabilities under conditions of stable prosperity in 1950 and 1960.

PRINTS by William Mortensen of Laguna Beach, Calif., whose working methods, described in a number of widely read books, have made him one of the best-known writers and teachers of photography in this country, are on view at the Camera Club of New York, 121 West Sixty-eighth Street.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In Robert M. Hutchins' description of his work with the Great Books Foundation in the times recently, a number of dubious propositions about liberal education were stated as if they were true, and a major hope was expressed about man's ability to live with the atom bomb through his acquaintance with a number of classical authors.

Despite declines on Friday, prices last week were still at unparalleled altitudes, and everyone from worried housewife to potential Presidential candidate was talking about the consequences of inflation.

TRIESTE, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Allied Military Government sources said today that Yugoslav troops, moving last night when no guards had been present, had taken over a section of a road from the Italians on the new frontier near Caporetto.
NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 20 (AP) -- A rising death toll from the hurricane that swept the Eastern gulf coast was counted tonight as ebbing waters permitted a survey of casualties and destruction.

Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, strongly protested yesterday against an Argentine proposal to the United Nations General Assembly's steering committee under which the world organization could consider appealing to the signatories of the Italian peace treaty to modify some of the pact's provisions.

COMPOST is a form of soil conservation. While its importance is beginning to be understood even by urban dwellers, it is the owner of a small garden who has the duty and pleasure of conserving that part of the nation's wealth which is represented by the soil on his property.
CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 20 -- Double Jay doublecrossed two-thirds of the racing fans who turned out to see the Jersey Handicap, the $30,000 added event that featured the card at Garden State Park today.

PFC. LEROY BOLSTER of Elim, Iowa, was a "pineapple soldier," which is to say he served his Army time on the Hawaiian island of Oahu and the only beach he stormed was Waikiki. LeRoy was a rangy, good-natured young man, inordinately fond of beer, girls and comic books.

THERE is more skulduggery than knight-errantry in this exciting tale of fourteenth-century England when the curtain was rising on the Hundred Years War. There were plots and counterplots, and the lords and some of the ladies of the court of Edward III were far busier with intrigues and personal ambitions than with the plans of the monarch to conquer Philip of France.

YONKERS, N.Y., Sept. 20 -- Three men ware wounded last night when an opponent of a union administration fired a .38-caliber pistol five times during a meeting of Local 543 of the Steamfitters and Helpers Union, AFL.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- J.M. Mehl, administrator of the Commodity Exchange Authority, said today that futures markets should "do their utmost to prevent unhealthy speculative tendencies" if they want to preserve their proper function in the distribution of farm products.

SEVERAL of the more unusual fruits offer interesting growing possibilities to home gardeners who are not interested in mass production but enjoy rounding out supplies for eating, preserving or freezing. The fruits are more than mere curiosities, but their limitations must be considered to assure success.

ANYONE can scoop up a few shovelfuls of earth and put a rose bush in place. It might even grow with such treatment. To be certain of success with roses, however, one must give some consideration beyond a merely careless planting.

ALBANY, Sept. 20 -- Charles H. Sells, state superintendent of public works, in a report described by Governor Dewey as "a magnificent piece of work," said today that $2,000,000,000 must be spent during the next 14 years to make New York's highways efficient and safe.

LONDON, Sept. 20 -- The British Cabinet decided today to accept the majority recommendations of the United Nations Special Committee of Inquiry on Palestine for partition of the Holy Land provided the United Nations participate fully in the implementation of the proposals, it was learned authoritatively tonight.

The five operating railroad brotherhoods last week added a 30 per cent wage increase to their previous request for changes in forty-four of the working rules. On the basis of operations in 1946, a wage rise of that size would mean an increase of $383,000,000 yearly in railroad operating costs exclusive of additional payroll taxes of $23,000,000 which the carriers would have to pay to the Federal Government.

THIS is the story of an Orthodox rabbi, a man with one foot in Heaven and the other in Zanesville, Ohio. Father -- William Manners' father -- was the spiritual leader of Zanesville's thirty-four Jewish families. Father claimed that Christianity was ''impractical," that it asked too much of erring mortals.

KOMOTINI, Northeastern Greece, Sept. 19 (Delayed) -- The smoldering ruins of peasants' houses in the villages of Kosmos and Kavacli and the steady stream of refugees with loaded oxcarts crowding in to Komotini bear witness today to the progressive chaos and collapse of Government authority in Thrace.

The sixth biennial convention of the National Maritime Union, which opens here tomorrow morning, is expected to be the stormiest of traditionally rough NMU meetings. The schism among union factions has been widening for more than a year and this convention is not expected to close the gap.

RENO, Nev., Sept. 20 -- Speaking here in reclamation-minded Nevada, Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, traveling through, the Far West in quest of support for the Republican Presidential nomination, declared tonight that this was "no time to spend money too lavishly on public works in general."

DECATUR, Ill., Sept. 20 -- Farmers wish to continue producing an abundance of food but they will not be able to do so if labor and industry continue to insist on controlled prices, Charles Shuman, president of the Illinois Agricultural Association, said today.

The text of Warren R. Austin's speech before the American Association for the United Nations last night follows: In accepting the award of the American Association for the United Nations, I wish first of all to express my profound appreciation for the constructive work of this body of devoted American citizens.

A woman found dead early yesterday on the Belt Parkway near Cross Bay Boulevard, Ozone Park, Queens, was identified formally last night as Mrs. Vera Kenney, 38 years old, a divorcee who lived with her two children at 537 Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn.

VILLANOVA, Pa., Sept. 20 (AP) -- Unleashing an array of backs with finesse and power behind a stalwart line, Villanova's Wildcats spelled trouble for future opponents today as they routed the Merchant Marine Academy of Kings Point, N.Y., 60 to 0, before an opening day crowd of 10,000.

IN the past few months the United States has launched a full-dress diplomatic offensive in answer to what our Government has officially described as the aggressive and expansionist program of the Soviet Union. This struggle for power between the two dominant nations of the postwar world does not threaten war, but is unquestionably wrecking the kind of collective security that was dreamed of at San Francisco.

HUMAN nature being what it is, business men are apt to be complacent about their own shortcomings when discussing social and economic problems -- and petulant about those of government and labor. One of the great merits of this book, written by a distinguished industrialist, is that it deliberately rejects the self-righteous approach.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Sept. 20 -- Ratification by the Bavarian Parliament of nominees to succeed four Social Democratic Ministers and three State Secretaries gave Bavaria a new Cabinet today. It is made up exclusively of members of the Christian Social Union.

To the Drama Editor: TO stage-struck youngsters who read the brochures, the professional dramatic school is a combination movie set and modeling agency which miraculously turns people into finished actors ripe for jobs on Broadway -- all within the short space of six to twelve months.

MARTHA'S VINEYARD, Mass., Sept. 20 -- A lot of surfcasters, like woodcock hunters, have secret fishing areas, the location of which they would not reveal for gold or friendship. If a poll were taken it undoubtedly would reveal that many of these spots were somewhere on Martha's Vineyard.
The Freedom Train, containing 330 documents and flags marking the development of liberty in the United States, will arrive in New York on Thursday and remain here on exhibition for six days.

On the occasion of his eightieth birthday, which he celebrates today, Henry L. Stimson has written an article for Foreign Affairs Magazine in which he indicts Soviet intransigence but rejects the idea that a "preventive war" is necessary to rid the world of the menace of communism.

Revival of speculative interest in security markets and a concurrent drop in commodities highlighted the financial picture last week. However, unsolved domestic and foreign problems overshadowed day-to-day developments. The gravity of these developments was made more pronounced by Secretary of State George C. Marshall's speech to the United Nations General Assembly.

THE image of Lincoln as we know it is formed, of course, at several removes. It comes to us filtered through the minds of the men who put down on paper their own images of Lincoln; and each biographer introduced his own set of refractions and distortions.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20 -- Be Faithful, 5-year-old daughter of the famed Bimelech, captured the $56,600 Hawthorne Gold Cup today in a finish that was so inconceivably close that the crowd of 21,681 spectators was kept waiting seven minutes while the judges decided the order of finish.

CHANGING travel habits of American, tourists are causing new developments in road maps and guides. Possibly an all-time record number of free road maps will be printed this year, a survey of map makers shows.

LONDON, Sept. 20 (Reuters) -- Arsenal again topped the English Football League's first division with a 3-0 victory over low-placed Stoke City today. With 15 points the Gunners lead Preston North End by two points. Preston suffered a 3-1 defeat by Sheffield United.

ABIGAIL SMITH -- descended from generations of prominent New England divines and political leaders -- deserves to rank as founder of the extraordinary Adams family almost as much as her husband, John Adams, son of an unknown Massachusetts farmer.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The Government estimates that United States occupation costs in Europe and Asia this fiscal year will cost $265,000,000 more than current appropriations, and the rise may be at least $500,000,000 if the British cease contributing.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 20 -- Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton, announced today that the university's Industrial Relations Section had surpassed its $360,000 goal in raising a fund to Celebrate its twenty-fifth anniversary.

THE love of a master for his ship, which sailors know and landlubbers can only imagine, is the chief ingredient poured into a slim but constantly seething volume by Simon Gantillon. Eloquently translated by Haakon M. Chevalier, who has harnessed the chemistry of words to generate as much violence as possible within a limited space, the little book emits like an erupting crucible an unending stream of passions -- of both man and nature.

Fiorello H. La Guardia died in his sleep at 7:22 A.M. yesterday. He was 64 years old. At the bedside were his wife, the former Marie Fisher, who had been his secretary while he was in Congress; their adopted children, Jean, 18 years old, and Eric, 15, and Mrs. La Guardia's sister, Miss Helen Fisher.

WITH coconut arriving again from the Philippines, macaroons appear on grocery shelves for the first time since the war. Most flattering to our palate are those made only with coconut, sugar and egg white.

HOLLYWOOD. ALDOUS HUXLEY is watching the translation of one of his own stories to the screen with more satisfaction than authors normally exhibit under such trying circumstances. The work is "The Gioconda Smile," a short story he wrote just after the first World War and published in a volume called "Mortal Coils," the present title of the film venture.

Leaders of the Machine Tool Congress, now in the midst of a ten-day national convention and exposition in Chicago, revealed that this industry is opening a new era of full disclosure of economic facts about industrial equipment.

IT'S Joe Page, of course. Bucky Harris is even booming his handsome relief pitcher for the award of the Most Valuable Player in the American League, a distinction never before given to a bullpen specialist. But Bucky's theory is that the big left-hander has won the equivalent of twenty-eight games for the Yankees and that they might not have taken the pennant without him.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Sept. 20 (AP) -- Southern and western Florida were getting back into contact with the rest of the state and nation today and counting up their hurricane damage.
MERIDEN, Conn., Sept. 20 (AP) -- Big Ed Walsh's adopted home town gave him a reception today that brought tears to the eyes of the 67-year-old former Chicago White Sox pitching ace.

Grain prices, viewed by the Government as the key to the food price spiral, submerged under selling waves at Chicago and other major markets yesterday for the third successive day as Government officials pressed their campaign against grain "speculators."

They came to cheer and remained to jeer -- 29,762 Flatbush fans who moved gaily into Ebbets Field yesterday with the confident expectation that they would see their Beloved Bums clinch their fourth pennant since the turn of the century.

JUST fifteen years ago this week in this Review: A lively issue, what with Buck, Benet (William Rose), Anderson, Hemingway and D.H. Lawrence. Mrs. Buck had a sequel to "The Good Earth," a novel entitled "Sons," and, according to J. Donald Adams, she "has enriched her wide canvas with this second panel * * *"
Following are excerpts from an article, "The Challenge to Americans," by Henry L. Stimson, former Secretary of War, in the new issue of foreign Affairs Magazine:
TAPPAN, N.Y., Sept. 20 -- Cap'n Willem Albertse Blaeuveldt just didn't know the war was over when he brought in as a prize the good ship Tabasco with her crew aboard.

GENEVA, Sept. 20 -- Deeply rooted in the traditions of every European people is some mode of celebrating the harvest festival. This year as the crops are cut and stored, fields and villages are bathed in golden sunshine and skies are blue.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- New pressures on President Truman to call a special session of Congress have developed this week.

BOSTON. SOME day in the year 1960, or thereabouts, a child of the new generation will stand in the John Deferrari Room in the Boston Public Library and study the portrait of the man whose gift of a $3,000,000 trust fund in September, 1947, paid for the room.

Away With Those Two! In the opinion of an observer of international affairs of many years' standing, now sojourning in New York after protracted and variegated trips abroad, those two shockingly overworked words, ideology and ideological, are fit candidates for the ashcan.

Probing the mysteries of the electron with tiny radar waves used to detect enemy submarines and airplanes during World War II, two Columbia University physicists have discovered hidden cosmic energies that contradict current established concepts of the atom.

CRISTOBAL, Canal Zone -- A travel bargain -- a trip around South America for a fare of $645 -- is offered here by the Royal Netherlands Steamship Line. The voyage takes about four months with stops in many ports, including three weeks in Buenos Aires.

All departments in retail stores reported good activity last week according to a survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Departments where trade was brisk and demand steady were the dress, coat, suit, sportswear and accessories departments.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 20 -- The West Coast budget-balancer, shopping for butter now costing 92 cents a pound, eggs 85 cents a dozen and meat close to $1 a pound, is not concerned too much with qualifying statistical indices. Mounting prices in the neighborhood stores, he says, are all the proof he needs that living costs are almost prohibitive.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were moderately active yesterday, but trading was rather nervous because of the disruption of communication lines with southern markets.

The New York University Law School will hold next Friday a "celebration banquet" at the Waldorf -Astoria Hotel at which plans for the proposed N.Y.U. Law Center will be made public, Dean Arthur T. Vanderbilt announced yesterday.

Factoring companies catering to soft goods industries are looking ahead with confidence to the expansion of their service despite the increase in public financing of textile firms and the undiminished trend toward verticalization, according to factoring executives last week.

With few buyers in town and many markets closed for the first two days of last week because of the Jewish holidays, wholesale activity was slow, according to the weekly market reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buyers.

POSTMASTER GENERAL, ROBERT E. HANNEGAN made available last week a photograph of the design of the 3-cent stamp which is to be issued Oct. 21 to mark the sesquicentennial of the launching of the frigate Constitution -- "Old Ironsides." The color was not announced.

A new relationship -- a widening of the spread between the yields on Government and corporate bonds -- has been established in the bond market. A year-long but almost imperceptible trend of high-grade corporate yields to higher levels was confirmed last week strikingly in the marketing of new obligations of the Detroit Edison Company, the Monongahela Power Company and the Iowa Public Service Company.

In a two and a half hour scrimmage, marked by long runs and passes, Columbia and Temple put the finishing touches to their preseason preparations yesterday at Baker Field. Both teams start regular competition this week-end, Columbia against Rutgers at Baker Field on Saturday and Temple against N.Y.U. at Philadelphia on Friday night.

As far as personnel is concerned, or the condition of the repertoire in general, there is not much to be said for the season of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo just closing, but it has been unusually fortunate in its selection of new works, two out of three of them constituting genuine additions to the repertory.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The Government of the Dominion of India declared today that "any conception of a conflict between India and Pakistan is repugnant not only on moral grounds but because any such conflict would result in disaster to both."

Dr. Herbert V. Evatt, Australia's Minister for External Affairs, yesterday asked Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko, who is President of the United Nations Security Council this month, to call an early session for a decision on a Governor for Trieste.

THERE were two John McDonalds in Taylorsville. They grew up together and were friends until the elder returned from his service in the Union Army with an empty eye-socket by which to remember the fighting at Shiloh.
PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 20 (AP) -- Two favorites of the 15,844 crowd, the Good News Stable's Big and Better, and R.A. Brown's Tennessee Kid, won today's $7,500 featured races at Narragansett Park.

NAPLES, N.Y. -- Vintnering time in the Finger Lakes district of north-central New York is one of the best seasons of the year for tourists to inspect the wine-growing country. Here are some of the best grapes in the United States and the wines they make are like no others.

THE House of the title was 2970 Groveland, later Ellis, Avenue. In part of our century's now remote Age of Innocence -- specifically, from its early teens to its late "Twenties -- this old-fashioned three-story red brick mansion had a degree of national and even international fame as a Mecca, and also frequently a refuge, for all sorts and conditions of poets.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The immense potentialities of motion pictures in serving, in conjunction with entertainment, to meet today's challenge to democracy and to foster a "reawakening of the blessings all of us enjoy" were emphasized today by Tom C. Clark, Attorney General.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- President Truman returned today from his 10,000-mile trip to Brazil to find himself confronted with the making of crucial decisions in a wide range of foreign and domestic problems.

John M. Henderson, president of R. Dixon Co., fruit and produce importers and distributors, 202 Franklin Street, died yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital, Seventh Avenue and Eleventh Street, from the effects of injuries suffered Sept. 10 in a traffic accident involving a taxicab in which he was a passenger.

The New York Metropolitan Regional Chapter of the newly formed National Student Association held its first meeting yesterday at the New York University School of Commerce with 100 representatives from eighteen colleges and universities in the metropolitan area. The session was devoted to the writing of a regional constitution, the organization of committees, and the formation of a program for the coming academic year.

ROCK gardens begin their blossom performance so soon in the spring that some early flower gems must be foregone unless planted now. Fall planting will also insure a good display because plants will become established by the time the peak of bloom is reached in May.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Sept. 20 -- The New York Library Association, an, organization of thousands of librarians trustees and directors from all parts of the state, today demanded that the Board of Regents reconsider its decision not to recommend state aid to libraries during 1948.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The sama synchronized combination of man and machine, Danny Foster of Oakland, Calif., and the Detroitowned Miss Peps V, which won the 1947 Gold Cup on Jamaica Bay last month, demonstrated on a windy, gray Potomac this afternoon that it is still the best speed boat racing outfit in America.

THE J. Arthur Rank and Michael Powell-Emeric Pressburger combine, sponsors of "Black Narcissus," will attempt to get a new rating from the Roman Catholic National Legion of Decency which condemned the picture.

ATHENS, Sept. 20 -- Premier Themistocles Sophoulis announced tonight that the United States Government had given approval, effective immediately, to Greece's request for an increase in the Greek Army to fight guerrillas.

LOS ANGELES. TWENTY years ago a man labored and brought forth a mouse and the civilized world still hasn't stopped applauding the miracle. Mickey Mouse is the goshdarndest single act of creation in the history of our civilization. He probably is more widely known than any President, King, artist, actor, poet, composer or tycoon who ever lived.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20 -- The Government's prosecution of James C. Petrillo, head of the American Federation of Musicians, will be renewed within "the next week or so" with the filing of an amended criminal information, Otto Kerner Jr., Federal attorney, said here today.

DURING a recent discussion on nursery schools some of the mothers present objected to the term "parent education." "Unfortunate" was one of their words for it. They said it implied that teachers "have all the answers." whereas many -- younger teachers particularly -- have a good deal to learn about children from parents.

A "SNAPSHOOTER" whose photographic experience is limited to a box camera writes that he now wants to enter the ranks of amateur photography and asks what he must have in equipment and knowledge of the workings of a better camera in order to make the jump.

GIRLS from 9 to 12 will be grateful for this easy-to-follow cook book. At this age they are most eager to try their hand in the kitchen but easily become discouraged if recipes are long and complex. The recipes in "Fun with Cooking" have been chosen for the minimum effort they require.

NEW HAWEN, CONN. NEW YORK, which has seen -- and rebelled at -- just one new theatrical offering since the season began, may look longingly to this city, 100 minutes from Shubert Alley, where playgoers already have attended three major productions in as many weeks.

MANILA, Sunday, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Twenty-six of the twenty-eight men who parachuted from a lost United States Army transport over Northern Luzon have been found safe, a Thirteenth Air Force spokesman reported at noon today.
ROME, Sept. 20 -- The "hunger march," organized by the Communists and Left-Wing Socialists to protest against the de Gasperi Government was held throughout Italy today without serious incidents.

William James once philosophized, "There are three stages in the history of every medical discovery. When it is first announced, people say it is not true. Then, a little later, when its truth can no longer be denied, they say it is not important.

THE Zane Grey Show, mentioned earlier in the summer as a possibility for the fall season, will have its premiere on WOR-Mutual on Tuesday from 9:30 to 10 P.M. The stories of the well-known writer of Western adventure tales will provide the material for the dramatic series.
Residential properties in scattered sections of New Jersey passed to new control in transactions reported yesterday.

Lack of a suitable convention and exposition building is costing New York millions of dollars annually in convention and exhibition business lost to other cities with superior convention and exhibition halls, according to a report made to the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau by Royal W. Ryan, executive vice president, and issued here yesterday.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 20 -- The movement of grain from the interior to Duluth is 50 per cent less than normal due to an acute shortage of railroad box cars, grain brokers reported today. Elevators at the head of Lake Superior are holding about 11,000,000 bushels, against a working capacity of 45,000,000 bushels, and stocks are not expected to increase in any large way until late in the year.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 29 -- Behind the scenes political maneuvering is becoming more intense here as the Iranian capital prepared for another meeting of its parliament tomorrow. With time running out, the Soviet Union is showing increasing impatience to bring the proposed contract for a joint Soviet-Iranian oil company before Parliament while Iran obviously is feinting for time.

MARIE SYRKIN has succeeded in scrupulously piecing together within one brilliantly written narrative the whole story of the sacrifice of the pioneers of Palestine in their attempts to save the remnants of European Jews.

THE September heat wave that broke only last week added an extra ten days or so to the "summer" season, extending swimming weather in the mountains far beyond the normal date. It also delayed the arrival of the autumn foliage, for as long as the weather is warm enough to make up-country lakes swimmable, it is too warm for the chemical processes by which leaves change color.

TOKYO, Sept. 20 -- Two conferences, held yesterday and today, between Central Government authorities and the Governors of Japan's rice-producing prefectures considerably clarified Japan's food situation for the coming year.

IN Baudelaire and Apollinaire French poetry supplied us with two outstanding art critics. The former was by far the completer: he not only felt (which was all Apollinaire could do), he also discriminated and understood and explained.

THE current exhibit of Useful Objects at the Museum of Modern Art goes beyond its traditional scope. As in former years, it calls public attention to available items of good design. And gift ideas are still there for those who have time to consider their Christmas lists between now and Nov. 23, when the show closes.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 20 -- President Truman was called upon today by Harold E. Stassen, Republican and only announced Presidential candidate, to start "promptly" a nation-wide "SaveFood" program with the aim of effecting a 20 per cent reduction throughout the country in food consumption and a consequent "15 per cent drop in prices."

On Dec. 21, 1944, an enemy phosphorus shell exploded near a 27-yearold soldier in battle. He was led away, psychologically a blind man, though his eyes had not been injured. In an evacuation hospital the diagnosis read "hysterical blindness." Eventually he reached a general Army hospital in the Paris area, and there Dr. Montague Ullman treated him hypnotically with results as striking as any described in medical literature.
PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Sept. 20 -- Negro troops from Manhattan and Brooklyn will play host to their families, relatives and friends at Camp Smith tomorrow.

A plea that the national church and synagogue bodies of the United States propose to the United Nations Assembly the establishment of a national Day of Repentance in every nation was made by Rabbi Israel Goldstein in his sermon yesterday at Congregation B'nai Jeshurun, Eighty-eighth Street, west of Broadway.

ALONG with the growth of the documentary film since the war has come a marked increase in the production and demand for 16mm. religious motion pictures in this country. While this field still is practically uncharted its potential is tremendous, according to those engaged in its development.

HOLLYWOOD. DELMAR DAVES, Vivcca Lindfors and Dennis Morgan have just returned to the Warner studio in Burbank after seven weeks in France on "To the Victor," a photoplay by Richard Brooks about the post-war problems of a French collaborationist's wife and an American black-market operator.

THE first sounds of celebration on the occasion of the League of Composers' twenty-fifth anniversary have already been heard. Eighteen of America's most prominent orchestras, including the New York Philharmonic-Symphony the New York City Symphony and the CBS Symphony, intend to schedule one of the eighty-six works commissioned by the league to date.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 20 -- In apparent defiance of provisions of the Taft-Hartley Law banning secondary boycotts, the New Jersey State Building and Construction Trades Council, AFL, voted today to continue giving "mutual aid and assistance" to unions affiliated with the council.

IOWA CITY, Iowa, Sept. 20 (AP) -- A big, bruising Iowa football squad fired its first 1947 thunderbolts today and scored nine touchdowns for a 59-to-0 victory over an under-manned North Dakota State eleven.

Adoption by this country of the cooperative housing system used in Sweden would be effective in solving the low-rent housing problem here, in the opinion of David Tishman, president of the Tishman Realty and Construction Company, who has just returned from a housing tour of the Scandinavian country.

WITH your permission, or without it if necessary, let us continue the discussion of the propriety of Arthur Miller's "All My Sons." A fortnight ago this column defended Mr. Miller's right to compose a play out of authentic American material without first making sure that he did not tread on touch toes -- for this is the only alternative to censorship.

HONOLULU -- Hawaii's program to restore its tourist reputation as the "Paradise of the Pacific" has advanced another step. The Hawaii Visitors Bureau announces that it is placing the first Hawaii travel advertising in mainland United States publications since the end of the war two years ago.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- Probably no plan of international cooperation was ever without its unattractive features to one or more of the parties, and the Marshall Plan for European recovery is no exception. For to make it really effective, United States citizens may again have to do without and make things last a little longer.

TO THE EDITOR: One note of understanding is worth more than a tirade of denunciation * * * and that note is given by Hanson Baldwin in his factual study of Russo-American relations, "War with Russia?" It is in the fact that a war of nerves is the only one which Soviet Russia is capable of conducting -- today.

INTERNATIONAL affairs took several sharp turns in the week with the opening of the United Nations Assembly sessions, but home interest focused upon the price question. At the hearings which were started last week, retailers appeared to make out a good case for themselves.

Two youths accused of a series of lower East Side hotel holdups were arrested yesterday by detectives under Deputy Chief Inspector Conrad Rothengast. A third man, on probation after a larceny conviction, was held for violation of the Sullivan Law.

NAZCA, Peru, Sept. 20 (U.P.) -- Three persons were known to be dead today and eleven were missing in the crash of a United States Army transport plane carrying fourteen persons, nine of them Americans, while en route from La Paz, Bolivia, to the United States.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20 -- The spiraling cost of living has created such a serious problem for householders and other consumers here that Government officials, food trade associations and some segments of the public have joined the battle to halt inflationary prices.

Complete unanimity prevailed briefly among delegates to the United Nations yesterday when they learned that Fiorello H. La Guardia had died. The representatives of fifty-five nations stood in silent tribute at a plenary session of the General Assembly at Flushing Meadow, Queens.

GIVE an average man a book and, if it's the right sort, he'll probably read it. Give Anthony N. Bade a book and, if it's the right sort, he'll very likely sell it for its weight in gold and more. Much more.
TO THE EDITOR: Samuel T. Williamson's "New England Isn't That Way" seems to "debunk" New England in no uncertain terms.

GARDENING can be divided into two distinct and separate parts. One is actual planting, and the other, equally important, might be called "garden building." Under this latter category fall the many tasks of construction that are vital to the beauty of a property, and also to its efficient maintenance.

The showdown between the United States and the Soviet Union had been developing for months, but it was no less frightening when it burst out at the opening week of the United Nations General Assembly.
HORNELL, N.Y., Sept. 20 (AP) -- Seventy-five years ago a reluctant mother led her 11-year-old son through the early morning darkness to his new job as a newspaper printer's devil.

DAFFODIL time, for gardeners, is September and October as well as April and May, for it is during these two months that the bulbs are planted. All of the preparations -- selection of places to plant, and setting but of bulbs -- are as enjoyable now as bloom will be in spring, and more important to the appearance of the spring garden than work done at other seasons.

Soviet charges of United States "warmongering," drew a spirited denial last night from the permanent United States representative to the United Nations, Warren R. Austin. He warned that the denunciatory blast delivered last Thursday by Deputy Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky would "discourage many Americans who have consistently believed that the Soviet purposes are peaceful."

SHRUB-PLANTING time, which extends until the ground is frozen, provides home gardeners with an opportunity to plant new and interesting shrubs. It takes no more time or space to grow choice varieties not found in most gardens, and any added cost for better kinds is incidental since they are a permanent investment, increasing in beauty and maturity as the years pass.

The 1947 Soviet harvest season, now past the midway mark, it seems clear, will be the best since the 1941 German invasion. Dispatches appearing in the Soviet press from the Ukraine, North Caucasus, Central Asia and other important agricultural areas paint a bright picture of a rich harvest overflowing the capacity of warwrecked transportation and storage facilities.

FRANKLIN, Mich., Sept. 20 -- A strong field of golfers from the United States, Canada and South Africa is assembled here at the Franklin Hills Country Club to take part in the forty-seventh annual women's national amateur championship which gets under way on Monday with an 18-hole qualifying round.

Tributes were paid yesterday to Fiorello H. La Guardia as champion of the common man, foe of race discrimination, friend of organized labor, leader in the cause of good government and one of the best Mayors in the history of New York City, and to his integrity as man and public servant.
Somewhere near the equator off the west coast of Africa there may be a calm over an area of warm ocean. Warm air rises and cold air then rushes in.
FALL is one of the two big flower-show times in the year. The dahlia and chrysanthemum take the limelight, with events across the country devoted to each.

SOME clarification of Broadway's money problem is becoming apparent with the passing weeks. Not so long ago the wailers held the wall, crying that funds for new shows had gone into hiding and production plans were being canceled right and left. Now, according to more sober citizens, the wailers have been wailing too loud.

Entomologist, Connecticut Agricultural Experiment Station THIS season's fruit harvest is discouraging in many places. Good home-grown fruit, however, is very good indeed, and worth struggling for against even such odds as we have seen this year.

WHEN a new lawn is made or an old one renewed the kind of seed to be used should be considered carefully. Not only ought seed to be high in its percentage of germination but it should be chosen for the particular soil and conditions under which it is to grow.

GEORGE FRAZIER'S "The One With the Mustache Is Costello" is a collection of brief biographical pieces which at one time or another seemed like a good idea to the editors of Life. It might be explained, for the benefit of the timid and unworldly, that the title is just one of those stupendous pieces of whimsy.
GENEVA, Sept. 20 -- Britain has provisionally rejected the new United States proposals on a tariff accord, it was learned authoritatively tonight.
THE junior reviewer is the one who gets the musical milk after it has been skimmed. In a word, he doesn't get the big names. But, oh, the quantity!

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- An increase in crime in the rural areas of the country in the first six months of this year was noted today by the Federal Bureau of Investigation in the publication of the agency's semi-annual bulletin of Uniform Crime Reports.

HOLLYWOOD. EVERY now and then, in common with individuals, Hollywood wearies of the sacksuit school of motion-picture fodder and with a giddy toss of the head turns with antic joy to the making of shoals of pictures in which all of the gentlemen wear silks, satins and lace cuffs and all of the ladies parade majestically around in furbelows, bustles and velvet neck bands, to the soft, enticing swish of silk petticoats.

BUCKNELL -- Language Program An increase in requirements for students beginning the study of foreign languages has gone into effect at Bucknell University with the opening of the fall term. Under the new program, beginning language classes will meet five hours a week (instead of three hours as formerly) for the first two semesters.
WE'RE off now, and no mistaking the fact, on the new exhibition season in New York. Last week's list stretched from here to there down our mid-September office roster.

The condensations from John G. Winant's forthcoming book on his experiences as wartime Ambassador to London which have appeared in this newspaper will serve a useful public service if they recall to citizens of the United States the spirit of those days when we made our country the arsenal of the democracies.
BIRMINGHAM (By Wireless). ONE of Birmingham's thousands of industrial workers, William Howell, counts his blessings and views Britain's economic crisis with stolid equanimity.

MR. CASEY'S follow on his "Such Interesting People" confirms what most newspaper men knew -- that no one matches him for journalistic anecdote. He has a free swing in storytelling. His punch-lines have echoing impact, and the incidental backroom terms that creep into his yarns come out astonishingly clean.

WITHOUT soil, there would be no gardens. All the money in the world to buy seeds, plants and pots is of little avail if there is no earth in which to grow them. Having acquired a piece of land, the gardener must work with it to make it productive.

STATE-WIDE sentiment is rapidly developing in favor of laws to require periodic inspection of automobiles. Such inspection was recommended as an outstanding highway safety measure by the Special Joint Legislative Committee on Motor Vehicle Problems.

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 20 -- Talk of "resistance" against soaring living costs is common in Minneapolis, but positive organized action is lacking. What individual action has been taken has had no restraining effect.

WAS HITLER the master mind of Germany's conquests or was he the tool of coldly planning, scientific minds ? Were the Luftwaffe and the panzer divisions the heart of German power or did it lie in the curious commingling of test tubes and espionage developed by the greatest single industrial combination in the world's history?

The 5,200-deadweight-ton freighter Eastport, built by the Germans in 1937, has been turned over to her new owners, the Eastport Steamship Corporation, an affiliate of Blidberg Rothchild Co., Inc., after being reconverted completely for peacetime operation, it was announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Religious education in the United States has entered a period of progress and growth, reports Dr. Roy G. Ross, general secretary of the International Council of Religious Education.

THE final programs of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo will take place today at the City Center. The afternoon bill will consist of "The Nutcracker," "Cirque de Deux" and "Rodeo." In the evening "Sylphides," "Lola Montez," "Cirque de Deux" and "Gaite Parisienne" will be given.

LONDON, Sept. 20 -- A policy of mass emigration to reduce the population of Britain from the present total of 45,000,000 to 35,000,000 or even 30,000,000 is being seriously discussed here. For the first time in 2,000 years and more of history, occupants of the British Isles are wondering whether they may not at last have outgrown their island home.

IN the Sept. 1 issue of Life, which this department had missed during its recent stay on the Vineyard, John Chamberlain made a rapid-fire survey of American writing -- chiefly in the field of the novel -- in the period between the wars and up to the almost immediate present.

MANY true garden gems are little known and therefore are rarely grown. Sections of my garden never fail to draw gasps of surprise when observers see a group of camassias in bloom or a spot of calochortus with its many, pretty flower heads nodding in full sunshine.

Several performances of new plays and musical comedies in the near future have been taken over to raise funds for philanthropic organizations. The Maternity Center Association will be the beneficiary of the performance of "Music in My Heart," a new musical comedy, on the night of Oct. 8 at the Adelphi Theatre.

CAN music be of help to those who are ill? Some studies have been made in search of an answer to this question, but there are no hard and fast findings. While physicians and musicians are still experimenting, it has become clear that music, properly handled and controlled, can make a contribution in a good many cases.

IN recent weeks the cities and villages, the highways and railroads of India have seen enacted one of the world's epic tragedies. At a time when the independence they had won from Britain was to have started Pakistan and the Indian Union on their courses, jehad, or holy war, swept the two new nations.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The House Committee on UnAmerican Activities today announced postponement until Oct. 20 of its "Hollywood investigation." It made public the names of fortythree witnesses, including some movie stars, who have been subpoenaed to appear here.

About 3,500 New Yorkers, many of them with tears in their eyes, filed past the coffin of former Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia yesterday evening in the Chapel of St. James of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

More than 1,140 prefabricated dwellings were produced toy Adirondack Homes during the past twelve months, representing $3,200,000 in finished, ready-to-live-in housing, Arthur E. Swann, executive vice president of the company, reported yesterday.

LONDON. THE grimmest economic blizzard ever which faces Britain this winter will be an outstanding chance for radio. The stoppage of American films, the limitations on private motoring and the increased restrictions on eating out spell a boom for home entertainment.

RENO, Nev., Sept. 20 -- The first phase of Senator Robert A. Taft's journey into the Far West in quest of support for the Republican Presidential nomination ended today as the sober-sided Ohioan left California after a stay of eight days.

BELGRADE, Sept. 20 (U.P.) -- The official Yugoslav news agency Tanjug reported today that "Fascist attacks" in Gorizia, Italy, have wounded more than 300 Slovenes and have caused damage estimated at 70,000,000 lire ($280,000).

AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 20 (AP) -- Displaying dazzling speed, tricky running and clever field generalship, the University of Texas Longhorns smothered Texas Tech's Red Raiders, 33 -- 0, today before 30,000 shirt-sleeved fans.

IN the ideal literary community there would be a benevolently dictatorial, critical board before which young writers would have to appear to have the plots of their novels approved in advance. This procedure would keep the beginning novelist from tackling an idea too big for his fledgling talent to handle; or, to say it brutally, it would keep him from spoiling an idea of which a good writer could make a good novel.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The National Guard Association of the United States urged today that active Communists be tried for treason, when circumstances warranted, and be given the full penalties upon conviction. The highest penalty for treason is death.

An important step in the direction of expanding and developing the study of Chinese and Far Eastern subjects has been taken by the School of Asiatic Studies of the Asia Institute with the addition of eight faculty members from the Woochefee Institute of New York.

RECENT paintings by Hugh Kappel in his current show at the Feigl Gallery reveal a decided advance over previously exhibited work. He worked, we are told, with Friesz and Gromaire; but in this work an individual style is clearly emerging.

Eleven thousand chemists met last week in New York to attend the 112th national meeting of the American Chemical Society -- the largest chemical conclave in history. Nearly a thousand technical papers were read, and these covered such widely varying subjects as new synthetic sex hormones, insecticides, nutrition, synthetic gasoline, photochemistry, isotopes and atomic physics.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The United States Chamber of Commerce today pledged a drive to return "the American economy to peacetime conditions" with emphasis on "much lower taxes" and balanced living costs. Present economic ills were attributed to "the distortions of war and the disorder in the decade before the war."

A REVEALING and affecting glimpse into one aspect of Bela Bartok's creative output may be had in a new Vox album (two twelve-inch disks), called A. Memorial to Bela Bartok. Here is the composer in simple, intimate vein, playing some of his own piano compositions.

Furniture and decorations of various periods from several collections, including that of Pauline osdick of Palm Beach, Fla., will be auctioned at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street, on Thursday, Friday and Saturday.

Action on the retail promotion front has turned definitely to volume -getting measures designed to get business quickly to help offset the rising costs of retail distribution and the tendency toward waning sales, according to observations made by authorities in the field this week.

Already one of the largest units of the United States Power Squadrons, the Bayside Squadron does things in a big way. Again this year it will conduct not one, but two concurrent free instruction courses in small-boat handling and navigation for the benefit of the growing hundreds of North Shore Long Islanders who are sea-minded.

GENEVA. FOR nearly five months this summer the United States has been represented in Europe by William Lockhart Clayton, Under-Secretary of State for Economic Affairs. For many weeks here in Geneva he has been the dominating figure in the international tariff discussions.

To the Drama Editor: DOWN at the bottom of the obituary pages of the Monday newspapers was printed a small notice that Benjamin H. Roberts, "a representative of Actors' Equity Association and an actor for twenty-seven years," had died.

A million-dollar housing project is under way in Englewood, N.J., to meet what the developer terms an acute demand for $40,000 to $50,000 homes. Harold Levinsohn, of that community, has his first model nearly finished and has started work on two more.

Open-market sales of Manhattan real estate during August showed a decline both in number and dollar volume, and the reduced activity was accompanied by lower values as gauged by the percentage of assessed valuation realized by the sellers.

The time was fourteen years ago, New York City was close to Bankruptcy. In the city government itself there was an atmosphere of moral bankruptcy. The Seabury investigation, just ended, had disclosed the corruption and "easy graft" of sixteen years of Tammany rule.

ALTHOUGH both masters can be called realists, the jump from the product or the vision of Rogier van der Weyden to that of Velasquez must seem even greater than the separation in time and place. In these two books from the Oxford University Press (of the series entitled Masterpieces of European Pictorial Art), the difference is almost violently marked.

THE jacket announces that this first novel is "the story of a girl you won't forget." In other words, when the book is closed, Julie lingers on. Perhaps she will in the minds of some readers, for she has the not-of-this-world quality that daydreaming readers love.

DETROIT, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The Tigers came through with a couple of late rallies today to beat Bob Feller, 3 -- 2, in the opener of a twin bill; and tied the Indians, 5 to 5, in the nightcap, called after nine innings because of darkness.

WHEN we reported, a few Sundays back, on an organization called the Electric Railroaders Association (this in connection with Theodore Pratt's "Mr. Thurtle's Trolley"), we thought we were paying a sentimental tribute to a nostalgic group of people devoted to memories of the old-time trolley car.

THE Shackleford family consists of Mrs. Theresa Shackleford, her son, Geoffrey, and her grandson, Mark Ballard, who is five years older than his Uncle Geof. Theresa is a strong willed old lady, accustomed to getting her own way by fair means or foul.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The Marshall Plan is the last hope for liberty in Western Europe. Only the Marshall Plan can help Western Europe to achieve the standard of living which is necessary if our kind of democracy is to survive.

BOSTON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Held to eight singles while losing the opener, 6-3, the Boston Red Sox bounced back with 14 hits for a 7-2 triumph over the Washington Senators in the second game of today's double-header before 11,168 fans.

OF comparatively modest design, but offering all the essential seagoing comforts of her larger, predecessors, the new Cunard White Star liner Media represents a type of moneyearner that is becoming more and more popular with ship operators and travelers.

ROYAL JELLY -- The queen bee owes her extraordinary vitality to food rather than to her life of ease, finds Dr. Thomas S. Gardner of the scientific department of Hoffman-La Roche, Nutley, N.J.A. study of royal jelly, a glandular secretion of worker bees which is the richest known source of pantothenic acid, has partially explained why a queen bee lives about five years but the average worker only three months.

AS former Mayor La Guardia remarks in his preface, this terse, hard-hitting book is truly the story of an honest cop. The late Commissioner Valentine has labeled it an autobiography: it is more the history of the metropolitan Police Department he did so much to revitalize during his eleven-year tenure.

AUTUMN comes to Vermont and New Hampshire and Maine, and the farmer's wife steams apple dumplings for the family dinner, serves them, hot and light, with a foamy sauce. This traditional Yankee dessert typifies New England cooking; what heresy that when the recipe appears in cook books, the dumplings are always baked rather fhan steamed!

The free state of Trieste comes into the world as an adopted child. Conceived amid the dissension of last year's Foreign Ministers' Conference in Paris, its future was forthwith placed in the hands of the United Nations, which has undertaken to guarantee its independence.

Rumors of currency devaluation by major foreign countries assumed prominence in foreign trade circles last week. Importers and exporters, and their co-workers in finance, admitted surprises may be in store. On the basis of their interpretation of facts that were known, however, they were inclined to doubt that devaluation, if undertaken, would bring substantial benefits.

PARIS, Sept. 20 -- While representatives of sixteen western European nations were completing in Paris this week their draft for an economic Marshall Plan, they were startled to learn that in New York the Secretary of State had proclaimed another Marshall Plan.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Today's report of he livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 300 head; total, 2,300 (estimated). Compared with week ago: butchers' hogs, under 240 pounds, around 75 cents to $1.50 lower; weights over 240 pounds, steady to
NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 20 (AP) -- An aerial survey today of the resort section along Mississippi's gulf coast showed that yesterday's hurricane left it a panorama of devastation.

BECAUSE of the ancient land-labor-capital formulation as the quantum of economics, our universities have offered instruction in labor problems as a branch of the economics curriculum. This is perhaps no more unfortunate than if the sociologists, the psychologists, the political scientists, or the historians had taken over the subject.

FOR THIS WEEK: Order bulbs and all perennials, roses or shrubs needed for fall planting without delay. . . . Pull up large weeds in flower borders and scythe those that have taken over rows vacated of plants or corners of the property. . . . Spray poison ivy starting to turn red against tree trunks or in other accessible places with 2, 4-D.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The first United Nations Statistical Congress, which came to a close this week, has made a notable start toward an international statistical system. Information which 600 statisticians from fifty-five nations exchanged here and arranged for in the future should help provide the missing data for national and world economic and social planning.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (U.P.) -- Congressional approval was urged tonight for a network of feederairlines which would provide threecent airmail service for smaller cities and stimulate "our weakened and fast disappearing aircraft industry."

IT is unfortunate that the title "Black Saga," under which this excellent novel was published in England, was not retained for the American edition. Any novel of Haiti at the time of the French Revolution is, inescapably, a saga of the remarkable Negroes who broke the bonds of slavery and made their country independent of France.

TO the adventurous gardene fall is as exciting as spring in the opportunity it offer for seed sowing. Planting seed is so much a part of spring and summer that it often as, tonishes the novice to learn how many kinds require a long period of cold before they will germinated.

WHETHER you use this book for reference purposes or merely for the kind of reading material that most animal lovers pore over from time to time, you will hardly be disappointed. Victor Calahane, chief biologist of America's national parks, is also an author of some repute; he is happily endowed with the combination of talents necessary for turning out such a book as "Mammals of North America."

SEPTEMBER recalls the gardener to his planting no less than the student to his books. Recent summerlike days have provided an interlude during which the fall projects could be considered while he was waiting for supplies and weather to make their achievement possible.

HERSHEY, Pa., Sept. 20 -- An intersectional game between Penn State and Washington State launched the 1947 college football campaign tonight, with the Nittany Lions downing the Cougars from the Pacific Coast, 27 -- 6, before a capacity crowd of 16,000 at the Hershey Stadium.

BOSTON, Sept. 20 -- Boston housewives, like their male providers, are appalled and indignant about the present price of food. Despite the fact that the Eastern panel of the Joint Congressional Price Investigating Committee spent much of this week in Boston, little has been done about the situation.

WILLIAM L. SHIRER'S "Berlin Diary," his journal of experiences as a foreign correspondent in Berlin before our entry into the war, was a powerful and significant book. When published in 1941 it was a potent force in bringing us to a realization of what Nazi Germany meant.

A supper dance to celebrate the fortieth anniversary of the opening of the Hotel Plaza will be given in the Terrace Room of that hostelry on Oct. 2 as a benefit for the Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York. Sponsored by Elizabeth Arden, the fete will include in a special song-and-dance program the entertainment of the era in which the Plaza was opened.
What means this sense of lateness that comes over one now, as if the rest of the year were down hill? How early in the year it begins to be late!"

John McNamara, leader of the two-day-old strike against the Railway Express Agency, yesterday denounced the provisions of the Railway Labor Act as outmoded and offered to place his union's demand for a forty-hour week before "any neutral arbitrator or panel."

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Dons, with such backfield stars as Charlie O'Rourke, Glenn Dobbs and Chuck Fenebock, fielded too much strength for the Brooklyn Dodgers and won, 48-to21, last night. The victory put the Dons all even with two triumphs and two setbacks, and the Dodgers deeper in the All-America Football Conference cellar.

Thirty-six passengers and five crew members of the Pan American clipper Defender, inbound from Bermuda, escaped unhurt last night when the big four-motored plane made a crash landing at Floyd Bennett Field in Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- After this week's exhibition of headline diplomacy at the United Nations, even Washington, which usually glories in housetop negotiation, is beginning to have its doubts.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- President Truman, who left here a "tadpole" and returned today a "shellback" in the realms of King Rex of the Equator, confronted new phases of old problems which will draw upon him for whatever toughness and vigor he gained in the "promotion" aboard the battleship Missouri.

FOR the past nine years a twocolumn box of humor has brightened the essentially humorless pages of Newsweek, a magazine devoted to the weekly mastication, of news for readers too busy for daily newspapers. The news has been none too good these past nine years, but the column has been consistently good.
Following is the text of yesterday's address by Foreign Minister Georges Bidault of France in the General Assembly of the United Nations, as furnished by the French delegation:

ELECTRONIC high - speed lamps can be synchronized directly with the camera shutter in a new addition to the Wollensak line, announced by the Raygram Corporation, distributors. The unit, available in three sizes, is the 135mm f/4.7 lens in "X" Synchromatic-Rapax shutter with built-in electrical contacts for flashing the "X" (trigger) type speed lamps in synchronization at all shutter speeds.

Two delayed-action charges, one by the King's Ranch's favored But Why Not and the other by Walter M. Jeffords' 17-to-1 shot Snow Goose, resulted in victories for those 3-year-old fillies in the two divisions of the Beldame Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- Despite its failure at the last session of Congress, the legislative budget provision of the 1946 Congressional Reorganization Act will be tried again next year, but this time a real effort to make it work appears to be shaping up.

KAY BELIVEAU's novel is a serious and honest attempt to portray the turmoil of a girl trying to find herself. Francesca Di Mazio, the heroine, like many young girls today, must take the measure of a sorely confused society while puzzling over her own inner conflicts.

IT is our well-advised understanding that that enterprising gentleman, Howard Hughes, has little regard for film critics. In fact, we hear he rather holds them in contempt. But we'd, like, anyhow, to offer Mr. Hughes our sincerest thanks.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 20 -- Bobo Newsom, whose bulky frame for a time was looming large as Bucky Harris' No. 1 world series hurler, lost a little in stature today, although there were extenuating circumstances.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The Communist defamation campaign against the United States has suddenly taken a distinct spurt in scope and intensity, particularly in southeastern Europe. Official observers are unable as yet to tell whether the development presages any dramatic change in relations between the Soviet Union and the West.

THE new Peterson field guide covering all birds found east of the hundredth meridian is easily the best of its kind ever put together, an invaluable convenience in sight identification. It now contains 290 pages as against 180 pages in the last previous edition.

WHEN Barnard begins another school year next Thursday its students will face a new dean -- the fourth in the fiftyeight-year history of the college. In a sense, Mrs. Millicent Carey McIntosh is unique among college deans, as Barnard might be called unique among women's colleges.

TO THE EDITOR: In THE TIMES Magazine I see a photo showing a street sign in London reading "Emigrate by air now to Ontario, Canada" and subsequently read that the first contingent of 50,000 English men and women are leaving for Canada "to relieve domestic shortages."

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 20 -- Those sea twins, Suds and Splash, came to the surface of Long Island Sound today in the next to last championship regatta of the summer season, sponsored by the Horseshoe Harbor Yacht Club. And out of the spume came another change in the long sailing jam for the lead among the International Class sloops.

Elimination of the requirement from the 1947 Federal tax returns that asked corporations to state whether a minimum of 70 per cent of their profits had been distributed to stockholders in the year, and to explain the reason, if they were not, as was the case in 1946, will have little effect, it is believed, on dividend payments to shareholders.

FRIEDA SCHLEMPKE got herself talked about in the Midwestern town of West Haven. Frieda was too attractive, too pushing, too successful with Junius Hake, in whose store she worked. Frieda married too hastily and too high in the West Haven social hierarchy, worked at Hake's even after marriage (it was the Eighteen Nineties), even after her children came.

BERLIN. ARMED only with a movie camera and an idea, Roberto Rosselini, producerdirector of "Open City," is just finishing work in Berlin's ruins on a picture called "Berlin, Year Zero." A modest, mild-mannered young Roman, Rosselini says he thinks the film will be his best work to date.

Georges Bidault, the French Foreign Minister, yesterday denied charges by Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, that the Marshall plan for economic help to Europe was an attempt to alienate the political and economic independence of European countries.

LOS ANGELES -- The advent of autumn brings California boosters their annual climax of frustration, because, having extolled the California summer as perfection, they feel impelled to prove that, somehow, the California fall can be superior.

A "BULLIONAIRE" is not necessarily a billionaire. He is a man who has made a fortune in cattle. Such a one was Clancy Devoe, who has been shot dead during a Texas sandstorm. Sheriff Jess Roden happens to be in Texas at the time -- or perhaps "happens" is not the right word.

For many years there was no concerted movement to extend the special privilege enjoyed by the taxpayers of some States growing out of community property laws. These State statutes permit of dividing the income of either the husband or the wife between them equally for income tax purposes.

SAMPSON, N.Y., Sept. 20 -- When Sampson College's 5,000 students come to the campus next week they will find that this former naval training center has finally taken on the flavor and appearance of a conventional institution of higher learning Former barracks are now attractive men's dormitories; mess halls have become cafeterias, and the anti-aircraft ranges are athletic fields.

Long awaited by the investment community, the statement of policy regarding direct American investments abroad was presented last week by Willard L. Thorp, Assistant Secretary of State for Economic Affairs. It was the first such public announcement to be offered by the United States Government, financial observers asserted yesterday.

ATHENS, Sept. 20 -- While the new Liberal-Populist coalition government of Greece has been received with reservations by practicing politicians here, it appears to be popular. It can claim to be representative and can submit to the scrutiny of American public opinion, Congress and the United Nations without qualms.

While some home builders on Long Island continue to concentrate on projects in the $10,000 price class, there has been a noticeable tendency in recent weeks toward the erection of residences definitely in the "luxury" class.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 20 -- If the United Nations should decide to create a Jewish state in Palestine, the Zionists could mobilize a security force of 50,000 armed and trained men within a short period, according to informed estimates here.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In a recent editorial you wrote an enthusiastic commendation of the Amnesty act adopted by the new Greek Cabinet at the suggestion of Premier Sophoulis. You described the measure as an "act of generosity" calculated to get the new Government off to a good start and as "a triumph of American diplomacy."

TANGIER, Va. -- Although Tangier Island, an idyllic little spot which Capt. John Smith discovered more than three centuries ago, has no apparent intention of becoming a vacation resort, it continues to be a most pleasant side trip from the mainland for anyone who has a few days to spare.

OMAHA, Sept. 20 -- Like the weather, high living costs are a universal topic of conversation in the Midwest, but nobody does much about them. Surveys have indicated that most of this region has fared slightly better than the East in the matter of food costs.

There is a prejudice among weathermen against speaking of storms which come at this season of the year as equinoctial storms. Their reasoning is simple. The equinox is a matter of astronomical movements, the relative positions of the earth and the sun. Storms are the result of atmospheric conditions, not of astronomical relationships.

For the past ten weeks delegates of sixteen nations of Western Europe have been gathered in the Grand Palais in Paris for the European Conference of Economic Cooperation. Their job has been to draw up a blueprint of Europe's needs and Europe's ability to help itself for submission to the United States.
