MOSCOW, Sept. 20 -- President Truman was the object today of one of the bitterest attacks ever made in the Soviet press against any United States official when an article in the weekly Literary Gazette accused him of "straining for the laurels of the Corporal from Munich."
No signs of early relief from the housing shortage in New York and other crowded centers yet have appeared.

In World Arena For two years a cold war has been waged between the United States of America and the Union of Soviet Spcialist Republics in virtually every arena in which the interests of the two meet. Last week, with sudden and dramatic emphasis, the cold war was translated into hot words before the greatest international forum in the world today -- the General Assembly of the United Nations.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 20 -- Mrs. Sherman R. Hoyt's white standard poodle, Ch. Blakeen Osprey, shown to perfection by his owner, topped a field of 385 at the twentieth annual dog show of the Eastern states exposition today.
The first week of the United Nations General Assembly session ended yesterday as it had begun, with the veto controversy cropping up in every speech.
BOSTON, Sept. 20 -- Presidential aspirants, after beating the bushes in the Midwest and West, are beginning to concentrate their attention upon New England.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. THE convention of the National Association of Broadcasters here last week demonstrated the extraordinary difficulties that lie ahead in curbing excessive commercialism on the air.

Irish Shipping, Ltd., founded in 1941 by the Irish Government as a "desperation measure," has grown to a point where it is now an integral part of Irish national economy, according to John P. Reihill, director of the company.

THESE fall weeks are the best time to make a perennial border. Almost two months of good planting weather lie ahead, with plenty of opportunity to set out and move plants, get bulbs into the ground, and even sow seeds with expectation of bloom next year.

NO doubt it is unwise to leap to conclusions in any field of human endeavor, and a bridge player no less than any other speculator may expect to suffer if he does so. Nevertheless, the following deal may point a moral.

Jan Masaryk, Foreign Minister of Czechoslovakia, asserted in the general debate of the United Nations General Assembly at Flushing Meadow yesterday that "Europe has gone definitely to the Left." He declared that it might be well for every member country to face that as a reality.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 20 -- The San Francisco Congress of Industrial Organizations council today announced its support of Representative Franck R. Havenner for Mayor, following by a few days similar action by the Union Labor party of the American Federation of Labor.

THE true visionary is the gardener who plants bulbs enthusiastically during fall. Anything less interesting in themselves than the round, deadappearing white or brown objects is hard to imagine. However, patience and perseverance with a trowel, and sometimes a crowbar, produce an amazing and enchanting succession of flowers for as long as eight or nine weeks in the spring.

To the Screen Editor: I AM in complete agreement with the letters criticizing American films, and my family and I have almost stopped going to the movies. Unfortunately, some of us older boys and girls living up here in the mountains will never get a chance to see the more adult French and English pictures, as the local theatres run largely to productions catering to citizens 9 or 10 years old.

MISS DE LA TORRE'S brief collection of pieces about eighteenth - century malefactors includes two old ballads and several bits of prose by writers contemporary with their subjects. The bulk of the book is, however, taken up with excerpts from the work of such recent connoisseurs as Andrew Lang, Raymond Postgate.
GENEVA, Switzerland, Sept. 20 -- The executive committee of the League of Red Cross Societies ended an eleven-day series of meetings in Geneva today.

The Fiorello H. La Guardia whom we prefer to remember is the La Guardia of the first two administrations -- the dynamic, aggressive, tirelessly competent Mayor who rid this city of the vice and incompetence of Tammany control and taught Tammany that it could never return in safety to its old ways.
TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 20 -- Bigger than ever, the Trenton State Fair will open tomorrow. It will be the main attraction, here and through the surrounding countryside for eight days and seven nights.

Still hopeful of moving up a notch or two from fourth place before the curtain drops on the 1947 National League campaign, the Giants unleashed their celebrated home-run punch against the Phillies yesterday. Circuit clouts by Johnny Mize, Bobby Thomson and Buddy Kerr supplied all the runs as Mel Ott's charges slugged their way to a 5-3 triumph before a crowd of 12,526 at the Polo Grounds.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 20 -- The Cardinals, stubbornly refusing to bow completely out of the National League pennant picture, again defeated the Cubs tonight, 5 to 0, thus retaining their mathematical chance of finishing in a tie with the Dodgers.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 20 -- Mrs. John T. Mahoney's 7year-old brown gelding Prompt Payment from Warrenton, Va., ridden by Miss Ellie Wood Keith of Charlottesville, Va., finished with 28 1/2 points to become the grand hunter champion of the forty-second annual Piping Rock horse show today.

WHAT many observers describe as the white hope of the air freight industry looks like the white hope of the air transport industry -- languishes in Columbus, Ohio, for lack of a sponsor with a few million dollars.

WASHINGTON. LAST January, when Carroll D. Kearns of Pennsylvania's Twenty-eighth district came to Washington, the musicians' union card he carried in his pocket noted only one of many memberships acquired in a determined, if frequently diverted, rise from the railroad tracks of New Castle.

The Fifty-fifth annual meeting of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers will be held on Nov. 12 to 15, at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel, it was announced yesterday. The program of the conference includes a meeting of the society's council, on Nov. 12, which will be followed by two days of technical discussions.

PARIS, Sept. 20 -- In opening the campaign of his Reunion of the French People in the coming local elections, Charles de Gaulle said in an address today at Lyon that the faulty structure of the French Government rendered it helpless in the face of France's most pressing problems.
James Forrestal, the first Secretary of Defense in the country's history, assumed office last week in the midst of change.

AMES, Iowa, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The Iowa State Cyclones, sparked by the brilliant passing of quarterback Ron Norman, opened their football season today with a 31-14 victory over the Iowa State Teachers College Panthers.

Henry A. Wallace, in three New Jersey speeches yesterday, attacked the Truman Administration, "reactionary capitalism" and universal military training, decried Senator Robert A. Taft's "eat less" advice and described himself as a champion of "progressive capitalism."

CHICAGO, Sept. 20 -- The national board of Americans for Democratic Action outlined today a seven-point program, based on establishment of a Federal Economic Adjustment Administration with wide legal authority over our economy.

ATLANTA, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Tony Penna, veteran pro from Cincinnati, shot near-perfect golf from tee to green today to post a thirdround five-under-par 66 and take the lead by three strokes in the North Fulton $10,000 open tournament at 208.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 20 -- The delay, forced by the Soviet Union, in getting agreement on effective peace forces has made it impossible for any member of the United Nations to determine the extent of its military responsibilities for collective security, Admiral H. Kent Hewitt, United States representative on the United Nations Military Staff Committee, charged today.

Curbstone sales of vegetables from farm trucks, an outdoor mass meeting, a motorcade through the city, and price testimony by housewives and wage-earners were planned yesterday by New Yorkers to impress the touring members of Congress who will begin a four-day stand here this morning in their investigation of high prices.
Ernie Lombardi came to the end of the trail yesterday as a Giant, and, so far as is known, as a big league ball player.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21 -- Lard futures fluctuated nervously last week on the Board of Trade, largely because of the weakness in grains, but there was aggressive buying at times attributed to smaller packers against export sales, and many inquiries for September and last quarter shipment abroad were said to be in the market.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP). -- Three national organizations today demanded prompt legislative action for government controls to deal with prices, aid to Europe and the abatement of inflation dangers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Robert N. Denham, general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board, said today that he would stand by his non-Communist affidavit ruling despite fears of the American Federation of Labor that it might damage its group.

Although It is only two and a half years old, Seven Park Avenue Foods, at the corner of Thirty-fourth Street, is a grocery that already is well known in the British Isles, on the European Continent and in China. Opened during the war, the shop has featured an overseas mailing service from the start, and to date 50,000 gifts have gone to people in those places.

RENO, Nev., Sept. 21 -- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican, of Ohio, called upon the Truman Administration today to put the United States "definitely on record" in support of the recommendations of the special United Nations Committee on Palestine, which he said offered a "sound compromise" of a "dangerous controversy."

Mayor O'Dwyer may soon have before him for consideration a new proposal for the creation of a Transit Authority to take over and operate the municipal transit lines at a self-sustaining fare, it was learned last night.

Fresh wall treatments that include both plywood paneling and new types of wallpaper have been used in Sloane's House of Years, which will reopen today after being redecorated. There are eight rooms on display, most of them furnished with Sloane's own reproductions of period designs.

With a cluster of three homeruns that sent their Major League record aggregate to 217 and their league record for consecutive game round-trippers to eighteen, the Giants yesterday rang down the curtain on the 1947 baseball season at the Polo Grounds.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:

NOW that they are at last available in book form in this country, it is easy to see why Bernard Shaw's last plays have never been, acted here. They just aren't very good plays. Since the great man himself admits that "Geneva; 'In Good King Charles's Golden Days' and Cymbeline Refinished"* are products of his "dotage," it should offend no perfect Shavians to find others agreeing with him.

Announcement by its president, Roland L. Redmond, that the Metropolitan has recently acquired the major part of the splendid collection formed by the late Joseph Brummer has created a considerable stir in American art circles. Indeed, the purchase must be called world-wide in the scope of its commanding significance, for it brings into our Metropolitan a varied wealth of material that would be as ardently welcomed by any of the great museums overseas.

ALBANY, Sept. 21. -- Alger B. Chapman, state tax Commissioner, preparing for prompt payment of New York's $400,000,000 soldiers bonus, if it is approved at the polls in November, anounced today the appointment of Col. Harold Riegelman of New York City, as special counsel to the Tax Department for administration of the bonus.
NANKING, Sept. 21 (AP) -- The Government's Central News Agency reported today the repulse of a Communist attack on Tungkwan, railway junction on the Honan-Shensi Province border.

BOSTON, Sept. 21 -- Seventy resolutions condemning James B. Carey, national secretary-treasurer of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, and other leaders of the anti-Communist bloc in the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers have been submitted by locals and district councils for action at the U.E. convention, opening here tomorrow.

Arturo Toscanini returned to Radio City to conduct a special concert of the NBC Symphony Orchestra late yesterday afternoon. The same program, which featured the radio premiere of the "Symphony 51/2" by Don Gillis, had originally been scheduled for Aug. 31, but was postponed because of the maestro's indisposition at that time.
The five important aircraft manufacturers in the New York area expect to survive the cutting of the Air Force that must follow reduced Congressional appropriations, a survey indicated here yesterday.

The second annual celebration of Agricultural Sabbath has been set for Saturday, Oct. 4, the Sabbath of Succoth, the traditional Jewish Thanksgiving week, it was announced yesterday by Rabbi Ahron Ophes of the Synagogue Council of America.

The national council of the National Maritime Union, CIO, will recommend to the union's sixth annual convention, which opens today, that it reaffirm the headquarters policy of "non-compliance" with the Taft-Hartley law, Ferdinand C. Smith, national secretary, announced last night.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 21 -- Edward Small has signed Orson Welles for the title role in "Cagliostro," a screen biography of the eighteenth-century mystic and impostor, which Gregory Ratoff will direct for Small at the Scalera studios in Rome, starting Oct. 7.

Dr. Ordway Tead, chairman of the Board of Higher Education, said yesterday that, despite over-crowded conditions, the 1947-48 school year would be fruitful for the 67,000 students of New York's four municipal colleges. The students will be in classrooms today for the beginning of the fall semester.

BERLIN, Sept. 21 (AP) -- The severest German drought in a hundred years has crippled three key phases of economy in the United States zone, Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor, reported today.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 21--Archbishop Joseph E. Ritter today warned Roman Catholics protesting the admission of Negro children into parochial schools with white pupils here that they will be excommunicated automatically from the Church if they persist in plans to bar the Negroes by civil action against the Archbishop.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 21 -- Princeton University's 1947-48 undergraduate body, numbering a record high of 3,600 students, was welcomed officially to the campus this afternoon in an address by Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of the university, in opening exercises in the university chapel.

Former President Herbert Hoover last night pictured the world food situation for the coming year as no better than that which existed in 1945 when "there were the gravest dangers of mass starvation." He outlined a program designed to meet the impending disaster.

President Truman, back at his desk, is scheduled today to consult with Secretary Marshall on the steadily deteriorating European situation. This will inevitably raise the question of whether or not Congress shall be called into special session. Secretary Marshall is believed to be seeking such action.

The three-day strike of 5,000 employes of the Railway Express Agency here spread across the Hudson River last midnight when the executive committee of Local 459 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, AFL, called out its 2,100 members and ordered token picketing in four Hudson County municipalities.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 21 -- If the Arab state suggested by the United Nation's Special Committe on Palestine should ever be established in a partitioned Palestine, Dr. Hussein F. Khalidi, secretary of the Palestine Arab Higher Committee, asserted today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21 -- A coffcerted drive to bring about lower prices for foodstuffs, reports that the Government had cut its export program by 100,000,000 bushels of all grain, uncertainty regarding margin requirements on speculative operations in futures and excellent weather conditions for maturing the new corn crop combined to bring about a drastic decline in prices last week on the Board of Trade.

Robert Cornman, a pianist of talent, made his New York recital debut at Town Hall late yesterday afternoon before a sizable and enthusiastic audience. The program ran from Bach through Chopin to Prokofieff, and the young performer was equal to every problem.

The plain people of the city said a last farewell yesterday to Fiorello H. La Guardia. In an unending stream they filed by the bier of their three-time Mayor as he lay in state, first in the small St. James Chapel of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine and later as his coffin rested at the foot of the great nave of the cathedral.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 21 -- West Coast waterfronts, two of which have been affected since mid-July by a dispute over the issue of collective bargaining on behalf of supervisory employes, are looking to a Los Angeles Superior Court to rule next Friday on an application for a preliminary injunction against picketing of ships operated by the Luckenbach Steamship Company.

"Exploring the Unknown," dramatizations of the miracles of modern science, will become a Sunday evening offering of WJZ and the ABC network on a sustaining basis beginning next Sunday, from 7:30 to 8 P.M. The program ended a sponsored run on WOR-Mutual on Aug. 31.

GENEVA, Sept. 21 -- A new phase in the short, stormy history of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe will begin tomorrow as the first of a series of meetings of the technical sub-committees opens in Geneva.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (U.P.) -- The nation's farmers received a record $24,500,000,000 for last year's crops and started 1947 with assets of $111,209,000,000, economists of the Department of Agriculture reported.

A coast-to-coast newspaper campaign for its work clothes for men will be launched beginning Oct. 15, Sweet Orr Co., Inc., announced over the week-end. Sixty-four newspapers with a totaL circulation of about twelve million will be used.

New York University's School of Education is starting serious study of the comics. A workshop course on "The Cartoon Narrative as a Medium of Communication" will open Wednesday, Prof. Harvey Zorbaugh, chairman of the Department of Educational Sociology, announced last night.

LONDON, Sept. 21 -- The stocK narkets here displayed marked instability last week. In some respects their behavior showed complete absence of logic, although this can be explained partly by its bewildering problems and by the government's measures to deal with the economic crisis.

Denying the charge that high food prices are caused by high profits to manufacturers, Paul S. Willis, president of the Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., estimated last night that the large food processors' profits will drop to 3 1/2 per cent of sales this year.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 21-- Attacks on crowded refugee trains and convoys in the troubled Punjab border region have resulted in death to at least forty-five refugees and injuries to more than seventy-five, according to tonight's official military reports for the last twenty-four hours.
TOKYO, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Several score Japanese marooned on their housetops by the flood covering the Kanto plain north of Tokyo received an unexpected visitor today, the emperor.

Buyers in the wholesale markets last week concentrated mainly on expediting delivery of goods already on order, rather than on making new commitments, according to the reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- President Truman spent a quiet work day in the White House today clearing his desk for an important round of conferences with cabinet members tomorrow on pressing foreign and domestic problems. Through these conferences he may decide whether to call a special session of Congress.

A three-run outburst in the top half of the ninth inning gave the Cleveland Buckeyes a 10-7 triumph over the New York Cubans in the second contest of the Negro world series yesterday at the Yankee Stadium before 9,000.

ALBANY, Sept. 21 -- The Advisory Committee on Teachers Salaries, in a preliminary report released today by Francis T. Spaulding, Commissioner of Education, recommends strongly that teachers play a major role in fixing the standards which will determine their qualification for promotional increments under the 1947 Teachers Salary Law.
TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 21 (AP) -- A record crowd, estimated at 60,000 persons, swarmed over the state fair grounds today as the week-long event opened its sixtieth presentation.

BOSTON, Sept. 21 -- Despite official disclaimers, there is much talk of organization of a "stop Dewey" movement among Republicans in Massachusetts, the key New England state because of its large electoral vote.

STROUDSBURG, Sept. 21 -- At the annual meeting of the Felt Association at Shawnee-on-Delaware yesterday, the wool felt industry took steps toward the further simplification of industrial consumers' purchasing requirements by advancing its standardization program by several important steps.

"Out of the most uncompromising material Christ makes men who can still turn the world upside down," the Right Rev. Frank A. McElwain, retired Bishop of Minnesota, said yesterday in a sermon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Cincinnati and Pittsburgh divided a twin bill today, the Pirates clubbing seven Redleg pitchers for an 11-7 victory after the Beds had won the opener, 3 -- 1, to give Ewell Blackwell his twenty-second victory of the season.
NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Flood waters began creeping higher in the New Orleans area today to add more devastation to the staggering losses suffered in the hurricane.

Tribute was paid yesterday to Fiorello H. La Guardia as Mayor, leader in civic reform, humanitarian and friend by four persons who knew him well -- Samuel Seabury, Adolf A. Berle Jr., Rabbi Stephen S. Wise and Newbold Morris.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21 (U.P.) -- The remnants of the Gulf hurricane lashed across the Middle West today and swept into southern Michigan. Winds of sixty-five miles an hour caused extensive property damage. Torrential rains and high winds damaged communication lines and disrupted traffic in some cities.
Three girls, aged 5 years, 4 years and 7 months, respectively, were found, apparently abandoned, last night at Madison Avenue and Fifty-first Street, outside the rectory of St. Patrick's Cathedral.

The Rev. Dr. Douglas C. Horton, chairman of the American Committee for the World Council of Churches, asserted yesterday that "we in this country will one day be faced with the same dilemma that beset England, the choice between coercion and conscience."

The victories of science and medicine in the past half century over acute diseases and infections have created a situation in which the emphasis of hospital care is shifting from acute maladies to degenerative and long-term illnesses, according to a study just completed by the Hospital Council of Greater New York.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Piling two more 15-mile heat victories on the scoring yesterday in the initial test, Danny Foster of Oakland, Calif., carried off the 1947 President's Cup today. In his amazing speed boat Miss Peps V., he ran up a perfect tally of 2,000 points, completely dominating the Potomac over his chief rivals, Dan Arena in Notre Dame and Guy Lombardo in Miss Great Lakes.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Sept. 21 -- Tired of retirement, Dr. Corydon M. Wassell, whose exploit in leading twelve wounded Navy men to safety in the Southwest Pacific in 1942 was the subject of a Presidential citation, a book and a motion picture, left his home at 30 Belmont Street here today to resume his early career as a medical missionary.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Sparked by the brilliant all-around play of Orban (Speck) Sanders, the New York Yankees passed and pounded to a 21-16 victory today over the San Francisco '49ers in an All-America Conference football game watched by a crowd of 52,819.

MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 20 (AP) -- A second tropical storm apparently was in the making tonight. A squall area over the Isle of Pines, south of Cuba, was gathering intensity and was moving northwestward at twelve to fourteen miles an hour.
PARIS, Sept. 21 -- Premier Paul Ramadier proclaimed today that France still recognized Russia's place in Europe, and was joined by President Vincent Auriol in warning against the danger of war.

Net sales of Montgomery Ward Co., Inc., in the six months ended with July established a new high record at $508,647,868, a gain of $90,250,648 or 21.6 per cent over the volume in the corresponding period last year, Sewell Avery, chairman of the board, reported to stockholders in the semi-annual statement released today.

At the end of last week, Mr. George Isaacs, Britain's Minister of Labor, announced the details of the Government's widely heralded plan for the "direction of labor." The measure provides for "sanctions" in the form of fines and jail sentences.

Considerable emphasis is being given in official quarters to the importance of high-level demand as a cause of rising food prices. Secretary of Commerce Harriman points out, "People have more to spend for food and they are bidding against each other for the food that is brought to the market."
J.E. Drew has been named associate director of public relations of the National Association of Manufacturers.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 21 -- Due almost entirely to the resumption of operations at steel plants here which had been shut down because of an outlaw railroad strike, steel ingot output for the country last week advanced 6 points to 90.5 per cent of capacity from the revised rate in the week before of 84.5 per cent.

The "high explosive" for the Christian is to avoid the defensive and take the offensive, the Rev. Dr. William E. Farndale, president of the Conference of the Methodist Church in England, declared yesterday morning in a sermon at Christ Church, Methodist, 520 Park Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Net public and private indebtedness, which stood at the beginning of this year at $393,000,000,000, showed a decline for the first time since 1931, the Department of Commerce reported today. The total was almost $15,000,000,000 less than at the end of 1945.

Week Ended Sept. 19, 1947 Pound sterling for spot and future delivery showed a firm undertone on a good turnover last week, an indication that there has been a lifting of the pressure which recently had effected irregularity in those documents. Balancing of demand for spot by commercials, contrasted with activity in futures representing hedges against commitments left the values of each moderately above those of the preceding week.

ATLANTA, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Toney Penna, a sentimental, favorite of the gallery, rallied, an the final holes today to capture the $10,000 North Bullion open golf tournament with a 281, one stroke in front of Jimmy Demaret.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 21 (AP) -- More than 1,000 employes of the Egyptian Army workshops marched to the Premier's offices today, denouncing Britain and the United States. They cheered Premier Mahmoud Fahmy Nokrashy Pasha and shouted, "long live Russia, Poland and Syria!"

A delegation of 350 parents and children motored to Pawling, N.Y., yesterday from 155th Street and St. Nicholas Avenue to see Governor Dewey and to urge him to maintain the present status of the city-state child care program. The group, part of the Child Care Center Parents Association, rode in forty private automobiles and two chartered buses.

Many special events and ceremonies will be held in the city this week in honor of the arrival on Thursday of the Freedom Train, bearing 130 documents and flags marking the development of liberty in the United States.

TOKYO, Sept. 21 -- Helped by large grants of American foodstuffs over the past two years, Japan is making progress toward the goal of a national diet of 2,100 calories daily, set by the Government's Economic Stabilization Board.

LONDON, Sept. 21--The British Government will treat any further flagrant denials of fundamental freedoms in Rumania, Bulgaria and Hungary as criminal violations of the peace treaties, a Foreign Office spokesman said tonight.

ROME, Sept. 21 -- Yesterday's 'hunger march" showed a desrease of Communist and Left-Wing Socialist strenth, according to neutral observers. It was intended to be a mobilization of the working class against the Government's policies but only moderately successful meetings resulted.

The proceeds from the sixth edition of "Fashions of the Times," sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES, to be presented on Oct. 28, 29, 30 and 31, will go to the scholarship fund of the Fashion Institute of Technology and Design, it was announced yesterday.

The common people of the world still retain their faith in the realization of the promises of the United Nations Charter "in spite of the strident forensic fury" of current United Nations meetings, General Assembly delegates from thirty-eight countries were told yesterday at a solemn high mass celebrated in St. Patrick's Cathedral for the success of the Assembly's session here.
JERUSALEM. Sept. 21 -- Masked men of the extremist Zionist underground group Irgun Zvai Leumi last night kidnapped a girl member of the moderate Haganah forces.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (UP) -- The National Federation of Small Business today urged President Truman to "move with dispatch" in carrying out a Congressional mandate to give small, independent producers a stronger voice in government.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- The American Red Cross announced tonight that its chapters had sheltered and fed more than 100,000 refugees from the areas in Florida, Alabama, Mississippi and Louisiana devastated by the hurricane.

MOSCOW, Sept. 21 (AP) -- The Communist newspaper Pravda declared today that United States Secretary of State Marshall was trying to turn the United Nations into an arena for waging "diplomatic war" on the Soviet Union. It asserted the action threatened the life of the world peace organization.

LONDON, Sept. 16 -- With his unemployed four - masted barque Pommern in sight from his windows, Capt. Gustaf Erikson has just died at Mariehamn, in the Aaland Islands of the Baltic, between Sweden and Finland.

Three art museums of the city -- the Metropolitan, the Museum of Modern Art and the Whitney Museum -- announced yesterday a program designed to clarify to an often bewildered public the main directions of American and foreign modern art.

BUENOS AIKES, Sept. 21 -- The Government press today implied that certain elements of the United States press had succeeded Spruille Braden, former United States Ambassador to Argentina, as the "agent of discord" in South America.

Probably the most effective force in driving commodity prices in the United States sharply upward was the "too hasty" relaxation and outright abolition of war controls, according to a bulletin titled "Credit Policies of the "United States."

Mortgage loans insured by the Federal Housing Administration have enabled builders to start the largest rental housing program ever attempted by private industry in the New York area, Thomas G. Grace, State Director of the FHA, reported yesterday.
The 1947 Dodgers may go into the records as the most dilatory pennant-clinching team in the history of the National League.
AMSTERDAM, Sept. 21 -- Somber but not desperate is the view of financial circles on the budget for 1948 submitted on Tuesday to Parliament by Finance Minister Pieter Lieftinck.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 21 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Steelers nullified a brilliant one-man show by their former team-mate, Bullet Bill Dudley, by capitalizing on Detroit Lion fumbles to win, 17 -- 10, in a thrilling National League football opener before 36,374 today.

LONDON, Sept. 21 -- Jeffrey Hamm, policy director of the pro-Fascist British League of Ex-Servicemen, was arrested tonight at the close of another in a series of stormy street corner meetings held by his group in London's East End.

Members of the National Zionist Administrative Council, ruling parliamentary body of the Zionist Organization of America, heard Zionist leaders yesterday term the reported decision of the British Cabinet to accept the majority recommendation of the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine an "encouraging development."

ZURICH, Sept. 21 -- An agreement has been reached between the Danish Government and two Swiss commercial banks for a five-year credit of $7,000,000 to cover American pre-war credits to Denmark, whose amortization was prevented by the German occupation.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:

Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State Chairman, announced yesterday that Senator Elmer F. Quinn and Assemblyman Irwin Steingut, the Democratic legislative leaders, would introduce at the next session of the Legislature a bill making New York a community-property state.

Prices of cotton for future delivery lost in the domestic market in the late trading last week virtually all of the substantial gains made in the early part of the period. At the close on Saturday, active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange showed for the week net changes ranging from a decline of 2 points to an advance of 28 points, with the distant July delivery showing the greatest increase.

Hermann Nickel, 18 years old, the first exchange student to come to this country from Germany since before the war, arrived here yesterday on the transport Ernie Pyle. The ship docked at Pier 61, North River, at 9:30 A.M. with 835 passengers after a nine-day crossing from Bremerhaven.

United Nations Week has ended and there still is a United Nations -- which may surprise some of those who took what was said at Lake Success and elsewhere at its face value. Neither Mr. Vishinsky nor any other Assembly speaker came out against the principles of the Charter, as he conceived them.

Returning tonight for a limited engagement at the National is "Anna Lucasta." As directed by Harry Wagstaff Gribble (he also helped out on the script) and produced by John Wildberg, the Philip Yordan play dealing with the vicissitudes of a Negro family already has given a splendid account of itself, having occupied the Mansfield for twenty-seven months.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Sept. 21--The powerful General Committee of the United Nations General Assembly approved today for Assembly discussion the United States proposals for the creation of an interim committee of the Assembly and the problem of Korean independence.
Continuing the upward post-war trend, America's colleges and universities this fall will have the greatest enrollment in the history of higher education.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -- The Army wall conduct a series of high-explosive experiments to determine the ability of underground structures to withstand blasts, including a simulated atomic explosion.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $52,243,317,448. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of in-debtedness, bills and notes as follows:

Skillful piloting and prompt work by Navy ground crews saved forty-one persons aboard the Pan American DC-4 Clipper that bellylanded at Floyd Bennett Field Saturday evening on its way in from Bermuda, according to investigators yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 21 -- Floyd (Bill) Bevens' stock as a world series mound entry rose sharply today as the big Yankee righthander tossed himself a neat shutout to beat the Athletics, 6 to 0, in the series finale before 18,333 onlookers.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21 -- Total personal consumption expenditures last year totaled $143,700,000,000, more than double the 1939 figure and more than 80 per cent in excess of what consumers spent in 1929, the Institute of Life Insurance said today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -- A special Senate committee laid plans today for a tour of war refugee centers in United States occupied zones of Western Europe to study admittance of displaced persons as immigrants to the United States.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:

WARSAW, Sept. 21 -- The June resolution of the Polish Socialist party's supreme council has been translated into intensive country-wide activity to widen the field of cooperation wit' the Communist party and to cement tighter relations between the two groups.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 21 -- Stewart Iglehart virtually turned in a one-man job as he led his Old Westbury team to a 10-7 triumph over Mexico's poloists in the final round match of the thirty-first national open championship on the Meadow Brook Club's International Field today.

It's only a $6,500 sprint with a four-horse field, but the fifth race on Belmont Park's opening program today has made a secondary attraction of the $25,000 added Fall Highweight Handicap and its fifteen-horse line-up:

There is nothing moody, unpredictable or introvertish about the goldfinch. When September's mellowness blesses the countryside and the fields, pastures and meadows are blankets of suncured brown grasses, flocks of the wild canaries swirl over the landscape in distinctive undulating flight.
A thousand persons attended the annual memorial service of the Square Club, Masonic organization of the Police Department, at the Riverside Church yesterday afternoon.

SALONIKA, Greece, Sept. 21 -- The increase in the Greek Army just approved by the Griswold Mission is far from providing the force needed to halt movements across the frontiers and to crush the guerrilla bands, according to the officers of units with whom this correspondent spent the past week in areas south of the Yugoslav and Bulgarian frontiers.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 21 (AP) -- The Washington Redskins came to life with three touchdowns in the final quarter today, but couldn't over-come a 31-point lead piled up by Green Bay in the first half, and the Packers came off with a 31-21 victory in a National Football League exhibition game.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 21 -- Those two apt sailors who used to wander from the Princeton campus and watch the ripples play on Lake Carnegie, which became part of their nautical training, had it out all this summer as the top skippers in the International Class of sloops on Long Island Sound.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (U.P.) -- Joseph W. Martin Jr., Speaker of the House of Representatives, issued a statement today supporting the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine. He said that this solution for "the tragic problem" * * * had been "delayed entirely top long."

WASHINGTON, D.C., Sept. 21 -- Production ' of radio and television receiver sets in August totaled 1,265,855, the Radio Manufacturers Association announced today. This brought output of RMA member-companies for the first eight months of 1947 to 11,031,935, and registered the first increase in monthly production since the peak was reached last April.

BOSTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Rae Scarborough, who had lost eight games in succession, today pitched a three-hit shutout as the Washington Senators blanked the Boston Red Sox, 3 -- 0, before 12,198 paid fans whose presence made the 1947 total at Fenway Park for the year 1,422,957, a new all time high.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 21 -- Premier Ahmad Ghavan's action In negotiating a fifty-year agreement with the Soviet Union in 1946 regarding the formation of a joint oil company in the northern provinces of Iran was challenged today in the Majlis (Parliament).

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 20 (Delayed) -- A proposal to lease Argentine piers and sheds to private shipping companies, as in the United States, has just passed the Senate and is due to come up for final action in the Lower House this week.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Cleveland's powerful and precision-packed Browns rolled up three touchdowns in the first period today and easily defeated the Baltimore Colts, 28 to 0, before 44,257 fans for their third straight victory in defense of their All-America Football Conference championship.

HAVANA, Sept. 21 (U.P.) -- Cuban authorities announced today that they had broken up an incipient revolt against the Government by seizing thirteen truckloads of guns and ammunition on a ranch outside Havana.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Sept. 21 -- Henry L. Stimson, former Secretary of State and Secretary of War during World War H celebrated his eightieth birthday today at his estate, Highhold, near here. He spent the day quietly at home until in the afternoon a group of the men who had been closest to him during the war years came to pay their respects and extend greetings.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Development of a true mass market for light airplanes requires the development of a four-place airplane comparable in accommodations to an automobile and which can be sold in the neighborhood of $5,000, or almost $3,000 less than present prices for such planes, according to T.P. Wright, Administrator of Civil Aeronautics.

PARIS, Sept. 21 -- The European Economic Conference on the Mar shall plan will formally complete its work tomorrow when, under the chairmanship of British Foreign Secretary Bevin, it will send its report to United States Secretary of State Marshall.

FRANKLIN, Mich., Sept. 21 -- A windstorm today greeted late arrivals who were hoping to get in a bit of practice for the qualifying round of the forty-seventh annual women's national golf championship, which gets under way over the Franklin Hills course here tomorrow with eighty contestants.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 21 -- The annual pro-member golf tolurnament at the Garden City Country Club wound up in a triple deadlock at 66 today.
SOFIA, Bulgaria, Sept. 21 -- A Sofia communique asserted tonight that Bulgarian subjects trained and armed on Greek soil, had returned to Bulgaria with, instructions to carry out "diversions."

BUFFALO, Sept. 21 -- More than 75,000 Catholics from Western New York and nearby states and from Canada are expected to take part in the eleventh Eucharistic Congress to be held in the United States, starting here tomorrow. Seven cardinals will take part in the services and a special message to the Congress from Pope Pius XII is expected.

Harsh criticism of British policy in Palestine and the demand that the United States support the United Nations in opening that country as a Jewish homeland were heard yesterday by 20,000 persons at a mass rally held in front of the Bronx County Building.

Harsh criticism of British policy in Palestine and the demand that the United States support the United Nations in opening that country as a Jewish homeland were heard yesterday by 20,000 persons at a mass rally held in front of the Bronx County Building.

JUST twenty-two years ago this month a baby-faced little boy gulped hard and timidly knocked on the door of John McGraw's office. Master Melvin Ott, aged 16, was about to launch a career of unparalleled brilliance. Just the other day he ended it with the simple announcement that he had formally retired as an active player.
William S. Connell has been appointed actuary of the North American Reassurance Company, it was announced yesterday.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 21 -- The National Association of Women Lawyers went on record today as reaffirming the principle of uniform divorce laws and voted to continue domestic relations clinics on a national scale at the concluding sessions of the group's forty-eighth national convention.

If the world is to have an enlightened public opinion, "we must have better, and yet better, newspapers," Sevellon Brown, editor and publisher of The Providence Journal-Bulletin, declared yesterday. He spoke at the opening of the second year of Columbia University's American Press Institute.
The average rate of return on endowment funds of American universities, and colleges is over 4 per cent, according to a survey of such funds completed by Scudder, Stevens Clark, investment counsel.

There was no lack of originality in the Esther Dorothy showing of furs presented yesterday at her new salon at 68 East Fifty-sixth Street. In addition to such imaginative designs as a coat of white broadtail fashioned on Chinese lines and a suit of black broadtail with a circular skirt, basque jacket and ermine tail-trimmed petticoat, there were wearable travel coats of beaver and nutria.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 22 -- The Luckenbach Steamship Company, with its operations here and in Los Angeles affected since midJuly by a strike of walking bosses affiliated with the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, announced tonight that it was cancelling temporarily its intercoastal service.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- A new advisory committee on international broadcasting was appointed by the State Department today. It is intended to function pending authorization by Congress of the International Broadcasting Foundation recommended by the State Department.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Forty-one railroads filed suit today in the Federal Court for the District of Columbia, asking the court to set aside an order of the Interstate Commerce Commission that would require railroads to pay each other $2 a day for the use of their freight cars.

The news that creation of a Transit Authority to take over and operate the municipal lines is being studied in the vicinity of City Hall is good news if it comes to anything. The public, which has watched the backing and filling on the transit-fare question through the years, and particularly in the last few months, will file this latest development in its future book and hope for the best.

Hector McNeil, British Minister of State, appealed to the Soviet Union yesterday to observe an international "code of conduct" that would enable the United Nations to function successfully without any change in its present structure.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- The International Emergency Food Council announced today that sugar-importing countries could exceed previously recommended allocations provided that they notified the board of completed transactions. The world sugar supply is so large, as a result of the Cuban bumper crop that it can flow fairly freely, but the IEFC warned that allocations could be clamped on again until Dec. 31 if necessary.

On the eve of Yom Kippur, an appeal for foster homes for Jewish children was issued yesterday by Mrs. Jacob H. Scheuer, chairman of the foster home department at the Jewish Child Care Association of New York, 329 East Sixty-second Street.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- German transport labor in the United States, French and British zones of Germany was welcomed into the ranks of the International Transport Workers Federation today. This step, considered an event of major importance in the International labor field, was announced by J.H. Oldenbroek, general secretary of the Transport Federation, whose executive board began a series of meetings here today.

United States foreign policy must be one that the whole world understands and respects, and it must be divorced from the 1948 election campaign, Eugene C. Pulliam, publisher of The Indianapolis Star, declared yesterday in an interview at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
Elmendorf Farm's Polynesian and William Helis' Rippey were the star performers in the rain-drenched show as Belmont Park's three-week fall race meeting opened yesterday.
Families moving from furnished rooms into their first real apartments are coping with their new decorating problems in a variety of ways.

George Abbott's job of getting into shape "High Button Shoes," the musical comedy headed by Phil Silvers and Nanette Fabray, which is now trying out in Philadelphia, is taking a little longer than the producer anticipated. Thus Mr. Abbott has decided to set back for the second time the rehearsal date of his own musical production, "Look, Ma, I'm Dancing."

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 22 -- Mounting hospital costs are pricing much of the population out of hospitalization, hospital administrators declared today and to meet the trend they urged increased governmental aid while opposing any Federal or state control of hospitals.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 22 -- Foreign correspondents in New Delhi through their association took cognizance today of the Government of India's extreme concern over dispatches about this country that are reaching the outside world.

DETROIT, Sept. 22 -- The leftwing majority of the international executive board of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, moved today for the censure and rebuke of Walter P. Reuther, president, for alleged "betrayal of his trust" and for "publicity acclaiming himself a champion of the infamous Taft-Hartley Act."

The United States, as Chairman David E. Lilienthal of the Atomic Energy Commission told an Indiana audience in a broadcast address last night, is "today designing, developing and producing" atomic weapons. Our present "monopoly in the production of such weapons will not last indefinitely," but today it still exists.

LONDON, Sept. 22 -- A spokesman for the Arab Office, self-styled London propagandist for the Arab League, said today that the Arab states had agreed secretly fifteen months ago to make a "complete economic and cultural break" with Europe and the United States if the United Nations undertook to partition Palestine.
LONDON, Sept. 22 -- Chancellor of the Exchequer Hugh Dalton's speech last Friday contained little that would have helped to remove uncertainties and the stock markets here today were quiet.

One of the most curious symptoms of a world half crazy with anxiety is the revival of Nazi-Fascism in England. One would think the war would have cleansed every British breast of the last faint trace of sympathy for Hitler and his methods. Instead, his evil doctrines seem to be spreading.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- President Truman received today from the highest Government official final recommendations on which to base decisions for implementing the Marshall plan for assistance to Europe.

Store Sales Gain 20.6% Sales of Manhattan and Brooklyn department stores for the week ended Sept. 20 increased 20.6 per cent over the corresponding week a year ago, according to the "flash" report yesterday of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

The game scheduled between the Yankees and Senators at the Stadium was rained out yesterday and the American League clubs will meet in a twin-bill today that will mark the end of their season's rivalry. Frank (Spec) Shea and Vic Raschi are expected to take the mound for the Yanks, who hold a big margin in the series with Washington, having dropped only seven decisions while winning thirteen.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- In an effort to support their campaign for a renewal of compulsory price controls, spokesmen for the Congress of Industrial Organizations and advocates of planned economy are contrasting present food prices with those in effect at the end of the Office of Price Administration.

LONDON, Sept. 22 -- The report of the sixteen-nation conference on aid under the Marshall program provoked a grim determination here today for it set goals that will be hard to reach. However, the Foreign Office, in a statement on the report, insisted that "realistic estimates were made of the production of industry and agriculture, coal and steel."

Federal Judge Stephen W. Brannan was asked yesterday to quash subpoenas requiring the Abitibi Power and Paper Company, a Canadian corporation, to produce its records for the examination of a grand jury investigating the newsprint industry.

WARSAW, Sept. 22 -- Just twenty-four hours after its arrival from Helsinki, Finland, the SmithMundt Joint Foreign Affairs subcommittee left Warsaw today to continue its whirlwind investigation of the United States Information Service Overseas and its study of Europe's economic and political situation.

Emir Feisal al Saud, chief delegate of Saudi Arabia, yesterday led another Arab attack against Jewish claims in Palestine by charging before the United Nations General Assembly at Flushing Meadow that the Zionists were guilty of Nazi practices.

Realization that the cotton textile supply situation will remain tight for some months to come has led retailers to place orders well ahead for men's shirts, housedresses and other items using eighty-square percales and combed broadcloths, it was learned yesterday.

Working girls are having to pay more than a 15 per cent rent rise for furnished rooms while salaries reflect a downward trend, it was reported yesterday at the Central Branch Young Women's Christian Association at Lexington Avenue and Fifty-third Street.

An engineer in the New Jersey Highway Department, seeking to build road separators on a six-lane highway in Passaic County that would reflect light at night and in fog, is credited with hitting upon an entirely new idea in traffic safety. Each separator, consisting of a strip of white cement twenty-four inches wide, has a scored surface and when the tires of an automobile hit it a loud hum is heard.

With both the East and West supplying markets here with autumn crops of pears, Bartletts, Clapps and Seckels from upstate, and Anjous, Boscs and Comice from California, Oregon and Washington, this fruit is now abundant and in many cases reasonably priced.

FRANKLIN, Mich., Sept. 22 -- Seventy-eight players in quest of thirty-two places in match-play struggled over a rain-sodden course today in the qualifying round of the forty-seventh annual women's national amateur golf championship at Franklin Hills Country Club.

Not more than 10 to 15 per cent of the 4,500 children now attending City and state subsidize child care centers will be dropped under provisions of the new program worked out by the Department of Welfare and the State Youth Commission, Welfare Commissioner Edward E. Rhatigan predicted yesterday.

LONDON, Sept. 22 -- How the late David Lloyd George, British Prime Minister in the first World War, refused an offer by Winston Churchill to join the War Cabinet in the dark days of 1940 is revealed in a book to be published in London soon.

BOSTON, Sept. 22 -- Asserting that the real crisis of the moment was "not on the Greek border but in American grocery stores," Henry A. Wallace called today for a special session of Congress to enact into law "a rationing and price control act with teeth in it."

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Sept. 22 -- Louis P. Marciante of Trenton, president of the New Jersey State Federation of Labor, said today the Taft-Hartley Act would compel the American Federation of Labor to enter the political field.

TOKYO, Sept. 22 (U.P.) -- More than 2,000 persons were reported dead or missing as a result of floods today. Rain still poured Water into Japan's choked rivers. More than 400 square miles of Honshu Island still were under Water.

TRIESTE, Tuesday, Sept. 23 (AP) -- A United States officer and two enlisted men were taken captive on the Trieste Free Territory frontier by Yugoslavs at about noon yesterday, an official report from headquarters of the United States troops in Trieste said early today.

Criticism of the standards of steamship transportation for the exchange of students between this country and the Continent was refuted here yesterday in letters to the United States Maritime Commission and the Moore-McCormack Lines, one of the operating companies.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday lost 5 to 19 points net in a session of moderate business.

The Brooklyn Dodgers won the National League pennant last night and, although it was almost midnight when the news was flashed here, the Borough of Brooklyn immediately started its long-delayed, roaring celebration of victory, The United Press reported.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- President Truman today named Paul H. Alling to be the first United States Ambassador to Pakistan.

John F. Montgomery, United States Ministed to Hungary from 1933 to 1941, is the author of "Hungary, The Unwilling Satellite," which Devin-Adair will publish on Oct. 17. Mr. Montgomery cites evidence to show that Hungary was never as enthusiastically nazified as has been generally believed, and also expresses his belief that a similar reluctance to conform may be prevalent in Hungary's present second phase as a satellite, this time of the Soviet Union.
WINDSOR, England, Sept. 22 (U.P.) -- A honeymoon suite has been set aside in Windsor Castle for Princess Elizabeth and Lieut. Philip Mountbatten after their marriage Nov. 20, it was learned today.

BUFFALO, Sept. 22 -- Welcomed to Buffalo by a crowd of 70,000 persons for the opening of the eleventh Eucharistic Congress to be held in the United States, Francis Cardinal Spellman of New York tonight urged men of good-will everywhere to unite in prayers for peace and to renew their faith in the efficacy of prayer.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Vast qantities of United States surplus goods, produced at a cost of aproximately $801,403,000, are on and in Europe for immediate sale for disposition within the framework of the Marshall relief plan, according to the latest official data available today.
C.W. Prestin has been appointed sales promotion manager for the New York sales district of the International Harvester Company.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Western Europe's appeal for $19,330,000,000 in aid under the Marshall Plan was greeted today with cautious reserve by members of Congress.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Federal Judge Emerich B. Freed today fined six ball-bearing manufacturers a total of $30,000 for price-fixing violations of the Sherman Act.

BOSTON, Sept. 22 -- An offer of $105,555 by L. Grossman Sons, Inc., of Quincy, dealers in lumber, and building supplies, was the highest bid today for purchase of the $1,000,000 Quoddy Village at the abandoned $37,000,000 Passa maquoddy tidal power project at Eastport, Me.

FRENCH LICK, Ind., Sept. 22 (AP) -- A prediction that the International Typographical Union would be "unsuccessful in its device to escape responsibility" under the Taft-Hartley law was made tonight by Thomas Shroyer general counsel of the joint Congressional committee to study operation of the new labor law.

LAKE TAHOE, Nev., Sept. 22 Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, bridling at what he termed "intemperate and untrue personal attacks" made upon him by Democrats because of his San Francisco speech on the cost of living, renewed his charge today that the Truman Administration is responsible for high prices.

Dr. Albert Einstein urged the General Assembly of the United Nations yesterday to assert its authority over the veto-paralyzed Security Council, once and for all, as one of a series of bold moves leading to supra-national government, with or without the Soviet Union.

The fight to remove the 20 per cent Federal excise tax on women's handbags has not been abandoned but will be waged even more intensively than heretofore when Congress reconvenes, it was declared yesterday by Abraham Mittenthal, co-director of the National Authority for the Ladies' Handbag Industry.

De Pinna's paid a salute to the oncoming winter season yesterday on the St. Regis Roof. Hooded coats, both untrimmed and furtrimmed, were exhibited and afternoon dresses under silver-blue mink and daytime ones under nutria were on view.

Amid all the hubbub and excitement among the Brooklyn Dodger officials and players over the news last night that the pennant had been presented to the Brooks, one individual remained calm and unruffled, The Associated Press reported.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 22 -- The Chief Justice of the United States, Fred M. Vinson, in an address here this evening, said that if this country was to play its role in world peace there must be a reaffirmation of faith by all in the fundamental values upon which American democracy is founded.

A 100-acre estate near Chungking, which served as wartime headquarters for Generalissimo and Mme. Chiang Kai-shek, was presented yesterday to the Methodist Church as a school and home for Chinese war orphans.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Sept. 22 -- Dick R. Lane of Des Moines, Iowa, president of the National Alcoholic Beverage Control Association, declared today that consumers could not look forward to any reduction in liquor prices until the $3 a gallon emergency tax imposed by the Government during the war is removed.

Teacher organizations, carrying over their bitter opposition to the so-called "superior merit" and "percentage promotion" sections of the 1947 State Teachers Salary Law, attacked yesterday the preliminary report of the Advisory Committee on Teachers Salaries released in Albany on Sunday by State Commissioner of Education Francis T. Spaulding.

MANILA, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Emmet O'Neal of Louisville, Ky., formally took up his duties as United States Ambassador to the Philippines today. He presented his credentials to President Manuel A. Roxas in a simple ceremony at Malacanan Palace.

Supreme Court Justice Bernard Botein yesterday granted a certificate of reasonable doubt to I. James Brody, former Deputy Commissioner of Marine and Aviation, and James V. Auditore, "millionaire boss stevedore," who were found guilty last month in General Sessions Court on charges of conspiracy and taking unlawful fees in the leasing of city piers.

MARTHA'S VINEYARD, Mass., Sept. 22 -- According to one angling member of the local Chamber of Commerce, this island is merely a "body of land surrounded by water and striped bass." Many of the surfcasters who tried the beaches here over last week-end are willing to agree with this definition.

RONNE EXPEDITION BASE, Stonington Island, Marguerite Bay, Antarctica, Sept. 21 (Delayed) -- A small British Auster plane and its crew of three men have been missing from Base E of the British Falkland Islands Dependency Survey here since Sept. 15.

Although the twenty-second World's Championship Rodeo does not start in Madison Square-Garden until tomorrow night, the atmosphere is already there. In the Garden basement yesterday, 750 head of cattle and a group of horses moved nervously in their corrals. It seemed that the animals knew the wild west show was about to begin.

PARIS, Sept. 22 -- At the European headquarters here of the Office of the Foreign Liquidation Commissioner, it was said today that the office was awaiting instructions from Washington concerning the disposal of the surplus military supplies to European nations.
New York Harbor paid its traditional tribute yesterday to the Italian liner Vulcania, which served during her wartime career as a transport for both Allied and Axis troops.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- The Department of Commerce reported today that there was a decline in manufacturers' sales and new orders during July, while inventory accumulation book-value dropped to the smallest figure in a twelvemonth period.
Present at the funeral service were representatives of every country that has a consulate in New York.

DECATUR, Ill., Sept. 22 -- For the production of goods and increasing production facilities, business and related enterprises paid out $11,000,000,000 more than was received in 1946, so that instead of having a surplus available for higher wages, business and industry actually created more purchasing power in the hands of consumers than could be expended for the goods offered for sale.

WARSAW, Sept. 22 -- The Polish Government rejected today the State Department's denial of connections between the United States Embassy here and the Polish underground. It announced that a new trial would open shortly "to shed more light" on alleged dealings of Arthur Bliss Lane, former Ambassador, with the underground.

MOSCOW, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Soviet newspaper readers were told today that Andrei V. Vishinsky's speech last week to the United Nations General Assembly had caused "complete panic and bubbling wrath" among "American reactionaries," pictured as wanting war with Russia.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22 -- Fourteen housewives, one single woman and eight men were selected before Federal District Judge John P. Barnes today as members of the special Federal grand jury called by the Department of Justice's Anti-Trust Division to investigate the high cost of food, and meat and milk in particular.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Dr. Isaiah Bowman, president of Johns Hopkins University, and principal geographical adviser to the late President Roosevelt during World War II, said today that "communism is absolutism designed to be more ruthless and complete than czarism.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Thomas K. Finletter, chairman of the President's Air Policy Commission, will confer with the Civil Aeronautics Board on the potential affects of an alleged rate war brewing between the standard airlines and the smaller cargo-carrying companies, he announced today.

WILLIAM, L. SHIRER, the stocky, blond, bald radio correspondent who wrote "Berlin Diary," dislikes and distrusts the Germans just as much today as he did six years ago when his book became a national best seller, and by the contagious quality of its emotion did so much to awaken this country to the menace and true nature of the Nazis.

PARIS, Sept. 22 -- John W. Snyder, United States Secretary of the Treasury, in beginning a series of talks with French officials on American aid, was said by French sources here today to have become -- since his European trip -- more convinced of the necessity of a special session of Congress.

An exhibition of Palestinian art -- water-colors, gouaches, small paintings on glass, drawings and prints -- has been added to the general Palestine Exhibition current since last May in the Museum of Science and Industry, Radio City.

A plea on behalf of the campaign to provide jobs for disabled veterans was made last night by Jack De Nove, assistant to the president of Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborne, Inc., at the meeting of the New York Personnel Management Association in the Columbia University Club, 4 West Forty-second Street.

CRAWFORDSVILLE. Ind., Sept. 22--David E. Lilienthal, chairman of the United States Atomic Energy Commission, made an impassioned plea here tonight for "a specific, program whereby in Crawfordsville and in all other American communities the people on their own can set about to learn the essential facts about atomic energy."

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 22 -- Premier Ahmad Ghavam announced through a spokesman today that he would present to the Majlis [Parliament] his "report" on the oil talks with the Soviet Union as soon as the current debate ended -- probably next week.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Employment in non-agricultural establishments in mid-August reached 42,558,000. This was an increase of more than 400,000 from July and was the highest employment level of 1947, it was announced today by Ewan Clague, head of the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Department of Labor.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22 -- The Northern States Power Company of Minnesota filed an application with the Securities and Exchange Commission today requesting permission to borrow $12,000,000 from a group of banks to finance in part construction which will cost $32,500,000.

Students attending colleges ana universities this fall will have to pay the highest rates for their education in the history of this country. Tuition, student fees and boarding costs have skyrocketed to unprecedented heights.
Dr. Herbert V. Evatt, Australian Minister of External Affairs, probably will be chairman of the special Palestine committee of the United Nations General Assembly, it was learned last night.

In outlining the policy for the rebuilding of a war-shattered Europe which has since come to be known as the Marshall Plan, in his now historic speech at Cambridge last June 5, the American Secretary of State summed up the essence of the proposal in these words.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 22 -- Expansion of Twentieth CenturyFox's distribution program for low-budget pictures was indicated today by the disclosure that Frank Seltzer Productions, a new organization, will sign contracts this week to make three films at a cost of approximately $160,000 each for Fox release.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox divided a twilightnight double-header with the St. Louis browns tonight when Joe Haynes hurled an eight-hit 4-to-0 win in the final after Sam Zoldak had hurled the Browns to a 4-to-2 victory in the first game.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Bulletin said today that the real solution to Great Britain's "dollar-shortage crisis" lay in greater British production, not restrictions on trade and currency exchange.
Office workers of Employers Mutual Insurance Companies were guests at a fashion show for the business girl presented last night by Emily Fifth Avenue in its Nassau Street store.

ST. LOUIS, Sept, 22 (AP) -- The Brooklyn Dodgers, though idle, clinched the National League pennant tonight when their secondplace rivals, the St. Louis Cardinals, were defeated by the Chicago Cubs, 6 to 3, in the night game of a day-night double header, played before 8,000 shivering fans.
Evaluating the capitalist world outlook, E.E. Lundberg, eminent Swedish economist, said last night there was some likelihood of a serious post-war depression in the United States.

SALEM, N.H., Sept. 22 (AP) -- With the mercury predicted to drop below freezing tonight, Dr. Harold M. Lewis, Rockingham Park track veterinarian, said he hoped for a frost which "might kill the swamp fever bug" which today claimed its twenty-eighth victim, West Fleet.

A twofold attack on ticket agencies in Harlem and on non-scheduled airplane operators in the New York-Puerto Rico air transport business has been begun by operators recognized by the Civil Aeronautics Board, it was learned yesterday.

The Long Island Rail Road went before the Public Service Commission again yesterday with a plea for additional funds to be derived from higher fares to carry out its $16,000,000 program of improvements.

United Nations officials put the finishing touches yesterday on a seventy-page report that they hope will result in streamlining the sessions of the General Assembly and save the organization valuable time and many thousands of dollars.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In THE NEW YORK TIMES of Sept. 10 I came upon a notice to the effect that the Patriarch of Moscow has appointed Archbishop Makary of New York to succeed Metropolitan Benjamin as his Exarch in North America, while the latter has been transferred to be Metropolitan of Riga and Latvia.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- A spirited rebuke to the Albanian Government was administered today by the State Department on the subject of charges aired in Tirana that certain alleged native saboteurs were in the pay of the United States.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: There is a serious new threat to the future well-being of our public lands of the West. Eastern taxpayers have an important stake in these regions and should be informed of what is happening.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: During the Middle Ages the average European was not a Frenchman, a German or an Italian, but rather a citizen of Europe. Linguistically, he was provincial, but culturally his boundaries were far broader. First, Crusaders banded together in common cause; later, minnesingers and troubadours roamed from place to place, carrying with them their stories, songs and gossip.

The stock market experienced yesterday another of its inconclusive Monday sessions as prices drifted irregularly and closed mixed with a definite leaning to the lower side. A few of the "thinmarket" stocks showed alterations of a point and more but the general run of issues, as well as the combined averages, dipped slightly.

Coaches were noticeable by their absence yesterday as the Football Writers Association held the first of its weekly luncheons at Toots Shor's restaurant. Not a mentor was on hand to report on the progress of his squad.

DON'T believe all you read about horse sense. If horses had any sense they would go to work at more respectable hours. It was in the murky gray of early morning that Jimmy Jones sent Armed out on the Belmont track yesterday for a slow gallop. But a party who is worth more than $600,000 shouldn't be required to be on the job at 7 A.M. He's entitled to keep banker's hours.
Fiorello H. La Guardia was laid to rest yesterday in the good earth of the city that he loved and served so well.
JERUSALEM, Sept. 22 -- Substantial support reportedly has been promised by the Arab League states to any measures by Palestine Arabs to resist partition.
A new opportunity for professional singers to try for a "break" in furthering their careers will be offered by WMCA beginning Sept. 29 when "New Voices" makes its debut.

An educational program for young Puerto Rican children who have recently migrated to New York will be the subject of a special Teacher's Institute at the New York University School of Education, it was announced yesterday by Dean Ernest O.Melby.

CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 22 (U.P.) -- Walter H. Donovan, general manager of Garden State Park, said today he believed the New York embargo on horses racing in other states resulted from a suspected case of swamp fever at Red Bank, N. J.

In its fight against mounting losses from theft and pilferage on piers and in warehouses, the shipping industry is considering a system of permanent pier employes who would be supplemented by extra, men as the need arose, it was learned yesterday.

VIENNA, Sept. 22--The Soviet Union refused to agree at today's sitting of the Austrian Treaty Commission that Austria's political and economic independence should be specifically guaranteed in the peace treaty against countries other than Germany.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Norman J. Wall of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics, Washington, reported today United States agriculture now is worth more than $111,000,000,000, a little more than twice the 1940 figure and an increase of $12,600,000,000 in a year.

The United Telephone Organizations and tour of its branches filed a damage suit for $700,000 in Federal Court yesterday against three locals of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, AFL.

MIAMI, Pla., Tuesday, Sept. 23 -- A new tropical storm, tame so far compared with the one that spread disaster from Florida to Louisiana last week, blew in on the west coast of Florida from the Gulf of Mexico early today.

DETROIT, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Hank Edwards' ninth-inning homer dropped Detroit back into a secondplace tie with Boston by giving Cleveland a 7-to-6 nightcap victory today after the Tigers had won the first game of the doubleheader, 6 to 4.

Tuna fish puffs are the main course in the menu that the City Department of Markets suggests for tonight's dinner. Total cost of this meal for a family of five is $2.85. The recipes for the puffs and tomato slaw are given.

Representatives of securities underwriting syndicates were in almost constant conference yesterday at successive meetings held for the purpose of pricing corporate and municipal bond issues aggregating; $150,000,000. The pending transactions, all of which will come up for competitive sale today, are as follows:
MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 22 -- School taxes have risen in all but one of Nassau County's sixty-five school districts, it was reported today.

TOKYO, Sept. 22 -- No deal has been signed for the sale of Australian wool to Japan, but Howard B. Leigh, secretary of the Australian Wool Realization Commission, will leave here Wednesday with the belief that his mission has been a success.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Three students who starred in Southern Conference basketball denied today that they had been "lured" to transfer to American University here and said they will get "less aid" here than they had at Washington and Lee and North Carolina State.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Three deeply concerned co-owners of the Pirates will meet here tomorrow to decide if Manager Billy Herman is to blame for the fact that a tide of freely spent greenbacks has failed to put the Buccos up among the National League leaders.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22 -- James C. Petrillo, its president, signed here today a "code of ethics" under which the American Federation of Musicians, AFL, will raise no objection to having music students play at public functions, broadcast musical programs and make audition recordings if their performances are in furtherance of the cause of music education and do not compete with those of professional musicians earning a living.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Sept. 22 -- The honeymoon is over for the Army football coaches. Everybody wants to get into the act of knocking off the team that stood as the scourge of the gridiron for the past three years.

ROME, Sept. 22 -- The Constituent Assembly decided late today to defer to Saturday the opening of debate on the Left-wing Socialists' motion of no confidence in the Government. It had previously been set to begin tomorrow.

LONDON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Col. James M. Gillespie and a crew of eleven fliers and observers sat by with "absolutely nothing to do" as a United States Army robot plane under his command completed its flight across the Atlantic today.
Convocation exercises were held yesterday as various colleges and institutions in the metropolitan area opened their classrooms for the fall semester.

A Congressional subcommittee investigating high living costs listened here yesterday to nearly seven hours of demonstrative testestimony by representatives of consumer, labor and kindred organizations in support of their demands for reinstitution of statutory price control.

Uncertainty in six line positions faced Coach Lou Little at Baker Field yesterday as Columbia entered the last stages of pre-season practice. The Lions open their 1947 campaign against Rutgers at Baker Field on Saturday.

Predictions that the sixth biennial convention of the National Maritime Union, CIO, would be the most turbulent since the union's inception were borne out yesterday as 600 delegates from the ports of the country met in Manhattan Center.

Dmitri Z. Manuilsky of the Ukraine told the United Nations General Assembly at Flushing Meadow yesterday that all the attacks on the veto were "part of the propaganda for a new war." He made this accusation after more than twenty nations had gone on record as favoring limitation or abolition of the veto.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- The National Labor Relations Board announced today that District 9 of the international Association of Machinists (independent) won the first election supervised by the NLRB to ascertain the sentiment of employes on the union shop under the Taft-Hartley law.

The Marshall plan should be practiced boldly and generously, with a $30,000,000,000 to $35,000,000,000 United States investment in peace, Dr. Alfonso Lopez, Colombian representative to the United Nations, told the General Assembly at Flushing Meadow in his opening address yesterday.

NANKING, Sept. 22 -- The fear that China's borderland province of Sinkiang might become the "Poland" of Asia was expressed by Gen. Chang Chih-chung, director of President Chiang Kai-shek's northwest headquarters, in a speech to Moslem Turki leaders before they withdrew from a Nankingsponsored coalition regime in Urumchi.

New production methods which are possible with the vastly improved machine tools now available include wider use of iron castings as a substitute for fabricated parts, Oliver Smalley, president, Meehanite Metal Corporation, New Rochelle, announced here yesterday after a survey of latest cost-cutting developments.
Meat, butter and egg wholesale prices took another fall yesterday, but housewives found food prices in most New York retail stores changed little, if at all, from last week's record highs.
