CHICAGO, Sept. 22 -- Grain markets were nervous on the Board of Trade today but prices averaged higher, with corn in the lead early, the May delivery opening 8 cents higher, the limit, after breaking 24 cents during the three previous days.

An artistic evening was presented to Town Hall listeners last night, when Frank Sherman Baker, tenor, made his recital debut there. The program included a group of Purcell; "La Bonne Chanson" for voice, piano and string quartet by Faure; a group of Schubert and Wolflieder and contemporary numbers containing first performances of Alex Wilder and William Ames songs.

Following is the text of address made yesterday by Hector McNeil, acting head of the United Kingdom delegation, in the General Assembly of the United Nations: It is my wish, Mr. President, to make a survey of the work done during the year.

Criticizing the increase in pension contributions paid by policemen as "absurd," John E.Carton president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, asserted last night that immediate reforms were mandatory.

SAN RAFAEL, Calif., Sept. 22 (AP) -- Justice of the Peace N. Charles Brusatori said tonight he had married Ann Cooper Hewitt, 35-year-old heiress, to her fourth husband, Frank (Rodeo Roy) Nicholson, 41, San Francisco free-lance radio artist.

The strike of 5,000 Railway Express Agency drivers and helpers, locally and 2,100 in New Jersey continued yesterday with no indications of an immediate settlement in the dispute over the length of the work week.

LONDON, Sept. 22 -- The conference on the future of the Italian colonies is scheduled to open in London Sept. 30, it was learned today. Invitations for this meeting were issued by the British Foreign Office to the United States, France and the Soviet Union, and acceptances have been received from Washington and Paris.

Governor Dewey yesterday endorsed a $2,000,000,000 highway building program for this state, but he warned that road expenditures were not "pork barrel" funds and unless construction was maintained our economy would become a "shrinking' and dying thing."

Painter in the House Now is the time, the visitor said, when many of us are privileged to meet on terms of close and friendly intimacy fellow citizens of ours of whom, in the course of the revolving year, we see too little and too few.

A sold-out house welcomed back the New York City Symphony and its conductor, Leonard Bernstein, in their first concert of the season at the City Center last night. The orchestra and Mr. Bernstein, who was beginning his third year as its leader, have proved that theirs is a valuable role in the city's musical life, since they play fresh, exciting programs in an exciting way and keep admission prices lower than most other ensembles.

CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 22 (AP) -- Macbeth, owned and bred by Joseph M. Roebling, gained a bit of revenge over Mrs. James V. Stewart's Dr. Almac by registering a three-length triumph today in the sloppy going of the Tioga Purse at Garden State Park.
CHICAGO, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 22 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, vice chairman of the Senate-House Committee investigating housing, today commended the Building Officials Conference of America for action which, he said, would help to permit mass production of housing, with resultant lowering of costs.

Exports of Swiss watch movements and complete watches to the United States for the current year will not exceed 7,000,000 units, compared with record export of 9,651,000 last year, Andre Ditisheim, senior partner and president, Ditisheim Cie., La Chaux du Fonds, Switzerland, producers of Vulcain watches, said yesterday.

PARIS, Sept. 22 -- The need for United States aid to Europe before the end of this year to prevent a widespread economic collapse and possible revolutions was emphasized today by Foreign Secretary Bevin of Britain, Count Sforza, Foreign Minister of Italy, and Pierre-Henri Teitgen, Acting Foreign Minister of France, at the final session of the European conference on the Marshall Plan.

NANKING, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The Chinese Government's Central News Agency reported today that Government air attacks inflicted heavy damage on Communist columns and installations at Lihwang, Shangcheng and Kushin, 135 miles northeast of Hankow.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- A Douglas C-54 Skymaster with a mechanical brain landed without human aid near London today after a robot directed hop from Newfoundland.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Congressman George H. Bender, in his letter to THE TIMES, speaks for a large group of our citizens when he criticizes our present foreign policy. I am in full accord with his statements.

The first man-made star sapphires and star rubies, to the layman undistinguishable from expensive naturally occurring gems, were put on display yesterday by Dr. F.H. Pough, curator of geology and mineralogy, at the Museum of Natural History.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Dale Mitchell tripled to send two teammates across the plate in the seventh inning and put the Cleveland Indians out in front for a 7-to-4 victory over the last-place St. Louis Browns before 747 fans tonight.

A special showing of antique furnishings will open this morning at Bergdorf Goodman in the newly decorated and restocked antiques and gifts department on the fourth floor. Most of the articles are British Eighteenth century furniture, silver, china and glass just received from abroad.

NANKING, Sept. 23 -- Although the foreign Ministry has begun to restrict the issuing of Chinese passports, private persons with the "right connections" are still being permitted to journey abroad under favored status. Students meeting all official passport regulations are barred from travel.

Bitterly attacking sections of the Feinberg law on superior merit rating for promoting teachers, the Joint Committee of Teachers Organizations sent instructions last night to the faculties of 850 city schools to boycott any discussion of the proposed rule or regulations through which these sections of the law would be put into effect.

ESSEX PELLS, N. J., Sept. 23 -- August Kammer of Baltusrol and W. Palen Conway also of Baltusrol tied for a three-stroke lead in the twenty-six annual State Seniors golf championship tourney today at Essex Fells Country Club. Kammer and Conway each posted sixover-par 77's.

BRIZE NORTON, England, Sept. 23 (UP) -- Col. James M. Gillespie said today the United States Army Air Forces' "automatic airplane" might try another record run in about two weeks, flying homeward via the Azores.

Sales of the Vick Chemical Company for the fiscal year ended with June set a new sales record at $41,803,472 for the ninth consecutive year, W.Y. Preyer, president, reported to stockholders yesterday. For the previous fiscal year the volume was $37,185,778.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 23 -- An integrated hospitals system under which hospitals and public health departments would pool their facilities to help achieve a healthier country and prevent thousands of needless deaths every year was advocated today by Dr. James A. Crabtree, deputy surgeon general of the United States Public Health Service.

G.G. Morarji, Bombay business man and president of the Federation of Piece Goods and Yarn Merchants of India, yesterday called on American textile export interests to request the Indian Government to equalize duties levied on cotton piece goods imports.

When a nation drapes itself in the robes of justice to murder its foremost patriot, as Bulgaria did to hang Nikola Petkov, it not only commits a shameful crime. It makes a mistake. In the free world outside it breeds horror and revulsion. Among its own people it sows seeds of resentment which some day will yield a crop of bloodshed to drench the savage band that rules the land today.

ROBERT S. ALLEN, whose belligerence as a co-author of, the syndicated political gossip column, "Washington-Merry-Go-Round," was famous for years, has written the most belligerent book about the European war since Ralph Ingersoll's. Mr. Alien (he was Colonel Alien when he lost an arm in Germany and returned to his duties after only ten days) is partisan, bitter, enthusiastic and sarcastic.

Robert Moses, Commissioner of Parks, announced yesterday that in a few weeks the War Department would be asked to sanction construction of a bridge across the Narrows from Brooklyn to Staten Island and that permission was expected soon afterward.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The Eightieth Congress, which has the ultimate power to decide whether the United States will undertake an executive program for the rehabilitation of Western Europe, is at this writing a scattered group of individuals.

The movement to "return the union to the rank and file" within the National Maritime Union, CIO, yesterday received its first real setback when the sponsoring group elected only six members to the important fifteen-man convention credentials committee.

FRANKLIN, Mich., Sept. 23 -- Playing for the second day in a blustery bitter wind, all the favorites came through in the first round of match play of the Fortyseventh Women's National Amateur golf championship over the Franklin Hills Country Club course today.

ALBANY, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Operations at the Port of Albany were halted today by a strike of the AFL International Longshoremen's Association called, a union official said, in retaliation against the Albany local of the AFL teamsters. About 130 stevedores and other workers left their jobs.

At a private showing yesterday afternoon at his establishment at 408 Park Avenue, Jonai celebrated his tenth anniversary in his own business. His selection of clothes was on the conservative side. It voiced the fashion trends but with restraint.

Buyers' Total Up in Week Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,325, against 1,221 last week and 909 in the corresponding week of 1946, according to lists published in the new york TIMES. There were 554 arrivals yesterday, compared with 156 last Tuesday.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced early yesterday but turned easier in the afternoon and closed 16 to 36 points net lower than on Monday.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Sept. 23 (AP) -- The New York Football Giants of the National League concluded their exhibition schedule tonight with a 21-0 victory over Jersey City of the American League before 3,000 fans.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 23 -- As a precaution against possible Arab disturbances or the British, evacuation of Palestine, underground Zionist security forces have lately undertaken an extensive program of training and recruitment. The preparatory measures are reported to include the following:
Colleges and universities throughout the United States are now engaged in the most extensive fundraising campaigns in the history of American higher education.

DETROIT, Sept. 23 -- With a single but important switch in factional lines, the international executive board of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, adopted today a resolution, censuring Walter P. Reuther, right-wing president, for alleged "betrayal of his trust."

TRIESTE, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The Trieste radio announced that the local labor federation had called a general strike in Trieste this afternoon. The British-American Military Government charged the action was "the first Communist attempt to hamper the essential life of Trieste and bring discredit" to the week-old Free Territory.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The United States Chamber of Commerce said today that the country's supply of fuel would be "adequate" for the coming winter contingent upon normal weather and freedom from strikes and transportation tie-ups.

SALONIKA, Greece, Sept. 23 -- Minus the Russian and Polish delegates, who already had departed, the members of the dissolved Balkan subcommission of the United Nations Security Council expressed the opinion last night that many of them would soon return as representatives of the United Nations General Assembly.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Hal Newhouser used his sixteenth victory of the season to pitch the Tigers back into undisputed possession of second place in American League standings with a 4-to-1 triumph over the White Sox before 942 chilled cash customers today.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Sept. 23 -- Nikola Petkov, stubborn, courageous leader of the Bulgarian Agrarian party and fighter against fascism who refused to compromise with the Communists even to save his own life, was hanged in the Sofia prison early today.

The Committee on Food of the President's Cabinet has reached an understanding on how much grain this country plans to export during the remainder of the present crop year. No secret is made of the fact that the figure agreed upon represents a decline from the corresponding total for the crop year ended June 30 last.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The State Department today blasted in unsparing terms the Bulgarian regime and Premier Dimitrov for executing Mr. Petkov.

Idlewild Airport, renamed "New York Internationa Airport" by the New York Port Authority, will be ready for international operation next spring, Austin J. Tobin, executive director of the Authority, said yesterday. He made the announcement at a luncheon of the aviation section of the New York Board of Trade at the Wings Club in honor of J. Hervey Law, newly appointed head of the Authority's airports.

Curtailment of luxury purchases by European countries to conserve exchange has compelled Cuba to cut her tobacco crop in half, it was disclosed yesterday by Dr. Ramon Sanchez Parodi, secretary of the Cuban National Tobacco Stabilization Fund, now visiting New York.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- An "aggressive appeal" by President Truman supporting a voluntary food conservation program to facilitate wheat and other food relief shipments to Western Europe was forecast today by officials at work on details of the program.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your correspondent in Spain, Sam Pope Brewer, sent you a story on Aug. 27 which I believe should have been called "Mythology of Spanish Social Insurance."

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- This nation must not permit a domestic crisis, no matter how important, to interfere with the keeping of our international obligations or our taking advantage of opportunities in Europe and Asia, Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll said here today.
LONDON, Sept. 23 -- Britain's Labor Government today was grappling with two strikes, both of which threatened its prestige in the European claim, for aid under the Marshall plan.

The jurisdiction of the United States District Court to adjudicate a $3,084,241 claim of the Isbrandtsen Company, Inc., steamship operators of 26 Broadway, against the Netherlands East Indies Government and the Netherlands Government was challenged yesterday before Judge Vincent L. Leibell.
Fall rushed the season yesterday by sending the mercury tumbling down at 7:05 A. M. to 41 degrees, the coldest temperature reading for Sept. 23 in the history of the local Weather Bureau.
Historic City Hall is to be the setting for a glittering fashion show at 9 P.M. Monday which will be replete with. 100 manikins on parade, Mayor O'Dwyer and Grover A. Whalen.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The Commerce Department said tonight that "no substantial increase in supply" of newsprint seems likely until 1949 or 1950.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The running attack being made by the Russians on the United States "is an indirect attack on the United Nations," Senator Tom Connally, one of the original sponsors of the United Nations in Congress, asserted today.

Despite opposition from Arab League spokesmen, the United Nations General Assembly yesterday formally approved the creation of a special committee of all member nations to deal with the Palestine inquiry committee's recommendation for partition of the Holy Land.

NARRAGANSETT, R.I., Sept. 23 -- No one will ever convince the surfcasters who spent the weekend in this general area that a northeaster is other than an undisguised blessing, for the stripers did everything but chase the anglers up the beach.

MARTHA'S VINEYARD, Mass., Sept. 23 (AP) -- Twelve-year-old Edward Amaral of Oak Bluffs took the lead in two juvenile classes in the Martha's Vineyard striped bass derby today, but in doing so fell from a rock into the sea while playing his fish.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The senior Democratic Congressional spokesman on foreign affairs, Senator Tom Connally of Texas, minimized today the need for an early special session to study aid to Europe.

A plunge comparable to two previous set-backs earlier this month was taken yesterday by the stock market. Selling did not develop until the afternoon, but then prices fell 1 to almost 3 points, and at the close of the market the combined averages showed a decline of 1.18 points.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Following is the text of the State Department's denunciation of the execution of Nikola Petkov, Bulgarian Opposition leader: The Department of State has received confirmation from the acting political representative in Sofia that Nikola Petkov was executed on Sept. 23.

SEATTLE, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft suffered a badly crushed left hand when the driver of his car slammed the door on it in the confusion of a vociferous and tumultuous reception here late today.

Secretary of State George C. Marshall and Dr. Wang Shih-chieh Jr., Minister of Foreign Affairs of China, appealed yesterday to the public generosity in this country to assist Chinese education, which they described as "on a starvation diet" at present.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- Development of safety and dependability in air transportation would make relatively easy the solution of all the other problems besetting the industry, W. A. Patterson, president of United Air Lines, testified today before the President's Air Policy Commission.

The American loan to Great Britain has not been used to finance nationalization or socialism in that country because up to now the nationalization program has hardly started, W.L. Jones, president of the Manchester Chamber of Commerce said yesterday at a luncheon held by the British Empire Chamber of Commerce at the Hotel Roosevelt.

The first collection of Parisdesigned furs to be seen here this season dispelled all fears of exaggerated extremes. Rather it was the lady-like quality and detail of these fashions from Worth, Paquin, Patou, Balmain, Lanvin and Raphael that were most notable when presented yesterday at Jaeckel.

The State of Pennsylvania awarded yesterday a new issue of $50,000,000 of public building construction bonds due from 1952 to 1976 to a banking syndicate headed by Drexel Co. and the First Boston Corporation, jointly, at a bid of 101.6899 for 1 3/8s, a net interest cost of 1.27559 per cent.

SO them Bums have win the pennant for theirself and they done nuthin, on the final day to clinch it. They just sits around in the rain, waitin for the Cardinals, the bums, to lose one-which they done. It wuz a long wait, pal, and we wuz gettin kinder scared when our tigers drop three in a row. But we win and therefore leave us give a rousin cheer for our side.

A knowledge of soil conservation to prevent dust bowls is more, important to the average American student than arithmetic, Clayton B. Seagears, State Superintendent of Conservation, yesterday told a conference called by the New York Zoological Society.
LONDON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The Times hailed the Paris Marshall plan proposals as offering "the chance of a daring and quite unprecedented experiment in international collaboration."

With Jackie Robinson singled out for special honors by his own legion of admirers, Brooklyn turned out 26,123 strong at Ebbets Field yesterday to pay wholehearted tribute to its beloved Dodgers in their newly confirmed role as 1947 National League champions.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 23 -- Restored to its design, decorations and furnishings of a century ago through, gifts exceeding $500,000 from John D. Rockefeller Jr., the home here that Washington Irving occupied from 1835 until his death in 1859 will be opened as a public shrine and museum on Oct. 5, Dr. Hugh Grant Rowell, director of the restoration, announced today.

Fall promotion of the Premier Vacuum Cleaner Division of the General Electric Company will be devoted to advertising the Premier "rug-meter," a device designed to maintain a firm seal between the vacuum cleaner and the rug, regardless of the thickness of the pile.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Scoring all their runs in the fourth inning, the Cubs defeated the Reds, 7 -- 2, before 1,311 fans today as Hank Wyse turned in a six-hitter for his sixth victory of the year.

THE HAGUE, Sept. 23 -- The Dutch Government's plan to form a central organization preparatory to an interim Federal Government for the United States of Indonesia and the dismissal of the Commission General for Indonesia were announced today by Dr. Louis J.M. Beel, Dutch Premier and Acting Minister for Overseas Affairs.

A "Save Washington Square" meeting was held last night at the Provincetown Playhouse, 133 Macdougal Street, to protest the building of the proposed New York University Law Center on a site facing Washington Square.

The cool weather has proven a powerful stimulant in the sale of coats and suits, it was learned yesterday from retail merchants and resident buyers who had been deeply concerned with the poor showings made by new styles in August and the first two weeks of September.

The report of the European Economic Conference in Paris, obtained by THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday, is a compromise between what the Europeans thought was necessary and what the State Department thought the United States Congress would accept.

DETROIT, Sept. 23 -- Evidence of widespread gambling within the automotive industry by workers while on the job on company property was disclosed today following the dismissal by the Ford Motor Company of nineteen employes, including three foremen, and the suspension of eighteen others after a reported "housewives' rebellion."

George Bernard Shaw has passed on some advice to the Children's World Theatre, Inc., which opens its season on Nov. 1 at the BarbizonPlaza Theatre with "Jack and the Beanstalk." Incorporated four months ago, the group recently wrote Mr. Shaw of their plans, and asked him for a statement regarding plays and theatre for children.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 23 -- The union hiring hall will be maintained in a new contract between the Pacific American Shipowners Association and the Sailors Union of the Pacific, an affiliate of the American Federation of Labor, under a tentative agreement reached in negotiations today.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Sept. 23 -- Speakers urged action on social problems to prevent war and chaos from spreading across the world as over 500 missionaries and Congregational Church leaders met today at sessions of the American Board of Commissioners or Foreign Missions.

The annual report of the council and trustees of the New York Academy of Medicine, made public yesterday, calls for plans to increase the academy's endowment by $3,000,000 and an increase in its working income through contributions, large or small, "to insure that there shall be no deficit at the end of 1947, and that moneys shall be acquired to apply to 1948."

TOKYO, Sept. 23 --The Japanese Government of Premier Kuniaki Koiso in 1944 and 1945 proposed to negotiate peace with Britain and the United States simultaneously with the collapse of the Hitler regime, then evidently at hand, according to a statement today to the Japanese Central Screening Committee which investigates the fitness of candidates for public office under the Allied purge directive.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- James Forrestal, the country's first Secretary of Defense, crossed the Potomac today to his new offices in the Pentagon Building where he will direct a job of integration which, he said, might take many months, perhaps years.

The wandering United Nations, now shuttling between a former fair building and a reconverted factory, must have a place to call its own immediately," Secretary-General Trygve Lie told the General Assembly yesterday.

When Secretary Marshall asked the nations of Europe to draw up their own recovery plan, he set in motion a process likely to have consequences far larger and more revolutionary than a program of American aid. This is the first reaction to a quick perusal of the report of the European Cooperation Committee in answer to the Marshall proposal.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Early in 1941 President Roosevelt established a system of non-statutory price controls. Congress supplanted these executive controls in February, 1942, when the Emergency Price Control Act became law. In September, 1942, while this statue was in force, the President officially announced that he was resolved to proceed upon his own executive responsibility to fill certain gaps in the existing statutory controls unless the Congress acted.

The Bellport Realty Company has agreed to sell a portion of its 120-acre property at Bellport, L.I., to the Atomic Energy Commission for a housing project, Louis Rinaldi, president of the company, reported yesterday. The property, formerly owned by the Wood Acres Realty Corporation, extends from South Country Road to the bay and is adjacent to the Bellport Country Club golf course.

Republican support for the move to repeal proportional representation is expected soon in the shape of formal statements from principal county leaders of the party in the city, it was indicated yesterday. The same sources said it would not be surprising if Governor Dewey added his support to the drive to repeal PR.

MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Sept. 23 -- General Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Chief of Staff, declared today that if Russia persisted in her "completely negative attitude" toward peace, the United States had no alternative but to organize a "little assembly" in the United Nations and to support its friends in Western Europe.
Dahlias in a large variety of size and color overflowed yesterday the roof garden of the Hotel Pennsylvania, where the thirty-third annual show of the American Dahlia Society opened for two days.

Expansion and activation of the World Commerce Corporation, ar organization of American, Canadian and British financial and business interests created to promote international trade through private means; was announced here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- Three members of the Interstate Commerce Commission began today to hear a plea of railroads operating in the East for increases in rates on freight in less than carload lots sufficient to yield the railroads an additional $29,000,000 a year net.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Sept. 23 -- Mrs. Alvan Ives of the Inwood Club turned in an 87 -- 10 -- 77 to take low net honors in the 'Women's Metropolitan Golf Association one-day tournament at the Nassau Country Club today.

Railroad Equipments Bond houses which specialize in the pricing and marketing of railroad equipment trust issues are facing a calendar of such financingrunning into an aggregate borrowing of about $25,000,000 by five carriers.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Use of oxygen in open hearth furnaces as a means of overcoming the steel shortage was discussed today by experts addressing the convention of the Association of Iron and Steel Engineers.

Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, warned the General Assembly yesterday that cooperation among the great power was the "very cornerstone" of the organization and urged a return to the spirit of cooperation expressed in the preamble to the Charter.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23 -- Buying of wheat futures by mills and cash interests gave that grain a strong tone on the Board of Trade today and helped advance corn in the early trading, but the latter turned weak under a resumption of general commission-house selling with stop-loss orders uncovered.

MIAMI, Sept. 23 -- The new tropical storm building toward hurricane strength lunged in off the Gulf of Mexico over the northern Florida peninsula tonight and threatened to sweep across the state and up the Georgia and Carolina seaboard.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The office of the National Labor Relations Board's independent general counsel swung into action today by filing, for the first time under the Taft-Hartley law, actions against two unions.
Columbia was running through its full repertoire of plays yesterday at the end of the last double session of practice at Baker Field before the squad moves down to the campus today.

CHICAGO. Sept. 23 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hoes. 7.500 head: total. 12.000: market slow: generally 23 to 50 cents lower on all weights butchers and sows; top S28.65 lor around three loads of choice 240 pounds: bulk of good and choice 200 to 280 pounds

There is a saga of the ocean, the old ocean of sailing ships, of tilted decks swept by foaming waves, of ropes drenched and strained by howling winds, in the life of Captain Gustaf Erikson, who died last week, aged seventy-five, in his native Aland Islands, in the Baltic between Sweden and Finland.

SEATTLE, Wash., Sept. 23 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, ignoring the boos of persons in the audience who sought to break up his first meeting in the Northwest, accepted the Taft-Hartley Labor Act tonight as an issue for 1948.

In response to Mr. Marshall's speech of June 5 the sixteen participating countries have met in Paris for the purpose of developing an economic recovery program and of determining the manner and extent to which these countries can, by their individual and collective efforts, bring about the achievement of that program.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The Government of the Dominion of India does not consider the United Nations to be an impartial authority for the investigation of communal riots in the Punjab, according to B.R. Sen, charge d'affaires, in the course of a news conference today at the Indian Embassy here.

Secretary General Trygve Lie assumed a hard task yesterday when he accepted an invitation to "say something" to the United Nations Assembly. Mr. Lie is, by the nature of his office, above the battle -- a servant of an organization representing fifty-five states.

The National Mediation Board continued its study yesterday of a possible solution to the five-dayold tie-up of the New York branch of the Railway Express Agency as other labor groups came to the support of the striking teamsters.

LONDON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Displaying official concern over the post war showing of its athletes, Britain's Government announced today it was subsidizing sports training in a bid to stop the rout of British teams in international competition.

Ballots for voting on the reorganization plan of the Equitable Building Corporation were mailed to stockholders yesterday by J. Donald Duncan, trustee. The plan was approved by Federal Judge John C. Knox on Sept. 12. Ballots must be returned by Oct. 15. A majority of the stock vote is required for approval of the plan.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 23 -- On the eve of the Day of Atonement, the holiest of the Jewish holy days, unknown persons desecrated a synagogue in Jerusalem today after British troops had searched the building for arms. The British military authorities have apologized to the Chief Rabbi and to the individual rabbis concerned.

For the first time, manufacturers of some leading durable goods lines of light machine tools and industrial and electrical supplies, have put into action plans to protect distributors against price declines, spokesmen revealed here yesterday.

VIENNA, Sept. 23 -- A new directive from Moscow, ordering that Russian propaganda here have an exclusively anti-American slant, is reported on good authority to have been received by the Soviet occupation authorities.
Jews throughout the world began the observance of Tom Kippur, the Day of Atonement, most sacred day in the Hebrew religious calendar, last night at sundown.
Despite another drop in wholesale meat prices, the retail markdowns for which housewives have seen waiting failed yesterday again to materialize at the corner butcher shop.

The executive council of the New York State Federation of Labor set machinery in motion yesterday that would prevent Communists from taking part in future conventions and conferences of the federation.

Century Theatres, which operates five movie houses in Brooklyn and other places on Long Island, announced yesterday the establishment of "Sat-R-Day Camps," to provide film entertainment exclusively prepared for young children and teen-agers.

ROME, Sept. 23 -- The farm laborers' agitation, which was settled in northern Italy last week, has spread to central Italy. Thirty thousand farm laborers have been on strike in the region around Rome since yesterday. About 30,000 went on strike in the Arezzo region today.

BUFFALO, Sept. 23 -- Catholics were told today at a series of religious functions in connection With the Provincial Eucharistic Congress being held here that their church and faith are under unrelenting attack in the world today and that they must fortify themselves with prayer and sacraments if they are to withstand the assaults and help bring a lasting and just peace to the world.

The problem of making adequate provision for the replacement of depreciating capital assets is among the most important now facing business as a result of the general rise in prices, according to the Guaranty Trust Company of New York.

With Assault frisky as a puppy when he took his morning exercise, his on-again-off-again due with Armed stayed in the "on" classification yesterday at Belmont Park, where the rival owners went into a huddle with George D. Widener, president of the Westchester Racing Association.

Prospects for the televising of the world series brightened yesterday with the disclosure that the National Broadcasting Company was conducting negotiations with A.B. (Happy) Chandler, Commissioner of Baseball. Whether NBC was prepared to meet the asking price of $100,000 for the video rights to the classic could not be ascertained, but it was known that the network regarded it as important to television's future that the games be carried.

FRENCH LICK, Ind., Sept. 23 (AP) -- The Union Employers' Section of the Printing Industry of America voted unanimously today to insist on full compliance with the Taft-Hartley Law in negotiations with the International Typographical Union, AFL.

LONDON, Sept. 23 -- With investors having little incentive to buy in the face of the uncertainties of Britain's export business and the possibility of a fall budget, business in stock markets here today was on a small scale. Industrials opened firm but owing to lack of business prices fell away at the close.

The pricing of new high-grade public-utility bond issues by underwriting syndicates reflected yesterday continued market pressure to rate the credit of the expanding industry on a higher-yield basis to fixed-income investors and to narrow the yield spread between new AA-rated and new AAA-rated bonds.

GENEVA, Sept. 23 -- As the stalemate in the Anglo-United States tariff negotiations continues, trade experts at Geneva are considering the consequences of an ultimate breakdown, though the balance of opinion is that this will not happen in the end.

At the annual meeting and election of the New York Drama Critics Circle, held yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Algonquin, a much more simplified procedure was adopted in choosing the best American and foreign play of the season.

Discouragement and Satisfaction With their eardrums still vibrating to the reverberations of the recent speech of Deputy Foreign Minister Vishinsky of the Soviet Union before the General Assembly of the United Nations, champions of Esperanto and other similar projects aimed at making international gatherings resemble well-trained choruses rather than modern Towers of Babel must be filled with a mixture of discouragement and satisfaction.

Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander celebrated yesterday his second anniversary as head of the department. In his office, filled, with baskets and vases of flowers, his desk covered with telegrams, the Commissioner said "the police today are keeping criminals out of circulation; crime is on the decrease."

CHICAGO, Sept. 27 -- Drift toward state socialism was stopped by the Republican Congress this year, Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr., Republican, of Massachusetts, speaker of the House, said here today. He was a guest at a luncheon given by Illinois Republican Congressmen and state party chiefs in the Stevens Hotel.

The first stage in the fight around the veto power of the Big Five ended yesterday, with Ecuador, the last speaker in the United Nations General Assembly's preliminary debate, warning that the privilege could not be allowed to stand in the way of hemispheric self-defense.

Overcrowding of students is just as prevalent in European colleges as it is in this country, Bryn J. Hovde, president of the New School, found after spending three months visiting universities and studying social and cultural conditions abroad.

Columbia University marked yesterday the official beginning of a new educational unit, the School of General Studies, at a luncheon in the Faculty House, 400 West 117th Street, for 100 college officials, members of the faculty and friends. Creation of the new unit followed reorganization of the department that had been known as University Extension.

The United States is maintaining an Atlantic Fleet of 400 vessels, ranging from landing craft to battleships and aircraft carriers, Admiral William H. P. Blandy, commander in chief of the Atlantic Fleet, said here yesterday after arriving for an inspection of naval facilities.

Among other interesting facts developed in a recent speech by Leonard Probst, State Commissioner of Probation, was a reference to the difference in cost between putting an offender in an institution and placing him on probation. Many offenders, of course, cannot be dealt with on a probation basis.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27 -- Drift toward state socialism was stopped by the Republican Congress this year, Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr., Republican, of Massachusetts, speaker of the House, said here today. He was a guest at a luncheon given by Illinois Republican Congressmen and state party chiefs in the Stevens Hotel.

The first stage in the fight around the veto power of the Big Five ended yesterday, with Ecuador, the last speaker in the United Nations General Assembly's preliminary debate, warning that the privilege could not be allowed to stand in the way of hemispheric self-defense.

LONDON, Sept. 23 (U.P.) -- Britain's most closely guarded secret since radar was locked up in Hartnell's fitting rooms is guarded by trusted employes sworn to secrecy. Only two persons, both members of royalty, will be present at its unofficial "unveiling" Monday, when the Princesses Elizabeth and Margaret will interrupt their vacation at Balmoral Castle, Scotland, next week for their first look at Elizabeth's wedding gown.

As the world picture darkens, it becomes necessary that this country not withhold essential aid from destitute peoples because it happens to disagree with their forms of government, and that our aid to those countries be administered by responsible agencies who will make certain that the recipients know where the help is coming from.

Among other interesting facts developed in a recent speech by Leonard Probst, State Commissioner of Probation, was a reference to the difference in cost between putting an offender in an institution and placing him on probation. Many offenders, of course, cannot be dealt with on a probation basis.

Reporting steel shipments of 31,210,945 net tons in the first six months of 1947, the American Iron and Steel Institute estimated yesterday that most consuming industries will receive one-third more steel this year than they did in 1946 and predicted that a new peace-time record of 62,000,000 tons of finished steel will be shipped this year if the current rate is maintained.

ROME, Sept. 23 -- The Italian Foreign Ministry said today that the Yugoslav legation had charged "violences" had been perpetrated against Slovenes in the Venezia Giulia area that had been handed over to Italy after ratification of the Italian peace treaty last week.

Minute Tapioca, which might have remained off the market many more years if Java had continued to be the only source, will appear in stores here within the next few days. This announcement came at a luncheon General Foods gave yesterday to reintroduce the product, now being made from the cassava flour of Brazil.
PARIS, Sept. 23 -- Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder has received a "terrifying" picture of the French financial situation, according to an official who attended his talks with high officials.

BOSTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- After being held to five hits by Phil Marchildon for a 9-3 setback in the opener, the Red Sox said their 1947 home farewells with a 6-5 victory today while splitting a double -header with the Athletics.

A 78-year-old woman was acclaimed yesterday as the first of her sex to win an annual $1,000 Lasker Award of the American Public Health Association. She is Dr. Alice Hamilton who pioneered in hygienic and industrial disease research at the Harvard Medical School and spent forty years in developing methods to prevent occupational ailments.

Bucky Harris gave his world series pitching talent another careful screening at the Stadium yesterday and what he saw as the Yankees polished off the Senators in both ends of a double-header was something of an eye-filling performance in two parts.
YESTERDAY'S EVENTS General Assembly Met at 11:10 A.M. at Flushing Meadow, Queens, and heard Dr. L. Neftale Ponce of Ecuador. Closed general debate at 11:25 A.M.

THE HAGUE, Sept. 23 (AP) -- A Dutch Government declaration said today that the predominant influence of "fanatics" and "malevolent elements" in the Indonesian Republican Government was a serious bar to renewed negotiations, but indicated that military action would not be resumed for the present.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 23 -- Plans for 1948 production of an episodic film dealing with the careers and deaths of nine unknown soldiers were announced today by RKO. The picture, to be titled "Honored Glory," will be based on an outline telegraphed to Dore Schary, studio production chief, by Henry Grunwald, a contributing editor of Time and Life magazines.

Several hundred persons gathered yesterday in front of Borough Hall, Brooklyn, to witness the first of a series of seven noonday rallies marking Rededication Week in connection with the arrival of the Freedom Train in the borough next Saturday.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Richard (Pancho) Gonzales, 19year-old Los Angeles municipal park courts product, provided the first major upset of the Pacific Southwest tennis tournament today when he defeated Jaroslav Drobny, Czech star, 3-6, 6-3, 7-5.

The Congressional price investigating subcommittee meeting here framed a request yesterday for immediate Presidential action to curb speculation on the country's big grain exchanges as a means of driving prices down.

Excerpts from Secretary Getteral Trygve Lie's address to the United Nations General Assembly follow: I was very happy when the president asked me yesterday afternoon whether I had something to say before the conclusion of the general debate.
CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 23 (AP) -- Christiana's Stables' Alexis, 7-10 choice, upset favorite players in the featured Kings Highway Purse at Garden State Park today.

Ward L. Atwood, assistant to the president, Woburn Chemical Company, has been named sales manager, succeeding Richard O'Rourke, who recently resigned the latter position because of illness but will continue to advise the company on special industrial relations projects.

BOSTON, Sept. 23 -- The United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, Congress of Industrial Organizations, voted today to demand that General Electric, Westinghouse and all other employers having contracts with the union join in boycotting the National Labor Relations Board under the Taft-Hartley Law.

Reform in conducting the National Air Races at Cleveland, which on Labor Day cost one life and placed many more in danger, was forecast here yesterday by Ben Franklin, general manager of the event. Three technical committees have been named, Mr. Franklin said, to effect "tighter control" of high speed planes in closed course racing.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Ralph Kiner, slugging Pittsburgh outfielder, got his, 51st home run of the year tonight but it wasn't enough to save the Pirates from another defeat as the second-place Cardinals triumphed, 8 to 4, before a chilled gathering of 10,330.

The issues for and against payment of a veterans bonus, which the voters of this state will decide in the November election, were discussed yesterday afternoon during the WQXR forum broadcast. "What's On Your Mind." The specific question discussed under the leadership of Iphigene Bettman was: "Should We Vote the Veterans' Bonus?"

Over the strong opposition of the Soviet bloc, the United Nations General Assembly voted yesterday, at Flushing Meadow, to include in its agenda the Greek question, the problem of Korean independence and the peace treaty with Italy.

Plans for a new apartment house at 251-53 West Seventy-fourth Street, estimated to cost $200,000, were filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings by H. Herbert Lilien, architect. The owners were listed as Emanual Jacobs and Irving Rosen, of 391 East 149th Street, in the Bronx.

BERLIN, Sept. 23 -- A reduction in the bread ration for Berlin, proposed today at a meeting of the Allied Control Council, was referred to a committee for study after discussion. The United States member led the opposition to the proposal.

A nation-wide drive to provide food packages for the British people was begun yesterday under the auspices of CARE, Cooperative for American Remittances to Europe. Entitled the "Princess Elizabeth Wedding Gift" and comprising items lacking in the British diet, the package was described by Douglas Fairbanks Jr., motion picture actor serving as chairman of the Share Through CARE Committee sponsoring the project, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The new sixteen-man board of directors of the reorganized New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad Company yesterday elected Howard S. Palmer president and chairman of the executive committee. He had been president and chief executive officer of the New Haven since Nov. 1, 1934, and trustee since Nov. 8, 1935.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 24 -- Congress will insist that any economic assistance offered Europe under the Marshall Plan "shall be predicated upon the showing of a sincere intent of those countries receiving the aid to help themselves," Joseph Martin Jr., Repubican, of Massachusetts, Speaker of the House, predicted here tonight in a speech prepared for delivery at the $100-a-plate Republican Founders Dinner at the Auditorium.

THE special race between Armed and Assault at Belmont on Saturday is beginning to bear a suspicious resemblance to that classic footnote that's found in railroad timetables, "Subject to change without notice." It's been on again, off again with such frequency that it sounds as though it had been arranged by InAgain-Out-Again Finnegan.

Investment banking syndicates competed here yesterday for the award of an aggregate of $28,000,000 in new bond and common stock issues of the Interstate Power Company as other banking groups placed on the market $100,000,000 of new bonds of the Duquesne Light Company and the Consumers Power Company.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 24 -- Leaders of the Building Officials Foundation received "constructive criticism" of their program today from Robert W. McChesney, chairman of a subcommittee of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, and offered a reply.
The futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned irregular yesterday and closed 15 points lower than on Tuesday on the October option and 1 point lower to 13 higher on other months.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 24 -- Charley Caldwell is old-fashioned enough to hold fast to the singlewing formation in an era when the "T" has come to be accepted as de riguer as the long hemline, but he has set a mode all of his own in training the Princeton football team.

A Douglas C-54 Skymaster with a mechanical brain has crossed the ocean all by itself. To be sure, fourteen were on board, but they were only observers or emergency crew. Not a hand touched the controls. It was not the first flight of the kind made by the Skymaster, but it was the longest, and hence the severest test of its automatic mechanism.

TOKYO, Sept. 24 -- Japan must expect "substantially less" food from the United States next year because of world crop shortages and the increased demands of hungry nations, the Japanese were informed today by the Allied command.

The stock market managed yesterday to recoup about half of the losses sustained on Tuesday but the follow-through lacked vigor and the key issues made only modest gains. With an advance of 0.39 point in the combined averages, the recovery was attributed purely to the lack of offerings.
City control over food prices, patterned in some respects after the municipal rent control law, will be sought in a bill to be introduced today in the City Council.

A proposed merger of the Evangelical and Reform Church with the Congregational Christian Church to form the United Church of Christ is well along the road to completion, officials of the Congregational Christian Church announced yesterday at their offices, 287 Fourth Avenue.

An intensive drive to assure compliance with export control regulations has been started by the Office of International Trade of the Department of Commerce, it was disclosed yesterday by, L. L. Horch, New York regional director for the department.

Staten Islanders will be keeping their fingers crossed now while waiting to see what comes of the intimation, broached by Commissioner Moses, that a crossing of the Narrows to Brooklyn may be in the offing. This time it is a bridge, for which Federal Government sanction would have to be obtained.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- An increase estimated at $61,254,000 in the country's express bill was approved today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24 (AP) -- The Tigers increased their second-place lead in the American League to a full game over the idle Red Sox tonight by defeating the White Sox, 5 to 4, in 10 innings before 2,806 persons.

Americans "will fight for themselves" to preserve their freedoms "wherever or whenever the occasion makes it necessary to do so," Lloyd Paul Stryker, attorney heading the speakers' committee of Mayor O'Dwyer's Rededication Committee for the Freedom Train, declared yesterday.

Coffee-vending machines may become one of the largest distribution channels for the beverage within the next few years, S.L. Luber, sales director of Rudd-Melikian, Inc., Philadelphia, declared yesterday at a demonstration in Hotel New Yorker of what was described as the first automatic hot coffee vender on the market.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 24 -- Thomas W. Balfe, vice president of the National Distillers Products Corporation, predicted today that liquor sales in 1948 would remain just as high as those of this year.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 24 -- The Hawaiian - Philippine Company of Manila, Philippine Islands, and the Pacific Finance Corporation of California, which has its principal office in Los Angeles, filed registration statements today with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Dr. Herbert V. Evatt, Australian Minister for External Affairs, aye his full backing last night of United States proposals for a year-round "Little Assembly" in The United Nations to help keep peace and security. He described them as not only justified but "esential."

Tough broncos, bulls, untamed calves, snorting Brahma steers roared into the Madison Square Garden arena last night. Cowboys by the score hit the hard dirt with regularity. Thirteen thousand tenderfeet howled "Yippee!" and "Ride em cowboy!" for two and onehalf hours.

RANGOON, Burma, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Former Premier U Saw and nine co - defendants were formally charged before a special tribunal today with the murder of Maj. Gen. U Aung San and six other Burmese Cabinet members.

Major improvements in equipment and supplies purchased by the Bureau of Yards and Docks and other establishments of the Navy were covered in reports of committees of the Navy Industrial Association, presented to trustees and members at their meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- When the President next Monday meets with the leaders of Congress to discuss "world problems" good manners will doubtless prevail as usual. Therefore, there will probably be no dispute over the'respective responsibility of the two major parties for existing high prices of food if these prices come into the discussion.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I was extremely interested in your editorial of Sept. 13 concerning the shortage of nurses, inasmuch as I am a registered nurse.

Sparkling Imagination was joined with sound artistry in the custom millinery collection of SaksFifth Avenue's Tatiana du Plessix presented yesterday at the Hotel Plaza. Basically this versatile designer held to three trends -- the small back-fitting hat, the one-sided hat, and the large hat with forward j- tting movement.

LODZ, Poland, Sept. 23 (Delayed) -- At least 40,000 textile workers have been on strike here for the last ten days against a Government-introduced speed-up. At the start of the strike they held possession of the huge Poznanski textile works for one night.
The outer edge of the tropical storm that has been traveling up the coast with diminishing intensity will strike the metropolitan area today, revised charts of the Weather Bureau showed last night.

The Freedom Train -- bearing its treasure of original historic mementoes such as a manuscript copy of the Declaration of Independence, the Bill of Rights, the Gettysburg Address, the Emancipation Proclamation, the battle flag-of Iwo, the Declaration of the United Nations -- was opened officially by Mayor O'Dwyer last night.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 24 (Reuters) -- Both India and Pakistan today stopped refugee traffic through the riot-torn Punjab after what appears to have been the worst massacre of refugees so far reported.

The Continental FM Network has completed new arrangements for its program from 8 to 9 P.M. tomorrow as the result of the ban by James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, on the chain's use of "live" musicians.

The conflict between Mayor O'Dwyer's pledge to continue the child-care program "as is" and the substitute State Youth Commission's juvenile delinquency prevention program was emphasized again yesterday in a letter from the Child Care Center Parents Association to Welfare Commissioner Edward E. Rhatigan.
Yesterday was the thirtieth anniversary of the Home Nursing Service of the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 24 (AP) -- George Munger hurled three-hit ball and Whitey Kurowski drove in four runs, two of them on his 27th homer of the year, as the Cardinals defeated the Pirates, 5-1, tonight before a crowd of 11,658.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- On the basis of a study of 258 power laundry establishments in 38 southern and mid-western cities, the Women's Bureau of the Department of Labor issued a statement today that "the laundry industry need not be synonymous with depressed wage and employment standards."

Pleas for world peace mingled with prayers for the plight of needy Jews abroad yesterday as Jews observed Yom Kippur, the Day of Atonement, in synagogues in the city. Rabbis voiced the need for religious understanding and their faith In the survival of Judaism.

LONDON, Sept. 24 -- Last night's drop in oil stocks on Wall Street due to fears of political complications affecting United States and Britain's Middle East oil concessions sent prices of petroleum producers down sharply at the opening of the stock markets here today.

Northeastern lumber producers have begun an all-out effort to recapture Eastern regional markets dominated since the early Nineteen Hundreds by Western pine interests and now open because of standing timber depletion in the so-called Inland Empire, R.E. Broderick, executive secretary, Northeastern Lumber Manufacturers Association, disclosed yesterday.
LONDON, Sept. 24 -- Britain will meet the coal export target set out for the nation in the Marshall plan. Lord Hyndley, head of the National Coal Board, said here today.
Columbia's varied offense, on which the Lions will depend most heavily against Rutgers Saturday, was the focus of Coach Lou Little's attention for the second straight day at Baker Field yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 24 -- Mark Hellinger has closed a deal with the Selznick releasing organization to produce six pictures for distribution by Selznick in the next two years, it was announced today. The pictures will be filmed by Hellinger's own company, Mark Hellinger Productions, but Vanguard Films, David O. Selznick's producing company, will participate in the financing.

Larry MacPhail, president of the New York Yankees, yesterday disclosed that ha intends to give up active direction of the organization after 1950, that Bucky Harris will continue as manager of the club next year and that he and his partners had turned down a $3,000,000 offer for a half-interest in ther vast sports enterprise.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 24 -- The American Bar Association called today on the American people for a united support of the foreign policy of the United States without regard to party lines, and recommended that action be taken By the United Nations to curb Russia's "paralyzing" veto power.

A Date With Autumn The first day of autumn arrived in our city on schedule, with bright sunshine in clean rain-washed skies and a marvelous crispness in the air. New Yorkers, who had taken to dawdling along their sidewalks during the delayed dog days, lapping over from August far into September, accepted it as invitation to "resume speed"-as the sign on the highway says just after you get your car clear of an incorporated village.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 24 -- The new parkway toll system in Westchester is unfair and unsound from all economic viewpoints, Harold T. Garrity, chairman of the Democratic County Committee, charged here tonight in predicting a $90,000,000 loss to the county.

CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 24 (AP) -- Calumet Farm's Twosy, fourth in one section of last year's Colonial Handicap, took down top honors, in this year's running of the Garden State Park fixture before a crowd of 16,289 today.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 24 -- More than 1,500,000 Americans are in need of long-term care because of chronic illness, Miss Edna Nicholson of Chicago, director of the Central Service for the Chronically III, reported today. She urged a coordinated program to provide for such patients, declaring that virtually no American community had more than half the needed facilities.

True to the tradition, that there are no halfway measures in connection with Dodger celebrations, the National League baseball pennant which the Flatbush clan grabbed this year will fly tomorrow from atop Borough Hall in Brooklyn.

"I Gotta Get Out," a comedy about horse-racing by Joseph Fields and Ben Sher, will make its debut this evening at the Cort Theatre under the auspices of Herbert H. Harris and Lester Meyer. Twenty-four backers are involved in the venture, representing a total investment of $75,000.

ESSEX FELLS, N.J., Sept. 24 -- W. Palen Conway of Baltusrol and Edgar Rorke of Rockaway River carded aggregate 158's to tie for the lead in the New Jersey State Seniors Golf Association championship today at the Essex Fells Country Club.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Preston Delano, controller of the currency, said today "we are in the full swing of a post-war inflation which is severe and dangerous" and appealed to the nation's banks to help put on the brakes.

United States naval forces in the Mediterranean "are the most fully manned and ready components of the fleets," Rear Admiral Cato D. Glover Jr., assistant chief of naval operations for strategic plans, disclosed yesterday.

It cannot be stressed too often that the struggle brought to a head in this session of the General Assembly is not against the Soviet Union but for the United Nations. The central issue is not the vindication of the American case, the Russian case or the case of any member nation but of the San Francisco Charter.

MASSENA, N.Y., Sept. 24 (AP) -- A crewman from the Canadian collier Milverton died here tonight, the second victim of a collision in the St. Lawrence River today that set off a terrific explosion and fire on the coal ship as an oil cargo spilled over its bows.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- American Overseas Aid, a fundraising organization combining the United Nations appeal for children with private agencies conducting voluntary relief programs in Europe and the Far East, was started today from the White House.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 24 -- To reduce the strain on the United Nations budget, Great Britain recommended today that the member nations limit to $150,000 the amount to be spent next year on social welfare advisory work taken over from the now defunct United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration.
Three men and the wife of one were arrested yesterday and charged with robbing the home of Arthur H. Bunker, a partner in Lehman Brothers, investment bankers.
GENEVA, Sept. 24 -- The Geneva Trade Conference unanimously approved today the text of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24 -- A credit survey of 261,358 business accounts, has revealed that 10.5 per cent are past due while the average on receivables is 32.69 days. The survey, conducted in August by the Chicago Association of Credit Men, included retail, wholesale -distributor and industrial accounts, R.L. Seaman, president, said today.

In his first public utterance here since retirement Vice Admiral Charles E. Rosendahl, USN (retired), criticized what he called his "beloved service" for its failure to develop a policy for the construction and operation of big rigid airships. He urged that airships be taken out of the Bureau of ,Aeronautics and put under the Bureau of Ships as displacement vessels.
DANBURY, Conn., Sept. 24 -- The Danbury Fair, annually one of the nation's top ranking agricultural expositions, opens for the seventy-fourth time on Saturday and will continue daily through Oct. 5.

The Liberal party has asked Mayor O'Dwyer to receive a delegation of party leaders in an effort to obtain his support for the continuation of the proportional representation method of electing members of the City Council, it was announced yesterday.

The newsprint supply in Great Britain, France and the Netherlands is "unbelievably small," Robert M. Fowler, president of the Newsprint Association of Canada, declared here yesterday, adding that newspapers there are not large enough to present a "minimum of essential information" about world affairs to the people.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninetyfour leading cities, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended Sept. 17:

Stevan Bergmann, Austrian pianist, made his American debut last night at Carnegie Hall. Previous to the war years, during which he was forced into manual labor by the Germans, Mr. Bergmann concertized extensively abroad and appeared as soloist with many important orchestras.

Senator Taft is said to believe that the demonstrations that have been staged against him in the West will make votes for him in the East. The demonstrators, presumably, believe they can rally sentiment against him by picketing his arrivals and departures from various cities and his meetings.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Villanova's Wildcats, smarting under four successive trouncings by Army's great wartime football machine, took stock of themselves today and optimistically looked forward to ending the cadets' twenty-eight-game unbeaten streak Saturday at West Point.

Underwriting managers here will make public offerings of securities issues here today as follows: Gum Products, Inc. -- 175,000 shares of Class A $5 par value 60 cents cumulative dividend convertible preferred stock and 175,000 shares of $1 par value common stock, in units of one share of the Class A stock and one share of common stock at $11.50 a unit, by Blair Co., Itfc.; Hardy Co., and A.M. Kidder Co.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 24 -- The admission of Yemen and Pakistan to the United Nations was recommended to the General Assembly by its Political and Security Committee at its opening meeting here today. The committee also elected officers and adopted a working schedule.

To the person who reads the Report of the Committee on European Economic Cooperation, the full text of which was reproduced in this newspaper yesterday, one fact, we think, will leave a deeper impression than any other. That is the soundness of the economic and financial principles upon which this study rests, both with respect to its analysis of Europe's problems and its proposals for solving them.

THE most unexpected stories that ever got into The Saturday Evening Post were Thomas Beer's. It was always a pleasure to find his mannered prose glittering in those acres of otherwise uncompromising clarity. No other setting could have shown them off so well. In a strange way they really belonged there.

The next session of Congress must deal effectively with the problem of obtaining the young men needed for the armed services if the military establishments are to fulfill their assigned commitments, Senator Leverett Saltonstall, Republican, of Massachusetts, and a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee, declared last night.

Donor was the big horse at Belmont Park yesterday. The Deering Howe color-bearer beat them all in the Jerome Handicap, $25,000 added mile test for 3-year-olds, and in so doing moved into the $100,000 earnings bracket.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- The United States has transferred more than 1,000 ships of its wartime merchant fleet to other countries as part of the Government's foreign aid program.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 24 -- Under the chairmanship of Dr. Hernan Santa Cruz, Chilean representative to the United Nations, the fifty-five nation Economic and Financial Committee of the General Assembly elected officers and adopted its agenda today.

COLOGNE, Germany, Sept. 24 -- The British Military Government will offer the 4,300 Exodus refugees tomorrow an opportunity to return to France, it was officially announced tonight. The refugees, who were debarked at Hamburg two weeks ago, are living in two camps near Luebeck.

The sixth biennial convention of the National Maritime Union, CIO, was recessed yesterday afternoon until today as "in no condition to transact business at this time," with only slightly more than 80 per cent of its delegates seated by the union's credentials committee.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Jack Kramer, United States singles champion, won his way into the quarter-final of the Pacific Southwest Tennis Tournament today, brushing aside with ease the challenge of Vladimir Cernik of Czechoslovakia by 6-1, 6-1.

VIENNA, Sept. 24 -- Austria's adherence to the Marshall plan was proclaimed by her Foreign Minister, Dr. Karl Gruber, tonight over Vienna's Ravag radio station after the Russians had initially refused to permit the broadcast, as written, and relented only when they learned it would be made in that case over American station Red White Red.

LONDON, Sept. 24 -- Britain's top union chiefs pledged their full support today for Sir Stafford Cripps' drive to build up exports as a means of solving the British economic crisis. But they called on the Government to use exceptional care and discretion" in applying its scheme for the limited direction of labor.

Prices in the United States inevitably will decline if the nations now restricting imports of American goods because of dollar shortages continue that policy, Jerome M. Ney, chairman of the board of the American Retail Federation, said yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 24 -- Following a brief oral clash in the United Nations General Assembly's Trusteeship Committee with the British delegate, Semyon K. Tsarapkin of the Soviet Union today won a postponement of the vote to adopt the Trusteeship Council's report covering its first session.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 24 -- With career members of the State Department pressing for a solution of the Palestine question that will not alienate the Arab countries, United States policy is still not decided, it was learned tonight.
RONNE ANTARCTIC RESEARCH EXPEDITION BASE, Stonington Island, Antarctica, Sept. 23 (Delayed) -- Three British fliers lost in the deadly Antarctic wilderness for nine days have been found and rescued.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 24. -- Secretary General Trygve Lie surprised the United Nations today with the news that new economies in operating costs this year and next would save the world organization at least $6,700,000 and perhaps as much as $9,400,000.

MOSCOW, Sept. 24 (U.P.) -- Pravda warned that coal production at the beginning of the year was running behind schedule and said that the shortage of coal was reflected in other industries. Coal fields in the great Don and Kuban basins are among those which are behind in their production schedules, the paper said.
Henry C. Beal, vice president of the Western Electric Company, has been elected a director of the Bell Telephone Laboratories to succeed C. G. Stoll, recently retired president of Western Electric.
PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 24 (AP) -- John Foster's Mister Chat came from behind to win the featured Newton Purse today at Narragansett Park.

A Federal anti-discrimination statute, modeled after the New York law and similarly administered, can be made to work satisfactorily for the over-all benefit of the nation, Senator Irving M. Ives declared last night.
CHICAGO, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Atomic scientists in Chicago today expressed interest and surprise in the Tokyo report of the increases in crop yields at Nagasaki.

Four Eighteenth Century rooms that might have been part of a home in Colonial Williamsburg have been reproduced in detail on the ninth floor of Katzenbach Warren, 49 East Fifty-third Street. They serve to introduce four new additions to the traditional wallpapers that have been authorized by Williamsburg Restoration, Inc.

Sintered alumina (aluminum oxide) is envisaged as a suitable material for the manufacture of blades for gas turbines, Dr. Eugene Byschkewitch, a former German scientist, has revealed in a heretofore secret report of his twenty-year research studies of ceramics, now available from the Office of Technical Services, the Department of Commerce disclosed here yesterday.

Myron C. Taylor, President Truman's personal representative at the Vatican, said yesterday upon arrival at La Guardia Field that he had "not heard about" reports that he planned to retire from his post as envoy. Mr. Taylor came from London after a tour through several countries in Europe.

The nation's gasoline stocks last week showed a further drop of 522,000 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end they were 81,987,000 barrels, compared with 82,509,000 at the end of the previous week and 86,846,000 on Sept. 21, 1946.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- At the moment when living costs are rising, Earl O. Shreve, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, said today that another wage rise would not increase supplies of butter and red meat but merely create fiercer competition for scarce commodities.

PARIS, Sept. 24 -- Having failed to obtain from John W. Snyder, United States Secretary of the Treasury, any pledge of immediate aid, the French Cabinet attacked today the problem of reorganizing France's finances to stave off bankruptcy.

Automobile telephone service for motorists traveling anywhere along United States Route 1 between Boston and Washington will start today. The last unit in a 450-mile chain of radiotelephone stations between the two cities has been completed, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday, and automobiles on or near the highway can be connected with all the switchboards in the nation's telephone network.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- Air travel at a cost comparable to railway coach fares was pictured as a practical venture in testimony given today by S.J. Solomon, president of Atlantic Airlines, Inc., before the President's Air Policy Commission.

Plans for altering the four buildings at 446-48 Third Avenue and 158-60 East Thirtyfirst Street, the southwest corner, into thirty-two apartments were announced in connection with the sale of the property by Alexander Horowitz to the 448 Third Avenue Corporation.

In a strongly-worded telegram blaming grain and commodity speculation for keeping food prices at "unjustifiable levels," a Congressional price investigating subcommittee asked President Truman yesterday to do everything in his-power to curb such "dangerous activity."

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 24 -- The Big Five will meet here tomorrow in a determined attempt to break the deadlock that has held up for ten months the selection of a Governor for the free territory of Trieste.

Commercial Paper Rate According to reports, dealers in commercial paper yesterday raised their quotations to 1 1/8 per cent to 1 1/4 per cent, from the level of 1 to 1 1/8 per cent which had prevailed for several months. It is understood that the action is not yet general, and for the present applies to less-than-prime names.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- The texts of the additional letters exchanged between Sumner Welles and Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt regarding the admission to this country of Johannes Eisler, as made public at today's public hearing of the House Un-American Acitivities Committee, follow:

BOSTON, Sept. 24 -- By a vote of more than six to one the convention of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, CIO, demanded today that members of the anti-communist bloc in the union be expelled unless they stopped their "factional disruption."

ALBANY, Sept. 24 -- The Public Service Commission today ordered a thorough investigation before granting proposed increases in intrastate commutation fares on the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad.

YESTERDAY'S EVENTS General Assembly Committee 1. (Political and Security) -- Recommended admission into United Nations of Yemen and Pakistan and to send legal question on Pakistan's status, raised by Argentina, to legal committee for study.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 24 (AP) -- C.W. Phellis Tillie Trott gained considerable favor among juvenile trotting fillies today by winning the $10,000 Hanover Shoe Farm Stake over the highly regarded Mercy Abbe and Song Girl.
PANAMA, Sept. 24 -- Non-recognition of the Government of Nicaragua is wrecking the economy of the country and ruining business, according to a recent visitor to Managua.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- The first "E.A. Fllene Co-Op" department store will serve 22,000 families in tnree great wartime housing developments in Arlington, Va., a suburb of Washington, Lester G. Ott., president and general manager, announced today.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 24 -- attacks on refugee trains on both the Indian and Pakistan sides of the Punjab border in the past few days have heightened communal tension there, a Government of India military spokesman said today.

Directors of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company announced yesterday that they had deferred action on the regular 40 cent quarterly common dividend due on Nov. 1 until later this year, when earnings from a temporary rate increase may be 'more clearly ascertained."

There is an "alarming discrepancy" between Manhattan and Brooklyn in the comparative appropriations for social needs, it was charged yesterday by Mrs. Travis H. Whitney, vice chairman of the Brooklyn Neighborhood Houses Fund.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- Henry Kaiser, counsel for the International Typographical Union, declared today that the complaint under the Taft-Hartley Act alleging that the union and its Baltimore local had refused to bargain with the employers had been hurriedly drawn and without sufficient investigation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- From the White House, Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt in 1939 twice appealed personally to the State Department's second highest policymaker in behalf of Johannes (Hanns) Eisler's efforts to enter this country on a visa from Cuba.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- John L. Lewis will fight, single-handedly, if necessary, to prevent the forthcoming American Federation of Labor Convention from going on record calling upon all affiliates and all members of the AFL's Executive Council to sign non-Communist affidavits under the TaftHartley Act.

Random notes: Just to prove that it is not necessary to travel a couple of hundred miles to get a big bass from the surf, Carl Oestreicher of New York City made a cast from the foot of New York Avenue at Long Beach and brought in a 38 3/4 pounder.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 24 -- About 500 delegates from sixteen independent Methodist groups on five continents attended the opening ceremonies of the Ecumenical Methodist Conference here today.
JERUSALEM, Sept. 24 -- Nationalistic young Jews marked the end of the Day of Atonement by defying a British edict. They blow the traditional ram's horn at the Wailing Wall tonight.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 24 -- Forty thousand men, the largest crowd ever assembled in western New York for a religious ceremony, gathered tonight in Civic Stadium to hear the Catholic attitude on employer-employe relations restated, by Francis Cardinal Spellman of New York, James Charles Cardinal McGuigan of Toronto, Canada, Bernard Cardinal Griffin of Westminster, London, and Normal Cardinal Gilroy of Sydney, Australia.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: When a former Under-Secretary of the Treasury asserts that it is his "considered belief" that an international agreement signed by about fifty countries, and to which the United States is a party, should be repealed this is a very serious matter.

The Dodgers lost their final home game of the season at Ebbets Field yesterday, but the fact that the Giants beat the Brooks, 6 to 5, was merely incidental to the 16,690 fans who had emotional and atmospheric shivers sitting through this epilogue in the chilly air.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 24 (AP) -- The Syracuse Chiefs captured the International League's Governors' Cup tonight before 11,388 fans by defeating the Buffalo Bisons, 10 to 3, in the seventh and deciding game of the series.

ROME, Sept. 24 -- Premier Alcide de Gasperi's position was seriously threatened today. Representatives of the six Leftist parties agreed on the need to replace his Government with a Center-Left coalition.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- President Truman has summoned Congressional leaders to a White House conference Monday to acquaint them with the rapidl deteriorating economic and financial condition of Western Europe and to obtain their reaction to demands for a special session of Congress.
