A Presidential emergency board opened a hearing here yesterday on a demand by the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, AFL, for a 40-cent hourly wage increase for Railway Express Agency drivers in seven cities, not including New York.

MOSCOW, Sept. 24 (AP) -- The Soviet Government announced today a new cradle-to-the-grave social security program for the coal miner in a move to assure permanent care for its workers and attract young people into this branch of the Soviet economy.

Net income of the Franklin Stores Corporation for the fiscal year ended June 30 amounted to $1,070,594, equal to $1.47 a share on the common stock, Frank Rubenstein, president, reported to stockholders yesterday. Earnings for the previous fiscal year were $1,479,667 or $2.06 a share on the common stock then outstanding.

DULUTH, Minn., Sept. 24 -- Harold E. Stassen, avowed aspirant for the 1948 Republican Presidential nomination, tonight urged the police chiefs of America in the year ahead to give "special attention toward clearing up Communist infiltration in America."

A four color, full page schedule in December will inaugurate the magazine consumer advertising for the Tip Toe automatic electric iron introduced this summer in test markets by Yale Towne Manufacturing Company, it was announced yesterday by Theodore J. Frernd, advertising and merchandising manager for Yale traffic appliances.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- William Benton resigned today as Assistant Secretary of State for Public Affairs, effective Tuesday.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 24 (ap) -- Grady Hatton, first up in the ninth banged the ball over the right-field fence to give the Reds a 6-to-5 victory over Chicago today and clinch fifth place in the National League for the Redlegs.

Labor has the largest interest in the state's good roads program Charles H. Sells, State Superintendent of Public Works, said yesterday at the annual convention of the American Association of State Highway Officials at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.
The works of two contemporary designers share the limelight in Lord Taylor's new furniture galleries which open today on the store's eighth floor.

Dishamatic Price Now $274.50 Lake States Products, Inc., Jackson, Mich., has increased the list price of its Dishamatie electric dishwashers to $274.50, C.K. Reynolds, sales manager, announced yesterday. The decision to increase the price, reached after agreement by distributors, was made "to guarantee a planned production and selling program in the face of rising labor and materials costs," Mr. Reynolds said.

Dmitri Mitropoulos, musical director of the Minneapolis Symphony, will be guest conductor of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra for four weeks, starting Nov. 20. He will conduct the first American performance of Mahler's Sixth Symphony, the "Alpine Symphony" of Richard Strauss, which the Philharmonic has not played in seventeen years, and the world premiere of Ernst Krenek's Fourth Symphony.

LONDON. Sept. 24 -- Britain will continue her efforts to make Germany self-supporting no matter what happens at the scheduled meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers, in November, Lord Pakenham, Minister responsible for the British zones in Germany and Austria, told members of the Foreign Press Association here today.

SEATTLE, Sept. 24 -- Mrs Martha Taft, wife of Senator Robert A. Taft, drew round after round of applause and gales of laughter today as she grave the Truman Administration a "going over" in a speech buttressed with "facts" which may have come from her husband but having a wit and discernment decidedly her own.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 24 -- A United Nations world capital, built of glass and marble, to provide majestic quarters for the "most important workshop in history," was unfolded, in a glowing color film previewed here today by the General Assembly's Headquarters Committee.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 24 -- Mrs. J.B. Balding of the home club turned in a 40, 36 -- 76, three strokes over par to win low Gross honors in the one-day tournament of the women's Long Island Golf Association on the Cedar Creek Club course today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (U.P.) -- The Department of Agriculture said today that the danger of a depression is much less now than after World War I but that it would be "rash" to dismiss the possibility completely.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 24 -- The European regional conference of the Bed Cross opened here today with delegates stressing that the important task of the organization was to set an example of peaceful cooperation. Fify-five delegates from twenty countries named Dr. Nikola Nikolitch, Belgrade delegate, chairman of the one-week conference.

Autumn has elbowed out summer, and though salads won't be appearing so often, nevertheless they will far from vanish, from our menus. Which brings us to two new salad dressings -- a homemadetasting mayonnaise and a French dressing that isn't our idea of a French dressing at all, but rather a fanciful interpretation of one.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- The United States has protested in Belgrade the "exceedingly dangerous" and "irresponsible actions" of Yugoslavia in presenting ultimatums demanding alterations in the provisonal boundary between the British -United States zone of the Free Territory of Trieste and Yugoslavia.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Leo Durocher left tonight to see the Dodgers play the Yankees in the world series, picked Brooklyn to win and added: "Last winter I said I hoped to manage Brooklyn until the day I died; that still goes."

No individual or minority ca escape responsibility for the course of human affairs, any more than can the majority, Dr. Frank D. Fackenthal, acting president of Columbia University, declared yesterday at the opening exercises of the university's 194th year.

FRANKLIN, Mien., Sept. 24 -- Tense struggles marked the second round of the forty-seventh women's national amateur golf championship as three of the eight matches went to the eighteenth green on the Franklin Halls course today.

DETROIT, Sept. 24 -- President Walter P. Reuther of the Congress of Industrial Organizations United Automobile Workers was further rebuffed by the union's International Executive Board today as leaders continued their heated sessions in the Hotel Statler.

CHICAGO. Sept. 24 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 5.500 head, total 9.000; market slow and uneven, but generally steady to 25 cents lower on butchers; sows around 25 cents lower; closed dull with a few late sales

Special prizes were announced before the thirty-third annual show of the American Dahlia Society closed its two-day display at the Hotel Pennsylvania last night. Sweepstakes winners in the several sections and the largest and finest blooms in several classifications had also been decided.

LONDON, Sept. 25 -- The British Government has proposed that the London meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers be held "late in November" to avoid conflicting with the sessions of the United Nations Assembly, the Foreign Office announced today.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 25 -- Since 1798 the New Jersey State Prison has been identified with Trenton, the state capital. But Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll today revealed a plan to tear down the prison, with its accommodations for 1,200 inmates including a 12cell death house and the execution chamber, and make Rahway Reformatory a new state prison.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 25 -- Declaring that price resistance has reached its stiffest point in years, Joseph B. Birnie of Atlanta, Ga., president of the Consumer Bankers Association, said today that many signs now indicate that consumer prices must come down if sales are to stay up.

Fish chowder that is made with dry skim milk is the main feature of the dinner menu for Friday as suggested by the City Department of Markets. For a family of five, the total cost of the meal is $2.07. The recipe for the chowder also is given.

BOSTON, Sept. 25 -- The War and Navy Departments have barred Communists or persons "affiliated with Communists or communistic activities" from working in plants manufacturing secret military equipment, the convention of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, CIO, was informed today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 25 (AP) -- A consent judgment terminating what the Government terms "monopolistic restraints" of the Southern Pacific Company and Pacific Greyhound Lines on bus transportation between Portland, Ore., and Los Angeles was entered in United States District Court here today.

The phrase most familiar to any angler who travels more than five miles from home for some fishing: "You should have been here yesterday," is rated second only to its companion: "You should have waited until next week."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- During the week ended Sept. 24 member bank reserve balances decreased $297,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 25 -- A full-dress debate on Palestine will be opened in a United Nations committee by the United Kingdom tomorrow with an announcement that Britain is ready to give up the Holy Land mandate, but will need assistance if she is to administer the country during any transition period leading to complete independence.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The State Department revealed tonight that a visa was granted to Pierre Courtade, correspondent for the French Communist paper Humanite to cover the United Nations General Assembly sessions with severe restrictions attached.

The Broadcasters Advisory Council was dissolved formally yesterday at a luncheon meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria. Its original organizers, including sponsors, advertising agencies and radio officials, decided that there was no further need for the council, since its proposed objectives were now being met by other groups.

The election of A.W. Bourne Jr. and H.W. McCobb as directors of the Standard Vacuum Oil Company has been announced by P.W. Parker, chairman, Mr. Bourne has been general manager of the company's China division and Mr. McCobb head of producing operations.

New York housewives found meat prices reduced 2 to 7 cents a pound in most butcher shops yesterday, thirteen days after wholesale prices had started slipping from near-record highs. Markets Commissioner Eugene G. Schulz, who declared that the belated drop in retail prices had been influenced by consumer resistance to "exorbitant prices," said the retail price reductions extended also to butter and eggs.

Commercial, industrial and agricultural loans of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System were further expanded last week, rising $33,000,000 to a new high level of $4,597,000,000, it was disclosed yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 25 -- Carl Krueger, who recently negotiated an arrangement with the Army for the distribution of the Air Force film. "Thunderbolt" has concluded another deal with the Government for "Triumph of the Will." the twelve-reel Nazi spectacle produced in Germany by Lenni Riefenstal before the war.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- President Truman's statement today on food follows: I am making public today a report from the Cabinet committee on world food problems which emphasizes a critical situation calling for immediate action by every American.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 25 -- The New Jersey State Federation of Labor in a series of resolutions adopted at its sixty-ninth annual convention today denounced the Taft-Hartley law and all Senators and Representatives voting for it. It also moved definitely into the field of political action in an endeavor to repeal the bill and to defeat in the coming election all exponents of the act.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Slick Airways, Inc., one of the air-freight companies formed since the war, today asked the Civil Aeronautics Board today to deny a petition of three major airlines which propose to reduce their freight rates to 12 cents a ton mile.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today the country faces danger of "economic collapse" if inflation continues unchecked and he suggested that: It might be better to reduce expenditures on the nation's military forces in order to aid foreign democracies -- to place spending to "maintain peace" above spending to "prepare for the next war."

ALBANY, Sept. 25. -- Saying the proposed reorganization scheme would cost preferred stockholders about $30,000,000, the Public Service Commission announced today it had rejected a company-sponsored plan for the consolidation of four companies of the Long Island Lighting System into a single operating utility.

The Board of City Magistrates voted yesterday to consider in Municipal Term Court instead of Traffic Court all cases arising under the new rules of the Department of Licenses that will affect the city's 10,000 parking lots and garages.
Small and sumptuous was the collection of custom-made fashions presented yesterday by Carrie Munn at her salon, 640 Madison Avenue.

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Sept. 25 -- Establishment of the Lovelace Foundation for Medical Education and Research, with assets of a million dollars, was announced here today. The assets consist of the entire property of the Lovelace Clinic, a group of practicing physicians well-known in the Southwest, and the foundation will be operated at the outset from the earnings in excess of operating expenses, thus following the precedent set by the Mayo Clinic at Rochester, Minn.

A new policy for the reorganization of the German economy as part of a program for the revival of Western Europe under the Marshall Plan was presented last night by Lewis H. Brown, chairman of the board of the Johns-Manville Corporation.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- President Truman appointed today a twenty-six-member Citizens' Food Committee to map an all-out domestic "save-food" campaign as a first requisite to the aid-Europe plan.

WASHITNGTON, Sept. 25 -- Thirteen days after Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt's intercession for Johannes (Hanns) Eisler, brother of Gerhart Eisler, said to be a Russian secret agent, a high State Department official suggested to the subordinate in charge of the matter that the German refugee not be excluded as a Communist immigrant in the absence of "definite and convincing proof."

NANKING, Sept. 25 -- China's battle to conserve her dwindling foreign exchange has led to an official campaign here to step up imports of acutely needed commodities from the sterling bloc countries, as opposed to those demanding dollar payment.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- President Truman said today the United States will call on LatinAmerican exporting countries to contribute to European recovery and to the Marshall plan.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 25 -- A drastic United States resolution on the Greek border issue was introduced today in the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 25 -- The Providence Washington Insurance Company of Providence, R.I., and the Liberty Loan Corporation of Chicago filed registration statements today with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: May I be allowed to clarify, in behave of your readers, the real meaning and significance of the various rebellion movements that have been reported take place in my country, Venezuel since the access to power of the prevent Revolutionary Junta of Government, on Oct. 18, 1945.

There must tie something entertaining about playing the horses, since the police are so opposed to it. But Joseph Fields and Ben Sher are not much more entertaining than the constabulary in "I Gotta Get Out," which was acted out of the corner of the mouth at the Cort last evening.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 25 -- The text of a draft resolution submitted by the United States to the General Assembly's Political and Security Committee today, proposing a special committee to observe the Balkan nations' compliance with the Assembly's recommendations, follows:

TACOMA, Wash., Sept. 25 -- The text of Senator Robert A. Taft's speech to the World Affairs Council of Tacoma was as follows: I appreciate the invitation which you have extended to me to talk to the World Affairs Council of Tacoma.

H. Ross Colwell, regional director of the United States Conciliation Service, announced yesterday that representatives of United States Steel's Federal Shipyard and the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, CIO, would meet at his office Tuesday in a renewed effort to settle the thirteen-week-old strike affecting shipyards on the East and Gulf Coast.

The Queens County Grand Jury completed yesterday the hearing of testimony in the crash of the American Airlines experimental plane Alpha, which fell into Bowery Bay Aug. 8 shortly after its take off from La Guardia Field, killing three members of the crew.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 25 -- The United Kingdom, which of all the fifty-five states in the United Nations is undergoing the greatest austerity in the dollar shortage, today answered Secretary General Trygve Lie's plan to cut the peace organization's 1948 budget by $5,000,000 by proposing a reduction of more than $9,000,000.

Active implementation through modern commercial treaties of the policy recently enunciated by Willard L. Thorp, Assistant Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, would go far toward increasing American direct investment abroad, it was stated yesterday by Austin T. Foster, chairman of the treaty committee of the National Foreign Trade Council and counsel for the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company.

PARIS, Sept. 25 -- France has asked Russia and Argentina for wheat, but even should they offer to meet the French bread-grain shortage she will not have the dollars with which to pay for it Thus, every angle of the French economic crisis comes back to the necessity for urgent credit aid from the United States, according to official quarters today.

The New York City Housing Authority sold yesterday $14,550,000 of temporary loan notes due April 16, 1948, at bids ranging from 0.80 per cent to 0.84 per cent. The proceeds will be used to continue the temporary financing of the Lillian Wald and Morrisania Houses.

Opposition to increasing depreciation charges against current income as a means of providing for replacement of plant facilities, in view of recent sharp increases in the price level, was expressed yesterday by the committee on accounting procedure of the American Institute of Accountants.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 25 -- Once upon a time the watch-word of football was "Stagg fears Purdue." Now everybody seems to be scared of Rutgers.

A threat of court action by delegates who had been denied seats by the credentials committee of the National Maritime Union's sixth biennial convention was the highlight of yesterday's session, and brought forth the most heated exchange of words since the convention opened Monday at the Manhattan Center.

The New York City Opera Company began its fall season at the City Center last night and put its best foot forward with a gripping performance of Richard Strauss "Salome." The opera was revived last spring. Upon its return to the stage it had more cohesion and concentration, and it held the eye and ear of the audience with a vise-like fascination.

The Veterans Administration announced yesterday that $6,000 anually is the maximum the administration will pay to doctors and dentists in New York State who treat disabled veterans on a fee basis. It was also announced that dentists and physicians are ineligible to participate in the VA medical care plan if they are retained by that agency as consultants, attending physicians or residents, except in special circumstances.

Hanns Eisler. brother or Gerhart, reputed secret agent of the Kremlin, denied that he was a Communist when asked the question point blank by Dr. Alvin S. Johnson, then head and now president emeritus of the New School for Social Research, Dr. Johnson said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- President Truman issued the following statement today on the Marshall Plan to aid Europe: The Secretary of State has transmitted to me the official report of the committee of European economic cooperation, prepared by the representatives of sixteen nations who have been meeting in Paris since early July.

Puget Sale Revived Another in a long series of efforts by the public utility districts in the state of Washington to acquire the properties of the Puget Sound Power and Light Company will begin on Monday before Seattle's Mayor.

The manifest enthusiasm that prompted long lines of New Yorkers to visit Track 30 of the Grand Central Station yesterday to go aboard Freedom Train was an inspiring thing in itself. It was a demonstration of the high esteem in which Americans hold their rights as free men and the reverence they feel for the historic documents that mark the path on which these rights have been won.

TACOMA, Sept. 25 -- Administration policies have plunged the world into a state of economic collapse, Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio declared tonight as, stating his full views on international affairs for the first time, he proposed a seven-point program of corrective action.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 25 -- The current underground struggle between Zionist dissident groups and the Jewish community's security forces last night for the first time erupted into shooting in Rehovoth. For fifteen minutes the Jewish market town reverberated to the clash of arms.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 25 -- The peaceful atmosphere of the United Nations Legal Committee was broken abruptly here today when Britain sharply criticized Yugoslavia for having challenged a General Assembly resolution on the ground that it had been proposed by the United States.

Two realty firm officials, who were found guilty twice of violating the city's new rent control laws, received five-day workhouse terms and fines totaling $500 when they appeared yesterday before Magistrate Charles E. Ramsgate in War Emergency Court.
The Bankers Trust Company has been appointed co-registrar for the $2.60 convertible preferred stock, no par value, of Seaboard Finance Company.

The Oakcrest Estates development at Kissena Boulevard and Sixty-fourth Avenue, Flushing, Queens, has been completely sold out, Joseph Rubenfeld, head of Allied Realties, reported yesterday. The project comprises twenty-six houses.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 25 -- Successful operation of an economical, small model atom smasher of the electron linear accelerator type was reported today by Dr. William W. Hansen, Stanford University physicist, with the prediction that energies of a billion electron volts, greater than any yet achieved by man, would be developed by a projected model 100 to 200 feet long.

A major change in foreign credit policies of coal exporter was contained in a resolution passed unanimously yesterday at the annual meeting of 150 members of the Coal Export Association at the Biltmore Hotel. Coal exporters recommended that in the future, all export coal be sold only against confirmed irrevocable letters of credit.

A selection of Shakespeare's thoughts on almost every subject of importance for ancient and modern man to show that he "could have written essays as good, if not better, than those of Bacon," will be published by Putnam Oct. 31 under the title "Essays of Shakespeare."

OAK RIDGE, Tenn., Sept. 25 -- The famous Clinton Laboratories here, a principal production plant for radioisotopes and the first Government-built nuclear research center, will be renamed Clinton National Laboratory and become the third of the Atomic Energy Commission's national laboratories.

LAKE SUCCESS. N.Y. Sept. 25 -- The powerful Latin-American bloc agreed today to support Canada's election to the United Nations Security Council -- virtually assuring the Dominion of a seat -- and tentatively decided to back Argentina for a second of three vacancies.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 25 (AP) -- President Frank E. McKinney of the Pirates announced tonight that Billy Herman had resigned as manager. The announcement was made at a press conference of the Pittsburgh club owners.

Not the least compelling of the many reasons for a special session of Congress to deal solely with the critical problem of aid to Europe is the large amount of unfinished domestic legislation that was left on Congressional desks when adjournment was taken on July 27.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 25 -- Charles Luckman, 38 years old, a soap manufacturer, assumed the chairmanship of the Citizens Food Committee today and promised that the American people would win "this war against starvation as they have won all wars."

Warren Lee Pierson, chairman of the Board of Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., and former head of the Export-Import Bank, declared yesterday that American air tourists' dollars would play an important part in the settlement of the world's economy.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- With the prices of farm products and foods reaching new peaks in the early part of the week, average primary market prices rose by 0.4 per dent in the week ended last Saturday over the level of the preceding week, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Department of Commerce.

Herbert Hoover denied yesterday that he had ever said that "we would never have been attacked by the Japanese if we had not given them provocation." A statement by the former President to that effect was contained in a recent interview written by Sidney Shalett, printed in the September issue, of the American Magazine, and given wide circulation in newspaper reprints and comment.

MOSCOW, Sept. 25 -- Russian political writers loosed against the United States and its leaders today a blast of denunciation unparalleled since the days when Adolf Hitler and his Nazis were their targets.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 25 -- The Dodgers closed their year's business at Shibe Park tonight by putting two more games in the victory column, although they labored only twelve and one-half innings, ten of them in the afterpiece.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Sept. 25 -- A conference of International Typographical Union, and American Newspaper Publishers Association representatives, called to "resolve existing differences," proceeded on schedule here today amid a hot dispute between the union and the National Labor Relations Board in Washington.

Eighteen of the thirty-one commodities comprising the Dun Bradstreet Wholesale Food Price Index dropped during the past week and only four advanced, lowering the figure 21 cents, or 2.9 per cent, to $6.91 as of Sept. 23, it was reported yesterday.

Arnold Constable Co. literally "said it with orchids" yesterday to celebrate its 122d anniversary, with every fiftieth customer to go through the front Fifth Avenue and Fortieth Street store entrance receiving a floral tribute.

The first New York State high school equivalency diploma tests to be offered candidates here will be held Oct. 21 and 22 in ten high schools of the city, it was announced yesterday by the office of William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- President Truman described the White House today as the finest jail in the world. He made his jocular statement to a group of State Bank Commissioners who called at his office after they had visited the Executive Mansion.
SHEFFIELD, England, Sept. 25 -- The British Government and industry are asking an anxious question these days: Will the steel production goal of 12,500,000 ingottons be reached this year?

This week-end's market news is brighter for housewives than it has been in some weeks. Considerably lower prices of meats are reported by the City Department of Markets, with reductions from 2 to 8 cents a pound on almost all the twenty-one cuts checked.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 25 -- The various parts of the construction industry, probably including the trade unions, will have a chance to make suggestions for changes in the basic building code of the Building Officials Conference of America before it is offered to municipalities for adoption about six months from now, it was disclosed today as the conference ended its four-day annual meeting here.

ESSEX FELLS, N.J., Sept. 25 -- At the Essex Fells Country Club today a new state seniors' golf champion was crowned in the person of Col. Martin S. Lindgrove of the Baltusrol Country Club, recent winner of the United States seniors' title.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The State Department directed the American Embassy in Belgrade today to deliver a protest against the seizure this week by Yugoslav troops of a United States Army officer and two enlisted men on the Trieste boundary.

FLORINA, Greece, Sept. 24 (Delayed) -- The military austerity of this frontier town, surrounded by guerrilla territory, was relieved today by the aerial visit of King Paul. His coming followed that of two American members of Congress, Representative Richard M. Nixon, Republican, of California, and James P. Richards, Democrat, of South Carolina, yesterday.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 25 -- President Truman deplored today the inability of the victorious Allied powers to cooperate for peace as they had for war in a message to the Ecumenical Methodist Conference here today.

The stock market offered again yesterday ample proof of the current confusion present over the outlook when prices returned to the lower side after having enjoyed a token rally on Wednesday. The final hour again proved the crucial period when, after early irregularity, the list sagged under moderately heavy offerings.

BUFFALO, Sept. 25 -- A crowd of 200,000 persons, the largest ever assembled in Buffalo for any occasion, jammed Delaware Park this afternoon for the closing sessions of the Centennial Eucharistic Congress at which Francis Cardinal Spellman of New York offered prayers for peace and invoked God's blessing on the Catholic Church and the United States.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 25 -- The Union of South Africa was denounced by seven nations here today for its failure to submit to the United Nations a trusteeship agreement for Southwest Africa in accordance with a resolution approved last year by the General Assembly.
LONDON, Sept. 25 -- An erroneous report that President Truman had decided to recall Congress to approve the sending of food to Europe had a cheering effect today on the stock markets here.

Unlike the morose, reticent fellow of last April, when an edict by Commissioner Albert B. Chandler blotted out one year of his baseball life, Leo Durocher flew into town early yesterday morning, bubbling over with good humor, enthusiasm and the desire to manage the Dodgers in 1948.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 25 -- To meet objections from other nations, the United States has decided to eliminate any reference to peace and security from the title of the proposed "Little Assembly," it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Gen. Carl Spaatz was elevated to the new office of Chief of Staff of the United States Air Force in a series of appointments made today by President Truman to fill the remaining upper vacancies in the unified national military establishment.

GENEVA, Sept. 25 -- The United States Government has spurned a Swiss suggestion that the Swiss Government advance 50,000,000 francs (about $11,700,000) to aid in the resettlement of displaced persons, it wag learned today.

Hundreds of passers-by and a long line of persons waiting outside of Grand Central Terminal to view the Freedom Train witnessed a brief, sharp clash between the police and pickets demonstrating on behalf of conscientious objectors at 7:10 o'clock last night.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 25 -- Imposition of tolls on Westchester parkways will not result in loss of $100,000,000 state and Federal aid for highway construction or of any fraction thereof, County Executive Herbert C. Gerlach declared today in contradicting assertions made last night by Harold T. Garrity, county Democratic chairman.

The city administration moved into the world series picture yeserday when Benjamin Fielding, License Commissioner, warned that his department was on the alert or illegal sales of tickets for fames either at the Yankee Stadium or Ebbets Field.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 25 (AP) -- Marion Direct, fast black daughter of Billy Direct, won almost as she pleased in both heats of the Hanover Stake for pacing 2-yearold fillies at the Lexington grand circuit trots today.

Speaking of Names "What's in a name?" our city scout said. "We have a sizable airport named for our late Mayor La Guardla. We have another, vastly larger, and still in the making, originally called Idlewild, a local name that was already there.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., Sept. 25 -- Brandywine, 10-year-old chestnut gelding, ridden by Miss Betty Jane Baldwin of West Chester, triumphed in three classes on the opening program of the three-day forty-sixth annual Bryn Mawr horse show today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Department store sales in the week ended Sept. 20 were 8 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1946:

Fluctuations in prices for cotton futures on the Now York Cotton Exchange were somewhat narrower yesterday than they have been recently and the close was 13 points higher to 1 point lower than on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- President Truman organized today a national drive against food waste, conceded that a special session of Congress might be needed for dealing with the European crisis and added a possible revival of wartime controls to the list of problems he would canvass with Congressional leaders Monday.

HAVANA, Sept. 25 -- With military authorities continuing their attempt to round up Dominican revolutionary elements, the fate of the alleged expedition against the Dominican Republic was uncertain today.

On the premise that people may be sleeping even in the foyer these days, Macy has decorated six model settings to show beds may be incorporated into rooms that are not primarily bedrooms. They are now on display along Plan-AHome Row on the seventh floor.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- As they slowly digest the Paris report of the sixteen nations which were invited by Secretary Marshall to propose the basis of a United States program to rehabilitate the economy of Europe, executive officials and members of Congress now in Washington are beginning to consider specific details of an eventual Marshall plan.

India's acute need for more highways and the 150,000-mile construction program now under consideration in that country were outlined yesterday by K.S. Raghavachary, deputy consulting road engineer, Government of India, New Delhi.

Not since the day in May when four successive odds-on choices lost have backera of favorites done as much wailing as they did at Belmont Park yesterday. Long shots scored a succession of victories, and in the fourth and fifth contests the longest-priced horses in the line-ups were the ones first under the wire.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 25 -- President Juan Peron's Cabinet met this morning, and although no official announcement has been issued, it is almost certain that ArgentineBritish relations, snarled since Britain's decision to halt the convertibility of sterling, are considerably advanced toward agreement.
JERUSALEM, Sept. 25 -- Talk of the outright evacuation of Palestine by the British has increased lately in Jerusalem.

As if it isn't bad enough to try to decide whether the Yankees or the Dodgers will win the world series, along comes that most bulky and obstreperous character, King Football, to muscle his way into the middle of the conversation. The gridiron sport begins in earnest this week-end and that only adds immeasurably to the confusion.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 25 -- Upholding the recommendations of its trial examiner, the Securities and Exchange Commission issued today a stop-order suspending the effectiveness of the "false and misleading" registration statement of the bankrupt Globe Aircraft Corporation of Fort Worth, Tex.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 25 -- Britain will get out of her present economic difficulties, although the way will be hard and the going rough, Viscount William A. Jowitt, Lord High Chancellor of Great Britain, declared tonight in an address at the annual dinner of the American Bar Association.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, sent a plea to President Truman today to call Congress into session immediately to re-establish rationing and price control of the essentials of living and to "impose full taxes on extortionate profits."

FRANKLIN, Mich., Sept. 25 -- Three Southerners and a girl from Connecticut fought their way into the semi-final round of the fortyseventh women's national amateur golf championship over the Franklin Hills course today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25 (A.P.) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by The United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs. 4.500 head; total 7.000; market closing dull, with advance lost, but trade generally steady to 25 cents higher; top, 328.50: bulk of good and choice 200-280 pounds, $27.75-

BOSTON, Sept. 25 -- In weather associated with Braves Field when the frost is on the pumpkin, Larry Jansen today planted himself in contention for the rookie-of-theyear honors when he tossed his twenty-first victory and kept the Giants in the throbbing battle for third place in the National League.

LONDON, Sept. 25 (U.P.) -- The Olympic Organizing Committee, turning a deaf ear to British agitation for cancellation of the games, announced for the first time today the program of events for the 1948 Olympic Games in London.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 25 -- The failure to accomplish greater coordination with public agencies in the health field through voluntary effort will mean the end of non-government hospitals, Graham L. Davis of Battle Creek, Mich., new president of the American Hospital Association, warned today at the closing session of the association's annual four-day meeting.
Approval of the three housing propositions that will appear on the ballot Nov. 4 was asked yesterday by State Housing Commissioner Herman T. Stichman and Deputy Mayor John J. Bennett.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today rejected the Interstate Power Company's application to sell 2,132,223 shares of its common stock, at a bid price of $4.05. The rejection blocked also the sale of $19,400,000 of first mortgage bonds, due 1977, at 101.9.

A favorite indoor sport in producing offices is to start at the top when casting a show and wind up with anyone who is available, provided the terms are not out of line. In the not-so-distant past entertainments galore have been mentioned for Beatrice Lillie, including that nostalgic "Charlot Revue" revival, which was to have reunited the famous triumvirate of Miss Lillie, Gertrude Lawrence and Jack Buchanan.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The Cardinals, beaten in their attempt to retain the National League championship assured themselves of second place today by defeating the Pirates, 15 -- 3 and 3 -- 1, before a ladies' day crowd of 12,584.

GARDEN CITY, L.I. Sept. 25 -- Scoring clean sweeps in four of the ten singles held this morning and two of the five Scotch four-somes played in the afternoon, New York enjoyed an eight-point margin with a total of 32 1/2 as the opening session of the 43-year-old Lesley Cup team competition was completed at the Garden City Golf Club today.

IRVING STONE'S biographical novel, "Adversary in the House,"* is an eloquent demonstration of a truth that too often is found out only through sad experience: that one of the most certain ways for two people to be miserable is for them to marry if their fundamental ideas, ideals, prejudices, aspirations and convictions are all unalterably opposed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- A new challenge to the operation of the Big Inch and Little Big Inch pipelines for the transmission of natural gas was presented today before the Federal Power Commission by coal, railroad and railway employe interests.

LONDON, Sept. 25 -- The British government will consult the Dominions to see whether any further concessions on Empire preferences can be made to the United states, authoritative sources said today after a Cabinet discussion of the issue.

Edgar Tallman has been appointed director of interior display for Lord Taylor, to succeed J. Robert Taylor who resigned as of Sept. 15, it was announced yesterday by Dorothy Shaver, president of the company. Mr. Tallman will continue his duties as store decorator in charge of planning and designing the decor for the new Lord Taylor branch stores.
LONDON, Sept. 25 -- The British Government informed Bulgaria today that it regarded the trial and execution of Nikola Petkov, Bulgarian Opposition leader, as a "travesty on justice."

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 25 -- Under the direction of its new coach, E.E. (Hooks) Mylin, New York. University opens it football season with Temple University under the lights at the Owls Stadium tomorrow night, before a crowd that may reach 20,000.

The Brooklyn Children's Aid Society was ordered yesterday to restore 11-year-old Barbara Ann Smith to her mother, Mrs. Daisy Nisch of 714 Evergreen Avenue, Brooklyn. Supreme Court Justice Francis G. Hooley in Brooklyn issued the order.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Following is the text of the Cabinet Food Committee's report, as released by the White House, together with a letter transmitting it to Presiden Truman: Sept. 22, 1947 Dear Mr. President:

In November, 1946, we witnessed the unprecedented spectacle of an Administration party losing a mid-term election by landslide proportions in the midst of a business boom unparalleled in peacetime. That debacle, it seemed clear in retrospect, was the result of an almost unbelievable failure by the party leadership to keep in touch with public opinion and the needs of the national economy.
